{"mumps": [{"archive_id": "7511414", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (03): USA (NE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7511414", "date": "2020-06-26 12:53:31", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (03): USA (NEBRASKA)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 24 Jun 2020\nSource: Scientific American (edited)\nhttps://www.scientificamerican.com/article/a-mumps-outbreak-among-fully-vaccinated-people/\n\n\nOn 5 Jun 2020, the US Centers for Disease Control (CDC) published the details of a recent multistate outbreak of mumps in its Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report (MMWR) [see reference below].\n\nThe outbreak involved 62 cases linked to a single asymptomatic wedding attendee. Even though mumps is a vaccine-preventable disease, 41 of the individuals infected in the reported incident had been fully vaccinated according to the current guidelines. What started as a mild illness in a caretaker of children in Nebraska grew into an epidemic involving communities in six different states. This raises concerns about waning immunity from childhood mumps immunization.\n\nMumps is a highly contagious disease of children and young adults. It is caused by a paramyxovirus of which there is only a single serotype. Humans are the only known host, and infections are spread by direct contact or through droplets from the upper respiratory tract.\n\nThe infection may remain asymptomatic for an incubation period that ranges from 12-25 days. When symptoms are apparent, mumps can present with initial flulike symptoms, such as fever, congestion and aches, followed by a characteristic painful swelling of the jaw. The index case of the outbreak developed left ear and jaw tenderness the day after attending the wedding. Her jaw swelling was noted 11 days after her initial exposure to the virus.\n\nIn most cases, the disease resolves spontaneously within 2 weeks of onset. However, complications such as deafness, infertility or encephalitis may result. Thankfully, the disease can be largely prevented by vaccination.\n\nThe history of mumps dates to the 5th century BC, when Hippocrates described the condition as a bilateral or unilateral swelling near the ears, and noted that some patients had bilateral or unilateral pain and swelling of the testicles. Isolation and culture of the virus did not occur until 1945, however, and a vaccination against it was first licensed in 1967.\n\nWithout routine immunization, the incidence of mumps would be projected to be 100-1000 cases per million, with an epidemic occurring every 4-5 years. Universal vaccination has been a crucial factor in the global decline in the incidence of mumps. Finland was the 1st country to declare itself mumps-free, in 2000, after a national 2-dose vaccination program for children, resulting in high vaccination coverage. In Korea, the mumps vaccine was included in a national immunization program in 1985, and booster doses began in 1997.\n\nSadly, according to the World Health Organization, the mumps vaccine had been introduced nationwide in only 122 countries by the end of 2018. As of June 2020, Japan, Afghanistan, Pakistan, India, and most countries in southeast Asia and sub-Saharan Africa did not have the mumps vaccine included in their national immunization programs.\n\nIn the United States, the CDC recommendation for childhood immunization against mumps is a 2-dose series. The 1st shot is given at 12-15 months of age; the 2nd at 4-6 years. A catch-up vaccination may be done for unimmunized children and adolescents, with 2 doses given at least 4 weeks apart. This is especially recommended for at-risk groups such as post-high school students, health care personnel and international travelers. The mumps vaccine is given along with vaccines against measles and rubella, a combination known as MMR. It confers a 78 percent risk reduction following one dose rising to 88 percent after receiving 2 doses.\n\n[Byline: Ekemini Hogan, Akpabio Akpabio, Utibe Effiong]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[[The finding that the contacts were fully vaccinated is concerning. Re-infection due to waning immunity has been a particular problem for young adults immunized against mumps.\n\nReference\n---------\nDonahue M, Hendrickson B, Julian D, et al. Multistate mumps outbreak originating from asymptomatic transmission at a Nebraska wedding -- Six states, August-October 2019. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2020; 69: 666-669. https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/69/wr/mm6922a2.htm\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nDiscussion [edited]\nA mumps outbreak involving 6 states occurred following exposure to an asymptomatic, fully vaccinated (1) index patient who reported extensive social interaction during the peak period of infectivity, in an environment where potentially susceptible persons were densely clustered. Mumps immunity after childhood vaccination can wane by early adulthood (6). It is likely that waning of vaccine-induced immunity contributed to this outbreak, because approximately 2/3 of patients had received 2 or more doses of MMR vaccine, and the median patient age was 35 years. Specific viral factors (such as mutations increasing pathogenicity and shedding) were not a likely contributor because mumps genotype G is commonly implicated in both sporadic cases and outbreaks in the United States (7). However, mumps is most infectious just before and during onset of parotitis (3), and the timing of the event likely contributed to transmission among exposed attendees because the index patient developed parotitis the day after the wedding. The wedding served as a setting conducive to droplet transmission, facilitated by close social contact.\n\nIsolation of ill persons and a communitywide MMR vaccination campaign helped end the outbreak. As of 1 Dec 2019, no additional cases had been identified in community A, nor had any additional cases been identified in any other state as linked to this outbreak. A decline in case count before the campaign was observed, which complicated assessment of the campaign's relative contribution in controlling the outbreak. Collaborative efforts, including early and regular communication between local, state, and national public health authorities, local health care providers, and community officials proved crucial for efficient resource mobilization, strengthened preparedness, and resulted in effective disease containment.\n\nThe full report and references are available at the URL above.\n\nAlso see,\nRasheed MAU, Hickman CJ, McGrew M, et al. Decreased humoral immunity to mumps in young adults immunized with MMR vaccine in childhood. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA. 2019116(38)19071-19076. doi:10.1073/pnas.1905570116; https://www.pnas.org/content/116/38/19071.long\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n'Significance\nThe live-attenuated mumps-measles-rubella (MMR) vaccine has been highly successful in the United States since its introduction 47 years ago. However, for the past decade, mumps outbreaks have been occurring among young adults who were vaccinated as children. Waning immunity has been proposed as a key contributing factor to mumps resurgence. In our sample (n = 71) of 18- to 23-year-old college students, the majority had detectable mumps IgG antibodies by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) but the magnitude was lower than rubella. Neutralizing antibody titers were 6-fold lower to a circulating genotype G mumps strain versus the vaccine strain. 10 percent of our participants had no detectable memory B cells to mumps. Strategies are needed to improve immunity to the mumps vaccine.'\n- Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map of Nebraska, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/229]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n A mumps outbreak involving 6 states occurred following exposure to an asymptomatic, fully vaccinated (1) index patient who reported extensive social interaction during the peak period of infectivity, in an environment where potentially susceptible persons were densely clustered. \n\nThe history of mumps dates to the 5th century BC, when Hippocrates described the condition as a bilateral or unilateral swelling near the ears, and noted that some patients had bilateral or unilateral pain and swelling of the testicles. Finland was the 1st country to declare itself mumps-free, in 2000, after a national 2-dose vaccination program for children, resulting in high vaccination coverage. It is likely that waning of vaccine-induced immunity contributed to this outbreak, because approximately 2/3 of patients had received 2 or more doses of MMR vaccine, and the median patient age was 35 years. MUMPS UPDATE (03): USA (NEBRASKA)\n*********************************\n doi:10.1073/pnas.1905570116; https://www.pnas.org/content/116/38/19071.long\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n'Significance\n \n\nMumps is a highly contagious disease of children and young adults. However, mumps is most infectious just before and during onset of parotitis (3), and the timing of the event likely contributed to transmission among exposed attendees because the index patient developed parotitis the day after the wedding. Even though mumps is a vaccine-preventable disease, 41 of the individuals infected in the reported incident had been fully vaccinated according to the current guidelines. Decreased humoral immunity to mumps in young adults immunized with MMR vaccine in childhood. In Korea, the mumps vaccine was included in a national immunization program in 1985, and booster doses began in 1997. Without routine immunization, the incidence of mumps would be projected to be 100-1000 cases per million, with an epidemic occurring every 4-5 years. As of June 2020, Japan, Afghanistan, Pakistan, India, and most countries in southeast Asia and sub-Saharan Africa did not have the mumps vaccine included in their national immunization programs. The live-attenuated mumps-measles-rubella (MMR) vaccine has been highly successful in the United States since its introduction 47 years ago. Re-infection due to waning immunity has been a particular problem for young adults immunized against mumps.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2020-06-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "1945-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-12-01 00:00:00", "1985-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6788791", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (14): UK (NT), USA (SC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6788791", "date": "2019-11-20 14:39:27", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (14): UK (NOTTINGHAMSHIRE), USA (SOUTH CAROLINA)\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA - South Carolina\n[2] UK - Nottinghamshire\n\n******\n[1] USA - South Carolina\nDate: Tue 19 Nov 2019\nSource: Charleston City Paper [edited]\nhttps://www.charlestoncitypaper.com/TheBattery/archives/2019/11/19/with-more-mumps-cases-college-of-charleston-shifts-messaging-to-contain-outbreak\n\n\nWith more than 40 cases of mumps now confirmed at the College of Charleston, the school has taken a few new approaches over the past week to contain the outbreak on campus.\n\nBeginning with 3 cases confirmed by officials on 23 Sep [2019], the school's weekly update reported 43 confirmed cases on 14 Nov [2019], a 65% jump from the 26 cases noted a week earlier on 7 Nov [2019].\n\nCollege of Charleston does require students to have the 3-part MMR [measles, mumps, and rubella] vaccine that prevents the spread of mumps in most cases, but they are able to request a waiver. Of more than 12 600 student medical records on file, 196 [students] have submitted waivers, the school told the Charleston City Paper in September [2019].\n\n'We will get through this together. In the meantime, every member of our campus community can and should take steps to safeguard themselves and others against mumps,' read the 14 Nov [2019] update from College of Charleston president Andrew T. Hsu. Previous dispatches were signed by campus emergency officials.\n\n'We are always evaluating the effectiveness of our various communications and making adjustments as needed,' says Ron Menchaca, the college's director of communications. 'With this latest update, which included an announcement of a targeted vaccine clinic, the college opted to issue the message directly from the president to differentiate it from previous updates from our emergency management team.'\n\nThe other new approach, the 'targeted vaccine clinic,' is specifically geared toward fraternities and sororities but is open to anyone on campus; [it is] scheduled for Tuesday and Wednesday [19-20 Nov 2019] this week from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. in the Stern Student Center ballroom.\n\n'The targeted vaccine clinic for students involved in fraternity and sorority activities is being held in response to a recommendation from the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control [SCDHEC] and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention due to known risk factors inherent in this population (living/socializing in close quarters, potential sharing of items that could transfer saliva, etc.),' says Menchaca.\n\nA representative from SCDHEC says that the targeted clinic isn't necessarily for those who have not received the vaccine, but rather for those in at-risk communities to receive a 2nd or 3rd dose in order to maximize their protections against illness.\n\nAlong with the climbing number of confirmed mumps cases and the clinic announcement, the school has also started new PSA [public service announcement]-style posts around campus and on social media.\n\n'Don't let mumps ruin your fun. Get vaccinated!' says one of the posts in large block letters above a list of 5 tips for avoiding the contagious disease. Those steps include self-isolating if you feel sick, practicing good hygiene, monitoring your own health, remaining vigilant to those around you, and, topping the list, getting vaccinated.\n\nThose on campus can seek treatment with Student Health Services, located behind the Robert Scott Smalls building near Calhoun Street or at <studenthealth.cofc.edu>.\n\nIn any case, many students will likely leave campus over the Thanksgiving holiday, 27-30 Nov [2019]. The last day of exams is [Wed 11 Dec 2019], when students will likely leave again until residence halls re-open on [Sun 5 Jan 2020].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nCharleston, South Carolina, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10996]\n\n******\n[2] UK (NT)\nDate: Mon 18 Nov 2019\nSource: BBC News [edited]\nhttps://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-nottinghamshire-50464911\n\n\nPublic Health England (PHE) said it is investigating a number of reports at Toot Hill School in Bingham.\n\nIn a statement, head teacher Sandy Paley said they are 'working closely' with PHE and advised all parents and staff. She added: 'Our 1st priority is always the well-being and health of our students, and we are continuing to monitor the situation closely.'\n\nPublic Health England has advised anyone who has not received the MMR [measles, mumps, and rubella] jab to get themselves vaccinated. The suspected mumps cases come months after hundreds of cases were confirmed among university students in Nottingham and amid a decline nationally in the uptake of childhood vaccinations.\n\nVanessa MacGregor, a consultant in health protection with PHE, said there has been a rise in suspected mumps cases, with teenagers and young people who have not had 2 doses of the MMR vaccination 'particularly vulnerable.'\n\n'Young adults who have not received the MMR or only received one dose should ensure that they take up the offer of MMR vaccination,' she said. 'However, it's not just students who are at risk, and we would urge everyone who hasn't received 2 doses of MMR vaccine to do so.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An earlier report in September 2019 mentions that 'Public Health England (PHE) has confirmed 306 cases of mumps across the East Midlands between April and June [2019]. A total of 2028 cases of mumps were confirmed across England during the same 2019 period. That is up from 795 cases confirmed in England during the previous quarter, continuing the increase seen at the start of the year [2019]' (https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-nottinghamshire-49594610).\n\nMumps is a contagious viral infection that used to be common in children before the introduction of the MMR vaccine. Mumps is most recognisable by the painful swellings in the side of the face under the ears (the parotid glands), giving a person with mumps a distinctive 'hamster face' appearance. Other symptoms of mumps include headaches, joint pain, and a high temperature, which may develop a few days before the swelling of the parotid glands.\nWhile mumps is not usually serious, the condition has similar symptoms to more serious types of infection, such as glandular fever and tonsillitis.\n\nA diagnosis can generally be made after seeing and feeling the swelling, looking at the position of the tonsils in the mouth, and checking the person's temperature to see if it's higher than normal. Mumps is spread through infected droplets of saliva that can be inhaled or picked up from surfaces and transferred into the mouth or nose.\n\nA person is most contagious a few days before the symptoms develop and for a few days afterwards. During this time, it's important to prevent the infection spreading to others, particularly teenagers and young adults who have not been vaccinated.\n\nSpread of infection can be prevented by\n- regularly washing your hands with soap;\n- using and disposing of tissues when you sneeze; and\n- avoiding school or work for at least 5 days after your symptoms 1st develop.\n\nThe combined MMR vaccine for mumps, measles, and rubella offers protection against mumps infection. The MMR vaccine is part of the routine NHS childhood immunisation schedule. - Mod.UBA\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nNottinghamshire, England, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6003]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nBeginning with 3 cases confirmed by officials on 23 Sep [2019], the school's weekly update reported 43 confirmed cases on 14 Nov [2019], a 65% jump from the 26 cases noted a week earlier on 7 Nov [2019]. \n\nSpread of infection can be prevented by\n- regularly washing your hands with soap;\n- using and disposing of tissues when you sneeze; and\n- avoiding school or work for at least 5 days after your symptoms 1st develop. \n\nVanessa MacGregor, a consultant in health protection with PHE, said there has been a rise in suspected mumps cases, with teenagers and young people who have not had 2 doses of the MMR vaccination 'particularly vulnerable.'\n\n'Young adults who have not received the MMR or only received one dose should ensure that they take up the offer of MMR vaccination,' she said. Asia (India)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6896275", "date": "2020-01-18 21:18:24", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (01): EUROPE (UNITED KINGDOM, IRELAND), ASIA (INDIA)\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nEurope\n---\n[1] Ireland\n[2] United Kingdom\nAsia\n---\n[3] India (West Bengal, Tajpur)\n\n******\nEurope\n---\n[1] Ireland\nDate: Fri 17 Jan 2020\nSource: RTE [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.rte.ie/news/newslens/2020/0117/1107997-mumps/\n\n\nOutbreaks of mumps have become widespread around the country, the Health Service Executive (HSE) has said. There were 132 cases of mumps reported to the Health Protection Surveillance Centre last week.\n\nMumps is a highly contagious viral infection, and the most common symptom of mumps is a swelling of the parotid glands. The glands are located on both sides of the face, and the swelling gives a person a distinctive 'hamster face' appearance.\n\nSpeaking on RTE's Morning Ireland, Dr. Kevin Kelleher, the HSE's Assistant National Director of Public Health, said it is happening because a large portion of 15- to 30-year-old people [do not have] full protection against mumps. He said not all of them are getting the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine or are getting only one dose, when people need at least 2 doses to be fully protected.\n\nThe HSE is warning schools, colleges and universities about the outbreak.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] United Kingdom\nDate: Wed 15 Jan 2020\nSource: Devon Live [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.devonlive.com/news/devon-news/mumps-outbreak-19-new-cases-3741359\n\n\nAn outbreak of 19 new cases of mumps has been reported across Devon in the last week. The contagious viral disease particularly affects under 25s. The new mumps figures have been released in the official Government weekly Statutory Notifications of Infectious Diseases report, with the highest number in Exeter.\n\nIt follows a warning that mumps is on the rise, particularly in university towns. Traditionally known as the 'kissing disease' because it spreads fast between groups of young people, mumps is a contagious viral infection recognisable by the painful swellings in the side of the face under the ears (the parotid glands), giving a person a distinctive 'hamster face' appearance.\n\nIn severe cases, it can develop into viral meningitis if it moves in the outer layer of the brain. Other complications include swelling of the testicles or ovaries (if the affected person has gone through puberty), which may affect a person's fertility.\n\n[Byline: Colleen Smith]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\nAsia\n---\n[3] India (West Bengal, Tajpur)\nDate: Wed 15 Jan 2020\nSource: Hindustan Times [edited]\nhttps://www.hindustantimes.com/cities/outbreak-declared-tajpur-school-under-surveillance-as-16-kids-found-infected-with-mumps/story-x64XDq5UaBBPc58sgu2zKO.html\n\n\nGovernment High School, Tajpur village, has been put under surveillance after 16 students of the school were found to be infected with mumps, a viral infection that swells up the saliva-producing glands of a person.\n\nA rapid response team had been dispatched to the school last week, after the students, all aged between 11 and 14, were found infected. The school currently has 106 students [enrolled], and all are under observation. The team had also surveyed the entire village and collected samples, to be sent to the Integrated Diseases Surveillance Program (IDSP) lab for testing.\n\nLack of measles, mumps, and rubella [MMR] vaccination is what leaves a person prone to the infection. Mumps virus spreads from person to person through infected saliva. If an individual is not immune, they can contract the viral by breathing in saliva droplets from an infected person.\n\nDr. Divjot Singh, epidemiologist, district health department, said the situation is now under control. 'We have asked the school's principal to relieve all students infected with mumps. The school will remain under surveillance for 15 more days. Medical officers are also carrying out awareness drive at the school and the village against mumps,' said Dr. Divjot Singh.\n\nLast year [2019], a mumps outbreak was reported from 2 areas of the district, including Andlu village in Raikot and Red Cross Bhavan, Sarabha Nagar, Ludhiana.\n\n[Byline: Harvinder Kaur]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\nAsia\n---\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n [2] United Kingdom\nAsia\n---\n In this update:\nEurope\n---\n MUMPS UPDATE (01): EUROPE (UNITED KINGDOM, IRELAND), ASIA (INDIA)\n*****************************************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org> Europe\n---\n \n\n\nGovernment High School, Tajpur village, has been put under surveillance after 16 students of the school were found to be infected with mumps, a viral infection that swells up the saliva-producing glands of a person. Traditionally known as the 'kissing disease' because it spreads fast between groups of young people, mumps is a contagious viral infection recognisable by the painful swellings in the side of the face under the ears (the parotid glands), giving a person a distinctive 'hamster face' appearance. \n\nMumps is a highly contagious viral infection, and the most common symptom of mumps is a swelling of the parotid glands. \n\n--\n [Byline: Colleen Smith]\n\n--\n [Byline: Harvinder Kaur]\n\n--\n [3] India (West Bengal, Tajpur)\n\n******\n \n\nLast year [2019], a mumps outbreak was reported from 2 "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (12): USA (NE, NM) Europe (UK)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6669354", "date": "2019-09-11 19:09:35", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (12): USA (NEBRASKA, NEW MEXICO) EUROPE (UNITED KINGDOM)\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n\nUSA\n---\n[1] Nebraska\n[2] New Mexico (Bernalillo County)\n\nEurope\n---\n[3] UK\n\n******\n[1] Nebraska\nDate: Mon 9 Sep 2019\nSource: Wahoo News [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.wahoo-ashland-waverly.com/news/dhhs-reports-increase-in-mumps-cases-issues-reminders/article_1b32a574-ce9d-11e9-ac05-ab51577b33a9.html\n\n\nThe Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) has seen a significant increase in mumps cases related to 2 recent outbreaks.\n\nAt least 30 cases have been identified, mainly among attendees of a wedding in Northeast Nebraska Public Health Department's jurisdiction (Cedar, Dixon, Thurston and Wayne counties) and a workplace in Four Corners Health Department's jurisdiction (Butler, Polk, York and Seward counties).\n\nDHHS is working with local health departments to investigate reported cases.\n\nPeople with mumps are most contagious 3 days before and 5 days after their symptoms begin.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] New Mexico (Bernalillo County)\nDate: Sun 8 Sep 2019\nSource: Outbreak News Today [abridged, edited]\nhttps://protect2.fireeye.com/url?k=c644fa01-9a7c5d63-c6460334-000babd9f75c-358785604a51e3da&q=1&u=http%3A%2F%2Foutbreaknewstoday.com%2Fmumps-cases-reported-in-bernalillo-county-nm-16517%2F>\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH) is investigating 6 mumps cases in Bernalillo County. The cases are in people aged 7-41 years.\n\n'We are encouraging health care providers to be on the lookout for additional mumps cases,' said Department of Health Secretary Kathy Kunkel. 'If people start experiencing mumps-like symptoms, they should contact their doctor.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] UK\nDate: Fri 6 Sep 2019\nSource: BBC [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-nottinghamshire-49594610\n\n\nThere were more than 300 cases of mumps across the East Midlands following an outbreak of the virus at 2 universities earlier this year [2019], it has been confirmed.\n\nDozens of students fell ill with mumps at Nottingham Trent University and the University of Nottingham.\n\nA total of 40 cases had been confirmed, and 223 cases suspected, by March 2019.\n\nNow Public Health England (PHE) has confirmed 306 cases of mumps across the East Midlands between April and June 2019.\n\nA total of 2028 cases of mumps were confirmed across England during the same 2019 period. That is up from 795 cases confirmed in England during the previous quarter, continuing the increase seen at the start of the year. The region's cases alone account for 15% of the country's total.\n\nPublic Health England (PHE) and both universities have urged students to get vaccinated ahead of the new term.\n\nThe student, who had the MMR vaccine as a child, returned to her placement when the infection had passed. 'I still felt a bit drained, but I was quite lucky the swelling only lasted the maximum period,' she said.\n\nPHE said the rise in mumps cases was mostly driven by university students and young people aged between 15 and 34. She said the figures 'clearly demonstrate the need for sustained high vaccination rates.' However, protection only comes if about 88% of people have been vaccinated, according to viral vaccines expert Prof Jonathan Ball, from the University of Nottingham. If a majority of people are vaccinated, those susceptible to the infection would benefit from 'herd immunity,' Prof Ball said.\n\nMumps is a contagious viral infection which causes swelling of the parotid glands. General symptoms can include headache, joint pain, feeling sick, tiredness, loss of appetite and a high temperature. It is spread in the same way as colds and flu, through infected droplets of saliva that can be inhaled or picked up from surfaces and transferred into the mouth or nose.\n\nMumps can lead to viral meningitis if the virus moves into the outer layer of the brain, although this is rare.\n\nOther complications include swelling of the testicles or ovaries, which may affect a person's fertility.\n\nA person is most contagious a few days before the symptoms develop and for a few days afterwards.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See the following study on waning mumps immunity over years:\n\n'Lewnard JA and Grad YH. Vaccine waning and mumps re-emergence in the United States. Sci Transl Med. 2018 Mar 21; 10(433): eaao5945. doi: 10.1126/scitranslmed.aao5945\n\nAbstract. Following decades of declining mumps incidence amid widespread vaccination, the United States and other developed countries have experienced a resurgence in mumps cases over the last decade. Outbreaks affecting vaccinated individuals and communities with high vaccine coverage have prompted concerns about the effectiveness of the live attenuated vaccine currently in use. It is unclear if immune protection wanes, or if the vaccine protects inadequately against currently circulating mumps virus lineages. Synthesizing data from 6 studies of mumps vaccine effectiveness, we estimated that vaccine-derived immune protection against mumps wanes on average 27 (95% confidence interval: 16 to 51) years post-vaccination. After accounting for this waning, we found no evidence that the emergence of heterologous virus genotypes contributed to changes in vaccine effectiveness over time. A mathematical model of mumps transmission confirmed the central role of waning immunity to the vaccine in the re-emergence of mumps cases. Outbreaks from 2006 to the present among young adults, and outbreaks in the late 1980s and early 1990s among adolescents, aligned with peaks in mumps susceptibility of these age groups predicted to be due to loss of vaccine-derived protection. In contrast, evolution of mumps virus strains escaping immune pressure would be expected to cause a higher proportion of cases among children, not adolescents and young adults as observed. Routine use of a 3rd vaccine dose at age 18 years, or booster dosing throughout adulthood, may be a strategy to prevent mumps re-emergence and should be assessed in clinical trials.' - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nNebraska, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/229\nNew Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233\nUnited Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40]", "summary": "If people start experiencing mumps-like symptoms, they should contact their doctor.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See the following study on waning mumps immunity over years:\n\n'Lewnard JA and Grad YH. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nNebraska, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/229\nNew Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233\nUnited Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40] In this update:\n\nUSA\n---\n Synthesizing data from 6 studies of mumps vaccine effectiveness, we estimated that vaccine-derived immune protection against mumps wanes on average 27 (95% confidence interval: 16 to 51) years post-vaccination. MUMPS UPDATE (12): USA (NEBRASKA, NEW MEXICO) EUROPE (UNITED KINGDOM)\n*********************************************************************\n A mathematical model of mumps transmission confirmed the central role of waning immunity to the vaccine in the re-emergence of mumps cases. \n\nPHE said the rise in mumps cases was mostly driven by university students and young people aged between 15 and 34. \n\nA total of 2028 cases of mumps were confirmed across England during the same 2019 period. \n\n'We are encouraging health care providers to be on the lookout for additional mumps cases,' said Department of Health Secretary Kathy Kunkel. ' Following decades of declining mumps incidence amid widespread vaccination, the United States and other developed countries have experienced a resurgence in mumps cases over the last decade. \n\nPeople with mumps are most contagious 3 days before and 5 days after their symptoms begin. [3] UK\n\n******\n \n\n--\n \n\n--\n \n\nMumps is a contagious viral infection which causes swelling of the parotid glands. In contrast, evolution of mumps virus strains escaping immune pressure would be expected to cause a higher proportion of cases among children, not adolescents and young adults as observed.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6841027", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (15): Europe (UK, Ireland), New Zealand (AU)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6841027", "date": "2019-12-14 19:53:00", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (15): EUROPE (UK, IRELAND), NEW ZEALAND (AUCKLAND)\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nEurope\n---\n[1] UK\n[2] Ireland (Dublin)\n\nPacific\n---\n[3] New Zealand (Auckland)\n\n******\n[1] UK\nDate: Wed 11 Dec 2019\nSource: Daily Mail [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-7782465/Mumps-outbreak-hits-hundreds-students-UK-fall-children-having-MMR-vaccine.html\n\n\nHundreds of students have been struck down by a severe outbreak of mumps that is spreading across British universities. Public Health England figures show that more than 7200 suspected mumps cases have been reported in the UK since July [2019], almost triple the same period last year [2018].\n\nHealth officials said students were driving the surge and urged any who missed out on the MMR jab to get vaccinated.\n\nMore than 15 000 mumps cases have been reported so far compared with just over 6000 at this time in 2018, according to Dr Doug Brown of the British Society for Immunology.\n\nIn recent weeks, outbreaks of the highly infectious disease have been reported at universities including Edinburgh, Cambridge, Oxford, and Bristol.\n\nThe surge in cases is linked to a dip in uptake of the MMR vaccine 2 decades ago. The current generation of students were born at the height of a mass health scare triggered in 1998, when now-disgraced doctor Andrew Wakefield made a link between the vaccine and autism.\n\nThe Daily Mail is running a major campaign to boost vaccine rates amid falling uptake of all 10 routine childhood jabs.\n\n[Byline: Eleanor Hayward]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Ireland (Dublin)\nDate: Mon 9 Dec 2019\nSource: Irish Times [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.irishtimes.com/news/health/biggest-mumps-outbreak-in-a-decade-continues-with-103-new-cases-last-week-1.4109746\n\n\nThe biggest mumps outbreak in a decade shows no sign of abating, with 103 new cases reported last week. So far this year [2019], 2458 cases of mumps have been reported, compared to 563 notified in all of 2018, according to the latest figures.\n\nWith the current outbreak mostly affecting teenagers and young adults, scores of schools and colleges have been affected. The Health Service Executive advises those diagnosed with the disease to stay at home for at least 5 days after their salivary glands swell in order to prevent the infection spreading.\n\nThe worst-affected part of the state is the greater Dublin area, which accounted for 1126 of the cases so far this year [2019], according to the HSE's Health Protection Surveillance Centre. In contrast, just 84 cases have been recorded in the Southern Health Board area.\n\nMen are slightly more affected than women, and 869 cases have been recorded among 15-19-year-olds alone.\n\nPublic health officials have blamed the current outbreak on a dip in the MMR (measles/mumps/rubella) vaccination rates 20 years ago. This resulted from publicity surrounding the since-discredited claims by Dr Andrew Wakefield linking the vaccine to a rise in autism cases.\n\nDoctors say the MMR vaccine is the best way to prevent the disease and its complications, though it is estimated to be only 88% effective in preventing mumps, and effectiveness wanes over time.\n\nSince 1988 when MMR was 1st introduced, the largest outbreak of mumps was reported in 2009 when more than 3600 cases were notified.\n\nFortunately, there is no sign of a measles outbreak this year [2019]. Some 75 cases have been reported in the 1st 11 months of 2019, 40 of them in the greater Dublin area.\n\n[Byline: Paul Cullen]\n\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] New Zealand (Auckland)\nDate: Tue 26 Nov 2019\nSource: The Spinoff [abridged, edited]\nhttps://thespinoff.co.nz/science/26-11-2019/highly-contagious-mumps-outbreak-hitting-auckland-gyms/\n\n\nThere's a new outbreak of the highly contagious viral disease mumps across the Auckland region, with localised clusters of cases diagnosed in Howick, Pakuranga, Auckland Central, and Ponsonby. The point of origin is unknown.\n\nIn its announcement, the Auckland Regional Public Health Service (ARPHS) noted that those affected included gym instructors working in community facilities across Auckland. The ARPHS pointed out that gym instructors are 'generally young adults who have lower vaccination rates and who also tend to mix and move between gyms.'\n\nIn the 18 months to August 2018, more than 1200 cases were reported in the Auckland region. While that outbreak was ultimately controlled, there have been 120 cases of mumps in Auckland so far this year [2019], with 49 of those in the past 4 weeks. The ARPHS has not seen increased rates of rubella to date this year [2019], but it's a disease they routinely monitor. Those who haven't received the MMR vaccine are at risk of contracting all 3 diseases, 2 of which are on the rise in New Zealand. According to Southern Cross, since the national vaccination programme containing the MMR vaccine was introduced in 1990, there have been generally around 20-30 cases of mumps per year across the country. During the 1st big post-MMR outbreak in 2017, more than 900 cases were recorded.\n\n[Byline: Josie Adams]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Gym instructors could readily spread the virus to their numerous contacts in gyms where they teach if those gym members are not fully immunized. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nUnited Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40\nIreland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39\nAuckland, New Zealand: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/606]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n [Byline: Paul Cullen]\n\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nUnited Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40\nIreland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Gym instructors could readily spread the virus to their numerous contacts in gyms where they teach if those gym members are not fully immunized. effective in preventing mumps, and effectiveness wanes over time.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "1126-03-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Mumps update (10): USA (TX) outbreak update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6601222", "date": "2019-08-01 21:53:53", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (10): USA (TEXAS) OUTBREAK UPDATE\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 30 Jul 2019\nSource: Precision Vaccinations [edited]\nhttps://www.precisionvaccinations.com/ice-says-they-quarantine-people-exposed-mumps-and-offer-related-vaccines\n\n\nAbout 100 new mumps cases have been identified in Texas immigrant-holding facilities in the last 5 weeks, according to reporting by News 88.7 in Houston, Texas.\n\nAccording to this Houston Public Media report on 29 Jul 2019, the new mumps cases include all federal facilities that hold immigrants, including Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), Customs and Border Protection, and shelters that hold unaccompanied migrant children.\n\n'To have this many cases concentrated in this relatively small population is distinctly unusual in the United States,' said Dr. Jody Rich, professor of Medicine and Epidemiology at Brown University and a volunteer with Physicians for Human Rights. 'We should be vaccinating all at-risk people as early as possible, particularly if we are about to confine them in a closed space with a bunch of other unvaccinated people in the setting of an outbreak.'\n\nThis mumps virus information was gathered through the Freedom of Information Act and confirmed mumps cases in at least 16 different detention facilities in Texas.\n\nPreviously, on 14 Jun 2019, federal authorities confirmed about 4276 individuals were in medical quarantine in 39 immigrant detention centers related to large numbers of mumps and chicken pox cases.\n\nSome of these mumps cases may have originated from countries such as Honduras, which announced significant mumps outbreaks during 2018.\n\n'From an operational perspective, the impact is significant in the short and long term and will result in an increase in cohort detainees' length of stay in detention, an inability to effect removal of eligible detainees, and postponing scheduled consular interviews,' said Nathalie Asher, executive associate director for ICE Enforcement and Removal Operations (ERO).\n\n'Preventing the spread of communicable diseases while in ICE custody is something we have demonstrated success doing,' Asher previously said.\n\nRoutine vaccination of US-bound refugees before travel to the United States is not legally required. However, routine vaccinations are strongly recommended and offered overseas to protect the health, prevent travel delays due to disease outbreaks, and, for children, allow more rapid integration into schools after arrival in the United States.\n\nThe CDC vaccination schedule is modified periodically (May 2019) based on changing Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices recommendations, logistics, or availability.\n\nUnfortunately, these are not the only mumps cases being reported in Texas during 2019.\n\nThe Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS) confirmed as of [Thu 1 Jul 2019] that there have been 385 total mumps cases during 2019.\n\nDue to a high vaccination rate in Texas, the number of mumps cases has been traditionally low, says DSHS. In 2017, only 470 cases of mumps were reported in Texas.\n\nAs an example of Texas being a proactive vaccination state, DSHS launched Operation Lone Star for its 21st year in July 2019.\n\nIn 2018, DSHS and partners delivered approximately 43 000 health services and vaccinations to 9346 people in southern Texas during this event.\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), there is a recurring mumps risk related to vaccine effectiveness 'waning.' According to a Harvard study in 2018, the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine-derived immune protection against mumps persists, on average, for just 27 years after the last-administered vaccine dose.\n\nIn response to this information, the CDC released new guidance suggesting when a 3rd dose of mumps vaccine is appropriate to administer.\n\nNationwide, from January [2019] to 19 Jul 2019, there have been 45 states and the District of Columbia reporting mumps infections in 1799 people, which is actually good news compared to previous years.\n\nFrom January 2016 to June 2017, health departments reported 9200 mumps cases, including outbreaks at schools, universities, athletics teams and facilities, church groups, workplaces, and large events.\n\nThe mumps virus is easily spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks.\n\nCDC officials say that 'it's never too late to be immunized.' In the USA, there are 2 approved mumps vaccines, MMR-II and ProQuad.\n\n[Byline: Don Ward Hackett]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks of mumps in immigrant-holding facilities is not new information. The ProMED-mail post of 6 Jun 2019 reported nearly 300 confirmed cases of mumps in ICE facilities and other immigration detention centers across the country, with the most cases concentrated in Texas, Mississippi, Arizona, and Georgia. Mumps virus transmission continues in Texas and likely in other states as individuals are held in close confinement under conditions that facilitate transmission of the virus. Dr. Jody Rich's advice to vaccinate all at-risk people as early as possible, particularly if we are about to confine them in a closed space with a bunch of other unvaccinated people in the setting of an outbreak, is prudent and good preventive medicine practice.\n\nIn the previous Mumps update (Mumps update: (09): USA (FL) quarantine; archive no. 20190609.6508541), Mod.UBA commented, 'Mumps is a viral illness caused by a paramyxovirus, a member of the Rubulavirus family. The average incubation period for mumps is 16-18 days, with a range of 12-25 days. The mumps virus replicates in the upper respiratory tract and is transmitted person-to-person through direct contact with saliva or respiratory droplets of a person infected with mumps. The risk of spreading the virus increases the longer and the closer the contact a person has with someone who has mumps. The infectious period is considered from 2 days before to 5 days after parotitis onset, although virus has been isolated from saliva as early as 7 days prior to and up to 9 days after parotitis onset. Mumps virus has also been isolated up to 14 days in urine and semen.\n\n'When people are ill with mumps, they should avoid contact with others from the time of diagnosis until 5 days after the onset of parotitis by staying home from work or school and staying in a separate room, if possible (https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/hcp.html).\n\n'If not strict quarantine, the suspected mumps cases should, prior to testing, be isolated/confined to separate living areas with hand hygiene and social distancing during the infectious period, since the high concentration of people in the camps can potentially result in outbreaks. - Mod.UBA]'\n\n- Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nTexas, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245]", "summary": "\n\nThis mumps virus information was gathered through the Freedom of Information Act and confirmed mumps cases in at least 16 different detention facilities in Texas. \n\n'If not strict quarantine, the suspected mumps cases should, prior to testing, be isolated/confined to separate living areas with hand hygiene and social distancing during the infectious period, since the high concentration of people in the camps can potentially result in outbreaks. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks of mumps in immigrant-holding facilities is not new information. \n\nFrom January 2016 to June 2017, health departments reported 9200 mumps cases, including outbreaks at schools, universities, athletics teams and facilities, church groups, workplaces, and large events. \n\nThe Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS) confirmed as of [Thu 1 Jul 2019] that there have been 385 total mumps cases during 2019. \n\n'When people are ill with mumps, they should avoid contact with others from the time of diagnosis until 5 days after the onset of parotitis by staying home from work or school and staying in a separate room, if possible (https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/hcp.html). The ProMED-mail post of 6 Jun 2019 reported nearly 300 confirmed cases of mumps in ICE facilities and other immigration detention centers across the country, with the most cases concentrated in Texas, Mississippi, Arizona, and Georgia. The mumps virus replicates in the upper respiratory tract and is transmitted person-to-person through direct contact with saliva or respiratory droplets of a person infected with mumps. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Previously, on 14 Jun 2019, federal authorities confirmed about 4276 individuals were in medical quarantine in 39 immigrant detention centers related to large numbers of mumps and chicken pox cases. According to this Houston Public Media report on 29 Jul 2019, the new mumps cases include all federal facilities that hold immigrants, including Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), Customs and Border Protection, and shelters that hold unaccompanied migrant children. According to a Harvard study in 2018, the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine-derived immune protection against mumps persists, on average, for just 27 years after the last-administered vaccine dose. Some of these mumps cases may have originated from countries such as Honduras, which announced significant mumps outbreaks during 2018. The infectious period is considered from 2 days before to 5 days after parotitis onset, although virus has been isolated from saliva as early as 7 days prior to and up to 9 days after parotitis onset. Nationwide, from January [2019] to 19 Jul 2019, there have been 45 states and the District of Columbia reporting mumps infections in 1799 people, which is actually good news compared to previous years. \n\n[Byline: Don Ward Hackett]\n\n--\n https://www.precisionvaccinations.com/ice-says-they-quarantine-people-exposed-mumps-and-offer-related-vaccines\n\n\nAbout 100 new mumps cases have been identified in Texas immigrant-holding facilities in the last 5 weeks, according to reporting by News 88.7 in Houston, Texas. In the previous Mumps update (Mumps update: (09): USA (FL) quarantine; archive no.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-01-25 00:00:00", "2019-06-06 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-05-25 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-06-14 00:00:00", "2019-07-25 00:00:00", "1799-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States :", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mississippi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Honduras", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Houston", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6652249", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Mumps update (11): USA (TX, NE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6652249", "date": "2019-09-01 12:56:30", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (11): USA (TEXAS, NEBRASKA)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Texas detention facilities\n[2] Nebraska\n\n******\n[1] Texas detention facilities\nDate: Fri 30 Aug 2019\nSource: MMWR [edited]\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.15585/mmwr.mm6834a4\n\n\nCitation. Leung J, Elson D, Sanders K, et al. Notes from the Field: Mumps in Detention Facilities that House Detained Migrants -- United States, September 2018-August 2019. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2019;68:749-750. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.15585/mmwr.mm6834a4\nhttps://tinyurl.com/yxbkpr2g\n------------------------------------\nOn 12 Oct 2018, 5 confirmed cases of mumps among migrants who had been transferred between 2 detention facilities were reported by the facilities to the Texas Department of State Health Services (TDSHS). By 11 Dec 2018, 8 Texas detention facilities and 6 facilities in 5 other states had reported 67 mumps cases to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) Health Service Corps (IHSC) or local health departments.\n\nOn 12 Dec 2018, TDSHS contacted CDC to discuss mumps control in detention facilities and facilitate communication with IHSC. During 4-17 Jan 2019, 6 more state health departments reported new cases in detention facilities, which prompted CDC and IHSC to launch a coordinated national outbreak response.\n\nDuring 1 Sep 2018-22 Aug 2019, a total of 898 confirmed and probable mumps cases (1) in adult migrants detained in 57 facilities (18% of 315 U.S. facilities that house ICE detainees*) were reported in 19 states (Figure); an additional 33 cases occurred among staff members. Private companies operated 34 facilities; 19 were county jails that house detained migrants, and 4 were ICE-operated. 44 percent (394) of cases were reported from facilities that house ICE detainees in Texas.\n\nMedian patient age was 25 years (range = 17-67); 846 (94%) were male. Based on detainee custody status during their incubation period (12-25 days before symptom onset), most (758, 84%) patients were exposed while in custody of ICE or another U.S. agency; 43 (5%) were exposed before apprehension; and the custody status at the time of exposure of 97 (11%) was unknown. Among those with data on complications, 79 (15%) of 527 male patients reported orchitis, and at least 13 patients were hospitalized. More than half (576, 64%) of cases were confirmed by quantitative reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction testing or viral culture testing at CDC, state public health laboratories, Association of Public Health Laboratories-CDC Vaccine Preventable Disease Reference Centers, or commercial laboratories. Sequencing of isolates from 70 patients identified genotype G, the most common mumps genotype detected in the United States since 2006 (2). IHSC provided over 25 000 doses of measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine in response to mumps in 56 facilities.\n\nSince 2015, approximately 150 mumps outbreaks and 16 000 cases have been reported in the United States, typically in close-contact settings such as universities, schools, and athletic events. This is the 1st report of mumps outbreaks in detention facilities.\n\nMMR vaccination efforts differ among detention facilities; facilities should follow local or state health department recommendations for preventing and responding to mumps (3) and should report cases and follow disease control guidance from their health department. Detainees and staff members at increased risk for mumps should be offered MMR vaccine per existing recommendations for vaccination during outbreaks (4,5). MMR vaccine has not been shown to be effective at preventing disease in persons already infected with mumps; facilities should be aware that cases might occur among detainees exposed before vaccination.\n\nHealth departments, CDC, IHSC, and facility health administration can work together to develop appropriate control measures based on local epidemiology and the specific needs of each facility. Identifying and vaccinating close contacts of exposed or symptomatic persons with mumps in detention centers is challenging. IHSC can look up transfer history and facilitate vaccine procurement for detainees in ICE custody upon request from facility health services administrators. CDC is coordinating communication among state and local health departments, IHSC, and other federal partners to mobilize appropriate resources and is providing technical support for implementing appropriate disease control and prevention measures. Effective public health interventions require understanding of facility and custody operations, which often involve frequent transfers of detainees (between facilities and states) and multiple entities with authority for operations and detainee custody.\n\nAs of 22 Aug 2019, mumps outbreaks are ongoing in 15 facilities in 7 states, and new introductions into detention facilities through detainees who are transferred or exposed before being taken into custody continue to occur.\n\n[See URL for references.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMary Marshall\n\n[Mumps is a viral illness caused by a paramyxovirus, family Rubulavirus. It spreads through direct contact with saliva or respiratory droplets from the mouth, nose, or throat. An infected person can spread the virus by\n- coughing, sneezing, or talking\n- sharing items that may have saliva on them, such as water bottles or cups\n- participating in close-contact activities with others, such as playing sports, dancing, or kissing\n- touching objects or surfaces with unwashed hands that are then touched by others\n\nAn infected person can likely spread mumps from a few days before their salivary glands begin to swell to up to 5 days after the swelling begins. A person with mumps should limit their contact with others during this time.\n\nBefore the U.S. mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, and many more unreported cases occurred. The disease caused complications, such as permanent deafness in children, and, occasionally, encephalitis, which could rarely result in death. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99% decrease in mumps cases in the United States. From year to year, the number of mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. However, outbreaks still occur, even among highly vaccinated populations.\n\nOrchitis occurs in approximately 20-30% of unvaccinated and 6-7% of vaccinated post-pubertal male mumps patients [In this report, 15% of the cases were noted to have this complication]. In 60% to 83% of males with mumps orchitis, only one testis is affected. Mumps orchitis has not been linked to infertility but may result in testicular atrophy and hypo-fertility (excerpted from https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/hcp.html).\n\nDetention facilities such as those on the US-Mexico border provide the perfect environment for mumps and other highly infectious diseases such as influenza and TB to spread among detainees. It is not clear what is being done to protect the health of at-risk detainees. See earlier ProMED-mail posts on mumps in these facilities. - Mod.LK\n\nProMED HealthMap: Texas, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245]\n\n******\n[2] Nebraska\nDate: Thu 29 Aug 2019\nSource: Sioux Land Proud [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.siouxlandproud.com/news/health-officials-warn-against-mumps-after-outbreak-in-northeast-nebraska/\n\n\nHealth officials are warning residents of mumps after 2 recent outbreaks in northeast Nebraska.\n\nThe Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) said that 30 cases were identified in the jurisdictions of the Nebraska Public Health Department and Four Corners Health Department. Nebraska Public Health Department manages Cedar, Dixon, Thurston and Wayne counties, while Four Corners Health Department's jurisdiction includes Butler, Polk, York and Seward counties.\n\nOf the 30 cases, most were among people attending a wedding in northeast Nebraska and at a work environment in the Four Corners Health Department jurisdiction.\n\nThe DHHS said they are working to investigate the cases as they work with the local health departments.\n\nIn 2018, there were only 12 reported cases of mumps and 6 in 2017. There were 49 cases in 2016.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED HealthMap: Nebraska, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/229]", "summary": "An infected person can spread the virus by\n- coughing, sneezing, or talking\n- sharing items that may have saliva on them, such as water bottles or cups\n- participating in close-contact activities with others, such as playing sports, dancing, or kissing\n- touching objects or surfaces with unwashed hands that are then touched by others\n\nAn infected person can likely spread mumps from a few days before their salivary glands begin to swell to up to 5 days after the swelling begins. \n\nMMR vaccination efforts differ among detention facilities; facilities should follow local or state health department recommendations for preventing and responding to mumps (3) and should report cases and follow disease control guidance from their health department. MMR vaccine has not been shown to be effective at preventing disease in persons already infected with mumps; facilities should be aware that cases might occur among detainees exposed before vaccination. {"archive_id": "6508541", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (09): USA (FL) quarantine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6508541", "date": "2019-06-09 12:08:04", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (09): USA (FLORIDA) QUARANTINE\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Florida outbreak\n[2] Immigrant detention centers\n\n******\n[1] Florida outbreak\nDate: 31 May 2019\nSource: 4 News [edited]\nhttps://mycbs4.com/news/local/mumps-outbreak-12-college-students-infected\n\n\nThe Alachua County Health Department is warning residents that there are 12 confirmed cases of mumps, primarily from college students at the University of Florida.\n\n'This is a little more than usual,' says Steve Orlando, University of Florida spokesman.\n\nAlachua County normally receives around 2 reported cases a year, and UF believes more students could be infected.\n\n'So, it's curious because these are individuals who are vaccinated, and that's what we are seeing nationwide,' says Paul Myers, Alachua County Health Department administrator.\n\nOfficials say it is still unclear why there has been an uptick with the virus. So far, the CDC shows 736 people have contracted mumps nationwide in 2019.\n\n'The sharing of the utensils, sharing of the cups, sharing of the water bottles, you know it is a very common thing for students to share those things, and that's exactly the kind of thing that could lead to transmission,' says Orlando.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Immigrant detention centers\nDate: 4 Jun 2019\nSource: Axios [edited]\nhttps://www.axios.com/immigrants-quarantined-30-ice-centers-mumps-outbreak-cdafc66b-7b99-4671-ba7e-3b7825458fea.html\n\n\nImmigrants have been quarantined in over 30 ICE [Immigration and Customs Enforcement] detention centers across the U.S. for mumps and a few cases of chickenpox in recent months, according to a Quartz investigation into information shared by attorneys.\n\nWhy it matters: Mumps is from a fast-spreading but relatively mild virus that sometimes causes serious complications. But the people who are quarantined also are not allowed access to their attorneys and cannot attend bond or asylum proceedings, Quartz points out.\n\nBy the numbers: Quartz found nearly 300 confirmed cases of mumps in ICE facilities and other immigration detention centers across the country, with the most cases concentrated in Texas, Mississippi, Arizona and Georgia.\n\nNot all state or county health departments monitor disease outbreaks in ICE facilities. Louisiana and California 'said they had no data on disease in ICE facilities,' Quartz reports, so the case numbers could be higher.\n\n'Local health authorities tasked with keeping civilian populations in their areas safe said they have no idea how widespread the mumps epidemic is in immigration facilities around the US,' Quartz reports.\n\nThere are also few consequences for ICE personnel who don't follow immunization or follow-up standards for detainees, per a recent internal investigation.\n\nThe recommended 2 doses of MMR vaccine are roughly 88 percent effective at preventing mumps, per the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a viral illness caused by a paramyxovirus, a member of the Rubulavirus family. The average incubation period for mumps is 16 to 18 days, with a range of 12 to 25 days. The mumps virus replicates in the upper respiratory tract and is transmitted person to person through direct contact with saliva or respiratory droplets of a person infected with mumps. The risk of spreading the virus increases the longer and the closer the contact a person has with someone who has mumps. The infectious period is considered from 2 days before to 5 days after parotitis onset, although virus has been isolated from saliva as early as 7 days prior to and up to 9 days after parotitis onset. Mumps virus has also been isolated up to 14 days in urine and semen.\n\nWhen a person is ill with mumps, they should avoid contact with others from the time of diagnosis until 5 days after the onset of parotitis by staying home from work or school and staying in a separate room if possible [https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/hcp.html].\n\nIf not strict quarantine, prior to testing, the suspected mumps cases should be isolated/confined to separate living areas with hand hygiene and social distancing during the infectious period, since the high concentration of people in the camps can potentially result in outbreaks. - Mod.UBA]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a viral illness caused by a paramyxovirus, a member of the Rubulavirus family. The infectious period is considered from 2 days before to 5 days after parotitis onset, although virus has been isolated from saliva as early as 7 days prior to and up to 9 days after parotitis onset. \n\nWhen a person is ill with mumps, they should avoid contact with others from the time of diagnosis until 5 days after the onset of parotitis by staying home from work or school and staying in a separate room if possible [https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/hcp.html]. \n\nIf not strict quarantine, prior to testing, the suspected mumps cases should be isolated/confined to separate living areas with hand hygiene and social distancing during the infectious period, since the high concentration of people in the camps can potentially result in outbreaks. The mumps virus replicates in the upper respiratory tract and is transmitted person to person through direct contact with saliva or respiratory droplets of a person infected with mumps. MUMPS UPDATE (09): USA (FLORIDA) QUARANTINE\n*******************************************\n [2] Immigrant detention centers\n\n******\n \n\n'Local health authorities tasked with keeping civilian populations in their areas safe said they have no idea how widespread the mumps epidemic is in immigration facilities around the US,' Quartz reports. \n\n'The sharing of the utensils, sharing of the cups, sharing of the water bottles, you know it is a very common thing for students to share those things, and that's exactly the kind of thing that could lead to transmission,' says Orlando. In this update:\n[1] Florida outbreak\n By the numbers: Quartz found nearly 300 confirmed cases of mumps in ICE facilities and other immigration detention centers across the country, with the most cases concentrated in Texas, Mississippi, Arizona and Georgia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2019-05-31 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alachua County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FLORIDA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mississippi", "country":
