"https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7014486", "date": "2020-02-22 12:41:28", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (02): USA (LOUISIANA), EUROPE (UNITED KINGDOM), RESEARCH\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Louisiana (Baton Rouge): Louisiana State University\nEurope\n---\n[2] UK: Public Health England\nResearch\n---\n[3] Tracking mumps\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] Louisiana (Baton Rouge): Louisiana State University\nDate: Wed 12 Feb 2020\nSource: The Advocate [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.theadvocate.com/baton_rouge/news/article_92998e40-4df3-11ea-adbe-43c918564c94.html\n\n\nOne week after Louisiana State University (LSU) announced an outbreak of mumps, the university confirmed 7 additional cases, bringing the total of infected students to 12, according to WAFB-TV. LSU officials are continuing to urge students to seek treatment if they have swollen and tender salivary glands under their ears or jaw.\n\nMumps is a contagious disease. Symptoms include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness and loss of appetite, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. It can be spread through contact with saliva or respiratory droplets.\n\nInfected people are advised to limit contact with others. They are contagious from a few days before swelling of the salivary glands until up to 5 days after the swelling begins.\n\n'Students with signs of mumps must be isolated for at least 5 days from the onset of salivary gland swelling,' LSU said in a release following the initial outbreak. 'There is no specific treatment for mumps or exposure to mumps. Most people with mumps recover fully. However, mumps can occasionally cause complications, and some of them are serious.'\n\nReceiving 2 doses of the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine in a person's lifetime is the best way to prevent mumps, LSU said. 'Proof of immunity to mumps or proof of 2 doses of MMR vaccine is currently required for all students at LSU.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 20 Feb 2020, the case number at LSU has increased to 16 (https://www.wbrz.com/news/lsu-mumps-outbreak-grows-university-now-confirms-16-cases). There are also confirmed cases of mumps reported at the following:\n- Grice Middle School in Hamilton Township, Mercer Township, New Jersey (https://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2020/02/20/confirmed-case-of-mumps-at-grice-middle-school-in-hamilton-township/)\n- William Penn, St. Georges Technical, Delaware (https://www.delawareonline.com/story/news/health/2020/02/20/health-department-investigating-3-cases-mumps-william-penn-st-georges-technical/4820857002/)\n- North Charleston High School, South Carolina (https://www.live5news.com/2020/02/20/dhec-confirms-case-mumps-north-charleston-high-school/).\n- Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nLouisiana, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/221]\n\n******\nEurope\n---\n[2] UK: Public Health England\nDate: Tue 18 Feb 2020\nSource: Cheshire East Council [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.cheshireeast.gov.uk/council_and_democracy/council_information/media_hub/media_releases/18022020-an-increase-in-the-cases-of-mumps-in-england.aspx\n\n\nOur Public Health team is recommending that children and young people who may have missed out on protection from mumps should receive a catch-up MMR vaccination. In England there has been a significant rise in the number of cases of mumps [in the past year].\n\nThe latest data from Public Health England (PHE) show that there were 5042 lab-confirmed cases of mumps in England in 2019 compared with 1066 cases in 2018. This is the highest number of cases since 2009.\n\nThe steep rise in cases in 2019 has been largely driven by outbreaks in universities and colleges. Many of the cases in 2019 were young adults born in the late 1990s and early 2000s who missed out on the MMR vaccine when they were children.\n\nIn Cheshire East, our uptake was less than 80% for the 2nd dose in the early 2000s, more than 15% below the figure required for group immunity. These cohorts are now old enough to attend college and university and are likely to continue fuelling outbreaks into 2020.\n\nMumps is a viral illness caused by a paramyxovirus. Mumps can be caught through direct contact with saliva or droplets from the saliva of an infected person.\n\n[MMR vaccine] uptake has improved locally in recent years with most practices achieving between 90% and 95% for the 1st dose; however, in some towns there are still more than 10% of children who have not had both doses of MMR before they start school.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nUnited Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40]\n\n******\nResearch\n---\n[3] Tracking mumps\nDate: Tue 11 Feb 2020\nSource: PLOS Biology [edited]\nhttps://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pbio.3000611\n\n\nRef: Wohl S, Metsky HC, Schaffner SF, et al: Combining genomics and epidemiology to track mumps virus transmission in the United States. PLoS Biol. 2020; 18(2):e3000611.\n\nAbstract\n--------\nUnusually large outbreaks of mumps across the United States in 2016 and 2017 raised questions about the extent of mumps circulation and the relationship between these and prior outbreaks. We paired epidemiological data from public health investigations with analysis of mumps virus whole genome sequences from 201 infected individuals, focusing on Massachusetts university communities. Our analysis suggests continuous, undetected circulation of mumps locally and nationally, including multiple independent introductions into Massachusetts and into individual communities. Despite the presence of these multiple mumps virus lineages, the genomic data show that one lineage has dominated in the USA since at least 2006. Widespread transmission was surprising given high vaccination rates, but we found no genetic evidence that variants arising during this outbreak contributed to vaccine escape. Viral genomic data allowed us to reconstruct mumps transmission links not evident from epidemiological data or standard single-gene surveillance efforts and also revealed connections between apparently unrelated mumps outbreaks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMary Marshall\n<mjm2020@googlemail.com>\n\n[Recommended reading. As the authors state: 'Understanding transmission routes can be crucial in guiding the public health response to an outbreak -- for example, whether efforts should be directed toward controlling mumps spread within a university or preventing virus importation.' - Mod.LK]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nUnited Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40]\n\n******\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n There are also confirmed cases of mumps reported at the following:\n- Grice Middle School in Hamilton Township, Mercer Township, New Jersey (https://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2020/02/20/confirmed-case-of-mumps-at-grice-middle-school-in-hamilton-township/)\n- William Penn, St. Georges Technical, Delaware (https://www.delawareonline.com/story/news/health/2020/02/20/health-department-investigating-3-cases-mumps-william-penn-st-georges-technical/4820857002/)\n- North Charleston High School, South Carolina (https://www.live5news.com/2020/02/20/dhec-confirms-case-mumps-north-charleston-high-school/). [1] Louisiana (Baton Rouge): Louisiana State University\nEurope\n---\n [2] UK: Public Health England\nResearch\n---\n In this update:\nUSA\n---\n LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nLouisiana, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/221]\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 20 Feb 2020, the case number at LSU has increased to 16 (https://www.wbrz.com/news/lsu-mumps-outbreak-grows-university-now-confirms-16-cases). MUMPS UPDATE (02): USA (LOUISIANA), EUROPE (UNITED KINGDOM), RESEARCH\n*********************************************************************\n Communicated by:\nMary Marshall\n<mjm2020@googlemail.com>\n\n[Recommended reading. Proof of immunity to mumps or proof of 2 doses of MMR vaccine is currently required for all students at LSU.'\n\n--\n Date: Tue 11 Feb 2020\nSource: PLOS Biology [edited]\n USA\n---\n Europe\n---\n Research\n---\n [3] Tracking mumps\n\n******\n Viral genomic data allowed us to reconstruct mumps transmission links not evident from epidemiological data or standard single-gene surveillance efforts and also revealed connections between apparently unrelated mumps outbreaks. \n\nThe latest data from Public Health England (PHE) show that there were 5042 lab-confirmed cases of mumps in England in 2019 compared with 1066 cases in 2018. [3] Tracking mumps\n \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2020-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6760373", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (13): USA (CA,PA) Europe (Belgium)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6760373", "date": "2019-11-04 15:42:53", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (13): USA (CALIFORNIA, PENNSYLVANIA) EUROPE (BELGIUM)\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] California (Los Angeles): prison\n[2] California (San Diego County): school\n[3] Pennsylvania (York County): prison\nEurope\n---\n[4] Belgium (Brussels): university\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] California (Los Angeles): prison\nDate: Thu 31 Oct 2019 6:18 PM PST\nSource: Los Angeles Times [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.latimes.com/california/story/2019-10-31/mumps-outbreak-mens-central-jail\n\n\nNearly 400 inmates have been quarantined after a mumps outbreak at Men's Central Jail, LA [Los Angeles] County sheriff's officials said.\n\nThe outbreak has infected 18 people in the jail since 22 Oct 2019, when at least one inmate unaware he was infected with the virus was housed at the jail, according to the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department, which runs the lockup. The inmate showed flu-like symptoms and had swollen glands around his neck.\n\nAuthorities are still investigating the source of the outbreak, which originated on the 3rd floor of the jail in downtown Los Angeles. Inmates on that floor and the 2nd floor are being quarantined. Inmates who are infected with the virus are being housed in the medical ward on the 7th floor.\n\nThe inmates will be quarantined until at least 21 Nov [2019], a date that may be extended if new cases are diagnosed.\n\n'We're taking it day by day,' said Capt. Jason Wolak, who oversees operations at the jail.\n\nSince the outbreak, about 350 of the quarantined inmates and 200 jail staff members have been vaccinated for measles, mumps, and rubella [MMR]. 3 staff members are under medical observation, though it's unclear if any are infected.\n\nThrough mid-October [2019], there were 2618 reported mumps infections nationwide, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nThe virus can be transmitted through physical contact, sharing drinks and utensils, or touching surfaces that have also been touched by someone infected.\n\nAlthough quarantined inmates can't attend court proceedings, they still can have contact with their attorneys, the Sheriff's Department said.\n\n[Byline: Alene Tchekmedyian]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nEric McDonald\n<Eric.McDonald@sdcounty.ca.gov>\n\n[It is difficult to control mumps in prisons because of crowded conditions, which brings inmates in close contact with each other. Furthermore, 'in the jail inmate population, medical histories are considered poor and inmate contact tracking is complicated. Thus, the infectious period, used to identify contacts of cases for quarantine, was defined as 5 days prior to symptom onset and 9 days following.\n\nThe General Recommendations for the prison in the situation of an outbreak are:\n- Inmates or staff with visible or reported symptoms should be immediately referred to health services.\n- An inmate with symptoms of mumps should be isolated for at least 9 days after the onset of symptoms or until infection is ruled out;\n- Staff with symptoms of mumps should be excluded from the workplace for at least 9 days from onset of symptoms or until infection is ruled out;\n- Exposed inmates should be quarantined until 25 days have passed after the last date of exposure;\n- Any staff member who had close contact with an individual diagnosed with mumps during the 7 days prior to symptom onset should not work with unexposed staff or inmates for a full 25 days.\n- Who should be vaccinated with one dose of MMR vaccine: inmates quarantined due to exposure; any staff who will work with quarantined or isolated inmates; any trustees or staff who visited a quarantined area during the probable exposure or communicable period.\n- As few personnel as possible should be assigned to cover quarantined areas.\n- If the transfer of a quarantined inmate is necessary, the inmate should be transferred alone and should immediately enter quarantine upon arrival at the new facility.\n- Exposed inmates can be released to the community but household immunizations are recommended.'\n\nReference\n---------\nRingsdorf L, Heerema B, Ruiz J, Sanchez R. Mumps: A jail outbreak and public health response. NCCHC Correct Care. 201; 24(4); https://www.ncchc.org/filebin/images/Website_PDFs/24-4.pdf\n- Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] California (San Diego County): school\nDate: Tue 29 Oct 2019 9:45 AM PST\nSource: County of San Diego Communications Office [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.countynewscenter.com/mumps-cases-reported-at-three-local-high-schools/\n\n\nThree unrelated people at 3 different high school campuses in the county recently tested positive for mumps and may have exposed others to the contagious virus, the County Health and Human Services Agency announced today [29 Oct 2019].\n\n[See source URL above for locations and dates of potential exposures to mumps]\n\nStudents, teachers, and staff who attended these schools on these dates are encouraged to be on the lookout for symptoms of mumps, which could begin to show as early as 12 days after exposure through 25 days after exposure.\n\n'We are working closely with school officials to inform the school communities about the symptoms of mumps and vaccine recommendations,' said Wilma Wooten, MD, MPH, County public health officer. 'Because there is no prevention after exposure for mumps, people should be watching for symptoms and make sure they have all the recommended doses of measles, mumps and rubella immunizations.'\n\nMumps cases increase\n--------------------\nTo date, a total of 47 mumps cases have been reported in San Diego County in 2019, the highest number in the past 25 years.\n\nIn the United States, the 2701 [2618; see https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html] mumps cases reported so far in 2019 are already greater than the 2612 cases recorded in 2018, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Over 6000 cases were reported nationally in 2016 and in 2017.\n\nIn California, 157 mumps cases have been reported this year [2019], 52 more cases than at the same time in 2018. Furthermore, according to the Mexican Ministry of Health, Baja California is also experiencing an increased number of mumps cases. Through 12 Oct 2019, a total of 654 mumps cases had been reported in the Mexican state, 292 more than the 362 mumps cases reported in 2018.\n\nWhat is mumps?\n--------------\nMumps is a highly contagious viral disease. It is spread by coughing, sneezing, or close contact with an infected person. Mumps causes a fever, headache, earache, and inflammation of the salivary glands which results in swelling and tenderness at the angle of the jaw. Anyone who thinks that they have mumps should contact their provider before going for care so proper precautions can be taken to prevent exposure to others.\n\nSevere complications are rare but can include meningitis, decreased fertility, permanent hearing loss, and, in extreme cases, fetal loss during 1st trimester of pregnancy. There is no treatment for mumps. Most people recover without problems.\n\n[Byline: Jose A Alvarez]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nThomas Christensen\n<Thomas.Christensen@sdcounty.ca.gov>\nEric McDonald\n<Eric.McDonald@sdcounty.ca.gov> and\nMary Marshall\n<mjm2020@googlemail.com>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of California, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204\nCalifornia county map: https://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/states/california/california-county-map.html]\n\n******\n[3] Pennsylvania (York County): prison\nDate: Wed 23 Oct 2019 8:18 AM EDT EST\nSource: York Daily Record [abridged, edited]\nhttps://eu.ydr.com/story/news/2019/10/22/mumps-cases-reported-york-county-prison-vaccinations-given/2450007001/\n\n\nMumps, a viral infection for which there is no treatment, has been reported at the York County Prison within the last several weeks.\n\nThe prison's medical provider works with the Pennsylvania Department of Health in treating and managing illnesses, such as mumps, chickenpox, and other infections, said Mark Walters, a spokesman for the County of York.\n\nA state Department of Health investigation started in the beginning of September [2018], according to Brittany Lauffer, a spokeswoman for the agency.\n\nThe last case that was investigated was in early October [2019], she said in an email. No additional cases have been reported since then. The prison vaccinated exposed contacts at the beginning of October, she said.\n\nThe assistance from the state should end in about 2 weeks, Walters said.\n\n[Byline: Teresa Boeckel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Pennsylvania, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/7034\nPennsylvania county map: https://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/states/pennsylvania/pennsylvania-county-map.html]\n\n******\nEurope\n---\n[4] Belgium (Brussels): university\nDate: Tue 22 Oct 2019\nSource: The Brussels Times [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.brusselstimes.com/all-news/belgium-all-news/74870/major-mumps-outbreak-on-the-uclouvain-brussels-campus/\n\n\nStudents from the UCLouvain [Catholic University of Leuven] have received an email warning of increased cases of mumps on the campus of Sint-Lambrechts-Woluwe and in the colleges in the municipality [of Brussels-Capital Region].\n\nThis information -- widely reported in Belgium -- was confirmed by the spokesperson for the University Isabelle Decoster to Belga.\n\nThe total number of infected is currently not known as students can go to doctors across the city. Sick students are asked to stay at home.\n\n[Byline: Jules Johnston]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Belgium: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/65239]", "summary": "An inmate with symptoms of mumps should be isolated for at least 9 days after the onset of symptoms or until infection is ruled out;\n- Staff with symptoms of mumps should be excluded from the workplace for at least 9 days from onset of symptoms or until infection is ruled out;\n- Exposed inmates should be quarantined until 25 days have passed after the last date of exposure;\n- Any staff member who had close contact with an individual diagnosed with mumps during the 7 days prior to symptom onset should not work with unexposed staff or inmates for a full 25 days. "2019-03-30 12:41:54", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (06): USA (PENNSYLVANIA) OUTBREAK UPDATE\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 Mar 2019\nSource: NPR [edited]\nhttp://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2019/03/28/707710860/vaccination-push-underway-to-contain-mumps-outbreak-in-philadelphia\n\n\nA mumps outbreak that began at Philadelphia's (PA) Temple University in February [2019] has snowballed, with the city's health department now reporting 106 cases associated with the flare-up. University officials say the vast majority of students involved had been immunized previously with the MMR vaccine, which protects against measles, mumps and rubella.\n\nSo why are so many still appearing on campus with the mumps' signature swollen cheeks?\n\nJames Garrow, a spokesperson for the Philadelphia Department of Public Health says, for mumps, the vaccine's power can wane over time. 'The MMR vaccine is excellent against measles and rubella. Against mumps it provides good immunity, but not excellent,' he says. 'By the time (students) get to college, their immunity is lowered.'\n\nOn Wednesday [27 Mar 2019], Temple set up a free clinic to provide students with booster shots. Mark Denys, the director of Student and Employee Health Services at Temple, says many of the 2206 people vaccinated had already received the required 2 rounds of the vaccine, but 'wanted to make sure they were covered.'\n\nHealth official are hopeful the booster, which will be offered again on Friday [29 Mar 2019], will help curtail the spread of the virus. But it could take a while.\n\n[Byline: Rebecca Ellis]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps can be prevented with the MMR vaccine, which is highly effective. This protects against 3 diseases: measles, mumps, and rubella. The CDC recommends that children get 2 doses of MMR vaccine: the 1st dose at 12-15 months of age and the 2nd dose at 4-6 years of age. However, mumps outbreaks can occur, particularly in settings where people have close prolonged contact, such as universities and close-knit communities.\n\nDuring these outbreaks, people who previously had 1 or 2 doses of MMR vaccine can get mumps as well. Experts aren't sure why vaccinated people still get mumps; it could be that their immune system didn't respond as well as it should have to the vaccine. Or their immune system's ability to fight the infection decreased over time. Disease symptoms are milder and complications are less frequent in vaccinated people. Also, high vaccination coverage helps to limit the size, duration, and spread of mumps outbreaks. So it's still very important to be up to date on the MMR vaccine (https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/vaccination.html).\n\nDuring a mumps outbreak, public health authorities might recommend an additional dose of MMR vaccine for people who belong to groups at increased risk for getting mumps. These groups are usually those who are likely to have close contact, such as sharing sport equipment or drinks, kissing, or living in close quarters, with a person who has mumps. - Mod.UBA\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nPhiladelphia, Pennsylvania, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/257]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n During a mumps outbreak, public health authorities might recommend an additional dose of MMR vaccine for people who belong to groups at increased risk for getting mumps. \n\nJames Garrow, a spokesperson for the Philadelphia Department of Public Health says, for mumps, the vaccine's power can wane over time. ' MUMPS UPDATE (06): USA (PENNSYLVANIA) OUTBREAK UPDATE\n*****************************************************\n University officials say the vast majority of students involved had been immunized previously with the MMR vaccine, which protects against measles, mumps and rubella. During these outbreaks, people who previously had 1 or 2 doses of MMR vaccine can get mumps as well. However, mumps outbreaks can occur, particularly in settings where people have close prolonged contact, such as universities and close-knit communities. Experts aren't sure why vaccinated people still get mumps; it could be that their immune system didn't respond as well as it should have to the vaccine. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps can be prevented with the MMR vaccine, which is highly effective. Mark Denys, the director of Student and Employee Health Services at Temple, says many of the 2206 people vaccinated had already received the required 2 rounds of the vaccine, but 'wanted to make sure they were covered.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "PENNSYLVANIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6148920", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (08): Malaysia (SL) Ireland (GY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6148920", "date": "2018-11-16 06:27:43", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (08): MALAYSIA (SELANGOR) IRELAND (GALWAY)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Malaysia (Rawang, Selangor state)\n[2] Ireland (Claregalway, County Galway): alert\n\n******\n[1] Malaysia (Rawang, Selangor state)\nDate: Sat 10 Nov 2018 8:57 AM MYT\nSource: New Straits Times, Malaysian National News Agency (Bernama) report [edited]\nhttps://www.nst.com.my/news/nation/2018/11/429797/rawang-school-partially-shut-amidst-mumps-outbreak\n\n\nAfter 14 students, aged between 10 and 12, came down with mumps, 6 classrooms at Sekolah Kebangsaan Bukit Sentosa in Rawang [Gombak district, Selangor] were ordered to be closed for 2 weeks. All 14 pupils received outpatient treatment at an area hospital and are reported to be in a stable condition, said Selangor health director Datuk Dr Khalid Ibrahim. The shuttered classes are now undergoing cleansing and disinfection measures to control the infection, he added.\n\nDr Khalid said mumps is caused by the _Paramyxovirus_, the symptoms of which are fever, headache, muscle pain, fatigue, loss of appetite, swelling and pain in the parotid (salivary) glands. He said it is an airborne virus which spreads through droplets of contaminated saliva or contact with contaminated objects. 'Those infected will usually take 2-3 weeks to recover,' Dr Khalid said, adding that students with mumps symptoms should avoid going to school to prevent infecting others.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Malaysia started its immunisation programme for mumps in 2002 with the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine, which reduces the risk of infection or its severity. According to health director-general, Datuk Dr Noor Hisham Abdullah, despite those infected with mumps being isolated and health education classes conducted, student mingling was allowing the virus to spread.\n\nComplications of infection can include meningitis and inflammation of the testicles, which can affect fertility in men in later life. Some patients can also experience less common complications such as inflammation of the pancreas, deafness, arthritis, and inflammation of the heart. - Mod.LK\n\nMaps of Malaysia: http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Malaysian.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39645]\n\n******\n[2] Ireland (Claregalway, County Galway): alert\nDate: Thu 15 Nov 2018 14:28 GMT\nSource: RTE Ireland [edited]\nhttps://www.rte.ie/news/connacht/2018/1115/1011103-hse-mumps/\n\n\nThe Health Service Executive [HSE] has reiterated a warning to parents in the west, following an increase in the number of cases of mumps in the region in recent weeks. Parents of students at a school in Claregalway [County Galway] have been notified that a number of children have developed mumps-like symptoms. It follows an increase in the number of cases of the condition in the area, mainly among those aged between 15 and 29.\n\nThe HSE says immunisation though the MMR vaccine provides the best protection for people, and it is urging those who have not had 2 doses of the vaccine to seek an additional dose. People who are uncertain if they have had 2 doses are also being advised to get vaccinated as soon as possible, because it can take up to 28 days for the antibodies to take effect.\n\nChildren who develop symptoms should be kept out of school for at least 5 days after the onset of neck swelling.\n\n[byline: Pat McGrath]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[About 1 month ago, 45 people were diagnosed with mumps in the western counties across Galway, Mayo, and Roscommon over a period of 7 weeks. Those affected by the viral outbreak were mainly between the ages of 15 and 29, as referred to above. (https://www.galwaydaily.com/news/hse-warns-of-mumps-outbreak-in-the-west-of-ireland/). - Mod.LK\n\nMaps of Ireland: http://smartraveller.gov.au/Countries/europe/northern/Pages/ireland.aspx#modal-country and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64659.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Pat McGrath]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[About 1 month ago, 45 people were diagnosed with mumps in the western counties across Galway, Mayo, and Roscommon over a period of 7 weeks. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Malaysia started its immunisation programme for mumps in 2002 with the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine, which reduces the risk of infection or its severity. After 14 students, aged between 10 and 12, came down with mumps, 6 classrooms at Sekolah Kebangsaan Bukit Sentosa in Rawang [Gombak district, Selangor] were ordered to be closed for 2 weeks.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Galway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "RTE Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Selangor", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6384687", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (05): Europe (UK) USA (PA) university", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6384687", "date": "2019-03-27 14:53:48", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (05): EUROPE (UK) USA (PENNSYLVANIA) UNIVERSITY\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] UK (Nottingham, England): university\n[2] USA (Philadelphia, Pennsylvania)\n\n******\n[1] UK (Nottingham, England): university\nDate: Tue 26 Mar 2019\nSource: BBC News [edited]\nhttps://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-nottinghamshire-47694563\n\n\nMore than 220 suspected cases of mumps have been reported at 2 universities, Public Health England (PHE) has said.\n\nStudents are being urged to ensure they are vaccinated due to an outbreak at Nottingham Trent University and the University of Nottingham.\n\nA total of 40 cases have been confirmed so far. PHE, which confirmed the cases, said it was working with the universities to persuade unprotected students to get the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] jab.\n\nLatest news and stories from the East Midlands Dr Vanessa MacGregor said: 'We have seen a rise in the figures recently and teenagers and young adults who have not had 2 doses of MMR vaccine are particularly vulnerable.\n\n'School leavers and other young adults who have not received the MMR or only received one dose should ensure that they take up the offer of MMR vaccination.'\n\nPHE said latest figures showed cases of mumps in England had decreased in 2018, with 1024 confirmed cases compared to 1796 in 2017.\n\nA spokesman for Nottingham Trent University said it was offering support to those affected.\n\n'If any students have any symptoms of the illness we would encourage them to visit their GP as they would do normally and inform a relevant member of staff on their course if it has an impact on their studies,' he said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of England, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14951]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Philadelphia, Pennsylvania)\nDate: Fri 22 Mar 2019 4:13 PM EDT\nSource: US News & World Report, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttps://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/pennsylvania/articles/2019-03-22/vaccine-clinics-to-be-held-at-temple-during-mumps-outbreak\n\n\nTwo vaccine clinics will be held at Philadelphia's Temple University in response to the ongoing mumps outbreak at the school that's now up to at least 93 cases.\n\nThe city's public health department said the MMR vaccine, for measles, mumps, and rubella, will be available to all Temple students, faculty and staff [27 and 29 Mar 2019] from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m.\n\nThe city says the numbers reported are high compared with those in past years; 54 cases were reported in 2010.\n\nMumps is a viral infection that involves swollen glands. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention say the MMR vaccine is the best protection.\n\nMumps vaccine has been part of routine childhood shots for decades, but research suggests that protection fades 10 or more years after the 2nd dose.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Pennsylvania, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/257\n\n[Improving the immunity status of the exposed populations can serve as an important control strategy. - Mod.UBA]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Pennsylvania, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/257\n\n[Improving the immunity status of the exposed populations can serve as an important control strategy. [2] USA (Philadelphia, Pennsylvania)\n\n******\n \n\nMumps vaccine has been part of routine childhood shots for decades, but research suggests that protection fades 10 or more years after the 2nd dose.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-03-25 00:00:00", "1024-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "1796-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6487675", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (08): USA (CO, TX), Asia (Malaysia)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6487675", "date": "2019-05-26 10:18:06", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (08): USA (COLORADO, TEXAS), ASIA (MALAYSIA)\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Colorado (Arapahoe Basin)\n[2] Texas (Hidalgo County)\nAsia\n---\n[3] Malaysia (Terengganu)\n\n******\n[1] Colorado (Arapahoe Basin)\nAt A-Basin Ski Area\nDate: Fri 24 May 2019\nSource: CBS Local [abridged, edited]\nhttps://denver.cbslocal.com/2019/05/24/mumps-summit-county-arapahoe-basin-ski-area/\n\n\nSummit County Public Health investigators are looking into a cluster of 6 confirmed mumps virus cases. The cases are all associated with people at Arapahoe Basin Ski Area.\n\nInvestigators are broadening their surveillance area for the possibility of more mumps cases. The confirmed cases are all employees or people associated with those employees. There are no known skiers or boarders confirmed in the mumps cases.\n\n[Byline: Matt Kroschel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Texas (Hidalgo County)\nDate: Fri 24 May 2019\nSource: Progress Times [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.progresstimes.net/news/local-news/12940-mumps-cases-found-in-every-major-hidalgo-county-city.html\n\n\nA massive education campaign led by the county health department aims to increase awareness and prevention of mumps, a contagious disease caused by a virus that is currently present in the Rio Grande Valley.\n\nLast week, a case of mumps was found at Bryan Elementary School, which is part of the Mission Consolidated Independent School District. When the discovery was made at the campus, students were sent home with a letter detailing how the district was handling the sanitation of the school, and phone calls were made that same evening.\n\nIn the letter, information on how the virus is spread, symptoms of the mumps and vaccination details were all highlighted. It also encouraged families to keep sick children out of school.\n\nAccording to Hidalgo County Health and Human Services Director Eduardo Olivarez, keeping the public informed in this way is one of the ways to keep the virus contained.\n\n'Of all the cases [in the county], over half of them are between 20 and 30 years old, which is odd,' Olivarez said. 'We're talking with the CDC [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention] and the Department of State Health Services, and we can't figure it out. It's not a new strain or a wild strain; it's genotype G, for general mumps. Across the country, it's all the same age group, so we don't think it was a bad lot of vaccines because it's so spread out.'\n\nAs of Monday [20 May 2019] morning, 46 confirmed cases of the mumps have been diagnosed in Hidalgo County since the end of March/beginning of April 2019.\n\n'Confirmation is done by a combination of laboratory testing and physical symptoms identified by a physician,' Olivarez said. 'We have reported cases in pretty much every major community in Hidalgo County, so this is no longer in just a concentrated area.'\n\nThere are cases in Mission, McAllen, Pharr, Weslaco, San Juan and Edinburg.\n\n'The good thing is of those 46 cases, probably less than 8 as of printing may still be contagious, but all the other cases are no longer contagious,' Olivarez said. 'But they're isolated; they are staying home from work or school.'\n\nOlivarez said that currently, there are 10 pending cases that the county is still waiting to hear results from. He brought up the R0 (pronounced 'R naught') measurement, which is the number of people one sick person will infect.\n\nThe R0 for mumps states that for every person who contracts the virus, 10 more will be infected. The value for hepatitis C and Ebola is 2, for HIV and SARS, 4, and measles is 18.\n\n'I'm expecting a 3rd wave, which is probably going to be right about now,' Olivarez said. 'Towards the end of this month [May 2019], I'm expecting more cases to come up just because of exposure. I'm expecting another one at the end of June 2019.'\n\nOlivarez said the high vaccination rate in the county has prevented the virus from spreading faster and kept it more contained. 46 cases out of over an estimated one million people is less than .01 percent.\n\n'We have an average vaccination rate [ages 6 to 19 in Hidalgo County] of 85 to 90 percent vaccinated,' Olivarez said. 'That's a high number, and it's been like that for several years.'\n\nThe department also stressed that the current spread of the virus has not come from any immigration issues in Hidalgo County. They have been in weekly contact with Customs and Border Patrol, who have seen one outbreak in a Cameron County detention facility but none in Hidalgo.\n\n'I average 2-3 mumps cases every year, usually found in children,' Olivarez said. 'This is the 1st time we have had a public outbreak in many years, probably over 15, 20 years.'\n\nThe mumps outbreak will be considered finished after the county goes 42 days without a case.\n\n[Byline: Jamie Trevino]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The report notes that over half of the cases are between 20 and 30 years old. It has been noted that mumps resurgence in young adults is likely due to waning vaccine-derived immunity. See https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/03/180321141401.htm; Date: 21 Mar 2018; Source: Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health:\n\nSummary:\nA resurgence of mumps in the US among vaccinated young adults appears to be due to waning of vaccine-induced immunity, according to a recent analysis. Researchers found vaccine-derived immune protection against mumps lasts about 27 years after the last dose. The findings suggest that, in addition to the currently recommended 2 doses of mumps vaccine in childhood, a 3rd dose at age 18 may help sustain protection.\n\nCitation. Lewnard JA and Grad YH. Vaccine waning and mumps re-emergence in the United States. Sci Transl Med. 2018 Mar 21; 10(433): eaao5945. doi:10.1126/scitranslmed.aao5945.\n\nAbstract.\n'Following decades of declining mumps incidence amid widespread vaccination, the United States and other developed countries have experienced a resurgence in mumps cases over the last decade. Outbreaks affecting vaccinated individuals and communities with high vaccine coverage have prompted concerns about the effectiveness of the live attenuated vaccine currently in use. It is unclear if immune protection wanes, or if the vaccine protects inadequately against currently circulating mumps virus lineages. Synthesizing data from 6 studies of mumps vaccine effectiveness, we estimated that vaccine-derived immune protection against mumps wanes on average 27 (95% confidence interval: 16 to 51) years post-vaccination. After accounting for this waning, we found no evidence that the emergence of heterologous virus genotypes contributed to changes in vaccine effectiveness over time. A mathematical model of mumps transmission confirmed the central role of waning immunity to the vaccine in the re-emergence of mumps cases. Outbreaks from 2006 to the present among young adults, and outbreaks in the late 1980s and early 1990s among adolescents, aligned with peaks in mumps susceptibility of these age groups predicted to be due to loss of vaccine-derived protection. In contrast, evolution of mumps virus strains escaping immune pressure would be expected to cause a higher proportion of cases among children, not adolescents and young adults as observed. Routine use of a 3rd vaccine dose at age 18 years, or booster dosing throughout adulthood, may be a strategy to prevent mumps re-emergence and should be assessed in clinical trials.' - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Malaysia (Terengganu)\nDate: Tue 14 May 2019\nSource: Rojak Daily [abridged, edited]\nhttp://www.rojakdaily.com/news/article/6813/mumps-cases-on-the-rise-in-terengganu-182-recorded-in-just-one-week\n\n\nThe spread of mumps in Terengganu has recorded an alarming increase to 182 cases as of Sun [12 May 2019], compared to only 114 cases earlier this month [May 2019], Astro Awani reported.\n\nTerengganu health director Dr Mohd Jusoh told the news portal that the increase of 68 cases within a span of 2 weeks involved a full boarding school in Kuala Terengganu. He also said that to date, 85 students from the school were infected with mumps, some of whom have recovered. An entire boarding school was infected.\n\nThese students, according to Dr Mohd Jusoh, are quarantined at their homes, as their schools do not have proper quarantine facilities. He added that quarantined students must be closely monitored by parents or guardians, so that they do not go out to public places such as Ramadan bazaars or shopping malls.\n\nMeanwhile, Terengganu Education Department director Shafruddin Ali Hussein told Bernama that his department has been working closely with the state Health Department to stop the spread of the disease.\n\nKnown as 'beguk' in Malay, mumps is a viral infection that primarily affects salivary glands. According to Mayo clinic, people infected with mumps either show no symptoms or very mild ones. However, when symptoms develop, they usually appear about 2-3 weeks after exposure to the virus.\n\n[Byline: RD Minion]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nMalaysia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/147]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Synthesizing data from 6 studies of mumps vaccine effectiveness, we estimated that vaccine-derived immune protection against mumps wanes on average 27 (95% confidence interval: 16 to 51) years post-vaccination. \n\nAs of Monday [20 May 2019] morning, 46 confirmed cases of the mumps have been diagnosed in Hidalgo County since the end of March/beginning of April 2019. \n\n'I average 2-3 mumps cases every year, usually found in children,' Olivarez said. ' In this update:\nUSA\n---\n A mathematical model of mumps transmission confirmed the central role of waning immunity to the vaccine in the re-emergence of mumps cases. \n\n[\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nMalaysia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/147] The spread of mumps in Terengganu has recorded an alarming increase to 182 cases as of Sun [12 May 2019], compared to only 114 cases earlier this month [May 2019], Astro Awani reported. MUMPS UPDATE (08): USA (COLORADO, TEXAS), ASIA (MALAYSIA)\n*********************************************************\n \n\n'The good thing is of those 46 cases, probably less than 8 as of printing may still be contagious, but all the other cases are no longer contagious,' Olivarez said. ' Following decades of declining mumps incidence amid widespread vaccination, the United States and other developed countries have experienced a resurgence in mumps cases over the last decade. \n\nInvestigators are broadening their surveillance area for the possibility of more mumps cases. \n\n'Of all the cases [in the county], over half of them are between 20 and 30 years old, which is odd,' Olivarez said. Chan School of Public Health:\n\nSummary:\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org> \n\nOlivarez said that currently, there are 10 pending cases that the county is still waiting to hear results from. \n\nThe mumps outbreak will be considered finished after the county goes 42 days without a case. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The report notes that over half of the cases are between 20 and 30 years old.
