Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< [3] Malaysia (Terengganu)\n\n******\n \n\nOlivarez said the high vaccination rate in the county has prevented the virus from spreading faster and kept it more contained. Asia\n---\n [Byline: Matt Kroschel]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis c", "measles", "mumps", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-05-20 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2019-04-25 00:00:00", "2019-05-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hidalgo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kuala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hidalgo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Weslaco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Juan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mission", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cameron County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6379783", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (04): USA (PA) outbreak", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6379783", "date": "2019-03-21 18:47:55", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (04): USA (PHILADELPHIA) OUTBREAK\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Philadelphia [St. Joseph's] University outbreak\nDate: Wed 20 Mar 2019\nSource: The Hawk Newspaper [edited]\nhttp://www.sjuhawknews.com/?p=12140\n\n\nSt. Joe's Student Health Center and the Philadelphia Department of Public Health have advised students on campus to take precautionary measures after an outbreak of mumps at nearby Temple University.\n\nAt the end of last month [February 2019], right before the school's spring break, Temple released a statement that there were 4 confirmed cases of mumps on campus. As of [18 Mar 2019], there have been 54 cases of mumps at Temple -- 12 confirmed and 42 probable --, according to the Philadelphia Department of Public Health.\n\nAlthough mumps cases were rare in the years following the introduction of the Mumps, Measles and Rubella (MMR) vaccine in 1971, a resurgence of outbreaks has occurred in recent years among vaccinated individuals. Many of those 54 people at Temple had the MMR vaccine. According to the Center for Disease Control (CDC), experts do not know exactly why vaccinated individuals still contract mumps. They suspect it could have to do with the number of doses and the immune system not responding properly to the vaccine.\n\nDana Perella, program manager for the Acute Communicable Disease Program at the Philadelphia Department of Public Health, said even though someone may have the MMR vaccine, cases can still occur years after vaccination, and the disease appears frequently on college campuses. 'Mumps outbreaks can still occur, and in recent years, have been reported in settings like universities, where individuals have close, prolonged contact,' Perella said.\n\nAlthough contracting mumps is possible even with vaccination, symptoms are not as severe or life-threatening if vaccinated. Those symptoms include fever, painful, swollen salivary glands and pain while chewing or swallowing. There is currently no treatment for mumps, but the immune systems of vaccinated individuals can fight off the virus in several days.\n\nNene Okunna, Ph.D., assistant professor of interdisciplinary health services and public health specialist, said the outbreak is a public health issue resulting from people not vaccinating their children out of fear that vaccinations cause autism -- a connection that has been repeatedly disproved. 'The problem is if people don't get vaccinated, then these diseases are spread across campus,' Okunna said. 'This is a problem particularly on university campuses because we have a lot of people on one campus. That's why it's so concerning what we are seeing at Temple.'\n\nSt. Joe's requires all incoming freshman and transfer students to have 2 doses of the MMR vaccine, as well as 2 varicella, 4 polio and 4 tetanus/diphtheria/ pertussis with a booster within the past 10 years, according to Eileen Bevilacqua, director of the Student Health Center.\n\nThis is not the case at all universities. Some schools recommend rather than require vaccinations. Until the mumps outbreak, this was the case at Temple. 'Temple did not have requirements for vaccine records other than meningitis, which is a federal law if a student lives in campus housing,' Bevilacqua said. 'On their website, they state they will now require proof of MMR, varicella and tetanus/ diphtheria/ pertussis of all incoming students.'\n\nEven though all St. Joe's students are required to have the MMR vaccine, Bevilacqua and the Philadelphia Department of Public Health still advise students to take precautionary measures, such as washing their hands, not sharing utensils and staying away from infected individuals for 5 days. 'The SHC [Student Health Center] constantly discusses with students infection control measures such as washing your hands, coughing and sneezing into your sleeve and frequently wiping down surfaces that are touched regularly with a disinfectant wipe,' Bevilacqua said.\n\n[Byline: Alysa Bainbridge]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Ship outbreak\nDate: Tue 19 Mar 2019\nSource: CNN [edited]\nhttps://edition.cnn.com/2019/03/19/politics/new-virus-case-us-warship/index.html\n\n\nA new case of a viral infection aboard a US navy warship was reported [Tue 19 Mar 2019], which means the USS Fort McHenry will continued to be quarantined at sea in the Middle East, according to the US Navy 5th Fleet.\n\nThe new case means 26 sailors and Marines have fallen ill on board since December [2018]. The Navy said it is awaiting findings from a medical team before deciding when the ship can be deemed safe to pull into a port.\n\nLast week CNN reported that the Fort McHenry had essentially been quarantined at sea for over 2 months and has been unable to make a port call due the outbreak of the mumps-like virus. The 26 sailors and Marines aboard the amphibious warship have been diagnosed with parotitis, which causes symptoms similar to mumps, according to US military officials.\n\nUntil CNN asked about the incident, the US military had not disclosed it. 'None of the cases are life-threatening and all have either already made or are expected to make a full recovery,' the 5th Fleet said in a statement provided to CNN last week.\n\nAll 703 military personnel aboard the ship have received measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) booster vaccinations, according to the US Navy's 5th Fleet headquartered in Bahrain.\n\nThe ship is currently operating in the Persian Gulf region and military medical officials are assessing when it may be deemed medically safe to make a port call.\n\nA US military official told CNN that when there are major disease outbreaks, a decision may be taken to halt port visits until 30 days after the last reported illness due to varying incubation periods. But the Fort McHenry did make a port call in early January in Romania when it was in the Black Sea before traveling back through the Mediterranean and into the Middle East.\n\nAfter they became ill, the patients were quarantined and treated in the ship's medical facility. Living and work spaces were disinfected. None of the personnel had to be medivac'd off the ship and all are expected to make a full recovery. The ship, which carries Marines to perform amphibious warfare duties, did have some of its scheduled training modified to deal with the outbreak's impact.\n\n[Byline: Barbara Starr]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] History of mumps and other vaccines\nDate: Wed 20 Mar 2019\nSource: STAT News [edited]\nhttps://www.statnews.com/2019/03/20/mumps-greg-cant-play-photo/?utm_source=STAT+Newsletters&utm_campaign=6e09894eb8-Daily_Recap&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_8cab1d7961-6e09894eb8-149684921\n\n\nIt was 1957 and Greg Cox, 7 years old, was at home in Altamont, Ill., a compress wrapped from chin to hairline. He was gazing wistfully out the window of the family's kitchen door at his younger brother, Doug, bundled up outdoors and ready to play. A sign was tacked to the door. 'Greg can't play,' it said. 'MUMPS.'\n\nThis was a decade before the start of the U.S. mumps vaccination program, and about 15 years before the combined vaccine for measles, mumps, and rubella -- MMR -- was licensed in the U.S. In the early 1960s, hundreds of thousands of American children a year contracted those diseases. [...-more]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[A resurgence of mumps in the US among vaccinated young adults as seen in the above report [1] appears to be due to waning of vaccine-induced immunity, according to a recent analysis. Researchers found vaccine-derived immune protection against mumps lasts about 27 years after the last dose. The findings suggest that, in addition to the currently recommended 2 doses of mumps vaccine in childhood, a 3rd dose at age 18 may help sustain protection among adults. The study [was] published 21 Mar 2018, in Science Translational Medicine [full article is available at http://stm.sciencemag.org/content/10/433/eaao5945].\n\nEarlier last year [2018] the MMWR published recommendations for a 3rd dose of mumps vaccine for those at particular risk of infection [reference below: subsequent numbered references can be found along with the full report at the URL below]: 'A substantial increase in the number of mumps outbreaks and outbreak-associated cases has occurred in the United States since late 2015 (Lewnard JA and Grad YH. Vaccine waning and mumps re-emergence in the United States. Sci Transl Med. 2018; 10(433). pii: eaao5945. doi: 10.1126/scitranslmed.aao5945; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29563321). To address this public health problem, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) reviewed the available evidence and determined that a 3rd dose of measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine is safe and effective at preventing mumps. During its October 2017 meeting, ACIP recommended a 3rd dose of a mumps virus-containing vaccine for persons previously vaccinated with 2 doses who are identified by public health authorities as being part of a group or population at increased risk for acquiring mumps because of an outbreak. The purpose of the recommendation is to improve protection of persons in outbreak settings against mumps disease and mumps-related complications. This recommendation supplements the existing ACIP recommendations for mumps vaccination.'(Marin M, Marlow M, Moore KL and Patel M. Recommendation of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices for use of a third dose of mumps virus-containing vaccine in persons at increased risk for mumps during an outbreak. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2018; 67(1): 33-8. doi: 10.15585/mmwr.mm6701a7. Available at https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/67/wr/mm6701a7.htm.). - Mod.UBA\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nPhiladelphia, Pennsylvania, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/257]", "summary": "[...-more]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[A resurgence of mumps in the US among vaccinated young adults as seen in the above report [1] appears to be due to waning of vaccine-induced immunity, according to a recent analysis. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Philadelphia [St. Joseph's] University outbreak\n \n\nEarlier last year [2018] the MMWR published recommendations for a 3rd dose of mumps vaccine for those at particular risk of infection [reference below: subsequent numbered references can be found along with the full report at the URL below]: 'A substantial increase in the number of mumps outbreaks and outbreak-associated cases has occurred in the United States since late 2015 (Lewnard JA and Grad YH. During its October 2017 meeting, ACIP recommended a 3rd dose of a mumps virus-containing vaccine for persons previously vaccinated with 2 doses who are identified by public health authorities as being part of a group or population at increased risk for acquiring mumps because of an outbreak. \n\nThis was a decade before the start of the U.S. mumps vaccination program, and about 15 years before the combined vaccine for measles, mumps, and rubella -- MMR -- was licensed in the U.S. Although mumps cases were rare in the years following the introduction of the Mumps, Measles and Rubella (MMR) vaccine in 1971, a resurgence of outbreaks has occurred in recent years among vaccinated individuals. To address this public health problem, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) reviewed the available evidence and determined that a 3rd dose of measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine is safe and effective at preventing mumps. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\nSt. Joe's requires all incoming freshman and transfer students to have 2 doses of the MMR vaccine, as well as 2 varicella, 4 polio and 4 tetanus/diphtheria/ pertussis with a booster within the past 10 years, according to Eileen Bevilacqua, director of the Student Health Center. M, Marlow M, Moore KL and Patel M. Recommendation of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices for use of a third dose of mumps virus-containing vaccine in persons at increased risk for mumps during an outbreak. \n\nNene Okunna, Ph.D., assistant professor of interdisciplinary health services and public health specialist, said the outbreak is a public health issue resulting from people not vaccinating their children out of fear that vaccinations cause autism -- a connection that has been repeatedly disproved. ' \n\nDana Perella, program manager for the Acute Communicable Disease Program at the Philadelphia Department of Public Health, said even though someone may have the MMR vaccine, cases can still occur years after vaccination, and the disease appears frequently on college campuses. ' \n\nLast week CNN reported that the Fort McHenry had essentially been quarantined at sea for over 2 months and has been unable to make a port call due the outbreak of the mumps-like virus. MUMPS UPDATE (04): USA (PHILADELPHIA) OUTBREAK\n**********************************************\n \n\n[Byline: Alysa Bainbridge]\n\n--\n \n\nEven though all St. Joe's students are required to have the MMR vaccine, Bevilacqua and the Philadelphia Department of Public Health still advise students to take precautionary measures, such as washing their hands, not sharing utensils and staying away from infected individuals for 5 days. ' The purpose of the recommendation is to improve protection of persons in outbreak settings against mumps disease and mumps-related complications. The findings suggest that, in addition to the currently recommended 2 doses of mumps vaccine in childhood, a 3rd dose at age 18 may help sustain protection among adults. As of [18 Mar 2019], there have been 54 cases of mumps at Temple -- 12 confirmed and 42 probable --, according to the Philadelphia Department of Public Health. \n\nAlthough contracting mumps is possible even with vaccination, symptoms are not as severe or life-threatening if vaccinated. \n\n\nSt. Joe's Student Health Center and the Philadelphia Department of Public Health have advised students on campus to take precautionary measures after an outbreak of mumps at nearby Temple University. Mumps outbreaks can still occur, and in recent years, have been reported in settings like universities, where individuals have close, prolonged contact,' Perella said. Researchers found vaccine-derived immune protection against mumps lasts about 27 years after the last dose. All 703 military personnel aboard the ship have received measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) booster vaccinations, according to the US Navy's 5th Fleet headquartered in Bahrain. \n\nA US military official told CNN that when there are major disease outbreaks, a decision may be taken to halt port visits until 30 days after the last reported illness due to varying incubation periods.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "pertussis", "rubella", "varicella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-12-25 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-10-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "1971-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "PHILADELPHIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bahrain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Altamont", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ill.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "St. Joe 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6110666", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (07): USA (CO) Marshallese community, 2016-2017", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6110666", "date": "2018-10-25 13:37:27", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (07): USA (COLORADO) MARSHALLESE COMMUNITY, 2016-2017\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 23 Oct 2018\nSource: Contagion Live [edited]\nhttps://www.contagionlive.com/news/colorado-mumps-outbreak-emphasizes-importance-of-community-partnerships-in-response-efforts\n\n\nIn January of 2017, the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) was made aware of 4 cases of mumps that were epidemiologically linked among individuals who were members of the same church in the Denver Metropolitan area.\n\nThe outbreak was observed in a Marshallese community, or in a population of people with ties to the Marshall Islands. The outbreak response is detailed in the US Center for Disease Control and Prevention's (CDC) latest Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report [see reference below].\n\n'Response to this mumps outbreak in a Colorado Marshallese community was facilitated by building relationships with church leaders, leading to early active surveillance, public education, and mumps, measles, and rubella (MMR) vaccination clinics,' the authors write in the report. 'These interventions might have contributed to the rapid interruption of transmission and limited spread of mumps to other local communities.'\n\nThe cases were first identified as being linked to the church on 19 Jan 2017, when patient interviews indicated that all of the ill individuals had attended events at the church. Local health departments worked in collaboration to launch an outbreak investigation immediately.\n\nHealth officials met with leaders of the church to implement active surveillance measures upon learning that facial swelling -- a symptom linked to mumps -- was circulating though members of the church community. The church leaders provided health officials with addresses and phone numbers of church members to inquire about vaccination history, occurrence and timing of symptoms, travel history, household visitors, and church attendance.\n\nIn total, church leaders provided a list of 21 members to officials, and a total of 17 members -- representing 15 households -- were responsive. The total number of individuals living in the 15 households was 117.\n\nHealth officials conducted interviews with the head of household and received information about 76 individuals. Among the 76, 22 individuals reported attending at least one other event at an additional Marshallese church. Additionally, 3 households reported visitors from Arkansas where a concurrent outbreak was occurring in the Marshallese population, including one visitor who reported a swollen jaw at the time of visit.\n\nIn total, there were 47 outbreak cases -- 17 confirmed and 30 probable -- across 2 counties in the Denver Metropolitan area. A probable outbreak case was defined as the occurrence of mumps-compatible symptoms on or after 1 Nov 2016, and an epidemiologic link to the Marshallese community. A confirmed case was defined as identification by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction or culture in an individual with a probable case.\n\nAmong ill individuals, 24 were male (51%), the median age was 20 years, and onset of illness ranged from 1 Nov 2016, to 28 Mar 2017. 46 cases (98%) occurred in Marshallese persons.\n\nReported symptoms included parotitis in 47% of individuals, bilateral swelling (22%), jaw pain (74%), malaise (62%), fever (57%), and submandibular swelling (47%).\n\nThe authors indicate a challenge was faced in determining MMR vaccination status in the patients. None of the confirmed case patients were able to provide personal vaccination records and 34 of 47 patients did not have doses recorded in the Colorado Immunization Information System.\n\nAs part of the outbreak response, health officials met with community leaders who disseminated information about mumps to prevent further transmission. As a result, vaccination clinics were held during the 5 weeks following outbreak identification with the goal of vaccinating all eligible individuals in the area. In total, 164 MMR doses were administered to 126 church attendees.\n\nThe outbreak was declared over on 17 May 2017, following 50 days or 2 incubation periods after the last reported case. No serious complications or deaths associated with the outbreak were reported.\n\nThe authors listed 3 distinct limitations of the findings. First, vaccination status was determined by information recorded in the Colorado Immunization registry, which likely did not consist of all of the affected individuals' vaccination records due to the highly mobile population in this area.\n\nLanguage and cultural barriers may have led to the collection of incorrect information despite the use of interpreters and translated documents. Also, there was uncertainty regarding living arrangements which made the identification of household members a challenge and may have resulted in incorrect estimations of household size.\n\nOverall, the ability to stop the spread of the outbreak by working with community leaders emphasizes the importance of using community partnerships in outbreak situations.\n\n[Byline: Michaela Fleming]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Reference\n---------\nMarx GE, Burakoff A, Barnes M, et al. Mumps outbreak in a Marshallese community -- Denver Metropolitan Area, Colorado, 2016-2017. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2018; 67(41): 1143-1146.; available at https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/67/wr/pdfs/mm6741a2-H.pdf\n\nThe public health response was very thorough and multifaceted, including active surveillance to identify individuals at risk, follow-up immunization with MMR vaccine, and public education. This approach was very effective. - Mod.LK]\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nDenver, Colorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1925]", "summary": "\n\nHealth officials met with leaders of the church to implement active surveillance measures upon learning that facial swelling -- a symptom linked to mumps -- was circulating though members of the church community. \n\n'Response to this mumps outbreak in a Colorado Marshallese community was facilitated by building relationships with church leaders, leading to early active surveillance, public education, and mumps, measles, and rubella (MMR) vaccination clinics,' the authors write in the report. ' A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The church leaders provided health officials with addresses and phone numbers of church members to inquire about vaccination history, occurrence and timing of symptoms, travel history, household visitors, and church attendance. \n\nIn total, there were 47 outbreak cases -- 17 confirmed and 30 probable -- across 2 counties in the Denver Metropolitan area. \n\nThe cases were first identified as being linked to the church on 19 Jan 2017, when patient interviews indicated that all of the ill individuals had attended events at the church. In total, church leaders provided a list of 21 members to officials, and a total of 17 members -- representing 15 households -- were responsive. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Reference\n \n\nReported symptoms included parotitis in 47% of individuals, bilateral swelling (22%), jaw pain (74%), malaise (62%), fever (57%), and submandibular swelling (47%). \n\nThe outbreak was declared over on 17 May 2017, following 50 days or 2 incubation periods after the last reported case. In January of 2017, the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) was made aware of 4 cases of mumps that were epidemiologically linked among individuals who were members of the same church in the Denver Metropolitan area. ; available at https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/67/wr/pdfs/mm6741a2-H.pdf\n\nThe public health response was very thorough and multifaceted, including active surveillance to identify individuals at risk, follow-up immunization with MMR vaccine, and public education. Overall, the ability to stop the spread of the outbreak by working with community leaders emphasizes the importance of using community partnerships in outbreak situations. As part of the outbreak response, health officials met with community leaders who disseminated information about mumps to prevent further transmission. MUMPS UPDATE (07): USA (COLORADO) MARSHALLESE COMMUNITY, 2016-2017\n******************************************************************\n A probable outbreak case was defined as the occurrence of mumps-compatible symptoms on or after 1 Nov 2016, and an epidemiologic link to the Marshallese community.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1976-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-01-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-05-17 00:00:00", "2017-01-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Marshall Islands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver Metropolitan Area", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver Metropolitan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6329434", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (02): USA (CO, TX), Europe (Ireland)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6329434", "date": "2019-02-21 16:07:02", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (02): USA (COLORADO, TEXAS), EUROPE (IRELAND)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Colorado (Aurora): ICE facility\n[2] Texas (Houston): ICE facility\n\nEurope\n---\n[3] Ireland\n\n******\n[1] Colorado (Aurora): ICE facility\nDate: Wed 20 Feb 2019, 3:44 PM\nSource: CBS [edited]\nhttps://denver.cbslocal.com/2019/02/20/jason-crow-ice-immigration-chicken-pox-aurora/\n\n\nMumps have been confirmed at the ICE facility in Aurora. Congressman Jason Crow wants to hear from the Department of Homeland Security about the situation with mumps, reported chicken pox and facility expansion at the Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility.\n\nICE responded to the mumps case with this statement, 'With the recent influx of migrants coming from the southern border, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has confirmed 1 new case of parotitis, mumps, at our Denver Contract Detention Facility. Medical personnel are credited with reducing the further infection of detainees by their quick reaction to quarantine everyone who may have been inadvertently exposed to stop the spread of the disease. Each detainee receives a medical examination upon arrival at the facility to check for potential signs of illness, however ICE has no way of knowing what viruses a person may have been exposed to prior to entering the facility. Mumps is highly contagious, easily contracted by nearby people and difficult to detect until symptoms appear. ICE and the medical professionals employed by GEO took the necessary steps to quickly isolate the exposed detainees, provide proper medical care and prevent further spread of the disease. Preventative steps included education, early recognition, and following the guidelines established by the CDC and Immigration Health Services Corps (IHSC). We strive to ensure people in our care are treated with compassion and we work to get them back to health as quickly as possible while mitigating the spread of this and all diseases.'\n\nA private contractor runs the facility on Oakland Street. Crow, a Democrat representing Aurora and Adams County, contends the facility has been remodeled to increase the number of detainees by several hundred.\n\nIn particular, Crow is concerned about reports of chicken pox outbreaks. 'There are workers, people and family members who are coming and going from this facility into our community- every day and if there are continued outbreaks we are very concerned about that from a public health and safety perspective,' said Crow during a visit to the facility on [Wed 20 Feb 2019].\n\nRA's brother is one of those being detained in the suddenly expanding facility. He wants to see his brother who is inside. Through his brother's attorney RA said, 'He is concerned about people from the border not sure how they are treating them here, if they are putting them in isolation.'\n\nAs many as 432 new beds have been put in place at the old ICE facility next door. Crow says he wants to know if the staff to oversee the detainees has been increased and if the backlog in processing detainees is the reason for the increase.\n\n'This was unannounced; the City of Aurora didn't know about the expansion of this facility. I, as the congressman who represents this district, didn't know about it.'\n\nCrow and Aurora City Councilwoman Allison Hiltz said it was important to know what is going on inside the federally supervised facility for health and safety reasons. They were turned away when they asked for a tour. ICE said that is done by appointment only.\n\nCrow says he expects it will take several days to get a response to his letter.\n\nCBS4 asked Sarah Jackson what she had heard. Her organization Casa de Paz has volunteers inside regularly to visit inmates. 'The person that they were to visit was quarantined because someone in their pod had chicken pox,' said Jackson. She says that means they can't meet lawyers or even leave the facility if they have won their cases.\n\nRA told us through his brother's attorney, Eric Martinson, that conditions are bad. 'My client said for the last 3 days had air conditioning on like penguins, shivering without enough blankets or clothes to stay warm.'\n\nICE wrote, 'ICE is committed to ensuring that everyone in our custody receives timely access to medical services and treatment. Comprehensive medical care is provided from the moment detainees arrive and throughout the entirety of their stay. All ICE detainees receive medical, dental and mental health intake screening within 12 hours of arriving at each detention facility, a full health assessment within 14 days of entering ICE custody or arrival at a facility, and access to daily sick call and 24-hour emergency care. Pursuant to our commitment to the welfare of those in the agency's custody, ICE spends more than USD 250M annually on the spectrum of healthcare services provided to detainees.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kudos to Congressman Jason Crow for looking into this deplorable situation. Apparently medical services do not include vaccination for highly infectious vaccine preventable diseases. Also see ProMED-mail Varicella update (02) on the varicella outbreak in the same ICE facility. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Texas (Houston): ICE facility\nDate: Sun 10 Feb 2019, 6:28 AM CST\nSource: KXAN [edited]\nhttps://www.kxan.com/news/texas/mumps-confirmed-in-7-detainees-at-houston-ice-facility/1769557822\n\n\nHealth officials say 7 cases of the mumps have been confirmed at a U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement detention facility in Houston. The Houston Health Department said on [Sat 9 Feb 2019] that the 7 adults were detained during their infectious period. Health officials say there's no evidence the disease was transmitted outside the facility. The health department is working with the facility on infection control.\n\nMumps is contagious and spreads through coughing and sneezing. Common symptoms are fever, headache, and painfully swollen salivary glands that can cause puffy cheeks. Most people recover within weeks. Outbreaks are rare but have happened in Texas and the Houston region.\n\nThe mumps vaccine is part of routine childhood shots. U.S. health officials recommend that by age 6, all children get vaccinated for mumps, measles and rubella.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nLaurence M Denis\n<Lmsdenis@gmail.com>\n\n[This is yet another ICE facility with a vaccine-preventable disease causing health problems for the detainees as well as potentially the staff of the facility. Are the unvaccinated staff being quarantined after exposure, as are the detainees? - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Ireland\nDate: Tue 12 Feb 2019, 5:30 AM\nSource: Irish Examiner [edited]\nhttps://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/84-increase-in-mumps-cases-reported-to-hpsc-903780.html\n\n\nThere has been an 84% increase in the number of cases of mumps reported to the Health Protection Surveillance Centre in recent weeks.\n\nOver the 1st 5 weeks of this year [2019], the number of cases has increased to 231, compared to just 36 over the same period last year [2018], an increase of 195. There were 50 cases of the highly infectious disease reported over the week ending [Sat 2 Feb 2019].\n\nMMR uptake rates among children in Ireland remain below the target of 95% needed to prevent the spread of mumps, according to the HPSC.\n\nLast week [4-10 Feb 2019], the HSE alerted Trinity College Dublin that there had been cases of mumps in the university and other students might have been exposed.\n\n[Byline: Evelyn Ring]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in cases is likely the result of growing vaccine hesitancy, similar to the situation with measles, which is part of the same MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) vaccine. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nColorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209\nTexas, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245\nIreland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in cases is likely the result of growing vaccine hesitancy, similar to the situation with measles, which is part of the same MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) vaccine. [1] Colorado (Aurora): ICE facility\n [1] Colorado (Aurora): ICE facility\n [2] Texas (Houston): ICE facility\n \n\n--\n [Byline: Evelyn Ring]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella", "varicella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-02-12 00:00:00", "2019-02-20 00:00:00", "2004-02-10 20:19:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2019-02-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Aurora City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States : http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Houston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Adams County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6307434", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (01): USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6307434", "date": "2019-02-10 11:38:03", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (01): USA\n**********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA summary: 2019\n[2] Texas (Laredo): 2018\n\n******\n[1] USA summary: 2019\nDate: Wed 6 Feb 2019\nSource: Precision Vaccinations [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.precisionvaccinations.com/mumps-cases-reported-georgia-north-dakota-pennsylvania-utah-and-wisconsin-during-2019\n\n\n\nWith most of the media focused on the ongoing measles outbreaks around the world, another vaccine-preventable, infectious disease has reached 5 [US] states during 2019.\n\nAs of 6 Feb 2019, the states of Georgia, North Dakota, Pennsylvania, Utah, and Wisconsin have reported mumps cases during 2019.\n\nThese state-based news reports have yet to be confirmed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), who has not yet issued a mumps outbreak report for 2019.\n\nDuring, 2018, the CDC did confirm 2251 mumps cases in 47 states and the District of Columbia. Additionally, several colleges reported on-campus mumps outbreaks.\n\nThe 2018 data were actually good news when compared to 2017 when over 6000 mumps cases were confirmed by the CDC.\n\nThe current states reporting mumps cases during 2019 are as follows:\n\nGeorgia: Nancy Nydam, Director of Communications for The Georgia Department of Public Health, wrote, 'An outbreak of mumps has been reported at the facility and the investigation is ongoing.'\n\nPennsylvania: Officials at Garrett-Ford Elementary in Drexel Hill, Delaware County, are warning parents after a student was diagnosed with mumps.\n\nNorth Dakota: The North Dakota Department of Health says 2 cases of mumps have been reported in Williams County. And, North Dakota Department of Health says there have 3 more cases of mumps recorded in Stark county.\n\nUtah: Parents of children attending Sunset Elementary School were sent a letter from the Southwest Utah Public Health Department, warning them after a student stayed home sick with the disease [15 Jan 2019], after exposing teachers and students for up to 3 days.\n\nWisconsin: A Marquette University student has contracted mumps. In an email to students, the school said the infected student lives in one of the residence halls.\n\nA major factor contributing to mumps outbreaks is being in a crowded environment, such as attending the same class, playing on the same sports team, or living in a dormitory with a person who is infectious with mumps, says the CDC.\n\nAlso, certain behaviors that result in exchanging saliva, such as kissing or sharing utensils, cups, lip balm, or cigarettes, might increase the spread of the virus.\n\nThe MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease.\n\nThe mumps component of the MMR vaccine has reported being 88 percent effective when a person gets 2 vaccine doses.\n\nAccording to another study, one potential cause of these mumps outbreaks is 'waning-immunization.'\n\nA previous study from the Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health found that vaccine-derived immune protection against mumps persists an average for about 27 years, after the last administered dose.\n\nIn response to the expanding number of mumps outbreaks, the CDC released guidance in October 2017, regarding when a 3rd dose of mumps vaccine is appropriate.\n\nThis new CDC guidance did not recommend a 3rd MMR dose outside of a 'confirmed mumps outbreak'.\n\nAnother reason for mumps outbreaks could be under-vaccinations by international travelers.\n\n[Byline: Don Ward Hackett; fact checked by Robert Carlson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not surprising that mumps cases are increasing in number. If fewer children are being vaccinated with the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine, all of these diseases will increase in the population. Furthermore, mumps immunity apparently wanes after approximately 27 years, making this age group vulnerable again. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\n\n******\n[2] Texas (Laredo): 2018\nDate: Sat 9 Feb 2019\nSource: KRGV [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.krgv.com/videos/group-of-migrants-along-border-found-to-be-sick-with-mumps\n\n\nA group of migrants along the southern border were found to be sick with the mumps. The cases were discovered near the Laredo border.\n\nAccording to local health officials, it was years ago since they last saw cases like this at a detention center.\n\nIn December [2018], 9 confirmed cases were detected at an Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility there.\n\nThousands of migrants cross through Laredo's ports of entry; Border Patrol reports 3449 were encountered there since October [2018].\n\nDr Hector Gonzalez, Laredo Health Department Director says, 'There's an international community of the entire border. So, people from all over cross, legally and illegally, every day.'\n\nThe City of Laredo Health Department was called in to the GEO detention center in Laredo.\n\nHealth screenings often reveal trends, explains Dr Gonzalez. 'We usually see 1-2 cases per year of tuberculosis, but we haven't seen mumps in years.'\n\nAccording to Dr Gonzalez, 9 migrants, mostly Central American and Mexican, have mumps.\n\nIn a statement provided by ICE, it stated they 'quarantine everyone who may have been inadvertently exposed to stop the spread of the disease.'\n\nIt also stated migrants normally get medical screening, a virus they were exposed to prior to the detention center stay could be harder to detect until symptoms became visible.\n\nDr Gonzalez said some people at the facility were vaccinated against the disease after the discovery was made.\n\nBoth local governments along the Laredo/Nuevo Laredo border are monitoring the situation.\n\nJose Martin Carmona Flores, Director of the Tamaulipas [Mexico] Institute for Migrants, said they offer migrants at their shelters several services. 'Before anything else, we check their health. '\n\nDr Gonzalez explains having international citizens in his city means health officials must foster a global awareness.\n\n'One of the things is we see people coming from other parts of the world, especially the Congo, from Africa, and we want to make sure there's no exposure to yellow fever, malaria. The Congo is having an outbreak of Ebola, but they're vaccinating everyone so, yes, we monitor very closely.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Texas, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5596\n\nMumps has the capacity to spread very quickly through the detained community who are living in close contact with each other. The virus is spread through saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat.\n\nAccording to the CDC, the virus can be transmitted before the salivary glands begin to swell and up to 5 days after the swelling begins. The early stages before swelling are risky since it is not evident the infected individual is infectious. It is for that reason that quarantine of exposed individuals is adopted . - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The current states reporting mumps cases during 2019 are as follows:\n\nGeorgia: Nancy Nydam, Director of Communications for The Georgia Department of Public Health, wrote, 'An outbreak of mumps has been reported at the facility and the investigation is ongoing.' promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Texas, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5596\n\nMumps has the capacity to spread very quickly through the detained community who are living in close contact with each other. LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\n\n******\n \n\nA previous study from the Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health found that vaccine-derived immune protection against mumps persists an average for about 27 years, after the last administered dose. \n\nThese state-based news reports have yet to be confirmed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), who has not yet issued a mumps outbreak report for 2019. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n \n\nThis new CDC guidance did not recommend a 3rd MMR dose outside of a 'confirmed mumps outbreak'. \n\nUtah: Parents of children attending Sunset Elementary School were sent a letter from the Southwest Utah Public Health Department, warning them after a student stayed home sick with the disease [15 Jan 2019], after exposing teachers and students for up to 3 days. The MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. A major factor contributing to mumps outbreaks is being in a crowded environment, such as attending the same class, playing on the same sports team, or living in a dormitory with a person who is infectious with mumps, says the CDC. \n\nAnother reason for mumps outbreaks could be under-vaccinations by international travelers. In response to the expanding number of mumps outbreaks, the CDC released guidance in October 2017, regarding when a 3rd dose of mumps vaccine is appropriate. The Congo is having an outbreak of Ebola, but they're vaccinating everyone so, yes, we monitor very closely.'\n\n--\n MUMPS UPDATE (01): USA\n**********************\n \n\nIt also stated migrants normally get medical screening, a virus they were exposed to prior to the detention center stay could be harder to detect until symptoms became visible. especially the Congo, from Africa, and we want to make sure there's no exposure to yellow fever, malaria.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "measles", "mumps", "rubella", "tuberculosis", "yellow fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-02-06 00:00:00", "2021-10-25 00:00:00", "2019-01-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-12-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2017-10-25 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6429994", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (07): Europe (Ireland), USA (IN, PA, UT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6429994", "date": "2019-04-20 15:01:41", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (07): EUROPE (IRELAND), USA (INDIANA, PENNSYLVANIA, UTAH)\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nEurope\n---\n[1] Ireland\n\nUSA\n---\n[2] Indiana\n[2b] Indiana University outbreak confirmed\n[3] Penn State University outbreak\n[4] Utah\n\n******\n[1] Ireland\nDate: Wed 17 Apr 2019\nSource: Leitrim Observer [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.leitrimobserver.ie/news/home/376482/ongoing-outbreak-of-mumps-in-leitrim-sligo-and-donegal.html\n\n\nThe HSE [Ireland's national health service] says it 'had not seen diseases like measles in Donegal, Sligo or Leitrim for a number of years, because 95% of children were vaccinated against them. Last year [2018], the uptake of childhood vaccinations dropped slightly in Donegal, and this resulted in an outbreak of measles in January this year [2019].'\n\nThe HSE says 'There is also an ongoing mumps outbreak across Donegal, Sligo and Leitrim. The HSE has been notified of 116 cases so far.\n\n'As soon as vaccination rates fall, diseases like measles and mumps return. Fortunately, the majority of people in Donegal, Sligo and Leitrim are protecting their children with vaccination. The most recent figures for 2018 show that 90% of children in Donegal received the MMR and 93% of children in Sligo and Leitrim received it.\n\n'However, over 95% of children need to be vaccinated with the MMR in order to prevent the spread of measles in our community. This is the goal for 2019, as it is really important for 'herd immunity'. In this way, we can protect newborns and vulnerable children, including those with cancer or immune problems who can't get vaccinated, from coming in contact with measles and other diseases like meningitis.'\n\nThis year [2019] European Immunisation Week runs 24-30 Apr. The goal is to raise awareness of the benefits of vaccination and to celebrate the vaccine heroes who contribute to protecting lives through vaccination. Vaccine heroes include health workers who administer vaccines, parents who choose vaccination for their children, and everyone who promotes vaccination.\n\n'Every parent wants to protect their child and do what's right for them. Sometimes it can be difficult to know what to do, now that there is so much false and misleading information on the internet and social media when it comes to vaccination,' says Dr. Laura Heavey, Specialist Registrar in Public Health Medicine in HSE North West, 'I would really encourage parents to look for information in the right places. Two good sources of reliable, evidence-based information are <www.immunisation.ie> and the Vaccine Knowledge Project at http://vk.ovg.ox.ac.uk/. Essentially all of the vaccines on the infant, child and adolescent schedule in Ireland are backed up with years of data on their safety.'\n\nAnother goal for the HSE in 2019 is to continue to increase the uptake of the HPV vaccine in teenagers. In 2018, 70% of teenage girls in Ireland got the vaccine. In Scotland, where HPV vaccination started over 10 years ago and 90% of teenage girls get the HPV vaccine, researchers have found that the vaccine has nearly wiped out cases of cervical pre-cancer in young women. We want to see as many Irish teenagers as possible getting vaccinated in 2019, so that we can see those same results here. This year [2019], the vaccine will also be offered to teenage boys. If all our young people receive the vaccine, cervical cancer could be eliminated in Ireland in the future.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Ireland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39]\n\n******\n[2] Indiana\nDate: Wed 17 Apr 2019\nSource: US News and World Report [edited]\nhttps://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/indiana/articles/2019-04-17/indiana-u-mumps-outbreak-reaches-16-cases-9-linked-to-frat\n\n\nIndiana University officials say the number of students diagnosed with mumps has more than doubled since last week to 16. University spokesman Chuck Carney said Wednesday [17 Apr 2019] that 9 of the cases are linked to a single fraternity he declined to identify.\n\nCarney says university officials have been in contact with the Indiana State Department of Health and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The new total compares with 7 cases announced last week. The first 2 cases were confirmed in February [2019], and a campus outbreak of the illness was declared last month [March 2019] after a 3rd case was confirmed.\n\nFree vaccines are available for anyone who has had close contact with infected students. Mumps is a viral illness that affects glands that produce saliva.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Indiana, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/217]\n\n******\n[2b] Indiana University outbreak confirmation\nDate: Thu 18 Apr 2019\nSource: People.com [edited]\nhttps://people.com/health/17-cases-mumps-indiana-university-fraternity/\n\n\nMore than a dozen cases of mumps have been reported at Indiana University [IU] this year [2019], and the majority have been linked to one of the school's fraternities. IU spokesman Chuck Carney says there have been 17 confirmed mumps cases on campus since 12 Feb 2019, of which 9 have been linked to a single fraternity house.\n\nWhile the school is not identifying the students or the fraternity, CNN reported that those affected by the outbreak were either members of the fraternity or had visited the house.\n\nCarney went on to say that every student enrolled at IU is required to have 2 doses of the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) vaccine -- the amount recommended by the CDC -- with an exemption available for religious reasons.\n\nOn 4 Apr 2019, the Monroe County Health Department held a free MMR vaccination clinic at the fraternity house, which allowed members to get a 3rd shot 'which provides about a month of boosted immunity.' Of the 149 members of the fraternity, 58% got a vaccine.\n\nThe school is also taking steps to promote healthy practices in general. 'We're making the campus aware and advising students to say home if they feel sick and otherwise practice good hygiene habits -- wash their hands with soap and water, don't drink or eat after someone, cover a sneeze with a tissue, for example,' Carney said. 'We want all of our 41 000-plus students to remain healthy, so they should go to the IU Health Center on the IU Bloomington campus and get checked out if they feel unwell or see their own doctor.'\n\nAccording to the Mayo Clinic, mumps is 'a viral infection that primarily affects saliva-producing (salivary) glands that are located near your ears.' Signs and symptoms of the virus typically develop between 2 to 3 weeks after exposure.\n\nIn addition to painful gland swelling, mumps can also cause fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue and loss of appetite. However, in rare cases, the contagious disease has been known to cause brain and spinal cord damage as well as death, according to the CDC. The virus is transmitted through saliva or mucus, and can be spread by sharing cups and utensils, or participating in close-contact activities, like sports or kissing, the CDC says.\n\nBoth mumps and measles can be prevented with the MMR vaccine, but measles cases are on the rise worldwide. The World Health Organization said in a report released on Monday [15 Apr 2019] that based on preliminary data, measles cases are up by 300% worldwide in the first 3 months of 2019, compared with the same period last year [2018], adding that the new data 'indicate a clear trend' of rising rates of infection.\n\nEarlier this year [2019], the organization named 'vaccine hesitancy' -- the 'reluctance or refusal to vaccinate despite the availability' -- as one of the biggest threats to global health in 2019. Thanks to the measles vaccine, 2 to 3 million deaths are prevented each year, WHO said, but that number could be much higher. 'A further 1.5 million could be avoided if global coverage of vaccinations improved,' the group said.\n\nCases of the measles in the USA are now at a 5-year high. As of 11 Apr, there have been a reported 555 measles cases in 2019, according to the CDC, the most since 2014.\n\nThe CDC says that there are currently outbreaks of the measles in several parts of the USA, including the Pacific Northwest, Michigan and New York City. They believe the outbreaks are due to people traveling to other countries with significant outbreaks, including Israel, the Philippines and Ukraine, and then coming back to the USA and infecting people in areas with low vaccination rates.\n\nAlthough the measles was considered eradicated in the USA as of 2000 thanks to the vaccine, some people are choosing to not vaccinate, partially due to the spread of misinformation about the vaccine, which has led parents to opt out of giving children the life-saving protections.\n\n[Byline: Maria Pasquini]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n[3] Penn State University outbreak\nDate: Wed 17 Apr 2019\nSource: WJAC-TV [edited]\nhttps://wjactv.com/news/local/penn-state-announces-mumps-outbreak-during-spring-2019-warns-community\n\n\nAnother case of the mumps has been confirmed at Penn State. This comes just a week after the university announced the 1st cases, during the spring semester. The university says this latest case is now the 3rd confirmed case of the mumps at the University Park campus, and the state's Department of Health considers this a mumps outbreak.\n\n'We're encouraging people that may have children or may not be immune to mumps to really be careful if they're coming to campus,' infectious disease manager and campus health liaison Shelley Haffner said. Haffner is giving a warning to those who might visit the University Park campus as it faces another mumps outbreak.\n\nHealth officials say mumps is a highly contagious disease that can be passed through saliva. Penn State also dealt with mumps outbreaks in spring 2017 and spring 2018.\n\nThe first 2 cases were confirmed last week. That led the university to put out a warning for folks before Blue-White Weekend activities begin, bringing big crowds. The university says it has 3 more suspected cases. 'We want to stress the importance of understanding possible is: They could end up being something other than mumps,' Haffner said.\n\nIn order to protect students, the university says one student has left campus and the others have been isolated until further notice.\n\nIf any students have come in contact with those infected, the university advises them to get a 3rd dose of the measles, mumps and rubella -- MMR -- vaccine. Students are required to be vaccinated. Those who don't have proof of the MMR vaccine may be excluded from campus. 'That means they cannot come to classes on campus, or live on campus,' Haffner said.\n\nHealth center officials say they're working closely with the Department of Health to monitor the situation. 'As I said, we only have 3 confirmed cases at this point so we're just going to have to wait and see if more cases develop,' Haffner said.\n\nUniversity officials say there is a concern when it comes to big crowds. Graduation is approaching but, if the number of cases doesn't increase, the situation will calm down.\n\n[Byline: Alexis Wainwright]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Pennsylvania, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/240]\n\n******\n[4] Utah\nDate: Tue 16 Apr 2019\nSource: KUTV [edited]\nhttps://kutv.com/news/local/unvaccinated-students-not-allowed-in-sanpete-county-schools-after-possible-mumps-outbreak\n\n\nStudents and faculty who haven't received the MMR vaccine (for measles, mumps and rubella) will be 'excluded' from school and school activities while health officials investigate a possible mumps outbreak. At least 2 Sanpete County residents have contracted mumps, the Central Utah Public Health Department announced in a press release Monday [15 Apr 2019]. The health department stated it was investigating 'other probable cases with close contact to the identified cases.'\n\nUnvaccinated individuals will be allowed to return to school 26 days from the onset of the last identified case, the department stated. Currently, that date would be 5 May 2019. Those individuals will have to provide documentation of their receipt of the MMR vaccine before they can return. No further information about the mumps-infected individuals would be released, the health department stated.\n\nMumps is contagious and caused by a virus, the department stated. Signs and symptoms of mumps include fever, headache, muscle aches, and swelling of the salivary glands, causing a tender and swollen jaw. Complications of mumps can include swelling of the brain, meningitis, and deafness.\n\nThe department provided some guidelines to reduce the risk of getting mumps, including:\n- Stay current on recommended vaccines; the MMR vaccine is the best way to reduce the likeliness of getting mumps. Know the vaccination status of yourself and any family members. A person is considered susceptible unless they have received 2 doses of the mumps vaccine or were born prior to 1957.\n- Contact your healthcare provider if you see signs of mumps in yourself or a family member. Do not go directly to a clinic or hospital without calling before. This will help to ensure that others are not exposed.\n\n[Byline: Alyssa Roberts]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Utah, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/246]\n\n[Mumps is a viral illness caused by a paramyxovirus. Transmission is by direct contact with saliva or droplets from the saliva of an infected person.\n\nEarly symptoms include a headache and fever characterised by swelling of the parotid glands that may be 1- or 2-sided. Other symptoms include pancreatitis, neuritis, arthritis, mastitis, nephritis, thyroiditis and pericarditis. Mumps is rarely fatal, but complications include swelling of the ovaries (oophoritis), swelling of the testes (orchitis), aseptic meningitis and deafness (https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/mumps-guidance-data-and-analysis).\n\nMumps is a notifiable disease in England and Wales, Ireland, and the USA.\n\nMumps is vaccine-preventable. In the UK, children receive 2 doses of the combined measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine as part of the routine childhood immunisation schedule. - Mod.UBA]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: KUTV [edited]\nhttps://kutv.com/news/local/unvaccinated-students-not-allowed-in-sanpete-county-schools-after-possible-mumps-outbreak\n\n\nStudents and faculty who haven't received the MMR vaccine (for measles, mumps and rubella) will be 'excluded' from school and school activities while health officials investigate a possible mumps outbreak. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Utah, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/246]\n\n[Mumps is a viral illness caused by a paramyxovirus. \n\nThe department provided some guidelines to reduce the risk of getting mumps, including:\n- Stay current on recommended vaccines; the MMR vaccine is the best way to reduce the likeliness of getting mumps. \n\nIf any students have come in contact with those infected, the university advises them to get a 3rd dose of the measles, mumps and rubella -- MMR -- vaccine. \n\nCarney went on to say that every student enrolled at IU is required to have 2 doses of the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) vaccine -- the amount recommended by the CDC -- with an exemption available for religious reasons. \n\nEarlier this year [2019], the organization named 'vaccine hesitancy' -- the 'reluctance or refusal to vaccinate despite the availability' -- as one of the biggest threats to global health in 2019. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Ireland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39]\n\n******\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Indiana, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/217]\n\n******\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Pennsylvania, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/240]\n\n******\n \n\nBoth mumps and measles can be prevented with the MMR vaccine, but measles cases are on the rise worldwide. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n The World Health Organization said in a report released on Monday [15 Apr 2019] that based on preliminary data, measles cases are up by 300% worldwide in the first 3 months of 2019, compared with the same period last year [2018], adding that the new data 'indicate a clear trend' of rising rates of infection. Last year [2018], the uptake of childhood vaccinations dropped slightly in Donegal, and this resulted in an outbreak of measles in January this year [2019].'\n\n MUMPS UPDATE (07): EUROPE (IRELAND), USA (INDIANA, PENNSYLVANIA, UTAH)\n**********************************************************************\n IU spokesman Chuck Carney says there have been 17 confirmed mumps cases on campus since 12 Feb 2019, of which 9 have been linked to a single fraternity house. \n\n'As soon as vaccination rates fall, diseases like measles and mumps return. Source: US News and World Report [edited]\nhttps://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/indiana/articles/2019-04-17/indiana-u-mumps-outbreak-reaches-16-cases-9-linked-to-frat\n\n\nIndiana University officials say the number of students diagnosed with mumps has more than doubled since last week to 16. \n\n--\n \n\n--\n [Byline: Maria Pasquini]\n\n--\n [Byline: Alexis Wainwright]\n\n--\n [Byline: Alyssa Roberts]\n\n--\n https://people.com/health/17-cases-mumps-indiana-university-fraternity/\n\n\nMore than a dozen cases of mumps have been reported at Indiana University [IU] this year [2019], and the majority have been linked to one of the school's fraternities. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nHealth officials say mumps is a highly contagious disease that can be passed through saliva. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nAnother goal for the HSE in 2019 is to continue to increase the uptake of the HPV vaccine in teenagers. In the UK, children receive 2 doses of the combined measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine as part of the routine childhood immunisation schedule. [4] Utah\n\n******\n \n\nMumps is vaccine-preventable. Although the measles was considered eradicated in the USA as of 2000 thanks to the vaccine, some people are choosing to not vaccinate, partially due to the spread of misinformation about the vaccine, which has led parents to opt out of giving children the life-saving protections. \n\nWhile the school is not identifying the students or the fraternity, CNN reported that those affected by the outbreak were either members of the fraternity or had visited the house. In Scotland, where HPV vaccination started over 10 years ago and 90% of teenage girls get the HPV vaccine, researchers have found that the vaccine has nearly wiped out cases of cervical pre-cancer in young women. \n\nCases of the measles in the USA are now at a 5-year high. \n\nCarney says university officials have been in contact with the Indiana State Department of Health and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. \n\nMumps is contagious and caused by a virus, the department stated.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-02-25 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2019-04-18 00:00:00", (PA, TX), Europe (Ireland)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6350670", "date": "2019-03-05 18:58:32", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (03): USA (PENNSYLVANIA, TEXAS), EUROPE (IRELAND)\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] USA summary\n[2] Pennsylvania\n[3] Texas\n\nEurope\n------\n[4] Ireland\n\n******\n[1] USA Summary\nDate: Wed 27 Feb 2019\nSource: Precision Vaccinations [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.precisionvaccinations.com/58-mumps-cases-reported-cdc-and-28-cases-reported-ice-during-2019\n\n\nThe ongoing measles outbreak now has anti-vaxx competition from another vaccine-preventable disease, mumps. From 1-31 Jan 2019, mumps infections have been reported in 58 people from 18 states to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).\n\nThis new data is good news when compared with 2018 when the CDC confirmed 2251 mumps cases. But, this CDC data may not include mumps cases reported by the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agency during 2019. So far, ICE facilities in Colorado and Texas have reported mumps cases.\n\nThe leading states reporting mumps cases during 2019 include, but are not limited to, the following:\n\n- Arkansas: The Department of Health said cases of the mumps have been confirmed on the campus of the University of Arkansas at Fayetteville. A total of 3 cases have been confirmed and there is another suspected case of the mumps at the university over the last few weeks.\n\n- Georgia: Nancy Nydam, Director of Communications for The Georgia Department of Public Health, wrote, 'An outbreak of mumps has been reported at the facility and the investigation is ongoing.'\n\n- Illinois: 8 cases were reported in 2 locations; 6 at Crystal Lake church and 2 at the McHenry County Correctional Facility. Health officials are working to determine if the 2 locations are related.\n\n- Indiana: 2 confirmed cases of the mumps have been found at Indiana University in Bloomington, health officials said.\n\n- Montana: 3 cases of mumps are confirmed in children attending Bozeman public schools, and health officials are investigating other possible cases.\n\n- North Dakota: The North Dakota Department of Health has confirmed 5 cases of mumps statewide, 3 of them in Stark County and 2 in Williams County.\n\n- Pennsylvania: Officials at a Delaware County elementary school are warning parents after a student was diagnosed with mumps. Officials at Garrett-Ford Elementary in Drexel Hill sent an email to parents regarding the health concern.\n\n- Utah: Southern Utah health officials say they have a reported case of mumps that popped up at an elementary school in St. George earlier this month [February 2019]. However, they believe because of the long delay before symptoms show, there could be more cases.\n\n- Wisconsin: A Marquette University student has contracted mumps. In an email to students, the school said the infected student lives in one of the residence halls.\n\nInternationally, Ireland has reported a mumps outbreak during 2019. According to reporting by the Irish Times, there have been 278 mumps cases in the 1st 6 weeks of 2019, compared with 43 for the same time in 2018, according to the HSE's Health Protection Surveillance Centre. A total of 9 outbreaks were reported in school, university, community, and private home settings, with the majority of cases occurring among teenagers and young adults.\n\nA major factor contributing to mumps outbreaks is being in a crowded environment or living in a dormitory with a person who is infectious with mumps, says the CDC.\n\nOne mumps outbreak in Ireland forced the cancellation of a schools rugby match in south Dublin, while Trinity College, DCU, and schools in Co Louth have also been affected. During 2018, various colleges have reported mumps cases, such as Cincinnati, Emory, Harvard, James Madison University, Michigan, Northern Colorado, Northeastern University, Oklahoma University, Penn State, TCU, Texas State and Western Illinois University.\n\nAccording to the previous study, another potential cause of these mumps outbreaks is 'waning-immunization'. A previous study from the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health found that vaccine-derived immune protection against mumps persists on average about 27 years, after the last administered dose.\n\nIn response to the expanding number of mumps outbreaks, the CDC released guidance in October 2017, regarding when the 3rd dose of mumps vaccine is appropriate. This new CDC guidance did not recommend a 3rd MMR dose outside of a 'confirmed mumps outbreak'.\n\nAnother reason for mumps outbreaks could be under-vaccinations by international travelers.\n\nThe mumps component of the MMR vaccine has reported being 88% effective when a person gets 2 vaccine doses.\n\n[Byline: Don Ward Hackett]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Pennsylvania: Temple University on alert after students test positive for mumps\nDate: Fri 1 Mar 2019\nSource: 6abc [abridged, edited]\nhttps://6abc.com/health/temple-on-alert-after-students-test-positive-for-mumps/5162886/\n\n\nStudents, faculty and staff at Temple University have been notified about cases of mumps on campus. Student Health Services says 4 Temple students have tested positive for the highly-infectious virus.\n\n[Fri 1 Mar 2019] was the last day before spring break and some Temple students were worried. 'Yeah, I'm a little concerned that means people aren't getting vaccinated,' student Caroline Gugel said.\n\n[Byline: Bob Brooks]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[One big concern with Spring break is that students who do not yet know they are infected can spread the virus to susceptible unvaccinated individuals when they travel outside the university. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Texas: immigration facilities\nDate: Fri 1 Mar 2019\nSource: KRGV [edited]\nhttps://protect2.fireeye.com/url?k=09d1b67e-55e910c3-09d34f4b-000babd9fa3f-5795fe99245699f6&u=https://www.krgv.com/news/group-of-migrants-in-immigration-facilities-sick-with-mumps/\n\n\nThe Texas Department of State Health Services confirmed there are 186 people with mumps at immigration facilities across the state; 5 of these people are employees.\n\nThe department reported there are no cases of mumps in the communities surrounding the facility.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See Mumps update (01): USA 20190210.6307434 for further discussion on the situation in the ICE facility in Laredo, Texas and Mumps update (02): USA (CO, TX), Europe (Ireland) 20190221.6329434 for ICE in Houston, Texas. During initial medical checks on the migrants entering the country, it would be good practice to vaccinate them with MMR. Similarly, all personnel working at the ICE facilities should be vaccinated to protect them and their families, as well as the incarcerated community within the facility and everyone outside. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] Ireland: Outbreak of mumps hits universities\nDate: Wed 27 Feb 2019\nSource: The Times [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/ireland/outbreak-of-mumps-hits-universities-50vmfl2f8\n\n\nA total of 384 cases mumps have been reported this year [2019] from Irish Universities, HSE figures have shown.\n\nThere were 64 new cases reported last week, bringing the total to 384 since the start of the year [2019]. The number of cases has been rising steadily in recent weeks, with 278 in the 1st 6 weeks of the year. Last year [2018] there had been 52 cases by the end of February. There were 576 cases in total last year [2018].\n\n[Byline : Catherine Sanz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Also see ProMED-mail Mumps update (02): USA (CO, TX), Europe (Ireland) 20190221.6329434 for more on the outbreak in Ireland. - Mod.LK]\n\n['Before the U.S. mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99% decrease in mumps cases in the United States. Since the 2-dose vaccination program was introduced in 1989, mumps cases have ranged year to year from a couple of hundred to several thousand. However, in recent years, there has been an increase in the number of reported cases, from 229 cases in 2012 to 6366 cases in 2016. The recent increase has been mainly due to multiple mumps outbreaks reported across the country in settings where people often have close contact with one another, like college campuses.' CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html). - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nIreland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See Mumps update (01): USA 20190210.6307434 for further discussion on the situation in the ICE facility in Laredo, Texas and Mumps update (02): USA (CO, TX), Europe (Ireland) 20190221.6329434 for ICE in Houston, Texas.
