"5877875", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (06): USA (HI) Mexico", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5877875", "date": "2018-06-26 21:01:35", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (06): USA (HAWAII) MEXICO\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] USA (Hawaii) outbreak\n[2] Mexico: Mumps alert\n\n******\n[1] Hawaii outbreak\nDate: Fri 22 Jun 2018\nSource: Hawaii News Now [edited]\nhttp://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/38490408/hawai-typically-sees-10-mumps-cases-a-year-an-outbreak-has-sickened-100-times-that\n\n\nHawaii typically sees 10 mumps cases a year. An outbreak has now sickened 100 times that. The mumps outbreak in Hawaii has hit the 1000 case mark, according to the state Health Department.\n\nTypically, the state sees less than 10 cases a year. In 2017, Hawaii saw more than 760.\n\nThe majority of cases were reported on Oahu, with 810 confirmed cases. Hawaii Island saw 134 cases, Kauai saw 49, and Maui has 7 confirmed cases.\n\nThis has been the largest outbreak of the disease in the islands in decades. An Oahu charter school even had to start winter break early to prevent the disease from spreading. There also have been 31 reports of complications since the outbreak, including hearing loss. 'For now, it's still trickling along,' said Dr. Sarah Park, Department of Health.\n\nPark said we're nowhere near ending the outbreak, although it seems the outbreak may at least be slowing down a bit. The outbreak started in March 2017, after the Health Department reported 9 people had the viral infection. The infection is spread through saliva. Park said sharing food, drinks, or other activities that could transmit saliva should be avoided.\n\nThe disease is not considered life-threatening, but there can be complications. Symptoms can include fever, headaches, swollen glands under the ear or jaw, and muscle aches.\n\nThe state Department of Health said the best way to prevent mumps is to get vaccinated.\n\nFor more information on mumps, visit the state Health Department's website.\n\n[Byline: Samie Gebers]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There, unfortunately, have been 31 cases of mumps in Hawaii with complications, including loss of hearing. With the exception of children who have underlying conditions that prevent them from being vaccinated, all other children old enough to be vaccinated should be, not only to protect themselves, but also to protect others who cannot be safely vaccinated. With 1000 cases, there must be a low proportion of children vaccinated, especially on Oahu. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nHawaii, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/214]\n\n******\n[2] Mexico: Mumps alert\nDate: Mon 25 Jun 2018\nSource: El Heraldo de Tabasco [in Spanish, trans. Mod.JG, edited]\nhttps://www.elheraldodetabasco.com.mx/local/alerta-salud-por-brote-de-paperas\n\n\nThe mumps outbreak currently occurring in our country is still affecting the population. Our (health) institution has taken care of in its different units 54 persons diagnosed with mumps. Five cases of this condition were seen last week, according to a report issued by the General Direction of Epidemiology from the Federal Health Secretary.\n\nThe data published in the Health Secretary website indicate that these 54 cases of this vaccine-preventable disease outnumber the 32 cases found during the same time period in 2017, emphasizing that the condition is equally affecting men and women.\n\nIn this sense, Mr. Fernando Izquierdo-Aquino, Public Health Sub-Secretary, pointed out that the National Epidemiological Surveillance Council sent a communication to all its facilities, declaring an alert state because of this mumps outbreak occurring since last April [2018], emphasizing that medical units should take special care with these cases.\n\n'We are alert in order to avoid blockade and take care of affected persons who may present with the symptoms; for this reason, the most important aspect is to immediately go to health-care facilities should any upper respiratory symptom occur,' he declared. Mr Izquierdo-Aquino also mentioned that the duration of this outbreak is unknown. The occurrence is located in the northern Mexican states, but the other state authorities are in an alert state.\n\n'Mumps is an acute self-limiting condition, as is the case for conjunctivitis, but it is a preventable condition, and our strength lies in our vaccination schedule, in which the triple viral vaccine (MMR: measles, mumps, and rubella) is administered to children less than 5 years of age,' he pointed out.\n\nThe Mexican National Epidemiological Surveillance System (SINAVE, according to its Spanish initials) has identified cases and outbreaks in the country since the last weeks of 2017. The increase in the number of mumps cases is affecting many areas of the country, especially Tamaulipas State in Ciudad Madero and Tampico municipalities; Quintana Roo State, Solidaridad municipality; and Nuevo Leon State, Monterrey municipality.\n\nUp to the 15th epidemiological week for 2018, 2619 mumps cases have been identified in Mexico; the most affected states are as follows: Tamaulipas, 561 cases (21 percent); Nuevo Leon, 302 (12 percent); Quintana Roo, 203 (8 percent); Jalisco, 189 (7 percent), and Chihuahua, 167 (6 percent).\n\nThe most affected age groups all over the country are 25-44-year-old adults, with 805 cases (31 percent); followed by the 20-24-year-old group, with 531 cases (20 percent), and 5-9-year-old children, with 388 cases (15 percent).\n\nGender distribution shows a mild male predominance, with 1450 affected males (55 percent) and 1169 female cases (45 percent).\n\nIn this year so far, mumps outbreaks have been identified in Mexico City, Sonora, and Chihuahua. These occurrences have a common feature: they tend to appear in colleges, affecting young people.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Parotitis is the name given to inflammation and infection of the largest of the salivary glands known as the parotid glands. Inflammation results in swelling of the tissues that surround the salivary glands, redness, and soreness. Salivary glands are responsible for producing saliva in the mouth, which has the important function of cleansing the mouth. Inflammation of the salivary glands reduces their ability to function properly and may lead to infections within the mouth.\n\nParotitis may result from many causes, including infection, drugs, radiation, and various diseases. Mumps was once the most common viral cause of parotitis, but vaccination has made mumps a rare disease today. Parotitis caused by bacterial infection is somewhat common in the United States (excerpted from https://www.healthgrades.com/conditions/parotitis).\n\nIt is not surprising that the outbreaks in Mexico have occurred in colleges affecting young people, as colleges have close living accommodations where infectious diseases easily spread. Furthermore, mumps immunity may be waning by the time an individual reaches college, making him/her susceptible to infection. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nMexico: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14\n]", "summary": "\n\nThe most affected age groups all over the country are 25-44-year-old adults, with 805 cases (31 percent); followed by the 20-24-year-old group, with 531 cases (20 percent), and 5-9-year-old children, with 388 cases (15 percent). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There, unfortunately, have been 31 cases of mumps in Hawaii with complications, including loss of hearing. Up to the 15th epidemiological week for 2018, 2619 mumps cases have been identified in Mexico; the most affected states are as follows: Tamaulipas, 561 cases (21 percent); Nuevo Leon, 302 (12 percent); Quintana Roo, 203 (8 percent); Jalisco, 189 (7 percent), and Chihuahua, 167 (6 percent). LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nHawaii, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/214]\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Parotitis is the name given to inflammation and infection of the largest of the salivary glands known as the parotid glands. \n\n'Mumps is an acute self-limiting condition, as is the case for conjunctivitis, but it is a preventable condition, and our strength lies in our vaccination schedule, in which the triple viral vaccine (MMR: measles, mumps, and rubella) is administered to children less than 5 years of age,' he pointed out. LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nMexico: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14\n] In this sense, Mr. Fernando Izquierdo-Aquino, Public Health Sub-Secretary, pointed out that the National Epidemiological Surveillance Council sent a communication to all its facilities, declaring an alert state because of this mumps outbreak occurring since last April [2018], emphasizing that medical units should take special care with these cases. \n\nGender distribution shows a mild male predominance, with 1450 affected males (55 percent) and 1169 female cases (45 percent). The data published in the Health Secretary website indicate that these 54 cases of this vaccine-preventable disease outnumber the 32 cases found during the same time period in 2017, emphasizing that the condition is equally affecting men and women. The increase in the number of mumps cases is affecting many areas of the country, especially Tamaulipas State in Ciudad Madero and Tampico municipalities; Quintana Roo State, Solidaridad municipality; and Nuevo Leon State, Monterrey municipality. Mumps alert\n\n******\n \n\nThe Mexican National Epidemiological Surveillance System (SINAVE, according to its Spanish initials) has identified cases and outbreaks in the country since the last weeks of 2017. MUMPS UPDATE (06): USA (HAWAII) MEXICO\n***************************************\n \n\n'We are alert in order to avoid blockade and take care of affected persons who may present with the symptoms; for this reason, the most important aspect is to immediately go to health-care facilities should any upper respiratory symptom occur,' he declared. In this posting:\n[1] USA (Hawaii) outbreak\n \n\nThe state Department of Health said the best way to prevent mumps is to get vaccinated. \n\nIt is not surprising that the outbreaks in Mexico have occurred in colleges affecting young people, as colleges have close living accommodations where infectious diseases easily spread. [Byline: Samie Gebers]\n\n--\n \n\n--\n Hawaii Island saw 134 cases, Kauai saw 49, and Maui has 7 confirmed cases. \n\nThis has been the largest outbreak of the disease in the islands in decades.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1450-03-25 00:00:00", "2049-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "1169-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2619-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sonora", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Solidaridad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Monterrey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jalisco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5780160", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (04): Mexico, USA (NY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5780160", "date": "2018-05-02 21:08:13", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (04): MEXICO, USA (NEW YORK)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Mexico\n[2] USA (New York); Goldman Sachs\n\n******\n[1] Mexico\nDate: Sat 29 Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/mexico-reports-mumps-outbreak-many-cases-college-students-91663/\n\n\nThe Mexican Ministry of Health has reported an outbreak of mumps in the country, many affecting university students, with outbreaks reported in Mexico City, Sonora and Chihuahua, according to the National Epidemiological Surveillance System (SINAVE) (computer translated).\n\nThrough [13 Apr 2018] 2619 cases of mumps have been reported in the country. The states with the highest number of cases are: Tamaulipas-561 (21 percent), Nuevo Le\u00f3n with 302 (12 percent), Quintana Roo with 203 (8 percent), Jalisco with 189 (7 percent) and Chihuahua with 167 (6 percent).\n\nThe most affected age groups nationwide are adults from 25 to 44 years old, with 805 (31 percent), followed by the group of 20 to 24 years old with 531 (20 percent) and children from 5 to 9 years old, with 388 (15 percent).\n\nLast year, Mexico reported a total of 4653 cases of mumps.\n\nMumps: Why it's seen a resurgence\n---------------------------------\nMumps is an acute infectious disease caused by the mumps virus. It is spread via coughing, sneezing, kissing, sharing glasses or utensils, and touching a surface that has the virus on it. Mumps is suspected when there is swelling of one or more of the saliva glands. The swelling may just be on one side, but is more commonly on both. Sometimes the glands under the tongue or jaw are affected also. Other possible symptoms of mumps include: fever, headache, earache, tiredness, sore muscles, dry mouth, poor appetite, and trouble talking, chewing, or swallowing.\n\nBefore the swelling occurs, flu-like symptoms appear in about half of those who get the virus. In children under 5, mumps can show up as a lung infection. Fever usually lasts 1 to 6 days but enlargement of the glands may go on for 10 days or longer. A few people may have little or no symptoms but can still spread the virus. When a person is exposed to mumps, it usually takes from 16 to 18 days for them to get sick, but it can range from 12 to 25 days. The virus is most contagious from 2 days before the swelling starts until 5 days after it goes away.\n\nWaning vaccine-derived immunity linked to mumps re-emergence: Study\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nGlobally, the World Health Organization has reported 585 315 cases of mumps in the present year through [13 Feb 2018], distributed as follows: Pacific West 57 percent (335 304), Africa 17 percent (100 576), East Mediterranean 13 percent (75 680), Southeast Asia 5 percent (31 739), Europe 4 percent (20 874) and the Americas 3 percent (21 142). The countries that have the largest number of reported cases are Japan 175 001 cases and China 159 031 cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See URL above for infographic aimed at college students depicting symptoms of mumps and steps they can take to protect themselves.]\n\n[Research using mumps vaccine effectiveness data and dynamic transmission modeling from Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health shows the increase in mumps in college age students is likely because protection can decline years after receiving the vaccine. While it is expected that 50 percent of people will retain protection for 19 years after receiving a mumps-containing vaccine, many people will maintain protection far longer, so the population average is about 27 years,' according to J Lewnard, Research Associate, Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health. The vaccine is nearly 90 percent effective after 2 doses, but a 3rd booster dose has been used to cut down on future cases, either in response to outbreaks or to prevent outbreaks.\n(Lewnard JA and Grad YH. Vaccine waning and mumps re-emergence in the United States. Science Translational Medicine 21 Mar 2018: Vol. 10, Issue 433, eaao5945 DOI: 10.1126/scitranslmed.aao5945). - Mod.LK]\n\n[A Healthmap/ProMED of Mexico can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14]\n\n******\n[2] USA (New York); Goldman Sachs\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2018\nSource: Dealbreaker [edited]\nhttps://dealbreaker.com/2018/04/mumps-outbreak-on-trading-floor-has-goldman-sachs-traders-wondering-which-of-the-seven-seals-this-one-is/\n\nTraders in Bankers Goldman Sachs infected with Mumps\n----------------------------------------------------\nGoldman Sachs is battling to contain a rare but contagious flare-up of mumps after a few employees contracted the disease. Employees on one of its trading floors showed signs of the disease this week and the firm told people to get shots or visit the firm's health center if they didn't receive the vaccine during childhood, according to a person with knowledge of the matter who asked to remain anonymous discussing internal conditions....-more\n\n[Byline: Thornton Mcenery]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Complications of mumps happen more often among adults than children, and may include: meningitis or encephalitis (inflammation of the membrane that covers the brain and spinal cord or inflammation of the brain), orchitis (inflammation of one or both testicles), mastitis (inflammation of breast tissue), parotitis (inflammation of one or both parotid glands), oophoritis (inflammation of one or both ovaries), pancreatitis (inflammation of the pancreas), deafness. https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/healthlibrary/conditions/infectious_diseases/mumps_in_adults_85,P00639. - Mod.LK]\n\n[A Healthmap/ProMED of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106 and of New York State, United States: at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234]", "summary": "Globally, the World Health Organization has reported 585 315 cases of mumps in the present year through [13 Feb 2018], distributed as follows: Pacific West 57 percent (335 304), Africa 17 percent (100 576), East Mediterranean 13 percent (75 680), Southeast Asia 5 percent (31 739), Europe 4 percent (20 874) and the Americas 3 percent (21 142). LK]\n\n[A Healthmap/ProMED of Mexico can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14]\n\n******\n \n\n[Byline: Thornton Mcenery]\n\n--\n Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\n \n\nMumps: Why it's seen a resurgence\n Goldman Sachs\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2018\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["4653-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Americas 3 percent", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jalisco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Mediterranean", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5518587", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (36): USA (HI) school", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5518587", "date": "2017-12-21 21:57:15", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (36): USA (HAWAII) SCHOOL\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 19 Dec 2017, 9:04 PM EST\nSource: Hawaii News Now [edited]\nhttp://www.k5thehometeam.com/story/37104694/mumps-outbreak-forces-charter-school-to-start-winter-break-early\n\n\nA total of 5 people have fallen ill with mumps at Kamaile Academy, and there are 2 additional suspect cases, prompting officials to start the school's winter break early and extend it by 5 days. Officials said winter break at the public charter school in Waianae would begin [Tue 19 Dec 2017] and continue through [16 Jan 2018]. The school said starting the winter break 2 days early and extending it by a week 'will allow us to get past the 25-day incubation period' for mumps.\n\nSo far in 2017, there have been 705 confirmed cases of mumps statewide, and 19 people have suffered from complications, the state Health Department reports. The large majority of those who have fallen ill have been on Oahu. 2017's outbreak is by far the largest number of cases Hawaii has seen in decades. In all of 2016, Hawaii saw just 10 total cases of mumps.\n\nTo tackle the growing outbreak of mumps, the state is recommending more people get vaccinated, even if they've already been vaccinated before. While mumps spreads easily, it's mostly preventable with a 2-dose vaccine. However, officials say mumps cases this year have been seen in vaccinated and unvaccinated individuals. Hawaii has seen an influx of mumps cases since March 2017, when the Health Department was made aware of 9 people with the viral infection. Some people with mumps have very mild or no symptoms. The disease is not considered life-threatening, but there are some prominent manifestations, especially the swelling of one or both salivary glands.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wai\u02bbanae is a census-designated place (CDP) in Honolulu County in the USA state of Hawaii.\n\nMy colleague Mod.LK has pointed out the lack of severe symptoms vaccinated individuals experience following infection with mumps in comments in the past that 'even though mumps cases occur even in fully vaccinated children and adults, the occurrence of the more severe complications is relatively rare now, evidence of some protection afforded by the vaccine.' Nonetheless, this is an important point to make frequently as it further supports the MMR vaccine's effectiveness even when full protection does not occur.\n\nOne paper among others that discusses the problem of genetic variation in the SH gene of mumps virus is Echevarr\u00eda JE, Castellanos A, Sanz JC, et al. Mumps Virus Genotyping: Basis and Known Circulating Genotypes. The Open Vaccine Journal, 2010, 3, 37-41 (available at: https://benthamopen.com/contents/pdf/TOVACJ/TOVACJ-3-37.pdf. Although the 12 genotypes of mumps virus currently recognized by the WHO are considered to be the same serotype, lack of full cross-protection between different genotypes has been reported and has been suggested as a cause of vaccine failure. However, other reports did not find this lack of cross reaction among different genotypes.\n\nJeryl-Lynn and Rubini vaccine strains belong to genotype A which is genetically distant from the other genotypes. Wild strains belonging to the A genotype used to be dominant before vaccination, but nowadays most MV wild strains belong to other genotypes. The genetic distance between genotype A vaccine strains and non-A wild strains has been proposed to be a determinant factor in vaccine failure. On the other hand, non-A vaccines have been more frequently associated with post vaccination meningitis and are considered less safe. Additional studies are needed to obtain a better balance between efficiency and safety in order to establish the best future strategy for achieving optimal vaccine efficacy. Data from neutralization experiments are still unclear. Another similar paper is Gouma S, Ten Hulscher HI, Schurink-van 't Klooster TM, et al. 2016. Mumps-specific cross-neutralization by MMR vaccine-induced antibodies predicts protection against mumps virus infection. Vaccine 2016, 34(35):4166 (abstract available at: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=27372154).\n\nRecent mumps outbreaks have been dominated by mumps genotype G virus strains, whereas the Jeryl Lynn mumps strain of the MMR vaccine belongs to genotype A. It has been shown previously that vaccinated persons develop sufficient neutralizing antibodies against wild type mumps genotype G virus, although the neutralization capacity is lower against the wild type strain as compared with the vaccine strain. However, no correlate of protection has been defined so far that distinguishes MMR vaccinated persons with sufficient immunological protection from those who are not protected against mumps virus infection. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nHawaii, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/214.]", "summary": "\n\nRecent mumps outbreaks have been dominated by mumps genotype G virus strains, whereas the Jeryl Lynn mumps strain of the MMR vaccine belongs to genotype A. It has been shown previously that vaccinated persons develop sufficient neutralizing antibodies against wild type mumps genotype G virus, although the neutralization capacity is lower against the wild type strain as compared with the vaccine strain. LK has pointed out the lack of severe symptoms vaccinated individuals experience following infection with mumps in comments in the past that 'even though mumps cases occur even in fully vaccinated children and adults, the occurrence of the more severe complications is relatively rare now, evidence of some protection afforded by the vaccine.' Mumps-specific cross-neutralization by MMR vaccine-induced antibodies predicts protection against mumps virus infection. Although the 12 genotypes of mumps virus currently recognized by the WHO are considered to be the same serotype, lack of full cross-protection between different genotypes has been reported and has been suggested as a cause of vaccine failure. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n A total of 5 people have fallen ill with mumps at Kamaile Academy, and there are 2 additional suspect cases, prompting officials to start the school's winter break early and extend it by 5 days. \n\nSo far in 2017, there have been 705 confirmed cases of mumps statewide, and 19 people have suffered from complications, the state Health Department reports. However, no correlate of protection has been defined so far that distinguishes MMR vaccinated persons with sufficient immunological protection from those who are not protected against mumps virus infection. \n\nTo tackle the growing outbreak of mumps, the state is recommending more people get vaccinated, even if they've already been vaccinated before. The genetic distance between genotype A vaccine strains and non-A wild strains has been proposed to be a determinant factor in vaccine failure. MUMPS UPDATE (36): USA (HAWAII) SCHOOL\n**************************************\n Hawaii has seen an influx of mumps cases since March 2017, when the Health Department was made aware of 9 people with the viral infection.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2036-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-01-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Echevarr\u00eda JE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Honolulu County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5704564", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (02): USA (VA,DE) resurgence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5704564", "date": "2018-03-23 12:09:07", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (02): USA (VIRGINIA, DELAWARE) RESURGENCE\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Virginia (James Madison University)\n[2] Delaware (Wilmington)\n[3] Resurgence\n\n******\n[1] Virginia (James Madison University)\nDate: Tue 20 Mar 2018 8:35 AM EDT\nSource: NBC News, Virginia department of Health release [edited]\nhttp://www.nbc29.com/story/37764477/health-officials-investigating-mumps-outbreak-at-james-madison-university\n\n\nThe Harrisonburg-Rockingham Health Department continues to investigate an ongoing mumps outbreak at James Madison University (JMU).\n\nTo date, mumps infections have been confirmed by lab testing in 5 staff members and 14 students. Lab results are currently pending for 3 additional students. The health department also is investigating several additional cases in the region that are apparently unrelated to JMU.\n\nMumps is an acute viral disease that is transmitted from person to person through direct contact with respiratory droplets spread by coughing and sneezing, or through contact with saliva from an ill person. Persons with mumps may have body aches, fever and swollen glands in the jaw. Most people recover from the illness in a week, but serious complications are possible.\n\nTo protect yourself from diseases like mumps that are spread through droplet contact, wash your hands frequently, cover your nose or mouth when you cough or sneeze and avoid droplet contact with people who are ill. Don't share cups or utensils and avoid close contact with people who are ill.\n\nThe health department is advising students and community members to review their immunization status and contact their health care provider to receive vaccine as needed. The measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine (MMR) is usually given when a child is 1 year old and again between the ages of 4 and 6 years. The mumps vaccine is 88 per cent effective in people who receive 2 doses, but some fully immunized individuals may still develop mumps. A 3rd dose of MMR vaccine may be recommended for individuals at high risk for infection due to close contact with someone who has mumps.\n\nPeople exposed to mumps may not show symptoms for 12-25 days, but infected individuals are able to transmit the infection to others up to 2 days before symptoms appear. If you have mumps-like symptoms or questions about your mumps immunizations, contact your health care provider. The health department and JMU will provide additional updates as new information becomes available or recommendations arise.\n\nFor more information about mumps, see http://www.vdh.virginia.gov/epidemiology/epidemiology-fact-sheets/mumps.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nHarrisonburg, Rockingham county, Virginia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9191\nVirginia county map: http://geology.com/county-map/virginia-county-map.gif]\n\n******\n[2] Delaware (Wilmington)\nDate: Wed 21 Mar 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/delaware-mumps-outbreak-associated-wilmington-dance-97963/\n\n\nThe Delaware Division of Public Health (DPH) reports as of [Tue 21 Mar] there are 3 known cases of mumps (1 confirmed and 2 probable cases) with a 4th case being investigated. The 3 cases identified so far are all known to have attended a social dance (Baile Mexicano or Mexican Dance) that took place at the Chase Center on the Riverfront in Wilmington on 10 Feb 2018.\n\nDPH is advising health providers to offer MMR vaccination to persons who report attending the Baile Mexicano dance as long as there are no contraindications.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nWilmington, Delaware: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10202]\n\n******\n[3] Resurgence\nDate: Wed 21 Mar 2018\nSource: ScienceDaily, Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health [edited]\nhttps://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/03/180321141401.htm\n\n\nMumps resurgence likely due to waning vaccine-derived immunity\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nSummary\n-------\nA resurgence of mumps in the US among vaccinated young adults appears to be due to waning of vaccine-induced immunity, according to a recent analysis. Researchers found vaccine-derived immune protection against mumps lasts about 27 years after the last dose. The findings suggest that, in addition to the currently recommended 2 doses of mumps vaccine in childhood, a 3rd dose at age 18 may help sustain protection among adults. The study [was] published 21 Mar 2018, in Science Translational Medicine [reference and press release cited below].\n\n'This analysis helps address a persistent question surrounding the recent mumps outbreaks, pointing to the key role played by waning vaccine induced immunity, and helps frame the research and policy questions on how best to control mumps,' said Yonatan Grad, assistant professor of immunology and infectious diseases at Harvard Chan School, who co-authored the study with Joseph Lewnard, postdoctoral research fellow at Harvard Chan School's Center for Communicable Disease Dynamics.\n\nAfter the mumps vaccine was introduced in the mid-1960s, mumps incidence in the US and other developed countries declined for decades. After recommendations for children to receive a second vaccine dose were issued in 1989, sustained reductions in mumps incidence led to optimism that vaccination could eliminate the disease from the US in the long term.\n\nBut recent mumps outbreaks, including on college campuses, began occurring among vaccinated young adults around 2006 and have continued to the present. The resurgence is troubling, the authors wrote, because mumps infections may cause complications such as testicular inflammation (which may result in infertility), meningitis, and deafness. Since cases have predominantly occurred in vaccinated populations, the mumps resurgence has prompted questions about what's to blame -- either waning immune protection from the mumps vaccine or new strains of the mumps that evade vaccine-driven protection.\n\nIn the new study, Harvard Chan School researchers pooled and analyzed data from six epidemiological studies of mumps vaccine effectiveness conducted over past decades in the US and Europe. The researchers estimated that 25 per cent of people in the US vaccinated against mumps may lose protection within 7.9 years, 50 per cent within 19 years, and 75 per cent within 38 years. Linking data from these studies to a mathematical model of mumps transmission, the researchers determined that waning immunity has played a central role not only in the recent re-emergence of mumps cases among young adults, but also in outbreaks that occurred in the late 1980s among adolescents who had received only one dose under earlier recommendations.\n\nIn contrast, the researchers found no evidence that new strains of mumps virus are contributing to changes in vaccine effectiveness. Moreover, their model suggested that new strains would not be expected to cause cases in age groups affected by recent outbreaks.\n\n'Vaccination is the centerpiece of current public health strategy against mumps,' said Lewnard. 'Knowing that protection wanes in the long term can help inform how we deploy vaccines to prevent or contain future outbreaks.'\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Lewnard JA, Grad YH. Vaccine waning and mumps re-emergence in the United States. Sci Transl Med. 2018; 10(433). pii: eaao5945. doi: 10.1126/scitranslmed.aao5945; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29563321\n2. Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health. Mumps resurgence likely due to waning vaccine-derived immunity. ScienceDaily. 21 Mar 2018. http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/03/180321141401.htm\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Please also see:\nhttps://www.cnn.com/2018/03/21/health/mumps-vaccine-study/index.html and https://www.webmd.com/vaccines/news/20180321/waning-vaccine-protection-may-be-driving-rise-in-us-mumps-cases.\n\nEarlier this year [2018] the MMWR published recommendations for a third dose of mumps vaccine for those at particular risk of infection [reference below: subsequent numbered references can be found along with the full report at the URL below]: 'A substantial increase in the number of mumps outbreaks and outbreak-associated cases has occurred in the United States since late 2015 (1,2). To address this public health problem, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) reviewed the available evidence and determined that a third dose of measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine is safe and effective at preventing mumps. During its October 2017 meeting, ACIP recommended a 3rd dose of a mumps virus-containing vaccine for persons previously vaccinated with 2 doses who are identified by public health authorities as being part of a group or population at increased risk for acquiring mumps because of an outbreak. The purpose of the recommendation is to improve protection of persons in outbreak settings against mumps disease and mumps-related complications. This recommendation supplements the existing ACIP recommendations for mumps vaccination (3).'\n\nMarin M, Marlow M, Moore KL, Patel M. Recommendation of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices for use of a third dose of mumps virus-containing vaccine in persons at increased risk for mumps during an outbreak. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2018; 67(1): 33-8. doi: 10.15585/mmwr.mm6701a7. Available at https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/67/wr/mm6701a7.htm.\n\n- Mod.LK", "summary": "\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nWilmington, Delaware: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10202]\n\n******\n For more information about mumps, see http://www.vdh.virginia.gov/epidemiology/epidemiology-fact-sheets/mumps.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map\n Since cases have predominantly occurred in vaccinated populations, the mumps resurgence has prompted questions about what's to blame -- either waning immune protection from the mumps vaccine or new strains of the mumps that evade vaccine-driven protection. \n\nEarlier this year [2018] the MMWR published recommendations for a third dose of mumps vaccine for those at particular risk of infection [reference below: subsequent numbered references can be found along with the full report at the URL below]: 'A substantial increase in the number of mumps outbreaks and outbreak-associated cases has occurred in the United States since late 2015 (1,2). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'This analysis helps address a persistent question surrounding the recent mumps outbreaks, pointing to the key role played by waning vaccine induced immunity, and helps frame the research and policy questions on how best to control mumps,' said Yonatan Grad, assistant professor of immunology and infectious diseases at Harvard Chan School, who co-authored the study with Joseph Lewnard, postdoctoral research fellow at Harvard Chan School's Center for Communicable Disease Dynamics. During its October 2017 meeting, ACIP recommended a 3rd dose of a mumps virus-containing vaccine for persons previously vaccinated with 2 doses who are identified by public health authorities as being part of a group or population at increased risk for acquiring mumps because of an outbreak. Linking data from these studies to a mathematical model of mumps transmission, the researchers determined that waning immunity has played a central role not only in the recent re-emergence of mumps cases among young adults, but also in outbreaks that occurred in the late 1980s among adolescents who had received only one dose under earlier recommendations. \n\nMarin M, Marlow M, Moore KL, Patel M. Recommendation of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices for use of a third dose of mumps virus-containing vaccine in persons at increased risk for mumps during an outbreak. http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/03/180321141401.htm\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n To address this public health problem, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) reviewed the available evidence and determined that a third dose of measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine is safe and effective at preventing mumps. \n\nAfter the mumps vaccine was introduced in the mid-1960s, mumps incidence in the US and other developed countries declined for decades. The mumps vaccine is 88 per cent effective in people who receive 2 doses, but some fully immunized individuals may still develop mumps. MUMPS UPDATE (02): USA (VIRGINIA, DELAWARE) RESURGENCE\n******************************************************\n \n\n\nMumps resurgence likely due to waning vaccine-derived immunity\n If you have mumps-like symptoms or questions about your mumps immunizations, contact your health care provider. \n\nTo protect yourself from diseases like mumps that are spread through droplet contact, wash your hands frequently, cover your nose or mouth when you cough or sneeze and avoid droplet contact with people who are ill. \n\nIn contrast, the researchers found no evidence that new strains of mumps virus are contributing to changes in vaccine effectiveness. The purpose of the recommendation is to improve protection of persons in outbreak settings against mumps disease and mumps-related complications. Harrisonburg, Rockingham county, Virginia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9191\nVirginia county map: http://geology.com/county-map/virginia-county-map.gif]\n\n******\n \n\nMumps is an acute viral disease that is transmitted from person to person through direct contact with respiratory droplets spread by coughing and sneezing, or through contact with saliva from an ill person. The findings suggest that, in addition to the currently recommended 2 doses of mumps vaccine in childhood, a 3rd dose at age 18 may help sustain protection among adults. \n\nPeople exposed to mumps may not show symptoms for 12-25 days, but infected individuals are able to transmit the infection to others up to 2 days before symptoms appear. \n\n\nThe Delaware Division of Public Health (DPH) reports as of [Tue 21 Mar] there are 3 known cases of mumps (1 confirmed and 2 probable cases) with a 4th case being investigated. A resurgence of mumps in the US among vaccinated young adults appears to be due to waning of vaccine-induced immunity, according to a recent analysis. After recommendations for children to receive a second vaccine dose were issued in 1989, sustained reductions in mumps incidence led to optimism that vaccination could eliminate the disease from the US in the long term.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-10-25 00:00:00", "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "1989-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rockingham county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "resurgence", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VIRGINIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Harrisonburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DELAWARE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wilmington", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5770504", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (03): Mexico, USA (DE, VA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5770504", "date": "2018-04-27 11:46:59", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (03): MEXICO, USA (DELAWARE, VIRGINIA)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Mexico\n[2] USA (Delaware)\n[3] USA (Virginia, William and Mary College)\n\n******\n[1] Mexico\nDate: Tue 24 Apr 2018\nSource: Excelsior [Google translated, edited]\nhttp://www.excelsior.com.mx/comunidad/advierten-sobre-brote-de-paperas-en-escuelas-de-la-cdmx/1234552\n\n\nA mumps outbreak is latent in universities in 7 states of the country. The outbreaks of greater risk have been located in student centers of the capital of the country, Sonora and Chihuahua.\n\nThe General Directorate of Epidemiology issued an epidemiological alert for the spread of cases of infectious parotitis in the country, which has mainly affected the student population.\n\nAccording to the epidemiological bulletin at week 16 of 2018, 2619 cases of infectious parotitis, known as mumps, have been reported.\n\nThe states with the highest number of cases are: Tamaulipas with 561, Nuevo Le\u00f3n with 302, Quintana Roo with 203, Jalisco with 189 and Chihuahua with 167.\n\nSince the beginning of 2018, cases and outbreaks of the disease have been reported in the United States.\n\nThe Ministry of Health emphasized that it was identified as affecting mainly university residents of the US center in Mexico.\n\nThe age groups most affected nationwide are adults aged 25-44 years, with 805, followed by the group of 20-24 years with 531 and children aged 5-9 years, with 388.\n\n[Byline: Ximena Mej\u00eda]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail of Mexico can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14.]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Delaware, New Castle County)\nDate: Tue 17 Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/delaware-reports-additional-mumps-cases-outbreak-total-now-15-74934/\n\n\nIn a follow-up on the mumps outbreak in New Castle County, Delaware, The Delaware Division of Public Health (DPH) is confirming 2 additional cases of the mumps as part of its ongoing investigation of an outbreak among attendees at 2 multi-cultural dances in New Castle County. This brings the total number of mumps cases to 15.\n\nAll of the individuals infected with mumps reside in New Castle County.\n\nNine of the 15 persons with mumps attended either the 10 Feb or 3 Mar 2018 social dance (Baile Mejicano) that took place at the Chase Center on the Riverfront in Wilmington. Two of the remaining 4 individuals live with someone who attended one of the dances, and the source of the mumps virus exposure for the remaining 4 individuals is still under investigation.\n\nMumps is an acute viral infection spread through saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat. An infected person can spread the virus by coughing, sneezing, talking, sharing items such as cups or eating utensils with others, and touching objects or surfaces with unwashed hands that are then touched by others.\n\nSymptoms typically start with a few days of fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, followed by swollen salivary glands, which results in puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw. Symptoms typically appear 16-18 days after infection, but can range from 12-25 days after infection. Some people with mumps may not have any symptoms. Most people with mumps recover completely in a few weeks. However, mumps can occasionally cause complications, especially in adults.\n\nPeople known or suspected to have mumps should stay away from school or work until 5 days after the onset of swollen salivary glands as there is no specific treatment for mumps.\n\nThe CDC recommends children get 2 doses of MMR vaccine, starting with the 1st dose at 12-15 months of age and the 2nd dose at 4-6 years of age. Teens and adults who did not get the recommended MMR vaccines per the above schedule should be vaccinated so they are up to date. During outbreaks, CDC also recommends that those at highest risk due to exposure to people with mumps should receive a 3rd dose of MMR.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 25 Apr 2018, cases number 19. All 19 individuals reside in New Castle County. The age ranges of adults with the mumps virus are 21-57 years old. Additionally, there was one child under the age of 5 infected. According to the Delaware News https://news.delaware.gov/2018/04/24/four-mumps-cases-identified-bringing-total-19/, this is the 1st time that more than 3 mumps cases have been recorded during any calendar year since at least 2005. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106 and Delaware, United States at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/211.]\n\n******\n[3] Virginia, William and Mary College\nDate: Wed 25 Apr 2018\nSource: The Virginia Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.vagazette.com/news/va-vg-wm-mumps-20180428-story.html\n\n\nThere has been a case of reported mumps at the College of William and Mary.\n\nThe announcement was sent out in an email by Virginia Wells, director of the student health center at William and Mary, and Virginia Ambler, vice president of student affairs, on 24 Apr 2018. The email said the Peninsula Health District identified a case of mumps, and the student has since been isolated. Larry Hill, a spokesman for the Peninsula Health District, said they are working with the college on this case. ...\n\nWells said in her email people known to have had contact with the sick student have been notified, but since college campuses are a close and compact environment, it's possible other students may have been exposed.\n\nIn Wells and Ambler's email, they recommended students to review their immunization status and contact their doctor to receive the vaccine as needed. This vaccine is usually to children at age 12 months and again between the ages of 4-6 years and is 88% effective in persons having received 2 doses. So, someone who received a full immunization may still develop mumps.\n\nThe Virginia Department of Health said people who are exposed to mumps may not show symptoms for 12-25 days, and those infected can transmit mumps to others 2 days before symptoms appear. The email from Wells and Ambler suggested contacting your doctor and self-isolating until your doctor directs otherwise if you begin to have mumps-like symptoms.\n\n'The university has taken all appropriate and recommended steps, including sharing this information with the campus community,' the email said. 'We will provide additional updates or recommendations if needed.'\n\nUpdate April 26\n----------\nA new announcement from Wells and Ambler said more cases of mumps have been reported on campus. The students who contracted the virus have been isolated, as with the 1st case.\n\nWhile Hill said Peninsula Health could not release the exact number of students who contracted mumps, there were several cases reported.\n\n[Byline: Amelia Heymann]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nVirginia, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/247]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe Virginia Department of Health said people who are exposed to mumps may not show symptoms for 12-25 days, and those infected can transmit mumps to others 2 days before symptoms appear. \n\nThe age groups most affected nationwide are adults aged 25-44 years, with 805, followed by the group of 20-24 years with 531 and children aged 5-9 years, with 388.\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail of Mexico can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14.] \n\nPeople known or suspected to have mumps should stay away from school or work until 5 days after the onset of swollen salivary glands as there is no specific treatment for mumps. and university students across the state. Outbreaks have been identified in 2 institutes of higher education in the state. Please contact VDH to report cases that may be associated with these outbreaks.\n\nDescription:\nThe Virginia Department of Health and the Central Shenandoah and Peninsula Health Districts are investigating 2 outbreaks of mumps at James Madison University in Harrisonburg, VA and the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, VA. Cases are occurring primarily in the student population, though additional cases have been identified among faculty and local community members. Other cases of mumps have been identified across the state that may be linked to these outbreaks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[One can find a summary of mumps Fri 18 May 2018\nSource: Otago Daily Times [edited]\nhttps://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/otago-mumps-outbreak-cant-be-contained\n\n\nMumps cases in Otago have spread to the point where Public Health South is now working to manage the infectious disease, rather than contain it.\n\nThe outbreak is believed to follow outbreaks in Auckland and parts of the Pacific.\n\nSince late 2016, there have been more than 1662 'probable or confirmed' cases of mumps notified nationwide, and Public Health South has recorded an increase in cases in Dunedin, Oamaru and Queenstown.\n\nAs a result, Medical Officer of Health Dr Keith Reid said the organisation had moved to a 'manage it' phase.\n\n'This means that there are now too many local people with mumps for case-by-case investigations to control the outbreak, and efforts will focus on vaccinating populations at risk.'\n\nThe MMR vaccine is free and is available from general practices and student health centres.\n\nFrom 1 Jan 2017, to yesterday [Thu 17 May 2018], 195 cases of mumps were notified in Otago, 90 of those were confirmed, he said.\n\n'Many of the Dunedin cases are connected to the University of Otago and associated with student travel to areas affected by mumps outbreaks.\n\n'Cases in Oamaru are associated with travel to overseas areas affected by mumps outbreaks and by subsequent local transmission within a school community.\n\n'Queenstown cases have been connected to several workplaces and travelers.'\n\nContact tracing will now be patient-led and Public Health South has developed a range of resources to support clinicians and patients with their diagnosis and management.\n\n[Byline: John Lewis]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap/ProMED of New Zealand can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap/ProMED of United States can be found at Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n'Many of the Dunedin cases are connected to the University of Otago and associated with student travel to areas affected by mumps outbreaks. From 1 Jan -- 21 Apr 2018, 45 states and the District of Columbia in the U.S. reported mumps infections in 923 people to CDC [but the case number is likely higher since mumps outbreaks are not reportable.] \n\n--\n [Byline: John Lewis]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-01-01 00:00:00", "2017-01-01 00:00:00", "2018-05-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NEW ZEALAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Auckland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ILLINOIS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Williamsburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queenstown", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VIRGINIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Harrisonburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Otago", "country": "unknown"}, "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5638266", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update: USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5638266", "date": "2018-02-20 12:30:01", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE: USA\n*****************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Alaska (Anchorage)\n[2] Alaska (Juneau)\n[3] Vermont (Burlington)\n[4] Texas: prison outbreaks\n\n******\n[1] Alaska (Anchorage)\nDate: Thu 15 Feb 2018 AKST\nSource: KTUU [edited]\nhttp://www.ktuu.com/content/news/Mumps-outbreak-in-Anchorage-now-over-200-confirmed-cases-474227083.html\n\n\nAccording to the Department of Health and Human Services, there are 215 confirmed cases and 33 probable cases [of mumps in Anchorage].\n\nAn epidemiologist for the state of Alaska says since 2012, it's seen a 98.7 percent increase in cases. 'We are definitely concerned.' Dr Amanda Tiffany said [Wed 14 Feb 2018]. 'In the 5 years prior to 2017 when our outbreak began, Alaska saw 3 mumps cases, so the fact that we are now reporting 248 cases is concerning.'\n\nMost of those cases during those years were travel-related but now, according to Dr Tiffany, the virus is successfully spreading because people have either developed a waning immunity to vaccinations or aren't vaccinated.\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the mumps component of the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine is about 88 percent effective. This means out of 100 people who are vaccinated, 12 people are still going to get mumps, and while mumps outbreaks aren't new in Alaska, Dr Tiffany believes people are vulnerable. 'Historically, when you have really high vaccination coverage, it's not such an issue to have a waning immunity and low vaccine effectiveness.' The epidemiologist added, 'but we do have people who are not being vaccinated, we are having many outbreaks, and people are being infected.'\n\nIt's important to note that the CDC says that Mumps outbreaks still happen even in highly vaccinated communities, however, 'high vaccination coverage helps to limit the size, duration, and spread of mumps outbreaks.'\n\nFor now, Dr Amanda Tiffany is helping spread the word to combat a disease that can be avoided. 'There are people when I speak with them and tell them about the mumps outbreak, they just look at me with a blank face.' Dr Tiffany said. 'Oh really mumps, that's a thing?'\n\nThe state now recommends a 3rd dose of the MMR vaccine for Anchorage residents who want additional protection against mumps if it has been 5 years since the 2nd dose or if the resident believes they are vulnerable.\n\n[Byline: Juan Montes]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This nearly doubles the number of cases reported in ProMED Mumps update (37): USA, New Zealand 20171230.5528344 on 29 Dec 2017, that is, 119 cases of the disease, with another 19 classified as 'probable'. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nAlaska: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/206]\n\n******\n[2] Alaska (Juneau)\nDate: Sun 18 Feb 2018\nSource: Juneau Empire [edited]\nhttp://juneauempire.com/local/news/2018-02-16/mumps-confirmed-juneau-first-time-20-years\n\n\nAs of Thu [15 Feb 2018], there has been one confirmed case of the disease in Juneau and 3 possible cases, said Alison Gaines, the nurse manager at the Juneau Public Health Center. The 1st case was diagnosed in January [2018], with the most recent suspected one springing up this past week, she said.\n\nAmanda Tiffany, an epidemiologist at the Alaska Division of Public Health, said this is the 1st confirmed case of mumps in Juneau since 1997.\n\nMumps is a contagious disease that causes swelling in a person's salivary glands. Other symptoms include fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue, and loss of appetite. The disease is almost never fatal and long-term effects are relatively rare. Mumps can cause some hearing loss, Tiffany said, as well as inflammation of the brain, brain membrane, testicles, or ovaries.\n\nThe main problem for people who have mumps, Tiffany said, is the pain that comes with the salivary gland swelling.\n\n'I think the perception is that mumps is not such a big deal, like, 'Well, you have it and then it goes away,' but if you speak with anyone who had it, they were miserable,' Tiffany said.\n\nStarting in the summer of 2017, though, an outbreak began in Anchorage. There have been 247 [now 248 -- see [1] above] cases statewide (now 215 confirmed and 33 probable) since May of 2017, Tiffany said, with 96 percent of them being in Anchorage. The most recent large outbreak was in 1995, when there were 10 confirmed cases in Kodiak, Tiffany said.\n\nThe sole confirmed case in Juneau, Gaines said, was in a person who had recently traveled to Anchorage.\n\n'There's no way to know 100 percent,' Gaines said of whether the patient contracted mumps in Anchorage, 'but there is a link there.'\n\nThe common MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) vaccination prevents mumps, and Tiffany said more than 91 percent of Alaskans aged 13-17 are up to date on their MMR vaccination. Tiffany said if people don't know whether they're vaccinated, they should call their health care provider.\n\nThis past [Mon 12 Feb 2018], the Department of Public Health sent a notice to the Juneau School District and to licensed daycares in town alerting them to the recent outbreak. Early symptoms are similar to that of a regular cold, but those who believe they have mumps should call their doctor and set up an appointment, Tiffany said. Physicians will likely advise people to isolate themselves for the 5 days after facial swelling starts.\n\n'We're trying hard to track cases and stop the spread,' Gaines said, 'and the easiest way to do that is to know the cases we have in town.'\n\n[Byline: Alex McCarthy]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Vermont (Burlington)\nDate: Fri 16 Feb 2018 5:08 PM EST\nSource: NBC 5, WPTZ/WNNE US [edited]\nhttp://www.mynbc5.com/article/mumps-outbreak-reported-at-st-michaels-college-uvm/18212508\n\n\nThe Vermont Heath Department has announced an outbreak of mumps at 2 Burlington colleges.\n\nOfficials said several students at The University of Vermont [UVM] and St Michael's College have been diagnosed with mumps.\n\nThe number of cases remains small.\n\nThe Health Department said it conducted 2 vaccination clinics this week [week of 12 Feb 2018] for students. About 450 doses of the MMR vaccine were administered. Vaccination clinics are planned for next week for students who live in 3 UVM dorms.\n\nParents of children who attend daycare centers on the UVM campus have been notified about the outbreak.\n\nSo far, no cases of mumps have been identified there.\n\n'Mumps may be spread through close contact, but some people who get it have very mild or no symptoms. Often, they may not know they have the disease,' deputy state epidemiologist Laura Ann Nicolai said. 'In a college setting, with shared space of dorms and classrooms, it's possible to be exposed to the virus through encounters with people who don't realize they're infected.'\n\nMumps is a contagious illness caused by a virus that can be spread through close person-to-person contact, such as coughing, sneezing, or sharing drinking glasses. The virus causes fever, swelling of the parotid glands, and can affect other parts of the body. Symptoms typically appear 16-18 days after infection, but can occur up to 25 days later. They include fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue, loss of appetite, and tenderness under the ears on one or both sides. There is no cure for mumps. Treatment involves bed rest, staying hydrated, and fever reduction.\n\nMost people who are ill with the virus recover completely in a few weeks.\n\n[Byline: Brad Evans]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[UVM requires proof of MMR vaccination, a 2-dose vaccine most commonly received before the age of 6, for enrolling undergraduate students, according to the UVM Center for Health and Wellbeing. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nBurlington, Vermont, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2472]\n\n******\n[4] Texas: prison outbreaks\nDate: Sun 18 Feb 2018 11:45\nSource: LMT online [edited]\nhttps://www.lmtonline.com/news/local/article/Possible-mumps-outbreak-shuts-part-of-two-Texas-12623799.php?utm_campaign=hptexas\n\n\nAnother possible mumps outbreak shut down visitation over the weekend [17-18 Feb 2018] for some parts of 2 Texas prisons.\n\nA stomach bug affected visiting at 3 other facilities, though Texas Department of Criminal Justice [TDCJ] spokesman Jason Clark said a 'relatively small number' of prisoners are affected.\n\nThe Beto Unit in Tennessee Colony [Anderson county] and the Segovia Unit in Edinburg [Hidalgo county] are both dealing with the possibility of mumps, while the McConnell [Bee county], Ellis [Walker county], and Terrell [Brazoria county] units are all grappling with gastrointestinal illnesses, Clark said.\n\nA number of mumps cases surfaced in early 2017 in Texas, and the disease made its way into the prison system around April, hitting Willacy County State Jail north of Brownsville and the nearby Lopez State Jail in Edinburg, according to TDCJ.\n\nAt one point last year [2017], roughly 10 inmates had confirmed cases, Clark said. But then the illness receded only to re-emerge in November at Willacy. Dozens of inmates went on medical lockdown there and also at Stringfellow Unit in Brazoria county after one symptomatic prisoner was transferred between the 2 units.\n\n'Mumps has been pretty prevalent down in South Texas,' Clark said at the time. 'And what you see in the community often makes its way into the prison system.'\n\nInmates with confirmed cases are put in isolation cells, while any inmates who may have been exposed are put on medical restriction.\n\nTDCJ offers vaccines for incoming inmates born after 1957, but the recent outbreaks come amid a nationwide uptick.\n\n'This is a vaccine-preventable disease,' said Dr Robert Atmar, professor and interim chief of infectious diseases at Baylor College of Medicine, 'and the thought is ... that immunity is waning and a lot of the people who've been affected in these outbreaks have been persons who have had a number of years since they've had a mumps vaccine.'\n\n[Byline: Keri Blakinger]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nTexas: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245\nTexas county map: http://geology.com/county-map/texas-county-map.gif\n\n[From 1-27 Jan 2018, 25 states in the US reported mumps infections in 130 people to CDC. The case numbers have increased since 27 Jan 2018, as 248 cases have been reported in Alaska -- see [1] above.\n\nMumps outbreaks can occur any time of year. A major factor contributing to outbreaks is being in a crowded environment, such as attending the same class, playing on the same sports team, or living in a dormitory with a person who has mumps [such as in colleges, prisons]. Also, certain behaviors that result in exchanging saliva, such as kissing or sharing utensils, cups, lip balm, or cigarettes, might increase spread of the virus. In some years, there are more cases of mumps than usual because of outbreaks.\n\nMumps outbreaks can still occur in highly vaccinated US communities, particularly in close-contact settings. However, high vaccination coverage helps limit the size, duration, and spread of mumps outbreaks. MMR vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. 2 doses of the vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective at protecting against mumps; 1 dose is 78 percent (range: 49-92 percent) effective. Studies have shown that the MMR vaccine protects against currently circulating mumps strains.\n\nIn 2016 and 2017, outbreaks ranged in size from a few to several hundred cases, have mostly affected young adults, and are likely due to a combination of factors. These factors include the known effectiveness of the vaccine, waning immunity following vaccination, and the intensity of exposure to the virus in close-contact settings (such as a college campus) coupled with behaviors that increase the risk of transmission.\n\n(Excerpted and edited from https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html See URL for a map showing distribution of mumps cases in the US and a figure with cases by year.) - Mod.LK]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nTexas: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245\nTexas county map: http://geology.com/county-map/texas-county-map.gif\n\n[From 1-27 Jan 2018, 25 states in the US reported mumps infections in 130 people to CDC. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This nearly doubles the number of cases reported in ProMED Mumps update (37): USA, New Zealand 20171230.5528344 on 29 Dec 2017, that is, 119 cases of the disease, with another 19 classified as 'probable'. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nBurlington, Vermont, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2472]\n\n******\n \n\n'This is a vaccine-preventable disease,' said Dr Robert Atmar, professor and interim chief of infectious diseases at Baylor College of Medicine, 'and the thought is ... that immunity is waning and a lot of the people who've been affected in these outbreaks have been persons who have had a number of years since they've had a mumps vaccine.' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[UVM requires proof of MMR vaccination, a 2-dose vaccine most commonly received before the age of 6, for enrolling undergraduate students, according to the UVM Center for Health and Wellbeing. - Mod. \n\nIt's important to note that the CDC says that Mumps outbreaks still happen even in highly vaccinated communities, however, 'high vaccination coverage helps to limit the size, duration, and spread of mumps outbreaks.' \n\nA number of mumps cases surfaced in early 2017 in Texas, and the disease made its way into the prison system around April, hitting Willacy County State Jail north of Brownsville and the nearby Lopez State Jail in Edinburg, according to TDCJ. \n\n[Byline: Alex McCarthy]\n\n--\n \n\n[Byline: Keri Blakinger]\n\n--\n \n\n(Excerpted and edited from https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html See URL for a map showing distribution of mumps cases in the US and a figure with cases by year.) \n\n'We're trying hard to track cases and stop the spread,' Gaines said, 'and the easiest way to do that is to know the cases we have in town.' This means out of 100 people who are vaccinated, 12 people are still going to get mumps, and while mumps outbreaks aren't new in Alaska, Dr Tiffany believes people are vulnerable. ' \n\nThe main problem for people who have mumps, Tiffany said, is the pain that comes with the salivary gland swelling. \n\nAmanda Tiffany, an epidemiologist at the Alaska Division of Public Health, said this is the 1st confirmed case of mumps in Juneau since 1997. \n\nMumps is a contagious illness caused by a virus that can be spread through close person-to-person contact, such as coughing, sneezing, or sharing drinking glasses. \n\nThe state now recommends a 3rd dose of the MMR vaccine for Anchorage residents who want additional protection against mumps if it has been 5 years since the 2nd dose or if the resident believes they are vulnerable. \n\nMost of those cases during those years were travel-related but now, according to Dr Tiffany, the virus is successfully spreading because people have either developed a waning immunity to vaccinations or aren't vaccinated. The common MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) vaccination prevents mumps, and Tiffany said more than 91 percent of Alaskans aged 13-17 are up to date on their MMR vaccination. \n\nMumps outbreaks can still occur in highly vaccinated US communities, particularly in close-contact settings. \n\n'Mumps may be spread through close contact, but some people who get it have very mild or no symptoms. In the 5 years prior to 2017 when our outbreak began, Alaska saw 3 mumps cases, so the fact that we are now reporting 248 cases is concerning.' \n\nOfficials said several students at The University of Vermont [UVM] and St Michael's College have been diagnosed with mumps. Date: Fri 16 Feb 2018 5:08 PM EST\nSource: NBC 5, WPTZ/WNNE US [edited]\n According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the mumps component of the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine is about 88 percent effective. \n\nA stomach bug affected visiting at 3 other facilities, though Texas Department of Criminal Justice [TDCJ] spokesman Jason Clark said a 'relatively small number' of prisoners are affected. [Byline: Juan Montes]\n\n--\n [Byline: Brad Evans]\n\n--\n \n\nThe Health Department said it conducted 2 vaccination clinics this week \n\nAn epidemiologist for the state of Alaska says since 2012, it's seen a 98.7 percent increase in cases. ' \n\nInmates with confirmed cases are put in isolation cells, while any inmates who may have been exposed are put on medical restriction.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-02-15 00:00:00", "2001-01-27 20:18:00", "2017-05-25 00:00:00", "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-02-18
