"5528344", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (37): USA, New Zealand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5528344", "date": "2017-12-30 10:45:41", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (37): USA, NEW ZEALAND\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Florida\n[2] Alaska\n\nNew Zealand\n---\n[3] North Island (Auckland)\n[4] South Island (Nelson Marlborough)\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] Florida\nDate: Wed 20 Dec 2017 18:59 EST\nSource: Daily Mail [edited]\nhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/article-5200247/Mumps-outbreak-Florida-highest-decade.html\n\n\nThis year's [2017] mumps outbreak is the highest number of reported cases Florida has experienced in the last 5 years combined.\n\nAt least 56 cases of mumps have been reported in the Sunshine State in 2017 across all ages.\n\nHalf of those cases are in patients who have received the MMR vaccination which is meant to prevent measles, mumps and rubella.\n\nThough Florida is experiencing a significant rise in infections, it is well below outbreaks in other states that have seen hundreds of cases of mumps this year [2017]. Health officials estimate that there are about 5000 cases of reported mumps across the US this year.\n\nThe majority of those outbreaks are in Arkansas, Missouri, New York, Washington, and Texas.\n\nIn Florida, most infections were reported in Broward, Collier, Duval, Hillsborough, and Palm Beach counties, according to a Florida Department of Health.\n\nThe 2017 count includes confirmed and probable cases, according to Brad Dalton, a health department spokesman, the Miami Herald reports.\n\nThis is the largest mumps outbreak in Florida in the past decade, though infection rates have been steadily increasing the past couple of years.\n\nIn 2016 there were 16 cases and 2015 there were 10 reported cases, meaning 2017 showed a significant increase.\n\nHealth officials suspect that there are more cases that have gone unreported due to patients experiencing minor to no symptoms. Symptoms typically include swollen glands, puffy cheeks, headaches, fever, chills and fatigue and usually appear about two weeks after being infected.\n\nMumps spreads through contact with infected saliva or mucus, commonly from sharing drinks or eating from the same cutlery.\n\nOutbreaks in Florida have been reported among those in close settings such as roommates or sports teammates.\n\nTreatment for mumps focuses on relieving symptoms until the body's immune system fights off the infection.\n\nThere are currently no medications to treat the mumps virus and it typically takes two weeks to fully recover.\n\nAccording to the CDC, the best way to prevent contracting the infection is to receive the MMR vaccination which is effective 88 percent of the time.\n\n\n[Byline: Kayla Brantley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 1 Jan-2 Dec 2017, 48 states and the District of Columbia in the US reported mumps infections in 4980 people to CDC. Before the US mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to under-reporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States. Since the 2-dose vaccination program was introduced in 1989, mumps cases have ranged year to year from a couple of hundred to several thousand. However, in recent years, there has been an increase in the number of reported cases, from 229 cases in 2012 to 5833 cases in 2016. The recent increase has been mainly due to multiple mumps outbreaks reported across the country in settings where people often have close contact with one another, like college campuses (from https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html, includes a map showing case numbers by state and figure showing cases over time, from 2000-2017, as of 2 Dec 2017).\n\nAlso see ProMED-mail Mumps update (36): USA (HI) school 20171221.5518587 for discussion by Mod.LL on the problem of diminished cross-protection by the vaccine where there is genetic variation in the infecting virus, or infection with a viral genotype that differs from that of the vaccine; recent outbreaks have been caused by genotype G while the MMR vaccine is against virus strains of genotype A.\n- Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nFlorida, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/24558\nFlorida county map: http://geology.com/county-map/florida-county-map.gif]\n\n******\n[2] Alaska (Anchorage)\nDate: Thu 28 Dec 2017 4:31 PM AKST\nSource: KTUU [edited]\nhttp://www.ktuu.com/content/news/Anchorage-mumps-outbreak-reaches-100-state-updates-vaccine-guidelines-467052963.html\n\n\nThe [Alaska] state health department says a mumps outbreak in Anchorage has surpassed 100 confirmed cases, and the department is updating its vaccination recommendations.\n\nThe state has confirmed 119 cases of the disease, with another 19 classified as 'probable.' The state says a booster dose of the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine is the best way to protect yourself, if you haven't received 2 doses of the vaccine already.\n\nThe state now recommends a 2nd dose of the vaccine for school-age children who have only received one dose, and for adults who are at high risk of mumps exposure, like healthcare workers, international travelers, and post-secondary students.\n\nFor people in group settings where mumps is currently circulating, or for Anchorage residents who are Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islanders, the state is recommending a 2nd dose of the vaccine for anyone whose 1st dose was at least 4 weeks ago, and a 3rd dose for anyone whose last round of the vaccine was more than 5 years ago.\n\nThe state says anyone with mumps should self-isolate by staying home and away from public spaces like school and work for 5 days after the onset of swollen glands.\n\nThe symptoms are tender, self-limited swelling of the parotid or other salivary glands lasting more than 2 days without another apparent cause. Headaches and muscle aches are also a sign.\n\nIt's spread by direct contact with respiratory droplets like coughing and sneezing and incubation is between 12 and 25 days. The disease is most contagious between 2 days before swelling, and 5 days afterward.\n\n[Byline: Kortnie Horazdovsky]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nAnchorage, Alaska, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3238]\n\n******\nNew Zealand\n---\n[3] North Island (Auckland)\nDate: Thu 21 Dec 2017 6:12 AM NZDT\nSource: RNZ (Radio New Zealand) [edited]\nhttps://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/346665/mumps-outbreak-now-an-epidemic\n\n\nThe mumps outbreak is an epidemic, say Auckland health leaders, who have asked the Ministry of Health to launch a nationwide vaccination campaign.\n\nThe public health officials say the low immunisation rates are also leaving the city vulnerable to a potentially deadly, large scale measles outbreak.\n\nThey said they were now dealing with an epidemic because the disease can't be contained.\n\nMore than 1000 people have contracted mumps in Auckland this year [2017], most of them from the so called 'lost generation' of 11-29 year olds with low rates of measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccination.\n\nThe chief executives of Auckland, Counties Manukau and Waitemata district health boards [DHBs], and 2 senior Auckland Regional Public Health service officials, wrote to the ministry saying a national response was needed to help slow the disease.\n\nCurrent measures were having little impact, their letter said. It asked for a 'catch-up' campaign for all those who haven't been vaccinated -- most of them adolescents and adults. That was crucial to bringing the outbreak under control and prevent it taking hold nationally, the letter said.\n\nMumps cases have already been reported in Dunedin, Whanganui, Northland, and Hamilton.\n\nIn a statement to RNZ [Radio NZ], Auckland Regional Public Health Service director Julia Peters said the outbreak could now be described as an epidemic because it was widespread and it was not possible to stop its transmission.\n\nThe outbreak was likely to continue for 2 years but with a nationwide vaccination programme the number of cases could be cut by 1/3, she said.\n\nAbout 1.3 million New Zealanders are aged 10-29 and if the estimate that 40 percent are not fully vaccinated is correct, that would mean 570 000 are susceptible to mumps.\n\nThe Ministry of Health said in a statement it would give a response to the DHBs shortly.\n\n[Byline: Rowan Quinn]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nAuckland, New Zealand: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/606]\n\n******\n[4] South Island (Nelson Marlborough)\nDate: Fri 29 Dec 2017 13:18 NZDT\nSource: Stuff, Nelson Mail [edited]\nhttps://www.stuff.co.nz/nelson-mail/news/100243814/Mumps-outbreak-spreads-to-Nelson-Marlborough\n\n\nA suspected case of mumps has health officials warning that the recent outbreak may have spread to the top of the South Island.\n\nPeople who stayed at the Inlet Backpackers in Collingwood on 27 Dec 2017 or Blue Moon Lodge in Havelock on 25 or 26 Dec 2017 may have been exposed to mumps.\n\nThe person with mumps has now been isolated, and people do not need to cancel bookings or alter their holiday plans, but remain alert to the symptoms.\n\nNelson Marlborough Public Health Service locum medical officer of health Dr Simon Baker said early symptoms of mumps included fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite. Later, the salivary glands on one or both sides of the face, cheeks, or jaw may become swollen and sore.\n\n'Should you develop any of these symptoms in the next 2-4 weeks please isolate yourself, and contact a doctor, who will probably call you in to have a swab taken, and give you further advice,' Baker said.\n\n'Immunisation is the best way to protect yourself from mumps, and we recommend you check your child health book or contact your doctor to make sure you have received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine, and are therefore fully immunised.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nNelson, New Zealand: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63530]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nAnchorage, Alaska, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3238]\n\n***** A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nFlorida, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/24558\nFlorida county map: http://geology.com/county-map/florida-county-map.gif]\n\n******\n \n\n'Immunisation is the best way to protect yourself from mumps, and we recommend you check your child health book or contact your doctor to make sure you have received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine, and are therefore fully immunised.'\n\n--\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 1 Jan-2 Dec 2017, 48 states and the District of Columbia in the US reported mumps infections in 4980 people to CDC. "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5464364", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (34): Canada, USA (AK,TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5464364", "date": "2017-11-25 12:13:27", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (34): CANADA, USA (ALASKA, TEXAS)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Canada (Manitoba)\n[2] USA (Alaska, Anchorage)\n[3] USA (Texas, Willacy County)\n\n******\n[1] Canada (Manitoba)\nDate: Tue 21 Nov 2017 09:00 AM\nSource: The Reminder [edited]\nhttp://www.thereminder.ca/news/local-news/mumps-cases-declining-after-record-summer-1.23095244\n\n\nAn outbreak of mumps in northern Manitoba is declining, but infection rates are still abnormally high.\n\nThe rate of reported infections in the region declined in September [2017] after 3 consecutive months when nearly 100 new cases were reported. 'For September, it looked like we had 62 cases in the north, which was down from 97 in August [2017],' said Dr Michael Isaac, chief medical officer for the Northern Health Region (NHR).\n\nIn June, 98 cases of mumps were reported in the region, with another 94 reported in July [2017]. Typically, between 0 and 5 cases are reported to NHR in a year....\n\nThe mumps virus has had a resurgence throughout Manitoba in the past year, with more than 1000 cases being reported in the province since January [2017]. Isaac said the outbreak began in Winnipeg last spring, gradually spreading to other communities from there. Cases have been found among all age groups. The illness is highly contagious and can be spread for as long as 3 weeks during the period of infection.\n\nSymptoms of the disease include headaches, muscle aches, fever and swollen glands around the neck, jaw and chin. Isaac also said the rate of complications arising from mumps cases has decreased during the outbreak, adding that few cases of severe side effects have been reported.\n\nDespite the high number of cases, the NHR reports that northern Manitoba has a higher than average rate of people vaccinated for mumps. Cases of mumps have been reported in people who have previously been vaccinated for the illness.\n\nIsaac said the mumps vaccine, like other immunizations, becomes less effective over time. 'There's no doubt that the length of time after you've had your vaccine can play a part in your immunity. It looks like, for example, people who were vaccinated 25, 30 years ago are likely less [immune] than people who were vaccinated last year,' he said.\n\nSmaller, tight-knit communities are more susceptible to highly contagious illnesses like mumps. 'Once you get a case or 2 in the community, because of that, the spread of the virus is greater,' said Isaac. 'I think the other thing that we have to take into account is, depending on the community, some communities have very high rates of overcrowding in housing stock. Where there's overcrowding - and it's not only mumps, it can be other things like tuberculosis and bacterial infections - there tends to be easier transmission in those environments. I think those 2 things, from a northern perspective, might explain some of the higher numbers we've been seeing.'\n\n[byline: Eric Westhaver]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap/ProMED of Canada can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Alaska, Anchorage)\nDate: Tue 21 Nov 2017\nSource: Daily News-Miner [edited]\nhttp://bit.ly/2hSL46p\n\n\nCases of the mumps are on the rise in Anchorage, according to a health bulletin put out by the Alaska Department of Health and Social Services. The state has identified 62 cases of confirmed, probable and suspected mumps, according to the bulletin. Most live in Anchorage or spent time there. It's the 1st outbreak in 5 years, according to the state health and social services website.\n\nMumps is a viral illness that typically starts with several days of fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue, loss of appetite and swollen salivary glands, the bulletin said. The best way to prevent mumps infection is through vaccination with a measles, mumps and rubella vaccine, commonly known as the MMR. The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is encouraging people in high-risk groups to get at least 3 doses of the MMR vaccine.\n\nGroups at the most risk for contracting mumps include people who participate in a group setting, such as a daycare, work or church, where mumps is circulating, or Anchorage residents who are Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n['As of [Wed 15 Nov 2017], 44 confirmed, 12 probable, and 6 suspect cases [updated numbers above] were identified (see figure at URL below). All 56 confirmed and probable cases were residents of or spent extensive time in Anchorage. Among the 44 confirmed patients, the median age was 24 years (range: 10-68), and 13 (29 per cent) were aged 18 years or over; 36 (82 per cent) self-identified as Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander (NH/PI), 3 (7 per cent) as white, one (2 per cent) as black, and 4 (9 per cent) were of unknown race; and 20 (45 per cent) were female. Two patients have been hospitalized; none have died. Of the 22 (50 per cent) confirmed patients whose vaccination status was known one had 4 doses of MMR, one had 3 doses, 17 had 2 doses, and 3 had one dose. Among patients with 2 or more doses of MMR, the median time from the most recent dose to illness onset was 12 years (range: 4-20 years).\n\n'Discussion\nTo date, this mumps outbreak has disproportionately impacted NH/PI people, who comprise 82 per cent of confirmed cases. For most patients, their infection was epidemiologically linked to a household or a congregate setting (such as work or church) where a case of mumps had been previously identified. While the original source of the outbreak is uncertain, several of the initial patients reported recent travel to or close contact with a person who had recently traveled to a Pacific island where mumps is circulating. Controlling a mumps outbreak requires high levels of herd immunity by vaccination. Because the vaccine is not 100 percent effective, however, many cases occur in fully-vaccinated patients during mumps outbreaks. In the current outbreak, 43 percent of patients had at least 2 doses of MMR. Moreover, waning immunity to the mumps component of the MMR vaccine contributes to mumps transmission. In this outbreak, a median of 12 years passed since receiving a 2nd dose among patients who had received 2 doses of MMR.\n\n'On [Wed 25 Oct 2017], ACIP recommended that persons previously vaccinated with 2 doses of MMR who are identified by public health as being at high-risk for mumps during an outbreak should receive a 3rd dose of MMR. Based on this ACIP recommendation and the pattern of disease in the Anchorage outbreak, a 3rd dose of MMR is advisable for certain people . These recommendations may be updated as the outbreak evolves.'\n\nSee http://www.epi.alaska.gov/bulletins/docs/b2017_28.pdf, State of Alaska Epidemiology Bulletin [excerpted and edited]. for figure, references and full report. - Mod.LK]\n\nA Healthmap/ProMED of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106 and\nAlaska, United States at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/206]\n\n******\n[3] USA (Texas, Willacy County)\nDate: Fri 17 Nov 2017 6:11 PM EST\nSource: KRGV [edited]\nhttp://www.krgv.com/story/36874240/mumps-outbreak-at-willacy-co-jail\n\n\nThere is another mumps outbreak at a Rio Grande Valley jail [in the southernmost tip of South Texas]. The Texas Department of Criminal Justice told Channel 5 News one offender at the state facility in Willacy County is confirmed to have the disease. The 47 other offenders in the dormitory, where the inmate was housed, are now on medical restriction.\n\nThe infected person is in isolation.\n\nMumps is contagious for 5 --7 days before symptoms show and up to 10 days after. If no other offenders show symptoms, the medical restriction will be lifted [Wed 22 Nov 2017.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap/ProMED of Texas, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245]", "summary": "If no other offenders show symptoms, the medical restriction will be lifted [Wed 22 Nov 2017.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap/ProMED of Texas, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245] A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n[byline: Eric Westhaver]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Among the 44 confirmed patients, the median age was 24 years (range: 10-68), and 13 (29 per cent) were aged 18 years or over; 36 (82 per cent) self-identified as Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander (NH/PI), 3 (7 per cent) as white, one (2 per cent) as black, and 4 (9 per cent) were of unknown race; and 20 (45 per cent) were female. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< LK]\n\nA Healthmap/ProMED of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106 and\nAlaska, United States at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/206]\n\n******\n On [Wed 25 Oct 2017], ACIP recommended that persons previously vaccinated with 2 doses of MMR who are identified by public health as being at high-risk for mumps during an outbreak should receive a 3rd dose of MMR. \n\nGroups at the most risk for contracting mumps include people who participate in a group setting, such as a daycare, work or church, where mumps is circulating, or Anchorage residents who are Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander. \n\nIn June, 98 cases of mumps were reported in the region, with another 94 reported in July [2017]. Of the 22 (50 per cent) confirmed patients whose vaccination status was known one had 4 doses of MMR, one had 3 doses, 17 had 2 doses, and 3 had one dose. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap/ProMED of Canada can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12]\n\n******\n MUMPS UPDATE (34): CANADA, USA (ALASKA, TEXAS)\n**********************************************\n Isaac also said the rate of complications arising from mumps cases has decreased during the outbreak, adding that few cases of severe side effects have been reported. \n\nMumps is a viral illness that typically starts with several days of fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue, loss of appetite and swollen salivary glands, the bulletin said. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n['As of [Wed 15 Nov 2017], 44 confirmed, 12 probable, and 6 suspect cases [updated numbers above] were identified (see figure at URL below). Date: Fri 17 Nov 2017 6:11 PM EST\nSource: KRGV [edited]\n An outbreak of mumps in northern Manitoba is declining, but infection rates are still abnormally high.\n\n To date, this mumps outbreak has disproportionately impacted NH/PI people, who comprise 82 per cent of confirmed cases. \n\nIsaac said the mumps vaccine, like other immunizations, becomes less effective over time. ' Among patients with 2 or more doses of MMR, the median time from the most recent dose to illness onset was 12 years (range: 4-20 years). While the original source of the outbreak is uncertain, several of the initial patients reported recent travel to or close contact with a person who had recently traveled to a Pacific island where mumps is circulating. Despite the high number of cases, the NHR reports that northern Manitoba has a higher than average rate of people vaccinated for mumps.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2068-10-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-06-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 00:00:00", "2021-08-25 00:00:00", "2034-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Willacy County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Winnipeg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anchorage", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manitoba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alaska", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5444251", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (33): USA (NY,DC,HI) CDC", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5444251", "date": "2017-11-15 17:21:46", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (33): USA (NEW YORK, DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, HAWAII), CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION\n***********************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] New York (Syracuse University)\n[2] District of Columbia (American University), New York (Syracuse University)\n[3] Hawaii\n[4] CDC\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] New York (Syracuse University)\nDate: Fri 10 Nov 2017\nSource: UC (Utica College) Tangerine [edited]\nhttps://uctangerine.com/2017/11/10/mumps-syracuse-university/\n\n\nAfter one student at Syracuse University [New York] contracted the mumps in late August [2017], the virus has since spread to more than 76 cases, with the confirmation that 37 students currently have the virus, causing a health epidemic on Syracuse's campus.\n\nAccording to the Centers of Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), mumps is a contagious virus that swells salivary glands.\n\nThe most common symptoms of mumps are a fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite, and swollen glands. These symptoms lead many to believe that they have a 'common cold' until days later, their cheeks are puffy and salivary glands are swollen, indicating that they have mumps.\n\nMumps can be easily spread, especially at college institutions such as Syracuse University.\n\n'Any institution is susceptible of viruses even if students are vaccinated,' said Julie Murawski, director of the UC [Utica College] Student Health Center. 'Mumps are spread through close contact, such as coughing, sneezing, talking, kissing, and sharing items from others.'\n\nTo become immune to the mumps virus, the MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) vaccination is offered and is mandatory for children to receive 2 doses prior to attending kindergarten. A 3rd dosage is not required, but is strongly considered during an outbreak. Syracuse University gave close contacts of those affected a 3rd dose to help them fight off the virus.\n\nWith the mumps outbreak happening an hour away from Utica, the UC community was concerned of something similar happening on its campus. Murawski, who has worked at UC since 1999, says there have been no cases of mumps, but UC has had bad cases of chickenpox and the flu in recent years.\n\n'It's very fortunate that there haven't been any mumps cases at UC, but we have had contagious diseases on campus,' Murawski said. 'We've dealt with international students with chicken pox before and every year we have a couple of students with the flu.'\n\nThe UC Student Health Center is currently advertising that students stop in to get their flu shot on the daysheet and with flyers on campus, which Murawski says helps motivate students to get vaccinated.\n\n'Flyers, email, and clinics have all helped raise awareness for making sure students get vaccinated,' Murawski said. 'We also have a receptionist at the front desk that asks students if they would like to receive a flu shot even if they are there for another visit. So far, we have vaccinated over 360 students and if we ever run out of vaccinations, we always order more.'\n\nBut even if students are vaccinated, they are not completely immune to the virus.\n\n'All vaccinations aren't 100 percent effective,' Murawski said. 'But, if a student gets sick after getting vaccinated, they experience less severe symptoms. We currently have 2 students with flu-like symptoms: 1 student was vaccinated and is experiencing minor symptoms while the other student wasn't vaccinated and is experiencing milder symptoms and is much sicker than the vaccinated student.'\n\nIn recent years, there has also been controversy on whether people should be vaccinated or not. UC nursing students shared their thoughts regarding how important it is to be vaccinated.\n\n'I believe all individuals should get vaccinated,' senior Michael Wells said. 'I do understand that individuals think that vaccines have a direct correlation to developmental disorders such as autism, however there has been extensive research into the connection between vaccinations and autism, none of which have provided substantial evidence backing that claim. Research has concluded that vaccines are safe to be administered to children.'\n\nBut, Wells also says that there's nothing that administrators and staff can do to make sure everyone gets vaccinated as it's the individual's choice.\n\n'Individuals are given a right to determine if they want to get vaccinated or not,' Wells said. 'Institutions like UC, however, can give the appropriate education on vaccinations in hopes to avoid an epidemic like the one that is occurring at SU. There is also a debate on whether or not parents should have the right to refuse vaccinations on their children, but that is a completely different debate.'\n\nUC currently has a student health portal where students can upload and share their immunization records with UC Admissions prior to coming to college, which the UC Student Health Center can access as well.\n\nSenior Emra Klempic said the UC health portal is very important and helps students in making sure they are up to date on their vaccinations.\n\n'Vaccinations are very safe and effective at preventing illnesses, such as the mumps and the flu, so everyone should get vaccinated and stay up to date,' Klempic said. 'If a student is missing a vaccination, they will notice that on the UC health portal and it's important that they receive the necessary vaccination as soon as possible, so that it doesn't end up becoming a public issue.'\n\n[Byline: Morgan Golliver]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of New York State can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1926. - Mod.LK\n\n******\n[2] District of Columbia (American University), New York (Syracuse University)\nDate: Sun 12 Nov 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/american-university-reports-additional-mumps-cases-syracuse-outbreak-update-66567/\n\n\nAmerican University [Washington DC] officials say they have been notified of an additional case of mumps by the DC Health Department (DC DOH), bringing the total to 7.\n\nThe new suspected case is a student who resides in Leonard Hall and has been isolated.\n\nOf the 7 mumps cases reported, 2 cases now have laboratory confirmation of the diagnosis (5 are classified as probable diagnoses). So far, all affected students have been contacted by DC DOH and were or are being isolated for the recommended five days after their initial symptoms develop.\n\nAccording to the DOH, 'Mumps spreads from person to person via droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person ...' We recommend that people take precautions and avoid kissing, sharing drinks or eating utensils. As with many infectious illnesses, frequent hand washing is also an important way to protect yourself because the virus may also be spread indirectly when a person touches items or surfaces without washing their hands and then someone else touches the same surface and rubs their mouth or nose. The virus typically goes away on its own, however, and patients fully recover.\n\nSyracuse University [see report in [1] above]\n---------------------------------------------\nIn Syracuse, NY, officials with SU Health Services report the number of confirmed and probable mumps cases are 39 and 77, respectively, as of 9 Nov 2017.\n\nA 3rd dose of measles-mumps-rubella (MMR), the 'outbreak dose' was offered to students all week free of charge.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Washington, DC can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6878. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Hawaii\nDate: Fri 10 Nov 2017\nSource: DG Alerts, State Health Agency; Student Health Services report [edited]\nhttp://dgalerts.docguide.com/hi-ny-dc-usa-mumps-update-500-cases-hi?nl_ref=newsletter&pk_campaign=newsletter\n\n\nThe Hawaii State Department of Health (DOH) continues to investigate an increasing number of cases of mumps infection statewide.\n\nThe disease has been confirmed in children and adults, both vaccinated and unvaccinated. Nearly 60 percent of cases have been in adults aged 18 years and older. There have been 16 reports of complications due to mumps infection (such as, orchitis, hearing loss).\n\nAs of 9 Nov 2017, there have been 557 confirmed cases of mumps for 2017, with the distribution of cases as follows:\n- Honolulu 450\n- Hawaii 61\n- Kauai 44\n- Maui 2\n\nDue to the current mumps outbreak in Hawaii, in addition to the routine vaccination recommendations above, persons born in 1957 or later, especially those who live or work in crowded conditions, should receive an additional MMR vaccine dose now.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Hawaii can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6878. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] CDC\nDate: Mon 06 Nov 2017\nSource: My Statesman, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution report [edited]\nhttp://www.mystatesman.com/news/national/vaccinated-not-the-mumps-are-the-rise-again-what-you-need-know/fz528bAaPwWoP0SlswybFK/\n\n\nLast year [2016], there were more than 6000 cases of the contagious disease mumps reported in the United States -- the highest number in 10 years.\n\nThat's according to the Atlanta-based Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which recommends everyone 15 months and older receive 2 doses of the MMR vaccine, which protects against 3 diseases: measles, mumps and rubella.\n\nThere's been a more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases since the pre-vaccine era and in 2010, the total annual cases were down in the hundreds.\n\nBut in recent years, there have been multiple mumps outbreaks reported across the country. In fact, the number of reported cases increased from 229 in 2012 to more than 6000 cases in 2016.\n\nThe last major outbreaks occurred in 2006, when the US saw more than 6500 reported cases, predominantly in the Midwest and among college-aged students.\n\nBetween 1 Jan and 7 Oct 2017, 47 states and the District of Columbia have reported approximately 4667 cases to the CDC.\n\n[Byline: Fiza Pirani]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The CDC summary of mumps cases in the US from 1 Jan to 4 Nov 2017 (a slightly later date than the report cited above), reports 47 states and the District of Columbia, 4980 people infected.\n\nSince the 2-dose vaccination program was introduced in 1989, mumps cases have ranged year to year from a couple of hundred to several thousand., However, in recent years, there has been an increase in the number of reported cases, from 229 cases in 2012 to 5833 cases in 2016. The recent increase has been mainly due to multiple mumps outbreaks reported across the country in settings where people often have close contact with one another, like college campuses.\n\nPast mumps outbreaks include 2016-17, when a large outbreak in a close-knit community in northwest Arkansas, resulted in nearly 3000 cases. And in 2015-16, outbreaks were reported from several university campuses, including a number of smaller outbreaks with limited spread. The 2 largest outbreaks were from Iowa and Illinois, each involving several hundred university students; both held wide-scale vaccination campaigns.\n(excerpted and edited from https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html. See full report for figure of mumps cases by year, and map of case numbers as of 4 Nov 2017) - Mod.LK]", "summary": "As of 9 Nov 2017, there have been 557 confirmed cases of mumps for 2017, with the distribution of cases as follows:\n- Honolulu 450\n- Hawaii 61\n- Kauai 44\n- Maui 2\n\nDue to the current mumps outbreak in Hawaii, in addition to the routine vaccination recommendations above, persons born in 1957 or later, especially those who live or work in crowded conditions, should receive an additional MMR vaccine dose now. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The CDC summary of mumps cases in the US from 1 Jan to 4 Nov 2017 (a slightly later date than the report cited above), reports 47 states and the District of Columbia, 4980 people infected. The 2 largest outbreaks were from Iowa and Illinois, each involving several hundred university students; both held wide-scale vaccination campaigns.\n LK\n\n******\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2033-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-01 00:00:00", "1977-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 "unknown"}, {"location": "Syracuse", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington , DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utica", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5493522", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (35): USA, UK, Pacific (NZ, Polynesia)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5493522", "date": "2017-12-09 21:36:23", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (35): UNITED STATES, UNITED KINGDOM, PACIFIC (NEW ZEALAND, POLYNESIA)\n**********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n----\n[1] New York (Syracuse)\n[2] Alaska (Anchorage)\n[3] Hawai'i\nUK\n----\n[4] England (Cumbria County)\nPacific\n----\n[5] New Zealand (North Island)\n[6] Polynesia (Tonga)\n\n******\nUSA\n----\n[1] New York (Syracuse)\nDate: Mon 27 Nov 2017\nSource: Daily Orange [edited]\nhttp://dailyorange.com/2017/11/syracuse-university-among-multiple-colleges-nationwide-experience-mumps-outbreak/\n\n\nSyracuse University health officials have said the campus mumps outbreak, at present, is not spreading as fast as it was earlier this semester.\n\nSyracuse University, which has had 45 confirmed and 81 probable cases of the mumps since the end of August [2017], is not the only college that [has] grappled with an outbreak of the disease in recent years.\n\nA mumps outbreak at the University of Missouri infected nearly 400 students in a 10-month span after the university confirmed a student contracted the disease in August 2016.\n\nBy the time a mumps outbreak at the University of Illinois ended in June 2016, 317 students had been infected.\n\nAnd 301 students caught the mumps during an outbreak at the University of Iowa between July 2015 and May 2016.\n\nSU health services officials say the disease is not spreading on campus as quickly as before. But, as the number of mumps infections spike nationwide, SU is one of the latest in a growing number of universities forced to handle the highly contagious disease on campus.\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 4980 people contracted the mumps nationwide between [Sun 1 Jan and Sat 4 Nov 2017]. In 2016, more than 6000 cases of the disease were reported, up from about 1500 cases in 2015. There were less than 500 cases of mumps nationwide in 2012.\n\nMumps cases reported to the CDC in 2016 and 2017 have primarily been 'associated with college settings,' according to the agency.\n\nBrittany Kmush, an assistant professor in the David B. Falk College of Sport and Human Dynamics who studies infectious diseases, said mumps can spread quickly on a college campus because students are interacting in close quarters, such as living together in dorms and coming in contact with each other in classrooms.\n\nBut scientists are not sure why the disease has been contracted in such high numbers in recent years.\n\n'Our evidence is limited to fully explain what has happened in the last couple of years,' said Kelly Moore, director of the Tennessee Immunization Program at the Tennessee Department of Health. 'If the answer were easy, we would have it by now.'\n\nMoore said researchers believe the mumps vaccine's effectiveness may wane as people get older. That may be one of the reasons why the disease has made a comeback in recent years, she added.\n\nTo attend college in New York state, students are required to receive 2 doses of the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine. Most are vaccinated when they are children.\n\nSince the end of October [2017], SU has hosted 7 clinics so students could receive a 3rd dose of the MMR vaccine. Every SU student who has contracted the mumps has been properly vaccinated, though, according to the health services website.\n\nAlthough a CDC advisory board in October [2017] unanimously recommended that people exposed to a mumps outbreak should receive a 3rd vaccine, federal officials also said there was limited scientific evidence showing whether the 3rd dose protected individuals against mumps-related complications, The Washington Post reported.\n\nBut is a 3rd vaccine effective? 'The simple answer is yes,' said Patricia Quinlisk, medical director of the Iowa Department of Public Health. But, she added, 'It's obviously more complex than that.' Quinlisk said the effectiveness of the 3rd MMR vaccine depends on the timing of mumps cases, who the cases are occurring in and whether cases are linked. A 3rd vaccine is effective, Quinlisk said, if there are multiple mumps cases in a single dorm during a short period of time. If there are isolated cases over a longer period of time, a 3rd vaccine isn't necessary, she added.\n\nThe Onondaga County Health Department only recommended a 3rd dose of the MMR vaccine after it was determined that:\n\nThere was high vaccination coverage at SU. Exposure settings, such as schools, colleges and dorms, were likely to cause easy transmission of the disease. There was a high attack rate and transmission of the mumps for at least 2 weeks.\n\nBrad Hutton, deputy commissioner of public health at the New York State Department of Health, said at a press conference in October [2017] that the 3rd vaccine will not stop the mumps from infecting those who have already been exposed to the disease.\n\nStill, roughly 30 percent of SU students received a 3rd MMR vaccine through the university's clinics, said Karen Nardella, medical director of Health Services.\n\nSU's response to the mumps outbreak\nBen Domingo, director of SU Health Services, said the university has handled the mumps before. 'We actually had a few close calls,' Domingo said. 'Last fall we had a case, and then we had a few cases in January [2017].'\n\nNone of the previous cases were considered an outbreak, he said. But, he added, those cases helped the university plan how it would confront a larger mumps outbreak.\n\nNardella said SU officials also looked at how the State University of New York New Paltz and University of Missouri handled mumps outbreaks.\n\nSU's response to the outbreak has included isolating students with confirmed or probable mumps cases from the rest of the campus community for up to 5 days.\n\n'The minute we were getting cases we were already familiar with the fact that, this fall, isolation was necessary,' Domingo said.\n\nStudents have been housed in South Campus apartments and the Sheraton Syracuse University Hotel and Conference Center. If a potentially infected student lives in university housing with their own bedroom and bathroom, such as on South Campus, they can spend their isolation there, Nardella said. But because some may have roommates, they are asked to wear a mask in the rooms' common areas. ...-more\n\nThe Onondaga County Health Department in late September [2017] ordered SU to 'exclude' students from campus who had not submitted vaccination records. Currently, 4 students remain excluded from campus, Nardella said.\n\nStudents can waive New York state's MMR vaccination requirement for medical or religious reasons.\n\nIf a person has a suppressed immune system or is taking certain medications, that could qualify as a medical exemption, Nardella said.\n\nThe 4 students excluded from campus will not be allowed to return to SU until at least [Thu 14 Dec 2017]. According to Health Services, they must remain off campus for a minimum of 26 days after the most recent confirmed mumps case. If a new mumps case is confirmed, the 26-day exclusion period starts over. ... - more\n\nNardella said the spread of mumps at SU began to slow in mid-November [2017], which she attributes to the vaccine clinics and communications from the university about how to prevent the transmission of the disease.\n\nIn mid-November, only 2 students were in isolation, she said.\n\n[Byline: Jordan Muller]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases rose to 51 as of [Wed 6 Dec 2017] and the number of probable cases increased to 81. The 51 confirmed cases represent the number of students diagnosed with mumps since August 2017. Some of those students have fully recovered. Probable cases are students with symptoms who require further testing. The outbreak began primarily among athletes and spread to other students.\n\nTo contain the outbreak, SU began offering students a 3rd dose of the mumps vaccine at the end of October 2017. SU has said all infected students had received the 2 required mumps vaccinations.\n\nSee discussion of 3rd vaccine in previous posts.\n\nA Healthmap/ProMED of New York State, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234 and the full United States at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Alaska (Anchorage)\nDate: Sat 2 Dec 2017\nSource: KTUU [edited]\nhttp://www.ktuu.com/content/news/Mumps-outbreak-sees-71-confirmed-cases-in-Anchorage-461426173.html\n\n\nA mumps outbreak has continued to spread throughout Anchorage with 71 confirmed cases and 15 probable cases reported since May [2017]. The state recommends people be especially vigilant identifying and treating the infection during the holidays.\n\nAs of [Fri 1 Dec 2017], the mumps outbreak has not spread beyond the Municipality of Anchorage.\n\nDr. Amanda Tiffany, an epidemiologist with the Department of Health and Social Services, says the Alaskan mumps outbreak mirrors a trend seen nationally. She says the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports over 4900 cases of mumps this year. Up to 47 states and the District of Colombia have all reported cases of mumps, according to Dr. Tiffany.\n\nTo put the outbreak in perspective, the DHSS says it saw less than 5 confirmed cases of mumps between 2012 and 2017. And all of those were travel related, meaning the infection was contracted outside Alaska and then brought into the state.\n\nThe DHSS can't be sure where this latest mumps outbreak started but nearby states have also reported significant mumps cases this year [2017]. Hawaii has reported more than 500 cases and Washington State has reported over 300 cases.\n\nThe current recommendation from the Department of Health and Social Services is to stay up-to-date with the measles, mumps and rubella vaccination (MMR). 'For Anchorage residents who self-identify as native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander, we recommend a 2nd dose of MMR,' Dr. Tiffany said. She says a 3rd dose is recommended for people who have had a 2nd dose within the past 5 years.\nDr. Tiffany explains the vast majority of reported cases have been seen in the Pacific Islander and native Hawaiian communities because the infection is spread through close contact.\n\nThe DHHS has some recommendations if a person suspects they may be infected with mumps:\n\n- Go to a healthcare provider. Dr. Tiffany says due to the similarity of its symptoms, mumps can often appear as other illnesses .\n\n- The MMR vaccine should be covered by health insurance or Medicaid.\n\n- If you experience facial swelling or a cough, tell family and friends because mumps has a long incubation period.\n\n- It's especially hard during the holidays but the state says it's essential to self-isolate for 5 days after symptoms start.\n\n[Byline: Sean Maguire]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See Mumps update (34): Canada, USA (AK,TX) 20171125.5464364 for discussion of why Pacific Islander and native Hawaiian communities are at greater risk.\n\nChildren should get 2 doses of MMR vaccine: 1st dose: 12-15 months of age; 2nd dose: 4-6 years of age (may be given earlier, if at least 28 days after the 1st dose)\n\nSome infants younger than 12 months should get a dose of MMR if they are traveling out of the country. (This dose will not count toward their routine series.)\n\nSome adults should also get MMR vaccine: Generally, anyone 18 years of age or older who was born after 1956 should get at least one dose of MMR vaccine, unless they can show that they have either been vaccinated or had all 3 diseases.\n\nMMR vaccine may be given at the same time as other vaccines.\n\nChildren between one and 12 years of age can get a 'combination' vaccine called MMRV, which contains both MMR and varicella (chickenpox) vaccines. (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/vis/vis-statements/mmr.html)\n\nA Healthmap/ProMED of Alaska, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/206. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Hawai'i\nDate: Mon 4 Dec 2017 06:10 AM\nSource: San Luis Obispo [edited]\nhttp://www.sanluisobispo.com/news/health-and-medicine/article187904159.html\n\n\nMumps infections have risen by over 6000 percent in Hawaii, the Department of Health said.\n\nStatewide, Hawaii had a total of 636 cases as of [Thu 30 Nov 2017]. Previously, the state saw 10 or fewer cases per year.\n\nExperts are having trouble explaining exactly what has caused the outbreak.\n\nState epidemiologist Dr. Sarah Park said some people were never vaccinated for mumps and other residents' immunity shots could be waning. The state has suggested that anyone born in 1957 or later receive another mumps shot to be safe.\n\nPark said it could also be that people are getting sick, but not sick enough to stay home and recover. Park said it's a common practice that she sees every flu season.\n'And we're seeing that with mumps,' Park said. 'And I think that above all is what's contributing.'\n\nHawaii county had just 2 confirmed cases from 2007--16, but is up to 72 this year [2017]. Six were diagnosed in the past week [week of Sun 26 Nov 2017], according to the Department of Health.\n\nA total of 2 Big Island schools -- West Hawaii Explorations Academy and Keonepoko Elementary School in Pahoa -- alerted families that their communities were affected, but neither said whether the sick person is a student or staff member, West Hawaii Today reported .\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap/ProMED of Hawaii, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/214. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\nUK\n----\n[4] England (Cumbria County)\nDate: Wed 6 Dec 2017\nSource: The Mail [edited]\nhttp://www.nwemail.co.uk/news/With-video-Latest-on-mumps-outbreak-across-Cumbria-71123e7c-7089-4cf2-99e4-fd75bc85a242-ds\n\n\nThere are hopes that a mumps outbreak in Cumbria could be over, with only one new case in the last week [week of Sun 26 Nov 2017].\n\nThroughout November [2017] there have been 8 cases across the county, leaving doctors on high alert.\n\nMumps has previously been recorded in Carlisle, South Lakeland and Allerdale, with other cases unconfirmed.\n\nBut latest figures show there was just one new confirmed case in the last week [week of Sun 26 Nov 2017]. This was in Allerdale.\n\nIt has prompted hopes that the outbreak may be over, though parents are still warned to remain on high alert.\n\nPublic health experts have urged them to ensure children are vaccinated to help prevent serious illness.\n\nMumps is a contagious virus resulting in painful swollen glands and a distinctive 'hamster face' appearance.\n\nIt was common in children before the MMR vaccine was introduced but is now fairly rare.\n\nAlthough mumps has been spreading across the North West, there were no cases in Cumbria until this month [December 2017].\n\nBut since [Wed 1 Nov 2017], they have been confirmed in north, south and west Cumbria by Public Health England.\n\nInitially 3 cases of mumps were recorded - in Carlisle, South Lakes and Allerdale. A further 3 - 2 in Carlisle and one in Allerdale - were confirmed the following week.\n\nLast week [week of Sun 26 Nov 2017].another 2 were confirmed in Carlisle and South Lakeland, with just one more in Allerdale in the last 7 days.\n\n[Byline: Pamela McGowan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap of the United Kingdom can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\nPacific\n----\n[5] New Zealand (North Island)\nDate: Mon 27 Nov 2017 4:08 pm\nSource: Scoop [edited]\nhttp://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/GE1711/S00111/confirmed-cases-of-mumps-and-pertussis-in-northland.htm\n\n\nNorthland DHB are appealing to Northland parents to ensure their family is up to date with Immunisations after confirmed cases of Mumps and Pertussis (Whooping Cough) in the region.\n\nNorthland DHB have been notified of 8 confirmed cases of mumps in school aged children from the Dargaville community. These confirmed now bring the number of notifications for the Northland Region to 24 this year [2017] - compared with 6 in 2016 and 3 in 2015.\n\nWith the school holiday period approaching and the current Mumps outbreak in Auckland, it is especially important for people under the age of 35, and for parents to check your family's vaccination status.\n\nMumps has recently gained attention internationally with members of the All Black squad contracting mumps, Medical Officer of Health Dr Virginia McLaughlin says this also highlights the importance of ensuring vaccines are up to date for young adults (up to 29 years of age).\n\n'Vaccination is the best protection against mumps. If you or your children have not had the recommended 2 MMR (Measles Mumps and Rubella) vaccinations, it is strongly recommended that you get these up to date.\n\nContact your doctor or practice nurse if you are unsure whether you or your family has been vaccinated, and book in vaccination if they haven't.'\n\nMumps can cause swelling in the glands around the face and can lead to meningitis in about one in 10 people. Mumps is spread through the air by breathing, coughing and sneezing, or through contact with infected saliva (ie kissing, sharing food and drink).\n\n'If you think you have mumps, please exclude from school or work and phone ahead to your GP, so that you are not sitting in the waiting room.\n\nWash your hands and cover your mouth when you cough.\n\nDr McLaughlin also confirmed an increase in notified cases of pertussis in Northland, with 48 notifications this year [2017] compared to 9 in 2016 and 36 in 2015.\n\nWhooping cough can be a very serious illness for babies and children, especially under one year of age.\n\n'There have been 25 notified cases of pertussis in Ngunguru, with others throughout the region. A baby was admitted to hospital for treatment and has made a good recovery.\n\nThis gives us an opportunity to check immunisation status for both pertussis and mumps. By doing this as individuals we can protect those most at risk in our community. Don't delay; check your immunisation status today!\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pertussis, also known as whooping cough, is a highly contagious respiratory disease. It is caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_. Pertussis is known for uncontrollable, violent coughing which often makes it hard to breathe. After cough fits, someone with pertussis often needs to take deep breaths, which result in a 'whooping' sound. Pertussis can affect people of all ages, but can be very serious, even deadly, for babies less than a year old.\n\nThe best way to prevent pertussis (whooping cough) is to get the vaccine. There are vaccines for babies, children, preteens, teens, and adults. DTaP is the childhood vaccine, and Tdap is the pertussis booster vaccine for preteens, teens, and adults.\n(from https://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/index.html)\n\nA Healthmap/ProMED of New Zealand can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[6] Polynesia (Tonga)\nDate: Sat 9 Dec 2017\nSource: NewsHub [edited]\nhttp://www.newshub.co.nz/home/health/2017/12/nats-hit-health-minister-over-tongan-mumps-outbreak.html\n\n\nA mumps outbreak in Tonga could have started in Auckland and the Government should take responsibility, 2 Opposition MPs say.\n\nShane Reti and Alfred Ngaro believe Tongan and other Pacific Island rugby league players at the recent World Cup could have been exposed to mumps while they were in Auckland.\n\nThey're upset because when Health Minister David Clark was asked about it, he said individual countries were responsible for their own immunisation regimes.\n\n'There are currently 1600 recorded cases in Tonga,' Mr Reti and Mr Ngaro said in a joint statement.\n\n'Is the minister saying that the complications of this disease such as deafness, sterility and meningitis don't matter in Pacific Island people?'\n\nThe MPs thinks the Government should offer advice to Tonga and help with its vaccination programme.\n\n'The minister is displaying an appalling lack of responsibility,' they said.\n\nDr Clark told Newshub mumps outbreaks in the Pacific are not uncommon.\n\n'The latest outbreak in Tonga began in March and peaked in June [2017] - before the Rugby League World Cup. The suggestion from the 2 National MPs that Tongan Rugby league players that contracted mumps in New Zealand have somehow caused the outbreak in Tonga does not make sense and is irresponsible at best.'\n\nHe said the Ministry of Health isn't aware of any requests for assistance from Tonga, which would actually come through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade.\n\n'Anyone who needs treatment while in New Zealand will receive it, but individual countries are responsible for their own vaccination programmes.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[Before sports teams travel to countries where mumps outbreaks are occurring, MMR vaccination status of each player should be checked. The coaches should advise unvaccinated players to immediately go to clinics that conduct immunizatons. Because measles and mumps are highly infectious, sports teams should take extra precautions to protect their players from disease even in country. They can become infected at home and when traveling, and can spread infection to other non-immunized individuals.\n\nA Healthmap/ProMED of Tonga can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases rose to 51 as of [Wed 6 Dec 2017] and the number of probable cases increased to 81. \n\nSU's response to the mumps outbreak\nBen Domingo, director of SU Health Services, said the university has handled the mumps before. ' \n\nChildren should get 2 doses of MMR vaccine: 1st dose: 12-15 months of age; 2nd dose: 4-6 years of age (may be given earlier, if at least 28 days after the 1st dose)\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See Mumps update (34): Canada, USA (AK,TX) 20171125.5464364 for discussion of why Pacific Islander and native Hawaiian communities are at greater risk. \n\nContact your doctor or practice nurse if you are unsure whether you or your family has been vaccinated, and book in vaccination if they haven't.'\n\nMumps can cause swelling in the glands around the face and can lead to meningitis in about one in 10 people. \n\n'Anyone who needs treatment while in New Zealand will receive it, but individual countries are responsible for their own vaccination programmes.'\n\n--\n Although a CDC advisory board in October [2017] unanimously recommended that people exposed to a mumps outbreak should receive a 3rd vaccine, federal officials also said there was limited scientific evidence showing whether the 3rd dose protected individuals against mumps-related complications, The Washington Post reported. \n\nBrad Hutton, deputy commissioner of public health at the New York State Department of Health, said at a press conference in October [2017] that the 3rd vaccine will not stop the mumps from infecting those who have already been exposed to the disease. ... - more\n\nNardella said the spread of mumps at SU began to slow in mid-November [2017], which she attributes to the vaccine clinics and communications from the university about how to prevent the transmission of the disease. \n\nTo contain the outbreak, SU began offering students a 3rd dose of the mumps vaccine at the end of October 2017. \n\nThe Onondaga County Health Department only recommended a 3rd dose of the MMR vaccine after it was determined that:\n\nThere was high vaccination coverage at SU. system or is taking certain medications, that could qualify as a medical exemption, Nardella said. \n\nStudents can waive New York state's MMR vaccination requirement for medical or religious reasons. \n\n\nThere are hopes that a mumps outbreak in Cumbria could be over, with only one new case in the last week [week of Sun 26 Nov 2017]. \n\nBut scientists are not sure why the disease has been contracted in such high numbers in recent years. \n\nSee discussion of 3rd vaccine in previous posts. \n\nWhooping cough can be a very serious illness for babies and children, especially under one year of age. http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/GE1711/S00111/confirmed-cases-of-mumps-and-pertussis-in-northland.htm\n\n\nNorthland DHB are appealing to Northland parents to ensure their family is up to date with Immunisations after confirmed cases of Mumps and Pertussis (Whooping Cough) in the region. \n\nSU health services officials say the disease is not spreading on campus as quickly as before.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "pertussis", "rubella", "varicella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-05-25 Zealand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5396070", "date": "2017-10-22 10:07:21", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (30): USA, NEW ZEALAND\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (New York, Syracuse)\n[2] New Zealand (Aukland)\n\n******\n[1] USA (New York, Syracuse)\nDate: Wed 18 Oct 2017\nSource: Syracuse.com [edited]\nhttp://www.syracuse.com/health/index.ssf/2017/10/post_54.html\n\n\nThe number of confirmed mumps cases at Syracuse University [SU] has risen to 24. There are also 27 probable cases.\n\nProbable cases are students who have symptoms, appear to have the disease, but are awaiting confirmatory lab tests.\n\nThe outbreak at SU began in August 2017. Some of the students with confirmed cases of mumps are no longer contagious and have made a full recovery.\n\nSU is isolating students who have mumps to stop the spread of the disease on campus. Some are staying in hotels.\n\nMost of the students at SU who contracted mumps had been vaccinated against the disease. Most schools require students to get 2 doses of the mumps vaccine.\n\nMumps is a serious contagious disease passed through saliva and respiratory secretions. Symptoms include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite, swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears or along the jaw.\n\nMumps outbreaks have been occurring on college campuses across the state and nation.\n\nSome colleges with outbreaks have offered students a 3rd mumps vaccination. The extra dose helped control an outbreak at the University of Iowa during the 2015-2016 school year, according to a recent study published in the New England Journal of Medicine [see comment below - Mod.LK].\n\nBut Onondaga County Health Department officials are not recommending a 3rd dose for SU students because they say there is not enough evidence it is helpful in people who are fully vaccinated.\n\n[Byline: James T. Mulder]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Implementation of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine for outbreak situations has been under discussion. The citation for the NEJM study referred to in the report above that evaluated a 3rd dose is: Cardemil CV et al. 2017. Effectiveness of a Third Dose of MMR Vaccine for Mumps Outbreak Control. N Engl J Med 2017; 377:947-956 September 7, 2017 DOI: 10.1056/NEJMoa1703309. [edited]:\n\nAbstract\n---------\n'Background. The effect of a 3rd dose of the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine in stemming a mumps outbreak is unknown. During an outbreak among vaccinated students at the University of Iowa, health officials implemented a widespread MMR vaccine campaign. We evaluated the effectiveness of a 3rd dose for outbreak control and assessed for waning immunity.'\n\n'Conclusions. Students who had received a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine had a lower risk of mumps than did those who had received 2 doses, after adjustment for the number of years since the 2nd dose. Students who had received a 2nd dose of MMR vaccine 13 years or more before the outbreak had an increased risk of mumps. These findings suggest that the campaign to administer a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine improved mumps outbreak control and that waning immunity probably contributed to propagation of the outbreak.'\n\nSee the article for the full report of results and discussion.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106 and of New York State, United States at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] New Zealand (Aukland)\nDate: Thu 19 Oct 2017\nSource: RNZ [edited]\nhttp://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/341879/mumps-outbreak-authorities-urge-vaccine-catch-ups\n\n\nPublic health officials in Auckland have told its 3 district health boards the region urgently needs a large-scale campaign to eliminate mumps.\n\nThere are now 637 confirmed or probable cases in the city, up from 300 in early September 2017.\n\nThough people usually recover well from the viral disease, there can be serious complications. So far, about 35 people -- 5 percent of cases -- have been hospitalised.\n\nIn a paper released under the Official Information Act, the Auckland Regional Public Health Service urged the DHBs to make catch-up doses of the mumps vaccine available to about 100 000 people who need it.\n\nThe regional health service's clinical director, Julia Peters, said offering people aged 10 to 29 a free measles, mumps and rubella vaccine would be the quickest way to end the outbreak.\n\nWhen the outbreak began in January [2017], cases mainly involved people from the Pacific either visiting this country or returning to live here. But the regional health service said most cases are now locally acquired, involving people living here who lack immunity.\n\nThe most at-risk group are those aged 10-29, mainly Pacific and Maori living in poorer communities in Auckland. About 77 percent of this age group are not fully vaccinated with the MMR vaccine.\n\nDistrict health boards haven't decided yet whether a large-scale programme will happen. Dr Peters said it would be a major undertaking. 'Doing something like that is a considerable logistical exercise, so it would require quite a lot of thought and planning if it was to go ahead. It's not just the funding. We'd need to assess the size of the at-risk population; it would need to be coordinated, staffed; we'd need to ensure the vaccination supplies, communications with the target population, and then the timing, and then how it would be rolled out.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of New Zealand can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Implementation of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine for outbreak situations has been under discussion. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of New Zealand can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.] We'd need to assess the size of the at-risk population; it would need to be coordinated, staffed; we'd need to ensure the vaccination supplies, communications with the target population, and then the timing, and then how it would be rolled out.'\n\n--\n Students who had received a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine had a lower risk of mumps than did those who had received 2 doses, after adjustment for the number of years since the 2nd dose. These findings suggest that the campaign to administer a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine improved mumps outbreak control and that waning immunity probably contributed to propagation of the outbreak.' Source: RNZ [edited]\nhttp://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/341879/mumps-outbreak-authorities-urge-vaccine-catch-ups\n\n\nPublic health officials in Auckland have told its 3 district health boards the region urgently needs a large-scale campaign to eliminate mumps. The effect of a 3rd dose of the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine in stemming a mumps outbreak is unknown. The regional health service's clinical director, Julia Peters, said offering people aged 10 to 29 a free measles, mumps and rubella vaccine would be the quickest way to end the outbreak. \n\nWhen the outbreak began in January [2017], cases mainly involved people from the Pacific either visiting this country or returning to live here. Students who had received a 2nd dose of MMR vaccine 13 years or more before the outbreak had an increased risk of mumps. MUMPS UPDATE (30): USA, NEW ZEALAND\n***********************************\n \n\nSome colleges with outbreaks have offered students a 3rd mumps vaccination. \n\nMost of the students at SU who contracted mumps had been vaccinated against the disease. \n\nSU is isolating students who have mumps to stop the spread of the disease on campus. \n\nProbable cases are students who have symptoms, appear to have the disease, but are awaiting confirmatory lab tests. [2] New Zealand (Aukland)\n\n******\n [Byline: James T. Mulder]\n\n--\n In a paper released under the Official Information Act, the Auckland Regional Public Health Service urged the DHBs to make catch-up doses of the mumps vaccine available to about 100 000 people who need it.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-09-07 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00", "2017-08-25 00:00:00", "2021-10-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Maori", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW ZEALAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Syracuse", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country":
