"New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Auckland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5407525", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (31): USA, MMR 3rd dose, Canada", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5407525", "date": "2017-10-27 11:40:47", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (31): USA, MMR 3RD DOSE, CANADA\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] New York (Syracuse)\n[2] MMR vaccine: 3rd dose\n[3] Hawaii\n\nCanada\n---\n[4] Manitoba\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] New York (Syracuse)\nDate: Wed 25 Oct 2017\nSource: Gant Daily, CNN report [edited]\nhttp://gantdaily.com/2017/10/25/mumps-outbreak-at-syracuse-as-cdc-weighs-new-vaccine-recommendation/\n\n\nAn outbreak of mumps has spurred Syracuse University [Onondaga County, New York] to offer students a 3rd 'booster' shot of the measles, mumps, and rubella [MMR] vaccine.\n\nAs of [Mon 23 Oct 2017], there have been 27 confirmed and 48 probable cases of mumps on campus, according to Syracuse University Health Services. Mumps is a contagious disease caused by a virus spread through saliva and mucus.\n\nIndependent of this outbreak, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices -- a panel of medical and public health experts who meet 3 times a year to offer vaccination guidance for the United States -- will vote [Wed 25 Oct 2017; see report below] on whether to recommend the use of a 3rd dose of the MMR vaccine during outbreaks. Committee recommendations are reviewed by the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nOther outbreaks in recent years, most notably one involving NHL [National Hockey League] players in 2014, have prompted the CDC to debate whether a 3rd dose of the vaccine should be recommended in such situations. A 3rd dose may prevent additional cases by further protecting those exposed to the virus.\n\nAbsent this official CDC recommendation, a 3rd dose is given during outbreaks on a case-by-case basis, such as the current one at Syracuse.\n\nThe health department of Onondaga county, where Syracuse University is located, reported 6 additional probable cases among non-campus members as of [Tue 24 Oct 2017].\n\nConfirmed cases have been verified by laboratory testing, while probable cases only include likely though unconfirmed symptoms.\n\nMumps typically begins with fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite lasting a few days. Most people will then see salivary glands swell, causing puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw.\n\n3rd dose recommendation\n-----------------------\nThe MMR vaccine is 88 percent effective when 2 doses have been given. In people who receive just one shot, the vaccine is less effective.\n\nMost recent outbreaks have occurred among vaccinated people, according to Dr Manisha Patel, a medical officer at the CDC.\n\nIn weighing a possible recommendation on [Wed 25 Oct 2017], the CDC advisory committee will review data from recent outbreaks, including the number of vaccinated people who became infected. In its deliberations, the panel will assess the impact of a 3rd dose in decreasing the size and duration of outbreaks.\n\nThe CDC currently recommends that children get their 1st dose when they are 12-15 months old and a 2nd dose at 4-6 years.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps tend to occur in areas where there is crowding and close contact, according to Patel. Campuses are a typical site for outbreaks because of the sharing of saliva: by coughing, sneezing, kissing, and sharing utensils, lipstick, or cigarettes.\n\nPossible complications\n----------------------\nThe incubation period for mumps ranges from 12-25 days; symptoms last at least 2 and usually more than 10 days. Mumps can occasionally cause complications, especially in adults. These include deafness and inflammation of the brain, ovaries, breast tissue, or testicles.\n\nSince it is caused by a virus, mumps will not respond to antibiotics. Doctors generally recommend bed rest and over-the-counter pain relievers. Most people with mumps recover completely in a few weeks, according to the CDC.\n\nBefore the US mumps vaccination program started in 1967, the CDC received reports of 186 000 cases each year. The actual number of cases was probably much higher but not always reported since most doctors considered the mumps a typical childhood disease. Since the development of the vaccine, cases have decreased by more than 99 percent in the United States.\n\nEach year, the number of mumps cases fluctuates within a range of a couple hundred to a couple thousand, according to Patel.\n\nIn 2016, the United States experienced the highest number of mumps cases in a decade: more than 6000, according to CDC preliminary reports.\n\nThe number of cases is high this year, too. As of 7 Oct 2017, the CDC has received reports of 4667 total mumps infections in 47 states and the District of Columbia for the year.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See ProMED-mail Mumps update (30): USA, New Zealand 20171022.5396070 for discussion of the impact of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine as presented in N Engl J Med 2017; 377: 947-956 by CV Cardemil et al (http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1703309), as well as item [2] below.\n\nThe state of New York can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1060. Onondaga county in central New York can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/new-york-county-map.gif. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] MMR vaccine: 3rd dose\nDate: Wed 25 Oct 2017\nSource: Stat News [edited]\nhttps://www.statnews.com/2017/10/25/mumps-vaccine-third-dose/\n\n\nWith the US facing a growing number of mumps outbreaks [see figure of cases by year at the source URL above], an expert panel that advises the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended [Wed 25 Oct 2017] that people who are at risk during outbreaks should receive an additional, 3rd dose of vaccine.\n\nThe Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices unanimously voted to approve a 3rd dose of mumps-containing vaccine as a tool for outbreak control, despite acknowledging evidence to support the practice is limited.\n\nThe recommendation states that people who have had 2 doses of mumps vaccine but who are identified by public health officials as being at risk in a mumps outbreak should receive the 3rd dose.\n\nMumps-containing vaccine is either the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine or a vaccine that contains those 3 plus the chickenpox vaccine. Experts hope the recommendation will help address a problem that has bedeviled public health authorities recently.\n\nAfter years of very low numbers of mumps cases -- fewer than 1000 cases nationally a year -- the disease has made a resurgence of sorts in the past decade or so. There were nearly 7000 cases nationally in 2006 and more than 6000 last year [2016]. As of early October [2017], there have been 4667 cases in 47 states and the District of Columbia so far in 2017. It's long been known that the mumps vaccine is less effective than those that protect against measles and rubella. Still, 2 doses of mumps vaccine -- the 1st given at between 12 and 15 months of age and the 2nd sometime between the ages of 4 and 6 years of age -- is thought to protect about 88 percent of people vaccinated.\n\nHowever, as mumps outbreaks have increased, public health officials have noticed that children and young adults -- especially the latter -- who received both recommended doses of vaccine were among those contracting the disease. In some cases, including in a large outbreak of mumps in northern Arkansas [USA] earlier this year [2017], authorities have resorted to giving additional doses of the vaccine. But the evidence proving additional doses overcomes the problem of waning protection has been lacking.\n\nLast month [September 2107] the New England Journal of Medicine published a study [see reference in item [1] above] that delved into the issue. It was based on data from a 2015-2016 mumps outbreak at the University of Iowa.\n\nThe researchers found that the longer it had been since a person received a 2nd dose of MMR vaccine, the more likely it was that he or she would contract the mumps. Students who had received their 2nd shot 13 years or more before the outbreak were 9 times more likely than more recently vaccinated students to be infected.\n\nGiven the recommended timing of MMR vaccination, teenagers and people in their early 20s could be vulnerable to contract mumps at a time when their lifestyles put them at higher risk, if they come in contact with the virus.\n\nOn [Wed 25 Oct 2016], a veteran vaccine expert -- Dr Stanley Plotkin, who is not a member of ACIP [Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices] -- suggested the committee should recommend a 3rd dose of mumps vaccine for all students entering university. But the idea was dismissed.\n\n'We did discuss this question. But ... we did not feel that we had any evidence to support a decision about a routine [3rd] dose outside of an actual exposure situation where there was an immediate need for that vaccine,' said Dr Kelly Moore, an ACIP member who chairs a work group that advises the panel on mumps vaccine. Moore is director of Tennessee's immunization program.\n\nThe mumps virus spreads in saliva; so activities like kissing, sharing drinks, and sharing cigarettes fuel its spread. Mumps outbreaks have been common on university campuses, but they have also occurred among athletes who play team sports. Several National Hockey League teams, for instance, have seen mumps spread along their benches.\n\nThe mumps virus causes symptoms that are common to lots of illnesses -- fever, headache, muscle aches. But the virus also infects salivary glands, leading to pronounced swelling on one or both sides of the face. It can also cause a painful condition known as orchitis -- swelling of the testicles -- in males who contract the virus after puberty.\n\nMost cases are mild, but there are serious complications in rare cases, including encephalitis (inflammation of the brain), deafness, and infertility. Severe cases are less common among people who have been vaccinated but still contract mumps.\n\n[Byline: Helen Branswell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps elimination in the United States has never been documented. The Healthy People 2020 mumps goal is to reduce the number of US-acquired cases, rather than elimination The 3rd dose may help attain this new goal.\n\nAlso see, 'Third MMR dose shows promise in curbing mumps outbreaks' http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2017/09/third-mmr-dose-shows-promise-curbing-mumps-outbreaks for a report on the impact of the 3rd dose of MMR on University of Iowa students during a mumps outbreak. 'The attack rate was lower in students who received 3 doses than in their peers who had gotten only 2-6.7 versus 14.5 cases per 1000 population. The researchers calculated that the vaccine was associated with a 60 percent to 78 percent reduction in mumps risk. ...\n\nThe improvement noted in vaccine effectiveness between the 2- and 3-dose groups at 7 days after vaccination suggests that the benefit occurs shortly after vaccination, which is likely due to a booster response. ... They said other factors, such as a coordinated public health response, implementation of a standard case definition, rapid testing, isolation, and enhanced awareness, also probably played a role in the decline of the outbreak, which occurred rapidly. ...\n\nThe authors concluded that longer-term benefits of routine 3-dose MMR administration requires further study, but for now, a 3rd-dose may be useful for outbreak control. And the drop-off seen in immunity may be useful in helping health officials decide if a 3rd dose would be helpful in stemming outbreaks in highly vaccinated populations.' - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Hawaii\nDate: Wed 25 Oct 2017\nSource: Pharmacist [edited]\nhttp://www.pharmacist.com/article/500-sickened-hawaii-mumps-outbreak\n\n\nHealth officials in Hawaii have reported a significant increase in mumps cases in the state's ongoing mumps outbreak. According to the Hawaii Department of Health, 500 cases of mumps have now been recorded, a 216-case increase since [24 Aug 2017]. The outbreak was first detected in March, with 409 cases recorded in Honolulu alone. Last year [2016], the state recorded a total of 10 mumps cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Hawaii, United States can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/214. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\nCanada\n---\n[4] Manitoba\nDate: Tue 24 Oct 2017 4:57 PM CDT\nSource: Winnipeg Free Press [edited]\nhttps://goo.gl/DQkLyA\n\n\nManitoba's public health department has reached out to schools and daycares as the province's mumps outbreak continues its lengthy run.\n\nIn documents dated [19 Oct 2017], and making their way to the public this week, Manitoba Health, Seniors and Active Living asks parents and guardians of young children and post-secondary students and faculty to be aware of the symptoms of mumps, what to do if they suspect an infection and how to help prevent one.\n\n'This letter serves as a reminder... to let people know the mumps outbreak is still continuing in Manitoba. It is important for people to know, even though they may not be hearing as much about it, that it is still ongoing,' Dr Elise Weiss, acting chief provincial public health officer, said [Tue 24 Oct 2017].\n\n(With schools back in session and students in close quarters, 'the goal of sending this letter out (is) there are measures people can take to help protect themselves.'\n\nAs of last [Thu 19 Oct 2017], there had been 1150 confirmed cases of the contagious viral infection since the beginning of the outbreak [1 Sep 2016], Manitoba Health says. The province normally experiences fewer than 10 cases a year.\n\nThe mumps occur mostly in children, commonly involving fever, headache, swollen salivary glands and cheeks, and difficulty chewing, swallowing, or talking. Symptoms appear 12-25 days after exposure to the virus through direct contact with the saliva of an infected person, and usually last for a week or more.\n\nThere is no treatment; prevention (especially via immunization) is the most important form of protection and management, Manitoba Health says in its bulletin, which is to be distributed to all school divisions, post-secondary institutions, and registered daycares.\n\nWinnipeg School Division [WSD] senior information officer Radean Carter said Tue afternoon [24 Oct 2017] she had yet to see the Manitoba Health reminder, but once it is logged, it will be passed on to all principals and vice-principals 'and they will share the information with parents.'\n\nEach WSD school will disseminate the information as it best sees fit, she said, with most making contact with parents and guardians via email lists, while some will also print the document to be sent home with students.\n\nWSD is the largest in the city with more than 33 000 students attending 78 facilities.\n\nMeanwhile, a year into the outbreak, the number of cases continues its slow climb, rising from 853 confirmed in the province as of [31 Aug 2017].\n\n'In many outbreaks, you will have your general, bell-shaped curve: you'll start slow, peak and then wane out. With mumps, what we are seeing is more... of a flatter, straighter line,' Weiss said, adding Manitoba Health is keeping a close eye on the age groups involved, not just the total number.\n\n'We see (mumps) in certain numbers every year in Manitoba and across Canada, so we have an average. When goes above that average, we start looking at it in terms of: is it meeting other criteria for an outbreak?' she said.\n\n'It would be the same thing for calling an end. A year ago, we had an increased number... in a university-aged population which has now spread to all age groups. The same criteria would be used to say it's over: it goes back down to baseline levels.'\n\nWhile the information contained in the mumps bulletin is important, Weiss said -- stressing the need for good hand hygiene and to stay home when sick -- it is not uncommon for Manitoba Health to issue such public reminders, pointing out the department's annual flu season push and a notice for a German measles outbreak in the 1990s.\n\n[Byline: Scott Emmerson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at http://mapsof.net/uploads/static-maps/Canada_Provinces_and_territories_map.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/261. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See ProMED-mail Mumps update (30): USA, New Zealand 20171022.5396070 for discussion of the impact of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine as presented in N Engl J Med 2017; 377: 947-956 by CV Cardemil et al (http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1703309), as well as item [2] below. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nMumps-containing vaccine is either the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine or a vaccine that contains those 3 plus the chickenpox vaccine. With the US facing a growing number of mumps outbreaks [see figure of cases by year at the source URL above], an expert panel that advises the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended [Wed 25 Oct 2017] that people who are at risk during outbreaks should receive an additional, 3rd dose of vaccine. \n\nAlso see, 'Third MMR dose shows promise in curbing mumps outbreaks' http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2017/09/third-mmr-dose-shows-promise-curbing-mumps-outbreaks for a report on the impact of the 3rd dose of MMR on University of Iowa students during a mumps outbreak. ' Independent of this outbreak, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices -- a panel of medical and public health experts who meet 3 times a year to offer vaccination guidance for the United States -- will vote [Wed 25 Oct 2017; see report below] on whether to recommend the use of a 3rd dose of the MMR vaccine during outbreaks. The recommendation states that people who have had 2 doses of mumps vaccine but who are identified by public health officials as being at risk in a mumps outbreak should receive the 3rd dose. On [Wed 25 Oct 2016], a veteran vaccine expert -- Dr Stanley Plotkin, who is not a member of ACIP [Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices] -- suggested the committee should recommend a 3rd dose of mumps vaccine for all students entering university. \n\nWhile the information contained in the mumps bulletin is important, Weiss said -- stressing the need for good hand hygiene and to stay home when sick -- it is not uncommon for Manitoba Health to issue such public reminders, pointing out the department's annual flu season push and a notice for a German measles outbreak in the 1990s. Source: Pharmacist [edited]\nhttp://www.pharmacist.com/article/500-sickened-hawaii-mumps-outbreak\n\n\nHealth officials in Hawaii have reported a significant increase in mumps cases in the state's ongoing mumps outbreak. \n\n[Byline: Scott Emmerson]\n\n--\n Still, 2 doses of mumps vaccine -- the 1st given at between 12 and 15 months of age and the 2nd sometime between the ages of 4 and 6 years of age -- is thought to protect about 88 percent of people vaccinated. But ... we did not feel that we had any evidence to support a decision about a routine [3rd] dose outside of an actual exposure situation where there was an immediate need for that vaccine,' said Dr Kelly Moore, an ACIP member who chairs a work group that advises the panel on mumps vaccine. An outbreak of mumps has spurred Syracuse University [Onondaga County, New York] to offer students a 3rd 'booster' shot of the measles, mumps, and rubella [MMR] vaccine. However, as mumps outbreaks have increased, public health officials have noticed that children and young adults -- especially the latter -- who received both recommended doses of vaccine were among those contracting the disease. After years of very low numbers of mumps cases -- fewer than 1000 cases nationally a year -- the disease has made a resurgence of sorts in the past decade or so. \n\nEach year, the number of mumps cases fluctuates within a range of a couple hundred to a couple thousand, according to Patel. \n\nBefore the US mumps vaccination program started in 1967, the CDC received reports of 186 000 cases each year. AK)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5340444", "date": "2017-09-25 23:20:01", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (27): PACIFIC (NEW ZEALAND), USA (HAWAI'I, ALASKA)\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nPacific\n------\n[1] New Zealand (North Island, Tauranga)\n[2] New Zealand (Auckland)\nUSA\n---\n[3] Hawai'i\n[4] Alaska (Anchorage)\n\n******\n[1] New Zealand (North Island, Tauranga)\nDate: Tue 19 Sep 2017\nSource: Bay Of Plenty Times [edited]\nhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/bay-of-plenty-times/news/article.cfm?c_id=1503343&objectid=11923656\n\n\nHealth authorities say 3 people have been diagnosed with mumps in Tauranga this month [September 2017]. However, there were concerns more people might unwittingly be carrying and passing on the virus.\n\nToi Te Ora Public Health Organisation chief medical officer Neil de Wet said mumps could have serious health complications including swelling of the brain, loss of hearing, and potential infertility in young men, but these were rare.\n\nDr de Wet said there had been an increase in mumps cases in New Zealand in the past year, but most of these were in Auckland [see next post]. Up until last week, there had been 3 confirmed cases in the Bay of Plenty District Health Board area.\n\n'In the past, our immunisation rates have been very low, so people who are now in those 2 age groups -- 10-19 and 20-29 -- historically had low immunisation rates. It's not surprising that we are seeing most cases in these age groups.'\n\nThe Auckland Regional Public Health Service had been notified of 300 cases of mumps from 1 Jan-4 Sep this year [2017].\n\nDr de Wet said because of the high mumps numbers nationally, it was hard to establish Auckland links to the local cases.\n\n'We do have mumps in our community, and people can be asymptomatic, especially younger children. They might not be symptomatic, so not every case will be diagnosed,' Dr de Wet.\n\nMumps symptoms include headaches, a general feeling of unwellness and swelling of the jaw area.\n\n'For most people, this is an unpleasant illness that will get better on its own after about a week.'\n\nMumps can be spread from person to person throughout the air by coughing and sneezing. The MMR vaccine, which is part of routine childhood vaccines, prevents mumps as well as measles and rubella.\n\nAnyone who feels they might be sick or at risk is encouraged to phone their family doctor to arrange an appointment at a time unlikely to infect anyone else, Dr de Wet said.\n\nThe last mumps epidemic in New Zealand was in 1994, with 188 hospitalisations. 20-30 cases of mumps were still notified each year; about half are in children under 10 years of age.\n\nAuckland medical officer of health Dr Josephine Herman said mumps was now at large in the local community, 'and the only way we can stop this spreading further is to achieve high levels of MMR vaccination in the population.'\n\n[Byline: Kiri Gillespie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail of New Zealand can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]\n\n******\n[2] New Zealand (Auckland)\nDate: Mon 25 Sep 2017\nSource: Stuff [edited]\nhttps://www.stuff.co.nz/auckland/97197173/the-mumps-outbreak-continues-to-spread-at-a-rapid-rate-through-the-auckland-region\n\n\nThe mumps outbreak continues to spread at a rapid rate through the Auckland region, a sign of low vaccination rates, as the city deals with the most serious outbreak in more than 20 years.\n\nMore than 440 cases have been reported in the region so far this year [2017], with about 5 per cent of those cases needing hospitalisation.\n\nHealth authorities say the outbreak began in West Auckland and has now spread to south Auckland and across the region.\n\nThe last similar outbreak of mumps was in 1994 when there were between 200-300 cases reported. Since then, only handfuls of cases were reported each year, many from overseas.\n\nAuckland Regional Public Health Service [ARPHS] medical officer of health Josephine Herman said she had seen mumps-related meningitis and testes inflammation.\n\nThe most common complication of the current outbreak had been orchitis, which is inflammation of the testicles.\n\nThe disease can cause inflammation of tissue surrounding the brain (meningitis), inflamed testicles or ovaries, and permanent deafness. It can also lead to infertility.\n\nThe primary sign of mumps is swollen salivary glands that cause the cheeks to puff out; the term 'mumps' is an old expression for lumps or bumps within the cheeks.\n\nOther symptoms include headache, muscle aches and pain while chewing or swallowing.\n\nARPHS is warning that a large number of 10-29 year olds are not only at risk of mumps but also of measles and rubella due to some parents rejecting the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) vaccine.\n\nThe service said the 'lost generation' of unprotected young people was partly due to the MMR controversy in the late 1990s, something which has been thoroughly discredited.\n\nEveryone needed to urgently check that they had had 2 doses of the MMR vaccine and to get immunised if they needed to, Herman said.\n\n[Byline: Shabnam Dastgheib]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Hawai'i\nDate: Fri 22 Sep 2017\nSource: The Garden Island [edited]\nhttp://thegardenisland.com/lifestyles/health-med-fit/largest-outbreak-in-years/article_35c8ed0e-4b4a-54be-8c8f-fb0a77855a12.html\n\n\nIt's been 40 years since the number of mumps cases has reached current levels in Hawaii, according to the state epidemiologist, Sarah Park.\n\nThe Department of Health reported on Thu [21 Sep 2017] 384 confirmed cases of mumps for 2017, with 32 confirmed cases on Kauai, 334 on Oahu, 17 on Hawaii Island and one on Maui.\n\nThe disease has been confirmed in adults and children, both vaccinated and unvaccinated, according to DOH.\n\nPark said she hasn't seen those kinds of numbers since the 1970s. It's not specifically associated with schools, and it's throughout the islands.\n\n'This is a community and statewide outbreak,' said DOH spokeswoman Janice Okubo. 'Any cases in schools are only an indication of disease activity associated with that particular community.'\n\nIn the past 9 years, Wilcox Medical Center has seen only 4 mumps cases, according to Faith Campbell, marketing manager for Wilcox Health. That's compared to the 30 confirmed on the island in just 2017.\n\n'We have definitely seen an increase this year [2017] in patients with mumps-related symptoms,' she said.\n\nThe most common symptoms of mumps include fever, headache, muscle aches, loss of appetite, tiredness, and swollen glands in front of the ears or jaw on one or both sides. Mumps is best known for the puffy checks and swollen jaw that it causes, which is the result of these swollen glands, according to Wilcox Health.\n\nSome people who get mumps can have very mild or no symptoms, while others may feel sick but will not have swollen glands.\n\n'That is why it is important to consult your health care provider if you are experiencing any of these symptoms and stay at home to avoid spreading the disease to others,' Campbell said.\n\nMumps prevention comes in the form of a vaccine given in 2 doses. The 1st is generally administered at 12-15 months, and the 2nd is administered at 4-6 years old. DOH urges those who have had only one dose of the MMR vaccine to make an appointment to get the booster.\n\n[Byline: Jessica Else]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the US state of Hawai'i can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/214.]\n\n******\n[4] Alaska (Anchorage)\nDate: Sat 23 Sep 2017\nSource: Alaska Dispatch News [edited]\nhttps://www.adn.com/alaska-news/health/2017/09/22/13-confirmed-mumps-cases-in-anchorage-outbreak/\n\n\n'We're currently experiencing a mumps outbreak in Anchorage, and right now, we have 13 confirmed cases,' said Joe McLaughlin, state epidemiologist and chief of the section of epidemiology with the Department of Health and Social Services.\n\nIt's the 1st outbreak in Alaska in decades. The last one was in 1995 in Kodiak, when 10 people were infected, according to the state.\n\nIn the past 5 years, there have only been 3 cases reported, and all were from people who contracted the illness out of state, McLaughlin said.\n\nThe current outbreak cases range from ages 14-58. About 60 percent have been among Anchorage's Pacific Islander population. And roughly half of the cases were in people who had received mumps vaccinations.\n\n'It's really important to note that if people were not vaccinated, our case counts would be much, much higher than they are,' McLaughlin said.\n\nMumps vaccinations, which come in 2 doses, are 88 percent effective in preventing the illness.\n\n[Byline: Laurel Andrews]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the notable increase in mumps outbreaks globally, the panel of experts on vaccinations, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, has set up a working group to investigate the use of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine in response to outbreaks and will recommend to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention changes to mumps vaccination policy if the decision is made that this is scientifically justified.\n\nSuggested reading. Cardemil Cv et al. Effectiveness of a Third Dose of MMR Vaccine for Mumps Outbreak Control. N Engl J Med 2017; 377:947-956 7 Sep 2017 DOI: 10.1056/NEJMoa1703309.\n\nBackground. The effect of a 3rd dose of the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine in stemming a mumps outbreak is unknown. During an outbreak among vaccinated students at the University of Iowa, health officials implemented a widespread MMR vaccine campaign. We evaluated the effectiveness of a 3rd dose for outbreak control and assessed for waning immunity.\n\nConclusions. Students who had received a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine had a lower risk of mumps than did those who had received 2 doses, after adjustment for the number of years since the 2nd dose. Students who had received a 2nd dose of MMR vaccine 13 years or more before the outbreak had an increased risk of mumps. These findings suggest that the campaign to administer a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine improved mumps outbreak control and that waning immunity probably contributed to propagation of the outbreak. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the US state of Alaska can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/206.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the notable increase in mumps outbreaks globally, the panel of experts on vaccinations, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, has set up a working group to investigate the use of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine in response to outbreaks and will recommend to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention changes to mumps vaccination policy if the decision is made that this is scientifically justified. (New York), Pacific (New Zealand, Malaysia)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5381315", "date": "2017-10-14 21:18:42", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (29): USA (NEW YORK), PACIFIC (NEW ZEALAND, MALAYSIA)\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] - [3] New York (Syracuse)\nPacific\n-----\n[2] New Zealand\n[3] Malaysia\n\n******\nUSA\n----\n[1] New York (Syracuse)\nDate: Fri 06 Oct 2017 8:34 PM\nSource: Syracuse.com [edited]\nhttp://www.syracuse.com/orangelacrosse/index.ssf/2017/10/mumps_outbreak_cuts_short_fall_seasons_of_syracuse_mens_womens_lacrosse.html\n\n\nSyracuse women's lacrosse coach Gary Gait and his team will sit out scrimmages at Penn State, Navy and Manhasset this month [October 2017].\n\nThe Syracuse men's and women's lacrosse teams are shutting down practice and scrimmages for the rest of the fall season in response to an outbreak of mumps.\n\nDuring the past few weeks, SU [Syracuse University] has been working with state and Onondaga County Health Department officials to respond to confirmed cases of mumps among its student population. Currently, 8 students have been diagnosed with mumps, including members of the men's and women's lacrosse teams.\n\n'Our student-athletes' safety, and the safety of all students, faculty and staff, remains our top priority,' said Director of Athletics John Wildhack said in a statement. 'After continued discussions, and with great counsel from the state and county, we are confident this is the right call.'\n\nThe men's and women's teams will not participate in any organized activities for a minimum of 3 weeks. This will allow the Department of Athletics to employ necessary measures to help prevent the further spread of the disease.\n\nThe women's team will not participate in fall play days at Penn State, Navy and Manhasset. The men's team will sit out a scrimmage against Maryland and Stony Brook.\n\nThe men's team had pulled out of scrimmages against Team Israel and the Iroquois Nation last week.\n\nSU's teams have been practicing for about a month. Practice for the spring season starts in January....-more\n\n[Byline: Lindsay Kramer]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap/ProMED of New York, USA can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234 and the United States at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\n\n******\n[2] Syracuse\nDate: Wed 11 Oct 2017\nSource: CNY Central [edited]\nhttp://cnycentral.com/news/local/county-health-officials-su-give-update-on-mumps-cases\n\n\nDuring a news conference [Wed 11 Oct 2017] morning, health officials confirmed 13 Syracuse University students have been diagnosed with mumps since 21 Sep [2017] and said there are 5 additional 'probable' cases. Each of the confirmed cases occurred in students who had received the vaccination, officials said.\n\nThe majority of cases affect members of the university's lacrosse team, which has been shut down for the semester. Students diagnosed have been isolated and the university has made arrangements to educate them.\n\nAll new students are asked to get the vaccination. Although health officials conceded that the vaccination isn't 100 percent effective, they said it is still the best way to prevent mumps.\n\n'Those who are vaccinated will have a very small percentage, will have milder cases,' Onondaga County Health Commissioner Dr. Indu Gupta said. 'Those who are not vaccinated will suffer, unfortunately, negative consequences. Serious consequences.'\n\nHealth professionals say the defining symptom for the infection is a swollen gland by the jaw. The illness is passed through the air; those infected might spread it with a sneeze or a cough\n\n******\n[3] Syracuse\n\nDate: Thu 12 Oct 2017 12:14 am\nSource: Daily Orange [edited]\nhttp://dailyorange.com/2017/10/mumps-can-lesson-campus-wide-communication-syracuse-university/\n\n\nThe 1st case of the mumps on Syracuse University's (SU) campus was confirmed in late August [2017]. But most of the campus community didn't know about the potential health scare until 21 Sep [2017], when SU confirmed a 2nd mumps case and sent out a campus-wide email.\n\nIn a contained environment like SU, members of the campus community deserve to know when their health is at risk. Clear and timely information is SU's only chance at shutting down rumors about outbreaks before they start.\n\nOnly those who may have been exposed to the 1st mumps case received a warning email on 5 Sep [2017]. There was a 2-week gap between the 1st and 2nd emails -- plenty of time for mumps rumors to grow without official word from the administration.\n\nEven since SU sent out its 21 Sep [2017] email, rumors of class cancellations and student quarantine locations have circulated campus. An official email right away could have addressed potential rumors regarding the outbreak to avoid confusion and misinformation.\n\nIt's natural for a campus-wide email about a contagious disease to wreak some havoc on the community. But despite there being 13 confirmed mumps cases at SU, students don't seem too worried.\n\nThat's not to say SU students shouldn't take the threat of this disease seriously. But in cases of future public health incidents, SU administrators shouldn't let the fear of creating panic stop them from spreading pertinent public health information.\n\nAll told, SU has handled the mumps scare effectively. The campus-wide email was clear and straightforward, and subsequent updates have been consistent. But should another virus spring up, students, faculty and staff should know if there's a contagious disease on campus as soon as possible so they can take extra precautions.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\nPacific\n-----\n\n[4] New Zealand\nDate: Sun 8 Oct 2017\nSource: Newshub [edited]\nhttp://www.newshub.co.nz/home/health/2017/10/severe-mumps-outbreak-in-auckland-despite-free-vaccine.html\n\n\nA severe mumps outbreak continues to worsen as almost twice as many Aucklanders have caught the illness in the last 10 months as in the 2 decades prior.\n\nThe Auckland Regional Public Health Service says 527 people have now had confirmed or likely cases of mumps in the 10 months to [Thu 5 Oct 2017].\n\nBy comparison, just 286 people caught the illness - which is spread through the air by breathing, coughing and sneezing - in the 20 years prior from 1997 -- 1 Jan 2017.\n\n'What we have in Auckland right now with mumps is a severe outbreak situation,' Medical officer of health Josephine Herman says.\n\nShe said the outbreak was hitting Pacific and M\u0101ori communities and those aged between 10-and-24 years the hardest.\n\nWhile about 80 percent of children aged up to 12 are immunised against mumps, Dr Herman says there was now a 'lost generation' of young people in their mid-20s, who weren't fully immunised.\n\nThis was because of changes made in 2001 to the age at which children were supposed to get their 2nd dose.\n\nNational immunisation data also showed only 42 percent of M\u0101ori and 45 percent of Pacific children were immunised.\n\n'We need people to ensure they have had 2 doses of the measles, mumps, rubella vaccine,' Dr Hermann said.\n\nMumps can cause painful swelling of the gland around the face and jaw, fever and headaches.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap/ProMED of New Zealand can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164]\n\n******\n[5] Malaysia\nDate: Sun 8 Oct 2017\nSource: The Malay Mail Online [edited]\nhttps://sg.news.yahoo.com/mumps-outbreak-not-caused-haj-pilgrims-says-dept-231700799.html\n\n\nAn outbreak of the mumps virus at 3 schools in Putrajaya since July [2017] was not from exposure to those back from Saudi Arabia, according to the Kuala Lumpur and Putrajaya Health Department.\n\nDepartment director Dr Zainudin Abdul Wahab said the cases were instead traced to students who were not immunised to the virus.\n\n'These cases have no correlation with the pilgrims returning from the either Mecca or Madinah.\n\n'Mumps can be averted if the measles-mumps-rubella vaccination were administered and since April last year the vaccine had been given twice: At age 9 months and 12 months,' he said in a statement.\n\nZainudin said the cluster of mumps cases was first detected on 25 Jul [2017] involving children from a Putrajaya school.\n\nSince then recurring cases at the same school and 2 additional schools pushed the number of cases to 17 as of [Fri 13 Oct 2017].\n\n'The patients are stable and received outpatient treatment. They are expected to make full recovery between 2 and 3 weeks,' he said.\n\n'This is not a serious illness and complications are rare but those showing symptoms are encouraged to seek treatment as soon as possible.'\n\nAttempts to contact Zainudin on why students at the 1st school were not screened and isolated after initial cases went unanswered.\n\nIt was not possible to determine how many students at the affected schools were not given their measles shots.\n\nZainudin also said the department engaged the headmasters and student affairs teachers at the affected schools to raise awareness on the disease and health education had been intensified.\n\nTypical symptoms of infection are - headache; swollen, painful salivary glands on one or both sides of the face; muscle aches, weakness and fatigue and loss of appetite.\n\nThe disease spreads via contact with virus bearing saliva on any surface of as droplets released when an infected individual either coughs or sneezes.\n\n[Byline: Jonathan Edward]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Putrajaya, officially the Federal Territory of Putrajaya, is a planned city and the federal administrative centre of Malaysia.\n\nA Healthmap/ProMED of Malaysia can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/147 ]\n\n[As has been the case in recent reports of mumps (and measles) outbreaks, lack of sufficient vaccine coverage is the problem. Measles, mumps, and rubella can be prevented with MMR vaccine. CDC recommends children get 2 doses of MMR vaccine, starting with the 1st dose at 12 through 15 months of age, and the 2nd dose at 4 through 6 years of age. Teens and adults also should also be up to date on their MMR vaccination.\n\nMMR vaccine is very safe and effective. The mumps component of the MMR vaccine is about 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective when a person gets 2 doses; one dose is about 78 percent (range: 49 percent-92 percent) effective.\n\nBefore the U.S. mumps vaccination program started in 1967, mumps was a universal disease of childhood. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States. Mumps outbreaks can still occur in highly vaccinated U.S. communities, particularly in close-contact settings such as schools, colleges, and camps. However, high vaccination coverage helps to limit the size, duration, and spread of mumps outbreaks. (CDC) - Mod.LK]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap/ProMED of New York, USA can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234 and the United States at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap/ProMED of New Zealand can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164]\n\n******\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: CNY Central [edited]\nhttp://cnycentral.com/news/local/county-health-officials-su-give-update-on-mumps-cases\n\n\nDuring a news conference [Wed 11 Oct 2017] morning, health officials confirmed 13 Syracuse University students have been diagnosed with mumps since 21 Sep [2017] and said there are 5 additional 'probable' cases. \n\n'Mumps can be averted if the measles-mumps-rubella vaccination were administered and since April last year the vaccine had been given twice: At age 9 months and 12 months,' he said in a statement. \n\n[Byline: Lindsay Kramer]\n\n--\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Putrajaya, officially the Federal Territory of Putrajaya, is a planned city and the federal administrative centre of Malaysia. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\nPacific\n----- \n\nThe Auckland Regional Public Health Service says 527 people have now had confirmed or likely cases of mumps in the 10 months to [Thu 5 Oct 2017]. ' [3] Malaysia\n\n******\n \n\n--\n \n\n--\n [Byline: Jonathan Edward]\n\n--\n \n\nDepartment director Dr Zainudin Abdul Wahab said the cases were instead traced to students who were not immunised to the virus. \n\n[4] New Zealand\n \n\n'What we have in Auckland right now with mumps is a severe outbreak situation,' Medical officer of health Josephine Herman says. \n\nEven since SU sent out its 21 Sep [2017] email, rumors of class cancellations and student quarantine locations have circulated campus. The mumps component of the MMR vaccine is about 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective when a person gets 2 doses; one dose is about 78 percent (range: 49 percent-92 percent) effective. \n\nZainudin also said the department engaged the headmasters and student affairs teachers at the affected schools to raise awareness on the disease and health education had been intensified. But most of the campus community didn't know about the potential health scare until 21 Sep [2017], when SU confirmed a 2nd mumps case and sent out a campus-wide email. \n\n'Those who are vaccinated will have a very small percentage, will have milder cases,' Onondaga County Health Commissioner Dr. Indu Gupta said. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nMumps can cause painful swelling of the gland around the face and jaw, fever and headaches.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2017-10-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-01-01 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Stony Brook", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "M\u0101ori", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mecca", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "m\u0101ori", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW ZEALAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5352710", "date": "2017-10-01 11:05:09", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (28): CANADA, USA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n\nCanada\n---\n[1] Manitoba\n[2] Ontario\n\nUSA\n---\n[3] Alaska\n[4] North Carolina, Raleigh\n[5] Hawai'i (Big Island)\n\n******\n[1] Manitoba\nDate: Mon 25 Sep 2017\nSource: The Reminder [edited]\nhttp://www.thereminder.ca/news/local-news/mumps-outbreak-confirmed-in-north-flin-flon-affected-1.22935150\n\n\nFlin Flon has fared comparatively well during a mumps outbreak in northern Manitoba. A total of 98 cases of the highly contagious viral disease were reported across the Northern Health Region (NHR) in June 2017, with another 94 in July 2017.\n\n'In a typical year, we'd see 0, maybe 3, 4, 5 cases. This is extremely high for us in the North,' said NHR medical health officer Dr. Michael Isaac.\n\nWhile numbers have yet to be finalized for August 2017, more than 60 cases had already been reported as of mid last week.\n\nAdditional cases were possible given the lag time between exposure to mumps and the presence of symptoms.\n\nIsaac confirmed cases of mumps have been reported in Flin Flon in the past 3 months, but the number is lower than in other northern locations.\n\n'In general, the number of cases that we've had in Flin Flon has been relatively lower than we've seen in some other parts in the region,' he said. 'That's not to say that the virus might not work its way into the community, given a bit more time.\n\n'We've seen it in small communities, in First Nations communities, and in some of our larger communities as well. I would say for the most part, there hasn't been a community where we haven't seen at least a case or 2.'\n\nMumps has been reported in all age groups.\n\nThe disease is characterized by fever, headaches, muscle pains and glandular swelling in the neck, chin and jaw. In serious cases, mumps can cause brain infections, meningitis, genital inflammation and swelling, and deafness.\n\nIsaac confirmed none of the cases reported in the NHR have involved the more severe symptoms. 'We're not seeing some of the significant and real consequences of the mumps,' he said. 'We just haven't seen much of that in Manitoba.'\n\nMumps can lay dormant in a person for up to 3 weeks before symptoms present themselves. Most people receive a vaccination against the disease as children.\n\nIsaac said a higher-than-average number of people in northern Manitoba are vaccinated, which reduces both the number of potential infections and the severity of symptoms.\n\n'Our vaccination rates are actually a little bit higher than the rest of the province, which is contributing to the less severe cases we're seeing,' he said.\n\nIsaac said it's very difficult to say what is behind the northern outbreak. One possible reason is that mumps can spread more easily when people live in overcrowded housing and in smaller, tight-knit communities.\n\n'It's just a lot easier for the virus to spread in those places,' Isaac said. 'People are out and about in the community, and your chances of being exposed to the virus on any given day may be higher than if you were living in Winnipeg.'\n\nAvoiding the mumps is as simple as receiving a vaccination. Isaac advises people to check their vaccination status and receive boosters if needed.\n\n'If you haven't had a mumps vaccine in the past, we're encouraging people to go ahead and do that,' he said. 'That will offer some protection for sure.'\n\nPeople who suspect they have the mumps are advised to call ahead to a clinic or ER and book an appointment in advance.\n\n'That helps from spreading the disease around unnecessarily when going through care,' Isaac said.\n\nFor people who strongly suspect they have the mumps, Isaac says the best course of action is to self-isolate for 5 days.\n\n'Once the 5 days is up, their chance of spreading the virus to anyone else is extremely low,' he said.\n\n[Byline: Eric Westhaver]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail of Canada can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12 and Manitoba Province, Canada, at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/261.]\n\n******\n[2] Ontario\nDate: Wed 27 Sep 2017\nSource: Global News [edited]\nhttps://globalnews.ca/news/3772710/peterborough-public-health-urges-vaccination-as-mumps-outbreak-continues/\n\n\nPeterborough Public Health wants residents to check their vaccination records after 3 people were diagnosed with the mumps virus.\n\nMedical Officer of Health, Dr. Rosana Salvaterra, said she wouldn't be surprised if more cases surfaced in the Peterborough area over the next few days.\n\n'There have been more than 100 cases in Ontario alone, so it's definitely not surprising that we're seeing an outbreak here,' she said.\n\nMumps causes fever, headaches and swollen salivary glands. The virus can put pregnant women at an increased risk for miscarriage, and some cases can lead to sterility in men.\n\n'About 10 per cent of cases will go on to develop meningitis,' Salvaterra said. 'People can lose their hearing, and it can be permanent.'\n\nThere is a vaccine for mumps, though Salvaterra said there are many people who may not have received a full dose of the vaccine.\n\nToday, children get 2 rounds of vaccination before starting school.\n\nBut Salvaterra said there is a generation that only got one dose, which puts them at risk of contracting the virus.\n\n'So check to make sure you've had 2 doses,' Salvaterra said. 'If you've had 2 doses, you've done the best possible thing to protect yourself, and about 88 per cent of those people will be protected.'\n\nAnyone who doesn't have the mumps vaccine is encouraged to call their health-care provider or visit the health unit.\n\n[Byline: Sarah Deeth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap of Ontario Province, Canada can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/260.]\n\n******\n[3] Alaska\nDate: Thu 28 Sep 2017\nSource: SitNews [edited]\nhttp://www.sitnews.us/0917News/092817/092817_mumps_outbreak.html\n\n\nThe Alaska Department of Health and Social Services and the Municipality of Anchorage have warned Anchorage residents of a recent spread of mumps and are encouraging residents to update their vaccinations if necessary. Several new mumps cases have been diagnosed in the past few months, and there are now 13 confirmed cases of the disease in Anchorage. Most of these cases have occurred in young adults.\n\nMumps is a contagious viral disease with symptoms that include swollen and tender cheeks, fever, head and muscle aches, and fatigue that appear 2-3 weeks after infection. Males may also develop sore or swollen testicles. Some people do not have any symptoms, and, infrequently, persons with mumps may experience serious health effects.\n\nLarge outbreaks of mumps have occurred this year [2017] across the country. State health officials suspect a traveler from outside Alaska may have brought the virus to Anchorage.\n\nMumps is spread by coughing, sneezing, talking, and sharing cups or utensils. Infected people without symptoms may be able to spread the disease to others.\n\nAlaskans can help protect themselves and their families from the spread of mumps by making sure their MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccinations are up to date. While some vaccinated individuals can still be infected, most people who have had 2 MMR vaccinations are immune to mumps. Young children and other people who have not been vaccinated are at a higher risk of contracting the disease.\n\nNearly all students in the Anchorage School District have had 2 doses of the MMR vaccine. Anyone unsure of their vaccination status should contact their health care provider.\n\nA person with mumps symptoms should call their health care provider before going into a doctor's office to prevent spreading illness in the waiting room.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the US state of Alaska can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/206.]\n\n******\n[4] North Carolina (Raleigh)\nDate: Fri 29 Sep 2017\nSource: WLOS [edited]\nhttp://wlos.com/news/local/nc-mumps-outbreak-leads-to-vaccination-plea\n\n\nOrange County health officials have identified 3 confirmed cases of mumps over the last 2 months. The ages of those infected haven't been released or whether they're in a concentrated place. But, health officials say the risk of becoming infected is low, especially if you've been properly vaccinated against mumps.\n\nIf you're unsure, now's the time to check your records or ask your doctor. There's also a blood test that can show whether you're already immune. You also want to start monitoring for symptoms, which include fever, headaches, fatigue, loss of appetite, and the swelling of your face or jaw. These would show up around 16 days after infection.\n\nMumps is spread through direct contact with an infected person's saliva and droplets from coughing and sneezing. Local health departments offer vaccines to prevent mumps infection. If you're already showing symptoms, you should stay home and call your doctor.\n\n[Byline: Brian Nemitz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 1 Jan-9 Sep 2017, 47 states and the District of Columbia in the U.S. reported mumps infections in 4439 people to CDC. In 2016, there were approximately 6366 cases reported to CDC; the number varies from year to year. See https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html for a figure showing year to year reported case numbers.\n\nSince the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99% decrease in mumps cases in the United States. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap of North Carolina, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/235.]\n\n******\n[5] Hawai'i (Big Island)\nDate: 30 Sep 2017\nSource: Hawai'I Tribune-Herald [edited]\nhttp://hawaiitribune-herald.com/news/local-news/big-island-mumps-cases-continue-increase\n\n\nThe state Department of Health's weekly mumps update Thu [28 Sep 2017] showed 24 Big Island mumps cases so far this year [2017].\n\nThe highly contagious virus has hit 419 people of various ages statewide this year [2017], the DOH reported. Hawaii County numbers continue to climb.\n\nThose with confirmed or suspected mumps should 'self-isolate' and avoid exposing others for 9 days after salivary glands swell.\n\nAlso, unvaccinated people exposed to mumps 'should not attend school, work or travel from day 12 through day 25 after exposure.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A [1] Manitoba\nDate: Mon 25 Sep 2017\n \n\n'In general, the number of cases that we've had in Flin Flon has been relatively lower than we've seen in some other parts in the region,' he said. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-06-25 00:00:00", "2017-09-25 00:00:00", "4439-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-07-25 00:00:00", "2017-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Manitoba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anchorage", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alaska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Peterborough", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orange County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manitoba Province", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5435146", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (32): South America, USA, New Zealand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5435146", "date": "2017-11-10 11:18:50", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (32): SOUTH AMERICA, USA, NEW ZEALAND\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] South America (Bolivia)\n[2] USA (Washington)\n[3] USA (District of Columbia)\n[4] New Zealand\n\n******\n[1] South America (Bolivia)\nDate: Wed 1 Nov 2017\nSource: Pagina Siete [in Spanish, trans. Mod.JG]\nhttp://www.paginasiete.bo/sociedad/2017/11/1/bolivia-registra-brote-inusitado-paperas-luego-cinco-anos-157841.html\n\n\nThis year [2017] Bolivia is experiencing an unusual outbreak of mumps. According to data from the Ministry of Health, the number of reported cases until now is 3 times higher compared to figures recorded 5 years ago.\n\n'We've had an important outbreak of mumps this year [2017],' pointed out Adolfo Zarate, Head of the Epidemiology area of the Ministry of Health, who also mentioned that during this year 2044 cases of mumps have been reported. This is 3 times the figure for 2013, when a similar outbreak took place, but only 776 cases were reported. Mr Zarate explained that this explosive condition is because of the change of season, and also because non-immunized people may gather, so this may generate the high number of cases.\n\nYesterday [31 Oct 2017], La Paz Health Service (SEDES, according to its Spanish initials) reported that the mumps vaccine, which is included within the MRM package (measles, rubella, and mumps) only confers 80 percent protection. The vaccine is administered to children between 12 and 24 months of age, and a booster dose is given when they are 4 years old.\n\nThe most affected departments are La Paz, 1698 cases; Santa Cruz, 221 cases, and Cochabamba. For this reason, Mr Zarate urged the (symptomatic) population to go to health centers in order to have timely therapy.\n\nIn La Paz city, SEDES reported last week that this is an alarming situation, since 'there is an explosive and persistent outbreak'.\n\nMumps is a viral disease that is transmitted from person to person through saliva (droplets). Affected persons most commonly present with the following symptoms: fever, sore throat, parotid gland enlargement (inflammation), and loss of appetite.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that all affected persons must get rest if they develop symptoms, since male subjects may develop orchitis (testis inflammation) or ovaritis (ovarian inflammation), which may lead -- in a small percentage of cases -- to infertility.\n\nHe also advised that affected persons must use masks; they must also avoid sharing cutlery and dishes, and thoroughly wash their hands. It is also important to disinfect the household using detergents, in order to prevent transmission of the disease to other members of the family.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that sanitary triage must be established in educational facilities, so that if parents, teachers, or school authorities find a symptomatic student, he/she must be immediately sent home and be isolated for at least 10 days.\n\nThe disease may occur at any age in a non-immunized person, but most commonly affected individuals are those less than 20 years of age.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Bolivia can be seen at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/bolivia_admin_2006.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Washington)\nDate: Thu 2 Nov 2017\nSource: iFIBER One News [edited]\nhttp://www.ifiberone.com/columbia_basin/mumps-and-whooping-cough-a-problem-in/youtube_71b3dcd4-c002-11e7-9a61-ff27becf4d65.html\n\n\nGrant County [Washington] saw an extraordinary amount of mumps cases this year [2017] with 45. The mumps outbreak was contained to the Columbia Basin Job Corps and the Ephrata School District. Grant County Health District's Theresa Atkinson says that was a fraction of the 888 cases reported statewide.\n\n'The mumps outbreak was incredibly large for our area,' said Adkinson Fortunately, no one currently has mumps in Grant County.\n\nThe same cannot be said about whooping cough with 78 current cases in the county. This year [2017], Moses Lake had 54 cases of pertussis, Ephrata had 22, Soap Lake 2 and both Royal City and Warden had 1.\n\n'It's the largest pertussis outbreak we've ever experienced,' said Adkinson.\n\nFor more on how to prevent these illnesses, go to http://granthealth.org.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248. Grant county can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/washington-county-map.gif. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n\n[3] USA (District of Columbia)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017\nSource: Washington Post [edited]\nhttps://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2017/11/06/mumps-reported-at-catholic-university-georgetown/\n\n\nMumps, an infectious disease carried on a sneeze or a cup, appears to be spreading among DC [USA, District of Columbia] universities, with cases reported at 3 schools.\n\nThe Catholic University of America recently identified a cluster of illness, with 4 confirmed mumps cases and 3 more suspected cases under investigation, a school spokeswoman said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nOn [Fri 3 Nov 2017], a message sent to the Georgetown University community said 2 undergraduates had been diagnosed with the disease.\n\nThe cases at Georgetown have been confirmed, according to a letter from the DC Department of Health.\n\nAnd American University has 2 confirmed mumps cases, as well as 4 suspected cases, school spokesman Mark Story said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nThe mumps cases at DC universities appear to be connected, though officials are still investigating, DC Department of Health spokeswoman Jasmine Gossett said.\n\n'We are monitoring them and are working with the universities and their student health centers, just to inform them and then educate those who may be at risk,' Gossett said.\n\nAt Catholic, the school has adjusted Communion distribution during Mass to help combat the illness, university spokeswoman Elise Italiano said. 'Normally, we offer Communion through the host and what we call the chalice, or the cup with wine,' Italiano said. 'And we suspended the 2nd practice . . . because of the possible spread through saliva. So, we've just taken that extra precaution.'\n\nMumps spreads through saliva or mucus, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Symptoms include fever, headaches, and swollen and tender glands under the ears, the CDC's website notes.\n\nGeorgetown officials asked infected students to cloister themselves for 5 days after the appearance of initial symptoms, a note to the campus from Vince WinklerPrins, assistant vice president for student health, said.\n\n'We will continue to monitor and support these students,' WinklerPrins said.\n\nIn an email sent to its campus community, Catholic said residential students who had reported mumps symptoms have been moved to an unoccupied space, in an attempt to limit exposure.\n\n'Students are able to return to rooms and classes after a 5-day period,' the email stated.\n\nCatholic's students were also briefed on how someone infected with mumps can spread the virus: by coughing or sharing a drink, for example. They were advised to keep their hands clean and to not share their utensils.\n\nThe University of Virginia [U-Va] has also recently urged students to take precautions after 2 suspected cases were identified. A U-Va spokesman did not immediately return an email seeking an update [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\n[Byline: Sarah Larimer]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAnn Zhang\nUniversity of Rochester\n<ayzhang24@gmail.com>\n\nProMED thanks Ann Zhang for alerting us to these cases.\n\n[Because of the rise in mumps outbreaks observed at US universities since 2006, a federal expert US panel has endorsed a 3rd vaccine dose in such outbreak situations. See http://wapo.st/2yoWDc1 for a report on this decision, as well as ProMED mail Mumps update (31): USA, MMR 3rd dose, Canada 20171027.5407525.\n\nWashington DC can be located on the maps at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/ and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/259. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] New Zealand (Auckland)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017 1:17 PM NZDT\nSource: NZ Herald, Newstalk ZB [edited]\nhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11940991\n\n\nPublic health service medical officer, Dr Josephine Herman, says NZ has a vulnerable population who have not been fully immunised.\n\nAuckland Regional Public Health Service has been notified of 740 cases of mumps since 1 Jan [2017]. Dr Herman, said this was the worst outbreak since 1994. 'This is quite a large outbreak, and something we're very concerned about, and trying our best to implement public health measures to try to contain,' Herman said.\n\nShe said Auckland was essentially free of the viral disease even late last year [2016], but the outbreak began after being picked up overseas. Herman said it particularly came from the Pacific Islands -- mostly Fiji, and later Tonga -- where the mumps vaccine was not available.\n\nShe said there have also been 'massive' outbreaks in the US and the UK, which has spread easily through universities, she said.\n\n'In terms of where the mumps infection is occurring, it's actually all throughout the world. New Zealand has been immune to it until late last year [2016] and early this year. Because we've had a vulnerable population here who have not been fully immunised with the MMR vaccine, it's allowed community spread to be well established.\n\n'We are importing mumps, as well as probably exporting it as well.'\n\nHerman said it was not possible to know if the rates of the disease have peaked.\n\nBut she said if people have not received the MMR vaccine, to do so immediately. Other ways to combat the spread include washing hands, covering coughs and cleaning commonly used items.\n\nHerman says for most adults, it's a mild illness. However, a small proportion can develop complications including meningitis or encephalitis. Young children are more at risk of developing harmful outcomes.\n\n[Byline: Jordan Bond]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak is a consequence of introduction of mumps into a community with low vaccination coverage. More often, mumps outbreaks are the consequence of waning immunity in young adults. But the Auckland outbreak is a reminder that even with elimination of mumps (and measles) from a country, high immunization levels must be maintained.\n\nMaps of New Zealand can be seen at http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dc/NZTerritorialAuthorities.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/606. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe Catholic University of America recently identified a cluster of illness, with 4 confirmed mumps cases and 3 more suspected cases under investigation, a school spokeswoman said [Mon 6 Nov 2017]. \n\n'We've had an important outbreak of mumps this year [2017],' pointed out Adolfo Zarate, Head of the Epidemiology area of the Ministry of Health, who also mentioned that during this year 2044 cases of mumps have been reported. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< The mumps cases at DC universities appear to be connected, though officials are still investigating, DC Department of Health spokeswoman Jasmine Gossett said. \n\n'In terms of where the mumps infection is occurring, it's actually all throughout the world. \n\n'We are importing mumps, as well as probably exporting it as well.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "pertussis", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2032-03-25 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00", "2044-03-25 00:00:00", "1698-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-01 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tonga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Paz", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Royal City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SOUTH AMERICA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NZ", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Cruz", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW
