"Grant County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5300162", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (25): USA (Hawai'i Island) New Zealand (AU)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5300162", "date": "2017-09-07 18:56:18", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (25): USA (HAWAI'I ISLAND) NEW ZEALAND (AUKLAND)\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Hawai'I (Hawai'I Island)\n[2] New Zealand (Aukland)\n\n******\n[1] Hawai'i (Hawai'i Island)\nDate: Sat 2 Sep 2017 12:05am\nSource: Hawaii Tribune-Herald [edited]\nhttp://hawaiitribune-herald.com/news/local-news/vigilance-urged-mumps-cases-increase-hawaii-island\n\n\nThe number of confirmed mumps cases on Hawaii Island has climbed to 8.\n\n'If you are seeing cases in your community, the likelihood of seeing additional cases should be expected,' said Ronald Balajadia, immunization branch chief with the state Department of Health.\n\nHe said people diagnosed with mumps on the Big Island range in age from 6--39. He declined to say where the new cases occurred.\n\nEarlier this month [September 2017], Naalehu Elementary School notified parents that mumps had been confirmed in a student. The student was asked to stay home for 2 weeks, the Ka'u-Keaau-Pahoa Complex Area superintendent said last week [week of Sun 27 Aug 2017].\n\nMumps is a highly transmissible virus that vaccination had controlled until outbreaks began worsening in 2006. It's problematic because a person is contagious for 2 days before facial swelling starts and for 9 days afterward.\n\nMumps has become a nationwide problem, with only 3 states reporting no cases to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: West Virginia, South Dakota and Wyoming. In Hawaii, 312 confirmed cases of mumps have been reported this year [2017].\n\nBalajadia's plea is that people diagnosed with mumps -- which has flu-like symptoms -- stay home from work or school while their condition is transmissible.\n\nHe said vaccination against mumps is 88 percent effective, meaning 12 percent of vaccinated people are at risk for development of mumps despite the MMR (measles mumps rubella) vaccination. Cases that develop among vaccinated individuals, though, tend to be less severe than without vaccination.\n\nBalajadia encourages people to talk with a physician about vaccination.\n\nPeople risk getting exposed, according to the CDC, by standing near someone who coughs or sneezes, sipping from the same glass of water, living in close quarters with a large group of friends or family, or eating from a shared plate of food.\n\nWhy are mumps a problem now? Balajadia said it's been many years since a major mumps outbreak. Hawaii's vaccination rate for schoolchildren is greater than 90 percent, Balajadia said. That means 10 percent of children in school are susceptible because they're not vaccinated for religious or health reasons, and 22 percent of vaccinated people overall also are susceptible to mumps.\n\n'It's a large pool of susceptibles,' Balajadia said. 'If people were not vaccinated to that degree, we would be seeing way more cases.'\n\nThe Department of Health's website urges anyone born after 1957 to get an MMR vaccination if the person has had no vaccination, or only one dose.\n\nPeople born before 1957 are presumed to already have been infected with mumps and built immunity.\n\nAll children are supposed to get 2 doses of MMR, one at age 12--15 months and a 2nd at age 4--6, the CDC recommends.\n\nHowever, the state DOH website recommends that 'due to the continued circulation of mumps in Hawaii, children between 1--4 years of age should receive their 2nd dose now.'\n\nThe 2nd dose should be given at least 4 weeks after the 1st.\n\nThe rise in Big Island cases, Balajadia said, should trigger people to be especially cautious about protecting themselves from exposure and about protecting others.\n\nWash hands repeatedly, he urged. Avoid sharing cups, spoons and forks with others. If someone is coughing or sneezing, turn away.\n\n[Byline: Jeff Hansel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Hawaii State Department of Health (DOH) continues to investigate an increasing number of cases of mumps infections statewide.\nThe disease has been confirmed in children and adults, both vaccinated and unvaccinated. Approximately half of cases have been in adults aged 18 years and older.\n\nAs of August 31, 2017:\nNumber of confirmed cases of mumps for 2017: 312\nCase count by island:\nOahu 277\nKauai 26\nHawaii 8\nMaui 1\n\n(From 31 Aug 2017 State of Hawaii, Department of Health, Disease Outbreak Control Division\nhttp://health.hawaii.gov/docd/department-of-health-investigating-mumps-cases/)\n\nFrom 1 Jan -- 12 Aug 2017, 47 states* and the District of Columbia in the U.S. reported mumps infections in 4240 people to CDC. An increase in mumps cases has been noted worldwide.\n\nA map of Hawaii, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/214]. - Mod.LK\n\n******\n[2] New Zealand (Aukland)\nDate: Tue 5 Sep 2017 7:01 pm\nSource: RNZ [edited]\nhttp://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/338728/mumps-outbreak-300-cases-in-auckland\n\n\nAn outbreak of mumps in Auckland is now widespread and is mostly affecting young Pasifika people, public health authorities say.\n\nThere have been 300 cases recorded since January [2017], which is more than all the cases over the previous 16 years. Public health authorities say it poses a serious risk to young people who have not been vaccinated.\n\nMedical Officer of Health Josephine Herman said 60 percent of cases so far have affected young adolescents in the Pasifika community.\n\nDoctors are especially worried about what they describe as a lost generation, now aged between 10 and 29, who failed to get the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) vaccine when they were children because of a now discredited controversy about the vaccine.\n\nThey say a pool of adults also missed out when the timing of free doses was changed in 2001, and that's left them at risk as well.\n\nMumps has taken hold in Auckland but is also occurring across the country. There have been at least 12 cases in Dunedin, in its 1st outbreak of the disease in years.\n\n'This is a situation that we are not very happy to be in because much of this could have been prevented with immunisation with the MMR vaccine,' Dr Herman said.\n\nShe urged all those who failed to get the vaccine, or were not sure whether they had had the required 2 doses, to get the free jab now.\n\n'We shouldn't be seeing measles, rubella and mumps in this day and age, with the technology we have and the advances we have made in health service delivery.'\n\nAuckland GP Emalia Lavemai, who runs school-based clinics in south and eastern Auckland, agreed with Dr Herman.\n\nShe said sterility was a rare complication of mumps for men, and there were other potential problems for pregnant women.\n\n'If they're not fully immunised and do contract mumps or rubella or measles, then there are an increase in miscarriage rates and other birth defects as well, if they contract [the disease] during their pregnancy.'\n\nA total of 80 percent of children up to 12 have had the MMR vaccine, but only 60 percent of P\u0101keh\u0101 children were covered in 1991, with rates for M\u0101ori and Pacific children lower at 42 and 45 percent respectively.\n\nAuckland University vaccine expert Helen Petousis-Harris said such low coverage meant the outbreak should have been expected, and it was not known how many of those aged 10 -- 29 are immunised.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The indigenous people lack sufficient vaccine coverage to protect them from an outbreak. It is important for public health officials to address this deficiency through education of the people on the importance and safety of vaccination.\n\nA Healthmap/ProMED of New Zealand can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n He said vaccination against mumps is 88 percent effective, meaning 12 percent of vaccinated people are at risk for development of mumps despite the MMR (measles mumps rubella) vaccination. \n\nBalajadia's plea is that people diagnosed with mumps -- which has flu-like symptoms -- stay home from work or school while their condition is transmissible.\n\n Maui 1\n\n(From 31 Aug 2017 State of Hawaii, Department of Health, Disease Outbreak Control Division\nhttp://health.hawaii.gov/docd/department-of-health-investigating-mumps-cases/)\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The indigenous people lack sufficient vaccine coverage to protect them from an outbreak. \n\nA total of 80 percent of children up to 12 have had the MMR vaccine, but only 60 percent of P\u0101keh\u0101 children were covered in 1991, with rates for M\u0101ori and Pacific children lower at 42 and 45 percent respectively. Number of confirmed cases of mumps for 2017: 312\nCase count by island:\n \n\nDoctors are especially worried about what they describe as a lost generation, now aged between 10 and 29, who failed to get the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) vaccine when they were children because of a now discredited controversy about the vaccine. \n\n'If you are seeing cases in your community, the likelihood of seeing additional cases should be expected,' said Ronald Balajadia, immunization branch chief with the state Department of Health. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Hawaii State Department of Health (DOH) continues to investigate an increasing number of cases of mumps infections statewide. \n\nMedical Officer of Health Josephine Herman said 60 percent of cases so far have affected young adolescents in the Pasifika community. \n\nThere have been 300 cases recorded since January [2017], which is more than all the cases over the previous 16 years. That means 10 percent of children in school are susceptible because they're not vaccinated for religious or health reasons, and 22 percent of vaccinated people overall also are susceptible to mumps. \n\nMumps has become a nationwide problem, with only 3 states reporting no cases to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: West Virginia, South Dakota and Wyoming. \n\n'We shouldn't be seeing measles, rubella and mumps in this day and age, with the technology we have and the advances we have made in health service delivery.' \n\n'If they're not fully immunised and do contract mumps or rubella or measles, then there are an increase in miscarriage rates and other birth defects as well, if they contract [the disease] during their pregnancy.' \n\nAuckland University vaccine expert Helen Petousis-Harris said such low coverage meant the outbreak should have been expected, and it was not known how many of those aged 10 -- 29 are immunised. \n\nAll children are supposed to get 2 doses of MMR, one at age 12--15 months and a 2nd at age 4--6, the CDC recommends. \n\nPeople born before 1957 are presumed to already have been infected with mumps and built immunity. \n\nMumps is a highly transmissible virus that vaccination had controlled until outbreaks began worsening in 2006. [2] New Zealand (Aukland)\n\n******\n \n\nPeople risk getting exposed, according to the CDC, by standing near someone who coughs or sneezes, sipping from the same glass of water, living in close quarters with a large group of friends or family, or eating from a shared plate of food. [Byline: Jeff Hansel]\n\n--\n \n\n--\n \n\nThe Department of Health's website urges anyone born after 1957 to get an MMR vaccination if the person has had no vaccination, or only one dose. LK\n\n******\n \n\nMumps has taken hold in Auckland but is also occurring across the country. \n\nBalajadia encourages people to talk with a physician about vaccination.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-10-29 00:00:00", "2017-08-31 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW ZEALAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5325095", "date": "2017-09-19 10:40:51", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (26): USA (TEXAS), CANADA (MANITOBA, BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA: Texas (Hidalgo County, Edinburg) jail\n[2] Canada: Manitoba, correctional center\n[3] Canada: British Columbia (Vancouver) alert\n\n******\n[1] USA: Texas (Hidalgo county, Edinburg) jail\nDate: Fri 15 Sep 2017 CEST\nSource: KRGV [edited]\nhttp://www.krgv.com/story/36371751/mumps-outbreak-at-lopez-state-jail\n\n\nAuthorities are reporting another mumps outbreak at the Lopez State Jail in Edinburg [Hidalgo county, Texas].\n\nThe Texas Department of Criminal Justice [TDCJ] confirms there are 149 offenders there who have been quarantined. 3 offenders recently tested positive for the illness.\n\nIf anyone has a loved one in the facility, the prison is asking for them to call before you head over for visitation.\n\nA notice posted on the TDCJ website said there is also housing areas at the gurney unit in Palestine, Texas and at the Willacy County State Jail that are under restrictions due to 'confirmed illnesses.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63143. Edinburg and Hidalgo county in southern Texas can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/texas-county-map.gif. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Canada: Manitoba, correctional center\nDate: Sat 16 Sep 2017 4:00 AM CDT\nSource: Winnipeg Free Press [edited]\nhttps://www.winnipegfreepress.com/local/numbers-of-patients-triples-in-mumps-outbreak-444808883.html\n\n\nAn outbreak of mumps at the Brandon Correctional Centre [BCC, Manitoba] has staff worried as the number of cases more than tripled in the past few weeks.\n\nA correctional centre staff member, who asked to remain anonymous for fear of losing their job, said the number of confirmed cases had gone to 9 from 2 in a 2-week period, with 3 more cases waiting to be confirmed as of [Thu 14 Sep 2017]. One of those confirmed cases is a staff member.\n\n'It may be small numbers, but it's still not small potatoes to us,' the staff member said. 'Staff at the centre are biting their nails... we want to exhale, but we can't.'\n\nMumps is a contagious viral infection that causes flu-like symptoms, swollen and painful salivary glands, swollen cheeks, difficulty chewing, swallowing or talking, and loss of appetite.\n\nMumps can be spread through the air and by sharing of food or drinks. It can also be contracted by touching something previously touched by an infected person.\n\nStaff are concerned there aren't enough reactive measures or preventative measures happening at the medium/maximum security centre that houses both men and women.\n\n'The clean up and the follow up for these communicable diseases is really poor, as far as we're concerned,' the staff member said, adding other inmates are given a mask and put in charge of wiping cells down with disinfectant after an infected inmate leaves the area.\n\nA quarantine area has also been set up in a disassociation cell next to a staff office less than 10 feet [3 m] away. Infected inmates are required to wear face masks at all times, the staff member said, but it doesn't always happen.\n\n'At one time, we had 3 guys in one cell with the mumps... they were hot and sweaty and they were tired of wearing their face masks so they took them off while we're serving them meals,' the source said.\n\nThe mumps cases started in the kitchen, the staff member said, adding to the concern with how quickly it's spread.\n\n'We hear (the inmates) during meal time, they'll say things like, 'Mmm, spaghetti with a side of mumps.' They know what's going on... I have yet to have anyone refuse a tray from the kitchen... but they're aware it's there.'\n\nA spokesperson for Manitoba Justice confirmed via email there have been a small number of inmates who have shown symptoms or tested positive for mumps, adding to date those symptoms have been flu-like and relatively minor, and the effect on operations has been minimal.\n\nWhen asked to comment further -- specifically on staff concerns -- the spokesperson said BCC is following public health advice on appropriate cleaning and other management protocols.\n\n'All of our correctional centres have health and safety representatives who are encouraged to raise employees' concerns with management. Though mumps is a recent example, the management of infectious diseases is an ongoing part of daily operations in all of our facilities,' the spokesperson wrote.\n\nRequests for a further interview with the superintendent of BCC or an official with Manitoba Justice were declined.\n\nThe staff member said several people have completed workplace health and safety forms, and the union has also been advised of their concerns.\n\n'Our officers strive to ensure the safety of everyone in the jail, so anytime a medical situation arises it's obviously concerning,' Manitoba Government and General Employees' Union president Michelle Gawronsky said via email. 'Public health has been involved and are providing guidance for staff and inmates, and we are taking direction from them on what next steps are needed.'\n\nStaff were encouraged to double-check their immunization records and make sure they are up-to-date, the staff member said, and BCC was required to provide a clinic for staff to receive the required vaccines to protect against mumps.\n\nThe Brandon Court House is also taking precautions, opting to have inmates with symptoms or confirmed mumps cases appear in court by video.\n\n[Byline: Erin DeBooy]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the close living quarters of inmates and movement of inmates between and within facilities, controlling mumps in a correctional setting can be difficult. Vaccination and quarantine are required to prevent continued transmission, and spread outside the facility.\n\nMaps of Canada can be seen at http://www.map-of-canada.org/canada-map-795.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12.\nA map of Manitoba province can be seen at https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/2f/Manitoba_generalmap.png. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Canada: British Columbia (Vancouver) alert\nDate: Thu 14 Sep 2017\nSource: Toronto Metro News [edited]\nhttp://www.metronews.ca/news/vancouver/2017/09/14/health-authority-calls-for-immunization-after-mumps-outbreak.html\n\n\nVancouver Coastal Health [VCH] is encouraging young people heading back to university to get immunized after 13 new cases of mumps were recorded over the past month.\n\nThe health authority says there have been 80 cases of mumps since February [2017], compared to 86 for all of last year. The average number of cases over the previous 5 years is 32.\n\nLast year [2016], Vancouver Canucks [ice hockey team] defenceman Troy Stecher was diagnosed with the contagious virus, while 5 teammates and a trainer all displayed symptoms of the illness.\n\n'We continue to see mumps in increasing numbers, and these outbreaks will continue unless young adults between the ages of 23 and 47 receive 2 doses of vaccine so they are fully protected,' said Dr Althea Hayden, VCH medical health officer, in a statement [Thu 14 Sep 2017].\n\nMumps is a virus that causes fever and swelling of the salivary glands, located below the jaw and ears and under the tongue. In rare cases it can cause sterility, deafness, and inflammation of the brain.\n\nThe virus is spread through saliva or mucus from the nose, mouth, or throat of an infected person. It can spread through coughs and sneezes and by sharing food, drinks, cigarettes, and by kissing.\n\nYoung people living in shared housing in close contact with others -- like those heading off to university -- are most likely to contract mumps, experts warned.\n\nVancouver Coastal Health says people born in 1970 of after need 2 doses of mumps vaccine, while those born between 1957 and 1969 need only one dose. People born before 1957 or have had a mumps infection are considered protected.\n\n[Byline: Jeff Hodson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As do the inmates in correctional facilities, students in universities live in close quarters, and frequently move between classes and living quarters, allowing for virus spread to unimmunized individuals or those with waning immunity. A 3rd MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine dose has been administered at some universities when outbreaks begin, with some success.\n\nA map of British Columbia and Vancouver Island can be seen at http://britishcolumbia.com/images/maps/british-columbia.gif. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "\n\nA notice posted on the TDCJ website said there is also housing areas at the gurney unit in Palestine, Texas and at the Willacy County State Jail that are under restrictions due to 'confirmed illnesses.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63143. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the close living quarters of inmates and movement of inmates between and within facilities, controlling mumps in a correctional setting can be difficult. \n\nA correctional centre staff member, who asked to remain anonymous for fear of losing their job, said the number of confirmed cases had gone to 9 from 2 in a 2-week period, with 3 more cases waiting to be confirmed as of [Thu 14 Sep 2017]. \n\nStaff were encouraged to double-check their immunization records and make sure they are up-to-date, the staff member said, and BCC was required to provide a clinic for staff to receive the required vaccines to protect against mumps. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n \n\n'We continue to see mumps in increasing numbers, and these outbreaks will continue unless young adults between the ages of 23 and 47 receive 2 doses of vaccine so they are fully protected,' said Dr Althea Hayden, VCH medical health officer, in a statement \n\n'The clean up and the follow up for these communicable diseases is really poor, as far as we're concerned,' the staff member said, adding other inmates are given a mask and put in charge of wiping cells down with disinfectant after an infected inmate leaves the area. \n\nWhen asked to comment further -- specifically on staff concerns -- the spokesperson said BCC is following public health advice on appropriate cleaning and other management protocols. \n\nYoung people living in shared housing in close contact with others -- like those heading off to university -- are most likely to contract mumps, experts warned. \n\nThe Brandon Court House is also taking precautions, opting to have inmates with symptoms or confirmed mumps cases appear in court by video. \n\nThe staff member said several people have completed workplace health and safety forms, and the union has also been advised of their concerns. \n\nThe health authority says there have been 80 cases of mumps since February [2017], compared to 86 for all of last year. \n\n'It may be small numbers, but it's still not small potatoes to us,' the staff member said. LK]\n\n******\n LK]\n\n******\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1957-03-25 00:00:00", "1969-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-02-25 00:00:00", "2032-03-25 00:00:00", "1970-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Manitoba province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Edinburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Palestine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "british COLUMBIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manitoba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://geology.com/county-map/texas-county-map.gif", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hidalgo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hidalgo county", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5197236", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (23): New Zealand (AU), USA (TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5197236", "date": "2017-07-22 19:22:53", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (23): NEW ZEALAND (AUKLAND), USA (TEXAS)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] New Zealand (Aukland)\n[2] USA (Texas)\n\n******\n[1] New Zealand (Aukland)\nDate: Thu 13 Jul 2017\nSource: Stuff [edited]\nhttps://www.stuff.co.nz/auckland/94571876/Mumps-outbreak-82-of-148-cases-in-west-Auckland\n\n\nWest Aucklanders account for more than half of the mumps cases confirmed this year [2017], with 40 cases confirmed after notifications from 12 schools - but the regional health service won't name them.\n\nAuckland Regional Public Health Service (ARPHS) clinical director Dr Julia Peters confirmed there was a mumps outbreak with 148 cases recorded in Auckland as of [Fri 7 Jul 2017]\n\nApproximately 82 confirmed cases of the viral illness were from west Auckland, she said. More than half of the west cases were males.\n\nPeters said close to half of the cases in west Auckland had been notified by schools - 40 in total. But the health body would not name the schools 'unless it's necessary to protect public health'.\n\nThe Western Leader found mumps cases had been notified by Massey High School in March, Don Buck Primary School in June [2017], Lincoln Heights School in July [2017] and Prospect School in Glen Eden in September last year [2016].\n\nPeters said the biggest concern were cases recorded in secondary schools because 'immunity in that age group was well [below] the national average'.\n\nShe said 58 of the people who became ill in west Auckland were not fully vaccinated with the MMR vaccine.\n\nPeters said 44 of those who had fallen ill were Pacific Islanders. Mumps cases among Samoans numbered 24, with 21 Maori people also contracting the viral illness.\n\nThe suburb of Massey recorded the highest numbers out west with 31 mumps cases, Henderson had 17 and Ranui 11. The rest of the west cases were isolated in other suburbs.\n\nA total of 3 west Aucklanders had been hospitalised.\n\nThe youngest west Auckland mumps sufferer was aged under one year, the oldest person diagnosed was aged 51.\n\nARPHS said half of the west Auckland cases were in the 10 to 19 [years old] age group.\n\n'Low MMR vaccination rates amongst those aged 10--29 years in west Auckland are one of the main drivers for the high numbers of mumps cases in west Auckland,' Peters said.\n\n'Many people with mumps were significantly unwell and some developed severe complications.'\n\nMales hospitalised from the outbreak in Auckland had pain and swelling in their testicles, known as orchitis, which in rare cases may led to infertility. One person had developed meningitis, and some women had experienced ovarian inflammation.\n\nPeters said the key was immunisation - 2 doses of the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine which was free of charge.\n\nMumps cases rose significantly this year [2017] - 51 cases from January to April which was 2 --3 times above the norm from the past 3 years.\n\nLast year [2016], there were 35 mumps cases notified but only 13 confirmed.\n\nThe last mumps outbreak in Auckland was in 2007 where there were 30 cases.\n\nPeters urged people to ask their doctor if their vaccinations were up to date, or seek medical help if they suspected mumps.\n\nMumps is spread via saliva or mucus when coughing, sneezing, or talking. Infected droplets can transfer up to one metre [3 feet]. It's easily transmitted through toys, keyboards and door handles.\n\nEarly symptoms of mumps include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite. The salivary glands on one or both sides of the face, cheeks or jaw may become swollen and sore after 2 days.\n\nIf people suspected mumps, they are asked to call their doctor, or Healthline for advice. For questions about vaccination visit <www.immune.org.nz>.\n\nThe measles, mumps and rubella vaccine is usually given in 2 doses, one at 15 months and one at 4-years-old.\n\n[Byline: Torika Tokalau-Chandra]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/335603/mumps-outbreak-169-infected-in-auckland, Julia Peters, clinical director of the Auckland Regional Public Health Service, said 80 percent of the 169 people with confirmed cases of mumps [as of Sat 22 Jul 201] were not fully vaccinated. The majority were aged between 10 and 29.\n\nAlso see ProMED-mail Mumps update (22): New Zealand, USA 20170708.5160387 - Mod.LK]\n\n[A map of New Zealand can be found at Healthmap http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Texas)\nDate: Sat 15 Jul 2017\nSource: Patch [edited]\nhttps://patch.com/texas/downtownaustin/mumps-outbreak-confirmed-university-texas-austin-campus-video\n\n\nUniversity of Texas at Austin officials on [Fri 14 Jul 2017] confirmed a mumps outbreak on campus after 7 people were diagnosed with the viral disease this week [week of 9-15 Jul 2017].\n\nAn email was sent campus-wide alerting to the mumps emergence, with a list of resources via the Healthyhorns website.\n\nMumps is a contagious and infectious viral disease that causes swelling of the parotid salivary glands in the face. Adult males contracting the disease are at risk of sterility. Complications of mumps, such as hearing loss, are potentially serious, but rare. The disease is considered to be extremely contagious.\n\nAmong the symptoms of mumps are:\n\nSwollen, painful salivary glands on one or both sides of your face (parotitis); fever; headache; muscle aches; weakness and fatigue; loss of appetite; pain while chewing or swallowing.\n\nImmediate medical care is suggested for those experiencing symptoms. Yet the Mayo Clinic reports there's no specific treatment for mumps. The website notes that mumps outbreaks still occur in the United States, and mumps is still common in many parts of the world, so getting a vaccination to prevent mumps remains important.\n\nSee Healthyhorns website with questions related to mumps and suggestions if felled by the disease .\n\n[Byline: Tony Cantu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/335603/mumps-outbreak-169-infected-in-auckland, Julia Peters, clinical director of the Auckland Regional Public Health Service, said 80 percent of the 169 people with confirmed cases of mumps [as of Sat 22 Jul 201] were not fully vaccinated. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nMumps cases rose significantly this year [2017] - 51 cases from January to April which was 2 --3 times above the norm from the past 3 years. \n\n'Low MMR vaccination rates amongst those aged 10--29 years in west Auckland are one of the main drivers for the high numbers of mumps cases in west Auckland,' Peters said. \n\nThe last mumps outbreak in Auckland was in 2007 where there were 30 cases.\n\n \n\n\nWest Aucklanders account for more than half of the mumps cases confirmed this year [2017], with 40 cases confirmed after notifications from 12 schools - but the regional health service won't name them. \n\nAuckland Regional Public Health Service (ARPHS) clinical director Dr Julia Peters confirmed there was a mumps outbreak with 148 cases recorded in Auckland as of [Fri 7 Jul 2017] \n\nThe Western Leader found mumps cases had been notified by Massey High School in March, Don Buck Primary School in June [2017], Lincoln Heights School in July [2017] and Prospect School in Glen Eden in September last year [2016]. Among the symptoms of mumps are:\n\nSwollen, painful salivary glands on one or both sides of your face (parotitis); fever; headache; muscle aches; weakness and fatigue; loss of appetite; pain while chewing or swallowing. \n\nARPHS said half of the west Auckland cases were in the 10 to 19 [years old] age group. Source: Patch [edited]\nhttps://patch.com/texas/downtownaustin/mumps-outbreak-confirmed-university-texas-austin-campus-video\n\n\nUniversity of Texas at Austin officials on [Fri 14 Jul 2017] confirmed a mumps outbreak on campus after 7 people were diagnosed with the viral disease this week \n\nThe youngest west Auckland mumps sufferer was aged under one year, the oldest person diagnosed was aged 51. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106] \n\nPeters said close to half of the cases in west Auckland had been notified by schools - 40 in total. \n\nApproximately 82 confirmed cases of the viral illness were from west Auckland, she said. \n\nMumps is a contagious and infectious viral disease that causes swelling of the parotid salivary glands in the face. The website notes that mumps outbreaks still occur in the United States, and mumps is still common in many parts of the world, so getting a vaccination to prevent mumps remains important. \n\nPeters said the biggest concern were cases recorded in secondary schools because 'immunity in that age group was well [below] the national average'. \n\n'Many people with mumps were significantly unwell and some developed severe complications.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 00:00:00", "2051-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-06-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aukland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Auckland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW ZEALAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Henderson", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Aucklanders", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA 20170708.5160387 - Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Glen Eden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5160387", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (22): New Zealand, USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5160387", "date": "2017-07-08 22:08:16", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (22): NEW ZEALAND, USA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nNew Zealand\n---\n[1] Aukland alert\n\nUSA\n---\n[2] Massachusetts (Harvard college) alert\n[3] New Hampshire (Dartmouth College)\n[4] Massachusetts Latino community\n\n******\nNew Zealand\n---\n[1] Aukland alert\nDate: Mon 3 July 2017\nSource: NZ City [edited]\nhttp://home.nzcity.co.nz/news/article.aspx?id=251026\n\n\nHealth officials are appealing to parents to immunize their children after an 'unrelenting mumps outbreak' hits Auckland.\n\nAn 'unrelenting mumps outbreak' hitting Auckland has health officials appealing to parents to immunize their children.\n\nMore than 130 cases have been reported in the city this year [2017], compared with 35 in 2016, the Auckland Regional Public Health Service says.\n\nIn 80 percent of cases, the patient has not been fully vaccinated.\n\n'It is disappointing because mumps is a preventable and serious disease,' the service's clinical director Julia Peters said.\n\n'Most recover from this disease. However in the last 6 months a number of people have suffered from severe complications.'\n\nThis included some adolescent males who were treated in hospital for pain and swelling in their testicles, which in rare cases can result in infertility.\n\nIn other cases, some females experienced ovarian inflammation and another person developed meningitis.\n\nNon-immune pregnant women who catch the disease risk miscarriage in the 1st 3 months. In rare cases, mumps can cause permanent hearing loss.\n\nWith almost 70 percent of this year's cases occurring in those aged between 10 and 19, Dr Peters urged parents to ensure their families' free measles mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccinations were up to date.\n\nMumps can spread quickly among those who are not immune, and one infected individual can cause an outbreak at a secondary school because immunity in that age group is well below the national average.\n\n'We are in the midst of an outbreak and already many students are scrambling to catch up on school work after missing school for several weeks,' Dr Peters said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of New Zealand can be found at Healthmap http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164]\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[2] Massachusetts (Harvard college) alert\nDate: Fri 23 Jun 2017\nSource: Boston Globe [edited]\nhttps://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2017/06/22/two-cases-mumps-confirmed-harvard/ASaNehAgaSel6aY9lVhvXK/story.html\n\n\nA total of 2 members of the Harvard University community have been diagnosed with mumps, according to an e-mail sent to Harvard students and staff.\n\nThe infections were confirmed [Thu 22 Jun 2017] and coincide with several other mumps diagnoses in the Boston area over the past month, Dr Paul J. Barreira, director of Harvard University Health Services, said in the e-mail.\n\nThose infected by the virus were not identified, but one of them is connected to the Harvard Biolabs complex on Divinity Avenue in Cambridge, according to Leslie Kirwan, dean for administration and finance in Harvard's Faculty of Arts and Sciences.\n\nKirwan said in the e-mail that those who have recently been in the Biolabs facility should take special note of the alert.\n\n[Byline: Jeremy C. Fox]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\npromed@promedmail.org\n\n[The Massachusetts Department of Public Health (DPH) issued a health alert for a Boston area mumps outbreak on Mon 5 Jun, to healthcare providers and local boards of health. See [4] below.\n\nFrom 1 Jan -- 17 Jun 2017, 44 states and the District of Columbia in the US reported mumps infections in 3562 people to CDC.\n\nMumps is no longer very common in the United States, but case numbers vary from year to year; mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. For example in 2016, there were approximately 5833 cases reported to CDC, and in 2012, there were 229. Before the U.S. mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to under-reporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States.\n\nSee map of cases and figure with number of cases over years at https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] New Hampshire (Dartmouth College)\nDate: Thu 6 Jul 2017\nSource: Fox News [edited]\nhttp://www.foxnews.com/health/2017/07/06/dartmouth-student-diagnosed-with-mumps.html\n\n\nHealth officials confirmed on [Wed 5 Jul 20917] that a Dartmouth College student has a case of the mumps and has been placed in isolation. A statement said the school's health providers are working with state officials to manage and test students with potential symptoms of the disease.\n\nStudents are being asked to contact Dartmouth College Health Services about any health concerns, while staff members and faculty are advised to consult their primary care physicians, The Union Leader reported.\n\n'We are writing to you today to provide you with information you will need to be an active part of the response to prevent the spread of mumps on campus,' Dr Ann Bracken, director of clinical medical services at the college health service, told students via email.\n\nAs of [Thu 6 Jul 2017], no other students had been tested for mumps, which the college requires vaccination against in order to register for classes with the exception of those who are exempted under specific circumstances, The Leader Union reported.\n\nMumps may cause a patient to experience puffy cheeks, swollen jaw, fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite or swollen salivary glands. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), symptoms can appear 16--18 days after infection, or up to 25 days after. The virus is contagious and could cause life-threatening complications if left untreated.\n\n--\nSubmitted by Dr. Jarod Hanson, DVM, PhD, DACVPM\nProMED-mail Associate editor\n<jarodhanson@gmail.com>\n\n[A Healthmap of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\n\n******\n[4] Massachusetts Latino community\nDate: Wed 5 Jul 2017 9:15 AM\nSource: Mass Live [edited]\nhttp://www.masslive.com/news/index.ssf/2017/07/mumps_outbreak_in_some_latino.html\n\n\nThe Massachusetts Department of Public Health says it will be reaching out to Latino communities in the state to increase awareness about the mumps virus, commonly spread through infected saliva, and to encourage vaccination against the potentially serious disease.\n\nThe Massachusetts Department of Public Health says it will be reaching out to Latino communities to increase awareness about the mumps virus, commonly spread through infected saliva, and to encourage vaccination against the potentially serious, highly infectious disease with the measles, mumps, and rubella [MMR] vaccine.\n\nAccording to the DPH, 12 new cases of mumps have been diagnosed since the end of March [2017] in the commonwealth among Latino residents of Chelsea, Boston, and Revere. Those diagnosed range in age from 20 -- 41, may represent a change in the epidemiology of mumps in the state, which experienced a large outbreak last year [2016], as none has any known connection to higher education, according to the DPH.\n\nTo date, according to the DPH, the majority of confirmed and probable mumps cases in the commonwealth have been among vaccinated college students and others linked to colleges and universities.\n\nIt is believed most of the Latino individuals diagnosed since March [2017] have not been vaccinated, and none is known to have traveled internationally.\n\nMMR vaccination is highly protective against mumps and is recommended for children and adults,' said Monica Bharel, the state's public health commissioner, in a statement.\n\n'In addition, those who have mumps should stay isolated at home for 5 days after their onset of swelling. Mumps is usually a mild disease but can cause serious illness. If you think you have mumps, stay home and call your healthcare provider.''\n\nThe DPH alerted healthcare providers and local boards of health, in the Greater Boston area, to the outbreak 5 June 2017.\n\nAccording to the DPH, those diagnosed presented symptoms of mumps between 24 Mar and 31 May [2017], and included members of the Colombian, Dominican, Guatemalan, and Salvadoran communities. None is known to have traveled internationally prior to becoming ill. For the majority of the residents, vaccination histories are unknown; most are believed to be unvaccinated against mumps.\n\nDPH and local health departments are investigating the clusters of outbreaks and instituting measures to prevent further infection. Unvaccinated individuals are most susceptible to mumps infection.\n\nMumps virus is spread through infected respiratory tract secretions. It can be spread within 3 -- 6 feet when an infected person coughs or sneezes or with direct contact with infected secretions, such as sharing water bottles.\n\nIn 2016, according to the DPH, Massachusetts experienced a large mumps outbreak with 252 reported cases, which is more than 15 times the usual number of mumps cases. Those cases were part of a national mumps outbreak, which saw more than 5800 mumps cases, the largest number in a decade.\n\nSo far this year [2017] the mumps outbreak continues in Massachusetts, with nearly 300 suspected cases of mumps investigated and 35 cases confirmed, according to the DPH.\n\n[Byline: Anne-Gerard Flynn]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See earlier posts on mumps to learn more about complications and vaccination schedule. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of New Zealand can be found at Healthmap http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164]\n\n***** ProMED-mail Associate editor\n<jarodhanson@gmail.com>\n\n[A Healthmap of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See earlier posts on mumps to learn more about complications and vaccination schedule. [4] Massachusetts Latino community\n\n******\nNew Zealand\n---\n \n\nThe Massachusetts Department of Public Health says it will be reaching out to Latino communities to increase awareness about the mumps virus, commonly spread through infected saliva, and to encourage vaccination against the potentially serious, highly infectious disease with the measles, mumps, and rubella [MMR] vaccine. \n\nMumps is no longer very common in the United States, but case numbers vary from year to year; mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. So far this year [2017] the mumps outbreak continues in Massachusetts, with nearly 300 suspected cases of mumps investigated and 35 cases confirmed, according to the DPH. [1] Aukland alert\n\nUSA\n---\n In 2016, according to the DPH, Massachusetts experienced a large mumps outbreak with 252 reported cases, which is more than 15 times the usual number of mumps cases. In this update:\nNew Zealand\n---\n *\nUSA\n---\n \n\nAs of [Thu 6 Jul 2017], no other students had been tested for mumps, which the college requires vaccination against in order to register for classes with the exception of those who are exempted under specific circumstances, The Leader Union reported. \n\n'We are writing to you today to provide you with information you will need to be an active part of the response to prevent the spread of mumps on campus,' Dr Ann Bracken, director of clinical medical services at the college health service, told students via email. Those cases were part of a national mumps outbreak, which saw more than 5800 mumps cases, the largest number in a decade. MUMPS UPDATE (22): NEW ZEALAND, USA\n***********************************\n \n\nMumps can spread quickly among those who are not immune, and one infected individual can cause an outbreak at a secondary school because immunity in that age group is well below the national average. \n\nThose infected by the virus were not identified, but one of them is connected to the Harvard Biolabs complex on Divinity Avenue in Cambridge, according to Leslie Kirwan, dean for administration and finance in Harvard's Faculty of Arts and Sciences.\n\n Source: Fox News [edited]\nhttp://www.foxnews.com/health/2017/07/06/dartmouth-student-diagnosed-with-mumps.html\n\n\nHealth officials confirmed on [Wed 5 Jul 20917] that a Dartmouth College student has a case of the mumps and has been placed in isolation. \n\nMMR vaccination is highly protective against mumps and is recommended for children and adults,' said Monica Bharel, the state's public health commissioner, in a statement. \n\nMore than 130 cases have been reported in the city this year [2017], compared with 35 in 2016, the Auckland Regional Public Health Service says. \n\nAn 'unrelenting mumps outbreak' hitting Auckland has health officials appealing to parents to immunize their children. Before the U.S. mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to under-reporting. \n\nMumps may cause a patient to experience puffy cheeks, swollen jaw, fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite or swollen salivary glands. \n\n'It is disappointing because mumps is a preventable and serious disease,' the service's clinical director Julia Peters said. \n\nMumps virus is spread through infected respiratory tract secretions. \n\nSee map of cases and figure with number of cases over years at https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html - Mod. \n\nStudents are being asked to contact Dartmouth College Health Services about any health concerns, while staff members and faculty are advised to consult their primary care physicians, The Union Leader reported. \n\n--\n [Byline: Jeremy C. Fox]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-01-01 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-06-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guatemalan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW ZEALAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cambridge", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chelsea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Auckland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NZ City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5262239", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (24): Australia (QL), New Zealand (OT), Brazil (AM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5262239", "date": "2017-08-20 09:44:05", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (24): AUSTRALIA (QUEENSLAND), NEW ZEALAND (OTAGO,) BRAZIL (AMAZONAS)\n*********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Australia (Cairns, Queensland)\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\n\n******\n[1] Australia (Cairns, Queensland)\nDate: Fri 11 Aug 2017 9:00 PM AEST\nSource: The Cairns Post [edited]\nhttps://tinyurl.com/y9nepfk5\n\n\nFar North Queenslanders have been urged to vaccinate their children following a spike in mumps cases in Cairns. There have been 14 cases of the highly infectious disease identified by Queensland Health since [24 Jul 2017], compared to the yearly average of only one case in the Cairns and Hinterland health district.\n\nTropical Public Health director Dr Steven Donohue said the mumps outbreak had spilled over to Cairns from northwest Queensland and the Northern Territory's Top End.\n\n'Outbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households,' he said.\n\nHe said the viral illness was spread just like influenza, by coughing or sneezing near other people and through unwashed hands.\n\n'Symptoms may occur around 2 weeks after exposure if the person is not immune,' he said. 'The illness usually lasts between 5-9 days.\n\n'One person in 3 who contracts mumps does not have any symptoms and doesn't realise they are sick, but they may still be contagious and infect may other people.'\n\nNorthern Queensland Primary Health Network chief executive Robin Moore said immunisation was a simple, safe and highly effective way to protect children and adults from preventable diseases like mumps.\n\n'This year's [2017] increase in the number of mumps cases in the Cairns region is a timely reminder to parents that immunisation is the best protection against preventable diseases such as these.\n\n'We urge all members of the community to be fully vaccinated.' ...\n\nThe disease is uncommon in developed countries, including Australia, because of the widespread use of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine.\n\nThis is given to children at 12 and 18 months, but free catch-up doses are available to anyone born after 1965 who may not have 2 recorded doses.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Bateman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/australia-political-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2954. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n\n******\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017 19:45 NZST\nSource: Stuff [edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/y7a56fv5\n\n\nUniversity of Otago students are being offered free booster shots after about 10 confirmed or suspected cases were reported in Dunedin [Otago, South Island].\n\nThree young people in Marlborough have contracted the contagious illness, with at least 1 case linked to an Auckland outbreak, while 2 have been confirmed in Nelson.\n\nNationally, an unusually high number of cases were reported from September 2016 to early 2017, and the Ministry of Health warned of 'an increased risk of further outbreaks'.\n\nAuckland reported 51 cases of mumps in the past month -- most aged 10 to 19 -- while several were recorded in Waikato earlier this year [2017].\n\nThe Auckland Regional Public Health Service said last month [July 2017] it was concerned not enough people were immunised in the face of the mumps outbreak.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is usually given in 2 doses, one at 15 months old and one at 4 years old.\n\nMost people recover from mumps, but it can have serious complications. The disease can cause inflammation of tissue surrounding the brain (meningitis), inflamed testicles or ovaries and deafness.\n\nMen hospitalised from the Auckland outbreak had pain and swelling in their testicles, known as orchitis, which in rare cases may lead to infertility.\n\nThe outbreak in Dunedin has prompted the Otago tertiary institution's student health team to offer free measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) booster shots to students who have not had two MMR vaccinations since 1990, or are unsure of their vaccination history.\n\nPro-vice-chancellor of health sciences Professor Peter Crampton, the convener of the university's pandemic planning group, said the group was 'determining our ongoing response as the situation develops.'\n\nThe outbreak coincided with a large-scale boil water notice issued for parts of Dunedin, including the student quarter, after untreated water got into part of the town's drinking water supply on [Mon 14 Aug 2017].\n\nAll students and staff had been sent information about mumps. Information had been posted on social media.\n\nMarlborough medical officer of health Dr Andrew Lindsay said mumps is 'highly contagious'. It spreads through the air by breathing, coughing and sneezing, or through contact with infected saliva; by kissing or sharing food and drink. It usually takes 12-25 days before symptoms appear -- including pain in the jaw, fever, headache, and swollen glands around the face and body. People with mumps re infectious for 7 days before swelling starts and for 5 days after they cease.\n\nPersonal hygiene is essential to avoid catching mumps, including frequent hand washing, stopping coughs and sneezes in tissues, keeping at least 1 metre [3 ft] away from others and ensuring kitchens and bathrooms are clean.\n\nDr Jill Sherwood, public health physician with the ESR (the Institute of Environmental Science and Research), earlier said the MMR vaccine was not as effective in mumps as it was in measles and rubella. 'The mumps component is only about 85 per cent effective, whereas the measles component will most likely give you lifetime coverage,' Sherwood said.\n\nThere have been no reported cases of mumps in Canterbury, a health board spokeswoman said.\n\n[Byline: Hamish Mcneilly, Jennifer Eder]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of New Zealand can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/political-map-of-New-Zealan.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/738. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017\nSource: Em Tempo [in Portuguese, trans. & summ., edited]\nhttp://www.emtempo.com.br/manaus-tem-surto-de-caxumba-com-230-casos/\n\n\nWith 230 cases of mumps in Manaus [Amazonas state] in 19 places, registered since April 2017, mainly in schools, the Municipal Health Department (Semsa) warns parents to keep the updated immunization booklet for children and adolescents.\n\nUp to 2016, there were no official mumps outbreak records in Manaus. In 2017, as of 18 Aug, there have been 230 cases reported from 19 localities, most of them in schools, which suggests low vaccination coverage in children and adolescents. The 1st outbreak was reported in April 2017 and the occurrence of cases is continuing until the month of August, according to the municipal health secretary. ...\n\n[Byline: Isac Sharlon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEmerson Capistrano\nEpidemiological Surveillance\nBoa Vista Health Service\nRoraima, Brazil\n<emerson.capistrano@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Emerson Capistrano for submitting this report. - Mod.LK\n\nMaps of Brazil can be seen at http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10254. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Boa Vista Health Service\nRoraima, Brazil\n<emerson.capistrano@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Emerson Capistrano for submitting this report. - Mod. \n\nAuckland reported 51 cases of mumps in the past month -- most aged 10 to 19 -- while several were recorded in Waikato earlier this year [2017]. \n\n[Byline: Isac Sharlon]\n\n--\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/australia-political-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2954. MUMPS UPDATE (24): AUSTRALIA (QUEENSLAND), NEW ZEALAND (OTAGO,) BRAZIL (AMAZONAS)\n*********************************************************************************\n \n\nTropical Public Health director Dr Steven Donohue said the mumps outbreak had spilled over to Cairns from northwest Queensland and the Northern Territory's Top End. \n\nThe outbreak coincided with a large-scale boil water notice issued for parts of Dunedin, including the student quarter, after untreated water got into part of the town's drinking water supply on [Mon 14 Aug 2017]. \n\nMarlborough medical officer of health Dr Andrew Lindsay said mumps is 'highly contagious'. \n\nThe disease is uncommon in developed countries, including Australia, because of the widespread use of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine. \n\n'One person in 3 who contracts mumps does not have any symptoms and doesn't realise they are sick, but they may still be contagious and infect may other people.' [Byline: Daniel Bateman]\n\n--\n Mcneilly, Jennifer Eder]\n\n--\n \n\nThis is given to children at 12 and 18 months, but free catch-up doses are available to anyone born after 1965 who may not have 2 recorded doses. \n\nThere have been no reported cases of mumps in Canterbury With 230 cases of mumps in Manaus [Amazonas state] in 19 places, registered since April 2017, mainly in schools, the Municipal Health Department (Semsa) warns parents to keep the updated immunization booklet for children and adolescents.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2016-09-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "1965-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-07-25 00:00:00", "2017-04-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NEW ZEALAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Waikato", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canterbury", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manaus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "marlborough", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "BRAZIL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dunedin", "country": "unknown"}, {"archive_id": "5007199", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (17): USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5007199", "date": "2017-05-02 06:05:10", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (17): USA\n***************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Mississippi (Pearl River Community College)\n[2] Missouri (Southeast Missouri State University)\n[3] Hawaii (Oahu)\n[4] New York (State University of New York at Albany)\n[5] Ohio (Kent state University)\n[6] North Carolina (Watauga County)\n\n******\n[1] Mississippi (Pearl River Community College)\nDate: Fri 28 Apr 2017\nSource: Picayune Item [edited]\nhttp://www.picayuneitem.com/2017/04/10-confirmed-cases-of-mumps-at-prcc/\n\n\nPearl River Community College is currently battling a mumps outbreak on the Poplarville campus. What started out as one confirmed case in early April 2017 has since spread to 10 students, all of which are either on the baseball team or in close contact with the team, vice president Dr Adam Breerwood said.\n\nAfter the 1st confirmed case, Breerwood said the school immediately contacted the Mississippi State Department of Health [MSDH] and initiated an emergency protocol, notifying faculty and students of the risk. All suspected areas of contagion were disinfected, specifically the workout and training areas and hand sanitizing containers often used by the baseball team, he said. As soon as students started to show symptoms, they were sent home to prevent further spread of the disease, Breerwood said. Some of the students have since returned to classes after being cleared by their doctors and the MSDH, he said.\n\nWith most of the cases under control, Breerwood said he hopes the issue will be resolved shortly; however, the virus can stay in the body for up to 25 days. 'It's a unique situation,' Breerwood said. 'We haven't heard of anybody getting the mumps in a number of years.'\n\nAt the recommendation of MSDH, the college provided vaccinations for the students to prevent their risk of infection, Breerwood said. As of Thu [27 Apr 2017] morning, he awaited word on whether the agency would recommend another round of vaccines. Students are scheduled to move out of the dorms on 5 May 2017, giving college staff time to decontaminate any possible areas before summer classes begin, Breerwood said.\n\nThe college currently doesn't require students to receive the mumps vaccine prior to enrollment, Breerwood said, but the administration is considering it now. 'This is what's somewhat ironic: LSU [Louisiana State University] had the same issue, and Loyola in New Orleans had it,' Breerwood said. 'I was surprised to hear that [MSDH] has seen outbreaks in the last couple of years.'\n\n[byline: Julia Arenstam]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap showing the location of Mississippi, United States can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/227.]\n\n******\n[2] Missouri, Southeast Missouri State University\nDate: Sun 30 Apr 2017\nSource: Southeastern Missourian [edited]\nhttp://www.semissourian.com/story/2408011.html\n\n\nThe university is optimistic it has passed the peak of a mumps outbreak 1st reported in February 2017, according to Southeast Missouri State University spokeswoman Ann Hayes. Hayes said as of Fri [28 Apr 2017], 58 students have confirmed cases of mumps, as determined by a medical test. 'Cape Girardeau Public Health is aware of these cases,' Hayes said.\n\nTest results still have not returned for 5 students suspected of having mumps, Hayes said, adding these students have been out of class and at home since they were suspected of having the disease. Another 41 students tested negative for mumps, Hayes said, and 23 students are 'probable' mumps cases. No testing was ordered because the students had a high exposure to other students who previously tested positive for mumps,' Hayes said. 'We are continuing to see lower numbers [of mumps cases],' she said.\n\nSoutheast hosted vaccination clinics on 7, 9 and 10 Mar 2017 in partnership with the Cape Girardeau County Public Health Center and the Campus Health Clinic, where a vaccine for measles, mumps and rubella, or MMR, was made available to students. Southeast is publicly updating its information at http://semo.edu/mumps. As of Sat [29 Apr 2017] afternoon, the website had not been updated to reflect the most recent numbers, Hayes said.\n\nOn 9 Mar 2017, the Southeast Missourian reported 29 confirmed cases of mumps on the campus.\n\n[byline: Marybeth Niederkorn]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap showing the location of Missouri, United States can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/227.]\n\n******\n[3] Hawaii (Oahu)\nDate: Fri 28 Apr 2017\nSource: KHON 2 [edited]\nhttp://khon2.com/2017/04/28/department-of-health-investigating-increase-in-mumps-cases-14-cases-this-year/\n\n\nThe State Department of Health [DoH] has confirmed 14 cases, all on Oahu, and says that none of the infected individuals have required hospitalization.\n\nMumps is easily spread, and causes swollen salivary glands, puffy cheeks, and a swollen jaw. The infection used to be common nationwide, and decreased greatly after people started getting vaccinated. Still, state epidemiologist Dr Sarah Park says outbreaks still occur. 'When we talk and look at other states in the nation, they're seeing similarly. It's concerning. For whatever reason, there's a lot of mumps nationwide,' Park said.\n\nLocally, Park is puzzled by the outbreak. Park says these cases are unusual, because cases are typically isolated. But investigators have been able to link 3 different clusters of mumps so far this year [2017]. 'It's the end of April [2017]. We're only 4 months into 2017, and we've already gone above what we normally see,' she said. Park says the health department can't figure out what caused the mumps outbreak. 'Either they were in the same group, or some similar setting they were in. It's not necessarily relatives. With all respiratory disease, the closer we are together, the more likely we spread infection,' Park said. 'We can connect this person to this person, and that person to that person, kind of like connect the dots. It's kind of frustrating. It's not been one unifying thing.' Park says the clusters of cases show how easily the infection spreads, and adds that the respiratory infection is more contagious than the flu. It is spread when an infected person coughs or sneezes.\n\nIn children, mumps is usually a mild disease. However, mumps can occasionally cause complications, especially in adults. Complications include:\n- meningitis (infection of the covering of the brain and spinal cord);\n- deafness (temporary or permanent);\n- encephalitis (swelling of the brain);\n- orchitis (swelling of the testicles) in males who have reached puberty;\n- oophoritis (swelling of the ovaries) and/or mastitis (swelling of the breasts) in females who have reached puberty.\n\nOfficials also say that while cases have been reported in vaccinated individuals, the best protection against the disease is vaccination. The MMR vaccine protects against measles, mumps, and rubella. The DoH says that all children should receive 2 doses of the MMR vaccine. The 1st dose is given at age 12-15 months and the 2nd dose at 4-6 years of age. All adults born in or after 1957 should also have documentation of vaccination, unless they have had a blood test showing they are immune to mumps. Certain adults at higher risk of exposure to mumps may need a 2nd dose of MMR vaccine. Two doses of the vaccine are 88 per cent effective at protecting against mumps, and one dose is 78 per cent effective.\n\nMumps is a contagious disease caused by a virus [family Paramyxovirus; genus _Rubulavirus_]. The classic symptom of mumps is called parotitis, which is a swelling of the salivary glands under the ears, resulting in a tender, swollen jaw. Other symptoms include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite. Persons should seek medical attention immediately if they develop symptoms.\n\nPeople with mumps are most infectious in the several days before and after the onset of parotitis. The disease is spread when an infected person coughs or sneezes. Transmission can also occur when sharing items, such as cups or eating utensils, or by touching contaminated objects or surfaces and then touching the eyes, nose, or mouth. Persons with mumps should stay home from school or work for 9 days after the onset of parotitis to keep from spreading the disease to others.\n\nAdditional information about mumps can be found on the DoH website at http://health.hawaii.gov/docd/disease_listing/mumps/.\n\n[byline: Brigette Namata]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap showing Hawaii can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/227.]\n\n******\n[4] New York (State University of New York at Albany)\nDate: Sat 29 Apr 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/mumps-eight-cases-reported-ualbany-students-19080/\n\n\nThe State University of New York, University at Albany (UAlbany) is currently dealing with 8 confirmed cases of mumps in the student body. The affected students are being cared for and are isolated from the rest of the student body while they recover. UAlbany is working closely with the Albany County Department of Health (ACDOH) to reduce the chances of the disease from spreading further. ... On Tue 25 Apr 2017, UAlbany and the Albany County Department of Health held a clinic that provided free vaccinations for more than 100 students.\n\nFor anyone who missed the clinic, the university has been providing students with free MMR vaccinations at Student Health Services over the past week. Students who have not had 2 MMR vaccinations are encouraged to make an appointment to receive the MMR vaccination.\n\nMumps prevention tips:\n- wash your hands frequently with soap and water or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer;\n- cover your mouth with a tissue or your elbow when you sneeze or cough;\n- do not share drinks, food, utensils, or any personal items that come in contact with saliva.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report was also submitted by Woodnard Givens, MS, MPH [assoc prof biol, Northern Virginia Community College Sterling, Virginia, USA] who was alerted to this news on the local Albany, New York paper; however, please note it is not open access http://m.timesunion.com/7day-breaking/article/8-cases-of-mumps-confirmed-at-UAlbany-106354.php. ProMED-mail thanks Mr Givens for sending the report.\n\nAn infographic aimed at college students depicting symptoms of mumps and steps they can take to protect themselves can be found at the URL above. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap showing the location of New York State, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234.]\n\n******\n[5] Ohio (Kent State University)\nDate: 28 Apr 2017\nSource: Fox8 [edited]\n\n[byline: Jen Steer Kent]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org' target='_blank' rel='noopener noreferrer'>http://fox8.com/2017/04/28/kent-state-issues-warning-after-confirmed-cases-of-mumps\n\n\nKent State University wants staff and students to be alert after confirmed cases of the mumps. On Fri [28 Apr] afternoon, the university sent out an email, which said the city of Kent and Portage County health departments [had] recently become aware of mumps cases at the main campus.\n\n'University Health Services is advising all students and university employees that it is likely that the mumps virus is circulating in the vicinity and advising everyone to be aware of the signs and symptoms of this virus,' the email from Kent State said. Kent State said people should verify their immunization status and contact University Health Services if they need to be vaccinated.\n\n[byline: Jen Steer Kent]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org\n\n[A HealthMap showing the location of Ohio, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/237.]\n\n******\n[6] North Carolina (Watauga County)\nDate: Mon 1 May 2017\nSource: WBTV [edited]\nhttp://www.wbtv.com/story/35284491/two-watauga-co-residents-confirmed-with-mumps-virus\n\n\nTwo college students who are both residents of Watauga County have been diagnosed with mumps, health officials said on Friday [28 Apr 2017]. As of 2017, there have been 3 confirmed cases of Watauga County residents who contracted the mumps virus.\n\nAccording to the Appalachian District Health Department, one of the students with the virus attends Appalachian State University, and the 2nd student attends the Caldwell Community College and Technical Institute Watauga Campus in Boone. Public health director Beth Lovette said both of the students are being treated and cooperating with health officials. Lovette released the following statement on Friday [28 Apr 2017]:\n\n'AppHealthCare and officials at both Appalachian State and Calwell Community College are monitoring this case closely. We are working together, consulting with the North Carolina Division of Public Health Communicable Disease team, sharing information, and taking swift and appropriate action in response to these additional diagnoses.' Public health officials said they were communicating with students who may have come into direct contact with the 2 students affected.\n\nLeroy Wright, interim vice chancellor for student development at Appalachian State, and Dena Holman, vice president of student services at CCC&TI, issued this joint statement: 'The health and safety of our students and employees is always our top priority. We have communicated with our students, faculty and staff about the situation and provided details about preventative measures as well as educational resources. We will remain vigilant and greatly appreciate the partnership with Appalachian District Health Department and the North Carolina Division of Public Health Communicable Disease team.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap showing the location of North Carolina, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/235.]", "summary": "\n\nMumps prevention tips:\n- wash your hands frequently with soap and water or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer;\n- cover your mouth with a tissue or your elbow when you sneeze or cough;\n- do not share drinks, food, utensils, or any personal items that come in contact with saliva.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Source: Fox8 [edited]\n\n[byline: Jen Steer Kent]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org' target='_blank' rel='noopener noreferrer'>http://fox8.com/2017/04/28/kent-state-issues-warning-after-confirmed-cases-of-mumps\n\n\nKent State University wants staff and students to be alert after confirmed cases of the mumps. \n\nAdditional information about mumps can be found on the DoH website at http://health.hawaii.gov/docd/disease_listing/mumps/.\n\n[byline: Brigette Namata]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n[byline: Julia Arenstam]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap showing the location of Mississippi, United States can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/227.] Complications include:\n- meningitis (infection of the covering of the brain and spinal cord);\n- deafness (temporary or permanent);\n- encephalitis (swelling of the brain);\n- orchitis (swelling of the testicles) in males who have reached puberty;\n- oophoritis (swelling of the ovaries) and/or mastitis (swelling of the breasts) in females who have reached puberty. Another 41 students tested negative for mumps, Hayes said, and 23 students are 'probable' mumps cases. MUMPS UPDATE (17): USA\n***************\n \n\nThe college currently doesn't require students to receive the mumps vaccine prior to enrollment, Breerwood said, but the administration is considering it now. ' \n\nAfter the 1st confirmed case, Breerwood said the school immediately contacted the Mississippi State Department of Health [MSDH] and initiated an emergency protocol, notifying faculty and students of the risk. University Health Services is advising all students and university employees that it is likely that the mumps virus is circulating in the vicinity and advising everyone to be aware of the signs and symptoms of this virus,' the email from Kent State said. \n\n\nTwo college students who are both residents of Watauga County have been diagnosed with mumps, health officials said on Friday [28 Apr 2017]. \n\nAn infographic aimed at college students depicting symptoms of mumps and steps they can take to protect themselves can be found at the URL above. No testing was ordered because the students had a high exposure to other students who previously tested positive for mumps,' Hayes said. What started out as one confirmed case in early April 2017 has since spread to 10 students, all of which are either on the baseball team or in close contact with the team, vice president Dr Adam Breerwood said.
