Date: Mon 1 May 2017\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-05-05 00:00:00", "2010-07-09 00:00:00", 05:55:50", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (19): EUROPE (UK), USA (HAWAII, PENNSYLVANIA, CALIFORNIA)\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nEurope\n---\n[1] UK (England, Oxford)\n\nUSA\n---\n[2] Hawaii\n[3] Pennsylvania, Pennsylvania State University\n[4] California, Los Angeles county\n\n******\nEurope\n---\n[1] UK (England, Oxford)\nDate: Fri 26 May 2017\nSource: Cherwell [edited]\nhttp://www.cherwell.org/2017/05/26/outbreak-of-mumps-plagues-oxfords-colleges/\n\n\nAn outbreak of mumps has left students sent home, cricket games cancelled, and preliminary and final exams under threat as students across Oxford come down with the infection. Cherwell has learned that major outbreaks have occurred at Exeter, Corpus Christi and St Anne's colleges, with as many as several dozen students falling ill across the entire university.\n\nIt is possible that the infection, an airbourne virus transmitted through coughing or sneezing, was spread at recent college balls. In serious cases, it can cause deafness and meningitis. Four Anne's students have reportedly been confined to their rooms, while 2 have been sent home to recover in quarantine. At Corpus, at least 3 students are affected, all of whom have either been asked to remain in their rooms or go to home for a brief period.\n\nJC is a 2nd year mathematician at Corpus who has contracted mumps and is sitting exams this term. Speaking to Cherwell, he said: 'How I got mumps is a mystery, as the incubation time is between 2--3 weeks.' Although the 'the college has been supportive and useful' by rearranging tutorials and relaxing deadlines, he said, he is concerned about upcoming examinations. He added that he 'can't really work, and as it's a viral infection, you can only treat the symptoms.'\n\nA post on the Corpus Christi College Cricket Club Facebook page announced that the St Anne's side had had to concede this week's scheduled match '[D]ue to an outbreak of mumps and food poisoning.'\n\nAccording to JB, a 2nd year at Corpus, feeling in college was relatively jovial. He told Cherwell: 'Oddly enough people really don't seem to be that worried about it at all. It's more of a cause for humour than a genuine cause for concern.'\n\nSpeaking exclusively to Cherwell, St Anne's JCR [junior common room] president Pranay Shah said: ''The mumps outbreak around a few Oxford colleges is a pretty terrible coincidence with finals, prelims and other exams for the majority of students, but the response from staff has been very helpful. As well as warning people of the [infection] methods and symptoms, advice from the NHS [National Health Service] and college nurse has been provided too.'\n\nOne student who has contracted mumps told Cherwell: 'The 1st I heard about it, someone I knew caught it and had been shipped home. 'Then one evening I got sharp pains in the corner of my jaw which were pretty uncomfortable but I didn't think much of it. Overnight, I was pretty feverish. I woke up the next day with my face all swollen up on the right hand side. I went to the doctor who confirmed it was mumps, so College told me to stay in my room in quarantine or go home. 'College have been pretty good about it -- they moved me to a room with en-suite so I could be a bit more comfortable, and the nurse has been around to check on me, but I'm not allowed to use kitchens or communal bathrooms. The first couple of days of infection were pretty grim, I was really weak, walking to Jericho meant I had to sleep for almost the rest of the day, and everything ached. I had dizziness, headaches and a high temperature, and a large swelling around the back of my jawbone.'\n\nBoth the Oxford University health guidelines and NHS website recommend that people entering higher education for the 1st time have the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) vaccine. In 2010, a similar outbreak saw 41 students contract mumps. Students with symptoms are advised to seek medical assistance.\n\n[byline: Felix Pope]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the United Kingdom can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40]\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[2] Hawaii\nDate: Fri 2 Jun 2017 8:27 am\nSource: SFGate [edited]\nhttp://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Hawaii-urges-resident-to-get-mumps-vaccination-as-11190915.php\n\n\nHawaii officials are urging all residents born in or after 1957 to get a mumps vaccination if they haven't already done so.\n\nThe state Health Department announced [Thu 1 Jun 2017] that 16 additional people have mumps, which brings the state's yearly total to 81 cases. The total is more than double the number of cases in the last 10 years combined, Hawaii News Now reported (http://bit.ly/2rsry4g ). The state had just 10 mumps cases last year [2016], 4 in 2015 and one in 2014.\n\nAnyone without evidence of immunity to mumps should receive at least one vaccine dose, health department officials said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hawaii is following the same trend of increased mumps activity seen in the continental US. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Pennsylvania, Pennsylvania State University\nDate: Wed 31 May 2017\nSource: Contagion Live [edited]\nhttp://www.contagionlive.com/news/mumps-outbreak-at-penn-state-infects-more-than-80-individuals\n\n\nPennsylvania State University (Penn State) has reported that the mumps outbreak that started in late January 2017 had reached 77 cases in April [2017]. More recently, a local Pennsylvania news outlet, Lancaster Online, reported that, as of 15 May [2017], the case count had reached 86.\n\nAlthough a majority of those who were infected during the ongoing outbreak have recovered, new cases are continuously popping up around campus. In addition, the University Health Services (UHS) urges all those who present with mumps-like signs and symptoms not attend large social functions, so as to control the spread of the outbreak. The UHS also recommends all who have come in close contact with infected individuals 'avoid large social activities, especially where food or drinks are shared or where the virus can be passed through saliva exposure, even if they are not showing symptoms,' since symptoms usually arise around 16 days after exposure.\n\nInfected individuals usually present with 'puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw,' due to swelling of the salivary glands. Other symptoms include fever, muscle ache, headache, and loss of appetite.\n\nAccording to the Penn State's immunization recommendations, most students, including those living on and off campus, whether they are new, returning, or transfer students, are expected to receive 2 doses of the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine, or submit results from a blood test proving immunity, as recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).\n\nStudents exempt from this requirement include exchange students, non-degree-seeking students, World Campus students, and those CDC recommends not to receive the vaccine, including pregnant women, anyone with previous allergies to the vaccine, and anyone with life-threatening allergy against neomycin. In addition, the CDC recommends individuals with certain chronic diseases inform their physician of their conditions prior to receiving vaccination.\n\nA Penn State press release reports that 'most of the confirmed mumps cases are in students who received the CDC-recommended 2 doses of MMR vaccine;' however, UHS still recommends those who have not received the vaccine or who are not immune to mumps - through previous infection - schedule an appointment with UHS or their primary care physician to be vaccinated 'immediately.'\n\nCommenting on the ongoing outbreak at Penn State, Shelley Haffner, infectious disease manager at UHS, said, 'While many students who contracted mumps earlier this semester are no longer infectious, we are still continuing to see several new cases each week on campus... It is important that everyone take steps not only to protect themselves from possible exposure, but also to prevent exposing others should they develop symptoms.'\n\nIn light of this ongoing outbreak, Penn State will 'exclude' anyone who does not provide proof of immunity from campus for the duration of 26 days if they have come in contact with an infected individual. Individuals who have presented with mumps-like symptoms have been placed in isolation based on protocols and recommendations from the CDC and the Pennsylvania Department of Health. In addition, several students have left campus 'during the infectious phase of the illness.' UHS has reached out to individuals who may have contracted infection and have already taken necessary steps to exclude those who have been identified as contacts of confirmed cases from the university campus.\n\n[byline: Sarah Anwar]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\n\n******\n[4] California, Los Angeles County\nDate: Thu 1 June 2017 4:57 PM PDT\nSource: Los Angeles Daily News [edited]\nhttp://www.dailynews.com/health/20170601/mumps-outbreak-declared-in-la-county-after-more-than-40-diagnoses\n\n\nMore than 40 people in Los Angeles County and surrounding regions have been diagnosed with mumps, prompting public health officials [Thu 1 Jun 2017] to declare an outbreak and issue an alert to physicians and providers to be aware of it.\n\nIn the alert, public health officials said many of the cases were initially misdiagnosed and there was a reliance of using false negative results. It's unclear when this occurred. Health officials also did not release the conditions of those who were diagnosed. A response from Los Angeles County public health officials was not immediately forthcoming [Thu 1 Jun 2017].\n\nBut health officials said most of the patients are men who have sex with men, and the majority of the cases were linked to patients being at large venues such as gyms, bars, theaters and nightclubs. Some of the patients are women and heterosexual men who have social connections to men who have sex with men, health officials noted. 'The majority of cases have had no documentation of complete vaccination; however, some cases were fully vaccinated,' according to the alert.\n\nMumps is highly infectious and spreads among those living in close quarters or at social settings. In March [2017], 7 men in LA County were diagnosed with mumps as part of 2 different clusters and occurred in men who have sex with men. It was unclear if those cases were related to the recent outbreak. 'A major factor contributing to outbreaks of mumps is being in a crowded environment,' according to the alert. 'Also, certain behaviors that result in exchanging saliva, such as kissing or sharing utensils, cups, lipstick or cigarettes, may increase the spread of the virus.'\n\nSymptoms include fatigue, body aches, headache, loss of appetite, a low-grade fever and swelling of the salivary glands, according to health experts. In adult men, mumps can sometimes lead to sterility.\n\nNationwide, 2570 people have been diagnosed with mumps from January to April of this year [2017], according to the federal CDC. The agency reports that mumps is no longer common in the United States, but some outbreaks have been reported. Last year [2016], there were 5833 cases. 'Before the US mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting,' according to CDC. 'Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been more than 99 per cent decrease in mumps cases in the United States.'\n\nMumps patients are contagious from 2 days before through 5 days after onset, according to CDC. Public health officials said routine vaccination is the most effective way to prevent the disease. California requires that all children entering kindergarten receive 2 doses of the MMR vaccine. As of 1 July 2016, only children with medical proof can be exempt.\n\n[byline: Susan Abram]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/214.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Felix Pope]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the United Kingdom can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40]\n\n******\n \n\n[byline: Sarah Anwar]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\n\n******\n \n\n[byline: Susan Abram]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/214.] A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nCommenting on the ongoing outbreak at Penn State, Shelley Haffner, infectious disease manager at UHS, said, 'While many students who contracted mumps earlier this semester are no longer infectious, we are still continuing to see several new cases each week on campus... Source: Contagion Live [edited]\nhttp://www.contagionlive.com/news/mumps-outbreak-at-penn-state-infects-more-than-80-individuals\n\n\nPennsylvania State University (Penn State) has reported that the mumps outbreak that started in late January 2017 had reached 77 cases in April [2017]. \n\nStudents exempt from this requirement include exchange students, non-degree-seeking students, World Campus students, and those CDC recommends not to receive the vaccine, including pregnant women, anyone with previous allergies to the vaccine, and anyone with life-threatening allergy against neomycin. In this update:\nEurope\n---\n [1] UK (England, Oxford)\n\nUSA\n---\n \n\nA Penn State press release reports that 'most of the confirmed mumps cases are in students who received the CDC-recommended 2 doses of MMR vaccine \n\nThe state Health Department announced [Thu 1 Jun 2017] that 16 additional people have mumps, which brings the state's yearly total to 81 cases. \n\nSpeaking exclusively to Cherwell, St Anne's JCR [junior common room] president Pranay Shah said: ''The mumps outbreak around a few Oxford colleges is a pretty terrible coincidence with finals, prelims and other exams for the majority of students, but the response from staff has been very helpful. According to the Penn State's immunization recommendations, most students, including those living on and off campus, whether they are new, returning, or transfer students, are expected to receive 2 doses of the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine, or submit results from a blood test proving immunity, as recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). \n\nBut health officials said most of the patients are men who have sex with men, and the majority of the cases were linked to patients being at large venues such as gyms, bars, theaters and nightclubs. MUMPS UPDATE (19): EUROPE (UK), USA (HAWAII, PENNSYLVANIA, CALIFORNIA)\n**********************************************************************\n Source: Los Angeles Daily News [edited]\nhttp://www.dailynews.com/health/20170601/mumps-outbreak-declared-in-la-county-after-more-than-40-diagnoses\n\n\nMore than 40 people in Los Angeles County and surrounding regions have been diagnosed with mumps, prompting public health officials \n\nAnyone without evidence of immunity to mumps should receive at least one vaccine dose, health department officials said. \n\nBoth the Oxford University health guidelines and NHS website recommend that people entering higher education for the 1st time have the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) vaccine. \n\nNationwide, 2570 people have been diagnosed with mumps from January to April of this year [2017], according to the federal CDC. Before the US mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting,' according to CDC. ' \n\nMumps patients are contagious from 2 days before through 5 days after onset, according to CDC. An outbreak of mumps has left students sent home, cricket games cancelled, and preliminary and final exams under threat as students across Oxford come down with the infection. {"archive_id": "5049677", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (18): USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5049677", "date": "2017-05-20 12:17:35", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (18): USA\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Texas\n[2] California (Orange County)\n[3] New York (Onondaga County)\n[4] Hawaii\n\n******\n[1] Texas\nDate: Fri 19 May 2017\nSource: CBS Austin [edited]\nhttp://keyetv.com/news/local/mumps-cases-on-the-rise-in-central-texas\n\n\nThe number of mumps cases rose to 94 in the Dallas area this week [week of Sun 14 2017]. At the same time, the Department of State Health Services confirms numbers in Central Texas are rising too -- 5 in Travis County in March and April [2017], and 2 cases in Hays County. Public health experts say the MMR vaccine is the key to stopping the outbreak from reaching the Austin area, but even if you got the shots, you may not be immune to the mumps.\n\nThat's because the MMR vaccine is 88 percent effective, meaning about 1 in 10 people won't develop the antibodies to fight off the diseases and won't know it.\n\nAt Austin Public Health's Far South Clinic, the health care workers are in the business of stopping preventable diseases. That includes mumps. 'We have seen a large outbreak in the Dallas area, in Cedar Hill,' said public health educator Colleen Christian. 'Here in Travis County, we haven't seen anything like that. We do have a few cases of mumps reported.' Christian believes there were no cases reported in Travis County last year [2016].\n\nChristian says many adults may not be immune to mumps. 'For it to be as effective as possible we recommend people get 2 doses of the vaccine,' she said. But 2 doses weren't recommended until the late 1980s. ...\n\nAdults born before 1957 likely have immunity from being exposed to the mumps virus before the vaccine was made available to the public. But if you were born between the late 1950s and late 1980s, doctors can test to see if you have immunity to the mumps. 'To find out if you are immune to the illnesses that the vaccines protect against, you could have a titer run which is where they draw your blood and look at the amount of antibodies that are available,' Christian said.\n\nSymptoms of mumps include fever, headache, throat pain and swelling of the salivary glands between the ear and jaw. If you have those symptoms, or you've been in contact with someone connected to the outbreak in North Texas, call your doctor.\n\n[Byline: Adela Uchida]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A ProMED/Healthmap of Texas, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245]\n\n******\n[2] California (Orange County)\nDate: Fri 19 May 2017 9:31 am\nSource: Orange County Register [edited]\nhttp://www.ocregister.com/2017/05/18/two-new-mumps-cases-in-orange-county-are-unrelated-to-chapman-outbreak/\n\n\nA total of 2 new mumps cases have been diagnosed that are unrelated to the Chapman University outbreak, the Orange County Health Care Agency said [Thu 18 May 2017].\n\nThe 2 patients, both in their 20s, did not have contact with the 13 Chapman students who fell ill between January and 18 April 2017, but had close contact with each other. One became sick in April [2017] and the other earlier this month [May 2017].\n\nNeither had traveled outside the country and public health officials are still determining if they had been vaccinated.\n\nDr Matt Zahn, the county's medical director for epidemiology, said Orange County has had 17 mumps cases so far this year [2017]. The county usually averages fewer than 5 cases a year, with most of those the result of international travel. Zahn said in an email that while it's encouraging that Chapman has not had a new case in a month, it's too soon to say the outbreak is over.\n\nThe incubation period for mumps is up to 25 days and he said at least 2 incubation periods should pass.\n\nSymptoms of mumps include: fever, headache, tiredness, muscle aches and swollen and tender salivary glands.\n\nIn an advisory sent to health care providers, the agency said all Chapman students who have received fewer than 2 doses of the Measles, Mumps, Rubella shot should be vaccinated.\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the recommended 2 doses of the vaccine are 88 percent effective against mumps, while one dose is 78 percent effective.\n\n[Byline: Courtney Perkes]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A ProMED/Healthmap of California, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204]\n\n******\n[3] New York (Onondaga county)\nDate: Thu 18 May 2017\nSource: Local Syr [edited]\nhttp://www.localsyr.com/news/local-news/health-alert-mumps-cases-reported-in-onondaga-county/716330193\n\n\nThe Onondaga County Health Department has reported 5 cases of mumps in Onondaga County over the past few days.\n\nAccording to department officials, one case was at West Genesee High School and 4 cases were reported at Syracuse University. All of the students were vaccinated.\n\nThe OCHD says that the mumps vaccine is roughly 88 to 90 percent effective.\n\nAll cases are still under investigation, and parents and students of these 2 institutions will receive notifications from health department.\n\nMumps is a serious contagious disease passed through saliva and respiratory secretions.\n\nSymptoms include: fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite, and swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears or along the jawline on one or both sides. Health officials say an ill person can transmit the disease for 5 days after the onset of swollen salivary glands. There is no specific treatment.\n\n[Byline: Jennifer Sanders]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A ProMED/Healthmap of New York State, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234]\n\n******\n[4] Hawaii\nDate: Thu 18 May 2017\nSource: Hawaii News Now [edited]\nhttp://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/35466404/doh-confirms-5-new-mumps-cases-in-growing-outbreak\n\n\nThe Hawaii State Department of Health announced 5 new cases of mumps [Thu 18 May 2017], bringing the total number of confirmed cases to 47 this year.\n\nThe DOH says the new cases involved children and adults located on Oahu.\nNone of the patients required hospitalization.\n\nNumbers of confirmed cases began to rise in March [2017] when the DOH was made aware of 9 people with the viral infection.\n\nSome 10 DOE schools have also been reportedly affected by mumps cases.\n\nIn December, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said the country was in the midst of its worst mumps outbreak in a decade.\n\nFrom [1 January -- 22 April] of this year [2017], 42 states and Washington, D.C. reported mumps infections in 2570 people.\n\nMumps is highly contagious; symptoms include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite. Some people with mumps have very mild or no symptoms.\n\nThe disease is not considered life threatening, but there are some lasting side effects, including the swelling of salivary glands and swollen jaws.\n\nThe DOH says they are expecting to see a continued increase in reported cases as the disease spreads. They advise getting the MMR vaccine to protect against the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A ProMED/Healthmap of Hawaii, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/214]\n\n[Compared with 2570 people infected in 2017 through 22 April, in all 2016, there were 5833 cases reported to the CDC.\nIn 2015-16, outbreaks were reported from several university campuses, including a number of smaller outbreaks with limited spread. The 2 largest outbreaks were from Iowa and Illinois, each involving several hundred university students; both held wide-scale vaccination campaigns. - Mod.LK\n\n\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/214.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A ProMED/Healthmap of Hawaii, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/214]\n\n[Compared with 2570 people infected in 2017 through 22 April, in all 2016, there were 5833 cases reported to the CDC. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A ProMED/Healthmap of New York State, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234]\n\n******\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A ProMED/Healthmap of Texas, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245]\n\n******\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A ProMED/Healthmap of California, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204]\n\n******\n \n\nDr Matt Zahn, the county's medical director for epidemiology, said Orange County has had 17 mumps cases so far this year [2017]. \n\nIn an advisory sent to health care providers, the agency said all Chapman students who have received fewer than 2 doses of the Measles, Mumps, Rubella shot should be vaccinated. (21): USA (OR,HI,CA) Europe (UK)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5126427", "date": "2017-06-23 19:38:34", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (21): USA (OREGON, HAWAII, CALIFORNIA) EUROPE (UK)\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Oregon (Union County)\n[2] Oregon (Jackson County)\n[3] Hawaii (Oahu)\n[4] California (Los Angeles County)\n\nEurope\n---\n[5] UK (London)\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] Oregon (Union County)\nDate: Mon 12 Jun 2017 11:26 AM PDT\nSource: The Observer [edited]\nhttp://www.lagrandeobserver.com/news/local/5373430-151/mumps-outbreak-hits-county\n\n\nThe [Oregon] Center for Human Development [CHD] announced [Mon 12 Jun 2017] there are 4 confirmed cases of mumps in Union County and 5 presumptive cases. The presumptive cases involve people who are displaying mumps symptoms but have not yet been confirmed by lab tests, according to Andi Walsh, community relations and emergency preparedness coordinator for the CHD.\n\nPeople of all ages are contracting the disease. 'It is not just a children's disease. It is affecting the entire community,' Walsh said.\n\nThe CHD is encouraging people to get vaccinated. 'We're asking all residents to get a mumps vaccine unless they have already received 2 doses of the vaccine,' Connie Carter, public health communicable disease nurse at CHD, said.\n\nMost individuals who contract mumps will have a mild illness that lasts a week or so, but some people may have more serious outcomes. 'Those outcomes include testicular swelling, hearing loss, swelling around the brain and spinal cord or brain damage,' Carter said.\n\nThough officials are urging county residents to get vaccinated against the virus, the vaccine might not work as well for some people, so having as many qualified individuals who are healthy enough to receive the vaccination is important.\n\n'Having high vaccine rates in the community also protects those who can't be vaccinated because they are too young or have a health condition that prevents it,' Carter said.\n\nMeanwhile, officials are working on pinpointing where the disease in Union County originated, but according to Carrie Brogoitti, public health administrator with CHD, the extensive investigation will take time.\n\nWhile it may never be known how mumps came to the county, public health workers want residents to know what the symptoms are and how the disease is contracted so they can protect themselves and their families.\n\nSymptoms of mumps include puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw. Other indicators of the virus include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, according to the news release. The 1st symptoms typically appear 16 to 18 days after infection and up to 25 days after initial contact.\n\n'Some people may not have signs of illness. If you think that you have the mumps, stay away from others,' Carter said. 'Do not show up at the emergency room or your health care provider's office. Instead, call your provider and ask what you should do next.'\n\nThe communicable disease is spread easily through fluids from the mouth, nose, or throat. It can spread two days before signs of the illness appear, and up to 5 days after the swelling begins.\n\nAn infected person can spread the virus by coughing, sneezing, talking, or sharing items such as cups or eating utensils with others and touching objects or surfaces with unwashed hands that are then touched by others, according to the release.\n\nHealth officials are warning that if someone thinks they might have contracted the mumps, then they should stay away from others.\n\nHealth officials are also encouraging anyone who thinks they might be infected to not show up at an emergency room or a health care provider's office. Health officials are urging anyone who believes they may have mumps to call their primary provider and ask for instructions, according to the release.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Oregon (Jackson County)\nDate: Fri 16 Jun 2017\nSource: KTVL [edited]\nhttp://ktvl.com/news/local/public-health-officials-seeing-mumps-outbreak-across-oregon\n\n\nJackson County [Oregon] Public Health officials say they're noticing a spike of mumps cases across the state.\n\nLocally, Jackson County has only had 1 confirmed case this year [2017].\n\nMumps is a vaccine-preventable disease, usually given to children at a year and then between the ages of 4 and 6 years old. Symptoms include fever, headache, and most notably swollen salivary glands. Public health officials said all diagnosed cases are reported to the county, so they prevent the illness from spreading.\n\n'Anytime we see something greater than the expected it keeps everybody busy. You're doing a lot of investigating trying to figure out why you are seeing an increase in whatever disease or virus it could be,' said Tanya Phillips with Jackson County Public Health.\n\nIf there are complications from mumps it can lead to inflammation around the brain or deafness.\n\n[Byline: Megan Allison]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Oregon can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/239. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/oregon-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Hawaii (Oahu)\nDate: Sat 17 Jun 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/hawaii-mumps-cases-tops-100-45599/\n\n\nThe Hawaii State Department of Health (DOH) has confirmed 8 additional cases this week [week of 17 Jun 2017] of Oahu residents with the mumps, pushing the total number of cases this year to 104.\n\nOn Tue 13 Jun 2017, 3 new cases were confirmed and involved 2 adults and 1 child. None of the cases required hospitalization and all 3 are recovering. An additional 5 cases were confirmed today [17 Jun 2017], involving 1 adult and 4 children, none of whom required hospitalization.\n\nDOH expects the current mumps outbreak to continue and the investigation of new cases is ongoing.\n\nThe MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine provides the best protection against the disease. 2 doses of the vaccine are 88 percent effective at protecting against mumps and 1 dose is 78 percent effective. Being fully vaccinated can help protect loved ones, family members, friends, classmates, and coworkers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Hawaii can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4520. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[4] California (Los Angeles County)\nDate: Tue 20 Jun 2017 00:16 PDT\nSource: Norcal News [edited]\nhttp://norcal.news/news/23802-mumps-outbreak-la-county-infects-42-people\n\n\nA sudden mumps outbreak in Los Angeles County [California] has now infected 42 people, and many of those are living on the Westside.\n\nNationally, mumps has been a major problem in recent years. There were 5833 cases nationwide last year [2016], and that number seems to be rising this year. As of May [2017], there have been 3176 nationwide cases this year, on pace to exceed last year's comfortably.\n\nSome vaccinated individuals have been affected, with the majority of cases being found in places where people are kept in closed quarters, such as college campuses. The MMR vaccine, designed to protect against mumps among other diseases, does not seem to be covering it.\n\nThe vaccine's effectiveness is not really in question, but there are thoughts of adding additional doses. Now, doses are given when children are about 1 year of age and then again before school age. The vaccine may wane before adulthood is reached. Some, like military members, are given additional doses of the vaccine in basic training, but the general population does not receive a booster.\n\nResearch has shone that it may be just a blip though. Most of those infected intermingle. Most of the cases have been seen on campuses, in bars, nightclubs, or other similar places. People infected tend to have the same social networks.\n\nIt is recommended that you limit contact with affected individuals. Do not share drinks. Avoid shaking hands. Make sure to wash your hands often. If you are infected, you should limit your contact with other people until you're better and should see a doctor immediately to start your treatment. Please be courteous to others and try not to spread the virus around.\n\nRegardless of this blip, the national incidence of mumps is down more than 99 percent since before the introduction of the MMR vaccine, so these numbers are nothing too much to worry about. It's just important that everyone take the proper precautions to avoid getting infected, especially if you live in an outbreak area.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4259. Los Angeles County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/california-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\nEurope\n---\n[5] UK (London)\nDate: Thu 15 Jun 2017\nSource: KCW Today [edited]\nhttp://www.kcwtoday.co.uk/2017/06/cases-mumps-measles-rise-throughout-london/\n\n\nThere has been a dramatic rise in reported cases of mumps, particularly in teenagers and young adults across London, public health officials warned. Public Health England (PHE), alongside the NHS, are investigating after nearly 450 cases were reported between [1 Jan-30 May 2017]. This is an increase of 150 cases compared to the same 5-month period in 2016. The City of Westminster had the lowest infection rate with only 8 cases, with 15 reported in Kensington and Chelsea.\n\nThis news comes in tandem with data that show that cases of measles have also sky-rocketed in London and the South East last year [2017], reaching the highest number since the last outbreak in 2012 (which saw 3873 cases across England and Wales). There were a total of 60 cases recorded in 2016 (there were 382 in 2012), compared to just 4 in 2015. London and the South West were the only 2 regions to record more cases of the viral infection last year [2016].\n\nThe upturn in both mumps and measles can be traced to the falling numbers of children undergoing the MMR vaccine. The World Health Organisation has set a target of 95 percent, but vaccination rates have fallen to 91.9 percent. This recent fall has followed years of broadly rising coverage since the MMR controversy, when the vaccine was linked to autism in a now-discredited paper in 1998 by Andrew Wakefield.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the United Kingdom can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/283\n\nThe mumps virus is an RNA virus belonging to the genus _Rubulavirus_ in the family Paramyxovirus. According to the CDC, mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. Before the U.S. mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States. However, this past year has seen a upswing in the number of mumps cases.\n\nMMR (Measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. 2 doses of the vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66 to 95 percent) effective at protecting against mumps; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49 percent to 92 percent) effective. It is important that children get vaccinated since the disease can be more severe in adults. While some people who get mumps have very mild or no symptoms, and often they do not know they have the disease, and most people with mumps recover completely in a few weeks, symptoms can be serious. Complications may include infections of the coverings of the brain (15 percent), pancreatitis (4 percent), permanent deafness, and painful testicular swelling which uncommonly results in infertility. Women may develop ovarian swelling but this does not increase the risk of infertility. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the United Kingdom can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/283\n\nThe mumps virus is an RNA virus belonging to the genus _Rubulavirus_ in the family Paramyxovirus. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4259. \n\nMMR (Measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. In this update:\nUSA\n---\n \n[5] UK (London)\n\n******\n 2 doses of the vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66 to 95 percent) effective at protecting against mumps; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49 percent to 92 percent) effective. Source: KTVL [edited]\nhttp://ktvl.com/news/local/public-health-officials-seeing-mumps-outbreak-across-oregon\n\n\nJackson County [Oregon] Public Health officials say they're noticing a spike of mumps cases across the state. \n\nThis news comes in tandem with data that show that cases of measles have also sky-rocketed in London and the South East last year [2017], reaching the highest number since the last outbreak in 2012 (which saw 3873 cases across England and Wales). [week of 17 Jun 2017] of Oahu residents with the mumps, pushing the total number of cases this year to 104.\n\n \n\nMumps is a vaccine-preventable disease, usually given to children at a year and then between the ages of 4 and 6 years old. MUMPS UPDATE (21): USA (OREGON, HAWAII, CALIFORNIA) EUROPE (UK)\n***************************************************************\n The [Oregon] Center for Human Development [CHD] announced [Mon 12 Jun 2017] there are 4 confirmed cases of mumps in Union County and 5 presumptive cases. \n\nWhile it may never be known how mumps came to the county, public health workers want residents to know what the symptoms are and how the disease is contracted so they can protect themselves and their families. \n\nThough officials are urging county residents to get vaccinated against the virus, the vaccine might not work as well for some people, so having as many qualified individuals who are healthy enough to receive the vaccination is important. We're asking all residents to get a mumps vaccine unless they have already received 2 doses of the vaccine,' Connie Carter, public health communicable disease nurse at CHD, said. \n\nDOH expects the current mumps outbreak to continue and the investigation of new cases is ongoing. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< [4] California (Los Angeles County)\n\nEurope\n--- 2 doses of the vaccine are 88 percent effective at protecting against mumps and 1 dose is 78 percent effective. While some people who get mumps have very mild or no symptoms, and often they do not know they have the disease, and most people with mumps recover completely in a few weeks, symptoms can be serious. USA\n---\n Europe\n---\n \n\nThe upturn in both mumps and measles can be traced to the falling numbers of children undergoing the MMR vaccine. \n\nSome vaccinated individuals have been affected, with the majority of cases being found in places where people are kept in closed quarters, such as college campuses. A sudden mumps outbreak in Los Angeles County [California] has now infected 42 people, and many of those are living on the Westside.\n\n \n\n--\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n [Byline: Megan Allison]\n\n--\n \n\n--\n \n\n--\n \n\n--\n \n\nMost individuals who contract mumps will have a mild illness that lasts a week or so, but some people may have more serious outcomes. ' \n\nHealth officials are warning that if someone thinks they might have contracted the mumps, then they should stay away from others. MJ]\n\n******\n MJ]\n\n******\n MJ]\n\n******\n The presumptive cases involve people who are displaying mumps symptoms but have not yet been confirmed by lab tests, according to Andi Walsh, community relations and emergency preparedness coordinator for the CHD. \n\n'Having high vaccine rates in the community also protects those who can't be vaccinated because they are too young or have a health condition that prevents it,' Carter said. \n\nMeanwhile, officials are working on pinpointing where the disease in Union County originated, but according to Carrie Brogoitti, public health administrator with CHD, the extensive investigation will take time. \n\nHealth officials are also encouraging anyone who thinks they might be infected to not show up at an emergency room or a health care provider's office. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4988318", "date": "2017-04-23 08:21:48", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (16): USA (TEXAS, MINNESOTA)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Texas\n[2] Texas, Dallas County\n[3] Minnesota\n\n******\n[1] Texas\nDate: Sat 15 April 2017\nSource: BABW News [edited]\nhttp://www.babwnews.com/2017/04/huge-disease-outbreak-in-u-s-sends-authorities-scrambling/\n\n\n[Mumps] has suddenly sprung up in the United States, and authorities are trying to figure out how to get a handle on the situation.\n\nA very unpleasant disease [mumps] has reared its ugly head in the United States, and authorities have been trying to understand why it's happening and how to stop it. Health department officials in Texas have announced that cases of mumps have surged to a 20-year high, and there may have been a bunch of exposures on South Padre Island where spring-breakers are celebrating.\n\nState health officials have reported 221 cases of mumps so far this year [2017], the most since 1994 when there were 234 cases. Mumps results in swollen salivary grands, swollen testicles, low fever, tiredness, and muscle aches, with symptoms emerging about 16 -- 18 days after exposure.\n\nInfections of mumps dived 99 percent since a vaccine was developed and released in 1967. The mumps vaccine protects 88 percent of people who are fully vaccinated, although some vaccinated people can still get sick if exposed.\n\n'The Texas Department of State Health Services is advising health care providers to be on alert for mumps in their patients as the state experiences a 20-year high in mumps cases,' states the THHS website 'State, regional and local health departments are currently investigating multiple outbreaks throughout the state, including one involving possible exposures on South Padre Island, a popular spring break destination for students from Texas and elsewhere in the United States. Texas has had 221 mumps cases this year [2017], the largest total since there were 234 cases in 1994.'\n\n[Byline: Dan Taylor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Texas, Dallas County\nDate: Wed 19 Apr 2017\nSource: FOX4News [edited]\nhttp://www.fox4news.com/news/249605964-story\n\n\nCedar Hill ISD officials held a forum [Wed 19 Apr 2017] night to provide more information to concerned parents about a severe mumps outbreak.\n\nDallas County Health and Human Services reports 84 mumps cases so far in 2017 [see [1] above, 221 cases total in state].\n\nUp to 64 of those cases are students and teachers in Cedar Hill ISD, with 3 more cases in DeSoto. Health officials have also identified 17 unrelated cases in Mesquite, Dallas and DeSoto.\n\nParents at the meeting submitted questions. Many wanted to know how the mumps is spreading and why.\n\n'You heard about the chicken pox, you heard about the meningitis, but the mumps you haven't heard about in so long, so you're kind of concerned, like can it cause death?' said parent [SA].\n\n[A] has a daughter at Cedar Hill High School. Her child is vaccinated, but [A] is still concerned about the mumps outbreak that started at her child's school.\n\n'What are we doing about this mumps outbreak? Are we cleaning the building?' [A] asked.\n\nDistrict officials said the outbreak started at Cedar Hill High School in February [2017].\n\nSince then, more cases have been found at 9th Grade Center, Collegiate High School, Permenter Middle School and High Pointe Elementary. 'When you get a bunch of kids all contained in small pockets of areas, like schools, the likelihood of spreading an airborne virus is gonna happen,' said Cedar Hill ISD superintendent Orlando Riddick.\n\nOfficials don't know the source but said they're doing their best to keep the situation under control.\n\n'We've started our cleaning processes and cleaning high touch areas,' superintendent Riddick said. 'We began to disinfect schools with a misting machine.'\n\nThe district has also hosted 4 vaccine booster clinics, saying more than 90 percent of their students are vaccinated.\n\nThe district's health director, Dr Michael Marshall, said infected people could be unknowingly spreading mumps.\n\n'The problem is simply that people are coming to school who are infected with the mumps and they don't know it,' said Dr Marshall.\n\nAccording to doctors, it can take up to 25 days until symptoms like fever, headache and loss of appetite show up. Some who are infected have no symptoms.\n\nParent [AG] said the district should be transparent about the outbreak. 'Just be transparent and make sure our building is clean and that it's safe for our children and teachers,'[G] said.\n\nAccording to health officials, those without the mumps vaccine are most at risk. Doctors recommend at least 2 vaccines, and even a 3rd booster shot to increase protection. However, one can still get mumps even with the proper vaccines.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Minnesota\nDate: Fri 21 APR 2017 11:30 PM\nSource: CBS News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbsnews.com/news/mumps-outbreak-reported-at-university-of-minnesota/\n\n\nUniversity of Minnesota health officials are warning students about a mumps outbreak on campus, CBS Minnesota reports.\n\nSo far there have been 6 reported cases, campus health officials say.\n\nIt's considered highly contagious and the disease is spread by coughing, sneezing or sharing items that you eat or drink.\n\nThe symptoms are pretty clear -- puffy cheeks, a swollen jaw accompanied by a fever, headaches and loss of appetite.\n\n'I've been at Boynton Health for 20 years and we have not had this situation before,' said Dr Gary Christenson, the chief medical officer at the University of Minnesota.\n\nChristenson said students are required to be vaccinated for mumps before they come to school, with a few exceptions. But even then, it's still possible to contract the disease.\n\nUp to 6 reported cases of mumps so far at the University may not seem like a large number. But on a campus like this, Christenson said anything over 3 cases is considered an outbreak.\n\n'One of the challenges of mumps is that for the 1st 2 days that someone has it, before they have symptoms, they are already shedding or can be exposing other people to it,' said Christenson.\n\nA couple years ago, the Minnesota Wild got caught in a mumps outbreak. And in February, the mumps again briefly sidelined forwards [ZP] and [JP]. Students believe that if it can spread quickly on a hockey team, it can spread just as quickly on campus.\n\n'If you are at the library or something, this is such a huge school, it's so hard for things not to be spread around,' said senior Maddie Trenholm.\n\nThat's why health officials are asking students or faculty who has been diagnosed to stay away for 5 days.\n\n'It's really hard to predict how long this will be an issue and how many cases we might have,' said Christenson.\n\nAnd with finals coming up, they are hoping to keep this from spreading as much as possible. The cases the university has seen so far are considered mild.\n\nA US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report in December 2016 shows that mumps are at a 10-year high -- and colleges seem to be especially hard hit by the contagious virus. The close quarters on campus make it easy for the disease to spread.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 1 Jan -- 25 Mar 2017, 42 states and the District of Columbia in the US reported 1965 cases of mumps to CDC.\n\nFrom year to year, mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. For example in 2016, there were approximately 5748 cases reported to CDC, and in 2012, there were 229. Before the US mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States.\n\n(excerpted / edited from CDC.gov). - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/354.]", "summary": "\n\n'The Texas Department of State Health Services is advising health care providers to be on alert for mumps in their patients as the state experiences a 20-year high in mumps cases,' states the THHS website 'State, regional and local health departments are currently investigating multiple outbreaks throughout the state, including one involving possible exposures on South Padre Island, a popular spring break destination for students from Texas and elsewhere in the United States. "1994-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-12-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dallas County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5095537", "date": "2017-06-09 17:11:02", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (20): USA (ILLINOIS, NEW YORK, MASSACHUSETTS)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Illinois, McLean county\n[2] Illinois, Algonquin\n[3] New York, Capital region\n[4] Massachusetts, Boston\n\n******\n[1] Illinois, McLean county\nDate: Tue 6 Jun 2017\nSource: The Pantagraph [edited]\nhttp://www.pantagraph.com/news/local/testing-encouraged-amid-mumps-outbreak/article_cfcf971c-6b33-556a-ba8e-2d0d27fe36f1.html\n\n\nA total of 5 McLean County residents have confirmed cases of mumps, leading the county health department on [Tue 6 Jun 2017] to encourage people experiencing symptoms to isolate from others until they can be tested for the virus.\n\nNone of the 5 residents -- ages 22 -- 52 -- needed to be hospitalized and all are recovering, said Lisa Slater of the McLean County Health Department. The agency is working with the infected individuals and notifying their close contacts about possible exposure to the virus.\n\n'We need to protect our most vulnerable populations -- those who cannot get the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine because of age or illness -- from exposure to mumps virus,' Melissa Graven, health department communicable disease supervisor, said in a statement for several days.\n\nPeople experiencing symptoms should stay home and call their health care provider. Everyone else should make sure they are up to date with their MMR vaccinations and, if they aren't, to make vaccination a priority, the health department said.\n\n[Byline: Paul Swiech]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Illinois, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/216]\n\n******\n[2] Illinois, Algonquin\nDate: Wed 7 Jun 2017 7:23 PM\nSource: Daily Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.dailyherald.com/news/20170607/officials-3-more-jacobs-high-students-test-positive-for-mumps\n\n\nA total of 3 more Jacobs High School students have tested positive for mumps, bringing the number of confirmed cases in the district to 6, school officials announced [Wed 7 Jun 2017].\n\nAll 6 students previously had been vaccinated, according to a news release from Community Unit District 300.\n\nThe 3 students who most recently tested positive for mumps went to class through the last day of school, which was 25 May [2017], the release said.\n\nStudents and staff members who are not vaccinated or have compromised immune systems have been kept out of the school since 15 May [2017], when the 1st student tested positive for mumps.\n\nNone of the 3 students who recently tested positive shared classes, athletics or activities within the school setting, school officials said.\n\nThe school district, along with the health departments in Kane and McHenry counties, is monitoring the cases.\n\nMumps symptoms include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite and swollen glands, according to the Kane County Health Department.\n\n[Byline: Katie Smith]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] New York, Capital region\nDate: Thu 8 Jun 2017\nSource: Times Union [edited]\nhttp://www.timesunion.com/allwcm/article/Capital-Region-has-first-mumps-outbreak-in-years-11206309.php\n\n\nIf you feel like you might have a bad cold, don't shrug it off. Swollen jaw or not, it could be mumps.\n\nThe Capital Region [New York] is experiencing its 1st outbreak of mumps in years, with 45 cases in the 4-county region so far in 2017. For some parts of the area, these are the 1st cases of mumps in several years. And in Rensselaer County this year's 2 reported cases are the 1st seen there in 20 years, said Public Health Director Mary Fran Wachunas.\n\nAlbany County has seen the lion's share of mumps this year [2017], with 29 cases.\nMost of them are traceable to 2 locations where the virus that causes the disease has spread. One is the University at Albany, where 22 patients had an association. The other is a local sports team, which had 6 cases.\n\nMumps cases by county, 2017\n\nAlbany : 29\nSaratoga: 13\nRensselaer: 2\nSchenectady: 1\n\nIn Saratoga County, where there have been 13 diagnosed cases of mumps, however, the patients are not connected by community, facility or demographic. That caused county officials to advise residents with suspected mumps symptoms to see a doctor immediately.\n\nThe most well-known symptom of mumps are swollen glands under the ears or jaw. But some patients who have the illness do not have that telltale sign, said Dr Rebecca Kobos, medical director for student health at UAlbany. Headache, muscle aches, loss of appetite and fever may be enough to indicate mumps, Kobos said, especially if a patient has been exposed to someone with the virus.\n\nHer advice: See a doctor and take it seriously. Rest and stay away from work or school, so you don't expose other people to the illness. Rare but serious complications of mumps include swelling of the reproductive organs or the brain, as well as deafness.\nCommon sense is also handy.\n\n'Precautions as simple as regular handwashing and covering one's mouth when coughing can go a long way to halt the spread of the virus,' said Catherine Duncan, director of public health in Saratoga County.\n\n[Byline: Claire Hughes]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of New York, United States, can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234]\n\n******\n[4] Massachusetts, Boston\nDate: Fri 9 Jun 2017\nSource: Eastie Times [edited]\nhttp://www.eastietimes.com/2017/06/09/eastie-part-of-recent-mumps-outbreak/\n\n\nThe state's Department of Public Health's (DPH) spokeswoman Ann Scales confirmed that some of 12 new cases of mumps that are part of an ongoing outbreak in the area originated in East Boston.\n\nSince the end of March [2017], 12 cases have been reported in Eastie, Boston, Chelsea and Revere among the neighborhood's Latino population.\n\nScales said the DPH will be reaching out to the Latino communities here and in the other communities affected by the outbreak in order to increase awareness about mumps and to encourage vaccination.\n\nThe DPH usually sees mumps outbreaks among college-age individuals attending local colleges and universities. However, what makes this outbreak unique is it is among adults ranging in age from 20 to 41 with no known connection to higher education. All of the residents hit by the outbreak are Latino and include members of the Colombian, Dominican, Guatemalan, and Salvadoran communities. None of those affected is known to have traveled internationally prior to becoming ill. For the majority of the residents, vaccination histories are unknown but most are believed to be unvaccinated against mumps. Unvaccinated individuals are most susceptible to mumps infection.\n\nHealth officials reported that this outbreak 'may represent a change in the epidemiology of mumps in Massachusetts'.\n\n'MMR vaccination is highly protective against mumps and is recommended for children and adults,' said Public Health Commissioner Monica Bharel, MD, MPH, referring to the Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR) vaccine. 'In addition, those who have mumps should stay isolated at home for 5 days after their onset of swelling. Mumps is usually a mild disease but can cause serious illness. If you think you have mumps, stay home and call your healthcare provider.''\n\nAccording to the DPH mumps virus is spread through infected respiratory tract secretions. It can be spread within 3 -- 6 feet when an infected person coughs or sneezes or with direct contact with infected secretions like sharing water bottles. The incubation period can range from 12 -- 25 days. Parotitis, or swelling of the salivary glands, is the most common symptom but non-specific symptoms such as myalgia, anorexia, malaise, headache, and low-grade fever may precede the parotitis by several days. In the pre-vaccine era, 15--30 percent of infections were asymptomatic.\n\nPeople are considered infectious from 2 days before symptoms begin until 5 days after the onset of parotid swelling. Therefore, those suspected of mumps should be isolated and should refrain from public activities for 5 days after the onset of swelling.\n\nDPH and local health departments are investigating these cases and instituting isolation and quarantine measures to control the spread of mumps.\n\nEast Boston Neighborhood Health Center could not confirm if any of the confirmed cases were treated at the clinic.\n\n[Byline: John Lynds]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Massachusetts, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/224]\n\n[According to the CDC [edited], from 1 Jan -- 20 May 2017, 42 states and the District of Columbia in the U.S. reported mumps infections in 3176 people to CDC.\n\nMumps is no longer very common in the United States. From year to year, mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. For example in 2016, there were approximately 5833 cases reported to CDC, and in 2012, there were 229. Before the U.S. mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States.\n\nSee https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html for a map and figure showing incidence of mumps since 2000. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/253.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of New York, United States, can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234]\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Illinois, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/216]\n\n******\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Massachusetts, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/224]\n\n \n\n'We need to protect our most vulnerable populations -- those who cannot get the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine because of age or illness -- from exposure to mumps virus,' Melissa Graven, health department communicable disease supervisor, said in a statement for several days. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Rensselaer: 2\nSchenectady: 1\n\nIn Saratoga County, where there have been 13 diagnosed cases of mumps, however, the patients are not connected by community, facility or demographic. \n\nMumps cases by county, 2017\n\nAlbany : \n\n'MMR vaccination is highly protective against mumps and is recommended for children and adults,' said Public Health Commissioner Monica Bharel, MD, MPH, referring to the Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR) vaccine. ' \n\n[Byline: Paul Swiech]\n\n--\n A total of 5 McLean County residents have confirmed cases of mumps, leading the county health department on [Tue 6 Jun 2017] to encourage people experiencing symptoms to isolate from others until they can be tested for the virus. \n\nStudents and staff members who are not vaccinated or have compromised immune systems have been kept out of the school since 15 May [2017], when the 1st student tested positive for mumps. \n\nAlbany County has seen the lion's share of mumps this year [2017], with 29 cases. \n\nMumps symptoms include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite and swollen glands, according to the Kane County Health Department. MUMPS UPDATE (20): USA (ILLINOIS, NEW YORK, MASSACHUSETTS)\n**********************************************************\n A total of 3 more Jacobs High School students have tested positive for mumps, bringing the number of confirmed cases in the district to 6, school officials announced [Wed 7 Jun 2017]. \n\nDPH and local health departments are investigating these cases and instituting isolation and quarantine measures to control the spread of mumps. \n\nScales said the DPH will be reaching out to the Latino communities here and in the other communities affected by the outbreak in order to increase awareness about mumps and to encourage vaccination. [Byline: Katie Smith]\n\n--\n [Byline: Claire Hughes]\n\n--\n [Byline: John Lynds]\n\n--\n \n\nAccording to the DPH mumps virus is spread through infected respiratory tract secretions. Before the U.S. mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. The Capital Region [New York] is experiencing its 1st outbreak of mumps in years, with 45 cases in the 4-county region so far in 2017. \n\n'Precautions as simple as regular handwashing and covering one's mouth when coughing can go a long way to halt the spread of the virus,' said Catherine Duncan, director of public health in Saratoga County. \n\nPeople are considered infectious from 2 days before symptoms begin until 5 days after the onset of parotid swelling. "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (15): NEW ZEALAND, USA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] New Zealand (Aukland)\n[2] USA (Colorado)\n[3] USA (Texas, Dallas County)\n[4] USA (Illinois, Lake County)\n[5] USA (Kentucky, Fayette County, Lexington)\n[6] USA (California, San Joaquin County, Stockton)\n\n******\n[1] New Zealand (Aukland)\nDate: Mon 3 Apr 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/auckland-reports-dozens-mumps-cases-2017-date-37446/\n\n\nThe Auckland Regional Public Health Service (ARPHS) announced today [Mon 3 Apr 2017] that since the beginning of the year, they have received 39 notifications of mumps, with most arising in West Auckland.\n\nThe age range of affected persons is 5 months to 51 years with over half occurring among students aged 10 -- 19 years.\n\nIn a letter to providers in mid-March [2017], ARPHS writes cases have been diagnosed after travel to Fiji, Tuvalu and Japan where childhood vaccinations may not have included the mumps. More recent cases have been diagnosed in a local school and a major containment strategy is underway to control the spread of mumps.\n\nThe best prevention against mumps is immunization with 2 doses of the measles, mumps, rubella vaccine (MMR).\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of New Zealand can be found at Healthmap http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Colorado)\nDate: Mon 3 Apr 2017 2:56 pm\nSource: Denver Post [edited]\nhttp://www.denverpost.com/2017/04/03/mumps-cases-booming-colorado/\n\n\nColorado this year [2017] is seeing a surge in mumps cases unlike any other in at least a decade, but a state Health Department official said it appears that the outbreak responsible for most of the cases so far is ending.\n\nIn only 3 months of 2017, Colorado has seen 60 reported cases of mumps, and more possible cases are being investigated, said Dr Lisa Miller, the state epidemiologist. That is more than 3 times the number of cases reported in the state all of last year [2016]. Every other year in the previous decade saw only single-digit case numbers.\n\nThe biggest reason for the dramatic spike this year [2017] has been an outbreak of 46 linked cases in Denver and Arapahoe County. But Miller said no new linked cases have been identified since the end of February [2017], and health officials are hopeful that vaccination clinics helped stem the outbreak.\n\n'But we are continuing to get sporadic cases of mumps that don't turn out to be related to the outbreak,' Miller said.\n\nThose isolated cases, Miller said, are the result of a nationwide mumps boom that mirrors Colorado's own increase. This year [2017], 37 states have reported more than 1000 mumps cases, combined, and Miller said outbreaks elsewhere will likely continue to keep Colorado case numbers ticking upward.\n\nThe mumps, which causes telltale painful swelling in the glands of the cheek and jaw, is often thought of as an old-time virus. Most people born before 1957 have probably been exposed to mumps in their lifetimes. But vaccination made mumps cases much more rare.\n\nMiller said the outbreak this year [2017] mostly occurred in unvaccinated people. Those who have been vaccinated can still catch mumps if exposed, but it is much less likely and the symptoms would be less severe.\n\nMiller said it is possible that mumps outbreaks are cyclical and that this year's will soon be relegated to history. But she also encouraged more people to get vaccinated in order to break the cycle.\n\n'The intervention is really very clear,' she said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[A map of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\n\n******\n[3] USA (Texas, Dallas County)\nDate: Wed 5 Apr 2017 9:45 PM\nSource: CBS Local [edited]\nhttp://dfw.cbslocal.com/2017/04/05/cedar-hill-at-center-of-mumps-outbreak/\n\n\nDallas County Health and Human Services report 76 mumps cases in the county, 56 of them coming from students and teachers in Cedar Hill ISD.\n\nA letter went out to Cedar Valley College students and staff alerting them about a high school student from Cedar Hill Collegiate Academy taking classes there might have exposed others.\n\nDallas County reported its 1st mumps case on 19 Jan [2016]. Each week since, there have been more cases.\n\nAudra Barrett, the VP for Instruction at Cedar Valley College said students and faculty in 4 classes may have been exposed. 'They were notified by our president but they were also given this letter as well with very direct bullet points of what needs to happen and what to look out for,' said Barrett.\n\nThe college isn't adding any additional cleaning beyond what's routine but the college is offering an immunization clinic on [Thu 6 Apr 2017].\n\n'Something that is touching close to home you just want to make sure that you are well prepared,' said Barrett.\n\nCedar Hill ISD in conjunction with DCHSS offered a booster shot or 3rd round of mumps, measles and rubella vaccine and started cleaning more.\n\nThere is no treatment for mumps, but most people recover completely in a few weeks.\n\n[Byline: Brittany Jeffers]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] USA (Illinois, Lake County)\nDate: Thu 06 Apr 2017 4:48 pm ET\nSource: Patch [edited]\nhttps://patch.com/illinois/grayslake/mumps-outbreak-impacts-four-counties-several-schools\n\n\nThe Lake County Health Department has been investigating a multi-jurisdictional outbreak of mumps. Health officials reported confirmed and probable cases at Barrington School District 220 and several other schools.\n\nThose who contracted mumps reside in Lake, Cook, Kane and McHenry counties, 13 according to a health department news release.\n\nOn [Mon 13 Mar 2017], the Health Department held a vaccination clinic for Barrington High School staff and students who were not up to date with their measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccinations. A 2nd MMR vaccination clinic is scheduled at the high school in April [2017].\n\nTo help prevent the virus from spreading:\n\n- Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when you cough or sneeze.\n- Dispose of used tissues in the trash can.\n- If you don't have a tissue, cough or sneeze into your upper sleeve or elbow, not your hands.\n- Wash your hands often with soap and water.\n- Disinfect frequently touched surfaces, such as toys, doorknobs, tables, counters.\n\n[Byline: Amie Rowland]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] USA (Kentucky, Fayette County, Lexington)\nDate: Fri 7 Apr 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/lexington-first-mumps-cases-2017-whooping-cough-schools-27631/\n\n\nOfficials with the Lexington-Fayette County Health Department have confirmed 2 mumps cases in Fayette County. These are the 1st mumps cases of the year [2017].\n\nMumps is a viral infection that causes painful swelling in the glands of the cheek and jaw. Other symptoms may include low-grade fever, fatigue, loss of appetite and headache, but about a 3rd of people who have the virus don't have symptoms. The virus is spread through direct contact with the respiratory droplets or saliva of an infected person. Serious complications from mumps are rare, but include meningitis and other problems.\n\nSymptoms of mumps usually appear from 16 to 18 days after exposure. A person with mumps can spread the disease from 2 days before to 5 days after gland swelling begins, so people with mumps should stay at home until at least 5 days after the swelling starts.\n\nHealth officials say the best way to protect against mumps in by getting vaccinated.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[6] USA (California, San Joaquin County, Stockton)\nDate: Fri 7 Apr 2017 12:47 PM\nSource: The Record [edited]\nhttp://www.recordnet.com/news/20170407/mumps-outbreak-confirmed-at-pacific\n\n\nA total of 2 students at University of the Pacific have confirmed cases of mumps, the 1st such cases in San Joaquin County since 2011, according to San Joaquin County Public Health Services.\n\nUp to 7 additional suspected cases among students are being investigated, and the university is working with the health department to stop the spread of the illness.\n\nPublic health officials are recommending that even fully vaccinated students get another dose of the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine for added protection.\n\n'We're recommending that 3rd dose to try to stop the spread of the disease,' Dr Julie Vaishampayan, assistant health officer, said in a statement. 'It does help if high numbers of students take that 3rd dose.'\n\nStudents who have never had the vaccine, and even those who have had only 1 dose, are even more exposed and should also be vaccinated.\n\nThe university is working with the student body to ensure access to the vaccine.\n\n'Our priority is to ensure that the students are taken care of and that faculty, staff and the Pacific community take measures to protect themselves,' said Pacific's Vice President for Student Life Patrick Day.\n\nThe 1st student with symptoms had traveled to an out-of-state conference in mid-February and developed symptoms in early March [2017]. Since late March, 2 students with close contacts to the initial student have been diagnosed with mumps, and several others have developed symptoms of inflammation of the parotid gland.\n\nAll the affected students are in the physical therapy and pharmacy programs. Students in the physician assistant program at the Sacramento campus who take some classes in pharmacy in Stockton are also being notified of possible exposure.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[7 additional student cases are being investigated. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1580.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of New Zealand can be found at Healthmap http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164]\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Source: Denver Post [edited]\nhttp://www.denverpost.com/2017/04/03/mumps-cases-booming-colorado/\n\n\nColorado this year [2017] is seeing a surge in mumps cases unlike any other in at least a decade, but a state Health Department official said it appears that the outbreak responsible for most of the cases so far is ending. Date: Wed 5 Apr 2017 9:45 PM\nSource: CBS Local [edited]\n MUMPS UPDATE (15): NEW ZEALAND, USA\n***********************************\n Apr 2017 12:47 PM\nSource: The Record [edited]\nhttp://www.recordnet.com/news/20170407/mumps-outbreak-confirmed-at-pacific Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n In only 3 months of 2017, Colorado has seen 60 reported cases of mumps, and more possible cases are being investigated, said Dr Lisa Miller, the state epidemiologist. \n\nPublic health officials are recommending that even fully vaccinated students get another dose of the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine for added protection. \n\nThose isolated cases, Miller said, are the result of a nationwide mumps boom that mirrors Colorado's own increase. On [Mon 13 Mar 2017], the Health Department held a vaccination clinic for Barrington High School staff and students who were not up to date with their measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccinations.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-04-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kentucky", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lexington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lake", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aukland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dallas County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Joaquin County Public Health Services", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fayette County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Joaquin County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Auckland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arapahoe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sacramento",
