"country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4922098", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (12): Canada (ON) USA (IL,AR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4922098", "date": "2017-03-24 10:05:36", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (12): CANADA (ONTARIO), USA (ILLINOIS, ARKANSAS)\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Canada (Ontario)\n[2] USA (Illinois)\n[3] USA (Arkansas) outbreak analysis\n\n******\n[1] Canada (Ontario)\nDate: Mon 20 Mar 2017\nSource: The Record [edited]\nhttp://www.therecord.com/news-story/7200186-small-increase-in-mumps-cases-in-waterloo-region/\n\n\nSo far this year [2017], 3 confirmed cases of mumps have been reported in Waterloo Region, mirroring a widespread bump in the virus's activity.\n\n'It's definitely something people should be aware of, but the risk is pretty low because most of our population is immunized,' said Kristy Wright, manager of infectious diseases for Region of Waterloo Public Health.\n\n'There's no need to panic. We're quite used to having this cyclical activity with mumps.'\n\nThere's been increased mumps activity across Ontario, as well as Canada and the United States. 'It is circulating. There is sporadic activity,' Wright said.\n\nIn Guelph, there are 3 confirmed cases among university aged people linked to a keg party held in mid-January [2017]. 2 more suspected cases are being followed.\n\nToronto Public Health is investigating a mumps outbreak in the city. There were 43 confirmed cases by [15 Mar 2017].\n\nWright said people should check their immunization records to ensure they've received 2 mumps vaccines, which is needed for optimal protection. The 1st dose is given around the 1st birthday, and the 2nd between 4 and 6. Some people only received 1 dose as a child. They can get a 2nd dose now.\n\nThose most affected by the recent spike in mumps activity are people 17-35 years old. It's thought the longer the time from the 2nd dose, the more susceptible a person may be.\n\n'We do see some waning effect, especially as you get older,' Wright said.\n\nThe virus is spread through droplets and requires close contact. That can include sharing drinks, kissing, and coughing or sneezing within one metre.\n\n'It tends to be a very social age group,' Wright said. 'That might contribute to spread among that age group.'\n\nSymptoms include fever, headache, and swelling in the salivary glands, Wright said. 'There are a lot of people who just have respiratory symptoms.'\n\nComplications such as meningitis are possible but rare, and most people are better in about a week.\n\nMumps activity goes in cycles and, fortunately, large outbreaks are rare because of high immunization rates, Wright said. Last year [2016], there was one case in the region. 'And in other years we have none at all,' she said.\n\nThe virus has a long incubation period, upwards of 25 days before symptoms appear. 'You can be contagious but not show any symptoms,' said Chuck Ferguson, spokesperson for the Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health.\n\nHe said the department is watching to see if anyone in contact with the current cases develops mumps to know if it's spreading in the community and who is at risk.\n\n[Byline: Johanna Weidner]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be accessed at http://mapsof.net/uploads/static-maps/Canada_Provinces_and_territories_map.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/260. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Illinois)\nDate: Wed 22 Mar 2017 5:15 AM CDT\nSource: Daily Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.dailyherald.com/article/20170322/news/170329654/\n\n\nStation Middle School [Barrington, Cook and Lake counties, Illinois] now has 3 confirmed cases of the mumps, making it the 2nd Barrington Area Unit School District 220 school to have an outbreak of the disease, district officials said [Tue 21 Mar 2017]. At Barrington High, the number of confirmed mumps cases increased to 6, and Superintendent Brian Harris said it could eventually go to as high as 10.\n\n'I wouldn't be surprised,' said Harris at the board of education meeting at Barrington High Tuesday night [21 Mar 2017]. '10 reported cases out of approximately 3500 people who are in and out of this building every day is still well below the public health information that talks about the effectiveness of vaccines.'\n\nAccording to the CDC, the mumps component of the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine is about 88 percent effective when a person gets 2 doses.\n\n'I do believe our school community has responded appropriately and diligently in all regards,' Harris said. 'I do believe that is part of the reason why we've seen so many reporting, I think parents and students are following up as we asked.'\n\nThe Lake County Health Department updates their website [http://lakecountyil.gov/3875/Mumps] daily with the latest number of confirmed, probable, and suspected mumps cases.\n\nOn 13 Mar 2017, the health department held a vaccination clinic for Barrington High School staff and students who were not up to date with their MMR vaccinations. Harris said 85 staff members took advantage of the opportunity. He said students likely didn't take advantage because more than 99 percent of them have received 2 MMR vaccines already. Adults born after 1957 and before 1989 were only required to get 1 MMR vaccine, so Harris said the staff members used the clinic to get a 2nd dose.\n\nHarris said there will be a similar clinic offered to staff and students and Station Middle School in the coming weeks.\n\nWhen new confirmed cases trickle in, it means the district's small number of students who are unvaccinated for religious or medical reasons have to spend more and more time away from the student population. The district has been helping those students continue their education from home in a variety of ways, including having access to coursework through their school-issued laptops. Harris said they are also inviting the students to come in and receive one-on-one instruction after school for things like tests and time learning in the lab.\n\nThe schools are thoroughly cleaned each night to health department specifications.\n\nMumps is a serious contagious disease. Common symptoms are fever, headache, and muscle aches, though up to half of people who get it have mild or no symptoms.\n\n[Byline: Doug T Graham]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Illinois can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/23024. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/illinois-county-map.gif. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Arkansas outbreak analysis\nDate: Wed 22 Mar 2017\nSource: NPR (National Public Radio) Shots [edited]\nhttp://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/22/520842043/social-media-math-and-the-mystery-of-a-mumps-outbreak\n\n\nIn August 2016, an outbreak of mumps began in Arkansas. Since then, there have been nearly 3000 cases of the disease across 33 counties in the state.\n\nAs a public health practitioner, I wondered: Why did this outbreak take off?\n\nMy team at HealthMap, a computational epidemiology lab based out of Boston Children's Hospital, began by rounding up as much data as we could.\n\nWe quickly discovered that the Arkansas Department of Health was releasing semi-regular PDF reports on the outbreak. The reports broke down cases by county, age, and school district (many of the people who have contracted mumps in the Arkansas outbreak are children). But there were no historical archives that could give us a sense of how the outbreak had grown over time.\n\nSo we turned to a tool called the HealthMap Digital Surveillance System, which collects social media reports and news about public health issues around the world and turns them into usable epidemiological data. (For example, this blog previously reported on how we used our surveillance system to collect Google search and participatory public health data to track and predict flu outbreaks.)\n\nFrom the HealthMap data about the mumps outbreak, we were able to estimate the total number of cases that had occurred since August 2016.\n\nAt that point, we had all the information we needed to tackle a more difficult question: What could the data tell us about vaccination in communities affected by the outbreak?\n\nBefore we get to our answer to that question, let's talk about mumps.\n\nMumps, like measles and rubella, is extremely contagious. Because of this, the measles-mumps-rubella, or MMR, vaccine is given in 2 doses. Even with both doses, the vaccine is imperfect. One out of every 10 individuals who receives it remains susceptible to the mumps virus. In the event of a mumps outbreak, some people who get sick will be people who were vaccinated; how many depends on what percentage of the people in the affected community are vaccinated.\n\nFor a disease as contagious as mumps, a 2-dose community-level vaccination rate as high as 96 percent may be necessary to prevent active transmission of the virus, maintaining so-called herd immunity. When the vaccination rate drops, herd immunity breaks down and outbreaks can take off.\n\nThe Arkansas Department of Health doesn't generally report high-resolution vaccination statistics to the public. But it has been collecting self-reported data on vaccination from individuals who were diagnosed with mumps during this particular outbreak. In the department's latest report, an average of about 70 percent of people who got mumps said they had received both doses of the mumps vaccine.\n\nHowever, studies have shown that self-reported vaccination rates are typically 1.5 to 2 times greater than actual vaccination rates. This means that the true 2-dose vaccination rate among mumps cases in Arkansas was probably closer to 35-46 percent.\n\nBut what about vaccination rates in the larger communities that these cases came from?\n\nAfter pairing our surveillance data with mathematical modeling methods, we estimated that the average 2-dose vaccination rate in communities affected by the outbreak was likely no higher than 89 percent and may have been as low as 70 percent, well below that ideal rate of 96 percent.\n\nOur complete methodology can be found in a study published in The Lancet Infectious Diseases [see citation below].\n\nAs vaccine hesitancy gains ground in the United States, we place ourselves at risk for vaccine-preventable diseases like measles, mumps, and rubella. While these childhood illnesses aren't fatal to most people, those who are most susceptible to serious adverse effects, such as children under the age of 1 and cancer patients, are often those who can't be vaccinated.\n\nAnd this is why herd immunity is so important. When we vaccinate, we protect not only ourselves but the most vulnerable members of our communities, too.\n\n[Byline: Maimuna Majumder]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Reference\n--------\nMajumder MS, Nguyen CM, Cohn EL et al: Vaccine compliance and the 2016 Arkansas mumps outbreak. Lancet Infect Dis. 2017; 17(4): 361-362; http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S1473-3099(17)30122-6.\n\nThis study reinforces the public health importance of vaccination. Mumps not only has the problem of lack of or incomplete vaccination series, but also waning immunity with age.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/208. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Illinois can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/23024. \n\nWright said people should check their immunization records to ensure they've received 2 mumps vaccines, which is needed for optimal protection. http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20170322/news/170329654/\n\n\nStation Middle School [Barrington, Cook and Lake counties, Illinois] now has 3 confirmed cases of the mumps, making it the 2nd Barrington Area Unit School District 220 school to have an outbreak of the disease, district officials said [Tue 21 Mar 2017]. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be accessed at http://mapsof.net/uploads/static-maps/Canada_Provinces_and_territories_map.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/260. - Mod. \n\nFrom the HealthMap data about the mumps outbreak, we were able to estimate the total number of cases that had occurred since August 2016. \n\nThe Lake County Health Department updates their website [http://lakecountyil.gov/3875/Mumps] daily with the latest number of confirmed, probable, and suspected mumps cases. \n\nMumps activity goes in cycles and, fortunately, large outbreaks are rare because of high immunization rates, Wright said. In the department's latest report, an average of about 70 percent of people who got mumps said they had received both doses of the mumps vaccine. After pairing our surveillance data with mathematical modeling methods, we estimated that the average 2-dose vaccination rate in communities affected by the outbreak was likely no higher than 89 percent and may have been as low as 70 percent, well below that ideal rate of 96 percent. \n\nAs vaccine hesitancy gains ground in the United States, we place ourselves at risk for vaccine-preventable diseases like measles, mumps, and rubella. \n\nIn Guelph, there are 3 confirmed cases among university aged people linked to a keg party held in mid-January [2017]. \n\nThose most affected by the recent spike in mumps activity are people 17-35 years old. \n\nToronto Public Health is investigating a mumps outbreak in the city. \n\nWhen new confirmed cases trickle in, it means the district's small number of students who are unvaccinated for religious or medical reasons have to spend more and more time away from the student population. [3] USA (Arkansas) outbreak analysis\n\n******\n For a disease as contagious as mumps, a 2-dose community-level vaccination rate as high as 96 percent may be necessary to prevent active transmission of the virus, maintaining so-called herd immunity. \n\nAt that point, we had all the information we needed to tackle a more difficult question: What could the data tell us about vaccination in communities affected by the outbreak? In the event of a mumps outbreak, some people who get sick will be people who were vaccinated; how many depends on what percentage of the people in the affected community are vaccinated. \n\n'I wouldn't be surprised,' said Harris at the board of education meeting at Barrington High Tuesday night [21 Mar 2017]. ' \n\nHarris said there will be a similar clinic offered to staff and students and Station Middle School in the coming weeks. \n\nMumps, like measles and rubella, is extremely contagious. According to the CDC, the mumps component of the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine is about 88 percent effective when a person gets 2 doses. The reports broke down cases by county, age, and school district (many of the people who have contracted mumps in the Arkansas outbreak are children). MUMPS UPDATE (12): CANADA (ONTARIO), USA (ILLINOIS, ARKANSAS)\n*************************************************************\n This means that the true 2-dose vaccination rate among mumps cases in Arkansas was probably closer to 35-46 percent. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Reference\n-------- [Byline: Johanna Weidner]\n\n--\n [Byline: Doug T Graham]\n\n--\n [Byline: Maimuna Majumder]\n\n--\n \n\n'I do believe our school community has responded appropriately and diligently in all regards,' Harris said. \n\nMumps is a serious contagious disease. \n\nSymptoms include fever, headache, and swelling in the salivary glands, Wright said. ' \n\nWe quickly discovered that the Arkansas Department of Health was releasing semi-regular PDF reports on the outbreak. At Barrington High, the number of confirmed mumps cases increased to 6, and Superintendent Brian Harris said it could eventually go to as high as 10. LK]\n\n******\n LK]\n\n******\n \nMajumder MS, Nguyen CM, Cohn EL et al: Vaccine compliance and the 2016 Arkansas mumps outbreak. \n\nBefore we get to our answer to that question, let's talk about mumps. So far this year [2017], 3 confirmed cases of mumps have been reported in Waterloo Region, mirroring a widespread bump in the virus's activity.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2016-08-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "1989-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Barrington High", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Waterloo Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4935375", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (14): Australia (QL), USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4935375", "date": "2017-03-30 11:52:03", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (14): AUSTRALIA (QUEENSLAND), USA\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Australia (North West Queensland and Gulf)\n[2] USA (Texas, Dallas County)\n[3] USA (Kansas, Ellis County)\n[4] USA (California, Orange County)\n[5] USA (Louisiana)\n\n******\n[1] Australia (North West Queensland and Gulf)\nDate: Fri 24 Mar 2017 2:17 PM AEST\nSource: The North West Star [edited]\nhttp://www.northweststar.com.au/story/4553415/mumps-outbreak-in-the-north/\n\n\nA mumps virus outbreak in North West Queensland and Gulf country has prompted calls for residents to check their MMR (measles/mumps/rubella) vaccine status.\n\nSo far this year [2017], 20 lab-confirmed cases of mumps have been recorded in the region, most of whom are indigenous.\n\nMount Isa Public Health Unit Director Dr Steven Donohue said some of the cases are linked to a similar outbreak in the Northern Territory, where about 130 people have acquired the infection since July 2015.\n\n'Several patients in the North West outbreak have been fully immunised so we suspect factors such as overcrowding and waning immunity may play a role,' Dr Donohue said.\n\nDr Donohue said all local clinics and communities have been urged to offer free extra doses of the MMR vaccine to people born after 1965 who did not have at least 2 documented [doses] on their immunisation records. 'People who are in close contact with the patients of the outbreak should get a 3rd dose,' he said.\n\nPrior to this year [2017], just one case of mumps had been recorded by the North West Hospital and Health Service since 2012.\n\nMumps usually causes swelling of parotid salivary glands under the angle of the jaw. Other symptoms include fever, headache and tiredness.\n\nIn severe cases, the disease can affect the testicles in males or the lining of the brain (meningitis).\n\nIt spreads easily through sneezing and coughing.\n\nDr Donohue said immunisation was the most effective counter-measure. 'Mumps is a virus so antibiotics do not work,' he said. 'If given before exposure, vaccination will prevent the disease in the majority of people.'\n\nMMR vaccine is routinely given at 12 and 18 months, but catch-up boosters can be given anytime.\n\nHowever the live, weakened vaccine cannot be given to pregnant women, young babies, or people with immune problems.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/24533. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Texas, Dallas County)\nDate: Sat 25 Mar 2017\nSource: Focus Daily News (FDN) [edited]\nhttp://www.focusdailynews.com/2017/03/25/cedar-hill-isd-continues-mumps-outbreak-dallas-county/\n\n\nThis week Dallas County health officials announced another increase in the number of mumps cases at Cedar Hill High School. According to DCHHS [Dallas County Health & Human Services], since the initial outbreak on [9 Feb 2017], there have been 49 cases reported between students and teachers.\n\nThat is a drastic increase since the last reported update of 28 cases, as students prepared for the Spring Break holiday [13-17 Mar 2017].\n\nCedar Hill Independent School District [CHISD] borders Ellis County as well, County Spokesperson Renae Crutchfield, did note not all cases are Dallas County residents.\n\nTo date, there have been 63 mumps cases in Dallas County. DCHHS has also identified 14 unrelated mumps cases in Mesquite, Dallas, and neighboring DeSoto [Dallas County].\n\nCedar Hill ISD Director of Communication Jamie Brown urges calm. He says that the statement from the county health department could easily confuse Cedar Hill residents.\n\n'The number Dallas County is reporting represents the total number of cases since [9 Feb 2017]. As of yesterday [24 Mar 2017], all of the teachers and students who were confirmed by the county have returned to class,' explains Brown. 'We do have some who are absent and are still waiting confirmation from the County.'\n\nAlthough the statistics are finally leaning in a positive direction for CHISD, Brown assures parents that the district has not relented in its efforts to combat the illness.\n\n'We are continuing to be vigilant with cleaning and communicating to students about the importance of hand-washing and proper hygiene,' said Brown. Strict cleaning efforts have been in place since [9 Feb 2017], when the district was first informed of the outbreak from DCHHS. 'We had our cleaning staff do an extensive cleaning of the campus that night,' said Brown. Furthermore, additional janitorial staff members came in over the weekend to deep clean in an effort to stop the spread of the disease.\n\nSince the mumps onslaught the district and DCHHS have partnered to host a number of clinics on the high school campus.\n\n'Actually we are playing host and Dallas County is providing the vaccines.'\n\nThe Centers For Disease Control recommends a 3rd dose, only when an individual has exposure to an ongoing outbreak.\n\n'Since February [2017], we have hosted 3 booster shot clinics at the high school. 2 additional for students who come from the Ninth Grade Center to attend classes or activities,' said Brown.\n\nDCHHS Health officials are urging immunization to protect against and prevent the spread of mumps. People with 2 rounds of mumps vaccinations (such as 2 MMR vaccines) are usually immune from mumps.\n\n'At 2 doses, the MMR vaccine has 88 percent effectiveness,' said Dr Christopher Perkins, Dallas County medical director. 'Getting vaccinated is the best option for protection in addition to washing hands frequently and cleaning/disinfecting objects or surfaces that may be contaminated with germs.'\n\nCurrently Cedar Hill officials are awaiting confirmation from DCHHS on a 3rd round of vaccinations at the Ninth Grade Center.\n\nMumps is a highly contagious viral disease that spreads by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks. Items used by a person suffering from the mumps, such as cups or soft drink cans, could carry the virus, which may spread to others.\n\nMumps patients often show symptoms of fever, headache, and swelling of the salivary glands, fatigue, muscle aches, and loss of appetite. Symptoms usually appear 16-18 days after infection, but this period can range from 12-25 days after infection.\n\n[Byline: Joshua C. Johnson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/58803. Dallas County in northeast Texas can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/texas-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] USA (Kansas, Ellis County)\nDate: Sun 26 Mar 2017\nSource: The Hays Daily News [edited]\nhttp://www.hdnews.net/news/officials-monitoring-kansas-mumps-outbreak/article_6e2f297a-968a-556a-b7cc-493668218e80.html\n\n\nLocal health officials are continuing to monitor a statewide mumps outbreak that so far has resulted in 13 suspected cases of the illness in Ellis County. Only 2 of those individuals have tested positive, said Kerry McCue, Ellis County health services administrator.\n\nBoth of those individuals are 'well past' the contagious period, he said.\n\nWhen a positive mumps case is identified, the Kansas Department of Health and Environment requires a 5-day quarantine.\n\nResidents are encouraged to make sure they are vaccinated and might have the option of a 'booster shot' as a precaution. There is not yet a recommended time when someone should get a booster, but that could change if the outbreak continues, McCue said.\n\n'I would assume that with the number of cases that have spread out across the nation, I imagine we'll all be recommended from the CDC to eventually get our 3rd one,' he said. 'There is not a specific time frame.'\n\nThere have been at least 79 confirmed mumps cases statewide, according to the most recent data available from KDHE [Kansas Department of Health and Environment].\n\nThe vaccine is not 100-percent effective, but those who get it are considered 9 times less likely to acquire the virus, he said. 'And if they do get it, it won't be as severe,' McCue said.\n\nThere are some exceptions: People who were born before 1957 are considered immune, as they likely already had the virus.\n\n2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) vaccine typically are recommended for children, 1 dose at between 12 and 15 months, and another between 4 and 6 years of age. Young children are not considered fully vaccinated until they receive the 2nd dose, but they do have some protection, said Kimberly Koerner, infection prevention officer at Hays Medical Center.\n\n'That's why we encourage anybody who can be vaccinated to be vaccinated, because they do help increase the coverage for everybody else in the community,' Koerner said. 'If we have a community that does practice preventative care by getting a vaccine, that helps cover those that aren't fully vaccinated or can't be fully vaccinated.'\n\nVaccines are available at the Ellis County Health Department or through primary care physician clinics.\n\nThough the exact source of the outbreak isn't yet clear, KDHE has linked possible exposure to wrestling and basketball events, Kansas State University and the University of Kansas, and travel to other states, according to the agency's website.\n\nThe most telling symptom is often pain and swelling in the glands below the jaw line. Other -- and often earlier -- symptoms include fever, headache, muscle aches, and fatigue, Koerner said. The virus has a lengthy incubation period, with symptoms typically showing 12-25 days after exposure.\n\nIf anyone suspects they might have the virus, they are encouraged to seek prompt medical attention. Patients, however, should call ahead to notify the medical clinic of their condition so steps can be taken to avoid exposing others, Koerner said.\n\nIn otherwise healthy patients, the illness doesn't usually lead to severe complications, she said.\n\n'It actually used to be very common,' she said. 'It's become highly uncommon since more people are being vaccinated.'\n\nOther preventive measures include practicing good personal hygiene and frequent handwashing. The airborne virus is carried through coughing, sneezing, talking or sharing eating utensils with others.\n\n'The number one way to stop the spread of germs is covering your cough and washing your hands,' Koerner said. 'We always ask people to do that, all the time. And avoid close contact with people when they're sick.'\n\n[Byline: Kaley Conner]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Kansas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8703. Ellis County in central Kansas can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/kansas-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[4] USA (California, Orange County)\nDate: Tue 28 Mar 2017\nSource: My News LA, City News Service report [edited]\nhttp://mynewsla.com/orange-county/2017/03/28/mumps-outbreak-at-least-7-chapman-university-students-sick/\n\n\nOrange County health officials said [Tue 28 Mar 2017, that] 4 Chapman University students have contracted mumps and 3 others also appear to have the illness. A half-dozen of the affected students are in Chapman's law school, and one is an undergraduate, according to the Orange County Health Care Agency [HCA].\n\nThe outbreak at the Christian Church-affiliated university in the city of Orange appears to have started [26 Jan 2017], with symptoms showing in one case as recently as last [Thu 23 Mar 2017], the HCA reported.\n\nThe outbreak correlates with other eruptions in mumps cases at college campuses around the country over the past several years.\n\nMost of the affected students were fully vaccinated, which is consistent with other college outbreaks nationally, according to the HCA's Jessica Good. Getting vaccinated lowers the risk of mumps substantially, but doesn't eliminate it, she said.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that the 2 doses of MMR recommended by doctors -- one at 12-15 months and a 2nd at 4-6 years old -- prevents mumps 88 percent of the time, according to the agency.\n\nThe 'most characteristic symptom' of mumps is 'parotid swelling,' according to the agency. 'Parotitis can initially manifest as earache and tenderness on palpation of the angle of the jaw.'\n\nOther symptoms include muscle ache, loss of appetite, malaise, headache or fever.\n\n[Byline: Jackie Fernandez]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/49257. Orange County in southern California can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/california-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[5] USA (Louisiana)\nDate: Wed 29 Mar 2017 12:12 AM CEDT\nSource: WAFB [edited]\nhttp://www.wafb.com/story/35016956/mumps-outbreak-at-lsu-now-up-to-20-cases\n\n\nLouisiana is in the midst of a small mumps outbreak. At the heart of that outbreak is the campus of LSU [Louisiana State University]. The 1st cases were reported by the Louisiana Department of Health around [16 Mar 2017], following a major outbreak in Arkansas.\n\nThe challenge, per assistant state health officer, Dr Parham Jaberi, is that someone infected with the mumps virus may not show symptoms for up to 3 weeks. 'It becomes a challenge because once we identify the problem through public health, we're playing catch up,' said Dr Jaberi.\n\nSymptoms of the mumps include fever, aches, fatigue, loss of appetite, and swollen salivary glands. The virus itself is not usually a serious illness and most people recover on their own. However, it is extremely contagious, leaving crowded areas like a college campus at high risk for infection.\n\n'Often times, it's spread through kissing, sharing of utensils, personal items, and in concentrated areas where people live close together,' said Jaberi.\n\nThe university has reported about 20 cases of mumps so far. Jaberi said there's been a handful of cases in other areas of the state as well. Doctors say a vaccine is the best way to prevent the mumps, but for the vaccine to be most effective, 2 doses are needed. Even then, it's not a guarantee. The Louisiana Department of Health says most of the current cases involve patients who were vaccinated.\n\nLSU requires immunizations for new students and recently offered booster shots in coordination with the health department and the CDC. Some preventative tips include:\n- stay at home for 5 days after symptoms begin; avoid school or work settings;\n- cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when you cough or sneeze;\n- don't share eating utensils, cups, drinking glasses, or water bottles;\n- clean surfaces that are frequently touched, such as computer devices, television remotes, doorknobs, tables, and counters, regularly with soap and water or with disinfecting wipes;\n- wash your hands frequently with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand cleaner\n\n[Byline: Elizabeth Vowell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Louisiana can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/221. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "Some preventative tips include:\n- stay at home for 5 days after symptoms begin; avoid school or work settings;\n- cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when you cough or sneeze;\n- don't share eating utensils, cups, drinking glasses, or water bottles;\n- clean surfaces that are frequently touched, such as computer devices, television remotes, doorknobs, tables, and counters, regularly with soap and water or with disinfecting wipes;\n- wash your hands frequently with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand cleaner\n\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/58803. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Kansas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8703. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/49257. AEST\nSource: The North West Star [edited]\nhttp://www.northweststar.com.au/story/4553415/mumps-outbreak-in-the-north/\n\n\nA mumps virus outbreak in North West Queensland and Gulf country has prompted calls for residents to check their MMR (measles/mumps/rubella) vaccine status. \n\n[Byline: Kaley Conner]\n\n--\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/24533. \n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that the 2 doses of MMR recommended by doctors -- one at 12-15 months and a 2nd at 4-6 years old -- prevents mumps 88 percent of the time, according to the agency. ' Source: Focus Daily News (FDN) [edited]\nhttp://www.focusdailynews.com/2017/03/25/cedar-hill-isd-continues-mumps-outbreak-dallas-county/\n\n\nThis week Dallas County health officials announced another increase in the number of mumps cases at Cedar Hill High School. \n\nMumps is a highly contagious viral disease that spreads by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks. \n\n'Often times, it's spread through kissing, sharing of utensils, personal items, and in concentrated areas where people live close together,' said Jaberi. \n\n'Several patients in the North West outbreak have been fully immunised so we suspect factors such as overcrowding and waning immunity may play a role,' Dr Donohue said. \n\n--\n [Byline: Joshua C. Johnson]\n\n--\n [Byline: Jackie Fernandez]\n\n--\n [Byline: Elizabeth Vowell]\n\n--\n MUMPS UPDATE (14): AUSTRALIA (QUEENSLAND), USA\n**********************************************\n \n\n'The number Dallas County is reporting represents the total number of cases since [9 Feb 2017]. \n\nThe university has reported about 20 cases of mumps so far. \n\n'We are continuing to be vigilant with cleaning and communicating to students about the importance of hand-washing and proper hygiene,' said Brown. [5] USA (Louisiana)\n\n******\n \n\n'The number one way to stop the spread of germs is covering your cough and washing your hands,' Koerner said. ' \n\nSince the mumps onslaught the district and DCHHS have partnered to host a number of clinics on the high school campus. \n\nWhen a positive mumps case is identified, the Kansas Department of Health and Environment requires a 5-day quarantine. \n\nDCHHS Health officials are urging immunization to protect against and prevent the spread of mumps. LK]\n\n******\n MJ]\n\n******\n MJ]\n\n******\n MJ]\n\n******\n \n\nMumps usually causes swelling of parotid salivary glands under the angle of the jaw. \n\nMost of the affected students were fully vaccinated, which is consistent with other college outbreaks nationally, according to the HCA's Jessica Good. \n\n'Since February [2017], we have hosted 3 booster shot clinics at the high school. \n\nBoth of those individuals are 'well past' the contagious period, he said. \n\nDr Donohue said immunisation was the most effective counter-measure. ' \n\nOther symptoms include muscle ache, loss of appetite, malaise, headache or fever. \n\nSymptoms of the mumps \n\nThe Centers For Disease Control recommends a 3rd dose, only when an individual has exposure to an ongoing outbreak. \n\nMMR vaccine is routinely given at 12 and 18 months, but catch-up boosters can be given anytime. \n\nLSU requires immunizations for new students and recently offered booster shots in coordination with the health department and the CDC. \n\nThere are some exceptions: People who were born before 1957 are considered immune, as they likely already had the virus.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2015-07-25 00:00:00", "1965-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-01-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dallas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4924853", "date": "2017-03-26 09:02:57", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (13): PORTUGAL, CANADA, USA, ANALYSIS\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Portugal (Porto)\n[2] Canada (Ontario, Waterloo region)\n[3] Canada (Ontario,Toronto)\n[4] USA (Illinois)\n[5] USA (Kansas)\n[6] USA (Washington, Seattle)\n[7] Analysis: USA (Arkansas) outbreak\n\n******\n[1] Portugal [Porto]\nDate: Sat 25 Mar 2017\nFrom: Andre Santos-Silva <punkwolfe@gmail.com>\n\n\nMumps, human, Porto, Portugal\n--------------------\nAt least four cases of mumps have been confirmed during the last week, and another is being investigated, in a small outbreak among university students aged 19-22, in Porto, Portugal. All patients had two doses of MMR vaccine.\n\nOngoing investigation seems to point to the index case being a toddler (age not specified) who is brother to one of the cases.\nIt is possible that more cases are still to appear, since the incubation period may go up to three weeks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAndre Santos-Silva\nCentro Hospitalar de S\u00e3o Jo\u00e3o\nPorto, Portugal\n<punkwolfe@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank Dr. Santos-Silvia for sharing this information with us.\n\nMumps immunity, even following the complete series of 2 doses, may wane with time, and infection may occur especially with prolonged contact, as with a sibling in this case. However, having been fully vaccinated does partially protect preventing severe complications occasionally seen with unvaccinated individuals. \n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED map of Porto, Portugal can be found at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8596 - Mod.LK]  \n\n******\n[2] Canada (Ontario, Waterloo region)\nDate: Mon 20 Mar 2017\nSource: The Record [edited]\nhttp://www.therecord.com/news-story/7200186-small-increase-in-mumps-cases-in-waterloo-region/\n\n\nA total of 3 confirmed cases of the mumps have been reported in Waterloo Region (Ontario province) so far this year [2017], mirroring a widespread bump in the virus's activity.\n\n'It's definitely something people should be aware of, but the risk is pretty low because most of our population is immunized,' said Kristy Wright, manager of infectious diseases for Region of Waterloo Public Health. 'There's no need to panic. We're quite used to having this cyclical activity with mumps.' There's been increased mumps activity across Ontario, as well as Canada and the United States.\n'It is circulating. There is sporadic activity,' Wright said.\n\nIn Guelph, there are 3 confirmed cases among university aged people linked to a keg party held in mid-January [2017]. Two more suspected cases are being followed.\n\nToronto Public Health is investigating a mumps outbreak in the city. There were 43 confirmed cases by [Wed 15 Mar2017].\n\nWright said people should check their immunization records to ensure they've received 2 mumps vaccines, which is needed for optimal protection. The 1st dose is given around the 1st birthday, and the 2nd between 4 and 6. Some people only received 1 dose as a child. They can get a 2nd dose now.\n\nThose most affected by the recent spike in mumps activity are people 17 -- 35 years old. It's thought the longer the time from the 2nd dose, the more susceptible a person may be.\n\n'We do see some waning effect, especially as you get older,' Wright said.\n\nThe virus is spread through droplets and requires close contact. That can include sharing drinks, kissing, and coughing or sneezing within 1 meter.\n\n'It tends to be a very social age group,' Wright said. 'That might contribute to spread among that age group.'\n\nSymptoms include fever, headache, and swelling in the salivary glands, Wright said. 'There are a lot of people who just have respiratory symptoms.'\n\nComplications such as meningitis are possible but rare, and most people are better in about a week.\n\nMumps activity goes in cycles and, fortunately, large outbreaks are rare because of high immunization rates, Wright said. Last year [2016], there was one case in the region. 'And in other years we have none at all,' she said.\n\nThe virus has a long incubation period, upwards of 25 days before symptoms appear.\n\n'You can be contagious but not show any symptoms,' said Chuck Ferguson, spokesperson for the Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health. He said the department is watching to see if anyone in contact with the current cases develops mumps to know if it's spreading in the community and who is at risk.\n\n[Byline: Johanna Weidner]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap showing the location of Ontario Province, Canada, can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/260]\n\n******\n[3] Canada (Ontario, Toronto)\nDate: Thu 23 Mar 2017 3:18PM EDT\nSource: CTV News Toronto [edited]\nhttp://toronto.ctvnews.ca/mumps-outbreak-in-toronto-grows-to-62-cases-1.3338044\n\n\nAn outbreak of the mumps is continuing to spread in the city of Toronto as the number of confirmed cases has grown to 62.\n\nIn a news release issued [Thu 23 Mar 2017], Toronto Public Health said that most of the cases are among people between the ages of 18 and 35 years old. As well, 5 of these cases have been linked to elementary and high schools in Toronto, either among staff or students.\n\n'All of the cases related to Toronto school settings acquired the mumps from close contact with a known individual who already had the mumps and not from the school setting,' Toronto Public Health said in the news release.\n\nRyerson University confirmed 2 cases of the mumps on campus earlier this week [week of 19 March 2017]. The other schools affected include King Edward Public School, Hodgson Senior Public School and Forest Hill Collegiate.\n\nToronto Public Health said the initial outbreak began in February [2017] when the number of cases hovered around 14, but that number has grown ever since. Originally, the outbreak was linked to bars and restaurants in the city's west-end, particularly between Queen Street and King Street from Spadina Avenue to Dufferin Street.\n\nIn Thursday's news release, Toronto Public Health said that broader community spread of the mumps is now occurring in Toronto.\n\nThe mumps is a viral infection which is typically found in saliva and respiratory droplets. It is spread through coughing, sneezing and coming into contact with a person's saliva by sharing drinks or utensils, food or water bottles, or by kissing.\n\nFurthermore, a major factor contributing to outbreaks of this infection is being in a crowded environment or being in close quarters consistently with a person who has the mumps.\n\nSymptoms for the virus include fever, swelling of one or more salivary glands, loss of appetite, tiredness, and headache.\n\nIn more severe cases, mumps can produce an infection in the brain, painful swelling of the testicles or ovaries, pancreatitis or hearing loss.\n\nToronto Public Health is urging residents of the city to call their doctor to ensure they are properly immunized. Those born between 1970 and 1992, in particular, should check their records as they may have only received 1 of the 2 necessary doses as a child.\n\n[Byline: Kayla Goodfield]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] USA (Illinois)\nDate: Wed 22 Mar 2017 5:15 AM\nSource: Daily Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.dailyherald.com/article/20170322/news/170329654/\n\n\nStation Middle School now has 3 confirmed cases of the mumps, making it the 2nd Barrington Area Unit School District 220 school to have an outbreak of the disease, district officials said [Tue 21 Mar 2017]. At Barrington High, the number of confirmed mumps cases increased to 6, and Superintendent Brian Harris said it could eventually go to as high as 10.\n\n'I wouldn't be surprised,' said Harris at the board of education meeting at Barrington High [Tue 21 Mar 2017] night. 'Ten reported cases out of approximately 3500 people who are in and out of this building every day is still well below the public health information that talks about the effectiveness of vaccines.'\n\nAccording to the CDC (Centers for disease Control and Prevention), the mumps component of the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine is about 88 percent effective when a person gets 2 doses.\n\nThe district has been getting updates on the slow spread of the disease via daily 3 p.m. conference calls with the Lake County Health Department.\n\n'I do believe our school community has responded appropriately and diligently in all regards,' Harris said. 'I do believe that is part of the reason why we've seen so many reporting, I think parents and students are following up as we asked.'\n\nThe Lake County Health Department updates their website daily with the latest number of confirmed, probable and suspected mumps cases.\n\nOn [Mon 13 Mar 2017], the health department held a vaccination clinic for Barrington High School staff and students who were not up to date with their MMR vaccinations. Harris said 85 staff members took advantage of the opportunity. He said students likely didn't take advantage because more than 99 percent of them have received 2 MMR vaccines already. Adults born after 1957 and before 1989 were only required to get one MMR vaccine, so Harris said the staff members used the clinic to get a 2nd dose.\n\nHarris said there will be a similar clinic offered to staff and students and Station Middle School in the coming weeks.\n\nWhen new confirmed cases trickle in, it means the districts small number of students who are unvaccinated for religious or medical reasons have to spend more and more time away from the student population. The district has been helping those students continue their education from home in a variety of ways, including having access to coursework through their school-issued laptops. Harris said they are also inviting the students to come in and receive one-on-one instruction after school for things like tests and time learning in the lab. The schools are thoroughly cleaned each night to health department specifications.\n\nMumps is a serious contagious disease. Common symptoms are fever, headache and muscle aches, though up to half of people who get it have mild or no symptoms.\n\n[Byline: Doug T. Graham]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap of the United States showing the location of Illinois, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/216]\n\n******\n[5] USA (Kansas)\nDate: Wed 22 Mar 2017 11:45 am\nSource: The Marysville Advocate [edited]\nhttp://www.marysvilleonline.net/news/article_b4fdb5b0-0f1c-11e7-bfeb-9f0c3389d848.html\n\n\nThe number of mumps cases confirmed in Marshall County was at 7 early this week, according to the Marshall County Health Department.\n\nInvestigation of potential cases is ongoing. Last week [week of 12 March] the agency reported 5 cases, and Marysville schools sent home an advisory letter to parents to watch for symptoms and to isolate potential cases. Health officials urge people who think they have symptoms to stay home and to contact a physician.\n\nSymptoms include a few days of fever, headache, muscle ache, fatigue and loss of appetite followed by swollen salivary glands.\n\nKansas Department of Health and Environment issued a [Thu 9 Mar 2017] letter to the Kansas USA Wrestling organization, which is a community of youth wrestling events, to notify them that mumps transmission has been documented at several wrestling tournaments in Kansas.\n\nKDHE 'has not identified all of the sources of these mumps infections,' the letter says. 'This means that additional, yet-to-be-identified kids or adults may still spread the disease at other wrestling events.'\n\nPeople who suspect they have mumps should stay home from work, school and any social or athletic activities including wresting tournaments and practices, health officials said in the letter.\n\nMumps outbreaks have been documented in several Kansas counties this winter. Some surrounding states have also had a number of cases, according to KDHE.\n\nMumps is caused by a virus and spreads through close contact with an infected person. Mumps can occasionally cause complications, including inflammation of the testicles or ovaries, meningitis, encephalitis and deafness. Most people with mumps recover completely in a few weeks.\n\nIn addition to staying isolated when a person has mumps, the spread of virus can be prevented by:\n- Washing hands often with soap and water.\n- Covering mouth and nose with a tissue when coughing or sneezing, and putting used tissue in the trash can. If no tissue is available, a person can cough or sneeze into the upper sleeve or elbow, not the hands.\n- Avoiding sharing drinks or eating utensils.\n- Disinfecting frequently touched surfaces, such as toys, doorknobs, tables, counters.\n\nAfter the introduction of the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) vaccine, mumps became less common in the United States, KDHE reports. MMR vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease.\n\nSome people who receive 2 doses of MMR can still get mumps, especially when they have prolonged, close contact with someone who has the disease. If a vaccinated person does get mumps, he or she will likely have less severe illness than an unvaccinated person. Therefore the best way to reduce the chance of getting the disease is by being vaccinated with the MMR vaccine.\n\n[Byline: Sarah Kessinger]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap of Kansas, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/219]\n\n******\n[6] USA (Washington, Seattle)\nDate: Thu 23 Mar 2017 7:18 pm\nSource: Seattle Times [edited]\nhttp://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/health/mumps-outbreak-spreads-to-uw-greek-system/\n\n\nWashington's mumps outbreak, the worst this decade, has spread to the fraternities and sororities at the University of Washington.\n\nThose cases were concentrated in the Greek system, according to an email from the UW Advisory Committee on Communicable Diseases, and 'we anticipate the number of cases among UW students will increase more broadly as the outbreak continues in King County and across Washington state.'\n\nThe UW advised those infected, or with symptoms, to stay home.\n\nStatewide, 664 cases of mumps have been reported since October [2016], according to the state Department of Health (DOH). That far surpasses the 53 cases in 2007, the previous high this decade. The last time the state saw such high numbers was 1977, David Johnson of DOH said.\n\nThe mumps virus can cause fever, headache, swelling of the cheeks and jaw, muscle aches and testicular pain and swelling. In rare cases, mumps can lead to more serious complications, such as sterility. Most people recover from mumps in a few weeks.\n\nIt is spread, particularly in crowded environments, through coughing, sneezing, kissing and other close contact, such as sharing food, drinks and cigarettes.\n\nColleges have been hot spots for mumps outbreaks in recent years, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).\n\nHealth officials say getting vaccinated is the best defense against mumps.\n\nThe recommended dose of the MMR vaccine, which protects against measles, mumps and rubella, varies by age. For children ages 1 to 5, it's 1 dose, Johnson said. The same goes for adults 20 to 59 years old. For those 5 to 19 years old, 2 doses are recommended.\n\nMost people born before 1957, when mumps was more widespread, probably were infected and have natural immunity.\n\n[Byline: Bob Young]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[7] Analysis: USA (Arkansas) outbreak\nDate: Wed 22 Mar 2017 7:35 PM ET\nSource: NPR Shots [edited]\nhttp://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/22/520842043/social-media-math-and-the-mystery-of-a-mumps-outbreak\n\n\nIn August 2016, an outbreak of mumps began in Arkansas. Since then, there have been nearly 3000 cases of the disease across 33 counties in the state.\n\nAs a public health practitioner, I wondered: Why did this outbreak take off?\n\nMy team at HealthMap, a computational epidemiology lab based out of Boston Children's Hospital, began by rounding up as much data as we could.\n\nWe quickly discovered that the Arkansas Department of Health was releasing semi-regular PDF reports on the outbreak. The reports broke down cases by county, age and school district (many of the people who have contracted mumps in the Arkansas outbreak are children). But there were no historical archives that could give us a sense of how the outbreak had grown over time.\n\nSo we turned to a tool called the HealthMap Digital Surveillance System, which collects social media reports and news about public health issues around the world and turns them into usable epidemiological data. (For example, this blog previously reported on how we used our surveillance system to collect Google search and participatory public health data to track and predict flu outbreaks.)\n\nFrom the HealthMap data about the mumps outbreak, we were able to estimate the total number of cases that had occurred since August 2016.\n\nAt that point, we had all the information we needed to tackle a more difficult question: What could the data tell us about vaccination in communities affected by the outbreak?\n\nBefore we get to our answer to that question, let's talk about mumps.\n\nMumps, like measles and rubella, is extremely contagious. Because of this, the measles-mumps-rubella, or MMR, vaccine is given in 2 doses. Even with both doses, the vaccine is imperfect. One out of every 10 individuals who receives it remains susceptible to the mumps virus. In the event of a mumps outbreak, some people who get sick will be people who were vaccinated; how many depends on what percentage of the people in the affected community are vaccinated.\n\nFor a disease as contagious as mumps, a two-dose community-level vaccination rate as high as 96 percent may be necessary to prevent active transmission of the virus, maintaining so-called herd immunity. When the vaccination rate drops, herd immunity breaks down and outbreaks can take off.\n\nThe Arkansas Department of Health doesn't generally report high-resolution vaccination statistics to the public. But it has been collecting self-reported data on vaccination from individuals who were diagnosed with mumps during this particular outbreak. In the department's latest report, an average of about 70 percent of people who got mumps said they had received both doses of the mumps vaccine.\n\nHowever, studies have shown that self-reported vaccination rates are typically 1.5 to 2 times greater than actual vaccination rates. This means that the true two-dose vaccination rate among mumps cases in Arkansas was probably closer to 35 percent to 46 percent.\n\nBut what about vaccination rates in the larger communities that these cases came from?\n\nAfter pairing our surveillance data with mathematical modeling methods, we estimated that the average two-dose vaccination rate in communities affected by the outbreak was likely no higher than 89 percent and may have been as low as 70 percent, well below that ideal rate of 96 percent.\n\nOur complete methodology can be found in a study published [Thu 23 Mar 2017] in The Lancet Infectious Diseases (see reference below).\n\nAs vaccine hesitancy gains ground in the United States, we place ourselves at risk for vaccine-preventable diseases like measles, mumps and rubella. While these childhood illnesses aren't fatal to most people, those who are most susceptible to serious adverse effects, such as children under the age of 1 and cancer patients, are often those who can't be vaccinated.\n\nAnd this is why herd immunity is so important. When we vaccinate, we protect not only ourselves but the most vulnerable members of our communities, too.\n\n[Byline: Maimuna Majumder]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See Majumder MS, Nguyen CM, Cohn EL et al. Vaccine compliance and the 2016 Arkansas mumps outbreak. The Lancet Infectious Diseases. 17(4):361-362. April 2017 http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S1473-3099(17)30122-6 for complete study with figures of increase in cases.\nA Healthmap of Arkansas, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/208. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap of the United States showing the location of Illinois, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/216]\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap of Kansas, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/219]\n\n******\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nAndre Santos-Silva\nCentro Hospitalar de S\u00e3o Jo\u00e3o\nPorto, Portugal\n<punkwolfe@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank Dr. Santos-Silvia for sharing this information with us. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\n'All of the cases related to Toronto school settings acquired the mumps from close contact with a known individual who already had the mumps and not from the school setting,' Toronto Public Health said in the news release. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap showing the location of Ontario Province, Canada, can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/260]\n\n******\n This means that additional, activities including wresting tournaments and practices, health officials said in the letter. \n\nToronto Public Health said the initial outbreak began in February [2017] when the number of cases hovered around 14, but that number has grown ever since. http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20170322/news/170329654/\n\n\nStation Middle School now has 3 confirmed cases of the mumps, making it the MUMPS UPDATE (13): PORTUGAL, CANADA, USA, ANALYSIS\n**************************************************\n \n\nAs vaccine hesitancy gains ground in the United States, we place ourselves at risk for vaccine-preventable diseases like measles, mumps and rubella. \n\nIn Guelph, there are 3 confirmed cases among university aged people linked to a keg party held in mid-January [2017]. According to the CDC (Centers for disease Control and Prevention), the mumps component of the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine is about 88 percent effective when a person gets 2 doses. [7] Analysis: USA (Arkansas) outbreak\n\n******\n \n\nThe mumps virus can cause fever, headache, swelling of the cheeks and jaw, muscle aches and testicular pain and swelling. \n\nMumps is caused by a virus and spreads through close contact with an infected person. \n\nMost people born before 1957, when mumps was more widespread, probably were infected and have natural immunity. \n\nWhen new confirmed cases trickle in, it means the districts small number of students who are unvaccinated for religious or medical reasons have to spend more and more time away from the student population. \n\nToronto Public Health is investigating a mumps outbreak in the city. \n\nColleges have been hot spots for mumps outbreaks in recent years, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Graham]\n\n--\n [Byline: Sarah Kessinger]\n\n--\n [Byline: Bob Young]\n\n--\n [Byline: Maimuna Majumder]\n\n--\n \n\nHealth officials say getting vaccinated is the best defense against mumps. \n\nMumps, like measles and rubella, is extremely contagious. In the event of a mumps outbreak, some people who get sick will be people who were vaccinated; how many depends on what percentage of the people in the affected community are vaccinated. \n\nMumps is a serious contagious disease. In this update:\n[1] Portugal (Porto)\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nOngoing investigation seems to point to the index case being a toddler (age not specified) who is brother to one of the cases. \n\nThe district has been getting updates on the slow spread of the disease via daily 3 p.m. conference calls with the Lake County Health Department. \n\nIt is spread, particularly in crowded environments, through coughing, sneezing, kissing and other close contact, such as sharing food, drinks and cigarettes. This means that the true two-dose vaccination rate among mumps cases in Arkansas was probably closer to 35 percent to 46 percent. \n\n'You can be contagious but not show any symptoms,' said Chuck Ferguson, spokesperson for the Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health. For a disease as contagious as mumps, a two-dose community-level vaccination rate as high as 96 percent may be necessary to prevent active transmission of the virus, maintaining so-called herd immunity. He said the department is watching to see if anyone in contact with the current cases develops mumps to know if it's spreading in the community and who is at risk. In a news release issued [Thu 23 Mar 2017], Toronto Public Health said that most of the cases are among people between the ages of 18 and 35 years old. \n\nSymptoms for the virus include fever, swelling of one or more salivary glands, loss of appetite, tiredness, and headache. \n\n'I do believe our school community has responded appropriately and diligently in all regards,' Harris said. The number of mumps cases confirmed in Marshall County was at 7 early this week, according to the Marshall County Health Department. After the introduction of the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) vaccine, mumps became less common in the United States, KDHE reports. From: Andre Santos-Silva <punkwolfe@gmail.com>\n\n\nMumps, human, Porto, Portugal\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-04-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1977-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-10-25 00:00:00", "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country":
