"url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4911532", "date": "2017-03-19 17:02:07", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (11): USA\n**********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Kansas\n[2] Louisiana\n[3] Pennsylvania\n\n******\n[1] Kansas\nDate: Thu 16 Mar 2017\nSource: The Topeka Capital-Journal [edited]\nhttp://cjonline.com/news/local/local-government/2017-03-16/mumps-outbreak-leads-dozens-kansas-cases-none-shawnee-county\n\n\nA nationwide outbreak of mumps included dozens of cases in Kansas, but so far no cases have been reported in Shawnee County.\n\nCarrie Delfs, of the Shawnee County Health Department on Thu 16 Mar 2017 briefed the county health board composed of the 3 county commissioners about the recent outbreak of the disease, which causes fever and swelling of the salivary glands. In 2016, more than 5000 people across the country reported mumps, she said. From 1 Jan through 25 Feb 2017, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported an additional 1077 cases.\n\nIn Kansas, there have been 56 cases reported in 12 counties, Delfs said.\n\nMumps has been most common on college campuses, where the disease is easily spread through coughing, sneezing and talking, said Gianfranco Pezzino, the county's health officer. Lawrence has reported 14 cases, according to statistics shared during the Thu 16 Mar 2017 meeting. Pittsburg reported 8 cases, while Manhattan had 3.\n\nWith few exceptions, including those for religious beliefs, most children are required to have at least 2 doses of the mumps vaccine before kindergarten. A 2-dose regiment is successful at preventing the disease about 88 percent of the time, but Pezzino said it is likely the vaccine begins to wear off by young adulthood.\n\nBefore the mumps vaccination program began in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher because of underreporting, according to the CDC. The 2016/2017 outbreak is the largest since 2006.\n\nSo far, Delfs said, there have been no cases reported in Shawnee County, but the disease can easily be spread in populations that haven't been fully vaccinated.\n\nMumps can't be treated with antibiotics because it is caused by a virus, but most cases clear within 2 weeks. In more extreme cases, mumps may lead to swelling in the brain and around the spinal cord, which can cause serious complications, including hearing loss.\n\n[Byline: Luke Ranker]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Louisiana\nDate: Sat 18 Mar 2017\nSource: Myarklamiss [edited]\nhttp://www.myarklamiss.com/news/local-news/louisiana-beginning-to-see-cases-of-mumps/673942529\n\n\nThe Louisiana Department of Health reports that cases of mumps are beginning to appear in Louisiana. As of Wed [15 Mar 2017], there have been 12 cases of mumps reported by the LDH Office of Public Health.\n\n'There has been a large outbreak of mumps cases in Arkansas, and we're starting to see cases in Louisiana now,' said Dr. Frank Welch, medical director of the state Immunization Program, Louisiana Department of Health.\n\nThe 1st cluster of cases has been identified at Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge. The university is taking extra precautions to prevent the spread among students and faculty. The Louisiana Department of Health has shared health alerts and education to remind health care providers, schools and universities about the signs and symptoms of mumps.\n\n'Our Louisiana culture is rich with festivals and celebrations including many scheduled for St. Patrick's Day this weekend. Large gatherings create an environment where germs and contagious illnesses spread easily,' said Dr. Jimmy Guidry, State Health Officer, LDH. 'This is a great time to remind everyone to take proper precautions to avoid getting sick.'\n\nThe Louisiana Department of Health offers these reminders to avoid the spread of infection:\n- Do not share drinks, utensils, or food.\n- Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when you cough or sneeze.\n- Clean surfaces that are frequently touched (such as toys, doorknobs, tables, counters, etc.) with soap and water or with cleaning wipes regularly.\n- Wash your hands frequently with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand cleaner.\n- If you have symptoms, stay at home for 5 days after symptoms begin; avoid school, work or large group settings.\n\nSymptoms of mumps include:\n- Fever\n- Headache\n- Muscle aches\n- Tiredness\n- Loss of appetite\n- Swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears on one or both sides\n\nDr. Welch added that a person who has the mumps virus may not know they are ill because it can take several weeks after the infection until the symptoms occur.\n\n'The infectious period is the time during which an infected person can spread the disease to others. People are most infectious from 1-2 days before onset of symptoms until 5 days after they notice inflammation of their salivary glands,' Welch added. 'It is for this reason that we advise these safe sharing precautions, especially at a time when people gather in large groups.'\n\nVisit http://www.ldh.la.gov/mumps for more information about mumps for more information.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Pennsylvania\nDate: Thu 16 Mar 2017\nSource: The Inquirer Daily News [edited]\nhttp://www.philly.com/philly/health/Do-Penn-State-mumps-cases-mean-college-students-need-more-shots-cdc-acip.html\n\n\nAs Pennsylvania State University copes with an ongoing outbreak of mumps, infectious-disease experts are investigating why vaccinated young people are getting sick and whether a booster shot would help.\n\n'We didn't see outbreaks like this 10 years ago,' said Kelly L. Moore, director of the Tennessee Immunization Project and chair of the mumps work group for the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP). Its vaccination recommendations become official policy for the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention when approved by the CDC director.\n\nThe government already recommends 2 shots, given at 12 to 15 months and just before entering school. The 2nd shot was added in 1989.\n\nIn recent outbreaks, public health authorities have suggested a 3rd dose for people in affected communities. Penn State recently began suggesting shots for several hundred students it deemed at high risk for mumps exposure.\n\nPenn State had its 1st case on 29 Jan 2017 and had 36 probable or confirmed cases on 3 Mar 2017, just before students headed out for spring break.\n\nThe total is now 45, said Shelley Haffner, infectious-disease manager at Penn State's student health center. She said the school would have a vaccination clinic on Thu [16 Mar 2017]. Students will be expected to submit the cost of the vaccine, which the school is still working out, to their insurance companies. The MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine usually costs about USD 150, she said.\n\nAll but one of the students with mumps symptoms has had at least one dose of the vaccine, Haffner said. The 1st student to become ill was fully vaccinated. Students are supposed to have 2 doses before entering the university, but some may not have had them at the correct age, she said.\n\nThe Pennsylvania Department of Health said Wed [15 Mar 2017] that it was not aware of mumps cases at any other Pennsylvania colleges.\n\nExperts in 2012 decided that the evidence for a 3rd shot was 'inconclusive,' Moore said. Now, because of multiple outbreaks of mumps over the last 2 years, the CDC and ACIP are studying the issue again. A recommendation is expected next year [2018], she said.\n\nHer group had its 1st meeting last month [February 2017], so it doesn't have answers yet, but it will investigate a lot of questions. Those include whether and how much the vaccine's effectiveness wanes over time and whether a 3rd dose could help prevent or shorten outbreaks. Another question is whether the vaccine's formula, which has been based on the same strain of virus since it was introduced in 1967, needs tweaking. Most of the current cases involve a different strain of mumps.\n\nOutbreaks since 2006 have occurred in well-vaccinated groups, including college and high school students.\n\nBefore the mumps vaccine was developed, there were about 186 000 cases a year in the United States. Not all were reported then, so the CDC said the actual numbers were likely much higher. Since then, there have been many years when only a couple of hundred cases were reported.\n\nBut there was a spike in cases in 2006, mainly among college students in the Midwest. That year, 6500 people got sick.\n\nThere was another spike last year [2016], with more than 5000 cases reported. As of the end of February 2017, 1077 cases had been reported this year [2017].\n\nTrish Perl, an infectious-disease doctor at the University of Texas who is on the board of the Infectious Diseases Society of America, said there was some evidence that the vaccine becomes less effective over time.\n\n'That is probably contributing to the outbreaks we've been seeing,' said Kristen Feemster, director of research for the Vaccine Education Center at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia.\n\nGiving 3rd doses during outbreaks is becoming more common, but it's not clear how effective that is. 'Mumps is really a pretty infectious disease,' and it takes 2 weeks after a shot for increased immunity to kick in, Perl said.\n\nEffectiveness of the vaccine is estimated at 77 percent after one dose and 88 percent after 2.\n\nPeople infected with the virus can spread it for 2-3 days before they have symptoms and 5 days after. The incubation period is long -- 16 to 18 days -- and some infected patients never have symptoms.\n\nOutbreaks in the last decade have mainly been among vaccinated people who belong to groups with frequent, close contact. 'The other thing that plays a role,' Moore said, 'is how intense and prolonged is your exposure to the virus.' College students, who live and go to class in groups and may exchange saliva through kissing and sharing of drinks, are prime candidates for exposure. The disease largely has not spread to wider communities.\n\nIn most people, mumps causes relatively mild symptoms such as fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue, and lack of appetite. The classic symptom is swelling and tenderness of the glands just below or in front of the ear or jaw.\n\nMumps can occasionally cause more severe complications, including inflammation of the testicles, brain, tissues covering the brain and ovaries as well as deafness.\n\nPerl and Moore both pointed out that vaccinated mumps victims have far fewer complications than those who have not gotten the shots. Haffner said that only one Penn State student has had a mumps complication and that did not require hospitalization.\n\nBefore vaccination, 12 percent to 50 percent of male mumps victims got testicular inflammation, Perl said. Three percent to 10 percent of boys and men who have been vaccinated get it. The percentage who suffered hearing loss has fallen from 4 percent to one percent or less, according to the Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, a CDC publication. The percentage needing hospitalization fell from 5.5 percent to 1-2 percent.\n\n'The cases that we're seeing now have far lower complication rates,' Moore said. 'We're not seeing people with serious illness in the hospital worrying about lifelong consequences.'\n\n[Byline: Stacey Burling]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See discussion of 3rd dose of MMR vaccine in previous posts.\n\nA map of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "\n\nSymptoms of mumps include:\n- Fever\n- Headache\n- Muscle aches\n- Tiredness\n- Loss of appetite\n- Swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears on one or both sides\n\nDr. Welch added that a person who has the mumps virus may not know they are ill because it can take several weeks after the infection until the symptoms occur. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\n'There has been a large outbreak of mumps cases in Arkansas, and we're starting to see cases in Louisiana now,' said Dr. Frank Welch, medical director of the state Immunization Program, Louisiana Department of Health. \n\nBefore the mumps vaccination program began in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher because of underreporting, according to the CDC. \n\nThe Pennsylvania Department of Health said Wed [15 Mar 2017] that it was not aware of mumps cases at any other Pennsylvania colleges. \n\nSo far, Delfs said, there have been no cases reported in Shawnee County, but the disease can easily be spread in populations that haven't been fully vaccinated. \n\n[Byline: Stacey Burling]\n\n--\n \n\nMumps has been most common on college campuses, where the disease is easily spread through coughing, sneezing and talking, said Gianfranco Pezzino, the county's health officer. \n\nBefore vaccination, 12 percent to 50 percent of male mumps victims got testicular inflammation, Perl said. \n\nAll but one of the students with mumps symptoms has had at least one dose of the vaccine, Haffner said. \n\nPenn State had its 1st case on 29 Jan 2017 and had 36 probable or confirmed cases on 3 Mar 2017, just before students headed out for spring break. \n\nMumps can't be treated with antibiotics because it is caused by a virus, but most cases clear within 2 weeks. \n\n'We didn't see outbreaks like this 10 years ago,' said Kelly L. Moore, director of the Tennessee Immunization Project and chair of the mumps work group for the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP). \n\nBefore the mumps vaccine was developed, there were about 186 000 cases a year in the United States. \n\nTrish Perl, an infectious-disease doctor at the University of Texas who is on the board of the Infectious Diseases Society of America, said there was some evidence that the vaccine becomes less effective over time. \n\nThe Louisiana Department of Health offers these reminders to avoid the spread of infection:\n- Do not share drinks, utensils, or food. \n\nPeople infected with the virus can spread it for 2-3 days before they have symptoms and 5 days after. It is for this reason that we advise these safe sharing precautions, especially at a time when people gather in large groups.'\n\nVisit http://www.ldh.la.gov/mumps for more information about mumps for more information. \n\n'The cases that we're seeing now have far lower complication rates,' Moore said. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-01-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "1989-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-02-25 00:00:00", "2045-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Baton Rouge", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pittsburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manhattan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "St. Patrick 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Louisiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shawnee County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4895943", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (09)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4895943", "date": "2017-03-12 18:35:14", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (09)\n*****************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] New Zealand (Otago)\n[2] USA [Oklahoma (Tulsa)]\n[3] USA (Texas)\n[4] USA (Colorado)\n\n******\n[1] New Zealand (Otago)\nDate: Tue 7 Mar 2017\nSource: Otago Daily News [edited]\nhttps://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/mumps-vigilance-advised-cases-increase\n\n\nOtago schools are warning parents to be vigilant as health officials express fears of an outbreak of mumps in New Zealand. Public health deputy director Harriette Carr said there had been 39 'confirmed and probable cases'' of mumps reported in New Zealand, between 1 Sep 2016 and 1 Mar 2017. The number was up to 3 times higher than for the corresponding periods in the previous 3 years.\n\nMost of the cases were reported from the Auckland region (26 cases). Other affected district health board areas are Northland (3 cases), Lakes (3), Capital and Coast, Canterbury (2 each), Taranaki, Hutt Valley and West Coast (1 each). '16 of the cases were likely to have been acquired overseas,'' Dr Carr said.\n\nThe age range of affected persons is 2 to 34 years, with about half the cases occurring in school-aged children and half in young adults. 'Though spread has been limited at this stage, there is an increased risk of further outbreaks, particularly given the start of the year for schools and universities,' said Dr Carr.\n\nOtago Primary Principals' Association chairwoman and Musselburgh School principal Debbie Smith said schools were being cautious in light of the threat. 'I would make sure there's something in school newsletters so people can be aware of it. Principals should follow the Ministry of Health's lead, and I suggest that parents keep an eye out.' The Ministry of Health and Ministry of Education advised that the best prevention against the disease was immunisation with 2 doses of the measles, mumps, rubella vaccine (MMR), which is free.\n\nTaking action before a mumps outbreak could minimise the effect or spread of the illness, Dr Carr said. 'School and university staff, educators, students and parents can help prevent mumps spreading in the community by making sure that their immunisations and their children's immunisations are up to date. If they are unsure, encourage them to check with their family doctor. Anybody not fully vaccinated with MMR for their age must get vaccinated, that is, all school-age and older students must have had 2 doses of MMR,' she said.\n\n- Mumps is a disease notifiable to the local medical health officer.\n\n- Symptoms include sore and swollen areas under the jaw/around the face, usually accompanied or preceded by fever, muscle soreness, poor appetite, fatigue and headache.\n\n- If a person develops symptoms of mumps, isolate them from others.\n\n- Susceptible people include those born after 1981 who have not had a mumps infection or have not been fully vaccinated.\n\n- People with mumps, and those who have been exposed to mumps, should not attend education or workplaces or mix with other susceptible people while they are infectious.\n\n- A person can be infectious for 7 days before the swelling of the salivary gland(s), and for 5 days after the swelling has gone down.\n\n- Complications include orchitis (inflammation of the testicles) in adult males; oophoritis (inflammation of the ovaries and/or breast tissue [mastitis]) in adult females; inflammation of the brain (encephalitis); inflammation of the tissue covering the brain and spinal cord (meningitis); and deafness.\n\n- Following a case of mumps, the local medical officer of health will make the decision on the exclusion from educational facilities of susceptible children or adults exposed to the case.\n\n[byline: John Lewis]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap of New Zealand can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA [Oklahoma (Tulsa)]\nDate: 8 Mar 2017\nSource: Fox 23 News [edited]\nhttp://www.fox23.com/news/tulsa-health-department-investigates-local-outbreak-of-mumps/500878702\n\n\nThe Tulsa Health Department (THD) is currently investigating an outbreak of mumps in Tulsa County. The department says they've identified 8 cases, 5 of which have been laboratory confirmed. One of the confirmed cases is a student at the at Owasso Public Schools' 7th grade center.\n\nHealth officials say they are following standard disease investigation and response protocols, such as working with individuals who have potentially been exposed through close contact with the confirmed and probable cases. The health department says they are working closely with Owasso Public Schools administration to ensure that students, parents and teachers who may have been exposed are notified and receive guidance on what precautions they may need to take.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] USA (Texas)\nDate: 9 Mar 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/dallas-area-30-mumps-cases-cedar-hill-high-school-51449/\n\n\nDallas County health officials reported in an update on Wed [8 Mar 2017] that [30] students and teachers at Cedar Hill High School have been identified as mumps cases. Not all cases are Dallas County residents. Dallas County Health and Human Services (DCHHS) is reporting 39 mumps cases in Dallas County for 2017.\n\nIn addition, DCHHS has a separate total of 9 additional unrelated mumps cases in the city of Mesquite and Dallas.\n\nDCHHS health officials are urging immunization to protect against and prevent the spread of mumps. People who have had 2 mumps vaccinations (such as 2 MMR vaccines) are usually considered immune to mumps. A 3rd dose of the MMR vaccine is only recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention when an individual is associated with an ongoing outbreak.\n\n'At 2 doses, the MMR vaccine is very impactful, at 88 per cent effectiveness,' said Dr Christopher Perkins, Dallas County medical director/health authority. 'A 3rd dose is recommended if you have been associated with an outbreak. Ensuring you are up to date with your vaccination is the best protection in addition to washing hands frequently and cleaning/disinfecting objects or surfaces that may be contaminated with germs.'\n\nDCHHS provides the 1st and 2nd dose of the MMR vaccine for children and adults. ... 'The increased number of mumps cases reported in the North Texas area underscores the importance of getting vaccinated,' said DCHHS director Zachary Thompson.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] USA (Colorado)\nDate: Sat 10 Mar 2017\nSource: The Denver Channel [edited]\nhttp://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/local-news/mumps-outbreak-pushes-colorado-past-infection-record\n\n\nThe number of mumps cases in Colorado continues to grow and has surpassed the state record amid an outbreak that has spread through several states. Health officials on Fri [10 Mar 2017] said they'd registered a total of 53 cases of mumps in the state since 1 Jan 2017. The old record was 51 cases following an outbreak in 2006. Colorado averages just 5.6 cases a year. Last year [2016], there were 17 cases.\n\nMumps is an infection spread by direct human-to-human contact through respiratory droplets or saliva. Average incubation periods range from 16 to 18 days on average but up to 12 to 25 days.\n\nSymptoms of the infection aren't limited to swelling of salivary and parotid glands across the cheek and jaw area; swelling can range from the frontal part of the ear and spread as fluid builds up. Other symptoms can at times include low-grade fevers, malaise, loss of appetite, headache and more, but not all who have mumps will exhibit symptoms. Severe complications from the infection are rare, but can include sterility, spontaneous abortion, deafness and more.\n\nOfficials advise ensuring family members are up to date on the MMR vaccine, noting that 2 doses of the vaccine are recommended for children. Even those who are vaccinated are susceptible to mumps, as the vaccine is only roughly 88 per cent effective, and effectiveness can wane after the vaccine has been administered.\n\n[byline: Kurt Sevits]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A ProMED-mail/HealthMap of the US showing the location of Texas, Oklahoma, and Colorado can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Kurt Sevits]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A ProMED-mail/HealthMap of the US showing the location of Texas, Oklahoma, and Colorado can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. The health department says they are working closely with Owasso Public Schools administration to ensure that students, parents and teachers who may have been exposed are notified and receive guidance on what precautions they may need to take.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n***** \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\n[byline: John Lewis]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap of New Zealand can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/dallas-area-30-mumps-cases-cedar-hill-high-school-51449/\n\n\nDallas County health officials reported in an update on Wed [8 Mar 2017] that [30] students and teachers at Cedar Hill High School have been identified as mumps cases. Source: Otago Daily News [edited]\nhttps://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/mumps-vigilance-advised-cases-increase\n\n\nOtago schools are warning parents to be vigilant as health officials express fears of an outbreak of mumps in New Zealand. MUMPS UPDATE (09)\n*****************\n Public health deputy director Harriette Carr said there had been 39 'confirmed and probable cases'' of mumps reported in New Zealand, between 1 Sep 2016 and 1 Mar 2017. Health officials on Fri [10 Mar 2017] said they'd registered a total of 53 cases of mumps in the state since 1 Jan 2017. \n\n- People with mumps, and those who have been exposed to mumps, should not attend education or workplaces or mix with other susceptible people while they are infectious. \n\nHealth officials say they are following standard disease investigation and response protocols, such as working with individuals who have potentially been exposed through close contact with the confirmed and probable cases. \n\nThe age range of affected persons is 2 to 34 years, with about half the cases occurring in school-aged children and half in young adults. ' \n\n'At 2 doses, the MMR vaccine is very impactful, at 88 per cent effectiveness,' said Dr Christopher Perkins, Dallas County medical director/health authority. ' In this update:\n[1] New Zealand (Otago)\n \n\n- Complications include orchitis (inflammation of the testicles) in adult males; oophoritis (inflammation of the ovaries and/or breast tissue [mastitis]) in adult females; inflammation of the brain (encephalitis); inflammation of the tissue covering the brain and spinal cord (meningitis); and deafness. \n\nDCHHS health officials are urging immunization to protect against and prevent the spread of mumps. \n\n- Susceptible people include those born after 1981 who have not had a mumps infection or have not been fully vaccinated. \n\nMost of the cases were reported from the Auckland region (26 cases). \n\nMumps is an infection spread by direct human-to-human contact through respiratory droplets or saliva. \n\n- Mumps is a disease notifiable to the local medical health officer. People who have had 2 mumps vaccinations (such as 2 MMR vaccines) are usually considered immune to mumps. [4] USA (Colorado)\n\n******\n \n\nSymptoms of the infection aren't limited to swelling of salivary and parotid glands across the cheek and jaw area; swelling can range from the frontal part of the ear and spread as fluid builds up. \n\nTaking action before a mumps outbreak could minimise the effect or spread of the illness The increased number of mumps cases reported in the North Texas area underscores the importance of getting vaccinated,' said DCHHS director Zachary Thompson. LK]\n\n******\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2016-09-01 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "1981-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-01-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tulsa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canterbury", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulsa County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dallas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dallas County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4880865", "date": "2017-03-05 16:42:38", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (08): CANADA, USA, COMMENT\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Canada (Ontario, Toronto)\n[2] Canada (New Brunswick, Alberta)\n[3] USA (Pennsylvania)\n[4] USA (Missouri)\n[5] Comment in response to RFI in ProMED posts Mumps update (05) & (06)\n\n******\n[1] Canada (Ontario, Toronto)\nDate: Thu 2 Mar 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/toronto-mumps-outbreak-rises-18-54425/\n\n\nIn a follow-up on the mumps outbreak in Toronto, city health officials report 4 additional cases since the outbreak was 1st reported approximately one week ago.\n\nCurrently, there have been 18 confirmed cases of mumps in Toronto in 2017 as of 1 Mar 2017, according to Toronto Public Health.\n\nThe outbreak is primarily affecting young adults, 18 to 35 years of age. Earlier reports on the investigation note that many of these cases have frequented bars in the west downtown core of Toronto.\n\nThe mumps virus is found in saliva and respiratory droplets. It is spread from person to person through coughing, sneezing, and coming into contact with a person's saliva by sharing drinks or utensils, food or water bottles, or by kissing. A major factor contributing to outbreaks is being in a crowded environment, such as attending the same class, playing on the same sports team or living in a dormitory with a person who has the mumps.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 4 Mar 2017, another 5 cases of mumps have been confirmed in Toronto, bringing the total to 22 this year (2017) in Toronto. Clusters of mumps cases have also emerged in the Prairies and Western Canada http://toronto.ctvnews.ca/toronto-mumps-outbreak-rises-to-22-cases-1.3309598. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Canada (New Brunswick; Alberta)\nDate: Thu 2 Mar 2017\nSource: Global News [edited]\nhttp://globalnews.ca/news/3283698/new-brunswicks-top-doctor-stresses-importance-of-proper-vaccination-confirms-two-cases-of-mumps/\n\n\nThe province's acting chief medical officer of health is reminding people about the importance of ensuring that their vaccinations are up to date. Dr. Jennifer Russell said 2 cases of mumps have been confirmed in New Brunswick, along with an outbreak of whooping cough.\n\n'Certainly, right now is the time to get checked to see if your vaccines are up to date for yourself and for your children,' Russell said.\n\nThree more mumps cases have been confirmed in Edmonton; Alberta's total has risen to 21.\n\nRussell said it's 'concerning' to have mumps in the province. According to the New Brunswick Department of Health's Routine Immunization Schedule, adults born after 1970 should have a 2nd booster vaccine to ensure they are protected.\n\n'When we have a disease that has a vaccine that allows you to prevent it, we want people to get those vaccines because it's really, really important, not just for their own health or for their children's health, but also for the health of the people around them who either can't get immunized, or maybe the immunization didn't quite work as well for them,' Russell said.\n\nShe said that the more people who get vaccinated, the safer everyone is in New Brunswick.\n\n'I'm not able to disclose any demographic information at this time, but just to say that we do have 2 cases right now, and they are connected; there was some contact,' Russell said.\n\nComplications from mumps can include meningitis, swollen testicles, and permanent deafness.\n\nRussell said there are no current cases of measles in New Brunswick but said it's something that can appear occasionally in the province.\n\nNew Brunswickers are encouraged to check with their health care provider or contact public health offices for more information on whether they need to update their vaccinations.\n\nDr. Russell said there is a current pertussis outbreak, more commonly known as whooping cough, in the Fredericton region.\n\nShe told Global News that the regional medical officer of health will be sending out a note to health care providers.\n\nRussell said there is a whooping cough vaccination given to children, but noted adults also require a booster shot. She said there can be complications from whooping cough that could result in death.\n\n[Byline: Adrienne South]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Whooping cough, or pertussis, is a serious disease that can cause babies to stop breathing. It is a vaccine-preventable disease that without vaccination is a very contagious disease that is most serious for babies. People with whooping cough usually spread the disease by coughing or sneezing while in close contact with others. Parents, older siblings, or other caregivers can give whooping cough to babies without even knowing they have the disease.\n\nYoung babies can get pneumonia (lung infection), and many have trouble breathing. About half of babies younger than one year old who get whooping cough end up in the hospital, and a few even die from the disease.\n\nBabies need protection because they can catch whooping cough from anyone around them, and it can make them very sick. Babies get protection from whooping cough vaccines in 3 important ways:\n- Through the Mother when she gets the whooping cough vaccine in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy.\n- By being surrounded with family members and caregivers who are up-to-date with their whooping cough vaccine.\n- By getting all doses of the whooping cough vaccine according to CDC's recommended schedule [excerpted and edited from CDC].\n\nA map of Canada showing the location of New Brunswick province can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/269. A map of Canada showing the location of Alberta can be found at https://binged.it/2m8sPen. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] USA (Pennsylvania)\nDate: Fri 3 Mar 2017\nSource: WJAC [edited]\nhttp://wjactv.com/news/local/possible-mumps-cases-at-penn-state-rises-to-27\n\n\nPenn State University is investigating a suspected outbreak of mumps after 27 'suspected, probable or confirmed' cases have been reported on campus.\n\nAccording to a news release from the school, 6 of the 27 cases have been confirmed by lab tests [Now, 12 cases have been confirmed (http://bit.ly/2m6zPZb). - Mod.LK].\n\nThe 1st case was diagnosed in late January [2017], and the school is now urging students and staff who are showing symptoms to remain isolated to help prevent the spread of the illness.\n\nPenn State said those infected should not immediately return to school following spring break.\n\nThe state's health department is continuing to monitor the situation alongside the school.\n\n[Byline: Lauren Petrelli]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the USA showing the location of Pennsylvania and Missouri can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/240.]\n\n******\n[4] USA (Missouri)\nDate: Sun 5 Mar 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/southeast-missouri-state-university-reports-15-mumps-cases-vaccine-clinics-scheduled-next-week-16881/\n\n\nIn light of recent reports of 15 confirmed mumps cases on the Southeast Missouri State University campus, The Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services has updated its recommendation and is encouraging all Southeast Missouri State University students to consider getting a 3rd dose of the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine in response to continued confirmed and suspected cases of mumps at the school.\n\nBecause the majority of those cases are within the fraternity and sorority community, the Cape Girardeau Public Health Center, with assistance from the Campus Health Clinic, will host a vaccination clinic for all members of the Greek Community, including those living on- and off-campus. ... This vaccination clinic is specifically for members of Southeast's Greek community, who health officials say have the greatest known risk factors and where the confirmed mumps cases are most concentrated.\n\nStudents who are not members of a fraternity or sorority can get a 3rd MMR dose by visiting the Campus Health Clinic. ... Students who are not part of the Greek community have a lower risk of contracting mumps based upon currently confirmed and suspected cases.\n\nThe reports at Southeast come on the heels of a mumps outbreak on the campus of the University of Missouri-Columbia reported this past fall [2016]. At the University of Missouri-Columbia, 350 confirmed and probable cases of mumps have been reported as of 23 Feb 2017.\n\nAccording to the Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services, the majority of cases continue to be reported among university students; 14 other colleges and universities across the State of Missouri have reported confirmed or suspected cases of mumps since August 2016.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There has been an increasing number of reports of mumps cases on campuses in the US because of the lifestyle of students and their age, which reflects time since a 2nd vaccination with MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine. The mumps component of the MMR vaccine is about 88 percent effective when a person gets 2 doses. More than 5000 cases of mumps were reported last year, 2016, in the United States, of which 19 outbreaks occurred on college campuses. This is the most in a decade. But importantly, even with infection with the mumps virus, those who have been vaccinated have fewer severe complications. A 3rd vaccine dose is being considered as a preventative measure. There is some evidence that this additional dose may help control mumps outbreaks among populations with preexisting high 2-dose vaccine coverage. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[5] Comment in response to RFI in ProMED-mail posts Mumps update (05) & (06)\nDate: Sun 5 Mar 2017\nFrom: Kamran Kadkhoda <kamrankadkhoda@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\n[Dr. Kadkhoda is responding to the RFI concerning the high incidence of mumps in previously vaccinated individuals, particularly young adults. From his response below, there clearly are a number of avenues to pursue to more fully understand the problem. ProMED-mail thanks Dr. Kadkhoda for his response. - Mod.LK]:\n\nThe best explanation so far is secondary vaccine failure/waning immunity: during the 1st decade or so after the vaccine, which uses genotype A strains, there's adequate cross-neutralization across different mumps genotypes, but after neutralization, capacity against non-A genotypes such as G wanes, then people may come down with clinical mumps. It'll be intriguing to see whether sub-neutralizing anti-mumps antibody levels help a new infection establish itself through antibody-dependent enhancement. It is also known that some HLA haplotypes play a role even in primary vaccine failure. All in all, significant pathogen inoculum should be another important factor on top of those mentioned above.\n\n--\nKamran Kadkhoda, Ph.D., D(ABMM), D(ABMLI)\nAssistant Professor - Clinical Microbiologist\nCadham Provincial Public Health Laboratory\nAdjunct Professor - Department of Immunology\nUniversity of Manitoba\nInvestigator at Children's Hospital Research Institute of Manitoba (CHRIM)\n<kamrankadkhoda@gmail.com>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 4 Mar 2017, another 5 cases of mumps have been confirmed in Toronto, bringing the total to 22 this year (2017) in Toronto. In light of recent reports of 15 confirmed mumps cases on the Southeast Missouri State University campus, The Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services has updated its recommendation and is encouraging all Southeast Missouri State University students to consider getting a 3rd dose of the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine in response to continued confirmed and suspected cases of mumps at the school. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Whooping cough, or pertussis, is a serious disease that can cause babies to stop breathing. LK]:\n\nThe best explanation so far is secondary vaccine failure/waning immunity: during the 1st decade or so after the vaccine, which uses genotype A strains, there's adequate cross-neutralization across different mumps genotypes, but after neutralization, capacity against non-A genotypes such as G wanes, then people may come down with clinical mumps. According to the Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services, the majority of cases continue to be reported among university students; 14 other colleges and universities across the State of Missouri have reported confirmed or suspected cases of mumps since August 2016. \n\nBecause the majority of those cases are within the fraternity and sorority community, the Cape Girardeau Public Health Center, with assistance from the Campus Health Clinic, will host a vaccination clinic for all members of the Greek Community, including those living on- and off-campus. ... 00:00:00", "2017-02-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-08-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswickers", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4875855", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (07): Canada, USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4875855", "date": "2017-03-03 12:19:32", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (07): CANADA, USA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Canada (Vancouver), USA\n[2] Epicore surveillance project responses\n\n******\n[1] Canada (Vancouver), USA\nDate: Tue 28 Feb 2017\nSource: The Canadian Press [edited]\nhttp://www.orangeville.com/sports-story/7164449-mumps-the-word-players-hope-nhl-can-contain-latest-outbreak/\n\n\nThe return of the mumps has caught some NHL players by surprise and they are counting on the league being better equipped to deal with the 2nd such outbreak in a little over 2 years.\n\n'Well, it happened the one time, and guys were concerned about it and thought it was going to be kind of gone forever,' Buffalo Sabres veteran forward Kyle Okposo said [Tue 28 Feb 2017]. 'I just hope it doesn't reach us. I feel for the guys that have it. Just want to make sure that it gets as contained as we can this time.'\n\nThe latest outbreak began in Vancouver, where the Canucks announced last weekend [25-26 Feb 2017] defenceman Troy Stecher had been diagnosed while 6 other players and a trainer were showing symptoms. On [Mon 27 Feb 2017], the Minnesota Wild announced forwards Zach Parise and Jason Pominville and assistant coach Scott Stevens were diagnosed with the highly contagious disease and must miss at least 3 games.\n\nThe developments raised concern after what occurred during the 1st half of the 2014-15 season: 24 players, including Pittsburgh star Sidney Crosby, representing 5 teams and 2 on-ice officials either showed symptoms or were diagnosed with the mumps.\n\nThe Wild were also affected in 2014, when 5 defensemen contracted the virus.\n'I don't know what to say to that. It's a lot for one team in a few years,' said Wild forward Mikael Granlund, whose brother, Markus Granlund, was among the Vancouver players showing symptoms.\n\nThere was enough worry in Minnesota that center Eric Staal wondered of the potential danger of players rubbing gloves against teammates' faces during the celebration following a 5-4 overtime win against Los Angeles on [Mon 27 Feb 2017] night. 'If someone had it in that pile, then we all got it,' Staal said. 'So we'll see what happens.'\n\nWild doctors recently provided players and staff with measles-mumps-rubella vaccination, as they did in 2014. The Wild equipment staff also uses a chemical spray on locker room cubicles each time players come off the ice. And Minnesota is one of 27 NHL teams using a Sani Sport machine to disinfect players' equipment.\n\nIn Vancouver, public health officials have yet to determine where or how Canucks players contracted mumps, Vancouver Coastal Health spokesman Gavin Wilson said. Wilson added the Vancouver region is not showing any signs of a spike in the mumps virus, unlike neighboring Washington State, which had a reported 503 cases already in 2017, as opposed to just 48 last year [2016].\n\nThere have been other pockets of outbreaks across the continent this year [2017], including the University of Missouri, which reported more than 320 confirmed and probably cases earlier this month [February 2017].\n\nFrom [1-28 Jan 2017], the Centers of Disease Control and Prevention said there have been 485 mumps infections reported in the United States, which already surpasses the 229 cases reported in 2012. Since 2000, there have been only 2 years -- 2006 and 2016 -- in which the number of mumps cases have topped 3000.\n\nMumps can be spread by saliva or mucus. The virus has a 12 - to 30 - day incubation period. Its typical symptoms are fever, headache, muscle aches and loss of appetite, followed by swollen salivary glands.\n\nThe CDC notes that while mumps are 'no longer very common' in the U.S., outbreaks do occur particularly in places where people have had prolonged close contact with a person with the virus, such as school, dorms or sports teams.\n\nIn an e-mail to The Associated Press, NHL Deputy Commissioner Bill Daly wrote it's unclear what prompted the recurrence. As for how the league is attempting to contain the latest outbreak, Daly wrote: 'Education, reinforcement of precautions and booster shots, where necessary.'\n\nThough booster shots work, they are only considered effective 88 percent of the time.\n\nIn Buffalo [NY], Sabres equipment manager Dave Williams said a protocol is put into place the moment a player shows any sign of sickness, even when involving what appears to be the common cold. The protocols include having players drink from their own water bottles, using hospital-strength disinfectant laundry detergent to wash the player's uniform separately.\n\nThe 1st professional hockey-related case of mumps this year [2017] occurred last month [January 2017], when 3 members of the New Jersey Devils' AHL affiliate in Albany, New York, contracted the virus.\n\nNashville Predators defenseman P.K. Subban said there's very little players can do to avoid getting mumps other than taking precautions. 'Professional sports is where all teams intertwine. We all touch every rink,' said Subban, noting the Predators played both the Wild and Canucks over the past 3 weeks. 'We've just been told to make sure our shots are up to date and wash our hands. That's it. That's all you can do.'\n\n[Byline: John Wawrow]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] EpiCore surveillance project responses\nDate: Thu 23 Feb - Thu 2 Mar 2017\nSource: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [edited]\n\n\nUSA (Tennessee, Memphis)\nAt least 4 cases of mumps have been seen in pediatric patients at Le Bonheur Children's Hospital in Memphis, TN as of [Fri 24 Feb 2017], as reported by a Medical Laboratory Technologist who obtained the information from an attending pediatrician at that hospital.\n\nUSA (Kansas)\nMumps has been identified in Kansas in high school wrestlers, as well as students at The University of Kansas in Lawrence, and in a mother and her child in Johnson County. The latter 2 sets of cases were likely associated with the University of Missouri. In the 1st case, there was a party with some students from the University of Missouri who later were sick with mumps, and in the 2nd, the child attended school at the University of Missouri and transmitted the virus to the mother.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\nProMED thanks all the Epicore members who submitted responses to this request for further information. - Mod.LK\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\nThe developments raised concern after what occurred during the 1st half of the 2014-15 season: 24 players, including Pittsburgh star Sidney Crosby, representing 5 teams and 2 on-ice officials either showed symptoms or were diagnosed with the mumps. \n\n[Byline: John Wawrow]\n\n--\n \n\nThere have been other pockets of outbreaks across the continent this year [2017], including the University of Missouri, which reported more than 320 confirmed and probably cases earlier this month [February 2017]. \n\nThe latest outbreak began in Vancouver, where the Canucks announced last weekend [25-26 Feb 2017] defenceman Troy Stecher had been diagnosed while 6 other players and a trainer were showing symptoms. \n\nThere was enough worry in Minnesota that center Eric Staal wondered of the potential danger of players rubbing gloves against teammates' faces during the celebration following a 5-4 overtime win against Los Angeles on [Mon 27 Feb 2017] night. ' MUMPS UPDATE (07): CANADA, USA\n******************************\n [2] Epicore surveillance project responses\n\n******\n From [1-28 Jan 2017], the Centers of Disease Control and Prevention said there have been 485 mumps infections reported in the United States, which already surpasses the 229 cases reported in 2012. \n\nWild doctors recently provided players and staff with measles-mumps-rubella vaccination, as they did in 2014. Wilson added the Vancouver region is not showing any signs of a spike in the mumps virus, unlike neighboring Washington State, which had a reported 503 cases already in 2017, as opposed to just 48 last year [2016]. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\n At least 4 cases of mumps have been seen in pediatric patients at Le Bonheur Children's Hospital in Memphis, TN as of [Fri 24 Feb 2017], as reported by a Medical Laboratory Technologist who obtained the information from an attending pediatrician at that hospital. In this update:\n[1] Canada (Vancouver), USA\n The return of the mumps has caught some NHL players by surprise and they are counting on the league being better equipped to deal with the 2nd such outbreak in a little over 2 years. \n\nUSA (Kansas)\n Date: Thu 23 Feb - Thu 2 Mar 2017\n Since 2000, there have been only 2 years -- 2006 and 2016 -- in which the number of mumps cases have topped 3000. \n\nThe Wild were also affected in 2014, when 5 defensemen contracted the virus.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-01-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-01-28 20:17:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-02-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pittsburgh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sani Sport", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lawrence", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johnson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Memphis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Albany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4864176", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (06): USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4864176", "date": "2017-02-27 17:44:57", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (06)\n****************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Alabama\n[2] California (Orange County)\n[3] Pennsylvania\n[4] Responses to RFI in Mumps update (05): USA (PA, MO - RFI), Canada (ON, AB) 20170223.4860461\n\n******\n[1] USA (Alabama)\nDate: Fri 24 Feb 2017\nSource: Epi-X (Epidemic Information Exchange)\nhttps://epix2.cdc.gov/v2/Reports/StandardReport/Display.aspx?id=61958&print=False&PSR=False\n\n\nAlabama Department of Public Health Investigates Mumps at the University of Alabama - 2017\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH) was recently notified by the University of Alabama (UA) Student Health Center that several students had been diagnosed with mumps. ADPH is investigating these notifiable disease cases and working closely with UA to contact potentially exposed people.\n\nDescription:\nThe Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH) was recently notified by the University of Alabama (UA) Student Health Center that several students had been diagnosed with mumps. ADPH is investigating these notifiable disease cases and working closely with UA to contact potentially exposed people.\n\nWhile UA has a highly vaccinated population of students, mumps can still occur in vaccinated communities, particularly in close-contact settings such as schools, colleges and camps. However, high vaccination coverage helps to limit the size, duration and spread of mumps.\n\nDuring this investigation, ADPH recommends that UA students, faculty and staff not vaccinated with two doses of measles, mumps, rubella vaccine (MMR), immediately receive a second MMR at Student Health Center, their doctor, or health department. ADPH strongly recommends students who do not have any record of MMR and decline to be vaccinated should not attend class for 25 days after exposure to mumps.\n\nIn 2016, Alabama reported only one case of mumps.\n\nOut of an abundance of caution, ADPH and UA have begun notifying the campus community about mumps, prevention tips, and vaccinations.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\npromed@promedmail.org\n\n[This is not a publicly available report at this time.\n\nA map of the United States showing the location of Arkansas, California, and Pennsylvania is available at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] California (Orange County)\nDate: Sat 25 Feb 2017\nSource: Orange County Register [edited]\nhttp://www.ocregister.com/articles/mumps-744955-students-symptoms.html\n\n\nFour Chapman law students sickened in mumps outbreak\n------------------------------------------------------------------\nFour students who attended Chapman Law School's back-to-school event in late January [2017] have been diagnosed with mumps, and more could have been exposed to the virus, county health officials said Fri [24 Feb 2017].\n\nOne case has been confirmed through testing and there are 3 probable cases, said Dr. Matthew Zahn, medical director of epidemiology and assessment at the Orange County Health Care Agency.\n\nThe 3 students were exposed as part of the same social group and are experiencing mumps symptoms, Zahn said.\n\nThe health agency has supplied vaccines to Chapman University. He said they will be administered through the campus clinic to students who were exposed.\n\nStudents were exposed to the virus 27 Jan at Rudy's Pub & Grill in Newport Beach, according to a Chapman University health alert issued Friday. University officials are encouraging students who attended the event and who may have been exposed to remain vigilant and get medical care if they experience symptoms.\n\nThe incubation period for the mumps virus is usually 12 to 25 days, which means it could take weeks for symptoms to develop, Zahn said. Mumps usually starts out with flu-like symptoms such as fever and muscle aches.\n\n'After a couple of days, you start to feel the classic symptoms of pain and swelling along the jaw line,' he said.\n\nThere is no treatment for mumps other than pain medication as it resolves on its own. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, mumps spreads through saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose or throat.\n\nAn infected person can spread the virus by coughing, sneezing or talking; by sharing items such as cups or beverages; through intimate contact; or by touching surfaces with unwashed hands.\n\nOrange County sees about 10 cases of mumps annually, Zahn said. Unlike measles, it's not a disease that is considered eradicated from the United States, he said.\n\n'But getting vaccinated can help protect you,' he said.\n\n[Byline: Deepa Bharath]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from Healthmap Alerts\npromed@promedmail.org\n\n******\n[3] Pennsylvania\nDate: Sat 25 Feb 2017\nSource: Altoona Mirror [edited]\nhttp://www.altoonamirror.com/uncategorized/2017/02/health-department-working-with-psu-on-mumps-cases/\n\n\nHealth department working with PSU [Penn State University] on mumps cases\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Pennsylvania Department of Health is investigating mumps cases on Penn State University's main campus.\n\nThe health department won't release details because of confidentiality rules, but Penn State says the 1st confirmed case was reported 29 Jan [2017]. Since then, there have been 19 other reported cases, including 4 confirmed by lab tests. The school is urging students and visitors to make sure their vaccinations are current.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from Healthmap Alerts\npromed@promedmail.org\n\n[ProMED looks forward to receiving more information on the origin of the cases. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] Responses to RFI in Mumps update (05): USA (PA, MO - RFI), Canada (ON, AB) 20170223.4860461 [edited]\n\nA. One anonymous submitter stated that several cases have been noted in Kansas since Thanksgiving [November] 2016. Over Thanksgiving vacation, there was a party at The University of Kansas, Lawrence, with some University of Missouri students who came down with mumps while there. In addition, cases have been reported in high school wrestlers across Kansas, and in a Mother in Johnson County, KS infected by her child who attended school at the University of Missouri.\n\n[ProMED thanks the submitter for this information.]\n\nB. Dr. Dirk Haselow [Arkansas Department fo Health] submitted a response to the RFI:\nI noticed a quote from an interview that I gave some time ago included in the thread. An important omission is as follows. While we have seen a higher than expected rate of parotitis in persons who have had 2 doses of MMR vaccine, we have seen exceptionally low rates of severe manifestations among our 2820 cases. (0 meningitis, 0 encephalitis, 1 pancreatitis, 5 hospitalizations, and 17 orchitis) Lumped together, these severe manifestations have occurred at roughly 100 fold lower rates than expected if our population was unvaccinated. The vaccine, while not perfect, clearly is working well to prevent severe disease.\n\nWe are in the process of conducting a study with CDC to estimate effectiveness of a 2nd dose and (in some cases a 3rd dose booster) in our outbreak.\n\n--\nDirk Haselow, MD, PhD\nState Epidemiologist and Outbreak Response Medical Director\nArkansas Department of Health\n4815 W. Markham St., Slot 48\nLittle Rock, AR 72205\n(o) 501-537-8969\n(f) 501-661-2300\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Haselow for his important note. We have pointed out the lack of severe symptoms vaccinated individuals experience following infection with mumps in comments in the past, most recently in Mumps update (01): USA (WA,TX) Archive Number: 20170110.4753366 - 'Even though mumps cases occur even in fully vaccinated children and adults, the occurrence of the more severe complications is relatively rare now, evidence of some protection afforded by the vaccine.' Nonetheless, this is an important point to make frequently as it further supports the MMR vaccine's effectiveness even when full protection does not occur.\n\nOne paper among others that discusses the problem of genetic variation in the SH gene of mumps virus is Echevarr\u00eda JE et al. Mumps Virus Genotyping: Basis and Known Circulating Genotypes. The Open Vaccine Journal, 2010, 3, 37-41. Although the 12 genotypes of mumps virus currently recognized by the WHO are considered to be the same serotype, lack of full cross-protection between different genotypes has been reported and has been suggested as a cause of vaccine failure. However, other reports did not find this lack of cross reaction among different genotypes.\n\nJerryl-Lynn and Rubini vaccine strains belong to genotype A which is genetically distant from the other genotypes. Wild strains belonging to the A genotype used to be dominant before vaccination, but nowadays most MV wild strains belong to other genotypes. The genetic distance between genotype A vaccine strains and non-A wild strains has been proposed to be a determinant factor in vaccine failure. On the other hand, non-A vaccines have been more frequently associated with post vaccination meningitis and are considered less safe. Additional studies are needed to obtain a better balance between efficiency and safety in order to establish the best future strategy for achieving optimal vaccine efficacy. Data from neutralization experiments are still unclear.\n\nAlso, from Gouma S et al. 2016. Mumps-specific cross-neutralization by MMR vaccine-induced antibodies predicts protection against mumps virus infection. Vaccine 34(35):4166.\n\nRecent mumps outbreaks have been] dominated by mumps genotype G virus strains, whereas the Jeryl Lynn mumps strain of the MMR vaccine belongs to genotype A. It has been shown previously that vaccinated persons develop sufficient neutralizing antibodies against wild type mumps genotype G virus, although the neutralization capacity is lower against the wild type strain as compared with the vaccine strain. However, no correlate of protection has been defined so far that distinguishes MMR vaccinated persons with sufficient immunological protection from those who are not protected against mumps virus infection.\n\nSee publications for references and full articles. - Mod.LK]\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "\n\nRecent mumps outbreaks have been] dominated by mumps genotype G virus strains, whereas the Jeryl Lynn mumps strain of the MMR vaccine belongs to genotype A. It has been shown previously that vaccinated persons develop sufficient neutralizing antibodies against wild type mumps genotype G virus, although the neutralization capacity is lower against the wild type strain as compared with the vaccine strain. \n\n--\nDirk Haselow, MD, PhD\nState Epidemiologist and Outbreak Response Medical Director\nArkansas Department of Health\n4815 A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from Healthmap Alerts\npromed@promedmail.org\n\n******\n Source: Altoona Mirror [edited]\nhttp://www.altoonamirror.com/uncategorized/2017/02/health-department-working-with-psu-on-mumps-cases/\n\n\nHealth department working with PSU [Penn State University] on mumps cases\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ In this update:\n[1] Alabama\n[2] California (Orange County)\n Little Rock, AR 72205\n(o) 501-537-8969\n(f) 501-661-2300\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Haselow for his important note. \nFour students who attended Chapman Law School's back-to-school event in late January [2017] have been diagnosed with mumps, and more could have been exposed to the virus, county health officials said Fri \n\n[Byline: Deepa Bharath]\n\n--\n [4] Responses to RFI in Mumps update (05): USA (PA, MO - RFI), Canada (ON, AB) 20170223.4860461\n\n******\n MUMPS - USA (06)\n****************\n \n\nWhile UA has a highly vaccinated population of students, mumps can still occur in vaccinated communities, particularly in close-contact settings such as schools, colleges and camps. \n\nB. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from Healthmap Alerts\n We have pointed out the lack of severe symptoms vaccinated individuals experience following infection with mumps in comments in the past, most recently in Mumps update (01): USA (WA,TX) Mumps-specific cross-neutralization by MMR vaccine-induced antibodies predicts protection against mumps virus infection. http://www.ocregister.com/articles/mumps-744955-students-symptoms.html\n\n\nFour Chapman law students sickened in mumps outbreak\n------------------------------------------------------------------ \n\nOrange County sees about 10 cases of mumps annually, Zahn said. https://epix2.cdc.gov/v2/Reports/StandardReport/Display.aspx?id=61958&print=False&PSR=False\n\n\nAlabama Department of Public Health Investigates Mumps at the University of Alabama - 2017\n Although the 12 genotypes of mumps virus currently recognized by the WHO are considered to be the same serotype, lack of full cross-protection between different genotypes has been reported and has been suggested as a cause of vaccine failure. \n\n--\n \n\n--\n \n\nOne paper among others that discusses the problem of genetic variation in the SH gene of mumps virus is Echevarr\u00eda JE et al. Health Center, their doctor, or health department. \n\nOne case has been confirmed through testing and there are 3 probable cases, said Dr. Matthew Zahn, medical director of epidemiology and assessment at the Orange County Health Care Agency. \n\nDescription:\n LK]\n\n******\n LK]\n\n******\n Archive Number: 20170110.4753366 - 'Even though mumps cases occur even in fully vaccinated children and adults, the occurrence of the more severe complications is relatively rare now, evidence of some protection afforded by the vaccine.' \n\nOut of an abundance of caution, ADPH and UA have begun notifying the campus community about mumps, prevention tips, and vaccinations. \n\nStudents were exposed to the virus 27 Jan at Rudy's Pub & Grill in Newport Beach, according to a Chapman University health alert issued Friday. \n\nJerryl-Lynn and Rubini vaccine strains belong to genotype A which is genetically distant from the other genotypes. \n\nThe health department won't release details because of confidentiality rules, but Penn State says the 1st confirmed case was reported 29 Jan [2017].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-02-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-29 00:00:00", "2021-01-27 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2820-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alabama", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orange County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Newport Beach", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johnson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps",
