"unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4900923", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (10)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4900923", "date": "2017-03-14 20:18:03", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (10)\n*****************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA: multistate summary\n[2] USA (Pennsylvania, Penn State University)\n[3] USA (Louisiana, Louisiana State University)\n[4] Australia (Queensland)\n\n******\n[1] USA: multistate summary\nDate: Fri 10 Mar 2017\nSource: DG Alerts from CDC (US); State Health Agencies [edited]\nhttp://dgalerts.docguide.com/multistate-usa-mumps-update-1000-cases-reported?nl_ref=newsletter&pk_campaign=newsletter\n\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), 37 states and the District of Columbia in the U.S. reported mumps infections in 1077 people to CDC from 1 Jan-25 Feb 2017. The distribution of cases is shown in a map [in the URL above].\n\nKansas\n------\nMumps cases have been reported in multiple counties in Kansas. The Kansas Department of Health Environment (KDHE) and affected local health departments are working closely together to identify cases and implement appropriate isolation and exclusion policies to prevent further spread of mumps. Many cases have reported attendance to wrestling tournaments in Kansas, have associations to the University of Kansas or Kansas State University, or reported travel to other states that are also currently experiencing large mumps outbreaks.\n\nAs of 4 Mar 2017, there have been 56 cases reported. Crawford and Douglas Counties have recorded the most mumps with 13 and 11 cases, respectively. The map below by KDHE indicates counties with mumps cases.\n\nCases range from age 14 to 57 years with a median age of 20 years. Three patients reportedly had complications to mumps and one person required hospitalization for their illness. Of these reported cases, 44 (82%) were vaccinated, 6 (11%) were not vaccinated, 4 (7%) with unknown vaccination history and 2 cases with vaccination history not yet assessed.\n\nCalifornia\n---------\nThe Los Angeles County Department of Public Health (LAC DPH) is investigating 2 clusters of mumps cases occurring in adult men in Los Angeles County. As of 9 Mar 2017, there have been 5 confirmed and 2 likely cases of mumps reported in adult men; the majority have been in HIV uninfected men who have sex with men. Contact investigations are ongoing.\n\nThe health department advises health care providers to consider the diagnosis of mumps among patients presenting with parotitis, other salivary gland swelling, and/or orchitis, even if patients have been vaccinated.\n\nMissouri\n-------\nThe Southeast Missouri State University continues to receive reports of students presenting to their health care provider or the Campus Health Clinic with symptoms of mumps. As of 9 Mar 2017, the University has received 36 confirmed reports of Southeast students infected with mumps (up from 15 cases reported a week ago).\n\nA majority of the confirmed cases are generally among students who are members of the university's Greek student community, specifically the fraternity community. Additionally, the campus has suspected cases of mumps from students who are symptomatic, and these students are currently self-quarantined while their test results are evaluated by the State of Missouri. All confirmed cases are shared with the Cape Girardeau County Public Health Center, and the campus has been working with both local and State of Missouri public health agencies in response to the confirmed and suspected cases.\n\nOklahoma\n---------\nThe Tulsa Health Department (THD) is currently investigating an outbreak of mumps in Tulsa County. There have been 8 cases identified, 5 of which have been laboratory confirmed. One of the confirmed cases is a student at the 7th Grade Center at Owasso Public Schools.\n\nTHD health officials are following standard disease investigation and response protocols which include working with individuals who have potentially been exposed through close contact with the confirmed and probable cases. THD is working closely with the Owasso Public Schools administration to ensure that students, parents and teachers who may have been exposed are notified and receive guidance on what precautions they may need to take.\n\nPersons who may have been exposed should have their immunization status evaluated, watch for signs and symptoms, and seek medical attention as soon as symptoms suggestive of mumps begin. Additionally, THD officials are notifying area clinics and hospitals to provide clinical guidance to health care providers.\n\nTexas\n-----\nDallas County Health and Human Services (DCHHS) is reporting 39 mumps cases in Dallas County for 2017. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends reporting all probable and confirmed cases of mumps when an outbreak occurs.\n\nDCHHS has identified 30 associated mumps cases between students and teachers in Cedar Hill High School. Not all cases are Dallas County residents. DCHHS has a separate total of 9 additional unrelated mumps cases in the city of Mesquite and Dallas.\n\nFor medical confidentiality and personal privacy reasons, DCHHS does not provide additional identifying information. DCHHS health officials are urging immunization to protect against and prevent the spread of mumps. People who have had 2 mumps vaccinations (such as 2 MMR vaccines) are usually considered immune from mumps. A 3rd dose of the MMR vaccine is only recommended by the CDC when an individual is associated with an ongoing outbreak.\n\nLouisiana\n--------\nThe Louisiana State University Student Health Center, working with the Louisiana Department of Health, has confirmed several student cases of the mumps.\n\nStudents with swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears or jaw on one or both sides of the face are advised to seek care at the Student Health Center or with their primary care provider as soon as possible.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap of the US may be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Louisiana, Louisiana State University)\nDate: Fri 10 Mar 2017\nSource: WAFB [edited]\nhttp://www.wafb.com/story/34727336/several-cases-of-mumps-confirmed-at-lsu\n\n\nThe LSU Student Health Center, along with the Louisiana Department of Health, have confirmed several cases of the mumps among the students.\n\nSince mumps is a contagious disease, the university is providing information to protect its students, faculty, and staff.\n\nThe school says students with swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears or jaw on one or both sides of the face should seek medical care at the Student Health Center or with their primary care physician as soon as possible.\n\nStudents exhibiting symptoms of mumps should be isolated for at least 5 days from the onset of salivary gland swelling. There is no specific treatment for mumps, however most people who contract the illness fully recover. Mumps can occasionally cause complications, some of them serious. Infected persons are typically contagious from 3 days before until up to 9 days after the onset of symptoms.\n\nMumps is spread by contact with infectious respiratory tract secretions and saliva. To help prevent transmission of the illness, people [who are infected] should follow these tips:\n- Practice good hand washing.\n- Do not eat or drink around others.\n- Cover nose and mouth with a tissue when coughing or sneezing.\n\nReceiving 2 doses of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine is the best way to prevent mumps. Proof of immunity to mumps or proof of 2 doses of the vaccine is required for all LSU students. However, the vaccine is not 100 percent effective, and the infection can occur even in vaccinated students [But serious complications rarely occur in vaccinated individuals. - Mod.LK].\n\n[Byline: Rachael Thomas]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] USA (Pennsylvania; Penn State University)\nDate: Mon 13 Mar 2017\nSource: Centre Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.centredaily.com/news/local/education/penn-state/article138349188.html\n\n\nOn Mon [13 Mar 2017], Penn State University released new numbers putting what was just 2 cases [of mumps], 1st reported as of 29 Jan 2017, at 38 probable patients. Of those, 17 have been confirmed by lab testing.\n\nThe contagious disease's most famous symptom is swelling of glands on the side of the face or neck, but others include things mistaken for the common cold, like headaches and fever. When it gets serious, it can cause swelling in other areas, like the pancreas, brain and spinal cord, according to the Mayo Clinic.\n\nThe virus can be life-threatening, but other complications can include sterility, miscarriage and hearing loss.\n\n'Students who have developed mumps symptoms have been isolated in accordance with Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and Pennsylvania Department of Health protocols and recommendations, and several of these students have left University Park and returned home during the infectious phase of the illness,' Penn State said in a release.\n\n'University Health Services staff have been in touch with those students who have been in close contact with any confirmed or probable mumps cases. We have excluded students from campus who were identified as a contact of a probable or confirmed case of mumps and could not provide proof of vaccination in an attempt to stop the disease from spreading.'\n\nSimilar treatment is being recommended to students who show symptoms: stay home, avoid contact with others for about 5 days and don't do anything that would involve coming into contact with someone else's saliva.\n\nWhile the CDC says that mumps is no longer common in the United States, Penn State is not the only place it is popping up in 2017. Since 1 Jan 2017, 1077 cases have been reported in 37 states. In 2016, more than 5000 cases were reported, including a number on university campuses. 'The 2 largest outbreaks were from Iowa and Illinois, each involving several hundred university students,' said the CDC.\n\nThe disease has decreased markedly since the 186 000 cases annually in 1967 before vaccinations produced a 99 percent reduction, the Atlanta-based public health institute said.\n\nPenn State warned that vaccinations are not 100 percent effective and still require people to take precautions. 'Most of the confirmed mumps cases are in students who received the CDC-recommended 2 doses of MMR vaccine. While 2 doses of MMR vaccine typically provide adequate immunity to the infection, the vaccination does not guarantee protection. According to the CDC, the mumps component of the MMR vaccine is about 88 percent effective when a person receives 2 doses,' the university said.\n\nStudents who have not been vaccinated or have immunity from a prior infection are being told to schedule appointments for the 2-dose shots at University Health Services or with their own doctors.\n\n'If you cannot show proof of immunity to mumps, you may be excluded from campus for up to 26 days,' Penn State said.\n\nRead more here: http://www.centredaily.com/news/local/education/penn-state/article138349188.html#storylink=cpy.\n\n[Byline: Lori Falce]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Australia (Queensland)\nDate: 14 Mar 2017\nSource: Whit Sunday Times [edited]\nhttps://www.whitsundaytimes.com.au/news/worst-virus-outbreak-20-years-affecting-young-peop/3154400/\n\n\nYoung adults who have long been protected from the threat of mumps may now be at risk as the protection from the vaccine begins to wear off, contributing to the biggest outbreak of its kind in 20 years.\n\nThe Courier-Mail is reporting that the measles, mumps, rubella vaccine may not be working properly, leaving many vulnerable to the mumps virus.\n\nThe largest outbreak of mumps was recorded last year [2016], with 804 cases nationally. Already, there have been 89 diagnosed this year [2017]. Of those, 27% should not have been susceptible because they had been inoculated against the disease through vaccinations given when they turned one, and another while they were under 6.\n\nAustralian Medical Association Queensland specialist Dr Paul Bartley said it was a 'recognised issue.'\n\n'It's difficult to work out what proportion of patients have waning immunity because they tend to only come to medical attention after they get sick,' he told the Courier-Mail. 'It's been pored over by public health professionals ... but nothing has been confirmed about a problem with the vaccine.'\n\nExperts are now considering a 3rd vaccination to help boost the community's protection against mumps. Dr Bartley said the idea was 'under active consideration.'\n\nMumps is a viral illness that causes fever and swollen salivary glands. Serious and potentially lethal complications include inflammation of the brain (encephalitis) or heart muscle (myocarditis). The disease is spread from person to person and is as contagious as the flu (influenza).\n\nMumps is uncommon in developed countries, including Australia, because of the widespread use of the mumps vaccine. Outbreaks still occur, so it is important to continue vaccinating children.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap of Australia may be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'University Health Services staff have been in touch with those students who have been in close contact with any confirmed or probable mumps cases. \n\n'Students who have developed mumps symptoms have been isolated in accordance with Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and Pennsylvania Department of Health protocols and recommendations, and several of these students have left University Park and returned home during the infectious phase of the illness,' Penn State said in a release. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap of the US may be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.] Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap of Australia may be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186.] \n\nThe health department advises health care providers to consider the diagnosis of mumps among patients presenting with parotitis, other salivary gland swelling, and/or orchitis, even if patients have been vaccinated. As of 9 Mar 2017, there have been 5 confirmed and 2 likely cases of mumps reported in adult men; the majority have been in HIV uninfected men who have sex with men. \n\nMumps is uncommon in developed countries, including Australia, because of the widespread use of the mumps vaccine. On Mon [13 Mar 2017], Penn State University released new numbers putting what was just 2 cases [of mumps], 1st reported as of 29 Jan 2017, at 38 probable patients. As of 9 Mar 2017, the University has received 36 confirmed reports of Southeast students infected with mumps (up from 15 cases reported a week ago). \n\nDCHHS has identified 30 associated mumps cases between students and teachers in Cedar Hill High School. MUMPS UPDATE (10)\n*****************\n Most of the confirmed mumps cases are in students who received the CDC-recommended 2 doses of MMR vaccine. ------\nMumps cases have been reported in multiple counties in Kansas. \n\nStudents exhibiting symptoms of mumps should be isolated for at least 5 days from the onset of salivary gland swelling. \n\nThe largest outbreak of mumps was recorded last year [2016], with 804 cases nationally. All confirmed cases are shared with the Cape Girardeau County Public Health Center, and the campus has been working with both local and State of Missouri public health agencies in response to the confirmed and suspected cases. http://www.wafb.com/story/34727336/several-cases-of-mumps-confirmed-at-lsu\n\n\nThe LSU Student Health Center, along with the Louisiana Department of Health, have confirmed several cases of the mumps among the students. \n\nA majority of the confirmed cases are generally among students who are members of the university's Greek student community, specifically the fraternity community. \n\nThe school says students with swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears or jaw on one or both sides of the face should seek medical care at the Student Health Center or with their primary care physician as soon as possible. \n\nSince mumps is a contagious disease, the university is providing information to protect its students, faculty, and staff. \n\nPersons who may have been exposed should have their immunization status evaluated, watch for signs and symptoms, and seek medical attention as soon as symptoms suggestive of mumps begin. \n\nStudents with swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears or jaw on one or both sides of the face are advised to seek care at the Student Health Center or with their primary care provider as soon as possible. Of these reported cases, 44 (82%) were vaccinated, 6 (11%) were not vaccinated, 4 (7%) with unknown vaccination history and 2 cases with vaccination history not yet assessed. \n\nThe disease has decreased markedly since the 186 000 cases annually in 1967 before vaccinations produced a 99 percent reduction, the Atlanta-based public health institute said. The Louisiana State University Student Health Center, working with the Louisiana Department of Health, has confirmed several student cases of the mumps. Additionally, the campus has suspected cases of mumps from students who are symptomatic, and these students are currently self-quarantined while their test results are evaluated by the State of Missouri. People who have had 2 mumps vaccinations (such as 2 MMR vaccines) are usually considered immune from mumps. Receiving 2 doses of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine is the best way to prevent mumps. The Kansas Department of Health Environment (KDHE) and affected local health departments are working closely together to identify cases and implement appropriate isolation and exclusion policies to prevent further spread of mumps. Many cases have reported attendance to wrestling tournaments in Kansas, have associations to the University of Kansas or Kansas State University, or reported travel to other states that are also currently experiencing large mumps outbreaks. \n\nStudents who have not been vaccinated or have immunity from a prior infection are being told to schedule appointments for the 2-dose shots at University Health Services or with their own doctors. \n\n'If you cannot show proof of immunity to mumps, you may be excluded from campus for up to 26 days,' Penn State said. The Courier-Mail is reporting that the measles, mumps, rubella vaccine may not be working properly, leaving many vulnerable to the mumps virus. We have excluded students from campus who were identified as a contact of a probable or confirmed case of mumps and could not provide proof of vaccination in an attempt to stop the disease from spreading.' \n\nWhile the CDC says that mumps is no longer common in the United States, Penn State is not the only place it is popping up in 2017. \nThe Tulsa Health Department (THD) is currently investigating an outbreak of mumps in Tulsa County. The Los Angeles County Department of Public Health (LAC DPH) is investigating 2 clusters of mumps cases occurring in adult men in Los Angeles County. \n\nMumps is a viral illness that causes fever and swollen salivary glands. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends reporting all probable and confirmed cases of mumps when an outbreak occurs. The Southeast Missouri State University continues to receive reports of students presenting to their health care provider or the Campus Health Clinic with symptoms of mumps. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nMumps is spread by contact with infectious respiratory tract secretions and saliva.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2017-02-25 00:00:00", "1077-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Louisiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulsa County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4817357", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (03): USA (AR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4817357", "date": "2017-02-05 18:40:00", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (03): USA (ARKANSAS)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 3 Feb 2017\nSource: Arkansas Matters [edited]\nhttp://www.arkansasmatters.com/news/local-news/mumps-the-latest-cases-in-arkansas/649536109\n\n\nThe Arkansas mumps outbreak continues to spread as 2 more school districts have announced cases.\n\nThe Pocahontas and Benton School Districts each announced a case of the mumps on Fri [3 Feb 2017].\n\nThe outbreak appears to still be primarily contained to the northwestern part of the state. So far, 49 different schools in 17 school districts, 3 colleges or vocational schools and 3 private schools have been affected by the mumps.\n\nArkansas currently leads the nation with more than 2000 mumps cases. The majority of these cases are among schoolchildren, the Arkansas Department of Health (ADH) says.\n\nThe ADH is also looking into 2 unconfirmed cases of the mumps involving students at Arkansas Tech in Russellville.\n\nMumps is spread from an infected person through coughing, sneezing, or contact with saliva. Mumps is a viral infection that causes one or more salivary glands (located in the cheeks, below and in front of the ears) to become inflamed, swollen, and tender. Other symptoms include fever, fatigue, headaches, swelling or tenderness in the neck/jaw area, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, rash, and flu-like symptoms.\n\nThe best way to prevent mumps is through vaccination. The mumps vaccination is given in combination as MMR or MMRV with measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella. Most students have received 1-2 MMR vaccinations. If you haven't received a vaccination for mumps, the MMR is available in the Health and Wellness Center. Keeping hands clean, coughing or sneezing into a tissue or your elbow, and refraining from sharing drinking or eating utensils are also important steps in preventing the spread of the illness.\n\n[Byline: Ellen Lampe]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the past several years, increasing numbers of college students and others have started getting mumps in spite of an effective vaccine, and 2016 marks the biggest spike in a decade. Seven states (Arkansas, Iowa, Indiana, Illinois, Massachusetts, New York and Oklahoma) have each reported more than 100 cases this year [2017]. [As of 31 Dec 2016, 46 states and the District of Columbia in the U.S. reported mumps infections in 5311 people to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Eight states have reported more than 100 cases this year [2017]: AR, IA, IN, IL, MA, NY, OK, and TX (data from CDC), with about half occurring in Arkansas in a variety of schools, workplaces and colleges. By comparison, in 2010, there were 2612 cases reported to the U.S. CDC, and in 2012, there were 229.\n\nMost mumps patients said they had received their 2 recommended doses of the combined measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine, according to the CDC. In Arkansas, the state with the largest outbreak, around 70 percent of the mumps patients self-reported that they were fully vaccinated against mumps, according to the CDC.\n\nSo what's behind the comeback? One factor may be that the vaccine's effectiveness appears to wane over 10 or 15 years, says William Schaffner, an infectious diseases specialist at Vanderbilt University Medical Center. Exactly why this year [2017] has been such a large problem, however, climbing to more than 4000 cases, remains a mystery. 'That has all of us puzzled,' Schaffner says. Vaccination coverage rates in the worst-affected states of Arkansas, Illinois and Iowa are generally high. All have 2-dose coverage rates of around 90 percent or better, according to the CDC.\n\nJanell Routh, a medical officer in the CDC's Division of Viral Diseases, says this year's [2017] sudden increase may simply be cyclical. 'We know generally that mumps cases wax and wane over the years. This year, in particular, we know the spike was driven by 3 large outbreaks,' she says.\n\nScientists agree that mumps outbreaks often occur in crowded environments where people may come into contact with one another's saliva or mucus via things like sharing food or drinks, or kissing. 'The virus is always out there,' says Paul Offit, a pediatrics professor at The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia. 'The most likely reason for these outbreaks is that vaccine immunity is fading,' he says. Routh says the agency still does not have strong enough evidence to answer that type of question. 'We don't know the level of antibody required to stop a case of mumps in a person, so that question of knowing whether the vaccine works less well over time is something we're still working to investigate,' she says.\n\nOther theories to explain the spike do not check out either, according to the CDC. It does not appear that the virus has mutated in a way that would make vaccines less effective against it, Routh says, noting that the main genotype of the virus in the U.S. has remained the same over the past decade. There is also no evidence the virus is being imported by unwitting travelers or students, Routh adds. 'We know the mumps vaccine is only 88 percent effective after 2 doses, so that means a certain portion of vaccinated people are still vulnerable,' she says, which underscores the possibility the cases could be home-grown. Also, the fact that about 30 percent of mumps cases are asymptomatic makes it difficult to trace outbreaks to one particular person, she says.\n\nThis winter [2016-2017], the CDC's Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices will consider whether or not to recommend a 3rd dose of the vaccine, Routh says. Her agency's guidelines already include administering a 3rd dose of the vaccine during an outbreak. So far, the effectiveness of this has not been established, but the CDC says it is working with college campuses that have had outbreaks in the past to assess the effectiveness of their emergency 3rd-dose campaigns. For now, Schaffner says, parents should check with their pediatricians to make sure their children are up to date on immunizations, and, if they are unsure, they should get their child a 3rd MMR vaccination.\n\n(Excerpted and edited from DF Maron. Scientific American. 16 Dec 2016 https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/whats-behind-the-2016-mumps-spike-in-the-u-s/.)\n\nA map showing the location of Arkansas in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/208. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the past several years, increasing numbers of college students and others have started getting mumps in spite of an effective vaccine, and 2016 marks the biggest spike in a decade. We know the mumps vaccine is only 88 percent effective after 2 doses, so that means a certain portion of vaccinated people are still vulnerable,' she says, which underscores the possibility the cases could be home-grown. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Most mumps patients said they had received their 2 recommended doses of the combined measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine, according to the CDC. colleges.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella", "varicella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2612-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "5311-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russellville", "country": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (04): USA (WA), New Zealand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4830961", "date": "2017-02-11 11:35:23", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (04): USA (WA), NEW ZEALAND\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (Washington)\n[2] New Zealand\n\n******\n[1] USA (Washington)\nDate: Tue 7 Feb 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/washington-mumps-outbreak-least-387-cases-36529/\n\n\nThe Spokane Regional Health District reported 152 cases of mumps in Spokane County as of [Sun 5 Feb 2017], with several more under investigation, therefore, the number is expected to grow in coming days.\n\nIn King County, the number of current cases in the county stands at 179 (72 confirmed, 107 probable), with 61.5 percent reported as up-to-date on MMR vaccine.\n\nAs of [Tud 7 Feb 2017] 44 confirmed and probable cases have been reported in Pierce County.\n\nThese and 5 other Washington counties that are reported mumps cases in the single digits puts the state's mumps outbreak to at least 387 as of this writing.\n\nMumps is caused by a virus. It is usually rare in the United States because most people have received immunizations to protect them against mumps. People born before 1957 are probably immune to mumps because most people had the disease before the immunizations were routinely given starting in the early 1970s.\n\nMumps is spread by close face-to-face contact with a person who has the infection.\n\nMumps is best known for the puffy cheeks and swollen jaw that it causes. This is a result of swollen salivary glands.\nThe most common symptoms include:\n- Fever\n- Headache\n- Muscle Aches\n- Tiredness\n- Loss of Appetite\n- Swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears on one of both sides (parotitis).\n\nSymptoms usually appear 16-18 days after infection, but this period can range from 12-25 days after infection. Some people who get mumps have very mild or no symptoms, and often they do not know they have the disease.\n\nA person with mumps should avoid prolonged, close contact with other people until at least 5 days after the start of the swollen glands because the person is contagious during this time. People who have mumps should not go to work or school, and stay home while they are contagious (5 days after the onset of gland swelling).\n\nThe MMR vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. People who have received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine are about 9 times less likely to get mumps than unvaccinated people who have the same exposure to mumps virus. However, some people who receive 2 doses of MMR can still get mumps, especially if they have prolonged, close contact with someone who has the disease, and it has been several years since they were vaccinated. If a vaccinated person does get mumps, they will likely have less severe illness than an unvaccinated person.\n\nBefore there was a vaccine, mumps was a common childhood disease in the United States. In some cases, the disease caused complications, such as permanent deafness in children and, occasionally, swelling of the brain (encephalitis), which in rare cases caused death. From year to year, the number of mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. In some years, there are more cases of mumps than usual because of outbreaks.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n2016-2017 Washington State Emerging Mumps Outbreak\n\n[According to preliminary data reported to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the number of infectious mumps cases in the United States is at a 10-year high. As of 3 Dec 2016, 4258 cases of mumps have been reported across 45 states and the District of Columbia - more than twice the number of mumps cases reported in 2015. Most of these cases are linked to a number of schools and college campuses who are reporting a surge in outbreak activity. As of 5 Jan 2017, Washington State is reporting a total of 151 cases of infectious mumps outbreaks (55 confirmed and 96 probable) in King, Pierce, Snohomish, Spokane, and Yakima counties.\n\nExcerpted from http://www.samishtribe.nsn.us/2016-2017-washington-state-emerging-mumps-outbreak/]\n\n[Note the case number appears to have more than doubled in the last month [January 2017], but this could be a\nreporting artifact. - Mod.LK]\n\n[The state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248. A county map can be seen at <http://geology.com/county-map/washington-county-map.gif.]\n\n******\n[2] New Zealand\nDate: Thu 9 Feb 2017 9:08 am\nSource: Radio NZ [edited]\nhttp://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/324117/mumps-outbreak-concern-after-case-numbers-rise\n\n\nHealth officials fear there could be an outbreak of mumps after 20 cases were reported in just 5 months - up to triple the usual rate.\n13 cases were reported in Auckland, while Rotorua and Taupo each had 3 cases. Cases were also reported in Wellington (2), Canterbury (1) and the West Coast (1).\n\nThe Ministry of Health said it appeared most of the cases had been acquired overseas, and had affected people between the ages of 2 and 31.\n\nThere was an increased risk of further outbreaks so people should check they were immunized, the ministry said.\n\nDeputy director of public health Harriett Carr said the rise in mumps cases usually stemmed from people not being immunized.\n'With these 20 cases among children and young adults, we think most have come from Fiji where there is a mumps outbreak at the moment,' she said.\n\n'There's always a chance people will pick up an illness and bring it back here when they're travelling, so the best thing we can do is make sure we have good immunization rates and that people are aware of the symptoms of these illnesses.'\n\nSymptoms of the viral illness include sore and swollen areas under the jaw, usually accompanied or preceded by fever, muscle soreness, poor appetite, and fatigue.\n\nMany people were unaware that mumps could be a serious illness, Dr Carr said. About 1 in 10 people get meningitis and there are other, rarer serious consequences.\nThe start of the school year heightened the possibility of further cases, she said. 'People should keep their children home if they think they might have mumps and contact their GP and Healthline.'\n\n[Byline: Sally Murphy]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[While most of these cases were likely acquired out of the country, it highlights the importance of maintaining a high level of immunity in the local population since the virus can be introduced with infected individuals. - Mod.LK\n\nA map of New Zealand may be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n2016-2017 Washington State Emerging Mumps Outbreak\n\n[According to preliminary data reported to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the number of infectious mumps cases in the United States is at a 10-year high. The most common symptoms include:\n- Fever\n- Headache\n- Muscle Aches\n- Tiredness\n- Loss of Appetite\n- Swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears on one of both sides (parotitis). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[While most of these cases were likely acquired out of the country, it highlights the importance of maintaining a high level of immunity in the local population since the virus can be introduced with infected individuals. \n\nThese and 5 other Washington counties that are reported mumps cases in the single digits puts the state's mumps outbreak to at least 387 as of this writing. As of 3 Dec 2016, 4258 cases of mumps have been reported across 45 states and the District of Columbia - more than twice the number of mumps cases reported in 2015. \n\nDeputy director of public health Harriett Carr said the rise in mumps cases usually stemmed from people not being immunized. There's always a chance people will pick up an illness and bring it back here when they're travelling, so the best thing we can do is make sure we have good immunization rates and that people are aware of the symptoms of these illnesses.'\n\nSymptoms of the viral illness include sore and swollen areas under the jaw, usually accompanied or preceded by fever, muscle soreness, poor appetite, and fatigue. People who have received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine are about 9 times less likely to get mumps than unvaccinated people who have the same exposure to mumps virus. \n\n[Byline: Sally Murphy]\n\n--\n MUMPS UPDATE (04): USA (WA), NEW ZEALAND\n****************************************\n http://outbreaknewstoday.com/washington-mumps-outbreak-least-387-cases-36529/\n\n\nThe Spokane Regional Health District reported 152 cases of mumps in Spokane County as of [Sun 5 Feb 2017], with several more under investigation, therefore, the number is expected to grow in coming days. \n13 cases were reported in Auckland, while Rotorua and Taupo each had 3 cases. \n\nThe Ministry of Health said it appeared most of the cases had been acquired overseas, and had affected people between the ages of 2 and 31. As of 5 Jan 2017, Washington State is reporting a total of 151 cases of infectious mumps outbreaks (55 confirmed and 96 probable) in King, Pierce, Snohomish, Spokane, and Yakima counties. A person with mumps should avoid prolonged, close contact with other people until at least 5 days after the start of the swollen glands because the person is contagious during this time. http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/324117/mumps-outbreak-concern-after-case-numbers-rise\n\n\nHealth officials fear there could be an outbreak of mumps after 20 cases were reported in just 5 months - up to triple the usual rate. \n\nMany people were unaware that mumps could be a serious illness, Dr Carr said. \n\nMumps is spread by close face-to-face contact with a person who has the infection. In some cases, the disease caused complications, such as permanent deafness in children and, occasionally, swelling of the brain (encephalitis), which in rare cases caused death. From year to year, the number of mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-02-09 09:08:00", "2017-01-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2017-02-07 00:00:00", "2017-01-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-12-03 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "4258-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canterbury", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spokane", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spokane County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wellington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "King County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yakima", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Auckland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Healthline", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pierce County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4713168", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (02): (QC) HCWs", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4713168", "date": "2016-12-21 16:37:02", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (02): (QUEBEC) HEALTHCARE WORKERS\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Dec 2016 14:18 EST\nSource: La Tribune [in French, trans. & edited Corr.SB]\nhttp://www.lapresse.ca/la-tribune/actualites/sherbrooke/201612/19/01-5052804-des-cas-doreillons-chez-des-employes-du-ciusss-chus.php\n\n\nCases of mumps in health care workers at the Hopital Fleurimont and Hotel-Dieu in Sherbrooke [Quebec] have been confirmed by the Estrie Public Health Department.\n\nThe reported cases, 4 confirmed and 1 probable, have all been investigated and there is no evidence of transmission of the disease among contacts of the patients at this time. Control measures were immediately put in place to limit the spread of the infection.\n\nMumps is a notifiable contagious disease that manifests as fever and swelling of the parotid glands in front of the ears. The disease usually resolves by itself in 3-10 days, but complications are relatively frequent.\n\nThe people who circulated between 1 and 13 Dec [2016] in the areas (surgery, radiology, emergency, intensive care, and the fetal and maternal clinic of the Fleurimont Hospital and surgery of the Hotel-Dieu, hospital) are asked to keep a look out for the appearance of symptoms and to consult a physician if necessary.\n\nPeople with symptoms are advised to wear a mask when visiting their doctor or other healthcare setting. The infectious period extends from 2 days before to up to 5 days after the onset of symptoms, according to a press release.\n\nAccording to the Public Health Directorate, the 5 workers were removed from the workplace and urged to wear a mask until the end of their contagious period. Staff and physicians who were in close contact with these workers were advised to withdraw immediately from work if symptoms consistent with mumps developed.\n\nIn addition, other workers who may have been in contact with infected persons have been advised to monitor their symptoms and to consult a physician if they develop. All of these people were advised to check their immunization status and update it as needed.\n\nThe disease resolves itself in 3-10 days, without treatment, the authorities said. It is transmitted by contact with respiratory secretions or saliva. The symptoms appear between 12 and 25 days.\n\n'The potential complications of mumps are relatively frequent, but permanent sequelae are rare,' says Dr Melissa Genereux, director of public health in the Eastern Townships.\n\nIn most cases, this disease does not cause a major health problem. On the other hand, some complications can occur, including meningitis (10 percent), inflammation of the testicles (20-30 percent in pubertal men) or ovaries (5 percent in pubescent women). More rarely, mumps [can] cause pancreatitis (2-5 percent of cases), encephalitis (1 to 2 cases per 10 000), deafness (1 in 20 000 cases), arthritis, or inflammation of the thyroid gland. The disease can cause a miscarriage in pregnant women in the 1st trimester.\n\nMumps [is] present all over the world and outbreaks continue to be recorded. This disease is rather rare in Quebec since vaccination because the last outbreak occurred in 2010 with 674 confirmed cases.\n\nPeople born before 1970 are [assumed to have acquired natural immunity to mumps]. For people born after 1970, it is possible to prevent this disease through vaccination.\n\nIn Quebec, the free vaccination program includes 2 doses of mumps vaccine in the same vaccine as the measles and rubella vaccine. Prior to 1996, a single dose was administered. A person who has received at least 1 dose is considered to have adequate vaccination.\n\n[Byline: Rene Marquis]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at http://mapsof.net/uploads/static-maps/Canada_Provinces_and_territories_map.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20676. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n More rarely, mumps [can] cause pancreatitis (2-5 percent of cases), encephalitis (1 to 2 cases per 10 000), deafness (1 in 20 000 cases), arthritis, or inflammation of the thyroid gland. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at http://mapsof.net/uploads/static-maps/Canada_Provinces_and_territories_map.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20676. The people who circulated between 1 and 13 Dec [2016] in the areas (surgery, radiology, emergency, intensive care, and the fetal and maternal clinic of the Fleurimont Hospital and surgery of the Hotel-Dieu, hospital) are asked to keep a look out for the appearance of symptoms and to consult a physician if necessary. \n\nThe disease resolves itself in 3-10 days, without treatment, the authorities said. \n\n'The potential complications of mumps are relatively frequent, but permanent sequelae are rare,' says Dr Melissa Genereux, director of public health in the Eastern Townships. \n\nMumps is a notifiable contagious disease that manifests as fever and swelling of the parotid glands in front of the ears. On the other hand, some complications can occur, including meningitis (10 percent), inflammation of the testicles (20-30 percent in pubertal men) or ovaries (5 percent in pubescent women). \n\nPeople with symptoms are advised to wear a mask when visiting their doctor or other healthcare setting. \n\nPeople born before 1970 are [assumed to have acquired natural immunity to mumps]. The infectious period extends from 2 days before to up to 5 days after the onset of symptoms, according to a press release. The reported cases, 4 confirmed and 1 probable, have all been investigated and there is no evidence of transmission of the disease among contacts of the patients at this time. Staff and physicians who were in close contact with these workers were advised to withdraw immediately from work if symptoms consistent with mumps developed. In Quebec, the free vaccination program includes 2 doses of mumps vaccine in the same vaccine as the measles and rubella vaccine.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["1970-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4860461", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (05): USA (PA, MO - RFI), Canada (ON, AB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4860461", "date": "2017-02-23 22:46:30", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (05): USA (PENNSYLVANIA. MISSOURI - REQUEST FOR INFORMATION), CANADA (ONTARIO, ALBERTA)\n****************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (Pennsylvania)\n[2] USA (Missouri) RFI\n[3] Canada (Ontario, Toronto)\n[4] Canada (Alberta)\n\n******\n[1] USA (Pennsylvania)\nDate: Sun 12 Feb 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/mumps-reported-penn-state-campus-advised-30144/\n\n\nPenn State University Health Services (UHS) is reporting that 2 cases of mumps have been confirmed on the University Park campus.\n\nThe students were isolated in accordance with Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and Pennsylvania Department of Health protocols and recommendations, and UHS staff have been in touch with those who have been in close contact with the individuals. The Pennsylvania Department of Health is monitoring the situation.\n\nMumps is a highly infectious disease passed through saliva and respiratory secretions. Symptoms often include tender swollen glands below the ear or along the jawline on one or both sides of the face and neck, headache, fever and cold-like symptoms. People with mumps are considered infectious from 2 days before swelling begins through 5 days after the start of swelling. For most people, 2 doses of the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine provide adequate immunity to the infection.\n\nUniversity Health Services, a unit of Penn State Student Affairs, advises the following:\nAll students, faculty and staff should check with their health care providers to confirm receipt of 2 doses of the MMR vaccine after their 1st birthday. Anyone who does not have immunity to mumps either through receipt of the 2-dose MMR vaccine or a previous mumps infection, should schedule an appointment to receive the vaccine.\n\nAll students who have not already done so are advised to request a copy of their immunization information from their private healthcare provider to be faxed to University Health Services. During a mumps outbreak, anyone who does not have proof of vaccination may be excluded from campus until 25 days after the last possible date of infection.\n\nAvoid sharing food and drinks, engaging in drinking games, or other activities that may result in saliva exposure. In addition, frequent hand hygiene and respiratory etiquette are also helpful in preventing the spread of this and many other diseases.\n\nAlthough the 2-dose MMR series is highly effective for most people, it is important to remember that no vaccine is 100 percent effective for every person. Unfortunately, there is not a good way to determine who has not developed immunity from the 2-dose vaccine series.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the United States showing the location of Pennsylvania can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/227]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Missouri) RFI\nDate: Mon 13 Feb 2017 5:12 p.m. CT\nSource: News Leader [edited]\nhttp://www.news-leader.com/story/news/education/2017/02/13/and-then-there-were-5-another-sps-student-tests-positive-mumps/97871010/\n\n\nA 5th case of mumps has been confirmed among Springfield Public Schools students.\n\nIn a [Mon 13 Feb 2017] alert, the district informed parents that a student at Westport Middle School had contracted the contagious disease, which is caused by a virus.\n\nIt came 72 hours after a Friday alert that a student at Carver Middle School also had the mumps.\n\nThey join 3 other students -- one at Central High School and 2 at Bissett Elementary -- who tested positive for mumps earlier this school year [September 2016]. The 3 lived in the same household.\n\nWestport and Bissett are in northwest Springfield, Central is in Midtown and Carver is in the southwest.\n\nUniversity of Missouri reports 31 confirmed mumps cases. Mumps typically includes a fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite and swollen salivary glands.\n\nThe Springfield-Greene County Health Department has not yet declared a mumps 'outbreak' in the area, noting there is no evidence to suggest a 'person-to-person' spread locally.\n\nKendra Findley, administrator of community health and epidemiology, said all 5 of the cases have been linked to an outbreak in northwest Arkansas.\n\nA confirmed mumps case is fairly rare because most individuals have built up an immunity to the disease.\n\nThe vaccine has been around since the 1950s and includes 2 shots, the 1st when a child is a toddler and the 2nd toward the end of elementary school.\n\nThe first 3 Springfield students to test positive, the ones who belonged to the same family, had all taken the vaccine. It is not yet clear if the Carver or Westport students had taken the shots.\n\n'Most of the ones we've dealt with so far have been immunized,' Findley said.\n\nShe said the outbreak in northwest Arkansas involves a virus with a 'strain or genotype' that is a little different and has been contracted by individuals who have been vaccinated.\n\nThere is no known treatment for mumps but children typically recover fully in a few weeks. However, there can be serious consequences for adults who contract the disease. She said adults can develop swelling in the brain, ovaries or testicles. That can cause infertility and even death.\n\nIn the district's health alert, officials stated that if an outbreak is declared, students that have not yet been vaccinated for mumps may be 'excluded' or told to stay home for up to 26 days.\n\nThe district is required to track and report vaccine compliance. At this point, 98 percent of students have received the recommended vaccines based on their age. The other 2 percent have sought medical or religious exemptions.\n\nThe Springfield district, in collaboration with the Springfield-Greene County Health Department, urged families interested in obtaining the immunization to contact their health care provider.\n\n[Byline: Claudette Riley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The report states that all 5 cases have been linked to an outbreak in northwest Arkansas. The Arkansas Department of Health (ADH) reported in November 2016 that in that outbreak, 90 to 95 percent of school-aged children and 30 to 40 percent of adults had been fully immunized.\n\nThis prompted health officials to look at the effectiveness of the mumps portion of the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine. According to state epidemiologist, Dirk Haselow, MD, PhD, the mumps strain seen in Arkansas is the most genetically distinct from the type used to make the vaccine. Haselow said the strain of the virus making the rounds may have evolved enough to surmount the vaccine, though he added that this hasn't yet been confirmed. [Excerpted and edited from http://bit.ly/2gowTGo]\n\n[If anyone has any further information on the genetics of the circulating strain of mumps, please let ProMED know. - Mod.LK]\n\n[A map of the United States showing the location of Missouri can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/227]\n\n******\n[3] Canada (Ontario, Toronto)\nDate: Wed 22 Feb 2017\nSource: The Star [edited]\nhttps://www.thestar.com/news/city_hall/2017/02/22/toronto-mumps-outbreak-might-be-linked-to-bars.html\n\n\nToronto mumps outbreak might be linked to bars. The city says 14 people have been confirmed to have mumps, which is highly contagious and can sicken people for 10 days\n\nToronto Public Health is warning the public about an outbreak of mumps that may be spreading in downtown bars.\n\nThe agency is investigating 14 lab-confirmed cases of the contagious disease, and other cases under investigation, with all those sickened between the ages of 18 and 35.\n\n'The investigation to date has identified that many of these cases have frequented bars in the west downtown core of Toronto. This may be a contributing factor in the circulation of this viral infection,' the release states.\n\nThe mumps virus, found in saliva and respiratory droplets, is spread through coughing, sneezing, and coming into contact with saliva by kissing or sharing drinks, utensils, food or water bottles.\n\n'A major factor contributing to outbreaks is being in a crowded environment, such as attending the same class, playing on the same sports team or living in a dormitory with a person who has the mumps,' public health says,\n\nThe risk to the general public from the infection is 'low' but people with concerns are advised to check the immunization records of themselves and family members.\n\nMumps symptoms include: swelling and pain in salivary glands in the sides of cheeks and jaw; fever; headache; muscle aches and pains; fatigue; and loss of appetite. Symptoms can last up to 10 days.\n\nComplications can include encephalitis, an infection in the brain; meningitis, an infection in the lining of the brain; painful swelling of the testicles or the ovaries; pancreatitis; and hearing loss. Pregnant women who become infected with mumps during the 1st 3 months of pregnancy are at risk of miscarriage\n\nPeople who think they have mumps should tell their doctor before arriving at a medical office.\n\nMost Torontonians born between 1970 and 1992 have had either 1 or 0 mumps vaccinations. That makes them more susceptible to infection than those born later, most of whom have had 2 vaccinations - at around 12 months of age and then again between the ages 4 and 6.\n\n[Byline: David Rider]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Spending leisure time in a crowded bar will contribute to mumps cases if immunity is waning or the individual was not fully vaccinated. - Mod.LK]\n\n[A map of Ontario Province, Canada can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/260]\n\n******\n[4] Canada (Alberta)\nDate: Wed 22 Feb 2017\nSource: CBC [edited]\nhttps://ca.news.yahoo.com/6-cases-mumps-reported-medicine-210455829.html\n\n\nAn outbreak of the mumps in the Medicine Hat area has benched several Western Hockey League players, and Alberta Health Services says it's likely just the beginning.\n\nAccording to AHS, there are 9 lab-confirmed cases of mumps the south zone. Seven of those cases are players and coaches with the local WHL team, the Tigers. The other 2 have had direct contact with the team.\n\nVivien Suttorp, lead medical officer of health for southern Alberta, says steps have been taken to contain the spread, which could be province-wide. 'At this point, a lot of that strategy is there's targeted messaging to, for example, hockey teams that might have been exposed,' said Suttorp.\n\nAlberta Health Services has also notified schools and post-secondary institutions across the province and alerted physicians and public health nurses to be on the lookout for symptoms.\n\nHockey teams have been told to ensure locker rooms and equipment is cleaned and to avoid sharing saliva through things like water bottles and towels.\n\nThose showing symptoms -- which include low-level fever, headache and swollen facial glands -- should be isolated for 5 days.\n\nThe 1st player to be diagnosed with the mumps plays for the Brandon Wheat Kings. His case was confirmed on [Tue 7 Feb 2017]. The Tigers' JD was diagnosed just last [Tue 21 Feb 2017].\n\nJD's roommate at his billet family's home had to move out as [he] was quarantined with the illness. He returned to the ice last night, and even scored a goal.\n\n'From what I heard from the other guys it's been a little bit worse for them than me, so I was a little bit lucky there,' he said.\n\nCoach Shawn Clouston said he hopes the worst is over, but as mumps has a 25-day incubation period, they will have to wait and see.\n\n'I think the challenging part is that it does have that long incubation period. I've done so much reading in the past week to try to understand what is going on ... we're hopeful that we're at the end of it.'\n\nIn a statement, the WHL said they have been working closely with medical staff and health authorities to minimize the spread of the virus.\n\n'With the assistance of the health authorities, WHL Clubs' experienced medical and training staff are continuing to ensure sanitization, early detection and quarantine protocols are being followed diligently,' the statement read.\n\nSuttorp said the Medicine Hat area has high vaccination rates, but the rates vary in southern Alberta. CBC News recently reported on vast differences between the communities of Pincher Creek and Fort Macleod.\n\nRates for the mumps, measles and rubella vaccine in Medicine Hat is 89.4 percent.\n\n'Of course, there's always worry with mumps, when we see further spread, that it ends up in some of our lower immunized communities and lower immunized schools,' she said.\n\nThose who contract mumps can experience complications including meningitis, inflammation of the testicles and pancreatitis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Alberta Province, Canada can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/263]\n\n[From 1 Jan -- 28 Jan 2017, 27 states in the U.S. reported mumps infections in 495 people to CDC.\n\nMumps is no longer very common in the United States. From year to year, mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. For example in 2016, there were 5311 cases reported to CDC, and in 2012, there were 229. Before the U.S. mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States (from CDC).\n\nIn Canada in the last 10 years there have been outbreaks of mumps mostly among young adults in British Columbia, Nova Scotia and Alberta. These outbreaks demonstrate how certain population groups are susceptible to getting mumps due to lack of previous vaccination or incomplete vaccination. Data from Canada, the United States, France, the United Kingdom and Finland show that the number of cases of mumps decreased by over 90 percent after mumps vaccine became available. Mumps encephalitis has virtually disappeared from countries with effective vaccination programs. (http://www.immunize.ca/en/diseases-vaccines/mumps.aspx)\n\nIn spite of the seeming upturn in cases, this is an impressive decrease in incidence of disease due solely to the success of the MMR vaccine. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/263.]", "summary": "\n\n'A major factor contributing to outbreaks is being in a crowded environment, such as attending the same class, playing on the same sports team or living in a dormitory with a person who has the mumps,' public health says,\n\nThe risk to the general public from the infection is 'low' but people with concerns are advised to check the immunization records of themselves and family members. [4] Canada (Alberta)\n\n******\n \n\nAlberta Health Services has also notified schools and post-secondary institutions across the province and alerted physicians and public health nurses to be on the lookout for symptoms. \n\nThe Springfield district, in collaboration with the Springfield-Greene County Health Department, urged families interested in obtaining the immunization to contact their health care provider. \n\nAll students who have not already done so are advised to request a copy of their immunization information from their private healthcare provider to be faxed to University Health Services. Before the U.S. mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. \n\n'The investigation to date has identified that many of these cases have frequented bars in the west downtown core of Toronto.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["5311-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-11-25 00:00:00", "2017-02-13 17:12:00", "2016-09-25 00:00:00", "2017-01-28 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-02-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pincher Creek", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Carver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "PENNSYLVANIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Springfield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4723331", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (34): (AR,TX,MO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4723331", "date": "2016-12-26 10:43:43", "main_text": "MUMPS-USA (34): (ARKANSAS, TEXAS, MISSOURI)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Arkansas (Marshallese)\n[2] Texas: cheerleading competitions\n[3] Missouri (Kansas City)\n\n******\n[1] Arkansas (Marshallese)\nDate: Fri 23 Dec 2016 5:12 PM EST\nSource: El Nuevo Herald, The Associated Press (AP) report [in Spanish, trans. Mod.LK, edited]\nhttp://www.elnuevoherald.com/vivir-mejor/salud/article122039909.html\n\n\nAccording to health officials, an epidemic of mumps is seriously affecting a community of citizens of the Marshall Islands residents of northwest Arkansas.\n\nCitizens of the Marshall Islands represent approximately 60 percent of the 2220 cases of mumps reported in the state through [Fri 23 Dec 2016]. The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette newspaper reported that the outbreak began in August 2016 (http://bit.ly/2hVVQYf).\n\nNate Smith, director of the State Health Department, said he doesn't know why so many people from the Marshall Islands are infected. Officials are investigating whether the vaccine is less effective for certain people. Smith said that the people of the Marshall Islands tend to live close to each other.\n\n'It's a bit like a college dormitory in terms of intensity of exposure,' he explained. Smith added that citizens of the Marshall Islands are involved in many community oriented events, where it is easy for transmission of infections.\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said that the epidemic in Arkansas is the largest since 2009 and 2010 when approximately 3000 people were infected in New York. Smith said that cases of mumps in Arkansas represent more than half of those reported this year [2016] at the national level.\n\nThe Department of Health had vaccinated almost 6600 people up to [Fri 23 Dec 2016]. Smith said that the efforts are showing results because only 12 cases were reported during the last 3 days of last week [week of 12 Dec 2016], 'which is really much less than we had for months.'\n\nThe Marshall Islands are located in the Pacific Ocean, more than 3200 kilometers (2000 miles) southwest of Hawaii. About 12 000 of its citizens live in Northwest Arkansas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a viral illness transmitted by the respiratory route, making dissemination possible in gatherings of people. The report does not specify the vaccination coverage of these citizens of the Marshall Islands who have developed the disease, which could be another factor contributing to this outbreak, apart from the possibility of lower effectiveness of the vaccine. It is necessary to investigate further in order to establish with certainty this behavior of the disease. - Mod.JG\n\nSee ProMED-mail Mumps - USA (21) 20161008.4545923 for reports of cases in other states in the United States -- Oklahoma and Washington -- and a discussion of the particular problem of providing protection to the Marshallese in Arkansas against vaccine-preventable diseases.\n\nA map showing the location of Arkansas in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/208 - Mod. LK]\n\n******\n[2] Texas: cheerleading competitions\nDate: Thu 22 Dec 2016 4:35 PM CST\nSource: KHOU-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.khou.com/news/health/dshs-investigating-two-north-texas-mumps-outbreaks/376855681\n\n\nState health officials are investigating 2 mumps outbreaks, one of which is connected to a series of cheerleading competitions in North Texas.\n\nThe Texas Department State Health Services [DSHS] is working with event organizers to notify those who attended 1 of 4 cheerleading competitions in November and December [2016] that they may have been exposed to mumps. DSHS said it has identified 11 mumps cases associated with this outbreak.\n\nA 2nd outbreak is being investigated in Johnson County, south of Fort Worth. Health officials have identified 72 cases in this outbreak, including 71 Johnson County residents and 1 Tarrant County resident. DSHS is working with school districts in the area to limit its spread since most of the cases are in students.\n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the infected person coughs, sneezes or talks. The virus can also be spread by sharing cups and utensils.\n\nSymptoms include swollen or tender salivary glands, low fever, tiredness and muscle aches. Men can also exhibit swollen or tender testicles.\n\nDSHS said people who are vaccinated can also contract the virus. The spread of mumps can be prevented or limited by covering coughs and sneezes, washing hands frequently with soap and water, and not sharing food or drinks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Texas in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245. A Texas county map can be found at http://geology.com/county-map/texas-county-map.gif.- Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Missouri (Kansas City)\nDate: Sun 25 Dec 2016\nSource: The Monitor Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.themonitordaily.com/mumps/213109/\n\n\nIf you experience fever, headaches, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, it is possible you have contracted mumps.\n\nThe mumps outbreak that has been sweeping through various regions across Missouri lately has spread to Kansas City, as well, according to health officials. At the moment, health agencies state that at least one case of an individual displaying mumps symptoms has been confirmed, says the Kansas City Health Department. As a consequence, an advisory has been issued on Thursday afternoon [22 Dec 2016].\n\nRex Archer, head of the Kansas City Health Department urges people who contracted the disease to stay inside, in order to contain the outbreak, via an official statement. In his plea, Mr Archer asks people to take several days off from either school or work-related duties for at least 5 days after the 1st symptoms emerge, such as the inflammation of the salivary glands. Rex Archer also says that individuals who came in contact with infected people could start displaying mumps symptoms anywhere in between 12 to 25 days after exposure to the virus. Ultimately, he recommends people who develop mumps symptoms to address their health care provider as soon as soon as possible. 'Questions about your immunity or vaccination status should be directed to your private physician', says Rex Archer.\n\nAs of now, roughly 200 cases of infected individuals have been confirmed by the University of Missouri in Columbia. In order to contain the outbreak, Kansas City Health Department officials say that they are closely monitoring the progression of the local case. Not only this, but health officials also give out several tips that could prevent other individuals from contracting the disease.\n\nDoctors strongly recommend citizens to thoroughly wash their hands as often as possible, covering their mouths with anything other than their hands when sneezing, like tissues or elbow, and avoiding sharing spoons, forks, knives, or other eating utensils with infected subjects. Ultimately, the Health Department representatives also believe that one of the best ways for the population to stay mumps-free is by disinfecting surfaces that are frequently touched, such as doorknobs, counters, tables, and handles.\n\n[Byline: John Birks]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Missouri in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4145. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a viral illness transmitted by the respiratory route, making dissemination possible in gatherings of people. \n\nCitizens of the Marshall Islands represent approximately 60 percent of the 2220 cases of mumps reported in the state through [Fri 23 Dec 2016]. \n\nThe Texas Department State Health Services [DSHS] is working with event organizers to notify those who attended 1 of 4 cheerleading competitions in November and December [2016] that they may have been exposed to mumps. The health department reported 10 confirmed cases a week ago. There are now 37, and more are expected to be diagnosed. About half of the cases are among students in the Keene Independent School District [ISD]. The other half are students in Cleburne ISD. There are also 6 adult cases confirmed among staff members at the schools.\n\nJohnson County's health director expects to see more cases through the new year [2017], but he said that after the susceptible population gets it, no one else will.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap showing the location of Texas, United States can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245.]\n\n******\n[2] Risk in colleges\nDate: Tue 13 Dec 2016\nSource: Education Dive [edited]\nhttp://www.educationdive.com/news/colleges-at-center-of-new-mumps-outbreak/432230/\n\n\nCBS News reports on a resurgence in mumps infections throughout the United States, with more than 2800 cases reported this year [2016], nearly double the number of confirmed illnesses in 2015.\n\nThe University of Missouri, which has reported nearly 200 cases of mumps infection this academic year [2016-17], has asked students to refrain from throwing social engagements on campus and asked students to avoid public places like bars in order to stem the outbreak.\n\nHarvard University [Massachusetts] and the State University of New York have each reported more than 60 confirmed mumps cases since last spring [2016], joining dozens of other campuses facing control issues with the disease commonly caused by exposure to sneezing, coughing or sharing cups and utensils.\n\nFor many colleges and universities, the greatest challenge is not in identifying or treating outbreaks among students but in trying to force students to change their social habits so that infection can be properly contained.\n\nFrom a public relations perspective, colleges which deliver information about the infection and quarantine instructions are best prepared for questions from parents, students and the media, and are the most likely to avoid suffering negative reactions in enrollment or coverage according to how transparent they can be about causes and responses to illness outbreaks.\n\n[Byline: Jarrett Carter]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Risk of infection with mumps (and measles) in colleges is high because of waning immunity following childhood vaccination with MMR and close associations among students in such settings. See recent mumps posts for discussion of waning immunity, especially against mumps, following MMR vaccine. While a 3rd vaccine prior to entering college may help control outbreaks, it may not be cost-effective. An alternative approach is to educate students about preventive practices and isolation to control virus transmission once an infected student is identified. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap of the United States may be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\n\n******\n[3] Washington\nDate: Tue 13 Dec 2016\nSource: Patch [edited]\nhttp://patch.com/washington/renton/mumps-outbreak-63-cases-5-local-cities\n\n\nThere are now mumps cases in 5 different cities in King County, plus several more over the border in Pierce County, King County reported Tuesday [13 Dec 2016]. There are now 63 cases -- 12 confirmed, 51 probable -- spread across Auburn, Kent, Federal Way, Black Diamond, and Pacific.\n\nThe outbreak emerged in Auburn 2 weeks ago, and the majority of cases are still located in that city. Health officials are urging the school district there to keep students who are not vaccinated against measles out of school until the outbreak subsides. However, mumps has now appeared in the Federal Way and Kent school districts, King County reported Tue [13 Dec 2016]. 44 of the 63 total cases are in children under age 17.\n\nAbout 67 percent of the people with mumps had received a measles/mumps/rubella (MMR) vaccination. The MMR vaccine is 88 percent effective, but even people who have been vaccinated have a higher chance of getting the virus if they are in close, sustained contact with mumps, health officials say.\n\nStill, health officials in Pierce and King counties recommend people get an MMR vaccination to prevent further spread of the outbreak. Mumps causes flu-like symptoms, plus painful swelling of the face and neck.\n\n[Byline: Neal McNamara]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap showing the location of Washington state, United States, can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Risk of infection with mumps (and measles) in colleges is high because of waning immunity following childhood vaccination with MMR and close associations among students in such settings.
