In this update:\n[1] Texas\n http://www.educationdive.com/news/colleges-at-center-of-new-mumps-outbreak/432230/\n\n\nCBS News reports on a resurgence in mumps infections throughout the United States, with more than 2800 cases reported this year [2016], nearly double the number of confirmed illnesses in 2015. \n\nAbout 67 percent of the people with mumps had received a measles/mumps/rubella (MMR) vaccination. Source: WBAP [edited]\nhttp://www.wbap.com/2016/12/09/mumps-outbreak-in-johnson-co-grows\n\n\nOne of the centers of a national mumps outbreak is in North Texas. \n\n--\n [Byline: Jarrett Carter]\n\n--\n [Byline: Neal McNamara]\n\n--\n [3] Washington\n\n******\n \n\n******\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2037-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-12-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "WASHINGTON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pierce County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johnson County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "King County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4713166", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (33): (TX, AR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4713166", "date": "2016-12-21 16:37:27", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (33): (TEXAS, ARKANSAS)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Texas\n[2] Arkansas\n\n******\n[1] Texas\nDate: Fri 16 Dec 2016\nSource: The Duncan Banner [edited]\nhttp://www.duncanbanner.com/news/precautions-to-take-as-mumps-outbreak-hits-texas/article_c76450fe-e087-5aff-b8b4-cf06140f199e.html\n\n\nLast week [week of 5 Dec 2016], the Texas Department of State Health Services issued an advisory of an outbreak of mumps in Johnson County, with additional cases identified in Collin, Dallas, Denton, and Tarrant Counties [Texas].\n\nRaven Holland, MD, a primary care physician at Family Clinic of Corsicana, explained the virus and what the community should know.\n\n'Mumps affect both children and adults. Infants less than age 1 are less likely to be affected due to passive protection from maternal antibodies, if she [the mother] has adequate immunity,' Dr Holland said.\n\n'The mumps virus is highly contagious and transmitted via spread of respiratory droplets. Transmission is most common among those living or congregating in close quarters (that is, dormitories, grade schools, sports teammates). The average incubation period is between 16-18 days, but may range from 12-25 days.'\n\nTypical symptoms include fever, headache, fatigue, and decreased appetite. These symptoms typically precede the classic symptom of swelling of the salivary glands by 3-5 days. Approximately 20 percent of people do not develop symptoms after infection, so awareness of possible exposure is very important.\n\n'It's important to practice good, frequent handwashing,' said Emily Carroll, director of the Navarro County Health Department. 'It's also important for people to check their immunization records. For more information, the Department of State Health Services website is http://www.dshs.texas.gov.\n\nDiagnostic testing is performed by obtaining a cheek swab for isolation of the virus (recommended) or viral antibody testing. Mumps may also be diagnosed by classic exam findings identified by your primary care provider. Treatment includes supportive care measures, including rest and OTC (over the counter) medications such as acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil) for fevers and pain.\n\nAlthough most people who contract mumps make a full recovery, it is such a public health concern due to serious complications including meningitis, deafness, encephalitis (inflammation of the brain), and orchitis (inflammation of the testicles). Vaccination is highly recommended for prevention.\n\nSince the advent of the mumps vaccine, the number of mumps cases has decreased in the US by over 99 percent. The Center for Disease Control (CDC) recommends that children receive 2 doses of the MMR vaccine between ages 12-15 months and 4-6 years. This vaccine also helps protect against measles and rubella, and 2 doses are 88 percent effective against the spread of the mumps virus. Even if your child has missed a dose, your primary care provider can administer the vaccine by 'catch-up' immunization schedules. Pregnant women should not receive the MMR vaccine. Adequate immunity against mumps is also important for those who travel internationally.\n\nIf you feel that you have these symptoms, contact your primary care provider prior to your appointment to ensure that proper control and safety measures are taken to prevent the spread of the disease to others.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/texas-county-map.gif. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Arkansas\nDate: Mon 19 Dec 2016 5:00PM CST\nSource: Arkansas Matters [edited]\nhttp://www.arkansasmatters.com/news/local-news/arkansas-worst-mumps-outbreak-since-1970s/623061868\n\n\nThe Arkansas mumps outbreak continues with about 2200 cases actively under investigation, a type of outbreak that hasn't been seen since the 1970s.\n\nIn a meeting at the Capitol [Mon 19 Dec 2016], lawmakers got an update on where the outbreak started and what may contribute to its spread, including vaccine exemptions. Health officials have tracked the strain to an initial outbreak at an Iowa college. They say 12 new cases were reported last week [week of 12 Dec 2016].\n\n'Mumps has a long incubation period, around 12-25 days, so we could see an upsurge next week. We're just going to keep doing what we know to do, until it goes away,' said Dr Nate Smith, Director and State Health Officer at the Arkansas Department of Health.\n\nThe Health Department says mumps has spread from Arkansas to Texas and Oklahoma. The Marshallese population in Northwest Arkansas has been especially hard-hit. About 60 percent of the region's cases have affected people in that community.\n\n[Byline: Ellen Lampe]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Arkansas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/208. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/arkansas-county-map.gif.\n\nFor discussion of the increase in mumps cases in the US in 2016, especially Arkansas, please see earlier posts listed below. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245. Date: Mon 19 Dec 2016 5:00PM CST\nSource: Arkansas Matters [edited]\nhttp://www.arkansasmatters.com/news/local-news/arkansas-worst-mumps-outbreak-since-1970s/623061868\n\n\n MUMPS - USA (33): (TEXAS, ARKANSAS)\n***********************************\n \n\nIf you feel that you have these symptoms, contact your primary care provider prior to your appointment to ensure that proper control and safety measures are taken to prevent the spread of the disease to others. \n\n'Mumps has a long incubation period, around 12-25 days, so we could see an upsurge next week. In this update:\n[1] Texas\n Last week [week of 5 Dec 2016], the Texas Department of State Health Services issued an advisory of an outbreak of mumps in Johnson County, with additional cases identified in Collin, Dallas, Denton, and Tarrant Counties [Texas]. [2] Arkansas\n\n******\n \n\n'The mumps virus is highly contagious and transmitted via spread of respiratory droplets. \n\n--\n [Byline: Ellen Lampe]\n\n--\n LK]\n\n******\n This vaccine also helps protect against measles and rubella, and 2 doses are 88 percent effective against the spread of the mumps virus. Since the advent of the mumps vaccine, the number of mumps cases has decreased in the US by over 99 percent. \n\nRaven Holland, MD, a primary care physician at Family Clinic of Corsicana, explained the virus and what the community should know. \n\nThe Health Department says mumps has spread from Arkansas to Texas and Oklahoma. \n\nDiagnostic testing is performed by obtaining a cheek swab for isolation of the virus (recommended) or viral antibody testing.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2033-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-12-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dallas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johnson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northwest Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Collin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4688282", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (30): (WA, NY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4688282", "date": "2016-12-09 17:22:56", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (30): (WASHINGTON, NEW YORK)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Washington: 4 cities\n[2] New York: CDC\n\n******\n[1] Washington: 4 cities\nDate: Wed 7 Dec 2016\nSource: Seattle Patch [edited]\nhttp://patch.com/washington/seattle/mumps-outbreak-44-reported-cases-4-cities\n\n\nMumps Outbreak: 44 Reported Cases in 4 Cities\n--------------------------------------------\nThe outbreak has more than quadrupled within one week.\n\nKing County's daily tally of mumps cases related to a local outbreak grew again Wednesday [7 Dec 2016].\n\nThere are now 44 cases -- 7 confirmed, the rest considered probable mumps. On Tuesday [6 Dec 2016], King County health officials announced that the outbreak had spread beyond Auburn, where it had originated, to Kent, Federal, Way, and Pacific. There are now 3 cases in Kent, and 1 each in Federal Way and Pacific.\n\nHealth officials are urging residents to get vaccinated, saying that it's the best way to avoid the virus -- and the best way to avoid spreading the virus. Mumps causes flu-like symptoms, but also painful swelling of the face, head, and neck.\n\n59 percent of the people who have come down with mumps were immunized. The vaccine is 88 percent effective. Meanwhile, the Auburn School District is being asked to excuse 200 students from school because they are not vaccinated, KING 5 is reporting.\n\nAlso on Wednesday [7 Dec 2016], the Centers for Disease Control reported that the U.S. is seeing the most mumps cases in a decade. There were almost 3000 cases in 45 states as of 5 Nov [2016], the agency reported.\n\n[Byline: Neal McNamara]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Protection from infection following immunization with the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine falls to about 60 per cent for mumps after 10-15 years. Moving the 2nd MMR dose from 3 years old to an older age would leave young children unprotected against measles and rubella, while a 3rd dose of MMR during adolescence might not be cost-effective since the effectiveness of another jab for those already with immunity is uncertain.\n\nIt is thought there would be very little added protection against measles and rubella and it might shift the burden of disease due to waning vaccine-induced immunity to older age groups. No advice has been offered on whether booster doses during outbreaks would work because evidence is limited. The best solution is to reinforce current policy on encouraging families of un- and undervaccinated children to put that right.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps in universities and colleges occur every 3-4 years, and though the highest risk is to completely unvaccinated students, 'it is likely some vaccinated students can catch mumps and pass the infection on to their close contacts without even knowing it' [Public Health England].\n\nExcerpted and edited from https://www.theguardian.com/society/2013/jul/04/rise-mumps-waning-immunity-mmr-vaccine.\n\nA map showing the location of Washington state, United States, can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] New York: CDC\nDate: Thu 8 Dec 2016\nSource: CNY Central [edited]\nhttp://cnycentral.com/news/local/doctors-infection-returns-at-highest-levels-in-a-decade-12-08-2016\n\n\nDoctors: Mumps outbreak returns at highest levels in a decade\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Centers for Disease Control [CDC] is tracking nearly 2900 hundred cases in 45 states, including New York.\n\nThe last time they fielded this many reports of infection was 2006.\n\nDoctors in the Capital Region [Albany, New York] are keeping a close eye on the numbers.\n\n'We feel like this minor outbreak of mumps isn't because of any heinous issue like people refusing immunizations or some contagion happening in some part of the world. What happens is, every couple of years, there's outbreaks in closely knit corners like college campuses, and there's a rise in the mumps,' explained Dr. Jim Saperstone, a pediatrician in the Albany area.\n\nThe CDC says much of the outbreak comes from college campuses.\n\nThe SUNY [State University of New York] system knows of 43 cases right now. 37 of them came from SUNY New Paltz. A spokesperson says all of those patients were immunized -- and all were isolated.\n\n'You can't prevent it. Like more contagious diseases, you're more contagious days before you know you have it. So you could be walking around and spreading it and not even know it,' Saperstone said.\n\nThe telltale signs of mumps are the puffy cheeks and salivary glands, along with a fever and discomfort. Doctors say the symptoms last for a couple of weeks.\n\nMumps can be spread through:\n- Coughing, sneezing or talking\n- Sharing items like cups or eating utensils\n- Touching objects with unwashed hands, which other people then touch\n\nIf you start to see any swelling, or have any questions, call your doctor.\n\nLate this evening [7 Dec 2016], New York's Department of Health provided this statement: 'The NYSDOH continues to provide technical assistance and guidance to local health departments and colleges in response to cases and outbreaks of mumps as they are reported. In settings in which outbreaks have been declared, the Department is recommending that colleges exclude individuals who have not been vaccinated against the mumps, until such time that the outbreak is over. Additionally, the Department has provided measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine to local health departments and colleges so they can vaccinate individuals during outbreaks.'\n\n[Byline: Cody Holyoke]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of New York state, United States, may be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "\n\nMumps can be spread through:\n- Coughing, sneezing or talking\n- Sharing items like cups or eating utensils\n- Touching objects with unwashed hands, which other people then touch\n\nIf you start to see any swelling, or have any questions, call your doctor. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Protection from infection following immunization with the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine falls to about 60 per cent for mumps after 10-15 years. \n\nOutbreaks of mumps in universities and colleges occur every 3-4 years, and though the highest risk is to completely unvaccinated students, 'it is likely some vaccinated students can catch mumps and pass the infection on to their close contacts without even knowing it' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of New York state, United States, may be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234. [1] Washington: 4 cities\n[2] New York: CDC\n\n******\n Source: CNY Central [edited]\nhttp://cnycentral.com/news/local/doctors-infection-returns-at-highest-levels-in-a-decade-12-08-2016\n\n\nDoctors: Mumps outbreak returns at highest levels in a decade\n \n\n[Byline: Cody Holyoke]\n\n--\n \n\nKing County's daily tally of mumps cases related to a local outbreak grew again Wednesday [7 Dec 2016]. MUMPS - USA (30): (WASHINGTON, NEW YORK)\n****************************************\n http://patch.com/washington/seattle/mumps-outbreak-44-reported-cases-4-cities\n\n\nMumps Outbreak: 44 Reported Cases in 4 Cities\n \n\n'We feel like this minor outbreak of mumps isn't because of any heinous issue like people refusing immunizations or some contagion happening in some part of the world. \n\nAlso on Wednesday [7 Dec 2016], the Centers for Disease Control reported that the U.S. is seeing the most mumps cases in a decade. Late this evening [7 Dec 2016], New York's Department of Health provided this statement: 'The NYSDOH continues to provide technical assistance and guidance to local health departments and colleges in response to cases and outbreaks of mumps as they are reported. \n\nThere are now 44 cases -- 7 confirmed, the rest considered probable mumps. \n\nHealth officials are urging residents to get vaccinated, saying that it's the best way to avoid the virus -- and the best way to avoid spreading the virus. [Byline: Neal McNamara]\n\n--\n LK]\n\n******\n \n\n59 percent of the people who have come down with mumps were immunized.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2016-12-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New York 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Albany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WASHINGTON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "King County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "King County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4801141", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (02): USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4801141", "date": "2017-01-29 20:52:57", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (02): USA\n**********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Minnesota ex Washington\n[2] Washington\n[3] Washington\n[4] Colorado\n\n******\n[1] USA (Minnesota ex Washington)\nDate: Fri 13 Jan 2017\nSource: CDC Epi-X [edited]\nhttps://epix2.cdc.gov/v2/Reports/StandardReport/Display.aspx?id=61612&print=False&PSR=False\n\n\nA case of mumps has been reported in an individual who participated in 'The Clash XV', a wrestling tournament in Rochester, MN on 30-31 Dec 2016. Teams from 16 states participated in the event, and wrestlers from 4 states had direct contact with the case and will be notified separately. [A total of 600 individuals were potentially exposed].\n\nThe Minnesota Department of Health received notification from the Washington State Department of Health that a Washington resident who participated in The Clash tournament on 30-31 Dec 2016 was reported as a mumps case in their ongoing outbreak. Symptom onset was early January 2017, and the case was infectious during the wrestling tournament. Participants in the event included individuals from Washington, Minnesota, North Dakota, California, Georgia, Arizona, Illinois, Oregon, Florida, Missouri, Wisconsin, South Dakota, New England, Ohio, Alabama, and Utah. Four states, including Minnesota, Illinois, California, and Oregon had team members who were directly exposed to the case and will be notified individually.\n\nMumps can occur in persons with 2 doses of measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine (MMR) with intense and repeated exposure. Precautions for mumps infection include making sure people are up to date with 2 doses of MMR vaccine, practicing good hand hygiene, and isolating symptomatic persons to avoid other exposures.\n\nWrestlers or other participants who develop parotitis or other mumps-compatible illness (e.g., orchitis, oophoritis) regardless of vaccine status, should follow-up with their health care provider, inform the provider that they may have been exposed to a mumps case, and take precautions against exposing others.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Washington\nDate: Wed 18 Jan 2017\nSource: Bonner County Daily Bee [edited]\nhttp://www.bonnercountydailybee.com/state_news/20170118/mumps_outbreak_threatens_area\n\n\nThere is a mumps outbreak in Spokane, and local health officials say it could be headed our way.\n\nSpokane had 56 cases of mumps as of Tue [17 Jan 2017] evening, and the number is expected to rise.\n\nMelanie Collett, spokeswoman for the Panhandle Health District, said there are no confirmed cases of mumps in North Idaho, but that will likely change, given the region's proximity to Spokane.\n\n'This is a very fluid situation, and we're working with local physicians to make sure any suspect cases are being reported and tested,' Collett said.\n\nMumps, a contagious disease caused by a virus, typically starts with a few days of fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, followed by swollen salivary glands. Mumps is often transmitted by people who are in close contact with one another, such as those living in the same house or dorm. Mumps usually goes away on its own in about 10 days. But in some cases, it can cause complications that affect the brain, the testicles, the ovaries, or the pancreas.\n\nKootenai Health has been alerted the outbreak is nearby and has isolation policies that go into effect if an outbreak of a communicable disease does come into the region.\n\nKim Papich, public information officer for the Spokane Regional Health District, said there is some evidence the Spokane outbreak is linked to a mumps outbreak in Seattle which started in late November 2016 and is still continuing, with 130 cases plus more in 5 surrounding counties.\n\nOf the 56 cases in Spokane, 34 are people who previously received the mumps, measles and rubella (MMR) vaccination. Ten of the cases are people who were not vaccinated, and there are 12 cases in which the vaccination status is unknown.\n\n'This has quickly turned into a polarized discussion on vaccinated and unvaccinated individuals, but we have so many cases that we're beyond that,' Papich said, noting that vaccinated individuals are 9 times less likely to get the mumps. 'We have about 400 000 vaccinated people in Spokane; only 27 of them are sick. If they weren't vaccinated, we'd have 400 000 people with the mumps.'\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2 doses of the vaccine are roughly 88 percent -- with a range of 66 to 95 percent -- effective at protecting against mumps. One dose is 49-92 percent effective.\n\nThe CDC also reports the last big outbreak of mumps in the U.S. was in 2006 when there were more than 6500 cases. Between 2011 and 2015, the national number of cases hovered between about 250 cases to 1500 cases. In 2016, however, the preliminary count was about 5500 cases, mostly concentrated in Iowa and Illinois at college campuses.\n\nThere are one or 2 cases of mumps in Idaho, but that's normal, and they're unlikely to be related to the Spokane outbreak, Papich said.\n\nCory Webster, infection prevention coordinator for Kootenai Health, said that other than vaccination, people can take steps to reduce the likelihood of getting any disease.\n\n'People can stay home from school or work if they're sick, wash hands, appropriately cover coughs, and avoid sharing drinks and eating utensils,' she said. 'Right now, we are educating our staff, patients and visitors.'\n\nWebster encouraged people who are ill to refrain from visiting loved ones at Kootenai Health, and to seek care for themselves.\n\nUltimately, vaccination is the best way to prevent mumps, according to both Panhandle and Spokane Regional health districts.\n\n[Byline: Bethany Blitz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Washington\nDate: Thu 26 Jan 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/washington-mumps-outbreak-nears-300-cases-88245/\n\n\nThe mumps outbreak in Washington state is on the cusp of 300 confirmed and probable cases, as 291 have been reported in 5 counties through Wed [25 Jan 2017].\n\nThe breakdown stands at King County (163), Spokane County (90), Pierce County (34), Snohomish County (3) and Yakima County (1).\n\nIn King County, 63.2 percent of patients report being up to date on their measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine. Roughly the same percentage has been reported as fully vaccinated in Spokane County.\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), mumps is a viral illness that is transmitted by direct contact with respiratory droplets or saliva from an infected person. It is best known for painful, swollen salivary glands that show up as puffy cheeks and swollen jaw.\n\nBoys may also have painful, swollen testicles. Other symptoms include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite.\n\nThere is no treatment, and symptoms usually resolve themselves within a few weeks. Mumps is usually a mild disease in children, but adults may have more serious disease with complications.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Colorado\nDate: Fri 27 Jan 2017\nSource: The Denver Channel [edited]\nhttp://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/local-news/mumps-outbreak-investigated-as-14-diagnosed-in-colorado-11-in-denver-metro\n\n\nA large outbreak of the mumps across the nation could be rippling into Colorado, health officials warned Friday [27 Jan 2017], as 14 cases were diagnosed in January 2017 alone.\n\nColorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) officials launched a large investigation with the Tri-County Health Department and Denver Public Health after 11 patients in Denver and Aurora learned they were diagnosed with the viral infection. Three other patients were diagnosed but aren't believed to be part of the outbreak, which overall could be linked to other states, specifically Washington.\n\nA fact sheet has been disseminated to doctors and physicians in the area, urging them to consider patients who have salivary gland swelling for further testing.\n\nAs mumps cases often go undetected or untested, the outbreak in Colorado is 'likely' to grow, CDPHE officials said.\n\nEven those who are vaccinated are susceptible to mumps, as the vaccine is only roughly 88 percent effective, and effectiveness can wane after the vaccine has been administered.\n\nMumps is an infection spread by direct human-to-human contact through respiratory droplets or saliva. Average incubation periods range from 16 to 18 days on average but can be up to 12 to 25 days.\n\nSymptoms of the infection aren't limited to swelling of salivary and parotid glands across the cheek and jaw area; swelling can range from the frontal part of the ear and spread as fluid builds up. Other symptoms can at times include low-grade fevers, malaise, loss of appetite, headache and more, but not all who have mumps will exhibit symptoms.\n\nSevere complications from the infection are rare but can include sterility, spontaneous abortion, deafness, and more.\n\nThe risks associated with the infection have prompted health officials concerned about the thousands of current cases across the nation to ask parents to be on the lookout.\n\n'Because of the high numbers of mumps cases across the country, it is especially important to make sure your children are vaccinated,' Rachel Herlihy, director of the Disease Control and Environmental Epidemiology Division at the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment, said.\n\n'Both adults and children should make sure they are up to date on their mumps vaccine.'\n\nIn Colorado, the CDPHE says that for children between 19 and 35 months old, 93.6 percent have one or more doses of the vaccine. For children between 13 and 17 years old, 92.3 percent have 2 or more doses of the vaccine.\n\n[Byline: Mark Belcher]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention expects the nationwide spike in mumps cases to continue into next month [February 2017].\n\nAccording to the CDC, mumps cases hit a 10-year high in late December 2016, with 5311 cases in the US.\n\nTwo of the largest outbreaks happened on university campuses in Iowa and Illinois; 220 cases were also reported at the University of Missouri by mid-December [2016].\n\nThe case count is lower than in 2006, when more than 6500 people were sickened. It's also down dramatically since the U.S. began its vaccination program in 1967. Before the push to get vaccinated, roughly 186 000 mumps cases were reported each year.\n\nThe measles, mumps and rubella vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps, health officials say. Two doses of the vaccine are 88 percent effective at protecting against mumps; one dose is 78 percent effective, according to the CDC (Excerpted from: http://woodtv.com/2017/01/13/cdc-mumps-cases-hit-10-year-high/).\n\nA map of the United States showing the locations of Minnesota, Washington, and Colorado can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention expects the nationwide spike in mumps cases to continue into next month [February 2017]. Spokane had 56 cases of mumps as of Tue [17 Jan 2017] evening, and the number is expected to rise.\n\nMelanie Collett, spokeswoman for the Panhandle Health District, said there are no confirmed cases of mumps in North Idaho, but that will likely change, given the region's proximity to Spokane. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\nKim Papich, public information officer for the Spokane Regional Health District, said there is some evidence the Spokane outbreak is linked to a mumps outbreak in Seattle which started in late November 2016 and is still continuing, with 130 cases plus more in 5 surrounding counties. \n\nWrestlers or other participants who develop parotitis or other mumps-compatible illness (e.g., orchitis, oophoritis) regardless of vaccine status, should follow-up with their health care provider, inform the provider that they may have been exposed to a mumps case, and take precautions against exposing others. \n\n'This has quickly turned into a polarized discussion on vaccinated and unvaccinated individuals, but we have so many cases that we're beyond that,' Papich said, noting that vaccinated individuals are 9 times less likely to get the mumps. ' \n\n'Because of the high numbers of mumps cases across the country, it is especially important to make sure your children are vaccinated,' Rachel Herlihy, director of the Disease Control and Environmental Epidemiology Division at the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment, said. \n\nMumps can occur in persons with 2 doses of measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine (MMR) with intense and repeated exposure. \n\nThe Minnesota Department of Health received notification from the Washington State Department of Health that a Washington resident who participated in The Clash tournament on 30-31 Dec 2016 was reported as a mumps case in their ongoing outbreak. \n\nAs mumps cases often go undetected or untested, the outbreak in Colorado is 'likely' to grow, CDPHE officials said. \n\nThere are one or 2 cases of mumps in Idaho, but that's normal, and they're unlikely to be related to the Spokane outbreak, Papich said. \n\nEven those who are vaccinated are susceptible to mumps, as the vaccine is only roughly 88 percent effective, and effectiveness can wane after the vaccine has been administered. \n\nOf the 56 cases in Spokane, 34 are people who previously received the mumps, measles and rubella (MMR) vaccination. \n\nMumps, a contagious disease caused by a virus, typically starts with a few days of fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, followed by swollen salivary glands. The measles, mumps and rubella vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps, health officials say. \n\n\nA large outbreak of the mumps across the nation could be rippling into Colorado, health officials warned Friday [27 Jan 2017], as 14 cases were diagnosed in January 2017 alone. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2 doses of the vaccine are roughly 88 percent -- with a range of 66 to 95 percent -- effective at protecting against mumps. MUMPS UPDATE (02): USA\n**********************\n \n\nMumps is an infection spread by direct human-to-human contact through respiratory droplets or saliva. \n\n'Both adults and children should make sure they are up to date on their mumps vaccine.' \n\n'This is a very fluid situation, and we're working with local physicians to make sure any suspect cases are being reported and tested,' Collett said. The mumps outbreak in Washington state is on the cusp of 300 confirmed and probable cases, as 291 have been reported in 5 counties through Wed [25 Jan 2017]. According to the CDC, mumps cases hit a 10-year high in late December 2016, with 5311 cases in the US. \n\nCory Webster, infection prevention coordinator for Kootenai Health, said that other than vaccination, people can take steps to reduce the likelihood of getting any disease. Precautions for mumps infection include making sure people are up to date with 2 doses of MMR vaccine, practicing good hand hygiene, and isolating symptomatic persons to avoid other exposures. "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (32): (OK, MO, NY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4704809", "date": "2016-12-18 17:54:21", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (32): (OKLAHOMA, MISSOURI, NEW YORK)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this post:\n[1] Oklahoma\n[2] Missouri\n[3] New York\n\n******\n[1] Oklahoma\nDate: Fri 16 Dec 2016, 4:17 PM EST\nSource: News9 [edited]\nhttp://www.news9.com/story/34075171/more-than-300-oklahomans-diagnosed-with-mumps\n\n\nHealth officials are investigating a state-wide outbreak of mumps. The contagious infection has showed up in at least 7 Oklahoma counties. Even if you've had your MMR vaccine, that's Measles, Mumps, and Rubella --turns out you're not in the clear-- in fact you could be infected and not even know it. So far, 324 people have been diagnosed in Canadian, McClain, Osage, Tulsa, Woods, Kay, and Garfield counties. Nearly 300 of those cases have been reported in Garfield County alone, with the 1st one reported in July [2016].\n\nAnd the most unsettling part of the outbreak? Most of the patients had gotten the MMR vaccine, but its only 88 percent effective in preventing mumps. And while those numbers are concerning, Epidemiologist Megan Holderness with the Oklahoma City County Health Department said Oklahoma isn't alone. 'In the whole U.S. there's about 3600 and that's the highest numbers in a decade,' said Holderness.\n\nShe said if you're showing symptoms like fever, headache, body aches and muscle pains, and in some cases, extreme swelling of the jaw or throat, go to the doctor and then stay home. 'Stay out of the school settings and crowded environments 5 days after that swelling begins,' continued Holderness.\n\nHealth officials say it's important to diagnose people with mumps, that way they can go to those locations and find out where the outbreak started. Then, they can start treatment in that area.\n\n[Byline: Sylvia Corkill]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most of these cases in Oklahoma (and Arkansas) are in Marshallese communities. Most are well vaccinated, but have a very tight-knit almost communal lifestyle which may promote transmission. - Mod.LM]\n\n[See ProMED mail Mumps - USA (21) 20161008.4545923 for a discussion of mumps cases among the Marshallese in Arkansas following transmission in schools and the community. Arkansas has reported approximately 2000 cases. Also see for additional information on the Oklahoma outbreak. - Mod.LK]\n\n[A map of Oklahoma, United States can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/238]\n\n******\n[2] Missouri\nDate: Fri 16 Dec 2016, 8:10 AM\nSource: Fox4 [edited]\nhttp://fox4kc.com/2016/12/16/university-of-missouri-mumps-outbreak-passes-200-cases-mark/\n\n\nThe number of confirmed and probable mumps cases at the University of Missouri has grown to 228. The University of Missouri released the latest numbers [Wed 14 Dec 2016] as students take finals before heading home for winter break.\n\nHealth officials say they plan to continue monitoring cases over the break and through January [2017]. The school also is recommending that students receive a 3rd dose of a vaccine that protects against mumps, as well as measles and rubella [MMR].\n\nThe school says most of the sickened students have recovered, with at least 190 of them no longer infectious. Mumps is a viral infection that causes swelling in the salivary glands and cheeks. The university is among several across the nation that has grappled with outbreaks this year.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Missouri, United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/227]\n\n******\n[3] New York\nDate: Fri 16 Dec 2016\nSource: New York State Department of Health (NYSDOH), Bureau of Immunization [edited]\nhttps://apps.health.ny.gov/pub/ctrldocs/alrtview/postings/Notification_21509.pdf\n\n\nHealth Advisory: Mumps Outbreaks - University Settings, Winter Break: Mumps Diagnosis, Testing and Reporting\n-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nSummary\n-------\nCases of mumps have been identified in increasing numbers on college campuses in New York and across the United States. As students return home for winter break there is the potential that exposed students will develop mumps and present to local healthcare providers for evaluation.\n\nCurrently, the State Universities of New York (SUNY) at New Paltz and Geneseo are experiencing mumps outbreaks. Up to 61 individuals who have been diagnosed with mumps are epidemiologically linked to the SUNY New Paltz Campus outbreak and 16 cases of mumps have been diagnosed that are associated with SUNY Geneseo. Suspect cases are under investigation at both institutions. More cases are expected to occur.\n\nAll students at both SUNY New Paltz and SUNY Geneseo who have not received any mumps-containing vaccine are considered susceptible and have been excluded from campus at this time. Those students who have received only 1 dose of mumps-containing vaccine have been advised to receive a 2nd dose of measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine to complete the recommended 2-dose series.\n\nThe vast majority of cases have been immunized with 2 doses of MMR vaccine. The median age of case patients is 20 years. Symptoms include swelling of the salivary glands (parotid, sub-mandibular or sub-lingual), malaise, headache, myalgia, fever, anorexia and jaw pain. Patients have also reported sore throat, earache and upper respiratory symptoms prior to onset of parotitis.\n\nNYSDOH is requesting that all medical providers consider and test for mumps in patients with symptoms that are clinically consistent with mumps without an alternative diagnosis, regardless of a patient's vaccination status. Please refer to the NYSDOH Vaccine Preventable Disease Control Guidelines for more information at:\nhttp://www.health.ny.gov/prevention/immunization/providers/outbreak_control_guidelines.htm\n\nIn response to the outbreak of mumps at SUNY New Paltz, the NYSDOH, Ulster County Department of Health, and SUNY New Paltz have recommended that all SUNY New Paltz students receive a 3rd dose of MMR. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has provided guidance for use of a 3rd dose of MMR as a control measure to consider during mumps outbreaks in settings where people are in close contact with one another and when traditional control measures, including high 2-dose coverage have failed to slow the spread of disease. There is evidence suggesting that a 3rd dose of the MMR vaccine may boost immunity among students and help prevent further spread of mumps on campus. MMR vaccination clinics were held on campus 13 and 14 Dec [2016] for all students to provide a 3rd dose of vaccine, or 2nd dose for those who had not yet completed the recommended 2-dose series. Students from SUNY New Paltz who did not receive a 3rd dose of MMR during these vaccination clinics may choose to discuss the recommendation for a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine with their healthcare provider during winter break. A 3rd dose is not currently being recommended for students attending other colleges or universities in New York State, nor for the general public. [...-more]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps are at a 10-year high (CDC). As of November [2016], 45 states and the District of Columbia reported a total of 2879 mumps infections - more than double the mumps cases reported in 2015. - Mod.LK]\n\n[A map of New York State, United States may be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234]\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234.]", "summary": "Dec 2016\nSource: New York State Department of Health (NYSDOH), Bureau of Immunization [edited]\nhttps://apps.health.ny.gov/pub/ctrldocs/alrtview/postings/Notification_21509.pdf\n\n\nHealth Advisory: Mumps Outbreaks - University Settings, Winter Break: Mumps Diagnosis, Testing and Reporting\n-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nSummary\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Please refer to the NYSDOH Vaccine Preventable Disease Control Guidelines for more information at:\nhttp://www.health.ny.gov/prevention/immunization/providers/outbreak_control_guidelines.htm\n\nIn response to the outbreak of mumps at SUNY New Paltz, the NYSDOH, Ulster County Department of Health, and SUNY New Paltz have recommended that all SUNY New Paltz students receive a 3rd dose of MMR. Those students who have received only 1 dose of mumps-containing vaccine have been advised to receive a 2nd dose of measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine to complete the recommended 2-dose series. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most of these cases in Oklahoma (and Arkansas) are in Marshallese communities. MMR vaccination clinics were held on campus 13 and 14 Dec [2016] for all students to provide a 3rd dose of vaccine, or 2nd dose for those who had not yet completed the recommended 2-dose series. LM]\n\n[See ProMED mail Mumps - USA (21) 20161008.4545923 for a discussion of mumps cases among the Marshallese in Arkansas following transmission in schools and the community. LK]\n\n[A map of Oklahoma, United States can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/238]\n\n******\n MUMPS - USA (32): (OKLAHOMA, MISSOURI, NEW YORK)\n************************************************\n Students from SUNY New Paltz who did not receive a 3rd dose of MMR during these vaccination clinics may choose to discuss the recommendation for a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine with their healthcare provider during winter break. \n\nAll students at both SUNY New Paltz and SUNY Geneseo who have not received any mumps-containing vaccine are considered susceptible and have been excluded from campus at this time. As of November [2016], 45 states and the District of Columbia reported a total of 2879 mumps infections - more than double the mumps cases reported in 2015. Dec 2016, 4:17 PM EST\nSource: News9 [edited]\n Up to 61 individuals who have been diagnosed with mumps are epidemiologically linked to the SUNY New Paltz Campus outbreak and 16 cases of mumps have been diagnosed that are associated with SUNY Geneseo. The school also is recommending that students receive a 3rd dose of a vaccine that protects against mumps, as well as measles and rubella [MMR]. \nCases of mumps have been identified in increasing numbers on college campuses in New York and across the United States. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< There is evidence suggesting that a 3rd dose of the MMR vaccine may boost immunity among students and help prevent further spread of mumps on campus. [...-more]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-01-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2032-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-12-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "McClain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulsa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "arkansa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Osage", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MISSOURI", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Woods", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garfield County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4753366", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update: USA (WA,TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4753366", "date": "2017-01-10 10:44:37", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE: USA (WASHINGTON, TEXAS)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Washington (King County)\n[2] Washington (Spokane County)\n[3] Texas (northern)\n\n******\n[1] Washington (King County)\nDate: Wed 4 Jan 2017 3:53 pm PST\nSource: Auburn Reporter [edited]\nhttp://www.auburn-reporter.com/news/mumps-outbreak-in-auburn-area-reaches-87/\n\n\nThe number of mumps cases in King County [Washington] has increased to 120, of them 92 in Auburn, according to Public Health Seattle & King County.\n\nOf those cases, 41 have been confirmed, 79 are probable.\n\nAs of [Wed 4 Jan 2017], 78 mumps cases have been found in children age 17 and younger. 69 percent of the cases reportedly were up to date with measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccination.\n\nKnown cities of residence with cases of the mumps include 9 in Kent, 5 in Federal Way, 3 in Pacific and Seattle, 2 in Covington and Des Moines, and 1 each in Algona, Renton, Bellevue, and Black Diamond.\n\nHighline Public Schools, Federal Way Public Schools, Kent School District, and Seattle Public Schools each have one case; the remaining cases in school-aged children are in the Auburn School District [ASD].\n\nASD notified families that children won't be allowed to return to school until they have at least one dose of the MMR vaccination. Without proof of that, the district will not allow children to return to school for at least 25 days after the last mumps case in ASD is resolved.\n\nThe health department advises that there may be cases unrecognized in other schools in the county, as well as in the community in general, and all families need to take precautions:\n\n- please do not have your child attend school when sick with mumps symptoms (fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite, and swollen cheeks or jaw);\n- see a health care provider if those symptoms develop; and\n- be up-to-date on MMR vaccine.\n\n'We strive to provide timely and accurate information to our families,' the school district said. 'Please be aware our schools are taking universal precautions to support your child's healthy classrooms. We will continue to keep you informed as Public Health -- Seattle & King County continues to keep us updated. Thank you for supporting our school community.'\n\nIf families have any questions or concerns about a child's health, they are urged to contact their health care providers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Washington (Spokane County)\nDate: Sun 8 Jan 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/spokane-host-vaccine-clinic-wednesday-10-mumps-cases-confirmed-42597/\n\n\nThe number of mumps cases reported in the Washington state outbreak has risen to 147 as of [Thu 5 Jan 2017], and the total cases reported in Spokane County has reached 10.\n\nThis has prompted the Spokane Regional Health District to host a free vaccination clinic on [11 Jan 2017]. Free measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccines will be available for all ages 11 Jan from 3-7 p.m. at the Salvation Army Community Center, 223 E. Nora Ave. The clinic is sponsored by Walgreens and the Salvation Army.\n\nOther vaccines, including flu shots and the tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis vaccine will be available for free.\n\nOf the 10 confirmed mumps cases in Spokane County, at least 5 were fully vaccinated, while the vaccination status of the remainder are unknown.\n\nMumps is an acute infectious viral disease that can cause swelling and tenderness of the salivary glands in the cheeks and jaw.\n\nThe virus is spread from person to person by coughing and sneezing and by direct contact with saliva and discharges from the nose and throat of infected individuals. Mumps is contagious 3 days prior to and 4 days after the onset of symptoms.\n\nSymptoms of mumps usually appear after 14-18 days of infection. They usually include fever, headache, and swelling and tenderness of one or more of the salivary glands, usually the parotid gland (located just below the front of the ear at the angle of the jaw). In mild cases the swelling may only last for 3 days to 4 days, but it may go on even up to a week or more. Approximately one-third of infected people do not exhibit symptoms. There is no specific treatment for mumps.\n\nMost complications that may arise involve other organs. Mumps can cause pain and swelling of the testicles, deafness and arthritis. It can cause central nervous system disorders such as encephalitis and meningitis.\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Mumps can be prevented with MMR (measles-mumps-rubella) vaccine. MMR vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. 2 doses of the vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective at preventing mumps; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49-92 percent) effective.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\nThe state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248. King and Spokane counties can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/washington-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\n******\n[3] Texas (northern)\nDate: Wed 4 Jan 2017 8:58 am CST\nSource: The Daily Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.dailytribune.net/news/mumps-outbreak-one-of-the-worst-in-years/article_323cfd90-d28e-11e6-bb82-cb3aa20460b2.html\n\n\nThe United States is seeing the worst mumps outbreak in years, including Texas, Oklahoma, and Arkansas. According to Tom Steele, breaking news producer at the Dallas News, the number of mumps cases in North Texas has surpassed 50 as an outbreak in Johnson County has grown and cases have been found in Dallas, Collin, Denton, and Tarrant counties.\n\nMost of the cases there are school-age children from Cleburne and Keene [in Johnson County]. Health officials have traced the virus to an outbreak in Arkansas, where several children from Keene had visited recently.\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) website, mumps is no longer very common in the United States. From year to year, mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. In 2010, there were 2612 cases reported to CDC, and in 2012, there were 229.\n\nBefore the United States mumps vaccination program began in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States.\n\nAs of 3 Dec 2016, 46 states and the District of Columbia in the United States reported mumps infections in 4258 people to CDC. 7 states have reported more than 100 cases this year [2016]: Arkansas, Iowa, Indiana, Illinois, Maine, New York, and Oklahoma.\n\nA report from the CDC states that the MMR vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. 2 doses of the vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66 to 95 percent) effective.\n\nThe MMR vaccine protects against currently circulating mumps strains.\n\nOutbreaks can still occur in highly vaccinated United States communities, particularly in close-contact settings. In recent years, outbreaks have occurred in schools, colleges, and camps.\n\n[Byline: Carly Scott]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34810. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/texas-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nMumps is caused by a virus from the genus _Rubulavirus_. As stated above, its symptoms include low-grade fever, respiratory problems, and most notably swelling of the parotid glands below the ear, known as parotitis. Although parotitis is the most easily recognized symptom of mumps, it occurs only in about 30-40 percent of cases. Other patients may have non-specific symptoms. Up to 20 percent of infected individuals may experience no symptoms at all. Symptoms typically occur 2-3 weeks after exposure to the virus.\n\nThe virus is spread by respiratory droplets. These can become airborne when an infected person coughs, sneezes, and talks. Additionally, a person can contract the virus by touching surfaces that are contaminated with infected droplets. Infected individuals are considered most contagious during a period starting several days before the appearance of parotitis (if it occurs), and running through the 5th day after it first appears. To keep a patient from spreading the virus to others, isolation is recommended for 5 days after parotitis begins.\n\nIn the United States, cases of mumps have dropped by 99 percent since the introduction of a vaccine in 1967, however, mumps has not yet been eliminated in the country. Recent large outbreaks have occurred among college students (2006, more than 6500 cases) and in a tradition-observant Jewish community, sparked by a boy who returned from a trip to the United Kingdom and began showing mumps symptoms while at a summer camp (2009-2010, more than 3400 cases).\n\nMumps cases typically peak in late winter or early spring.\n\nMumps can be a mild disease, but complications may occur. These include meningitis; testicular inflammation in males who have reached puberty, among whom about half experience some degree of testicular atrophy; inflammation of the ovaries or breasts in females who have reached puberty; and permanent deafness in one or both ears. Before the development of a mumps vaccine, the disease was one of the major causes of deafness in children.\n\nThe live, attenuated mumps vaccine used today in the United States was licensed in 1967. Even though mumps cases occur even in fully vaccinated children and adults, the occurrence of the more severe complications is relatively rare now, evidence of some protection afforded by the vaccine . The MMR vaccine was licensed in 1971. The rubella component of the vaccine was changed in 1979, but the mumps and measles components have remained the same since 1971.\n(Excerpted and edited from http://www.historyofvaccines.org/content/articles/mumps)\n\nIt may be informative to evaluate whether the current mumps vaccine strain is still fully effective against circulating mumps strains, although it is thought to be. As of 26 Nov 2016, there have been 3800 reports of mumps from 45 states and DC. 94 percent of the children and 45 percent of adults have been up to date on vaccination. Arkansas reported more than 1750 cases of mumps, compared with 7 cases in 2015 and 1 in 2014 (CDC). But large outbreaks have been observed previously as noted, in 2006 and 2009-10.\n\nAt times, a 3rd dose has been given during outbreaks. While there are conflicting results, when administered early in the outbreak, this additional dose appears to be effective. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "\n\nThe health department advises that there may be cases unrecognized in other schools in the county, as well as in the community in general, and all families need to take precautions:\n\n- please do not have your child attend school when sick with mumps symptoms (fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite, and swollen cheeks or jaw);\n- see a health care provider if those symptoms develop; and\n- be up-to-date on MMR vaccine. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The number of mumps cases reported in the Washington state outbreak has risen to 147 as of [Thu 5 Jan 2017], and the total cases reported in Spokane County has reached 10.\n\n \n\nBefore the United States mumps vaccination program began in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n 2 doses of the vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective at preventing mumps; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49-92 percent) effective. In the United States, cases of mumps have dropped by 99 percent since the introduction of a vaccine in 1967, however, mumps has not yet been eliminated in the country. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\nThe state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34810. \n\nAs of [Wed 4 Jan 2017], 78 mumps cases have been found in children age 17 and younger. \n\nKnown cities of residence with cases of the mumps include 9 in Kent, 5 in Federal Way, 3 in Pacific and Seattle, 2 in Covington and Des Moines, and 1 each in Algona, Renton, Bellevue, and Black Diamond. Recent large outbreaks have occurred among college students (2006, more than 6500 cases) and in a tradition-observant Jewish community, sparked by a boy who returned from a trip to the United Kingdom and began showing mumps symptoms while at a summer camp (2009-2010, more than 3400 cases). \n\nOf the 10 confirmed mumps cases in Spokane County, at least 5 were fully vaccinated, while the vaccination status of the remainder are unknown. According to Tom Steele, breaking news producer at the Dallas News, the number of mumps cases in North Texas has surpassed 50 as an outbreak in Johnson County has grown and cases have been found in Dallas, Collin, Denton, and Tarrant counties. \n\nMumps cases typically peak in late winter or early spring. Even though mumps cases occur even in fully vaccinated children and adults, the occurrence of the more severe complications is relatively rare now, evidence of some protection afforded by the vaccine . Arkansas reported more than 1750 cases of mumps, compared with 7 cases in 2015 and 1 in 2014 (CDC). \n\nMumps is an acute infectious viral disease that can cause swelling and tenderness of the salivary glands in the cheeks and jaw. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States. It may be informative to evaluate whether the current mumps vaccine strain is still fully effective against circulating mumps strains, although it is thought to be. MUMPS UPDATE: USA (WASHINGTON, TEXAS)\n*************************************\n A report from the CDC states that the MMR vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. \n\nSymptoms of mumps usually appear after 14-18 days of infection. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Mumps can be prevented with MMR (measles-mumps-rubella) vaccine. 69 percent of the cases reportedly were up to date with measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccination. MMR vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. \n\nMumps can be a mild disease, but complications may occur. \n\nMost of the cases there are school-age children from Cleburne and Keene [in Johnson County]. Date: Wed 4 Jan 2017 3:53 pm PST\nSource: Auburn Reporter [edited]\nhttp://www.auburn-reporter.com/news/mumps-outbreak-in-auburn-area-reaches-87/ Date: Wed 4 Jan 2017 8:58 am CST\nSource: The Daily Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.dailytribune.net/news/mumps-outbreak-one-of-the-worst-in-years/article_323cfd90-d28e-11e6-bb82-cb3aa20460b2.html MJ\n\nMumps is caused by a virus from the genus _Rubulavirus_. Although parotitis is the most easily recognized symptom of mumps, it occurs only in about 30-40 percent of cases. From year to year, mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. The number of mumps cases in King County [Washington] has increased to 120, of them 92 in Auburn, according to Public Health Seattle & King County. \n\n--\n [Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\n [Byline: Carly Scott]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "measles", "mumps", "pertussis", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-01-05 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2612-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-10-25 00:00:00", "1979-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "4258-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-01-11 00:00:00", "2017-01-04 00:00:00", "1971-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location":
