"main_text": "MUMPS - USA (28): (OREGON, MISSOURI)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Oregon (Marion County)\n[2] Missouri: University of Missouri\n\n******\n[1] Oregon (Marion County)\nDate: Wed 23 Nov 2016\nSource: KATU News [edited]\nhttp://katu.com/news/health/mumps-outbreak-reported-in-marion-county\n\n\nAn outbreak of mumps is hitting Marion County [Oregon], with 4 confirmed cases of the infection since the beginning of October [2016]. Marion County Health Department officials said they have 8 more suspected mumps cases reported since [3 Oct 2016], including 2 patients that are related to people with lab confirmation.\n\nThe people who contracted mumps didn't have vaccinations or the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] booster shot. The age range of those people is 1 year old to 40 years old. These are the 1st cases in Marion County since 2012.\n\nThe mumps disease is caused by a virus. Symptoms include a fever, headache and muscle aches, tiredness, and swelling under the ears or jaw. It takes about 2 weeks to develop the symptoms after being exposed to someone with mumps. The disease can be spread through coughing or sneezes. Officials said it can be spread 2 days before signs of the illness show up until 5 days after the swelling appears.\n\n'The best way you can prevent mumps is to get the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine,' says Dr Karen Landers, Marion County health officer. The routine MMR vaccine starts at around 1 year of age. It also requires a booster to complete the vaccination. Landers said that the outbreaks are on the rise around the country in states like Maine, Missouri, and Arkansas.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Oregon can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5700. Marion County in north western Oregon can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/oregon-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Missouri: University of Missouri\nDate: Wed 23 Nov 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/mizzou-mumps-outbreak-many-linked-greek-life-community-50651/\n\n\nThe number of confirmed and probable mumps cases at the University of Missouri has increased in the past week as the school's student health center puts the total at 73 [Wed 23 Nov 2016], up from 58 about 1 week ago. University officials say many of the cases have links to the Greek Life community [university fraternities and sororities].\n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks. Items used by an infected person, such as cups or soft drink cans, can also be contaminated with the virus, which may spread to others if those items are shared. Symptoms typically appear 16-18 days after infection, but this period can range from 12-25 days after infection. It is usually a mild disease, but can occasionally cause serious complications.\n\nThe commonest complication is inflammation of the testicles (orchitis) in males who have reached puberty; rarely does this lead to fertility problems. Other rare complications include inflammation of the brain and/or tissue covering the brain and spinal cord (encephalitis/meningitis), inflammation of the ovaries (oophoritis) and/or breasts (mastitis) in females who have reached puberty, and deafness.\n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See ProMED Mumps - USA (26): universities, schools 20161119.4639792 for a discussion of mumps in the US.\n\nA map showing the location of Missouri in the United States can be fund at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16851. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See ProMED Mumps - USA (26): universities, schools 20161119.4639792 for a discussion of mumps in the US. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Oregon can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5700. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/mizzou-mumps-outbreak-many-linked-greek-life-community-50651/\n\n\nThe number of confirmed and probable mumps cases at the University of Missouri has increased in the past week as the school's student health center puts the total at 73 [Wed 23 Nov 2016], up from 58 about 1 week ago. MUMPS - USA (28): (OREGON, MISSOURI)\n************************************\n Source: KATU News [edited]\nhttp://katu.com/news/health/mumps-outbreak-reported-in-marion-county\n\n\nAn outbreak of mumps is hitting Marion County [Oregon], with 4 confirmed cases of the infection since the beginning of October [2016]. \n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks. \n\n'The best way you can prevent mumps is to get the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine,' says Dr Karen Landers, Marion County health officer. Marion County Health Department officials said they have 8 more suspected mumps cases reported since [3 Oct 2016], including 2 patients that are related to people with lab confirmation. MJ]\n\n******\n Other rare complications include inflammation of the brain and/or tissue covering the brain and spinal cord (encephalitis/meningitis), inflammation of the ovaries (oophoritis) and/or breasts (mastitis) in females who have reached puberty, and deafness. Date: Wed 23 Nov 2016\n Date: Wed 23 Nov 2016\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Marion County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MISSOURI", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4673013", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (29): (TX, CT, WA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4673013", "date": "2016-12-03 11:17:32", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (29): (TEXAS, CONNECTICUT, WASHINGTON)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Texas: schools\n[2] Texas: elementary school\n[3] Connecticut (New Haven): Yale University\n[4] Washington (King County)\n\n******\n[1] Texas: schools\nDate: Wed 30 Nov 2016\nSource: Cleburne Times-Review [edited]\nhttp://www.cleburnetimesreview.com/news/parents-informed-of-confirmed-case-of-mumps-at-wheat-chs/article_d605d93c-b778-11e6-98bc-0fad2199c48b.html\n\n\nRegional health officials notified Cleburne late today [Wed 30 Nov 2016] of confirmed cases of mumps at Wheat Middle School and Cleburne High School.\n\nThis followed Keene ISD [Independent School District]'s announcement of several suspected cases in their district earlier today. [See below.]\n\nParents of all CISD students were notified of the situation through district email Wed [30 Nov 2016] evening. The message included an advisory letter from the Texas Department of State Health Services.\n\n'We do not want parents to be alarmed, but rather aware of the situation and informed of the disease and its symptoms,' Superintendent Kyle Heath said. 'The health and welfare of our students is of the utmost importance to our district. Working with our nursing staff and regional and state health officials, we will continue to monitor the situation.'\n\nProtection against the disease is addressed by 2 doses of the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine, which is among the state immunization requirements for Texas public schools.\n\nParents were encouraged to contact their family physician if they had any questions or concerns regarding the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Texas, United States, can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Texas: elementary school\nDate: Thu 1 Dec 2016\nSource: ABC 13 [edited]\nhttp://abc13.com/health/mumps-outbreak-at-texas-elementary-school/1634231/\n\n\nMumps outbreak at Texas elementary school\n-----------------------------------------\nA once-dormant contagious disease has sprouted up in a North Texas town, causing a school district to issue a health warning.\n\nAt least 10 cases of mumps have been confirmed by health authorities in Johnson County.\n\nOf the cases, 7 involve students within Keene ISD.\n\n'I think the parents have to be very careful,' said MV, a parent.\n\nParents like MV want to know what the district and county health department are doing about mumps.\n\nDoctors think the outbreak originated from a family who traveled to Arkansas over the Thanksgiving holiday [around 24 Nov 2016].\n\n'My kids have already the immunization and I think that will cover,' said MV.\n\nNot every parent within the district feels the shots are necessary.\n\n'You definitely don't want 7 or 10 cases to turn into 40 and that can easily happen,' said Ricky Stephens, the superintendent for Keene ISD.\n\nStephens said the 34 students, who are not vaccinated or are under-vaccinated, will not be able to attend school for the next 26 days.\n\n'You can't just do one campus and assume you're safe,' said Stephens.\n\n[Last] week, Dallas County issued a health advisory regarding 1 confirmed case with the possibility of several others.\n\n'Mumps is almost unheard of in this day in age,' said Dr. Elvin Adams with the Johnson County Health Department.\n\nDr. Adams said patients usually feel tired and weak. Then a fever is possible and that is when the glands in a person start swelling.\n\n'So you look like a chipmunk that has a mouthful of nuts,' said Dr. Adams.\n\nWhile Dr. Adams said it is not considered a lethal disease, it can be painful and easily spread if nothing is done.\n\nThe state health department plans to be on Keene ISD property on Thu [1 Dec 2016] to give out vaccines to students who need shots.\n\nKTVT reports that any students who choose not to get vaccinated, must wait the 26 days because the disease can incubate for 25 days.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Connecticut (New Haven): Yale University\nDate: Thu 1 Dec 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/yale-reports-two-suspected-cases-mumps-75617/\n\n\nYale reports 2 suspected cases of mumps\n---------------------------------------\nTwo suspected cases of mumps have been reported at Yale University [New Haven, Connecticut], one in an undergraduate living on campus and one in a graduate student living off campus, Yale Health Director, Paul Genecin, M.D. wrote yesterday [30 Nov 2016].\n\nOver 90 percent of Yale undergraduates have received mumps vaccine, but it is still possible for students or other members of the campus community to contract the disease.\n\nMumps is a highly contagious respiratory disease that is spread through indirect or direct contact with an infected person's nose or throat droplets, such as when an infected person coughs or sneezes. It is best known for the puffy cheeks and swollen jaw that it causes because of inflammation of the salivary glands under the ears on one or both sides. Other common symptoms include fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue and loss of appetite. Some people who get mumps have very mild or no symptoms, and often they do not know they have the disease.\n\nMost people with mumps recover completely in a few weeks. However, mumps can occasionally cause severe complications, especially in adults. Treatment includes rest, fluids, and over-the-counter medicine to reduce fever and discomfort. Since mumps is caused by a virus, antibiotics are not used as a treatment.\n\nPeople with mumps can spread the infection for up to 2 days before, and 5 days after, symptoms develop, so those infected can spread the disease before they feel sick. Symptoms typically appear 16 to 18 days after infection, but this period can range from 12 to 25 days after infection.\n\nStudents who have mumps or mumps-like symptoms will be asked to go home if they live close enough to New Haven or if their parent or guardian is able to pick them up. Students who are not able to go home will be cared for at Yale Health until they are no longer contagious. Faculty and staff with symptoms should consult their health care providers; they should not come to work.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Connecticut, United States, can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/210. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] Washington (King County)\nDate: Fri 2 Dec 2016\nSource: Seattle Patch [edited]\nhttp://patch.com/washington/seattle/king-county-mumps-outbreak-grows-22\n\n\nKing County Mumps Outbreak Grows to 22\n--------------------------------------\nKing County Public Health said Fri [2 Dec 2016] afternoon that the number of mumps cases in the county has grown from 9 to 22 since Wed [30 Nov 2016]. Of those 22 cases, 5 are confirmed and 17 are probable.\n\nHealth officials are warning anyone with mumps symptoms to stay away from others, and they are urging everyone to get vaccinated.\n\nThe county said that all of the cases are in Auburn [Washington], and 15 of the cases are in children ages 5 to 17. When the county reported the initial outbreak earlier this week, all of the mumps cases were confined to a single family.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is about 88 percent effective, King County Health Officer Dr. Jeffrey Duchin has said. Even still, everyone should get the vaccine, he said.\n\n'Because some people do not respond to the vaccine and mumps spreads easily from person to person, outbreaks can still occur in vaccinated populations. But, if unvaccinated, many, many more people would become ill,' Duchin said in a statement Fri [2 Dec 2016].\n\n[Byline: Neal McNamara]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In an earlier report (30 Nov 2016) (http://patch.com/washington/seattle/mumps-outbreak-emerging-south-king-county-health-officials) by Neal McNamara (Seattle Patch), Duchin described this current outbreak as a 'blip.' In a typical year, there are between 0 and 7 cases total in King County. All but one of the people infected this year with mumps is under age 18.\n\nA map showing the location of Washington state, United States, can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \nKing County Public Health said Fri [2 Dec 2016] afternoon that the number of mumps cases in the county has grown from 9 to 22 since Wed [30 Nov 2016]. USA (27): (NY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4648552", "date": "2016-11-23 12:56:14", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (27): (NEW YORK)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 18 Nov 2016 9:28 AM EST\nSource: NBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/Mumps-College-SUNY-New-Paltz-Viral-Disease-Infection-High-School-Spread-Outbreak-401882415.html\n\n\nAn outbreak of mumps that has affected more than a dozen people at the State University of New York [SUNY] at New Paltz has spread to the town's high school and could possibly reach even further, according to the school's latest health update. Since early October [2016], 16 people, including at least 8 members of the swim team at SUNY New Paltz and one athletic staff member, have come down with the mumps, a highly contagious viral disease. The [Ulster] county health department has an additional 8 probable cases.\n\nAccording to the school, one of the students afflicted with the condition, which is characterized by fever, headache, and swelling of the salivary glands, had been in close contact with a student at the New Paltz High School, and now the high school student has been diagnosed with a probable case of mumps. The high school student has been in close contact with a student at the New Paltz Middle School, and though the younger student does not have the mumps at this time, staff and parents at both secondary schools are being warned their children may have been exposed.\n\nSUNY New Paltz said it has been in touch with the school district and has offered to provide assistance as needed. Upcoming Thanksgiving [24 Nov 2016] travel and gatherings compound the possibility for the mumps outbreak to spread.\n\nAfter a person is exposed, symptoms usually appear 16-18 days after infection, but this period can range from 12-25 days after infection. Mumps can't be treated. Aside from headache, other symptoms include low-grade fever, fatigue, muscle aches, and loss of appetite.\n\nThe disease is transmitted by close contact, sharing utensils and drinking glasses, and through saliva contact by kissing or other means. Health officials recommend washing hands frequently as a preventative measure.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See ProMED-mail report on mumps at SUNY New Paltz in: Mumps - USA (26): universities, schools 20161119.4639792.\n\nThe state of New York can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20514. MUMPS - USA (27): (NEW YORK)\n****************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2016-11-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ulster County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Paltz", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4609609", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (24): (MO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4609609", "date": "2016-11-05 17:38:07", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (24): (MISSOURI)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 4 Nov 2016\nSource: Missourian [edited]\nhttp://bit.ly/2ebJahs\n\n\n8 mumps cases confirmed at MU [University of Missouri], number expected to increase\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nEight MU students been diagnosed with mumps, and the MU Student Health Center expects that number to rise over the next 25 days.\n\nOn Wed [2 Nov 2016], the MU News Bureau confirmed that 4 students had been diagnosed with the virus, and the health center updated the total to 8 on Fri [4 Nov 2016] afternoon.\n\nSome other students have made appointments with the Student Health Center and displayed symptoms of mumps, but it will take up to a week before test results come in, health center spokesperson Pam Roe said. She did not have an exact number of how many students have come in with symptoms of the virus.\n\nIt can take about 25 days to display symptoms of mumps, which include a fever, swollen glands, fatigue, aching muscles and a headache, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention website. The virus is spread through mucus or saliva.\n\nNine MU students were confirmed to have mumps in the summer of 2015, and one student was diagnosed in April [2016].\n\nStudents who have received the Mumps, Measles and Rubella [MMR] vaccine are 9 times less likely to contract the illness, Roe said. Those with a vaccine will likely have fewer or less intense symptoms.\n\nAnyone with these symptoms should seek medical attention immediately, Roe said. Students should not attend their classes if they show symptoms.\n\n[Byline: Annabel Ames]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is becoming increasingly more common on college campuses in the United States. In 2016, the disease has been reported at the State University of New York at Buffalo, Indiana University, University of Kentucky, University of San Diego, University of Southern Maine, Saint Anselm College [New Hampshire] and Harvard University [Massachusetts], among others (from http://outbreaknewstoday.com/mumps-alert-issued-at-the-university-of-missouri-47560/).\n\nMost children in the US are immunized as infants and toddlers, but may not be protected for life. And, of course, those who do not get vaccinated are not protected. Adults who move to the US from countries without MMR immunization programs, are at risk. Global travel increases the chances of these diseases spreading. It is likely for these reasons that we are seeing mumps cases at colleges in the US. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16851.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is becoming increasingly more common on college campuses in the United States. \n\nSome other students have made appointments with the Student Health Center and displayed symptoms of mumps, but it will take up to a week before test results come in, health center spokesperson Pam Roe said. On Wed [2 Nov 2016], the MU News Bureau confirmed that 4 students had been diagnosed with the virus, and the health center updated the total to 8 on Fri [4 Nov 2016] afternoon. \nEight MU students been diagnosed with mumps, and the MU Student Health Center expects that number to rise over the next 25 days. \n\nIt can take about 25 days to display symptoms of mumps, which include a fever, swollen glands, fatigue, aching muscles and a headache, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention website. \n\nStudents who have received the Mumps, Measles and Rubella [MMR] vaccine are 9 times less likely to contract the illness, Roe said. MUMPS - USA (24): (MISSOURI)\n****************************\n \n\n\n8 mumps cases confirmed at MU [University of Missouri], number expected to increase\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Hampshire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MISSOURI", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Buffalo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4616380", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (25): (AR,NY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4616380", "date": "2016-11-09 17:06:04", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (25): (ARKANSAS, NEW YORK)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (Arkansas)\n[2] USA (Arkansas), CDC\n[3] USA (New York)\n\n******\n[1] USA (Arkansas)\nDate: Mon 7 Nov 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/mumps-cases-top-1000-arkansas-16004/\n\n\nThe Arkansas Department of Health (ADH) now puts the number of suspected and lab confirmed mumps cases in the country's largest outbreak to 1028, according to data published Mon [7 Nov 2016]. The north western counties of Benton, Madison and Washington and the central Arkansas county of Pulaski are affected by the outbreak.\n\nAs previously reported, a large percentage of cases are in adults and children who have been vaccinated. Through the end of October [2016], the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has provisionally reported more than 2800 cases. This tops the total mumps cases reported in all of 2010 (2612), the previous high.\n\nMumps is an acute viral infection of the salivary glands. Symptoms include swelling and tenderness of the cheeks, usually preceded by fever, headache and muscle aches. Mumps infection can also lead to more serious health complications such as testicular infection and inflammation, meningitis, and encephalitis (inflammation of the brain).\n\nTransmission occurs through sneezing, coughing, contact with saliva (through sharing of utensils, towels, kissing, sharing cigarettes and drinks, etc), or from contact with surfaces that have become contaminated with the mumps virus. The incubation period is 16-18 days, and individuals are considered most infectious from 2 days prior through 5 days after the onset of symptoms.\n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Arkansas in the US can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/208. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Arkansas), CDC\nDate: Tue 8 Nov 2016\nSource: Epi-X (The Epidemic Information Exchange) [edited]\nhttps://epix2.cdc.gov/v2/Reports/StandardReport/Display.aspx?id=61062&print=False&PSR=False\n\nUpdate #3: Mumps outbreak in north west Arkansas community and schools -- Arkansas, 2016\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nThe Arkansas Department of Health continues to investigate and respond to a large outbreak of mumps in north west Arkansas. The majority of cases are Marshallese and are believed to have acquired the infection within local churches and school settings. MMR vaccination clinics are ongoing.\n\nThe Arkansas Department of Health (ADH) has been investigating an outbreak of mumps in north west Arkansas (NWA) since Mid-August. A CDC Epi-Aid team deployed to Little Rock and NWA to assist with the outbreak response from 8 Sept 2016 until 28 Sept 16. They returned again on 4 Nov 2016 to investigate vaccine effectiveness among the affected community. A Marshallese dignitary group traveled from the Republic of the Marshall Islands to NWA on 2 Nov 2016 to assist in community outreach and vaccination efforts.\n\nAs of Tue 8 Nov [2016], we are aware of 1140 cases (626 laboratory confirmed -- via PCR -- and 514 probable cases). At least 134 additional suspects have pending laboratory testing at the state public health laboratory. The majority of cases are in the Marshallese (65 per cent). Transmission has spread to 53 schools in 5 different school districts and 4 private schools, 41 businesses or work places and 54 churches. The majority of cases are 5-17 years old (67 per cent) with an age range of 4 months-82 years. Language barriers are a major issue in conducting investigations as most of the cases are Marshallese or Spanish speaking and interpreters are needed to conduct effective interviews.\n\nThankfully, most cases have had mild disease. A total of 3 cases were hospitalized, 4 had orchitis, 1 had deafness, and 958 cases had typical parotitis. No pancreatitis or encephalitis has been observed.\n\nVaccination clinics are ongoing. To date approximately 4514 doses of MMR have been given at 55 vaccination clinics. As of Tue 8 Nov [2016], about 93 per cent of cases in children are up-to-date on vaccine. In contrast, 42 per cent of adult cases are up-to-date. Several 3rd MMR dose clinics have been conducted and more are planned.\n\nThere are 626 confirmed cases, 514 probable. An estimated 9000 individuals have been exposed, but there have been no deaths.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The link to this report is not publicly available, but ProMED-mail considers it useful to disseminate and share the information.\n\nArkansas is not the only state in the United States reporting increased cases of mumps. See ProMED-mail: Mumps - USA (21) 20161008.4545923 for reports of cases in Oklahoma and Washington, and a discussion of the particular problem of providing protection to the Marshallese in Arkansas against vaccine-preventable diseases. The Arkansas Department of Health helped to open a health care clinic for this population, with assistance from the Affordable Care Act. One can only hope this program is left intact. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] USA (New York)\nDate: Mon 7 Nov 2016\nSource: Times Herald Record [edited]\nhttp://www.recordonline.com/news/20161107/12th-case-of-mumps-at-suny-new-paltz\n\n\nThe count in the mumps outbreak at SUNY [State University of New York] New Paltz is up to 12 and could grow higher. On Mon [7 Nov 2016], the college posted the update on its website saying the latest person to come down with the disease is a member of the athletics staff. That person is currently at home, recovering.\n\nLast week, officials said 23 students who [had not been] immunised against mumps had been sent home as well. Most of the students with confirmed cases were on the campus swim team. Officials have canceled swim meets for the rest of the semester.\n\nThe notice on Mon [7 Nov 2016] said more cases could develop. If they do, they are expected to show up between Mon [7 Nov 2016] and [28 Nov 2016]. That is based on the 26-day incubation period for mumps.\n\n[byline: Paul Brooks]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the USA showing the location of New York can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Arkansas in the US can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/208. - Mod. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n[byline: Paul Brooks]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Source: Epi-X (The Epidemic Information Exchange) [edited]\nhttps://epix2.cdc.gov/v2/Reports/StandardReport/Display.aspx?id=61062&print=False&PSR=False\n\nUpdate #3: Mumps outbreak in north west Arkansas community and schools -- Arkansas, 2016\n---------------------------------------------------------------------- \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< As of Tue 8 Nov [2016], we are aware of 1140 cases (626 laboratory confirmed -- via PCR -- and 514 probable cases). The Arkansas Department of Health (ADH) now puts the number of suspected and lab confirmed mumps cases in the country's largest outbreak to 1028, according to data published Mon [7 Nov 2016]. MUMPS - USA (25): (ARKANSAS, NEW YORK)\n**************************************\n [3] USA (New York)\n\n******\n A total of 3 cases were hospitalized, 4 had orchitis, 1 had deafness, and 958 cases had typical parotitis. \n\nArkansas is not the only state in the United States reporting increased cases of mumps. \n\nThe Arkansas Department of Health continues to investigate and respond to a large outbreak of mumps in north west Arkansas. LK]\n\n******\n LK]\n\n******\n \n\nAs previously reported, a large percentage of cases are in adults and children who have been vaccinated. Date: Mon 7 Nov 2016\n Date: Mon 7 Nov 2016\n \n\nThere are 626 confirmed cases, 514 probable. \n\nTransmission occurs through sneezing, coughing, contact with saliva (through sharing of utensils, towels, kissing, sharing cigarettes and drinks, etc), or from contact with surfaces that have become contaminated with the mumps virus. Date: Tue 8 Nov 2016\n \n\nThe Arkansas Department of Health (ADH) has been investigating an outbreak of mumps in north west Arkansas (NWA) since Mid-August. As of Tue 8 Nov [2016], about 93 per cent of cases in children are up-to-date on vaccine. See ProMED-mail: Mumps - USA (21) 20161008.4545923 for reports of cases in Oklahoma and Washington, and a discussion of the particular problem of providing protection to the Marshallese in Arkansas against vaccine-preventable diseases.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:00", "1028-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2612-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-09-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Benton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Little Rock", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of the Marshall Islands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4587708", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (23): universities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4587708", "date": "2016-10-27 10:55:47", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (23): UNIVERSITIES\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] California: San Diego State University\n[2] New Hampshire: University of New Hampshire\n[3] Massachusetts: Framingham State University\n\n******\n[1] California: San Diego State University\nDate: Tue 25 Oct 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/mumps-cases-up-in-san-diego-this-year-11000/\n\n\nSan Diego County [California] health officials have reported another local university with a student confirmed positive for mumps. A San Diego State University (SDSU) student was recently confirmed positive for the viral infection after exposure to another student who had been ill and likely also had mumps.\n\nThe 2 students are housemates living off campus and were up-to-date with mumps vaccinations. The students were not hospitalized and have recovered.\n\nIt is not known where the 1st student who became ill was exposed to mumps, but there is no apparent connection to the recent mumps cases reported at California State University San Marcos or San Diego Christian College.\n\n'SDSU is working closely with the County to inform the university community about the symptoms of mumps and vaccine recommendations,' said Sayone Thihalolipavan, MD, MPH, County deputy public health officer. 'These unrelated cases at campuses in the county mean that mumps may be present in the community, which is why we encourage that everyone be up-to-date with measles, mumps, and rubella [MMR] immunizations.'\n\nSo far this year [2016], 19 mumps cases have been reported in San Diego County. This compares to 3 or fewer mumps cases noted annually in recent years.\n\nThrough 15 Oct 2016, 2570 mumps cases have been reported nationwide in 45 states and the District of Columbia.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/22466. San Diego County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] New Hampshire: University of New Hampshire\nDate: Tue 25 Oct 2016 2:42 pm ET\nSource: Patch [edited]\nhttp://patch.com/new-hampshire/exeter/mumps-outbreak-unh\n\n\nA mumps outbreak was discovered at the University of New Hampshire and state health officials urged the local community to be vigilant against the highly contagious and potentially deadly disease.\n\nAccording to state Epidemiologist Benjamin Chan, 3 people 'with a link to the university' have been diagnosed with mumps. The ages and genders of the individuals were not released.\n\nThe student population is likely safe from contracting the disease, as a mumps vaccine is a condition of enrollment. But Chan said university workers and those who spend time on campus and are not vaccinated should be cautious.\n\nMumps is a viral infection easily transmitted through saliva and surface contact. Symptoms include swelling and tenderness of the cheeks, fever, headache, and muscle aches. In can cause more serious complications and in rare cases is deadly, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nMumps cases are on the rise in New Hampshire and across the country, Chan said.\n\nFrom 2011 to 2015, there were 5 mumps cases in New Hampshire. So far this year [2016], there have been 9 cases, Chan said.\n\n[Byline: Jason Claffey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Not only students, but the entire campus community needs to be up-to-date on vaccination with MMR vaccine to protect against measles, mumps, and rubella virus infection, all of which can cause serious disease in adults. Mumps virus causes fever, headache, muscle pain, loss of appetite, and swollen glands. It can lead to deafness, meningitis (infection of the brain and spinal cord covering), painful swelling of the testicles or ovaries, and occasionally, sterility. - Mod.LK\n\nThe state of New Hampshire can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9144. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Massachusetts: Framingham State University\nDate: Tue 25 Oct 2016\nSource: NECN [edited]\nhttp://www.necn.com/news/health/Framingham-State-University-Student-Tests-Positive-For-Mumps-398584601.html\n\n\nA student at Framingham State University in Framingham, Massachusetts, has tested positive for mumps, according to university officials.\n\nOfficials at the university said they were notified by the Massachusetts Department of Public Health after the student was tested for the disease. As a precaution, the student was housed in an isolation room on campus immediately after being seen in the campus Health Center.\n\n'The student has remained in isolation for 5 days in adherence with the Department of Public Health guidelines,' university officials said in a statement.\n\nThe student, who has not been identified, was immunized with 2 doses of MMR vaccine, which are 88 percent effective in preventing mumps, according to the Massachusetts Department of Public Health. Although rare, someone can still can get the disease if they have been in very close contact with someone who is infected.\n\nUniversity officials are urging students who have had symptoms of jaw swelling, fever, headache, stiff neck, or loss of appetite to notify the health center or their doctor as soon as possible.\n\n'We are checking the immunization records of all roommates and students in the affected student's classes to make sure they have submitted documentation of the required immunizations and will be contacting those who have not,' school officials said.\n\n[Byline: Melissa Buja]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Massachusetts can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31504. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Not only students, but the entire campus community needs to be up-to-date on vaccination with MMR vaccine to protect against measles, mumps, and rubella virus infection, all of which can cause serious disease in adults. MJ]\n\n******\n MJ]\n\n******\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2570-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Framingham", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Hampshire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4639792", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (26): universities, schools", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4639792", "date": "2016-11-19 11:21:38", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (26): UNIVERSITIES, SCHOOLS\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] New York: State University of New York (SUNY) at New Paltz\n[2] Massachusetts: Harvard University\n[3] Missouri: University of Missouri\n[4] Maine: local colleges, CDC\n[5] Iowa (Dubuque County)\n\n******\n[1] New York: State University of New York (SUNY) at New Paltz\nDate: Tue 15 Nov 2016\nSource: NBC New York [edited]\nhttp://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/Mumps-Outbreak-New-York-College-State-University-New-Paltz-SUNY-Health-Sick-Students-Swim-401294296.html\n\n\nSo far, 15 cases of mumps have been confirmed at the State University of New York [SUNY] at New Paltz, an increase of 6 in the last 2 weeks.\n\nAt least 8 members of the school's intercollegiate swim team, along with 1 athletics staff member, are among those who fell ill, the school said.\n\nIt's not clear if the latest cases are connected to the mumps spread on the swim team, which county health officials first learned of in early October [2016].\n\nMumps is a highly contagious viral disease characterized by fever, headache and swelling of the salivary glands. Other symptoms include low-grade fever, fatigue, muscle aches and loss of appetite. After a person is exposed, symptoms usually appear 16-18 days after infection, but this period can range from 12-25 days after infection. Mumps can't be treated. 2 weeks ago, college health officials sent a letter to users of the school's athletic facilities cautioning them about possible infection. According to the school, the state Health Department has indicated there is minimal risk of transmission, but the school has been taking various precautions.\n\nThe affected students, who have been immunized against mumps, have been isolated for the recommended period of time. 20 students who have not been immunized have been sent home until December [2016].\n\nCampus tours and general information sessions will proceed as scheduled, but residence halls home to affected students will be avoided for the time being.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is highly contagious and is characterized by fever, headache and fatigue, among other symptoms. The disease can't be treated and while the vaccine is not 100 percent effective, 2 doses of the vaccine are the best protection. (See more below) Officials say the affected students have been quarantined, which should help stop the spread of the virus.\n\nA map showing the location of New York State in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/56406. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Massachusetts: Harvard University\nDate: Fri 18 Nov 2016 6:45 AM EST\nSource: Mass Live [edited]\nhttp://www.masslive.com/news/boston/index.ssf/2016/11/four_harvard_students_diagnose.html\n\n\n[According to officials at Harvard University and a report by The Boston Globe, 4 students have been diagnosed with the mumps virus.]\n\nThe contagious virus hit the campus in an outbreak last spring [2016], which peaked at 66 active cases and resulted in school health officials quarantining some students, according to The Harvard Crimson.\n\nThe reemergence of mumps, eradicated from the campus as of September [2016], has Harvard staff working with local public health officials to investigate a possible connection between the former outbreak and the new infections.\n\nExperts say living in close quarters -- such as college dorms -- makes one particularly susceptible to mumps, even if they have been vaccinated.\n\nThe disease is rare. An average year in the US sees no more than several thousand cases of mumps.\n\nSwelling in the salivary glands is one of the key symptoms of mumps. Infected people also suffer fevers, aches, and muscle fatigue. The disease is highly contagious and can spread through respiratory droplets, caused by a cough or sneeze.\n\nMost people in the developed world receive the mumps vaccine as children, which has lead to the disease being nearly eradicated. However, according to the World Health Organization, the vaccine is only 85 percent effective.\n\nHarvard officials have asked students to make health and prevention a top priority. Last spring [2016], over a dozen Harvard students were quarantined to prevent the spread.\n\nHarvard is not the only school dealing with a mumps problem. Tufts university confirmed 9 cases in the past 3 weeks, and Framingham State University also had a student test positive for mumps earlier in the fall, The Boston Globe reported.\n\n[Byline: Alban Murtishi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Massachusetts in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4323. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Missouri: University of Missouri\nDate: Thu 17 Nov 2016 15:27 GMT\nSource: Mail Online/Daily Mail, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://dailym.ai/2grwUeo\n\n\nThere are another 27 probable cases of people [at the University of Missouri] who have been in close contact with someone with confirmed mumps showing symptoms for at least 2 days. The university says it's working with health officials to control the outbreak.\n\nMumps is a viral infection that causes swelling in the salivary glands and cheeks. Anyone with symptoms is asked to stay at home.\n\nIt has been on the rise nationally this year.\n\nThe [US] Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says 2345 mumps cases had been reported as of last month [October 2016].\nThat's more than twice as many as in all of 2015.\n\nOther universities also have reported cases this year [2016], including Harvard. Last week it emerged more than a dozen students have contracted mumps at the State University of New York [SUNY; see item [1] above].\n\nThe outbreak [at University of Missouri], first reported last month [October 2016], started on the school's swim team. This week, 4 unrelated students were diagnosed with the debilitating infection.\n\nIt is the latest in a serious of outbreaks across the country in the last few months.\n\nDozens were diagnosed with mumps in New York City in August [2016], just weeks before more than 400 people were struck down with the virus across Arkansas.\n\nThe escalating outbreak at SUNY has sparked an urgent investigation to contain the spread, with swim team practice suspended until further notice.\n\nAny students yet to get the MMR (mumps, measles, rubella) vaccination have been ordered to stay at home for 26 days. But the school insists tours for prospective students will continue as normal.\n\nThe infection is incurable and can lead to devastating health concerns in adults. Sufferers have lost their hearing, become infertile, and had swollen brains. Some people do not experience any symptoms. Typically, symptoms include swollen glands, headaches, a fever, chills, fatigue, and a lack of appetite. Sufferers have described feeling pain in their stomach, neck, pelvis, and testicles.\n\nSince widespread implementation of the MMR jab, it is now barely reported. As the maps [included with this report at the source URL above] show, incidents of mumps are few and vaccinations rates are high.\n\nA mumps infection can also travel to and infect other parts of the body. When this occurs it often causes swelling and discomfort in the affected area. One of those developments is orchitis, [a swelling of one or both testicles], which affects around 25 percent of post-pubescent males. Roughly half the time it also causes the affected testicle to shrink in size. Mumps can also lead to viral meningitis, acute pancreatitis, and oophoritis (swelling of one or both ovaries). In very rare cases (around 0.1 per cent) mumps can cause encephalitis, a life-threatening inflammation of the brain. Symptoms of encephalitis include flu-like symptoms, headache, confusion, dizziness, change in personality, change in behavior, drowsiness, disorientation, seizures, and loss of consciousness.\n\nAnyone suffering these symptoms after contracting mumps should call 911 immediately. This condition requires emergency treatment in a hospital's intensive care unit (ICU).\n\n[Byline: Mia De Graaf]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[One of the 2 maps appended to this report shows how many Americans have received the MMR vaccine and the rates of mumps infection per state. The proportion immunized ranges from 81.7-99.7 percent, according to the CDC. The other map shows the mumps incidence per 100 000 people from 0 to 4.31 in 2014, as reported to the CDC. Mumps is a nationally notifiable disease, meaning that any cases must be reported to the local public health department, which in turn will report them to the CDC.\n\nA map showing the location of Missouri in the United States can be fund at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16851. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] Maine: local colleges, CDC\nDate: Fri 18 Nov 2016\nSource: Epi-X (The Epidemic Information Exchange) [edited]\n\n\nNotification of potential mumps exposure at colleges in Maine -- 2016\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Maine Center for Disease Control and Prevention is investigating an outbreak of mumps associated with local colleges. Bates College in Lewiston, Maine, first identified a case with symptom onset on 27 Sep 2016 and transmission continues with new cases identified this week [week of 14 Nov 2016]. Bowdoin College identified a case with symptom onset on 31 Oct 2016 in an individual with an epi-link to Bates College. Bowdoin then identified subsequent cases.\n\nBoth colleges are on Thanksgiving break starting Sat 19 Nov 2016 and exposed students may be traveling during this time.\n\nHealth departments investigating possible mumps cases in persons with a link to Bates or Bowdoin College should be aware of the potential for exposure and are asked to contact Maine Center for Disease Control and Prevention\n\n[Byline: Sara Robinson, Kijafa Dickinson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The link to this report is not publicly available, but ProMED-mail considers it useful to disseminate and share the information.\n\nA map showing the location of Maine in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/222. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[5] Iowa (Dubuque County)\nDate: Fri 18 Nov 2016 12:52 PM CST\nSource: WQAD 8, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://wqad.com/2016/11/18/mumps-outbreak-in-eastern-iowa-is-worst-in-a-decade/\n\n\nHealth officials are puzzled by an outbreak of the mumps among Dubuque County students that has now climbed to 30 cases, which is more than 1/3 of all cases statewide.\n\nAccording to Dubuque County Health Department executive director Patrice Lambert, the source of the outbreak has not yet been determined. Lambert says this is the worst outbreak in 10 years in the county.\n\nDubuque Community School District' health services coordinator, Rhonda Ramler, says officials haven't seen a pattern to the students who have been affected.\n\nThe Telegraph Herald reports that precautions are being taken to try and halt the spread of the disease, which can cause fever, headaches, and swollen salivary glands.\n\nA spokesperson from the Scott County Health Department said there are currently no known cases of mumps in the Quad-Cities area [Scott County in southeastern Iowa and Henry, Mercer, and Rock Island counties in northwest Illinois; the main cities are Davenport and Bettendorf in Iowa, and Rock Island and Moline in Illinois].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Iowa in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29642. An Iowa county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/iowa-county-map.gif.\n\nMumps cases are surging in US colleges and schools this year, 2016. It is not clear why this large increase in cases is occurring.\n\nMumps is no longer very common in the United States. From year to year, mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. For example in 2010, there were 2612 cases reported to CDC, and in 2012, there were 229. Before the US mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States.\n\nMMR vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. 2 doses of the vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66 to 95 percent) effective at protecting against mumps; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49 to 92 percent) effective. The MMR vaccine protects against currently circulating mumps strains. Outbreaks can still occur in highly vaccinated US communities, particularly in close-contact settings. In recent years, outbreaks have occurred in schools, colleges, and camps. However, high vaccination coverage helps limit the size, duration, and spread of mumps outbreaks.\n\nExcerpted and edited from http://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "\n\nHealth departments investigating possible mumps cases in persons with a link to Bates or Bowdoin College should be aware of the potential for exposure and are asked to contact Maine Center for Disease Control and Prevention\n\n[Byline: Sara Robinson, Kijafa Dickinson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[One of the 2 maps appended to this report shows how many Americans have received the MMR vaccine and the rates of mumps infection per state. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is highly contagious and is characterized by fever, headache and fatigue, among other symptoms. Date: Fri 18 Nov 2016 12:52 PM CST\nSource: WQAD 8, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://wqad.com/2016/11/18/mumps-outbreak-in-eastern-iowa-is-worst-in-a-decade/ Source: Epi-X (The Epidemic Information Exchange) [edited]\n\n\nNotification of potential mumps exposure at colleges in Maine -- 2016\n \n\nMMR vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. MUMPS - USA (26): UNIVERSITIES, SCHOOLS\n***************************************\n \n\nMumps is a highly contagious viral disease characterized by fever, headache and swelling of the salivary glands. \n\nDozens were diagnosed with mumps in New York City in August [2016], just weeks before more than 400 people were struck down with the virus across Arkansas. Health officials are puzzled by an outbreak of the mumps among Dubuque County students that has now climbed to 30 cases, which is more than 1/3 of all cases statewide. Date: Fri 18 Nov 2016 6:45 AM EST\nSource: Mass Live [edited]\nhttp://www.masslive.com/news/boston/index.ssf/2016/11/four_harvard_students_diagnose.html \n\nAny students yet to get the MMR (mumps, measles, rubella) vaccination have been ordered to stay at home for 26 days. \n\nMost people in the developed world receive the mumps vaccine as children, which has lead to the disease being nearly eradicated. \n\nThe affected students, who have been immunized against mumps, have been isolated for the recommended period of time. \n\nExperts say living in close quarters -- such as college dorms -- makes one particularly susceptible to mumps, even if they have been vaccinated. \n\nMumps is a viral infection that causes swelling in the salivary glands and cheeks. \n\nOther universities also have reported cases this year [2016], including Harvard. \n\nThe outbreak [at University of Missouri], first reported last month [October 2016], started on the school's swim team. \n\nSwelling in the salivary glands is one of the key symptoms of mumps. \n\nDubuque Community School District' health services coordinator, Rhonda Ramler, says officials haven't seen a pattern to the students who have been affected. \n\n--\n [Byline: Mia De Graaf]\n\n--\n \n\n--\n 2 doses of the vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66 to 95 percent) effective at protecting against mumps; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49 to 92 percent) effective. Before the US mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. In this update:\n[1] New York: State University of New York (SUNY) at New Paltz\n \n\n\nThere are another 27 probable cases of people [at the University of Missouri] who have been in close contact with someone with confirmed mumps showing symptoms for at least 2 days. \n\nBoth colleges are on Thanksgiving break starting Sat 19 Nov 2016 and exposed students may be traveling during this time. (Dubuque County)\n\n******\n LK]\n\n******\n LK]\n\n******\n \n\nAnyone suffering these symptoms after contracting mumps should call 911 immediately. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nA mumps infection can also travel to and infect other parts of the body. Mumps is a nationally notifiable disease, meaning that any cases must be reported to the local public health department, which in turn will report them to the CDC. \n\nHarvard is not the only school dealing with a mumps problem.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2016-10-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-09-27 00:00:00", "2021-08-25 00:00:00", "2016-11-14 00:00:00", "2612-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2345-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Henry", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Davenport", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scott County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lewiston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dubuque County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rock Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4459649", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (17): (AR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4459649", "date": "2016-09-02 12:42:58", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (17): (ARKANSAS)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 31 Aug 2016\nSource: Bristol Herald Courier [edited]\nhttp://www.heraldcourier.com/news/health-agency-reports-mumps-outbreak-in-northwest-arkansas/article_89e9be81-6a98-5a4a-86fa-1c79a6aa34a3.html\n\n\nArkansas' biggest cluster of mumps cases in more than 5 years has been confirmed in the north west part of the state, and unvaccinated students at affected schools are being asked to stay home until the outbreak ends. There are 2 confirmed cases and 7 suspected cases of mumps in the Springdale area, which is the largest cluster since 2010, the Arkansas Department of Health said on Wed 31 Aug [2016].\n\nThe outbreak currently affects 4 schools in the Springdale School District. Health Department spokeswoman Meg Mirivel said that unvaccinated students who attend a school with a confirmed case of mumps must stay home for 26 calendar days -- the maximum incubation period for mumps -- from the point of exposure. Mirivel said those afflicted include both vaccinated and unvaccinated people.\n\nMumps is a viral infection that causes swelling in the salivary glands and cheeks. Those with the illness may also have headaches, fatigue, muscle aches, and low-grade fevers.\n\n'Mumps is easily spread from person to person,' state epidemiologist Dr Dirk Haselow said. 'We expect to see more cases in the coming weeks. We urge Arkansans to make sure that they and their loved ones are up-to-date on the MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) vaccine.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[MMR vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. 2 doses of the vaccine are 88 per cent (range: 66-95 per cent) effective at preventing mumps; one dose is 78 per cent (range: 49-92 per cent) effective.\n\nSee further discussion of the measles, mumps, rubella vaccine in ProMED-mail posts listed below.\n\nA map of the USA showing location of Arkansas can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/208. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "We urge Arkansans to make sure that they and their loved ones are up-to-date on the MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) vaccine.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[MMR vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Health Department spokeswoman Meg Mirivel said that unvaccinated students who attend a school with a confirmed case of mumps must stay home for 26 calendar days -- the maximum incubation period for mumps -- from the point of exposure. 2 doses of the vaccine are 88 per cent (range: 66-95 per cent) effective at preventing mumps; one dose is 78 per cent (range: 49-92 per cent) effective. \n\n\nArkansas' biggest cluster of mumps cases in more than 5 years has been confirmed in the north west part of the state, and unvaccinated students at affected schools are being asked to stay home until the outbreak ends.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4562698", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (22): (AR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4562698", "date": "2016-10-16 05:36:07", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (22): (ARKANSAS)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 15 Oct 2016\nSource: Northwest Arkansas Democrat Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.nwaonline.com/news/2016/oct/15/mumps-outbreak-is-state-s-largest-in-de/\n\n\nNorth west Arkansas' mumps outbreak is the state's largest in at least 2 decades and is one of the bigger outbreaks in the country in recent years, state officials said this week. The Arkansas Health Department counted 520 confirmed or strongly suspected cases of the virus in Springdale, Rogers and Bentonville as of late Thursday [13 Oct 2016]. Dr Dirk Haselow, an epidemiologist with the department, said on Wednesday [12 Oct 2016] that he expects the number to keep rising for some time.\n\n'Two weeks ago, I would have been much more confident that this outbreak was dampening,' he said. 'Right now it looks like it's taking another step up.' Haselow said the state before this outbreak typically saw 4 or so cases a year of the disease. Mumps often causes flu-like aches and fever along with swollen salivary glands around the face, but rarely leads to more serious ailments. There's no treatment specific to the virus, so people who catch it must wait it out.\n\nThe state's data doesn't go back more than about 20 years, making it difficult to know for sure when Arkansas last had so many mumps cases, Haselow said. The outbreak is an unusual spike in mumps cases for Arkansas since the vaccine was developed in the 1960s, which drove the nation's cases down from hundreds of thousands each year to a couple thousand or fewer in each of the past 5 years.\n\nTwo doses of the vaccine generally protect 88 per cent of the people who receive it from any symptoms, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. People who fall into the 12 per cent often experience shorter and less severe symptoms even if they catch the virus, Haselow has said, but they can still spread it, as can people who aren't vaccinated.\n\nThose immunity gaps are enough for mumps to get a foothold, at least for a while. The federal disease centers tracked a 2014 outbreak in Ohio that affected more than 400 people, and another around 2010 in Guam affected about 500 people. Others have affected thousands of people. In 2006, an outbreak that spread over several Midwestern states and college campuses eventually reached more than 6000 people, according to CDC.\n\nArkansas' outbreak seems to have been sparked by another in Iowa in the past year or so. Health officials there counted almost 600 cases from January to August [2016], according to the Iowa Center for Acute Disease Epidemiology.\n\nLike an ember flying away from a fire, a traveler chaperoning several children from north west Arkansas as they flew back home in early August [2016] seems to have carried the virus to Springdale, Haselow said. It spread into a single family, then appears to have spread into their church before reaching several public schools. The 1st schools affected grouped around US 412 in eastern Springdale, according to the Health Department. The cluster of schools then spread through town westward to Tontitown. Rogers schools were affected next, mostly around US 71 Business. At least one probable case was found at Bentonville's Washington Junior High School last week.\n\nThe virus can survive only moments on a surface, but the districts have nonetheless been cleaning buses and school surfaces and keeping an eye out for symptoms since the outbreak's start. For the most part, there hasn't been virus transmission from one school student to another, Haselow said.\n\n'The fact that we have it here is somewhat random,' said Dr Gary Wheeler, chief medical officer for the Health Department, adding occasional outbreaks somewhere in the country are inevitable. Where Iowa's mumps came from is less clear, said Dr Patricia Quinlisk, Iowa's state epidemiologist. The state's outbreak centered on the University of Iowa, where students and other residents often travel to and from other states, athletic events and other colleges. The virus can be spread by coughing, sneezing and kissing and spreads more readily in places where people live close together, which can make campuses particularly vulnerable. Quinlisk said the primary outbreak seems to have wound down by early this year, partly thanks to 3rd doses of the vaccine for thousands of students. 'However, it did get seeded out to other parts of Iowa, so we continue to see small outbreaks around the state,' she added. 'We're still higher than we would be in a normal year.'\n\nArkansas has also started tackling the outbreak with 3rd vaccine doses in some cases. The Health Department offered targeted vaccine clinics at more than a dozen specific workplaces and schools where the virus has been particularly common and organized 2 free public vaccine clinics so far at the Jones Center in Springdale. More than 2500 vaccine doses have been given out as of this week as part of the outbreak response, according to the Health Department, including almost 500 at the 2nd Jones Center clinic Thursday [13 Oct 2016].\n\nThat doesn't count the thousands or tens of thousands of people who haven't had to deal with the disease thanks to the vaccine's protection, Wheeler said, praising Springdale Public Schools for a relatively high vaccination rate. The Health Department hasn't seen other complications such as encephalitis or hospitalizations at all. 'It's paying off,' Wheeler said of vaccinations, adding that despite the growing number of cases, 'it's relatively contained still.'\n\n[byline: Dan Holtmeyer]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[More than 30 schools in north west Arkansas have reported at least one student with the mumps virus. Now those cases are spreading to adults, according to Dr Dirk Haselow, the epidemiologist quoted above. The clinics administering vaccine and a 3rd dose should help bring this outbreak of unprecedented size under control.\n\nA map of Arkansas is available at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/208. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Dan Holtmeyer]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[More than 30 schools in north west Arkansas have reported at least one student with the mumps virus. Source: Northwest Arkansas Democrat Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.nwaonline.com/news/2016/oct/15/mumps-outbreak-is-state-s-largest-in-de/\n\n\nNorth west Arkansas' mumps outbreak is the state's largest in at least 2 decades and is one of the bigger outbreaks in the country in recent years, state officials said this week. \n\nThat doesn't count the thousands or tens of thousands of people who haven't had to deal with the disease thanks to the vaccine's protection, Wheeler said, praising Springdale Public Schools for a relatively high vaccination rate. The outbreak is an unusual spike in mumps cases for Arkansas since the vaccine was developed in the 1960s, which drove the nation's cases down from hundreds of thousands each year to a couple thousand or fewer in each of the past 5 years. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Quinlisk said the primary outbreak seems to have wound down by early this year, partly thanks to 3rd doses of the vaccine for thousands of students. ' In 2006, an outbreak that spread over several Midwestern states and college campuses eventually reached more than 6000 people, according to CDC.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Springdale", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bentonville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "tontitown", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4478210", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (18): (AR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4478210", "date": "2016-09-10 09:32:10", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (18): (ARKANSAS)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (Arkansas) outbreak\n[2] USA (Arkansas) spread\n\n******\n[1] USA (Arkansas) outbreak\nDate: Fri 2 Sep 2016\nSource: ArkansasMatters, KNWA report [edited]\nhttp://www.arkansasmatters.com/news/local-news/ar-mumps-outbreak-numbers-still-rising\n\n\nArkansas Mumps Outbreak Numbers Still Rising\n--------------------------------------------\nThere are now 4 confirmed cases of mumps and 48 reported cases in Northwest Arkansas, according to the Arkansas Department of Health (ADH).\n\nThat brings the total of reported mumps cases to 52.\n\nOn Thursday [1 Sep 2016], there were 2 confirmed cases and 37 reported cases of mumps. Meg Mirivel with the ADH said she expects the number to rise.\n\nThe 'outbreak' began on Wednesday [31 Aug 2016] with 8 reported cases of mumps. The number has since increased by 6 times.\n\nThe ADH said there is a concern with potential for exposure because of the Labor Day [5 Sep 2016] holiday weekend travel. The department said it can be weeks before symptoms appear.\n\nMumps symptoms include fever, headache, muscles aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite. There is no treatment, and symptoms usually resolve themselves within a few weeks. Mumps is usually a mild disease in children, but adults may have more serious disease with complications, according to the ADH.\n\nThe current CDC recommendations for MMR vaccination are as follows:\n\n- For children younger than 6 years of age, 1 dose of MMR vaccine or MMRV (measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella) vaccine at age 12-15 months, followed by a 2nd dose of either MMR vaccine or MMRV vaccine at age 4-6 years.\n\n- For children age 7 through 18 years not previously vaccinated, 1 dose of MMR vaccine or MMRV vaccine, followed by a 2nd dose of either MMR vaccine or MMRV vaccine at least 4 weeks after the 1st dose.\n\n- For adults born in 1957 or later and not previously vaccinated, 1 dose of MMR vaccine.\n\n- A 2nd dose of MMR vaccine is recommended for adults born in 1957 or later, who are students in a post-secondary educational institution, work in a health care facility, or plan to travel internationally. The 2nd dose should be administered a minimum of 28 days after the 1st dose.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The previous post on mumps in Arkansas indicated those afflicted include both vaccinated and unvaccinated individuals. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Arkansas) spread\nDate: Thu 8 Sep 2016\nSource: Greenwich Time, AP (Associated Press) report [edited]\nhttp://www.greenwichtime.com/news/education/article/Northwest-Arkansas-mumps-outbreak-spreads-into-9211309.php\n\n\nNorthwest Arkansas mumps outbreak spreads into Rogers\n-----------------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of mumps in northwest Arkansas has spread into Rogers [in Benton County, northwest Arkansas].\n\nRogers School District spokeswoman Ashley Siwiec told reporters Thursday [8 Sep 2016] that at least 2 students likely had mumps.\n\nArkansas Health Department epidemiologist Dr. Dirk Haselow said there are 76 confirmed or suspected cases of the virus that was 1st found in late August [2016] in Springdale schools [in Washington and Benton counties, northwest Arkansas].\n\nThe outbreak is the state's largest since 2010 when 5 cases were confirmed. It's centered in northwest Arkansas, where the Health Department says the opt-out rate for vaccinations exceeds any other area of the state. State law allows parents to claim medical, religious or philosophical exemptions from school vaccination requirements.\n\nMumps is a viral infection that causes swelling in the salivary glands and cheeks and may include headaches, fatigue, muscle aches and low-grade fevers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps virus is an enveloped single-stranded, linear negative-sense RNA virus of the Rubulavirus genus and Paramyxovirus family. Initial signs and symptoms often include fever, muscle pain, headache, and feeling tired. This is then usually followed by painful swelling of one or both parotid glands. Symptoms typically occur 16 to 18 days after exposure and resolve after 7 to 10 days. Symptoms in adults are often more severe than in children. About 1/3rd of people have mild or no symptoms. Complications may include infections of the covering of the brain (15 percent), pancreatitis (4 percent), permanent deafness, and painful testicular swelling which uncommonly results in infertility.\n\nMumps can be prevented with MMR (measles-mumps-rubella) vaccine. MMR vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. Two doses of the vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective at preventing mumps; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49-92 percent) effective.\n\nSee Mumps - USA (17): (AR) 20160902.4459649 for further discussion of mumps outbreak in Arkansas.\n\nA map of the USA showing the location of Arkansas can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/208. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "\n\nThe current CDC recommendations for MMR vaccination are as follows:\n\n- For children younger than 6 years of age, 1 dose of MMR vaccine or MMRV (measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella) vaccine at age 12-15 months, followed by a 2nd dose of either MMR vaccine or MMRV vaccine at age 4-6 years. \n\n- For children age 7 through 18 years not previously vaccinated, 1 dose of MMR vaccine or MMRV vaccine, followed by a 2nd dose of either MMR vaccine or MMRV vaccine at least 4 weeks after the 1st dose. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The previous post on mumps in Arkansas indicated those afflicted include both vaccinated and unvaccinated individuals.
