Source: ArkansasMatters, KNWA report [edited]\nhttp://www.arkansasmatters.com/news/local-news/ar-mumps-outbreak-numbers-still-rising\n\n\nArkansas Mumps Outbreak Numbers Still Rising\n \n\n- A 2nd dose of MMR vaccine is recommended for adults born in 1957 or later, who are students in a post-secondary educational institution, work in a health care facility, or plan to travel internationally. Two doses of the vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective at preventing mumps; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49-92 percent) effective. MUMPS - USA (18): (ARKANSAS)\n****************************\n \n\n- For adults born in 1957 or later and not previously vaccinated, 1 dose of MMR vaccine. \n\nMumps can be prevented with MMR (measles-mumps-rubella) vaccine. \n\nSee Mumps - USA (17): (AR) 20160902.4459649 for further discussion of mumps outbreak in Arkansas. \n\nMumps is a viral infection that causes swelling in the salivary glands and cheeks and may include headaches, fatigue, muscle aches and low-grade fevers. On Thursday [1 Sep 2016], there were 2 confirmed cases and 37 reported cases of mumps. \n\nMumps symptoms include fever, headache, muscles aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite. \nAn outbreak of mumps in northwest Arkansas has spread into Rogers [in Benton County, northwest Arkansas]. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps virus is an enveloped single-stranded, linear negative-sense RNA virus of the Rubulavirus genus and Paramyxovirus family.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella", "varicella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-08-31 00:00:00", "2016-09-08 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-09-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Benton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MMRV", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "springdale", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "mmrv", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Benton County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4528777", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (20)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4528777", "date": "2016-10-01 11:13:15", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (20)\n****************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (Arkansas, Oklahoma)\n[2] USA (Arkansas)\n[3] USA (California)\n\n******\n[1] USA (Arkansas, Oklahoma)\nDate: Tue 20 Sep 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/arkansas-mumps-outbreak-tops-200-oklahoma-outbreak-up-10-90200/\n\n\nIn a follow-up on the mumps outbreaks in Arkansas and Oklahoma, health officials in Arkansas have seen the outbreak top 200 cases with official suspected and lab confirmed cases now at 210.\n\nThe outbreak affects 30 schools in the Huntsville, Rogers, and Springdale School Districts in northwest Arkansas.\n\nIn the mumps outbreak in Garfield County, Oklahoma, the number of cases has risen to 14, up 10 cases in less than a week. State and local public health officials are working closely with schools and healthcare providers to rapidly identify suspected cases and exclude affected persons from childcare centers, schools or workplaces during the timeframe they are able to transmit mumps to other persons.\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), mumps is a viral illness that is transmitted by direct contact with respiratory droplets or saliva from an infected person. It is best known for painful, swollen salivary glands that show up as puffy cheeks and swollen jaw. Boys may also have painful, swollen testicles. Other symptoms include fever, headache, muscles aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite. There is no treatment, and symptoms usually resolve themselves within a few weeks. Mumps is usually a mild disease in children, but adults may have more serious disease with complications.\n\nThe measles mumps rubella [MMR] vaccine is safe and effective. Two doses of MMR vaccine is 88 percent effective in preventing mumps\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org\n\n[See more on the mumps outbreak in Arkansas below. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Arkansas)\nDate: Fri 30 Sep 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/mumps-cases-continue-climb-in-northwest-arkansas-70127/\n\n\nThe mumps outbreak that has affected 3 counties in northwest Arkansas continues to grow. As of Friday [30 Sep 2016], The Arkansas Department of Health (ADH) puts the case count at 376 under investigation.\n\nBenton, Washington, and Madison, all in the northwestern corner of the state, remain the only counties involved.\n\nADH reports the outbreak has affected 11 workplaces and 3 school districts and 35 schools in the above counties.\n\nTwo-thirds of the cases are reported in school aged children (242), prompting health officials to target the outbreak response to minimizing transmission within the impacted schools. ADH is requiring students who have a mumps, measles, and rubella (MMR) vaccine exemption to be excluded from school for 26 days from the date of exposure or for the duration of the outbreak, whichever is longer.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is safe and effective. Two doses of MMR vaccine is 88 percent effective in preventing mumps. It is a live virus vaccine and is not recommended for pregnant women or patients with a weakened immune system. Adults born before 1957 are generally considered to be immune to mumps and do not need to receive the MMR vaccine.\n\nNationally, the CDC has reported 1897 mumps cases from 44 states through 10 Sep [2016].\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] USA (California)\nDate: Thu 29 Sep 2016\nSource: Outbreak News today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/mumps-on-college-campuses-cal-state-san-marcos-student-the-latest-67093/\n\n\nSan Diego health officials have reported a mumps case in an undergraduate student at California State University San Marcos. The San Diego County Health and Human Services Agency says the student may have exposed others on campus between 6-9 and 12-14 [Sep 2016].\n\nThe student lived off campus and was up-to-date with mumps vaccinations, but was diagnosed with the highly contagious viral disease by blood tests reported to the County this week. The student was not hospitalized and has recovered.\n\nIndividuals can become ill with mumps 12-25 days after exposure.\n\nThis case is not related to the possible mumps exposure at the Casbah music venue on 28 Aug [2016]. It is not known where the student was exposed to the viral illness.\n\n'Cal State San Marcos is working closely with the County to notify individuals who were directly exposed to the person with mumps,' said Wilma Wooten, M.D., M.P.H., County public health officer. 'We are encouraging immunizations for students and staff who are not up-to-date.'\n\nMumps is a highly contagious viral disease. It is spread by coughing, sneezing or close contact with an infected person. Mumps causes a fever, headache, earache, and inflammation of the salivary glands which results in swelling and tenderness at the angle of the jaw. Anyone who thinks that they may have mumps should contact their provider before going for care so proper precautions can be taken to prevent exposure to others.\n\nSevere complications are rare, but can include meningitis, decreased fertility, permanent hearing loss, and, in extreme cases, fetal loss during 1st trimester of pregnancy. There is no treatment for mumps. Most people recover without problems.\n\nThe best way to prevent mumps is by getting the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) vaccine. Two doses of the vaccine are recommended -- one at 12 to 15 months of age and another at 4 to 6 years of age. A 3rd booster shot is recommended for those in close living conditions when there is an outbreak.\n\nMumps is becoming increasingly more common on college campuses in the United States. The disease has been reported on multiple college campuses in 2016 including the State University of New York at Buffalo, Indiana University, University of Kentucky, University of San Diego, University of Southern Maine, Saint Anselm College in New Hampshire and Harvard University [in Massachusetts], among others.\n\n2016 has seen the most mumps cases in the US since 2010. Through 10 Sep [2016], the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has reported 1897 cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Any location where people are living in close contact is prime territory for spread of infectious diseases like mumps. But what is disturbing about these cases is that many of the students were fully vaccinated. This may indicate a booster is needed before entering college.\n\nA map of the United States may be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "Two doses of MMR vaccine is 88 percent effective in preventing mumps\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org\n\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe best way to prevent mumps is by getting the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) vaccine. USA (16): (NY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4446845", "date": "2016-08-28 10:38:14", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (16): (NEW YORK)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 26 Aug 2016\nSource: Patch [edited]\nhttp://patch.com/new-york/longbeach/long-beach-mumps-outbreak-growing-steadily\n\n\nThe outbreak of mumps in Long Beach is growing, according to health officials. Newsday reported that there have been 18 more recorded cases since the beginning of the month [August 2016], bringing the total to 36. The infection hasn't spread off the Barrier Island yet, officials have said.\n\nMumps mainly affects children. According to the Centers for Disease Control, mumps typically causes fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite and swollen and tender salivary glands. The swollen glands often give children a swollen, puffy face.\n\nIt is spread through coughs or sneezes by infected people but can also be spread by sharing and touching objects an infected person has touched. It often starts spreading before the salivary glands swell, so a person with mumps might be spreading it before they know they have it.\n\n[Byline: Alex Costello]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See discussion of the measles, mumps, rubella vaccine in previous ProMED-mail posts below.\n\nA HealthMap of New York, USA can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See discussion of the measles, mumps, rubella vaccine in previous ProMED-mail posts below. MUMPS - USA (16): (NEW YORK)\n****************************\n \n\nIt is spread through coughs or sneezes by infected people but can also be spread by sharing and touching objects an infected person has touched. It often starts spreading before the salivary glands swell, so a person with mumps might be spreading it before they know they have it.\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-08-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Long Beach", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4395407", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (15): (New York City) alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4395407", "date": "2016-08-05 13:11:07", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (15): (NEW YORK CITY) ALERT\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[The email version of this post erroneously inverted the viral name and family of virus name. This has been corrected in the archives. - Mod.MPP]\n\nDate: Wed 3 Aug 2016 14:06 EST\nSource: Daily Mail [edited]\nhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/article-3722300/Mumps-outbreak-NYC-two-dozen-adults-20s-30s-diagnosed-infection.html\n\n\nMumps is [a virus] that causes an infection of the salivary gland, preventable by MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine. The highly infectious virus is spread by saliva on cups, cutlery, plates, etc. Many do not experience symptoms but mumps can be devastating.\n\nMore than 2 dozen adults have contracted mumps in New York City, health officials fear. There are at least 18 people in their 20s and 30s currently being treated for the highly infectious virus in Long Beach -- and medics believe there are as many as 25.\n\nSince widespread implementation of the MMR jab, it is now barely reported. The sudden outbreak has shocked the medical community, since 97 per cent of New Yorkers have received the mumps, measles, and rubella (MMR) vaccine.\n\nIt sparks fears that there may be a new strain of the [virus].\n\nResidents on Long Island [New York] have been warned to wash all glasses, plates, and cutlery in a hot dishwasher to blitz the highly infectious virus, which is spread through saliva.\n\nAnd anyone who thinks they may have symptoms should self-quarantine for at least 5 days and seek medical help.\n\n'If you know you're sick please stay home and don't transmit this,' Nassau County Health Commissioner, Dr Lawrence Eisenstein, said. 'It is highly contagious, and even those who were vaccinated can get mumps.'\n\nHe said anyone who has only received one MMR jab should consider getting a top-up booster to protect against mumps.\n\nTypically, symptoms include puffy cheeks, swollen glands, headaches, a fever, chills, fatigue, muscle aches, and a lack of appetite. Sufferers have described feeling pain in their stomach, neck, pelvis, and testicles. Sufferers have lost their hearing, become infertile, and had swollen brains. Some people do not experience any symptoms.\n\nA mumps infection can also travel to and infect other parts of the body. When this occurs it often causes swelling and discomfort in the affected area.\n\nOne of those developments is orchitis, [an inflammation of one or both testicles, which affects around 25 per cent of post-pubescent males. Roughly half the time it also causes the affected testicle to shrink in size.\n\nMumps can also lead to viral meningitis, acute pancreatitis, and oophoritis (swelling of one or both ovaries). In very rare cases (around 0.1 per cent) mumps can cause encephalitis, a life-threatening inflammation of the brain. Symptoms of encephalitis include flu-like symptoms, headache, confusion, dizziness, change in personality, change in behavior, drowsiness, disorientation, seizures, and loss of consciousness.\n\nAnyone suffering these symptoms after contracting mumps should call 911 immediately. This condition requires emergency treatment in a hospital's intensive care unit (ICU).\n\n[Byline: Mia De Graaf]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a viral illness caused by a _Rubulavirus_, a member of the _paramyxovirus_ family. These cases of mumps may be a consequence of unvaccinated individuals becoming infected, infection of immunized individuals with a mutated strain of the virus that is escaping antibody to the virus, or more likely, waning antibody.\n\nProtective levels of antibodies induced by the MMR vaccine were first suggested to be lifelong; however, the levels of measles, mumps, or rubella antibodies have been shown to decline over time, faster after vaccinations than when naturally acquired. ...\n\nThis was shown to happen especially when the incidence of measles, mumps, and rubella [in the population] became very low ... and natural diseases did not boost the once-gained antibody levels.\n\nA study conducted in Finland demonstrated that 15 years after the 2nd dose of the MMR vaccine, the rate of seropositivity in initially seronegative vaccinees was 95 percent, 74 percent, and 100 percent for measles, mumps, and rubella, respectively. However, the geometric mean levels of antibodies against all 3 viruses declined significantly from the levels achieved after the 2nd MMR dose, although with a slower rate of decline during the last 7 years. ...\n\nA relatively large number of [the Finnish] vaccinees have become seronegative to mumps during the follow-up period. The proportion of low-level (equivocal) antibodies against mumps was higher than for measles or rubella. However, the EIA [enzyme immunoassay] used may have influenced the mumps seropositivity rate, because it is known to have a lower sensitivity than the neutralization test and tends to overestimate equivocal and negative results. In addition, the mumps component of the trivalent MMR vaccine seems to be the weakest of the 3 antigens in inducing humoral immunity. At any rate, our recent study shows that cellular immunity to mumps persists at least 21 years after the first MMR vaccination and is not dependent on antibody status.\n\nExcerpted and edited from Davidkin I et al: Persistence of measles, mumps, and rubella antibodies in an MMR-vaccinated cohort: a 20-year follow-up. J Infect Dis. 2008; 197(7): 950-6. doi: 10.1086/528993; http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/197/7/950.long.\n\nAlso see discussion of measles, mumps, rubella vaccine in previous ProMED-mail posts.\n\nA map of New York, USA can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "\n\nA study conducted in Finland demonstrated that 15 years after the 2nd dose of the MMR vaccine, the rate of seropositivity in initially seronegative vaccinees was 95 percent, 74 percent, and 100 percent for measles, mumps, and rubella, respectively. \n\nProtective levels of antibodies induced by the MMR vaccine were first suggested to be lifelong; however, the levels of measles, mumps, or rubella antibodies have been shown to decline over time, faster after vaccinations than when naturally acquired. ... A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThis was shown to happen especially when the incidence of measles, mumps, and rubella [in the population] became very low ... and natural diseases did not boost the once-gained antibody levels. \n\n\nMumps is [a virus] that causes an infection of the salivary gland, preventable by MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a viral illness caused by a _Rubulavirus_, a member of the _paramyxovirus_ family. \n\nAlso see discussion of measles, mumps, rubella vaccine in previous ProMED-mail posts. These cases of mumps may be a consequence of unvaccinated individuals becoming infected, infection of immunized individuals with a mutated strain of the virus that is escaping antibody to the virus, or more likely, waning antibody. The sudden outbreak has shocked the medical community, since 97 per cent of New Yorkers have received the mumps, measles, and rubella (MMR) vaccine. \n\nMumps can also lead to viral meningitis, acute pancreatitis, and oophoritis (swelling of one or both ovaries). [New York] have been warned to wash all glasses, plates, and cutlery in a hot dishwasher to blitz the highly infectious virus, which is spread through saliva.\n\n \n\nAnyone suffering these symptoms after contracting mumps should call 911 immediately. \n\nA relatively large number of [the Finnish] vaccinees have become seronegative to mumps during the follow-up period. \n\nMore than 2 dozen adults have contracted mumps in New York City, health officials fear. There are at least 18 people in their 20s and 30s currently being treated for the highly infectious virus in Long Beach -- and medics believe there are as many as 25.\n\n It is highly contagious, and even those who were vaccinated can get mumps.'\n\n \n\nA mumps infection can also travel to and infect other parts of the body. I et al: Persistence of measles, mumps, and rubella antibodies in an MMR-vaccinated cohort: a 20-year follow-up. The proportion of low-level (equivocal) antibodies against mumps was higher than for measles or rubella. At any rate, our recent study shows that cellular immunity to mumps persists at least 21 years after the first MMR vaccination and is not dependent on antibody status. However, the geometric mean levels of antibodies against all 3 viruses declined significantly from the levels achieved after the 2nd MMR dose, although with a slower rate of decline during the last 7 years. ... \n\nOne of those developments is orchitis, [an inflammation of one or both testicles, which affects around 25 per cent of post-pubescent males. However, the EIA [enzyme immunoassay] used may have influenced the mumps seropositivity rate, because it is known to have a lower sensitivity than the neutralization test and tends to overestimate equivocal and negative results. In addition, the mumps component of the trivalent MMR vaccine seems to be the weakest of the 3 antigens in inducing humoral immunity. \n\nIt sparks fears that there may be a new strain of the [virus]. [Byline: Mia De Graaf]\n\n--\n MUMPS - USA (15): (NEW YORK CITY) ALERT\n In very rare cases (around 0.1 per cent) mumps can cause encephalitis, a life-threatening inflammation of the brain.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:20", "2021-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Long Beach", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK CITY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Long Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4545923", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Mumps - USA (21)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4545923", "date": "2016-10-08 23:10:45", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (21)\n****************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (Oklahoma)\n[2] USA (Washington)\n[3] USA (Arkansas) Marshallese\n\n******\n[1] USA (Oklahoma)\nDate: Tue 4 Oct 2016\nSource: News Desk [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/oklahoma-mumps-outbreak-tops-40-kay-county-child-confirmed-92978/\n\n\nOklahoma health officials today [4 Oct 2016] reported additional confirmed mumps cases, primarily in Garfield County.\n\nAccording to the Oklahoma State Department of Health (OSDH), the state's Epi team has reported 43 cases, with another 10 still under investigation.\n\nIn addition to the Garfield County cases, OSDH has reported a confirmed case of mumps in a Kay County school-aged child and a probable case of mumps in a Kay County adult.\n\nBoth cases have social connections with individuals who are part of the mumps outbreak in Garfield County. State and local public health officials are working closely with schools and healthcare providers to rapidly identify suspected mumps cases and exclude affected persons from childcare centers, schools or workplaces during the timeframe they are able to transmit mumps to other persons.\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Mumps is a viral illness that is transmitted by direct contact with respiratory droplets or saliva from an infected person. It is best known for painful, swollen salivary glands that show up as puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw. Boys may also have painful, swollen testicles. Other symptoms include fever, headache, muscles aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite. There is no treatment, and symptoms usually resolve themselves within a few weeks. Mumps is usually a mild disease in children, but adults may have more serious disease with complications.\n\n'If parents observe symptoms of mumps in their child, we are strongly requesting that the child be kept at home for the 5 days after those symptoms are discovered,' said State Epidemiologist Dr. Kristy Bradley. 'This is the most effective way to prevent the disease from spreading.'\n\nThe 2 doses of the MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine that are required for school attendance are 88 per cent effective in preventing mumps.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] USA (Washington)\nDate: Fri 7 Oct 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/spokanes-whitworth-university-reports-three-mumps-cases-97428/\n\n\nSpokane, WA health officials announced Wed [5 Oct 2016] 3 cases of mumps in Whitworth University students. The 1st case occurred when one of the students was exposed to mumps while traveling outside the U.S. The other 2 cases were contracted through close contact with the 1st student. All 3 individuals were fully immunized against the mumps.\n\nThe 3 students are no longer contagious and were in isolation while symptomatic. To date, there are no other known or suspected cases of mumps among the Whitworth community. The risk of acquiring mumps to Spokane's general population is low.\n\nA measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps. Even in a highly vaccinated population, it is possible that some people will get the illness. Whitworth requires students meet all of Washington state's immunization requirements.\n\nClose contacts of these 3 cases are being followed up on to monitor for symptoms. Whitworth University officials sent notifications to all other students and families.\n\nNancy Hines, Whitworth communications director, said: 'We take the health of our student, faculty and staff population seriously and are taking every precaution to mitigate the spread of mumps on our campus. With these 3 cases, we have armed our campus community with the necessary information to avoid the mumps infection.'\n\n'Although we hope to contain this to just 3 cases, mumps is spread from person to person when in close contact with each other,' said Dr. Joel McCullough, SRHD interim health officer. 'We urge individuals to make sure that they and their loved ones are up to date on the MMR vaccine.'\n\nIn children, mumps is usually a mild disease. Adults may have more serious disease and more complications.\n\nMumps is spread through saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat. An infected person can spread the virus by:\n- Coughing, sneezing, or talking.\n- Sharing items, such as cups or eating utensils, with others.\n- Touching objects or surfaces with unwashed hands that are then touched by others.\n\nThe infectious period of mumps is 3 days before to 5 days after the onset of salivary gland swelling. Other common symptoms include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite.\n\nOfficials from the health district and Whitworth University advise students, faculty, or staff who experience mumps symptoms to seek medical care, either through Whitworth Student Health & Counseling Center or other health care providers.\n\nIndividuals who are concerned about getting the mumps can reduce their risk of becoming ill by:\n- Getting vaccinated against the mumps.\n- People who have received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine are about 9 times less likely to get mumps than unvaccinated people who have the same exposure to mumps virus.\n- If a vaccinated person does get mumps, they will likely have less severe illness than an unvaccinated person.\n- Most children and young adults have received at least one dose of the MMR vaccine. Two doses of MMR vaccine are more effective than one dose.\n- Always covering nose and mouth when coughing or sneezing.\n- Washing hands frequently.\n- Disposing of used tissues and other similar objects appropriately.\n- Avoiding sharing glasses, eating utensils, water bottles, cigarettes, and makeup.\n\nSpokane County's last confirmed mumps case was in 2009. Counting Spokane's cases, since 1 Jan 2016, state health officials confirmed 6 cases of mumps in Washington state: the 3 in Spokane County and 3 cases unrelated to Spokane's outside Spokane County. In 2015, Washington confirmed 7 cases of mumps statewide.\n\nNationally, the CDC has reported 1897 mumps cases from 44 states through 10 Sep 2016.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is interesting to note, as in a number of previous ProMED reports, that the students were fully vaccinated when they contracted mumps. A 3rd vaccination just prior to entering college/university may be needed to boost protection for students living in close quarters. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] USA (Arkansas) Marshallese\nDate: Fri 7 Oct 2016\nSource: Epi-X [edited]\nNot publicly available\n\n\nThe Arkansas Department of Health continues to investigate and respond to a large outbreak of mumps in northwest Arkansas. The majority of cases are Marshallese and are believed to have common exposures within a local church and in school settings. MMR vaccination clinics are ongoing.\n\nDescription:\nThe Arkansas Department of Health (ADH) has been investigating an outbreak of mumps in northwest Arkansas (NWA) since mid-August [2016]. A CDC Epi-Aid team was deployed to Little Rock and NWA to assist with the outbreak response from 8 Oct 2016 until 28 Oct 2016.\n\nThe index case appears to be an unvaccinated 27-year-old woman with no international travel but who was visited by an individual who traveled from an area in Iowa where mumps was spreading at that time. As of Fri 7 Oct 2016, we are aware of 427 cases (196 laboratory confirmed via PCR) and 231 Epi-linked cases or clinically diagnosed). At least 25 additional suspects have pending laboratory testing at the state public health laboratory. The majority of cases are in Marshallese (66%) and are believed to have common exposures within a local church. Transmission has spread from that site to 37 schools in 4 different school districts, 17 businesses or work places, and 30 churches. The majority of cases are 5-17 years old (66%) with an age range of 7 months-82 years. Language barriers are a major issue in conducting investigations, as the majority of cases are Marshallese or Spanish speaking, and interpreters are needed to conduct effective interviews.\n\nVaccination clinics are ongoing. To date, approximately 2030 doses of MMR have been given at 17 vaccination clinics, and more clinics are scheduled in the coming weeks. As of today [7 Oct 2016], about 90% of cases in children are up-to-date on vaccine. In contrast, 35 per cent of adult cases are up-to-date.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Starting in August 2016, many cases of mumps have been reported in the Springdale [Arkansas] area through school and community transmission. As of Fri [7 Oct 2016], 322 suspected or lab confirmed cases have been reported in northwest Arkansas, where a large population of Marsallese live.\n\nMarshallese have been migrating from their North Pacific archipelago to the Ozark Mountains of Arkansas since the 1980s to earn money, educate their children, and seek medical care. The 2nd-largest U.S. continental population of Marshallese is concentrated in Springdale (Washington and Benton Counties; the 2010 federal census counted 4324 islanders in Arkansas).\n\nA Compact of Free Association with the United States was signed in 1986 which allows islanders to freely travel to the United States as migrants on just a passport, without visas or foreign employment credentials. Islander children born in the United States are conveyed citizenship.\n\nThe unique migration arrangement led to a Marshallese diaspora in the late 1980s. Islanders have settled in Hawaii, California, and Washington, but the largest continental population is located in Springdale, Arkansas.\n\nMarshallese in Arkansas generally live in multi-family, multi-generational households. Despite the amenities the Springdale area offers to the Marshallese, only American-born Marshallese children have access to U.S. entitlements. Compact migrants cannot participate in the American political system or legally apply for Medicaid, Medicare, Social Security, or ARKids First (S-Chip) supplements, even though taxes to support such entitlements are deducted from many U.S. migrants' paychecks. As a result, Arkansas communities are burdened with providing healthcare to islanders lacking resources. The population, which now consumes a western diet, is plagued by diabetes, heart disease, tuberculosis, and obesity. Hansen's disease is endemic. A remnant elder population suffers from effects of the Cold War-era nuclear bomb tests, and some experts believe that the entire population may be immunocompromised.\n\nWith federal start-up funding and support from the Arkansas Department of Health, a Marshallese clinic for working poor islanders opened in Springdale in 2011. Operating costs are shouldered by the state. An interdisciplinary and voluntary taskforce called 'Gaps in Services to Marshallese,' made up of both public and private social and healthcare experts guided by stakeholders, is dedicated to serving the pressing needs of islanders. Of some assistance is the federal Affordable Care Act of 2010, which will allow Marshallese to purchase health insurance through the national health insurance marketplace (coverage beginning in 2014). They will be eligible for tax-credit subsidies to aid in the purchase of the insurance.\nExcerpted from: http://www.encyclopediaofarkansas.net/encyclopedia/entry-detail.aspx?entryID=5972.\n\nIt is very likely this population had not been vaccinated with MMR vaccine, leading to this outbreak after exposure to an infected individual. But the vaccination clinics described in the report above should go a long way towards stopping this current outbreak. The best way to prevent a mumps outbreak is for a population to have a vaccination rate of at least 90-95 per cent to build herd immunity.\n\nA map of the US showing Oklahoma, Washington, and Arkansas is available at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Counting Spokane's cases, since 1 Jan 2016, state health officials confirmed 6 cases of mumps in Washington state: the 3 in Spokane County and 3 cases unrelated to Spokane's outside Spokane County. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n State and local public health officials are working closely with schools and healthcare providers to rapidly identify suspected mumps cases and exclude affected persons from childcare centers, schools or workplaces during the timeframe they are able to transmit mumps to other persons. \n\n'Although we hope to contain this to just 3 cases, mumps is spread from person to person when in close contact with each other,' said Dr. Joel McCullough, SRHD interim health officer. \n- People who have received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine are about 9 times less likely to get mumps than unvaccinated people who have the same exposure to mumps virus. \n\nThe 2 doses of the MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine that are required for school attendance are 88 per cent effective in preventing mumps. In addition to the Garfield County cases, OSDH has reported a confirmed case of mumps in a Kay County school-aged child and a probable case of mumps in a Kay County adult. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Starting in August 2016, many cases of mumps have been reported in the Springdale [Arkansas] area through school and community transmission. MUMPS - USA (21)\n****************\n http://outbreaknewstoday.com/spokanes-whitworth-university-reports-three-mumps-cases-97428/\n\n\nSpokane, WA health officials announced Wed [5 Oct 2016] 3 cases of mumps in Whitworth University students. http://outbreaknewstoday.com/oklahoma-mumps-outbreak-tops-40-kay-county-child-confirmed-92978/\n\n\nOklahoma health officials today [4 Oct 2016] reported additional confirmed mumps cases, primarily in Garfield County. \n\n'If parents observe symptoms of mumps in their child, we are strongly requesting that the child be kept at home for the 5 days after those symptoms are discovered,' said State Epidemiologist Dr. Kristy Bradley. ' \n\nBoth cases have social connections with individuals who are part of the mumps outbreak in Garfield County. A measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps. We urge individuals to make sure that they and their loved ones are up to date on the MMR vaccine.'\n\nIn children, mumps is usually a mild disease. Officials from the health district and Whitworth University advise students, faculty, or staff who experience mumps symptoms to seek medical care, either through Whitworth Student Health & Counseling Center or other health care providers. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is interesting to note, as in a number of previous ProMED reports, that the students were fully vaccinated when they contracted mumps. [3] USA (Arkansas) Marshallese\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Nationally, the CDC has reported 1897 mumps cases from 44 states through 10 Sep 2016. \n\nClose contacts of these 3 cases are being followed up on to monitor for symptoms. \n\nMumps is spread through saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat. \n\nSpokane County's last confirmed mumps case was in 2009. \n- Getting vaccinated against the mumps. With these 3 cases, we have armed our campus community with the necessary information to avoid the mumps infection.' To date, there are no other known or suspected cases of mumps among the Whitworth community. The Arkansas Department of Health (ADH) has been investigating an outbreak of mumps in northwest Arkansas (NWA) since mid-August [2016].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "plague", "rubella", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "1986-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-09-10 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-01-01 00:00:00", "1897-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Little Rock", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spokane County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spokane County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Springdale", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kay County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": USA (19)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4495932", "date": "2016-09-17 18:29:12", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (19)\n****************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (New York)\n[2] USA (Illinois): CDC guidance on MMR vaccine\n[3] USA (Oklahoma)\n[4] USA (New York)\n\n******\n[1] USA (New York)\nDate: Tue 13 Sep 2016\nSource: Newsday [edited]\nhttp://www.newsday.com/news/health/mumps-outbreak-in-long-beach-grows-to-nearly-50-cases-officials-say-1.12310605\n\n\nLong Beach [New York] mumps outbreak nears 50 cases, say officials\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe mumps outbreak that has been evident this summer in Long Beach has continued to grow as health experts across the country have begun documenting an unrelated spate of cases in nearly every state, health officials said Tuesday [13 Sep 2016].\n\nLocally, the outbreak has remained concentrated in the barrier island region where multiple suspect cases are under investigation by the State Department of Health.\n\n[byline: Delthia Ricks]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] USA (Illinois): CDC guidance on MMR vaccine\nDate: September 2016\nSource: Healio Infectious Disease News [edited]\nhttp://www.healio.com/infectious-disease/vaccine-preventable-diseases/news/print/infectious-disease-news/%7Be12a2a27-d121-4dc0-b05a-bbf77f921fd1%7D/cdc-considers-guidance-on-third-mmr-dose-following-campus-outbreak\n\n\nCDC considers guidance on 3rd MMR dose following campus outbreak\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently offered guidance on a 3rd dose of the measles-mumps-rubella [MMR] vaccine for adolescents and young adults following a recent mumps outbreak at the University of Illinois.\n\n'No formal recommendation for or against the use of a 3rd MMR dose has been issued by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP),' Justin P Albertson, MS, from the Illinois Department of Public Health, and colleagues wrote in a recent MMWR. 'However, CDC has provided guidelines for use of a 3rd dose as a control measure during mumps outbreaks in settings in which persons are in close contact with one another, where transmission is sustained despite high 2-dose MMR coverage, and when traditional control measures fail to slow transmission.'\n\nThe Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) confirmed an outbreak of mumps at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (C-UPHD) on 1 May 2015. Between April 2015 and May 2016, researchers identified 317 cases on campus. The university, IDPH and the university's McKinley Health Center recommended a 3rd MMR vaccination due to the seasonal trends and characteristics of the population at risk.\n\nAbout 50 000 students and staff members were targeted for 3rd-dose vaccination on C-UPHD campus. A total of 8200 doses of MMR were administered at multiple vaccination sites at the university between 6 and 27 Aug 2015 to determine if a 3rd dose of MMR would prevent further exposure of mumps to healthy staff and students. In addition, the C-UPHD center administered 3300 doses in the fall and spring semesters.\n\nEpidemiological analysis showed that all 317 cases of mumps were associated with the university. Cases in students totaled 278 (88 per cent), 3 (1 per cent) occurred in staff members and 36 (11 per cent) in people not associated with the university but who had contact with students or the campus grounds. Among those who were diagnosed at the time of parotitis onset, 50 patients had received 3 doses of MMR vaccine, 232 patients had received 2 doses, 12 patients had received 1 dose, 7 patients were unvaccinated and 16 patients were unaware if they had been vaccinated. 90 per cent of patients with a 3rd dose received it during the outbreak, and 10 per cent had received it previously independent of this outbreak, according to the researchers.\n\n'In light of the recent increased incidence of mumps, CDC is gathering additional data to assess use of a 3rd dose of vaccine to inform decision-making during outbreak responses and potential changes in the recommendations,' they wrote.\n\nReference:\nAlbertson JP, et al. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2016;doi:10.15585/mmwr.mm62529a2.\n\n[byline: Kate Sherrer]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[While a 3rd dose of the vaccine sounds like it might be helpful in boosting immunity, it must be given sufficiently prior to exposure for the immunity to be boosted to be protective. As noted above, 50 patients (out of 317) had received 3 doses of MMR vaccine. One must assume they were not vaccinated with the 3rd dose in time to protect them.\n\nA 3rd vaccination appears to have been very effective in the following study: Ogbuanu IU, et al. Pediatrics 2012; 130(6)(http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/pediatrics/early/2012/10/30/peds.2012-0177.full.pdf). This study was conducted to assess the impact of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine during an outbreak in 2009-2010 among school students in 6th-12th grade. The decline in incidence shortly after the intervention suggests that a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine may help control mumps outbreaks among populations with preexisting high 2-dose vaccine coverage. The results indicated that of 2265 eligible students, 2178 (96.2 per cent) provided documentation of having received 2 previous doses of MMR vaccine, and a high proportion (1755 or 80.6 per cent) chose to receive an additional vaccine dose. The overall attack rate for all 6th- to 12th-grade students declined from 4.93 per cent in the prevaccination period to 0.13 per cent after vaccination (P, .001). Villagewide, overall attack rate declined by 75.6 per cent after the intervention. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] USA (Oklahoma)\nDate: Thu 15 Sep 2016\nSource: Enid News & Eagle [edited]\nhttp://www.enidnews.com/news/local_news/update-some-in-suspected-mumps-outbreak-were-vaccinated/article_47c989a4-7b67-11e6-8e84-dffe3f42c206.html\n\n\nUpdate: Some in suspected mumps outbreak were vaccinated\n--------------------------------------------------------\nGarfield County Health Department has confirmed at least some of the individuals who have or are suspected of having mumps in Garfield County [Oklahoma] have been vaccinated against the disease.\n\n'I don't have numbers on this just yet -- but it does look as though some were fully vaccinated with MMR,' Carla Dionne, director of Garfield County Health Department, reported in an email to the Enid News & Eagle. She added that this particular vaccine -- measles, mumps and rubella -- 'is 88 per cent effective -- but not perfect. Individuals with 2 doses can still get mumps.'\n\nEnid Public Schools [EPS] sent out a text message Wednesday [14 Sep 2016] evening reporting that Garfield County Health Department has confirmed multiple cases of mumps in the community, including at Longfellow Middle School and Enid High School.\n\nOklahoma Health Department later reported there have been 4 confirmed cases in Garfield County and at least 34 suspected cases.\n\nEPS requires students to be in compliance with Oklahoma vaccination laws, EPS Communications Director Amber Graham Fitzgerald said. 'Prior to (Wednesday's) events, the EPS Health Services Department established (Thursday) as the deadline for compliance,' she said. 'Those not in compliance -- there are about 12 students who don't have the MMR vaccine -- will not be allowed to return to school until they are in compliance.' This does not include students who have a religious or physical exemption from vaccinations, she said.\n\nLaurence Burnsed, an epidemiologist with the Acute Disease Service for the Oklahoma State Department of Health, confirmed that some of those who are suspected of contracting the disease in Enid have been vaccinated and that others have not been or do not know if they have been vaccinated. 'That's what you might expect in an outbreak situation,' Burnsed said. 'If you have the recommended 2 doses of MMR, you're at an 88 per cent level of protection, so if 100 people were exposed, you would still have about 12 experiencing symptoms. The vaccine is not 100 per cent protective.' In the health department's collaboration with school officials, Burnsed said there seems to be a good level of vaccinations.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is available at Garfield County Health Department.\n\nMumps is a virus spread though coughing, sneezing and direct contact with saliva through eating or drinking after an infected person, according to Garfield County Health Department. Symptoms can last 7-10 days and usually appear 12-25 days after infection.\n\nMumps is characterized by puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw, due to swollen salivary glands. Other symptoms include body aches, tiredness and fever, and males may experience swollen, painful testicles, according to the department. In order to prevent spreading mumps, children who exhibit such symptoms should not attend school or day care through 5 days after the illness begins, according to the department.\n\nBurnsed encouraged those who have not been vaccinated or who are behind on their vaccination schedule to get the MMR vaccine to help protect against the illness. Burnsed also said the state department is not ruling out that Enid's suspected outbreak could be related to a similar outbreak in Arkansas. 'It's certainly possible, considering the proximity,' Burnsed said. 'But we are still gathering information.'\n\nOn Monday [12 Sep 2016], the Arkansas Department of Health reported almost 100 cases of mumps have been confirmed in the state, with most being in Springdale, but some reported in Rogers and potential cases in Fayetteville, Huntsville and West Fork, according to the Arkansas Democrat Gazette.\n\n[byline: Sally Asher]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The cases in Oklahoma had been fully vaccinated with 2 doses, but still came down with measles. This suggests 3 doses may be more protective. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] USA (New York)\nDate: Thu 15 Sep 2016\nSource: New York Upstate [edited]\nhttp://www.newyorkupstate.com/news/2016/09/ny_warns_state_colleges_about_mumps_outbreak.html\n\n\nNew York warns state colleges about mumps outbreak\n--------------------------------------------------\nA mumps case at SUNY [State University of New York] Oswego may be linked to an outbreak of the contagious viral infection in the Long Beach area of Long Island [New York]. The State Health Department is warning colleges throughout the state the Long Beach outbreak could lead to other cases. The State Health Department said public health officials on Long Island have identified 45 mumps cases related to the Long Beach outbreak since July [2016].\n\nA SUNY Plattsburgh student also was recently diagnosed with mumps, but the source of that infection is still under investigation.\n\nBoth schools have notified unvaccinated students they will be barred from campus for 26 days after the last possible exposure if they do not get vaccinated. The health department said this step is being taken to avoid a large outbreak.\n\nMumps is characterized by fever, headache, swelling of the salivary glands, fatigue, muscle aches and loss of appetite. After a person is exposed to mumps, symptoms usually appear 16 to 18 days after infection. Mumps cannot be treated.\n\nTwo doses of the mumps vaccine provides the best protection against the disease, according to the health department.\n\nThe department offered these tips to prevent the spread of mumps:\n- do not share food, drinks, utensils or other personal items that may contain saliva;\n- wash hands frequently with soap and water or use an alcohol-based hand rub;\n- cover your mouth with a tissue when sneezing or coughing and discard the tissue;\n- clean and disinfect objects and surfaces that may be contaminated with germs.\n\nPeople with mumps should stay home away from public places for 5 days after the onset of symptoms and limit contact with others in their households.\n\nMumps is no longer common in the United States. As of 13 Aug [2016], 1786 cases nationwide had been reported to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [in 2016].\n\n[byline: James T Mulder]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps may no longer be common in the US, but this year (2016) there appear to be a spate of cases throughout the country to the extent that CDC is considering a 3rd dose of the MMR vaccine in certain situations.\n\nA map of the US showing all states discussed can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: James T Mulder]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps may no longer be common in the US, but this year (2016) there appear to be a spate of cases throughout the country to the extent that CDC is considering a 3rd dose of the MMR vaccine in certain situations. \n\n[byline: Kate Sherrer]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[While a 3rd dose of the vaccine sounds like it might be helpful in boosting immunity, it must be given sufficiently prior to exposure for the immunity to be boosted to be protective. \n\n[byline: Sally Asher]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The cases in Oklahoma had been fully vaccinated with 2 doses, but still came down with measles. \n\n[byline: Delthia Ricks]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n***** The department offered these tips to prevent the spread of mumps:\n- do not share food, drinks, utensils or other personal items that may contain saliva;\n- wash hands frequently with soap and water or use an alcohol-based hand rub;\n- cover your mouth with a tissue when sneezing or coughing and discard the tissue;\n- clean and disinfect objects and surfaces that may be contaminated with germs. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Among those who were diagnosed at the time of parotitis onset, 50 patients had received 3 doses of MMR vaccine, 232 patients had received 2 doses, 12 patients had received 1 dose, 7 patients were unvaccinated and 16 patients were unaware if they had been vaccinated. \n\n'In light of the recent increased incidence of mumps, CDC is gathering additional data to assess use of a 3rd dose of vaccine to inform decision-making during outbreak responses and potential changes in the recommendations,' they wrote. \n\nOn Monday [12 Sep 2016], the Arkansas Department of Health reported almost 100 cases of mumps have been confirmed in the state, with most being in Springdale, but some reported in Rogers and potential cases in Fayetteville, Huntsville and West Fork, according to the Arkansas Democrat Gazette. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently offered guidance on a 3rd dose of the measles-mumps-rubella [MMR] vaccine for adolescents and young adults following a recent mumps outbreak at the University of Illinois. The decline in incidence shortly after the intervention suggests that a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine may help control mumps outbreaks among populations with preexisting high 2-dose vaccine coverage. The results indicated that of 2265 eligible students, 2178 (96.2 per cent) provided documentation of having received 2 previous doses of MMR vaccine, and a high proportion (1755 or 80.6 per cent) chose to receive an additional vaccine dose. 90 per cent of patients with a 3rd dose received it during the outbreak, and 10 per cent had received it previously independent of this outbreak, according to the researchers. MUMPS - USA (19)\n****************\n \n\nTwo doses of the mumps vaccine provides the best protection against the disease, according to the health department. However, CDC has provided guidelines for use of a 3rd dose as a control measure during mumps outbreaks in settings in which persons are in close contact with one another, where transmission is sustained despite high 2-dose MMR coverage, and when traditional control measures fail to slow transmission.' \n\nThe Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) confirmed an outbreak of mumps at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (C-UPHD) on 1 May 2015. Cases in students totaled 278 (88 per cent), 3 (1 per cent) occurred in staff members and 36 (11 per cent) in people not associated with the university but who had contact with students or the campus grounds. [New York] mumps outbreak nears 50 cases, say officials\n The mumps outbreak that has been evident this summer in Long Beach has continued to grow as health experts across the country have begun documenting an unrelated spate of cases in nearly every state, health officials said Tuesday [13 Sep 2016]. The State Health Department said public health officials on Long Island have identified 45 mumps cases related to the Long Beach outbreak since July [2016]. http://www.enidnews.com/news/local_news/update-some-in-suspected-mumps-outbreak-were-vaccinated/article_47c989a4-7b67-11e6-8e84-dffe3f42c206.html\n\n\nUpdate: Some in suspected mumps outbreak were vaccinated\n CDC considers guidance on 3rd MMR dose following campus outbreak\n A total of 8200 doses of MMR were administered at multiple vaccination sites at the university between 6 and 27 Aug 2015 to determine if a 3rd dose of MMR would prevent further exposure of mumps to healthy staff and students. \n\nAbout 50 000 students and staff members were targeted for 3rd-dose vaccination on C-UPHD campus. http://www.newyorkupstate.com/news/2016/09/ny_warns_state_colleges_about_mumps_outbreak.html\n\n\nNew York warns state colleges about mumps outbreak\n \n\nOklahoma Health Department later reported there have been 4 confirmed cases in Garfield County and at least 34 suspected cases. \n\nMumps is a virus spread though coughing, sneezing and direct contact with saliva through eating or drinking after an infected person, according to Garfield County Health Department. \n\nLocally, the outbreak has remained concentrated in the barrier island region where multiple suspect cases are under investigation by the State Department of Health. \n\n'No formal recommendation for or against the use of a 3rd MMR dose has been issued by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP),' Justin P Albertson, MS, from the Illinois Department of Public Health, and colleagues wrote in a recent MMWR. ' She added that this particular vaccine -- measles, mumps and rubella -- 'is 88 per cent effective -- but not perfect. \n\nLaurence Burnsed, an epidemiologist with the Acute Disease Service for the Oklahoma State Department of Health, confirmed that some of those who are suspected of contracting the disease in Enid have been vaccinated and that others have not been or do not know if they have been vaccinated. ' [4] USA (New York)\n\n******\n This study was conducted to assess the impact of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine during an outbreak in 2009-2010 among school students in 6th-12th grade.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-05-01 00:00:00", "2016-09-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2178-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2016-05-25 00:00:00", "2016-09-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2016-09-14 00:00:00", "2016-09-12 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "1755-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Garfield County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fayetteville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Long Beach", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Springdale", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Huntsville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York Upstate", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Fork", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Long Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4228383", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada: (BC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4228383", "date": "2016-05-18 11:17:49", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA: (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 May 2016\nSource: News Talk 980 CKNW [edited]\nhttp://www.cknw.com/2016/05/13/mumps-outbreak-among-young-adults-in-whistler/\n\n\nHealth officials are urging those living in Whistler [British Columbia] to make sure their mumps vaccinations are up to date after an outbreak among young adults.\n\nVancouver Coastal Health Medical Health Officer Dr Paul Martiquet says 11 cases of the mumps have been reported in Whistler, a tourist town populated by foreign workers.\n\n'Some of them aren't up to date with their immunization status, as a result, we've had mumps outbreaks [the last one in] 2011. We are advising everyone who was born after 1970 to make sure they are immunized, and to make sure they've had 2 doses of the vaccine -- not just one.'\n\nThe highly contagious viral infection causes fever and swelling of the salivary glands. It is spread through coughing, sneezing, or sharing cups or utensils touched by saliva or mucus [of an infected person].\n\n[Byline: Shelby Thom]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at https://canadaalive.files.wordpress.com/2014/02/canada_political_map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11997. Whistler Blackcomb is a major ski resort located 121 km [75 mi] north of Vancouver, in British Columbia.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps continue to occur in Canada and the proportion of cases aged 20 years and older has increased. Complications such as orchitis (inflammation of the testicles) and oophoritis (inflammation of the ovaries) are relatively frequent; permanent sequelae like deafness are rare.\n\nMumps vaccine is available as measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) or measles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccine. Mumps vaccine effectiveness has been estimated at 62 to 91 percent for 1 dose and at 76 to 95 percent for 2 doses. Reactions to MMR and MMRV vaccine are generally mild and transient and include pain and redness at the injection site, low-grade fever, and rash.\n\n(Excerpted from http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/publicat/cig-gci/p04-mump-orei-eng.php). - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n [Byline: Shelby Thom]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at https://canadaalive.files.wordpress.com/2014/02/canada_political_map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11997. \n\nMumps vaccine is available as measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) or measles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccine. MUMPS - CANADA: (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n**********************************\n \n\nOutbreaks of mumps continue to occur in Canada and the proportion of cases aged 20 years and older has increased. Mumps vaccine effectiveness has been estimated at 62 to 91 percent for 1 dose and at 76 to 95 percent for 2 doses.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella", "varicella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1970-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-05-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Whistler", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4319848", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (14): (NE, MI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4319848", "date": "2016-06-30 22:57:28", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (14): (NEBRASKA, MICHIGAN)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (Nebraska): Creighton University\n[2] USA (Michigan)\n\n******\n[1] USA (Nebraska): Creighton University\nDate: June 2016\nSource: EpiX - The Epidemic Information Exchange [edited]\nhttps://epix2.cdc.gov/v2/Reports/StandardReport/Display.aspx?id=59822&print=False&PSR=False [login required]\n\n\nCall for Cases: Mumps Exposure, Incoming Freshmen and their Families, Creighton University -- Omaha, Nebraska, 2016\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n167 incoming college freshmen and family members from 17 states exposed to an infectious mumps case at Creighton University in Omaha, Nebraska on 9-10 Jun [2016]. Report cases to Douglas County Health Department at 402-444-7214.\n\nThe Douglas County Health Department (Omaha, Nebraska) has identified a laboratory-confirmed (PCR+) case of mumps in a student at Creighton University in Omaha, Nebraska. Symptom onset was 12 Jun 2016. On 9-10 Jun 2016, this student worked on the 'Summer Preview' orientation program, attended by 167 incoming freshmen students and their families, with possible exposure to the infected Creighton student. 'Summer Preview' is a 2-day program in which incoming freshmen visit campus with their families to register for classes and obtain student IDs. Students came from CA, CO, FL, IA, IL, IN, KS, MA, MN, NC, NE, OH, SD, TX, WA, and WI [USA].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 6 Jun 2016, 33 states (AL, AZ, CA, CO, CT, FL, GA, HI, ID, IL, IN, IA, KS, KY, ME, MA, MI, MN, MT, NE, NH, NJ, NY [including New York City], NC, ND, OH, OR, PA, SC, TN, TX, VA, and WI) in the U.S. reported mumps infections in 1272 people to CDC. Four states have reported more than 100 cases this year: IA, IN, IL and MA.\n\nAlthough mumps cases have seen a sharp decline since the CDC began recommending a 2-dose vaccine prevention plan in 1988, outbreaks are still prevalent, particularly in high-contact social settings like college campuses. Mumps is transmittable through the air or by touching unwashed, contaminated surfaces, and the rising cases bring into question vaccination practices, waning immunity, and college healthcare.\n\nConcerns unique to colleges\n---------------------------\nMumps outbreaks can be difficult to detect at 1st because doctors are not always thinking about the disease, said Susan Even, MD, executive director of the University of Missouri Student Health Center and chair of the American College Health Association (ACHA)'s Vaccine Preventable Disease Advisory Committee. ...\n\nOne dose of the MMR vaccine affords 78 per cent protection, while 2 doses provide 88 per cent effectiveness, according to the CDC. The vaccine is the best prevention for mumps, and Even encourages colleges to ask for proof that their students are immunized and not just assume they are.\n\nThe disease is contagious at least 5 days before symptoms appear, and not all students experience or report symptoms.\n\n[Excerpted from http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2016/04/early-reports-show-mumps-rise-2016-including-campuses]\n\nA map of Nebraska, USA, may be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/229. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Michigan)\nDate: Thu 30 Jun 2016\nSource: WTVB [edited]\nhttp://wtvbam.com/news/articles/2016/jun/30/health-agency-warns-of-mumps-exposure/\n\n\nHealth agency warns of mumps exposure\n-------------------------------------\nThe Branch-Hillsdale-St. Joseph Community Health Agency is asking health care providers to be on alert for potential exposures to mumps, particularly in Hillsdale County [Michigan]. They say the suspect case took place in an out-of-state camper who was attending a local camp. It's the 1st Hillsdale County case of the mumps since 2008.\n\nMumps is a highly contagious illness spread by contact with an infected person through coughing, sneezing, sharing utensils and other personal contact.\n\nSymptoms include headaches, loss of appetite and a low grade ever. Infections with the mumps virus may also present with severe abdominal pain or pelvic pain. While mumps is usually a mild disease, there could be complications.\n\nHealth officials say you should check your immunization status with your health care provider.\n\nDoctors are being asked to notify the health department of any suspect cases.\n\nPeople who have mumps or are suspected of having mumps should notify their physician and follow medical directions.\n\nThere is no treatment for mumps, only supportive care such as bed rest, fluids and fever reducing medications.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Michigan, USA, may be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/225. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: WTVB [edited]\nhttp://wtvbam.com/news/articles/2016/jun/30/health-agency-warns-of-mumps-exposure/\n\n\nHealth agency warns of mumps exposure\n --------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n167 incoming college freshmen and family members from 17 states exposed to an infectious mumps case at Creighton University in Omaha, Nebraska on 9-10 Jun [2016]. \nMumps outbreaks can be difficult to detect at 1st because doctors are not always thinking about the disease, said Susan Even, MD, executive director of the University of Missouri Student Health Center and chair of the American College Health Association (ACHA)'s Vaccine Preventable Disease Advisory Committee.
