[2] USA (Michigan)\n\n******\n \n\nMumps is a highly contagious illness spread by contact with an infected person through coughing, sneezing, sharing utensils and other personal contact. [USA].\n\n--\n \n\nConcerns unique to colleges\n \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-06-12 00:00:00", "2016-06-06 00:00:00", "2021-09-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2009-06-10 20:16:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-06-25 00:00:00", "1272-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hillsdale County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Symptom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Omaha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "AL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "in", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4237258", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (12): (WI,NE,MA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4237258", "date": "2016-05-22 00:11:06", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (12): (WISCONSIN, NEBRASKA, MASSACHUSETTS)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (Wisconsin) - Milwaukee\n[2] USA (Nebraska) - Midland University\n[3] USA (Massachusetts) - Harvard University\n\n******\n[1] USA (Wisconsin) - Milwaukee\nDate: Thu 19 May 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/milwaukee-reports-3-mumps-cases-42691/\n\n\nMumps, city of Milwaukee, Wisconsin, 3 confirmed cases\n------------------------------------------------------\nMilwaukee reports 3 mumps cases.\n\nThe City of Milwaukee Health Department (MHD) has received reports of 3 confirmed cases of mumps infection in city residents, including area college students and community members.\n\nMumps is a contagious respiratory illness caused by the mumps virus. It is spread through the air by droplets and contact with saliva or mucus from infected persons. Mumps can be transmitted through coughing and sneezing as well as sharing food or beverage items and utensils with infected individuals.\n\nSymptoms of mumps include fever, body aches, headaches, and swelling or pain of the salivary glands near the ears and jaw. Anyone who experiences these symptoms should contact his/her health care provider for diagnosis and testing.\n\nThe MHD recommends that persons experiencing symptoms consistent with mumps infection, especially swelling of one or both salivary glands, call your healthcare provider and stay home from work or school for a minimum of 5 days after the onset of swelling. Individuals are also advised to cover their mouths and noses when coughing or sneezing and wash hands frequently with soap and water.\n\nWhile most individuals recover fully, mumps infection can occasionally cause serious complications in adults that can include inflammation of the testicles in men or ovaries and breasts in women, inflammation of the brain (encephalitis), and temporary or permanent deafness.\n\nVaccination with 2 doses of mumps-measles-rubella (MMR) vaccine is the best way to prevent mumps infection. Public health officials advise individuals to be aware of their vaccination status, and seek advice from a health care provider if your vaccinations are not up to date.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Wisconsin, USA can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2399. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Nebraska) - Midland University\nDate: Fri 20 May 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/nebraska-mumps-cluster-reported-at-midland-university-in-fremont-98940/\n\n\nMumps: Health Officials in Eastern Nebraska announce cluster of cases in students at Midland University in Fremont\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nMumps cluster reported at Midland University in Fremont on 20 May 2016.\n\nHealth officials in Eastern Nebraska announced today [20 May 2016] a cluster of mumps among college-aged young adults enrolled at Midland University in Fremont.\n\nThe Three Rivers Public Health Department says 10 cases to date.\n\nA health advisory was sent to health care providers in Nebraska asking them to be on the lookout for cases of mumps and to contact their local health department about suspected cases.\n\nThree Rivers Public Health Department wants the community to educate themselves about the symptoms, transmission, and prevention of mumps and to make sure he or she is fully vaccinated with the MMR vaccine to prevent this virus from spreading. Mumps clusters can happen even in highly vaccinated populations. Annually the number of reported mumps cases can range from a few hundred to a couple thousand in the United States.\n\n'Mumps is highly contagious so it's important to practice good hygiene habits as that will help reduce illnesses. If you know someone who has mumps or suspect someone may have the disease, contact your physician or your local public health department,' said Terra Uhing Executive Director, Three Rivers Public Health Department.\n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes or talks. Items used by an infected person, such as cups or soft drink cans, can also be contaminated with the virus, which may spread to others if those items are shared.\n\nSymptoms typically appear 16-18 days after infection, but this period can range from 12-25 days after infection. It is usually a mild disease, but can occasionally cause serious complications.\n\nThe most common complication is inflammation of the testicles (orchitis) in males who have reached puberty; rarely does this lead to fertility problems.\n\nOther rare complications include inflammation of the brain and/or tissue covering the brain and spinal cord (encephalitis/meningitis), inflammation of the ovaries (oophoritis) and/or breasts (mastitis) in females who have reached puberty, and deafness. Anyone who is not immune from either previous mumps infection or from vaccination can get mumps.\n\nAs of 29 Apr 2016, the CDC reports 727 mumps cases nationally.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Nebraska, USA can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53326. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] USA (MA) - Harvard University\nDate: Tue 17 May 2016\nSource: NBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.nbcnews.com/feature/college-game-plan/harvard-mumps-outbreak-continues-commencement-will-go-n575526\n\n\nThe show will be going on at Harvard [Cambridge, Massachusetts]. The commencement, that is. An ongoing breakout of mumps won't impact the 26 May [2016] ceremony featuring director Steven Spielberg, even if the viral illness is making life miserable for nearly 5 dozen members of the Harvard community -- students, faculty and staff.\n\nAs of 12 May [2016], there were 59 confirmed cases of the illness, with 12 people in isolation, according to the most recent update by Cambridge health officials. That's up slightly from 41 cases in late April [2016].\n\nHarvard University Health Services (HUHS) has been keeping the community informed of best practices for preventing the spread of the illness, and is working with the Massachusetts Department of Public Health and the Cambridge Public Health Department, explains HUHS director Dr. Paul J. Barreira in a statement to TODAY.\n\nThe outbreak began in March [2016], but an increase in the number of cases isn't that unusual. 'In a community with a large residential population, one would expect to see increasing cases of mumps,' he says. Although Harvard community members were indeed vaccinated, the so-called MMR (mumps, measles, and rubella) vaccine offers different levels of protection depending on the illness.\n\nThe measles portion of the vaccine, for example, is about 93 percent effective with one dose, while 2 doses give people 97 percent protection, according to the CDC.\n\nBut the mumps portion is less effective. Two doses of mumps vaccine are 88 percent effective at preventing the illness, while one dose is 78 percent effective. 'The measles vaccine is so good it spoils us,' says Dr. Paul Sax, clinical director of Infectious Disease at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston.\n\nAlthough there are no plans to cancel graduation ceremonies, 'given the 2- to 3-week incubation period for the mumps virus, students who come down with the virus at this point may have to miss certain end-of-year activities if they are ill,' says Barreira.\n\nNow that's a buzzkill, too, especially for any mumps-ridden graduating senior.\n\nStudents leaving campus for summer break and out of close proximity of each other will be a big help in curtailing the illness, he says.\n\nProtecting yourself from mumps starts with vaccination, but there are also some common-sense things that people should be doing, he adds, citing hand washing, covering your mouth and nose when sneezing, and avoiding sharing cups and utensils.\n\n'(Mumps) outbreaks have happened before, and they will happen again,' says Sax, a professor of medicine at Harvard Medical School. 'But the message is this one will end.'\n\nAlthough mumps outbreaks vary from year to year and the vaccine is 'not 100 percent effective,' says Dr. Paul Sax, clinical director of Infectious Disease at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston -- without it there would have potentially been many more cases among the Harvard community, which numbers about 40 000 students, faculty and staff.\n\n[Byline: Joan Raymond]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Massachusetts may be accessed at http://mapsof.net/uploads/static-maps/massachusetts_cities_and_towns.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8159. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nAlthough mumps outbreaks vary from year to year and the vaccine is 'not 100 percent effective,' says Dr. Paul Sax, clinical director of Infectious Disease at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston -- without it there would have potentially been many more cases among the Harvard community, which numbers about 40 000 students, faculty and staff. \n\nA health advisory was sent to health care providers in Nebraska asking them to be on the lookout for cases of mumps and to contact their local health department about suspected cases. \n\nThe City of Milwaukee Health Department (MHD) has received reports of 3 confirmed cases of mumps infection in city residents, including area college students and community members. Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/milwaukee-reports-3-mumps-cases-42691/\n\n\nMumps, city of Milwaukee, Wisconsin, 3 confirmed cases\n------------------------------------------------------ \n\nVaccination with 2 doses of mumps-measles-rubella (MMR) vaccine is the best way to prevent mumps infection. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Wisconsin, USA can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2399. Barreira in a statement to TODAY. MUMPS - USA (12): (WISCONSIN, NEBRASKA, MASSACHUSETTS)\n******************************************************\n http://outbreaknewstoday.com/nebraska-mumps-cluster-reported-at-midland-university-in-fremont-98940/\n\n\nMumps: Health Officials in Eastern Nebraska announce cluster of cases in students at Midland University in Fremont\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------- \n\nProtecting yourself from mumps starts with vaccination, but there are also some common-sense things that people should be doing, he adds, citing hand washing, covering your mouth and nose when sneezing, and avoiding sharing cups and utensils. \n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes or talks. \n\nOther rare complications include inflammation of the brain and/or tissue covering the brain and spinal cord (encephalitis/meningitis), inflammation of the ovaries (oophoritis) and/or breasts (mastitis) in females who have reached puberty, and deafness. An ongoing breakout of mumps won't impact the 26 May [2016] ceremony featuring director Steven Spielberg, even if the viral illness is making life miserable for nearly 5 dozen members of the Harvard community -- students, faculty and staff. \n\nSymptoms of mumps include fever, body aches, headaches, and swelling or pain of the salivary glands near the ears and jaw. \nMilwaukee reports 3 mumps cases. [3] USA (Massachusetts) - Harvard University\n\n******\n \n\n'(Mumps) outbreaks have happened before, and they will happen again,' says Sax, a professor of medicine at Harvard Medical School. ' \n\n--\n [Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\n [Byline: Joan Raymond]\n\n--\n \n\n'Mumps is highly contagious so it's important to practice good hygiene habits as that will help reduce illnesses. \nMumps cluster reported at Midland University in Fremont on 20 May 2016.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-05-26 00:00:00", "2021-05-12 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-05-20 00:00:00", "2016-05-25 00:00:00", "2016-05-19 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fremont", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cambridge", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Milwaukee", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of Milwaukee Health Department", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4192049", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (11): (MA) student cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4192049", "date": "2016-04-29 21:25:05", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (11): (MASSACHUSETTS) STUDENT CASES\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 27 Apr 2016\nSource: CNN [edited]\nhttp://edition.cnn.com/2016/04/27/health/harvard-university-mumps-outbreak/index.html\n\n\n'Please stop infecting each other.'\n\nThat's the message Harvard University has for students after a mumps outbreak left 40 people sick over the past 2 months. The university first announced mumps cases in February [2016], and infections have steadily increased despite efforts to isolate patients.\n\nPaul J Barreira, director of the Massachusetts university's health services, told the student newspaper that the rise in cases is worrying. 'I'm actually more concerned now than I was during any time of the outbreak,' Barreira told The Harvard Crimson. 'I'm desperate to get students to take seriously that they shouldn't be infecting one another.'\n\nMumps is spreading so fast, it could affect the university's [26 May 2016] commencement, he said. 'If there's a spike this week, that means those students expose others, so now we're looking at a potential serious interruption to commencement for students,' Barreira told the student newspaper. 'Students will get infected and then go into isolation.'\n\nLast month [March 2016], the public health department in Cambridge, where Harvard is located, said all students affected had been immunized against mumps before they contracted it.\n\nMumps is a viral infection that causes swelling in the salivary glands and cheeks, earache, jaw pain, and general symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and headache. The virus can be transmitted through respiratory droplets and contact with saliva or mucus. Most mumps patients completely recover.\n\n[Byline: Faith Karimi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail (Mumps - USA (10): (IN,MA) student cases 20160415.4162668), there were 19 confirmed and 30 suspect cases of mumps on the Harvard University campus as of 29 Mar 2016. We are now told in the news report above there are a total of 40 cases, but we are not told how many of these are confirmed or suspected.\n\nMumps outbreaks even among vaccinated populations have been reported frequently during recent years, especially among college students where the intensity of exposure among students was presumed to have overcome the vaccine-induced immunity (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1681_article.htm).\n\nFor a discussion of mumps, see my comments in ProMED-mail post Mumps - USA: (OH) university students 20140308.2321285.\n\nHarvard University is a private research university in Cambridge, Massachusetts (US), with 6700 undergraduate and 14 500 postgraduate students (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvard_University). A map showing the location of the Harvard campus in the city of Cambridge, Massachusetts can be found at http://tinyurl.com/gtspt9l. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4323.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail (Mumps - USA (10): (IN,MA) student cases 20160415.4162668), there were 19 confirmed and 30 suspect cases of mumps on the Harvard University campus as of 29 Mar 2016. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThat's the message Harvard University has for students after a mumps outbreak left 40 people sick over the past 2 months. Mumps outbreaks even among vaccinated populations have been reported frequently during recent years, especially among college students where the intensity of exposure among students was presumed to have overcome the vaccine-induced immunity (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1681_article.htm). \n\nPaul J Barreira, director of the Massachusetts university's health services, told the student newspaper that the rise in cases is worrying. ' MUMPS - USA (11): (MASSACHUSETTS) STUDENT CASES\n***********************************************\n \n\nHarvard University is a private research university in Cambridge, Massachusetts (US), with 6700 undergraduate and 14 500 postgraduate students (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvard_University). \n\nMumps is spreading so fast, it could affect the university's [26 May 2016] commencement, he said. ' For a discussion of mumps, see my comments in ProMED-mail post Mumps - USA: (OH) university students 20140308.2321285.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-02-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2016-05-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cambridge", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4136830", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (08): (ND)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4136830", "date": "2016-04-03 22:22:33", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (08): (NORTH DAKOTA)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 1 Apr 2016\nSource: WDAY 6 ABC [edited]\nhttp://www.wday.com/news/north-dakota/3999853-outbreak-mumps-north-dakota\n\n\nThe North Dakota Department of Health (NDDoH) has received 14 reports of mumps since 24 Feb 2016. 8 of the cases were reported from Ward County. The age range of cases is 14 to 86 years. The NDDoH is urging North Dakotans to be sure they have received their MMR vaccine. Anyone with symptoms of mumps should be evaluated by a health care provider, and, if they have mumps, stay home for 5 days after symptoms started, and avoid contact with others.\n\nMumps is a viral illness best known for the puffy cheeks and swollen jaw that it causes as a result of swollen salivary glands. The most common symptoms include: fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite, swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears on one or both sides (parotitis).\n\nMumps is generally a mild illness, but can cause complications, such as deafness, and inflammation of the testicles, brain, and ovaries. Symptoms may appear from 12 to 25 days after infection. People with symptoms are recommended to see a health care provider for testing, because other illnesses, including influenza, can cause parotitis.\n\n'The best way to prevent mumps is to be vaccinated,' according to Molly Howell, Immunization Program Manager for the NDDoH. 'The MMR vaccine protects against measles, mumps, and rubella. All children are recommended to receive MMR vaccine at 12 to 15 months of age and again at 4 to 6 years of age. MMR vaccine is required to attend child care, school, and colleges in North Dakota. People born before 1957 are generally considered immune to mumps due to the high rate of infection at that time.'\n\nOnly 2 of the mumps cases had a history of 2 doses of MMR vaccine. 'It is not surprising to see mumps cases in vaccinated individuals,' said Howell. 'The mumps component of the MMR vaccine is about 88 percent effective, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. MMR vaccine is the only tool that we have available to prevent mumps; 88 percent is a lot better than not being vaccinated at all. People who have received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine are about 9 times less likely to get mumps than unvaccinated people who have the same exposure to mumps virus.'\n\nMumps spreads when an infected person coughs or sneezes. A good way to prevent transmission of mumps is to practice good hygiene habits; regularly wash hands with soap and water, sneeze and coughing into a tissue or your elbow, and avoid sharing drinks, food and utensils.\n\n[Byline: Molly Howell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak has affected a broad age group from 14-86 years. These individuals may not have been fully vaccinated with 2 doses, the individuals were among the 20 percent where the vaccine is ineffective, or vaccine effectiveness may be waning with age. The vaccine is 80 percent effective. Even when not fully protective, the vaccine may lower the number of people who get sick when exposed to the virus, and lowers risk of problems.\n\nMMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine is recommended routinely for all children at age 12 through 15 months, with a 2nd dose at age 4 through 6 years. The 2nd dose of MMR can be given as early as 4 weeks (28 days) after the 1st dose and be counted as a valid dose if both doses were given after the child's 1st birthday. The 2nd dose is intended to produce immunity in the small number of people who fail to respond to the 1st dose.\n\nAdults with no evidence of immunity should get 1 dose of MMR unless the adult is in a high-risk group. High-risk people need 2 doses and include healthcare personnel, international travelers, students at post-high school educational institutions, people exposed to measles in an outbreak setting, and those previously vaccinated with killed measles vaccine or with an unknown type of measles vaccine during 1963 through 1967. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/236.]", "summary": "High-risk people need 2 doses and include healthcare personnel, international travelers, students at post-high school educational institutions, people exposed to measles in an outbreak setting, and those previously vaccinated with killed measles vaccine or with an unknown type of measles vaccine during 1963 through 1967. \n\nMMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine is recommended routinely for all children at age 12 through 15 months, with a 2nd dose at age 4 through 6 years. People who have received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine are about 9 times less likely to get mumps than unvaccinated people who have the same exposure to mumps virus.'\n\n \n\n'The best way to prevent mumps is to be vaccinated,' according to Molly Howell, Immunization Program Manager for the NDDoH. 'The MMR vaccine protects against measles, mumps, and rubella. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n These individuals may not have been fully vaccinated with 2 doses, the individuals were among the 20 percent where the vaccine is ineffective, or vaccine effectiveness may be waning with age. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak has affected a broad age group from 14-86 years. \n\nOnly 2 of the mumps cases had a history of 2 doses of MMR vaccine. ' Anyone with symptoms of mumps should be evaluated by a health care provider, and, if they have mumps, stay home for 5 days after symptoms started, and avoid contact with others. The 2nd dose of MMR can be given as early as 4 weeks (28 days) after the 1st dose and be counted as a valid dose if both doses were given after the child's 1st birthday. All children are recommended to receive MMR vaccine at 12 to 15 months of age and again at 4 to 6 years of age.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1963-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-02-24 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ward County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4262176", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (13): (NE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4262176", "date": "2016-06-02 20:25:32", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (13): (NEBRASKA)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 31 May 2016\nSource: The Columbus Telegram [edited]\nhttp://columbustelegram.com/news/local/midland-mumps-outbreak-spreading/article_a1075c86-1767-5070-adc7-eceac2f3426c.html\n\n\nMidland [University] mumps outbreak spreading\n---------------------------------------------\nThe Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services says there has been a surge in mumps cases related to an outbreak at Midland University in Fremont.\n\nThe department announced Tuesday [31 May 2016] that the number of mumps cases increased from 10 to 21, after new cases were reported last week [week ending 28 May 2016] in Cass, Douglas, Dodge, Hall, Madison and Platte counties.\n\nAuthorities said 10 cases of the virus were previously reported at Midland University. The 1st case reported symptoms on 16 Apr [2016] and the last was reported 13 May [2016].\n\nThose cases were identified among vaccinated students at the Fremont University.\n\nThe mumps component of the MMR vaccine does not guarantee life-long immunity, but those who are vaccinated for mumps are less likely to contract the virus.\n\nOfficials say most students have now returned home for the summer and some started experiencing symptoms.\n\nThe department is working with local health officials to investigate the cases.\n\nThe viral infection's symptoms include swollen salivary glands, fever, jaw pain, headaches and muscle aches.\n\nMumps is a contagious disease that has no specific treatment. It is spread by coughing, sneezing and other contact with saliva or mucus from an infected person. An individual is most contagious 3 days before and 5 days after the onset of symptoms.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy) report from April 2016 noted that mumps appears to be on the rise in 2016, including on campuses (http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2016/04/early-reports-show-mumps-rise-2016-including-campuses):\n\n'Recent headlines about US college mumps outbreaks appear to herald the start to a busy year for the disease and underscore the ongoing challenges that campuses face.\n\n'While mumps hit a low point of 229 cases in 2011, in the past 2 years, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has recorded more than 1000 cases annually. In updating its numbers yesterday [7 Apr 2016], the CDC said that, as of 1 Apr [2016], public health departments have reported 467 mumps cases already this year.\n\n'Although mumps cases have seen a sharp decline since the CDC began recommending a 2-dose vaccine prevention plan in 1988, outbreaks are still prevalent, particularly in high-contact social settings like college campuses. Mumps is transmittable through the air or by touching unwashed, contaminated surfaces, and the rising cases bring into question vaccination practices, waning immunity, and college healthcare.\n\n'Concerns unique to colleges\n----------------------------\n'Mumps outbreaks can be difficult to detect at 1st because doctors are not always thinking about the disease, said Susan Even, MD, executive director of the University of Missouri Student Health Center and chair of the American College Health Association (ACHA)'s Vaccine Preventable Disease Advisory Committee.\n\n'Although she thinks that colleges are becoming more vigilant about looking for mumps, the disease is contagious at least 5 days before symptoms appear, and not all students experience or report symptoms.\n\n'In 2006, the CDC listed 6854 mumps cases, with 84 per cent of the cases through October of that year occurring at Midwestern colleges. College-aged people had the highest infection rates, and the most cited reason is because of their close-proximity lifestyle. The ACHA, in a presentation about a 2006 University of Iowa (UI) outbreak, listed parties, sports, dormitories, and travel as risk factors.\n\n'Those aspects of college life do not seem to change much, which is perhaps why U.S. colleges have reported cases of mumps this year on Midwest colleges in places like Iowa, Indiana, Ohio, and Wisconsin. Eastern schools like Harvard University (16 cases as of 22 Mar [2016]) have also had some outbreaks and the University of Texas-Austin reported a case at the end of January [2016].\n\n'While outbreaks may seem to center around college campuses, Cristina Cardemil, MD, MPH, a medical epidemiologist in the CDC's Division of Viral Diseases, points out that various populations, such as children, older adults, and other communities are being affected, too.\n\n'Looking at the bigger picture, she said, the number of mumps cases are not exceeding the vaccine success rate, nor is the slight upward trend in cases over the past few years indicative of a growing pattern.\n\n''Even in the best-case scenario where everyone is vaccinated,' Cardemil said, 'We're still going to see a number of mumps cases every year.' A 2014 study in Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report (MMWR) noted that 91.9 per cent of the U.S. population had received at least 1 dose of the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine.\n\n'One dose of the MMR vaccine affords 78 per cent protection, while 2 doses provide 88 per cent effectiveness, according to the CDC. The vaccine is the best prevention for mumps, and even encourages colleges to ask for proof that their students are immunized and not just assume they are.\n\n'The CDC recommends that children receive MMR vaccine at 12 through 15 months of age and again at 4 through 6 years of age.\n\n'Waning immunity is a difficult question to answer, as many different factors such as vaccination rates (including community pockets with lower-than-average vaccine uptake), dose number, and individual predisposition factor into it, Cardemil said. She added that some studies have supported the idea that mumps immunity dissipates as time goes by, but more studies need to be done for the results to become conclusive.\n\n'Adult booster dose?\n--------------------\n'UI is one of a handful of colleges that have used free 3rd doses of MMR as booster shots to prevent mumps spread. More than 5000 UI students took advantage of the free vaccine during the 2015-16 season, which so far has seen almost 300 mumps cases in Johnson County, most of which were at UI.\n\n'Although CDC researchers obtained data about the 3rd dose's effects, the school has not seen its conclusions, according to Jim Kellogg, the director of The University of Iowa Student Health & Wellness.\n\n'The 3rd MMR dose may or may not keep mumps from spreading -- the CDC neither recommends for or against it. Cardemil cautions that using that treatment for every outbreak is not practical because of the resources and finances it takes.\n\n'In addition to the vaccine booster, UI reached its students through multiple communication platforms to remind them to practice healthy habits and teach them about the symptoms of mumps. Lisa James, RN, MSN, the associate director of UI's clinical outreach, said that students were slow to 'take action' unless a personal acquaintance contracted the disease. For those who did become sick, supportive treatment, pain and fever medication, and an excused isolation period were arranged.\n\n'Compared with the 2006 UI outbreak, which involved at least 55 cases, Kellogg said that the campus is now more prepared and able to react quicker because its data tracking was able to show university officials the rising trends that started mid-summer and continued through winter break. James added that the university's response was bolstered by increased communication with local public health officials.\n\n'The CDC strongly encourages that health departments report outbreaks of the mumps, which it lists as a nationally notifiable disease. As both Cardemil and Kellogg state, the college outbreaks are not sequestered to just the campus; mumps patients from the outside infect the college community, and vice versa.'\n\nAlso see discussion of measles, mumps, rubella vaccine in previous posts.\n\nA map of Nebraska, USA can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/229. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy) report from April 2016 noted that mumps appears to be on the rise in 2016, including on campuses (http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2016/04/early-reports-show-mumps-rise-2016-including-campuses):\n\n'Recent headlines about US college mumps outbreaks appear to herald the start to a busy year for the disease and underscore the ongoing challenges that campuses face. \n\nThe department announced Tuesday [31 May 2016] that the number of mumps cases increased from 10 to 21, after new cases were reported last week [week ending 28 May 2016] in Cass, Douglas, Dodge, Hall, Madison and Platte counties. \n\n'Although mumps cases have seen a sharp decline since the CDC began recommending a 2-dose vaccine prevention plan in 1988, outbreaks are still prevalent, particularly in high-contact social settings like college campuses. \n\n'While mumps hit a low point of 229 cases in 2011, in the past 2 years, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has recorded more than 1000 cases annually. \n\n'In 2006, the CDC listed 6854 mumps cases, with 84 per cent of the cases through October of that year occurring at Midwestern colleges. \n\n'Those aspects of college life do not seem to change much, which is perhaps why U.S. colleges have reported cases of mumps this year on Midwest colleges in places like Iowa, Indiana, Ohio, and Wisconsin. ----------------------------\n'Mumps outbreaks can be difficult to detect at 1st because doctors are not always thinking about the disease, said Susan Even, MD, executive director of the University of Missouri Student Health Center and chair of the American College Health Association (ACHA)'s Vaccine Preventable Disease Advisory Committee. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'Although she thinks that colleges are becoming more vigilant about looking for mumps, the disease is contagious at least 5 days before symptoms appear, and not all students experience or report symptoms. Looking at the bigger picture, she said, the number of mumps cases are not exceeding the vaccine success rate, nor is the slight upward trend in cases over the past few years indicative of a growing pattern. In updating its numbers yesterday [7 Apr 2016], the CDC said that, as of 1 Apr [2016], public health departments have reported 467 mumps cases already this year. \n\n'Waning immunity is a difficult question to answer, as many different factors such as vaccination rates (including community pockets with lower-than-average vaccine uptake), dose number, and individual predisposition factor into it, Cardemil said. More than 5000 UI students took advantage of the free vaccine during the 2015-16 season, which so far has seen almost 300 mumps cases in Johnson County, most of which were at UI. The mumps component of the MMR vaccine does not guarantee life-long immunity, but those who are vaccinated for mumps are less likely to contract the virus. \n\nAlso see discussion of measles, mumps, rubella vaccine in previous posts. \n\nAuthorities said 10 cases of the virus were previously reported at Midland University. \n\n'The 3rd MMR dose may or may not keep mumps from spreading -- the CDC neither recommends for or against it. Mumps is transmittable through the air or by touching unwashed, contaminated surfaces, and the rising cases bring into question vaccination practices, waning immunity, and college healthcare. Eastern schools like Harvard University (16 cases as of 22 Mar [2016]) have also had some outbreaks and the University of Texas-Austin reported a case at the end of January [2016]. Even in the best-case scenario where everyone is vaccinated,' Cardemil said, 'We're still going to see a number of mumps cases every year.' \n\n'One dose of the MMR vaccine affords 78 per cent protection, while 2 doses provide 88 per cent effectiveness, according to the CDC.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2016-04-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-05-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-05-13 00:00:00", "2016-05-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Johnson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cass", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Midland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fremont", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4104627", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (07): (MT) student cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4104627", "date": "2016-03-18 17:57:10", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (07): (MONTANA) STUDENT CASES\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Mar 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/mumps-outbreak-strikes-seven-in-belgrade-public-schools-40838/\n\n\nIn a follow-up to a report last week [see ProMED-mail post Mumps - USA (04): (MA, MT) student cases 20160311.4084267], an additional 3 cases of mumps have been confirmed and reported in Gallatin County, Montana, according to local health officials. This brings the number of cases to 7, all associated with Belgrade Public Schools.\n\nThe Gallatin City-County Health Department is working closely with Belgrade schools, as well as healthcare providers and partners at the Montana Department of Public Health and Human Services, to identify students most at risk for contracting mumps and to implement infection control measures recommended by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control & Prevention (CDC).\n\nIt is important for parents to know that most students in Belgrade schools have significant protection against mumps through immunizations required by Montana state law and recommended by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. While mumps does have some serious but rare potential health effects, the risk of these outcomes is significantly reduced by the vaccine and infection control precautions being pursued by the health department and the schools.\n\n'These new cases are not unexpected,' said Matt Kelley, Health Officer with Gallatin City-County Health Department. 'In fact, we are now in the period when those exposed to the initial cases of the disease would begin to show symptoms.'\n\nTwo new mumps cases were reported to the health department over the past 5 days. One person attends Belgrade Middle School. A 2nd person attends Saddle Peak Elementary School, but was not in school while the disease was contagious. Another case -- also a middle school student who had extended close contact to a confirmed case -- was classified as a case after becoming symptomatic.\n\n'It's important for people to understand that mumps can be a serious disease, but vaccines and infection control measures have made the most serious side effects exceedingly rare.'\n\nThe Gallatin City-County Health Department is working to identify students in settings where cases of mumps have been identified and will be contacting those parents to provide information and health care guidance. In most cases, students who are most susceptible to mumps are those who have not been vaccinated against the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See ProMED mail post Mumps - USA (04): (MA, MT) student cases 20160311.4084267 for the report on 4 earlier mumps cases in Belgrade, Montana, schools. It is likely the students in this most recent report became infected prior to recognizing the infection in the 1st set of students reported 9 Mar 2016, as the incubation period is 12-25 days. It is not clear what infection controls were put in place, but the American Academy of Pediatrics and the Centers for Disease Control have determined that unimmunized students can return to school immediately after being vaccinated with the MMR vaccine.\n\nThe state of Montana can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12939. Gallatin County, in southern Montana, can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/montana-county-map.gif. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See ProMED mail post Mumps - USA (04): (MA, MT) student cases 20160311.4084267 for the report on 4 earlier mumps cases in Belgrade, Montana, schools. In a follow-up to a report last week [see ProMED-mail post Mumps - USA (04): (MA, MT) student cases 20160311.4084267], an additional 3 cases of mumps have been confirmed and reported in Gallatin County, Montana, according to local health officials. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The Gallatin City-County Health Department is working closely with Belgrade schools, as well as healthcare providers and partners at the Montana Department of Public Health and Human Services, to identify students most at risk for contracting mumps and to implement infection control measures recommended by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control & Prevention (CDC). \n\nIt is important for parents to know that most students in Belgrade schools have significant protection against mumps through immunizations required by Montana state law and recommended by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The Gallatin City-County Health Department is working to identify students in settings where cases of mumps have been identified and will be contacting those parents to provide information and health care guidance. MUMPS - USA (07): (MONTANA) STUDENT CASES\n*****************************************\n While mumps does have some serious but rare potential health effects, the risk of these outcomes is significantly reduced by the vaccine and infection control precautions being pursued by the health department and the schools.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gallatin County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gallatin City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12939", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgrade", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4095024", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (06): (CA, NY) student cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4095024", "date": "2016-03-15 15:20:40", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (06): (CALIFORNIA, NEW YORK) STUDENT CASES\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (California): mumps students\n[2] USA (New York): mumps students\n\n******\n[1] USA (California): mumps students\nDate: Mon 14 Mar 2016\nSource: NBC San Diego [edited]\nhttp://www.nbcsandiego.com/news/local/Mumps-Cases-at-University-San-Diego-372011972.html\n\n\nNew cases have been identified in a mumps outbreak at the University of San Diego, county health officials reported Mon [14 Mar 2016].\n\nThree more undergraduate students have been diagnosed with mumps after coming in contact with the student who was 1st diagnosed in February [2016]. That student lived in off-campus housing, officials said.\n\nA 5th student who lives on campus was diagnosed just last week.\n\n'For me, when I heard about it, I was kind of scared, but then I didn't really know anyone who had it, and they also offered the vaccination. So I think I'm a going to get that,' a USD student told NBC 7.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention defines a mumps outbreak as 3 or more cases linked by time and place.\n\nA patient suffering from the mumps often has a fever, headache, earache, and inflammation of the salivary glands.\n\n'The complications can be something called encephalitis, inflammation of the brain, meningitis or inflammation of the surrounding of the brain, or orchitis, which is inflammation of the testicles and inflammation of ovaries. And those last 2 can cause infertility,' Dr. Eric McDonald of the San Diego County Health Department explained. Coughing, sneezing, kissing or close contact with an infected person can spread the disease.\n\nAn outbreak of mumps has also been reported at Harvard University. The CDC has received 250 reports of mumps so far in 2016. The total number of cases reported last year was 1057.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is said to be 88-percent effective in preventing the mumps. Free immunizations are being offered to all undergraduate students at the university to keep the outbreak from spreading, the San Diego County Health and Human Services Agency said. USD students and staff can call (619) 260-4595 to find out details on 2 vaccination clinics scheduled for this week.\n\n[Byline R. Stickney and Bridget Naso]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[We have recently been witnessing an upsurge in mumps reports in college students. Since mumps outbreaks most often occur in winter and spring, this is not unexpected. Case reports are still well below the numbers seen in 2015 - 1057, and 2014 - 1223. The usual level, according to CDC, is several hundred cases per year. Generally high vaccination coverage helps limit the size, duration, and spread of mumps outbreaks. Students at post-high school educational institutions, such as college, trade schools, and training programs, who do not have evidence of immunity (protection) against mumps need 2 doses of MMR vaccine, separated by at least 28 days.\n\nA HealthMap of California in the United States can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (New York): mumps student\nDate: Sat 12 Mar 2016\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\nhttp://www.niagara-gazette.com/news/local_news/health-officials-investigate-mumps-outbreak-at-ub/article_86bf4c5e-e871-11e5-96a8-538a42604c81.html\n\n\nNew York state health officials are investigating a possible mumps outbreak at SUNY Buffalo. The state Department of Health says the university has identified 2 probable and 4 suspected cases of mumps among its students.\n\nStudents are on spring break until 21 Mar 2016. UB officials are reviewing immunization records to identify students who may need to either be vaccinated or excluded from school when classes resume.\n\nMumps is a highly contagious viral disease characterized by fever, headache and swelling of the salivary glands.\n\nWhile the mumps vaccine is not 100 percent effective, 2 doses of the vaccine provide the best protection against mumps.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nWhile the mumps vaccine is not 100 percent effective, 2 doses of the vaccine provide the best protection against mumps. There have been 24 confirmed cases at Butler University, 18 at Indiana University and 4 each at Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis and Purdue University.\n\nMumps activity at the IU [Indiana University] campuses and Butler appears to be slowing, but the Purdue cases arose this week. College campuses, where many people live in close quarters with one another, are particularly rich environments in which the disease can spread rapidly.\n\nState health officials urge college students to make sure they have been vaccinated against the disease, which can lead to puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw. Other symptoms include fever, headache and muscle aches. Some people with mumps have mild symptoms and may not even know they have the disease.\n\nMumps is spread up to 2 days before and 5 days after symptoms begin.\n\n[Byline: Shari Rudavsky]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Indiana may be accessed at http://www.nationsonline.org/maps/USA/Indiana_map.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/217. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Mumps: USA (Massachusetts)\nDate: Wed 13 Apr 2016\nFrom: A trusted source who prefers to remain anonymous\n\nAs of 29 Mar 2016, there have been 19 confirmed and 30 suspect cases of mumps at Harvard University [Massachusetts]. A letter was sent to prospective students from the Office of Admissions and Financial Aid recommending that those who have not been vaccinated, not visit the campus due to their increased risk of contracting the virus. Likewise, those who may have been exposed to mumps or know they are infected with it, not visit campus for the health and safety of others. Harvard University Health Services has been working closely with the Massachusetts Department of Public Health and the Cambridge Public Health Department to track and monitor the situation. Procedures are in place to protect current students and visitors.\n\n\n\n[In 2006, the United States experienced a multi-state mumps outbreak involving more than 6500 reported cases. This resurgence predominantly affected college-aged students living in the Midwest, with outbreaks occurring on many different Midwestern college campuses.\n\nIn 2009 to 2010, 2 large outbreaks occurred. One multi-year outbreak involved about 3000 people and mostly affected high school-aged students who were part of a close-knit religious community in New York City and attended schools in which they had very close contact. The outbreak started when an infected student in this religious community returned from the United Kingdom where a large mumps outbreak was occurring.\n\nThe 2nd outbreak involved about 500 people, mostly school-aged children, in the U.S. Territory of Guam.\n\nIn 2011-2013, there were several smaller mumps outbreaks reported on college campuses in California, Virginia, and Maryland. However, these all had limited spread, and national case counts for these years were at usual levels (several hundred cases per year).\n\nExcerpted from http://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html.\n\nMumps activity seems to be high this year (2016), but the case numbers to date are lower than 2014 and 2015, i.e., 1223 and 1057, respectively. While it is only April, spring semester in colleges will be ending soon.\n\nA map showing Massachusetts can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4323. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4323.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: Indy Star [edited]\nhttp://www.indystar.com/story/news/2016/04/08/mumps-outbreak-reaches-65-mostly-colleges/82796644/\n\n\nMumps, 1st reported in February [2016] on many local college campuses, has continued to spread with a total of 65 people in Central Indiana who have now been diagnosed with the highly contagious respiratory disease, state health officials say. \n\nWhile the majority of cases have occurred on college campuses, 15 community cases, unconnected to those at colleges, also have been reported, the Indiana State Department of Health said Friday [8 Apr 2016] in a news release. MUMPS - USA (10): (INDIANA, MASSACHUSETTS) STUDENT CASES\n********************************************************\n \n\nState health officials urge college students to make sure they have been vaccinated against the disease, which can lead to puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw.
