[2] Mumps: USA (Massachusetts)\n\n******\n In this update:\n[1] Mumps: USA (Indiana)\n \n\nMumps is spread up to 2 days before and 5 days after symptoms begin. \n\nThe 2nd outbreak involved about 500 people, mostly school-aged children, in the U.S. Territory of Guam.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-02-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "1057-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "1223-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "INDIANA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4148390", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (09): (MN,ND,IN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4148390", "date": "2016-04-09 09:30:45", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (09): (MINNESOTA, NORTH DAKOTA, INDIANA)\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Mumps - USA (Minnesota, North Dakota)\n[2] Mumps - USA (Indiana)\n[3] Mumps - USA (Indiana)\n\n******\n[1] Mumps - USA (Minnesota, North Dakota)\nDate: Wed 6 Apr 2016\nSource: Thief River Falls Times [edited]\nhttp://www.trftimes.com/news/mumps-outbreak-reported\n\n\nAs of 29 Mar 2016, a total of 16 confirmed and probable mumps cases were reported in Minnesota, according to the Minnesota Department of Health [MDH]. On average, fewer than 10 cases are reported each year in the state.\n\nIn North Dakota, 14 cases have been reported since 24 Feb 2016. Most were in Ward County. On average, fewer than 3 cases are reported in North Dakota each year. [See ProMED-mail post Mumps - USA (08): (ND) 20160403.4136830 for post from North Dakota reporting these 14 cases age 14-86, and commentary. - Mod.LK]\n\nMumps is a highly contagious viral infection that causes swelling and tenderness in the salivary glands, cheeks and jaw, said Anita Cardinal, public health nurse and director of Inter-County Nursing Service in Thief River Falls [Minnesota]. Other symptoms include a low-grade fever, a headache, muscle aches, and a loss of appetite. Up to 30 percent of those with the illness exhibit no symptoms, according to MDH.\n\nMumps can spread 3 days before the person shows signs of the illness to 5 days after the symptoms have appeared. The most contagious period is 48 hours before the symptoms appear. There is no treatment for mumps, but individuals can receive care for their symptoms.\n\nMumps may be prevented with vaccinations. Cardinal noted that the mumps vaccine (as part of the MMR vaccine -- measles, mumps and rubella) is typically given to children 12 months to 15 months old. Another booster shot is given at 4 to 6 years old.\n\nCardinal also encouraged people to cover their coughs and use proper handwashing techniques. In addition, she noted that people shouldn't share eating utensils or beverage containers.\n\nIf people suspect they have mumps, they should call their healthcare provider. Mouth, throat and/or blood samples may be collected to confirm the diagnosis. They should also stay home for 5 days after the swelling has started.\n\n[Byline: April Scheinoha]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing North Dakota and Minnesota can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/236. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Mumps - USA (Indiana)\nDate: Wed 6 Apr 2016\nSource: Health Aim [edited]\nhttp://www.healthaim.com/mumps-outbreak-purdue-university/50398\n\n\nHealth officials at Purdue University [West Lafayette, Indiana] are on high alert after patients with mumps were detected on campus. Students, staff and faculties demonstrating symptoms of mumps were asked to refrain from entering the West Lafayette campus.\n\nTippecanoe County health officials are working closely with officials from Purdue to abate possible outbreak by containing the 5 patients with mumps and tracing possible contacts.\n\nMumps is caused by a viral infection and can be transmitted by coughing and sneezing. Therefore, health officials are on top of the situation to control the quick spreading of the infection.\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, symptoms of mumps include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite, and swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears on one or both sides. These symptoms can manifest 12 to 25 days after the virus infect the host. It incubates in the body until the patient's immune system goes down.\n\nGail Walenga of the Purdue University Student Health Center encouraged people within the vicinity to stay home if they have shown signs of mumps. Do not risk going out, unless it is an urgent one.\n\nThey were also advised to check on their immunization records and update whether they had the latest shot for MMR (mumps, measles and rubella). There are members of the population who are at high-risk for mumps.\n\nMedicine.net listed down the risk factors:\n- Failure to be immunized completely (2 separate doses) with exposure to those with mumps.\n- Age: The highest risk of contracting mumps is to children between 2-12 years of age.\n- Season: epidemics of mumps were most likely during the winter/spring seasons.\n- Travel to high-risk regions of the world: Africa, general Indian subcontinent region, and Southeast Asia. These areas have a very low rate of vaccination.\n\n[Byline: Lucielle Campanero]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Adults born in 1957 or later who have not been vaccinated or have not had mumps should get vaccinated. College students, teachers, healthcare personnel, and international travelers are at increased risk for mumps. Mumps is part of the combination vaccine, MMR, that also protects against measles and rubella.\n\nSerious complications of mumps are more common among adults than children. Rare complications caused by mumps include infections of the brain and spinal cord, arthritis, kidney and pancreas problems, deafness, and inflammation of the ovaries.\n\nAs recently as 2006 and 2009-10, the US experienced large mumps outbreaks. The ages affected by outbreaks can vary. In 2006, most cases were in people age 18 to 24; in 2009-2010, the majority was in adolescents age 11 to 17.\n\nExtracted from http://www.adultvaccination.org/vpd/mumps. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Mumps - USA (Indiana)\nDate: Thu 7 Apr 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/mumps-in-indiana-schools-purdue-university-the-latest-to-report-cases-65006/\n\n\nThe Indiana State Department of Health has reported mumps outbreaks at 4 universities as Purdue University in West Lafayette becomes the latest school to report an outbreak of the viral vaccine preventable disease.\n\nSchool and local and state health officials are investigating 5 confirmed or probable cases of mumps on the West Lafayette campus. In addition, the collaboration is working to identify and directly notify anyone who may have been in close contact with these cases, and advises faculty, staff, students and members of the community to educate themselves on the symptoms, transmission and prevention of mumps.\n\nIn addition to Purdue, state health officials have reported 45 mumps cases on 3 other campuses -- Indiana University in Bloomington (17), Butler University [in Indianapolis] (24) and Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis (IUPUI) with 4.\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, symptoms for mumps include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite, and swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears on one or both sides. Mumps is spread from direct and indirect contact with an infected person's respiratory droplets, which can be transmitted by sneezing and coughing. People with mumps can spread their infections for up to 2 days before and 5 days after the onset of symptoms. Anyone with symptoms is highly encouraged to stay home and avoid others to prevent the further spread of illness and to seek care as soon as possible.\n\nMumps is caused by a virus, so antibiotics are not indicated. Symptoms typically appear 16-18 days after infection but can range from 12-25 days. Generally, mumps is a mild illness, and some people may not have any symptoms. While complications and more serious issues can result from a mumps infection, they are generally rare, with a 1 percent to 3 percent complication rate.\n\nAt this time, university members are encouraged to check their vaccination records with their primary-care provider and obtain copies if needed. Currently, the best way to prevent mumps is to be vaccinated with 2 doses of the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine, or MMR. Individuals born after 1957 who have not had 2 doses of vaccine or are unable to find their records are encouraged to seek advice from a health care provider or contact the local health department on receiving an MMR vaccine. Persons born before 1957 are considered to be immune to mumps due to the high rate of infection prior to routine vaccination. Two doses of vaccine are only considered around 88 percent effective at preventing infection, so some people who have been fully vaccinated with 2 MMRs may still contract mumps.\n\nPracticing good hygiene habits -- such as regularly washing your hands with soap and water, sneezing and coughing into a tissue or your elbow, and avoiding the sharing of drinks, food and utensils -- is a good way to prevent illness and transmission. Additionally, if you believe you may have symptoms of mumps, isolating yourself from contact with others and seeking care as soon as possible could prevent additional spread of mumps.\n\nStudents or staff with symptoms -- even if they have received a MMR vaccine -- should stay home and call ahead before going to an urgent care or the Purdue Student Health Center. If students have concerns about possible symptoms, they should contact the Purdue Student Health Center or their primary-care provider. Treatment for mumps is geared toward alleviating symptoms. Bed rest, a soft diet and a pain reliever for aches are often recommended.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Indiana may be accessed at http://www.nationsonline.org/maps/USA/Indiana_map.jpg. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/217.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Adults born in 1957 or later who have not been vaccinated or have not had mumps should get vaccinated. In addition to Purdue, state health officials have reported 45 mumps cases on 3 other campuses -- Indiana University in Bloomington (17), Butler University [in Indianapolis] (24) and Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis (IUPUI) with 4.\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing North Dakota and Minnesota can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/236. - Mod. \n\nMumps can spread 3 days before the person shows signs of the illness to 5 days after the symptoms have appeared. \n\nMedicine.net listed down the risk factors:\n- Failure to be immunized completely (2 separate doses) with exposure to those with mumps. Cardinal noted that the mumps vaccine (as part of the MMR vaccine -- measles, mumps and rubella) is typically given to children 12 months to 15 months old. Additionally, if you believe you may have symptoms of mumps, isolating yourself from contact with others and seeking care as soon as possible could prevent additional spread of mumps. \n\nTippecanoe County health officials are working closely with officials from Purdue to abate possible outbreak by containing the 5 patients with mumps and tracing possible contacts. \n\nStudents or staff with symptoms -- even if they have received a MMR vaccine -- should stay home and call ahead before going to an urgent care or the Purdue Student Health Center. \n\nSchool and local and state health officials are investigating 5 confirmed or probable cases of mumps on the West Lafayette campus. [3] Mumps - USA (Indiana)\n\n******\n Currently, the best way to prevent mumps is to be vaccinated with 2 doses of the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine, or MMR. In this update:\n[1] Mumps - USA (Minnesota, North Dakota)\n LK]\n\nMumps is a highly contagious viral infection that causes swelling and tenderness in the salivary glands, cheeks and jaw, said Anita Cardinal, public health nurse and director of Inter-County Nursing Service in Thief River Falls [Minnesota]. MUMPS - USA (09): (MINNESOTA, NORTH DAKOTA, INDIANA)\n****************************************************\n \n\nGail Walenga of the Purdue University Student Health Center encouraged people within the vicinity to stay home if they have shown signs of mumps. People with mumps can spread their infections for up to 2 days before and 5 days after the onset of symptoms. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, symptoms of mumps include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite, and swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears on one or both sides. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, symptoms for mumps include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite, and swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears on one or both sides. \n\nMumps is caused by a viral infection and can be transmitted by coughing and sneezing. \n\nThey were also advised to check on their immunization records and update whether they had the latest shot for MMR (mumps, measles and rubella). In addition, the collaboration is working to identify and directly notify anyone who may have been in close contact with these cases, and advises faculty, staff, students and members of the community to educate themselves on the symptoms, transmission and prevention of mumps. Two doses of vaccine are only considered around 88 percent effective at preventing infection, so some people who have been fully vaccinated with 2 MMRs may still contract mumps. \n\nIf people suspect they have mumps, they should call their healthcare provider. Individuals born after 1957 who have not had 2 doses of vaccine or are unable to find their records are encouraged to seek advice from a health care provider or contact the local health department on receiving an MMR vaccine. The Indiana State Department of Health has reported mumps outbreaks at 4 universities as Purdue University in West Lafayette becomes the latest school to report an outbreak of the viral vaccine preventable disease. [Byline: April Scheinoha]\n\n--\n [Byline: Lucielle Campanero]\n\n--\n [Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\n \n\nSerious complications of mumps are more common among adults than children. \n\nMumps is caused by a virus, so antibiotics are not indicated.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-02-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2009-10-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Indianapolis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Lafayette", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ward County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "INDIANA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tippecanoe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bloomington", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4088535", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (05): (MA) student cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4088535", "date": "2016-03-12 22:10:23", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (05): (MASSACHUSETTS) STUDENT CASES\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Mar 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/harvard-mumps-outbreak-now-at-11-cases-23688/\n\n\nOfficials with the Cambridge Public Health Department reported today additional mumps cases among Harvard University students at the Cambridge [Massachusetts] campus. The current total cases now stands at 11.\n\nHarvard University Health Services [HUHS] Director, Dr Paul J. Barreira, wrote in a message to the Harvard community earlier this week:\n\nWe all have a responsibility to help prevent the spread of the virus. With spring recess only a few days away, I know many of you will be leaving the Cambridge area, and I write to remind you that it is even more important to be vigilant in taking precautions to prevent the spread of mumps if you are planning to travel.\n\nIf you are experiencing facial swelling, jaw pain, ear ache, or testicular swelling, you should refrain from public activities, avoid travel and public transportation, and contact HUHS at 617-495-5711 to be evaluated, even if you have been vaccinated. Doing this is crucial to minimizing the exposure of others to the virus.\n\nMumps spreads through saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat. An infected person can spread the virus by coughing, sneezing, or talking; sharing items, such as cups or eating utensils, with others; and touching objects or surfaces with unwashed hands that are then touched by others.\n\nPeople may be able to spread mumps from 2 days before symptom onset to 5 days after symptom onset.\n\nSymptoms (fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite and swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears on one or both sides) typically appear 14-18 days after infection, but this period can range from 12-25 days after infection. Very rarely, the virus can also cause swelling of the heart and joints, meningitis (swelling of the brain and spinal cord), and encephalitis (swelling of the brain itself).\n\nMumps can be prevented with MMR (measles-mumps-rubella) vaccine. Most children and young adults have received at least one dose of MMR vaccine. Two doses of MMR vaccine are more effective than one dose.\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), as of 4 Mar 2016, 250 mumps cases were reported nationally.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See discussion of mumps in the United States in ProMED-mail post Mumps - USA (04): (MA, MT) student cases 20160311.4084267.\n\nA map showing Massachusetts can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8159. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See discussion of mumps in the United States in ProMED-mail post Mumps - USA (04): (MA, MT) student cases 20160311.4084267. \n\nSymptoms (fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite and swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears on one or both sides) typically appear 14-18 days after infection, but this period can range from 12-25 days after infection. \n\nIf you are experiencing facial swelling, jaw pain, ear ache, or testicular swelling, you should refrain from public activities, avoid travel and public transportation, and contact HUHS at 617-495-5711 to be evaluated, even if you have been vaccinated. \n\nPeople may be able to spread mumps from 2 days before symptom onset to 5 days after symptom onset. \n\nHarvard University Health Services [HUHS] Director, Dr Paul J. Barreira, wrote in a message to the Harvard community earlier this week:\n\nWe all have a responsibility to help prevent the spread of the virus. MUMPS - USA (05): (MASSACHUSETTS) STUDENT CASES\n***********************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cambridge", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4078373", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (03): (MA) student cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4078373", "date": "2016-03-08 22:38:39", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (03): (MASSACHUSETTS) STUDENT CASES\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 7 Mar 2016\nSource: The Crimson [edited]\nhttp://www.thecrimson.com/article/2016/3/7/university-quarantines-students-mumps/\n\n\nAdministrators at the college, Harvard University Health Services [HUHS] and Cambridge Public Health Department are working to contain the spread of mumps and care for students who have been affected by the virus by relocating them to isolated housing for an extended period of time.\n\n'We have officially an outbreak of mumps in this population,' HUHS Director Paul J. Barreira said. 'It's happening with students who are well-immunized, so it's a breakthrough infection. So the task is to get the population to act in ways that minimizes the spread of the virus.'\n\nThe number of confirmed cases at the university has not increased since Barreira's email last Wed [2 Mar 2016], which stated that 6 students on campus had contracted the virus. Since that time, Barreira has circulated information about preventing the spread of the virus and encouraged students exhibiting symptoms of mumps to contact HUHS.\n\n'We have no way of knowing how it came on campus,' Barreira said. 'Public Health is responsible with interviewing everybody, and then they try to do a contact mapping to see if they can identify how it came to campus, but at this point, they're not optimistic they will find what's called the index case.'\n\nBarreira said preventive measures against mumps include practicing hygienic habits like hand washing and refraining from sharing eating utensils, seeing a doctor at the onset of mumps-like symptoms, and isolating suspected cases early.\n\n'We examine and identify clinically people who are at risk, do a buccal swab to check for virus, then we communicate to the college,' Barreira said. 'Then the college notifies the house and then identifies the room that they're going to move into.'\n\nThe Cambridge Public Health Department mandates that students infected with mumps be quarantined in a single room with an individual bathroom for 5 days. Since most dorm rooms share a bathroom, students are housed elsewhere on campus, according to Barreira.\n\nIn an emailed statement, college spokesperson Rachael Dane said the college is 'utilizing various locations on campus for students who need to self-isolate, including rooms in some of the houses and Harvard-owned properties. We are also taking special precautions with regards to cleaning these spaces, with Facilities Maintenance Operations custodians undergoing special training cleaning the rooms and disposing of waste,' Dane wrote.\n\n99 percent of undergraduates have been vaccinated against mumps, according to Barreira. Barreira added that although some other universities verify mumps immunizations through a questionnaire, Harvard requires documentation of the vaccine.\n\n'In this state, we require 2 shots, one month apart,' Barreira said. 'We often test to see if there's adequate antibodies too. In some states around the country, they only require one shot, which by [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention] standards is considered under-immunization.'\n\nThough some Harvard affiliates have asked whether a 3rd booster shot for all students would help prevent the spread of the virus, Barreira said there is no evidence that a 3rd booster shot would provide more immunity.\n\n'The CDC is very clear in their recommendations that a 3rd shot doesn't provide more immunity,' Barreira said. 'So if you've been well vaccinated, there's no indication that a 3rd shot will give you any more protection.'\n\nAs undergraduates prepare for spring break, university administrators will send 'a message encouraging responsible behavior when traveling with respect to careful hygiene and not using public transportation if ill,' Barreira wrote in an email.\n\nIn the meantime, administrators are informing parents of students about the recent mumps outbreak. On Wed [2 Mar 2016], Dean of the College Rakesh Khurana sent an email to Harvard parents looping them into Barreira's latest email about the virus.\n\n[Byline: Menaka V. Narayanan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps virus is the causative agent of mumps, a disease characterized by swelling of the parotid glands, salivary glands, and other epithelial tissues. Infection is accompanied by high morbidity. The symptoms of mumps are fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite, and swollen glands. Most people recover fully, but there is a rare chance of serious complications, such as deafness. The disease is still present even with availability of an effective vaccine.\n\nBefore the U.S. began vaccinating against mumps in 1967 [MMR - measles-mumps-rubella vaccine], there were about 186 000 cases reported each year, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Now, the amount of yearly cases ranges from a couple hundred to a couple thousand yearly. There were 2612 cases in 2010 and 229 in 2012, and in 2014 and 2015, 1223 and 1057 cases, respectively, reports the CDC.\n\nA map of Massachusetts, USA can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/224. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "\n\nBarreira said preventive measures against mumps include practicing hygienic habits like hand washing and refraining from sharing eating utensils, seeing a doctor at the onset of mumps-like symptoms, and isolating suspected cases early. \n\nThough some Harvard affiliates have asked whether a 3rd booster shot for all students would help prevent the spread of the virus, Barreira said there is no evidence that a 3rd booster shot would provide more immunity. ' MUMPS - USA (03): (MASSACHUSETTS) STUDENT CASES\n***********************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2612-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "1223-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "1057-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4084267", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (04): (MA, MT) student cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4084267", "date": "2016-03-11 09:06:43", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04): (MASSACHUSETTS, MONTANA) STUDENT CASES\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Massachusetts: University of Massachusetts students\n[2] Montana: Belgrade schools\n\n******\n[1] Massachusetts: University of Massachusetts students\nDate: Wed 9 Mar 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/umass-boston-reports-2nd-mumps-case-99723/\n\n\nFollowing reports of the 1st case of mumps in a UMass [University of Massachusetts] Boston (UMB) last week [week of 1 Mar 2016], school officials announced [Tue 8 Mar 2016] a 2nd confirmed case of the contagious viral disease.\n\nThe 1st on campus case occurred on 20 Feb 2016 during the UMB Men's hockey team match against University of Southern Maine (USM), according to a University Health Services release.\n\nUSM has previously reported a confirmed mumps case last week.\n\nMumps is a contagious disease. The most common symptom is swelling of the cheeks and jaw due to inflammation of one or both of the saliva glands near the ear and back of the jaw. However, up to half of the people with mumps may not have enough swelling to show. Other symptoms include fever, headache, stiff neck, and loss of appetite.\n\nCurrently, there is no specific treatment for mumps. Supportive care should be given as needed. If someone becomes very ill, they should seek medical attention. If someone seeks medical attention, they should call their healthcare provider in advance so that they do not have to sit in the waiting room for a long time and possibly infect other people.\n\nUMB student health asks that you seek medical care if you experience any of the symptoms noted above in the next 2 weeks. Please call or come to see us, or visit your own healthcare provider. Please be sure to tell your provider that there was a confirmed case of mumps on campus.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The report stated the University of Massachusetts Boston hockey team was matched against Southern Maine University (SMU), and in the next line stated 'USM has previously reported a confirmed mumps case last week.' Since SMU is Southern Methodist University, but the report names the University as Southern Maine University, I have taken the liberty of changing the name to University of Southern Maine, USM, which I suspect is correct.\n\nPlease see comments about mumps activity in the United States following item [2] below. - Mod.LK\n\nThe state of Massachusetts can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16731. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Montana: Belgrade schools\nDate: Wed 9 Mar 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/mumps-reported-in-belgrade-montana-students-70542/\n\n\nHealth officials in Gallatin County, Montana are reporting on 4 mumps cases among students in Belgrade schools. All of the confirmed cases attend Belgrade High School or Belgrade Middle School.\n\nMumps is a viral disease characterized by swelling of the parotid or salivary glands along the face, neck, and jaw. The swelling can last from 2 to 10 days. The incubation period, (time from when you were infected to when you have symptoms) is 12-25 days. Other symptoms, in addition to the swelling around the neck and jaw, include fever, malaise (tiredness), muscle aches, and headache. Up to 25% of people with mumps may have few or no symptoms.\n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person. Saliva can pass from one person to another when they share straws, spoons, forks, cups, cans, bottles, and even lip gloss. Mumps is also commonly spread when an infected person coughs or sneezes, and a non-infected person inhales respiratory droplets that contain the virus.\n\nIf you do have mumps, you should avoid prolonged, close contact with other people until at least 5 days after your salivary glands begin to swell because you are contagious during this time.\n\nParents of children who may be most susceptible to mumps will be notified by staff from Gallatin City-County Health Department who will provide information and health care guidance. In most cases, students who are most susceptible to mumps are those who have not been vaccinated against the disease.\n\nThe good news is that guidance from the American Academy of Pediatrics and the Centers for Disease Control has determined that unimmunized students can return to school immediately if they are vaccinated against mumps.\n\nStudents who have religious or medical exemptions for the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine may be excluded from school for 25 days or more, depending on the course of the outbreak. But again, if students are vaccinated with the MMR vaccine they can return to school immediately.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Montana can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35926. Gallatin County, in southern Montana, can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/montana-county-map.gif.\n\nFrom 2000 through 2012, an average of 1135 mumps cases (range: 229 to 6584) were reported annually in the United States. Large outbreaks occurred in 2006 (6584 cases) and in 2009 and 2010 (approximately 3500 cases). Outbreaks occurred primarily among previously vaccinated persons in densely populated settings (colleges and religious communities). A provisional total of 438 mumps cases were reported in 2013.\n\nMMR vaccine is recommended routinely for all children age 12 through 15 months, with a 2nd dose at age 4 through 6 years. The 2nd dose is not a booster, but rather is intended to produce immunity in the small number of people who fail to respond to the 1st dose. 2-5% of people do not develop measles immunity after the 1st dose of vaccine. This occurs for a variety of reasons.\n\nTo protect against mumps, adults with no evidence of immunity should get 1 dose of MMR unless the adult is in a high-risk group. High-risk people need 2 doses and include healthcare personnel, international travelers, and students at post-high school educational institutions, among others (excerpted/edited from http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_mmr.asp).\n\nMumps is no longer common in the United States, but periodic mumps outbreaks occur, particularly in winter and spring, and cases may still occur despite prior vaccination. Crowded environments, such as college classes, organized sports, or dormitories, are a major contributing factor to the spread of mumps if the virus is introduced.\n\n80 to 90% of vaccinees will be fully protected, but those who do become infected following vaccination tend to have milder disease when exposed to the virus. If a community maintains a high vaccination rate, the risk of exposure declines too. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The report stated the University of Massachusetts Boston hockey team was matched against Southern Maine University (SMU), and in the next line stated 'USM has previously reported a confirmed mumps case last week.' A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Montana can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35926. \n\nMumps is no longer common in the United States, but periodic mumps outbreaks occur, particularly in winter and spring, and cases may still occur despite prior vaccination. Following reports of the 1st case of mumps in a UMass [University of Massachusetts] Boston (UMB) last week [week of 1 Mar 2016], school officials announced [Tue 8 Mar 2016] a 2nd confirmed case of the contagious viral disease. \n\nStudents who have religious or medical exemptions for the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine may be excluded from school for 25 days or more, depending on the course of the outbreak. \n\nThe good news is that guidance from the American Academy of Pediatrics and the Centers for Disease Control has determined that unimmunized students can return to school immediately if they are vaccinated against mumps. \n\nIf you do have mumps, you should avoid prolonged, close contact with other people until at least 5 days after your salivary glands begin to swell because you are contagious during this time. ALERT\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 27 Feb 2016\nSource: WCVB Boston [edited]\nhttp://www.wcvb.com/news/health-and-human-services-warns-of-college-campus-mumps-outbreak/38228470\n\n\nThe New Hampshire Department of Health and Human services issued a health alert Friday night [25 Feb 2016] warning health care providers of a mumps outbreak at a New Hampshire college campus.\n\nState epidemiologist Dr Ben Chan said the outbreak is at St Anselm College in Goffstown.\n\nAccording to the health alert the New Hampshire Division of Public Health Services has confirmed 2 cases in a lab and identified 3 other probable cases.\n\nAll the patients are members of the men's college hockey team and all had received prior vaccinations.\n\nOfficials say the vaccinations are considered 88 percent effective after a 2-dose series.\n\nThe Division of Public Health Services is conducting a contact investigation but said the timing of this outbreak coinciding with St Anselm's spring break [27 Feb-5 Mar 2016] will make things difficult as students prepare to travel.\n\nThis could aid in the spread of the virus by potentially exposing other people across the state or the country.\n\nOfficials say health care providers should notify the Division of Public Health Services about any patient presenting signs and symptoms consistent with mumps, especially if they have been in contact with anyone from the college.\n\n[Byline: Cam Tranchemontagne]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[More cases may become evident in New Hampshire since the incubation period is 16-18 days, with a range of 12-25 days. The infected individuals had been vaccinated, but the vaccine is not 100 percent effective, rather 88 percent effective after the 2-dose series.\n\nIncreased mumps activity was recently reported by ProMED-mail in Colorado in a health care facility and in Kentucky at the University [see ProMED mail Mumps - USA: (CO,KY) increased incidence 20160225.4050452]. It also was noted that Iowa has been experiencing an ongoing outbreak of mumps since July 2015. - Mod.LK\n\nThe state of New Hampshire can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/52089. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/new-hampshire-county-map.gif. Saint Anselm College is a Catholic Benedictine liberal arts college in Hillsborough County>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[More cases may become evident in New Hampshire since the incubation period is 16-18 days, with a range of 12-25 days. \n\nIncreased mumps activity was recently reported by ProMED-mail in Colorado in a health care facility and in Kentucky at the University [see ProMED mail Mumps - USA: (CO,KY) increased incidence 20160225.4050452]. The New Hampshire Department of Health and Human services issued a health alert Friday night [25 Feb 2016] warning health care providers of a mumps outbreak at a New Hampshire college campus. \n\nAll the patients are members of the men's college hockey team and all had received prior vaccinations.\n\n MUMPS - USA (02): (NEW HAMPSHIRE) STUDENT CASES, ALERT\n******************************************************\n Officials say health care providers should notify the Division of Public Health Services about any patient presenting signs and symptoms consistent with mumps, especially if they have been in contact with anyone from the college. The Division of Public Health Services is conducting a contact investigation but said the timing of this outbreak coinciding with St Anselm's spring break [27 Feb-5 Mar 2016] will make things difficult as students prepare to travel. According to the health alert the New Hampshire Division of Public Health Services has confirmed 2 cases in a lab and identified 3 other probable cases.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-07-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Hampshire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hillsborough County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Goffstown", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kentucky", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3758370", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Argentina: (SF) increased incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3758370", "date": "2015-10-31 19:39:13", "main_text": "MUMPS - ARGENTINA: (SANTA FE) INCREASED INCIDENCE\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 28 Oct 2015\nSource: La Capital [in Spanish, trans. Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ, edited]\nhttp://www.lacapital.com.ar/la-ciudad/Advierten-sobre-un-brote-de-paperas-y-piden-controlar-el-carne-de-vacunacion-20151028-0058.html\n\n\nThe [Argentina] Ministry of Health has issued a warning about the proliferation of more cases of mumps than usual throughout the country.\n\nDr Julio Bafani, director of epidemiology for the Ministry of Health of Santa Fe [province], recommended that anyone who has any contact with sick persons 'have their vaccination cards [status] checked' at the nearest health center. In declarations to the [radio] program 'Todos en La Ocho,' the provincial government official said that many of the provinces 'are experiencing outbreaks of mumps, but these reports have been overshadowed by other more important news.'\n\n'From the epidemiology department we are in touch with all the area directors, and we know that there are more cases of mumps than usual in all provinces of the country, many of them in adolescents. Therefore, we insist that all [unvaccinated] persons who have had contact with someone with mumps take their vaccination card to the nearest health center and ask to be vaccinated,' he said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a contagious disease caused by a virus belonging to the genus _Rubulavirus_ in the family _Paramyxovirus_. It contains a linear, single-stranded molecule of negative-sense RNA 15 384 nucleotides long. It spreads through saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat. An infected person can spread the virus by:\n- coughing, sneezing, or talking,\n- sharing items, such as cups or eating utensils, with others, and touching objects or surfaces with unwashed hands that are then touched by others.\n\nMumps likely spreads before the salivary glands begin to swell and up to 5 days after the swelling begins.\n\nIn Argentina, 0 cases of mumps were reported to the WHO in 2014, 3772 in 2013, 4619 in 2012, 5481 in 2011, 5083 in 2010. These new cases in 2015 break the pattern of the downward trend in case numbers in this country (http://apps.who.int/immunization_monitoring/globalsummary/timeseries/tsincidencemumps.html).\n\nMumps can be prevented with MMR (measles-mumps-rubella) vaccine. MMR vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. Two doses of the vaccine are 88 per cent (range: 66-95 per cent) effective at preventing mumps; one dose is 78 per cent (range: 49-92 per cent) effective.\n\nThe 1st vaccine against mumps was licensed in the USA in 1967. By 2005, mumps rates declined by more than 99 per cent thanks to high 2-dose vaccination coverage among children.\n\nPartly excerpted from http://www.cdc.gov/mumps/. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1169.]", "summary": "\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a contagious disease caused by a virus belonging to the genus _Rubulavirus_ in the family _Paramyxovirus_. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Two doses of the vaccine are 88 per cent (range: 66-95 per cent) effective at preventing mumps; one dose is 78 per cent (range: 49-92 per cent) effective. An infected person can spread the virus by:\n- coughing, sneezing, or talking,\n- sharing items, such as cups or eating utensils, with others, and touching objects or surfaces with unwashed hands that are then touched by others. \n\n'From the epidemiology department we are in touch with all the area directors, and we know that there are more cases of mumps than usual in all provinces of the country, many of them in adolescents. \n\nMumps can be prevented with MMR (measles-mumps-rubella) vaccine. MUMPS - ARGENTINA: (SANTA FE) INCREASED INCIDENCE\n*************************************************\n \n\nMumps likely spreads before the salivary glands begin to swell and up to 5 days after the swelling begins. The outbreak began in Trondheim, but residents of Oslo, Bergen and elsewhere along the west coast have also fallen ill.\n\nMumps is caused by a virus that leaves those infected with painful swelling of the glands in their neck. Symptoms include fever, muscle pain, headache, fatigue and, ultimately, the swelling. It's mostly viewed as a children's disease but can also infect adults, including some who were infected as children or had vaccinations that have worn off over time.\n\nDoctors in Trondheim alerted state officials at the Institute for Public Health (Folkehelseinstituttet) late last week. By then, cases were spreading beyond Trondheim. All students suffering symptoms that can be confused with flu were urged to undergo testing. Dr Karin Ronning of the health institute said the outbreak is believed to have been brought in by foreign students.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Excerpted from the Norwegian Institute of Public Health http://www.fhi.no/eway/default.aspx?pid=240&trg=MainContent_6894&Main_6664=6894:0:25,7555:1:0:0:::0:0&MainContent_6894=6706:0:25,9612:1:0:0:::0:0:\n'Since 1969, all children in Norway have been offered vaccination against measles via the Childhood Immunisation Programme. The measles vaccine is given in the form of 2 doses of MMR vaccine at 15 months and at 11 years (Grade 6). If there is an increased risk of infection, the vaccine may be given as early as 9 months, but a booster dose at 15 months of age is recommended.'\n\nThere is an option in Norway to not take vaccines, thus outbreaks such as this current one may occur. Nonetheless, the case count has dropped significantly since 1960; see the URL above for Figure 1 - Cases of measles per 100 000 inhabitants in Norway from 1900 to 2014. Source: Statistics Norway (1900-1974) and MSIS (1975-2014), and Figure 2 - vaccination coverage for measles vaccine, 2014, 2-year-olds (per cent). Coverage for the entire country (hele landet) and by county. Figure: norgeshelsa.no. The measles vaccine is given in the form of 2 doses of MMR vaccine at 15 months and at 11 years (Grade 6). If there is an increased risk of infection, the vaccine may be given as early as 9 months, but a booster dose at 15 months of age is recommended.' \n\n--\n Nonetheless, the case count has dropped significantly since 1960; see the URL above for Figure 1 - Cases of measles per 100 000 inhabitants in Norway from 1900 to 2014.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1960-03-25 00:00:00", "1969-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Trondheim", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oslo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3690007", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (09): (IL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3690007", "date": "2015-10-04 16:53:54", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (09): (ILLINOIS)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 1 Oct 2015\nSource: WBJC Illinois [edited]\nhttp://www.wjbc.com/2015/10/01/mumps-outbreak-at-bloomington-high-school/\n\n\nMumps continues to be a problem in the Bloomington-Normal area. The McLean County Health Department is reporting that Bloomington High School now has at least 3 cases of mumps, which qualifies as an outbreak at the school.\n\nAll of those in the county infected with the mumps are between the ages of 15 and 54. Increased mumps activity has also been reported at Normal West, University High School, Illinois State University and Heartland Community College.\n\n[byline: Terry James]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/216.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Terry James]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/216.] A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "3662990", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (08): (IL) college students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3662990", "date": "2015-09-22 17:45:55", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (08): (ILLINOIS) COLLEGE STUDENTS\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 28 Aug 2015\nFrom: Richard Lampman <richlamp@illinois.edu> [edited]\n\n\nThe number of mumps cases increased even during the summer break, which is why there is a potential for a rapid increase in cases now that the students have returned to campus. The suggestion of maintaining a 6-foot distance would be difficult in any classroom or cafeteria.\n\n--\nRichard L. Lampman (retired)\nMedical Entomologist\nIllinois Natural History Survey\n<richlamp@illinois.edu>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Richard Lampman for drawng attention to the expanding mumps epidemic in Illinois. - Mod.CP]\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 22 Sep 2015\nSource: The News Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.news-gazette.com/news/local/2015-08-26/updated-number-mumps-cases-tops-100-local-outbreak-more-clinics-set.html\n\n\nLocal health officials are continuing to try to get a growing University of Illinois mumps outbreak under control by offering 2 more free, all-day vaccination clinics for students this week. Students are also being urged to keep their distance from each other.\n\n'Try to maintain a 6-foot distance from other individuals, which admittedly isn't possible in many classroom environments,' says a mass communication just sent to students and their families, advising them about protecting themselves and the rest of the community from the mumps outbreak that began in April 2015 and escalated over the summer.\n\nHealth officials have linked most cases of mumps, a highly contagious viral illness, to the UI campus. There were 101 confirmed cases as of Wednesday [16 Sep 2015?], according to Champaign-Urbana Public Health District Administrator, Julie Pryde. Most mumps cases have been mild, since they've involved people who have been vaccinated with the measles/mumps/rubella vaccine. But there remains a potential for a serious case among those who aren't able to safely receive the vaccine, Pryde said.\n\nThe health district and the UI McKinley Health Center have been steadily giving an extra, 3rd dose of the vaccine to students, faculty and staff since early August 2015 in hope of getting the outbreak under control before most students returned for the fall [2015] semester, and other students were asked to get an extra vaccine dose before they returned to campus. But officials have yet to see the outbreak tail off.\n\nWith the rest of the students back on campus now, she said, 'it has the potential to explode. That's what we're trying to avoid. All of a sudden, the kids are back.' Those who haven't had an extra MMR shot have 2 extra chances to get one at vaccination clinics being held from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Wednesday and Thursday [23-24 Sep 2015] at the Illinois Union.\n\nPryde said the public health district has also blanketed medical providers throughout Illinois with information about mumps and urged them to test anyone with mumps symptoms, since this isn't an illness often seen these days. One thing that has horrified her, she said, is that there have been adults walking around in this outbreak with clear cases of mumps that were misdiagnosed. 'We've talked about it incessantly,' she said.\n\nDr. Robert Palinkas, director of the UI McKinley Health Center, said all mumps outbreaks that have occurred at universities over the past decade have involved vaccinated students. That's because the blended MMR vaccine involves a strong component for measles, but the vaccine for mumps is only 89 percent effective.\n\nPalinkas told students and faculty at a Senate Executive Committee meeting on Monday [21 Sep 2015] that since there's no treatment for mumps, the only options are to provide booster shots, isolate those who get sick, and try to do something difficult to do on campus, inhibit social interaction.\n\n'I had to go to a kid's apartment today [22 Sep 2015] and drag him to McKinley under threat of whatever and make him call his mom to come get him, because he didn't want to leave town because it was the 1st week of school, and he had mumps,' he said. 'So it's a struggle.'\n\nHealth officials always notify roommates and housing units when a student gets mumps, but 'at this point, it's going to be a more careful and thoughtful process of excluding more and more people,' who may have been exposed, given that several thousand students might not be immune to the disease, he said. Students 'are not going to be happy with some of the sanctions,' he said. 'It will be a challenge.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is an acute viral disease that is spread from person to person by coughing or sneezing. Some people may have no symptoms or very mild symptoms, but they can still pass the virus on to others.\n\nThe symptoms of mumps include a low-grade fever and swelling or tenderness of one or more of the salivary glands in the cheeks and under the jaw. In males who have gone through puberty, up to 30 percent may experience testicular pain and swelling.\n\nSymptoms usually appear between 12 and 25 days after a person has been exposed to the mumps virus. As many as 30 to 40 percent of infected people will not have symptoms, and nearly 50 percent will have non-specific or mostly respiratory symptoms, with or without infection in the salivary glands.\n\nThere is a vaccine to protect against mumps. The vaccine is given as part of a combination vaccine called the MMR vaccine, which protects against measles, mumps, and rubella.\n\nVaccination of adults: To prevent mumps. adults born in 1957 or later including non-pregnant women of childbearing age who do not have a medical contraindication should receive at least one dose of the MMR vaccine, unless they can document that they have received at least one dose of mumps-containing vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of immunity to the disease.\n\nCollege and university students, healthcare personnel, and international travelers are at increased risk for mumps and should receive 2 doses of the MMR vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of immunity to ensure adequate protection.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is very safe and highly effective with few side effects. Mild reactions such as fever, redness, or swelling at the injection site have been reported. Adult women may infrequently have joint symptoms like pain and stiffness from the rubella part of the vaccine.\n\nThe potential risks associated with measles, mumps, and rubella are much greater than the potential risks associated with the vaccine. MMR vaccine should not be given to persons who are pregnant or severely immuno-suppressed. For more information, see http://www.adultvaccination.org/vpd/mumps/facts.html#sthash.nEYhTe7K.dpuf. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/32379.]", "summary": "\n\nThe health district and the UI McKinley Health Center have been steadily giving an extra, 3rd dose of the vaccine to students, faculty and staff since early August 2015 in hope of getting the outbreak under control before most students returned for the fall [2015] semester, and other students were asked to get an extra vaccine dose before they returned to campus. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\n'Try to maintain a 6-foot distance from other individuals, which admittedly isn't possible in many classroom environments,' says a mass communication just sent to students and their families, advising them about protecting themselves and the rest of the community from the mumps outbreak that began in April 2015 and escalated over the summer. \n\nHealth officials always notify roommates and housing units when a student gets mumps, but 'at this point, it's going to be a more careful and thoughtful process of excluding more and more people,' who may have been exposed, given that several thousand students might not be immune to the disease, he said. \n\nCollege and university students, healthcare personnel, and international travelers are at increased risk for mumps and should receive 2 doses of the MMR vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of immunity to ensure adequate protection. Medical Entomologist\nIllinois Natural History Survey\n<richlamp@illinois.edu>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Richard Lampman for drawng attention to the expanding mumps epidemic in Illinois. - Mod. adults born in 1957 or later including non-pregnant women of childbearing age who do not have a medical contraindication should receive at least one dose of the MMR vaccine, unless they can document that they have received at least one dose of mumps-containing vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of immunity to the disease. \n\nPalinkas told students and faculty at a Senate Executive Committee meeting on Monday [21 Sep 2015] that since there's no treatment for mumps, the only options are to provide booster shots, isolate those who get sick, and try to do something difficult to do on campus, inhibit social interaction. \n\nThe potential risks associated with measles, mumps, and rubella are much greater than the potential risks associated with the vaccine. The vaccine is given as part of a combination vaccine called the MMR vaccine, which protects against measles, mumps, and rubella. Most mumps cases have been mild, since they've involved people who have been vaccinated with the measles/mumps/rubella vaccine. Pryde said the public health district has also blanketed medical providers throughout Illinois with information about mumps and urged them to test anyone with mumps symptoms, since this isn't an illness often seen these days. \n\nDr. Robert Palinkas, director of the UI McKinley Health Center, said all mumps outbreaks that have occurred at universities over the past decade have involved vaccinated students. MUMPS - USA (08): (ILLINOIS) COLLEGE STUDENTS\n*********************************************\n \n\nHealth officials have linked most cases of mumps, a highly contagious viral illness, to the UI campus. That's because the blended MMR vaccine involves a strong component for measles, but the vaccine for mumps is only 89 percent effective. \n\n\nLocal health officials are continuing to try to get a growing University of Illinois mumps outbreak under control by offering 2 more free, all-day vaccination clinics for students this week. The number of mumps cases increased even during the summer break, which is why there is a potential for a rapid increase in cases now that the students have returned to campus.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2015-09-21 00:00:00", "2015-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-04-25 00:00:00", "2015-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4050452", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Mumps - USA: (CO,KY) increased incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4050452", "date": "2016-02-25 17:17:21", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA: (COLORADO, KENTUCKY) INCREASED INCIDENCE\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n\n[1] USA (Colorado): mumps incidence\n[2] USA (Kentucky): increase in activity mumps\n\n******\n[1] USA (Colorado): mumps incidence\nDate: Wed 24 Feb 2016\nSource: CBS4 Denver [edited]\nhttp://denver.cbslocal.com/2016/02/24/mumps-outbreak-in-denver-county-investigated/\n\n\nPublic health officials are investigating an outbreak of 6 mumps cases in Denver County [Colorado]. The outbreak is among a group of residents and health care personnel.\n\nOfficials believe the source of the infection is thought to be a person who recently moved to Colorado from Iowa with additional infections resulting from exposures in a health care setting. Iowa has been experiencing an ongoing outbreak of mumps since July 2015.\n\nWhile infectious, the person socialized with a group of 3 friends who all subsequently developed unilateral parotid swelling and tenderness in late January [2016]. Those people were evaluated and treated for mumps at the Denver Adult Urgent Care Clinic on 2 Feb 2016.\n\n'All had some jaw swelling in this region which is pretty common for mumps. They also had low grade temperatures and just felt ill,' infectious disease Dr. Heather Young told CBS4 Health Specialist Kathy Walsh.\n\nYoung is a physician at Denver Health Medical Center and serves as the hospital's epidemiologist.\n\n20 days later, 2 health care personnel who treated those patients at the urgent care clinic developed symptoms consistent with mumps. 'Not having a high awareness that mumps in the community leads to other spread,' said Young.\n\nYoung said all 6 of the adult patients had been vaccinated against the disease. She said the mumps vaccine is about 88 percent effective and immunity can wane after about 15 to 20 years. 'Right now, we're not recommending another vaccine. But we'll wait for further guidance from the CDPHE (Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment),' said Young.\n\nMumps cases are usually mild, but some can have serious complications. 'Some of those are inflammation of the brain or encephalitis, inflammation of the testes which can lead to fertility problems in men or inflammation of the ovaries or breasts in women,' explained Young.\n\nDenver Health is contacting those who visited Denver Health Adult Urgent Care Clinic on 28, 30, 31 Jan, 2 Feb 2016.\n\nAdditional Information from the Colorado Department of Health and Environment\n-----------------------------------------------------------------------------\nMumps is a viral infection that can cause painful swelling of one or more of the salivary glands, typically the parotid glands. Other symptoms may include low-grade fever, malaise, and headache, but approximately 1/3rd of infected persons do not have clinically apparent illness so cases often go undetected. Severe complications from mumps are rare, but can include inflammation of the brain and/or tissue covering the brain and spinal cord, inflammation of the ovaries and/or breast, sterility, orchitis, spontaneous abortion, or deafness. Despite high vaccination rates and an effective vaccine, cases are likely to occur among vaccinated individuals because the vaccine is not 100 percent effective (estimated effectiveness for 2 doses is 88 percent) and vaccine-induced immunity can wane.\n\nInfection control\n-----------------\nMumps is transmitted by direct contact with respiratory droplets or saliva from an infected person. Mumps may be spread by freshly contaminated fomites. The average incubation period is 16-18 days, with a range of 12-25 days. The period of maximum communicability is from 1-2 days before onset of salivary gland swelling to 5 days after onset of salivary gland swelling.\n\nFor disease investigation purposes, consider mumps cases infectious 2 days prior to salivary gland swelling through 6 days of swelling (5 days after swelling onset with the day of onset counted as day 0).\n\n[Byline: Kathy Walsh]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] USA (Kentucky): increase in activity mumps\nDate: Sun 21 Feb 2016\nSource: Beacon Transcript [edited]\nhttp://www.beacontranscript.com/the-mumps-is-spreading-like-wildfire-in-the-us/5343/\n\n\nThe University of Kentucky has recently reported that the health authorities identified 3 more cases of mumps among students. According to the CDC, the mumps is spreading like wildfire in the US, with 69 confirmed cases so far.\n\nMostly viewed as a childhood disease, mumps can have some nasty effects once you grow older. And even as a child, it can put your life at risk. The mumps, also called epidemic parotitis (the inflammation of the salivary glands), is mainly caused by the mumps virus.\n\nThe most common symptoms associated with this disease are fever, headache and muscle pain. However, some of the patients reported fatigue after contracting the mumps virus. These symptoms usually resurface within an interval of 16 to 18 days, although in some cases it may take longer (12 to 25 days).\n\nAccording to the medical literature, most of the symptoms associated with epidemic parotitis are mild, but, in some instances, the patients can suffer from complications. The CDC notes that the most common complication associated with the mumps are meningitis or inflammation of the brain. Approximately 15 percent of the patients diagnosed with the mumps can suffer from this complication.\n\nThe virus can also induce pancreatitis in approximately 4 percent of the patients. Perhaps the most severe complication that can occur is permanent deafness. Moreover, it is also a known fact that older patients treated for the mumps can become infertile.\n\nOther complications associated with this childhood disease are swelling of the testicles or of the ovaries and swelling of the breasts.\n\nHow is the disease transmitted? According to the CDC, everyone infected with the mumps virus is a carrier, regardless of how severe the case is. Usually, epidemic parotitis is transmitted by droplets of saliva or mucus from an infected person. Anyone who is infected can infect others in return through sneezes, coughs or talking. Sharing personal objects like toothbrushes, towel or cups can also help the virus to spread.\n\nUnfortunately, there is no cure for the disease, only supportive care. In case someone comes down with mumps, doctors recommend lots of bed rest, fluids and if necessary, to apply either ice or heat to the neck or to the groin. If the pain becomes acute, the patient can take pain relief medicine like acetaminophen.\n\nMoreover, the doctors have noted that gargles with water and soft food may ease the symptoms. As precautionary methods, the physicians urge their patients not to take aspirin for mumps. In some children, taking aspirin has caused another disease called Reye's syndrome.\n\nThe mumps is spreading like wildfire in the US, and the CDC recommends that all who have been exposed should go to the nearest clinic in order to receive 2 doses of the MMR vaccine.\n\n[Byline: Angelina Stapp]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is no longer very common in the United States. From year to year, mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. For example, 2010 was a peak year with 2612 cases, while in 2012, there were 229. In 2014 and 2015, there were 1223 and 1057 cases, respectively. Before the US mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99 per cent decrease in mumps cases in the United States.\n\nIn some years, there are more cases of mumps than usual because of outbreaks. Mumps outbreaks can occur any time of year but often occur in winter and spring.\n\nMMR vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. Two doses of the vaccine are 88 per cent (range: 66-95 per cent) effective at protecting against mumps; one dose is 78 per cent (range: 49-92 per cent) effective. Outbreaks can still occur in highly vaccinated US communities, particularly in close-contact settings.\n\nExtracted and edited from http://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/220.]", "summary": "For disease investigation purposes, consider mumps cases infectious 2 days prior to salivary gland swelling through 6 days of swelling (5 days after swelling onset with the day of onset counted as day 0). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n20 days later, 2 health care personnel who treated those patients at the urgent care clinic developed symptoms consistent with mumps. ' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\nMMR vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. [2] USA (Kentucky): increase in activity mumps\n\n******\n In this update:\n\n[1] USA (Colorado): mumps incidence\n Despite high vaccination rates and an effective vaccine, cases are likely to occur among vaccinated individuals because the vaccine is not 100 percent effective (estimated effectiveness for 2 doses is 88 percent) and vaccine-induced immunity can wane. The mumps, also called epidemic parotitis (the inflammation of the salivary glands), is mainly caused by the mumps virus. Two doses of the vaccine are 88 per cent (range: 66-95 per cent) effective at protecting against mumps; one dose is 78 per cent (range: 49-92 per cent) effective. \n\nMumps cases are usually mild, but some can have serious complications. ' \nMumps is a viral infection that can cause painful swelling of one or more of the salivary glands, typically the parotid glands. \n\nMostly viewed as a childhood disease, mumps can have some nasty effects once you grow older. \n\n'All had some jaw swelling in this region which is pretty common for mumps. The period of maximum communicability is from 1-2 days before onset of salivary gland swelling to 5 days after onset of salivary gland swelling. Severe complications from mumps are rare, but can include inflammation of the brain and/or tissue covering the brain and spinal cord, inflammation of the ovaries and/or breast, sterility, orchitis, spontaneous abortion, or deafness. \n\nOther complications associated with this childhood disease are swelling of the testicles or of the ovaries and swelling of the breasts. -----------------\nMumps is transmitted by direct contact with respiratory droplets or saliva from an infected person. The IDPH says 4 cases have been found at the college. Letters are being sent out to students, faculty and staff the health department has determined were in close contact with those who were infected.\n\nAs of [16 Sep 2015], 6 cases of mumps have been identified in McLean County and more test results are pending.\n\nThe symptoms of mumps include fever, headache and swollen salivary glands, and malaise. Symptoms usually appear 12 to 25 days after [a person becomes] infected.\n\n[Byline: Joe Ragusa]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak appears to be part of the larger epidemic affecting students in more than one educational establishment in the state of Illinois. So far it has been reported [in ProMED-mail post 20150828.3608518] that: 'Champaign-Urbana [Illinois] is experiencing the largest outbreak of the mumps ever to hit the area with around 100 cases confirmed as of Wednesday morning [26 Aug 2015]. Researchers say the mass mumps outbreak began this spring [2015] on the University of Illinois campus. They attribute the spread of the infection to students living in close quarters and interacting in large social settings. The best protection against the mumps is the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine, but the standard 2 doses only offer 85 percent protection. So the CDC and the Illinois Department of Public Health recommend everyone in the community get a 3rd booster shot, which increases that immunity level to 95 percent.' - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/7999.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n So far it has been reported [in ProMED-mail post 20150828.3608518] that: 'Champaign-Urbana [Illinois] is experiencing the largest outbreak of the mumps ever to hit the area with around 100 cases confirmed as of Wednesday morning \n\n\nMumps outbreak declared at Heartland Community College: Illinois\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< The best protection against the mumps is the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine, but the standard 2 doses only offer 85 percent protection. Researchers say the mass mumps outbreak began this spring [2015] on the University of Illinois [U of I] campus. They attribute the spread of the infection to students living in close quarters and interacting in large social settings.\n\nThe best protection against the mumps is the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine, but the standard 2 doses only offer 85 percent protection.\n\nSo the CDC and the Illinois Department of Public Health recommend everyone in the community get a 3rd booster shot, which increases that immunity level to 95 percent.\n\n'We just have to reach that breaking point. And we don't know what that is so far,' said Awais Vaid, Director of Planning and Research at the Champaign-Urbana Public Health District. 'But experts say that if you can boost the immunity in this population, which is a close knit community, we will see those numbers go down pretty soon.'\n\nMass vaccination clinics are being held at the Illini Union [student union for the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign] from 10 AM to 4 PM through [Fri 28 Aug 2015]. Vaccines are free to U of I students, faculty, and staff.\n\nSo far, 4500 have been vaccinated at the clinics, and organizers expect to vaccinate 3000-4000 more in the coming days.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promed.org>\n\n[The extent of this outbreak is unprecedented and no explanation is offered. The standard mumps vaccine is efficient and effective. No explanation is provided for the lapse in control in Champaign-Urbana.
