USA (05): (IOWA) RETURNING UNIVERSITY STUDENTS\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 20 Aug 2015\nSource: KCRG.com [edited]\nhttp://www.kcrg.com/subject/news/health/as-mumps-cases-increase-in-johnson-county-officials-push-vaccination-20150819\n\n\nHealth officials in Johnson County say they've seen an increase in mumps cases in recent weeks, just as thousands of students begin returning to the University of Iowa.\n\nDoug Beardsley, Director of Johnson County Public Health, said there have been 15 cases of mumps reported in Johnson County in 2015. State disease tracking information suggests most of those reports have come within the last couple of weeks. Typically there are zero to one cases of mumps reported a year in Johnson County, Beardsley said. 'It is unusual,' Beardsley said. 'It's an unnecessary illness.'\n\nMumps can be prevented with the MMR vaccine, which is administered to most kids in the United States during the first few years of their lives. The MMR [mumps measpes and rubella] vaccination is a requirement for kids in Iowa's public education system, licensed child care centers and at public universities. Exemptions are granted for religious and health reasons.\n\nLast week the University of Iowa urged students to get up-to-date on their vaccinations before returning to campus after 6bb cases of the mumps were reported among UI students in the past few weeks.\n\nBeardsley said it's possible for the disease to spread even among people who have been vaccinated. 'Even if you have been vaccinated you should stay away from someone [infected with mumps],' said Beardsley.\n\nMumps is a viral disease that includes fever, muscle pain, headache, tired feeling and swelling of the throat. Symptoms are usually benign, but can last for a couple of weeks.\n\n[Byline: Mark Carlson, KCRG-TV9]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a contagious infection caused by mumps virus, a member of the family _Paramyxoviridae_. Mumps is most common in children over the age of 2 who have not been vaccinated, and also causes disease in unvaccinated teenagers and young adults, although older people may contract the disease as well.\n\nOnce a person has become infected with mumps, it takes 2-3 weeks for the symptoms to appear. However, an infected person can spread the infection even when they do not have any symptoms -- the disease is contagious from 7 days before and up to 9 days after the onset of symptoms. It can be a potentially serious disease for children and young adults.\n\nThe virus causes salivary glands to become swollen and tender on 1 or both sides of the face, resulting in enlarged cheeks. Other symptoms include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness and loss of appetite, and can last up to 10 days. For teenagers, getting mumps can cause swelling in the testicles or ovaries, and can lead to sterility. Swelling of the brain can occur in the most serious cases, albeit rarely.\n\nIn adolescents, mumps is most common among students beginning their higher education due to inadequate vaccination in their earlier years. The MMR vaccine is generally highly effective in recipients of all ages. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/218.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a contagious infection caused by mumps virus, a member of the family _Paramyxoviridae_. \n\nLast week the University of Iowa urged students to get up-to-date on their vaccinations before returning to campus after 6bb cases of the mumps were reported among UI students in the past few weeks. Mumps is most common in children over the age of 2 who have not been vaccinated, and also causes disease in unvaccinated teenagers and young adults, although older people may contract the disease as well. \n\nMumps is a viral disease that includes fever, muscle pain, headache, tired feeling and swelling of the throat. \n\nOnce a person has become infected with mumps, it takes 2-3 weeks for the symptoms to appear. \n\nDoug Beardsley, Director of Johnson County Public Health, said there have been 15 cases of mumps reported in Johnson County in 2015. MUMPS - USA (05): (IOWA) RETURNING UNIVERSITY STUDENTS\n******************************************************\n However, an infected person can spread the infection even when they do not have any symptoms -- the disease is contagious from 7 days before and up to 9 days after the onset of symptoms. \n\n\nHealth officials in Johnson County say they've seen an increase in mumps cases in recent weeks, just as thousands of students begin returning to the University of Iowa.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johnson County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3563027", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Ireland (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3563027", "date": "2015-08-06 20:46:50", "main_text": "MUMPS - IRELAND (02)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 6 Aug 2015\nSource: Irish Examiner [edited]\nhttp://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/mumps-outbreak-as-2000-cases-reported-346524.html\n\n\nThere has been a major outbreak of mumps in Ireland over the past 12 months with almost 2000 cases of the highly infectious disease having been notified to the health authorities.\n\nA significant number of the outbreaks were in the HSE [Health and Safety Executive] South region which includes Cork, Kerry, Waterford and South Tipperary and where notifiable cases were twice the national average. However, the highest incidence of mumps was in the North-West.\n\nThe scale of the outbreak, since July 2014, has led the Health Protection Surveillance Centre to recommend an increase in the overall coverage of the MMR [measles, mumps and rubella] vaccine among teenagers and young adults to prevent similar large outbreaks in future.\n\nThe centre said official figures showed there were large gaps in the uptake of the 2-dose MMR vaccination. It claimed many outbreaks were linked to schools, colleges and universities as well as among families.\n\nThe centre, which monitors all infectious disease in the Republic, also observed the vaccination status of patients was not routinely available or reported. Such data were not available in 41 percent of all cases.\n\nNevertheless, the centre said it appeared a large proportion of cases had received 1 to 3 doses of the MMR vaccine with a majority having had at least 1 vaccine. The vaccine, introduced in Ireland in 1988, protects against measles, mumps and rubella. It is usually given to children aged 12 months followed by a booster dose at 4 to 5 years.\n\nThe infection can be highly dangerous in older children and adults as it can lead to serious complications such as meningitis and encephalitis through secondary infection.\n\nAs there is no cure for mumps, treatment is aimed at relieving the symptoms and preventing the further spread of infection.\n\nThe HPSC [Health Protection Surveillance Centre] said recent results were in line with other international outbreaks of mumps which had shown waning immunity to the mumps component of the MMR vaccine as a factor in a number of outbreaks of the disease.\n\nResearch has shown there were 1993 reported cases of mumps notified to the health authorities in the past 12-month period with outbreaks reported across most regions and all age groups. Males accounted for 56 percent of all cases.\n\nThe median age of those infected was 20 years, although the youngest sufferer was 2 months old while the eldest was aged 89 years. 2/3rds of those infected with mumps were aged 15 to 24. Among those cases for whom vaccination data was available in the 15 to 24 age group, a large majority of these reported having received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine.\n\nPatients in the HSE South region, which also includes Carlow and Kilkenny, accounted for 29 percent of all cases with a notification rate twice the national average at 86.7 per 100 000 population.\n\nHowever, the highest incidence of mumps was in the North-West (with 93.3 cases per 100 000), while the national average was 43.4 per 100 000 population. The lowest rate (17 per 100 000) was seen in the North-East.\n\nOnly 48 percent aged 12 months or older of those infected were reported as having one or more vaccinations, while the vaccination status of more than 1000 cases was unknown or not reported.\n\nTwo doses of the MMR vaccine are 88 percent effective at preventing mumps while one dose provides 78 percent cover.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a contagious infection, caused by mumps virus, a member of the family _Paramyxoviridae_. Mumps is most common in children over the age of 2 who have not been vaccinated, and also causes disease in unvaccinated teenagers and young adults, although older people may contract the disease as well. In the cases reported above, a large majority reported having received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine. Immunity appears to have waned over time or was only partial to begin with. The MMR vaccine, against measles, mumps, and rubella, is least effective against mumps. As stated in the report, 2 doses of the MMR vaccine are 88 percent effective at preventing mumps while 1 dose provides 78 percent cover.\n\nMumps is spread from person to person via airborne droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes, or through direct contact with the infected person or contaminated items.\n\nOnce a person has become infected with mumps, it takes 2-3 weeks for the symptoms to appear. However, an infected person can spread the infection even when they do not have any symptoms -- the disease is contagious from 7 days before and up to 9 days after the onset of symptoms. It can be a potentially serious disease for children and young adults.\n\nThe virus causes salivary glands to become swollen and tender on one or both sides of the face, resulting in enlarged cheeks. Other symptoms include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness and loss of appetite, and can last up to 10 days. For teenagers, getting mumps can cause swelling in the testicles or ovaries, and can lead to sterility. Swelling of the brain can occur in the most serious cases, albeit rarely. See discussion in ProMED-mail post Mumps - USA (04): (IL, MO) university students 20150730.3546295.\n\nIn 2014, in Ireland, the number of people diagnosed with mumps [up to November 2014] more than doubled when compared to the previous year, 2013. There were more than 400 cases of the highly contagious airborne disease diagnosed in 2014, compared with a total of 184 cases in 2013. [And this current report is 5-fold higher to date for 2015.] The 2014 outbreak predominantly affected young adults and teenagers. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39.]", "summary": "\n\nResearch has shown there were 1993 reported cases of mumps notified to the health authorities in the past 12-month period with outbreaks reported across most regions and all age groups. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n As stated in the report, 2 doses of the MMR vaccine are 88 percent effective at preventing mumps while 1 dose provides 78 percent cover. There were more than 400 cases of the highly contagious airborne disease diagnosed in 2014, compared with a total of 184 cases in 2013.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2014-11-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "1993-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-07-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "mumps", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3442934", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (03): (IL) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3442934", "date": "2015-06-16 19:18:12", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (03): (ILLINOIS), UNIVERSITY STUDENTS\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 14 Jun 2015\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/mumps-outbreak-reported-in-illinois-23-cases-identified-44553/\n\n\nIllinois health officials have identified 23 cases of mumps in a local outbreak in Champaign-Urbana, primarily in university students. Local media reports that a Champaign-Urbana Public Health District official said most of the patients had been vaccinated, so the illness hasn't been severe. However, health officials say the outbreak could grow.\n\nMumps is a contagious, vaccine-preventable, acute viral illness that is spread through droplets of saliva or through mucus of an infected person. According to the Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH), symptoms of mumps usually appear 14 days to 18 days after infection. They usually include fever, headache, tiredness, muscle aches, loss of appetite and swelling and tenderness of one or more of the salivary glands, usually the parotid gland (located just below the front of the ear at the angle of the jaw). In mild cases, the swelling may only last for 3-4 days but can last up to a week or more. Approximately 1/3rd of infected people do not exhibit symptoms.\n\nThere is no specific treatment for mumps, but there are treatments that can help relieve some symptoms. Persons with symptoms of mumps should contact their primary care physician. Persons that become very ill should seek medical attention. Mumps vaccine is the best way to prevent mumps. This vaccine is included in the combination measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) and measles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccines.\n\nChildren should receive the 1st dose of mumps-containing vaccine at 12-15 months and the 2nd dose at 4-6 years. All adults born during or after 1957 should have documentation of one dose. Adults at higher risk, such as university students, health care personnel, international travelers and persons with potential mumps outbreak exposure should have documentation of 2 doses of mumps vaccine or other proof of immunity to mumps.\n\nSimple measures can be carried out to prevent the spread of mumps. Persons who are ill should remain home for 5 days after onset of salivary gland swelling to help contain the spread of the virus. In addition, make sure to wash your hands; don't share eating or drinking utensils; clean surfaces that are frequently touched and cover your cough or sneeze into a tissue or your sleeve -- do NOT cough or sneeze into your hand.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A comprehensive description of measles virus and measles disease can be accessed at the WHO Measles Factfile: Know the risks; check your status; protect yourself (http://www.who.int/features/factfiles/measles/en/). - Mod.CP]\n\n[The virus usually causes mild disease in children, but in adults can lead to complications, such as meningitis [inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding the brain] and orchitis [inflammation of the testes, usually unilateral] which occurs in 20-30 percent of post-pubertal males and is a risk factor for testicular cancer, - Mod.JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/216.]", "summary": "Adults at higher risk, such as university students, health care personnel, international travelers and persons with potential mumps outbreak exposure should have documentation of 2 doses of mumps vaccine or other proof of immunity to mumps. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A comprehensive description of measles virus and measles disease can be accessed at the WHO Measles Factfile: Know the risks; check your status; protect yourself (http://www.who.int/features/factfiles/measles/en/). CP]\n\n[The virus usually causes mild disease in children, but in adults can lead to complications, such as meningitis [inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding the brain] and orchitis [inflammation of the testes, usually unilateral] which occurs in 20-30 percent of post-pubertal males and is a risk factor for testicular cancer, - Mod. This vaccine is included in the combination measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) and measles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccines. \n\nChildren should receive the 1st dose of mumps-containing vaccine at 12-15 months and the 2nd dose at 4-6 years. \n\nMumps is a contagious, vaccine-preventable, acute viral illness that is spread through droplets of saliva or through mucus of an infected person. Mod.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3323826", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Australia (WA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3323826", "date": "2015-04-26 13:07:25", "main_text": "MUMPS - AUSTRALIA (WESTERN AUSTRALIA)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri24 Apr 2015\nSource: ABC Kimberley News [edited]\nhttp://www.abc.net.au/local/photos/2015/04/24/4223311.htm\n\n\nSix cases of mumps have been diagnosed in the Kimberley [in Western Australia].\n\n'Most of the cases have been in children from 8-13 years, but we have had an adult case in the Broome area,' according to the senior public health nurse. She said that mumps is not common in the highly vaccinated Kimberley population. 'We haven't had a case of mumps in the Kimberley since 2009, other than a few cases in the detention centres, so this is unusual.' The last outbreak started 8 years ago and infected 153 people. 'This was a prolonged mumps outbreak in a vaccinated Aboriginal population. So we're concerned that we may see something similar in 2015,' Ms Eastwood said.\n\nMumps is a virus spread via respiratory droplets and is regarded as highly infectious. 'The symptoms of mumps are fever, mild chest illness, headache, and the cardinal sign is swelling of the salivary glands, lumps behind and below the jaw, and pain near the ear when chewing.' While mumps typically resolves after 7-10 days, complications may include infections of the coverings of the brain, pancreatitis, permanent deafness, and painful testicular swelling.\n\nAlthough the Kimberley population is highly vaccinated, it is thought that immunity declines after 5 years, making infection possible. 'People who have been vaccinated who get mumps are not as unwell as people who haven't been vaccinated,' the public health nurse stated.\n\nRates of infection by mumps have decreased by 90 per cent since vaccination was [developed] in 1967. 'The rates before infection used to be 250 per 100 000 people. And that mainly occurred in children. And after the vaccination program, that's dropped to about 0.4 in a 100 000. But it just shows how infectious mumps is,' said the public health nurse. The vaccine is being used as a booster to try to prevent a wider outbreak in Kimberley. 'We're offering contacts of cases an additional vaccine [dose] to boost their immunity and try to control the spread of the disease.'\n\nHealth authorities are asking those infected to help stem the spread of the virus. 'If you have mumps, stay away from school, work and social gatherings. Tell people you've been in contact with [over] the week before that you have mumps, and tell them to go to the doctor if they get symptoms,' she said.\n\nThe public health nurse said that simple hygiene is the best way people can avoid infection from the mumps virus. 'Handwashing is a good way of stopping the spread of mumps, and don't share saliva by sharing eating utensils, cigarettes or kissing.'\n\n[byline: Ben Collins]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Kimberley is one of the 9 regions of Western Australia. It is in the northern part of Western Australia.\n\nMumps is a contagious disease that is caused by mumps virus. Mumps typically starts with a few days of fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, and is followed by swelling of salivary glands. Anyone who is not immune from either previous mumps infection or from vaccination can get mumps. Before the routine vaccination was introduced, mumps was a common illness in infants, children and young adults.\n\nMumps is no longer very common, but outbreaks continue to occur, most commonly where people have had prolonged, close contact with a person who has mumps, such as attending the same class, playing on the same contact sports team, or living in the same accommodation with someone who has mumps. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186.]", "summary": "\n\nMumps is no longer very common, but outbreaks continue to occur, most commonly where people have had prolonged, close contact with a person who has mumps, such as attending the same class, playing on the same contact sports team, or living in the same accommodation with someone who has mumps. \n\n[byline: Ben Collins]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Kimberley is one of the 9 regions of Western Australia. MUMPS - AUSTRALIA (WESTERN AUSTRALIA)\n*************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "3395573", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (QC): school children", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3395573", "date": "2015-05-29 18:41:31", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (QUEBEC): SCHOOL CHILDREN\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[The original post of this erroneously put Guelph in Quebec rather than Ontario where it belongs. - Mod.MPP]\n\nDate: Fri 29 May 2015\nSource Guelph Mercury [edited]\nhttp://www.guelphmercury.com/news-story/5649727-public-health-investigating-mumps-outbreak-in-two-guelph-high-schools/\n\n\nWellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health is investigating an outbreak of mumps at 2 Guelph high schools, the 1st cases of the disease in the area since 2010.\n\nChuck Ferguson, spokesperson for the health unit, said there are 2 reported cases of mumps at 2 different Catholic high schools, Bishop Macdonell and Our Lady of Lourdes. 'We haven't determined a link between the cases, and there are 4 suspected cases in total that we're investigating,' Ferguson said on Thursday [28 May 2015].\n\nPeople can protect themselves from getting mumps by getting the free vaccination, part of the measles, mumps rubella (MMR) childhood vaccine. Two doses are required.\n\nStudents at both schools who choose not to be vaccinated will be kept home from school for a minimum of 16 days or until the outbreak is over, Ferguson said. If a student who is missing a 2nd dose of the vaccine agrees to get it, they can return to school.\n\nFerguson said that keeping kids at home is not a measure that's taken lightly by the health unit. 'We work with parents; we work with schools; we work with doctors to make sure kids are protected, but if there's an outbreak and they're not vaccinated, there's nothing we can do but remove them from school for their own protection,' he said.\n\nTamara Nugent, director of education for the Wellington Catholic District School Board, said the number of kids that will be affected is shifting. 'By the end of this week, I think we'll have a good sense of how many students there are,' she said. 'We know that it's very few. It's just a matter of records and making sure that the public health unit has those on file; that's often the case.'\n\nNugent said the board is working with the public health unit to take all of the 'preventative and precautionary measures' they can, such as encouraging kids to wash their hands and not share water bottles or musical instruments with mouthpieces.\n\nMumps is very contagious and can be spread by coughing, sneezing, kissing or using an object an infected person has recently used. Ferguson said it's unclear where the mumps outbreak started, but there are sporadic cases in Ontario, and the 1st case may have been brought into the area through travel.\n\nThe symptoms of mumps include fever, swollen glands, and headache. It's caused by a virus, and antibiotics cannot treat it, so doctors often let it run its course. Mumps used to be a rare disease but is now making somewhat of a comeback.\n\nWhile people born before 1970 are supposed to have natural immunity to the mumps, those born in the 1980s and 1990s may have missed getting the 2nd dose of the vaccine, which was introduced in 1996.\n\n[Byline: May Warren]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Public health Agency of Canada (2014) states that: Outbreaks of mumps continue to occur in Canada, and the proportion of cases aged 20 years and older has increased. Complications such as orchitis and oophoritis are relatively frequent; permanent sequelae like deafness are rare. Mumps vaccine is available as measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) or measles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccine. Mumps vaccine effectiveness has been estimated at 62-91 percent for one dose and 76-95 percent for 2 doses. Reactions to MMR and MMRV vaccine are generally mild and transient and include pain and redness at the injection site, low-grade fever, and rash.\n\nMumps-containing vaccine is recommended for routine immunization of children and for immunization of children and adolescents who missed mumps immunization on the routine schedule. Mumps-containing vaccine is recommended for susceptible adults born in 1970 or later. Adults born before 1970 can be presumed to have acquired natural immunity to mumps; however, susceptible health care workers, travellers, and military personnel should receive MMR vaccine, regardless of the year of birth. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/268.]", "summary": "\n\nMumps-containing vaccine is recommended for routine immunization of children and for immunization of children and adolescents who missed mumps immunization on the routine schedule. Source Guelph Mercury [edited]\nhttp://www.guelphmercury.com/news-story/5649727-public-health-investigating-mumps-outbreak-in-two-guelph-high-schools/\n\n\nWellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health is investigating an outbreak of mumps at 2 Guelph high schools, the 1st cases of the disease in the area since 2010. \n\nNugent said the board is working with the public health unit to take all of the 'preventative and precautionary measures' they can, such as encouraging kids to wash their hands and not share water bottles or musical instruments with mouthpieces. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Public health Agency of Canada (2014) states that: Outbreaks of mumps continue to occur in Canada, and the proportion of cases aged 20 years and older has increased. Adults born before 1970 can be presumed to have acquired natural immunity to mumps; however, susceptible health care workers, travellers, and military personnel should receive MMR vaccine, regardless of the year of birth. \n\nStudents at both schools who choose not to be vaccinated will be kept home from school for a minimum of 16 days or until the outbreak is over, Ferguson said. We work with parents; we work with schools; we work with doctors to make sure kids are protected, but if there's an outbreak and they're not vaccinated, there's nothing we can do but remove them from school for their own protection,' he said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella", "varicella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-05-25 00:00:00", "1970-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-05-28 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3462267", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (02): (ON) school children", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3462267", "date": "2015-06-24 18:07:57", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (02): (ONTARIO) SCHOOL CHILDREN\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 21 Jun 2015\nSource: Guelph Mercury [edited]\nhttp://www.guelphmercury.com/news-story/5691559-guelph-area-mumps-outbreak-now-at-14-confirmed-cases/\n\n\nThere are now 14 confirmed cases of mumps in the area and the illness has impacted students at at least 3 local schools, according to the local health unit.\n\nWellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health reported Tue 23 Jun 2015 that the volume of local mumps cases has risen and students at the Bishop Macdonell, John F. Ross and Our Lady of Lourdes high schools in Guelph are tied to the outbreak.\n\n'Public Health continues to monitor suspect cases in other area high schools (as well),' according to a release issued by the agency. In connection with the announcement, the health unit also issued a call for area students to quickly notify their family doctors if symptoms develop. These include fever, salivary gland swelling and sensitivity, headaches and cold-like symptoms.\n\n'We want students to fully participate in summer jobs, volunteering or school, but we also want to stop the outbreak of this potentially serious disease. Students who are off to summer jobs or volunteer opportunities should call and advise their family physician if they begin to develop symptoms, particularly if they are spending the summer around young children or someone with an underlying medical condition,' said Dr. Nicola Mercer, Medical Officer of Health of Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health, in statement issued on Tuesday. 'If they are attending summer school, students need to be fully vaccinated or they may be excluded from attending class if there is another confirmed case linked to that school.'\n\nThe 14 confirmed cases are the 1st locally since 2010. With the cases being so far restricted to students and with the end of classes just days away, the health unit predicted in its release Tuesday that 'mumps won't be on a summer holiday.'\n\n'This particular disease is spread by (respiratory) droplets,' Mercer said in a telephone interview. Young people may share things like spoons, drinking straws and kisses. 'These are all activities where they're sharing saliva or sharing droplets.'\n\nWhere mumps is present, that presents a potential risk. Precautions aside from vaccination? 'If you're sick, then you should stay home, so you don't give the disease to other people,' Mercer said. 'If you cough into your elbow or sneeze into your elbow, wash your hands,'\nshe continued. Remind others to do so, as well.\n\nMumps is an acute viral illness, preventable through vaccination, the Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care advises. That's the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) vaccine.\n\n'Before routine vaccination for mumps was introduced, mumps was a common infection in infants, children and young adults,' the Ministry advises on its website. The illness is spread through person-to-person contact, notably coughing and sneezing that scatters infected droplets through the air. The vaccine's been available since the late 1960s. The College of Family Physicians of Ontario reported in a 2011 journal article by Dr. Scott Smith that mumps had over a decade reappeared in clusters in Canada, the U.S. and Britain.\n\n'Outbreaks in Canada have predominantly affected adolescents and young adults, in part because these individuals are too young to have acquired natural immunity from childhood exposure but too old to have received the benefit of the 2-dose MMR vaccine,' it stated.\n\nMumps made international headlines late in 2014 when 9 National Hockey League players became afflicted.\n\n[Byline: Vik Kisch]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The city of Guelph is a community of over 120 000 people situated in the heart of southern Ontario, just 100 km west of Toronto.\n\nMumps symptoms typically appear 16 to 18 days after infection, but this period can range from 12 to 25 days after infection. Mumps is best known for the swelling of the cheeks and jaw that it causes, which is a result of parotitis (inflammation of the salivary glands). Mumps also causes fever and headache. Mumps can be contagious from 7 days before and up to 5 days after the salivary glands begin to swell. Up to half of people who get mumps have very mild or no symptoms, and therefore do not know they were infected with mumps.\n\nPeople who show symptoms usually recover after a week or 2, but mumps can occasionally cause serious complications. The most common complication is orchitis (swelling of the testicles) in males who have reached puberty; rarely does this lead to fertility problems. Other rare complications include encephalitis (swelling of the brain) and/or meningitis (swelling of the tissue covering the brain and spinal cord) and oophoritis (swelling of the ovaries) in females who have reached puberty; and deafness. Mumps infection during the 1st trimester of pregnancy may increase the risk of a miscarriage.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is a 3-in-1 vaccine that protects against measles, mumps and rubella (German measles). It should be given to children soon after their 1st birthday. A 2nd dose is given in combination with varicella (chicken pox), as MMRV (a 4-in-1 vaccine) at 4-6 years of age. Vaccination against measles, mumps and rubella is required by law for all children attending school in Ontario (unless exempted) (http://www.health.gov.on.ca/en/public/publications/immune/mmr.aspx. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/260.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'Before routine vaccination for mumps was introduced, mumps was a common infection in infants, children and young adults,' the Ministry advises on its website. \n\nWellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health reported Tue 23 Jun 2015 that the volume of local mumps cases has risen and students at the Bishop Macdonell, John F. Ross and Our Lady of Lourdes high schools in Guelph are tied to the outbreak. \n\nMumps symptoms typically appear 16 to 18 days after infection, but this period can range from 12 to 25 days after infection. Students who are off to summer jobs or volunteer opportunities should call and advise their family physician if they begin to develop symptoms, particularly if they are spending the summer around young children or someone with an underlying medical condition,' said Dr. Nicola Mercer, Medical Officer of Health of Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health, in statement issued on Tuesday. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The city of Guelph is a community of over 120 000 people situated in the heart of southern Ontario, just 100 km west of Toronto. \n\n\nThere are now 14 confirmed cases of mumps in the area and the illness has impacted students at at least 3 local schools, according to the local health unit. \n\n'Outbreaks in Canada have predominantly affected adolescents and young adults, in part because these individuals are too young to have acquired natural immunity from childhood exposure but too old to have received the benefit of the 2-dose MMR vaccine,' it stated. MUMPS - CANADA (02): (ONTARIO) SCHOOL CHILDREN\n**********************************************\n \n\nMumps is an acute viral illness, preventable through vaccination, the Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care advises. Other rare complications include encephalitis (swelling of the brain) and/or meningitis (swelling of the tissue covering the brain and spinal cord) and oophoritis (swelling of the ovaries) in females who have reached puberty; and deafness. Up to half of people who get mumps have very mild or no symptoms, and therefore do not know they were infected with mumps.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella", "varicella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2015-06-23 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Britain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MMRV", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wellington - Dufferin - Guelph Public Health", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3546295", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Mumps - USA (04): (IL, MO) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3546295", "date": "2015-07-30 12:02:06", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04): (ILLINOIS, MISSOURI) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Illinois: university students\n[2] Missouri: university students\n\n******\n[1] Illinois: university students\nDate: Tue 28 Jul 2015\nSource: RRstar, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.rrstar.com/article/20150728/NEWS/150729501\n\n\nMumps outbreak centered at University of Illinois\n-------------------------------------------------\nThe Illinois Department of Public Health says the state has 73 known mumps cases right now and more than 2/3 are in Champaign County. State and local health officials say the number of cases in the Champaign area is at 50 and could climb.\n\nHealth officials tell the News-Gazette that most of the cases are linked to the University of Illinois campus. And thousands of students who are away are expected to be back on campus in the next few weeks for fall classes.\n\nDr Robert Palinkas is director of the McKinley Health Center. He said mumps outbreaks happen periodically on campus. But he said the current outbreak is the largest in more than a decade. Palinkas said the university is working to isolate students who have mumps.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Illinois can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/23973. Champaign County, east central Illinois, can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/illinois-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Missouri: university students\nDate: Tue 28 Jul 2015\nSource: St Louis Post-Dispatch [edited]\nhttp://www.stltoday.com/lifestyles/health-med-fit/health-officials-monitoring-undisclosed-number-of-people-after-mizzou-mumps/article_d159f5ba-2f97-5819-9f7f-46b1214c1a01.html\n\n\nHealth officials monitoring undisclosed number of people after Mizzou [University of Missouri] mumps outbreak\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nMizzou issues alert over suspected area mumps cases. Determination of mumps has yet to be confirmed through laboratory testing.\n\nThe Columbia/Boone County Department of Public Health and Human Services is monitoring an undisclosed number of people following the current mumps outbreak where 6 University of Missouri-Columbia have tested positive for the disease.\n\nIn addition to the 6 confirmed cases, health officials have identified another probable case and 4 other potential mumps cases.\n\nHealth officials launched an investigation 20 Jul 2015 after they were alerted to a potential cluster of people possibly sick with mumps. Spokeswoman Andrea Waner said the department is monitoring people who have come in close and direct contact with the 6 confirmed cases.\n\nWaner did not say how many people were being monitored. 'Right now, it's really about awareness and communication,' she said, adding that most mumps cases don't lead to serious complications.\n\nMeanwhile, Mizzou has sent out a number of alerts to parents, students, prospective students, and anyone who has been on campus since late June [2015]. All current and prospective students are urged to keep updated on their university-required immunizations.\n\nMumps is a viral illness that can cause fever, body aches, headaches, fatigue, swelling of the salivary glands or pain with chewing and swallowing. Among men, mumps can lead to swelling of the testicles. Among women, mumps can lead to swelling of the ovaries, which may cause abdominal pain or swelling of the breasts.\n\nThe illness typically spreads when an uninfected person inhales respiratory droplets when an infected person talks, coughs or sneezes.\n\nAbout 1/3 of the people who contract the mumps virus do not develop any symptoms.\n\n[Byline: Koran Addo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Missouri can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16851. Columbia County, in north central Missouri, can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/missouri-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nThe mumps virus is an RNA virus belonging to the genus _Rubulavirus_ in the family _Paramyxovirus_. According to the CDC, mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand per year. Before the United States mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States.\n\nOutbreaks can occur any time of the year but occur most commonly in winter and spring. Mumps virus is highly contagious, therefore a major factor contributing to outbreaks is being in a crowded environment, such as attending the same class, playing on the same sports team, or living in a dormitory with a person who has mumps -- thus the cases reported above in 2 university settings.\n\nMMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. 2 doses of the vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66 to 95 percent) effective at protecting against mumps; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49 percent to 92 percent) effective.\n\nThe most common symptoms include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite, swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears on one or both sides (parotitis). Symptoms typically appear 16-18 days after infection, but this period can range from 12-25 days after infection.\n\nSome people who get mumps have very mild or no symptoms, and often they do not know they have the disease. Most people with mumps recover completely in a few weeks. However, symptoms in adults are often more severe than in children. Complications may include infections of the coverings of the brain [meningitis] (15 percent), pancreatitis (4 percent), permanent deafness, and painful testicular swelling which uncommonly results in infertility. Women may develop ovarian swelling but this does not increase the risk of infertility. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Illinois can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/23973. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Missouri can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16851. Mumps virus is highly contagious, therefore a major factor contributing to outbreaks is being in a crowded environment, such as attending the same class, playing on the same sports team, or living in a dormitory with a person who has mumps -- thus the cases reported above in 2 university settings. \n\nMMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine prevents most, but not all, cases of mumps and complications caused by the disease. 2 doses of the vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66 to 95 percent) effective at protecting against mumps; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49 percent to 92 percent) effective. \n\nThe Columbia/Boone County Department of Public Health and Human Services is monitoring an undisclosed number of people following the current mumps outbreak where 6 University of Missouri-Columbia have tested positive for the disease. \n\n\nHealth officials monitoring undisclosed number of people after Mizzou [University of Missouri] mumps outbreak\n \n\nHealth officials launched an investigation 20 Jul 2015 after they were alerted to a potential cluster of people possibly sick with mumps. \n\nMumps is a viral illness that can cause fever, body aches, headaches, fatigue, swelling of the salivary glands or pain with chewing and swallowing. In addition to the 6 confirmed cases, health officials have identified another probable case and 4 other potential mumps cases. [2] Missouri: university students\n\n******\n \nMizzou issues alert over suspected area mumps cases. \n\nAbout 1/3 of the people who contract the mumps virus do not develop any symptoms. http://www.rrstar.com/article/20150728/NEWS/150729501\n\n\nMumps outbreak centered at University of Illinois\n \n\nMeanwhile, Mizzou has sent out a number of alerts to parents, students, prospective students, and anyone who has been on campus since late June [2015]. MJ\n\nThe mumps virus is an RNA virus belonging to the genus _Rubulavirus_ in the family _Paramyxovirus_. \n\nHealth officials tell the News-Gazette that most of the cases are linked to the University of Illinois campus. \n\n--\n [Byline: Koran Addo]\n\n--\n Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States. Right now, it's really about awareness and communication,' she said, adding that most mumps cases don't lead to serious complications.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "2050-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Champaign County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MISSOURI", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Columbia County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ILLINOIS", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3080644", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA: (PA) professional hockey team players", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3080644", "date": "2015-01-09 10:24:06", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA: (PENNSYLVANIA), PROFESSIONAL HOCKEY TEAM PLAYERS\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 7 Jan 2015\nSource: Pittsburgh Post Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.post-gazette.com/news/health/2015/01/07/Mumps-outbreak-stumps-Allegheny-County-health-officials/stories/201501070175\n\n\nAn outbreak of mumps in Allegheny County has been confined to the Pittsburgh Penguins organization, health officials said today [7 Jan 2015].\n\nCenter Sidney Crosby, defenseman Olli Maatta, right winger Beau Bennett, winger Steve Downie and goalie Thomas Greiss were diagnosed with the disease late last year [2014] that also afflicted players on 4 other National Hockey League teams.\n\nDonald Burke, an infectious disease-trained epidemiologist and member of the county health board, said the outbreak across the league was unusual. '[It] doesn't make a whole lot of epidemiological sense to have such a confined outbreak in what is an adult population of a disease that is normally a childhood disease that is vaccine-preventable,' he said.\n\nEight separate specimens from the county were sent to a state lab for testing but came back negative for mumps, said health department medical epidemiologist Kristen Mertz. Although causing discomfort, mumps only rarely leads to serious complications, according to health officials.\n\nClasses at Sharpsville Area School District in Mercer County were canceled Monday [5 Jan 2015] as a precaution against 2 suspected cases of the mumps.\n\n[Byline: Molly Born]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 16 Dec 2014\nSource: Pittsburgh Post Gazette [edited]\nhttp://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:MZAEJfdLHw8J:www.post-gazette.com/news/health/2014/12/16/Mumps-outbreak-hitting-Crosby-other-hockey-players-confuses-experts/stories/201412160092+&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us\n\n\nThe questions around the National Hockey League [NHL] mumps outbreak that finally found its way to the Penguins this past weekend start with the obvious: Didn't we eradicate the mumps? The short answer: Well, we almost did.\n\nOnce a common disease with painful and sometimes catastrophic results (sterility in men and miscarriages in pregnant women), mumps is a virus spread through saliva contact from person to person, from something as innocuous as touching the same counter surface as someone with the disease or as obvious as being near someone who sneezes.\n\nBut after the creation of the vaccine for mumps in 1967, the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommendation in 1977 that it be a regular vaccine for toddlers, and the recommendation in 1990 that a 2nd dose of the vaccine be given to children about 4 years after the 1st, the number of cases dropped by about 98 percent.\n\nBut pockets of resistance to the eradication of the disease have persisted from several different quarters.\n\nThere are those who have resisted vaccinating their children, despite the proven success of the mumps vaccine, because of a variety of fears; there are about 10 percent of people who have been vaccinated whose bodies simply don't respond, so-called 'nonresponders' who are still susceptible; and there is some belief that the effectiveness of vaccination may wane over time, requiring that adults get an additional booster shot (the Allegheny County Health Department recommends all adults get a mumps booster).\n\nThere also appear to be people apparently along the lines of Penguins star Sidney Crosby who were vaccinated recently and appeared to respond well to the vaccination, but still contracted the disease.\n\n'As physicians, we were caught on our heels by this,' said Matt McCarthy, an infectious disease physician for Weill Cornell Medical Center in New York City. 'Why is Sidney Crosby -- a young, healthy guy with a good response to the vaccine -- getting this disease? There's something that's not adding up.'\n\nPrior to becoming infected sometime in the past 3 weeks, presumably from an opponent on one of the other 4 teams with the infection, Mr. Crosby had a booster shot in February 2014 before he left for the Olympic Games in Russia.\n\nProbably as a result, his antibody count -- which would show whether his body could fight the disease off -- was high enough when the Penguins tested him and the rest of the team on 3 Dec 2014 that they didn't think he was even susceptible. Others on the team -- including Beau Bennett, who may also have the mumps -- and staff did have low antibody counts, though, and 19 of them were given booster shots of the vaccine on 6 Dec 2014.\n\nSo what is happening that is leading to this outbreak?\n\nResearch following a 2006 outbreak of mumps in the Midwest, primarily on college campuses, found that antibodies were higher in those with a more recent vaccine dose and that there were no set amounts of antibodies in people that appeared to be the safe level that definitively prevented the person from contracting the disease.\n\n'That's the problem,' said Jennifer Preiss, a family physician in Pittsburgh who works with Allegheny Health Network. 'No one knows at what level they're immune.'\n\nDr. Preiss said that in her 24 years of practice, she has had 3 patients with the disease, which is why it concerns her that young, healthy men are catching it now.\n\nSome researchers have questioned whether the 2006 outbreak, and others over the last 3 decades, could be the result of the United States' decision in 1992 to switch the vaccine of choice from one strain to another, in an effort to be more effective.\n\n'It's possible the switch in vaccines is part of these outbreaks,' Dr. McCarthy said. 'I had not considered it until today.'\n\nBut it is the small percentage of the population that is not immunizing their children that concerns Michael Green, who works with infectious diseases at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh of UPMC.\n\nPrior to 1967, 'parents didn't have to look far to see someone suffering from these diseases we've largely eliminated with vaccines' like mumps and polio, he said. 'But now, you don't see a lot of people with mumps or polio, so people think, 'I don't have to vaccinate my child.' We need to push with parents that [think] vaccines are not [needed].'\n\nFortunately, Allegheny County children have high, 2-dose mumps vaccination rates, at 91 percent, largely because schools require it before admitting students, said Kristen Mertz, a medical epidemiologist at the Allegheny County Health Department.\n\nThere was only one confirmed mumps case in Allegheny County prior to the Penguins' cases, just 2 all of last year [2014], and none in 2010, 2011 or 2012, she said.\n\nDr. Green said Children's is monitoring the situation to see whether the staff has to isolate patients who met Mr. Bennett during a visit there Thursday [11 Dec 2014]. He visited with most of the rest of the team, though not Mr. Crosby, to deliver Christmas presents. The Penguins did not know then that Mr. Crosby had the disease or that Mr. Bennett might have it (test results are due back today [16 Dec 2014]).\n\n'Of course we're concerned' that any of the kids at Children's may have been infected, Penguins spokesman Tom McMillan said Monday [15 Dec 2014]. 'Kids are such a focus of what we do.'\n\nThe team canceled another event set for this Friday [19 Dec 2014] in which 17 needy families and kids were going to come to the rink to receive Christmas gifts and meet the team. The gifts will be delivered to their homes, instead, and 'we'll try to visit with them later in the season,' he said.\n\n[Byline: Sean D. Hamill]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of mumps, see my comments in ProMED-mail post Mumps - USA: (OH) university students 20140308.2321285.\n\nMumps outbreaks even among vaccinated populations have been reported frequently during recent years, especially among college students where the intensity of exposure among students was presumed to have overcome the vaccine-induced immunity (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1681_article.htm).\n\nThe Pittsburgh Penguins are a professional ice hockey team based in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins). They are members of the National Hockey League (NHL). Pittsburgh is the seat of Allegheny County and, with a population of 305 841 is the 2nd-largest city in the U.S. state of Pennsylvania in the mid-Atlantic region of the U.S. (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/240.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\nThere are those who have resisted vaccinating their children, despite the proven success of the mumps vaccine, because of a variety of fears; there are about 10 percent of people who have been vaccinated whose bodies simply don't respond, so-called 'nonresponders' who are still susceptible; and there is some belief that the effectiveness of vaccination may wane over time, requiring that adults get an additional booster shot (the Allegheny County Health Department recommends all adults get a mumps booster). \n\nFortunately, Allegheny County children have high, 2-dose mumps vaccination rates, at 91 percent, largely because schools require it before admitting students, said Kristen Mertz, a medical epidemiologist at the Allegheny County Health Department. USA (06): (OH) update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2524005", "date": "2014-06-06 15:33:43", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (06): (OHIO) UPDATE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 2 Jun 2014\nSource: The Global Dispatch [edited]\nhttp://www.theglobaldispatch.com/ohio-mumps-outbreak-tops-400-measles-outbreak-goes-over-200-200/\n\n\nThe number of mumps cases reported in Central Ohio has reached 404 cases as of today, according to a Columbus Public Health (CPH) press release Monday [2 Jun 2014]. 220 of the cases are linked to the Ohio State University outbreak that began in early March [2014]. How bad is the mumps outbreak in Ohio? CPH officials say that last year [2013], there were 438 cases recorded nationwide.\n\nAlthough mumps is typically a mild infection, there are complications that are possible with the viral infection. CPH reports that 13 people required hospitalization from their illness; a dozen males suffered with orchitis while 4 women have faced oophoritis. One patient has suffered either partial or complete hearing loss.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When the status of this mumps outbreak was last posted by ProMED-mail, there was a total of 361 cases (Mumps - USA (03): (OH) update 20140409.2391429), with 208 cases in Franklin County where the Ohio State University [OSU] campus is located. Now there are 404 cases, with 220 of the cases linked to Ohio State University (OSU).\n\nThe American College Health Association has recommended that colleges and universities require that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before college enrollment (http://www.acha.org/topics/docs/CDC_ACHA_Mumps_Recommendations_Jul13.pdf). However, OSU does not mandate immunization against mumps before matriculation.\n\nNevertheless, mumps outbreaks among vaccinated populations have been reported frequently during recent years, especially among college students, where the intensity of exposure among students presumably overcomes vaccine-induced immunity (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1681_article.htm). Perhaps waning post-vaccination immunity and antigenic differences between outbreak strains and the vaccine virus are additional explanations for mumps outbreaks in highly vaccinated populations (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/47/11/1458.full). - Mod.ML\n\nThe state of Ohio can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/645. Franklin County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/ohio-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When the status of this mumps outbreak was last posted by ProMED-mail, there was a total of 361 cases (Mumps - USA (03): (OH) update 20140409.2391429), with 208 cases in Franklin County where the Ohio State University [OSU] campus is located. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe American College Health Association has recommended that colleges and universities require that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before college enrollment (http://www.acha.org/topics/docs/CDC_ACHA_Mumps_Recommendations_Jul13.pdf). The number of mumps cases reported in Central Ohio has reached 404 cases as of today, according to a Columbus Public Health (CPH) press release Monday [2 Jun 2014]. Nevertheless, mumps outbreaks among vaccinated populations have been reported frequently during recent years, especially among college students, where the intensity of exposure among students presumably overcomes vaccine-induced immunity (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1681_article.htm). Perhaps waning post-vaccination immunity and antigenic differences between outbreak strains and the vaccine virus are additional explanations for mumps outbreaks in highly vaccinated populations (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/47/11/1458.full). MUMPS - USA (06): (OHIO) UPDATE\n*******************************\n Now there are 404 cases, with 220 of the cases linked to Ohio State University (OSU). 220 of the cases are linked to the Ohio State University outbreak that began in early March [2014].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2014-06-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Franklin County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2982582", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (08): (ID) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2982582", "date": "2014-11-22 15:52:45", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (08): (IDAHO) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 21 Nov 2014\nSource: Idaho Department of Health and Welfare [edited]\nhttp://www.healthandwelfare.idaho.gov/Default.aspx?tabid=130&ctl=ArticleView&mid=3061&articleId=1801\n\n\nAn outbreak of mumps involving University of Idaho Moscow [Latah County, Idaho] students is leading public health officials to urge students to use the upcoming holiday break to check their vaccination records to make certain they are current for the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccination before they return for classes. As of Wednesday [19 Nov 2014], 10 laboratory-confirmed cases of mumps have been reported, with over 20 additional reports being investigated, including 2 in the Moscow community.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is the best way to prevent mumps. Students who have not previously had mumps or who have no record of any doses of MMR vaccine should receive 2 doses at least 28 days apart; students who received only 1 dose of MMR vaccine should receive a 2nd dose. Students can check with the University of Idaho Student Health Services, their primary care provider, local public health office or a local pharmacy about receiving an MMR vaccine.\n\nMumps is a contagious virus that spreads from person-to-person via droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks. An infected person can spread the virus before being sick. The virus is also spread when someone with mumps touches items or surfaces without washing their hands, and then someone else touches the same item or surface and rubs their mouth or nose. Symptoms, which can appear up to 25 days after being exposed, may include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, loss of appetite, and swollen or tender salivary glands under the ears on one or both sides of the head. The most common complication of mumps infection in adults is testicular inflammation. Rare complications include meningitis, encephalitis, inflammation of the ovaries, and deafness. Anyone experiencing symptoms compatible with mumps should contact their health care professional. Up to half of people with mumps have very mild or no symptoms and might not know they are infected.\n\nAnyone infected with the mumps virus should stay home for 5 days after symptoms begin, while minimizing close contact with other people. Infected people should avoid sharing drinks or eating utensils, cover all coughs and sneezes, wash their hands frequently with soap and water, and regularly clean frequently touched surfaces.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of mumps, see my comments in ProMED-mail post Mumps - USA: (OH) university students 20140308.2321285.\n\nNevertheless, mumps outbreaks even among vaccinated populations have been reported frequently during recent years, especially among college students where the intensity of exposure among students was presumed to have overcome the vaccine-induced immunity (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1681_article.htm).\n\nThe American College Health Association has recommended that colleges and universities require that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of MMR vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before enrollment (http://www.acha.org/topics/docs/CDC_ACHA_Mumps_Recommendations_Jul13.pdf). Immune globulin is not effective postexposure prophylaxis (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/downloads/mumps.pdf). In an outbreak setting, MMR vaccine might reduce transmission to susceptible persons not yet exposed to the mumps virus. The CDC has evaluated use of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine for mumps outbreak control during 2 previous mumps outbreaks in which transmission was sustained, despite high 2-dose coverage (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6148a2.htm). During both outbreaks, targeted vaccination was followed by a decrease in mumps incidence among the target group.\n\nMoscow is a college town, with 23 800 residents in 2010 census, in the U.S. state of Idaho near the state's western border with Washington State. The University of Idaho campus is adjacent to the southwest side of town, with about 11 000 students housed in 4 residence halls, as well as 27 fraternity and sorority houses (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Idaho). For a map showing the location of Moscow in the state of Idaho, see https://www.google.com/maps/place/University+of+Idaho/. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16004.]", "summary": "An outbreak of mumps involving University of Idaho Moscow [Latah County, Idaho] students is leading public health officials to urge students to use the upcoming holiday break to check their vaccination records to make certain they are current for the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccination before they return for classes. Students who have not previously had mumps or who have no record of any doses of MMR vaccine should receive 2 doses at least 28 days apart; students who received only 1 dose of MMR vaccine should receive a 2nd dose. The CDC has evaluated use of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine for mumps outbreak control during 2 previous mumps outbreaks in which transmission was sustained, despite high 2-dose coverage (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6148a2.htm). \n\nMumps is a contagious virus that spreads from person-to-person via droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks. \n\nThe American College Health Association has recommended that colleges and universities require that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of MMR vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before enrollment (http://www.acha.org/topics/docs/CDC_ACHA_Mumps_Recommendations_Jul13.pdf). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of mumps, see my comments in ProMED-mail post Mumps - USA: (OH) university students 20140308.2321285. MUMPS - USA (08): (IDAHO) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS\n*********************************************\n Anyone infected with the mumps virus should stay home for 5 days after symptoms begin, while minimizing close contact with other people.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Latah County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2588034", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (07): (OH) update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2588034", "date": "2014-07-04 14:36:28", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (07): (OHIO) UPDATE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 3 Jul 2014\nSource: Cleveland.com, The Plain Dealer [edited]\nhttp://www.cleveland.com/healthfit/index.ssf/2014/07/ohio_mumps_cases_at_35-year_hi.html\n\n\nA mumps outbreak that began on the Ohio State University [OSU] campus in January [2014] has now infected 447 people, the largest outbreak the state has seen since 1979, when there were 930 cases of the disease, according to Columbus Public Health (CPH). A total of 155 students, 31 OSU staff members and 54 community members with an OSU link have fallen ill. The campus outbreak has also spread to Indiana and North Carolina, where one OSU student from each state became sick shortly after returning home for the summer, CPH spokesman Jose Rodriguez said.\n\nThe most recent Ohio mumps case was reported on [23 Jun 2014], according to the Ohio Department of Health, and the people affected have ranged in age from 6 months to 80 years old. CPH is reporting that among those who have fallen ill there have been cases of hearing loss, and inflammation of the testes and ovaries, which are rare complications of the disease. There have also been 14 hospitalizations.\n\nMumps is a highly contagious respiratory disease caused by a virus. Fortunately, most people with mumps recover completely after a few weeks. The most common symptoms are similar to those of the flu: high fever, aches and fatigue. The virus can also cause a tell-tale swelling of the parotid glands in the jaw, called parotitis, which can be painful and make swallowing and eating difficult.\n\n[Byline: Brie Zeltner]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When ProMED-mail last posted almost a month ago, there was a total of 361 cases of months in Ohio (Mumps - USA (06): (OH) update 20140606.2524005). Most cases were in Franklin County (208 cases, 58 percent) and linked to the Ohio State University (OSU) campus in the city of Columbus, Ohio. The city of Columbus and OSU are located in Franklin County. The outbreak subsequently spread into the surrounding counties (Delaware, Fairfield, Licking, and Union) in central Ohio. Now there are 447 cases, and most cases continue to be linked to OSU (240 cases, 54 percent), with spread to the US states of Indiana and North Carolina, as students return home for summer break.\n\nThe American College Health Association has recommended that colleges and universities require that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before college enrollment (http://www.acha.org/topics/docs/CDC_ACHA_Mumps_Recommendations_Jul13.pdf). However, OSU does not mandate immunization against mumps before matriculation.\n\nNevertheless, mumps outbreaks among vaccinated populations have been reported frequently during recent years, especially among college students, where the intensity of exposure among students presumably overcomes vaccine-induced immunity (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1681_article.htm). Perhaps waning post-vaccination immunity and antigenic differences between outbreak strains and the vaccine virus are additional explanations for mumps outbreaks in highly vaccinated populations (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/47/11/1458.full). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/237.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When ProMED-mail last posted almost a month ago, there was a total of 361 cases of months in Ohio (Mumps - USA (06): (OH) update 20140606.2524005). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe American College Health Association has recommended that colleges and universities require that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before college enrollment (http://www.acha.org/topics/docs/CDC_ACHA_Mumps_Recommendations_Jul13.pdf). http://www.cleveland.com/healthfit/index.ssf/2014/07/ohio_mumps_cases_at_35-year_hi.html\n\n\nA mumps outbreak that began on the Ohio State University [OSU] campus in January [2014] has now infected 447 people, the largest outbreak the state has seen since 1979, when there were 930 cases of the disease, according to Columbus Public Health (CPH).
