Last night [20 May 2014] there were 18 confirmed cases reported over the last 5 days at the Radcliffe Square college [Brasenose College]. Health authorities are now working to contain the outbreak.\n\nThe college's bursar Philip Parker said: 'There have been 18 cases. All of those students have either gone home or we're segregating them from other students with a quarantine area. 'Of course we're concerned, but we've acted well and taken steps to contain it.' University spokesman Matt Pickles said: 'The college is working with the college nurse and doctors and taking advice from Health Protection Agency to ensure that the best advice and information is provided to students, including the signs and symptoms to look out for. The college is advising any students who suspect they might have mumps-like symptoms to stay in their room and phone the college nurse or GP for advice.' He added that all new students coming to the university are strongly recommended to seek vaccination with 2 doses of the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine before they arrive in Oxford.\n\nMumps is a contagious virus, which causes painful swellings under the ears, headaches, joint pain, and a high temperature. It usually takes between 16 and 18 days for the symptoms to develop and people are infectious between 2 days before and 4 days after the start of symptoms. It spreads from person to person in the same way as a cold -- through coughs, sneezes, and saliva.\n\nIt is important to protect teenagers and young adults who have not been vaccinated against the infection, which can develop into meningitis or other serious complications.\n\nThere was a similar outbreak in March 2010, when 41 students from Oxford University and 4 from Oxford Brookes University contracted the virus.\n\nStudents are being urged to have a 2nd dose of the MMR vaccine to ensure they are protected.\n\n[byline: Alex Wynick]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The American College Health Association has recommended that colleges and universities require that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before college enrolment (http://www.acha.org/topics/docs/CDC_ACHA_Mumps_Recommendations_Jul13.pdf).\n\nNevertheless, mumps outbreaks among vaccinated populations have been reported frequently during recent years, especially among college students, where the intensity of exposure among students presumably overcomes vaccine-induced immunity (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1681_article.htm). Perhaps waning post-vaccination immunity and antigenic differences between outbreak strains and the vaccine viruses are additional explanations for mumps outbreaks in highly vaccinated populations (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/47/11/1458.full). However, the news report above fails to give us the mumps vaccination status of the affected students. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39210.]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The American College Health Association has recommended that colleges and universities require that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before college enrolment (http://www.acha.org/topics/docs/CDC_ACHA_Mumps_Recommendations_Jul13.pdf). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Nevertheless, mumps outbreaks among vaccinated populations have been reported frequently during recent years, especially among college students, where the intensity of exposure among students presumably overcomes vaccine-induced immunity (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1681_article.htm). \n\n[byline: Alex Wynick]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< University spokesman Matt Pickles said: 'The college is working with the college nurse and doctors and taking advice from Health Protection Agency to ensure that the best advice and information is provided to students, including the signs and symptoms to look out for. MUMPS - UK: (ENGLAND) STUDENTS\n******************************\n Perhaps waning post-vaccination immunity and antigenic differences between outbreak strains and the vaccine viruses are additional explanations for mumps outbreaks in highly vaccinated populations (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/47/11/1458.full).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2014-05-20 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2413572", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (04): (WI) update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2413572", "date": "2014-04-18 12:39:42", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04): (WISCONSIN) UPDATE\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Apr 2014\nFrom: Janet Welter <welter@rarc.wisc.edu> [edited]\n\n\nThe number of confirmed mumps cases at UW-Madison [University of Wisconsin, Madison] continues to increase. 5 student cases have been identified at this time and UHS [University Health Services] continues to work with public health officials to monitor the situation.\n\nMumps is a contagious viral illness that spreads by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks.\n\nWhile most people who have been given the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine are usually protected for life against mumps infections, the illness can still occur in previously immunized persons.\n\nFaculty and staff should take the following steps to stay healthy and prevent spreading mumps:\n1. Watch for symptoms, even if you have been vaccinated, and stay home if you are sick. If you experience mumps symptoms (fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue, and swelling of the cheek and jaw area) contact your private healthcare provider.\n\nIt's a campus expectation that anyone suspected of having mumps stays home from school, work, or similar activities for 5 days. We encourage faculty and staff to allow students with mumps symptoms to stay home from class and work, and to provide alternate arrangements.\n\nThere is no treatment for mumps, but you can soothe your symptoms by getting plenty of bed rest, taking over-the-counter pain killers such as ibuprofen or Tylenol to relieve any pain, and drinking plenty of fluids.\n\n2. Take a page from the flu playbook with preventive actions. Wash your hands regularly with soap and water; sneeze and cough into a tissue or your elbow; and avoid sharing drinks, food, and utensils.\n\n3. Check your immunization records to make sure you've had 2 doses of the MMR vaccine. See your private healthcare provider or local pharmacy if you need a 2nd dose.\n\nFor more information:\nMumps FAQs http://www.uhs.wisc.edu/health-topics/mumps/faq.pdf\nMumps (CDC) http://www.cdc.gov/mumps/\n\n--\nJanet Welter, DVM, MPH, PHD, DACLAM\nChief Campus Veterinarian\nUniversity of Wisconsin-Madison\n<welter@rarc.wisc.edu>\nhttp://www.rarc.wisc.edu\n\n[ProMED-mail appreciates this report from Dr Welter. Mumps outbreaks can be difficult to control on university campuses and unfortunately, immunity is sometimes incomplete, even after appropriate immunization. Another larger outbreak was recently reported in the Ohio State University campus. Most universities in the US require proof of immunity to mumps at the time of enrollment.\n\nMore complete comments by Moderator ML are found in ProMED-mail archive no 20140409.2391429. - Mod.LM\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6812.]", "summary": "For more information:\nMumps FAQs http://www.uhs.wisc.edu/health-topics/mumps/faq.pdf\nMumps (CDC) http://www.cdc.gov/mumps/\n\n--\nJanet Welter, DVM, MPH, PHD, DACLAM\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n University of Wisconsin-Madison\n<welter@rarc.wisc.edu>\nhttp://www.rarc.wisc.edu\n\n[ProMED-mail appreciates this report from Dr Welter. \n\nFaculty and staff should take the following steps to stay healthy and prevent spreading mumps:\n1. \n\nWhile most people who have been given the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine are usually protected for life against mumps infections, the illness can still occur in previously immunized persons. \n\nThere is no treatment for mumps, but you can soothe your symptoms by getting plenty of bed rest, taking over-the-counter pain killers such as ibuprofen or Tylenol to relieve any pain, and drinking plenty of fluids. \n\nMumps is a contagious viral illness that spreads by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks. MUMPS - USA (04): (WISCONSIN) UPDATE\n************************************\n \n\nIt's a campus expectation that anyone suspected of having mumps stays home from school, work, or similar activities for 5 days.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tylenol", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2321285", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA: (OH) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2321285", "date": "2014-03-08 10:29:23", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA: (OHIO) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 7 Mar 2014\nSource: WBNS-10TV [edited]\nhttp://www.10tv.com/content/stories/2014/03/06/ohio-state-university-mumps-outbreak-on-campus.html\n\n\nThe Ohio State University said Thursday night [6 Mar 2014] 9 students on campus have mumps and they suspect 2 more cases. The Columbus [Ohio] health department will investigate the suspected cases on Friday [7 Mar 2014]. Officials are investigating to determine how the disease has been spread at the school.\n\nA total of 4 male students have reported cases, and 5 female students have come down with the mumps. 10TV has confirmed one case is a member of the Sigma Chi Fraternity. The fraternity declined to comment. The ages of those infected range from 19 to 22.\n\n10TV learned about the outbreak around 2:00 p.m. The university sent out a warning letter to students and staff around 9:30 p.m.\n\nMumps is a viral infection that affects the salivary glands. The illness usually lasts around 7-10 days. It is highly contagious and can rapidly spread among members living in close quarters. For all Ohio State students, the Wilce Student Health Center is available. Visit the website at http://shs.osu.edu/ for hours of operation and a list of additional facilities that provide medical care off campus and after hours.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 7 Mar 2014\nSource: WOSU, NPR News report [edited]\nhttp://wosu.org/2012/news/2014/03/07/osu-mumps-outbreak-increases-to-13-cases/\n\n\nLocal health officials say the Ohio State University mumps outbreak continues to afflict more students. Columbus Public Health officials say the number of confirmed cases of mumps now totals 13. A total of 7 women and 6 men between the ages of 18 and 22 have tested positive for the highly contagious disease.\n\nCPH medical director Doctor Mysheika Williams Roberts said the majority of the students who have mumps report receiving their childhood vaccinations.\n\n'The mumps component of the MMR vaccine has traditionally been known to be 80-90 percent effective, so it's not unusual,' Roberts said, for some people to contract the disease. 'And when they've had other large outbreaks of this size or larger at college campuses, we have seen a considerable number of cases who were vaccinated.' Roberts expects the number of cases to increase. She said at this time all students are recovering at home.\n\nMumps causes swelling of salivary glands and flu-like symptoms. It can lead to infertility in men, and women can have ovarian swelling. The disease also can lead to viral meningitis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a contagious infection that is caused by the mumps virus (family Paramyxoviridae). Mumps is spread in respiratory droplets, and the incubation period is 14-25 days (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/downloads/mumps.pdf). As many as 20 percent of mumps infections are asymptomatic. An additional 40 to 50 percent may have only nonspecific symptoms. The illness is characterized by low-grade fever, headache, and myalgias, followed by swelling and tenderness of salivary glands, usually the parotid gland. Complications include orchitis, oophoritis, meningitis, and pancreatitis. Mumps has also been associated with sudden onset of unilateral sensorineural deafness in children that may rarely be permanent and may be associated with vestibular symptoms (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3767776).\n\nThe mumps vaccine was licensed in 1967 and is usually administered as part of a combination vaccine that provides protection against measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr4708.pdf). Live mumps virus vaccines in the United States are derived from the Jeryl Lynn mumps vaccine strain. Post-licensure studies in the United States demonstrated that 1 dose of mumps vaccine was 78-91 percent effective in preventing clinical mumps with parotitis; a study from the United Kingdom indicated a vaccine effectiveness of 88 percent for 2 doses of MMR vaccine compared with 64 percent for a single dose (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5522a4.htm). The MMR vaccine in the United States is given in 2 doses: The 1st dose is given at 12-15 months of age and the 2nd dose before entering school, at 4-6 years of age (http://www.vaccines.gov/diseases/mumps/index.html).\n\nNevertheless, mumps outbreaks among vaccinated populations have been reported frequently during recent years, especially among college students where the intensity of exposure among students was presumed to have overcome the vaccine-induced immunity (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1681_article.htm).\n\nThe American College Health Association has recommended that colleges and universities require that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of MMR vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before enrollment (http://www.acha.org/publications/docs/acha_ripi_mar2011.pdf). Immune globulin is not effective postexposure prophylaxis (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/downloads/mumps.pdf). In an outbreak setting, MMR vaccine might reduce transmission to susceptible persons not yet exposed to the mumps virus. The CDC has evaluated use of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine for mumps outbreak control during 2 previous mumps outbreaks in which transmission was sustained, despite high 2-dose coverage (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6148a2.htm). During both outbreaks, targeted vaccination was followed by a decrease in mumps incidence among the target group.\n\nThe Ohio State University (OSU) is a large public research university in Columbus, Ohio, with about 28 000 undergraduates and more than 35 on-campus residence halls, with additional separate housing for graduate and professional students, plus multiple extra-curricular organizations where social mixing can occur (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_State_University). Columbus is the capital of and the largest city in the US state of Ohio. This city can be found on a map of the state of Ohio at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:OHMap-doton-Columbus.svg. -Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/2uyX.]", "summary": "Post-licensure studies in the United States demonstrated that 1 dose of mumps vaccine was 78-91 percent effective in preventing clinical mumps with parotitis; a study from the United Kingdom indicated a vaccine effectiveness of 88 percent for 2 doses of MMR vaccine compared with 64 percent for a single dose (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5522a4.htm). Visit the website at http://shs.osu.edu/ for hours of operation and a list of additional facilities that provide medical care off campus and after hours.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n The CDC has evaluated use of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine for mumps outbreak control during 2 previous mumps outbreaks in which transmission was sustained, despite high 2-dose coverage (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6148a2.htm). \n\nThe mumps vaccine was licensed in 1967 and is usually administered as part of a combination vaccine that provides protection against measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr4708.pdf). \n\nThe American College Health Association has recommended that colleges and universities require that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of MMR vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before enrollment (http://www.acha.org/publications/docs/acha_ripi_mar2011.pdf). Nevertheless, mumps outbreaks among vaccinated populations have been reported frequently during recent years, especially among college students where the intensity of exposure among students was presumed to have overcome the vaccine-induced immunity (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1681_article.htm). \n\n'The mumps component of the MMR vaccine has traditionally been known to be 80-90 percent effective, so it's not unusual,' Roberts said, for some people to contract the disease. ' The university sent out a warning letter to students and staff around 9:30 p.m.\n\nMumps is a viral infection that affects the salivary glands. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a contagious infection that is caused by the mumps virus (family Paramyxoviridae). The Ohio State University said Thursday night [6 Mar 2014] 9 students on campus have mumps and they suspect 2 more cases. \n\nThe Ohio State University (OSU) is a large public research university in Columbus, Ohio, with about 28 000 undergraduates and more than 35 on-campus residence halls, with additional separate housing for graduate and professional students, plus multiple extra-curricular organizations where social mixing can occur (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_State_University). \n\nCPH medical director Doctor Mysheika Williams Roberts said the majority of the students who have mumps report receiving their childhood vaccinations. A total of 4 male students have reported cases, and 5 female students have come down with the mumps. Live mumps virus vaccines in the United States are derived from the Jeryl Lynn mumps vaccine strain. The MMR vaccine in the United States is given in 2 doses: The 1st dose is given at 12-15 months of age and the 2nd dose before entering school, at 4-6 years of age (http://www.vaccines.gov/diseases/mumps/index.html).
