The outbreak is in Franklin, Delaware, and Madison Counties, according to the Columbus Public Health Department.\n\nThe majority of those cases, 208, are linked to the Ohio State University. The ages of patients range from 4 months to 80 years old.\n\nThe health department is urging everyone to make sure they've had both doses of the MMR [measles mumps rubella] vaccine. Symptoms of the mumps include fever, headaches, tiredness, and swelling of the salivary glands.\n\n[Byline: Dawn Faugl]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When ProMED-mail last posted the status of this mumps outbreak there were a total of 153 cases (Mumps - USA (03): (OH) update 20140409.2391429). Most cases were in Franklin County (135 cases) and linked to the Ohio State University [OSU] campus in the city of Columbus, Ohio. The city of Columbus and OSU are located in Franklin County. The outbreak subsequently spread into the surrounding counties (Delaware, Fairfield, Licking, and Union) in central Ohio. Now there are 361 cases, and most cases continue to be in Franklin County (208 cases).\n\nThe American College Health Association has recommended that colleges and universities require that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of MMR vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before college enrollment (http://www.acha.org/topics/docs/CDC_ACHA_Mumps_Recommendations_Jul13.pdf). However, OSU does not mandate immunization against mumps before matriculation.\n\nNevertheless, mumps outbreaks among vaccinated populations have been reported frequently during recent years, especially among college students where the intensity of exposure among students presumably overcomes vaccine-induced immunity (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1681_article.htm). Perhaps waning post-vaccination immunity and antigenic differences between outbreak strains and the vaccine viruses are additional explanations for mumps outbreaks in highly vaccinated populations (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/47/11/1458.full). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/237.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When ProMED-mail last posted the status of this mumps outbreak there were a total of 153 cases (Mumps - USA (03): (OH) update 20140409.2391429). \n\nThe American College Health Association has recommended that colleges and universities require that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of MMR vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before college enrollment (http://www.acha.org/topics/docs/CDC_ACHA_Mumps_Recommendations_Jul13.pdf). Nevertheless, mumps outbreaks among vaccinated populations have been reported frequently during recent years, especially among college students where the intensity of exposure among students presumably overcomes vaccine-induced immunity (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1681_article.htm). Perhaps waning post-vaccination immunity and antigenic differences between outbreak strains and the vaccine viruses are additional explanations for mumps outbreaks in highly vaccinated populations (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/47/11/1458.full). MUMPS - USA (05): (OHIO) UPDATE\n*******************************\n \n\nThe health department is urging everyone to make sure they've had both doses of the MMR [measles mumps rubella] vaccine. Now there are 361 cases, and most cases continue to be in Franklin County (208 cases).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2014-05-16 00:00:00", "2014-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Fairfield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Columbus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Licking", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Franklin County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Franklin", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1931146", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (06): (NJ) bar & grill associated", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1931146", "date": "2013-09-08 21:07:31", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (06): (NEW JERSEY), BAR AND GRILL ASSOCIATED\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 8 Sep 2013\nSource: Tribtown.com, Associated Press [edited]\nhttp://www.tribtown.com/view/story/8b2972e7fe2c46deadd4f66695cd928a/NJ--Mumps\n\n\nHealth officials in Monmouth County have confirmed one case of mumps and are looking into more than 2 dozen others. County public health coordinator Michael Meddis said Friday [6 Sep 2013] that lab results were positive for one case and that 26 other reported cases were still under investigation. Meddis says the reported cases are all adults with the exception of one pre-school aged child.\n\nHealth officials say most individuals have either been patrons or employees of D'Jais Bar and Grill in Belmar. D'Jais will be closed for the weekend and has carried out cleaning and sanitizing recommendations from the Health Department.\n\nMumps-like symptoms include the swelling of salivary glands along with fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite. Officials are trying to determine the possible source of infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to another version of this report, mumps virus infection can be spread by respiratory secretions and saliva (like kissing or yelling in someone's face) and by sharing drinks or making contact with unclean surfaces with respiratory secretions on them, circumstances that may have pertained at this particular club.\n\nNonetheless, it is highly unusual for an outbreak of mumps virus infection to originate at one particular Bar/Grill, although mumps outbreaks have occasionally been associated with clubs involving contact sports. Further information is awaited to determine whether this is an isolated event or a major outbreak of disease. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/35Bq.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to another version of this report, mumps virus infection can be spread by respiratory secretions and saliva (like kissing or yelling in someone's face) and by sharing drinks or making contact with unclean surfaces with respiratory secretions on them, circumstances that may have pertained at this particular club. \n\nNonetheless, it is highly unusual for an outbreak of mumps virus infection to originate at one particular Bar/Grill, although mumps outbreaks have occasionally been associated with clubs involving contact sports. MUMPS - USA (06): (NEW JERSEY), BAR AND GRILL ASSOCIATED\n********************************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Monmouth County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belmar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2380592", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (02): (OH) update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2380592", "date": "2014-04-04 15:16:50", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (02): (OHIO) UPDATE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Apr 2014\nSource: LimaOhio.com [edited]\nhttp://www.limaohio.com/news/news/4055443/ODH-says-Delaware-mumps-part-of-outbreak\n\n\nThe Ohio Department of Health [ODH] on Wednesday [2 Apr 2014] declared cases of mumps in Delaware County are now considered part of the community-wide outbreak in central Ohio.\n\nA total of 10 cases have been reported to the Delaware General Health District [DGHD] as of Wednesday afternoon, none of which have been confirmed by lab results. Until ODH made the announcement Wednesday, the cases in Delaware County were considered suspect -- clinically presenting as mumps but unconfirmed by labs -- and were not counted as part of the outbreak in Columbus and the surrounding areas. The change occurred as more cases are reported outside of Ohio State University [OSU], where the outbreak began. 'We believe that there is an exposure going on outside the university now,' said ODH spokesperson Melanie Amato. 'We're getting more information on cases now.'\n\nColumbus Public Health also announced an increase in cases Wednesday, with 24 community cases in Columbus and Franklin County and 95 cases reported in Franklin, Fairfield, Licking, Union and Hamilton counties related to the OSU outbreak, for a total of 119 cases. Until the announcement Wednesday, individual health departments were tracking community cases if not related to the OSU outbreak. Amato said local health departments will still track and record the cases within their area, but ODH will track the outbreak as a whole and report compiled numbers to the media in the mornings.\n\nThe 1st cases of mumps, a viral illness spread from person to person by droplets from the nose and mouth, were seen at OSU in February [2014]. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), close quarters in university dorms makes spreading the virus easy. In March [2014], cases began appearing in other communities without ties to the university outbreak.\n\nDGHD director of personal health Joan Bowe said recommendations for Delaware [County] residents have not changed: get vaccinated. Children should be vaccinated with MMR [measles mumps rubella vaccine] on or after their 1st birthday, followed by a 2nd dose at 4 to 6 years of age. Adults may receive a booster, which is recommended for post-secondary students and health care workers, according to the CDC. Adults born before 1957 are considered to have natural immunity as most had the virus before the vaccine was introduced to the public.\n\nThe 10 cases in Delaware [County] have occurred in residents ranging in age from 11 to 47. Cases at OSU have occurred in men and women between the ages of 18 and 58, while the other cases have shown up in residents of Columbus and Franklin County between the ages of 2 and 55.\n\n'Mumps is a reportable disease, which means physicians are mandated to contact the health department to report a suspect case and to let us know if they are sending blood in for lab work,' said DGHD spokesperson Traci Whittaker. 'We work with our local healthcare providers throughout the investigation, including receiving updated lab results as they become available.'\n\nThe [OHD] defines a mumps outbreak as 3 or more probable or confirmed cases clustered in a time and place, and the cases are likely related. Prior to lab confirmation, mumps reports are considered suspect -- unless an outbreak has been declared. In the event of an outbreak, all cases without confirmation are considered probable.\n\nSymptoms include fever, body aches, fatigue, swelling of salivary glands, or pain with chewing or swallowing. Up to 15 percent of people with mumps may also experience stiff neck and headache. Men may also experience orchitis, a testicular inflammation that causes pain, swelling, nausea, vomiting and fever. Some women may experience symptoms of inflammation of the ovaries and breasts. Symptoms usually begin 14 to 18 days after catching the virus, but the virus can be spread to others before symptoms even occur, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Transmission is likely before the salivary glands begin to swell and within 5 days after the swelling starts.\n\nAbout 1/3rd of patients will show mild symptoms or no symptoms. If symptoms do occur, residents are encouraged to contact their primary care provider. Residents can contact their primary care provider or the [DGHD] for vaccine availability at 740-368-1700.\n\nDGHD also recommends prevention through frequent hand washing, covering mouth and nose during a cough or sneeze, and not sharing cups or utensils. CPH recommends staying home and away from others for 5 days after symptoms begin.\n\nFrom 2004 to 2013, Delaware [County] had 5 cases of mumps reported -- the most recent of which was in 2009 -- and all were classified as suspect. No confirmed or probable cases of mumps were reported between 2004 and 2013 in Delaware County, and no mumps outbreaks were recorded in Delaware County during that time.\n\nMore information about mumps is available from the CDC at http://www.cdc.gov/mumps.\n\n[Byline: Stacy Kess]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail recently posted a report of the mumps outbreak on the OSU campus in the city of Columbus, Ohio, at which time there was a total of 13 confirmed cases of mumps -- 7 women and 6 men between 18 and 22 years of age (ProMED-mail post Mumps - USA: (OH) university students 20140308.2321285). Now there are 24 community cases in Columbus and 95 cases reported in Franklin, Fairfield, Licking, and Union counties that surround Columbus in central Ohio, and Hamilton County (the county seat of Cincinnati in southwest Ohio) for a total of 119 cases, plus apparently an additional 10 cases in Delaware County, another county that surrounds Columbus. Columbus, the county seat of Franklin County, is also the capital of and the largest city in the US state of Ohio. For a map of Ohio that shows the location of this state's counties, see http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6d/Ohio_Counties_Labeled_White.svg.\n\nThe Ohio State University (OSU) is a large public research university in Columbus, Ohio, with about 28 000 undergraduates and more than 35 on-campus residence halls, with additional separate housing for graduate and professional students, plus multiple extra-curricular organizations where social mixing can occur to facilitate spread of the disease (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_State_University).\n\nThe mumps vaccine was licensed in 1967 and is usually administered as part of a combination vaccine that provides protection against measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr4708.pdf). Live mumps virus vaccines in the US are derived from the Jeryl Lynn mumps vaccine strain. Post-licensure studies in the United States demonstrated that 1 dose of mumps vaccine was 78-91 percent effective in preventing clinical mumps with parotitis; a study from the United Kingdom indicated a vaccine effectiveness of 88 percent for 2 doses of MMR vaccine compared with 64 percent for a single dose (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5522a4.htm). The MMR vaccine in the United States is given in 2 doses: The 1st dose is given at 12-15 months of age and the 2nd dose before entering school, at 4-6 years of age (http://www.vaccines.gov/diseases/mumps/index.html).\n\nNevertheless, mumps outbreaks among vaccinated populations have been reported frequently during recent years, especially among college students where the intensity of exposure among students was presumed to have overcome the vaccine-induced immunity (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1681_article.htm).\n\nThe American College Health Association has recommended that colleges and universities require that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of MMR vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before college enrollment (http://www.acha.org/topics/docs/CDC_ACHA_Mumps_Recommendations_Jul13.pdf). Immune globulin is not effective postexposure prophylaxis (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/downloads/mumps.pdf). In an outbreak setting, MMR vaccine might reduce transmission to susceptible persons not yet exposed to the mumps virus. The CDC has evaluated use of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine for mumps outbreak control during 2 previous mumps outbreaks in which transmission was sustained, despite high 2-dose coverage (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6148a2.htm). During both outbreaks, targeted vaccination was followed by a decrease in mumps incidence among the target group. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/237.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail recently posted a report of the mumps outbreak on the OSU campus in the city of Columbus, Ohio, at which time there was a total of 13 confirmed cases of mumps -- 7 women and 6 men between 18 and 22 years of age (ProMED-mail post Mumps - USA: (OH) university students 20140308.2321285). Columbus Public Health also announced an increase in cases Wednesday, with 24 community cases in Columbus and Franklin County and 95 cases reported in Franklin, Fairfield, Licking, Union and Hamilton counties related to the OSU outbreak, for a total of 119 cases. Now there are 24 community cases in Columbus and 95 cases reported in Franklin, Fairfield, Licking, and Union counties that surround Columbus in central Ohio, and Hamilton County (the county seat of Cincinnati in southwest Ohio) for a total of 119 cases, plus apparently an additional 10 cases in Delaware County, another county that surrounds Columbus. Post-licensure studies in the United States demonstrated that 1 dose of mumps vaccine was 78-91 percent effective in preventing clinical mumps with parotitis; a study from the United Kingdom indicated a vaccine effectiveness of 88 percent for 2 doses of MMR vaccine compared with 64 percent for a single dose (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5522a4.htm). The CDC has evaluated use of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine for mumps outbreak control during 2 previous mumps outbreaks in which transmission was sustained, despite high 2-dose coverage (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6148a2.htm). \n\nThe mumps vaccine was licensed in 1967 and is usually administered as part of a combination vaccine that provides protection against measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr4708.pdf). No confirmed or probable cases of mumps were reported between 2004 and 2013 in Delaware County, and no mumps outbreaks were recorded in Delaware County during that time. The [OHD] defines a mumps outbreak as 3 or more probable or confirmed cases clustered in a time and place, and the cases are likely related. \n\nThe American College Health Association has recommended that colleges and universities require that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of MMR vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before college enrollment (http://www.acha.org/topics/docs/CDC_ACHA_Mumps_Recommendations_Jul13.pdf). The Ohio Department of Health [ODH] on Wednesday [2 Apr 2014] declared cases of mumps in Delaware County are now considered part of the community-wide outbreak in central Ohio. Until ODH made the announcement Wednesday, the cases in Delaware County were considered suspect -- clinically presenting as mumps but unconfirmed by labs -- and were not counted as part of the outbreak in Columbus and the surrounding areas. From 2004 to 2013, Delaware [County] had 5 cases of mumps reported -- the most recent of which was in 2009 -- and all were classified as suspect. Nevertheless, mumps outbreaks among vaccinated populations have been reported frequently during recent years, especially among college students where the intensity of exposure among students was presumed to have overcome the vaccine-induced immunity (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1681_article.htm). \n\n'Mumps is a reportable disease, which means physicians are mandated to contact the health department to report a suspect case and to let us know if they are sending blood in for lab work,' said DGHD spokesperson Traci Whittaker. Amato said local health departments will still track and record the cases within their area, but ODH will track the outbreak as a whole and report compiled numbers to the media in the mornings.\n\n Cases at OSU have occurred in men and women between the ages of 18 and 58, while the other cases have shown up in residents of Columbus and Franklin County between the ages of 2 and 55. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Children should be vaccinated with MMR [measles mumps rubella vaccine] on or after their 1st birthday, followed by a 2nd dose at 4 to 6 years of age. \n\nA total of 10 cases have been reported to the Delaware General Health District [DGHD] as of Wednesday afternoon, none of which have been confirmed by lab results. \n\nThe Ohio State University (OSU) is a large public research university in Columbus, Ohio, with about 28 000 undergraduates and more than 35 on-campus residence halls, with additional separate housing for graduate and professional students, plus multiple extra-curricular organizations where social mixing can occur to facilitate spread of the disease (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_State_University).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Columbus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fairfield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Licking", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cincinnati", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Franklin County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Franklin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hamilton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1832549", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (05): (NJ) young adults, correction", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1832549", "date": "2013-07-19 09:28:50", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (05): (NEW JERSEY), YOUNG ADULTS, CORRECTION\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 16 Jul 2013\nFrom: David Harrowe <dharrowe@tpchd.org> [edited]\n\n\nAt the end of a recent ProMED post on mumps in young adults in Lakewood, New Jersey [Mumps - USA (04): (NJ) young adults 20130717.1830577], moderator CP wrote: 'Orthodox Jewish communities in general decline to have their children vaccinated.'\n\nI think CP's statement above may be erroneous. I can find no orthodox Jewish proscription against vaccination. Indeed, it seems Jewish law can be interpreted as being supportive of vaccination.\n\nDoes CP have any data on vaccination rates among orthodox Jewish children that would support the statement? A retraction would seem in order if data exists to the contrary.\n\nLastly, mumps could spread more readily among orthodox Jewish children studying in religious institutions not due to a lack of vaccination, but rather due to the nature of religious study in which groups of children are often close together, thereby fostering droplet transmission.\n\n--\nDavid Harrowe, M.D.\n<DHarrowe@tpchd.org>\n\n[I thank Dr Harrowe for providing this information, and I gladly retract my erroneous statement.\n\nI had presumed erroneously that the mumps outbreak affecting mainly members of an orthodox Jewish community in New Jersey, and similarly the current measles outbreak in New York City affecting a different, mainly orthodox Jewish community (See ProMED-mail post: Measles update (27) 20130707.1811679), might reflect some religious restriction on vaccination. In fact, in prior investigations of mumps outbreaks in the US, orthodox Jewish communities have been found to be appropriately vaccinated. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/35Bq.]", "summary": "\n\nI had presumed erroneously that the mumps outbreak affecting mainly members of an orthodox Jewish community in New Jersey, and similarly the current measles outbreak in New York City affecting a different, mainly orthodox Jewish community (See ProMED-mail post: Measles update (27) 20130707.1811679), might reflect some religious restriction on vaccination. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n At the end of a recent ProMED post on mumps in young adults in Lakewood, New Jersey [Mumps - USA (04): (NJ) young adults 20130717.1830577], moderator CP wrote: 'Orthodox Jewish communities in general decline to have their children vaccinated.' Lastly, mumps could spread more readily among orthodox Jewish children studying in religious institutions not due to a lack of vaccination, but rather due to the nature of religious study in which groups of children are often close together, thereby fostering droplet transmission. \n\n--\nDavid Harrowe, M.D.\n<DHarrowe@tpchd.org>\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lakewood", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1773439", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Australia (02): (NS) alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1773439", "date": "2013-06-14 16:43:16", "main_text": "MUMPS - AUSTRALIA (02): (NEW SOUTH WALES) ALERT\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 13 Jun 2013\nSource: Walcha News [edited]\nhttp://www.walchanewsonline.com.au/story/1571050/warning-on-nsw-mumps-outbreak/?cs=24\n\n\nNew South Wales [NSW] Health has warned of a current outbreak of mumps across the state, urging members of the public to check their vaccination status. Dr Vicky Sheppeard, the director of communicable diseases for NSW Health, said there have been 15 reported cases of the disease in May [2013], clustered in several areas. It's highly likely more cases have not been reported. She said that the disease can be very serious for affected adults. 'Complications can include swelling of the testicles in males, and rarely inflammation of the brain, the lining of the brain and spinal cord, pancreatitis and hearing loss,' she said. A mumps infection during pregnancy can result in miscarriage, and the ovaries and testicles can also be affected.\n\nWhile most children are vaccinated against the disease, Dr Sheppeard said that many adults would not have any resistance to it, as the required 2 doses weren't routinely offered until the 1990s. 'Many people in their 20s, 30s, and early 40s will not be immune, so it is particularly important they check their status with their doctor and get vaccinated if they are not sure,' she said.\n\n'To prevent the spread of mumps, children and adults should have 2 doses of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine.' Symptoms of the disease include fever, loss of appetite, and tiredness and headaches, followed by swelling and tenderness of the salivary glands, especially near the jaw. Up to one-third of sufferers, however, have no symptoms. Mumps can be caught by breathing in the virus after a sufferer coughs or sneezes, or by direct saliva contact. It can then take 2 to 3 weeks to develop, and affected people are infectious a week before and up to 9 days after the glands have swollen. There is no specific treatment for mumps.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The consequences of mumps infection in adults include pain and swelling of the testicles (orchitis), which affects one in 5 of all males who get mumps after puberty. The swelling of their testicles normally begins 4 to 8 days after the swelling of the parotid gland. Occasionally, swelling can occur up to 6 weeks after the swelling of the glands. The swelling is usually very sudden and affects only one testicle. Just under half of all males who get mumps-related orchitis will notice some shrinkage of their testicles and an estimated 1 in 10 men will experience a drop in their sperm count.\n\nViral meningitis can occur if the mumps virus spreads into the outer protective layer of the brain which is known as the meninges. It occurs in one in 7 cases of mumps. Unlike bacterial meningitis, which is regarded as a potentially life-threatening medical emergency, viral meningitis causes much milder, flu-like symptoms, and the risk of serious complications are low. Sensitivity to light and vomiting are common symptom of viral meningitis. The symptoms of viral meningitis usually pass within 14 days.\n\nOne in 20 females who gets mumps after puberty will experience swelling of your ovaries (oophoritis), which can cause symptoms of lower abdominal pain, high temperature, and sickness. The symptoms of oophoritis are usually short-lived. One in 20 cases of mumps leads to pancreatitis. The most common symptom is the sudden pain in the centre of the upper abdomen. Other symptoms of acute pancreatitis can include sickness, diarrhoea, fever, and less frequently jaundice.\n\nRare but potentially serious complications of mumps include encephalitis (1 in 1000 cases) or permanent hearing loss (1 in 20 000 cases).\n\nAbstracted from NHS Choices http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Mumps/Pages/Complications.aspx. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/4966.]", "summary": "\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The consequences of mumps infection in adults include pain and swelling of the testicles (orchitis), which affects one in 5 of all males who get mumps after puberty. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nOne in 20 females who gets mumps after puberty will experience swelling of your ovaries (oophoritis), which can cause symptoms of lower abdominal pain, high temperature, and sickness. \n\n'To prevent the spread of mumps, children and adults should have 2 doses of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine.' Rare but potentially serious complications of mumps include encephalitis (1 in 1000 cases) or permanent hearing loss (1 in 20 000 cases). Complications can include swelling of the testicles in males, and rarely inflammation of the brain, the lining of the brain and spinal cord, pancreatitis and hearing loss,' she said. \n\nViral meningitis can occur if the mumps virus spreads into the outer protective layer of the brain which is known as the meninges. Symptoms of the disease include fever, loss of appetite, and tiredness and headaches, followed by swelling and tenderness of the salivary glands, especially near the jaw. Just under half of all males who get mumps-related orchitis will notice some shrinkage of their testicles and an estimated 1 in 10 men will experience a drop in their sperm count. \n\nWhile most children are vaccinated against the disease, Dr Sheppeard said that many adults would not have any resistance to it, as the required 2 doses weren't routinely offered until the 1990s. ' MUMPS - AUSTRALIA (02): (NEW SOUTH WALES) ALERT\n***********************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:20", "2021-03-25 00:00:30"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2391429", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (03): (OH) update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2391429", "date": "2014-04-09 15:28:32", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (03): (OHIO) UPDATE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 8 Apr 2014\nSource: The Columbus Dispatch [edited]\nhttp://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2014/04/08/mumps-outbreak-has-sickened-153-including-9-month-old-baby.html\n\n\nThe number of Ohioans sickened in a mumps outbreak that began at Ohio State University [OSU] climbed to 153 yesterday [7 Apr 2014] and includes a 9 month old [baby].\n\nMeanwhile, OSU leaders and experts from public health and the Wexner Medical Center are preparing to examine the health crisis. Interim university president Joseph A Alutto appointed a mumps advisory executive team last week to review university policies, OSU spokeswoman Liz Cook said. The group will 'take a very careful and closer look at the outbreak and really try to determine next steps to really protect the university campus and the greater community,' she said.\n\nCook said she did not know whether the team was to specifically consider requiring students to be vaccinated before attending Ohio State. Some other schools mandate vaccination against mumps, but Ohio State does not. The advisory team has yet to meet, and Cook said she did not know when members would conclude their discussions or issue a report or recommendations.\n\nOutbreak cases have now been found in the following counties: Franklin (135), Delaware (12), Athens (1), Belmont (1), Fairfield (1), Hamilton (1), Licking (1), and Pickaway (1).\n\nOne of 2 people who became temporarily deaf as a result of the mumps has recovered, said Columbus Public Health spokesman Jose Rodriguez. There are now 6 cases of orchitis (swollen testicles) associated with the outbreak, he said. The condition can lead to sterility, though that is rare.\n\nRodriguez said news that a baby was sickened was particularly troubling. Babies under a year old are too young to have received a vaccine and are especially vulnerable, as are older children and adults who have not had both rounds of the vaccine against measles, mumps, and rubella.\n\n[byline: Misti Crane]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail recently posted reports of the mumps outbreak that started on the Ohio State University (OSU) campus in the city of Columbus, Ohio and then spread into the surrounding counties (Delaware, Franklin, Fairfield, Licking, and Union) in central Ohio, but also involved Hamilton County in the south western portion of the state, in which the city of Cincinnati is located. As of the last previous post (4 Apr 2014) the total number of cases was 129. Now there are 153 cases, with 3 additional counties involved (Athens in south eastern, Belmont in eastern, and Pickaway in central Ohio), although most cases continue to be in Franklin County in which the city of Columbus and OSU are located.\n\nThe mumps vaccine is administered as part of a combination vaccine that provides protection against measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr4708.pdf). The MMR vaccine in the United States is given in 2 doses: the 1st dose is given at 12-15 months of age and the 2nd dose before entering school, at 4-6 years of age (http://www.vaccines.gov/diseases/mumps/index.html). The American College Health Association has recommended that colleges and universities require that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of MMR vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before college enrolment (http://www.acha.org/topics/docs/CDC_ACHA_Mumps_Recommendations_Jul13.pdf). However, the news report above says that OSU does not mandate immunization against mumps before matriculation. Nevertheless, mumps outbreaks among vaccinated populations have been reported frequently during recent years, especially among college students where the intensity of exposure among students was presumed to have overcome the vaccine-induced immunity (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1681_article.htm). Perhaps waning post-vaccination immunity and antigenic differences between outbreak strains and the vaccine viruses are additional explanations for mumps outbreaks in highly vaccinated populations (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/47/11/1458.full).\n\nCDC has evaluated use of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine for mumps outbreak control during 2 previous mumps outbreaks in which transmission was sustained, despite high 2-dose coverage (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6148a2.htm). During both outbreaks, targeted vaccination was followed by a decrease in mumps incidence among the target group.\n\nColumbus is the capital of and the largest city in the US state of Ohio. For a map of Ohio that shows the location of this state's counties, see http://geology.com/county-map/ohio.shtml.\n\nOhio State University (OSU) is a large public research university in Columbus, Ohio, with about 28 000 undergraduates and more than 35 on-campus residence halls, with additional separate housing for graduate and professional students, plus multiple extra-curricular organizations where social mixing can occur to facilitate spread of the disease (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_State_University). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/237.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Misti Crane]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail recently posted reports of the mumps outbreak that started on the Ohio State University (OSU) campus in the city of Columbus, Ohio and then spread into the surrounding counties (Delaware, Franklin, Fairfield, Licking, and Union) in central Ohio, but also involved Hamilton County in the south western portion of the state, in which the city of Cincinnati is located. \n\nCDC has evaluated use of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine for mumps outbreak control during 2 previous mumps outbreaks in which transmission was sustained, despite high 2-dose coverage (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6148a2.htm). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nOutbreak cases have now been found in the following counties: Franklin (135), Delaware (12), Athens (1), Belmont (1), Fairfield (1), Hamilton (1), Licking (1), and Pickaway (1). \n\nOhio State University (OSU) is a large public research university in Columbus, Ohio, with about 28 000 undergraduates and more than 35 on-campus residence halls, with additional separate housing for graduate and professional students, plus multiple extra-curricular organizations where social mixing can occur to facilitate spread of the disease (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_State_University). Nevertheless, mumps outbreaks among vaccinated populations have been reported frequently during recent years, especially among college students where the intensity of exposure among students was presumed to have overcome the vaccine-induced immunity (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/4/13-1681_article.htm). The American College Health Association has recommended that colleges and universities require that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of MMR vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before college enrolment (http://www.acha.org/topics/docs/CDC_ACHA_Mumps_Recommendations_Jul13.pdf). Perhaps waning post-vaccination immunity and antigenic differences between outbreak strains and the vaccine viruses are additional explanations for mumps outbreaks in highly vaccinated populations (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/47/11/1458.full). The mumps vaccine is administered as part of a combination vaccine that provides protection against measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr4708.pdf). Babies under a year old are too young to have received a vaccine and are especially vulnerable, as are older children and adults who have not had both rounds of the vaccine against measles, mumps, and rubella.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-04-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Belmont", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Columbus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hamilton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Franklin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fairfield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Franklin County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Athens", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Licking", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cincinnati", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1830577", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (04): (NJ) young adults", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1830577", "date": "2013-07-17 17:46:19", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04): (NEW JERSEY) YOUNG ADULTS\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 17 Jul 2013\nSource: The Ocean Signal [edited]\nhttp://www.oceancountysignal.com/2009/10/23/mumps-outbreak-in-lakewood-nj/\n\n\nThe Ocean County Health Department, in collaboration with the New Jersey Department of Health and Senior Services, is currently investigating multiple reports of mumps in Lakewood Township [New Jersey]. The majority of cases is in fully immunized young adults and may have spread to household and other close contacts. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that all children and adults of vaccination age have 2 doses of measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine. Strict enforcement of vaccination is important for preventing and stopping outbreaks. Mumps vaccine (usually MMR) is the best way to prevent mumps. Children should be given the 1st dose of MMR vaccine soon after the 1st birthday (12 to 15 months of age). The 2nd dose is recommended before the start of kindergarten.\n\nSymptoms of mumps include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite; followed by swelling of salivary glands. The parotid salivary glands (which are located within the cheek, near your jaw line, below your ears) are most frequently affected. While rare, other severe complications are possible -- seeking medical attention at the onset of symptoms is important.\n\nMumps occurs worldwide and there are still outbreaks in the United States. Humans are the only known host to mumps. Outbreaks can occur in highly immunized populations, most often in people who have not been immunized; however, there have been outbreaks in individuals who are fully immunised. Mumps virus replicates in the upper respiratory tract and is spread through direct contact with respiratory secretions or saliva. The infectious period or time that an infected person can transmit mumps to a non-infected person is from 3 days before symptoms appear to about 9 days after the symptoms appear. The incubation time, which is the period from when a person is exposed to virus to the onset of any symptoms, can vary from 16 to 18 days (range 12-25 days).\n\nIndividuals, whether they have been vaccinated against mumps or not, [who] exhibit the above symptoms, need to seek medical attention immediately to be evaluated. Anyone who is being considered [as] having a possible case of mumps needs to be appropriately excluded from social settings that may enable transmission, and should be immediately reported to the Ocean County Health Department. Anyone with mumps should not go back to child care, school or work for at least 5 days after symptoms begin. It is extremely important that individuals who may have been in contact with a suspected mumps case should be educated on the signs and symptoms of mumps and should seek medical attention if any of these symptoms begin.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Unfortunately, this report provides little information concerning the number of cases diagnosed, the ages of the victims and their vaccination status. This information is important because the risks for transmission of measles, rubella, and mumps at post-high school educational institutions can be high because these institutions bring together large concentrations of persons who may be susceptible to these diseases. Therefore (in the United States), colleges, universities, technical and vocational schools, and other institutions for post-high school education require that all undergraduate and graduate students have received 2 doses of MMR vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before enrolment. Students who do not have documentation of MMR vaccination or other acceptable evidence of immunity at the time of enrolment should be admitted to classes only after receiving the 1st dose of MMR vaccine. These students should be administered a 2nd dose of MMR vaccine one month later (but no sooner than 28 days after the 1st dose).\n\nLakewood Township is a township in Ocean County, New Jersey, United States. As of the 2010 United States Census the township had a total population of 92 843. The township ranked as the 7th-most-populous municipality in the state in 2010 after having been ranked 22nd in 2000. The sharp increase in population from 2000 to 2010 was led by increases in the township's Orthodox Jewish and Latino communities. Lakewood is one of the hubs of Orthodox Judaism and is home to one of the largest yeshivas in the world. The large Orthodox population comprises more than half of the township's population. This may explain the occurrence of mumps virus infection in the township, since Orthodox Jewish communities in general decline to have their children vaccinated.\n\nA map of the counties of New Jersey showing the location of Ocean County can be accessed at: http://www.funnewjersey.com/upload_user/New_Jersey_State_info/MAP_OF_NEW_JERSEY_COUNTIES.HTM. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/7F8d.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n It is extremely important that individuals who may have been in contact with a suspected mumps case should be educated on the signs and symptoms of mumps and should seek medical attention if any of these symptoms begin. The infectious period or time that an infected person can transmit mumps to a non-infected person is from 3 days before symptoms appear to about 9 days after the symptoms appear. Therefore (in the United States), colleges, universities, technical and vocational schools, and other institutions for post-high school education require that all undergraduate and graduate students have received 2 doses of MMR vaccine or have other acceptable evidence of measles, rubella, and mumps immunity before enrolment. This information is important because the risks for transmission of measles, rubella, and mumps at post-high school educational institutions can be high because these institutions bring together large concentrations of persons who may be susceptible to these diseases. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Unfortunately, this report provides little information concerning the number of cases diagnosed, the ages of the victims and their vaccination status. \n\nIndividuals, whether they have been vaccinated against mumps or not, [who] exhibit the above symptoms, need to seek medical attention immediately to be evaluated. \n\nSymptoms of mumps include fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite; followed by swelling of salivary glands. The incubation time, which is the period from when a person is exposed to virus to the onset of any symptoms, can vary from 16 to 18 days (range 12-25 days). The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that all children and adults of vaccination age have 2 doses of measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine. Mumps vaccine (usually MMR) is the best way to prevent mumps. Anyone with mumps should not go back to child care, school or work for at least 5 days after symptoms begin.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orthodox Judaism", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lakewood Township", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ocean County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1723475", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK: (England) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1723475", "date": "2013-05-19 12:03:04", "main_text": "MUMPS - UK: (ENGLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 17 May 2013\nSource: Cherwell [edited]\nhttp://www.cherwell.org/news/uk/2013/05/17/mumps-outbreak-affects-finalists\n\n\nMumps outbreak affects final exams in several Oxford colleges\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nMumps has broken out in at least 2 colleges, jeopardising finalists' exams and rowers' Summer Eights [rowing regatta] efforts. Cases have been confirmed by doctors in St Hilda's and Corpus Christi, while students are reporting further unconfirmed cases in St John's. Cherwell understands that several students who have caught the illness are approaching exams.\n\nIn an email to Corpus students, the Welfare Dean Judith Maltby told the college, 'It has been brought to our attention that there are several cases of mumps within the University and there have been 2 confirmed cases within Corpus.' The email continued, 'If it is confirmed that you have the virus you will be encouraged to go home (where possible) for 5 days. If going home is not possible please contact the College Office immediately.'\n\nStudents have alleged that Corpus's Boat Club has been particularly affected. Students have stated that 2 M1 rowers, and one W1 rower, have been affected by the illness. Clare Franklin, President of Corpus Christi College Boat Club, told Cherwell, 'There have been 3 confirmed cases of mumps within the boat club, which is less than ideal in the run up to Summer Eights. However, all affected members have gone home, and we are hopeful that they will recover quickly.' Guy Ward, a 1st year lawyer and rower for Corpus, said, 'It's certainly not helping our Summer Eights efforts, as rowers tend to be fairly close. All it takes is one rower to get it and, due to the proximity, everybody is at risk.'\n\nThere have also been 4 reported cases in St Hilda's College. One medical student at St Hilda's commented, 'It seems like quite a few people have been affected, one of whom has had the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] jab. No one is safe.' Pete Evans, a 1st year German and Linguistics student at Hilda's, said, 'This outbreak is terrible for finalists. I hope the university takes the illness into account when marking exams, otherwise this could be disastrous for students.'\n\nOxford University's Exam Regulations make allowances for illness. They state in section 11, if the examiners 'consider, on the evidence of the work submitted, that but for the illness or other urgent cause affecting the candidate's performance, he or she would have obtained Honours, they may deem the candidate to have obtained Honours.'\n\nAn Oxford University spokesperson was unable to confirm the number of students affected by mumps, but stated, 'In any such case the network of college nurses and doctors will work in partnership with the local Health Protection Agency to take all the appropriate measures.' She added, 'Any student who suspects they might have mumps-like symptoms should stay in their room or at home and phone their college doctor, nurse or GP for advice.'\n\nMumps is a viral illness which is rarely fatal, but is highly contagious. Its symptoms include a headache and fever, followed by swelling and soreness of the parotid salivary gland, located behind the jaw. According to the Oxford University website, 'Over the last 4 years there has been a large outbreak of mumps in young adults across the UK and there has been a recent increase in mumps amongst students.' Scientists have linked the recent growth in mumps outbreaks to public opposition to the MMR jab, after a 1998 study linked the vaccination to autism. Its researcher, Andrew Wakefield, has since been struck off the medical register, and his conclusions are largely discredited. However, after his findings were reported globally, the number of children receiving the vaccination in the UK fell from 92 percent to below 80 percent. The last major outbreak was in 2008, when 1348 cases were confirmed, and 2 people died.\n\n[Byline: Rowan Borchers]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks of mumps occur occasionally in universities and similar educational institutions where young adults from diverse backgrounds congregate. Although the current mumps virus vaccine strains included in the triple MMR vaccine induce sufficient immunity to protect virtually all young children from mumps virus infection, the level of immunity maintained in older children and young adults may be less than adequate to provide protection under all circumstances -- as was the situation in at least one case in Oxford. More frequently mumps virus infection may occur in young adults where MMR triple vaccine coverage has been below the optimum of at least 95 percent, which has been the situation in some parts of the UK since 1998. It is unusual, however, for mumps virus infection to be a risk factor in the outcome of rowing regattas. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3Z2-.]", "summary": "Although the current mumps virus vaccine strains included in the triple MMR vaccine induce sufficient immunity to protect virtually all young children from mumps virus infection, the level of immunity maintained in older children and young adults may be less than adequate to provide protection under all circumstances -- as was the situation in at least one case in Oxford. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks of mumps occur occasionally in universities and similar educational institutions where young adults from diverse backgrounds congregate. \n\nAn Oxford University spokesperson was unable to confirm the number of students affected by mumps, but stated, 'In any such case the network of college nurses and doctors will work in partnership with the local Health Protection Agency to take all the appropriate measures.' According to the Oxford University website, 'Over the last 4 years there has been a large outbreak of mumps in young adults across the UK and there has been a recent increase in mumps amongst students.' In an email to Corpus students, the Welfare Dean Judith Maltby told the college, 'It has been brought to our attention that there are several cases of mumps within the University and there have been 2 confirmed cases within Corpus.' More frequently mumps virus infection may occur in young adults where MMR triple vaccine coverage has been below the optimum of at least 95 percent, which has been the situation in some parts of the UK since 1998. \nMumps has broken out in at least 2 colleges, jeopardising finalists' exams and rowers' Summer Eights [rowing regatta] efforts. MUMPS - UK: (ENGLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS\n*****************************************\n http://www.cherwell.org/news/uk/2013/05/17/mumps-outbreak-affects-finalists\n\n\nMumps outbreak affects final exams in several Oxford colleges\n------------------------------------------------------------- Clare Franklin, President of Corpus Christi College Boat Club, told Cherwell, 'There have been 3 confirmed cases of mumps within the boat club, which is less than ideal in the run up to Summer Eights. The last major outbreak was in 2008, when 1348 cases were confirmed, and 2 people died.\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-03-25 00:00:00", "1348-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "St John 's", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1725865", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK (02): (England) university students, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1725865", "date": "2013-05-20 17:07:53", "main_text": "MUMPS - UK (02): (ENGLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, COMMENT\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 May 2013\nFrom: Peter English <peter.english@phe.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Mumps - UK: (England) university students 20130519.1723475\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn the post it was stated that: 'Scientists have linked the recent growth in mumps outbreaks to public opposition to the MMR jab, after a 1998 study linked the vaccination to autism. Its researcher, Andrew Wakefield, has since been struck off the medical register, and his conclusions are largely discredited. However, after his findings were reported globally, the number of children receiving the vaccination in the UK fell from 92 percent to below 80 percent. The last major outbreak was in 2008, when 1348 cases were confirmed, and 2 people died.'\n\n[Dr Peter English points out at that:] 'The Wakefield scare started in 1998. That was 14 years ago. University students will be age 18 years or older, so they were not affected by this. Prior to the scare the uptake of MMR was better; but a catch-up vaccination campaign for children who had only had a single dose of MMR in the 1990s used an MR vaccine, protecting against measles and rubella only, so some of the students may have had only one dose of mumps containing (MMR) vaccine.' There is more information about this at: 'Questions and answers about mumps and MMR' at http://www.ganfyd.org/index.php?title=Questions_and_answers_about_mumps_and_MMR. Interested readers are recommend to consult this document.\n\n--\nDr Peter M B English\nGMC No 3002861\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control\nUK\n<peter.english@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Peter English for drawing attention to this situation, which is relevant to the interpretation of this outbreak. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n GMC No 3002861\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control\nUK\n<peter.english@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Peter English for drawing attention to this situation, which is relevant to the interpretation of this outbreak. - Mod. MUMPS - UK (02): (ENGLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, COMMENT\n*******************************************************\n Prior to the scare the uptake of MMR was better; but a catch-up vaccination campaign for children who had only had a single dose of MMR in the 1990s used an MR vaccine, protecting against measles and rubella only, so some of the students may have had only one dose of mumps containing (MMR) vaccine.' [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Mumps - UK: (England) university students 20130519.1723475\n In the post it was stated that: 'Scientists have linked the recent growth in mumps outbreaks to public opposition to the MMR jab, after a 1998 study linked the vaccination to autism.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1348-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wakefield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MR", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1604476", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Australia: (WA), alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1604476", "date": "2013-03-26 16:54:35", "main_text": "MUMPS - AUSTRALIA: (WESTERN AUSTRALIA), ALERT\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 26 Mar 2013\nSource: The West Australian [edited]\nhttp://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/a/-/breaking/16443436/warning-on-mumps-outbreak/\n\n\nWarning on mumps outbreak\n-------------------------\nAn outbreak of mumps in Perth has worsened, with health authorities confirming 30 cases since late December [2012] compared with the usual handful in a year. Several patients have been admitted to hospital, though none has become seriously ill.\n\nThe Health Department's latest Virus Watch bulletin said there had been 3 new cases in the past week and urged GPs to be on the lookout for patients with the highly infectious viral illness. It said most of the Perth patients had been infected locally and were older teenagers or adults aged in their 20s and 30s, and many were partially or fully vaccinated against mumps. A department spokeswoman said yesterday that none of the confirmed cases was in young children. 'We are not aware of any cases with serious complications, although a few cases have been admitted to hospital with [mild] complications, including orchitis (swollen testicles) in men and meningitis,' she said. Although mumps is highly contagious, it is rarely seen any more because of the widespread use of the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine in childhood. But if untreated, it can lead to serious complications including meningitis, miscarriage, encephalitis, hearing loss and pancreatitis.\n\nThe department said the cases did not appear to be linked, suggesting mumps virus was in wide circulation and there were many other cases in the community not being detected. It said GPs should test for mumps in all patients showing signs, regardless of whether they had been vaccinated, using blood and urine tests and throat swabs. Symptoms of mumps include fever, loss of appetite, tiredness and headaches, followed by swelling and tenderness of the salivary glands. The infection spreads when a person breathes in mumps virus, usually after someone infected has coughed or sneezed. Doctors say people born after 1965 need to ensure they received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine and not just one, which might not provide enough protection.\n\n[Byline: Cathy O'Leary]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps disease occurs world-wide. Mumps vaccine is an attenuated virus included as a component of the MMR triple vaccine of childhood. Typically outbreaks of mumps occur where young adults are congregated together in university dormitories or under similar circumstances. Indeed nowadays some universities and similar institutions may require confirmation of previous mumps vaccination in childhood prior to admission of applicants. Even so outbreaks are not infrequent in such circumstances, hence the recommendation for revaccination wherever the disease reappears.\n\nThe reason for the reappearance of mumps among those vaccinated in childhood is attributed to waning immunity rather than the emergence of mumps virus antigenic variants in the population, although genetically distinct mumps virus strains are present globally. This interpretation is supported by the observation that those experiencing mumps virus infection naturally prior to 1965 retain lifelong immunity.\n\nThe city of Perth is the capital of Western Australia. A map of Western Australia can be viewed at: http://www.welt-atlas.de/karte_von_westaustralien_3-905. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "\n\nThe reason for the reappearance of mumps among those vaccinated in childhood is attributed to waning immunity rather than the emergence of mumps virus antigenic variants in the population, although genetically distinct mumps virus strains are present globally. Although mumps is highly contagious, it is rarely seen any more because of the widespread use of the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine in childhood. There are currently 15 confirmed cases of mumps among students, and there are an additional 38 suspected cases on the university's campus. The number of cases has risen from just one week ago [up from 5 on 13 Mar 2013 - Mod.CP], when the university 1st notified students about multiple laboratory-confirmed cases.\n\nWhile the virus has not spread to the community, the Virginia Health Department said it's concerned the virus could spread outside of the university.\n\nSymptoms include headache, fever and nausea. Health authorities have vaccinated more than 300 children in the affected district and disinfected villages, educational facilities, as well as given necessary medicines to local residents.\n\nSchools scrubbed tables, equipment, and disinfected all corners of the school to ensure clean environmental hygiene.\n\n[Byline: K. Nguyen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org\n\n[Mumps is a common childhood infection. The hallmark of infection is swelling of the parotid gland. Aseptic meningitis and encephalitis are common complications of mumps together with orchitis and oophoritis, which can arise in adult men and women, respectively. Other complications include deafness and pancreatitis.\n\nMumps is vaccine-preventable, and one dose of mumps vaccine is about 80 percent effective against the disease. Routine vaccination has proven very effective in reducing the incidence of mumps and is presently used by most countries.\n\nThis outbreak appears to centred on a particular primary school in one local district. It may be that the remoteness of Lao Cai province has limited comprehensive coverage of the population, and the continued presence of susceptible individuals has enabled the infection to spread. Information on the extent of vaccine coverage in Lao Cai and adjacent provinces in Viet Nam would be welcomed.\n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks. Items used by an infected person can also be contaminated with the virus, which may spread to others if those items are shared. In addition, the virus may spread when someone with mumps touches items or surfaces without washing their hands and someone else then touches the same surface and rubs their mouth or nose. Most mumps transmission likely occurs before the salivary glands begin to swell and up to 5 days after the swelling begins.\n\nA map of the provinces of Viet Nam showing Lao Cai province in the far north can be accessed at: http://www.mande.co.uk/htpap/provinces.htm. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1jtz.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks. \n\nMumps is vaccine-preventable, and one dose of mumps vaccine is about 80 percent effective against the disease. \n\n\nHealth authorities in the northern mountainous province of Lao Cai on Tue 19 Mar 2013 reported an outbreak of mumps in Bao Ha Commune of Bao Yen District, with 50 people infected so far. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1589886", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA: (MD) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1589886", "date": "2013-03-16 14:09:24", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA: (MARYLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 14 Mar 2013\nSource: Medical Daily [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.medicaldaily.com/articles/14257/20130314/mumps-virus-outbreak-baltimore-loyola-university.htm\n\n\nMumps virus outbreak in Baltimore's Loyola University\n-----------------------------------------------------\nLoyola campus officials have put out a campus community alert to watch out for symptoms of the rare virus. The students who came down with mumps live on and off the North Baltimore campus. Mumps virus used to be very common in the United States among infants, children, and young adults, but became rare after a widespread vaccination campaign for measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR). The MMR vaccine is one of the recommended childhood immunizations, given first when a child is 12 to 15 months old and followed up with a 2nd shot, usually before the child enters school by age 6. The MMR vaccine is reputed to be 90 per cent effective, and like many schools, Loyola University requires the MMR vaccination for all enrolled students.\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, mumps symptoms start with several days of fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, which are followed by swelling of the salivary glands and testicular or ovarian inflammation within 2 to 4 weeks of infection. Half of the people who get mumps, however, show mild or no symptoms.\n\nMumps virus is contagious, and spreads through the saliva or mucus of an infected person. Anyone who is not already immune to the mumps virus from vaccination or previous infection can be afflicted by it. As one might imagine with a disease that spreads through bodily fluids, mumps outbreaks are most common in places that bring together many young people living in the same place, like summer camps and universities.\n\nAccording to the Baltimore Sun, Loyola University officials notified the campus community of the 1st cases before spring break started on 4 Mar 2013, and sent a warning letter this week [week of 11 Mar 2013] about the growing number of cases. In addition to the 12 confirmed cases of the mumps virus, several more suspected cases have been reported, said Loyola University spokeswoman Courtney Jolley.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks of mumps occur occasionally in universities and similar educational institutions where young adults from diverse backgrounds congregate. Although the current mumps virus vaccine strains included in the triple MMR vaccine induce sufficient immunity to protect virtually all young children from mumps virus infection, the level of immunity maintained in older children and young adults may be less than adequate to provide protection under all circumstances. This reduced extent of protection does not appear to be a consequence of antigenic diversity among circulating mumps viruses, although genetically distinct strains of mumps virus appear to circulate globally. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/5Xzm.]", "summary": "Although the current mumps virus vaccine strains included in the triple MMR vaccine induce sufficient immunity to protect virtually all young children from mumps virus infection, the level of immunity maintained in older children and young adults may be less than adequate to provide protection under all circumstances. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks of mumps occur occasionally in universities and similar educational institutions where young adults from diverse backgrounds congregate. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Mumps virus used to be very common in the United States among infants, children, and young adults, but became rare after a widespread vaccination campaign for measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR). This reduced extent of protection does not appear to be a consequence of antigenic diversity among circulating mumps viruses, although genetically distinct strains of mumps virus appear to circulate globally. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, mumps symptoms start with several days of fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, which are followed by swelling of the salivary glands and testicular or ovarian inflammation within 2 to 4 weeks of infection. As one might imagine with a disease that spreads through bodily fluids, mumps outbreaks are most common in places that bring together many young people living in the same place, like summer camps and universities. The university is warning the campus about the outbreak, which heightened since early March [2013]. Virginia Health Department officials say they have lab-confirmed 5 to 10 cases of mumps. Another 10 patients showed symptoms which may be resulting from the virus. University officials say they wasted no time in warning everyone on and off campus. Emails were mass sent to students, parents, faculty and staff.\n\nMost children in the U.S. are immunized for MMR -- measles, mumps and rubella. Generally, you can't get into schools, including the University of Richmond, without [evidence of] those shots. However, doctors say that doesn't mean a rare outbreak of the virus can't happen. Dr. Parham Jaberi of the Virginia Department of Health says 'Mumps is a similar illness] to a cold [with symptoms of) fever, headache, muscle aches. People feel tired. They may have a loss of appetite,' said Jaberi. Another common symptom of mumps is swollen cheeks. Patients may also develop other inflammation of other organs, including testicular inflammation in men. Mumps is contagious. It's transferred through droplets of body fluid, mainly saliva. The best way to avoid mumps is to cover your mouth and wash your hands.\n\nDoctors say mumps is usually not serious and can be fended off in a few days. The Virginia Health Department is trying to figure out why this mumps outbreak is happening. Officials say international traveling may be to blame. They also say there are universities in nearby states reporting cases of mumps\n\n[Byline: Kelly Avellino]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It may be convenient to ascribe this outbreak of mumps on campus to international travel since outbreaks of mumps occur sporadically in universities and similar educational institutions at this time of year.
