[Byline: Kelly Avellino]\n\n--\n Dr. Parham Jaberi of the Virginia Department of Health says 'Mumps is a similar illness] to a cold [with symptoms of) fever, headache, muscle aches.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VIRGINIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Richmond", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Commonwealth of Virginia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1494583", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Pakistan: (SD), fatalites, NOT", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1494583", "date": "2013-01-12 17:53:48", "main_text": "MUMPS - PAKISTAN: (SINDH), FATALITIES, NOT\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 12 Jan 2013\nFrom: a correspondent\n\n\nRe: Mumps - Pakistan: (SD), fatalities, RFI 20130110.1491581\n----------------------------------------------------\nProMED-mail has been informed by a reliable source in Pakistan that there have been no press reports of an extensive outbreak of mumps virus infection in Sindh province of Pakistan. In contrast there have been numerous press reports (See: ProMED-mail Measles updates (01) and (02) describing country-wide outbreaks of measles virus infection.\n\nIt seems likely that the report of fatalities associated with a province-wide outbreak of mumps virus infection (relayed by a Foreign News Agency) is erroneous -- possibly as a result of confusion arising from the identity of of the vaccine (Mumps, measles and rubella triple vaccine) employed in control of the outbreak of disease, and in part due to inaccurate statements (or interpretation of statements) by administrators in Sindh province.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nIt seems likely that the report of fatalities associated with a province-wide outbreak of mumps virus infection (relayed by a Foreign News Agency) is erroneous -- possibly as a result of confusion arising from the identity of of the vaccine (Mumps, measles and rubella triple vaccine) employed in control of the outbreak of disease, and in part due to inaccurate statements (or interpretation of statements) by administrators in Sindh province. ----------------------------------------------------\nProMED-mail has been informed by a reliable source in Pakistan that there have been no press reports of an extensive outbreak of mumps virus infection in Sindh province of Pakistan.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sindh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1553506", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Spain (02): (GA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1553506", "date": "2013-02-21 17:35:16", "main_text": "MUMPS - SPAIN (02): (GALICIA)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 20 Feb 2013\nSource: La Voz de Vigo [in Spanish, trans - Mod. JG/CP, edited]\nhttp://www.lavozdegalicia.es/noticia/vigo/2013/02/19/brote-dispara-vigo-casos-paperas-llegara-galicia/0003_201302V19C4991.htm\n\n\nEvery 5 years, there is an increase in the number of cases of mumps in Galicia. These are cyclic outbreaks. There was one of such instances between 2001 and 2002, another one between 2005 and 2006, so now another outbreak was expected and it is occurring in Vigo, the most populated area of Galicia, compared with elsewhere in the autonomous region. So far this year [2013], 193 persons in Vigo have become infected with mumps.\n\nFor the last week for which official information is available, 4-11 Feb 2013, 39 persons became infected in Vigo, whereas in the rest of Galicia, 43 people became infected. So, what is going on in Vigo to explain this high incidence of mumps?\n\n'It is merely chance,' said the chief of the Epidemiological Alert Service in the Sanitation Council in this province. She explained that, for instance, the previous outbreak started in the Pontevedra area and then it spread outwards. 'We foresee that this outbreak may extend to the whole of Galicia.' Considering past experience, experts expect that this increase in the number of cases may last for the whole year. When measuring the incidence of a disease, the value is expressed as the number of (new) cases per 100 000 inhabitants. For 2012, the incidence of mumps in Galicia was 1.5 cases per 100 000 inhabitants. During the last 4 weeks of 2012, the figure increased to 6.8 per 100 000. In Vigo at present, the incidence of mumps is 33.1 cases per 100 000 inhabitants. In other words, the figure has skyrocketed 22-fold.\n\nHealth officials do not completely know what has happened but several hypotheses have been proposed. A mumps vaccine is included in the routine immunization schedule. One dose is administered at 15 months of age and the other at 3 years, as part of the so called triple viral [MMR] vaccine, which also includes immunisation against measles and rubella. This schedule was introduced in Galicia in 1982. One hypothesis explaining this occurrence states that the triple vaccine may lose its effectiveness with time. Another hypothesis proposes that there may be a group of persons that missed one dose of vaccine because until 1999 the 2nd dose was administered at 11 years of age, and subsequently the vaccine was administered at 3 years of age. The 3rd hypothesis proposes that persons born before 1980, who never received the vaccine, may play a role in this occurrence [that is, the persistence of mumps virus infection].\n\nMs. Maria Jose Faraldo notes that mumps is 'a benign and mild viral infection'. Nowadays this condition is particularly affecting young people between 15 and 25 years of age. Many cases have been detected in different health centers in the city. Health authorities recommend that in order to avoid spreading the disease, affected persons not go to school or to their workplace during a 5 day period after the occurrence of swelling in the parotid gland area.\n\n[Byline: Angel Paniagua]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The periodicity of epidemics of mumps virus infection in Spain is an interesting phenomenon and may be a consequence of the properties of the vaccine strains incorporated into the MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccines employed in earlier years. In a recent comparison (see: Demicheli V, Rivetti A, Debalini MG, Di Pietrantonj C: Vaccines for measles, mumps and rubella in children. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2012 Feb 15; 2:CD004407. doi: 10.1002/14651858.CD004407.pub3; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22336803) the effectiveness of at least one dose of MMR in preventing clinical mumps in children is estimated to be between 69 percent and 81 percent for the vaccine prepared with Jeryl Lynn mumps strain and between 70 percent and 75 percent for the vaccine containing the Urabe strain. Vaccination with MMR containing the Urabe strain has demonstrated to be 73 percent effective in preventing secondary mumps cases. Effectiveness of Jeryl Lynn containing MMR in preventing laboratory-confirmed mumps cases in children and adolescents was estimated to be between 64 percent to 66 percent for one dose and 83 percent to 88 percent for 2 vaccine doses.\n\nHowever there may be other reasons for the periodicity such as the proportion of the population receiving mumps virus vaccine.\n\nGalicia is an autonomous community in northwest Spain, with the official status of a nationality. It comprises the provinces of A Coruna, Lugo, Ourense, and Pontevedra, being bordered by Portugal to the south, the Spanish autonomous communities of Castile and Leon and Asturias to the east, the Atlantic Ocean to the west, and the Bay of Biscay to the north. It had a population of 2 778 913 in 2012. Vigo is a is a city and municipality, the most populous city in Galicia, and the 14th in Spain.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Spain can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/5wxA. Maps of Galicia can be accessed at http:./www.map-of-spain.co.uk/galicia_maps.htm. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "doi: 10.1002/14651858.CD004407.pub3; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22336803) the effectiveness of at least one dose of MMR in preventing clinical mumps in children is estimated to be between 69 percent and 81 percent for the vaccine prepared with Jeryl Lynn mumps strain and between 70 percent and 75 percent for the vaccine containing the Urabe strain. Effectiveness of Jeryl Lynn containing MMR in preventing laboratory-confirmed mumps cases in children and adolescents was estimated to be between 64 percent to 66 percent for one dose and 83 percent to 88 percent for 2 vaccine doses. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The periodicity of epidemics of mumps virus infection in Spain is an interesting phenomenon and may be a consequence of the properties of the vaccine Another hypothesis proposes that there may be a group of persons that missed one dose of vaccine because until 1999 the 2nd dose was administered at 11 years of age, and subsequently the vaccine was administered at 3 years of age. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n One dose is administered at 15 months of age and the other at 3 years, as part of the so called triple viral [MMR] vaccine, which also includes immunisation against measles and rubella. \n\nHowever there may be other reasons for the periodicity such as the proportion of the population receiving mumps virus vaccine. For 2012, the incidence of mumps in Galicia was 1.5 cases per 100 000 inhabitants. In Vigo at present, the incidence of mumps is 33.1 cases per 100 000 inhabitants. MUMPS - SPAIN (02): (GALICIA)\n*****************************\n Every 5 years, there is an increase in the number of cases of mumps in Galicia. \n\nMs. Maria Jose Faraldo notes that mumps is 'a benign and mild viral infection'. strains incorporated into the MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccines employed in earlier years. When measuring the incidence of a disease, the value is expressed as the number of (new) cases per 100 000 inhabitants.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-02-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "1982-03-25 00:00:00", "1980-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-02-11 20:13:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vigo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MUMPS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Galicia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Coruna", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1546740", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Spain: (Madrid)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1546740", "date": "2013-02-17 14:54:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - SPAIN: (MADRID)\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 16 Feb 2013\nSource: Madridactual.es [in Spanish, trans. Mod.JG/CP, edited]\nhttp://www.madridactual.es/20130214494299/la-consejeria-de-sanidad-en-alerta-ante-el-aumento-del-brote-de-paperas\n\n\nThe mumps outbreak that is currently affecting some youngsters in Madrid may spread. Mumps is mild and not a 'severe' disease, but there can be no room for complacency, said Dr. Antonio Alemany, Chief of Primary Care. Dr. Alemany stated that the outbreak had begun at the beginning of the month [February 2013] and that the outbreak is not restricted to Madrid. He stated that it represents a new cycle of the disease, which tends to occur every 3-6 years.\n\nHe said that people 'are more or less protected,' depending on the immunogenic capability of the vaccines they might have received. Dr. Alemany explained that vaccines used in Spain before 1999 had a 50.5 percent antigen content [protective capacity?], whereas those vaccines used more recently, particularly those manufactured 'using more advanced technology,' have a 'much higher protection capacity,' between 88 and 90 percent. Dr. Alemany recognized that children vaccinated before 1999 have a 50.5 percent likelihood of being protected, meaning that 'they do not have a complete defense' against the disease as a consequence of the characteristics of that particular vaccine they had received.\n\nDr. Alemany also stated that, from an epidemiological point of view, 'being that this disease is quite communicable, we can expect that the number of cases of mumps in Madrid may increase,' but he pointed out that there is no [reason] for concern 'because of the typical characteristics of this condition.' Dr Alemany also stated that: 'It depends on the characteristics of the virus and climatic conditions, since outbreaks may occur more frequently during the cold season.' Dr. Alemany also indicated that cases of mumps are occurring in several autonomous communities, 'since viruses do not recognize borders or geographical limits.'\n\nAccording to Dr Alemany, mumps is a common disease during infancy 'that usually does not necessitate hospitalisation and can be treated at home with plenty of rest, lots of non-acidic fluids, with use of analgesics for alleviating headache or for temperature control.' He explained also that in many cases, a person may have the virus and not develop the disease, or he/she may develop a mild form of this condition.\n\nOn the other hand, Dr. Salvador Victoria, Counselor of the Presidency and Spokesman for the Madrid Community Local Government, stated last Thursday [14 Feb 2013] that the outbreak of mumps recorded in Madrid 'is similar to the situation occurring in other areas in Spain, and that it does not have a special significance.'\n\nAccording to the General Direction for Primary Care, the present situation is not a general outbreak, but it consists of 'local outbreaks occurring in specific sites' in which 'timely epidemiological investigations are being carried out.' When asked about this situation in a press conference after the Government Council meeting, Dr. Victoria explained that the Madrid Health Council had changed the vaccine in 1999 that was provided at that time by the Spanish Ministry of Health; and he mentioned also that in 2007, a vaccination campaign was carried out in 9- to 12-year old children, 'so they may have complete immunity against mumps.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks of mumps have been frequent throughout Spain in recent years. The symptoms of mumps usually develop 14 to 25 days after a person is infected with mumps virus. The average incubation period is around 17 days. Swelling of the parotid glands is the most common symptom of mumps. Both glands are usually affected by the swelling, although only one gland can be affected. The swelling can cause pain, tenderness, and difficulty with swallowing. Other symptoms of the mumps include: headache, joint pain, sickness, abdominal pain and fever.\n\nMumps is spread in the same way as colds and flu: via infected droplets of saliva that can be inhaled or picked up from surfaces and passed into the mouth or nose. A person is most contagious 1-2 days before the onset of symptoms and for 5 days afterwards. During this time, it is important to try to prevent spreading the infection to others, particularly teenagers and young adults who have not been vaccinated. Normally, infection resolves without complications and provides life-long immunity.\n\nFor unvaccinated persons born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should consider vaccinating these individuals with 2 doses of MMR vaccine at the appropriate interval (for measles and mumps) and one dose of MMR vaccine (for rubella), respectively. For unvaccinated personnel born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should recommend 2 doses of MMR vaccine during an outbreak of measles or mumps and one dose during an outbreak of rubella.\n\nTwo doses of mumps vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective at preventing the disease; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49-92 percent) effective. The 1st vaccine against mumps was licensed in the United States in 1967, and by 2005, high 2-dose childhood vaccination coverage reduced disease rates by 99 percent. Adults at higher risk, such as university students, health care personnel, and international travelers, and persons with potential mumps outbreak exposure, should ensure that they have been vaccinated. (Further information can be obtained from the USCDC website at (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/mumps.html#vaccines). - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zJm.]", "summary": "For unvaccinated personnel born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should recommend 2 doses of MMR vaccine during an outbreak of measles or mumps and one dose during an outbreak of rubella. For unvaccinated persons born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should consider vaccinating these individuals with 2 doses of MMR vaccine at the appropriate interval (for measles and mumps) and one dose of MMR vaccine (for rubella), respectively. When asked about this situation in a press conference after the Government Council meeting, Dr. Victoria explained that the Madrid Health Council had changed the vaccine in 1999 that was provided at that time by the Spanish Ministry of Health; and he mentioned also that in 2007, a vaccination campaign was carried out in 9- to 12-year old children, 'so they may have complete immunity against mumps.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n< \n\nTwo doses of mumps vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective at preventing the disease; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49-92 percent) effective. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nDr. Alemany also stated that, from an epidemiological point of view, 'being that this disease is quite communicable, we can expect that the number of cases of mumps in Madrid may increase,' but he pointed out that there is no [reason] for concern 'because of the typical characteristics of this condition.' The 1st vaccine against mumps was licensed in the United States in 1967, and by 2005, high 2-dose childhood vaccination coverage reduced disease rates by 99 percent. \n\nOn the other hand, Dr. Salvador Victoria, Counselor of the Presidency and Spokesman for the Madrid Community Local Government, stated last Thursday [14 Feb 2013] that the outbreak of mumps recorded in Madrid 'is similar to the situation occurring in other areas in Spain, and that it does not have a special significance.' The symptoms of mumps usually develop 14 to 25 days after a person is infected with mumps virus. According to Dr Alemany, mumps is a common disease during infancy 'that usually does not necessitate hospitalisation and can be treated at home with plenty of rest, lots of non-acidic fluids, with use of analgesics for alleviating headache or for temperature control.' Adults at higher risk, such as university students, health care personnel, and international travelers, and persons with potential mumps outbreak exposure, should ensure that they have been vaccinated.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-02-25 00:00:00", "2013-02-14 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MUMPS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1454739", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Isle of Man", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1454739", "date": "2012-12-16 19:14:14", "main_text": "MUMPS - ISLE OF MAN\n*******************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 14 Dec 2012\nSource: Isle of Man Examiner [edited]\nhttp://www.iomtoday.co.im/news/health/isle-of-man-hit-by-mumps-outbreak-1-5222912\n\n\nThe viral disease mumps has taken hold among a generation of people who weren't vaccinated after the MMR autism scare in the 1990s. Until the end of November 2012, the island had seen 196 cases so far this year [2012]. More have been reported since the beginning of this month [December 2012]. Usually, the figures would be measured in dozens.\n\nDr Paul Emerson, consultant in public health medicine, said: 'It is down to a combination of things. In the 1990s, uptake of the MMR vaccine [among children] fell because of the Wakefield fiasco, which linked MMR to autism and which was proven to be unfounded.' That generation, now adolescents and in their 20s, have been hit in the latest outbreak. Those born before 1970, before vaccination, were more likely to have natural lifelong immunity. The MMR vaccine drops off in effectiveness 10 to 15 years after it's given. So anyone who had the jab when they were younger should see their GP again to get a booster.\n\n'Mumps is more serious in men,' said Dr Emerson. 'It can lead to sterility. It can lead to a nasty fever and pain in the groin area.' Women are also more likely to miscarry if they get mumps in the 1st trimester of a pregnancy. Dr Emerson stressed there was no evidence it could lead to foetal abnormalities.\n\nThe virus is not as infectious as measles or chicken pox. However, it is spread the same way as flu, though direct contact with saliva, coughing, sneezing, and kissing. Encounters under the mistletoe during the festive season might be best avoided. Dr Emerson advised anyone with mumps to treat the symptoms. Earlier this year [2012], St. George's football team was hit, as 5 players contracted the virus.\n\nAnecdotal reports received at Isle of Man newspapers suggest a number of school classes and workplaces have been affected. Mumps is a serious infection which can cause deafness, among other problems. The MMR vaccine is the best way to prevent mumps. It should be routinely given when children are 12 months old, and a 2nd dose should be given when they are 3 years 4 months old.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Isle of Man is a self-governing British Crown Dependency; it is neither part of the United Kingdom nor the European Union, although its foreign relations and defense are the responsibility of the United Kingdom government. The island is 33 miles (52 km) long and 13 miles (22 km) wide and is located in the middle of the northern Irish Sea, between Great Britain and the Republic of Ireland. A map of the Isle of Man can be accessed at: http://www.gov.im/infocentre/townstreetMaps/StreetMap.aspx.\n\nThe population of the Isle of Man in 2011 was 83 327, so the more than 196 cases of mumps represents an unusually large outbreak of the disease. Dr Emerson's admonition that: 'Encounters under the mistletoe during the festive season might be best be avoided' could be construed as a travel alert. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1G16.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe population of the Isle of Man in 2011 was 83 327, so the more than 196 cases of mumps represents an unusually large outbreak of the disease. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n< It should be routinely given when children are 12 months old, and a 2nd dose should be given when they are 3 years 4 months old. Until the end of November 2012, the island had seen 196 cases so far this year [2012]. \n\n--\n \n\n\nThe viral disease mumps has taken hold among a generation of people who weren't vaccinated after the MMR autism scare in the 1990s. The island is 33 miles (52 km) long and 13 miles (22 km) wide and is located in the middle of the northern Irish Sea, between Great Britain and the Republic of Ireland. \n\nAnecdotal reports received at Isle of Man newspapers suggest a number of school classes and workplaces have been affected. CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1G16.] Date: Fri 14 Dec 2012\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-12-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:20", "1970-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wakefield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Great Britain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "St. George 's", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1491581", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Pakistan: (SD), fatalities, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1491581", "date": "2013-01-10 20:37:37", "main_text": "MUMPS - PAKISTAN: (SINDH), FATALITIES, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 10 Jan 2013\nSource: Milenio, EFE Agency report [in Spanish, machine trans., summ., edited]\nhttp://www.milenio.com/cdb/doc/noticias2011/58e132e4827a63012a2ed82bbc081e0c\n\n\nMore than 100 children have died in the province of Sindh in the south of Pakistan, after an outbreak of mumps was declared a month ago and today [10 Jan 2013] many experts attributed it to the poor vaccination policy of the authorities, which did not reach the necessary population to prevent the spread of the disease. 'When there is a large group of unimmunized children it is very easy to see an outbreak such as this one,' Dr Buttha Tariq, Unicef responsible for immunization in neighboring Punjab province, told EFE news agency, adding that mumps 'is one of the most contagious diseases and it spreads very quickly.'\n\n'The outbreak was declared at the beginning of last month [December 2012]; just during that month about 90 children died, and in January [2013] we've had 14 deaths already,' said Dr Suresh Kumar of the Sindh Provincial Health Ministry.\n\nKumar added that a vaccination campaign that aims to reach more than 3 million children aged between 6 months and 12 years was launched months ago, and he hopes the outbreak [will be contained] by immunisation and greater awareness of parents. Kumar, like other experts consulted, said that the affected area, close to the river Indus, has been badly hit by flooding in the past 3 years, which has worsened the living conditions of many households. 'Many lost their homes and now live with other families crammed into small houses with limited resources, which is an ideal breeding ground for infections such as mumps,' said Kumar.\n\nA spokeswoman for the World Health Organization (WHO), Maryam Yunus, also recalled that child malnutrition is directly related to the risk of mumps virus infection and its effects are greater. 'Many of the people displaced by the floods are malnourished,' she said, adding that most deaths of affected children occur from complications such as pneumonia or diarrhea. 'Pneumonia is the most common complication and that which causes most deaths,' said Buttha.\n\nThe experts agreed that now it is important to focus on the treatment of those affected (in December there were at least 2500 cases, according to official figures) with antibiotics and vitamins to improve the immune system of sick children.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a viral illness caused by a paramyxovirus of the genus _Rubulavirus_. The classic symptoms of mumps include parotitis in about 50 percent of the cases, either unilateral or bilateral, which develops an average of 16 to 18 days after exposure. Swelling can also be seen in the submandibular and sublingual gland in a small percentage. Nonspecific symptoms including myalgia, anorexia, malaise, headache, and low-grade fever may precede parotitis by several days. As many as 40-50 percent of mumps infections are associated with nonspecific or primarily respiratory symptoms, particularly among children less than 5 years of age. Only 30-40 percent of mumps infections produce typical acute parotitis. In 15-20 percent of infections, cases are asymptomatic. The average incubation period for mumps is 16-18 days, with a range of 12-25 days. Fever may persist for 3-4 days and parotitis, when present, usually lasts 7-10 days. Persons with mumps are usually considered most infectious from 1-2 days before until 5 days after onset of parotitis. Outbreaks of mumps accompanied by high mortality are rare and not usually associated with outcomes such as pneumonia and gastroenteritis. Further information would be appreciated.\n\nHowever, mumps can cause acquired sensorineural hearing loss in children; incidence is estimated at 1 in 20 000 cases. Mumps-associated encephalitis occurs in less than 2 per 100 000 cases and approximately 1 percent of encephalitis cases are fatal. Some complications of mumps are known to occur more frequently among adults than among children. Adults have a higher risk for mumps meningoencephalitis than children. In addition, orchitis occurs in up to 30-40 percent of cases in post pubertal males. Although it is frequently bilateral, it rarely causes sterility. Mastitis has been reported in as many as 31 percent of female patients older than 15 years who have mumps. Other rare complications of mumps are oophoritis and pancreatitis. Aseptic meningitis occurs in 10 percent of cases and is associated with a good prognosis. Although mumps infection in the 1st trimester of pregnancy may result in fetal loss, there is no evidence that mumps during pregnancy causes congenital malformations. The long-term effects of mumps virus infection such as paralysis, seizures, etc., are very rare.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail of Pakistan can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/2NT8. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "\n\n\nMore than 100 children have died in the province of Sindh in the south of Pakistan, after an outbreak of mumps was declared a month ago and today [10 Jan 2013] many experts attributed it to the poor vaccination policy of the authorities, which did not reach the necessary population to prevent the spread of the disease. ' A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The classic symptoms of mumps include parotitis in about 50 percent of the cases, either unilateral or bilateral, which develops an average of 16 to 18 days after exposure. Mumps-associated encephalitis occurs in less than 2 per 100 000 cases and approximately 1 percent of encephalitis cases are fatal. As many as 40-50 percent of mumps infections are associated with nonspecific or primarily respiratory symptoms, particularly among children less than 5 years of age. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a viral illness caused by a paramyxovirus of the genus _Rubulavirus_. \n\nKumar added that a vaccination campaign that aims to reach more than 3 million children aged between 6 months and 12 years was launched months ago, and he hopes the outbreak [will be contained] by immunisation and greater awareness of parents. Although mumps infection in the 1st trimester of pregnancy may result in fetal loss, there is no evidence that mumps during pregnancy causes congenital malformations. Persons with mumps are usually considered most infectious from 1-2 days before until 5 days after onset of parotitis. However, mumps can cause acquired sensorineural hearing loss in children; incidence is estimated at 1 in 20 000 cases. When there is a large group of unimmunized children it is very easy to see an outbreak such as this one,' Dr Buttha Tariq, Unicef responsible for immunization in neighboring Punjab province, told EFE news agency, adding that mumps 'is one of the most contagious diseases and it spreads very quickly.' \n\n'The outbreak was declared at the beginning of last month [December 2012]; just during that month about 90 children died, and in January [2013] we've had 14 deaths already,' said Dr Suresh Kumar of the Sindh Provincial Health Ministry. \n\nThe experts agreed that now it is important to focus on the treatment of those affected (in December there were at least 2500 cases, according to official figures) with antibiotics and vitamins to improve the immune system of sick children.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2013-01-10 00:00:00", "2021-12-25 00:00:00", "2012-12-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Indus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Milenio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Buttha", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1441071", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, 2011 - USA: (CA) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1441071", "date": "2012-12-06 18:24:58", "main_text": "MUMPS, 2011 - USA: (CALIFORNIA), UNIVERSITY STUDENTS\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 7 Dec 2012\nSource: MMWR Weekly, Volume 61, No. 48 ;986-989 [abbreviated & edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6148a2.htm?s_cid=mm6148a2_e\n\n\nMumps is a vaccine-preventable viral disease characterized by swelling of the salivary glands; serious complications (e.g., meningitis, encephalitis, orchitis, or oophoritis) can occur. On 29 Sep 2011, the California Department of Public Health (CDPH) confirmed by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) 3 cases of mumps among students recently evaluated at their university's student health services with symptoms suggestive of mumps. An investigation by CDPH, student health services, and the local health department identified 29 mumps cases. The presumed source patient was an unvaccinated student with a history of recent travel to Western Europe, where mumps is circulating. The student had mumps symptoms over 28 days before the onset of symptoms among the patients confirmed on 29 Sep 2011. Recognizing that at least 2 generations of transmission had occurred before public health authorities were alerted, measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine was provided as a control measure. This outbreak demonstrates the potential value of requiring MMR vaccination (including documentation of immunization or other evidence of immunity) before college enrollment, heightened clinical awareness, and timely reporting of suspected mumps patients to public health authorities [see also the ProMED-mail reports listed below. - Mod.CP].\n\nOn 25 Aug 2011, the presumed source patient, an unvaccinated male aged 21 years, arrived at the university's student health services with fever and unilateral facial and jaw swelling. The initial diagnosis was cellulitis, and antibiotics were prescribed. By day 6 after symptom onset, the patient complained of testicular pain, and mumps was suspected. He had not been vaccinated against mumps and had traveled to Western Europe during the exposure period. He was referred for mumps serological testing, but did not follow through. His illness was not reported to the local health department when mumps was suspected. Approximately 3 weeks later, a 2nd student, the source patient's roommate, was treated at student health services for fatigue and unilateral pain and swelling of the jaw and neck. This patient, a male aged 21 years with a history of receiving 2 doses of MMR vaccine, received a diagnosis of parotitis. Mumps serologies were drawn, and he was advised to isolate himself in his room for 5 days. Mumps immunoglobulin M (IgM) testing was negative, and immunoglobulin G testing was positive, a pattern that does not rule out acute mumps because the ability to detect IgM is poor in vaccine recipients. The local health department was not notified. When 3 subsequent cases of mumps were confirmed by PCR on 29 Sep 2011 at CDPH, an investigation was initiated.\n\nDuring the outbreak period (25 Aug 2011-7 Jan 2012), investigators identified 29 cases that met the Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists 2010 case definition of mumps.* The outbreak period extended from the symptom onset date of the source patient through 2 incubation periods after the symptom onset of the last laboratory-confirmed case. The average incubation period for mumps is 16-18 days (range: 12-25 days); thus, the timing of the 1st 5 patients indicated that at least 2 generations of transmission had occurred by the time public health was notified. Case-finding activities included notifying health-care providers serving the affected community, requesting PCR testing for persons with clinically compatible symptoms, and alerting adjacent local health departments to notify CDPH of suspected mumps cases.\n\nAll patients had epidemiologic links to the university: 27 (93 percent) were students; one was a close contact of a student, and one was a public health staff member who assisted during a mumps vaccination clinic. Among the 29 cases, 13 (45 percent) were laboratory confirmed by PCR; one was confirmed by the presence of mumps IgM, and the remainder were confirmed on the basis of symptoms clinically compatible with mumps together with epidemiologic links to the university. Of the epidemiologically linked cases, 11 were negative and 4 were not tested by PCR. All viral specimens were genotype G, the predominant mumps genotype circulating in Western Europe. Eight patients (28 percent), including the source patient, were students who participated in organized sports. Four of the 1st 5 patients resided in congregate housing, and 17 (59 percent) illnesses occurred among students living in congregate housing. Among the 29 cases, 22 (76 percent) mumps illnesses occurred among persons previously vaccinated with the recommended 2 doses of MMR vaccine.\n\nCDC recommendations for mumps outbreak control include defining the at-risk population and transmission setting, and rapidly identifying and vaccinating persons without presumptive evidence of immunity (1). Other recommended control measures include cough etiquette, respiratory and hand hygiene, and isolation of infectious patients for 5 days. Early in the outbreak, the university arranged alternate housing to isolate infectious patients who resided in congregate housing; however, as the number of patients increased, this became less feasible. Students were encouraged to monitor themselves for mumps symptoms, and symptomatic students were encouraged to go to student health services for testing.\n\nOf approximately 36 000 students enrolled at the university; an estimated 9300 reside in housing owned by, operated by, or affiliated with the university. Recognizing that at least 2 generations of transmission had occurred before public health authorities were alerted to this outbreak, and wanting to avert a larger outbreak, the local health department and the university, in consultation with CDPH and CDC, decided to provide MMR vaccine as a control measure. The university recommends that matriculating students receive 2 doses of MMR vaccine but does not require proof of MMR vaccination before matriculation, making student vaccination status difficult to assess. Therefore, messages sent to the university community advised that an additional dose of MMR vaccine, irrespective of previous MMR vaccination status, was recommended for all university community members, with an emphasis on those residing in congregate housing. Beginning one week after the local health department was alerted, 5 vaccination clinics were held during a 4-week period; a total of 3631 persons received a dose of MMR vaccine.\n\nMMWR Editorial Note:\n\nThis outbreak demonstrates that even persons who have received 2 doses of mumps vaccine might not be protected against mumps and highlights the importance of heightened clinical awareness and timely reporting of suspected mumps cases to public health authorities (2). The effectiveness of MMR vaccine to prevent mumps has been estimated at medians of 78 percent (range: 49-91 percent) for one dose and 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) for 2 doses (3). Despite a substantial decline in U.S. mumps cases since mumps vaccine licensure in 1967, large mumps outbreaks have occurred in recent years among vaccinated populations. The World Health Organization indicates that only 62 percent of countries use mumps vaccine in national programs. Although MMR vaccine is included in national programs in Europe, MMR vaccination rates declined in many European countries over the last decade because of vaccine safety concerns, and outbreaks of measles and mumps have occurred. Public colleges and universities in 22 states and the District of Columbia require that enrolling students provide documentation that they have received 2 doses of MMR vaccine.\n\nAlthough mumps outbreaks have occurred in populations in which many persons have received 2 doses of MMR vaccine, prematriculation MMR vaccination might prevent the introduction of mumps and limit its spread if it is introduced into a university setting. In this outbreak, the suspected source patient was unvaccinated, and the outbreak might have been prevented if a prematriculation requirement had been in place. Documentation of MMR vaccination also can allow public health officials to rapidly assess the mumps vaccination status of exposed students and prioritize vaccination efforts.\n\nRecognition and prompt reporting of clinically suspected mumps, even in the absence of laboratory confirmation, facilitates early implementation of control measures and can mitigate outbreaks. Reliable identification of mumps infections can be difficult; PCR testing is preferred when testing previously vaccinated persons. Control measures for mumps are limited. Neither MMR vaccine nor immune globulin is effective as postexposure prophylaxis; however, in an outbreak setting, MMR vaccine might reduce transmission to susceptible persons not yet exposed to the mumps virus.\n\nEven though a population might be highly vaccinated, some persons who have received 2 doses of MMR vaccine still will be susceptible. Data collected during previous mumps outbreaks on college campuses indicate that extended person-to-person contact, in combination with waning vaccine-induced immunity, might make colleges and universities high-risk settings for outbreaks, even when 2-dose MMR vaccination coverage is high. In addition, patients are infectious before onset of parotitis, and asymptomatic persons can transmit disease. Isolation of patients for 5 days after parotitis onset and monitoring of contacts for symptoms are primary control measures. However, even strict isolation of reported patients is unlikely to completely interrupt disease transmission. CDC has evaluated use of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine for mumps outbreak control during 2 previous mumps outbreaks in which transmission was sustained despite high 2-dose coverage. During both outbreaks, targeted vaccination was followed by a decrease in mumps incidence among the target group. Available data are insufficient to recommend for or against the use of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine for mumps outbreak control. Because control measures for mumps are limited, the ability to offer a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine might be a tool that could be used in an attempt to limit the extent of mumps outbreaks, particularly in high-risk settings.\n\nColleges and universities should consider implementing prematriculation immunization requirements similar to those recommended by the American College Health Association, including ensuring that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of MMR vaccine. Public health officials should be aware of disclosure limitations under FERPA and how these might impact communicable disease reporting requirements and timely investigation of outbreaks. Clinicians should be diligent about reporting suspected cases of mumps to local health departments, and PCR testing should be performed for vaccinated persons with suspected mumps. More data are needed regarding the effectiveness of the use of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine to control outbreaks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This mumps outbreak occurred at a university that did not require proof of MMR vaccination of students before enrollment. The presumed source patient was an unvaccinated student who had recently returned from Western Europe, where mumps was circulating. Among the 29 cases, 22 (76 percent) mumps illnesses occurred among persons previously vaccinated with the recommended 2 doses of MMR vaccine. This outbreak demonstrates that even persons who have received 2 doses of mumps vaccine might not be protected against mumps and highlights the importance of heightened clinical awareness and timely reporting of suspected mumps cases to public health authorities.\n\nReliable identification of mumps infections can be difficult; PCR testing is preferred when testing previously vaccinated persons. Control measures for mumps are limited. Neither MMR vaccine nor immune globulin is effective as postexposure prophylaxis; however, in an outbreak setting, MMR vaccine might reduce transmission to susceptible persons not yet exposed to the mumps virus.\n\nColleges and universities should consider implementing prematriculation immunization requirements similar to those recommended by the American College Health Association, including ensuring that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of MMR vaccine.\n\nInterested readers should consult the original text via the source URL to view the figure, tabulated data and references. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hcv.]", "summary": "\n\nMMWR Editorial Note:\n\nThis outbreak demonstrates that even persons who have received 2 doses of mumps vaccine might not be protected against mumps and highlights the importance of heightened clinical awareness and timely reporting of suspected mumps cases to public health authorities (2). This outbreak demonstrates that even persons who have received 2 doses of mumps vaccine might not be protected against mumps and highlights the importance of heightened clinical awareness and timely reporting of suspected mumps cases to public health authorities. \n\nAlthough mumps outbreaks have occurred in populations in which many persons have received 2 doses of MMR vaccine, prematriculation MMR vaccination might prevent the introduction of mumps and limit its spread if it is introduced into a university setting. CDC has evaluated use of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine for mumps outbreak control during 2 previous mumps outbreaks in which transmission was sustained despite high 2-dose coverage. On 29 Sep 2011, the California Department of Public Health (CDPH) confirmed by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) 3 cases of mumps among students recently evaluated at their university's student health services with symptoms suggestive of mumps. Despite a substantial decline in U.S. mumps cases since mumps vaccine licensure in 1967, large mumps outbreaks have occurred in recent years among vaccinated populations. Clinicians should be diligent about reporting suspected cases of mumps to local health departments, and PCR testing should be performed for vaccinated persons with suspected mumps. Recognizing that at least 2 generations of transmission had occurred before public health authorities were alerted to this outbreak, and wanting to avert a larger outbreak, the local health department and the university, in consultation with CDPH and CDC, decided to provide MMR vaccine as a control measure. Because control measures for mumps are limited, the ability to offer a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine might be a tool that could be used in an attempt to limit the extent of mumps outbreaks, particularly in high-risk settings. Among the 29 cases, 13 (45 percent) were laboratory confirmed by PCR; one was confirmed by the presence of mumps IgM, and the remainder were confirmed on the basis of symptoms clinically compatible with mumps together with epidemiologic links to the university. Among the 29 cases, 22 (76 percent) mumps illnesses occurred among persons previously vaccinated with the recommended 2 doses of MMR vaccine. Among the 29 cases, 22 (76 percent) mumps illnesses occurred among persons previously vaccinated with the recommended 2 doses of MMR vaccine. The average incubation period for mumps is 16-18 days (range: 12-25 days); thus, the timing of the 1st 5 patients indicated that at least 2 generations of transmission had occurred by the time public health was notified. An investigation by CDPH, student health services, and the local health department identified 29 mumps cases. \n\nColleges and universities should consider implementing prematriculation immunization requirements similar to those recommended by the American College Health Association, including ensuring that students have documented receipt of 2 doses of MMR vaccine.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2011-09-29 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-08-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1441128", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Spain (06): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1441128", "date": "2012-12-06 18:31:09", "main_text": "MUMPS - SPAIN (06): (ASTURIAS)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 6 Dec 2012\nSource: El Comercio [in Spanish, machine trans. edited]\nhttp://www.elcomercio.es/v/20121206/asturias/salud-detecta-brote-paperas-20121206.htmlomersio\n\n\nA mumps outbreak in Asturias was confirmed yesterday [5 Dec 2012] after the Health Department indicated that 150 cases had been diagnosed in recent weeks. This is the 3rd outbreak occurring in the region in the last decade. Epidemiological Surveillance experts relate it to the ease of transmission of the disease in which 1/3rd of the infections are so mild that there is no warning of an outbreak.\n\nMost of the patients are male, aged between 15 and 34 years. Langreo is the area with the largest number of detected cases, but the outbreak has spread to Gijon, Oviedo, and Aviles. Although much of the population is vaccinated, the Health Ministry stated yesterday [5 Dec 2012] that the virus spreads easily because the vaccine is not 100 percent effective, and occasionally there can be an abrupt increase in the number of cases. One of the outbreaks was centered in the faculty of biology at Oviedo, where several of the students contracted the disease, spreading alarm among their fellow students.\n\nThe Directorate General of Public Health recommends that patients do not go to school or work until 4 days after the onset of symptoms. The Director General also advises those under 35 who have not been vaccinated previously to go to their health center to be vaccinated.\n\nMumps can cause major complications, particularly in men, in whom complications can result in sterility if not properly treated.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks of mumps have been frequent throughout Spain in recent years. The symptoms of mumps usually develop 14 to 25 days after a person is infected with mumps virus. The average incubation period is around 17 days. Swelling of the parotid glands is the most common symptom of mumps. Both glands are usually affected by the swelling, although only one gland can be affected. The swelling can cause pain, tenderness, and difficulty with swallowing. Other symptoms of the mumps include: headache, joint pain, sickness, abdominal pain and fever.\n\nMumps is spread in the same way as colds and flu: inside infected droplets of saliva that can be inhaled or picked up from surfaces and passed into the mouth or nose. A person is most contagious 1-2 days before the onset of symptoms and for 5 days afterwards. During this time, it is important to try to prevent spreading the infection to others, particularly teenagers and young adults who have not been vaccinated. Normally, infection resolves without complications and provides life-long immunity.\n\nFor unvaccinated persons born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should consider vaccinating these individuals with 2 doses of MMR vaccine at the appropriate interval (for measles and mumps) and one dose of MMR vaccine (for rubella), respectively. For unvaccinated personnel born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should recommend 2 doses of MMR vaccine during an outbreak of measles or mumps and one dose during an outbreak of rubella.\n\nTwo doses of mumps vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective at preventing the disease; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49-92 percent) effective. The 1st vaccine against mumps was licensed in the United States in 1967, and by 2005, high 2-dose childhood vaccination coverage reduced disease rates by 99 percent. Adults at higher risk, such as university students, health care personnel, and international travelers, and persons with potential mumps outbreak exposure should ensure that they have been vaccinated. (Further information can be obtained from the USCDC website (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/mumps.html#vaccines).\n\nAsturias, officially the Principality of Asturias, is an autonomous community of Spain. It is coextensive with the province of Asturias and contains nearly all of the territory that was part of the former Kingdom of Asturias. The autonomous community of Asturias is bordered by Cantabria to the east, by Castile and Leon to the south, by Galicia to the west, and by the Bay of Biscay to the north.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap of Asturias can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1mjx. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "For unvaccinated personnel born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should recommend 2 doses of MMR vaccine during an outbreak of measles or mumps and one dose during an outbreak of rubella. For unvaccinated persons born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should consider vaccinating these individuals with 2 doses of MMR vaccine at the appropriate interval (for measles and mumps) and one dose of MMR vaccine (for rubella), respectively. \n\nTwo doses of mumps vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective at preventing the disease; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49-92 percent) effective. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The 1st vaccine against mumps was licensed in the United States in 1967, and by 2005, high 2-dose childhood vaccination coverage reduced disease rates by 99 percent. The symptoms of mumps usually develop 14 to 25 days after a person is infected with mumps virus. Although much of the population is vaccinated, the Health Ministry stated yesterday [5 Dec 2012] that the virus spreads easily because the vaccine is not 100 percent effective, and occasionally there can be an abrupt increase in the number of cases. Adults at higher risk, such as university students, health care personnel, and international travelers, and persons with potential mumps outbreak exposure should ensure that they have been vaccinated. \n\n\nA mumps outbreak in Asturias was confirmed yesterday [5 Dec 2012] after the Health Department indicated that 150 cases had been diagnosed in recent weeks. \n\nMumps is spread in the same way as colds and flu: inside infected droplets of saliva that can be inhaled or picked up from surfaces and passed into the mouth or nose. \n\nMumps can cause major complications, particularly in men, in whom complications can result in sterility if not properly treated. MUMPS - SPAIN (06): (ASTURIAS)\n******************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oviedo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gijon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Asturias", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cantabria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MUMPS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1419241", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Spain (05): (PA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1419241", "date": "2012-11-21 18:43:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - SPAIN (05): (PALENCIA)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 20 Nov 2012\nSource: ABC.es [In Spanish, machine transl., edited]\nhttp://www.abc.es/local-castilla-leon/20121120/abci-brote-paperas-palencia-vacunas-201211201742.html\n\n\nMumps outbreak in Palencia affects children and youths\n------------------------------------------------------\nThe Epidemiological Surveillance Service of the Junta de Castilla y Leon has reported that an epidemic of mumps affecting children and adolescents which commenced in the spring has continued to developed and is forcing a reexamination of the organisation of vaccination in schools.\n\nAccording to information provided by the regional government, the clinical symptoms of mumps are acute inflammation of unilateral of bilateral parotid glands, fever and malaise. Local reports indicate that none of those affected in Palencia required hospitalisation and all are recovering well.\n\nThe regional Health Service has stated that in order to further interrupt virus transmission among children and juveniles it will become necessary to review the vaccination status of contacts of the patients, both in school and in the family setting.\n\nLikewise the appearance of cases of mumps in particular schools will require review of the vaccination status of all classmates of each affected child in particular schools and where appropriate carry out vaccination. Similar measures are recommended for the family members and social contacts of affected cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the absence of numbers, it is difficult to evaluate this situation. The persistence of mumps virus infection in a vaccinated, or perhaps partially vaccinated, population may be a reflection of the lesser immunising efficiency of the mumps component of the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) triple vaccine. Further information would be appreciated regarding the prevalence of measles virus infection in this community, which might reveal gaps in immunisation coverage.\n\nPalencia is the capital of the province of Palencia in the autonomous community of Castille and Leon, Spain. The Junta de Castilla y Leon is the governing body and administration of Castilla y Leon and exercises executive and regulatory power. Likewise the appearance of cases of mumps in particular schools will require review of the vaccination status of all classmates of each affected child in particular schools and where appropriate carry out vaccination. MUMPS - SPAIN (05): (PALENCIA)\n******************************\n The Epidemiological Surveillance Service of the Junta de Castilla y Leon has reported that an epidemic of mumps affecting children and adolescents which commenced in the spring has continued to developed and is forcing a reexamination of the organisation of vaccination in schools. The number of cases reported as of Monday [8 Oct 2012] is 583; this is up from 157 cases reported just one week earlier.\n\nDespite the surge in mumps cases, a spokesman for the Education Ministry said that no schools have been closed due to the outbreak.\n\nAccording to the report, Giza Governorate has so far reported the most number of cases, with 240. Minya has reported 95, Beni Suef 48, and Fayoum 38, with Cairo reporting only 12.\n\nLast week, Health Ministry undersecretary Amr Qandil projected rising numbers of mumps cases this winter season, but assured it would not be a public health emergency.\n\nMumps is also an acute viral disease that is characterized by fever and swelling and tenderness in one or more of the salivary glands. Maximum infectiousness occurs between 2 days prior to onset of illness to 4 days afterwards. It is spread from person-to-person by respiratory droplets (for example, when you sneeze) or by direct contact with items that have been contaminated with infected saliva.\n\nComplications to mumps may include: orchitis (which has been reported to be a risk factor for testicular cancer), encephalitis and spontaneous abortion. Sterility in males is a rare possible outcome.\n\nMumps can be prevented with vaccination. Two doses of mumps vaccine are 88 per cent (range: 66-95 per cent) effective at preventing the disease; one dose is 78 per cent (range: 49-92 per cent) effective.\n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Just 7 days ago more than 100 cases of mumps were reported in Qena governorate. Now 583 cases have been reported from 5 other governorates. Giza Governorate has so far reported the most case with 240, followed by Minya with 95, Beni Suef with 48, Fayoum with 38, and Cairo with only 12.\n\nPreviously the outbreak in Qena governate was attributed to an interruption in the supply of MMR vaccine. It would seem that the vaccine shortage extends country-wide. If so, a corresponding increase in the prevalence of measles virus infection would be expected also.\n\nA map of the locations of the governorates of Egypt can be accessed at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governorates_of_Egypt. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zkM.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Two doses of mumps vaccine are 88 per cent (range: 66-95 per cent) effective at preventing the disease; one dose is 78 per cent (range: 49-92 per cent) effective. The number of cases reported as of Monday [8 Oct 2012] is 583; this is up from 157 cases reported just one week earlier. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Just 7 days ago more than 100 cases of mumps were reported in Qena governorate. \nAn outbreak of the viral infection, mumps, has spread through schools nationwide in Egypt, according to an Egypt Independent report on Mon 8 Oct 2012. \n\nLast week, Health Ministry undersecretary Amr Qandil projected rising numbers of mumps cases this winter season, but assured it would not be a public health emergency. \n\nComplications to mumps may include: orchitis (which has been reported to be a risk factor for testicular cancer), encephalitis and spontaneous abortion. \n\nMumps is also an acute viral disease that is characterized by fever and swelling and tenderness in one or more of the salivary glands.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2048-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2038-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fayoum", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Qena", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1320324", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Egypt: vaccine shortage", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1320324", "date": "2012-10-02 16:18:45", "main_text": "MUMPS - EGYPT: VACCINE SHORTAGE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 1 Oct 2012\nSource: The Disease Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.healthmap.org/news/over-100-egyptian-children-face-mumps-outbreak-10112\n\n\nEgyptian Children Face Mumps Outbreak\n-------------------------------------\nMore than 100 children have been affected by a mumps outbreak in Marashda [official name Al Mar\u0101shidah located in Qina governorate], Egypt, with 43 cases and 70 infections reported. Officials at the Ministry of Health insist that this is not a serious outbreak. However, many children are not attending school out of fear of infection.\n\nMumps is caused by mumps virus and is spread when a person comes into contact with infected droplets of saliva or mucus, usually through coughing, sneezing, or sharing dishes. Symptoms of the disease include fever, headache, and fatigue, along with serious complications such as inflammation of the brain and deafness.\n\nEgyptian officials are working to provide treatment for infected youth. However, vaccination is considered the best strategy for avoiding mumps infection. The vaccination for mumps is a combination vaccine for measles, mumps, and rubella, (MMR). It is recommended that children receive 2 doses: one at age 12-15 months and another at age 4-6 years. The 1st MMR vaccine became available in 1967 and has reduced mumps prevalence by 99 percent.\n\nThis outbreak has occurred alongside news that Egypt is facing a nationwide vaccine shortage. Administrative delays have prevented the health ministry from replacing expired vaccines. While vaccines are available in private clinics, their costs make them unattainable to most patients. 'The longer the government fails to immunize these children, the more vulnerable to disease they are,' explained Eman Masoud, head of the Pediatrics Section at Abul Riesh University Hospital in Cairo.\n\nExperts recommend that people experiencing symptoms of mumps contact a provider immediately and avoid situations where they might infect others, such as in a clinic waiting room.\n\n[Byline: Lauren Edmundson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is likely that this large outbreak of mumps virus infection is a consequence of disruption of the routine programme of immunisation of children with the combined MMR (mumps, measles and rubella) vaccine due to a temporary shortage of vaccine in Egypt.\n\nMumps virus was isolated in 1945, and an inactivated vaccine was developed in 1948. This vaccine produced only short-lasting immunity, and its use was discontinued in the mid-1970s. Most vaccines contain the Jeryl Lynn strain of live attenuated mumps virus vaccine. Mumps vaccine produces an inapparent, or mild, noncommunicable infection. More than 97 percent of recipients of a single dose develop measurable antibody. Seroconversion rates are similar for single antigen mumps vaccine or the combined MMR vaccine. A study in the United Kingdom documented vaccine effectiveness of 88 percent with 2 doses. The duration of vaccine-induced immunity is believed to be greater than 25 years, and is probably lifelong in most vaccine recipients. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3BOS.]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is likely that this large outbreak of mumps virus infection is a consequence of disruption of the routine programme of immunisation of children with the combined MMR (mumps, measles and rubella) vaccine due to a temporary shortage of vaccine in Egypt. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nMumps is caused by mumps virus and is spread when a person comes into contact with infected droplets of saliva or mucus, usually through coughing, sneezing, or sharing dishes. Seroconversion rates are similar for single antigen mumps vaccine or the combined MMR vaccine. \n\nMumps virus was isolated in 1945, and an inactivated vaccine was developed in 1948. \nMore than 100 children have been affected by a mumps outbreak in Marashda [official name Al Mar\u0101shidah located in Qina governorate], Egypt, with 43 cases and 70 infections reported. The vaccination for mumps is a combination vaccine for measles, mumps, and rubella, (MMR). The duration of vaccine-induced immunity is believed to be greater than 25 years, and is probably lifelong in most vaccine recipients. MUMPS - EGYPT: VACCINE SHORTAGE\n****************************** Most vaccines contain the Jeryl Lynn strain of live attenuated mumps virus vaccine.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1945-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "1948-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Qina", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1192457", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Australia: (QL) Gold Coast, adult", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1192457", "date": "2012-07-06 13:44:57", "main_text": "MUMPS - AUSTRALIA: (QUEENSLAND) GOLD COAST, ADULT\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 6 Jul 2012\nSource: News Gold Coast [edited]\nhttp://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2012/07/06/429701_gold-coast-news.html\n\n\nGold Coast doctors say a lack of immunisation boosters could be behind an outbreak of mumps in the city. The extremely contagious disease has struck many adults on the coast and anyone with symptoms is warned to have minimal contact with others. Symptoms include swollen and painful glands, fatigue, and fever.\n\nGold Coast Medical Association president Dr Peter McLaren said it was rare to see mumps in adults. 'It is usually something contracted as a child and can be quite harmful to adults, especially males,' he said. 'Adult men can experience painful swelling in their groin region and this can cause fertility problems.' Dr McLaren said an increasing lack of faith in immunisation meant diseases were spread more easily. 'When someone is immunised it is much harder for them to contract a disease,' he said. 'Many of the adults with mumps may have been immunised but the immunity lessens after so many years. Booster shots can be given but it is up to the individual.'\n\nThose diagnosed with mumps will not show symptoms until about a week after contracting the virus. They are advised to stay away from non-infected people for 5 to 9 days after swelling begins. In rare cases, no symptoms are apparent and a blood test is needed for diagnosis. Anyone with swelling around the jawline, neck, and behind the ears is encouraged to see their doctor.\n\n[byline: Jessica Elder]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report gives no indication of the scale of this outbreak, or any other precise information other than that children appear not to be involved.\n\nMumps typically starts with a few days of fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, and is followed by swelling of salivary glands. Anyone who is not immune from either previous mumps infection or from vaccination can get mumps. Mumps infection is most often confused with swelling of the lymph nodes of the neck. Lymph node swelling can be differentiated by the well-defined borders of the lymph nodes, their location behind the angle of the jawbone, and lack of the ear protrusion or obscuring of the angle of the jaw, which are characteristics of mumps. In 50-60 per cent of cases of clinical mumps, cerebrospinal fluid pleocytosis occurs. However, clinical evidence of meningitis or encephalitis appears in less than 10 per cent of patients with mumps. Serious sequelae are rare. For example, deafness after mumps occurs in 0.5 to 5 per 100 000 cases. Death occurs in less than 2 per cent of mumps encephalitis cases.\n\nOrchitis occurs in about 25 per cent of adolescent and adult males with mumps and is rare in prepubescent males. One or both testes may be involved, with lower abdominal pain, fever, and chills, and possibly epididymitis. The involved testis and adjacent skin become swollen and red. Orchitis occurs within one week of parotitis and usually lasts 4 days. Infertility is rare even when both testes are involved. Oophoritis occurs in 5 per cent of post pubertal females with mumps and is characterized by pelvic pain and tenderness. Infertility generally does not occur. Mastitis may also occur. Less common complications of mumps infection include pancreatitis, myocarditis, arthritis, thyroiditis, deafness, and spontaneous abortion (see http://www.cdc.gov/mumps/clinical/qa-physical-complic.html).\n\nThe HealthMap interactive map of the Australian state of Queensland, showing the location of Gold Coast city, can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1kAX. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n[byline: Jessica Elder]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nOrchitis occurs in about 25 per cent of adolescent and adult males with mumps and is rare in prepubescent males. \n\nMumps typically starts with a few days of fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, and is followed by swelling of salivary glands. Lymph node swelling can be differentiated by the well-defined borders of the lymph nodes, their location behind the angle of the jawbone, and lack of the ear protrusion or obscuring of the angle of the jaw, which are characteristics of mumps. \n\nGold Coast Medical Association president Dr Peter McLaren said it was rare to see mumps in adults.
