Death occurs in less than 2 per cent of mumps encephalitis cases.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "GOLD coast", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1176218", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Spain (03): (Catalonia) Girona", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1176218", "date": "2012-06-21 19:20:42", "main_text": "MUMPS - SPAIN (03): (CATALONIA), GIRONA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 21 Jun 2012\nSource: Vanguardia.com Girona [in Spanish, machine trans. edited]\nhttp://www.lavanguardia.com/local/girona/20120620/54314548761/paperas-brote-girona.html\n\n\nThe mumps outbreak that has affected the surrounding region since the 2nd half of December [2011] has entered its final stage. The official responsible for epidemiological surveillance in Girona, Neus Camps, explained that there has been no case since late May 2012 and, therefore, the outbreak is expected to terminate in late June 2012.\n\nIn total, 148 people have been affected, of whom only 3 have had complications that resulted in hospitalisation. Experts point out that vaccination is essential to prevent outbreaks of communicable diseases. This year [2012], nearly 7000 young people between 16 and 19 years of age whose vaccination status was inadequate will have been revaccinated with MMR vaccine.\n\nA group of people from Girona at the end of the year [2011] traveled to an area of the country where mumps virus infection was prevalent. When they returned home, 5 members of the group fell ill a few days after their return. Medical tests diagnosed mumps, a disease that causes a very characteristic swelling of glands located under each cheek. No specific treatment for mumps is available. Vaccination is the best protection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps spreads from person to person via droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks. The virus may also be spread indirectly when someone with mumps touches items or surfaces without washing their hands and then someone else touches the same surface and rubs their mouth or nose. However, mumps is less contagious than measles or chickenpox. The incubation period of mumps is usually 16 to 18 days but can range from 12 to 25 days. Individuals with mumps usually 1st feel sick with nonspecific symptoms like headache, loss of appetite, and low-grade fever.\n\nThe most well-known sign of mumps is 'parotitis,' the swelling of the salivary glands, or parotid glands, below the ear. Parotitis occurs only in 30-40% of individuals infected with mumps. Some people with mumps have no signs or symptoms of illness; others may have respiratory symptoms or only nonspecific symptoms such as headache, loss of appetite, and low-grade fever.\n\nIn children, mumps is usually a mild disease. Adults may have more serious disease and more complications. Central nervous system involvement (meningitis) is common, but is usually not serious. Meningitis (with headache, stiff neck) occurs in up to 15 percent of people with mumps but usually resolves without any permanent damage. Up to 50 percent of postpubertal males experience orchitis (testicular inflammation) as a complication of mumps. This may involve pain, swelling, nausea, vomiting, and fever, with tenderness of the area possibly lasting for weeks. Approximately half of patients with orchitis have some degree of testicular atrophy, but sterility is rare.\n\nInflammation of the ovaries (oophoritis) and/or breasts (mastitis) can occur in females who have reached puberty. An increase in spontaneous abortion has been found among women who developed mumps during the 1st trimester of pregnancy in some studies but not in others; however, there is no evidence that mumps causes birth defects. Deafness, in one or both ears, can occur in approximately one per 20 000 reported cases of mumps.\n\nPeople with mumps are usually considered most infectious from a few days before until 5 days after the onset of parotitis. Mumps patients should be isolated for 5 days after their glands begin to swell. If the exposed person has not been vaccinated against mumps, receiving the vaccine after exposure to the virus will not help prevent disease; vaccination may help against future exposure (from: http://www.immunize.org/catg.d/p4211.pdf).\n\nGirona is a city in the northeast of Catalonia, Spain at the confluence of the rivers Ter, Onyar, Galligants and Guell. The population numbered 96 722 in January 2011. It is the capital of the province of the same name and of the comarca (district) of the Girones. The interactive HealthMap of Catalonia can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/2Cxf. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps spreads from person to person via droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nPeople with mumps are usually considered most infectious from a few days before until 5 days after the onset of parotitis. Some people with mumps have no signs or symptoms of illness; others may have respiratory symptoms or only nonspecific symptoms such as headache, loss of appetite, and low-grade fever. An increase in spontaneous abortion has been found among women who developed mumps during the 1st trimester of pregnancy in some studies but not in others; however, there is no evidence that mumps causes birth defects. Individuals with mumps usually 1st feel sick with nonspecific symptoms like headache, loss of appetite, and low-grade fever. \n\nA group of people from Girona at the end of the year [2011] traveled to an area of the country where mumps virus infection was prevalent. If the exposed person has not been vaccinated against mumps, receiving the vaccine after exposure to the virus will not help prevent disease; vaccination may help against future exposure (from: http://www.immunize.org/catg.d/p4211.pdf). The incubation period of mumps is usually 16 to 18 days but can range from 12 to 25 days. Meningitis (with headache, stiff neck) occurs in up to 15 percent of people with mumps but usually resolves without any permanent damage. MUMPS - SPAIN (03): (CATALONIA), GIRONA\n***************************************\n The virus may also be spread indirectly when someone with mumps touches items or surfaces without washing their hands and then someone else touches the same surface and rubs their mouth or nose. Medical tests diagnosed mumps, a disease that causes a very characteristic swelling of glands located under each cheek.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-01-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MUMPS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Girona", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1234954", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Spain (04): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1234954", "date": "2012-08-08 17:22:28", "main_text": "MUMPS - SPAIN (04): (ASTURIAS)\n*************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 8 Aug 2012\nSource: LNE.ES [in Spanish, trans. Mod.JG, edited]\nhttp://www.lne.es/aviles/2012/08/07/detectan-brote-paperas-area-sanitaria-jovenes-veinteaneros/1280950.html\n\n\nHealthcare professionals detected an outbreak of mumps in the Aviles Health area that is currently affecting young persons in their early 20s (23 years old on average). Most of the cases have been diagnosed at Gozon Health Centre. Nevertheless, this communicable disease that causes a painful inflammation of the salivary glands has been described more frequently in Arriondas and Langreso communities, according to the last report of the Asturias Epidemiological Surveillance System. Up to August of this year [2012], 131 cases of mumps have been reported in Asturias, approximately 80 more cases compared to those reported for the whole year 2011.\n\nHealthcare professionals interviewed by this paper pointed out that the disease has been affecting mainly male subjects more than 20 years old that did not have mumps during their childhood -- after developing the disease, affected subjects become immunized for life -- or who had never been vaccinated with the triple [measles, mumps and rubella] vaccine that confers protection against measles, rubella, and mumps. Even so, these mumps outbreaks have not reached a level comparable with an epidemic that occurred in this region in 2002, when more than 1500 cases were diagnosed. There was also an outbreak reported in Asturias in 2007. At that time, the Health Council attributed the reappearance of this disease to persons moving towards and from autonomous communities where the disease had occurred in the past.\n\nThe Health Services in Asturias have advised since year 2000 that every person between 15 and 35 years of age that has not developed mumps in the past must get the vaccination against this infection. The vaccine may protect up to 85 per cent of immunized persons, consequently, some may develop the disease, but in a milder form.\n\nMumps is caused by a virus that is transmitted from person to person through respiratory droplets (i.e. by sneezing), or by direct contact with articles that have been contaminated with infected saliva. Mumps occurs more frequently in children between 2-12 years of age who have not been vaccinated, but the infection may occur at any age. The incubation period lasts between 12 and 24 days.\n\nAccording to healthcare experts, the most frequent symptoms are the following: pain in the face, fever, headache, sore throat, parotid gland inflammation, and temple or mandible inflammation. Other symptoms of this disease that may occur in men are testis inflammation and scrotal pain and inflammation. Physical examination generally confirms gland inflammation. There is no specific therapy for mumps. Cold or hot compresses on the affected areas in the neck and paracetamol may alleviate pain. The use of aspirin in children affected by mumps is discouraged in order to prevent the occurrence of Reye's syndrome.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promdmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person. Most mumps transmission occurs before the salivary glands begin to swell and up to 5 days after the swelling begins. Therefore, mumps patients should be isolated for 5 days after their glands begin to swell. The incubation time can range from 12-25 days.\n\nGenerally, persons can be considered immune to mumps if they were born before 1957, have serologic evidence of mumps immunity, have documentation of physician-diagnosed mumps, or have documentation of vaccination with at least one dose of live mumps vaccine on or after their 1st birthday. Demonstration of mumps IgG antibody by any commonly used serologic assay is acceptable evidence of mumps immunity.\n\nFor unvaccinated persons born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should consider vaccinating these individuals with 2 doses of MMR vaccine at the appropriate interval (for measles and mumps) and one dose of MMR vaccine (for rubella), respectively. For unvaccinated personnel born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should recommend 2 doses of MMR vaccine during an outbreak of measles or mumps and one dose during an outbreak of rubella.\n\nTwo doses of mumps vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective at preventing the disease; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49-92 percent) effective. The 1st vaccine against mumps was licensed in the United States in 1967, and by 2005, high 2-dose childhood vaccination coverage reduced disease rates by 99 percent. Adults at higher risk, such as university students, health care personnel, and international travelers, and persons with potential mumps outbreak exposure should ensure that they have been vaccinated. Further information can be obtained from the USCDC website (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/mumps.html#vaccines).\n\nAviles is an industrial city in Asturias, Spain. Asturias, officially the Principality of Asturias, is an autonomous community of Spain. It is coextensive with the province of Asturias and contains nearly all of the territory that was part of the former Kingdom of Asturias. The autonomous community of Asturias is bordered by Cantabria to the east, by Castile and Leon to the south, by Galicia to the west, and by the Bay of Biscay to the north.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap of Asturias can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1mjx. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Healthcare professionals interviewed by this paper pointed out that the disease has been affecting mainly male subjects more than 20 years old that did not have mumps during their childhood -- after developing the disease, affected subjects become immunized for life -- or who had never been vaccinated with the triple [measles, mumps and rubella] vaccine that confers protection against measles, rubella, and mumps. For unvaccinated persons born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should consider vaccinating these individuals with 2 doses of MMR vaccine at the appropriate interval (for measles and mumps) and one dose of MMR vaccine (for rubella), respectively. For unvaccinated personnel born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should recommend 2 doses of MMR vaccine during an outbreak of measles or mumps and one dose during an outbreak of rubella. Generally, persons can be considered immune to mumps if they were born before 1957, have serologic evidence of mumps immunity, have documentation of physician-diagnosed mumps, or have documentation of vaccination with at least one dose of live mumps vaccine on or after their 1st birthday. \n\nTwo doses of mumps vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective at preventing the disease; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49-92 percent) effective. The 1st vaccine against mumps was licensed in the United States in 1967, and by 2005, high 2-dose childhood vaccination coverage reduced disease rates by 99 percent. Up to August of this year [2012], 131 cases of mumps have been reported in Asturias, approximately 80 more cases compared to those reported for the whole year 2011.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1967-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cantabria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MUMPS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Langreso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Asturias", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1129263", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Serbia: (VO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1129263", "date": "2012-05-11 00:55:58", "main_text": "MUMPS - SERBIA: (VOJVODINA)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 10 May 2012\nSource: Eurosurveillance Edition 2012, 17(19) 10 May 2012 [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=20169\n\n\nOngoing mumps outbreak in Novi Sad, the Autonomous Province of Vojvodina, January to April 2012\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Authors: Rajcevic S, Seguljev Z, Petrovic V, et al]\n\nBackground\n----------\nFrom 16 Jan to 30 Apr 2012, a total of 119 cases of mumps were notified in Novi Sad, Serbia. Of these cases, 89 (75 percent), were among students. The average age of cases was 22 years old (range 3-37). The outbreak is still ongoing in Novi Sad and is spreading to other parts of the Vojvodina province. As of 30 Apr 2012, 209 cases have been notified in the province among those 119 from Novi Sad.\n\nResurgent outbreaks of mumps have recently been reported from several European Union and neighbouring countries [1-7]. Here we report on an ongoing mumps outbreak in Novi Sad, capital of the Autonomous Province of Vojvodina, Serbia. Similarly to outbreaks in England, Netherlands and Israel in recent years, the present one affects mainly young adults [8-10].\n\nMumps is a vaccine-preventable disease caused by a paramyxovirus. The typical clinical picture comprises fever, headache, malaise, painful unilateral or bilateral parotid swelling and complications such as orchitis, meningitis and encephalitis occur. Mumps is a notifiable disease in Serbia.\n\nOutbreak description\n--------------------\nOn 16 Jan 2012, the Institute for Student Health Care in Novi Sad reported 2 cases of mumps among students who study at University of Novi Sad, to the Institute of Public Health of Vojvodina. These students had spent the Christmas and New Year holidays [2011] in Bosnia and Herzegovina, where a large outbreak of mumps is ongoing [7,11,12].\n\nNovi Sad is the 2nd largest city in Serbia, capital of the northern Serbian province of Vojvodina, and the administrative centre of the South Backa district. The urban area has a population of 221 854, while its municipal area has a population of 335 701 [13].\n\nSince 25 Jan 2012, the Public Health Service in Novi Sad has been registering further cases of mumps among students and residents of the town. These had not travelled during the maximum length of the incubation period, 25 days. Here we provide detailed information about cases up to 30 Apr 2012.\n\nCase definition\n---------------\nAn imported case of mumps is defined as any person in Novi Sad with a history of painful swelling of one or both parotid glands without any other apparent cause, epidemiologically linked with a case of mumps in Bosnia and Herzegovina within the maximum length of the incubation period.\n\nA possible case is defined as a case with a clinical picture compatible with mumps diagnosed by a physician after 16 Jan 2012, in Novi Sad.\n\nAn epidemiologically linked case is defined as any person in Novi Sad meeting the clinical criteria and epidemiologically linked with a confirmed or imported case of mumps.\n\nA confirmed case is defined as a case with symptoms compatible with mumps and with serological confirmation of IgM mumps antibodies and/or verification by PCR from throat swabs in any person not vaccinated in the previous 2 months.\n\nBy 30 Apr 2012, a total of 119 cases had been reported from Novi Sad to the Institute of Public Health of Vojvodina of which 25 were considered as imported. In total, 32 cases were laboratory-confirmed (IgM or PCR-positive), genotyping was not performed. 87 cases were clinically diagnosed as either possible cases (n=45) or epidemiologically linked cases (n=42).\n\nThe average age of cases was 22 years. The youngest case was three years old and the oldest was 37 years of age. Cases occurred most frequently in the 20 to 29-year-old age group (n=91; 76 percent). There were more male (n=70) than female (n=49) cases. 13 cases were hospitalised with complications, 9 with orchitis, and 4 with pancreatitis. In total 13 percent of males over 15 years old contracted orchitis. For 86 cases, there was no information or data about previous mumps vaccination. The remaining 33 cases were vaccinated, among which 29 had received 2 doses of measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine. 4 were vaccinated with only one dose of MMR.\n\nPublic health response\n----------------------\nThe public health authorities of Vojvodina, advised the paediatric health services to revisit immunisation records of all children between one and 14 years of age and to call-in and vaccinate children who had not received the recommended MMR vaccine for temporary reasons, as soon as possible.\n\nOther epidemic control measures include, disseminating information to health services and the general public about the mumps outbreak by the public health authorities, isolating infected persons and limiting contact with them. Furthermore, persons who had been in contact with those infected, are placed under medical surveillance and receive information about the disease.\n\nDiscussion and conclusion\n-------------------------\nImmunisation against mumps was introduced in Serbia in 1986. Between 1996 and 2006, a combined MMR vaccine was administered according to a 2-dose schedule at the ages of 12 months and 12 years but no later than 14 years of age. In 2006, the schedule was changed and the 2nd dose is now administered at the age of 7.\n\nIn Serbia, before vaccination against mumps became part of the Serbian childhood vaccination schedule, mumps occurred frequently among children 5 to 9 years of age. Since the introduction of mumps vaccine into the routine childhood immunisation schedule, the number of cases has declined dramatically from 240 in 1982, to 30 in 1994 [14-16].\n\nIn Novi Sad, after introduction of the MMR vaccine into the national schedule in 1996, a total of 36 cases of mumps were registered between 1996 and 2011. The incidence rate was low and ranged from zero per 100 000 population in the period from 2007 to 2009 to 3.3 per 100 000 population in 2003 [17].\n\nThe importation of mumps cases from Bosnia and Herzegovina contributes to the epidemic spread of mumps in 2012 in Novi Sad and further on in Vojvodina. Ill students infected in Novi Sad probably represent a source for the further spread of the outbreak to other towns, all over Vojvodina Province, where there are a number of susceptible people in age groups that were not targeted for mumps vaccination as children and adolescents. In total, from 16 Jan to 30 Apr 2012, 209 cases of mumps were registered in Vojvodina among those 119 from Novi Sad, with the majority of cases in 20 to 29 year olds.\n\nThe fact that new outbreaks of mumps take place decades after vaccine introduction, and the occurrence of cases among young adults and previously immunised persons, indicate the need for further improvement of prevention strategies. The complication rate early in this outbreak of 13 percent is slightly higher than that in the literature and also highlights the need for attention [18,19].\n\n[Interested readers should access the full text at the source URL above to obtain the full list of references cited. - Mod.CP]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Autonomous Province of Vojvodina is an autonomous province of Serbia, located in the northern part of the country, in the Pannonian Plain of Central Europe. Its capital and largest city is Novi Sad. Vojvodina has a population of about 2 million (approximately 27 percent of Serbia's total).\n\nSuperficially it would appear that the current outbreak in Vojvodina may be an extension of the ongoing mumps epidemic in Bosnia and Herzegovina coupled with less than comprehensive MMR vaccination throughout Serbia. However, other factors may be important and further analysis is awaited.\n\nThe autonomous province of Vojvodina can be found on the map at http://mappery.com/maps/Serbia-and-surrounding-area-Map.mediumthumb.png. The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Serbia can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/2lf*. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "\n\nA confirmed case is defined as a case with symptoms compatible with mumps and with serological confirmation of IgM mumps antibodies and/or verification by PCR from throat swabs in any person not vaccinated in the previous 2 months. MUMPS - SERBIA: (VOJVODINA)\n***************************\n By 30 Apr 2012, a total of 119 cases had been reported from Novi Sad to the Institute of Public Health of Vojvodina of which 25 were considered as imported. \n\nThe average age of cases was 22 years. The public health authorities of Vojvodina, advised the paediatric health services to revisit immunisation records of all children between one and 14 years of age and to call-in and vaccinate children who had not received the recommended MMR vaccine for temporary reasons, as soon as possible. Between 1996 and 2006, a combined MMR vaccine was administered according to a 2-dose schedule at the ages of 12 months and 12 years but no later than 14 years of age. \n\nMumps is a vaccine-preventable disease caused by a paramyxovirus. \n\nResurgent outbreaks of mumps have recently been reported from several European Union and neighbouring countries [1-7].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2012-01-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "1982-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-05-10 00:00:00", "1986-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-01-16 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Autonomous Province of Vojvodina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bosnia and Herzegovina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vojvodina Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bosnia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Serbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vojvodina", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1109536", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada: (MB), school outbreak", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1109536", "date": "2012-04-21 17:23:52", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA: (MANITOBA), SCHOOL OUTBREAK\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 21 Apr 2012\nSource: Winnipeg Free Press [edited]\nhttp://www.winnipegfreepress.com/local/mumps-outbreak-infected-11-at-city-school-148365115.html\n\nMumps outbreak infected 11 at city school\n-----------------------------------------\n8 students and 3 adults at one Winnipeg school contracted mumps in an unusual outbreak this winter that resulted in more than 200 people being immunised. The Winnipeg Regional Health Authority [WRHA] is using the outbreak to draw attention to the 'Immunization Awareness Week' next week. But the WRHA will not name the school, will not give the ages of the students involved nor say whether the adults are teachers, and will not say if it is a public or private school. There is no public health risk and identifying the school and its community could violate the privacy of health information of individuals, the WRHA said.\n\nSeveral city school divisions said Thursday the outbreak did not occur in any of their schools. The Manitoba Teachers' Society said the teachers' union would expect to be aware of outbreaks of illness in a school, which suggests the outbreak may have been in a private school. 'It's really important that people remember the importance of immunization,' Dr. Michael Routledge, a public officer of health, said Thursday [19 Apr 2012]. Routledge said immunizations are safe and effective, and Winnipeg has a good rate of immunization.\n\nNevertheless, 2010 data showed only 66 per cent of 7-year-olds in the city received every recommended immunization, though most of the rest were missing only one or 2, Routledge said. He said the WRHA became aware of the mumps outbreak in late December [2011] and tracked it for 2 months. 'We identified what ended up as 11 cases,' he said. He said mumps is a viral disease that is usually benign, causing the cheeks to swell. But it can cause sterility in males and in a small number of cases, can lead to encephalitis. It is also contagious, he said.\n\nRoutledge said the cases were in one school and teachers were involved, though the health authority is not saying if the three 3 cases were teachers. 'We worked with the parents associated with the school,' he said. One person who developed mumps had been in the process of receiving immunization, but there was under-immunization in that school population, he said. More than 200 people associated with the school were immunized after the outbreak.\n\nThe WRHA sent all physicians in the province a letter advising them to be on the alert for symptoms of mumps. The Education Department referred all questions about the mumps outbreak to Manitoba Health, which cited the privacy of personal health information and deferred to the WRHA for comment. To see what Manitoba Health told the province's doctors in January about the outbreak, go to:\nhttp://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/cdc/protocol/mumps.pdf.\n\n(By: Nick Martin)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n['Even though mumps was described by Hippocrates more than 2 thousand years ago and a vaccine has been available for decades, the disease continues to spread in our communities and act in unexpected ways. During the prevaccine era in the United States, 90% of all children had experienced mumps virus infection by 14 years of age and large outbreaks occurred regularly, especially when those raised in rural areas were brought together into crowded situations, such as military barracks. After a mumps vaccine was licensed in 1968 and recommended for all children in 1977, the reported incidence of mumps began to decline substantially.\n\nA resurgence of outbreaks of both mumps and measles in the mid-1980s, often among high school and college students, resulted in the Immunization Practices Advisory Committee recommendation in late 1989 of a second dose of measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine. By the 2006\u20132007 school year, between 81% and 100% of children entering schools in the United States had received 2 doses. Between 2000 and 2005, less than 350 cases of mumps were reported annually in the United States, and an elimination goal for mumps was set for the year 2010. In 2006, however, college campuses in Iowa were the initial foci of what became the largest epidemic of mumps in 2 decades; by the end of that year, 6584 cases of mumps had been reported in the United States. [Taken from: M. Patricia Quinlisk, Journal of Infectious Diseases, Volume 202, Issue 5 Pp. 655-656; http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/202/5/655].\n\nOutbreaks of mumps have been reported frequently in Canada in the recent past as documented by the ProMED-mail posts listed below. These outbreaks have generally been associated with schools and educational establishments. In the present situation the reluctance of the Winnipeg Regional Health Authority to identify the school affected is unusual and seemingly illogical. It suggests perhaps that the school involved actively discouraged vaccination of its scholars and staff members for religious or philosophical reasons. Further information would be welcomed.\n\nThe City of Winnipeg, in the province of Manitoba, can be located by accessing the interactive HealthMap at: http://healthmap.org/r/2fAU. - Mod.CP]]", "summary": "\n\nA resurgence of outbreaks of both mumps and measles in the mid-1980s, often among high school and college students, resulted in the Immunization Practices Advisory Committee recommendation in late 1989 of a second dose of measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine. It brings the total number of students infected since the start of the month [February 2012] to 30 although university officials had claimed the outbreak was leveling off.\n\nNHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde's Public Health Protection Unit is liaising closely with the university and health officials said none of the students were giving cause for concern.\n\n[Byline: Carol Wilson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previously the HPS (Health Protection Scotland) Weekly Report dated 15 Feb 2012 indicated that since 7 Feb 2012, the Glasgow University Medical Centre has seen 26 cases of mumps in students attending Glasgow University. The students are between 18 and 22 years old, both male and female, attending different courses, and staying in different places.\n\nGlasgow University has asked all students to contact their GP for MMR vaccine if they have not already had 2 doses. MMR vaccine protects against measles, mumps, and rubella and is usually given at the ages of 13/14 months and around 4 years. Those who have missed doses of vaccine should get MMR vaccine from their GP. NHS [National Health Service] Greater Glasgow and Clyde has contacted all universities and colleges within its area to advise of the outbreak at Glasgow University and urge a reminder to all students in all institutions to obtain vaccine from their GP if they are under-immunized (see http://www.documents.hps.scot.nhs.uk/ewr/pdf2012/1207.pdf).\n\nOf the students who have contracted mumps virus infection it would be relevant to determine if any had received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine and were not protected. There are continuing doubts about the effectiveness of the mumps component of the MMR vaccine.\n\nGlasgow can be located in the interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map at http://healthmap.org/r/1OwW. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previously the HPS (Health Protection Scotland) Weekly Report dated 15 Feb 2012 indicated that since 7 Feb 2012, the Glasgow University Medical Centre has seen 26 cases of mumps in students attending Glasgow University. \n\nOf the students who have contracted mumps virus infection it would be relevant to determine if any had received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine and were not protected. \n\nGlasgow University has asked all students to contact their GP for MMR vaccine if they have not already had 2 doses. MUMPS - UK: (SCOTLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, ALERT\n A health warning has been reissued to students after 15 more cases of mumps were reported at Glasgow University. The students are between 18 and 22 years old, both male and female, attending different courses, and staying in different places. Date: Thu 16 Feb 2012\n There are continuing doubts about the effectiveness of the mumps component of the MMR vaccine. \n\nGlasgow can be located in the interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map at http://healthmap.org/r/1OwW. - Mod. Source: Evening Times [edited]\nhttp://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/alert-as-more-students-are-hit-by-mumps-30-university-students-now-have-mumps-1.1148192\n\n\n **\n \n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-02-07 00:00:00", "2012-02-25 00:00:00", "2012-02-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Clyde", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1086759", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Spain: (Catalonia) Girona", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1086759", "date": "2012-03-31 19:54:02", "main_text": "MUMPS - SPAIN: (CATALONIA) GIRONA\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 31 Mar 2012\nSource: Medicinatv.com [In Spanish, trans. by Mod.MPP, edited]\nhttp://www.medicinatv.com/noticias/un-brote-de-paperas-afecta-a-mas-de-un-centenar-de-personas-en-girona-231309\n\n\nOutbreak of mumps infects 106 persons in GIrona\n------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of mumps affecting 106 people in Girona [northern Spain] has been ongoing since December 2011 and up through the present is still continuing. In response to this outbreak, the Health Advisory Group of the Ministry has recommended that all individuals vaccinated with the triple vaccine [MMR] between 1994 and 1996 return for repeat vaccination. According to one report the Primary Care Centers in Girona reported 3 cases of mumps in the second half of December 2011, with further cases appearing during January, February and March 2012. The 106 identified cases all recovered without incident. The communities with the highest number of reported cases are Girones, Baix Emporda and Selva, although there have been cases in other communities of the region. The Health Council recommends the revaccination strategy as a means of controlling the outbreak and preventing further cases. The rationale for the revaccination is that between 1994 and 1996 vaccination was done using the triple vaccine [MMR] which contained the Rubini strain of mumps virus. The primary health care centers that have received the doses of vaccines are informing those individuals who should be receiving the vaccine. 50 percent of the identified cases in the Girona area are youths between the ages of 16 and 18 years, although the age range for mumps cases include individuals from adolescents through adults, ages 17 to 42 years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from <HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The mumps virus component of the triple MMR vaccine has been the weakest component of the triple MMR vaccine, tending to induce weaker and less persistent immune responses than the measles and rubella virus components. Different attenuated strains of mumps virus have served as the mumps component of the MMR triple vaccine at various times in the past. The Rubini strain was the mumps component of the MMR vaccine used in Spain previously, and may have been a less effective immunogen. Other strains used in the past, such as the Urabe strain, were latter withdrawn due to cases of transient mild viral meningitis. The Jeryl Lynn strain is now the mumps virus component favoured in most MMR vaccines, although later this strain was found to comprise two distinguishable substrains, JL1 and JL2. The JL1 strain was preferentially selected by propagation in Vero and chick embryo fibroblast cell cultures, whereas the JL2 strain was preferentially selected by passage in embryonated chicken eggs. Consequently differently produced MMR virus vaccines may differ in this respect. It remains to be seen whether the revaccination strategy involving deployment of a currently available MMR vaccine will provide better protect of the adolescent population.\n\nGirona is a city in the northeast of Catalonia, Spain at the confluence of the rivers Ter, Onyar, Galligants and G\u00fcell. A map of Catalonia, showing the location of Girona, can be accessed at: http://www.kyero.com/map/55539-catalonia-map. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The mumps virus component of the triple MMR vaccine has been the weakest component of the triple MMR vaccine, tending to induce weaker and less persistent immune responses than the measles and rubella virus components. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n 50 percent of the identified cases in the Girona area are youths between the ages of 16 and 18 years, although the age range for mumps cases include individuals from adolescents through adults, ages 17 to 42 years. Different attenuated strains of mumps virus have served as the mumps component of the MMR triple vaccine at various times in the past. The rationale for the revaccination is that between 1994 and 1996 vaccination was done using the triple vaccine [MMR] which contained the Rubini strain of mumps virus. The Jeryl Lynn strain is now the mumps virus component favoured in most MMR vaccines, although later this strain was found to comprise two distinguishable substrains, JL1 and JL2. According to one report the Primary Care Centers in Girona reported 3 cases of mumps in the second half of December 2011, with further cases appearing during January, February and March 2012. The Rubini strain was the mumps component of the MMR vaccine used in Spain previously, and may have been a less effective immunogen. The JL1 strain was preferentially selected by propagation in Vero and chick embryo fibroblast cell cultures, whereas the JL2 strain was preferentially selected by passage in embryonated chicken eggs. Outbreak of mumps infects 106 persons in GIrona\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2011-12-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Girona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MUMPS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "GIrona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "933346", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - France: rugby league players", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=933346", "date": "2011-11-01 16:53:37", "main_text": "MUMPS - FRANCE: RUGBY LEAGUE PLAYERS\n************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 1 Nov 2011\nSource: Moneycontrol.com, Reuters report [edited]\nhttp://www.moneycontrol.com/news/wire-news/mumps-epidemic-forces-french-to-postpone-games_608077.html\n\n\nMumps epidemic forces French to postpone games\n----------------------------------------------\nThe rough and tumble of macho French league rugby has been curtailed\nby an unexpected source -- an epidemic of mumps. The virus, normally\nassociated with children, has forced the French rugby union league\n(LNR) to postpone next weekend's Basque derby between Biarritz and\nBayonne after another Top 14 game was called off for the same reason.\n\n'Because of an epidemic of mumps within the Lyon squad (...) the LNR\nhas decided, as a precaution, to postpone the Biarritz v Bayonne\ngame,' the LNR said in a statement on Monday [31 Oct 2011]. The LNR\nexplained it made the decision to avoid possible contamination by the\nBiarritz players as they [had] faced Lyon on 22 Oct 2011.\n\nThe Bordeaux versus Lyon game was postponed last week because Lyon\nplayers were suffering from mumps.\n\n[Byline: Julien Pretot]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps predominately, but not exclusively, is a disease of childhood.\nThe classic symptoms of mumps include parotitis in about 50 percent\neither unilateral bilateral, which develops an average of 16 to 18\ndays after exposure. Swelling can also be seen in the submandibular\nand sublingual gland in a small percentage of cases. Nonspecific\nsymptoms including myalgia, anorexia, malaise, headache, and low-grade\nfever may precede parotitis by several days. As many as 40-50 percent\nof mumps infections are associated with nonspecific or primarily\nrespiratory symptoms.\n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose,\nor throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs,\nsneezes, or talks. Items used by an infected person, such as soft\ndrink cans or eating utensils, can also be contaminated with the\nvirus. In addition, the virus may spread when someone with mumps\ntouches items or surfaces without washing their hands.\n\nMost mumps transmission likely occurs before the salivary glands begin\nto swell and up to 5 days after the swelling begins. The incubation\ntimes can range from 12-25 days.\n\nMumps occurs sporadically among young adults due to absence of\nvaccination in childhood or diminishing immunity. It might be expected\nthat infection would be associated with contact sports such as\nAmerican and rugby football. However, it is curious that this mumps\noutbreak is associated with the League version of Rugby football,\nwhich involves fewer players and less contact than rugby Union\nfootball. It may be that MMR vaccination in childhood has been less\ncomprehensive in the South and West of France than elsewhere.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of France can be accessed\nat: http://healthmap.org/r/1oxc - Mod.CP]", "summary": "RUGBY LEAGUE PLAYERS\n************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n However, it is curious that this mumps\noutbreak is associated with the League version of Rugby football,\nwhich involves fewer players and less contact than rugby Union\nfootball. The virus, normally\nassociated with children, has forced the French rugby union league\n(LNR) to postpone next weekend's Basque derby between Biarritz and\nBayonne after another Top 14 game was called off for the same reason. \n\n'Because of an epidemic of mumps within the Lyon squad (...) the LNR\nhas decided, as a precaution, to postpone the Biarritz v Bayonne\ngame,' the LNR said in a statement on Monday [31 Oct 2011]. \n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose,\nor throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs,\nsneezes, or talks. The classic symptoms of mumps include parotitis in about 50 percent\neither unilateral bilateral, which develops an average of 16 to 18\ndays after exposure. As many as 40-50 percent\nof mumps infections are associated with nonspecific or primarily\nrespiratory symptoms. Nonspecific\nsymptoms including myalgia, anorexia, malaise, headache, and low-grade\nfever may precede parotitis by several days. It might be expected\nthat infection would be associated with contact sports such as\nAmerican and rugby football.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MUMPS", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1087523", "headline": "PRO>  Mumps - Spain (02): Background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1087523", "date": "2012-04-02 02:16:29", "main_text": "MUMPS - SPAIN (02): BACKGROUND\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 1 Apr 2012\nFrom: 'Dr.Steve Berger' <mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n\nComment on: 'Mumps - Spain: (CA) Girona 20120331.1086759'\n-----------------------------------\nSpain's experience with vaccine-preventable disease is a paradigm for the success of immunization. Reports of measles, mumps and rubella in this country declined dramatically following the introduction of routine MMR in 1981 [1,2] -- see graph [3]: http://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/MMR-Spain.png.\n\nMumps rates for the entire region have remained low since 2000, see graph: http://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Mumps-Iberia.png.\n\nSeroprevalence surveys:\n\n91.1 percent in Catalonia (1996)\n92.1 percent of persons ages 17 to 36 in Barcelona (1992 to 1993)\n\nNotable outbreaks:\n\n1987 -- An outbreak (104 cases) was reported among school children in Castellon.\n1992 (publication year) -- An outbreak (52 cases) was reported in Zaragoza.\n1993 to 1994 -- Outbreaks (216 cases total in 19 outbreaks) were reported in Toledo.\n1995 to 1996 -- An outbreak was reported in Leon.\n1997 -- An outbreak (283 cases) was reported in an urban area in Andalucia.\n1999 to 2000 -- An outbreak (33 cases) was reported at a school in Huesca.\n2000 -- An outbreak (35 cases) was reported among 3-to-4 year old children in San Sebastian.\n2005 -- An outbreak (145 cases) was reported in Almeria.\n2006 -- An outbreak (63 cases) was reported at a school in Bizkaia.\n2006 to 2007 -- An outbreak (1397 cases) was associated with a festival in the Navarre region.\n2008 -- An outbreak (116 cases) was reported in Jerez de la Frontera.\n\nReferences:\n\n1. Berger SA. Infectious Diseases of Spain, 2012. 557 pp, 194 graphs, 2850 references. Gideon e-books,\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-spain/.\n\n2. Berger SA. Mumps: Global Status, 2012. 167 pp, 191 graphs, 433 references. Gideon e-books,\nhttp://www.http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/mumps-global-status/.\n\n3. Gideon graph tool at, http://www.GIDEONonline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Gideon-Graphs.pps.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n\n\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Professor Steve Berger for provision of these background data that record the past success of the Spanish authorities in containment of mumps virus infection by MMR vaccination. - Mod.CP\n]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n 92.1 percent of persons ages 17 to 36 in Barcelona (1992 to 1993)\n\nNotable outbreaks:\n\n1987 -- An outbreak (104 cases) was reported among school children in Castellon. \n2006 to 2007 -- An outbreak (1397 cases) was associated with a festival in the Navarre region. An outbreak (283 cases) was reported in an urban area in Andalucia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1981-03-25 00:00:00", "1987-03-25 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "1992-03-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "1397-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Toledo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Barcelona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MUMPS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Almeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Sebastian", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Huesca", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "929906", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Colombia (02): Bogota, prisoners", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=929906", "date": "2011-10-31 18:03:56", "main_text": "MUMPS - COLOMBIA (02): BOGOTA, PRISONERS\n****************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 27 Oct 2011\nSource: Caracol.com [in Spanish, trans. Mod.JG, edited]\nhttp://www.caracol.com.co/noticias/actualidad/alerta-por-posible-epidemia-en-la-carcel-modelo-se-detectaron-323-casos-de-paperas/20111027/nota/1568994.aspx\n\n\nCAPRECOM (a state-run healthcare provider) has reported that as a\nresult of a survey performed in the Carcel Modelo (the Model Prison,\nthe main prison in Bogota, the Capital City of Colombia), 323 cases of\nmumps have been confirmed, raising fears of an uncontrolled epidemic.\n\nThe 1st case was reported in September 2010, an inmate in the north\narea of Carcel Modelo. Subsequently, in order to prevent spread of the\ndisease, CAPRECOM implemented the following 4 measures:\n- firstly, the healthcare team would treat independently each\nindividual showing symptoms;\n- secondly, if necessary, inmates with a confirmed diagnosis of mumps\nwould be isolated;\n- 3rd, CAPRECOM would distribute information through lectures to the\nother prisoners, and;\n- fourthly preventive measures would be reinforced, particularly\nwhere there was direct contact with healthcare personnel working in\nthe prison, including physicians, nurses, and technicians.\n\nINPEC (the Colombian National Prison Authority ) reported that the\nmumps outbreak in Carcel Modelo had spread to the northern wing of the\nprison and announced that there would be restricted access to the\nprison in the case of children, pregnant women, and the elderly.\n\nINPEC also released its own figures with respect to case numbers,\nrevealing that as of 27 Oct 2011, there are 191 affected inmates in\nareas 4 and 5. They also stated that the initial manifestations of\nthis viral infection occurred in the northern wings of Carcel Modelo,\nin areas 1A and 1B. As soon as the presence of mumps virus infection\nwas confirmed, inmates were moved to the former high-security wing,\nwhich had been emptied some months ago and now served as a Special\nHealth Unit, to provide isolation facilities.\n\nIn addition to restrictions on admission and release of prisoners from\nthe affected wings, the movement of inmates to other prisons in the\ncountry will also be suspended.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From a single case in September 2011, the outbreak had affected 65\nprisoners by 14 Oct 2011 and now may affect as many as 323 prisoners.\nClearly, this is a major outbreak not yet under control. It also\nsuggests that MMR vaccination coverage is far from comprehensive in\nColombia.\n\nLa Modelo is a prison in Bogota, Colombia with a population of about\n11 000 inmates. The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Colombia\ncan be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1l0z. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Subsequently, in order to prevent spread of the\ndisease, CAPRECOM implemented the following 4 measures:\n- firstly, the healthcare team would treat independently each\nindividual showing symptoms;\n- secondly, if necessary, inmates with a confirmed diagnosis of mumps\nwould be isolated;\n- 3rd, CAPRECOM would distribute information through lectures to the\nother prisoners, and;\n- fourthly preventive measures would be reinforced, particularly\nwhere there was direct contact with healthcare personnel working in\nthe prison, including physicians, nurses, and technicians. MUMPS - COLOMBIA (02): BOGOTA, PRISONERS\n****************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n this viral infection occurred in the northern wings of Carcel Modelo,\nin areas 1A and 1B. As soon as the presence of mumps virus infection\nwas confirmed, inmates were moved to the former high-security wing,\nwhich had been emptied some months ago and now served as a Special\nHealth Unit, to provide isolation facilities. \n\nINPEC (the Colombian National Prison Authority ) reported that the\nmumps outbreak in Carcel Modelo had spread to the northern wing of the\nprison and announced that there would be restricted access to the\nprison in the case of children, pregnant women, and the elderly. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From a single case in September 2011, the outbreak had affected 65\nprisoners by 14 Oct 2011 and now may affect as many as 323 prisoners. \n\n\nCAPRECOM (a state-run healthcare provider) has reported that as a\nresult of a survey performed in the Carcel Modelo (the Model Prison,\nthe main prison in Bogota, the Capital City of Colombia), 323 cases of\nmumps have been confirmed, raising fears of an uncontrolled epidemic.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-09-25 00:00:00", "2010-09-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colombia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bogota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Capital City of Colombia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "910587", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Colombia: (Bogota) prisoners", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=910587", "date": "2011-10-15 21:05:19", "main_text": "MUMPS - COLOMBIA: (BOGOTA) PRISONERS\n************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 14 Oct 2011\nSource: Caracol Radio [In Spanish, machine transl., edited]\nhttp://www.caracol.com.co/noticias/judicial/por-brote-de-paperas-restringen-visitas-en-la-carcel-modelo-de-bogota/20111014/nota/1562635.aspx\n\n\nAn outbreak of mumps restrict visits at the Modelo prison in Bogota\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nAs the result of an outbreak of mumps which has affected 56 inmates,\nvisits by children, pregnant women and seniors have been restricted.\nThose affected are in isolation to prevent spread of the virus. The\n1st signs of viral infection were detected among prisoners in cells\nlocated in in the north of the prison, in bays 1A and 1B.\n\nIn addition to restriction on visitors, the transfer of prisoners to\nother parts of the country has been suspended for the duration of the\noutbreak.\n\nThe Supreme Judicial Council has been asked to suspend admissions of\nprisoners to this jail until the infection has been eliminated and\nnormalcy restored.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Humans are the only known host of the mumps virus. Spread is from\nperson to person, and occurs by airborne or droplet transmission.\nExposed persons should be considered infectious from 12 to 25 days\nafter exposure. The mean incubation period is 19 days with a range of\n14-25 days. It is likely therefore that the Modelo prion in Bogota\nwill be closed to visitors for some time to come.\n\nThe most common and characteristic clinical presentation of mumps is\nan acute and tender parotid swelling which develops 16-18 days after\nexposure in up to 70 percent of cases. Mumps may present as a lower\nrespiratory tract infection, and asymptomatic and subclinical mumps\nvirus infections are common and may represent up to 20 percent of all\ninfections. Serious complications, including encephalitis, may precede\nor follow the parotitis and can also occur without any apparent\ninvolvement of the salivary glands. Encephalitis is a rare but serious\ncomplication that affects 0.02-0.3 percent of cases and it is\nresponsible for most of the mumps associated deaths. Orchitis occurs\nin 25-50 percent of mumps infections in post pubertal men. In about 30\npercent of cases the orchitis is bilateral and may lead to\noligospermia, subfertility and decreased testosterone production but\nonly rarely sterility.\n\nImmunisation is the only effective method of prevention. The large\nnumber of prisoners affected in the outbreak in the Modelo prison\nindicates that many young adults in Colombia have not been recipients\nof the MMR (mumps, measles and rubella) vaccine. Furthermore\nmathematical modelling indicate that 85-90 percent immunisation\ncoverage in a population is required to achieve herd immunity and the\nelimination of mumps transmission.\n\nLa Modelo is a prison in Bogota, Colombia, which has a population of\nabout 11 000 inmates. The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of\nColombia can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1l0z. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "MUMPS - COLOMBIA: (BOGOTA) PRISONERS\n************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The\n1st signs of viral infection were detected among prisoners in cells\nlocated in in the north of the prison, in bays 1A and 1B.\n\nIn addition to restriction on visitors, the transfer of prisoners to\nother parts of the country has been suspended for the duration of the\noutbreak. Mumps may present as a lower\nrespiratory tract infection, and asymptomatic and subclinical mumps\nvirus infections are common and may represent up to 20 percent of all\ninfections. The large\nnumber of prisoners affected in the outbreak in the Modelo prison\nindicates that many young adults in Colombia have not been recipients\nof the MMR (mumps, measles and rubella) vaccine. Furthermore\nmathematical modelling indicate that 85-90 percent immunisation\ncoverage in a population is required to achieve herd immunity and the\nelimination of mumps transmission. In about 30\npercent of cases the orchitis is bilateral and may lead to\noligospermia, subfertility and decreased testosterone production but\nonly rarely sterility. \n\nThe most common and characteristic clinical presentation of mumps is\nan acute and tender parotid swelling which develops 16-18 days after\nexposure in up to 70 percent of cases. Encephalitis is a rare but serious\ncomplication that affects 0.02-0.3 percent of cases and it is\nresponsible for most of the mumps associated deaths. \n\nThe Supreme Judicial Council has been asked to suspend admissions of\nprisoners to this jail until the infection has been eliminated and\nnormalcy restored.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bogota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colombia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "907139", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK (04): England (CU)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=907139", "date": "2011-10-12 19:10:25", "main_text": "MUMPS - UK (04): ENGLAND (CUMBRIA)\n**********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 11 Oct 2011\nSource: News and Star [edited]\nhttp://www.newsandstar.co.uk/news/health-warning-as-mumps-cases-rise-in-cumbria-1.886632?referrerPath=news/road_safety\n\n\nCases of mumps are on the rise in Cumbria. Young adults are being\nreminded to check whether they have received both doses of vaccine\nagainst measles, mumps and rubella. So far this year [2011], 14 cases\nof mumps have been confirmed across Cumbria, already an increase on\nthe 10 recorded for the whole of last year [2010]. Health bosses are\nkeen to prevent a large outbreak similar to that of 2009, when 97\ncases were recorded.\n\nMeasles is also more likely to spread where groups of young people\nfrom different areas begin living in close proximity, such as in\nuniversity and college halls of residence. Anyone who is not sure\nwhether they have had both doses can contact their GP surgery and ask\nfor a booster MMR injection.\n\nDr Nigel Calvert, associate director of public health for NHS Cumbria,\nsaid: 'In the last few years, there has been an increase in the number\nof cases of mumps, particularly in teenagers and young adults. This\ncan be a concern because mumps is a virus which can easily spread and,\nin some cases, affect fertility. In addition, there is also concern\nabout the rise in cases of measles among young people living in close\nproximity in other areas of the country.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Close to 950 000 cases of mumps were reported in Europe from 2000 to\n2008, with the highest incidence in the 5-9 years and 10-14-years-old\nage groups. In 2008, the hospitalisation rate was 12 percent in\ncountries that reported these data (n=14 348).\n\nMumps is primarily a respiratory infection, and as such is transmitted\nby aerosol and respiratory droplets. The invasion of the respiratory\ntract is frequently accompanied by viremia that results in organ\ninvolvement with a preference for the salivary glands. The most common\nand characteristic clinical presentation of mumps is an acute and\ntender parotid swelling which develops 16-18 days after exposure in up\nto 70 percent of cases. The swelling may be unilateral or bilateral\n(30-40 percent of cases) and the inflamed swollen parotid gland lifts\nthe earlobe up and out in a characteristic fashion. The submandibular\nand sublingual glands may also be involved and swollen. Mumps may\npresent as a lower respiratory tract infection, particularly in young\nchildren.\n\nAsymptomatic and subclinical mumps virus infections are common and may\nrepresent up to 20 percent of all infections. Serious complications,\nincluding encephalitis, may precede or follow the parotitis and can\nalso occur without any apparent involvement of the salivary glands.\nCentral nervous system (CNS) infection is common with mumps, and up to\n50 percent of patients have been shown to have asymptomatic\npleocytosis in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).\n\nImmunisation against mumps has been associated with a marked decline\nin the incidence of mumps disease in many European countries as well\nas in the United States, but there are also indications that vaccine\neffectiveness may be lower than what the vaccine efficacy studies\nindicate. There is large variation in the reported incidence of mumps\nacross Europe. Countries with the highest incidence report figures\nalmost 100-fold of those of countries with the lowest incidence.\nFurther information can be obtained at:\nhttp://ecdc.europa.eu/EN/HEALTHTOPICS/MUMPS/BASIC_FACTS/Pages/factsheet_professionals.aspx?MasterPage=1.\n\nCumbria is a county located in the northwest of England. It is one of\nthe most sparsely populated counties in the United Kingdom, with about\n73.4 people per km squared. Cumbria contains the Lake District\nNational Park. It can be located in the Map of the counties of England\nat: http://www.picturesofengland.com/mapofengland/counties-map.html.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "MUMPS - UK (04): ENGLAND (CUMBRIA)\n**********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Close to 950 000 cases of mumps were reported in Europe from 2000 to\n2008, with the highest incidence in the 5-9 years and 10-14-years-old\nage groups. \n\nImmunisation against mumps has been associated with a marked decline\nin the incidence of mumps disease in many European countries as well\nas in the United States, but there are also indications that vaccine\neffectiveness may be lower than what the vaccine efficacy studies\nindicate. The most common\nand characteristic clinical presentation of mumps is an acute and\ntender parotid swelling which develops 16-18 days after exposure in up\nto 70 percent of cases. In addition, there is also concern\nabout the rise in cases of measles among young people living in close\nproximity in other areas of the country.'\n\n--\n \nCentral nervous system (CNS) infection is common with mumps, and up to\n50 percent of patients have been shown to have asymptomatic\npleocytosis in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). \n\nDr Nigel Calvert, associate director of public health for NHS Cumbria,\nsaid: 'In the last few years, there has been an increase in the number\nof cases of mumps, particularly in teenagers and young adults. \n\nMeasles is also more likely to spread where groups of young people\nfrom different areas begin living in close proximity, such as in\nuniversity and college halls of residence. So far this year [2011], 14 cases\nof mumps have been confirmed across Cumbria, already an increase on\nthe 10 recorded for the whole of last year [2010].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cumbria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "899707", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (02): (CA) university students, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=899707", "date": "2011-10-06 17:39:51", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (02): (CALIFORNIA) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, ALERT\n*********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Oct 2011\nSource: Bay City News, via foxreno.com [edited]\nhttp://www.foxreno.com/news/29397458/detail.html\n\n\nFor members of the University of California at Berkeley community,\nfever, headaches, muscle aches and fatigue could spell more than a\ncommon cold; they could mean a case of the mumps.\n\nThe university community is experiencing an outbreak of the viral\ninfection after several cases of mumps were confirmed in students last\nThursday [29 Sep 2011], campus health officials said. On Tuesday [4\nOct 2011], UC Berkeley's health services website posted an alert about\nthe outbreak, encouraging all Cal students, faculty and staff --\nregardless of their vaccination history -- to receive an additional\ndose of the measles, mumps, rubella vaccine, or MMR. Most people\nreceive 2 doses of MMR, with the 1st administered at 12 to 15 months\nof age and the 2nd given any time at least 4 weeks after the 1st dose.\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus originating from the\nmouth, nose or throat of an infected person.\n\n'University Health Services and the City of Berkeley's Public Health\nDivision are working closely with the California Department of Public\nHealth to limit (the) spread of the disease,' the alert read. Members\nof the UC Berkeley community should review their vaccination history,\nand health officials recommend that people seek vaccination if they\nare not sure whether they have received 2 doses of MMR. Officials also\nsaid that a 3rd MMR dose may be helpful in stopping mumps outbreaks.\n\nThe cases confirmed last week involved students residing on the\nClark-Kerr campus, which is about a half a mile south of the main\ncampus, and living in the Cloyne student cooperative on the north side\nof campus. A suspected case also involved a student residing in the\nCheney Hall dormitory. The number of confirmed cases was not provided\nin the alert.\n\nSymptoms generally develop 16 to 18 days after exposure to the virus\nbut may manifest anywhere between 14 to 25 days after exposure, health\nofficials said. Those who may have been exposed to mumps should be\nalert for symptoms including fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue\nand loss of appetite, as well as swollen or tender salivary glands\nunder the ears, jaw or under the tongue on one or both sides of the\nface.\n\nUniversity health officials advise those who may be infected to stay\nhome and contact a health care provider. UC Berkeley students or Tang\nCenter patients may contact the nurse advice line at (510) 643-7197.\nCalls to representatives from University Health Services and the City\nof Berkeley's Public Health Division seeking comment were not\nimmediately returned today [5 Oct 2011].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the absence of information concerning the number of confirmed\ncases of mumps virus infection, it is difficult to assess the\nseriousness of this outbreak. However, it is likely that this outbreak\nof mumps, as has occurred recently in this age group elsewhere, is\nanother consequence of the recent decline in uptake of the MMR\nvaccine, which has been the cause of the recent upsurge in cases of\nmeasles. Further information is awaited. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "MUMPS - USA (02): (CALIFORNIA) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, ALERT\n*********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n On Tuesday [4\nOct 2011], UC Berkeley's health services website posted an alert about\nthe outbreak, encouraging all Cal students, faculty and staff --\nregardless of their vaccination history -- to receive an additional\ndose of the measles, mumps, rubella vaccine, or MMR. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the absence of information concerning the number of confirmed\ncases of mumps virus infection, it is difficult to assess the\nseriousness of this outbreak. However, it is likely that this outbreak\nof mumps, as has occurred recently in this age group elsewhere, is\nanother consequence of the recent decline in uptake of the MMR\nvaccine, which has been the cause of the recent upsurge in cases of\nmeasles. Those who may have been exposed to mumps should be\nalert for symptoms including fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue\nand loss of appetite, as well as swollen or tender salivary glands\nunder the ears, jaw or under the tongue on one or both sides of the\nface. \n\nThe cases confirmed last week involved students residing on the\nClark-Kerr campus, which is about a half a mile south of the main\ncampus, and living in the Cloyne student cooperative on the north side\nof campus. Members\nof the UC Berkeley community should review their vaccination history,\nand health officials recommend that people seek vaccination if they\nare not sure whether they have received 2 doses of MMR. \n\nThe university community is experiencing an outbreak of the viral\ninfection after several cases of mumps were confirmed in students last\nThursday", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2011-09-29 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the City of Berkeley 's Public Health \n Division", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bay City News", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "889629", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA: (IL) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=889629", "date": "2011-09-28 18:16:37", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: (ILLINOIS) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 27 Sep 2011\nSource: Herald-Whig [edited]\nhttp://www.whig.com/story/news/Mumps-092811\n\n\nMumps outbreak reported on QU campus\n------------------------------------\nThe Adams County Health Department (ACHD) and Quincy University (QU)\nsay several cases of mumps have been reported on the college campus.\nIn a press release, QU officials said students have received\ninformation about mumps and are being given the opportunity to get\nvaccinations to reduce the risk of contracting the mumps. The press\nrelease stated the department does not consider this cluster of cases\nwill increase risk of mumps disease to the general public 'since cases\nare limited to a single localized population.'\n\nJerrod Welch, director of clinical and environmental services for the\nACHD, says the number of cases of mumps is believed to be under 10.\n\n'Mumps is a disease that by the time you have symptoms, you are no\nlonger contagious or very contagious,' Welch said. 'The symptoms\nusually resolve themselves within a number of days.'\n\nMumps is an acute viral infection of the salivary glands. Symptoms may\ninclude fever, headache, muscle ache and swelling and tenderness of\nthe salivary glands under the ears or jaw on one or both sides of the\nface. Infection takes place through direct contact with respiratory\ndroplets from the nose or throat, through saliva, coughing, sneezing\nor from any surface contaminated with mumps virus. Because it's a\nviral infection, mumps does not respond to antibiotic treatment. QU\nstudents and faculty have been provided with a campus contact hotline\nnumber for questions or concerns about mumps. Welch urged people who\nbelieve they have mumps or any communicable disease to contact their\nhealth care provider by phone. 'The thing we least want to do is\nexpose people by going into a waiting room,' Welch said.\n\n[Byline: Rodney Hart]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Quincy University is an independent, coeducational, primarily\nundergraduate institution which is rooted in the Catholic and\nFranciscan tradition. It is located In Quincy, Illinois. The student\npopulation numbers approximately 1300.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps virus infection occur frequently where young adults\nare housed in close contact on university campuses. Such outbreaks are\ngenerally a consequence of either deficiencies in MMR vaccination\ncoverage in the home communities of the students, or the lesser\nimmunogenicity of the mumps virus component of the MMR vaccine. -\nMod.CP]\n\nQuincy University is located in the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive\nmap at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1hSS. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "The press\nrelease stated the department does not consider this cluster of cases\nwill increase risk of mumps disease to the general public 'since cases\nare limited to a single localized population.'\n\nJerrod Welch, director of clinical and environmental services for the\nACHD, says the number of cases of mumps is believed to be under 10. Such outbreaks are\ngenerally a consequence of either deficiencies in MMR vaccination\ncoverage in the home communities of the students, or the lesser\nimmunogenicity of the mumps virus component of the MMR vaccine. Symptoms may\ninclude fever, headache, muscle ache and swelling and tenderness of\nthe salivary glands under the ears or jaw on one or both sides of the\nface. \nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In a press release, QU officials said students have received\ninformation about mumps and are being given the opportunity to get\nvaccinations to reduce the risk of contracting the mumps.
