' \nThe Adams County Health Department (ACHD) and Quincy University (QU)\nsay several cases of mumps have been reported on the college campus.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-09-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Quincy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "QU", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "905545", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (04): (CA) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=905545", "date": "2011-10-11 14:58:40", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04): (CALIFORNIA) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS\n**************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 10 Oct 2011\nSource: The Daily Californian [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.dailycal.org/2011/10/10/mumps-outbreak-at-uc-berkeley-grows-to-over-40-cases/\n\n\nMumps outbreak at UC Berkeley grows to over 40 suspected and confirmed\ncases\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe California Department of Public Health confirmed Monday [10 Oct\n2011] that the mumps outbreak at UC Berkeley -- which has grown to 44\nsuspected and confirmed cases -- began when a UC Berkeley student\ncontracted the virus in Great Britain. Department spokesperson Matt\nConens said in an email Monday [10 Oct 2011] that laboratory-confirmed\ncases of the virus [disease] had increased from 7 to 9 cases and\nsuspected cases had grown to approximately 35 cases.\n\nAccording to Mike Sicilia, spokesperson for the department, the\ndepartment located the source of the outbreak through interviewing\ninfected students. 'We believe this outbreak was started by a student\nwho was exposed to mumps while in Europe and returned to campus and\nunfortunately developed mumps and spread it to others,' Sicilia said.\n'It's actually not unusual for outbreaks of mumps in the US that there\nhas been some contact with someone who has been out of the country.'\n\nUniversity Health Services has been advised by the department as well\nas the City of Berkeley Division of Public Health to refocus its\ncontainment efforts on students in high-population housing, where\nofficials currently suspect the outbreak began. University Health\nServices medical director Brad Buchman said prevention efforts are\nbeing focused on high-population student living areas with shared\ndining and bathroom facilities, including dorms, coops, and\nfraternities and sororities, because these areas have seen the most\nsuspected and confirmed cases. Cases have been reported in the\nresidence halls, coops, and in fraternity and sorority houses across\ncampus, including Cloyne Court and the Clark Kerr Campus.\n\nThe Berkeley Student Cooperative [BSC], which has experienced at least\none confirmed and one suspected case of the virus, has responded to\nthe outbreak by educating residents about preventative measures. 'The\nhealth worker coordinator is disseminating resource material and all\nthe information we've gotten from the chancellor,' said BSC executive\ndirector Jan Stokley. 'We're educating people at the house level about\nwhat the symptoms are and what to do to prevent contagion.'\n\nHealth officials at UC Berkeley and the department are recommending\nthat at-risk individuals who have already received 2 doses of the\nvaccine receive a 3rd dose. According to Buchman, though 2 doses of\nthe vaccine were thought sufficient, previous outbreaks have revealed\nthat up to half the patients with mumps had already had 2 doses.\n\nBuchman said most reported cases of the virus have been mild and\ninvolved swelling of the parotid gland and inflammation of the\ntesticles. The mumps, measles, and rubella vaccine will be available\nfor free to students, faculty and staff at the Tang Center from 12\np.m. to 5 p.m. Tuesday [11 Oct 2011] and from 12 p.m. to 6 p.m. Friday\n[14 Oct 2011].\n\n[Byline: Jamie Applegate]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose,\nor throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs,\nsneezes, or talks. Items used by an infected person, such as soft\ndrink cans or eating utensils, can also be contaminated with the\nvirus, which may spread to others if those items are shared. In\naddition, the virus may spread when someone with mumps touches items\nor surfaces without washing their hands and someone else then touches\nthe same surface and rubs their mouth or nose. The incubation time can\nrange from 12-25 days. Most mumps transmission likely occurs before\nthe salivary glands begin to swell and up to 5 days after the swelling\nbegins. Therefore, isolation of mumps patients is recommended for 5\ndays after their glands begin to swell.\n\nMumps was initially considered a monotypic virus and immunity induced\nby one vaccine strain lead to a significant reduction of reported\ncases of mumps. However, large outbreaks in vaccinated individuals and\nmonoclonal antibody studies have revealed that there are several\nstrains of mumps virus. Additionally, both symptomatic and subclinical\nre-infections in vaccinated and unvaccinated individuals with\ndifferent genotypes of mumps virus have been reported. (For more\ninformation, see\nhttp://ecdc.europa.eu/EN/HEALTHTOPICS/MUMPS/BASIC_FACTS/Pages/factsheet_professionals.aspx?MasterPage=1).\nIn this respect it will be relevant to establish if the outbreak\nstrain in California corresponds the predominant mumps virus genotype\n(G5) circulating in the UK currently (see: Mumps - UK (02): (Scotland)\nyoung people 20110224.0612). - Mod.CP]\n\n[For the HealthMap/ProMED map of California, USA showing the location\nof Berkeley, see http://healthmap.org/r/1jDz. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "University Health\nServices medical director Brad Buchman said prevention efforts are\nbeing focused on high-population student living areas with shared\ndining and bathroom facilities, including dorms, coops, and\nfraternities and sororities, because these areas have seen the most\nsuspected and confirmed cases. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of Berkeley Division of Public Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Great Britain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "832443", "headline": "PRO> Mumps - Czech Republic (02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=832443", "date": "2011-08-23 16:26:42", "main_text": "MUMPS - CZECH REPUBLIC (02): BACKGROUND\n***************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 23 Aug 2011\nFrom: Steve Berger\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n\nNotwithstanding an ongoing outbreak in northern Bohemia, the Czech\nRepublic has managed to reduce mumps to levels comparable to those of\nthe United States. In the following graph, I have contrasted rates per\n100 000 population for these 2 countries:\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Mumps-Czech.png.\n(The graph generation system is outlined in [1]).\n\nNote that a precipitous decline in mumps in the Czech Republic\nfollowed the introduction of widespread MMR vaccination in 1987.\n[2,3]\n\nReferences:\n-----------\n1. Gideon Graphs module\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Gideon-Graphs.pps\n(click link at lower left)\n2. Berger SA. Infectious Diseases of the Czech Republic, 2011. 424 pp,\n139 graphs, 1192 references. Gideon e-books,\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-the-czech-republic/\n3. Gideon e-books,\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/mumps-global-status/\n\n--\n Notwithstanding an ongoing outbreak in northern Bohemia, the Czech\nRepublic has managed to reduce mumps to levels comparable to those of\nthe United States. Gideon e-books,\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-the-czech-republic/\n3.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1987-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Czech Republic", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "832442", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Bermuda", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=832442", "date": "2011-08-23 16:24:06", "main_text": "MUMPS - BERMUDA\n***************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 22 Aug 2011\nSource: Bernews [edited]\nhttp://bernews.com/2011/08/several-cases-of-mumps-reported/\n\n\nBermuda Health Department: Several Cases Of Mumps Reported\n----------------------------------------------------------\nThe Department of Health today [22 Aug 2011] confirmed that physicians\nin the community have reported several cases of mumps, a vaccine\npreventable disease, in August. Although a serious disease, mumps is\nnow very uncommon. There have been only a total of 8 confirmed cases\nof mumps reported on the island over the past 10 years.\n\nThe Chief Medical Officer Dr. John Cann expressed concern over the\nnumber of reported cases this year, in light of our high immunization\ncoverage rates. He noted that mumps is highly communicable and it only\ntakes a few unvaccinated individuals to initiate transmission.\n\nMumps is usually a mild viral disease characterized by mild fever,\nheadache, muscle ache and swelling of the parotid salivary glands\n(located in the area between the neck and jaw, below the ears).\nSerious side effects of mumps are more common among adults than\nchildren. The disease is spread by contact with an infected person,\nthrough coughing and sneezing.\n\nMumps vaccine [contained in MMR (Measles, Mumps, and Rubella) combined\nvaccine] can prevent this disease. The vaccine given to children on a\n2-dose schedule prevents almost all cases of mumps [But see:\nProMED-mail post 'Mumps - Czech Republic: (SK) supplementary\nvaccination? 20110822.2553 - Mod.CP]. The MMR vaccine was introduced\nfor general use in Bermuda in 1983 as part of Bermuda's childhood\nimmunization programme. The majority of children have been fully\nimmunized by the age of 6 years. MMR is given at 15 months and a\nbooster is given between the ages of 4 to 6 years.\n\nThe Department of Health recommends that parents check their child's\nimmunization record to see if he or she has had the mumps or MMR\nvaccine. If your child has not been vaccinated and is 15 months of age\nor older, contact your pediatrician or family physician to have your\nchild vaccinated as soon as possible.\n\nIn addition, the department recommends that parents, who suspect that\ntheir child has mumps, contact their physician for diagnosis and\ntreatment Public Health Nurses will contact parents of children who\nmay have been exposed to individuals with mumps to ascertain their\nimmunization status and help determine whether they are protected. The\nHealth Department also said that children with suspected mumps should\nbe excluded from school/day care for at least 9 days after the swollen\nglands 1st appeared.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It may be that MMR vaccine coverage in Bermuda in recent years has\nbeen less than optimal. It is not stated whether the mumps cases are\nunvaccinated individuals. However it is now well established that the\nmumps component of the triple MMR vaccine is less protective than the\nother 2 components, and a small proportion of vaccinated individuals\nmay still be at risk of infection.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Bermuda can be accessed\nat: http://healthmap.org/r/1a6J. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "MUMPS - BERMUDA\n***************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In addition, the department recommends that parents, who suspect that\ntheir child has mumps, contact their physician for diagnosis and\ntreatment Public Health Nurses will contact parents of children who\nmay have been exposed to individuals with mumps to ascertain their\nimmunization status and help determine whether they are protected. The vaccine given to children on a\n2-dose schedule prevents almost all cases of mumps [But see:\nProMED-mail post 'Mumps - Czech Republic: (SK) supplementary\nvaccination? However it is now well established that the\nmumps component of the triple MMR vaccine is less protective than the\nother 2 components, and a small proportion of vaccinated individuals\nmay still be at risk of infection. The\nHealth Department also said that children with suspected mumps should\nbe excluded from school/day care for at least 9 days after the swollen\nglands 1st appeared. \n\nMumps is usually a mild viral disease characterized by mild fever,\nheadache, muscle ache and swelling of the parotid salivary glands\n(located in the area between the neck and jaw, below the ears). \n\nThe Department of Health recommends that parents check their child's\nimmunization record to see if he or she has had the mumps or MMR\nvaccine. The Department of Health today [22 Aug 2011] confirmed that physicians\nin the community have reported several cases of mumps, a vaccine\npreventable disease, in August. If your child has not been vaccinated and is 15 months of age\nor older, contact your pediatrician or family physician to have your\nchild vaccinated as soon as possible.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1983-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-08-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "900631", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (03): (CA) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=900631", "date": "2011-10-07 10:44:49", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (03): (CALIFORNIA) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS\n**************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 6 Oct 2011\nSource: The Epoch Times [edited]\nhttp://www.theepochtimes.com/n2/united-states/mumps-outbreak-on-uc-berkeley-campus-62503.html\n\n\nMumps outbreak on University of California at Berkeley campus\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nAt least 7 mumps cases have been confirmed at the University of\nCalifornia [UC] at Berkeley, according to reports on Thursday [6 Oct\n2011].\n\nMumps is a disease generally associated with small children and causes\nfever, aches, weakness, and headaches. It is spread via saliva or\nmucus from the mouth, nose, or throat.\n\nCases of mumps at the campus have risen sharply in the past week after\nit was first discovered in 4 people on Friday [30 Sep 2011]. 'There\nhasn't been an outbreak in at least 5 years,' Kim LaPean, a\nspokesperson with Berkeley's health center, told The San Francisco\nChronicle. There are 13 more suspected cases.\n\nAccording to an alert sent out by the university, school officials are\nworking with the state 'to limit (the) spread of the disease,'\naccording to the CBS-5 television station.\n\n[Byline: Jack Phillips]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPatricia Doyle, PhD\n<dr_p_doyle@hotmail.com>\n\n[This press report indicates that there may be as many as 20 cases of\nmumps among students at the UC Berkeley campus.\n\nBerkeley is situated on the east shore of San Francisco Bay in\nNorthern California. It can be located in the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at http://healthmap.org/r/1jDz. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "MUMPS - USA (03): (CALIFORNIA) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS\n**************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nPatricia Doyle, PhD\n<dr_p_doyle@hotmail.com>\n\n[This press report indicates that there may be as many as 20 cases of\nmumps among students at the UC Berkeley campus. So far 31\ncases have been reported in Ontario, including 2 in Ottawa.\n\n'There were 2 cases ... they have completely recovered and they have\npassed the stage where they could pass the virus on to anyone else,'\nsays Brenda MacLean of Ottawa Communicable Disease Prevention.\n\nMumps used to be a common childhood disease, but has been under\ncontrol since the development of a vaccine. Mumps is a viral infection\ntransmitted through direct contact. Signs of the infection include:\nFever, swelling or tenderness in the throat glands, and pain while\nchewing.\n\nOttawa typically sees 3 or 4 cases of mumps per year. Public Health\nofficials say the recent cases are not cause for alarm.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n****\n[2]\nDate: 29 Sep 2011\nFrom: John P. Maher, MD\nWest Chester, PA 19382\n<jmaher@chesco.org>\n\n\n[ProMED-mail received the following comment subsequent to the post\nentitled: 'Mumps - USA: (IL) university students, archive number\n20110928.2936,' about a mumps outbreak in Illinois, USA, which is\nequally applicable to the preceding Canadian post. - Mod.CP]\n\nOne can't help but wonder from the reassuring tone of the news release\nwhether the health department and/or the University health officials\ndidn't miss a 'teachable moment' with this outbreak, considering there\nis no mention therein about the potential (although perhaps uncommon)\ncomplications of preventable mumps infections, including orchitis,\naseptic meningitis, pancreatitis, hearing loss, etc.\n\n--\nJohn P. Maher, MD\nPublic Health Physician\nChester County Health Department\n601 Westtown Road, Ste 295\nWest Chester, PA 19382\n<jmaher@chesco.org>\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, is\navailable at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1i3l - CopyEd.EJP]", "summary": "CP]\n\nOne can't help but wonder from the reassuring tone of the news release\nwhether the health department and/or the University health officials\ndidn't miss a 'teachable moment' with this outbreak, considering there\nis no mention therein about the potential (although perhaps uncommon)\ncomplications of preventable mumps infections, including orchitis,\naseptic meningitis, pancreatitis, hearing loss, etc.\n\n--\nJohn P. Before deciding on\nrevaccination of adolescents, Vit wants to have an immunological\nsurvey carried out next year [2012] to show whether adolescents remain\nimmune against mumps or need a further vaccination, strengthening\ntheir immunity.\n\n'We defeated the epidemic in north Bohemia, but we still want to\ncomplete the immunologic survey next year [2012] to decide on whether\nadditional vaccination is needed in some areas to protect the group of\nchildren aged 14, 15 and more,' Vit said. A discussion is underway on\nwhat other infections the survey should map [immunity of] apart from\nmumps.\n\nIn the Usti region, north Bohemia, the epidemic afflicted mainly\npeople in the 14 to 19 age category. The Health Ministry, in\ncooperation with the regional health inspection, reacted by having 11\n832 children in the region vaccinated for free.\n\n>From January 2011 to the 14th week of 2011, a total of 516 cases of\nmumps were reported in 4 of the region's 7 districts, which is 61.7\npatients per 100 000 inhabitants. The cases in the Usti region made up\n76 percent of mumps cases that were registered nationwide in the given\nperiod.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps outbreaks in recent years have given rise to questions about\nthe effectiveness of the mumps vaccine. A recent study in Israel\nexamined epidemiological data from a recent mumps outbreak there and\nobserved that the epidemiological and laboratory evidence suggested\nthat many previously vaccinated adolescents and young adults were now\nsusceptible to mumps because their vaccine-based immunity has waned.\nThey concluded that booster vaccination programmes for those at high\nrisk of infection during mumps outbreaks -- particularly those in\ncongregate living environments -- merit priority consideration (Anis\nE, Grotto I, Moerman L, Warshavsky B, Slater PE, Lev B. Mumps outbreak\nin Israel's highly vaccinated society: are two doses enough? Infect.\n2011 Apr 20:1-8,\nhttp://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=8259199).\n\nShelley L. Deeks, et al. (An assessment of mumps vaccine effectiveness\nby dose during an outbreak in Canada (CMAJ. 2011 June 14; 183(9):\n1014-1020, http://www.cmaj.ca/content/183/9/1014) reported that the\nvaccine effectiveness of one dose of the MMR vaccine ranged from\n49.2-81.6 percent, whereas vaccine effectiveness of 2 doses ranged\nfrom 66.3-88.0 percent. If vaccine effectiveness of 85 percent for 2\ndoses of the vaccine is assumed, vaccine coverage of 88.2 percent and\n98.0 percent would be needed to interrupt community transmission of\nmumps. They concluded that outbreaks occurring in Ontario and\nelsewhere serve as a warning against complacency over vaccination\nprogrammes. (See also: ProMED-mail: Mumps - Canada (04): (ON)\n20110809.2418).\n\nIt is likely that an analysis of the situation in northern Bohemia\nwould reinforce these conclusions. A map of the Czech Republic showing\nthe location of North Bohemia can be accessed at:\nhttp://www.czechpoint.co.uk/maps/map5.htm. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "2011 June 14; 183(9):\n1014-1020, http://www.cmaj.ca/content/183/9/1014) reported that the\nvaccine effectiveness of one dose of the MMR vaccine ranged from\n49.2-81.6 percent, whereas vaccine effectiveness of 2 doses ranged\nfrom 66.3-88.0 percent. A recent study in Israel\nexamined epidemiological data from a recent mumps outbreak there and\nobserved that the epidemiological and laboratory evidence suggested\nthat many previously vaccinated adolescents and young adults were now\nsusceptible to mumps because their vaccine-based immunity has waned. They concluded that booster vaccination programmes for those at high\nrisk of infection during mumps outbreaks -- particularly those in\ncongregate living environments -- merit priority consideration (Anis\nE, Grotto I, Moerman L, Warshavsky B, Slater PE, Lev B. Mumps outbreak\nin Israel's highly vaccinated society: are two doses enough? Czech chief health inspector Michael Vit has told CTK [Czech News\nAgency] that he is considering revaccination of adolescents against\nmumps in view of the recent epidemic of the disease in a north\nBohemian region [Stredocesky or Usti nad Labem] where 996 cases were\nreported in the 1st 4 months of this year [2011]. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps outbreaks in recent years have given rise to questions about\nthe effectiveness of the mumps vaccine. \n\n'We defeated the epidemic in north Bohemia, but we still want to\ncomplete the immunologic survey next year [2012] to decide on whether\nadditional vaccination is needed in some areas to protect the group of\nchildren aged 14, 15 and more,' Vit said. From January 2011 to the 14th week of 2011, a total of 516 cases of\nmumps were reported in 4 of the region's 7 districts, which is 61.7\npatients per 100 000 inhabitants. The cases in the Usti region made up\n76 percent of mumps cases that were registered nationwide in the given\nperiod.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-01-25 00:00:00", "2011-06-14 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Czech Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "824022", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (05): (ON)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=824022", "date": "2011-08-17 16:11:31", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (05): (ONTARIO)\n******************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 16 Aug 2011\nSource: The London Free Press [edited]\nhttp://www.lfpress.com/news/london/2011/08/15/18556386.html\n\n\nWith 4 cases of mumps discovered among Londoners, the Middlesex-\nLondon Health Unit is urging returning university and college-age\nstudents to get [vaccinated against] measles, mumps and rubella. The\nclose quarters that bring together young people from a wide area are\nprime breeding grounds for the airborne disease.\n\n'It's not an epidemic,' said Marlene Price, manager of vaccine and\npreventable diseases for the health unit. But anyone born since 1970\nis advised to seek a 2nd dose of vaccine, because most have had only\none. Persons born before 1970 are seen as having natural immunity, she\nsaid, because they have likely already been exposed and have stronger\ndefense mechanisms. [However], persons born before 1970 who work in\nhealth care or the military also should seek a 2nd vaccination, she\nsaid.\n\nMumps can lead to fever, muscle aches, headaches, fatigue, swelling of\nglands and can develop into complications that include infections of\nthe brain, ovaries, breasts or pancreas. Price said anyone who\ndevelops mumps symptoms should stay home and consult their health-care\nprovider, student health services or attend health unit walk-in\nimmunization clinics in London and Strathroy.\n\nTo prevent the spread of mumps, things that have been in other\npeople's mouths should not be shared, kissing avoided, and coughs and\nsneezes should be stifled into the elbow. Frequent hand-washing is\nrecommended.\n\nPrice said the imminent arrival of students will create ideal\nconditions to promote the spread of mumps.\n\n[Byline: Chip Martin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not stated whether the cases of mumps now appearing in London,\nOntario are related directly to the cases recently reported in Toronto\n[see: Mumps - Canada (04): (ON) 20110809.2418], or to the original\noutbreak in British Columbia. Further information is awaited.\n\nReaders are referred to the previous post in this thread for\ndiscussion of the effectiveness of the mumps virus component of the\nmeasles, mumps and rubella (MMR) triple vaccine.\n\nA map of the province of Ontario showing the location of London can be\naccessed at:\nhttp://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/auth/english/maps/reference/provincesterritories/ontario/referencemap_image_view.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "MUMPS - CANADA (05): (ONTARIO)\n******************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Price said anyone who\ndevelops mumps symptoms should stay home and consult their health-care\nprovider, student health services or attend health unit walk-in\nimmunization clinics in London and Strathroy. [Byline: Chip Martin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< \n\nReaders are referred to the previous post in this thread for\ndiscussion of the effectiveness of the mumps virus component of the\nmeasles, mumps and rubella (MMR) triple vaccine. With 4 cases of mumps discovered among Londoners, the Middlesex-\nLondon Health Unit is urging returning university and college-age\nstudents to get [vaccinated against] measles, mumps and rubella. \n\nMumps can lead to fever, muscle aches, headaches, fatigue, swelling of\nglands and can develop into complications that include infections of\nthe brain, ovaries, breasts or pancreas. \n\nTo prevent the spread of mumps, things that have been in other\npeople's mouths should not be shared, kissing avoided, and coughs and\nsneezes should be stifled into the elbow.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "1970-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Strathroy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "853060", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Bosnia & Herzegovina: ongoing outbreak", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=853060", "date": "2011-09-01 17:26:34", "main_text": "MUMPS - BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA: ONGOING OUTBREAK\n************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 1 Sep 2011\nSource: Eurosurveillance 2011; 16(35) [abridged, edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19959\n\n\nOngoing large mumps outbreak in the Federation of Bosnia and\nHerzegovina. Dec 2010 to Jul 2011\n----------------------------------------------\n[abridged from: Hukic M, Ravlija J, Dedeic Ljubovic A, Moro A, Arapcic\nS, Muller CP, et al. Ongoing large mumps outbreak in the Federation of\nBosnia and Herzegovina, Bosnia and Herzegovina, December 2010 to July\n2011]\n\nSummary\n-------\n>From December 2010 until the end of July 2011, 5261 mumps cases were\nrecorded in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, leading to an\nincidence of 225.8 per 100 000. 15 to 19 year olds (43 per cent) were\nmost affected, and 62 per cent of cases were male. Mumps-specific IgM\nantibodies were found in about 70 per cent of sera investigated,\ncomplications were reported in 41 per cent of 81 hospitalised\npatients. The outbreak affected mainly those unvaccinated or unaware\nof their vaccination status and is probably due to vaccination\nfailures during the war and post-war period (1992-1998).\n\nIn December 2010, the cantons of Zenica-Doboj (n=40) and Central\nBosnia (n=34) reported an increased number of mumps cases to the\nMinistry of Health of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Subsequently, the number\nof mumps patients continued to rise, and more cantons reported cases.\nBy the end of July 2011, a total of 5261 cases were reported to the\nMinistry of Health.\n\nBackground\n----------\nImmunisation against mumps was introduced in Bosnia and Herzegovina in\n1980 in the form of a combined vaccine against measles, mumps, and\nrubella (MMR) [1]. Until 1992, it was recommended to vaccinate\nchildren between one and 14 years of age without documented history of\nmumps with one dose of MMR vaccine. Between 1992 and 1995, the war\ncaused disruptions to the routine immunisation programme in the\ncountry, and these disruptions continued also during the post-war\nperiod (1996-1998). In 2001, a 2-dose schedule with MMR vaccine was\nimplemented throughout the country, with the 1st dose given at the age\nof 12 months and the 2nd dose at the age of 7 years and no later than\n14 years. The MMR vaccine produced by the Institute of Immunology\nZagreb was used until 2009 and contained the L-Zagreb strain as the\ncomponent, and since 2010, the Glaxo SmithKline MMR vaccine containing\nthe Jeryl Lynn strain has been employed [1,2]. The average coverage\nwith MMR vaccine for the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina between\n1998 and 2009 ranged from 84-92 per cent for the 1st dose, and from\n53-92 per cent for the 2nd dose (figure 1).\n\nMumps is a notifiable disease in Bosnia and Herzegovina and is\nreported on the basis of clinical symptoms and epidemiological data.\nReporting of mumps is normally done by the doctors to the Institute\nfor Public Health, which looks for epidemic evidence and provides\ninformation to the Ministry of Health.\n\nThe 1st reports on mumps in Bosnia and Herzegovina date back to 1956\n[3]. In the period before 1980, when vaccination against mumps was\nintroduced, morbidity was high with an incidence ranging from 189 to\n253 cases per 100 000 inhabitants per year (figure 2). After\nintroduction of the vaccine, incidence decreased from 123 in 1981 to\n3.5 in 1992. During the war from 1992 to 1995, the reported incidence\nof mumps was between 7.8 and 5.1, but reporting was irregular, and\nunderreporting is likely. Between 1999 and 2002, 25 smaller outbreaks\nwere reported with a total of 2743 cases. The last outbreak of mumps\nin Bosnia and Herzegovina occurred in 2002 with a total of 410\nreported cases, and until December 2010 only few cases were notified\n[4].\n\nAt the beginning of December 2010, a mumps outbreak started in the\nFederation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and is still currently ongoing.\nThis report describes the mumps outbreak in the country and includes\ndata from December 2010 until the end of July 2011.\n\nDescription of the outbreak\n---------------------------\nSince the start of the outbreak in December 2010, 5261 cases have\noccurred in 9 of the 10 cantons of the country; however, cantons are\naffected to a different extent. In December 2010, 85 cases were\nreported, and the peak of the outbreak was in April 2011 with 1240\ncases reported (figure 3).\n\nThe most severely affected cantons are Central Bosnia Canton (n=2156\ncases), Zenica-Doboj Canton (n=1695), Sarajevo Canton (n=1035), and\nHerzegovina-Neretva Canton (n=326). Together, they account for about\n99 per cent of all cases. Only a few cases have been reported in\nUna-Sana, Tuzla, Bosnian Podrinje, West Herzegovina, and West Bosnia\ncantons, and no cases from Posavina Canton (figure 4).\n\nFor 5219 patients, data on age and sex are available. The majority\n(3255/5219; 62 per cent) are male, and the most affected age groups\ninclude the 15 to 19 year olds (2232/5219; 43 per cent), followed by\n20 to 29 year olds (1254/5219; 24 per cent) (figure 5).\n\nPatients with serious clinical symptoms such as fever, temperature\nabove 38.5 C, swelling of the parotid and/or salivary glands, and\nfatigue were hospitalised. A total of 81 patients were admitted to the\nClinical Centre University of Sarajevo, but we have no data for other\nhospitals. The vast majority were male (67/81, 83 per cent), and 30 of\nthem had orchitis (30/67, 45 per cent). One female and 2 male patients\nhad meningitis (3/81, 4 per cent).\n\nVaccination status of cases\n---------------------------\nFor 34 per cent of the cases (1774/5219) vaccination status was\nunknown. About 33 per cent of cases (1722/5219) were unvaccinated, 18\nper cent (939/5219) were vaccinated with one dose of a\nmumps-containing vaccine, and only 15 per cent (784/5219) had received\n2 doses (figure 6).\n\nLaboratory findings\n-------------------\nSamples were collected for laboratory analysis from 104 cases: throat\nswabs from 32, throat swabs and serum from 48, and only serum from 24\nof them. The cases' age ranged from 7-48 years (median: 22.15 \u00b1\n7.47), and 83 per cent were male. All 72 serum samples were tested\nwith the Siemens Enzygnost anti-parotitis virus kit for mumps-specific\nIgG and IgM antibodies. 68 samples were IgG positive (94 per cent), 3\nwere borderline, and one was negative. A total of 50 samples were\npositive for IgM (69 per cent), 8 were borderline, and 14 were\nnegative. The results of PCR and sequence analysis from throat swabs\nare pending.\n\nControl measures\n----------------\nIn March 2011, the federal minister of health declared a mumps\nepidemic. It was recommended to increase the vaccination coverage with\n2 doses of MMR vaccine in children between one and 14 years of age,\nand some schools with increased case numbers were temporarily closed.\nOther epidemic control measures by public health authorities,\nsupported by doctors and/or teachers in the schools included: (i)\nhealth education, (ii) disseminating information about general and\npersonal sanitary and hygienic measures to take, (iii) isolating\ninfected persons and limiting contact with them, (iv) disinfection of\narticles of general use, and (v) frequent hand washing in order to\nlimit further spread of the disease. The control measures were in\naccordance with protocols for prevention and infection control.\n\nDiscussion and conclusions\n--------------------------\nIn recent years, mumps outbreaks were reported from many countries all\nover the world [5-8]. In Bosnia and Herzegovina, disruption in the\nimmunisation program during the war (1992-1995) and in the post-war\nperiod (1996-1998) left considerable numbers of children susceptible\nto measles, rubella, and mumps [9]. The children, who were supposed to\nget their 1st vaccination between 1992 and 1998 are now between 14 and\n20 years old and constitute a large proportion of the people affected\nby the current outbreak. Our data also show that most cases in the\ncurrent outbreak (85 per cent) either did not know their vaccination\nstatus or reported being not or incompletely vaccinated.\n\nThe geographical regions with the highest case numbers in the current\nmumps outbreak largely concur with the areas that were most severely\naffected during previously reported rubella and measles epidemics\n[10,11]. Also, during the war from 1992 to 1995, immunisation was not\nfully implemented across the entire territory of Bosnia and\nHerzegovina. The program of immunisation was not the same across the\nCantons. Two doses of vaccine were used in the Posavina,\nHerzegovina-Neretva and West Herzegovina cantons, while in other\ncantons, only one dose was implemented. Some small outbreaks occurred\nin Una-Sana Canton and Tuzla Canton, and they had additional\nvaccination with monovalent parotitis vaccine, and that is the\nprobable reason for the smaller number of cases in these cantons in\nthe current outbreak.\n\nSimilar to the rubella outbreak in 2010 [10], more males contracted\nthe disease (62 per cent), and the most severely affected age group\nwere young adolescents (15 to 19 years of age, 43 per cent). High\nnumbers of mumps cases in male adolescents were reported recently from\nseveral countries, such as Israel, the United Kingdom, the\nNetherlands, and the United States [5,12-14].\n\nThe majority of cases reported during the current outbreak were\ndiagnosed based on clinical symptoms, sometimes supported by\nepidemiological data. Only a few samples were collected from\nnon-hospitalised patients for laboratory confirmation, as the clinical\npicture was considered typical. In about 70 percent of the serum\nsamples, mumps-specific IgM antibodies were detected, confirming the\nclinical diagnosis.\n\nInformation about complications and hospitalisations related to the\noutbreak is incomplete. The available data point to complications in\nabout 7 per cent of the female (meningitis) and 48 per cent of the\nmale (meningitis and orchitis) hospitalised patients, however, total\nnumbers of cases are low. Symptomatic meningitis has been reported to\noccur in up to 15 per cent of patients and orchitis in as many as 50\nper cent of post-pubertal males in other studies [12].\n\nIn conclusion, Bosnia and Herzegovina is currently facing a large\noutbreak of mumps with an incidence of 225.8 in the Federation of\nBosnia and Herzegovna in the 1st half of 2011. The outbreak is\nprobably related to failures to vaccinate during the war and post-war\nperiod between 1992 and 1998. Monitoring of the immunisation status\nand vaccine effectiveness, high vaccination coverage rates with 2\ndoses, and catch-up campaigns are necessary to avoid measles, mumps,\nor rubella outbreaks in the future.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The figures and references have been omitted from this posting, and\ninterested readers should consult the original document via the source\nURL.\n\nFormerly one of the 6 federal units constituting the Socialist Federal\nRepublic of Yugoslavia, Bosnia and Herzegovina gained its independence\nduring the Yugoslav Wars of the 1990s. A map of Bosnia and Herzegovina\ncan be accessed at\nhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina#Bosnian_War_.281992.E2.80.931995.29.\n\nThe level of immunisation achieved in Bosnia and Herzegovina, despite\na decline in cases between 2002 and 2010, has not been sufficient to\ninterrupt the transmission of mumps virus infection. As the triple MMR\nvaccine has been in use since 1980, it would be interesting to have\ninformation on the incidence of measles and rubella during the same\nperiod.\n\nThe MMR vaccine produced by the Institute of Immunology Zagreb was\nused until 2009 and contained the L-Zagreb strain as component, and\nsince 2010, the Glaxo SmithKline MMR vaccine containing the Jeryl Lynn\nstrain has been employed. Was there a reason for this? - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Other epidemic control measures by public health authorities,\nsupported by doctors and/or teachers in the schools included: (i)\nhealth education, (ii) disseminating information about general and\npersonal sanitary and hygienic measures to take, (iii) isolating\ninfected persons and limiting contact with them, (iv) disinfection of\narticles of general use, and (v) frequent hand washing in order to\nlimit further spread of the disease. MUMPS - BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA: ONGOING OUTBREAK\n************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Some small outbreaks occurred\nin Una-Sana Canton and Tuzla Canton, and they had additional\nvaccination with monovalent parotitis vaccine, and that is the\nprobable reason for the smaller number of cases in these cantons in\nthe current outbreak.\n\n About 33 per cent of cases (1722/5219) were unvaccinated, 18\nper cent (939/5219) were vaccinated with one dose of a\nmumps-containing vaccine, and only 15 per cent (784/5219) had received\n2 doses (figure 6). The majority\n(3255/5219; 62 per cent) are male, and the most affected age groups\ninclude the 15 to 19 year olds (2232/5219; 43 per cent), followed by\n20 to 29 year olds (1254/5219; 24 per cent) (figure 5). The available data point to complications in\nabout 7 per cent of the female (meningitis) and 48 per cent of the\nmale (meningitis and orchitis) hospitalised patients, however, total\nnumbers of cases are low. The last outbreak of mumps\nin Bosnia and Herzegovina occurred in 2002 with a total of 410\nreported cases, and until December 2010 only few cases were notified\n Mumps-specific IgM\nantibodies were found in about 70 per cent of sera investigated,\ncomplications were reported in 41 per cent of 81 hospitalised\npatients. The average coverage\nwith MMR vaccine for the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina between\n1998 and 2009 ranged from 84-92 per cent for the 1st dose, and from\n53-92 per cent for the 2nd dose (figure 1). In Bosnia and Herzegovina, disruption in the\nimmunisation program during the war (1992-1995) and in the post-war\nperiod (1996-1998) left considerable numbers of children susceptible\nto measles, rubella, and mumps [9]. In 2001, a 2-dose schedule with MMR vaccine was\nimplemented throughout the country, with the 1st dose given at the age\nof 12 months and the 2nd dose at the age of 7 years and no later than\n14 years. The geographical regions with the highest case numbers in the current\nmumps outbreak largely concur with the areas that were most severely\naffected during previously reported rubella and measles epidemics\n Monitoring of the immunisation status\nand vaccine effectiveness, high vaccination coverage rates with 2\ndoses, and catch-up campaigns are necessary to avoid measles, mumps,\nor rubella outbreaks in the future. High\nnumbers of mumps cases in male adolescents were reported recently from\nseveral countries, such as Israel, the United Kingdom, the\nNetherlands, and the United States [5,12-14]. \nImmunisation against mumps was introduced in Bosnia and Herzegovina in\n1980 in the form of a combined vaccine against measles, mumps, and\nrubella (MMR) The children, who were supposed to\nget their 1st vaccination between 1992 and 1998 are now between 14 and\n20 years old and constitute a large proportion of the people affected\nby the current outbreak. Between 1992 and 1995, the war\ncaused disruptions to the routine immunisation programme in the\ncountry, and these disruptions continued also during the post-war\nperiod (1996-1998). The MMR vaccine produced by the Institute of Immunology\nZagreb was used until 2009 and contained the L-Zagreb strain as the\ncomponent, and since 2010, the Glaxo SmithKline MMR vaccine containing\nthe Jeryl Lynn strain has been employed [1,2]. The MMR vaccine produced by the Institute of Immunology Zagreb was\nused until 2009 and contained the L-Zagreb strain as component, and\nsince 2010, the Glaxo SmithKline MMR vaccine containing the Jeryl Lynn\nstrain has been employed. As the triple MMR\nvaccine has been in use since 1980, it would be interesting to have\ninformation on the incidence of measles and rubella during the same\nperiod. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Similar to the rubella outbreak in 2010 [10], more males contracted\nthe disease (62 per cent), and the most severely affected age group\nwere young adolescents (15 to 19 years of age, 43 per cent). In December 2010, 85 cases were\nreported, and the peak of the outbreak was in April 2011 with 1240\ncases reported (figure 3). Our data also show that most cases in the\ncurrent outbreak (85 per cent) either did not know their vaccination\nstatus or reported being not or incompletely vaccinated. \n\nThe majority of cases reported during the current outbreak were\ndiagnosed based on clinical symptoms, sometimes supported by\nepidemiological data. Symptomatic meningitis has been reported to\noccur in up to 15 per cent of patients and orchitis in as many as 50\nper cent of post-pubertal males in other studies [12]. In the period before 1980, when vaccination against mumps was\nintroduced, morbidity was high with an incidence ranging from 189 to\n253 cases per 100 000 inhabitants per year (figure 2). The outbreak affected mainly those unvaccinated or unaware\nof their vaccination status and is probably due to vaccination\nfailures during the war and post-war period (1992-1998). In December 2010, the cantons of Zenica-Doboj (n=40) and Central\nBosnia (n=34) reported an increased number of mumps cases to the\nMinistry of Health of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Since the start of the outbreak in December 2010, 5261 cases have\noccurred in 9 of the 10 cantons of the country; however, cantons are\naffected to a different extent. From December 2010 until the end of July 2011, 5261 mumps cases were\nrecorded in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, leading to an\nincidence of 225.8 per 100 000. Until 1992, it was recommended to vaccinate\nchildren between one and 14 years of age without documented history of\nmumps with one dose of MMR vaccine. Only a few cases have been reported in\nUna-Sana, Tuzla, Bosnian Podrinje, West Herzegovina, and West Bosnia\ncantons, and no cases from Posavina Canton (figure 4). The level of immunisation achieved in Bosnia and Herzegovina, despite\na decline in cases between 2002 and 2010, has not been sufficient to\ninterrupt the transmission of mumps virus infection. It was recommended to increase the vaccination coverage with\n2 doses of MMR vaccine in children between one and 14 years of age,\nand some schools with increased case numbers were temporarily closed.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1992-03-25 00:00:00", "1981-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2743-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "1956-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-04-25 00:00:00", "5219-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-12-25 00:00:00", "1240-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2032-03-25 00:00:00", "1980-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Zagreb", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bosnia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bosnia and", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yugoslavia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "symptomatic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Herzegovna", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bosnia and Herzegovina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Posavina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Herzegovina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tuzla", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "813559", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (04): (ON)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=813559", "date": "2011-08-09 16:47:02", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (04): (ONTARIO)\n******************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 8 Aug 2011\nFrom: Effie Gournis\n<egourni@toronto.ca>\n\n\nOutbreak of mumps in Toronto - Canada (Ontario)\n-----------------------------------------------\nToronto Public Health reports 11 cases of mumps (10 confirmed and 1\nprobable) since 20 Jul 2011. The index case for this cluster travelled\nfrom Vancouver (where a mumps outbreak that started in Whistler [see\nProMED-mail references below] has recently spread) to Toronto on 3 Jun\n2011 and developed symptoms on 9 Jun 2011. Transmission was initially\nconfined to employees and patrons at the Toronto financial district\nrestaurant where the index case worked, but has now spread to other\nsites. Currently, all confirmed cases have some link (work, meeting,\nor other activities) to the downtown financial core of Toronto. A\nsmall number of other cases linked to this outbreak have also been\nreported from other health units within Ontario.\n\nThe median age of the 11 cases is 34 years, with a range of 24 to 47\nyears; 73 per cent of cases are male. One case had received 2 doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine, 3 cases had received a single dose, and the\nrest had an unknown vaccination history. Reports continue to be\nreceived and investigated. Genotyping of all lab-confirmed cases is\npending.\n\nToronto Public Health's response has included: 1) a vaccine clinic for\nemployees of the restaurant, 2) 2 public health alerts to assist\nclinicians with diagnosing mumps and infection prevention and control\nmeasures for their office, 3) promotion of vaccine messages through\nmedia outlets, and 4) the exclusion from work of susceptible employees\nin a high risk setting (for example, health care workers) for the\nperiod 12 to 26 days following their exposure.\n\nOne other confirmed case of mumps also travelled to Vancouver during\ntheir period of acquisition and was reported before this outbreak.\nThere was no evidence of any further transmission from this case.\n\n--\nEffie Gournis, manager, Communicable Disease Surveillance Unit,\nToronto Public Health\nDr Barbara Yaffe, director and associate medical officer of health,\nCommunicable Disease Control, Toronto Public Health\nDr Allison Chris, associate medical officer of health, Communicable\nDisease Control, Toronto Public Health\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Toronto Public Health for provision of this\nofficial update.\n\nThese observations indicate that, whereas the mumps virus component of\nthe MMR triple vaccine may be adequate to eliminate infection at the\ncommunity level, not all individuals may be protected against\nre-exposure.\n\nRecently SL Deeks and colleagues published 'An assessment of mumps\nvaccine effectiveness by dose during an outbreak in Canada' (CMAJ\n2011; 183(9), June 14, http://www.cmaj.ca/content/183/9/1014. They\nreported that vaccine effectiveness of one dose of the MMR vaccine\nranged from 49.2 per cent to 81.6 per cent, whereas vaccine\neffectiveness of 2 doses ranged from 66.3 per cent to 88.0 per cent.\nAssuming a vaccine effectiveness of 85 per cent for 2 doses of the\nvaccine, vaccine coverage of 88.2 per cent and 98.0 per cent would be\nneeded to interrupt community transmission of mumps if the\ncorresponding reproductive values were 4 and 6.\n\nTheir estimates of vaccine effectiveness of one and 2 doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine were consistent with the estimates that have\nbeen reported in other outbreaks. Outbreaks occurring in Ontario and\nelsewhere serve as a warning against complacency over vaccination\nprogrammes.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Canada can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/007x. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "\n\nToronto Public Health's response has included: 1) a vaccine clinic for\nemployees of the restaurant, 2) 2 public health alerts to assist\nclinicians with diagnosing mumps and infection prevention and control\nmeasures for their office, 3) promotion of vaccine messages through\nmedia outlets, and 4) the exclusion from work of susceptible employees\nin a high risk setting (for example, health care workers) for the\nperiod 12 to 26 days following their exposure. They\nreported that vaccine effectiveness of one dose of the MMR vaccine\nranged from 49.2 per cent to 81.6 per cent, whereas vaccine\neffectiveness of 2 doses ranged from 66.3 per cent to 88.0 per cent.\n MUMPS - CANADA (04): (ONTARIO)\n******************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Assuming a vaccine effectiveness of 85 per cent for 2 doses of the\nvaccine, vaccine coverage of 88.2 per cent and 98.0 per cent would be\nneeded to interrupt community transmission of mumps if the\ncorresponding reproductive values were 4 and 6. \n\nThese observations indicate that, whereas the mumps virus component of\nthe MMR triple vaccine may be adequate to eliminate infection at the\ncommunity level, not all individuals may be protected against\nre-exposure.\n\n The index case for this cluster travelled\nfrom Vancouver (where a mumps outbreak that started in Whistler [see\nProMED-mail references below] has recently spread) to Toronto on 3 Jun\n2011 and developed symptoms on 9 Jun 2011. Transmission was initially\nconfined to employees and patrons at the Toronto financial district\nrestaurant where the index case worked, but has now spread to other\nsites. \n\n--\nEffie Gournis, manager, Communicable Disease Surveillance Unit,\nToronto Public Health\n \n\nTheir estimates of vaccine effectiveness of one and 2 doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine were consistent with the estimates that have\nbeen reported in other outbreaks.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-06-09 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-06-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "698377", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, supermarket - UK: England, susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=698377", "date": "2011-04-13 16:49:38", "main_text": "MUMPS, SUPERMARKET - UK: ENGLAND, SUSPECTED\n*******************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Apr 2011\nSource: Medway Messenger [edited]\nhttp://www.kentonline.co.uk/medway_messenger/news/2011/april/13/mumps_outbreak.aspx\n\n\nMumps has broken out among staff at Gillingham's new Tesco Extra\nstore. Ten people have been off work from the Courteney Road store\nsuffering from an illness with mumps-like symptoms in the last month.\n\nA spokesman said: 'It is under control, and everyone is receiving\nmedication. More than 500 people work at the store, so it is a very\nsmall percentage. 'Where staff have felt ill at the store, they have\nbeen sent home immediately. If anyone has phoned in with the symptoms,\nthey have been told to stay at home for 7 days.' The store reopened at\nthe end of February 2011 after an extensive refurbishment and\nexpansion.\n\nA member of the public contacted the Medway Messenger to express her\nconcern about mumps there because she has family members who use the\nstore with young children, some of whom had not had their MMR\nvaccinations.\n\nThe outbreak matches a recent sharp rise in the number of cases of\nmeasles and mumps nationally and across Kent. The general situation\nhas prompted the Health Protection Agency (HPA) in the southeast to\nreiterate a warning to parents, urging them to ensure children are\nfully protected with 2 doses of MMR [measles, mumps and rubella]\nvaccine.\n\nSpokesperson Teresa Cash said: 'We have not been made aware of a\nparticular problem/outbreak in Gillingham. There has been an increase\nin reports of mumps-like symptoms in the Kent HPU area over the last\nfew days. These are as yet unconfirmed by laboratory testing. These\nreports are of individual cases, some of whom may well have\nconnections to particular places, but this is a detail about which we\nwould not necessarily always be informed.'\n\nSo far in 2011 in the Kent Health Protection Unit (HPU), there have\nbeen 115 reports of mumps-like symptoms, but only 24 confirmed cases.\nThere were 52 confirmed cases in the same period in 2010. In the whole\nof 2010, the Kent HPU had 116 confirmed cases of mumps. Data had been\nrecorded differently in previous years, so it was not possible to give\na proper comparison. Ms Cash added: 'It should be noted that it is\nlikely that many cases go undiagnosed or unreported.'\n\n>From January to the end of March 2011, there had been 19 confirmed\ncases of measles in Kent, one of the highest levels in the southeast\nregion, with a total of 42 for the period. In the whole of 2010 in\nKent, there were 7 confirmed cases of measles with 107 confirmed cases\nin 2009.\n\n[Byline: Mary Louis]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The high level of measles cases in the county indicates that the\nuptake of MMR vaccine has been less than optimal, and, consequently, a\nproportion of children and young adults will be vulnerable to mumps\nvirus infection. It would be interesting to know the ages and\nhistories of the supermarket staff affected by this mumps outbreak.\n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose,\nor throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs,\nsneezes or talks. Items used by an infected person can also be\ncontaminated with the virus. In addition, the virus may spread when\nsomeone with mumps touches items or surfaces without washing their\nhands and someone else then touches the same surface and rubs their\nmouth or nose (such as at a supermarket check-out).\n\nMost mumps transmission likely occurs before the salivary glands\nbegin to swell and within the 5 days after the swelling begins.\nTherefore, mumps patients should be isolated for 5 days after their\nglands begin to swell.\n\nMost people with mumps recover fully. However, mumps can occasionally\ncause complications, and some of them can be serious. Complications\nmay occur even if a person does not have swollen salivary glands\n(parotitis) and are more common in people who have reached puberty.\nComplications of mumps can include: Inflammation of the testicles\n(orchitis), inflammation of the brain (encephalitis) and inflammation\nof the ovaries (oophoritis) and/or breasts (mastitis) in females who\nhave reached puberty. Temporary or permanent deafness is a rare\noutcome.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the county of Kent can\nbe accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/0GtB to show the location of\nthe town of Gillingham. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "MUMPS, SUPERMARKET - UK: ENGLAND, SUSPECTED\n*******************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The general situation\nhas prompted the Health Protection Agency (HPA) in the southeast to\nreiterate a warning to parents, urging them to ensure children are\nfully protected with 2 doses of MMR [measles, mumps and rubella]\nvaccine. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The high level of measles cases in the county indicates that the\nuptake of MMR vaccine has been less than optimal, and, consequently, a\nproportion of children and young adults will be vulnerable to mumps\nvirus infection. In addition, the virus may spread when\nsomeone with mumps touches items or surfaces without washing their\nhands and someone else then touches the same surface and rubs their\nmouth or nose (such as at a supermarket check-out). Complications of mumps can include: Inflammation of the testicles\n(orchitis), inflammation of the brain (encephalitis) and inflammation\nof the ovaries (oophoritis) and/or breasts (mastitis) in females who\nhave reached puberty. A member of the public contacted the Medway Messenger to express her\nconcern about mumps there because she has family members who use the\nstore with young children, some of whom had not had their MMR\nvaccinations. These\nreports are of individual cases, some of whom may well have\nconnections to particular places, but this is a detail about which we\nwould not necessarily always be informed.' \n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose,\nor throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs,\nsneezes or talks. In the whole of 2010 in\nKent, there were 7 confirmed cases of measles with 107 confirmed cases\nin 2009. From January to the end of March 2011, there had been 19 confirmed\ncases of measles in Kent, one of the highest levels in the southeast\nregion, with a total of 42 for the period. There has been an increase\nin reports of mumps-like symptoms in the Kent HPU area over the last\nfew days. Source: Medway Messenger [edited]\nhttp://www.kentonline.co.uk/medway_messenger/news/2011/april/13/mumps_outbreak.aspx\n\n\nMumps has broken out among staff at Gillingham's new Tesco Extra\nstore. \n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the county of Kent can\nbe accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/0GtB to show the location of\nthe town of Gillingham. Complications\nmay occur even if a person does not have swollen salivary glands\n(parotitis) and are more common in people who have reached puberty.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-01-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "699835", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada: (BC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=699835", "date": "2011-04-15 16:29:39", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA: (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n**********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 14 Apr 2011\nSource: News 1130 [edited]\nhttp://www.news1130.com/news/local/article/212600--an-outbreak-of-mumps-in-whistler\n\n\nOutbreak of mumps in Whistler\n-----------------------------\nWith 15 lab confirmed cases of mumps in Whistler, British Columbia,\nCanada, so far, Coastal Health is warning young people about the\nvirus.\n\nMumps is most commonly transmitted by saliva. It typically starts\nwith a few days of fever, headache, muscle aches and loss of appetite,\nand is followed by swelling of salivary glands. There is no specific\ntreatment.\n\nMedical Health officer Doctor Paul Martiquet says it's best not to\nshare anything your mouth has touched, like utensils or water bottles.\n'This is the type of behaviour that allows mumps to be spread, and\nthat is what we're seeing happening in Whistler.'\n\nHe says ultimately immunization is your best defence. Nurses will be\ngiving out free mumps shots this weekend at the Telus World Ski and\nSnowboard Festival in Whistler [15-24 Apr 2011]. If you are just\nvisiting or live in the area, you are eligible to receive the free\nvaccine. You can also get your booster shot by calling the Whistler\nHealth Care Centre at 604-932-3202 to arrange an appointment.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The incubation period for mumps virus infection can range from 12-25\ndays (commonly 14-18 days). Most mumps virus transmission is thought\nto occur before the salivary glands begin to swell and for up to 5\ndays after the swelling commences. Consequently persons intending to\nparticipate in the Telus World Ski and Snowboard Festival should\nreview their vaccination status and if in doubt should consider taking\nadvantage of the offer of free vaccination.\n\nA map of British Columbia, showing the location of Whistler, can be\nfound at:\nhttp://www.jnweb.com/british-columbia/map-bc.html. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Canada can be accessed at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/007x . - Mod.CP]", "summary": "MUMPS - CANADA: (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n**********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Consequently persons intending to\nparticipate in the Telus World Ski and Snowboard Festival should\nreview their vaccination status and if in doubt should consider taking\nadvantage of the offer of free vaccination. Most mumps virus transmission is thought\nto occur before the salivary glands begin to swell and for up to 5\ndays after the swelling commences. It typically starts\nwith a few days of fever, headache, muscle aches and loss of appetite,\nand is followed by swelling of salivary glands. With 15 lab confirmed cases of mumps in Whistler, British Columbia,\nCanada, so far, Coastal Health is warning young people about the\nvirus. Nurses will be\ngiving out free mumps shots this weekend at the Telus World Ski and\nSnowboard Festival in Whistler Source: News 1130 [edited]\nhttp://www.news1130.com/news/local/article/212600--an-outbreak-of-mumps-in-whistler\n\n\nOutbreak of mumps in Whistler\n The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Canada can be accessed at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/007x .", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Whistler", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "715847", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK (03): (England) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=715847", "date": "2011-05-06 23:54:14", "main_text": "MUMPS - UK (03): (ENGLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS\n**********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 May 2011\nSource: BBC New UK [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-lancashire-13295418\n\n\nUniversity mumps vaccine outbreak advice\n----------------------------------------\nStudents across north west England have been advised to check their\nvaccination records after outbreaks of mumps at 2 universities. The\ndisease has affected 47 students at the University of Central\nLancashire (UCLan) and 35 at the University of Manchester since\nFebruary [2011].\n\nThe Health Protection Agency (HPA) has advised students to ask their\nGPs [general practitioners] if they have had the full MMR [mumps,\nmeasles, and rubella] vaccine. It said some may have missed out on\ntheir 2nd protective dose of MMR.\n\nDr Sam Ghebrehewet of the HPA said: 'Mumps is an ever-present risk in\nuniversities and further education colleges. It is an infectious\ndisease that spreads easily amongst young adults who missed out on the\nprotection of 2 doses of MMR vaccine when they were children. 2 doses\nof the MMR vaccine are necessary for full protection.'\n\nMumps is a viral illness marked by symptoms of swollen neck glands,\nfever, and headache. Its complications can result in meningitis and\ndeafness.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[Mumps outbreaks often occur in congregate settings, where prolonged,\nclose contacts facilitate transmission. Mumps is spread by droplets of\nsaliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person,\nusually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks. Items used by an\ninfected person, such as cups or soft drink cans, can also be\ncontaminated with the virus, which may spread to others if those items\nare shared. Most mumps transmission likely occurs before the salivary\nglands begin to swell and within the 5 days after the swelling begins.\nTherefore, mumps sufferers should be isolated for 5 days after their\nglands begin to swell. The level of immunity produced by a single dose\nof the MMR triple vaccine may not be fully protective (with regard to\nmumps) and may decline with time. A 2nd dose of vaccine may be\nrequired to produce adequate protection in all circumstances, and in\nparticular in the case of young adults who may have received only a\nsingle dose of vaccine previously.\n\nThe University of Central Lancashire is located at Preston in the\nCounty of Lancashire in the north of England. Preston and Manchester\ncan be located via the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of\nEngland at http://healthmap.org/r/00A0. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "MUMPS - UK (03): (ENGLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS\n**********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n A 2nd dose of vaccine may be\nrequired to produce adequate protection in all circumstances, and in\nparticular in the case of young adults who may have received only a\nsingle dose of vaccine previously. Items used by an\ninfected person, such as cups or soft drink cans, can also be\ncontaminated with the virus, which may spread to others if those items\nare shared. The\ndisease has affected 47 students at the University of Central\nLancashire (UCLan) and 35 at the University of Manchester since\n \n\nThe Health Protection Agency (HPA) has advised students to ask their\nGPs [general practitioners] if they have had the full MMR [mumps,\nmeasles, and rubella] vaccine. The level of immunity produced by a single dose\nof the MMR triple vaccine may not be fully protective (with regard to\nmumps) and may decline with time. It is an infectious\ndisease that spreads easily amongst young adults who missed out on the\nprotection of 2 doses of MMR vaccine when they were children. Mumps is spread by droplets of\nsaliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person,\nusually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2035-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-02-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n County of Lancashire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Preston", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "764567", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (02): (BC) alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=764567", "date": "2011-06-22 17:03:18", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (02): (BRITISH COLUMBIA) ALERT\n*********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 21 Jun 2011\nSource: CBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/story/2011/06/21/bc-mumps-alert.html\n\n\nMumps outbreak hits Metro Vancouver\n-----------------------------------\nThe British Columbia Centre for Disease Control (BCCDC) has issued a\nhealth alert for mumps virus infection for the Lower Mainland,\nfollowing an outbreak in Whistler earlier this spring [see ProMED-mail\nreport archived as: Mumps - Canada: (BC) 20110415.1188]. A total of 77\npeople have contracted the disease according to the BCCDC. About 50 of\nthose cases were from an earlier outbreak in Whistler and Squamish and\nthe rest have been in the Lower Mainland. About 70 per cent of the\ncases were between 18 and 35 years of age, but cases have ranged from\none to 54 years of age.\n\n'We do have cases in the Vancouver area now, whereas the earlier part\nof the outbreak was really in Whistler and Squamish,' said Dr Monica\nNaus. It's the 1st sizeable mumps outbreak in the province since 2008\nand it is largely affecting young adults. But the centre did not say\nhow many cases have been discovered or specify where it has been\ndetected around Metro Vancouver or the Fraser Valley. In 2008 nearly\n200 people in the Fraser Valley and Metro Vancouver were infected with\nthe normally rare virus. The outbreak was been traced back to a Fraser\nValley religious group that opposes the mumps vaccination.\n\n'Symptoms of mumps include fever, sore throat or cough, swelling of\nthe salivary glands, usually the parotid glands, resulting in\n'chipmunk cheeks',' said the alert, which was issued on Monday [20 Jun\n2011]. 'Mumps can cause meningitis, and orchitis (inflammation of the\ntesticles) which is more common in adult males and rarely results in\nsterility, as well as other serious complications such as deafness. It\nis spread by respiratory secretions through coughing and sneezing but\nalso direct contact such as kissing or sharing utensils or water\nbottles.'\n\n'Anyone who suspects they have mumps should contact their physician\nby telephone 1st or call the HealthLink BC. Mumps is contagious so\nanyone with this infection should avoid exposing others especially in\nmedical waiting rooms and emergency rooms,' according to the alert.\n\nThe centre is asking parents to immunize their children with the MMR\nvaccine and for adults to make sure their own immunizations are up to\ndate. 'In BC, children receive 2 doses of mumps vaccine at 12 and 18\nmonths. The vaccine is given as the combined measles, mumps and\nrubella (MMR) vaccine, and provides protection against all 3 diseases.\nFor best protection against mumps, those born in 1970 and later should\nalso receive 2 doses.'\n\nSince 1995, children in BC have received a mumps vaccine at 12 months\nof age and 18 months, Dr Perry Kendall, the provincial health officer\nsaid in 2008. But older children may have only gotten one dose of the\nvaccine, meaning they are at an 80 per cent level of protection,\nversus 95 per cent protection for those with a 2nd dose.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps typically starts with a few days of fever, headache, muscle\naches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, and is followed by swelling of\nsalivary glands. Anyone who is not immune from either previous mumps\ninfection or from vaccination can get mumps. The incubation period for\nmumps virus infection can range from 12-25 days (commonly 14-18 days).\nMost mumps virus transmission is thought to occur before the salivary\nglands begin to swell and for up to 5 days after the swelling\ncommences.\n\nVaccination is normally achieved using the MMR (measles, mumps and\nrubella) triple vaccine, which has the added advantage of enhancing\nimmunity to measles virus infection in children and young adults who\nmay be at risk of measles infection through inadequate or no previous\nvaccination.\n\nA map of British Columbia, showing the locations of Whistler, Metro\nVancouver, and the Fraser Valley can be found at\nhttp://www.jnweb.com/british-columbia/map-bc.html. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Canada can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/007x. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "MUMPS - CANADA (02): (BRITISH COLUMBIA) ALERT\n*********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nVaccination is normally achieved using the MMR (measles, mumps and\nrubella) triple vaccine, which has the added advantage of enhancing\nimmunity to measles virus infection in children and young adults who\nmay be at risk of measles infection through inadequate or no previous\nvaccination. The British Columbia Centre for Disease Control (BCCDC) has issued a\nhealth alert for mumps virus infection for the Lower Mainland,\nfollowing an outbreak in Whistler earlier this spring [see ProMED-mail\nreport archived as: Mumps - Canada: (BC) 20110415.1188]. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap alerts via ProMED-mail\n< It\nis spread by respiratory secretions through coughing and sneezing but\nalso direct contact such as kissing or sharing utensils or water\nbottles.' \n\nSince 1995, children in BC have received a mumps vaccine at 12 months\nof age and 18 months, Dr Perry Kendall, the provincial health officer\nsaid in 2008. \n\n'Symptoms of mumps include fever, sore throat or cough, swelling of\nthe salivary glands, usually the parotid glands, resulting in\n'chipmunk cheeks',' said the alert, which was issued on Monday promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps typically starts with a few days of fever, headache, muscle\naches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, and is followed by swelling of\nsalivary glands. Most mumps virus transmission is thought to occur before the salivary\nglands begin to swell and for up to 5 days after the swelling\ncommences. But older children may have only gotten one dose of the\nvaccine, meaning they are at an 80 per cent level of protection,\nversus 95 per cent protection for those with a 2nd dose.
