About 70 per cent of the\ncases were between 18 and 35 years of age, but cases have ranged from\none to 54 years of age. \n\n'We do have cases in the Vancouver area now, whereas the earlier part\nof the outbreak was really in Whistler and Squamish,' said Dr Monica\nNaus.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2008-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "1970-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Whistler", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "779929", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (03): (BC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=779929", "date": "2011-07-07 17:23:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (03): (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n***************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Jul 2011\nFrom: Jat Sandhu <Jat.Sandhu@vch.ca>\n\n\n[Submitted in response to the ProMED-mail post archived as: Mumps -\nCanada (02): (BC) alert 20110622.1912. - Mod.CP]\n\nBackground:\nVancouver Coastal Health Authority has been investigating an outbreak\nof mumps occurring initially in Whistler and spreading more recently\nto surrounding municipalities. Mumps is a viral illness characterized\nby swollen salivary glands, fever, and headache. In severe cases,\nmeningitis, orchitis (testicular swelling) and hearing loss can\noccur.\n\nSince February 2011, a total of 90 cases have been reported, mostly\nin young adults.\n\nSetting:\nWhistler is a popular ski and outdoor activities destination north of\nVancouver that attracts visitors and seasonal employees from all over\nthe world. The permanent population of Whistler is estimated to be\napproximately 10 500, although the area attracts over 2700 seasonal\nemployees and 14 800 visitors each year. An additional estimated 3700\nemployees commute to Whistler on a daily basis from surrounding\ncommunities, increasing the daily average population to approximately\n32 000. The entire region of Vancouver Coastal Health, which includes\nWhistler, has a population of 1.1 million.\n\nEpidemiology:\nMumps is spread by direct contact with the saliva of an infected\nperson. Current case definition includes individuals having symptoms\nconsistent with mumps illness and:\n(a) laboratory confirmation of mumps RNA; or\n(b) epidemiological links to a laboratory confirmed case; or\n(c) recent travel to Whistler.\n\nThe earliest date of symptom onset was 22 Feb 2011 in a Whistler\nresident, and while cases continue to reside predominantly in the\nWhistler region, increasing numbers of cases in surrounding cities,\nincluding Vancouver and Richmond, have been reported. Several of these\nrecent cases have no known links to Whistler; though many are\nclustered among the same household or social network.\n\nThe disease is primarily affecting young adults; the median age of\nall cases is 27.0 years (age range: 1-54 years), and 54 cases (60.0\nper cent) are male.\n\nTransmission among initial Whistler-linked cases was primarily by\nsharing marijuana joints, cigarettes, drinks, and utensils.\n\nNearly 60 per cent of cases with links to Whistler are employed\neither by the mountain resort or in the hospitality and retail sector.\nThese sectors employ a largely seasonal workforce arising from many\ndifferent countries across the globe.\n\nClinical presentation:\nNearly all cases presented with unilateral or bilateral parotitis\n(97.8 per cent). 22 per cent of male cases presented with orchitis.\nOther symptoms included fever (58.9 per cent), myalgia (34.4 per\ncent), headache (24.4 per cent), pharyngitis (22.2 per cent),\narthralgia (7.8 per cent), fatigue (7.8 per cent), and nausea (5.6 per\ncent).\n\nIdentified cases have been encouraged to self-isolate for 9 days\nfollowing symptom onset.\n\nImmunization history:\nThe majority of cases have not received the 2 doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine needed for full protection. As Whistler hosts\na largely transient (and international) population, immunization\nhistories of residents vary greatly.\n\nIn our health region, most children and youth born between 1970 and\n1995 will not have had 2 doses of MMR, as the 2nd dose was not\nincluded in the routine immunization schedule for this age group. A\n2nd MMR at 18 months of age became part of routine infant immunization\nin 1996.\n\nGenotype:\n16 cases to date have been confirmed as Genotype G, a common genotype\nof mumps that was observed in several other recent North American\noutbreaks.\n\nPublic health response to date:\n- Notification has been given to all primary care providers and\nemergency physicians in the health region to be vigilant for patients\npresenting with swelling of the parotid gland, or other\nmumps-compatible illness.\n\n- Collection of laboratory specimens including blood for serology and\nbuccal swabs and/or urine for detection of mumps virus RNA.\n\n- Recommendation of 2 doses of mumps containing vaccine for all\nindividuals born on or after 1 Jan 1970. One dose is recommended for\nall individuals born between 1 Jan 1957 and 31 Dec 1969 who do not\nhave evidence of immunity to mumps.\n\n- Notification to all health jurisdictions across Canada through the\nCNPHI (Canadian Network for Public Health Intelligence) web platform.\n\n- Media advisory in Whistler (March and April 2011) on outbreak and\ninformation on where to access vaccine and messaging for those without\nhealth insurance.\n\n- Drop-in immunization clinics have been held at the Whistler Health\nCare Centre since March 2011.\n\n- A targeted immunization campaign was launched in Whistler to\ncoincide with the 10-day Telus Ski & Snowboard Festival (15-24 Apr\n2011), the largest annual winter sports and music festival in North\nAmerica. Over 600 doses of MMR were given to contacts of cases and\nindividuals who live and work in Whistler through vaccination at\nworksites and a drop-in clinic at a centrally located community\npharmacy. Approximately 50 per cent of those taking up vaccination\nwere overseas nationals of Australia, New Zealand, United Kingdom,\nSouth Africa, and smaller numbers from other European and Asian\ncountries.\n\nFurther planned public health response:\n- Continued messaging and immunization to target post-secondary\neducational institutions in the region with a particular focus on new\nstudents arriving in August 2011 for the start of the new academic\nyear.\n\n- Targeted immunization at staff orientations to be held by major\nemployers in the resort municipality of Whistler in anticipation of\nnew international staff arriving in the fall [2011].\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nPaul Martiquet MD\nMedical Health Officer\n\nReka Gustafson MD\nMedical Health Officer and Medical Director Communicable Disease\nControl\n\nEmily Laflamme MPH\nRegional Epidemiologist, Public Health Surveillance Unit\n\nJat Sandhu PhD\nRegional Director, Public Health Surveillance Unit\nOffice of the Chief Medical Health Officer\nVancouver Coastal Health Authority\n800 601 West Broadway\nVancouver, British Columbia\nCanada V5Z 4C2\nhttp:www.vch.ca\n<phsu@vch.ca>\n\n[Contact <phsu@vch.ca> at Vancouver Coastal Health Authority\nhttp:www.vch.ca for further information.\n\nFor the VCH Health Watch monthly public health bulletin (with map of\nregion), see\nhttp://www.vch.ca/your_health/disease_surveillance/health_watch/.\n\nSince the previous report, the number of confirmed cases of mumps\nvirus infection has increased from 77 to 90, indicating that the\noutbreak has not yet been contained. ProMED-mail thanks Dr Jat Sandu\nand colleagues for provision of this detailed account of the current\nsituation regarding the mumps outbreak centered on the Whistler resort\narea of British Columbia and the response of the local health\nauthority.\n\nA map of British Columbia, showing the locations of Whistler and\nVancouver, can be found at\nhttp://www.jnweb.com/british-columbia/map-bc.html. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Canada can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/007x. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nPaul Martiquet MD\nMedical Health Officer\n\nReka Gustafson MD\nMedical Health Officer and Medical Director Communicable Disease\nControl\n\nEmily Laflamme MPH\nRegional Epidemiologist, Public Health Surveillance Unit\n\nJat Sandhu PhD\n MUMPS - CANADA (03): (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n***************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n For the VCH Health Watch monthly public health bulletin (with map of\nregion), see\nhttp://www.vch.ca/your_health/disease_surveillance/health_watch/.\n\nSince the previous report, the number of confirmed cases of mumps\nvirus infection has increased from 77 to 90, indicating that the\noutbreak has not yet been contained. \n\nFurther planned public health response:\n- Continued messaging and immunization to target post-secondary\neducational institutions in the region with a particular focus on new\nstudents arriving in August 2011 for the start of the new academic\nyear. \n\nPublic health response to date:\n- Notification has been given to all primary care providers and\nemergency physicians in the health region to be vigilant for patients\npresenting with swelling of the parotid gland, or other\nmumps-compatible illness. Current case definition includes individuals having symptoms\nconsistent with mumps illness and:\n(a) laboratory confirmation of mumps RNA; or\n(b) epidemiological links to a laboratory confirmed case; or\n(c) recent travel to Whistler. ProMED-mail thanks Dr Jat Sandu\nand colleagues for provision of this detailed account of the current\nsituation regarding the mumps outbreak centered on the Whistler resort\narea of British Columbia and the response of the local health\nauthority. Other symptoms included fever (58.9 per cent), myalgia (34.4 per\ncent), headache (24.4 per cent), pharyngitis (22.2 per cent),\narthralgia (7.8 per cent), fatigue (7.8 per cent), and nausea (5.6 per\ncent). \n\nThe earliest date of symptom onset was 22 Feb 2011 in a Whistler\nresident, and while cases continue to reside predominantly in the\nWhistler region, increasing numbers of cases in surrounding cities,\nincluding Vancouver and Richmond, have been reported. \n\nGenotype:\n16 cases to date have been confirmed as Genotype G, a common genotype\nof mumps that was observed in several other recent North American\noutbreaks. \n\n- A targeted immunization campaign was launched in Whistler to\ncoincide with the 10-day Telus Ski & Snowboard Festival (15-24 Apr\n2011), the largest annual winter sports and music festival in North\n Over 600 doses of MMR were given to contacts of cases and\nindividuals who live and work in Whistler through vaccination at\nworksites and a drop-in clinic at a centrally located community\npharmacy. An additional estimated 3700\nemployees commute to Whistler on a daily basis from surrounding\ncommunities, increasing the daily average population to approximately\n32 000. Approximately 50 per cent of those taking up vaccination\nwere overseas nationals of Australia, New Zealand, United Kingdom,\nSouth Africa, and smaller numbers from other European and Asian\ncountries. \n\nThe disease is primarily affecting young adults; the median age of\nall cases is 27.0 years (age range: 1-54 years), and 54 cases (60.0\nper cent) are male. \n\nIn our health region, most children and youth born between 1970 and\n1995 will not have had 2 doses of MMR, as the 2nd dose was not\nincluded in the routine immunization schedule for this age group. \n\n- Targeted immunization at staff orientations to be held by major\nemployers in the resort municipality of Whistler in anticipation of\nnew international staff arriving in the fall [2011]. \n\n- Media advisory in Whistler (March and April 2011) on outbreak and\ninformation on where to access vaccine and messaging for those without\nhealth insurance. http:www.vch.ca\n<phsu@vch.ca>\n\n[Contact <phsu@vch.ca> at Vancouver Coastal Health Authority\nhttp:www.vch.ca for further information.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-08-25 00:00:00", "2011-02-22 00:00:00", "1970-01-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2700-03-25 00:00:00", "1969-12-25 00:00:00", "2011-02-25 00:00:00", "2011-04-25 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Richmond", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Whistler", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "629313", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK: (Scotland) young people", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=629313", "date": "2011-01-15 19:00:04", "main_text": "MUMPS - UK: (SCOTLAND) YOUNG PEOPLE\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 13 Jan 2011\nSource: BBC News Scotland [edited]\n<http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-12184237>\n\n\nMumps outbreak hits young people in Oban, Argyll\n------------------------------------------------\nYoung people in Oban are being advised to ensure they are vaccinated\nagainst mumps after an outbreak in the Scottish west coast town. NHS\n[National Health Service] Highland said about 50 cases had been identified,\nmainly among teenagers and those in their early 20s. It is believed\nreturning students and increased social events over the festive period may\nhave contributed to the spread of the virus.\n\nMumps is spread through saliva and is transmitted by coughs and sneezes.\nSymptoms include swelling on the angle of the jaw on one or both sides of\nthe face. Often there are several days of earlier symptoms, which could\ninclude fever, headache, fatigue, muscle aches, and loss of appetite.\n\nDoctors have said that teenagers in Oban who have not had all their MMR\n[measles, mumps, and rubella triple vaccine] jabs should make sure they are\nup to date with vaccination.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a significant outbreak in a small relatively isolated town of\naround 8000 inhabitants on the west coast of Scotland. A significant\ncomponent of the population are young people who become dispersed for\nemployment or further education. It is likely that their return for the\nChristmas/New Year holiday period has sparked this outbreak. It may also\nsignify low MMR vaccine coverage locally and may further be a consequence\nof the lower immunogenicity of the mumps virus component of the triple vaccine.\n\nOban can be located on the west coast of Scotland, Argyll and Bute Council\nArea, using the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Scotland at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0mhJ>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 13 Jan 2011\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< It may also\nsignify low MMR vaccine coverage locally and may further be a consequence\nof the lower immunogenicity of the mumps virus component of the triple vaccine. It is believed\nreturning students and increased social events over the festive period may\nhave contributed to the spread of the virus. Oban can be located on the west coast of Scotland, Argyll and Bute Council\nArea, using the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Scotland at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0mhJ>. A significant\ncomponent of the population are young people who become dispersed for\nemployment or further education. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a significant outbreak in a small relatively isolated town of\naround 8000 inhabitants on the west coast of Scotland. Young people in Oban are being advised to ensure they are vaccinated\nagainst mumps after an outbreak in the Scottish west coast town.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-01-13 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oban , Argyll", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Argyll", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "494377", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Israel (05): corr.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=494377", "date": "2010-08-16 14:00:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - ISRAEL (05): CORRECTION\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[This posting replaces ProMED-mail Mumps - Israel (05) 20100814.2799,\ndated 7 Aug 2010, in which item [1] is a text that should have been\ndiscarded following discussions with Israel's MOH.\n\nProMED-mail regrets the error. - Mods.AS/DK]\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Sun 8 Aug 2010\nSource: a correspondent who has requested anonymity [edited]\n\n\nWith respect to the ongoing outbreak of mumps in Israel, it seems\nthat the disease has become more widely spread, apparently affecting\nadditional sectors of the population [see prior ProMED-mail posting\n'Mumps - Israel (04): Yeshiva students 20100723.2472']. As of 10 Jul\n2010 (the most recent available weekly epidemiological report), the\ntotal number of reported confirmed cases this year is 4185 (compared\nwith 6 confirmed cases during the same period last year - 2009).\nThere is spread of disease in kindergartens and elementary schools in\ncentral/coastal Israel, in addition to Jerusalem. This includes\nchildren who have been MMR vaccinated, as well as some of those duly\nboosted (with the Jeryl Lynn mumps vaccine) at the age of 6-8.\n\nGenotyping of the prevailing G5 virus strain, reportedly revealed a\nsingle nucleotide difference, initially in Jerusalem and later on in\nBnei-Brak. The possibility that this nucleotide difference has had\nany impact on vaccine efficacy in the country has been a matter for\n(inconclusive) discussion.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\na correspondent who has requested anonymity\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 2 Aug 2010\nSource: Haaretz [edited]\n<http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/west-nile-fever-hits-12-people-in-israel-leaving-one-dead-1.305379>\n\n\n[The following information is the last paragraph in a newswire on the\nWest Nile virus outbreak in Israel. - Mod.MPP]\n\nThe Ministry has also noted a rise in the incidence of mumps in\nrecent months, with 4190 cases since the beginning of the year\n[January 2010]. A ministry advisory committee has recommended a\nprogram of mumps vaccinations, particularly in areas where the\noutbreaks have occurred, notably in ultra-Orthodox communities.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following response to the 2 items above has been kindly provided\nby the Israeli Ministry of Health and is gratefully acknowledged:\n\n'In January 2010 the Ministry of Health noted a rise in the incidence\nof mumps. A ministry advisory committee has recommended a program of\nmumps vaccinations, particularly in areas where the outbreaks have\noccurred, notably in ultra-Orthodox communities. In recent months\nincidence has decreased, but the outbreak is still ongoing after it\npeaked on April 2009, with a total of 4190 cases since the beginning\nof the year. It should be noted that the spread of the disease to the\ngeneral population is limited: case incidence is highest in the\nultra-orthodox community'. - Mods.AS/CP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Israel can be accessed\nat <http://healthmap.org/r/00JC>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[This posting replaces ProMED-mail Mumps - Israel (05) 20100814.2799,\ndated 7 Aug 2010, in which item [1] is a text that should have been\ndiscarded following discussions with Israel's MOH. With respect to the ongoing outbreak of mumps in Israel, it seems\nthat the disease has become more widely spread, apparently affecting\nadditional sectors of the population [see prior ProMED-mail posting\n'Mumps - Israel (04): Yeshiva students 20100723.2472']. As of 10 Jul\n2010 (the most recent available weekly epidemiological report), the\ntotal number of reported confirmed cases this year is 4185 (compared\nwith 6 confirmed cases during the same period last year - 2009). In recent months\nincidence has decreased, but the outbreak is still ongoing after it\npeaked on April 2009, with a total of 4190 cases since the beginning\nof the year. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following response to the 2 items above has been kindly provided\nby the Israeli Ministry of Health and is gratefully acknowledged:\n\n'In January 2010 the Ministry of Health noted a rise in the incidence\nof mumps. MPP]\n\nThe Ministry has also noted a rise in the incidence of mumps in\nrecent months, with 4190 cases since the beginning of the year\n A ministry advisory committee has recommended a program of\nmumps vaccinations, particularly in areas where the outbreaks have\noccurred, notably in ultra-Orthodox communities. A ministry advisory committee has recommended a\nprogram of mumps vaccinations, particularly in areas where the\noutbreaks have occurred, notably in ultra-Orthodox communities. It should be noted that the spread of the disease to the\ngeneral population is limited: case incidence is highest in the\nultra-orthodox community'. This includes\nchildren who have been MMR vaccinated, as well as some of those duly\nboosted (with the Jeryl Lynn mumps vaccine) at the age of 6-8. Communicated by:\na correspondent who has requested anonymity\n\n******\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps", "west nile virus"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "4185-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-08-07 00:00:00", "2009-04-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2010-01-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jerusalem", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "mumps - ISRAEL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "661728", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK (02): (Scotland) young people", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=661728", "date": "2011-02-24 18:00:05", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED KINGDOM (02): (SCOTLAND) YOUNG PEOPLE\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 24 Feb 2011\nSource: Eurosurveillance, Volume 16, Issue 8 [abbreviated, edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19803>\n\n\nOngoing outbreak of mumps infection in Oban, Scotland, November 2010\nto January 2011. By J Walker1, S Huc1, K Sinka2, A Tissington1, K\nOates1 At: 1 -- Health Protection, NHS Highland, Inverness, Scotland,\nUnited Kingdom 2 -- Health Protection Scotland, Glasgow, Scotland,\nUnited Kingdom\n\nSummary\n-------------\nWe report on an ongoing outbreak of 119 cases of mumps virus\ninfection in the Oban area of Scotland, from 29 Nov 2010 to 31 Jan\n2011. The median age of cases was 20 years, with the highest incidence\nin the 13-19-year-olds. A total of 53 cases had received 2 doses of\nmeasles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine, in accordance with the United\nKingdom vaccination schedule, while 33 had received only one dose, and\n30 had not been vaccinated.\n\nOutbreak description\n------------------\nNHS [National Health Service] Highland Health Protection Team in\nScotland was notified on 29 Nov 2010 of one case of mumps in Oban, a\nrural coastal town, with a population of around 8000, on the west\ncoast of Scotland. There were no further cases for a 2-week period,\nbut by 20 Dec 2010, an outbreak in Oban was obvious, with 23 cases.\nMany of the cases were notified around the Christmas holiday period\nwhen young people returned from work and university in urban areas.\n\nBy 31 Jan 2011, a total of 119 cases had been notified in the Oban\narea. These represented more notifications than for the rest of\nScotland for the same period (90 cases in a population of 5 168 500\nindividuals). Of the 119 cases notified in Oban, 18 were laboratory\nconfirmed, and 101 were clinically diagnosed by local GPs (based on\nthose presenting with typical clinical features, including parotitis\nafter 29 Nov 2010).\n\nBackground\n-----------\nMumps, an infection caused by a paramyxovirus, is characterised by\nparotitis. It may also cause orchitis, pancreatitis and meningitis,\namong other clinical features. In Scotland, mumps is a notifiable\ndisease and is reported electronically to health boards by clinicians,\nin particular by general practitioners.\n\nMumps immunisation was introduced in the United Kingdom (UK) in 1988\nas a single dose of measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine, for those\naged 12-15 months. Before 1988, mumps virus caused outbreaks among\n5-9-year-olds every 3 years. They would now be aged 23 years and over.\nIn 1996, a 2-dose schedule was introduced: the 1st dose is given to\nchildren aged 13 months, and the 2nd dose is given from the age of 3\nyears and 4 months onwards.\n\nCurrent vaccination uptake rates for the 1st dose of MMR vaccine at\n24 months (for the year ending 31 Mar 2010) were 93.7 percent for\nScotland and 91.5 percent for the Argyll area (in which Oban is\nlocated). However, in the years post 1998, following a vaccine\ncontroversy which involved an alleged link between autism and the MMR\nvaccine, the uptake rates fell, reaching a low level in Scotland of\n88.5 percent and in Argyll of 85.6 percent in 2003. This cohort, who\nwould have been due vaccination in 1998-2003, would now be 8-14 years\nold.\n\nFollowing a large outbreak of mumps which affected the whole of the\nUK in 2005, the number of cases fell until 2009, when an increase was\nseen again. In Scotland, this increase has been characterised by\nperiodic, localised occurrences of mumps cases: the outbreak reported\nhere is the latest. Recently, there have been reports of outbreaks of\nmumps in other parts of the UK and other countries.\n\nCase information\n----------------\nOf the 119 cases, 63 were females and 56 males. The age range of\ncases was 4 to 71 years: 85 of the cases were in the 13-29 age group,\nand 12 were aged over 40 years. Anecdotal information revealed 3 cases\nwith complications (orchitis, pancreatitis). However, more detailed\ninformation on complications overall is currently being evaluated.\n\nBy 31 Jan 2011, vaccination status was known for 116 of the 119\ncases: 53 had received 2 doses of MMR vaccine, 33 had received only\none dose, and 30 received no doses. For those who had one dose, the\ndate of vaccination ranged from 5 Dec 1988 to 23 Feb 2009. For those\nwho had received 2 doses, the vaccination dates ranged from 28 Sep\n1989 for the 1st dose to 13 May 2008 for the 2nd dose.\n\nThe majority of the cases aged under 22 years had received 2 doses of\nMMR vaccine (53 of 80). Among the 9 cases aged 12 years or under, 8\nhad received 2 doses; among the 49 cases aged between 13 and 19 years,\n37 had received 2 doses and 11 one dose.\n\nAnecdotally, it appears that the index case may have been a student\nat one of Scotland's main universities who had returned home for the\nholidays. Many of the initial cases had subsequently attended a school\ndance and a large party in Oban. There was no common link with place\nof residence.\n\nCases continue to be notified, but the rate of notifications has\ndecreased. The peak date of symptom onset for cases was 10 Jan 2011,\nwhen 11 cases were notified. By 31 Jan 2011, there were 18\nlaboratory-confirmed cases; the rest were clinically diagnosed.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nSome GPs reported that not all those affected presented to GP\npractices, and our numbers may, therefore, be an underestimate. On the\nother hand, we applied a non-specific case definition which led to\nwide inclusion of cases.\n\nInitial concerns regarding a historical problem with a vaccine batch\nwere soon discarded as the date ranges for the 1st and 2nd\nvaccinations were wide, and vaccinations were given in different\npractices by different individuals, and there was no link with any\nparticular vaccine batch numbers.\n\nThe main limitation in our study is the low number of\nlaboratory-confirmed cases. We felt that after the initial tranche of\ncases, clinical diagnosis was adequate, and this was undertaken by\nseveral different primary care teams (101 of the 119 were clinically\ndiagnosed). The laboratory has confirmed that the strain involved is\ngenotype G5, in common with all strains currently seen in the UK.\n\nMMR vaccination coverage was affected by adverse publicity some years\nago, and uptake rates fell to a low of 85.6 percent in 2003 in the\nOban area. Unvaccinated individuals, plus those who were immunised but\nin whom protection had subsequently waned, combined to provide a\ncohort of vulnerable individuals who were infected in this outbreak.\nThe 45 percent (n=53) of notified cases who had received 2 doses of\nMMR vaccine is higher than the 29 percent of cases reported in England\nand Wales in 2010 and the 31 percent reported in England in 2004-05\nbut lower than the 61 percent noted in the Netherlands in 2010 and the\n75 percent reported in New Jersey, United States in 2009-10. If we\nlook at the 13-19 years age group in our study -- the most affected\nage group -- 76 percent (n=37) had received 2 doses of MMR.\n\nPublished estimates of MMR vaccine efficacy to protect against mumps\nvary. It has been reported as 88 percent (95 percent confidence\nintervals (CI): 83 percent to 91 percent) for one dose and 95 percent\n(95 percent CI: 93 percent to 96 percent) for 2 doses. In addition, 2\ndoses of vaccine were reported as being more effective (88 percent (95\npercent CI: 62 percent to 96 percent)) than a single dose (64 percent\n(95 percent CI: 40 percent to 78 percent)). Furthermore, waning\nimmunity in older vaccinated individuals has been reported.\n\nAlthough the numbers in our cohort are small, they add to the growing\nbody of evidence which suggests that immunity to mumps virus may wane\nover time. These cases highlight the importance of ensuring high\nuptake of the recommended 2 doses of MMR. They also imply a need for\nfurther research into long-term mumps immunity among those partially\nor fully vaccinated in order to inform future immunisation\nprogrammes.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Readers are recommended to read the full text of this report to view\nthe graphical presentation of the data and the specific references\ncited. This analysis re-enforces the general observation that the\nimmunity conferred by the mumps component of the triple MMR vaccine is\nless complete than that provided by the other 2 components.\n\nOban can be located on the west coast of Scotland, Argyll and Bute\nCouncil Area using the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of\nScotland at <http://healthmap.org/r/0mhJ>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "The 45 percent (n=53) of notified cases who had received 2 doses of\nMMR vaccine is higher than the 29 percent of cases reported in England\nand Wales in 2010 and the 31 percent reported in England in 2004-05\nbut lower than the 61 percent noted in the Netherlands in 2010 and the\n75 percent reported in New Jersey, United States in 2009-10. In addition, 2\ndoses of vaccine were reported as being more effective (88 percent (95\npercent CI: 62 percent to 96 percent)) than a single dose (64 percent\n(95 percent CI: 40 percent to 78 percent)). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 24 Feb 2011\n It has been reported as 88 percent (95 percent confidence\nintervals (CI): 83 percent to 91 percent) for one dose and 95 percent\n(95 percent CI: 93 percent to 96 percent) for 2 doses. \n\nCurrent vaccination uptake rates for the 1st dose of MMR vaccine at\n24 months (for the year ending 31 Mar 2010) were 93.7 percent for\nScotland and 91.5 percent for the Argyll area (in which Oban is\nlocated). A total of 53 cases had received 2 doses of\nmeasles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine, in accordance with the United\nKingdom vaccination schedule, while 33 had received only one dose, and\n30 had not been vaccinated. However, in the years post 1998, following a vaccine\ncontroversy which involved an alleged link between autism and the MMR\nvaccine, the uptake rates fell, reaching a low level in Scotland of\n88.5 percent and in Argyll of 85.6 percent in 2003. Of the 119 cases notified in Oban, 18 were laboratory\nconfirmed, and 101 were clinically diagnosed by local GPs (based on\nthose presenting with typical clinical features, including parotitis\nafter 29 Nov 2010). Among the 9 cases aged 12 years or under, 8\nhad received 2 doses; among the 49 cases aged between 13 and 19 years,\n37 had received 2 doses and 11 one dose. We felt that after the initial tranche of\ncases, clinical diagnosis was adequate, and this was undertaken by\nseveral different primary care teams (101 of the 119 were clinically\ndiagnosed). At: 1 -- Health Protection, NHS Highland, Inverness, Scotland,\nUnited Kingdom 2 -- Health Protection Scotland, Glasgow, Scotland,\nUnited Kingdom\n\nSummary\n \nvaccinations were wide, and vaccinations were given in different\npractices by different individuals, and there was no link with any\nparticular vaccine batch numbers. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Readers are recommended to read the full text of this report to view\nthe graphical presentation of the data and the specific references\ncited. By 31 Jan 2011, vaccination status was known for 116 of the 119\ncases: 53 had received 2 doses of MMR vaccine, 33 had received only\none dose, and 30 received no doses. They also imply a need for\nfurther research into long-term mumps immunity among those partially\nor fully vaccinated in order to inform future immunisation\nprogrammes. Unvaccinated individuals, plus those who were immunised but\nin whom protection had subsequently waned, combined to provide a\ncohort of vulnerable individuals who were infected in this outbreak.\n Background\n-----------\nMumps, an infection caused by a paramyxovirus, is characterised by\nparotitis. Israel (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=492717", "date": "2010-08-14 14:00:04", "main_text": "MUMPS - ISRAEL (05)\n*******************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Sat 7 Aug 2010\nFrom: a correspondent who has requested anonymity [edited]\n\n\nProMED-mail has received the following information from a reliable source:\nWith respect to the ongoing outbreak of mumps in Israel, there is local\nconcern that there has been complacency on the part of the Ministry of\nHealth (see prior ProMED-mail posting: Mumps - Israel (04): Yeshiva\nstudents 20100723.2472). From personal experience, our 6 year old grandson\nand his friends are ill with mumps (fortunately mild, uncomplicated cases).\nThey were vaccinated once, pending 2nd vaccination this coming year -- the\nrecommendation is for the 2nd dose to be given during the 1st year of\nelementary school, using the Jeryl Lynn mumps vaccine. We have heard of\ncases occurring following the booster dose, especially in schools.\n\nAs of 10 Jul 2010 (the most recent available weekly epidemiologic report),\nthe total number of reported confirmed cases this year [2010] is 4185\n(compared with 6 confirmed cases during the same period in 2009).\nGenotyping of the virus involved revealed strain G5 in Jerusalem, and later\non in Bnei-Brak a single nucleotide difference was detected. There has been\ndiscussion that this nucleotide difference has had an impact on vaccine\nefficacy in the country.\n\n--\ncommunicated by a correspondent who has requested anonymity\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 2 Aug 2010\nSource: Haaretz [edited]\n<http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/west-nile-fever-hits-12-people-in-israel-leaving-one-dead-1.305379>\n\n\n[The following information is the last paragraph in a newswire on the West\nNile virus outbreak in Israel. - Mod.MPP]\nThe Ministry has also noted a rise in the incidence of mumps in recent\nmonths, with 4190 cases since the beginning of the year [January 2010]. A\nministry advisory committee has recommended a program of mumps\nvaccinations, particularly in areas where the outbreaks have occurred,\nnotably in ultra-Orthodox communities.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Subsequent to these reports further enquiries have elicited the following\ninformation.\n1. With respect to the ongoing outbreak of mumps in Israel, it seems that\nthe disease has become more widely spread, apparently affecting additional\nsectors of the population [see prior ProMED-mail posting: Mumps - Israel\n(04): Yeshiva students 20100723.2472]. As of 10 Jul 2010 (the most recent\navailable weekly epidemiologic report), the total number of reported\nconfirmed cases this year (2010) is 4185 (compared with 6 confirmed cases\nduring the same period last year - 2009). There is spread of disease in\nkindergartens and elementary schools in central/coastal Israel, in addition\nto Jerusalem. This includes children who have been MMR vaccinated, as well\nas some of those duly boosted (with the Jeryl Lynn mumps vaccine) at the\nage of 6-8. Genotyping of the prevailing G5 virus strain, reportedly\nrevealed a single nucleotide difference, initially in Jerusalem and later\non in Bnei-Brak. The possibility that this nucleotide difference has had\nany impact on vaccine efficacy in the country has been a matter for\n(inconclusive) discussion.\n\n2. The following response to the 2 items above has been kindly received\nfrom the Israeli Ministry of Health and is gratefully acknowledged: In\nJanuary 2010 the ministry of Health noted a rise in the incidence of mumps.\nA ministry advisory committee has recommended a program of mumps\nvaccinations, particularly in areas where the outbreaks have occurred,\nnotably in ultra-Orthodox communities. In recent months incidence has\ndecreased, but the outbreak is still ongoing after it peaked on April 2009,\nwith a total of 4190 cases since the beginning of the year. It should be\nnoted that the spread of the disease to the general population is limited:\ncase incidence is highest in the ultra orthodox community. - Mods.AS/CP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Israel can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00JC>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n As of 10 Jul 2010 (the most recent\navailable weekly epidemiologic report), the total number of reported\nconfirmed cases this year (2010) is 4185 (compared with 6 confirmed cases\nduring the same period last year - 2009). With respect to the ongoing outbreak of mumps in Israel, it seems that\nthe disease has become more widely spread, apparently affecting additional\nsectors of the population [see prior ProMED-mail posting: Mumps - Israel\n(04): Yeshiva students 20100723.2472]. With respect to the ongoing outbreak of mumps in Israel, there is local\nconcern that there has been complacency on the part of the Ministry of\nHealth (see prior ProMED-mail posting: Mumps - Israel (04): Yeshiva\nstudents 20100723.2472). A\nministry advisory committee has recommended a program of mumps\nvaccinations, particularly in areas where the outbreaks have occurred,\nnotably in ultra-Orthodox communities. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< ,\nthe total number of reported confirmed cases this year [2010] is 4185\n(compared with 6 confirmed cases during the same period in 2009). They were vaccinated once, pending 2nd vaccination this coming year -- the\nrecommendation is for the 2nd dose to be given during the 1st year of\nelementary school, using the Jeryl Lynn mumps vaccine. The following response to the 2 items above has been kindly received\nfrom the Israeli Ministry of Health and is gratefully acknowledged: In\nJanuary 2010 the ministry of Health noted a rise in the incidence of mumps. In recent months incidence has\ndecreased, but the outbreak is still ongoing after it peaked on April 2009,\nwith a total of 4190 cases since the beginning of the year. A ministry advisory committee has recommended a program of mumps\nvaccinations, particularly in areas where the outbreaks have occurred,\nnotably in ultra-Orthodox communities. \n\n--\ncommunicated by a correspondent who has requested anonymity\n\n******\n This includes children who have been MMR vaccinated, as well\nas some of those duly boosted (with the Jeryl Lynn mumps vaccine) at the\nage of 6-8. It should be\nnoted that the spread of the disease to the general population is limited:\ncase incidence is highest in the ultra orthodox community.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-01-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2009-04-25 00:00:00", "4185-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jerusalem", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "mumps - ISRAEL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Israel", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "474633", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK: (England, Sussex)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=474633", "date": "2010-07-24 16:00:04", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED KINGDOM: (ENGLAND, SUSSEX)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 23 Jul 2010\nSource: The Argus, Brighton News [edited]\n<http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/8288698.Brighton_mumps_outbreak_will__get_worse_/>\n\n\nBrighton mumps outbreak will 'get worse'\n----------------------------------------\nA top doctor has warned a mumps outbreak is likely to get worse\nduring the summer holidays. Thousands of holidaymakers and\ndaytrippers are expected to visit Brighton and Hove as the city's\ntourism industry prepares for its busiest time of the year.\n\nThe city's director of public health, Tom Scanlon, said it was 'more\nthan likely' the number of mumps cases would go up during the next 8\nweeks. He said: 'The illness is mainly affecting young people in\ntheir 20s and there are going to be large numbers visiting the city\nand going out and socialising. 'Unlike measles, which normally\naffects schoolchildren and would be likely to show a fall in numbers\nin the summer because of the holidays, I would expect to see an\nincrease when it comes to mumps.'\n\nThere have been 112 confirmed cases across Sussex [county] so far\nthis year and numbers are expected to soon pass the 139 recorded for\nthe whole of 2009. The worst-hit area is Brighton and Hove, which has\nhad 52 cases so far, almost double the number in 2009. A total of 39\npeople have been affected in East Sussex, just 3 short of the 42 in\n2009. West Sussex has had 21 patients struck down so far, which is\nlower than the 70 the year before. However in 2009, there was a large\noutbreak of cases at Chichester College [in West sussex], which\nskewed the numbers. Cases are affecting both young adults and\nteenagers.\n\nThe rise in cases has sparked renewed calls for people to make sure\nthey are vaccinated with the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR)\nvaccine. The take-up rate for the 1st of 2 recommended MMR jabs in\nBrighton and Hove is currently 82 percent but the percentage having\ntwo doses is 69 percent. This is well below the 90 percent the World\nHealth Organisation says needs to be vaccinated to protect a\ncommunity. Take-up rates are higher in East and West Sussex but there\nis still room for improvement.\n\nDr Scanlon said: 'It certainly seems as if the numbers of mumps cases\nare actually spreading around Sussex and not just Brighton and Hove\nand that is concerning. 'This is a potentially very serious disease\nand I would urge all those eligible to get vaccinated as soon as\npossible.' Those affected are mainly young adults. This may be\nbecause the MMR vaccine was not available when they were small.\nOthers may not have had the jab [injection] because of concerns about\nresearch published in the late 1990s, which suggested a link with\nautism. This [research] has since been discredited. In most cases\nmumps is mild but it can cause serious complications, particularly\nfor men, including sterility, an inflammation of the pancreas,\ndeafness and viral meningitis.\n\n[Byline: Siobhan Ryan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For comparison, an analysis of the numbers of laboratory confirmed\nmumps cases in England and Wales by district, updated to the end of\nNovember 2009, can be found in the Health Protection Agency report at:\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2010/news0210.htm#mmps>.\n\nA map of the county of Sussex showing the location of Brighton and\nHove can be found at:\n<http://www.visitsussex.org/site/explore-sussex/flash-map>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United Kingdom can be\naccessed at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/008E>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 23 Jul 2010\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For comparison, an analysis of the numbers of laboratory confirmed\nmumps cases in England and Wales by district, updated to the end of\nNovember 2009, can be found in the Health Protection Agency report at:\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2010/news0210.htm#mmps>. In most cases\nmumps is mild but it can cause serious complications, particularly\nfor men, including sterility, an inflammation of the pancreas,\ndeafness and viral meningitis.\n\n Unlike measles, which normally\naffects schoolchildren and would be likely to show a fall in numbers\nin the summer because of the holidays, I would expect to see an\nincrease when it comes to mumps.' The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United Kingdom can be\naccessed at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/008E>. - Mod. \n\nThere have been 112 confirmed cases across Sussex [county] so far\nthis year and numbers are expected to soon pass the 139 recorded for\nthe whole of 2009. \n\nDr Scanlon said: 'It certainly seems as if the numbers of mumps cases\nare actually spreading around Sussex and not just Brighton and Hove\nand that is concerning. ' The rise in cases has sparked renewed calls for people to make sure\nthey are vaccinated with the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR)\nvaccine. The city's director of public health, Tom Scanlon, said it was 'more\nthan likely' the number of mumps cases would go up during the next 8\nweeks. He said: 'The illness is mainly affecting young people in\ntheir 20s and there are going to be large numbers visiting the city\nand going out and socialising. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-11-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:20"], "locations": [{"location": "East Sussex", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brighton", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "441762", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - United Kingdom: (England)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=441762", "date": "2010-06-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED KINGDOM: (ENGLAND)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 3 Jun 2010\nSource: The Argus, Brighton News [edited]\n<http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/8197331.Mumps_outbreak_sweeps_across_Brighton_and_Hove/>\n\n\nMumps outbreak sweeps across Brighton and Hove\n----------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of mumps is continuing to sweep across Brighton and Hove.\nThere have been 46 confirmed cases of the virus in the city since\nJanuary compared to 27 for the whole of 2009. Health bosses say cases\nare affecting both young adults and children and are concerned there\ncould be more to come before the outbreak is contained. One teenager\nfrom Hove ended up in intensive care at the Royal Sussex County\nHospital in Brighton after being struck down by the virus. He is\nstill in hospital but no longer in intensive care and is progressing\nwell.\n\nThe outbreak has been blamed on the low uptake of the measles, mumps\nand rubella [MMR] vaccine. The take up rate for the 1st of 2\nrecommended MMR jabs is currently at 82 percent but the percentage\nhaving 2 doses is 69 percent. This is well below the 90 percent the\nWorld Health Organisation says needs to be vaccinated to protect a\ncommunity.\n\nThose affected are mainly young adults, who may have been too old\nbecause the vaccine was not around when they were young. Others may\nnot have had the jab because of concerns about research published in\nthe late 1990s which suggested a link with autism. This study has\nbeen largely discredited but take up rates have struggled to recover.\n\nCases of mumps have also emerged across the rest of the county [of\nSussex], with 25 in East Sussex so far this year and 18 in West\nSussex.\n\n[Byline: Siobhan Ryan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A proposition that the combined vaccination for measles, mumps and\nrubella (MMR) might raise a child's risk of bowel disorders and\nautism has proved to be one of the most controversial in medical\nscience for decades. In 1998 Dr Wakefield claimed he had evidence\nthat children's behaviour changed drastically shortly after they\nreceived the triple MMR jab. Dr Wakefield theorised that the\ncombination of the 3 virus strains contained in MMR may overload the\nbody's immune system and cause the bowel disorder to develop.\nAlthough his theories were discredited subsequently on the basis of\ndata for MMR vaccination accumulated throughout the world, the\ncontroversy caused vaccination rates to fall sharply particularly in\nthe UK and Ireland. Although last week, Dr Wakefield was struck off\nthe Medical Register by the General Medical Council for serious\nprofessional misconduct, lasting damage had been done and vaccination\nrates are only now beginning to recover. The city of Brighton and\nHove has a large student population and appears to particularly badly\naffected by the drop in overall MMR vaccine coverage.\n\nThe city of Brighton and Hove was established when 2 adjacent towns,\nBrighton and Hove, joined together to become a city. Brighton and\nHove is in the county of Sussex on the south coaast of England and\ncan be located using the HealthMap/ProMEDmail interactive map of\nEngland at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00A0>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 3 Jun 2010\n Brighton and\nHove is in the county of Sussex on the south coaast of England and\ncan be located using the HealthMap/ProMEDmail interactive map of\nEngland at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00A0>. - Mod. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A proposition that the combined vaccination for measles, mumps and\nrubella (MMR) might raise a child's risk of bowel disorders and\nautism has proved to be one of the most controversial in medical\nscience for decades. Although his theories were discredited subsequently on the basis of\ndata for MMR vaccination accumulated throughout the world, the\ncontroversy caused vaccination rates to fall sharply particularly in\nthe UK and Ireland. Although last week, Dr Wakefield was struck off\nthe Medical Register by the General Medical Council for serious\nprofessional misconduct, lasting damage had been done and vaccination\nrates are only now beginning to recover. Dr Wakefield theorised that the\ncombination of the 3 virus strains contained in MMR may overload the\nbody's immune system and cause the bowel disorder to develop.\n The take up rate for the 1st of 2\nrecommended MMR jabs is currently at 82 percent but the percentage\nhaving 2 doses is 69 percent. \n\nCases of mumps have also emerged across the rest of the county [of\nSussex], with 25 in East Sussex so far this year and 18 in West\nSussex. The city of Brighton and\nHove has a large student population and appears to particularly badly\naffected by the drop in overall MMR vaccine coverage.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "East Sussex", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brighton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "607147", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, young adults - Germany: (BY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=607147", "date": "2010-12-17 19:00:07", "main_text": "MUMPS, YOUNG ADULTS - GERMANY: (BAVARIA)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 16 Dec 2010\nSource: Eurosurveillance, Volume 15, Issue 50 [abbreviated & edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19748>\n\n\nOngoing outbreak of mumps affecting adolescents and young adults in\nBavaria, Germany\n----------------------------------\nBy: W Otto1, A Mankertz2, S Santibanez2, H Saygili3, J Wenzel4, W\nJilg4, W F Wieland1, S Borgmann 3\n1. Department of Urology, St. Josef Hospital, University of\nRegensburg, Regensburg, Germany\n2. National Reference Centre Measles, Mumps, Rubella, Robert Koch\nInstitute, Berlin, Germany\n3. Synlab Medical Care Service, Medical Care Centre Weiden, Weiden, Germany\n4. Institute of Medical Microbiology and Hygiene, University of\nRegensburg, Regensburg, Germany\n\nSummary\n-------\nSince the introduction of the 2-dose MMR vaccination regime, the\nincidence of mumps virus infections has substantially declined.\nHowever, mumps outbreaks have recently been reported from several\ncountries. Here we report an ongoing mumps outbreak in Germany.\nBetween 1 Jul 2010 and 31 Oct 2010, 115 infections have been\nlaboratory-confirmed. Reported complications include one case of\nmeningitis and 21 cases of orchitis, suggesting a high rate of\ncomplications. We suggest a vaccination campaign for young adults in\nnorthern Bavaria to limit severe mumps infections.\n\nIntroduction\n------------\nMumps virus infections may have a variable clinical outcome. Most\ncommonly they lead to fever and parotitis. However, up to 30 per cent\nof male adolescent mumps cases develop orchitis. The German Standing\nCommittee on Vaccination (Standige Impfkommission, STIKO) recommends\nthat children be vaccinated with 2 doses of MMR measles-mumps-rubella\n(MMR) or measles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccine within their\n1st 2 years of life (between 11 and 14 months and between 15 and 23\nmonths) [1]. Mumps is not a notifiable disease in Germany, therefore\ninformation about mumps cases or outbreaks is scant. In other European\ncountries, the introduction of a 2-dose MMR vaccination regime\nresulted in a strong decline of the number of mumps virus infections\n[2-4]. However, resurgent outbreaks of mumps were recently reported\nfrom several European countries [2-11], the United States (US) and\nCanada [12-14]. Many of the outbreaks were seen in highly vaccinated\npopulations, calling mumps virus vaccine efficiency into question\n[2-4, 6-9]. Here we report on an ongoing mumps outbreak in Germany.\n\nMethods and Results\n-------------------\nThe Synlab Medical Care Service Centre, Weiden, Bavaria, analyses\nlaboratory samples from about 40 hospitals and more than 2000\nphysicians serving outpatients predominantly from northern Bavaria\n[15]. In this study, results of serological mumps tests were\nevaluated. Data collected between January 2009 and October 2010 were\nexamined. In total, 1248 serum samples were examined for IgM\nantibodies and 4824 samples for IgG antibodies. More than 99 percent\nof these samples were derived from Bavarian patients.\n\nMumps antibody testing of patient sera was performed by using\nEnzygnost ELISA (anti-parotitis-virus/IgM and\nanti-parotitis-virus/IgG, Siemens Healthcare Diagnostics Products,\nMarburg, Germany). Results of IgM ELISA were given as negative,\nborderline (equivocal), and positive. Results of IgG ELISA were given\nas negative (under 230 U/ml), borderline (equivocal) (230-500 U/ml),\nand positive (over 500 U/ml). In the present analysis, acute mumps\ninfection was assumed when patients were IgM antibody positive or when\npatients either showed a borderline IgM antibody test result in\ncombination with typical symptoms or had detectable mumps virus\nribonucleic acid (RNA).\n\nThe German Reference Centre for measles, mumps and rubella virus at\nthe Robert Koch Institut performed PCR [polymerase chain reaction]\nanalyses from either throat swabs and/or urine samples. Genotyping of\ndetected mumps virus was performed as recommended in the Proposal for\nGenetic Characterisation of wild-type mumps strains [16].\n\nClinical data from mumps patients with orchitis were recorded at the\nDepartment of Urology at the St. Josef Medical Centre in Regensburg.\nThe Department of Urology is a facility of the University of Regensburg.\n\nIn the pre-outbreak period from January 2009 to June 2010, the number\nof patients infected with mumps virus was low (median per month N = 1\n(range 0-3)). However, this number has dramatically increased since\nthe outbreak started. In July 2010, 6 patients tested positive for\nmumps IgM antibodies. In August 2010, 18 patients tested positive, in\nSeptember 2010, 22 patients and in October 2010, 32 patients,\nrespectively. Additionally, in August 2010, 11 patients exhibiting\nmumps infection symptoms had borderline IgM test results. In September\n2010, this number was 8, and in October 2010, the number was 13.\n\nFurthermore, positive PCR results were obtained from 7 patients. Only\n2 of the patients showed IgM antibodies, while all PCR-positive\npatients exhibited IgG antibodies (median 14 000 U/ml). Genetic\ncharacterisation of mumps virus detected in the clinical material of 7\ncases revealed presence of genotype G.\n\nIn total, 115 mumps infections were confirmed positive at the Weiden\nSynlab laboratory and at the Robert Koch Institute between 1 Jul and\n31 Oct 2010. The median age was 24.5 years (mean 26.8 years, range\n14-62 years). However, information on the vaccination status was\navailable from only 7 mumps patients. One of them was unvaccinated,\none patient had received one dose of MMR, and 5 patients had been\nvaccinated twice.\n\nThe majority of the infections occurred in the city of Regensburg\n(about 135 000 inhabitants) or in the surrounding area. This finding\nwas most prominent in August 2010, while in September and October\n2010, an increasing number of cases were noted in the region located\nnorthwest of Regensburg.\n\nIn August 2010, one patient was diagnosed with mumps meningitis and a\n2nd case was suspected in November 2010. In total, 21 patients were\ntreated at the St. Josef Hospital in Regensburg (median age 26 years)\nbetween July and October 2010, resulting in a total of 76 days of\nhospitalisation.\n\nDiscussion\n---------\nWe give a preliminary description of an ongoing outbreak of mumps\nvirus infection in northern Bavaria. Similarly to previous outbreaks\nin Austria, Luxembourg, Ireland and the Netherlands, the present\noutbreak affects mainly young adult patients [4, 5, 9,11].\n\nWe suppose that the actual number of affected patients is by far\nhigher than 115 cases, since certainly not every clinical case was\nconfirmed in our laboratory. Furthermore, the present case definition\nin Germany uses positive IgM antibody and/or positive PCR results\n[17]. Many patients with clinical symptoms displayed high IgG antibody\ntitres probably due to prior immunisation or infection. As known from\nother viral diseases a viral re-infection is not necessarily\naccompanied by a rise in IgM antibodies but rather by an increase of\nIgG antibodies. Accordingly, during the outbreak months of July,\nAugust, September and October 2010, the median IgG titres were\nmarkedly higher than those observed in the previous months (January\n2009-June 2010). This supports the hypothesis that many mumps\n(re-)infections were accompanied by an increase of IgG antibody titre\nand not by the formation of IgM antibodies. This may have resulted in\nan underestimation in the number of mumps cases.\n\nAbsence of mumps virus-specific IgM antibodies in the majority of the\nclinical cases, as determined in the current outbreak in Germany, is\nconcordant with the laboratory data reported by the Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention from an outbreak observed in a highly\nvaccinated population in the USA [12].\n\nIn contrast to Germany, mumps is a notifiable disease in Ireland and\nthe Netherlands, where the collection of epidemiological data from\nmany patients has been possible. In these populations, the majority of\nthe patients had been vaccinated, and, at least in the Dutch group,\nmost patients had been vaccinated twice [9]. Although we could get\nonly limited information about vaccination status, our data support\nthe finding that most patients had been vaccinated completely,\nindicating that complete vaccination does not prevent mumps infection\nin an outbreak situation with absolute certainty.\n\nThe current outbreak in Bavaria was caused by mumps virus genotype G.\nPrevious analyses have revealed that this genotype was associated with\nseveral mumps outbreaks in Europe and the USA [2,5,18,19]. The\npossible emergence of a mutant strain of mumps virus has been reported\nunder the selective pressure of immunisation with limited or no\ncross-protection induced by the vaccine strain [20]. A recent analysis\nindicated that individuals possessing low levels of neutralising\nantibodies may be at risk for breakthrough infections [21]. These\nfindings underline the importance of investigating whether the current\nsituation in Germany is due to a high degree of susceptible\nindividuals or to a breakthrough of a currently circulating wildtype\nmumps virus.\n\nIn the present outbreak, predominantly young male patients have been\naffected. Complications as mumps orchitis have resulted in the\nhospitalisation of at least 13 young adult males. The outbreak started\nin the city of Regensburg (about 135 000 inhabitants) and its\nsurrounding area. In September and October 2010, an increasing number\nof cases was noted in the region located northwest of Regensburg. Due\nto very recent observations, this trend also continued in November\n2010, and it seems probable that the outbreak will soon reach the city\nof Nuremberg (about 500 000 inhabitants) and surroundings with 1.2\nmillion inhabitants.\n\nMeasures taken by public health service in Luxembourg were recently\nproven to help in confining a mumps outbreak among the military staff\n[5]. Furthermore, a mass-vaccination successfully stopped a mumps\noutbreak in Austria [11]. Therefore, it appears highly beneficial to\ninitiate a vaccination campaign in northern Bavaria.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Interested readers should consult the original text via the URL in\nthe heading in order to view the tabulated data, figures and the\nliterature references.\n\nThe analysis of this extensive continuing outbreak of mumps in\nBavaria, Germany raises some interesting questions. Most of the\npatients had received 2 doses of (MMR or MMRV) vaccine previously,\nindicating that complete vaccination does not always provide\nprotection against mumps virus infection in an ongoing outbreak\nsituation such as the current outbreak in Regensburg. It is still\nunclear whether this represents a deficiency in the immunising\ncapacity of the mumps component of the vaccine, or a change in the\nantigenicity of the outbreak strain. The latter seems less likely\nsince the outbreak strain is the ubiquitous G genotype.\n\nRecent observations indicate that the outbreak has continued through\nNovember 2010, and it is likely the outbreak will extend to the more\ndensely populated city of Nuremberg and its surroundings.\n\nA map of Bavaria showing the location of Regensburg can be accessed\nat: <http://munich.usconsulate.gov/news/map.html>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Germany is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00tN>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "The German Standing\nCommittee on Vaccination (Standige Impfkommission, STIKO) recommends\nthat children be vaccinated with 2 doses of MMR measles-mumps-rubella\n(MMR) or measles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccine within their\n1st 2 years of life (between 11 and 14 months and between 15 and 23\nmonths) A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 16 Dec 2010\n Genetic\ncharacterisation of mumps virus detected in the clinical material of 7\ncases revealed presence of genotype G.\n\nIn total, 115 mumps infections were confirmed positive at the Weiden\nSynlab laboratory and at the Robert Koch Institute between 1 Jul and\n31 Oct 2010. In the present analysis, acute mumps\ninfection was assumed when patients were IgM antibody positive or when\npatients either showed a borderline IgM antibody test result in\ncombination with typical symptoms or had detectable mumps virus\nribonucleic acid (RNA). \n\nAbsence of mumps virus-specific IgM antibodies in the majority of the\nclinical cases, as determined in the current outbreak in Germany, is\nconcordant with the laboratory data reported by the Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention from an outbreak observed in a highly\nvaccinated population in the USA [12]. Most of the\npatients had received 2 doses of (MMR or MMRV) vaccine previously,\nindicating that complete vaccination does not always provide\nprotection against mumps virus infection in an ongoing outbreak\nsituation such as the current outbreak in Regensburg. Although we could get\nonly limited information about vaccination status, our data support\nthe finding that most patients had been vaccinated completely,\nindicating that complete vaccination does not prevent mumps infection\nin an outbreak situation with absolute certainty. These\nfindings underline the importance of investigating whether the current\nsituation in Germany is due to a high degree of susceptible\nindividuals or to a breakthrough of a currently circulating wildtype\nmumps virus. Due\nto very recent observations, this trend also continued in November\n2010, and it seems probable that the outbreak will soon reach the city\nof Nuremberg (about 500 000 inhabitants) and surroundings with 1.2\nmillion inhabitants. In other European\ncountries, the introduction of a 2-dose MMR vaccination regime\nresulted in a strong decline of the number of mumps virus infections\n Mumps antibody testing of patient sera was performed by using\nEnzygnost ELISA (anti-parotitis-virus/IgM and\nanti-parotitis-virus/IgG, Siemens Healthcare Diagnostics Products,\nMarburg, Germany). Accordingly, during the outbreak months of July,\nAugust, September and October 2010, the median IgG titres were\nmarkedly higher than those observed in the previous months (January\n2009-June 2010). The\npossible emergence of a mutant strain of mumps virus has been reported\nunder the selective pressure of immunisation with limited or no\ncross-protection induced by the vaccine strain [20]. It is still\nunclear whether this represents a deficiency in the immunising\ncapacity of the mumps component of the vaccine, or a change in the\nantigenicity of the outbreak strain. In total, 21 patients were\ntreated at the St. Josef Hospital in Regensburg (median age 26 years)\nbetween July and October 2010, resulting in a total of 76 days of\nhospitalisation. This finding\nwas most prominent in August 2010, while in September and October\n2010, an increasing number of cases were noted in the region located\nnorthwest of Regensburg. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Interested readers should consult the original text via the URL in\nthe heading in order to view the tabulated data, figures and the\nliterature references. As known from\nother viral diseases a viral re-infection is not necessarily\naccompanied by a rise in IgM antibodies but rather by an increase of\nIgG antibodies. In the pre-outbreak period from January 2009 to June 2010, the number\nof patients infected with mumps virus was low (median per month N = 1\n In August 2010, 18 patients tested positive, in\nSeptember 2010, 22 patients and in October 2010, 32 patients,\nrespectively. Genotyping of\ndetected mumps virus was performed as recommended in the Proposal for\nGenetic Characterisation of wild-type mumps strains [16]. \n\nRecent observations indicate that the outbreak has continued through\nNovember 2010, and it is likely the outbreak will extend to the more\ndensely populated city of Nuremberg and its surroundings. \n\nThe German Reference Centre for measles, mumps and rubella virus at\nthe Robert Koch Institut performed PCR [polymerase chain reaction]\nanalyses from either throat swabs and/or urine samples. Only\n2 of the patients showed IgM antibodies, while all PCR-positive\npatients exhibited IgG antibodies (median 14 000 \n\nMeasures taken by public health service in Luxembourg were recently\nproven to help in confining a mumps outbreak among the military staff\n \n\nWe suppose that the actual number of affected patients is by far\nhigher than 115 cases, since certainly not every clinical case was\nconfirmed in our laboratory. Many of the outbreaks were seen in highly vaccinated\npopulations, calling mumps virus vaccine efficiency into question\n Ongoing outbreak of mumps affecting adolescents and young adults in\nBavaria, Germany\n Similarly to previous outbreaks\nin Austria, Luxembourg, Ireland and the Netherlands, the present\noutbreak affects mainly young adult patients [4, 5, 9,11]. However, resurgent outbreaks of mumps were recently reported\nfrom several European countries [2-11], the United States (US) and\nCanada In these populations, the majority of\nthe patients had been vaccinated, and, at least in the Dutch group,\nmost patients had been vaccinated twice [9]. This supports the hypothesis that many mumps\n(re-)infections were accompanied by an increase of IgG antibody titre\nand not by the formation of IgM antibodies. In contrast to Germany, mumps is a notifiable disease in Ireland and\nthe Netherlands, where the collection of epidemiological data from\n MUMPS, YOUNG ADULTS - GERMANY: (BAVARIA)\n****************************************\n One of them was unvaccinated,\none patient had received one dose of MMR, and 5 patients had been\nvaccinated twice. The\nDepartment of Health and Human Services reported on Fri 7 May 2010 it's\nbeen notified of 20 confirmed or probable cases of mumps. So far, 6 of\nthose cases have been confirmed by the state through lab testing. The\nDepartment says 18 of the cases were traced to an alumni basketball\ntournament held on 26-27 Mar 2010 at Columbus Scotus High School. One of\nthe cases involved an Arizona resident, and one a Colorado resident.\n\nOn Wed 5 May 2010, Iowa health officials issued a warning about a small\noutbreak of mumps in the north west part of that state. Nebraska officials\nsay it's not yet known whether the outbreaks are related.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Despite virtually universal MMR (measles-mumps-rubella) vaccination in the\nUSA outbreaks of mumps occur repeatedly wherever young adults congregate\ntogether, in this case by reason of a basketball tournament.\n\nMaps of the state of Nebraska locating Columbus in the east of the state\ncan be accessed at <http://geology.com/state-map/nebraska.shtml>. The data\n[are] the latest available. However, the figures are unofficial and\nwill not be certified by the public health officials of various\nstates or the CDC until next year [2011], the Rochester Infectious\nDisease Examiner reports.\n\nThe data provided cover the 1st 25 weeks of 2010, through 26 Jun\n2010. According to the data, New York City's mumps outbreak\ncontinues, though the number of new mumps cases in upstate New York\nand New Jersey appears to have declined. Preliminary numbers indicate\nthat New York City has reported 927 cases of mumps in 2010 through 26\nJun 2010. Upstate New York has reported 644 cases, with an additional\n257 reported in New Jersey, the Rochester Infectious Disease Examiner\nreports. The CDC has had reports of 2106 cases of mumps nationwide,\nwith 87 percent of those from New York and New Jersey.\n\n'Mumps vaccine, which is included in the combination\nmeasles-mumps-rubella and measles-mumps-rubella-varicella vaccines,\nis the best way to prevent mumps,' the CDC told the Rochester\nInfectious Disease Examiner. 'Mumps vaccine effectiveness has been\nestimated at 62 to 91 percent for one dose and 76 to 95 percent for 2 doses.'\n\n[Byline: Paul Tinder]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Before routine vaccination was introduced in the United States,\nmumps was a common illness in infants, children and young adults.\nBecause most people have now been vaccinated, mumps has become a rare\ndisease in the United States. However, as indicated above, at least 2\ndoses of vaccine are required to achieve an adequate level of\nimmunity, Consequently there will always be a proportion of the\npopulation with inadequate protection in the event of reintroduction\nof mumps virus into the community.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the USA can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01aH>. - Mod.TCP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 8 Jul 2010\n \n\n'Mumps vaccine, which is included in the combination\nmeasles-mumps-rubella and measles-mumps-rubella-varicella vaccines,\nis the best way to prevent mumps,' the CDC told the Rochester\nInfectious Disease Examiner.
