Israel (04): Yeshiva students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=474091", "date": "2010-07-23 17:00:04", "main_text": "MUMPS - ISRAEL (04): YESHIVA STUDENTS\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 23 Jul 2010\nSource: The Jerusalem Post [edited]\n<http://www.jpost.com/HealthAndSci-Tech/Health/Article.aspx?id=182330>\n\n\nHealth Ministry unfazed by mumps\n--------------------------------\nThere have been 3400 reported cases of the mumps since January\n[2010], 2400 of them in the Jerusalem area alone -- compared to 6 to\n10 cases during an ordinary year, according to National Council for\nthe Child Chairman Dr. Yitzhak Kadman.\n\nKadman asked the Health Ministry this week [19-23 Jul 2010] for an\nexplanation, since the mumps/measles/rubella (MMR) vaccine is\ngenerally given to protect children from these infectious viral\ndisease.\n\nLast November [2009], the Health Ministry's epidemiology department\nissued a directive about mumps, saying that within the 2 months\nbefore that date, there had been an outbreak of the disease, that 78\npercent of the patients had been males aged 10 to 24 -- and that most\nhad occurred in haredi yeshivot [orthodox religious boarding schools\nfor males] in Jerusalem, Bnei Brak, Petah Tikva and Modi'in Illit.\n\nThe number of cases in kindergartens and schools has been small, Dr.\nItamar Grotto, the Ministry's Chief of Public Health, told The\nJerusalem Post on Thursday [22 Jul 2010].\n\n'The origin of the outbreak was in haredi yeshivot in Brooklyn, New\nYork, and in New Jersey [see ProMED-mail references below. - Mod.CP],\nbut there are also reports of mumps out of Holland, England, and\nGermany in recent months that had nothing to do with the haredi\ncommunity,' he asserted.\n\n'We are not worried,' Grotto added. 'It is under control.' The number\nof cases has been on the decline since March [2010]. The Ministry\nurges everyone to make sure children get vaccinated with the MMR\nvaccine, even though no vaccine offers 100 percent protection, and\nthis particular vaccine is less effective than others that protect\nagainst childhood diseases. [This is true only of the mumps component\nof the triple vaccine. - Mod.CP] Most people who get the MMR vaccine\nat age one and age 6 are protected against mumps, Grotto assured.\n\nThe Ministry has sent information in recent months to the haredi\nmedia and to rabbis and yeshivot.\n\n[Byline: Judy Siegel-Itzkovich]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The situation in Jerusalem does not appear to be unique. Most\nrecently in August 2009, an outbreak of mumps originating in a summer\ncamp in Sullivan County, New York state, became the largest mumps\noutbreak since 2006, when the United States experienced an outbreak\nof mumps with 6584 reported cases. The outbreak primarily affected\nmembers of a tradition-observant (Jewish) religious community, in\nspite of a high level of vaccination (see MMWR, November 12, 2009 /\n58(Dispatch); 1-4 available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm58d1112a1.htm?s_cid=mm58d1112a1_e>).\nElsewhere similar outbreaks have occurred in colleges and schools\nwhere children and young adults may be living in close contact.\n\nOver 4 months up to mid-January 2010 some 600 cases of mumps had been\nreported in the Jerusalem district and more than 850 nationally in\nIsrael, the majority of whom (70 percent) have been male. Case\ninvestigation showed that the outbreak emerged in male-attended\nreligious high schools and colleges (yeshivas). In view of the fact\nthat the number of cases since January has risen to 3400 (2400 in the\nJerusalem area) the Ministry of Health's optimism seems misplaced.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Israel is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/013l>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "[2009], the Health Ministry's epidemiology department\nissued a directive about mumps, saying that within the 2 months\nbefore that date, there had been an outbreak of the disease, that 78\npercent of the patients had been males aged 10 to 24 -- and that most\nhad occurred in haredi yeshivot [orthodox religious boarding schools\nfor males] in Jerusalem, Bnei Brak, Petah Tikva and Modi'in Illit. (17) [edited]\n\n\nGuam mumps outbreak update\n--------------------------\nAs of Mon 3 May 2010, there have been 142 confirmed or probable mumps cases\nrecorded on Guam as a result of the current ongoing outbreak, with 71\nadditional suspect cases still under investigation.\n\nOnly 2 cases have required hospitalization (both had co-morbidities) and\nthere have been no mumps-related deaths thus far.\n\n83 per cent of confirmed and probable cases have been in children under 18\nyears of age, the highest number of cases (44) occurring in the age group\n11-13.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nAlice E Hadley, MLS, AHIP(D)\n<Alice.Hadley@med.navy.mil>\n\n[The mumps epidemic continues to spread. The number of confirmed or\nprobable cases of mumps on the island of Guam has increased to more than a\n142 cases from the 5 cases reported initially on 25 Mar 2010.\n\nThe majority of cases have been children, which is unexpected since Guam\nlaw requires all students entering school to submit proof of immunization\nthat includes 2 doses of the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine. It\nmay be that the mumps component of the MMR vaccine is less immunogenic that\nthe measles and rubella components and 2 doses are not sufficient to\nprovide complete protection. Alternatively perhaps the law is not being\nenforced.\n\nGuam is located in the western north Pacific Ocean, and is the largest and\nsouthernmost island in the Mariana Islands archipelago. A map of Guam can\nbe accessed at\n<http://www.picresorts.com/en/Guam/Background/Map-Of-Guam.jpg>. He contracted the\ndisease after interacting with members of an English rugby team.\n\nOne person from that team was diagnosed with mumps virus infection\nand 4 others developed symptoms consistent with the disease. The team\nis now back in England.\n\nMumps causes swelling of the cheeks and jaw and is spread by coughing\nand sneezing. Symptoms may include low grade fever, headache, muscle\naches, tiredness, loss of appetite, and swelling of salivary glands.\n\n[Byline: Ashton Smith]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Mumps is usually a mild disease, but can occasionally cause serious\ncomplications. The most common complication is inflammation of the\ntesticles (orchitis) in males who have reached puberty, occasionally\nleading to fertility problems. Other rare complications include\ninflammation of the brain and/or tissue covering the brain and spinal\ncord (encephalitis/meningitis), inflammation of the ovaries\n(oophoritis) and/or breasts (mastitis) in females who have reached\npuberty, and deafness.\n\nAlthough the majority of young adults the USA and the UK should be\nprotected by routine MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccination in\nchildhood, there is some evidence that immunity to mumps virus\ninfection tends to decline. Contact sports such as rugby football may\nexacerbate the situation by increasing the risk of transmission of\ninfection. - Mod.CP]\n\n[The states of North Carolina and Virginia can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00CA>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 30 Apr 2010\n Other rare complications include\ninflammation of the brain and/or tissue covering the brain and spinal\ncord (encephalitis/meningitis), inflammation of the ovaries\n(oophoritis) and/or breasts (mastitis) in females who have reached\npuberty, and deafness. Although the majority of young adults the USA and the UK should be\nprotected by routine MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccination in\nchildhood, there is some evidence that immunity to mumps virus\ninfection tends to decline. Contact sports such as rugby football may\nexacerbate the situation by increasing the risk of transmission of\ninfection.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Danville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NORTH CAROLINA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "419470", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (07): (TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=419470", "date": "2010-05-01 22:00:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED STATES OF AMERICA (07): (TEXAS)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 30 Apr 2010\nSource: KBTX.com [edited]\n<http://www.kbtx.com/local/headlines/92499409.html>\n\n\nMumps Cases in Brazos County\n----------------------------\nOne confirmed case of mumps has been reported in Brazos County,\nTexas, and several probable cases are also being looked into by the\ncounty health department. Mumps symptoms can include fever, headache,\nmuscle aches, tiredness and loss of appetite. Swelling of the\nsalivary glands can also follow.\n\nAccording to WebMD, symptoms will not appear in up to one-third of\npeople infected, especially in children younger than 2 years\nold.Those who are infected are able to spread mumps up to 2 days\nbefore symptoms begin, and then for between 5 and 9 days after the\nsymptoms start. Symptoms usually last for 10 days if they manifest\nthemselves. Only complicated cases require hospitalization, according\nto WebMD. Most recover with rest and care at home.\n\n'Although the Measles-Mumps-Rubella (MMR) vaccine is not a\nprophylactic treatment once exposed to mumps, it is advised to check\nyour immunization status to protect from possible future exposures,'\naccording to the release from the Brazos County Health Department [BCHD].\n\nHealth care providers are required to report both probable and\nconfirmed cases of mumps to their local health department. No other\ninformation concerning the confirmed or potential cases was released\nby the BCHD.\n\n[Byline: Steve Fullhart]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[No information about the age, sex, condition and circumstances of\nthe patient is provided. Consequently the risk of onward transmission\nof infection cannot be estimated. Further information about mumps\nvirus infection in general can be obtained at the WebMD website:\n<http://children.webmd.com/tc/mumps-topic-overview>.\n\nBrazos County can be located in East Central Texas using the Texas\nCounty Locator at:\n<http://www.county.org/resources/countydata/bin/locater.html>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United States is\navailable at: <http://healthmap.org/r/01bw>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 30 Apr 2010\n Although the Measles-Mumps-Rubella (MMR) vaccine is not a\nprophylactic treatment once exposed to mumps, it is advised to check\nyour immunization status to protect from possible future exposures,'\naccording to the release from the Brazos County Health Department [BCHD]. Communicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[No information about the age, sex, condition and circumstances of\nthe patient is provided. Those who are infected are able to spread mumps up to 2 days\nbefore symptoms begin, and then for between 5 and 9 days after the\nsymptoms start. One confirmed case of mumps has been reported in Brazos County,\nTexas, and several probable cases are also being looked into by the\ncounty health department. According to WebMD, symptoms will not appear in up to one-third of\npeople infected, especially in children younger than 2 years\nold. Further information about mumps\nvirus infection in general can be obtained at the WebMD website:\n<http://children.webmd.com/tc/mumps-topic-overview>. No other\ninformation concerning the confirmed or potential cases was released\nby the BCHD.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazos County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "428934", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (10): (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=428934", "date": "2010-05-17 12:00:04", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (10): (CALIFORNIA)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 16 May 2010\nSource: Los Angeles Times [edited]\n<http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-mumps-20100516,0,4560829.story>\n\n\nA mumps outbreak on the East Coast -- the largest in the United\nStates in 4 years -- may be spreading to Los Angeles [LA] County. So\nfar this year [2010], 9 cases of mumps have been reported, 2 more\nthan were seen in all of 2009, according to county health officer\nJonathan Fielding.\n\nFour of the mumps cases may be related to an outbreak, largely among\nOrthodox Jews, that has persisted in New York and New Jersey for\nalmost a year. According to the New York State Department of Health,\nthere have been more than 2800 confirmed and probable mumps cases in\nNew York and 315 in New Jersey. The outbreak has also spread to\nQuebec [Canada], where 20 mumps cases have been linked to the New\nYork outbreak, and to Israel, where more than 2600 have been infected.\n\nDr David Keene, a pediatrician in Beverly Hills, saw 2 mumps cases\nrecently, involving a student who attends the private high school\nYeshiva Ohr Elchonon Chabad in the Fairfax district of Los Angeles\nand a 2-year-old whose uncle attends the school. 'A lot of people\nwent traveling at Passover, which was about six weeks ago. They went\nhome and visited their friends with mumps, and three weeks later they\ngot sick,' Keene said.\n\nHealth officials said the Orthodox Jewish community as a whole has\nhigh vaccination rates, which is limiting the outbreak's size. The\nproblem is that the vaccine is not completely effective. One dose is\n73 percent to 91 percent effective; those who get a booster shot see\n79 percent to 95 percent effectiveness. 'Sometimes, when mumps gets\nestablished somewhat in a community and you determine immunization\nrates are pretty high, sometimes it just has to run its course,' said\nTom Skinner, a spokesman for the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nThe New York outbreak began in June 2009 when an unvaccinated\n11-year-old boy visited Britain, where mumps outbreaks remain a\nproblem. He then attended a summer camp in New York's Sullivan County\nfor Jewish boys. The disease, transmitted by coughing and sneezing,\nspread when the campers returned home.\n\nThe outbreak fits the profile of the last major US mumps outbreak in\n2006, spreading in places where people have prolonged, close contact.\nOutbreaks have been notable at boys-only Orthodox Jewish schools,\nwhere students sit for long periods facing a study partner. Another\nreason could be the larger size of many Orthodox families, the CDC said.\n\nRabbi Chaim Cunin of Chabad of California, a Westwood-based Orthodox\ngroup, said his community has been monitoring the outbreak since last\nyear [2009]. 'We live in a frequent-flier age. If the Jewish\ncommunity on the East Coast has an issue, it's certainly something we\nwould monitor on the West Coast,' Cunin said. Private Jewish schools\nhave been on a 'heightened state of alert' to quickly send sick\nchildren home, he said.\n\nMumps, which causes fever, aches, and fatigue, can also swell\nsalivary glands, causing what are called 'chipmunk cheeks.' Most\npeople recover within 10 days. Before the vaccine was released in\n1967, about 186 000 people in the United States got the mumps every\nyear, but the number has since fallen to fewer than 500 cases\nannually. Keene said some of the rare complications of mumps include\ndeafness and inflammation of the testicles. If that happens in males\nafter adolescence, it could in rare cases cause sterility.\n\nHealth officials have been concerned about a drop in childhood\nvaccinations based on allegations, since discredited, that vaccines\ncause autism. The Times in 2009 reported that a rising number of\nCalifornia parents were choosing to send their children to\nkindergarten without routine vaccinations, putting hundreds of\nelementary schools in the state at risk for outbreaks of childhood\ndiseases eradicated in the US years ago.\n\n[Byline: Rong-Gong Lin II]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The current outbreak of mumps in California may be a delayed\nconsequence of the outbreak, largely among Orthodox Jews, that has\npersisted in New York and New Jersey for almost a year, and\nsubsequently spread to Canada (Quebec) and Israel. This report\nsuggests that the spread of mumps in the Orthodox Jewish community\nmay not be due to lesser uptake of vaccine than in the rest of the\npopulation but rather is a consequence of 2 social factors, namely\nlarger family size and educational practices. These outbreaks have\noften occurred at boys-only Orthodox Jewish schools, where students\nsit for long periods facing a study partner, providing greater\nopportunity for transfer of infection.\n\nA map of the counties of Southern California showing the location of\nLos Angeles County can be accessed at\n<http://gocalifornia.about.com/cs/maps/l/bl_castmap_cty.htm>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United States is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01hL>). - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 16 May 2010\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The current outbreak of mumps in California may be a delayed\nconsequence of the outbreak, largely among Orthodox Jews, that has\npersisted in New York and New Jersey for almost a year, and\nsubsequently spread to Canada (Quebec) and Israel. This report\nsuggests that the spread of mumps in the Orthodox Jewish community\nmay not be due to lesser uptake of vaccine than in the rest of the\npopulation but rather is a consequence of 2 social factors, namely\nlarger family size and educational practices. Dr David Keene, a pediatrician in Beverly Hills, saw 2 mumps cases\nrecently, involving a student who attends the private high school\nYeshiva Ohr Elchonon Chabad in the Fairfax district of Los Angeles\nand a 2-year-old whose uncle attends the school. ' Before the vaccine was released in\n1967, about 186 000 people in the United States got the mumps every\nyear, but the number has since fallen to fewer than 500 cases\nannually. So\nfar this year [2010], 9 cases of mumps have been reported, 2 more\nthan were seen in all of 2009, according to county health officer\nJonathan Fielding. Sometimes, when mumps gets\nestablished somewhat in a community and you determine immunization\nrates are pretty high, sometimes it just has to run its course,' said\nTom Skinner, a spokesman for the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Guam (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=415102", "date": "2010-04-24 08:00:04", "main_text": "MUMPS - GUAM (02)\n*****************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 23 Apr 2010\nSource: Pacific Daily News, guampdn.com [edited]\n<http://www.guampdn.com/article/20100423/NEWS01/4230309>\n\n\nCDC to help with mumps outbreak\n-------------------------------\nMore than 100 cases of mumps have been reported on the island, and new\ncases are being reported daily, the Department of Public Health and Social\nServices announced yesterday [Thu 22 Apr 2010]. A team from the United\nStates' Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is on the island\nto assist Guam's public health agency in responding to the outbreak.\n\nMumps is a viral illness that can cause fever, headache, muscle aches,\ntiredness and painful swelling of the salivary glands under the ears. In\nsome cases, the contagious disease can lead to more serious complications.\n\nGuam normally reports one or 2 cases of mumps each year, the public health\ndepartment has said. Late last month [March 2010], the agency confirmed the\nisland's 5th mumps case and was monitoring 10 suspected cases. Of those 5\nconfirmed cases, 4 were students in Guam's public schools.\n\nThe public health department is asking residents to report any illnesses\nwith facial swelling to the agency. Those who are sick with this symptom\nshould stay home from school or work for 5 days from the start of the swelling.\n\n[byline: Dionesis Tamondong]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases of mumps on the island of Guam has increased to more\nthan a hundred from the 5 cases reported on 25 Mar 2010. Whereas the\noriginal cases were mostly schoolchildren, the age range of the new cases\nis not stated. Since Guam law requires all students entering school to\nsubmit proof of immunization that includes 2 doses of the measles, mumps\nand rubella (MMR) vaccine, it may be that the new cases are adults where\nthe consequences of mumps virus infection are more serious. Clarification\nwould be welcomed.\n\nGuam is located in the western north Pacific Ocean, and is the largest and\nsouthernmost island in the Mariana Islands archipelago. A map of Guam can\nbe accessed at\n<http://www.picresorts.com/en/Guam/Background/Map-Of-Guam.jpg>. Department of Education Superintendent\nNerissa Bretania Underwood this week issued a health alert for all\npublic schools, urging staff, students and parents to be more aware\nand act immediately when they suspect someone may have the contagious\ndisease.\n\nOf the 5 confirmed cases, 4 are students in the public schools: 2 at\nSimon Sanchez High School, one at John F. Kennedy High School and the\nmost recent case at Jose Rios Middle School, said Annette Aguon,\nimmunization program manager for the Department of Public Health and\nSocial Services' Bureau of Communicable Disease Control. A 5-year-old\nwho doesn't attend school is also a confirmed case.\n\nGuam normally receives about one case of mumps per year, Aguon said,\nadding that Public Health is treating the cases as an outbreak because\nof the unusually high number. There are about 10 other suspected cases\nthat Public Health is monitoring, Aguon said.\n\nThe 1st case was confirmed 10 Mar 2010 involving a Sanchez High\nstudent, and that case has been linked to 2 of the others, Aguon said.\nPublic Health continues to investigate how the disease was contracted\nand the level of exposure to family members and classmates of those\nconfirmed with mumps. Underwood has ordered school staff to monitor\nstudents closely and ensure their immunization records are up to date.\nInformation handouts have been sent home with students, she added.\n\n[Byline: Dionesis Tamondong]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Mumps is a viral infection characterized by fever, swelling and pain\nor tenderness of the parotid glands and/or the salivary glands. Up to\nhalf of those who contract mumps have very mild or no symptoms.\nSymptoms typically appear 16 to 18 days after infection, but this\nperiod can range from 12 to 25 days. The virus is spread from person\nto person by respiratory droplets, or by direct contact with items\nthat have been contaminated with infected saliva. Mumps most commonly\noccurs in children ages 2 to 12 who have not been vaccinated against\nthe disease. However, the infection can occur at any age. Those with\nsuspected mumps should be excluded from work or school until 5 days\nafter the onset of swelling of the face and cheek.\n\nGuam law requires all students entering school to submit proof of\nimmunization that includes 2 doses of the measles, mumps and rubella\n(MMR) vaccine. School officials are currently assessing those students\nidentified as close contacts of known cases to ensure compliance with\nvaccination requirements.\n\nGuam is located in the western north Pacific Ocean, and is the largest\nand southernmost island in the Mariana Islands archipelago. A map of\nGuam can be accessed at:\n<http://www.picresorts.com/en/Guam/Background/Map-Of-Guam.jpg>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Guam is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01bB>.\n- Mod.CP]\n\n[Although mumps is considered an inconsequential childhood disease,\norchitis (inflammation of a testicle) occurs in 20-30 percent of\npost-pubertal males, but usually without causing sterility; aseptic\nmeningitis in 10 percent of cases, nerve deafness and rarely\nencephalitis, which can be fatal. So vaccination during childhood is\na sensible precaution. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "MUMPS - GUAM: SCHOOL CHILDREN\n*****************************\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 27 Mar 2010\n \n\nOf the 5 confirmed cases, 4 are students in the public schools: 2 at\nSimon Sanchez High School, one at John F. CP]\n\n[Although mumps is considered an inconsequential childhood disease,\norchitis (inflammation of a testicle) occurs in 20-30 percent of\npost-pubertal males, but usually without causing sterility; aseptic\nmeningitis in 10 percent of cases, nerve deafness and rarely\nencephalitis, which can be fatal. \nPublic health officials late Thursday [25 Mar 2010] confirmed the\nisland's 5th case of mumps this year, prompting the agency to treat\nthe situation as an outbreak. \nPublic Health continues to investigate how the disease was contracted\nand the level of exposure to family members and classmates of those\nconfirmed with mumps. Nerissa Bretania Underwood this week issued a health alert for all\npublic schools, urging staff, students and parents to be more aware\nand act immediately when they suspect someone may have the contagious\ndisease. \n\nGuam normally receives about one case of mumps per year, Aguon said,\nadding that Public Health is treating the cases as an outbreak because\nof the unusually high number. \n\nGuam law requires all students entering school to submit proof of\nimmunization that includes 2 doses of the measles, mumps and rubella\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Mumps is a viral infection characterized by fever, swelling and pain\nor tenderness of the parotid glands and/or the salivary glands. School officials are currently assessing those students\nidentified as close contacts of known cases to ensure compliance with\nvaccination requirements.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Aguon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sanchez", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Underwood", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "397135", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (05): (NY), alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=397135", "date": "2010-03-17 16:00:02", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (05): (NEW YORK), ALERT\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 17 Mar 2010\nSource: WCAX.com, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\n<http://www.wcax.com/Global/story.asp?S=12153829>\n\n\nState health officials say 3 cases of mumps have been confirmed at\nthe State University of New York in Plattsburgh. They say that all\nstudents who haven't had 2 doses of mumps vaccine should be excluded\nfrom returning to school from spring break [13-22 Mar 2010] until\nthey're fully vaccinated. Inoculation clinics have been scheduled for\ntoday -- Wednesday [17 Mar 2010] -- and Monday [22 Mar 2010] on a\nwalk-in basis at the university health center.\n\nSymptoms of mumps include fever, headache, muscle weakness, and loss\nof appetite along with the characteristic swelling and tenderness in\nsalivary glands. It rarely leads to serious complications.\n\nOfficials say they haven't found any connection to an outbreak of\nmumps that began last summer [2009] in Orange and Rockland [New York].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[This report suggests that there is no connection between these 3\ncases and the earlier mumps outbreak in New York in 2009. It would be\nof interest to know when these 3 cases became infectious. If they had\ninfected other students before they dispersed during spring break,\nthere would have been a risk of spread to other places, many of them\ndistant from Plattsburgh.\n\nA map showing the location of Plattsburgh in far northeastern New\nYork State can be accessed at\n<http://www.plattsburgh.edu/admissions/nysmap.php>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the USA can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01aH>. - Mod.TY]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 17 Mar 2010\n They say that all\nstudents who haven't had 2 doses of mumps vaccine should be excluded\nfrom returning to school from spring break [13-22 Mar 2010] until\nthey're fully vaccinated. If they had\ninfected other students before they dispersed during spring break,\nthere would have been a risk of spread to other places, many of them\ndistant from Plattsburgh. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[This report suggests that there is no connection between these 3\ncases and the earlier mumps outbreak in New York in 2009. \n\nSymptoms of mumps include fever, headache, muscle weakness, and loss\nof appetite along with the characteristic swelling and tenderness in\nsalivary glands. Source: WCAX.com, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\n<http://www.wcax.com/Global/story.asp?S=12153829>\n\n\nState health officials say 3 cases of mumps have been confirmed at\nthe State University of New York in Plattsburgh.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rockland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orange", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Plattsburgh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "406034", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (06): (NY, PA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=406034", "date": "2010-04-06 18:00:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED STATES OF AMERICA (06): (NEW YORK, PENNSYLVANIA)\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] New York state\nDate: Thu 1 Apr 2010\nSource: WCAX, Local Vermont News [edited]\n<http://www.wcax.com/Global/story.asp?S=12239717>\n\n\n9 confirmed mumps cases at Plattsburgh State\n--------------------------------------------\nHealth officials say there are now more confirmed cases of mumps\nvirus infection at Plattsburgh State [college]. School officials say\nthere are now 9 confirmed cases with 6 more pending. Affected\nstudents are reportedly only showing mild symptoms like fever, aches\nand swollen glands.\n\nThe school is insisting that everyone be vaccinated. Students can get\nthe vaccine for free at the health center on campus or at any county\nhealth department.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Pennsylvania\nDate: Fri 2 Apr 2010\nSource: The Morning Call [edited]\n<http://www.mcall.com/news/local/all-a10_5mumps.7226377apr02,0,4866870.story>\n\n\nHealth officials studying mumps case\n------------------------------------\nAn Allentown, Pennsylvania, child has contracted mumps but it is\nunclear if the case is connected to a multi-state outbreak of the\ncontagious virus in the Northeast, health officials said Thursday [1\nApr 2010]. The child, who was not identified, has swollen glands and\nother symptoms associated with mumps, said Allentown Health Bureau\nDirector Vicky Kistler. Health officials are investigating how the\nchild became ill. 'We want to make sure we don't have an outbreak\nhere locally,' Kistler said.\n\nSo far, the child's case does not appear to be connected to other\nconfirmed cases in the state, Kistler said. As of last week, the\nstate Department of Health was reporting 3 cases of mumps in\nsoutheastern Pennsylvania. Those cases were associated with a\nnational outbreak, primarily affecting Hasidic Jewish populations\nfrom New York and New Jersey. The outbreak is the largest in the U.S.\nsince 2006, when almost 6600 cases were reported in six Midwestern\nstates. In a normal year, about 300 cases are reported nationwide.\n\nAs of last week, there were 2903 cases of mumps reported nationally\nsince an outbreak began last summer in a boys camp in the Catskill\nMountains, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nMumps typically start with a few days of fever, headache, muscle\naches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, and is followed by swelling\nof glands in the neck. Anyone who is not immune from either previous\nmumps infection or from vaccination can get mumps. But vaccination\nisn't a guarantee against contracting mumps. In New York, almost all\nof those infected had received mumps vaccine, which suggests that\ncrowded households and close contact in schools can sometimes\noverwhelm the protective effects of immunization.\n\nKistler advised parents to monitor children for symptoms. Parents who\nsuspect their children have mumps should keep them away from others\nand seek medical attention, calling doctors in advance so infected\nchildren don't sit in crowded waiting rooms.\n\nBefore the routine vaccination program was introduced in the U.S.,\nmumps was common in infants, children and young adults. Now that most\npeople are vaccinated, mumps has become rare in the United States.\n'We have a community that tends to be well vaccinated against mumps,'\nKistler said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Theses reports appear to record sporadic outbreaks of mumps virus\ninfection unconnected to the major outbreak originating in New York\nstate. The New York state outbreak subsequently spreading to adjacent\nstates and eventually abroad to Quebec and Israel, mainly through the\nmovement of students attending Yeshiva schools.\n\nAllentown can be located in the map of Pennsylvania at:\n<http://geology.com/cities-map/pennsylvania.shtml>, and Plattsburg in\nthe map of New York state at:\n<http://www.planetware.com/i/map/US/new-york-state-map.jpg>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United States is\navailable at: <http://healthmap.org/r/01bQ>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] New York state\n \nAn Allentown, Pennsylvania, child has contracted mumps but it is\nunclear if the case is connected to a multi-state outbreak of the\ncontagious virus in the Northeast, health officials said Thursday [1\n Parents who\nsuspect their children have mumps should keep them away from others\nand seek medical attention, calling doctors in advance so infected\nchildren don't sit in crowded waiting rooms. In New York, almost all\nof those infected had received mumps vaccine, which suggests that\ncrowded households and close contact in schools can sometimes\noverwhelm the protective effects of immunization. \n\nAllentown can be located in the map of Pennsylvania at:\n<http://geology.com/cities-map/pennsylvania.shtml>, and Plattsburg in\nthe map of New York state at:\n<http://www.planetware.com/i/map/US/new-york-state-map.jpg>. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Theses reports appear to record sporadic outbreaks of mumps virus\ninfection unconnected to the major outbreak originating in New York\nstate. --------------------------------------------\nHealth officials say there are now more confirmed cases of mumps\nvirus infection at Plattsburgh State [college]. \n\nMumps typically start with a few days of fever, headache, muscle\naches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, and is followed by swelling\nof glands in the neck. As of last week, there were 2903 cases of mumps reported nationally\nsince an outbreak began last summer in a boys camp in the Catskill\nMountains, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Source: WCAX, Local Vermont News [edited]\n<http://www.wcax.com/Global/story.asp?S=12239717>\n\n\n9 confirmed mumps cases at Plattsburgh State\n As of last week, the\nstate Department of Health was reporting 3 cases of mumps in\nsoutheastern Pennsylvania. The child, who was not identified, has swollen glands and\nother symptoms associated with mumps, said Allentown Health Bureau\n Source: The Morning Call [edited]\n<http://www.mcall.com/news/local/all-a10_5mumps.7226377apr02,0,4866870.story>\n\n\nHealth officials studying mumps case\n The New York state outbreak subsequently spreading to adjacent\nstates and eventually abroad to Quebec and Israel, mainly through the\nmovement of students attending Yeshiva schools. The outbreak is the largest in the U.S.\nsince 2006, when almost 6600 cases were reported in six Midwestern\nstates.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2903-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yeshiva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Allentown", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Plattsburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "PENNSYLVANIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "418994", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, students - Netherlands", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=418994", "date": "2010-04-30 19:00:03", "main_text": "MUMPS, STUDENTS - NETHERLANDS\n*****************************\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 29 Apr 2010\nSource: Eurosurveillance, Volume 15, Issue 17, [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19554>\n\n\nOngoing mumps outbreak in a student population\nwith high vaccine coverage, Netherlands, 2010\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nSummary\n-------\nSince December 2009, mumps incidence has\nincreased in the Netherlands. As of 20 Apr 2010,\n172 cases have been notified on the basis of\nlaboratory confirmation or linkage to a\nlaboratory-confirmed case. Of these, 112 were\nstudents, the majority of whom had been\nvaccinated (81 percent). Although outbreaks in\nvaccinated populations have been described\nbefore, risk factors for exposure and\nsusceptibility, and dose-dependent vaccine\neffectiveness in a student population of this nature are relatively unknown.\n\nBackground\n----------\nMumps has been a notifiable disease in the\nNetherlands since 2009. Notification criteria\ninclude at least one related symptom (acute onset\nof painful swelling of the parotid or other\nsalivary glands, orchitis or meningitis) and\nlaboratory confirmation of infection or an\nepidemiological link to a laboratory-confirmed\ncase [1]. The measles\u00admumps\u00adrubella (MMR) vaccine\ncontaining the Jeryl Lynn mumps virus strain was\nintroduced in the Netherlands in 1987.\nVaccination is recommended, with a 2 dose\nschedule at the age of 14 months and 9 years. In\n2007 and 2009, an epidemic (genotype D) occurred\nin a socio-geographically clustered, Dutch\nreformed protestant community with low\nvaccination coverage [2]. Nationally however,\nvaccine coverage with 2 doses has been\nconsistently above 93 percent [3]. Despite this,\nan outbreak of mumps occurred among vaccinated\nnational and international students at a\nparticular school in 2004 [4]. A resurgence of\nmumps has been observed in vaccinated populations\nin countries worldwide since 2004 [5].\n\nDescriptive epidemiology\n------------------------\nIn the 11 months from January to November 2009,\n65 cases of mumps were reported to the National\nInstitute for Public Health and Environment\n(RIVM) in the Netherlands. Between 1 Dec 2009 and\n20 Apr 2010, 172 notifications of mumps cases\nwere received, of whom 24 percent became ill in\nlate February (week 11) 2010. Seventy-nine of the\ncases were from the Municipal Health Service\n(MHS) Zuid-Holland West (including the city of\nDelft), 44 were from MHS Hollands-Midden\n(including the city of Leiden) and accounted for\nthe majority of cases in week 11, 11 were\nreported in MHS Utrecht, and an additional 38\ncases were reported from other regions across the\nNetherlands. The median age was 21 years (range:\n4 to 46 years) and 58 percent (n=99) were male.\nMost of the patients had mild symptoms, but 14 (9\npercent) reported some complication, which in 12\ncases was orchitis (12 percent of men). One\nperson was hospitalised for one night due to\nsevere symptoms but had no complications.\nRoutinely collected notification data revealed\nthat a large proportion of cases (n=112, 65\npercent) were students. A further 11 cases were contacts of students.\n\nA total of 27 student-cases (24 percent of cases)\nreported attending a student party (attended by\nover 2000 students) held in mid-February (week 8)\nover 4 days and nights in a building of the\nLeiden student's association. The students\nsuspected this to be the source of infection.\nGiven the incubation period of mumps is typically\n16 to 18 days, this would coincide with the surge\nin cases seen in week 11 in MHS Hollands-Midden.\nSome attended the party for one night only\n(mainly students from Delft and Utrecht), but the\nmajority from Leiden attended for 3 or 4 days and\nnights in succession. An outbreak investigation\ninto risk factors for acquisition of mumps by the\nMHS in Leiden, Delft and Utrecht is currently\nunderway in collaboration with the Centre for\nInfectious Disease Control of RIVM.\n\nMicrobiological findings\n------------------------\nThe clinical diagnosis of notified cases was\nlaboratory-confirmed by at least one method in 46\npercent of cases (n=79): by detection of a\nmumps-specific IgM antibody response in 20\npercent of cases (n=32), by detection of mumps\nvirus RNA in 30 percent (n=48), and/or by\ncultivation of mumps virus in 10 percent (n=16).\nWhere there was no laboratory confirmation, an\nepidemiological link to a laboratory-confirmed\ncase was established in 45 percent of cases\n(n=78). 5 cases did not meet notification\ncriteria because they were linked\nepidemiologically to an index case, but\nlaboratory confirmation of that index case was\nnot established at the time of notification. The\nremaining 10 cases reportedly met the\nnotification criteria, but reasons for\nnotification were incomplete or missing (n=6\npercent). Genotyping of isolated mumps viruses\nrevealed that the outbreak strain belonged to the G5 lineage.\n\nVaccination status of cases\n---------------------------\nReported vaccination coverage among cases,\nparticularly among the students, was high. (Data\ntabulated in the original text). Of the 164 for\nwhom vaccine status was known, 115 (70 percent)\nwere vaccinated and 100 (61 percent) had received\nat least 2 mumps vaccinations. Among the 106\nstudents for whom vaccine status was known, 85\n(81 percent) were vaccinated at least once, and\n79 of them were vaccinated at least twice.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nMumps outbreaks among vaccinated populations are\nreported world-wide [5-7]. Clinical attack rates\nare generally lower in vaccinated populations\n(indicating a protective effect), but there is\ngrowing evidence of waning immunity over time,\n[8-10] leading to secondary vaccine failure\n[4,10-12]. The majority of cases in this outbreak\nwere students aged 18 to 24 years, of whom 73\npercent had received at least 2 mumps\nvaccinations. The clustering of cases among\nstudents (in Leiden and to a lesser extent in\nDelft and Utrecht) suggests that intensive social\ncontact during the 4-day party may have\nfacilitated transmission. Shared living\nfacilities among members of the students'\nassociation, and the close contact environment of\nroutine college life are also likely contributing risk factors [13,14].\n\nIn accordance with recommendations from the World\nHealth Organization [15], most countries now\noffer a 2-dose vaccine schedule for mumps. In the\nNetherlands, all birth cohorts since 1982 have\nbeen offered 2 vaccine doses. Exceptionally,\nthere is a suggestion that those born in 1986 and\n1987 (now aged 23), were offered 3 doses of MMR\nat the age of 14 months, 4 years and 9 years\n[16], but this remains to be confirmed. Dutch\nchildren are older when they receive the 2nd\nvaccine dose (at age 9 years) compared to those\nin the United Kingdom, the United States and\nCanada, where it is given at 4 to 6 years of age.\nBoosting of the immune response by circulating\nwildtype virus is unlikely as mumps has not been\nwidespread in the Netherlands except for a\nrestricted outbreak within the religious\ncommunity a few years previously [2]. Primary\nvaccine failure is possible but a\npost-vaccination seroprevalence of 93.2 percent\nhas been shown in children under the age of 3\nyears in the Netherlands [17]. In addition to the\nintensive social contact implicated in this\noutbreak, the fact that it occurred among the\noldest vaccinated cohorts in the Netherlands who\nreceived 2 vaccine doses makes secondary vaccine failure more plausible.\n\nCareful investigation will be required to\nestablish the relationship between increasing age\non the one hand, and incidence rates, severity\nand post-exposure disease susceptibility on the\nother. Comparison of pre- and post-exposure\nantibody titres in a longitudinal study could\ngive clues about correlates for protection\nagainst mumps virus infection, as this is not\nwell understood for persons who have received 2\ndoses of the mumps vaccine. Antigenic differences\nbetween the Jeryl Lynn vaccine strain (genotype\nA) and the viral strain in this and other\noutbreaks (genotype G) have also previously been\nimplicated [11], but recent data suggests a good\ndegree of serologic cross-immunity between Jeryl Lynn and other genotypes [18].\n\nCurrent outbreak response measures concentrate on\ngathering good surveillance data, and students in\nthe cities affected by this mumps outbreak who\nare not fully vaccinated (i.e., with 2 doses of\nMMR) are advised to complete their MMR\nvaccination. In response to an ongoing outbreak\nin the United States among a population of young\nadults (age 7-18 years) with a similar high\nvaccination coverage, public health officials in\nNew York have been offering a 3rd dose of MMR\nvaccine in some schools since January 2010 [12].\nThe lower incidence of mumps in the Netherlands\namong those born in 1986 who may have received 3\nvaccine doses in childhood is certainly\ninteresting in this respect, but further\ninvestigation is required to confirm this.\n\nOn assessment, the risk of a large national\noutbreak in the Netherlands is considered to be\nlow because of high overall vaccine coverage and\nthe clustered nature of student social life.\nOffering a 3rd vaccine dose is not planned at\npresent. With the cooperation of the municipal\nhealth services and the students' associations,\nwe intend to conduct further research to better\nunderstand the risk factors associated with mumps\nexposure and susceptibility, and dose-related vaccine effectiveness.\n\nReferences\n----------\n(1)Parotitis epidemica: Bof (Mumps)\nB26. Bilthoven: National Institute for Public\nHealth and the Environment (RIVM); 2009.\n[Accessed 12 April 2010]. Available from:\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/infectieziekten-A-Z/infectieziekten/Parotitis_epidemica/index.jsp>.\nDutch.\n(2) Karagiannis I, van Lier A, van Binnendijk R,\nRuijs H, Fanoy E, Conyn-Van Spaendonck M, et al.\nMumps in a community with low vaccination\ncoverage in the Netherlands. Eurosurveillance.\n2010;12(13):pii:18901. Available from:\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=18901>\n(3) van Lier E, Oomen P, Oostenburg M, Zwakhals\nS, Drijfhout I, de Hoogh P, et al.\nVaccinatiegraad Rijksvaccinatieprogramma\nNederland. Verslagjaar 2009. [National\nImmunisation Programme in the Netherlands. Annual\nReport 2009]. Bilthoven: National Institute for\nPublic Health and the Environment (RIVM); 2009..\nAvailable from: <http://www.rivm.nl/bibliotheek/rapporten/210021010.pdf>\n(4) Brockhoff HJ, Mollema L, Sonder GJ, Postema\nCA, van Binnendijk RS, Kohl RH, et al. Mumps\noutbreak in a highly vaccinated student\npopulation, The Netherlands, 2004. Vaccine. 2010;9;28(17):2932-6.\n(5) Dayan GH, Rubin S. Mumps outbreaks in\nvaccinated populations: are available mumps\nvaccines effective enough to prevent outbreaks?\nClin Infect Dis. 2008;47(11):1458-67.\n(6) Stein-Zamir C, Shoob H, Abramson N,\nTallen-Gozani E, Sokolov I, Zentner G. Mumps\noutbreak in Jerusalem affecting mainly male\nadolescents. Euro Surveill. 2009;14(50):pii=19440. Available from:\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19440>\n(7) Schwarz NG, Bernard H, Melnic A, Bucov V,\nCaterinciuc N, An der Heiden M, et al. Mumps\nOutbreak in the Republic of Moldova, 2007-2008.\nPediatr Infect Dis J. 2010 Mar 19. [Epub ahead of print].\n(8) Briss PA, Fehrs LJ, Parker RA, Wright PF,\nSannella EC, Hutcheson RH, et al. J Infect Dis. 1994;169(1):77-82.\n(9) Cohen C, White JM, Savage EJ, Glynn JR, Choi\nY, Andrews N, et al. Mumps vaccine\nperformance among university students during a\nmumps outbreak. Clin Infect Dis. 2008;46(8):1172-80.\n(11) Peltola H, Kulkarni PS, Kapre SV, Paunio M,\nJadhav SS, Dhere RM. Mumps outbreaks in Canada\nand the United States: time for new thinking on\nmumps vaccines. Clin Infect Dis. 2007;45(4):459-66.\n(12) Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\n(CDC). Update: Mumps Outbreak - New York and New\nJersey, June 2009-January 2010. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2010;12;59(5):125-9.\n(13) Whyte D, O'Dea F, McDonnell C, O'Connell NH,\nCallinan S, Brosnan E, et al. Mumps epidemiology\nin the mid-west of Ireland 2004-2008: increasing\ndisease burden in the university/college setting.\nEuro Surveill. 2009;14(16):pii=19182. Available\nfrom: <http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19182>\n(14) Huang AS, Cortese MM, Curns AT, Bitsko RH,\nJordan HT, Soud F, et al. Risk factors for mumps\nat a university with a large mumps outbreak.\nPublic Health Rep. 2009;124(3):419-26.\n(15) World Health Organisation. Mumps Virus\nVaccines. Wkly Epidemiol Rec. 2007;82(7):51-60.\n(16) Inspectie voor de gezondheidszorg.\n[Inspectorate for Health]. Available at:\n<http://www.rivm.nl/bibliotheek/rapporten/210021001.pdf>\n(17) van den Hof S, Beaumont MT, Berbers GA, de\nMelker HE. Antibody induced\nby immunization with the Jeryl Lynn mumps vaccine\nstrain effectively neutralizes a heterologous\nwild-type mumps virus associated with a large\noutbreak. J Infect Dis. 2008;198(4):508-15.\n\n[Byline: J Whelan 1,2, R van Binnendijk1, K\nGreenland1,2, E Fanoy 3,1, M Khargi 4, K Yap 5, H\nBoot1, N Veltman1, C Swaan1, A van der Bij1, H de Melker1, S Hahne1, at:\n1. Centre for Infectious Disease Control,\nRijksinstituut voor Volksgezondheid en Milieu\n(National Institute for Public Health\nand Environment, RIVM), Bilthoven, the Netherlands\n2. MUMPS, STUDENTS - NETHERLANDS\n*****************************\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\n [Byline: J Whelan 1,2, R van Binnendijk1, K\nGreenland1,2, E Fanoy 3,1, M Khargi 4, K Yap 5, H\nBoot1, N Veltman1, C Swaan1, A van der Bij1, H de Melker1, S Hahne1, at:\n1. Available from:\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=18901>\n(3) van Lier E, Oomen P, Oostenburg M, Zwakhals\nS, Drijfhout I, de Hoogh P, et al. ProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 29 Apr 2010\n Available from:\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19440>\n(7) Schwarz NG, Bernard H, Melnic A, Bucov V,\nCaterinciuc N, An der Heiden M, et al. Mumps outbreaks in\nvaccinated populations: are available mumps\nvaccines effective enough to prevent outbreaks? Ongoing mumps outbreak in a student population\nwith high vaccine coverage, Netherlands, 2010\n Most of the patients had mild symptoms, but 14 (9\npercent) reported some complication, which in 12\ncases was orchitis (12 percent of men). In accordance with recommendations from the World\nHealth Organization [15], most countries now\noffer a 2-dose vaccine schedule for mumps. Vaccine effectiveness\nestimates, 2004-2005 mumps outbreak, England.\n Mumps\noutbreak in a highly vaccinated student\npopulation, The Netherlands, 2004. Given the incubation period of mumps is typically\n16 to 18 days, this would coincide with the surge\nin cases seen in week 11 in MHS Hollands-Midden. Nationally however,\nvaccine coverage with 2 doses has been\nconsistently above 93 percent [3]. Mumps outbreaks in Canada\nand the United States: time for new thinking on\nmumps vaccines. The measles\u00admumps\u00adrubella (MMR) vaccine\ncontaining the Jeryl Lynn mumps virus strain was\nintroduced in the Netherlands in 1987. Routinely collected notification data revealed\nthat a large proportion of cases (n=112, 65\npercent) were students. A resurgence of\nmumps has been observed in vaccinated populations\nin countries worldwide since 2004 [5]. An outbreak investigation\ninto risk factors for acquisition of mumps by the\nMHS in Leiden, Of these, 112 were\nstudents, the majority of whom had been\nvaccinated (81 percent). In the\nNetherlands, all birth cohorts since 1982 have\nbeen offered 2 vaccine doses. (2) Karagiannis I, van Lier A, van Binnendijk R,\nRuijs H, Fanoy E, Conyn-Van Spaendonck M, et al.\n ----------\nMumps has been a notifiable disease in the\nNetherlands since 2009.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1987-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2003-01-01 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "1982-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "1986-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2010-04-12 00:00:00", "2010-01-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-12-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "N Veltman1", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Stockholm", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jerusalem", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delft", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leiden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Moldova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zeist", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utrecht", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Callinan S", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New \n Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zoetermeer", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "388658", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=388658", "date": "2010-02-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04)\n****************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 25 Feb 2010\nSource: The Pediatric SuperSite [edited]\n<http://www.pediatricsupersite.com/view.aspx?rid=61325>\n\n\nACIP discusses factors leading to mumps outbreak in the north east\n------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe number of cases linked to a June [2009] mumps outbreak at a New York\nsummer camp has climbed to 2336, CDC [Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention] officials reported during the Advisory Committee on\nImmunization Practices [ACIP] meeting this week [24-25 Feb 2010]. After\ninitial spread into other populations throughout the state and areas of New\nJersey, CDC epidemiologist Kathleen Gallagher said the disease has now been\nexported to Connecticut, Quebec, and Israel.\n\nIncidence remains highest among boys in the Hasidic community because they\nusually spend longer hours at private schools, Gallagher said, mostly\naround other people belonging to this population. In addition to day\nstudents, these schools also board students from a variety of other regions\nand states. Therefore, boys potentially exposed to mumps may inadvertently\nspread the disease among other communities when they return home for\nholidays, emphasizing the importance of up-to-date, 2-dose vaccinations in\nthis age group.\n\nThe potential for a 3-dose measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine (MMR II,\nMerck) was also a focal point at the meeting. Currently, officials in\nOrange County, New York have tried administering a 3rd dose to children in\nefforts to control the outbreak. Although little data are available,\nGallagher said studies to evaluate the efficacy of a 3-dose vaccine regimen\nare ongoing.\n\nAdditional discussion addressed the genotype responsible for the outbreak,\nas well as the current vaccine's ability to effectively prevent the spread\nof disease. Officials have identified genotype G from the United Kingdom,\nwhich was also present in the 2006 mumps outbreak, as the culprit for the\ncurrent outbreak. Gallagher noted that there was 'nothing special' about\ngenotype G, and the MMR vaccine may [induce] antibodies to this strain.\n\nNevertheless, other committee members said the mumps component of the MMRV\n[measles, mumps, rubella, varicella] has always been less effective than\nthe measles and rubella components, and some attributed this to the strain\ncontained in the vaccine. 'It's a complex situation that we have, but as\nI've said to my colleagues from Merck, we do need a better mumps strain\nthan we currently have,' Stanley A Plotkin, MD, of Sanofi-Pasteur, said.\n'Even though we have a number of [mumps strains], none of them are perfect.'\n\n[byline: Melissa Foster]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases in this outbreak has increased from the 1521 reported\non 29 Jan 2010 to the current figure of 2336. This outbreak is still far\nfrom contained and now has spread in the USA to the state of Connecticut,\nas well as to Quebec, Canada, and Israel.\n\nThe mumps component of the current MMR triple vaccine may be less effective\nthan the other components of the triple vaccine. The potential value of\ngiving 3 doses of MMR vaccine was discussed at the ACIP meeting, in efforts\nto control the outbreak. Results are awaited. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 25 Feb 2010\n The number of cases linked to a June [2009] mumps outbreak at a New York\nsummer camp has climbed to 2336, CDC [Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention] officials reported during the Advisory Committee on\nImmunization Practices [ACIP] meeting this week [24-25 Feb 2010]. Therefore, boys potentially exposed to mumps may inadvertently\nspread the disease among other communities when they return home for\nholidays, emphasizing the importance of up-to-date, 2-dose vaccinations in\nthis age group. \n\n[byline: Melissa Foster]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< After\ninitial spread into other populations throughout the state and areas of New\nJersey, CDC epidemiologist Kathleen Gallagher said the disease has now been\nexported to Connecticut, Quebec, and Israel. \n\nAdditional discussion addressed the genotype responsible for the outbreak,\nas well as the current vaccine's ability to effectively prevent the spread\nof disease. Case investigation has shown that\nthe outbreak emerged in male attended religious high schools and\ncolleges (yeshivas). Female cases have been mainly secondary,\nhousehold contacts.\n\nAbout 60 percent of patients had received 2 doses of MMR, another 20\npercent had received one dose (13 percent age appropriate). As opposed\nto previous outbreaks in Jerusalem where active case investigation\nshowed 95 percent of cases to be unvaccinated, only 20 percent of\ncases in the present outbreak were unvaccinated.\n\nThe predominance of males, vaccinated individuals, and the low rate of\ntransmission to the surrounding community should, in our opinion, call\nfor further investigation.\n\n--\nDr Chen Stein-Zamir\nJerusalem District Health Office\n86 Jaffa Road\nJerusalem 94341\nIsrael\n<chen.zamir@lbjr.health.gov.il>\n\n[The situation in Jerusalem does not appear to be unique. Most\nrecently in August 2009, an outbreak of mumps originating in a summer\ncamp in Sullivan County, New York state became the largest mumps\noutbreak since 2006, when the United States experienced an outbreak of\nmumps with 6584 reported cases. The outbreak primarily affected\nmembers of a tradition-observant (Jewish) religious community, in\nspite of a high level of vaccination (see MMWR, November 12, 2009 /\n58(Dispatch); 1-4 available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm58d1112a1.htm?s_cid=mm58d1112a1_e>).\n\nElsewhere similar outbreaks have occurred in colleges and schools\nwhere children and young adults may be living in close contact.\n\nDr Chen Stein-Zamir and colleagues have documented the current\nJerusalem outbreak at an earlier stage in some detail (see\nEurosurveillance 14(50), 17 Dec 2009 at\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19440>).\nThey concluded then that: 'The reasons for the particular\ncharacteristics of these recent mumps outbreaks are unclear. Possible\nexplanations include a combination of primary and secondary vaccine\nfailure, waning immunity, inadequate vaccine effectiveness, and\nprevious low immunisation coverage. Contributory factors include\nliving conditions in specific population groups such as college\nfreshmen, army recruits, and adolescent students in boarding schools.'\n\nReaders are invited to suggest other factors which might contribute to\nthe current situation in Jerusalem. - Mod.CP]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Israel is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/013l>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 26 Jan 2010\n Most\nrecently in August 2009, an outbreak of mumps originating in a summer\ncamp in Sullivan County, New York state became the largest mumps\noutbreak since 2006, when the United States experienced an outbreak of\nmumps with 6584 reported cases. The outbreak primarily affected\nmembers of a tradition-observant (Jewish) religious community, in\nspite of a high level of vaccination (see MMWR, November 12, 2009 /\n58(Dispatch); 1-4 available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm58d1112a1.htm?s_cid=mm58d1112a1_e>). As opposed\nto previous outbreaks in Jerusalem where active case investigation\nshowed 95 percent of cases to be unvaccinated, only 20 percent of\ncases in the present outbreak were unvaccinated. Dr Chen Stein-Zamir\nJerusalem District Health Office\n86 Jaffa Road\nJerusalem 94341\n Possible\nexplanations include a combination of primary and secondary vaccine\nfailure, waning immunity, inadequate vaccine effectiveness, and\nprevious low immunisation coverage. Over the past 4 months some 600 cases of mumps have been reported in\nthe Jerusalem district and over 850 nationally in Israel, the majority\nof whom (70 percent) have been male. Case investigation has shown that\nthe outbreak emerged in male attended religious high schools and\ncolleges (yeshivas). \n\nThe predominance of males, vaccinated individuals, and the low rate of\ntransmission to the surrounding community should, in our opinion, call\nfor further investigation.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-11-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-08-25 00:00:00", "2010-01-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jerusalem", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sullivan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "mumps - ISRAEL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "379294", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (02): NYC", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=379294", "date": "2010-02-10 17:00:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (02): NEW YORK CITY\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 9 Feb 2010\nSource: New York City Department of Health and Metal Hygiene [edited]\n<http://www.nyc.gov/html/doh/html/pr2010/pr004-10.shtml>\n\n\nThe Health Department continues to identify mumps cases in Brooklyn's\nJewish communities and is encouraging young adults -- especially\nmales -- in the community to get vaccinated unless they know they\nhave been fully vaccinated in the past. As the Health Department\nnoted in a December 2009 medical alert, young men in Williamsburg,\nCrown Heights and Borough Park have experienced high levels of mumps\nfor several months. As of 8 Feb 2010, the agency had confirmed 909\ncases and was investigating an additional 344. Most cases have\noccurred in males, and an increasing number of cases have been in\nyoung adults, ages 18 to 30. Complications from mumps can include\nviral meningitis, hearing loss and reproductive problems for men.\n\n'Vaccination against mumps is important for your health, your\nfamily's health, and your community's health,' said Dr. Jane R.\nZucker, the Health Department's assistant commissioner for\nimmunization. 'Mumps can lead to serious complications in people who\nare not vaccinated, especially adults. If you have not been\nvaccinated against mumps, or do not remember if you have received the\nprotective vaccine, get vaccinated.'\n\nChildren should receive a measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine on or\nafter their 1st birthday, followed by a 2nd dose at 4 to 6 years of\nage. Families that lack regular doctors can call 311 for information\non where children can get vaccinated. People 10 or older who have no\nrecord of past vaccination can get the vaccine on 17 and 18 Feb 2010\nat the locations listed below. Each site will have separate entrances\nfor women and men and will have separate staff members to vaccinate\nthem. The staff will be culturally sensitive and respectful.\n\nWilliamsburg\nWed 17 Feb 2019\n2 pm-10 pm\nThe Marquis\n575 Bedford Avenue (between Keap Street and Rodney Street)\nBrooklyn, NY 11211\n\nBorough Park\nThu 18 Feb 2010\n2 pm-10 pm\nAnshe Sfard Hall\n4502 14th Avenue (between 45th Street and 46th Street)\nBrooklyn, NY 11219\n\nPeople over 10 can also receive free or at low-cost MMR vaccine at\nany of these health centers:\n\nWilliamsburg\nQuality Health Center\n432 Bedford Avenue\nBrooklyn, NY 11211\nCall for times at 718-387-2408\n\nODA Health Center\n14 Heyward Street,\nBrooklyn, NY 11211\nCall for times at 718-260-4600\n\nBorough Park\nEzra Medical Center\n1312 38th Street\nBrooklyn, NY 11218\nCall for times at 718-686-7600\n\nMaimonides Medical Center Primary Care Site\n1250 57th Street\nBrooklyn, NY 11219\nCall for times at 718-283-5700\n\nMumps spreads by respiratory droplets through infected saliva that\ncan be released when an infected person coughs or sneezes. Symptoms\ninclude fever, body aches, headaches, and swelling of the salivary\nglands. The gland just below the ear is most often affected.\n\nAmong males, mumps can lead to orchitis, a testicular inflammation\nthat causes pain, swelling, nausea, vomiting and fever. Among some\nwomen with mumps, inflammation of the ovaries or breasts can occur.\nUp to 15 percent of people with mumps may suffer headaches and stiff necks.\n\nIf you become infected with mumps:\n- Stay at home for 5 days after symptoms begin.\n- Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when you cough or sneeze.\n- Wash your hands frequently with soap and water.\n\nTo protect yourself and your family from mumps:\n- Mumps vaccine is given on or after a child's 1st birthday. It is\ncombined with measles and rubella vaccines in a formulation known as\nMMR (measles-mumps-rubella).\n- A 2nd dose of MMR vaccine is recommended before children enter\nschool at 4 to 6 years of age.\n- Anyone who has received 2 doses of MMR vaccine is much less likely\nto develop mumps. But many adults do not remember their vaccination\nhistory and do not have records of it. Adults who are unsure of their\nvaccination history should get vaccinated.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[This outbreak, now with more than 900 confirmed cases, started as an\ninfection imported from England into a summer camp for Orthodox\nJewish boys in New York State. Since then, it has escalated into a\nmajor outbreak of mumps affecting parts of the Jewish community of\nNew York City. It is to be hoped that there will be a good response\nto the call for vaccination reproduced above.\n\nA map of the Brooklyn district of New York City can be accessed at\n<http://www.aaccessmaps.com/show/map/us/ny/brooklyn_hospital>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the USA can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/016D>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 9 Feb 2010\n If you have not been\nvaccinated against mumps, or do not remember if you have received the\nprotective vaccine, get vaccinated.'\n\nChildren should receive a measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine on or\nafter their 1st birthday, followed by a 2nd dose at 4 to 6 years of\nage.
