Thu 18 Feb 2010\n2 pm-10 pm\n Symptoms\ninclude fever, body aches, headaches, and swelling of the salivary\nglands.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-02-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-02-18 00:00:00", "2009-12-25 00:00:00", "2010-02-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Borough Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Williamsburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "370574", "headline": "PRO> Mumps - Israel (02): Yeshiva students, 2009", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=370574", "date": "2010-01-23 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - ISRAEL (02): YESHIVA STUDENTS, 2009\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 23 Jan 2010\nFrom: Sidhe Wolf\n<faerywolf@eilatcity.co.il>\n\n\nA comment\n---------\nIn the Eurosurveillance article reproduced in the ProMED-mail post archived\nas Mumps - Israel: Yeshiva students, 2009 20100106.0059, it was concluded\nthat: 'The 2 main characteristics of the current outbreak in Jerusalem are\nthe predominance of male adolescents in religious boarding schools and the\nfact that most cases (74 per cent) are appropriately vaccinated for their\nage. The male predominance is striking, and requires further study.'\n\nA cultural note that would explain the male predominance: only males study\nin orthodox yeshivas (and Israel's religious institutions are almost\nexclusively orthodox), thus only males are spending almost all their time\ntogether, 24/7, in the infectious environment. They would likely have also\nbeen the only ones in contact, or at least very close contact, with the\ninfected visiting American yeshiva students mentioned, as well.\n\n--\nM Ben-Shaprut\n<faerywolf@eilatcity.co.il>", "summary": "In the Eurosurveillance article reproduced in the ProMED-mail post archived\nas Mumps - Israel: Yeshiva students, 2009 20100106.0059, it was concluded\nthat: 'The 2 main characteristics of the current outbreak in Jerusalem are\nthe predominance of male adolescents in religious boarding schools and the\nfact that most cases (74 per cent) are appropriately vaccinated for their\nage. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 23 Jan 2010\n \n\nA cultural note that would explain the male predominance: only males study\nin orthodox yeshivas (and Israel's religious institutions are almost\nexclusively orthodox), thus only males are spending almost all their time\ntogether, 24/7, in the infectious environment. They would likely have also\nbeen the only ones in contact, or at least very close contact, with the\ninfected visiting American yeshiva students mentioned, as well. \n\n--\nM Ben-Shaprut\n<faerywolf@eilatcity.co.il> A comment\n---------\n MUMPS - ISRAEL (02): YESHIVA STUDENTS, 2009\n From: Sidhe Wolf\n<faerywolf@eilatcity.co.il>\n\n\n **\n The male predominance is striking, and requires further study.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jerusalem", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "mumps - ISRAEL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "eurosurveillance", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "379854", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (03): (NY, NJ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=379854", "date": "2010-02-11 17:00:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (03): (NEW YORK AND NEW JERSEY)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 12 Feb 2010\nSource: Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, 2010 / 59(05);125-129 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5905a1.htm?s_cid=mm5905a1_e>\n\n\nUpdate: Mumps Outbreak - New York and New Jersey, June 2009 to January 2010\n-----------------------------------------\nState and local health departments, in collaboration with CDC,\ncontinue to investigate a mumps outbreak that began in New York in\nJune 2009 (1). The index case occurred in a boy aged 11 years who had\nreturned on 17 Jun 2009 from a trip to the United Kingdom, where\napproximately 7400 reports of laboratory-confirmed mumps were\nreceived by the Health Protection Agency in 2009 [see:\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2010/news0210.htm#mmps>]. He then\nattended a New York summer camp for tradition-observant Jewish boys,\nwhere he became symptomatic on 28 Jun 2009. Subsequently, other camp\nattendees and a staff member were reported to have mumps, and\ntransmission continued in multiple locations when the camp attendees\nreturned home. As of 29 Jan 2010, a total of 1521 cases had been\nreported, with onset dates from 2 Jun 2009, through 29 Jan 2010, a\nsubstantial increase from the 179 cases reported as of 30 Oct 2009\n(1). The outbreak has remained confined primarily to the tradition-obse!\nrvant Jewish community, with less than 3 percent of cases occurring\namong persons outside the community. The largest percentage of cases\n(61 percent) has occurred among persons aged 7 to 18 years, and 76\npercent of the patients are male. Among the patients for whom\nvaccination status was reported, 88 percent had received at least one\ndose of mumps-containing vaccine, and 75 percent had received 2\ndoses. This is the largest mumps outbreak that has occurred in the\nUnited States since 2006 (2). Although mumps vaccination alone was\nnot sufficient to prevent this outbreak, maintaining high measles,\nmumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccination coverage remains the most\neffective way to prevent outbreaks and limit their size when they occur.\n\nMumps cases included in this report were reported by 29 Jan 2010.\nCases were classified according to the 2008 case definition of the\nCouncil of State and Territorial Epidemiologists; only cases of\nprobable and confirmed mumps are included in this report. In the\nUnited States, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices\n(ACIP) recommends that children receive 2 doses of measles, mumps,\nand rubella (MMR) vaccine, with the 1st dose administered at 12-15\nmonths and the 2nd dose near the time of school entry (at 4-6 years).\nMethods used to obtain the vaccination status of patients have\nincluded parental report, review of vaccination cards, and\nverification from health-care providers.\n\nThe 1521 outbreak-related mumps cases have been reported from several\ncounties in New York and New Jersey; local transmission is\ncontinuing. The majority (675 [44 percent]) of cases have been\nreported from New York City (primarily Brooklyn), followed by Orange\nCounty, New York (364 [24 percent]); Rockland County, New York (298\n[20 percent]); and 4 counties in New Jersey (159 [10 percent]). 25 (2\npercent) cases (reported during 28 Jun-8 Sep 2009) were associated\nwith the summer camp in Sullivan County, New York; however, no\nadditional cases occurred in the county after the camp ended in late\nAugust 2009. Of the 1521 patients, 1477 (97 percent) are members of\nthe tradition-observant Jewish community. Of the 44 cases not\nassociated with this religious community, 33 have been reported from\nNew York City; 7 from New Jersey; 2 from Orange County, New York; and\n2 from Rockland County, New York. Many of these outside cases have\noccurred among persons who have reported regular contact !\nwith members of the affected community.\n\nDiagnostic laboratory testing for mumps (i.e., detection of mumps\nimmunoglobulin M antibodies by various methods, detection of mumps\nRNA by real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction, or\nisolation of mumps virus in cell culture) has been performed for 761\n(50 percent) cases. Of these, 385 (51 percent) cases are laboratory confirmed.\n\nOf the 1518 patients whose age is known, 1385 (91 percent) are aged\nover 6 years. The median age of patients is 15 years (range 3 months\nto 90 years) and is similar in all areas with ongoing transmission\nexcept New Jersey, where the median age is 17 years. Of the 1489\npatients whose sex is known, 1136 (76 percent) are male. 65 reports\nof complications from mumps have been received: orchitis (55 cases),\npancreatitis (5 cases), aseptic meningitis (2 cases), transient\ndeafness (one case), Bell's palsy (one case), and oophoritis (one\ncase). 19 hospitalizations from mumps have been reported; no deaths\nhave occurred.\n\nVaccination status is known for 1115 patients: 966 (91 percent) of\n1062 patients aged 18 years and under and 149 (33 percent) of 456\npatients aged 19 years and over. Of these patients, 976 (88 percent)\nhad received at least one dose of mumps-containing vaccine before the\noutbreak, and 839 (75 percent) had received 2 doses. Among patients\naged 7-18 years, the age group with the majority of cases and for\nwhom 2 doses of MMR vaccine is recommended, 93 percent had received\nat least one dose, and 85 percent had received 2 doses. The\nvaccination status of the patients varies by location. The percentage\nof patients aged over 6 years (for whom vaccination status is known)\nwho had received 2 doses of mumps vaccine is highest in Orange\nCounty, New York (86 percent), followed by New York City (83\npercent), New Jersey (76 percent), and Rockland County, New York (73 percent).\n\nPublic health response measures in all affected areas have continued\nthroughout the outbreak. Health-care providers have been notified\nabout the ongoing outbreak, the importance of verifying that children\nhave received all recommended vaccinations, and the need to offer\nvaccinations to adults with unknown vaccination status who do not\nhave a history of mumps. State and local health departments also have\nworked with affected schools to enhance vaccination policies,\nincluding policies to exclude unvaccinated children from school\nduring outbreaks and to isolate children at home for 5 days after\nonset of parotitis. Certain jurisdictions have encouraged providers\nto offer a 2nd dose of MMR vaccine to children aged 1-4 years;\nhowever, this strategy has not been a focus of the public health\nresponse because of the small proportion (4.9 percent) of cases\nreported in this age group.\n\nBeginning on 19 Jan 2010, in Orange County, New York, public health\nofficials began offering a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine in 3 schools\nwhere, despite documentation of a high level of 2-dose coverage among\nstudents, transmission had continued for over 2 months. This\nintervention is being carried out under an Institutional Review\nBoard-approved protocol that provides for an evaluation of the impact\nof the intervention.\n\n(Reported by: P High, MHS, Ocean County Health Dept, EF Handschur,\nMPH, OS Eze, MD, B Montana, MD, C Robertson, MD, C Tan, MD, New\nJersey Dept of Health and Senior Svcs. JB Rosen, MD, KP Cummings,\nMPH, MK Doll, MPH, JR Zucker, MD, CM Zimmerman, MD, New York City\nDept of Health and Mental Hygiene; T Dolinsky, Rockland County Dept\nof Health; S Goodell, MPH, B Valure, Orange County Health Dept; C\nSchulte, D Blog, MD, E Rausch-Phung, MD, P Smith, MD, New York State\nDept of Health. A Barskey, MPH, G Wallace, MD, P Kutty, MD, H McLean,\nPhD, K Gallagher, DSc, R Harpaz, MD, GL Armstrong, MD, L Lowe, MS, R\nMcNall, PhD, J Rota, MPH, P Rota, PhD, C Hickman, PhD, WJ Bellini,\nPhD, Div of Viral Diseases, National Center for Immunization and\nRespiratory Diseases. I Ogbuanu MD, A Apostolou, PhD, EIS officers, CDC.)\n\nMMWR Editorial Note:\n\nThe mumps outbreak in the New York/New Jersey area has grown\nsubstantially, and anecdotal reports from certain affected areas\nsuggest that the rate of new cases is not decreasing; the appearance\nof a downward trend in recent weeks (illustrated by a figure in the\noriginal text) is partly a result of reporting delays. The outbreak\nis occurring almost exclusively in a specific religious community,\nand no cases outside this community have resulted in sustained transmission.\n\nLike the mumps outbreaks that occurred in 2006 (2), much of the\ncurrent outbreak is occurring in congregate settings, where\nprolonged, close contact among persons might be facilitating\ntransmission. Within the affected religious community, cases have\noccurred predominantly among school-aged boys, who attend separate\nschools from girls. The higher rate among boys might be a result of\nthe additional hours that boys in this community spend in school\ncompared with girls, including long periods in large study halls,\noften face-to-face with a study partner.\n\nIn addition, transmission in the community overall might be\nfacilitated by relatively large household sizes. According to the\n2000 U.S. Census, the mean household size in one of the affected\ncommunities was 5.7, compared with a mean U.S. household size of 2.6.\nThe limited transmission to persons outside the community might be a\nresult of the relatively less interpersonal contact between persons\ninside and outside the community.\n\nAlthough the school settings and large household sizes might be\npromoting transmission, the high vaccination coverage in the affected\ncommunity likely is limiting the size of the outbreak. In addition,\nhigh vaccination coverage in surrounding communities is the most\nplausible reason that the few cases outside of the affected community\nhave not caused other outbreaks.\n\nIn this outbreak, as in other recent mumps outbreaks among highly\nvaccinated populations (3), most cases have occurred in vaccinated\npersons. The mumps vaccine has greatly reduced the incidence of mumps\nin the United States. From 1967, when the mumps vaccine was 1st\nlicensed, to the early 2000s, the number of reported cases decreased\nfrom 186 000 to less than 500 annually (2). Nonetheless, the\neffectiveness of the mumps component of the MMR vaccine is lower than\nthat of the measles and rubella components. Estimates of the\neffectiveness of the mumps vaccine have varied in previous studies,\nranging from 73 percent to 91 percent after one dose and from 79\npercent to 95 percent after 2 doses (3-5). At least one study found 2\ndoses to be more effective than one dose (6).\n\nPublic health officials began offering a 3rd dose of vaccine to\nstudents in certain schools in Orange County, New York, because mumps\ntransmission had continued among students, despite their high rate of\n2-dose coverage. Although a previous study indicated that a 3rd dose\nof MMR vaccine for seronegative college students resulted in rapid\nseroconversion with a low rate of IgM response, which is indicative\nof an anamnestic immune response (7), ACIP has not recommended a 3rd\ndose, and no data exist on the effectiveness of a 3rd dose in either\nreducing the risk for mumps or altering the course of an outbreak.\nData obtained from use of the 3rd dose of MMR vaccine in Orange\nCounty might be used to guide future options for mumps outbreak\ncontrol in settings with high 2-dose coverage.\n\nThis outbreak emphasizes that mumps outbreaks can occur in highly\nvaccinated populations. Although several factors play a role in mumps\ncontrol in the United States, maintenance of high 2-dose MMR vaccine\ncoverage remains the most effective way to prevent and limit the size\nof mumps outbreaks.\n\nReferences:\n(1) CDC. Mumps outbreak---New York, New Jersey, Quebec, 2009. MMWR\n2009;58:1270--4.\n(2) Barskey AE, Glasser JW, LeBaron CW. Mumps resurgences in the\nUnited States: a historical perspective on unexpected elements.\nVaccine 2009;27:6186--95.\n(3) Dayan GH, Rubin S. Mumps outbreaks in vaccinated populations: are\navailable mumps vaccines effective enough to prevent outbreaks? Clin\nInfect Dis 2008;47:1458--67.\n(4) Hviid A, Rubin S, Muhlemann K. Mumps. Lancet 2008;371:932--44.\n(5) Marin M, Quinlisk P, Shimabukuro T, et al. Mumps vaccination\ncoverage and vaccine effectiveness in a large outbreak among college\nstudents---Iowa, 2006. Vaccine 2008;26:3601--7.\n(6) Cohen C, White JM, Savage EJ, et al. Vaccine effectiveness\nestimates 2004--2005 mumps outbreak, England. Emerg Infect Dis 2007;13:12--7.\n(7) Date AA, Kyaw MH, Rue AM, et al. Long-term persistence of mumps\nantibody after receipt of 2 measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccinations\nand antibody response after a third MMR vaccination among a\nuniversity population. J Infect Dis 200815;197:1662--8.\n(8) CDC. Updated recommendations of the Advisory Committee on\nImmunization Practices (ACIP) for the control and elimination of\nmumps. MMWR 2006;55:629--30.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The mumps outbreak in the New York/New Jersey area has grown\nsubstantially, with 1521 cases documented, and anecdotal reports from\ncertain affected areas suggesting that the rate of new cases is not\ndecreasing. Among patients for whom vaccination status was reported,\n88 percent had received at least one dose of mumps-containing\nvaccine, and 75 percent had received 2 doses. Thus, previous reports\nof the low vaccination status of this particular community are not\nborne out. A factor in transmission not previously considered is the\nrole of household size, which is 5.7 in this community compared with\n2.6 overall in the USA. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Although a previous study indicated that a 3rd dose\nof MMR vaccine for seronegative college students resulted in rapid\nseroconversion with a low rate of IgM response, which is indicative\nof an anamnestic immune response (7), ACIP has not recommended a 3rd\ndose, and no data exist on the effectiveness of a 3rd dose in either\nreducing the risk for mumps or altering the course of an outbreak.\n The percentage\nof patients aged over 6 years (for whom vaccination status is known)\nwho had received 2 doses of mumps vaccine is highest in Orange\nCounty, New York (86 percent), followed by New York City (83\npercent), New Jersey (76 percent), and Rockland County, New York (73 percent). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 12 Feb 2010\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The mumps outbreak in the New York/New Jersey area has grown\nsubstantially, with 1521 cases documented, and anecdotal reports from\ncertain affected areas suggesting that the rate of new cases is not\ndecreasing. In the\nUnited States, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices\n(ACIP) recommends that children receive 2 doses of measles, mumps,\nand rubella (MMR) vaccine, with the 1st dose administered at 12-15\nmonths and the 2nd dose near the time of school entry (at 4-6 years). Certain jurisdictions have encouraged providers\nto offer a 2nd dose of MMR vaccine to children aged 1-4 years;\nhowever, this strategy has not been a focus of the public health\nresponse because of the small proportion (4.9 percent) of cases\nreported in this age group. 25 (2\npercent) cases (reported during 28 Jun-8 Sep 2009) were associated\nwith the summer camp in Sullivan County, New York; however, no\nadditional cases occurred in the county after the camp ended in late\nAugust 2009. \n\nThe mumps outbreak in the New York/New Jersey area has grown\nsubstantially, and anecdotal reports from certain affected areas\nsuggest that the rate of new cases is not decreasing; the appearance\nof a downward trend in recent weeks (illustrated by a figure in the\noriginal text) is partly a result of reporting delays. The index case occurred in a boy aged 11 years who had\nreturned on 17 Jun 2009 from a trip to the United Kingdom, where\napproximately 7400 reports of laboratory-confirmed mumps were\nreceived by the Health Protection Agency in 2009 [see:\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2010/news0210.htm#mmps>]. Health-care providers have been notified\nabout the ongoing outbreak, the importance of verifying that children\nhave received all recommended vaccinations, and the need to offer\nvaccinations to adults with unknown vaccination status who do not\nhave a history of mumps. State and local health departments also have\nworked with affected schools to enhance vaccination policies,\nincluding policies to exclude unvaccinated children from school\nduring outbreaks and to isolate children at home for 5 days after\nonset of parotitis. Among patients\naged 7-18 years, the age group with the majority of cases and for\nwhom 2 doses of MMR vaccine is recommended, 93 percent had received\nat least one dose, and 85 percent had received 2 doses. Estimates of the\neffectiveness of the mumps vaccine have varied in previous studies,\nranging from 73 percent to 91 percent after one dose and from 79\npercent to 95 percent after 2 doses (3-5). Among the patients for whom\nvaccination status was reported, 88 percent had received at least one\ndose of mumps-containing vaccine, and 75 percent had received 2\ndoses. post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 6 Feb 2010\nSource: The Canadian Press, Associated Press report [edited]\n<http://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5jJASM2l2fTQhk-avl9SkFlGaskxw>\n\n\nLargest mumps outbreak in years spreads as more than 300 cases\ndiagnosed in New York suburbs\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nMore than 300 people have been diagnosed with mumps in suburban New\nYork as America's largest outbreak of the disease in years spreads.\nAlmost all the cases are among Orthodox Jews.\n\nA health official says 303 people in the Rockland County towns of\nMonsey and New Square have been diagnosed with the highly infectious disease.\n\nInvestigators say the outbreak started in August 2009 at a Jewish\nsummer camp in Sullivan County with an 11-year-old boy who brought\nthe disease from England. It has since spread to Jewish communities\nin Brooklyn, New Jersey, and Orange County in upstate New York, [and\nsubsequently to Quebec province in Canada (see Mumps - USA (07): (NY)\n20091220.4297) and to Jerusalem in Israel (see Mumps - Israel:\nYeshiva students, 2009 20100106.0059>. - Mod.CP]\n\nMumps is spread by coughing and sneezing with the most common\nsymptoms being fever, headache, and swollen salivary glands under the jaw.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Stemming from an initial mumps outbreak at a summer camp for boys\nfrom Orthodox Jewish communities, by the beginning of December 2009,\n247 New York City residents plus 131 other state residents had\ncontracted the disease. The outbreak remains restricted mostly to\nJewish Orthodox adolescent boys in pockets of New York, New Jersey,\nand Quebec (Canada), according to official reports from the New York\nCity and State Departments of Health. The number of confirmed cases\nin New York has increased now to about 300.\n\nAlmost simultaneously an extensive outbreak of mumps is affecting\nadolescent boys attending yeshiva schools in Israel. A number of the\nIsraeli patients reported contact with yeshiva students from the\nUnited States (New York) who visited Israel during holidays in\nmid-September 2009 and some of whom were reported to have recently\nhad mumps. It appears that the mumps virus responsible for this\noutbreak originated in England (where mumps vaccination is less than\ncomprehensive) and has been transmitted through communities of mostly\nadolescent boys in the USA, Canada, and Israel. These religious\ncommunities in general are reluctant to accept vaccination.\n\nA map of the counties of New York state showing Rockland County in\nthe south of the state can be accessed at\n<http://www.visitnewyorkstate.net/regions/>.\nAn interactive map showing the location of Monsey in Rockland County\ncan be accessed at\n<http://www.mapquest.com/maps?city=Monsey&state=NY>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the USA can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/016D>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 6 Feb 2010\n A number of the\nIsraeli patients reported contact with yeshiva students from the\nUnited States (New York) who visited Israel during holidays in\nmid-September 2009 and some of whom were reported to have recently\nhad mumps. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Stemming from an initial mumps outbreak at a summer camp for boys\nfrom Orthodox Jewish communities, by the beginning of December 2009,\n247 New York City residents plus 131 other state residents had\ncontracted the disease. It appears that the mumps virus responsible for this\noutbreak originated in England (where mumps vaccination is less than\ncomprehensive) and has been transmitted through communities of mostly\nadolescent boys in the USA, Canada, and Israel. The outbreak remains restricted mostly to\nJewish Orthodox adolescent boys in pockets of New York, New Jersey,\nand Quebec (Canada), according to official reports from the New York\nCity and State Departments of Health. It has since spread to Jewish communities\nin Brooklyn, New Jersey, and Orange County in upstate New York, [and\nsubsequently to Quebec province in Canada (see Mumps - USA (07): (NY)\n ----------------------------------------------------------------------\nMore than 300 people have been diagnosed with mumps in suburban New\nYork as America's largest outbreak of the disease in years spreads. \n\nInvestigators say the outbreak started in August 2009 at a Jewish\nsummer camp in Sullivan County with an 11-year-old boy who brought\nthe disease from England. Largest mumps outbreak in years spreads as more than 300 cases\ndiagnosed in New York suburbs\n \n\nA map of the counties of New York state showing Rockland County in\nthe south of the state can be accessed at\n<http://www.visitnewyorkstate.net/regions/>.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2009-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rockland County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orange County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sullivan County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "352735", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, students - UK (11): (England)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=352735", "date": "2009-12-17 15:00:04", "main_text": "MUMPS, STUDENTS - UNITED KINGDOM (11): (ENGLAND)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 16 Dec 2009\nSource: BBC News [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/8415838.stm>\n\n\nStudents warned over mumps cases\n--------------------------------\nThe MMR [measles, mumps, and rubella] triple vaccine protects against\nmeasles, mumps, and rubella virus infection. Students are being warned to\nprotect themselves against mumps after a surge in the number of cases.\nThere have been 315 confirmed infections in Greater Manchester this year\ncompared with 36 in 2008. Across Cumbria and Lancashire the number rose\nfrom 97 to 341 confirmed cases and in Merseyside and Cheshire the numbers\nrose to 304 from 111. People aged under 25 are being urged to have the MMR\nvaccine before they return to college after the Christmas holiday. Leaflets\nand posters about mumps have been put up in universities and colleges.\n\nProfessor Qutub Syed, from the Health Protection Agency, said: 'We have\nseen a sharp rise in the figures this year [2009] and teenagers and young\nadults who have not had 2 doses of MMR vaccine are particularly vulnerable.\nThere is evidence in parts of the region that the disease is spreading in\nstudent populations. That is why we are working closely with the\nuniversities and colleges to inform students about mumps and to explain why\nvaccination is important.'\n\nThe usual symptoms for mumps are a painful inflammation and swelling of the\nglands under one or both sides of the jaw, fever, and headache. Some people\nsuffer complications that can include inflammation of the pancreas; viral\nmeningitis (inflammation of the brain); inflamed and swollen testicles in\nmen and ovaries in women. Mumps can also cause deafness.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Remarkably the current surge in cases of mumps seems to be country-wide\nand presumably affects predominantly the new intake of students into\ninstitutions of higher education. This phenomenon is likely to be\nconsequence of the continuing suboptimal uptake of MMR vaccine throughout\nthe United Kingdom.\n\nAn interactive map showing the regions and cities of England can be\naccessed at\n<http://www.woodlands-junior.kent.sch.uk/customs/questions/regions/index.htm>,\nand the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of England is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00A0>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 16 Dec 2009\n \n\nAn interactive map showing the regions and cities of England can be\naccessed at\n<http://www.woodlands-junior.kent.sch.uk/customs/questions/regions/index.htm>,\nand the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of England is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00A0>. Some people\nsuffer complications that can include inflammation of the pancreas; viral\nmeningitis (inflammation of the brain); inflamed and swollen testicles in\nmen and ovaries in women. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Remarkably the current surge in cases of mumps seems to be country-wide\nand presumably affects predominantly the new intake of students into\ninstitutions of higher education. \n\nProfessor Qutub Syed, from the Health Protection Agency, said: 'We have\nseen a sharp rise in the figures this year [2009] and teenagers and young\nadults who have not had 2 doses of MMR vaccine are particularly vulnerable. That is why we are working closely with the\nuniversities and colleges to inform students about mumps and to explain why\nvaccination is important.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Greater Manchester", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "335300", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, Yeshiva students - Israel, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=335300", "date": "2009-11-19 18:00:07", "main_text": "MUMPS, YESHIVA STUDENTS - ISRAEL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 18 Nov 2009\nSource: Yeshiva World News (YWN) [edited]\n<http://theyeshivaworld.com/news/General+News/42239/Mumps+Continues+to+Spread+in+Yeshivas+in+Eretz+Yisrael.html>\n\n\nIt appears that mumps is continuing to spread in chareidi yeshivas in\nEretz Yisrael [the Land of Israel], with signs of infection beginning\nto appear in Chevron Yeshiva. YWN-Israel reported that the illness\nhas already infected many bochrim in Ohr Shmuel (Yerushalayim) and a\nBnei Brak yeshiva, in which 100 of 160 talmidim were diagnosed.\n\nCases of mumps have also been detected in Yeshiva Maynei Shel Torah.\nIn the case of the latter, as well as Yeshivas Chevron, roshei\nyeshiva have informed talmidim that if they detect the earliest signs\nof the illness, or suspect they may have it, they are to immediately\nleave the beis medrash and seek medical attention and/or prophylactic\ntreatment.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The students at these educational institutions are presumed to be\nmales, teen-agers and young adults. The incidence of mumps among\nstudents at these institutions seems extraordinarily high (100 out of\n160 in one instance) and suggests that few have been vaccinated or\nperhaps received only a single dose of vaccine. Further information\nwould be welcomed verifying the extent of this outbreak, the\nrelationship between these institutions, and the vaccination status\nof the pupils.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Israel can be accessed\nat: <http://healthmap.org/r/00aH>. - ModsAS/CP]\n.............................................cp/arn/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The students at these educational institutions are presumed to be\nmales, teen-agers and young adults. The incidence of mumps among\nstudents at these institutions seems extraordinarily high (100 out of\n160 in one instance) and suggests that few have been vaccinated or\nperhaps received only a single dose of vaccine. Further information\nwould be welcomed verifying the extent of this outbreak, the\nrelationship between these institutions, and the vaccination status\nof the pupils.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Israel can be accessed\nat: <http://healthmap.org/r/00aH>. - ModsAS/CP]\n.............................................cp/arn/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "summary": "\n.............................................cp/arn/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 18 Nov 2009\n ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n In the case of the latter, as well as Yeshivas Chevron, roshei\nyeshiva have informed talmidim that if they detect the earliest signs\nof the illness, or suspect they may have it, they are to immediately\nleave the beis medrash and seek medical attention and/or prophylactic\ntreatment. ***********************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\n The incidence of mumps among\nstudents at these institutions seems extraordinarily high (100 out of\n160 in one instance) and suggests that few have been vaccinated or\nperhaps received only a single dose of vaccine. Further information\nwould be welcomed verifying the extent of this outbreak, the\nrelationship between these institutions, and the vaccination status\nof the pupils. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The students at these educational institutions are presumed to be\nmales, teen-agers and young adults. YWN-Israel reported that the illness\nhas already infected many bochrim in Ohr Shmuel (Yerushalayim) and a\nBnei Brak yeshiva, in which 100 of 160 talmidim were diagnosed.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yeshiva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "360999", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Israel: Yeshiva students, 2009", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=360999", "date": "2010-01-06 20:00:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - ISRAEL: YESHIVA STUDENTS, 2009\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 17 Dec 2009\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2009; 14(50) [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19440>\n\n\nMumps outbreak in Jerusalem affecting mainly male adolescents\n-------------------------------------------------------------\n[Rapid communication: C Stein-Zamir, H Shoob, N Abramson, et al.\nJerusalem District Health Office, Ministry of Health, Israel]\n\nMumps is a notifiable disease in Israel by law. From mid-September\n2009 to 7 Dec 2009, 173 cases of mumps have been reported to the\nJerusalem District Health Office [up from 105 on 16 Nov 2009. -\nMod.CP]. The patients were mainly (147/173; 85 percent) students in\nyeshivas (religious academies operated as boarding schools) in\nseveral Jerusalem neighbourhoods and 2 neighbouring cities, and 142\nof 173 (82 percent) were males. The epidemic curve is presented shows\na pattern compatible with person-to-person transmission. The median\nage of the patients was 14.5 years and the mean was 14.8 plus/minus\n7.3 years. Altogether, 60 schools have been affected [listed in a\ntable in the original text]. The outbreak spread to other regions of\nthe country, and up to 7 Dec 2009 over 250 cases have been reported\nwith similar demographic and epidemiologic characteristics.\n\nThe clinical picture included unilateral and bilateral parotitis. One\npatient (a 19 year-old) was hospitalised in a urology department with\norchitis and another 3 were admitted to ear, nose, and throat\ndepartments. A further 6 patients were observed for varying periods\nin hospital emergency departments and discharged.\n\nCase ascertainment included: positive mumps IgM antibody (in 20\npatients) and positive real-time RT-PCR in urine (in 4 patients). The\nvirus was classified by the central virology laboratory of the Israel\nministry of health as genotype G5. The remaining 149 cases were\ndiagnosed on the basis of clinical features together with an\nepidemiologic association.\n\nOf the 173 patients, 116 (67 percent) had received 2 doses of\nmeasles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine (Priorix GlaxoSmithKline\nBiologicals-Jeryl Lynn strain), 29 (16.8 percent) had received one\ndose (age-appropriate in 12 of them), 20 (11.6 percent) were not\nimmunised, and in another eight patients (4.6 percent) the\nimmunisation status was unknown\n\nA number of patients reported contact with yeshiva students from the\nUnited States (New York) who visited Israel during the High Holidays\nin mid-September 2009 and some of whom were reported to have recently\nhad mumps.\n\nOutbreak control measures included investigations in the relevant\nschools to determine the students' vaccination status and referral\nfor completion of MMR vaccination where necessary. Information on the\noutbreak was circulated to all health maintenance organisations in\nthe District and to the public via the mass media.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nMumps is an acute viral infection; a third of infections are\nsubclinical, another 30-40 percent are expressed clinically as\nunilateral or bilateral parotitis. Complications occur more\nfrequently in adults than in children; 10-15 percent of mumps\npatients develop meningo-encephalitis. Orchitis occurs in 20-50\npercent of post-pubertal men, but sterility is rare. Other\ncomplications include pancreatitis, oophoritis, deafness, arthritis,\nthyroiditis, and myocarditis. Transmission is through droplet\ninfection. Confirmation of mumps infection includes serological\ntesting (for IgM antibodies by various methods), identification of\nmumps RNA by RT-PCR and viral isolation in cell culture (1).\n\nMumps vaccination was included in the routine childhood immunisation\nschedule in Israel in 1984, and since 1994 has been administered in a\ntwo-dose schedule at ages 12 months and 6 years (1st grade in school)\nin the form of the MMR vaccine, and since 2008 as\nmeasles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccine. The average overall\nimmunisation coverage for the 1st dose of mumps vaccine (MMR/MMRV) in\nthe Jerusalem District has been maintained between 93 and 96.7\npercent over the past decade [Jerusalem District Health Office,\nunpublished data]. It is to be noted that in 1992, the coverage for\nthe 1st dose of MMR among the Jewish population of Jerusalem was a\nmere 82.3 percent.\n\nMumps control in Israel improved significantly during the 1990's (2),\nalthough periodic outbreaks still occurred due to under-vaccination,\nprimary vaccine failure, and waning immunity. In 1998 and 2005, 2\noutbreaks (each of the order of 100 cases) occurred in Israel. In\n2006, 12 cases were reported; 6 were reported in 2007 and 13 in 2008.\nSerological studies performed in the late 1990s revealed relatively\nlow mumps antibody levels among adolescents and army recruits in\nIsrael, ranging from 59 to 83.3 percent positivity; such levels do\nnot guarantee adequate herd immunity (3, 4).\n\nMumps outbreaks, mainly involving adolescents and young adults, have\nemerged recently in several countries. A nationwide mumps outbreak\noccurred in the United Kingdom in 2004-2005, with 56 390 reported\ncases. The majority (79 percent) were aged 15-24 years; two thirds\nwere unvaccinated. Non-availability of MMR vaccine probably\ncontributed to susceptibility of the birth cohorts 1983-1986 [5]. In\nthe United States, the largest outbreak in 20 years occurred in\n2006-2007, encompassing more than 6 000 cases centred in college\ncampuses. Of the students aged 18-24 years, 84 percent had been\nvaccinated with 2 doses of mumps vaccine (6). The epidemic occurred\ndespite high vaccination rates and low mumps activity in the community (7).\n\nEngland and Wales are currently in the throes of an outbreak of mumps\ncentred in college campuses, with 998 cases reported in\nJanuary-February 2009, and further cases still being reported, mainly\namong college students. The circulating genotype is G5 (8).\n\nOther European outbreaks have been reported in recent years. In an\nAustrian outbreak involving over 200 cases (9), 49 percent of the\npatients were unvaccinated -- a very different situation from the\noutbreak we report. In the Republic of Moldova, an extremely large\noutbreak of nearly 20 000 cases was reported in 2007-2008 (10). Most\nof the patients (96 percent) had received only one dose of MMR. A\n2-dose schedule was introduced in that country in 2002, for birth\ncohorts from 1995 onwards.\n\nIn an ongoing mumps outbreak in the United States (New York, New\nJersey), and Canada (Quebec), 179 and 15 cases, respectively, were\nreported in August-October 2009. The affected individuals are mainly\nmembers of a Jewish religious community (83 percent males; median age\n14 years). Of those for whom vaccination status is known 72 percent\nwere vaccinated with 2 doses. The virus was of genotype G [?] (11).\n\nConclusions\n-----------\nThe 2 main characteristics of the current outbreak in Jerusalem are\nthe predominance of male adolescents in religious boarding schools\nand the fact that most cases (74 percent) are appropriately\nvaccinated for their age. The male predominance is striking, and\nrequires further study.\n\nIt had been observed that the mumps component of the MMR vaccine\nprovides inferior protection compared to the measles and rubella\ncomponents. Unlike the levels of 95 percent and 98 percent provided\nby the latter 2, the mumps protection levels are approximately 62 85\npercent and 85 88 percent for the 1st and 2nd doses, respectively.\n\nRecently, the effectiveness in the United Kingdom was determined as\n88 percent and 95 percent, respectively. However, the effectiveness\nof one dose waned from 96 percent in two year-olds to 66 percent in\n11-12 year-olds, and the effectiveness of two doses from 99 percent\nin 5-6 year-olds to 86 percent in 11-12 year-olds [12].\n\nThe reasons for the particular characteristics of these mumps\noutbreaks are unclear. Possible explanations include a combination of\nprimary and secondary vaccine failure, waning immunity, inadequate\nvaccine effectiveness, and previous low immunisation coverage.\nContributory factors include living conditions in specific population\ngroups such as college freshmen, army recruits, and adolescent\nstudents in boarding schools.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Atkinson W, Wolfe S, Hamborsky J, McIntyre L, editors:\nEpidemiology and Prevention of Vaccine-Preventable Diseases. 11th ed.\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Chapter 13: Mumps.\nWashington, D.C.: Public Health Foundation; 2009. p.189-91. Available from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/default.htm>.\n2. Slater PE, Anis E, Leventhal A: The control of mumps in Israel.\nEur J Epidemiol. 1999 Sep;15 (8): 765-7 [abstract available from\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10555621>].\n3. Muhsen K, Aboudy Y, Mendelson E, et al: Prevalence of mumps\nantibodies in the Israeli population in relation to mumps vaccination\npolicy and incidence of disease. Epidemiol Infect. 2008 May; 136(5):\n688-93 [abstract available from\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17608960>].\n4. Huerta M, Davidovitch N, Aboudy Y, et al: Declining population\nimmunity to mumps among Israeli military recruits. Vaccine. 2006 Sep\n11; 24(37-39): 6300-3 [abstract available from\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16844272>].\n5. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC): Mumps epidemic -\nUnited Kingdom, 2004-2005. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2006 Feb 24;\n55(7): 173-5 [available from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5507a1.htm>].\n6. Dayan GH, Quinlisk MP, Parker AA, et al: Recent resurgence of\nmumps in the United States. N Engl J Med. 2008 Apr 10; 358(15):\n1580-9 [available from\n<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/full/358/15/1580>].\n7. Barskey AE, Glasser JW, LeBaron CW: Mumps resurgences in the\nUnited States: A historical perspective on unexpected elements.\nVaccine. 2009 Oct 19; 27(44): 6186-95 [abstract available from\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19815120>.\n8. Health Protection Agency: Continued increase in mumps in\nuniversities 2008-2009. Health Protection Report. 2009; 3(14), 9 Apr\n2009, United Kingdom. Available from\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2009/news1409.htm>.\n9. Schmid D, Holzmann H, Alfery C, et al: Mumps outbreak in young\nadults following a festival in Austria, 2006. Euro Surveill. 2008;\n13(7): pii=8042. Available from\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=8042>.\n10. Mossong J, Bonert C, Weicherding P, et al: Mumps outbreak among\nthe military in Luxembourg in 2008: epidemiology and evaluation of\ncontrol measures. Euro Surveill. 2009; 14(7): pii=19121. Available from\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19121>.\n11. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC): Mumps outbreak\n- New York, New Jersey, Quebec, 2009. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2009\nNov 20; 58(45): 1270-4 [available from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm58d1112a1.htm>].\n12. Cohen C, White JM, Savage EJ, et al: Vaccine effectiveness\nestimates, 2004-2005 mumps outbreak, England. Emerg Infect Dis. 2007\nJan; 13(1):12-7 [available from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/EID/13/1/12.htm>].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The continued prevalence of mumps in several different countries in\nthe face of high levels of vaccination may be due to poor initial\nresponse to vaccination in a proportion of individuals and/or early\nwaning of the immune response in others. One predisposing factor has\nbeen the congregation of young adults in colleges and similar\neducational establishments. The yeshiva system of boarding schools in\nIsrael and in orthodox Jewish communities elsewhere seems to provide\nsimilar conditions allowing the transmission of mumps in younger\nage-groups despite higher levels of vaccination. Further information\nregarding the containment of the Jerusalem outbreak would be welcomed.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Israel can be accessed\nat\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00aH>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "\n\nOf the 173 patients, 116 (67 percent) had received 2 doses of\nmeasles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine (Priorix GlaxoSmithKline\nBiologicals-Jeryl Lynn strain), 29 (16.8 percent) had received one\ndose (age-appropriate in 12 of them), 20 (11.6 percent) were not\nimmunised, and in another eight patients (4.6 percent) the\nimmunisation status was unknown\n\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 17 Dec 2009\n \n\nMumps vaccination was included in the routine childhood immunisation\nschedule in Israel in 1984, and since 1994 has been administered in a\ntwo-dose schedule at ages 12 months and 6 years (1st grade in school)\nin the form of the MMR vaccine, and since 2008 as\nmeasles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccine. \nSerological studies performed in the late 1990s revealed relatively\nlow mumps antibody levels among adolescents and army recruits in\nIsrael, ranging from 59 to 83.3 percent positivity; such levels do\nnot guarantee adequate herd immunity (3, 4). The average overall\nimmunisation coverage for the 1st dose of mumps vaccine (MMR/MMRV) in\nthe Jerusalem District has been maintained between 93 and 96.7\npercent over the past decade [Jerusalem District Health Office,\nunpublished data]. However, the effectiveness\nof one dose waned from 96 percent in two year-olds to 66 percent in\n11-12 year-olds, and the effectiveness of two doses from 99 percent\nin 5-6 year-olds to 86 percent in 11-12 year-olds [12]. \n\nEngland and Wales are currently in the throes of an outbreak of mumps\ncentred in college campuses, with 998 cases reported in\nJanuary-February 2009, and further cases still being reported, mainly\namong college students. The patients were mainly (147/173; 85 percent) students in\nyeshivas (religious academies operated as boarding schools) in\nseveral Jerusalem neighbourhoods and 2 neighbouring cities, and 142\nof 173 (82 percent) were males. The 2 main characteristics of the current outbreak in Jerusalem are\nthe predominance of male adolescents in religious boarding schools\nand the fact that most cases (74 percent) are appropriately\nvaccinated for their age. In an\nAustrian outbreak involving over 200 cases (9), 49 percent of the\npatients were unvaccinated -- a very different situation from the\noutbreak we report. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The continued prevalence of mumps in several different countries in\nthe face of high levels of vaccination may be due to poor initial\nresponse to vaccination in a proportion of individuals and/or early\nwaning of the immune response in others. A number of patients reported contact with yeshiva students from the\nUnited States (New York) who visited Israel during the High Holidays\nin mid-September 2009 and some of whom were reported to have recently\nhad mumps. The yeshiva system of boarding schools in\nIsrael and in orthodox Jewish communities elsewhere seems to provide\nsimilar conditions allowing the transmission of mumps in younger\nage-groups despite higher levels of vaccination. In\nthe United States, the largest outbreak in 20 years occurred in\n2006-2007, encompassing more than 6 000 cases centred in college\ncampuses. One\npatient (a 19 year-old) was hospitalised in a urology department with\norchitis and another 3 were admitted to ear, nose, and throat\ndepartments. Unlike the levels of 95 percent and 98 percent provided\nby the latter 2, the mumps protection levels are approximately 62 85\npercent and 85 88 percent for the 1st and 2nd doses, respectively. From mid-September\n2009 to 7 Dec 2009, 173 cases of mumps have been reported to the\nJerusalem District Health Office [up from 105 on 16 Nov 2009. In an ongoing mumps outbreak in the United States (New York, New\nJersey), and Canada (Quebec), 179 and 15 cases, respectively, were\nreported in August-October 2009. Muhsen K, Aboudy Y, Mendelson E, et al: Prevalence of mumps\nantibodies in the Israeli population in relation to mumps vaccination\npolicy and incidence of disease. \n\nOutbreak control measures included investigations in the relevant\nschools to determine the students' vaccination status and referral\nfor completion of MMR vaccination where necessary. Mumps control in Israel improved significantly during the 1990's (2),\nalthough periodic outbreaks still occurred due to under-vaccination,\nprimary vaccine failure, and waning immunity. Complications occur more\nfrequently in adults than in children; 10-15 percent of mumps\npatients develop meningo-encephalitis. A nationwide mumps outbreak\noccurred in the United Kingdom in 2004-2005, with 56 390 reported\ncases. The outbreak spread to other regions of\nthe country, and up to 7 Dec 2009 over 250 cases have been reported\nwith similar demographic and epidemiologic characteristics. Source: Eurosurveillance edition 2009; 14(50) [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19440>\n\n\nMumps outbreak in Jerusalem affecting mainly male adolescents\n Mossong J, Bonert C, Weicherding P, et al: Mumps outbreak among\nthe military in Luxembourg in 2008: epidemiology and evaluation of\ncontrol measures. Mumps is an acute viral infection; a third of infections are\nsubclinical, another 30-40 percent are expressed clinically as\nunilateral or bilateral parotitis. \n\nIt had been observed that the mumps component of the MMR vaccine\nprovides inferior protection compared to the measles and rubella\ncomponents. Confirmation of mumps infection includes serological\ntesting (for IgM antibodies by various methods), identification of\nmumps RNA by RT-PCR and viral isolation in cell culture (1). The affected individuals are mainly\nmembers of a Jewish religious community (83 percent males; median age\n14 years). Possible explanations include a combination of\nprimary and secondary vaccine failure, waning immunity, inadequate\nvaccine effectiveness, and previous low immunisation coverage. It is to be noted that in 1992, the coverage for\nthe 1st dose of MMR among the Jewish population of Jerusalem was a\nmere 82.3 percent. Contributory factors include living conditions in specific population\ngroups such as college freshmen, army recruits, and adolescent\nstudents in boarding schools. The median\nage of the patients was 14.5 years and the mean was 14.8 plus/minus\n7.3 years. 2006 Sep\n11; 24(37-39): 6300-3 [abstract available from\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16844272>]. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2006 Feb 24;\n55(7): 173-5 [available from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5507a1.htm>]. 2008 May; 136(5):\n688-93 [abstract available from\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17608960>]. A\n2-dose schedule was introduced in that country in 2002, for birth\ncohorts from 1995 onwards. Apr 10; 358(15):\n1580-9 [available from\n<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/full/358/15/1580>]. \n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Israel can be accessed\nat\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00aH>. Information on the\noutbreak was circulated to all health maintenance organisations in\nthe District and to the public via the mass media. The remaining 149 cases were\ndiagnosed on the basis of clinical features together with an\nepidemiologic association. One predisposing factor has\nbeen the congregation of young adults in colleges and similar\neducational establishments. The\nvirus was classified by the central virology laboratory of the Israel\nministry of health as genotype G5. Other\ncomplications include pancreatitis, oophoritis, deafness, arthritis,\nthyroiditis, and myocarditis. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Of the students aged 18-24 years, 84 percent had been\nvaccinated with 2 doses of mumps vaccine (6). \n\nCase ascertainment included: positive mumps IgM antibody (in 20\npatients) and positive real-time RT-PCR in urine (in 4 patients). Cohen C, White JM, Savage EJ, et al: Vaccine effectiveness\nestimates, 2004-2005 mumps outbreak, England. \n\nMumps outbreaks, mainly involving adolescents and young adults, have\nemerged recently in several countries. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC): Mumps outbreak\n- New York, New Jersey, Quebec, 2009. Recently, the effectiveness in the United Kingdom was determined as\n88 percent and 95 percent, respectively. Schmid D, Holzmann H, Alfery C, et al: Mumps outbreak in young\nadults following a festival in Austria, 2006. In\n2006, 12 cases were reported; 6 were reported in 2007 and 13 in 2008. In the Republic of Moldova, an extremely large\noutbreak of nearly 20 000 cases was reported in 2007-2008 (10). The epidemic occurred\ndespite high vaccination rates and low mumps activity in the community (7). Of those for whom vaccination status is known 72 percent\nwere vaccinated with 2 doses. \n\nThe reasons for the particular characteristics of these mumps\noutbreaks are unclear.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella", "varicella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2009-12-25 00:00:00", "2009-12-07 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "1580-09-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "1270-04-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "1992-03-25 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00", "1984-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jerusalem", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "D.C.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Jerusalem District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "N Abramson", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Luxembourg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Schmid D", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New \n Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Moldova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "353691", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (06): (NY,NJ,CT) alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=353691", "date": "2009-12-19 19:00:04", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED STATES OF AMERICA (06): (NEW YORK, NEW JERSEY, CONNECTICUT)\nALERT\n********************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Fri 18 Dec 2009\nSource: myfox.com, New York [edited]\n<http://www.myfoxny.com/dpp/health/091218-brooklyn-mumps-outbreak-continues>\n\n\nBrooklyn mumps outbreak continues\n---------------------------------\nA mumps outbreak in Brooklyn that has lasted for months has prompted health\nofficials to issue a multistate mumps outbreak alert, warning health care\nproviders in New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut to be aware of the\nproblem. New York City is dealing with nearly 600 confirmed and suspected\ncases. Most of the patients have one thing in common: religion. The cases\nstarted turning up in late August [2009].\n\nMumps is an illness characterized by acute swelling of the salivary gland\nlasting 2 or more days. The illness can cause deafness and encephalitis. A\nperson can be infected for 2 days before symptoms appear. The health\ndepartment is telling people who suspect they have mumps to stay home for 5\ndays. Children who are not fully vaccinated against mumps are the highest\nrisk of infection.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 19 Dec 2009\nSource: The Jewish Week [edited]\n<http://www.thejewishweek.com/viewArticle/c36_a17351/News/New_York.html>\n\n\nNot immune from mumps\n---------------------\nStemming from an initial mumps outbreak that wreaked havoc at a Jewish camp\nthis summer [summer of 2009], 247 New York City residents plus 131 other\nstate residents [as of 1 Dec 2009] have since contracted the disease, which\nremains mostly contained among fervently Orthodox adolescent boys in\npockets of New York, New Jersey, and Quebec, according to official reports\nfrom the New York City and State Departments of Health.\n\nThe trigger case occurred back in June [2009], when an 11 year old boy\nreturned to his Sullivan County summer camp after traveling in the United\nKingdom, where an ongoing outbreak has now reached about 4000 cases [see\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/infections/immunisation.htm>, the Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported. From there, the mumps spread\nto 24 other boys at the camp and continued to plague their local\ncommunities when they returned home, and the median age of patients remains\naround 14.\n\nBut perhaps the most frustrating news to some parents is that most of the\naffected patients had received their proper 2-dose vaccination as children\n-- 83 per cent, according to CDC.\n\n'This is a very confusing issue not only for ourselves but for providers\nand parents,' said Cindy Schulte, vaccine-preventable disease surveillance\nofficer at the New York State Department of Health. 'If you have a\npopulation that's fairly well but unevenly vaccinated, by logic, you're\ngoing to end up having some disease in the effective population.' The\nmeasles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine has an 85 to 91 per cent efficacy\nrate among those who take the proper doses, she said.\n\nThe commonest symptoms of this viral disease are fever, muscle aches, and\nparotitis -- the signature inflammation of the salivary glands below the\near. Though no deaths have occurred thus far and symptoms may often be\nsubtle, there have been several hospitalizations and one potential case of\nmeningoencephalitis (inflammation of the brain), according to Dr Debra\nBlog, medical director at the Bureau of Immunization Program in the New\nYork State Department of Health.\n\nMumps can be particularly dangerous to pubescent boys, doctors say, because\na small number will develop orchitis, a swelling of the testicles that can\npotentially (though rarely) lead to infertility. The same goes for girls,\nwho can develop swelling of the ovaries that can lead to sterility. While\nmumps cases among women have certainly increased since the summer, New York\nCity infections remain around 79 per cent male, Blog explained.\n\n'These communities tend to have social contact with themselves and tend to\nbe a bit isolated from the outside community,' she said. 'In New York City\nespecially it's going through their schools.'\n\nAs of 30 Oct 2009, CDC had only reported a total of 179 cases in New York\nand New Jersey and another 15 in Canada, but New York City health officials\nsay that the numbers have increased so dramatically in the past month\nsimply because doctors are taking more care to report their ill patients to\nthe government.\n\n'We're still getting cases reported virtually every day,' said Dr Chris\nZimmerman, medical director at the Bureau of Immunization in the New York\nCity Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. 'There was a substantial\nincrease just from the week before the alert to when the alert came out.'\nIt is difficult to maintain an exact number of cases, Schulte added,\nbecause disease spread is a 'fluid number'.\n\nA mumps outbreak of this size has not occurred since 2006, when the United\nStates experienced over 6500 cases that were particularly hard-hitting\namong college dormitory residents in Iowa. But the current wave largely\nremains within pocketed chasidic communities, all linked back to that one\nsummer camp flare-up. 'There have been less than a handful of cases outside\nthe community,' Zimmerman said. 'The population is segregated -- these kids\nare not going to public schools, they're going to yeshivas,' he continued.\n'They only have the opportunity to interact with other boys in their\ncommunity.'\n\nAnd while statistics show that an overwhelming majority of the kids in\nthese neighborhoods are in fact properly vaccinated, the few outliers are\nprobably the ones perpetuating the disease spread, he added. 'Overall,\nimmunization coverage is good, but this is a community that has had\nresistance to MMR vaccines -- their parents have claimed religious\nexemptions,' Zimmerman said.\n\nYet despite outbreaks that have resurfaced from time to time, state medical\nofficials still maintain the mumps vaccine is a successful product,\nparticularly in what Blog calls 'evenly vaccinated communities' -- those\nwho pretty much unanimously undergo the immunization.\n\nRegarding the disease spread, another crucial element worth considering\namong the allegedly vaccinated patients is whether or not their dosages\nwere properly refrigerated speculated Dr Michael Augenbraun, a professor of\nepidemiology at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. 'Breaks in the 'cold\nchain' are a serious problem for vaccine efficacy if, for example, an\noffice allowed for a vaccine to sit out on countertops overnight,'\nAugenbraun said, noting that we have no way of knowing this after so many\nyears, however.\n\nThus far, despite the one hospitalization and some cases of orchitis,\ncomplications from this outbreak have generally been minimal. About 56 per\ncent of the confirmed cases exhibited the parotitis, according to Schulte.\n'We're not seeing the same rate of complications that we saw in the\npre-vaccine era,' Zimmerman said, noting that before the vaccine, another\ndangerous side effect of the mumps was permanent deafness. But the subtle\nnature of so many of these current cases may be yet another reason that the\ndisease is spreading, because parents neglect to see a doctor about their\nchildren's illnesses. So what can parents do to protect their families from\ncatching the mumps?\n\nThey should make sure that their children have received the 2 dosages of\nthe vaccine on time, ideally before their 1st birthday, Schulte said. If an\nolder child has not yet received the vaccine but hasn't yet been exposed to\nthe illness, this child too should be immunized. And if a child or adult\nbecomes sick, the best thing to do, as always, is to stay home from school\nor work, wash hands frequently and see a doctor. Blog added, 'Isolation and\nvaccination are the most effective things along with common sense.'\n\n[byline: Sharon Udasin]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is now a very large outbreak in a population that is considered to be\nwell vaccinated. This is perhaps a consequence of maintenance of an\nimported infection in a sub-set of the population which has declined\nvaccination on the basis of religious convictions. Additionally, or\nalternatively, it may reflect an inherent lower immunogencity of the mumps\nvirus component of the triple MMR vaccine.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United States of America\ncan be accessed at <http://healthmap.org/r/009V>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "ALERT\n********************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n******\n Stemming from an initial mumps outbreak that wreaked havoc at a Jewish camp\nthis summer [summer of 2009], 247 New York City residents plus 131 other\nstate residents [as of 1 Dec 2009] have since contracted the disease, which\nremains mostly contained among fervently Orthodox adolescent boys in\npockets of New York, New Jersey, and Quebec, according to official reports\nfrom the New York City and State Departments of Health. \n\nThe trigger case occurred back in June [2009], when an 11 year old boy\nreturned to his Sullivan County summer camp after traveling in the United\nKingdom, where an ongoing outbreak has now reached about 4000 cases [see\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/infections/immunisation.htm>, the Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported. \n\nAs of 30 Oct 2009, CDC had only reported a total of 179 cases in New York\nand New Jersey and another 15 in Canada, but New York City health officials\nsay that the numbers have increased so dramatically in the past month\nsimply because doctors are taking more care to report their ill patients to\nthe government. Though no deaths have occurred thus far and symptoms may often be\nsubtle, there have been several hospitalizations and one potential case of\nmeningoencephalitis (inflammation of the brain), according to Dr Debra\nBlog, medical director at the Bureau of Immunization Program in the New\nYork State Department of Health. A mumps outbreak in Brooklyn that has lasted for months has prompted health\nofficials to issue a multistate mumps outbreak alert, warning health care\nproviders in New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut to be aware of the\nproblem. Yet despite outbreaks that have resurfaced from time to time, state medical\nofficials still maintain the mumps vaccine is a successful product,\nparticularly in what Blog calls 'evenly vaccinated communities' -- those\nwho pretty much unanimously undergo the immunization. \n\n[byline: Sharon Udasin]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap alerts via ProMED-mail\n< From there, the mumps spread\nto 24 other boys at the camp and continued to plague their local\ncommunities when they returned home, and the median age of patients remains\naround 14. Dec 2009\nSource: myfox.com, New York [edited]\n<http://www.myfoxny.com/dpp/health/091218-brooklyn-mumps-outbreak-continues>\n\n\nBrooklyn mumps outbreak continues\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Overall,\nimmunization coverage is good, but this is a community that has had\nresistance to MMR vaccines -- their parents have claimed religious\nexemptions,' Zimmerman said.
