' We're not seeing the same rate of complications that we saw in the\npre-vaccine era,' Zimmerman said, noting that before the vaccine, another\ndangerous side effect of the mumps was permanent deafness. \n\nThe commonest symptoms of this viral disease are fever, muscle aches, and\nparotitis -- the signature inflammation of the salivary glands below the\near. The\nmeasles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine has an 85 to 91 per cent efficacy\nrate among those who take the proper doses, she said. But perhaps the most frustrating news to some parents is that most of the\naffected patients had received their proper 2-dose vaccination as children\n-- 83 per cent, according to CDC.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "plague", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-06-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sullivan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CONNECTICUT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States of America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "349758", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada: (ON)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=349758", "date": "2009-12-11 17:00:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA: (ONTARIO)\n*************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 11 Dec 2009\nSource: The Nugget [edited]\n<http://www.nugget.ca/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=2211768>\n\n\nMumps outbreak spreads to West Nipissing students\n-------------------------------------------------\nThe outbreak at Nipissing University and Canadore College last month\n[November 2009] -- traced to someone who travelled outside of the\ncountry -- has spread to West Nipissing, with a total of 13 confirmed\ncases in the district, said Dr. Jim Chirico, medical officer of\nhealth with the North Bay Parry Sound District Health Unit.\n\nThe average age of people infected is 20 and has been primarily\nmales. 'This is probably the largest cluster in Ontario,' Chirico\ntold a news conference on Tue 8 Dec 2009, noting there are 60 cases\nin the province. Meningitis can occur in 10 percent of cases, with\none case in the district likely linked to the mumps virus.\n\nAnyone born after 1992 likely received 2 doses of the MMR (mumps,\nmeasles, rubella) vaccine, while people born between 1970 to 1992 may\nhave only received one dose of vaccine and can get a catch-up\nvaccination. Two vaccination clinics are planned in West Nipissing.\nChirico said 62 percent of cases in the district involve people who\nreceived both doses, while the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention has seen that in about 72 percent of cases.\n\n'One of the theories is that the virus has mutated. That's possible\n[but unlikely - Mod.CP]. Other possibilities could be that the\nvaccine [i.e., immunity] wears off in a shorter period of time than\nwe had anticipated,' Chirico said. He said close contact in schools\ncould also be behind the outbreak.\n\nMumps is an infection of the salivary glands caused by a virus, and\nit spreads easily through the exchange of saliva by sharing drinks,\nfood, cigarettes, musical instruments, kissing, coughing and\nsneezing. 'Teenagers are more likely to spread it just because of the\nsocial contact that they have. That's why we're trying to get the\nmessage out to them,' Chirico said.\n\nThe health unit recommends people check to see if they have received\nboth MMR vaccine doses, as well as washing hands frequently and not\nsharing personal items that come in contact with saliva. 'If you\ndon't have the catch-up vaccination, you should really look at your\nimmunization records and check with your family doctor to make sure\nthat you've had the 2 doses.' Chirico said affected school boards\nhave been contacted to work with teachers and staff to reduce the\nrisk of exposure.\n\nNorthern Ontario is seeing the same strain as an outbreak that\nstarted in August (2009) in the northeastern United States. Chirico\nsaid mumps outbreaks peak every 2 to 5 years, and it's curious to see\none during an H1N1 flu outbreak. Before this year, there was only one\ncase in the district in the last decade, he said.\n\nMumps\n-----\nAnyone with the following symptoms is asked to contact their health\ncare provider and isolate themselves for 9 days: Fever; swelling and\npainful salivary glands on one or both sides of the jaw; headache;\ncold-like symptoms. There is no treatment for mumps. Most people will\nrecover from the infection, and some may not even know they have it.\nComplications may include swollen and tender testicles in males, and\novarian inflammation resulting in abdominal pains in women.\n\nMumps rarely leads to sterility, but can lead to meningitis or a\nswelling of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. Mumps\nmay also cause hearing loss and miscarriages in the 1st 3 months of\npregnancy. One to 2 cases out of 10 000 can cause encephalitis or\nswelling of the brain that can lead to paralysis, neurological damage\nand seizures. About 4 percent of mumps cases can cause an inflamed pancreas.\n\nFor more information visit the North Bay Parry Sound District Health\nUnit website at <http://www.healthunit.biz>.\n\n[Byline: Maria Calabrese]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[West Nipissing, adjacent to Quebec province, is the most bilingual\ncommunity in Ontario, with 73.4 percent of its population fluent in\nboth English and French. Its location is shown in the map of Ontario\nat: <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Nipissing,_Ontario>.\n\nIn the absence of other information it is presumed that this outbreak\nis an extension of the recent mumps outbreak in Quebec, and is not an\nextension of the trans-Canada outbreak in university student of the\nprevious year. In Sep/Oct 2009 members of traditional religious\ncommunities attending a summer camp in New York state, where there\nwas an outbreak of mumps (which subsequently became the largest in\nthe United States since 2006), traveled to the province of Quebec to\nattend religious gatherings. Subsequently 15 cases of mumps were\nreported in Montreal and the Laurentian region of Quebec province.\n\nFurther information would be welcomed. - Mod.CP]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map of Ontario, Canada, is\navailable at: <http://healthmap.org/r/00HF> - CopyEd.EJP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 11 Dec 2009\n In Sep/Oct 2009 members of traditional religious\ncommunities attending a summer camp in New York state, where there\nwas an outbreak of mumps (which subsequently became the largest in\nthe United States since 2006), traveled to the province of Quebec to\nattend religious gatherings. Anyone born after 1992 likely received 2 doses of the MMR (mumps,\nmeasles, rubella) vaccine, while people born between 1970 to 1992 may\nhave only received one dose of vaccine and can get a catch-up\nvaccination. [November 2009] -- traced to someone who travelled outside of the\ncountry -- has spread to West Nipissing, with a total of 13 confirmed\ncases in the district, said Dr. Jim Chirico, medical officer of\nhealth with the North Bay Parry Sound District Health Unit. In the absence of other information it is presumed that this outbreak\nis an extension of the recent mumps outbreak in Quebec, and is not an\nextension of the trans-Canada outbreak in university student of the\nprevious year. \n\nMumps is an infection of the salivary glands caused by a virus, and\nit spreads easily through the exchange of saliva by sharing drinks,\nfood, cigarettes, musical instruments, kissing, coughing and\nsneezing. ' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[West Nipissing, adjacent to Quebec province, is the most bilingual\ncommunity in Ontario, with 73.4 percent of its population fluent in\nboth English and French. If you\ndon't have the catch-up vaccination, you should really look at your\nimmunization records and check with your family doctor to make sure\nthat you've had the 2 doses.' Chirico said 62 percent of cases in the district involve people who\nreceived both doses, while the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention has seen that in about 72 percent of cases. \n\nThe health unit recommends people check to see if they have received\nboth MMR vaccine doses, as well as washing hands frequently and not\nsharing personal items that come in contact with saliva. ' Chirico\nsaid mumps outbreaks peak every 2 to 5 years, and it's curious to see\none during an H1N1 flu outbreak. Chirico said affected school boards\nhave been contacted to work with teachers and staff to reduce the\nrisk of exposure.\n\n One to 2 cases out of 10 000 can cause encephalitis or\nswelling of the brain that can lead to paralysis, neurological damage\nand seizures. This is probably the largest cluster in Ontario,' Chirico\ntold a news conference on Tue 8 Dec 2009, noting there are 60 cases\nin the province. Source: The Nugget [edited]\n<http://www.nugget.ca/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=2211768>\n\n\nMumps outbreak spreads to West Nipissing students\n Other possibilities could be that the\nvaccine [i.e., immunity] wears off in a shorter period of time than\nwe had anticipated,' Chirico said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-11-25 00:00:00", "2021-08-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "1992-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Nipissing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chirico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montreal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "353958", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (07): (NY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=353958", "date": "2009-12-20 19:00:02", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (07): (NEW YORK)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 19 Dec 2009\nSource: loHud.com, The Journal News, Associated Press report [edited]\n<http://www.lohud.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=2009912190331>\n\n\nThe number of people in Rockland County who have come down with mumps has\njumped to 152 as part of what state and federal health officials are\ncalling the largest outbreak of the disease nationwide in years. Just about\nall local cases of the highly infectious disease are among Orthodox Jewish\nand Hasidic residents of Monsey and New Square, according to the Rockland\nDepartment of Health. So far, there is no indication that people outside\nthose communities are coming down with mumps, she said.\n\nThe outbreak started in August [2009] in a Sullivan County, NY summer camp\nfor Orthodox boys, according to the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention (CDC). Health officials traced the outbreak to an 11 year old\ncamper who had recently returned from England, where at least 4000 people\nhave come down with the disease. That camper spread the illness to 25 other\npeople at the camp ranging in age from 9 to 30, with a median age of 12,\naccording to CDC.\n\nWhen the campers went home later in the summer, they apparently brought the\ndisease with them to Jewish communities in Rockland and Orange counties,\nthe Borough Park section of Brooklyn, Lakewood, N.J., and Quebec [Canada],\naccording to health officials.\n\n'The outbreak has spread and gradually increased in size and is now the\nlargest US mumps outbreak since 2006,' CDC said in a bulletin. It's also\nthe largest outbreak in New York since 2005, according to Tom Allocco, a\nspokesman for the state Department of Health. More than 300 cases have been\nreported statewide outside of New York City, with half in Rockland and half\nin Orange County, primarily in the [village of] Kiryas Joel, according to\nhealth officials.\n\nAs of late October [2009], there were 79 confirmed cases in Brooklyn, 40\ncases in Lakewood, New Jersey, and 15 cases in Quebec, primarily in\nMontreal, according to CDC. At least 3 people have been hospitalized,\naccording to CDC. The median age of the patients is 14 years, and most (83\nper cent) are male, according to the federal agency.\n\nMumps is caused by a virus that usually spreads through saliva and can\ninfect many parts of the body, especially the salivary glands. It can lead\nto inflammation and swelling of the brain and other organs. It can cause\ndeafness and leave men sterile.\n\nThe vaccine, which also protects against measles and rubella, is given in 2\ndoses: one when a child is 12 months old and the other between the ages of\n4 and 6 or when the child begins kindergarten. The vaccine [measles, mumps,\nand rubella (MMR) vaccine] is thought to be 85 per cent effective during an\noutbreak. At least 60 per cent of the people in Rockland who have\ncontracted mumps during the current outbreak had not been fully immunized,\nFacelle said.\n\nThe Rockland Department of Health is reaching out to community leaders,\nincluding rabbis and yeshiva directors, to stress the importance of\nimmunization, Facelle said. Many of the parents who were interviewed by\nhealth officials indicated that they did not immunize their children\nbecause of their religious beliefs. But local religious leaders said there\nis nothing in Jewish law that prohibits vaccination. Rabbi David Eidensohn,\na frequent Orthodox Jewish commentator on family issues said: 'Any parent\nwho doesn't get their child vaccinated is being foolish and endangering the\nentire community.' Dr Yakov Tendler, a Monsey internist whose patients\ninclude many of the Orthodox community, said that he has treated some\nadults with mumps who had been fully immunized but contracted the disease\nfrom a child. 'There are a lot of crazies out there who are putting their\nchildren and everyone else at risk,' he said.\n\nReligious leaders have to make it clear that children must be vaccinated,\nhe said. 'The rabbinic community has to chastise congregants who are not\nvaccinating,' he said.\n\n[byline: Jane Lerner]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[This outbreak, initiated at a summer camp in New York state where the\ndisease had been imported by a single camper, continues to extend\nthroughout New York State, almost entirely confined to Orthodox Jewish\ncommunities, where there has been past reluctance in a minority of the\npopulation to accept protective MMR vaccination.\n\nA map of the counties of New York state showing Rockland County in the\nsouth of the state can be accessed at\n<http://www.visitnewyorkstate.net/regions/>. An interactive map showing the\nlocation of Monsey in Rockland County can be accessed at:\n<http://www.mapquest.com/maps?city=Monsey&state=NY>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United States of America can\nbe accessed at <http://healthmap.org/r/009V>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 19 Dec 2009\n [This outbreak, initiated at a summer camp in New York state where the\ndisease had been imported by a single camper, continues to extend\nthroughout New York State, almost entirely confined to Orthodox Jewish\ncommunities, where there has been past reluctance in a minority of the\npopulation to accept protective MMR vaccination. Dr Yakov Tendler, a Monsey internist whose patients\ninclude many of the Orthodox community, said that he has treated some\nadults with mumps who had been fully immunized but contracted the disease\nfrom a child. ' More than 300 cases have been\nreported statewide outside of New York City, with half in Rockland and half\nin Orange County, primarily in the [village of] Kiryas Joel, according to\nhealth officials. Just about\nall local cases of the highly infectious disease are among Orthodox Jewish\nand Hasidic residents of Monsey and New Square, according to the Rockland\nDepartment of Health. Rabbi David Eidensohn,\na frequent Orthodox Jewish commentator on family issues said: 'Any parent\nwho doesn't get their child vaccinated is being foolish and endangering the\nentire community.' The number of people in Rockland County who have come down with mumps has\njumped to 152 as part of what state and federal health officials are\ncalling the largest outbreak of the disease nationwide in years. \n\nThe outbreak started in August [2009] in a Sullivan County, NY summer camp\nfor Orthodox boys, according to the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention (CDC). \n\n[byline: Jane Lerner]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n Health officials traced the outbreak to an 11 year old\ncamper who had recently returned from England, where at least 4000 people\nhave come down with the disease. \n\nThe Rockland Department of Health is reaching out to community leaders,\nincluding rabbis and yeshiva directors, to stress the importance of\nimmunization, Facelle said. At least 60 per cent of the people in Rockland who have\ncontracted mumps during the current outbreak had not been fully immunized,\nFacelle said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-08-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rockland County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sullivan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lakewood", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "N.J.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Borough Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orange County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montreal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rockland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States of America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "336029", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Israel (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=336029", "date": "2009-11-20 15:00:04", "main_text": "MUMPS - ISRAEL (02)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 18 Nov 2009\nSource: Haaretz - Israel News [edited]\n<http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1128723.html>\n\n\nMinistry: Israel in midst of mumps outbreak\n-------------------------------------------\nIsrael is in the midst of a mumps outbreak, the Health Ministry\nannounced this week [week of 16 Nov 2009]. Since the beginning of\nSeptember [2009], 105 people have been diagnosed with mumps, most\nbetween the ages of 10 and 24. During the same period in 2008, only 4\npeople were diagnosed with the disease, a contagious virus\ncharacterized by swollen salivary glands. Only 13 cases were reported\nfor the entire year. In 2007, only 6 mumps cases were reported.\n\nOf the current cases, 82 are people from Jerusalem, but the disease\nhas also been found in the central region (11 cases), Tel Aviv (5),\nthe south (4), and Haifa (2). One of the patients developed\ntesticular infection, a complication of mumps, and is hospitalized in\na Jerusalem hospital.\n\nItamar Grotto, director of Public Health Services in the Health\nMinistry, believes the increase in the number of cases stems from the\nfact that the mumps inoculation was added to the national vaccination\nprogram only in 1988, along with measles and rubella. The mumps\nvaccine is given to children in 2 doses -- at the age of 1 year and\nin 1st grade.\n\n'The outbreak is believed to have occurred among Israelis who didn't\nget both doses,' Grotto said. Most of the patients are believed to be\nfrom communities that refuse to be inoculated, particularly the\nultra-Orthodox. 'People who are not inoculated are not exposed to\nchildren's diseases, because the population around them has been\ninoculated. However, they tend to contract these diseases as adults,\nand at this stage the diseases are more dangerous due to possible\ncomplications,' said Professor David Greenberg, of the Pediatric\nInfectious Disease Unit in the Soroka University Medical Center at\nBen-Gurion University.\n\nIn most cases, mumps runs it course without treatment, but one-tenth\nof patients develop mild forms of meningitis. In other cases, it\ncould lead to testicular infection or ovarian inflammation. In men it\ncould also lead to deafness or sterility. The Israel Pediatrics\nAssociation called on parents to make sure their children receive\nboth doses of the mumps vaccine, in keeping with the national program.\n\nAn increase in mumps cases has also been reported in the United\nStates and Canada. At the end of last week [week of 9 Nov 2009], 15\nstudents at Jerusalem's Or Shmuel Yeshiva came down with mumps,\napparently after being in close proximity to a student who contracted\nthe disease in Brooklyn [currently the site of an ongoing outbreak of\nmumps in the USA, see: ProMED-mail archive references below}.\n\n[Byline: Dan Even]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The late introduction of universal mumps vaccination in Israel may\nin part explain the extent of the current outbreak of mumps in young\nadults. Additionally the fact that most of the patients are believed\nto be from ultra-orthodox communities, that decline vaccination, may\nexplain the high incidence of mumps among Yeshiva students as\nreported in the preceding ProMED-mail report archive no.\n20091119.3990). It is clear that the population of Israel contains an\nappreciable proportion of individuals unvaccinated or partially\nvaccinated, and that the country as a whole is vulnerable to\nintroduction of infection from elsewhere (in this case probably the\nUSA or Canada).\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Israel can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00aH>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 18 Nov 2009\n At the end of last week [week of 9 Nov 2009], 15\nstudents at Jerusalem's Or Shmuel Yeshiva came down with mumps,\napparently after being in close proximity to a student who contracted\nthe disease in Brooklyn [currently the site of an ongoing outbreak of\nmumps in the USA, see: ProMED-mail archive references below}. However, they tend to contract these diseases as adults,\nand at this stage the diseases are more dangerous due to possible\ncomplications,' said Professor David Greenberg, of the Pediatric\nInfectious Disease Unit in the Soroka University Medical Center at\nBen-Gurion University. It is clear that the population of Israel contains an\nappreciable proportion of individuals unvaccinated or partially\nvaccinated, and that the country as a whole is vulnerable to\nintroduction of infection from elsewhere (in this case probably the\nUSA or Canada). Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The late introduction of universal mumps vaccination in Israel may\nin part explain the extent of the current outbreak of mumps in young\nadults. \n\nItamar Grotto, director of Public Health Services in the Health\nMinistry, believes the increase in the number of cases stems from the\nfact that the mumps inoculation was added to the national vaccination\nprogram only in 1988, along with measles and rubella. In other cases, it\ncould lead to testicular infection or ovarian inflammation.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Haifa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jerusalem", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tel Aviv", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "mumps - ISRAEL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "315208", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (03): (NY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=315208", "date": "2009-10-23 19:00:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED STATES OF AMERICA (03): (NEW YORK)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 23 Oct 2009\nSorce: All Headline News (AHN) [edited]\n<http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/7016779670>\n\n\nNew York Mumps Outbreak Strikes 57 People\n-----------------------------------------\nThe New York Department of Health has confirmed an outbreak of old\nfashioned mumps in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn where at\nleast 57 confirmed or probable cases have been reported since 21 Aug 2009.\n\nOfficials say the outbreak was traced back to a child who went to\nBritain, then attended summer camp in upper New York state and\ninfected fellow campers there who brought the disease back with them\nto Brooklyn where it has continued to spread. Most of the victims\nhave been between the ages of 10 to 15, but the youngest patient so\nfar was a 1-year-old, while the oldest victim was 42.\n\nHealth officials are puzzled over why it is spreading though. While\nvaccination rates are low in Britain, at least 75 percent of the\nBrooklyn victims had received the normal 2 doses of mumps vaccine.\nHowever, the vaccine only has a 90 percent effective rate.\n\nThere is no treatment for the disease that causes painful swelling of\nthe salivary glands. Mumps usually runs its course in about 10 days.\nComplications can lead to deafness or even death and was a childhood\nscourge until vaccination largely ended the disease in developed nations.\n\nMumps is spread by large respiratory droplets of the virus spread\nthrough coughs and sneezes.\n\n[Byline: Linda Young]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is likely that this outbreak was initiated by a child (presumably\nunvaccinated) who had returned to New York from the United Kingdom\nwhere mumps infection is still widespread due to deficiencies vaccine\ncoverage (as documented by the ProMED-mail archived reports for 2009\nlisted below). Subsequent transmission of mumps infection in New York\nhas embraced 57 people ranging in age from 1 to 42 years. While it is\naccepted that the mumps component of the MMR vaccine is less\nimmunogenic than the other 2 components, and that 2 doses are\nrecommended, the large number of cases and the wide age range suggest\nthat there may be a higher proportion of unvaccinated individuals in\nthe Brooklyn area than elsewhere in the city. This may be a\nconsequence of negligence or avoidance of vaccination on grounds of\nreligious or other beliefs. - Mod.CP]\n\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank Dr. George Robertson for submitting\na similar article. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "While it is\naccepted that the mumps component of the MMR vaccine is less\nimmunogenic than the other 2 components, and that 2 doses are\nrecommended, the large number of cases and the wide age range suggest\nthat there may be a higher proportion of unvaccinated individuals in\nthe Brooklyn area than elsewhere in the city. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 23 Oct 2009\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is likely that this outbreak was initiated by a child (presumably\nunvaccinated) who had returned to New York from the United Kingdom\nwhere mumps infection is still widespread due to deficiencies vaccine\ncoverage (as documented by the ProMED-mail archived reports for 2009\nlisted below). \nThe New York Department of Health has confirmed an outbreak of old\nfashioned mumps in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn where at\nleast 57 confirmed or probable cases have been reported since 21 Aug 2009. While\nvaccination rates are low in Britain, at least 75 percent of the\nBrooklyn victims had received the normal 2 doses of mumps vaccine.\n Most of the victims\nhave been between the ages of 10 to 15, but the youngest patient so\nfar was a 1-year-old, while the oldest victim was 42. Britain, then attended summer camp in upper New York state and\ninfected fellow campers there who brought the disease back with them\nto Brooklyn where it has continued to spread. Sorce: All Headline News (AHN) [edited]\n<http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/7016779670>\n\n\nNew York Mumps Outbreak Strikes 57 People\n This may be a\nconsequence of negligence or avoidance of vaccination on grounds of\nreligious or other beliefs.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-08-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2042-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Britain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Borough Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "233735", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK (09): (England)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=233735", "date": "2009-07-04 19:00:12", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED KINGDOM (09): (ENGLAND)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 4 Jul 2009\nSource: The Grimsby Telegraph [edited]\n<http://www.thisisgrimsby.co.uk/news/Mumps-outbreak-vaccinated-plea/article-1136766-detail/article.html>\n\n\nMumps outbreak: get vaccinated now plea\n---------------------------------------\nA mumps outbreak in North East Lincolnshire has seen cases soar -- with\n1333 per cent more so far this year compared with the whole of 2008. The\nHealth Protection Agency reports that cases of mumps in the area have risen\nfrom 3 in the whole of 2008 to 43 in 1st half of 2009. But most of those\nnew cases have been diagnosed in the last 5 weeks. The majority of the\nlatest cases have been found in people aged between 15 and 24, who may not\nhave received the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) jab as children. Now\nhealth bosses are urging teenagers and young adults who have not had the\nrequired 2 doses of the vaccine to get immunised by their GP (general\npractitioner). Tony Hill, director of public health for North East\nLincolnshire Care Trust Plus, said: 'We want them to get the vaccine and we\nare also saying to parents of young children that they need to get them\nimmunised, too.\n\n'Mumps can be a very serious illness. Most of the time it's quite mild, but\nit can certainly be very unpleasant, and in the most serious cases it can\ncause sterility in men. The mumps virus, which causes swelling of the\nsalivary glands, fever, headache and in some cases, swelling of the\ntesticles, is a notifiable disease -- meaning doctors are required by law\nto report suspected infections to the HPA [Health Protection Agency].\n\nAs it takes 14 to 21 days for the symptoms of mumps to develop, however,\nthe true figure of how many people are affected by the disease is as yet\nunknown.\n\nA 20 year old from Cleethorpes who has spent the last week in bed with the\nbug said: 'The symptoms are pretty unpleasant, and I've been at home in bed\nfor the best part of a week, but I'm on the mend now. I would recommend to\nanyone who hasn't had the MMR jab to do it now, as having the mumps is not\na nice way to spend your summer.'\n\nFurther information on mumps can be found on the HPA website at\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk>.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the counties of England showing Lincolnshire in the east of the\ncountry can be accessed at\n<http://www.picturesofengland.com/mapofengland/counties-map.htm>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 4 Jul 2009\n The mumps virus, which causes swelling of the\nsalivary glands, fever, headache and in some cases, swelling of the\ntesticles, is a notifiable disease -- meaning doctors are required by law\nto report suspected infections to the HPA [Health Protection Agency]. Now\nhealth bosses are urging teenagers and young adults who have not had the\nrequired 2 doses of the vaccine to get immunised by their GP (general\npractitioner). \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< \n\nA 20 year old from Cleethorpes who has spent the last week in bed with the\nbug said: 'The symptoms are pretty unpleasant, and I've been at home in bed\nfor the best part of a week, but I'm on the mend now. \n\nAs it takes 14 to 21 days for the symptoms of mumps to develop, however,\nthe true figure of how many people are affected by the disease is as yet\nunknown. The majority of the\nlatest cases have been found in people aged between 15 and 24, who may not\nhave received the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) jab as children.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "1333-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lincolnshire", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "230391", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK (08): (England)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=230391", "date": "2009-06-30 15:00:08", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED KINGDOM (08): (ENGLAND)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 29 Jun 2009\nSource: Times & Star [edited]\n<http://www.timesandstar.co.uk/home/mumps_outbreak_in_cumbria?referrerPath=2.874/home>\n\n\nMumps outbreak in Cumbria\n-------------------------\nThere is a mumps outbreak in Cumbria as an increase in cases has been seen\nacross the county. Last week [week of 22 Jun 2009], 11 new suspected cases\nwere confirmed in Cumbria and many of these were in people aged 18 to 25.\nOnly 12 cases have been recorded in Cumbria so far this year [2009] but\nthis could rise to 23 with the latest possible outbreak, compared with 29\ncases in the whole of last year [2008]. Associate director of public health\nDr Nigel Calvert said: 'In the last few years there has been a noticeable\nincrease in the number of cases of mumps, particularly in teenagers and\nyoung adults. This can be a concern as mumps [is caused by] a virus, which\ncan easily spread and in some cases affect fertility. If you're going to be\nattending a new college or university in the autumn, or if you're not sure\nif you've had both doses of MMR [measles, mumps, and rubella], please go\nsee your doctor and get a booster. Mumps can make you feel very ill and\nit's so easy to avoid catching it.'\n\n[Mumps virus infection] causes fever, headache, and painful swollen glands\nin the face neck and jaw and although most cases are mild some people can\nexperience complications, which can be serious. The best way for people to\nprotect themselves is to make sure they have had 2 doses of the MMR\nvaccine, which are usually given to children before they start school.\nAnyone can check if they're fully immunised or arrange a free booster\ninjection by seeking advice from their GP [general practitioner] or\npractice nurse.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Cumbria, which embraces the English Lake District can be accessed\nat <http://www.thecumbriadirectory.com/Cumbria_Map/Cumbria_Map.php>, and a\nmap of the counties of England can be found at\n<http://www.picturesofengland.com/mapofengland/counties-map.html>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the UK can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00uV>.\n\nAccording to the UK Health Protection Agency before the introduction of the\nmeasles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine in 1988, mumps occurred commonly\nin school-age children, and more than 85 per cent of adults had evidence of\nprevious mumps infection. Mumps was the cause of about 1200 hospital\nadmissions each year. Mumps was made a notifiable disease in the UK in\nOctober 1988 at the time of the introduction of the MMR vaccine. High\ncoverage of the MMR vaccine resulted in a substantial reduction in mumps\ntransmission in the UK and the incidence declined in all age groups,\nincluding those too old to have been immunised.\n\nSince 1999, there has been a considerable increase in confirmed mumps\ncases. Most of these cases have occurred in adolescents or young adults who\nwere too old to have been offered MMR vaccine when it was introduced in\n1988 or to have had a 2nd dose when this was introduced in 1996. They had\nnot previously been exposed to natural mumps infection as children and so\nremained susceptible.\n\nIn late 2004, a further increase in clinically diagnosed and confirmed\nmumps infections was observed. The vast majority of confirmed cases were in\nthose born between 1980 and 1987 and outbreaks occurred mainly in higher\neducation institutions.\n\nCurrently the incomplete acceptance of the triple MMR vaccine in the UK\nallows continued circulation of mumps virus in the community and leaves a\ncohort of young adults vulnerable to infection as witnessed in this\noutbreak in Cumbria and elsewhere in the UK. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 29 Jun 2009\n According to the UK Health Protection Agency before the introduction of the\nmeasles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine in 1988, mumps occurred commonly\nin school-age children, and more than 85 per cent of adults had evidence of\nprevious mumps infection. Currently the incomplete acceptance of the triple MMR vaccine in the UK\nallows continued circulation of mumps virus in the community and leaves a\ncohort of young adults vulnerable to infection as witnessed in this\noutbreak in Cumbria and elsewhere in the UK. High\ncoverage of the MMR vaccine resulted in a substantial reduction in mumps\ntransmission in the UK and the incidence declined in all age groups,\nincluding those too old to have been immunised. If you're going to be\nattending a new college or university in the autumn, or if you're not sure\nif you've had both doses of MMR [measles, mumps, and rubella], please go\nsee your doctor and get a booster. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Cumbria, which embraces the English Lake District can be accessed\nat <http://www.thecumbriadirectory.com/Cumbria_Map/Cumbria_Map.php>, and a\nmap of the counties of England can be found at\n<http://www.picturesofengland.com/mapofengland/counties-map.html>. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< \n\n[Mumps virus infection] causes fever, headache, and painful swollen glands\nin the face neck and jaw and although most cases are mild some people can\nexperience complications, which can be serious. Only 12 cases have been recorded in Cumbria so far this year [2009] but\nthis could rise to 23 with the latest possible outbreak, compared with 29\ncases in the whole of last year [2008]. Most of these cases have occurred in adolescents or young adults who\nwere too old to have been offered MMR vaccine when it was introduced in\n1988 or to have had a 2nd dose when this was introduced in 1996. Dr Nigel Calvert said: 'In the last few years there has been a noticeable\nincrease in the number of cases of mumps, particularly in teenagers and\nyoung adults.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "1988-10-25 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cumbria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "293703", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (02): (MA), students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=293703", "date": "2009-09-17 23:00:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (02): (MASSACHUSETTS), STUDENTS\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 16 Sep 2009\nSource: MASSLPA.org [edited]\n<http://www.masslpa.org/content/northeastern-university-issues-public-health-update-mumps-outbreak>\n\n\nIn recent days, 3 students were treated by University Health and\nCounseling Services (UHCS) after exhibiting symptoms consistent with\nmumps virus infection. They were immediately isolated to prevent\nfurther spreading of the illness while testing and evaluation by\npublic health officials are underway. Mumps is caused by a virus and\ncan be spread when the infected person sneezes, coughs or talks in\nclose proximity to others. University health experts are working\nclosely with state and public health officials and following their\nadvice on taking the necessary steps to make sure members of the\ncampus community remain informed and safe.\n\nIf your student has received 2 MMR (measles, mumps, rubella)\nvaccinations, he/she is not likely to become ill with mumps. However,\nif your student believes that he/she has any signs or symptoms of\nmumps, including swelling of the cheeks and jaw, please advise them to\nvisit UHCS or see their health care provider if they are not on campus.\n\nPrevention remains the simplest and strongest measure to combat the\nspread of mumps, so please remind your student to practice good hand\nhygiene and cough etiquette around others. Please visit the UHCS\nwebsite for more information on mumps.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[In late April 2009, a cluster of cases of mumps at Northeastern\nUniversity in Boston caused the university administrators to urge some\n500 students to be especially vigilant for signs of mumps because they\ncould have shared classes with some 9 undergraduates believed to have\ncontracted mumps virus infection. From the above report, it seems that\nnot all vulnerable students responded to this advice. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[In late April 2009, a cluster of cases of mumps at Northeastern\nUniversity in Boston caused the university administrators to urge some\n500 students to be especially vigilant for signs of mumps because they\ncould have shared classes with some 9 undergraduates believed to have\ncontracted mumps virus infection. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 16 Sep 2009\n However,\nif your student believes that he/she has any signs or symptoms of\nmumps, including swelling of the cheeks and jaw, please advise them to\nvisit UHCS or see their health care provider if they are not on campus. The cases\nare mostly among older teenagers and students in their early 20s, as\nthey were too old to have received the measles, mumps and rubella\nvaccine or only received one of the 2 doses required for full\nprotection [against mumps virus infection].\n\nIn the last 3 months of 2008, there were 695 cases of mumps reported\ncompared with 1691 in the 1st 3 months of 2009. There were 2440 cases\nin total in 2008, but this remains well below figures seen in the\nlast mumps epidemic in 2005, when there were 43 378.\n\nCases have been reported across England and Wales, with outbreaks in\nuniversities and colleges. A report from the Health Protection Agency\nsaid that only 12 per cent of cases are in people born after 1990,\nwhen the 2-dose MMR schedule became universal, showing this approach\nis working well.\n\nMumps virus is spread through saliva, and symptoms begin with a\nheadache and fever before the characteristic swelling of the glands\nin the neck, but in 30 per cent of cases, there are no outward signs.\nComplications can include swelling of the ovaries and testicles,\naseptic meningitis and deafness.\n\nNew cases of measles have dropped in the 1st 3 months of 2009, with\n382 cases confirmed compared with 404 in the last 3 months of 2008.\nNine in 10 of these cases were in people aged 19 or younger, and, in\n14 cases, the patient had received one dose of the MMR jab, and in 3\ncases, they had received 2 doses. Dr Mary Ramsay, an immunisation\nexpert at the Health Protection Agency, said: 'We would urge parents\nto ensure their children are immunised against these infections. It's\ngood to see that recent MMR coverage is starting to improve, but we\ncannot stress enough that measles is serious, and in some cases it\ncan be fatal. Delaying immunisation puts children at risk. It is\nnever too late to get your child immunised with the MMR vaccine.\nMumps is also on the increase but not because of the recent decline\nin MMR uptake. The high numbers are mainly among older teenagers and\nyoung adults in their early 20s, and mostly among those in further or\nhigher education establishments. Some in this age group were too old\nto be routinely vaccinated with MMR when it was 1st introduced in\n1988, and some others may only have received one dose of MMR. The\nnumber of cases has increased more steeply in recent years because\nmany of the young adults in this cohort (born between 1981 and 1989)\nare now at university or in further education colleges. This large\nnumber of people in semi-closed institutions allows the disease to\npass more easily from one person to another. As the susceptible group\nis quite large, we expect to see high numbers of cases to continue\nover the next few years.'\n\n[Byline: Rebecca Smith]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[These figures suggest that there is a case for offering\nsupplementary MMR vaccination to college entrants in their late teens\nand early 20s who were too old to have received the MMR vaccine or\nonly received one of the 2 doses required for full protection against\nmumps virus infection. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[These figures suggest that there is a case for offering\nsupplementary MMR vaccination to college entrants in their late teens\nand early 20s who were too old to have received the MMR vaccine or\nonly received one of the 2 doses required for full protection against\nmumps virus infection. The cases\nare mostly among older teenagers and students in their early 20s, as\nthey were too old to have received the measles, mumps and rubella\nvaccine or only received one of the 2 doses required for full\nprotection [against mumps virus infection]. In 2008, just 2 people\ncontracted confirmed cases of mumps in the county, but this year [2009], 61\npeople were diagnosed with the illness in just 6 months between January and\nJuly 2009.\n\nIn the east of England, 467 confirmed cases of mumps were reported up to\nJuly 2009 compared with 136 cases in total in 2008. The HPA says that young\npeople aged 15 to 24 are most affected in the region; the age group makes\nup 73 per cent of all cases reported in 2009. Dr Joe Kearney, regional\ndirector for the HPA in the east of England, said: 'Young people who\nhaven't received 2 doses of MMR should speak to their GP [general\npractitioner] urgently.'\n\nIn contrast, the number of confirmed cases of measles in Bedfordshire seems\nto be decreasing. Last year [2008], there were 5 people diagnosed with\nmeasles, and from January to July this year [2009], there have been only 2.\nAcross the region [the HPA East of England Region comprises the counties of\nCambridgeshire and Peterborough, Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire, Essex,\nSuffolk, and Norfolk. - Mod.CP], 70 cases were reported to the HPA up to\nJuly 2009, compared with a total of 90 cases in 2008. (For more information\non MMR vaccination, visit <http://www.immunisation.nhs.uk/Vaccines/MMR>).\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The contrast between the number of measles cases and the number of mumps\ncases is striking. This may be a consequence of the relative lesser\nimmunogenicity of the mumps component of the triple MMR vaccine, such that\na single dose of the measles component may be sufficient to confer adequate\nimmunity, whereas a 2nd immunisation is required to achieve adequate\nprotection against mumps virus infection.\n\nThe county of Bedfordshire can be located in the map of the Counties of\nEngland at\n<http://www.picturesofengland.com/mapofengland/counties-map.html>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 13 Oct 2009\n This may be a consequence of the relative lesser\nimmunogenicity of the mumps component of the triple MMR vaccine, such that\na single dose of the measles component may be sufficient to confer adequate\nimmunity, whereas a 2nd immunisation is required to achieve adequate\nprotection against mumps virus infection. In 2008, just 2 people\ncontracted confirmed cases of mumps in the county, but this year [2009], 61\npeople were diagnosed with the illness in just 6 months between January and\nJuly 2009. Dr Joe Kearney, regional\ndirector for the HPA in the east of England, said: 'Young people who\nhaven't received 2 doses of MMR should speak to their GP [general\npractitioner] urgently.'
