Last year [2008], there were 5 people diagnosed with\nmeasles, and from January to July this year [2009], there have been only 2.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-07-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bedfordshire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Peterborough", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hertfordshire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "175211", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA: (MA) ex Ireland", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=175211", "date": "2009-04-17 13:00:51", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA: (MASSACHUSETTS) ex IRELAND\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 16 Apr 2009\nSource: White Coat Notes, boston.com [edited]\n<http://www.boston.com/news/health/blog/2009/04/4_northeastern.html>\n\n\nMumps cases suspected at Northeastern University\n------------------------------------------------\nA total of 4 Northeastern University students have suspected cases of\nmumps, Boston public health officials announced today [16 Apr 2009],\nand they urged any unvaccinated students and staff to get immunized\nagainst this once-common childhood illness.\n\nThough laboratory results are not yet back to confirm these as mumps\ncases, Dr. Anita Barry, director of infectious diseases at the Boston\nPublic Health Commission, said the 4 students -- 2 of whom just\nreturned from Ireland where there was a recent mumps outbreak -- have\nsymptoms that are consistent with mumps. Given the relative ease with\nwhich this illness can be spread, she said, 'it's likelly we'll see\nmore cases.'\n\nMumps is caused by a virus that is spread through infected\nrespiratory tract secretions, and people typically catch it by being\nwithin 3 to 6 feet of an infected person who coughs or sneezes.\nHowever, it is difficult to tell whether someone is infectious or\nnot. Barry said people are generally considered to be infectious from\n3 days before until 5 days after the onset of swelling of the\nsalivary glands. She said most infected people often feel sick for a\nfew days with low-grade fever and 'look like chipmunks.' The\nincubation period for mumps is usually 16 to 18 days, meaning it\ntakes that long for symptoms to appear after someone has been exposed\nto the virus. But as many as one in 3 people infected with the mumps\nvirus show nosymptoms at all. Serious complications are rare with\nmumps, but it has been known in rare cases to cause hearing loss in children.\n\nThe mumps vaccine doesn't always protect against the illness. Barry\nsaid all 4 sick Northeastern students have medical records showing\nthat they had the 2 recommended doses of mumps vaccine. Barry said\nroughly 10 or 20 percent of those who receive the mumps vaccine are\nstill vulnerable to the illness.\n\n[Byline: Patricia Wen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nKathryn Kelley\nBrigham and Women's Hospital\nUSA\n<kkelley@rics.bwh.harvard.edu>\n\n[It is somewhat surprising that the all 4 affected students at\nNortheastern University had ben properly vaccinated, although it is\nknown that vaccine-induced protection may wane in a small proportion\nof individuals (M.M.Cortese et al., Clin Infect Dis. 2008 Apr\n15;46(8): 1172-80).\n\nIt is not surprising, however, that these students were exposed to\nmumps infection during a stay in Ireland. According to The Dublin\nCity University College View of 21 Mar 2009\n(<http://www.thecollegeview.com/2009/03/21/mumps-outbreak-hitting-colleges/>)\nan outbreak of mumps across Ireland is affecting students worst. It\nis reported that there have been over 800 cases of mumps throughout\ncolleges all over Ireland this year (2009). That's up from well under\n100 at the same time last year. 14 people have been admitted into\nhospital this year with the viral illness.\n\nMumps has been on the increase in Ireland since last year [2008], and\nthere is currently an extensive outbreak among students in England,\nWales and Northern Ireland (see:\n<http://www.hpsc.ie/hpsc/News/MainBody,3484,en.html> and ProMED-mail\nreferences below), as well as in the the Republic of Ireland (see:\nContinued increase in mumps cases in 2009. Health Protection\nSurveillance Centre (Republic of Ireland). [online] [10 Mar 2009]). - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Given the relative ease with\nwhich this illness can be spread, she said, 'it's likelly we'll see\nmore cases.'\n\nMumps is caused by a virus that is spread through infected\nrespiratory tract secretions, and people typically catch it by being\nwithin 3 to 6 feet of an infected person who coughs or sneezes.\n \n\nMumps has been on the increase in Ireland since last year [2008], and\nthere is currently an extensive outbreak among students in England,\nWales and Northern Ireland (see:\n<http://www.hpsc.ie/hpsc/News/MainBody,3484,en.html> and ProMED-mail\nreferences below), as well as in the the Republic of Ireland (see:\nContinued increase in mumps cases in 2009. Brigham and Women's Hospital\nUSA\n<kkelley@rics.bwh.harvard.edu>\n\n[It is somewhat surprising that the all 4 affected students at\nNortheastern University had ben properly vaccinated, although it is\nknown that vaccine-induced protection may wane in a small proportion\nof individuals (M.M.Cortese et al., Clin Infect Dis. Though laboratory results are not yet back to confirm these as mumps\ncases, Dr. Anita Barry, director of infectious diseases at the Boston\nPublic Health Commission, said the 4 students -- 2 of whom just\nreturned from Ireland where there was a recent mumps outbreak -- have\nsymptoms that are consistent with mumps. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 16 Apr 2009\n A total of 4 Northeastern University students have suspected cases of\nmumps, Boston public health officials announced today [16 Apr 2009],\nand they urged any unvaccinated students and staff to get immunized\nagainst this once-common childhood illness. The\nincubation period for mumps is usually 16 to 18 days, meaning it\ntakes that long for symptoms to appear after someone has been exposed\nto the virus. Barry\nsaid all 4 sick Northeastern students have medical records showing\nthat they had the 2 recommended doses of mumps vaccine. Barry said\nroughly 10 or 20 percent of those who receive the mumps vaccine are\nstill vulnerable to the illness. It\nis reported that there have been over 800 cases of mumps throughout\ncolleges all over Ireland this year (2009). Barry said people are generally considered to be infectious from\n3 days before until 5 days after the onset of swelling of the\nsalivary glands.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boston", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "326473", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (04): (NY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=326473", "date": "2009-11-06 16:00:10", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04): (NEW YORK)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 5 Nov 2009\nSource: The Journal News, LoHud.com [edited]\n<http://www.lohud.com/article/20091105/NEWS03/911050414/-1/SPORTS/Outbreak-of-mumps-in-Monsey--Spring-Valley>\n\n\nOutbreak of mumps in Monsey, Spring Valley\n------------------------------------------\nAt least 45 children in Rockland have been diagnosed with mumps, a highly\ninfectious disease that is also being reported in communities in Brooklyn\nand Orange County, New York, according to the state Department of Health.\nThe Rockland cases have all occurred in religious communities in Monsey and\nSpring Valley, according to an alert issued this week [week of 2 Nov 2009]\nby the State Department of Health.\n\nThe State [Department of Health] is also tracking 62 cases reported in the\nBorough Park section of Brooklyn, as well as 7 confirmed cases in Kiryas\nJoel in Orange County. Other cases connected to the outbreak have also been\nreported in Lakewood, New Jesey, and in Quebec [Canada], according to\nhealth officials.\n\nThe outbreak apparently started in August [2009] in a summer camp in\nSullivan County, New York, attended primarily by children from Borough\nPark, according to the State [Department of Health].\n\nRockland health officials are working to try to make sure that the disease\ndoesn't spread, said commissioner of health Dr Joan Facelle. 'We are\nworking with the community to try to contain it,' she said. 'We are\nencouraging timely vaccinations and urging parents to keep kids home when\nthey are sick.' The number of cases appears to be increasing, but the\ndisease is not spreading beyond religious communities in Monsey and Spring\nValley, she said.\n\n[byline: Jane Lerner]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The New York Department of Health confirmed an outbreak of mumps in the\nBorough Park section of Brooklyn where at least 57 confirmed or probable\ncases occurred beginning 21 Aug 2009. That outbreak was traced back to a\nchild who had visited the United Kingdom, then on return attended a summer\ncamp in upper New York state. It appears this child had contracted mumps\n(presumably in the UK) and then infected fellow campers who brought the\ndisease back with them to Brooklyn where it has continued to spread. Most\nof the victims in Brooklyn have been between the ages of 10 to 15, but the\nyoungest patient so far was 1 year old, while the oldest victim was 42. It\nis likely that the outbreak in Rockland County described above originated\namong attendees at the summer camp and subsequently spread among\ncommunities in the lower Hudson Valley poorly protected against mumps virus\ninfection as a consequence of their religious persuasions.\n\nRockland County is located in the state of New York, 19 km (12 mi)\nnorth-northwest of New York City. It is part of the New York Metropolitan\nArea. A map showing the location of Rockland County can be accessed at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rockland_County,_New_York>. The state of New\nYork can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US\nat <http://healthmap.org/r/00_8>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 5 Nov 2009\n It\nis likely that the outbreak in Rockland County described above originated\namong attendees at the summer camp and subsequently spread among\ncommunities in the lower Hudson Valley poorly protected against mumps virus\ninfection as a consequence of their religious persuasions. \n\n[byline: Jane Lerner]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The New York Department of Health confirmed an outbreak of mumps in the\nBorough Park section of Brooklyn where at least 57 confirmed or probable\ncases occurred beginning 21 Aug 2009. \n\nThe outbreak apparently started in August [2009] in a summer camp in\nSullivan County, New York, attended primarily by children from Borough\nPark, according to the State [Department of Health]. The Rockland cases have all occurred in religious communities in Monsey and\nSpring Valley, according to an alert issued this week [week of 2 Nov 2009]\nby the State Department of Health. At least 45 children in Rockland have been diagnosed with mumps, a highly\ninfectious disease that is also being reported in communities in Brooklyn\nand Orange County, New York, according to the state Department of Health. The number of cases appears to be increasing, but the\ndisease is not spreading beyond religious communities in Monsey and Spring\nValley, she said. Other cases connected to the outbreak have also been\nreported in Lakewood, New Jesey, and in Quebec [Canada], according to\nhealth officials.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2042-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Borough Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New \n York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Monsey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "rockland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Borough \n Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rockland County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jesey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lakewood", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sullivan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rockland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orange County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "175697", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps: USA (MA); UK (Scotland)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=175697", "date": "2009-04-19 18:00:55", "main_text": "MUMPS: USA (MASSACHUSETTS); UK (SCOTLAND)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.or>\n\nIn this post:\n[1] USA (Boston, Massachusetts)\n[2] UK (Scotland)\n\n******\n[1] USA (Boston, Massachusetts)\nDate: 17 Apr 2009\nSource: Boston.com White Coat Notes [edited]\n<http://www.boston.com/news/health/blog/2009/04/mumps_spreads_t.html>\n\n\nThe number of Northeastern University students suspected of being\nsick with the mumps rose to 9 this evening, with one suffering\nsymptoms sufficiently severe to require hospitalization, Boston\npublic health authorities said. The students bear the telltale signs\nof the viral illness, including facial swelling, fever, headaches,\nmuscle pain, fatigue, and loss of appetite. The germs [virus] can\nspread via coughing, sneezing, or talking. All 9 students are\nundergraduates, and they range in age from 18-22, said university\nspokesman Mike Armini.\n\nTo contain the spread of the disease, which in rare cases can lead to\nbrain inflammation and deafness, Northeastern and disease specialists\nfrom the Boston Public Health Commission have urged the ill students\nto avoid crowds and stay in their rooms. Some of the students live in\non-campus dormitories while others reside off campus. 'All of their\nroommates, if they have roommates, are being tested,' Armini said.\n'And if there's a need to provide an individual room for someone,\nthat will be done.'\n\nIn a letter, university administrators urged about 500 students to be\nespecially vigilant for signs of the mumps because they shared\nclasses with the undergraduates believed to be stricken with the\ndisease, a once-common scourge of childhood now seen infrequently in\nthe United States because of widespread vaccination.\n\nNortheastern authorities estimate that 99 percent of the student body\nis immunized, and shots are being offered to the handful who are not.\nAlthough the vaccine provides protects most people, it fails to\nprovide full protection for 10 to 20 percent of those who receive it,\ndisease specialists estimate.\n\n[Byline: Stephen Smith]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nKathryn Kelley\n<kkelley@rics.bwh.harvard.edu>\n\n[The number of mumps cases in the university student population has\nincreased from 4, reported on 16 Apr 2009 (see ProMED archive number\n20090417.1455), to 9 a day later. It is interesting that 9 mumps\ncases in this report from Boston, Massachusetts, has created greater\nconcern than the 9 cases in Scotland in the report below, perhaps\nbecause within the university student population the risk of\ntransmission among the susceptible cohort (mumps virus non-immune) is\ngreater.\n\nA map showing the location of Boston, Massachusetts, in the\nnortheastern US can be accessed at\n<http://www.infoplease.com/atlas/state/massachusetts.html>\n- Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[2] UK (Scotland)\nDate: Sat 18 Apr 2009\nSource: Evening News (Edinburgh) [edited]\n<http://edinburghnews.scotsman.com/health/Mumps-hits-9-across-region.5183344.jp>\n\n\nIn the Lothians last week, 9 cases of mumps were among the infectious\ndiseases recorded. The area's count made up for more than half of the\ncountry's overall cases, with the majority understood to have\noccurred in 15-24-year-olds.\n\nAlthough the figure is higher than it has been for some time, it is\nnot thought to be high enough to cause any concern among health\nchiefs.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealth Map Alerts via\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Lothians are located on the south bank for the Firth of Forth.\nAn interactive map of the area can be accessed at\n<http://www.maplandia.com/united-kingdom/scotland/scotland/east-lothian/drem/>\n- Mod.TY]", "summary": "It is interesting that 9 mumps\ncases in this report from Boston, Massachusetts, has created greater\nconcern than the 9 cases in Scotland in the report below, perhaps\nbecause within the university student population the risk of\ntransmission among the susceptible cohort (mumps virus non-immune) is\ngreater. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.or>\n\nIn this post:\n Communicated by:\nKathryn Kelley\n<kkelley@rics.bwh.harvard.edu>\n\n[The number of mumps cases in the university student population has\nincreased from 4, reported on 16 Apr 2009 (see ProMED archive number\n20090417.1455), to 9 a day later. \n\nIn a letter, university administrators urged about 500 students to be\nespecially vigilant for signs of the mumps because they shared\nclasses with the undergraduates believed to be stricken with the\ndisease, a once-common scourge of childhood now seen infrequently in\nthe United States because of widespread vaccination. \n\nTo contain the spread of the disease, which in rare cases can lead to\nbrain inflammation and deafness, Northeastern and disease specialists\nfrom the Boston Public Health Commission have urged the ill students\nto avoid crowds and stay in their rooms. The number of Northeastern University students suspected of being\nsick with the mumps rose to 9 this evening, with one suffering\nsymptoms sufficiently severe to require hospitalization, Boston\npublic health authorities said. Communicated by:\nHealth Map Alerts via\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Lothians are located on the south bank for the Firth of Forth.\n \n\nA map showing the location of Boston, Massachusetts, in the\nnortheastern US can be accessed at\n<http://www.infoplease.com/atlas/state/massachusetts.html>\n- Mod. \n\nNortheastern authorities estimate that 99 percent of the student body\nis immunized, and shots are being offered to the handful who are not.\n All 9 students are\nundergraduates, and they range in age from 18-22, said university\nspokesman Mike Armini.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "331682", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (NY, NJ), Canada (QC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=331682", "date": "2009-11-13 23:00:44", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (NEW YORK, NEW JERSEY), CANADA (QUEBEC)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 12 Nov 2009\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2009; 58 (dispatch): 1-4 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm58d1112a1.htm?s_cid=mm58d1112a1_e>\n\n\nMumps outbreak: New York, New Jersey, Quebec, 2009\n--------------------------------------------------\nMumps is a vaccine-preventable viral infection characterized by fever\nand inflammation of the salivary glands and whose complications\ninclude orchitis, deafness, and meningo-encephalitis (1). In August\n2009, CDC was notified of the onset of an outbreak of mumps in a\nsummer camp in Sullivan County, New York. The outbreak has spread and\ngradually increased in size and is now the largest US mumps outbreak\nsince 2006, when the United States experienced a resurgence of mumps\nwith 6584 reported cases (2). On [18 Aug 2009], public health\ndepartments in Sullivan County, New York state, and CDC began an\ninvestigation into the mumps outbreak, later joined by departments in\nNew York City and other locales. As of [30 Oct 2009], a total of 179\nconfirmed or probable cases had been identified from multiple\nlocations in New York and New Jersey, and an additional 15 cases had\nbeen reported from Canada.\n\nThe outbreak has primarily affected members of a tradition-observant\nreligious community; median age of the patients is 14 years, and 83\npercent are male. 3 persons have been hospitalized. Although little\ntransmission has occurred outside the [religious] community, mumps can\nspread rapidly in congregate settings such as colleges and schools;\ntherefore, public health officials and clinicians should heighten\nsurveillance for mumps and ensure that children and adults are\nappropriately vaccinated.\n\nMumps cases in the United States have been classified according to the\n2008 case definition of the Council of State and Territorial\nEpidemiologists, and cases in Canada have been classified in\naccordance with Case Definitions for Diseases Under National\nSurveillance. Patients in the United States are considered to have\nage-appropriate vaccinations for mumps if they are aged 1-6 years and\nhave received 1 dose of a mumps-containing vaccine, aged 7-18 years\nand have received 2 doses of vaccine, or aged 19-52 years and have\nreceived 1 dose of vaccine (3,4). Patients aged 7-18 years who have\nreceived 1 dose are considered to have received a partially\nage-appropriate vaccination.\n\nOutbreak reports\n----------------\nSullivan County, New York. On [18 Aug 2009], the New York State\nDepartment of Health was notified of mumps cases in a summer camp\nserving approximately 400 boys from the tradition-observant religious\ncommunity. The index patient was a boy aged 11 years who had returned\non [17 Jun 2009] from the United Kingdom, where a mumps outbreak is\nongoing with approximately 4000 cases, primarily in unvaccinated young\nadults in the general population. The boy became symptomatic at camp\non [28 Jun 2009]. A total of 25 cases were reported among camp\nattendees and staff members. The median age of patients was 12 years\n(range: 9-30 years), and all were male. Of the 24 patients for whom\nvaccination status was reported, 20 (83 percent) had received\nage-appropriate vaccination with 2 doses, one (4 percent) had received\npartial age-appropriate vaccination with 1 dose, and 3 (13 percent)\nwere unvaccinated. The attack rate in this camp was approximately 6\npercent (25 of 400).\n\nBrooklyn, New York. The majority of campers were residents of the\nBorough Park neighborhood of Brooklyn, where mumps transmission began\nafter their return home from camp. Although returning campers were\nimplicated in most of the initial exposures, no predominant focus of\nspread was identified. By [30 Oct 2009], 79 additional persons from\nBrooklyn or other boroughs who were linked to the outbreak had been\nreported, exclusive of returning campers. The median age of these\npatients was 14 years (range: 8 months-84 years), and 81 percent were\nmale. Of the 61 patients (77 percent) for whom vaccine is recommended\nand vaccination status and age were reported, 47 (77 percent) had\nreceived age-appropriate vaccination, 6 (10 percent) had received\npartial age-appropriate vaccination, and 8 (13 percent) were\nunvaccinated.\n\nOcean County, New Jersey. On [26 Sp 2009], the New Jersey Department\nof Health and Senior Services was informed of 8 suspected mumps cases\nin 2 Ocean County private schools for boys with both boarder and\ncommuter students from the same religious community. The index\npatient, who became symptomatic at one of the boarding schools on [6\nSep 2009], was aged 20 years and a resident of the Borough Park\nneighborhood of Brooklyn, New York. Transmission was initially limited\nto the schools but subsequently was observed in households and the\ncommunity. By [30 Oct 2009], a total of 40 cases had been reported.\nThe median age of patients was 19.5 years (range: 1-65 years), and 83\npercent were male. Mumps vaccination status was reported for 29 (73\npercent) patients, of whom 28 (97 percent) had received\nage-appropriate vaccination.\n\nRockland County, New York. 4 of the patients who had attended the\nSullivan County summer camp resided in Rockland County, New York. By\n[30 Oct 2009], an additional 27 cases (exclusive of returning campers)\nhad been reported among members of the same religious community, with\ntransmission occurring in a variety of settings, including a school\nfor boys. The median age of patients was 12 years (range: 1-62 years),\nand 23 (85 percent) were male. Mumps vaccination status was reported\nfor 19 (70 percent), of whom 11 had received age-appropriate\nvaccination, and 2 had received partial age-appropriate vaccination.\n\nOrange County, New York. In September [2009], members of the same\nreligious community in Orange County visited a synagogue in Brooklyn.\nDuring [8-14 Oct 2009], 8 cases occurred among the travelers. The\nmedian age of patients was 18 years (range: 11-23 years), and 5 were\nmale. 7 patients had received age-appropriate vaccination with 2\ndoses, and one was unvaccinated.\n\nQuebec, Canada. Members of affected New York and New Jersey\ncommunities traveled to the province of Quebec to attend religious\ngatherings during [19 Sep-11 Oct 2009]. By [30 Oct 2009], 15 cases\n(patient age range: 8-47 years) from Montreal and the Laurentian\nregion of the province had been reported to the Public Health Agency\nof Canada. All patients were male, and 11 had documented vaccination\nwith at least 1 dose of mumps-containing vaccine.\n\nTransmission outside the religious community\n------------------------------------------------\nDuring [28 Jun-30 Oct 2009], 5 cases outside the affected religious\ncommunity were reported. 2 cases occurred in New York City, and 3\noccurred in Ocean County, New Jersey. The 2 New York City patients\nwere a man aged 40 years who had probable worksite exposures to\nmembers of the affected community and a boy aged 4 years who had no\nidentified exposure. The 3 New Jersey cases were patients aged 17, 29,\nand 66 years who had no identified exposures. 2 of the 5 patients had\nreceived 2 documented doses of mumps-containing vaccine, 1 had\nreceived 2 undocumented doses, and 2 had unknown vaccination status.\n\nLaboratory testing\n------------------\nOf the 179 cases reported as of [30 Oct 2009] in the United States, 85\n(47 percent) have been laboratory-confirmed, and the remaining 94\ncases (53 percent) have met the clinical case definition. Laboratory\ntests used to confirm cases of mumps included detection of mumps\nimmunoglobulin M antibodies by various methods, detection of mumps RNA\nby real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (5), and\nisolation of mumps virus in cell culture. These tests were conducted\nby CDC and state and commercial laboratories. Mumps virus classified\nas genotype G was identified from multiple specimens sent to CDC,\nconsistent with the probable importation of mumps into Sullivan County\nfrom the ongoing mumps outbreak in the United Kingdom (6).\n\nEpidemiologic summary\n---------------------\nOf the 178 (99 percent) patients whose sex is known, 149 (84 percent)\nare male. The median age of the 178 patients for whom age is known is\n14 years (range: 8 months-84 years). Of the 141 patients (79 percent)\nfor whom vaccine is recommended and vaccination status and age were\nreported, 113 (80 percent) had received age-appropriate vaccination, 9\n(6 percent) had received partial age-appropriate vaccination, and 19\n(13 percent) were unvaccinated. Of the 141 patients, 102 (72 percent)\nhad received 2 doses, 20 (14 percent) 1 dose, and 19 (13 percent) zero\ndoses.\n\nComplications have occurred in 16 (9 percent) cases, including\norchitis (15 cases) and temporary deafness (1 case). 3\nhospitalizations for orchitis have been reported. No deaths have\noccurred.\n\nResponse measures\n-----------------\nHealth officials issued alerts in New Jersey, New York City, and\nelsewhere in New York state to health-care providers, urging them to\nincrease active surveillance for mumps, to consider mumps diagnoses\neven if patients had documented vaccinations and, when indicated, to\nperform appropriate diagnostic testing. Isolation and quarantine\nprocedures were reviewed, and health-care providers were urged to\nensure that all children and adults were appropriately vaccinated.\n\n[Reported by a long list of names, available at the source URL]\n\nMMWR editorial note\n-------------------\nBefore routine mumps vaccination was initiated, most persons acquired\ninfection during childhood. In 1967, a live, attenuated mumps virus\nvaccine was licensed in the United States, and by 2005 high coverage\nwith 2 doses among children had reduced the incidence of mumps by 99\npercent (2). In 2006, a resurgence occurred in the United States, with\nthe highest attack rate among persons aged 18-24 years; 57 percent of\npatients had previously received 2 doses of vaccine (2). In 2007 and\n2008, incidence declined to 800 and 454 cases, and outbreaks involved\nfewer than 20 cases.\n\nThe ongoing mumps outbreak is the largest since 2006 and primarily has\naffected a tradition-observant religious community. Mumps outbreaks\nperpetuated by community transmission outside of congregate settings\n(such as, camps, schools, and colleges) are unusual in highly\nvaccinated populations (2). In this outbreak, the limited transmission\nof mumps into the general population might be attributable to\ngenerally high vaccination levels and little interaction between\nmembers of the affected religious community and persons in surrounding\ncommunities. Vaccination rates in the religious community in this\noutbreak have not been measured, but according to the 2008 National\nImmunization Survey, overall age-appropriate mumps vaccination rates\nfor children in New York City, New York state, and New Jersey were\nhigh: 90 percent or higher for receipt of 1 dose among children aged\n19-35 months and 90 percent or higher for receipt of 2 doses among\nadolescents aged 13-17 years. However, mumps incidence commonly peaks\nin the winter (2), and vaccine-preventable diseases have spread from\nreligious communities to the general population during the peak\ntransmission season (7).\n\nOf those patients in this outbreak whose vaccination status was known,\n72 percent had received 2 doses of mumps-containing vaccine, compared\nwith 57 percent in the 2006 outbreak. Mumps vaccine effectiveness has\nbeen estimated at 73-91 percent for 1 dose and 76-95 percent for 2\ndoses (8,9). Studies during the 2006 US mumps resurgence suggested\nthat outbreaks could occur among highly-vaccinated populations such as\ncollege students, where frequent close contact occurs and where more\nthan 10 years have passed since most of the population received a 2nd\ndose (9). However, even in such settings, attack rates were less than\n8 percent in 2006 for those with 2 doses, suggesting that the vaccine\nwas highly effective in preventing disease for the vast majority of\nthose exposed (9). In the current outbreak, the attack rate at the\nsummer camp was approximately 6 percent.\n\nBecause 43 percent of the world's nations have no mumps vaccination\nprogram (10), and certain nations with mumps vaccination programs,\nsuch as the United Kingdom, have experienced large-scale outbreaks,\nthe risk for mumps exposure is increased with foreign travel. When\nimportations occur, congregate settings in the United States, such as\ncolleges and schools, have been foci of indigenous mumps transmission\n(2).\n\nWhen possible, persons with suspected mumps should be isolated for 5\ndays after onset of parotitis and, if they visit a health-care\nsetting, droplet precautions should be initiated immediately. Clinical\nspecimens (both serum and buccal swabs) should be collected from\npersons with suspected mumps as soon as possible after symptom onset.\nAdults and children should receive age-appropriate vaccination.\nUniversity students, health-care personnel, and persons with potential\nmumps outbreak exposure should have documentation of 2 doses of mumps\nvaccine or other proof of immunity to mumps. Although vaccination is\nnot considered effective postexposure prophylaxis for mumps,\nnon-immune contacts should be vaccinated with measles, mumps, rubella\n(MMR) vaccine to prevent risk from subsequent exposures. Any suspected\nmumps case should be reported to the health department in the area\nwhere the patient resides. Additional information regarding mumps\nvaccination is available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/mumps/default.htm#recs>.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Plotkin SA, Rubin SA: Mumps vaccine. In: Plotkin SA, Orenstein WA,\nOffit PA, eds. Vaccines. 5th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2008:\n435-65.\n2. Barskey AE, Glasser JW, LeBaron CW: Mumps resurgences in the United\nStates: a historical perspective on unexpected elements. Vaccine 2009;\n27(44): 6186-95 [abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19815120>].\n3. CDC. Measles, mumps, and rubella -- vaccine use and strategies for\nelimination of measles, rubella, and congenital rubella syndrome and\ncontrol of mumps: recommendations of the Advisory Committee on\nImmunization Practices (ACIP). MMWR 1998; 47(No. RR-8) [available at\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00053391.htm].\n4. CDC. Updated recommendations of the Advisory Committee on\nImmunization Practices (ACIP) for the control and elimination of\nmumps. MMWR 2006; 55: 629-30 [available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5522a4.htm>].\n5. Boddicker JD, Rota PA, Kreman T, et al: Real-time reverse\ntranscription-PCR assay for detection of mumps virus RNA in clinical\nspecimens. J Clin Microbiol 2007; 45: 2902-8 [available at\n<http://jcm.asm.org/cgi/content/full/45/9/2902>].\n6. Rota JS, Turner JC, Yost-Daljev MK, et al: Investigation of a mumps\noutbreak among university students with two measles-mumps-rubella\n(MMR) vaccinations, Virginia, September-December 2006. J Med Virol\n2009; 81(10): 1819-25 [abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19697404>].\n7. Parent du Chatelet I, Floret D, Antona D, et al: Measles resurgence\nin France in 2008, a preliminary report. Eurosurveill 2009; 14(6): 5-7\n[available at\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19118>].\n8. Dayan GH, Rubin S: Mumps outbreaks in vaccinated populations: are\navailable mumps vaccines effective enough to prevent outbreaks? Clin\nInfect Dis 2008; 47(11): 1458-67 [available at\n<http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/full/10.1086/591196>].\n9. Marin M, Quinlisk P, Shimabukuro T, et al: Mumps vaccination\ncoverage and vaccine effectiveness in a large outbreak among college\nstudents - Iowa, 2006. Vaccine 2008; 26(29-30): 3601-7 [abstract\navailable at\n,http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18539365>].\n10. World Health Organization. Global status of mumps immunization and\nsurveillance. Wkly Epidemiol Rec 2005; 80:418-24 [available at\n<http://www.who.int/wer/2005/wer8048.pdf>].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This ongoing mumps outbreak is the largest since 2006 and primarily\nhas affected a religious community. Mumps vaccine effectiveness has\nbeen estimated at 73-91 percent for 1 dose and 76-95 percent for 2\ndoses. Thus, outbreaks may occur among highly vaccinated populations\nsuch as college students, where frequent close contact occurs and\nwhere more than 10 years have passed since most of the population\nreceived a 2nd dose.\n\nThe MMWR recommendation is that public health officials should be\naware that a mumps outbreak is ongoing, consider the diagnosis of\nmumps in patients with symptoms consistent with the disease, and\nensure that children and adults (particularly in congregate settings\nsuch as universities and hospitals) have received an appropriate\nnumber of MMR vaccine doses. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Vaccination rates in the religious community in this\noutbreak have not been measured, but according to the 2008 National\nImmunization Survey, overall age-appropriate mumps vaccination rates\nfor children in New York City, New York state, and New Jersey were\nhigh: 90 percent or higher for receipt of 1 dose among children aged\n19-35 months and 90 percent or higher for receipt of 2 doses among\nadolescents aged 13-17 years. Patients in the United States are considered to have\nage-appropriate vaccinations for mumps if they are aged 1-6 years and\nhave received 1 dose of a mumps-containing vaccine, aged 7-18 years\nand have received 2 doses of vaccine, or aged 19-52 years and have\nreceived 1 dose of vaccine (3,4). \n\nThe MMWR recommendation is that public health officials should be\naware that a mumps outbreak is ongoing, consider the diagnosis of\nmumps in patients with symptoms consistent with the disease, and\nensure that children and adults (particularly in congregate settings\nsuch as universities and hospitals) have received an appropriate\nnumber of MMR vaccine doses. Of the 61 patients (77 percent) for whom vaccine is recommended\nand vaccination status and age were reported, 47 (77 percent) had\nreceived age-appropriate vaccination, 6 (10 percent) had received\npartial age-appropriate vaccination, and 8 (13 percent) were\nunvaccinated. Of the 141 patients (79 percent)\nfor whom vaccine is recommended and vaccination status and age were\nreported, 113 (80 percent) had received age-appropriate vaccination, 9\n(6 percent) had received partial age-appropriate vaccination, and 19\n(13 percent) were unvaccinated. Of the 24 patients for whom\nvaccination status was reported, 20 (83 percent) had received\nage-appropriate vaccination with 2 doses, one (4 percent) had received\npartial age-appropriate vaccination with 1 dose, and 3 (13 percent)\nwere unvaccinated. Although little\ntransmission has occurred outside the [religious] community, mumps can\nspread rapidly in congregate settings such as colleges and schools;\ntherefore, public health officials and clinicians should heighten\nsurveillance for mumps and ensure that children and adults are\nappropriately vaccinated. \nHealth officials issued alerts in New Jersey, New York City, and\nelsewhere in New York state to health-care providers, urging them to\nincrease active surveillance for mumps, to consider mumps diagnoses\neven if patients had documented vaccinations and, when indicated, to\nperform appropriate diagnostic testing. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 12 Nov 2009\n Laboratory\ntests used to confirm cases of mumps included detection of mumps\nimmunoglobulin M antibodies by various methods, detection of mumps RNA\nby real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (5), and\nisolation of mumps virus in cell culture. Studies during the 2006 US mumps resurgence suggested\nthat outbreaks could occur among highly-vaccinated populations such as\ncollege students, where frequent close contact occurs and where more\nthan 10 years have passed since most of the population received a 2nd\ndose (9). In this outbreak, the limited transmission\nof mumps into the general population might be attributable to\ngenerally high vaccination levels and little interaction between\nmembers of the affected religious community and persons in surrounding\ncommunities. \n\nMumps cases in the United States have been classified according to the\n2008 case definition of the Council of State and Territorial\nEpidemiologists, and cases in Canada have been classified in\naccordance with Case Definitions for Diseases Under National\nSurveillance. Because 43 percent of the world's nations have no mumps vaccination\nprogram (10), and certain nations with mumps vaccination programs,\nsuch as the United Kingdom, have experienced large-scale outbreaks,\nthe risk for mumps exposure is increased with foreign travel. In 1967, a live, attenuated mumps virus\nvaccine was licensed in the United States, and by 2005 high coverage\nwith 2 doses among children had reduced the incidence of mumps by 99\npercent (2). The outbreak has spread and\ngradually increased in size and is now the largest US mumps outbreak\nsince 2006, when the United States experienced a resurgence of mumps\nwith 6584 reported cases (2). Mumps virus classified\nas genotype G was identified from multiple specimens sent to CDC,\nconsistent with the probable importation of mumps into Sullivan County\nfrom the ongoing mumps outbreak in the United Kingdom (6). The index patient was a boy aged 11 years who had returned\non [17 Jun 2009] from the United Kingdom, where a mumps outbreak is\nongoing with approximately 4000 cases, primarily in unvaccinated young\nadults in the general population. On [26 Sp 2009], the New Jersey Department\nof Health and Senior Services was informed of 8 suspected mumps cases\nin 2 Ocean County private schools for boys with both boarder and\ncommuter students from the same religious community. Although vaccination is\nnot considered effective postexposure prophylaxis for mumps,\nnon-immune contacts should be vaccinated with measles, mumps, rubella\n(MMR) vaccine to prevent risk from subsequent exposures. The 2 New York City patients\nwere a man aged 40 years who had probable worksite exposures to\nmembers of the affected community and a boy aged 4 years who had no\nidentified exposure. On [18 Aug 2009], the New York State\nDepartment of Health was notified of mumps cases in a summer camp\nserving approximately 400 boys from the tradition-observant religious\ncommunity. Measles, mumps, and rubella -- vaccine use and strategies for\nelimination of measles, rubella, and congenital rubella syndrome and\ncontrol of mumps: recommendations of the Advisory Committee on\nImmunization Practices (ACIP). By [30 Oct 2009], 15 cases\n(patient age range: 8-47 years) from Montreal and the Laurentian\nregion of the province had been reported to the Public Health Agency\nof Canada. However, even in such settings, attack rates were less than\n8 percent in 2006 for those with 2 doses, suggesting that the vaccine\nwas highly effective in preventing disease for the vast majority of\nthose exposed (9). However, mumps incidence commonly peaks\nin the winter (2), and vaccine-preventable diseases have spread from\nreligious communities to the general population during the peak\ntransmission season (7). Mumps outbreaks\nperpetuated by community transmission outside of congregate settings\n(such as, camps, schools, and colleges) are unusual in highly\nvaccinated populations (2). [30 Oct 2009], an additional 27 cases (exclusive of returning campers)\nhad been reported among members of the same religious community, with\ntransmission occurring in a variety of settings, including a school\nfor boys. On [18 Aug 2009], public health\ndepartments in Sullivan County, New York state, and CDC began an\ninvestigation into the mumps outbreak, later joined by departments in\nNew York City and other locales. As of [30 Oct 2009], a total of 179\nconfirmed or probable cases had been identified from multiple\nlocations in New York and New Jersey, and an additional 15 cases had\nbeen reported from Canada. Thus, outbreaks may occur among highly vaccinated populations\nsuch as college students, where frequent close contact occurs and\nwhere more than 10 years have passed since most of the population\nreceived a 2nd dose. Mumps vaccination status was reported\nfor 19 (70 percent), of whom 11 had received age-appropriate\nvaccination, and 2 had received partial age-appropriate vaccination. When\nimportations occur, congregate settings in the United States, such as\ncolleges and schools, have been foci of indigenous mumps transmission\n(2). --------------------------------------------------\nMumps is a vaccine-preventable viral infection characterized by fever\nand inflammation of the salivary glands and whose complications\ninclude orchitis, deafness, and meningo-encephalitis (1). \n\nOf those patients in this outbreak whose vaccination status was known,\n72 percent had received 2 doses of mumps-containing vaccine, compared\nwith 57 percent in the 2006 outbreak. 2 of the 5 patients had\nreceived 2 documented doses of mumps-containing vaccine, 1 had\nreceived 2 undocumented doses, and 2 had unknown vaccination status. Mumps vaccination status was reported for 29 (73\npercent) patients, of whom 28 (97 percent) had received\nage-appropriate vaccination. University students, health-care personnel, and persons with potential\nmumps outbreak exposure should have documentation of 2 doses of mumps\nvaccine or other proof of immunity to mumps. Of the 141 patients, 102 (72 percent)\nhad received 2 doses, 20 (14 percent) 1 dose, and 19 (13 percent) zero\ndoses. In 2006, a resurgence occurred in the United States, with\nthe highest attack rate among persons aged 18-24 years; 57 percent of\npatients had previously received 2 doses of vaccine (2). Mumps vaccine effectiveness has\nbeen estimated at 73-91 percent for 1 dose and 76-95 percent for 2\ndoses (8,9). Mumps vaccine effectiveness has\nbeen estimated at 73-91 percent for 1 dose and 76-95 percent for 2\ndoses. \n\nThe outbreak has primarily affected members of a tradition-observant\nreligious community; median age of the patients is 14 years, and 83\npercent are male. Patients aged 7-18 years who have\nreceived 1 dose are considered to have received a partially\nage-appropriate vaccination. Of the 179 cases reported as of [30 Oct 2009] in the United States, 85\n(47 percent) have been laboratory-confirmed, and the remaining 94\ncases (53 percent) have met the clinical case definition. The median age of these\npatients was 14 years (range: 8 months-84 years), and 81 percent were\nmale. Rota JS, Turner JC, Yost-Daljev MK, et al: Investigation of a mumps\noutbreak among university students with two measles-mumps-rubella\n(MMR) vaccinations, Virginia, September-December 2006. Marin M, Quinlisk P, Shimabukuro T, et al: Mumps vaccination\ncoverage and vaccine effectiveness in a large outbreak among college\nstudents - Iowa, 2006. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2009; 58 (dispatch): 1-4 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm58d1112a1.htm?s_cid=mm58d1112a1_e>\n\n\nMumps outbreak: New York, New Jersey, Quebec, 2009\n The\nmedian age of patients was 18 years (range: 11-23 years), and 5 were\nmale.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2047-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-08-25 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Borough Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rockland County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Borough Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montreal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "student - Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ocean County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orange County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sullivan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "157945", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - FY Rep. Macedonia (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=157945", "date": "2009-02-18 13:00:50", "main_text": "MUMPS - THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA (03)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 6 Feb 2009\nSource: Balkan Insight online [edited]\n<http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/main/news/16483/>\n\n\nMacedonia mumps epidemic tops 2000 cases\n----------------------------------------\nAnother 135 cases of mumps were registered in [FYR] Macedonia on\nThursday [5 Feb 2009], raising the total number of infected to over\n2000 across the country, the Health Ministry said. Of the\nnewly-infected patients 10 had to be hospitalized due to the severity\nof their condition. Around 50 patients, mainly children, have been\nhospitalized in total. Earlier this week, health authorities kicked\noff an emergency mass vaccination campaign to deal with the outbreak,\naimed at all children aged 15-19 that had not been vaccinated before.\nSome parents asked schools to shut down provisionally until the\noutbreak is contained, but authorities have not reached a formal decision yet.\n\nMumps is a viral infectious disease that mainly attacks children. It\nis spread from person to person through contact with respiratory\nsecretions such as saliva, but can also be spread by sharing food,\ndrinks, and kissing. Symptoms including swelling of the glands close\nto the jaw, fever, headache and muscle ache. Mumps is considered a\nmild to moderate disease, but carries the risk of complications\nincluding hearing loss, meningitis, sterility in men and spontaneous\nmiscarriage.\n\n[Byline: Sinisa-Jakov Marusic]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This mumps epidemic in FYR Macedonia is unusually large. A total of 66\nstudents were identified as having the symptoms and those infected have\nbeen sent home to recover.\n\nJohn Gallally, head of student support services, said: 'The university has\ntaken the suspected outbreak very seriously and immediately sought expert\nguidance from the Health Protection Agency. We have been working very\nclosely with the agency. They have visited the campus and are satisfied\nwith the precautions being carried out. We have been advised to carry on\nour business as normal. We have student health advisers on both campuses to\nadvise on a daily basis and anyone showing the symptoms has been told to\nstay at home for at least 5 days.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMapAlerts\nvia ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks of mumps continue to occur among young adults attending further\neducation colleges and universities in the United Kingdom as a consequence\nin part of to the less than optimal acceptance of the triple mumps,\nmeasles, and rubella (MMR) vaccine, and in part to the lesser\nimmunogenicity of the mumps virus component of the triple vaccine.\n\nThe 2 campuses of the University of Chichester are located on the south\ncoast of England in the adjacent tows and Chichester and Bognor Regis which\ncan be located using the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the\nUnited Kingdom at <http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=54.5,-2,5>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "We have student health advisers on both campuses to\nadvise on a daily basis and anyone showing the symptoms has been told to\nstay at home for at least 5 days.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMapAlerts\nvia ProMED-mail\n< A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 20 Feb 2009\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks of mumps continue to occur among young adults attending further\neducation colleges and universities in the United Kingdom as a consequence\nin part of to the less than optimal acceptance of the triple mumps,\nmeasles, and rubella (MMR) vaccine, and in part to the lesser\nimmunogenicity of the mumps virus component of the triple vaccine. New figures from the Health\nProtection Agency (HPA) show that there were 39 cases of the infection\nacross the city in 2008 -- many among people in their late teens and 20s.\n\nThe authority has identified people born between 1980 and 1990 as at the\ngreatest risk. Anyone in this age range may have missed out on a\nmumps-containing vaccine or getting natural immunity through a previous\nbout of the illness. Prior to the mumps, measles, and rubella (MMR)\ninjection being introduced in 1988, vaccines were only available for\nmeasles and rubella.\n\nMumps can spread rapidly in environments such as colleges and universities,\nwhere it is passed on by coughing, sneezing, and kissing.\n\nDr Mark Kealy, of the South West Peninsula Health Protection Unit, said:\n'Mumps is a viral illness which can lead to serious complications. At the\nvery best, it takes students out of studies -- and socialising -- for 2\nweeks as they recover. 'We've seen a 40 per cent increase in mumps cases\nover the last 6 months in Devon and Cornwall, and in most cases it is an\nentirely avoidable illness.' The HPA is urging all students born in that\ndecade to check their vaccination history with their GP [general\npractitioner]. Two doses of MMR are required to give the fullest protection\nagainst mumps. The injection is free and there is no upper age limit. The\nnumber of cases across Devon and Cornwall rose from 19 in the 1st half of\nlast year [2008] to 27 cases in the 2nd half. Colleges and universities\nacross the 2 counties are sending out the advice direct to students on\nemail, or placing it on intranet home pages and including it in student\nbulletins. Young people who suspect they have the infection are advised to\ncontact their GP or student health service.\n\nGeneral practices in the Devon and Cornwall area have been alerted to the\nsymptoms, which may include: fever, headaches, aches and pains, and swollen\nglands along the jaw line. There is no specific treatment for mumps, so for\nmost people it will clear up by itself. However, complications may include\nswelling of the ovaries, swelling of the testes, aseptic meningitis, and\ndeafness.\n\nFor further information on mumps and MMR, visit the NHS (National Health\nService) MMR website at <http://www.immunisation.nhs.uk/Vaccines/MMR>.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Another consequence of the less than optimal uptake of MMR vaccine in the UK.\n\nThe counties of Devon and Cornwall in south west England can be located on\nthe map at <http://www.abcounties.co.uk/counties/map.htm>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United Kingdom, showing the\ncity of Plymouth on the south west coast of England, is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=2640194&g=2652355&v=54.5,-2,5> - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 10 Feb 2009\n For further information on mumps and MMR, visit the NHS (National Health\nService) MMR website at <http://www.immunisation.nhs.uk/Vaccines/MMR>.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< Colleges and universities\nacross the 2 counties are sending out the advice direct to students on\nemail, or placing it on intranet home pages and including it in student\nbulletins. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United Kingdom, showing the\ncity of Plymouth on the south west coast of England, is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=2640194&g=2652355&v=54.5,-2,5> - Mod. We've seen a 40 per cent increase in mumps cases\nover the last 6 months in Devon and Cornwall, and in most cases it is an\nentirely avoidable illness.' New figures from the Health\nProtection Agency (HPA) show that there were 39 cases of the infection\nacross the city in 2008 -- many among people in their late teens and 20s. The\nnumber of cases across Devon and Cornwall rose from 19 in the 1st half of\nlast year [2008] to 27 cases in the 2nd half. \n\nGeneral practices in the Devon and Cornwall area have been alerted to the\nsymptoms, which may include: fever, headaches, aches and pains, and swollen\nglands along the jaw line. Prior to the mumps, measles, and rubella (MMR)\ninjection being introduced in 1988, vaccines were only available for\nmeasles and rubella.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-02-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Devon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Plymouth", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "173341", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, students - UK (06): (England, Wales)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=173341", "date": "2009-04-10 18:01:01", "main_text": "MUMPS, STUDENTS - UNITED KINGDOM (06): (ENGLAND, WALES)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org\n\n\nDate: Thu 9 Apr 2009\nSource: Health Protection Report, Volume 3, No 14, 2009 [edited]\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2009/news1409.htm#mumps0809>\n\n\nContinued increase in mumps in universities 2008/2009\n-----------------------------------------------------\nAs reported previously [1], the number of mumps cases notified in\nEngland and Wales increased in early 2009 and has continued to\nincrease during March. Outbreaks have been reported from several\nuniversities and colleges. A similar increase has been reported from\nthe Republic of Ireland [2].\n\nA large epidemic of mumps affecting university students 1st occurred\nin the academic year 2004/5 [3] and continued into 2005/6, declining\nin 2006/7 and 2007/8. During the final quarter of 2008, 695 cases of\nmumps were confirmed compared to 447 in the previous quarter [4]. So\nfar in 2009, 998 cases of mumps with onset in January or February\nhave been confirmed mumps IgM or RNA positive in England and Wales.\nThis compares to 322, 274, and 1173 cases in the same periods of\n2008, 2007, and 2006 respectively. During 2009, cases have been\nconfirmed in all English regions and Wales with high numbers from the\nSouth West (204), South East (180), and North West (162) regions. For\nthe remaining regions the number of cases confirmed was as follows:\nYorkshire and Humberside (115), London (86), East of England (81),\nWest Midlands (64), East Midlands (48), North East (30), and Wales\n(27). The genotype currently circulating is a G5, the same strain\nthat has been circulating over the past 5 years and responsible for\noutbreaks in other parts of Europe [5,6].\n\n[These data are illustrated in the original text by a figure showing\nthe 5 week moving average of mumps notifications, England and Wales\n2003-2009. - Mod.CP]\n\nReason for the increase\n-----------------------\nThe previous epidemic was attributed to a cohort of young adults,\nborn between 1981 and 1990, who were at increased risk of mumps.\nThese individuals were born before the implementation of the routine\n2-dose MMR programme and had therefore either received no MMR\nvaccine, or only one dose. As control of mumps was excellent after\n1990, this group remained susceptible until they entered the\nuniversity or college setting, when transmission of mumps was\nfacilitated. During 2008, 1403 (57 percent) of the confirmed cases\nwere in those born between 1981 and 1990 . [Data illustrated by a\nfigure in the original text. - Mod.CP]\n\nDespite this clear picture, the reason why the numbers of cases have\nincreased in this academic year, after remaining lower in both 2006/7\nand 2007/8 is not entirely clear. One explanation may be that, since\nthe widespread transmission in 2005/6, 3 new cohorts of students have\nentered college and therefore another susceptible pool has been\nre-established in this setting.\n\nIn the previous epidemic, although the vaccinated cohorts were\nlargely protected from mumps, cases were confirmed in vaccinated\nindividuals. By the 2008/9 academic year, most students would have\nbeen eligible for one or 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella),\nand so a higher proportion of vaccine failures are expected amongst\nthe cases. Initial reports are consistent with this observation.\n\nIn 2004-5, analysis of protection from vaccination showed that,\nalthough individual protection from vaccination was high, there was\nevidence of declining protection over time, particularly in those who\nhad only received one dose of vaccine [7]. Investigations during\nuniversity outbreaks in the United States, where vaccine coverage for\n2 doses has been in place for longer, also suggested that waning\nprotection may have contributed [8]. Secondary vaccine failure may\ntherefore also explain a proportion of cases.\n\nSurveillance and control\n------------------------\nContinued surveillance, including confirmation of the diagnosis, is\nimportant for ensuring accurate epidemiological data. In persons who\nhave been previously vaccinated, the serological diagnosis of mumps\ncan be difficult as the IgM response may be delayed and reach lower\nlevels. For rapid diagnosis, an oral fluid taken in the 1st 14 days\nof illness is preferred as this can be tested for both IgM\n(Immunoglobulin M) and viral RNA (ribonucleic acid). If this is not\npossible then parallel serum and throat swab or paired serum samples\ncan be collected.\n\nIn 2005 and 2006, the incident team for the national mumps outbreak\nrecommended that the priorities were to ensure that systems were in\nplace to ensure that those entering university were fully vaccinated\nwith MMR in the future. This included ensuring that pupils attending\nfor the Year 10 booster and university entrants from 2005 onwards had\nreceived 2 doses of MMR.\n\nThe team also concluded that university vaccination campaigns in\nparticular are likely to achieve low uptake and are unlikely to stop\noutbreaks. The offer of individual vaccination, however, should be\navailable to students who are unvaccinated or have received only one\ndose of MMR. Approaches being taken in individual universities this\nyear have included using text messaging and university computer\nnetworks to alert students to these recommendations.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. HPA. Mumps increase in university students, Health Protection\nReport [serial online] 2009; 3(10): News. Available at\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2009/news1009.htm#mumps>.\n\n2. Continued increase in mumps cases in 2009. Health Protection\nSurveillance Centre (Republic of Ireland). [online] [10 March 2009]\n<http://www.hpsc.ie/hpsc/News/MainBody,3484,en.html>.\n\n3. J Infect Dis.\n2008 15;197(12): 1662-8.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The extent and intensity of the mumps epidemic in the current\nacademic year is surprising in view of the decline of mumps in\nuniversity students during both 2006/2007 and 2007/2008, subsequent to\nthe major outbreak in 2005/2006. As suggested above, it may be that\nsince 2005/2006 3 new cohorts of students have entered colleges and\nuniversities and established a new pool of susceptibles.\n\nEfforts to increase awareness of the risk of exposure to mumps\ninfection among university students must be continued. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Mumps in male college students may lead to orchitis (inflammation of\nthe testes) and sterility, a good selling point for taking the\nvaccine. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org\n\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The extent and intensity of the mumps epidemic in the current\nacademic year is surprising in view of the decline of mumps in\nuniversity students during both 2006/2007 and 2007/2008, subsequent to\nthe major outbreak in 2005/2006. By the 2008/9 academic year, most students would have\nbeen eligible for one or 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella),\nand so a higher proportion of vaccine failures are expected amongst\nthe cases. As control of mumps was excellent after\n1990, this group remained susceptible until they entered the\nuniversity or college setting, when transmission of mumps was\nfacilitated. In 2005 and 2006, the incident team for the national mumps outbreak\nrecommended that the priorities were to ensure that systems were in\nplace to ensure that those entering university were fully vaccinated\nwith MMR in the future. In 2004-5, analysis of protection from vaccination showed that,\nalthough individual protection from vaccination was high, there was\nevidence of declining protection over time, particularly in those who\nhad only received one dose of vaccine [7]. Laboratory confirmed cases of mumps, England and Wales:\nOctober to December 2008.Health Protection Report [serial online]\n2009;3(14)news.\n Investigations during\nuniversity outbreaks in the United States, where vaccine coverage for\n2 doses has been in place for longer, also suggested that waning\nprotection may have contributed [8]. One explanation may be that, since\nthe widespread transmission in 2005/6, 3 new cohorts of students have\nentered college and therefore another susceptible pool has been\nre-established in this setting. In persons who\nhave been previously vaccinated, the serological diagnosis of mumps\ncan be difficult as the IgM response may be delayed and reach lower\nlevels. \n\nA large epidemic of mumps affecting university students 1st occurred\nin the academic year 2004/5 [3] and continued into 2005/6, declining\nin 2006/7 and 2007/8. So\nfar in 2009, 998 cases of mumps with onset in January or February\nhave been confirmed mumps IgM or RNA positive in England and Wales. \n\n[These data are illustrated in the original text by a figure showing\nthe 5 week moving average of mumps notifications, England and Wales\n2003-2009. CP]\n\n[Mumps in male college students may lead to orchitis (inflammation of\nthe testes) and sterility, a good selling point for taking the\nvaccine. - Mod. As reported previously [1], the number of mumps cases notified in\nEngland and Wales increased in early 2009 and has continued to\nincrease during March. Approaches being taken in individual universities this\nyear have included using text messaging and university computer\nnetworks to alert students to these recommendations.\n\n In the previous epidemic, although the vaccinated cohorts were\nlargely protected from mumps, cases were confirmed in vaccinated\nindividuals. CP]\n\nDespite this clear picture, the reason why the numbers of cases have\nincreased in this academic year, after remaining lower in both 2006/7\nand 2007/8 is not entirely clear. Long-term persistence of mumps antibody after receipt of 2\nmeasles-mumps- rubella (MMR) vaccinations and antibody response after\na third MMR vaccination among a university population. This included ensuring that pupils attending\nfor the Year 10 booster and university entrants from 2005 onwards had\nreceived 2 doses of MMR. During 2009, cases have been\nconfirmed in all English regions and Wales with high numbers from the\nSouth West (204), South East (180), and North West (162) regions. As suggested above, it may be that\nsince 2005/2006 3 new cohorts of students have entered colleges and\nuniversities and established a new pool of susceptibles. MUMPS, STUDENTS - UNITED KINGDOM (06): (ENGLAND, WALES)\n*******************************************************\n Cui A, Myers R, Xu W, Jin L. Analysis of the genetic variability\nof the mumps SH gene in viruses circulating in the UK between 1996\nand 2005. J Infect Dis.\n2008 15;197(12): 1662-8.\n\n--\n These individuals were born before the implementation of the routine\n2-dose MMR programme and had therefore either received no MMR\nvaccine, or only one dose. The team also concluded that university vaccination campaigns in\nparticular are likely to achieve low uptake and are unlikely to stop\noutbreaks. The offer of individual vaccination, however, should be\navailable to students who are unvaccinated or have received only one\ndose of MMR. The genotype currently circulating is a G5, the same strain\nthat has been circulating over the past 5 years and responsible for\noutbreaks in other parts of Europe [5,6].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "1662-08-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "1173-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-06-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Opp M", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East midland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North West", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Luxembourg", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "156274", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK (04): (England, Wales)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=156274", "date": "2009-02-12 18:00:46", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED KINGDOM (04): (ENGLAND, WALES)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] Mumps - UK: (England)\n[2] Mumps - UK: (Wales)\n\n******\n[1] Mumps - UK: (England)\nDate: Thu 12 Feb 2009\nFrom: Peter English <Peter.English@hpa.org.uk>\n\n\nA comment re: Mumps - UK (03): (England) 20090211.0619\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe moderator's comment that this is 'Another consequence of the less than\noptimal uptake of MMR vaccine in the UK' needs to be challenged. That may\nbe a part of the problem, but there are 2 other significant factors here,\nand it would be wrong to overstate the case. (The mumps epidemic has been\ncited by some of those engaged with anti-vaccinationists as evidence of the\nharm caused by vaccine scares; anti-vaccinationists could claim that this\nis a false argument to undermine the strength of the case against them.)\n\nThe 1st, and probably most important, factor is that there is a cohort of\npeople who had a single dose of MMR (single-component mumps vaccine has\nnever been licensed or widely used in the UK) before the introduction of a\n2nd dose with the 'pre-school booster vaccinations' in October 1996. Many\nof these will have had an MR vaccine during a programme implemented in\nschools; but there was insufficient mumps vaccine available at the time to\nuse MMR for this programme. In Mary Ramsay's words (in an internal Health\nProtection Agency document; I'm not sure whether a version was published):\n'The cohort identified to be at particularly high risk of mumps were those\nwho are too old to have received 2 doses of MMR in the routine schedule\n(born before 1992) but young enough to have grown up during a period of low\nincidence and so to have escaped catching mumps as a child.'[1]\n\nThe 2nd factor is that the duration of effective immunity following mumps\nvaccination is lower than for measles and rubella.[2]\n\nReferences:\n1. Ramsay M. Recent epidemiology of mumps in England and Wales - UPDATE.\nLondon: HPA Centre for Infections, 2005 (31/1/05); 1-5.\n2. Cohen C, White JM, Savage EJ, Glynn JR, Choi Y, Andrews N, et al.\nVaccine effectiveness estimates, 2004-2005 mumps outbreak, England. Emerg\nInfect Dis 2007; 13(1): 12-7. <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/EID/13/1/12.htm>.\n\n--\nDr Peter M B English\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control\nSurrey & Sussex\nUK\n<Peter.English@hpa.org.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Peter English for his perceptive comments. - Mod.CP]\n\n******\n[2] Mumps - UK: (Wales)\nDate: Tue 10 Feb 2009\nSource: Wales Online [edited]\n<http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/health-news/2009/02/10/experts-investigate-second-mumps-outbreak-in-wales-91466-22896340/>\n\n\nAn investigation has been launched into a 2nd outbreak of mumps in Wales.\nPublic health experts are investigating 6 cases of suspected mumps in\nSwansea. And there have been a further 31 cases of the illness -- 2\nconfirmed and 29 suspected -- in Anglesey and Gwynedd since 27 Dec 2009. No\nlinks between the 2 outbreaks have been established, but it is thought that\na number of the cases are in children and young people who have previously\nreceived at least one dose of the MMR vaccine.\n\nSwansea became the heartland of the MMR backlash in Wales following claims\nin 1998 that the jab was linked to autism and bowel disease. The MMR uptake\nrate is now improving. The National Public Health Service for Wales (NPHS)\nhas urged any teenagers or young adults who have not had both doses of the\ntriple vaccine to ensure they are immunised against measles, mumps and\nrubella. Dr Hoffmann, a consultant in communicable disease control for the\nNPHS, said: 'The MMR vaccine is extremely effective in protecting against\nmeasles and rubella, with 99 per cent of those who have received 2 doses\nprotected for many years. One dose of MMR protects around 65 per cent of\nthose who receive it against mumps, with a 2nd dose of MMR improving\nimmunity to around 85 per cent of recipients. So it is possible to see\nmumps in individuals who have been vaccinated with MMR, although this is\nnot common.'\n\nIn the North Wales outbreak, at least 26 of the people who have developed\nmumps had previously received the recommended 2 doses of MMR. Dr Judy Hart,\na consultant in communicable disease control for the NPHS, said: 'MMR\nuptake is very high on Anglesey, so most school children are protected.\nHowever, young people aged 16 and over were too old to have received a\nroutine 2nd dose of MMR before school entry when it was introduced in 1996.\nThey are more likely to be susceptible to mumps, as it is spread by coughs\nand sneezes and directly through close personal contact. Symptoms include\nswelling on the angle of the jaw on one or both sides of the face. This may\nbe preceded by several days of general symptoms such as fever, headache,\ntiredness, muscle aches, and loss of appetite.'\n\nThe NPHS is advising that anyone with mumps symptoms should see their GP or\nfamily doctor and stay away from school or work until 5 days after the\nstart of the swelling, when they are no longer infectious.\n\n[byline: Madeleine Brindley]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "In Mary Ramsay's words (in an internal Health\nProtection Agency document; I'm not sure whether a version was published):\n'The cohort identified to be at particularly high risk of mumps were those\nwho are too old to have received 2 doses of MMR in the routine schedule\n(born before 1992) but young enough to have grown up during a period of low\nincidence and so to have escaped catching mumps as a child. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] Mumps - UK: (England)\n \n\nThe 1st, and probably most important, factor is that there is a cohort of\npeople who had a single dose of MMR (single-component mumps vaccine has\nnever been licensed or widely used in the UK) before the introduction of a\n2nd dose with the 'pre-school booster vaccinations' in October 1996.
