MUMPS - MACEDONIA (02)\n Date: Sun 1 Feb 2009\n **\n Geographic Medicine\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "the Gideon Database", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macedonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States '", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "151701", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK (WLS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=151701", "date": "2009-01-30 20:00:50", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED KINGDOM (WALES)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 30 Jan 2009\nSource: BBC News online [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/north_west/7848857.stm>\n\n\nVaccine call after 16 mumps cases\n---------------------------------\nPeople are being urged to make sure they have had the MMR [measles,\nmumps and rubella] vaccination after 16 cases of mumps in [the Isle\nof] Anglesey and Gwynedd in the last month. The National Public\nHealth Service for Wales (NPHS) says 15 of those affected had been\ngiven the recommended 2 doses of the MMR vaccine.\n\nA total of 10 secondary school pupils in Amlwch on Anglesey are\nunderstood to have been sent home with the illness. GPs in the 2\nareas have been alerted to the problem. Health officials from\nAnglesey's Local Health Board (LHB) have sent letters to parents\nthrough Ysgol Syr Thomas Jones in Amlwch where pupils have become\nill. All the suspected cases have emerged since 27 Dec 2008.\n\nThe health service said it is possible, but not common, to get mumps\nafter being vaccinated with MMR which protects against measles, mumps\nand rubella and is given as part of the routine childhood\nimmunisation programme. Dr Judy Hart, Consultant in Communicable\nDisease Control, said: 'The MMR vaccine is extremely effective in\nprotecting against measles and rubella, with 99 percent of those who\nhave received 2 doses protected for many years. However, while it is\nstill very effective compared to other vaccines, MMR does not provide\nsuch high levels of protection against mumps infection compared to\nmeasles and rubella.' Dr Hart said one dose of MMR protects around 65\npercent of those who receive it against mumps, with a 2nd dose of MMR\nimproving immunity to around 85 percent of recipients. 'So it is\npossible to see mumps in individuals who have been vaccinated with\nMMR, although this is not common,' said Dr Hart\n\n'MMR uptake is very high on Anglesey so most school children are\nprotected. However, young people aged 16 and over were too old to\nhave received a routine 2nd dose of MMR before school entry when it\nwas introduced in 1996. They are more likely to be susceptible to\nmumps and require a 2nd dose now.'\n\nMumps is spread by coughs and sneezes and directly through close\npersonal contact. Symptoms include swelling on the angle of the jaw\non one or both sides of the face. Beforehand, there may be several\ndays of symptoms such as fever, headache, tiredness, muscle aches,\nand loss of appetite. Anyone with these symptoms is being advised to\nconsult their GP and stay away from school or work until 5 days after\nthe start of the swelling, when they are no longer infectious.\n\nDr Hart added: 'Anyone in a school or community where mumps cases are\nreported who have not already been fully immunised with 2 doses of\nMMR should be vaccinated immediately.' There is no upper age limit\nfor vaccination. The NPHS has issued letters to GPs in Anglesey and\nGwynedd to alert them to the increase in suspected mumps.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett.\n\n[Outbreaks of mumps in children and young adults continue to be a\nproblem in the UK, often as a consequence of the poor uptake of the\ntriple MMR vaccine. However, MMR uptake is considered to be very high\nin Angelsey so most school children are protected. The reason may lie\nin the relative lower immunogenicity of the mumps component of the\ntriple vaccine and the observation that immnity is not always\nsustained even after a 2nd immunisation.\n\nA map of the counties of Wales showing the Isle of Angelsey and\nGwynedd in the north is available at:\n<http://www.walesdirectory.co.uk/counties.htm>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 30 Jan 2009\n \n\nThe health service said it is possible, but not common, to get mumps\nafter being vaccinated with MMR which protects against measles, mumps\nand rubella and is given as part of the routine childhood\nimmunisation programme. So it is\npossible to see mumps in individuals who have been vaccinated with\nMMR, although this is not common,' said Dr Hart\n\n'MMR uptake is very high on Anglesey so most school children are\nprotected. Dr Judy Hart, Consultant in Communicable\nDisease Control, said: 'The MMR vaccine is extremely effective in\nprotecting against measles and rubella, with 99 percent of those who\nhave received 2 doses protected for many years. However, while it is\nstill very effective compared to other vaccines, MMR does not provide\nsuch high levels of protection against mumps infection compared to\nmeasles and rubella.' The reason may lie\nin the relative lower immunogenicity of the mumps component of the\ntriple vaccine and the observation that immnity is not always\nsustained even after a 2nd immunisation. \n\nDr Hart added: 'Anyone in a school or community where mumps cases are\nreported who have not already been fully immunised with 2 doses of\nMMR should be vaccinated immediately.' People are being urged to make sure they have had the MMR [measles,\nmumps and rubella] vaccination after 16 cases of mumps in [the Isle\nof] Anglesey and Gwynedd in the last month. Dr Hart said one dose of MMR protects around 65\npercent of those who receive it against mumps, with a 2nd dose of MMR\nimproving immunity to around 85 percent of recipients. ' [Outbreaks of mumps in children and young adults continue to be a\nproblem in the UK, often as a consequence of the poor uptake of the\ntriple MMR vaccine.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-01-30 00:00:00", "2008-12-27 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Amlwch", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Angelsey", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "154196", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK (02): (Wales)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=154196", "date": "2009-02-06 21:00:44", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED KINGDOM (02): (WALES)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 5 Feb 2009\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2009; 14(5) [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19109>\n\n\nMumps outbreak on the island of Anglesey, North Wales, December\n2008-January 2009\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nOver a 5-week period since late December 2008, 23 cases of clinical\nmumps in young people have been reported in North Wales. All cases\nhave social links, and most of them have received 2 doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine.\n\nSince 27 Dec 2008, the North Wales Health Protection Team of the\nNational Public Health Service for Wales has been notified of 23\ncases of clinical mumps. The onset dates are shown in the Figure\n[displayed in the original text]. The age range was 9-37 years with a\nmedian of 15-16 years, and similar numbers of males and females were\naffected. The cases are all linked via family or social groups.\n\nEpidemiological investigation\n-----------------------------\nThe 1st case reported on 27 Dec 2008 was a student in Manchester\nwhere, as confirmed by the Health Protection Unit, a number of mumps\ncases have occurred among students in recent weeks. They received an\nincrease in notifications in the 1st week of December 2008, which\npeaked in the 2nd week of December, and it is plausible that the\nstudent was infected at this time. Transmission from this case\nprobably occurred at a Young Farmers party held on Anglesey on the 27\nDec 2008. Members of 2 local Young Farmers groups were invited,\ncomprising around 50 young people aged 13 to 27 years.\n\nAn unusual feature of this outbreak is that 20 of the cases had\nreceived 2 doses of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine and 2\ncases had had one dose. The only unvaccinated case was a 37 year-old\npatient who was too old to have been offered MMR as a child. Most\ncases appear to be mild, with no reports to date of orchitis or other\ncomplications. MMR vaccine was introduced into the childhood\nvaccination programme of the United Kingdom (UK) in 1988. The mumps\nstrain currently used in the MMR vaccine is Jeryl Lynn. However, some\nof the older cases (over 17 years-old) in this outbreak will have\nreceived MMR vaccine containing the Urabe strain, which was used in\nthe UK from 1988 to 1992.\n\nLaboratory investigation\n------------------------\nOne case was admitted to the district general hospital where blood\nfor serology was taken. This was reported as negative for IgM against\nmumps virus, but positive for IgG with no evidence of recent\ninfection. This sample was taken the day after onset of symptoms, and\nwould have been too early to capture an IgM response. A convalescent\nsample has been requested.\n\nAnother case, who is a healthcare worker, had paired sera taken by\nthe Occupational Health Department, which showed a rising titre of\nmumps antibodies and was therefore confirmed as recent mumps\ninfection by the regional virology laboratory.\n\nSalivary swab samples of the remaining 21 clinical cases have been\nsubmitted to the reference laboratory at the Health Protection Agency\nCentre for Infections (CfI) at Colindale. The results for 3 cases\nhave been received to date and are as follows:\n\nCase 1: the samples were IgM-negative and IgG-positive (very high\ntitre), possibly indicating infection. A repeat salivary antibody\ntest has been requested to ascertain whether IgM titres have\nsubsequently risen.\n\nCase 2: the samples were IgM-negative and IgG-positive, although the\ntitre was not particularly high. This is consistent with past\nimmunisation, but does not allow confirmation of recent mumps\ninfection. The patient's general practitioner notes that it was a\nvery mild case of mumps.\n\nCase 3: the samples tested IgM-positive and IgG-positive (very high\ntitre). Recent mumps infection is confirmed.\n\nTwo recent cases have been swabbed within 48 hours of onset, and\ntheir samples will be tested by PCR [polymerase chain reaction] at\nthe CfI reference laboratory.\n\nDiscussion and conclusion\n-------------------------\nSalivary swabs are usually submitted 2 weeks after notification of\nclinical mumps. In this outbreak blood samples have been taken in\nindividual cases because of special circumstances. The laboratory\nresults to date indicate that this is a genuine outbreak of mumps,\nalthough the timing of some of the samples may not have been optimal\nfor capturing the antibody response.\n\nThis outbreak is different form the one described in Austria in 2008,\nwhere 49.1 percent of the young people affected had not been\nvaccinated (1). However, in the Netherlands, a number of fully\nvaccinated individuals were affected as part of an outbreak in a\npredominantly unvaccinated community in 2008 (2).\n\nUptake of MMR vaccination has historically been high in Anglesey, and\nthe majority of cases in the outbreak had received 2 doses. The lack\nof cases among unvaccinated individuals may reflect the high uptake\nof vaccine, and an investigation is ongoing to determine coverage\nrates for the birth cohorts involved. Current isolates from mumps\ncases in the UK have been identified as genotype G. Further tests are\nrequired in order to confirm that this is also the genotype for this outbreak.\n\nThe mumps component of the MMR vaccine does not provide the same high\nlevels of protection as the measles and rubella components. One dose\nprotects around 65 percent (62 percent-85 percent) of those who\nreceive it (3). A 2nd dose raises the effectiveness to around 85\npercent. This still leaves one in 6 recipients of 2 MMR doses\nvulnerable to mumps. This primary vaccine failure may be the\nexplanation for this outbreak, but the contribution of waning\nimmunity, secondary vaccine failure, must also be considered.\n\nInfection control measures\n--------------------------\nLetters have been sent to the school many of the cases attend,\nadvising that all children should ensure that they have received 2\ndoses of MMR vaccine. Letters have also been sent to general\npractitioners in the area alerting them to the fact that cases of\nmumps are occurring despite complete vaccination status, and\npreparing them for requests for MMR vaccination.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Schmid D, Holzmann H, Popow-Kraupp TH, Wallenko H, Allerberger F:\nMumps vaccine failure or vaccine scheme failure? Clin Microbiol\nInfect 2007.13(11): 1138-9.\n2. Karagiannis I, van Lier A, van Binnendijk R, Ruijs H, Fanoy E,\nConyn-Van Spaendonck, et al: Mumps in a community with low\nvaccination coverage in the Netherlands. Euro Surveill 2008; 13(24):\npii=18901. Available from\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=18901>.\n3. Cohen C, White JM, Savage EJ, Glynn JR, Choi Y, Andrews N, et al:\nVaccine effectiveness estimates, 2004-2005 mumps outbreak, England.\nEmerg Infect Dis 2007; 13(1): 12-7. Available from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/EID/13/1/pdfs/12.pdf>.\n\n[Reported by: C Roberts, G Porter-Jones, J Crocker, J Hart\nNorth Wales Health Protection Team, National Public Health Service\nfor Wales, Mold, Flintshire, United Kingdom]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the counties of Wales showing the Isle of Anglesey in the\nnorth is available at <http://www.walesdirectory.co.uk/counties.htm>\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United Kingdom is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=2657311&v=53.25,-4.333,5>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 5 Feb 2009\n \n\nAnother case, who is a healthcare worker, had paired sera taken by\nthe Occupational Health Department, which showed a rising titre of\nmumps antibodies and was therefore confirmed as recent mumps\ninfection by the regional virology laboratory. However, some\nof the older cases (over 17 years-old) in this outbreak will have\nreceived MMR vaccine containing the Urabe strain, which was used in\nthe UK from 1988 to 1992. Letters have also been sent to general\npractitioners in the area alerting them to the fact that cases of\nmumps are occurring despite complete vaccination status, and\npreparing them for requests for MMR vaccination. --------------------------\nLetters have been sent to the school many of the cases attend,\nadvising that all children should ensure that they have received 2\ndoses of MMR vaccine. The laboratory\nresults to date indicate that this is a genuine outbreak of mumps,\nalthough the timing of some of the samples may not have been optimal\nfor capturing the antibody response. The lack\nof cases among unvaccinated individuals may reflect the high uptake\nof vaccine, and an investigation is ongoing to determine coverage\nrates for the birth cohorts involved. Source: Eurosurveillance edition 2009; 14(5) [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19109>\n\n\nMumps outbreak on the island of Anglesey, North Wales, December\n2008-January 2009\n \n\n[Reported by: C Roberts, G Porter-Jones, J Crocker, J Hart\nNorth Wales Health Protection Team, National Public Health Service\nfor Wales, Mold, Flintshire, United Kingdom]\n\n--\n They received an\nincrease in notifications in the 1st week of December 2008, which\npeaked in the 2nd week of December, and it is plausible that the\nstudent was infected at this time. \n\nAn unusual feature of this outbreak is that 20 of the cases had\nreceived 2 doses of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine and 2\ncases had had one dose. The results for 3 cases\nhave been received to date and are as follows:\n\nCase 1: the samples were IgM-negative and IgG-positive (very high\ntitre), possibly indicating infection. The 1st case reported on 27 Dec 2008 was a student in Manchester\nwhere, as confirmed by the Health Protection Unit, a number of mumps\ncases have occurred among students in recent weeks. All cases\nhave social links, and most of them have received 2 doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine. \n\nTwo recent cases have been swabbed within 48 hours of onset, and\ntheir samples will be tested by PCR [polymerase chain reaction] at\nthe CfI reference laboratory. \n\nSalivary swab samples of the remaining 21 clinical cases have been\nsubmitted to the reference laboratory at the Health Protection Agency\n \n\nThis outbreak is different form the one described in Austria in 2008,\nwhere 49.1 percent of the young people affected had not been\nvaccinated (1). Since 27 Dec 2008, the North Wales Health Protection Team of the\nNational Public Health Service for Wales has been notified of 23\ncases of clinical mumps. Current isolates from mumps\ncases in the UK have been identified as genotype G. Further tests are\nrequired in order to confirm that this is also the genotype for this outbreak. This was reported as negative for IgM against\nmumps virus, but positive for IgG with no evidence of recent\ninfection.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1138-09-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-02-05 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-12-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Flintshire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mold", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anglesey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "151992", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Macedonia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=151992", "date": "2009-01-31 22:00:44", "main_text": "MUMPS - MACEDONIA\n*****************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 31 Jan 2009\nFrom: Marija PopStefanija\n<marija_popstefanija@yahoo.com>\nSource: Dnevnik\n<http://www.dnevnik.com.mk/?ItemID=11B0C9E112E25E448739E96DF7A7AAAA>\n& Nova Makedonia\n\n[in Macedonian, trans. by submitter, edited]\n\n\nMumps outbreak in the Republic of Macedonia\n-------------------------------------------\nAn increase of cases of mumps has been reported in the Republic of\nMacedonia since last year [2008], including outbreaks in 12 different\ntowns. In the Clinic of Infectious Diseases (Medical Faculty,\nUniversity of Skopje) in January 2009 alone, there were 234 cases of\nmumps reported, including 50 who were hospitalized, 20 with a\ncomplication of orchitis [inflammation of the testes] and 18 with\nmeningitis. In the State Institute of Health, they are reporting 16\npercent of the mumps cases have complications, and more than half are\nteenagers between 15-19.\n\nAbout one third of the cases have received one mumps vaccination and\nsome have received 2 doses. The vaccine was introduced as a school\nrequirement in 1982. Until 1997, only one dose of the vaccine was\nrequired. The World Health Organization is now recommending 2 doses\nof the vaccine. The vaccine was not available due to a shortage in\nMacedonia from 1990-1994 and a lot of children at that time were not\nvaccinated. In December of 2008, the vaccine recommendation was\nextended to the age group 15-19.\n\nThe director of the Clinic of Infectious Diseases in Skopje, Zvonko\nMilenkovic, said that government has requested that the WHO help them\nwith tests to determine if the vaccine is protective against the virus\nthat is circulating. What is happening in Macedonia, he said, is\nsimilar to what happened to Western European countries like\nSwitzerland and England, and in the United States as well. In 1993,\nUNICEF donated mumps vaccines to Macedonia, but in the past 6 years\nall of the vaccines have been purchased from 2 companies, Pasteur and\nGlaxoSmithKline.\n\n--\nMarija PopStefanija, MPH, MS\nEpidemiologist\nMass Department of Public Health\nWestern Mass Public Health Center\nN424 Morril Bld. UMass\nAmherst, MA 01002\n<marija.popstefanija@state.ma.us>\n\n[These reports reflect continuing problems in achieving eradication\nof mumps by vaccination. UMass\nAmherst, MA 01002\n<marija.popstefanija@state.ma.us>\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-01-25 00:00:00", "1982-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "1993-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-12-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Macedonian", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macedonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Macedonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "126048", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, students - UK: (England)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=126048", "date": "2008-11-08 12:00:36", "main_text": "MUMPS, STUDENTS - UK: (ENGLAND)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 7 Nov 2008\nSource: This is Gloucestershire.co.uk [edited]\n<http://www.thisisgloucestershire.co.uk/latestnews/Students-Gloucestershire-red-alert-mumps-outbreak/article-456770-detail/\narticle.html>\n\n\nStudents on red alert after mumps outbreak\n------------------------------------------\nStudents at the University of Gloucestershire [in the west of England] are\non alert following a mumps outbreak. A total of 10 students in Cheltenham\nand Gloucester have been diagnosed with the infection and the number is\nexpected to rise. Health officials are now working at the university's 4\ncampuses in Cheltenham and Gloucester, which house more than 9500 full and\npart time students, in an effort to contain the outbreak. The Health\nProtection Agency is working with the university and is checking all\nsuspected cases of the illness that have been reported in the past 2 weeks.\n\nA warning letter has been sent to all students from the university's\nmedical officer, urging them to check for symptoms. Students and staff\nunder the age of 25 have been asked to check if they have had the MMR\n[measles, mumps, and rubella] jab and consult their GP [general\npractitioner]. They are also urged not to mix with other students for a\nweek if mumps is suspected. Mumps virus is highly contagious and in severe\ncases can cause deafness, viral meningitis, and infertility.\n\nLawrence Knight, of the Health Protection Agency South West, said: 'We are\nawaiting the test results from 3 students to ascertain whether these are\nisolated [cases]. The university's medical officer has taken a proactive\napproach by warning students, and that is quite right so people can look\nout for symptoms [of] mumps. This is an illness that can spread as easily\nas the flu. For some it is a mild infection and for others it is much more\nunpleasant. We would urge anyone who is concerned about symptoms to see\ntheir GP as soon as possible.'\n\nA spokesman for the University of Gloucestershire said: 'We believe around\n10 students have contracted mumps and have been diagnosed at the\nuniversity's medical centre. This is a small isolated outbreak. Students\nliving in Gloucestershire can go to their local GP or to the university\nmedical centre for an MMR jab if they are concerned.'\n\nAndrew Gravells, chairman of Gloucestershire's Health Overview and Scrutiny\nCommittee, added: 'This could be potentially very serious for the people\naffected and I would urge students and staff at the university to act on\nthe good advice that's being made available.' Cheltenham based students or\nstaff can call the University Medical Centre on 01242 714400. Gloucester\nstudents can call 01452 522709.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps virus infection in young adults is likely to be a consequence of\nincomplete or absence of MMR vaccination in their earlier years. The\nsymptoms of mumps are fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of\nappetite; followed by swelling of salivary glands. The parotid salivary\nglands are most frequently affected. Severe complications are rare, but\nmumps can cause inflammation of the brain and/or tissue covering the brain\nand spinal cord (encephalitis/meningitis), inflammation of the testicles\n(orchitis), inflammation of the ovaries and/or breasts (oophoritis and\nmastitis), spontaneous abortion, and deafness.\n\nMumps virus replicates in the upper respiratory tract and is spread through\ndirect contact with respiratory secretions or saliva or through fomites.\nThe infectious period, or time that an infected person can transmit mumps\nto a non-infected person, is from 3 days before symptoms appear to about 9\ndays after the symptoms appear. The incubation time, which is the period\nfrom when a person is exposed to virus to the onset of any symptoms, can\nvary from 16 to 18 days (range 12-25 days).\n\nA map of the counties of England showing the location of Gloucestershire\ncan be accessed at\n<http://www.picturesofengland.com/mapofengland/counties-map.html>, and the\nlocations of Gloucester and Cheltenham can be found using the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United Kingdom at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed? v=54.5,-2,5>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "\n\nA map of the counties of England showing the location of Gloucestershire\ncan be accessed at\n<http://www.picturesofengland.com/mapofengland/counties-map.html>, and the\nlocations of Gloucester and Cheltenham can be found using the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United Kingdom at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed? A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 7 Nov 2008\n Severe complications are rare, but\nmumps can cause inflammation of the brain and/or tissue covering the brain\nand spinal cord (encephalitis/meningitis), inflammation of the testicles\n(orchitis), inflammation of the ovaries and/or breasts (oophoritis and\nmastitis), spontaneous abortion, and deafness. \n\nAndrew Gravells, chairman of Gloucestershire's Health Overview and Scrutiny\nCommittee, added: 'This could be potentially very serious for the people\naffected and I would urge students and staff at the university to act on\nthe good advice that's being made available.' \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< \n\nA spokesman for the University of Gloucestershire said: 'We believe around\n10 students have contracted mumps and have been diagnosed at the\nuniversity's medical centre. The infectious period, or time that an infected person can transmit mumps\nto a non-infected person, is from 3 days before symptoms appear to about 9\ndays after the symptoms appear. The university's medical officer has taken a proactive\napproach by warning students, and that is quite right so people can look\nout for symptoms [of] mumps. The incubation time, which is the period\nfrom when a person is exposed to virus to the onset of any symptoms, can\nvary from 16 to 18 days (range 12-25 days). \n\nLawrence Knight, of the Health Protection Agency South West, said: 'We are\nawaiting the test results from 3 students to ascertain whether these are\nisolated [cases]. Health officials are now working at the university's 4\ncampuses in Cheltenham and Gloucester, which house more than 9500 full and\npart time students, in an effort to contain the outbreak.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "72741", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Ireland: (Limerick)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=72741", "date": "2008-04-16 12:00:22", "main_text": "MUMPS - IRELAND: (LIMERICK)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 15 Apr 2008\nSource: Limerick Post [edited]\n<http://www.limerickpost.ie/dailynews.elive?id=8747&category=Daily-Tue>\n\n\nMumps and measles alert\n-----------------------\nThe Department of Public Health in Limerick [province of Munster] has\nrecently been notified of 18 cases of mumps across the Mid-West area,\nwith over half of these amongst students at the University of\nLimerick (UL). GPs (general practitioners) in Limerick have been\nalerted to the increased cases, which comes at a time when Ireland\nhas also been shown to have one of the worst records in Europe at\nfighting measles.\n\nLow uptake of the MMR [mumps, measles, and rubella] vaccination,\nwhich currently stands at 77 per cent, makes Ireland one of 4\ncountries named and shamed in a World Health Organisation (WHO)\nsurvey as having particularly low immunity to measles, mumps, and\nrubella among adults and children.\n\nIn the University of Limerick, close contacts have been offered\nimmunisation through the Student Health Service and GPs across the\nMid-West have been put on the alert for symptoms. The HSE [Health\nService Executive] is advising students on the UL campus to ensure\nthat they are protected against mumps unless they are already immune.\nImmunity to mumps will result from having either received 2 doses of\nthe MMR vaccine in the past; been immunised during the outbreak of\nmumps that occurred at UL in March 2005, or already have had clinical\nmumps. According to a spokesperson from the HSE, most of those born\nsince 1988 have had 2 doses of MMR vaccine.\n\n'If people are definitely not immune nor certain, they should seek\nmedical advice through their GP or Student Health Centre as to\nwhether they need a dose of the MMR vaccine to protect them at this\ntime. University staff who think that they are not immune have been\nadvised to attend their own general practitioner for this vaccine,'\nhe advised.\n\nMeanwhile, deputy Jan O'Sullivan, is calling for an urgent campaign\nto encourage parents to immunise their children, to prevent a measles\nepidemic.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[A vaccination coverage rate of 77 per cent is considered\nunsatisfactory from a public health standpoint as the pool of\nsusceptibles remains at a level that will support continued\ntransmission of the measles virus, and the mumps virus as well.\n\nProMED-mail has had numerous postings mentioning the challenges faced\nin several countries as a result of the anti-vaccine lobby that has\nresulted in lower coverages with measles-containing vaccines. It is a\npity that the anti-vaccine lobby hasn't been reviewing the data and\nliterature to see the actual impact of measles seen in the\npre-vaccine era, with immediate complications (primary measles\npneumonia, encephalitis, severe diarrhea with dehydration, and death\nrelated to these complications) and subacute to delayed\ncomplications, such as sub-acute sclerosing panencephalitis. - Mod.MPP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Ireland can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=53.2,-8.2,5>.\nLimerick is located in the mid-western part of the country. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "It is a\npity that the anti-vaccine lobby hasn't been reviewing the data and\nliterature to see the actual impact of measles seen in the\npre-vaccine era, with immediate complications (primary measles\npneumonia, encephalitis, severe diarrhea with dehydration, and death\nrelated to these complications) and subacute to delayed\ncomplications, such as sub-acute sclerosing panencephalitis. - Mod. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 15 Apr 2008\n \n\nLow uptake of the MMR [mumps, measles, and rubella] vaccination,\nwhich currently stands at 77 per cent, makes Ireland one of 4\ncountries named and shamed in a World Health Organisation (WHO)\nsurvey as having particularly low immunity to measles, mumps, and\nrubella among adults and children. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[A vaccination coverage rate of 77 per cent is considered\nunsatisfactory from a public health standpoint as the pool of\nsusceptibles remains at a level that will support continued\ntransmission of the measles virus, and the mumps virus as well. Immunity to mumps will result from having either received 2 doses of\nthe MMR vaccine in the past; been immunised during the outbreak of\nmumps that occurred at UL in March 2005, or already have had clinical\nmumps. \n\n'If people are definitely not immune nor certain, they should seek\nmedical advice through their GP or Student Health Centre as to\nwhether they need a dose of the MMR vaccine to protect them at this\ntime. GPs (general practitioners) in Limerick have been\nalerted to the increased cases, which comes at a time when Ireland\nhas also been shown to have one of the worst records in Europe at\nfighting measles. The Department of Public Health in Limerick [province of Munster] has\nrecently been notified of 18 cases of mumps across the Mid-West area,\nwith over half of these amongst students at the University of\nLimerick (UL).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Limerick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "78512", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, students - UK: (London)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=78512", "date": "2008-05-08 18:00:21", "main_text": "MUMPS, STUDENTS - UNITED KINGDOM: (LONDON)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 6 May 2008\nSource: Your Local Guardian online [edited]\n<http://www.epsomguardian.co.uk/news/topstories/display.var.2251007.0.mumps_outbreak_at_kingston_university.php>\n\nKingston University [London, UK] students have been urged to attend\nemergency immunisation clinics this week, after 20 suspected cases of\nmumps were reported in the last month. Already, 5 students have been\ndiagnosed with the highly contagious virus, which causes swelling of\nthe neck and face, fever and earache, as well as deafness and severe\nabdominal pain in more serious cases.\n\nIn males over 12, it can lead to inflammation of the testicles and --\nin rare cases -- sterility. More cases at the university are\nsuspected, leading to fears of a repeat of the last scare there in\n2005, when 548 vulnerable staff and students were given emergency vaccinations.\n\nThe university has already sent a warning email to all campus-goers\nhighlighting the risks of mumps and detailing how they can get\nprotected at campus drop-in clinics.\n\nDr Paul Crook, consultant in communicable disease control at the\nSouth-west London Health Protection Unit, said: 'We are working\nclosely with Kingston University to help prevent further cases of\nmumps. We strongly recommend that students at the university who have\nnot been immunised with 2 doses of MMR [measles, mumps, and rubella\nvaccine] take this opportunity to ensure they are adequately\nprotected from the virus.'\n\nGill Deane, head of the university's health and counselling service,\nsaid: 'We take the health of our students and staff very seriously\nand are confident that the steps we are taking working with the\nhealth protection unit will minimise the impact of the illness on campus.\n\n'About 140 vaccinations have now been given and we would urge any\nstudents who have not been immunised to get in touch with their GP,\nor attend one of the drop-in immunisation sessions.'\n\n[Byline: Mike Didymus, Ian Paynton]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The majority of these cases are likely to be students who for\nwhatever reason were not vaccinated in childhood, or received only\none of the 2 doses of MMR vaccine necessary to provide complete immunity.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED interactive map of the UK can be used to locate\nKingston-on-Thames, the site of Kingston University London, just\nsouthwest of the centre of London\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=54.5,-2,5>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 6 May 2008\n \n\nGill Deane, head of the university's health and counselling service,\nsaid: 'We take the health of our students and staff very seriously\nand are confident that the steps we are taking working with the\nhealth protection unit will minimise the impact of the illness on campus. Source: Your Local Guardian online [edited]\n<http://www.epsomguardian.co.uk/news/topstories/display.var.2251007.0.mumps_outbreak_at_kingston_university.php>\n\nKingston University [London, UK] students have been urged to attend\nemergency immunisation clinics this week, after 20 suspected cases of\nmumps were reported in the last month. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The majority of these cases are likely to be students who for\nwhatever reason were not vaccinated in childhood, or received only\none of the 2 doses of MMR vaccine necessary to provide complete immunity. We strongly recommend that students at the university who have\nnot been immunised with 2 doses of MMR [measles, mumps, and rubella\nvaccine] take this opportunity to ensure they are adequately\nprotected from the virus.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LONDON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "87754", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (03): (BC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=87754", "date": "2008-06-15 22:00:24", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (03): (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 13 Jun 2008\nSource: The Province online [edited]\n<http://www.canada.com/theprovince/news/story.html?id=34086d7e-0ee4-4493-b24c-d6af2bd70521>\n\n\nHealth officials are reminding all children and adults to make sure\ntheir immunizations are up to date after an outbreak of 47 cases of\nmumps in the eastern Fraser Valley, most of them in Chilliwack.\n'Certainly, the number of cases is unusual,' said Dr. Nadine Loewen\nof the Fraser Health Authority. She said last year [2007], there were\n11 cases in the area but none in 2003 and 2005, and the 2nd-largest\noutbreak of 34 cases dates back to 1997.\n\nThe virus, which affects the salivary glands and causes swollen\ncheeks, among other symptoms, has affected all ages, from a\n2-year-old to a 59-year-old, said Loewen. It's likely a person who\nwasn't immunized against mumps picked up the virus in Alberta, where\nthere is also an outbreak, and spread it to others who weren't\nimmunized. There are also sporadic cases in Abbotsford, Agassiz and\nMission, and officials are determining whether they're connected to\nthe Chilliwack outbreak. She said the high number of cases this year\n[2008] compared with the last 10 years is due to the fact that the\nvirus can take hold and then pick up speed if those affected spread\nit to others who aren't immunized.\n\nThe virus is spread through saliva and can be picked up by sharing a\nwater bottle, glass or cigarette, or through coughing. About 90 per\ncent of the population is immunized, and anyone born after 1956 and\nlikely after 1970 has a natural immunity to it because of exposure to\nmumps as a child, said Loewen.\n\nSymptoms include fatigue, muscle aches and pains, and coughing. Those\nwith the mumps are infectious generally for 9 days after the swelling\nbegins and should stay at home, she said. It can cause swollen\ntesticles or ovaries and lead to sterility and, in rare cases, cause\ninflammation of the brain. For more information on immunization, go to\n<http://www.bchealthguide.org/immunization.stm>.\n\n[Byline: Susan Lazaruk]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Five laboratory-confirmed cases of mumps in Chilliwack were reported\nin ProMED-mail on 14 Mar 2008 (see: Mumps - Canada: (BC)\n20080311.0980. This outbreak appears not to have been contained.\n\nMumps virus, the causative agent of mumps disease, is a paramyxovirus\nclassified in the genus_ Rubulavirus_ of the sub-family\n_Paramyxovirinae_. It is possible that a outsider initiated this\noutbreak in a community containing a few partially vaccinated or\nunvaccinated individuals.\n\nMumps vaccine has had a checkered history. It is now normally\nadministered as a component of the triple MMR (Mumps, Measles and\nRubella) vaccine. The current vaccine is effective, and children\nshould be given the 1st dose of MMR vaccine soon after the 1st\nbirthday (12 to 15 months of age). The 2nd dose is recommended before\nthe start of kindergarten. The current 'Jeryl Lynn' strain of mumps\nvaccine was developed by Dr. Maurice Hillman from the mumps virus\nthat infected his 5-year-old daughter (whose name was Jeryl Lynn).\nOriginally, just one dose of the MMR vaccine was recommended. In\n1989, the American Academy of Family Physicians, the American Academy\nof Pediatrics, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's\nAdvisory Committee on Immunization Practices, changed the\nrecommendation to 2 doses, primarily to immunize the small percent of\npeople who do not respond to the measles component of the MMR\nvaccine. Immunity to mumps virus infection is important for adults at\nhigh risk of exposure to mumps infection, including college students\nand health care workers. People born before 1957 are generally\nconsidered immune to mumps through environmental exposure in their youth.\n\nThroughout Canada, there have been occasional outbreaks of mumps in\nuniversity students and others of the same age (see references\nbelow). In the event of a mumps outbreak, students may not be allowed\nto remain in school unless they are vaccinated or have other proof of\nimmunity. Those who remain susceptible should be excluded from school\nuntil at least 26 days after the onset of mumps in the last infected\nperson at that school.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the Canadian province of\nBritish Columbia showing the location of Chilliwack some 50 miles to\nthe east of Vancouver, can be accessed at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=55.4,-101.9,4>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "In\n1989, the American Academy of Family Physicians, the American Academy\nof Pediatrics, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's\nAdvisory Committee on Immunization Practices, changed the\nrecommendation to 2 doses, primarily to immunize the small percent of\npeople who do not respond to the measles component of the MMR\nvaccine. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 13 Jun 2008\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Five laboratory-confirmed cases of mumps in Chilliwack were reported\nin ProMED-mail on 14 Mar 2008 (see: Mumps - Canada: (BC)\n It's likely a person who\nwasn't immunized against mumps picked up the virus in Alberta, where\nthere is also an outbreak, and spread it to others who weren't\nimmunized. About 90 per\ncent of the population is immunized, and anyone born after 1956 and\nlikely after 1970 has a natural immunity to it because of exposure to\nmumps as a child, said Loewen. \n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the Canadian province of\nBritish Columbia showing the location of Chilliwack some 50 miles to\nthe east of Vancouver, can be accessed at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=55.4,-101.9,4>. The current 'Jeryl Lynn' strain of mumps\nvaccine was developed by Dr. Maurice Hillman from the mumps virus\nthat infected his 5-year-old daughter (whose name was Jeryl Lynn). Immunity to mumps virus infection is important for adults at\nhigh risk of exposure to mumps infection, including college students\nand health care workers. \n\nThe virus, which affects the salivary glands and causes swollen\ncheeks, among other symptoms, has affected all ages, from a\n2-year-old to a 59-year-old, said Loewen. She said last year [2007], there were\n11 cases in the area but none in 2003 and 2005, and the 2nd-largest\noutbreak of 34 cases dates back to 1997. Health officials are reminding all children and adults to make sure\ntheir immunizations are up to date after an outbreak of 47 cases of\nmumps in the eastern Fraser Valley, most of them in Chilliwack. In the event of a mumps outbreak, students may not be allowed\nto remain in school unless they are vaccinated or have other proof of\nimmunity. The current vaccine is effective, and children\nshould be given the 1st dose of MMR vaccine soon after the 1st\nbirthday (12 to 15 months of age).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1970-03-25 00:00:00", "1956-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1989-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "69587", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Australia: (WA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=69587", "date": "2008-03-31 17:00:21", "main_text": "MUMPS - AUSTRALIA: (WESTERN AUSTRALIA)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 31 Mar 2008\nSource: WA News thewest.com.au [edited]\n<http://www.thewest.com.au/default.aspx?MenuID=77&ContentID=65320>\n\n\nMumps outbreak spreads to WA from NT cases\n------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of mumps, which appears to have spread to Western\nAustralia (WA) from the Northern Territory (NT), has caused about 10\ntimes the usual number of cases so far this year [2008]. A total of\n46 cases of the childhood infection had been reported to health\nauthorities by the middle of last month [February 20008] compared\nwith 4 cases at the same time last year and 6 in early 2006.\n\nThe Health Department, which is investigating the outbreak, described\nthe number of cases as surprising and well above normal. They\nappeared to be part of an outbreak which started in a boarding school\nin the Northern Territory last year [2008] and spread firstly into\nthe Kimberley and then into other parts of WA. While most of this\nyear's cases have been in the Kimberley and the Goldfields, several\nhave been reported in the metropolitan area [Perth].\n\nMumps is a contagious infection caused by a virus and occurs mainly\nin school-aged children. It had become rarer thanks to the MMR\nvaccine which protects against mumps, measles and rubella and is\ngiven to children when they are babies and as they start preschool.\nInfection spreads when a person breathes in the mumps virus that has\nbeen coughed or sneezed into the air by an infectious person. The\nmumps virus can also spread from person to person via direct contact\nwith infected saliva. Serious complications from the mumps are\nuncommon but can include inflammation of the brain, spinal cord and\npancreas, hearing loss and sterility.\n\nThe department's director of communicable disease control, Paul Van\nBuynder, said that although parents needed to ensure their children\nwere properly immunised against mumps, there was no evidence that the\nspike in cases was because fewer children were being vaccinated.\n\n'We have always known that mumps vaccine is not as effective as the\nmeasles vaccine, but the rate of disease is surprising,' he said.\n'The Communicable Disease Control Directorate is conducting a\ndetailed study with NT Health to investigate why this has happened.\nThere is no indication at present that this represents low\nvaccination levels. The Department of Health continues to encourage\nparents to make sure their children's immunisations are up-to-date.'\n\nThe routine time for the MMR vaccination is at 12 months then again at 4 years.\n\n[Byline: Cathy O'Leary]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\nThe interactive HealthMap of Australia can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=-25.7,134.5,4> to show the location of\nthe state of Western Australia. The Kimberley district is located in\nthe northeastern part of the state (see map at\n<http://www.ozhorizons.com.au/wa/map.htm>) with the Goldfields\ndistrict lying to the south.\n\nCorresponding information for the mumps outbreak in the Northern\nTerritory would be appreciated. It is not clear whether the outbreak\nin Western Australia is a consequence of inadequate vaccine coverage\nor is a problem of vaccine efficacy. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 31 Mar 2008\n The department's director of communicable disease control, Paul Van\nBuynder, said that although parents needed to ensure their children\nwere properly immunised against mumps, there was no evidence that the\nspike in cases was because fewer children were being vaccinated. A total of\n46 cases of the childhood infection had been reported to health\nauthorities by the middle of last month [February 20008] compared\nwith 4 cases at the same time last year and 6 in early 2006. They\nappeared to be part of an outbreak which started in a boarding school\nin the Northern Territory last year [2008] and spread firstly into\nthe Kimberley and then into other parts of WA. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\nThe interactive HealthMap of Australia can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=-25.7,134.5,4> to show the location of\nthe state of Western Australia. The Kimberley district is located in\nthe northeastern part of the state (see map at\n<http://www.ozhorizons.com.au/wa/map.htm>) with the Goldfields\ndistrict lying to the south.
