It had become rarer thanks to the MMR\nvaccine which protects against mumps, measles and rubella and is\ngiven to children when they are babies and as they start preschool. Source: WA News thewest.com.au [edited]\n<http://www.thewest.com.au/default.aspx?MenuID=77&ContentID=65320>\n\n\nMumps outbreak spreads to WA from NT cases\n The\nmumps virus can also spread from person to person via direct contact\nwith infected saliva.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "106418", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (05): (BC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=106418", "date": "2008-08-27 18:00:30", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (05): (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 26 Aug 2008\nSource: seattlepi.com, Associated Press report [edited]\n<http://seattlepi.nwsource.com/local/6420ap_canada_mumps_outbreak.html>\n\n\nMumps outbreak in British Columbia's Fraser Valley\n--------------------------------------------------\nAGASSIZ: A growing mumps outbreak has been reported in the Fraser Valley,\neast of Vancouver and north of Washington state's Whatcom County. About 200\npeople have been verified to have the virus in areas as far west as Burnaby\nin the Vancouver suburbs, Dr Elizabeth Brodkin, medical health officer for\nthe Fraser Health Authority, said on Tuesday.\n\nIn an average year, fewer than 100 cases are reported across Canada. The\nBritish Columbia Centre for Disease Control is convening a provincial task\nforce to meet in two weeks to develop a strategy for combatting the\noutbreak, Brodkin said. Mumps is spread through saliva, and health\nofficials warned against the sharing of water bottles, drinking cups,\nmusical instruments, and cigarettes as well as coughing and sneezing\nwithout covering the nose and mouth. 'We've tried to do advertising to the\ngeneral public about the importance of not sharing spit because that's how\nthis thing has spread,' she said. 'We're calling it the don't-share-spit\ncampaign.'\n\nThe virus arrived in British Columbia from Alberta, where 300 people were\ninfected, and spread through a Fraser Valley religious group that shuns\nimmunization, Brodkin said. 'It's part of their belief system that this is\nnot the right thing to do,' she said. 'This outbreak, at least, got going\nbecause it took hold in an unimmunized community, so they are the ones who\nare really sitting ducks for infection.'\n\nAbout a third of those who are infected with the virus don't have any\nsymptoms but could still be spreading it. Symptoms include swelling of the\nglands under the jaw and chin and can be as severe as meningitis or\ninflamed testicles. Immunity to mumps dissipates over time, and people\nwho've had the disease 30 years ago could contract it again unless they are\nrevaccinated, Brodkin said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Previous outbreaks of mumps in Canada have been associated predominantly\nwith the dispersal of young adults from educational institutions.\nInvolvement of religious communities which do not permit vaccination has\nbeen less common, although elsewhere frequently outbreaks of measles have\ninvolved such communities. The mumps outbreak described above appears to be\nan extension of the outbreak further west at Chilliwack (see: Mumps -\nCanada (03): (BC) 20080615.1890) and involves a larger number of cases.\n\nMumps vaccine has had a checkered history. It is now normally administered\nas a component of the triple MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) vaccine. The\ncurrent vaccine is effective, and children should be given the 1st dose of\nMMR vaccine soon after the 1st birthday (12 to 15 months of age). The 2nd\ndose is recommended before the start of kindergarten. The current 'Jeryl\nLynn' strain of mumps vaccine was developed by Dr Maurice Hillman from the\nmumps virus that infected his 5 year old daughter (whose name was Jeryl\nLynn). Originally, just one dose of the MMR vaccine was recommended. In\n1989, the American Academy of Family Physicians, the American Academy of\nPediatrics, and the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's\nAdvisory Committee on Immunization Practices, changed the recommendation to\n2 doses.\n\nImmunity to mumps virus infection is important for adults at high risk of\nexposure to mumps infection, including college students and health care\nworkers. People born before 1957 are generally considered immune to mumps\nthrough environmental exposure in their youth.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Canada can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=55.4,-101.9,4> to locate British Columbia. A\nmap of the Fraser Valley showing Chilliwack and Agassiz can be accessed at\n<http://www.bchomesforsale.com/maps/ fraservalleymap.htm>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 26 Aug 2008\n In\n1989, the American Academy of Family Physicians, the American Academy of\nPediatrics, and the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's\nAdvisory Committee on Immunization Practices, changed the recommendation to\n2 doses. The current 'Jeryl\nLynn' strain of mumps vaccine was developed by Dr Maurice Hillman from the\nmumps virus that infected his 5 year old daughter (whose name was Jeryl\nLynn). Mumps is spread through saliva, and health\nofficials warned against the sharing of water bottles, drinking cups,\nmusical instruments, and cigarettes as well as coughing and sneezing\nwithout covering the nose and mouth. ' About 200\npeople have been verified to have the virus in areas as far west as Burnaby\nin the Vancouver suburbs, Dr Elizabeth Brodkin, medical health officer for\nthe Fraser Health Authority, said on Tuesday. The\nBritish Columbia Centre for Disease Control is convening a provincial task\nforce to meet in two weeks to develop a strategy for combatting the\noutbreak, Brodkin said. \n\nImmunity to mumps virus infection is important for adults at high risk of\nexposure to mumps infection, including college students and health care\nworkers. \n\nThe virus arrived in British Columbia from Alberta, where 300 people were\ninfected, and spread through a Fraser Valley religious group that shuns\nimmunization The\ncurrent vaccine is effective, and children should be given the 1st dose of\nMMR vaccine soon after the 1st birthday (12 to 15 months of age). Immunity to mumps dissipates over time, and people\nwho've had the disease 30 years ago could contract it again unless they are\nrevaccinated, Brodkin said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1989-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Whatcom County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "101909", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (04): (ON)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=101909", "date": "2008-08-10 01:00:29", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (04): (ONTARIO)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 8 Aug 2008\nSource: The London Free Press online [edited]\n<http://lfpress.ca/newsstand/News/Local/2008/08/08/6383901-sun.html>\n\n\nMumps found in 10 cases in Oxford County\n----------------------------------------\nPublic health officials have scheduled 2 immunization clinics next\nweek [11-13 Aug 2008] following an outbreak of mumps in Oxford\nCounty, Ontario, Canada. A total of 10 cases of mumps have been\nconfirmed, primarily in Norwich Township. A percentage of the\nNetherlands Reformed community who live there have not received the\nMMR vaccine that protects against measles, mumps and rubella. 'All 10\nwere unimmunized people,' said Mike Bragg, director of Oxford County\nPublic Health and Emergency Services.\n\nMumps is a viral illness with symptoms that include fever, headache,\nmuscle aches, fatigue, and swelling and pain in salivary glands. Some\nchildren may also experience cold symptoms. Complications from mumps\ncan be serious, including encephalitis, meningitis, arthritis or\ndeafness. One in 3 men may develop painful swollen testicles that, in\nrare cases, result in infertility. Pregnant women with mumps are also\nat an increased risk for miscarriage during their 1st trimester.\n\nEvery year there are on average about 20 cases of mumps in Ontario.\nOther provinces with current outbreaks of mumps include British\nColumbia and Alberta. The Netherlands is also reporting an outbreak.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps in Canada have shown that young adults, who have\nreceived only one dose of mumps vaccine, may also be at risk of\ndeveloping the disease, Bragg said. Oxford County public health\nreceived a report 30 Jul 2008 from an out-of-county hospital that\nblood work from a patient from Norwich indicated a diagnosis of\nmumps, a reportable disease.\n\nAn investigation revealed the cases of mumps date back to May [2008].\nThe MMR vaccine for these groups in the Norwich area is available\nfrom family doctors and clinics offered by public health. The 1st\nclinic will be held at the Norwich Community Centre on Monday [11 Aug\n2008] from 3 p.m. to 7 p.m. A 2nd clinic will be at the Norwich\nTownship office in Otterville on Wednesday [13 Aug 2008] from 3 p.m. to 7 p.m.\n\nIn 2005, an outbreak of measles spread quickly throughout the\nunimmunized population of Rehoboth Christian School in Norwich, whose\n651 pupils are members of the Netherlands Reformed community. A final\ntally of labconfirmed reports topped out at 283 cases of rubella\nwithin county borders.\n\n[Byline: Heather Rivers]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Religious communities which decline MMR vaccine continue to be at\nrisk of mumps and rubella infection in addition to the highly\ncontagious measles virus infection. Recently ProMED-mail reported a\nchain of outbreaks of measles virus infection through\nvaccine-rejecting communities in Europe, and a possible Canadian link\nto a measles outbreak in one such community in The Netherlands\n(Measles, anthroposophic community - The Netherlands (02):\n(Hague) 20080802.2370; Measles, anthroposophic community - The\nNetherlands: (The Hague) 20080731.2353).\n\nA map of Oxford county, showing the location of Norwich township is\navailable at:\n<http://www.county.oxford.on.ca/>. The HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of Canada at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed? v=55.4,-101.9,4> can be used to locate\nthe province of Ontario. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 8 Aug 2008\n Recently ProMED-mail reported a\nchain of outbreaks of measles virus infection through\nvaccine-rejecting communities in Europe, and a possible Canadian link\nto a measles outbreak in one such community in The Netherlands\n A 2nd clinic will be at the Norwich\nTownship office in Otterville on Wednesday [13 Aug 2008] from 3 p.m. to 7 p.m.\n\nIn 2005, an outbreak of measles spread quickly throughout the\nunimmunized population of Rehoboth Christian School in Norwich, whose\n651 pupils are members of the Netherlands Reformed community. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Religious communities which decline MMR vaccine continue to be at\nrisk of mumps and rubella infection in addition to the highly\ncontagious measles virus infection. Oxford County public health\nreceived a report 30 Jul 2008 from an out-of-county hospital that\nblood work from a patient from Norwich indicated a diagnosis of\nmumps, a reportable disease. A percentage of the\nNetherlands Reformed community who live there have not received the\nMMR vaccine that protects against measles, mumps and rubella. ' have shown that young adults, who have\nreceived only one dose of mumps vaccine, may also be at risk of\ndeveloping the disease, Bragg said. The 1st\nclinic will be held at the Norwich Community Centre on Monday [11 Aug\n2008] from 3 p.m. to 7 p.m. (Measles, anthroposophic community - The Netherlands (02):\n(Hague) 20080802.2370; Measles, anthroposophic community - The\nNetherlands: (The Hague) 20080731.2353). Source: The London Free Press online [edited]\n<http://lfpress.ca/newsstand/News/Local/2008/08/08/6383901-sun.html>\n\n\nMumps found in 10 cases in Oxford County\n \n\nA map of Oxford county, showing the location of Norwich township is\navailable at:\n<http://www.county.oxford.on.ca/>.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-11-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oxford", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norwich Township", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Otterville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Hague", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oxford County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "69469", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=69469", "date": "2008-03-30 23:00:26", "main_text": "MUMPS - MOLDOVA, PRIDNESTROVYE (04)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 26 Mar 2008\nSource: NR2 News Agency [trans. Mod.NR, edited]\n<http://www.nr2.ru/>\n<http://tiraspol.info/2008/03/26/v-pridnestrove-zafiksirovana-novaya-vspyshka-infekcionnogo-parotita/>\n\n\nAn outbreak of mumps has been registered among local school children\nin Novokomissarovka village in the Dubosar district of Pridnestrovye.\nIt was recognized simultaneously in 3 children, one of whom suffered\ncomplications. According to public health physician Valeriy\nPishnograev, as the incubation period for mumps is 23 days, the\nschool will be closed for a quarantine period. After the spring\nbreak, children will be allowed to return to school only after\nmedical check-up by an infectious diseases specialist.\n\nSince the beginning of the year [2008], 19 people have been infected\nwith mumps in the Dubosar district. The local infectious diseases\ndoctors are assuming that mumps has spread to the Pridnestrovye\nregion from Moldavia [outside of Russia, usually rendered as Moldova\n- Mod.CP]. Already by December 2007, the disease had become\nwidespread. Most of the infected were young people 14-20 years of\nage. In Moldavia, since the beginning of 2008, 1200 cases of mumps\nhave been registered, whereas in 2006, there were only 96 cases.\nAccording to experts, this is a consequence of the fact that many\npeople were not vaccinated in the 1980's.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pridnestrovye is a disputed territory whose status is presently a\nmatter of negotiation between Russia and the Republic of Moldova\n(see: <http://news.rin.ru/eng/news///8904/1//>). According to\nWikipedia, the territory is currently administered by an unrecognized\nbreakaway authority under the name Pridnestrovian Moldovan Republic.\nThe mumps outbreak described in this report is part of a larger\noutbreak affecting the whole region (see references below).\n\nAn interactive map of the Republic of Moldova can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=47.2,28.5,5>, and a map of the\nadministrative regions and urban centres of Moldova (showing the\nposition of the Pridnestrovye region) is available at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moldova#Administrative_divisions>.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap of the Republic of Moldova can be accessed\nat <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=47.2,28.5,5>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 26 Mar 2008\n \n\nAn interactive map of the Republic of Moldova can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=47.2,28.5,5>, and a map of the\nadministrative regions and urban centres of Moldova (showing the\nposition of the Pridnestrovye region) is available at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moldova#Administrative_divisions>. The local infectious diseases\ndoctors are assuming that mumps has spread to the Pridnestrovye\nregion from Moldavia [outside of Russia, usually rendered as Moldova\n- Mod. Communicated by:\nProMED-RUS <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pridnestrovye is a disputed territory whose status is presently a\nmatter of negotiation between Russia and the Republic of Moldova\n(see: <http://news.rin.ru/eng/news///8904/1//>). According to public health physician Valeriy\nPishnograev, as the incubation period for mumps is 23 days, the\nschool will be closed for a quarantine period. In Moldavia, since the beginning of 2008, 1200 cases of mumps\nhave been registered, whereas in 2006, there were only 96 cases.\n After the spring\nbreak, children will be allowed to return to school only after\nmedical check-up by an infectious diseases specialist. MUMPS - MOLDOVA, PRIDNESTROVYE (04)\n****************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-12-25 00:00:00", "1980-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Republic of Moldova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moldova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moldavia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pridnestrovye", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Novokomissarovka village", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "69980", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada: 2007 review", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=69980", "date": "2008-04-03 04:00:19", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA: 2007 REVIEW\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 5 Mar 2008\nSource: Public Health Agency of Canada [edited]\n<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/mumps-oreillons/prof-eng.php>\n\n\n[What follows is an abbreviated version of the Public Health Agency Report.\nInterested readers should consult the full document at the URL given above.\n- Mod.CP]\n\nMumps in Canada, 2007\n---------------------\nAs of Wed 5 Mar 2008, 1284 confirmed cases of mumps have been reported in\n2007 from 10 out of 13 Canadian provinces and territories [see table below\nand an accompanying figure in the original text - Mod.CP]. Confirmed cases\nare either laboratory-confirmed or clinically compatible and linked to a\nlaboratory-confirmed case. There have been ongoing outbreaks centered in\nthe Maritime provinces and in the province of Alberta. In addition, several\nother provinces experienced increased mumps activity in 2007.\n\nTable. Geographical and sex distribution of confirmed mumps cases reported\nin Canada. Onset 31 Dec 2006-29 Dec 2007 (n=1284):\nProvince/territory / case count / percentage male\nNova Scotia / 777 / 49\nAlberta / 258 / 58\nNew Brunswick / 124 / 57\nOntario / 48 / 33\nBritish Columbia / 25 / 44\nQuebec / 20 / 55\nPrince Edward Island / 13 / 73\nNewfoundland Labrador / 10 / 40\nManitoba / 7 / 57\nSaskatchewan / 2 / 50\nNunavut / 0 / 0\nNorthwest Territories / 0 / 0\nYukon Territory / 0 / 0\nNational Total / 1284 / 51\n\nIt is assumed that most people born before 1970 (about 40 years old) are\nimmune to mumps, as they were likely naturally exposed to the mumps virus\nin the period before immunization significantly reduced the amount of mumps\nvirus that was circulating. Most people born between 1990 and 1994 (12 and\n17 years old depending on the province/territory of residence) were offered\n2 doses of mumps-containing vaccine due to the introduction of a 2nd dose\nof measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine for measles control in 1996-97 in\nmost provinces and territories. This has left a susceptible cohort of\npeople born between 1970 through 1990 (to a lesser extent through 1994) who\nwere only eligible for one dose of mumps-containing vaccine and who are not\nassumed to have natural immunity. It is important to note that the age at\nwhich natural immunity to mumps can be assumed is not known with certainty\nand that some individuals born prior to 1970 may still be susceptible to mumps.\n\n[The interested reader should consult the original text for a more detailed\ngraphic presentation of these data. - Mod.CP]\n\nThe majority of cases (58 per cent) reported in 2007 were aged 20-29 years\n[data illustrated graphically in the original text]. For those cases where\ninformation was reported (n=594), 50 per cent were post-secondary students.\nThe reason for the particular susceptibility among those who are college\nand university-aged is multifactorial. They are too young for natural\nimmunity and too old for routine 2-dose MMR immunization. Mumps has a\nfairly long infectious period (up to 16 days), a long incubation period (14\nto 25 days), and up to 20 per cent of infectious cases show no signs or\nsymptoms. In addition, the very social and mobile lifestyles of this age\ngroup appear to be facilitating disease transmission and interfering with\ncontrol measures. This age group tends not to adhere to isolation requests,\nand they generally do not participate when immunization is offered.\nFurthermore, post-secondary students often share living/sleeping\narrangements, many are involved in competitive sports, they frequent\nbars/pubs/nightclubs and travel during school holidays and breaks.\nAdditional cases in this demographic group and possibly other jurisdictions\nwould not be unexpected.\n\nOf those mumps cases reported in 2007 with known immunization history\n(n=586), 8 per cent (45) had received 2 or more doses, 73 per cent (430)\nhad received one dose and 19 per cent (111) received no doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine.\n\nThe data on mumps hospitalizations and complications are incomplete.\nComplications have been reported in about 8 per cent of cases in 2007.\nThere have been reports of orchitis (76), oophoritis (9), hearing loss (8),\nmastitis (3), meningitis (1), encephalitis (1), pancreatitis (1) and\nnephritis (1). Less than 2 per cent of cases have resulted in hospital\nemergency department visits, overnight observation or hospital admission.\n\nImmunization\n------------\nMumps remains endemic in many countries throughout the world. Mumps vaccine\nis used in only 57 per cent of World Health Organization member countries,\npredominantly in countries with more developed economies. The Public Health\nAgency of Canada encourages parents, guardians and adults to maintain\nup-to-date immunizations for themselves and their children.\n\nThe National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) provides the Public\nHealth Agency of Canada with ongoing and timely medical, scientific, and\npublic health advice relating to immunization. NACI released their updated\nrecommendations for mumps-containing vaccine in August 2007. They recommend\n2 doses of the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine for infants and\nchildren. In addition, they recommend a 2nd dose of MMR vaccine for certain\nhigh-risk adults born in or after 1970 who have not received 2 doses of the\nvaccine and are possibly susceptible to the mumps virus. This includes\nstudents in secondary and post-secondary institutions and health-care\nworkers. All NACI guidelines can be accessed on the Public Health Agency of\nCanada's website <http://www.naci.gc.ca>.\n\nIndividual provinces and territories implement immunization programs within\ntheir respective jurisdictions according to local need and decision\nprocesses. The 2004 National Immunization Coverage Survey (NICS) found that\n94 per cent of Canadian children had received a single dose of the MMR\nvaccine by their 2nd birthday. Coverage estimates for the 2nd dose of MMR\nvaccine by 7 years of age was 79 per cent. Other results from the 2004\nNational Immunization Coverage Survey can be found in the Canadian National\nReport on Immunization. The recent outbreaks and increases in mumps cases\nacross Canada have led to targeted immunization activities in several\nprovinces and territories. [This information is presented comprehensively\nin tabulated form in the original text, which should be consulted by the\ninterested reader].\n\nOn 11 Dec 2007, Health Canada advised provincial and territorial health\nauthorities not to use 3 lots of measles-mumps-rubella vaccine while the\nDepartment investigated 6 suspected cases of anaphylaxis in Alberta\npatients. All anaphylactic events were associated with the same lot number\nand involved young adults who had a previous history of allergy. All the\nindividuals recovered upon treatment. The vaccinations took place during a\ncatch-up campaign for young adults in response to a mumps outbreak. The\nreview found no link between the vaccine lot and the adverse events in\nAlberta. The suspensions have been lifted, and the lots are available for\nuse by provinces and territories to vaccinate adults and children <http://\nwww.hc-sc.gc.ca/ahc-asc/media/advisories-avis/_2008/2008_35_e.html>.\n\nLaboratory testing and viral strain\n-----------------------------------\nThe clinical and laboratory diagnosis of mumps can be difficult. Proper\nspecimen collection and transportation along with appropriate laboratory\ntesting and cautious interpretation of results are important. In 2007, the\nPublic Health Agency of Canada's National Microbiology Laboratory revised\ntheir laboratory guidelines for the diagnosis of mumps. The guidelines are\navailable on the Public Health Agency of Canada's website\n<http://www.nmllnm.gc.ca/english/mumps.htm>.\n\nIdentifying virus strains is useful for differentiating vaccine and\nwild-type strains, linking cases, linking outbreaks, tracking importations,\nand documenting the elimination of a particular strain from a geographic\narea. The viral strain in the 2 2007 Canadian outbreaks (Maritimes and\nAlberta) is identical to the genotype G strain detected from the 2005-2006\nNova Scotia outbreaks, the United States' multistate outbreak in 2006 and\nthe United Kingdom epidemic (2004-2006). In the United States' outbreak,\nthere were over 2500 cases reported in at least 13 states. It involved\nseveral university and college campuses, and the median age was 21 years.\nIn the United Kingdom, the epidemic peaked at more than 50 000\nnotifications, with the majority being 15-24 years old.\n\nThe G genotype is not unusual or rare and, like the rest of known genotypes\nof mumps, it has been circulating globally for decades or longer. There are\nmultiple strains of mumps virus, and there is evidence that the immunity\ninduced by one mumps virus strain protects against infection by other\nstrains (10). However, there is also some evidence suggesting that the\nimmune response directed against one genotype of mumps may not provide\nabsolute protection against infection with mumps viruses of other genotypes\n(11,12). Mumps virus detection, isolation and genotyping are available at\nthe National Microbiology Laboratory.\n\nPublic health actions\n---------------------\nMumps cases are asked to self-isolate for a period of 9 days following the\nonset of symptoms. The vaccine status of close contacts (that is, household\nand intimate contacts/exchange of saliva) is assessed and updated so that\nthey receive 2 doses of MMR vaccine. Guidelines have been put in place for\nhealth care workers who are cases or who are contacts of mumps cases.\n\nPublic health and primary care providers are encouraged to refer to their\nlocal or provincial/territorial ministry of health for specific\nrecommendations on action that may be required within their jurisdiction.\n\nAll provinces and territories are being kept informed of the epidemiologic\nsituation and the public health management strategies in the affected\njurisdictions. Based on this, all jurisdictions are encouraged to continue\nmonitoring mumps activity within their regions and report any changes\nand/or cases to the Public Health Agency of Canada, particularly in\nprovinces and territories not currently affected by the on-going outbreaks.\n\nThe Public Health Agency of Canada along with the provinces and territories\nis developing national guidelines for mumps outbreak prevention and\ncontrol. This group is drawing on the experiences and expertise both here\nin Canada and other countries.\n\nSeveral provinces, territories and post-secondary institutions are\nencouraging students to ensure their immunization is up-to-date (readers\nshould refer to specific provincial/territorial public health authorities\nand educational institutions).\n\nThe Public Health Agency of Canada will continue to provide updates on the\ncurrent outbreak of mumps. The agency is working with the affected\nprovinces in monitoring this outbreak, providing technical advice and\nassisting with laboratory testing of clinical specimens at the National\nMicrobiology Laboratory. The Public Health Agency of Canada supports the\nprovincial outbreak response strategies that include the recommended\nisolation of cases and targeted immunization of contacts and susceptible\ncohorts.\n\nThe Public Health Agency of Canada recommends that jurisdictions\nexperiencing outbreaks should consider offering an additional dose of MMR\nvaccine for immunization in outbreak settings. Some jurisdictions are\nencouraging and/or offering MMR vaccine to healthcare workers and\npost-secondary students. In other jurisdictions, there are ongoing\ndiscussions regarding an expanded immunization strategy to target the\nsusceptible cohort. Readers should refer to their local or\nprovincial/territorial ministry of health for specific recommendations.\n\nThe Public Health Agency of Canada encourages parents, guardians and adults\nto maintain up-to-date immunizations for themselves and their children and\nencourages susceptible individuals to be immunized in accordance with the\nNational Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) guidelines. All\nguidelines can be accessed at <http://www.naci.gc.ca>.\n\nNACI currently recommends a 2nd dose of MMR vaccine for certain adults born\nafter 1970. This includes students at post secondary institutions and\nhealth care workers.\n\nSelected references\n---------------------\n1. Atkinson W, Hamborsky J, McIntyre L, Wolfe S, editors.Epidemiology and\nprevention of vaccine-preventable diseases. 10th ed. Washington DC:\nCDC/Public Health Foundation, 2007.\n2. Canadian Immunization Guide. 7th Edition. Ottawa, ON: Public Health\nAgency of Canada, 2006.\n3. National Advisory Committee on Immunization: Statement on mumps vaccine.\nCCDR 2007; 33(8): 1-10.\n4. Outbreak of Mumps Among Young Adults - Vancouver, British Columbia. CCDR\n1997; 23(22).\n5. Outbreak of mumps, Montreal, October 1998 to March 1999 - with a\nparticular focus on a school. CCDR 2000; 26(8).\n6. Alberta Health and Wellness. Public health notifiable disease management\nguidelines. June 2005. URL: <http://www.health.gov.ab.ca/\nprofessionals/NotifiableDiseases.html>, accessed 23 Nov 2007.\n7. Watson-Creed G, Saunders A, Scott J, et al. Two successive outbreaks of\nmumps in Nova Scotia among vaccinated adolescents and young adults. CMAJ\n2006; 175(5): 483-8.\n8. CDC. Measles, mumps, and rubella -- vaccine use and strategies for\nelimination of measles, rubella, and congenital rubella syndrome and\ncontrol of mumps: recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization\nPractices (ACIP). MMWR 1998; 47(RR-8); 1-57.\n9. Jin L, Rima B, Brown D, et al. Proposal for genetic characterisation of\nwild-type mumps strains: Preliminary standardisation of the nomenclature.\nArch Virol 2005; 150; 1903-9.\n10. Nojd J, Tesfaldet T, Samulesson, et al. Mumps virus neutralizing\nantibodies do not protect against reinfection with a heterologous mumps\nvirus genotype. Vaccine 2001; 19: 1727-31.\n11. Rubin S, Mauldin J, Chumakov K, et al. Serological and phylogenetic\nevidence of monotypic immune responses to different mumps virus strains.\nVaccine 2006; 24; 2662-8.\n12. Orvell C, Alsheikhly A, Kalantari M, et al. Characterization of\ngenotype-specific epitopes of the HN protein of mumps virus. J Gen Virol\n1997; 78: 3187-93.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The preceding report gives a comprehensive account of the mumps outbreaks\nwhich affected 10 of the 13 Canadian provinces in 2007. The analysis is\napplicable to mumps outbreaks elsewhere.\n\nThe report also concludes that several adverse anaphylactic reactions\nencountered in a catch-up programme in Alberta were not mediated by a\nparticular vaccine lot, which had been withdrawn temporarily. The suspect\nvaccine lot has been released for general use. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 5 Mar 2008\n Most people born between 1990 and 1994 (12 and\n17 years old depending on the province/territory of residence) were offered\n2 doses of mumps-containing vaccine due to the introduction of a 2nd dose\nof measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine for measles control in 1996-97 in\nmost provinces and territories. J Gen Virol\n1997; 78: 3187-93.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The preceding report gives a comprehensive account of the mumps outbreaks\nwhich affected 10 of the 13 Canadian provinces in 2007. \n\nOf those mumps cases reported in 2007 with known immunization history\n(n=586), 8 per cent (45) had received 2 or more doses, 73 per cent (430)\nhad received one dose and 19 per cent (111) received no doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine. Alberta / 258 / 58\nNew Brunswick / 124 / 57\nOntario / 48 / 33\nBritish Columbia / 25 / 44\n Measles, mumps, and rubella -- vaccine use and strategies for\nelimination of measles, rubella, and congenital rubella syndrome and\ncontrol of mumps: recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization\nPractices (ACIP). On 11 Dec 2007, Health Canada advised provincial and territorial health\nauthorities not to use 3 lots of measles-mumps-rubella vaccine while the\nDepartment investigated 6 suspected cases of anaphylaxis in Alberta\npatients. Mumps has a\nfairly long infectious period (up to 16 days), a long incubation period (14\nto 25 days), and up to 20 per cent of infectious cases show no signs or\nsymptoms. \n\nThe Public Health Agency of Canada encourages parents, guardians and adults\nto maintain up-to-date immunizations for themselves and their children and\nencourages susceptible individuals to be immunized in accordance with the\nNational Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) guidelines. Mumps virus neutralizing\nantibodies do not protect against reinfection with a heterologous mumps\nvirus genotype. MUMPS - CANADA: 2007 REVIEW\n***************************\n This includes\nstudents in secondary and post-secondary institutions and health-care\nworkers. The suspensions have been lifted, and the lots are available for\nuse by provinces and territories to vaccinate adults and children <http://\nwww.hc-sc.gc.ca/ahc-asc/media/advisories-avis/_2008/2008_35_e.html>. Confirmed cases\nare either laboratory-confirmed or clinically compatible and linked to a\nlaboratory-confirmed case. The report also concludes that several adverse anaphylactic reactions\nencountered in a catch-up programme in Alberta were not mediated by a\nparticular vaccine lot, which had been withdrawn temporarily. There have been reports of orchitis (76), oophoritis (9), hearing loss (8),\nmastitis (3), meningitis (1), encephalitis (1), pancreatitis (1) and\nnephritis (1). The Public Health\nAgency of Canada encourages parents, guardians and adults to maintain\nup-to-date immunizations for themselves and their children. Dec 2006-29 Dec 2007 (n=1284):\nProvince/territory / case count / percentage male\n Furthermore, post-secondary students often share living/sleeping\narrangements, many are involved in competitive sports, they frequent\nbars/pubs/nightclubs and travel during school holidays and breaks. The\nreview found no link between the vaccine lot and the adverse events in\nAlberta. Other results from the 2004\nNational Immunization Coverage Survey can be found in the Canadian National\nReport on Immunization. In other jurisdictions, there are ongoing\ndiscussions regarding an expanded immunization strategy to target the\nsusceptible cohort. The guidelines are\navailable on the Public Health Agency of Canada's website\n<http://www.nmllnm.gc.ca/english/mumps.htm>. In addition, the very social and mobile lifestyles of this age\ngroup appear to be facilitating disease transmission and interfering with\ncontrol measures. [This information is presented comprehensively\nin tabulated form in the original text, which should be consulted by the\ninterested reader]. Proper\nspecimen collection and transportation along with appropriate laboratory\ntesting and cautious interpretation of results are important. Guidelines have been put in place for\nhealth care workers who are cases or who are contacts of mumps cases.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["1903-09-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "1284-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-02-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2662-08-25 00:00:00", "2005-06-25 00:00:00", "2057-01-25 00:00:00", "1970-03-25 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-12-25 00:00:00", "1976-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2045-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States '", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montreal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "65398", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada: (BC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=65398", "date": "2008-03-11 18:00:17", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA: (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 10 Mar 2008\nSource: BCLocalNews.com, Chilliwack Progress report [edited]\n<http://www.bclocalnews.com/news/16450111.html>\n\n\nFraser Health is reporting 5 lab-confirmed cases of mumps in\nChilliwack, in the wake of larger outbreaks in Alberta. 'It's been\ncoming at us from east to west,' said Fraser Health medical health\nofficer Dr Gillian Arsenault, who pointed to cases documented in Nova\nScotia, and later Alberta.\n\n'Apparently some of those infected [in Chilliwack] had either direct\nor indirect contact with the Alberta connection. So for anyone\nplanning to go to Alberta, now is a good time to get vaccinated,' she\nsaid.\n\nThe local cases are likely just the tip of the iceberg given the\n'sneaky' nature of the mumps virus, she said. The virus is spread by\nsaliva, so a cough or sneeze can send it travelling through the air\nwith fine mist droplets. 'When we have lab-confirmed cases, it means\nthere are more cases we don't know about,' said Dr Arsenault. 'The\nreason for that is roughly one-third of infected people display no\nsymptoms at all. For them it's just like a rotten cold.' Another\nthird of sufferers will experience swollen glands, testicles, or some\nother physical clue, and the swelling always comes on the heels of\nthe cold-like symptoms. An individual who's been exposed can be\ninfected and not know it, she said. 'It only takes one coughing\ninfected person in an ER or waiting room to spread the virus.'\n\nA mumps alert went out from Fraser Health offices last week [3-9 Mar\n2008] warning Chilliwack residents to make sure their vaccinations\nare up to date. Older adults are more at risk for serious disease, if\nthey're not immune through vaccination or through having had the\ndisease. 'People born before 1970 tend to have been around the virus\nand are more likely to be immune,' she said. 'The hardest hit include\nteens and young adults. Those who are 18 years or younger, attending\npost-secondary, or child/health care workers born after 1956, are\neligible for 2 free doses of Measles-Mumps-Rubella (MMR) vaccine.\n\n'If you have been around someone who has the mumps, you might have\nit, so check your vaccinations and if you think you may have it,\nphone first before heading into your doctor's office,' Dr Arsenault\nsaid. 'There is no 100 per cent guarantee of immunity, so everyone\nneeds to be careful.' Since the mumps infection affects the salivary\nglands, she said it's crucial to avoid sharing mouthpieces, drinking\nglasses, and other ways of 'swapping spit.' Asked if she thought\nBritish Columbia's population was immune enough to stop an outbreak,\nshe couldn't answer definitively. 'We don't know,' she said. Small\nclusters of mumps cases have been reported in other communities over\nthe past year, which didn't in fact turn into larger outbreaks of the\nvirus. 'We're hoping the same will happen here,' said the health\nofficial. 'We don't know how fast or how big this iceberg is, so it's\na good time to get the word out. The more people know, the more\nlikelihood it won't turn into a big outbreak.' Mumps 'very rarely'\nkill people, she said, but they can fall ill and feel awful.\n\nA total of 399 cases were reported in Alberta between 1 Sep 2007 and\n4 Mar 2008, with the majority of cases in the Chinook region of\nsouthern Alberta, and the rest in Calgary. There were also outbreaks\nin Nova Scotia. 'It shows we're not completely immune,' said\nArsenault. 'When that happens the waves of outbreaks are further\napart.'\n\n[Byline: Jennifer Feinberg]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The Canadian mumps outbreak of 2007 has progressed across Canada\nfrom east to west and has now reached the Pacific coast of British\nColumbia. It remains to be seen whether the British Columbian\nhealth-care system will have more success in containing this mumps\noutbreak than their Albertan counterpart, which has had to deal with\n399 cases so far.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Canada at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=55.4,-101.9,4> can be used to locate\nBritish Columbia.\nThe Chilliwack district is described at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chilliwack%2C_British_Columbia>. -\nMod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 10 Mar 2008\n It's been\ncoming at us from east to west,' said Fraser Health medical health\nofficer Dr Gillian Arsenault, who pointed to cases documented in Nova\nScotia, and later Alberta. \n\n'If you have been around someone who has the mumps, you might have\nit, so check your vaccinations and if you think you may have it,\nphone first before heading into your doctor's office,' Dr Arsenault\nsaid. ' Small\nclusters of mumps cases have been reported in other communities over\nthe past year, which didn't in fact turn into larger outbreaks of the\nvirus. ' It remains to be seen whether the British Columbian\nhealth-care system will have more success in containing this mumps\noutbreak than their Albertan counterpart, which has had to deal with\n399 cases so far. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The Canadian mumps outbreak of 2007 has progressed across Canada\nfrom east to west and has now reached the Pacific coast of British\nColumbia. Another\nthird of sufferers will experience swollen glands, testicles, or some\nother physical clue, and the swelling always comes on the heels of\nthe cold-like symptoms. \n\nA total of 399 cases were reported in Alberta between 1 Sep 2007 and\n4 Mar 2008, with the majority of cases in the Chinook region of\nsouthern Alberta, and the rest in Calgary. Source: BCLocalNews.com, Chilliwack Progress report [edited]\n<http://www.bclocalnews.com/news/16450111.html>\n\n\nFraser Health is reporting 5 lab-confirmed cases of mumps in\nChilliwack, in the wake of larger outbreaks in Alberta. ' \n\nA mumps alert went out from Fraser Health offices last week [3-9 Mar\n2008] warning Chilliwack residents to make sure their vaccinations\nare up to date. Since the mumps infection affects the salivary\nglands, she said it's crucial to avoid sharing mouthpieces, drinking\nglasses, and other ways of 'swapping spit.' Those who are 18 years or younger, attending\npost-secondary, or child/health care workers born after 1956, are\neligible for 2 free doses of Measles-Mumps-Rubella (MMR) vaccine. So for anyone\nplanning to go to Alberta, now is a good time to get vaccinated,' she\nsaid.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1956-03-25 00:00:00", "1970-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Calgary", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ER", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "54265", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=54265", "date": "2008-01-31 14:00:15", "main_text": "MUMPS - MOLDOVA, PRIDNESTROVYE (02): BACKGROUND\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDare: Thu 31 Jan 2998\nSource: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease & Epidemiology Network) [edited]\n<http://www.GideonOnline.com>\n\n\nre: Mumps - Moldova: background information\n-------------------------------------------\nRecent outbreaks of mumps in Moldova illustrate the fact mumps rates in\nthis region have been erratic for the past 3 decades, but appear to be\ndeclining slowly. See graph at\n<http://exhibit.gideononline.com/mumps-moldova.jpg>.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nDr Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[An interactive map oft region showing the relationship of Moldova to the\nother surrounding countries featured in the Gideon graph (Poland, Romania,\nthe Russian Federation, Slovakia, and Ukraine) is accessible at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=47.2,28.5,5>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Tel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[An interactive map oft region showing the relationship of Moldova to the\nother surrounding countries featured in the Gideon graph (Poland, Romania,\nthe Russian Federation, Slovakia, and Ukraine) is accessible at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=47.2,28.5,5>. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDare: Thu 31 Jan 2998\n \nRecent outbreaks of mumps in Moldova illustrate the fact mumps rates in\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2998-01-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Slovakia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moldova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Russian Federation", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "90968", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Netherlands: increased incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=90968", "date": "2008-06-27 17:00:26", "main_text": "MUMPS - NETHERLANDS: INCREASED INCIDENCE\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 26 Jun 2008\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly release, 2008 13(26) [edited &\nabbreviated Mod.CP]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=18914>\n\n\nIncreased mumps incidence in the Netherlands: review of the possible\nrole of vaccine strain and genotype\n---------------------------------------------------------------------------\nAs reported in a recent issue of Eurosurveillance, a mumps outbreak\nis ongoing in the Netherlands despite high vaccination coverage of\n90-95 percent (1). The reported mumps cases are restricted to\ngeographic regions with a high percentage of residents who are\nmembers of a religious community that rejects vaccination.\nConsequently, two thirds of the mumps patients were not vaccinated.\nHowever, also vaccinated individuals in these regions were affected\n(1). Since 1987, the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) combination vaccine\nproduced by the Netherlands Vaccine Institute (NVI) is part of the\nDutch national immunisation programme and administered at the ages of\n14 months and 9 years.\n\nNVI's MMR vaccine contains the Jeryl Lynn mumps strain. The Jeryl\nLynn strain consists of 2 distinct viral isolates (JL-2 and JL-5).\nClinical studies have demonstrated 80-100 percent seroconversion\nafter a single dose of the Jeryl Lynn mumps vaccine (2).\nOutbreak-based studies have shown an effectiveness of the Jeryl Lynn\nmumps vaccine ranging between 63 percent and 96 percent, depending on\nthe number of vaccinations given (2-4). The Jeryl Lynn strain has\nconsistently been shown to be very safe (4,5). Table 1 shows an\noverview of available mumps vaccine strains [Readers should access\nthe source URL to view these data. - Mod.CP]\n\nThe RIT 4385 mumps strain was derived from one of the 2 distinct\nvirus populations of the Jeryl Lynn strain. Comparative studies of\nthe RIT 4385 and Jeryl Lynn vaccines showed similar seroconversion\nrates, although the geometric mean titre was significantly higher\namong recipients of the Jeryl Lynn vaccine (2). Several vaccines\nderived from the Urabe AM9 mumps strain were withdrawn from the\nmarket due to an excessive number of cases of vaccine-associated\naseptic meningitis (6). The effectiveness of the Urabe vaccine ranges\nbetween 54 and 87 percent (3,5). Another vaccine strain, Rubini, has\nshown to be less potent with respect to effectiveness (2,3,5). For\nthis reason, the WHO (World Health Organisation) recommends that the\nRubini strain should not be used in national immunisation programmes\n(2). The Leningrad-3 strain was developed in the former Soviet Union\nand its protective efficacy has been estimated to be 91-99 percent\n(2,4). Unfortunately, aseptic meningitis is a particularly common\nevent among recipients of this vaccine strain (4,7). Furthermore, it\nhas been reported that the Leningrad-3 strain can be transmitted\nhorizontally, causing symptomatic disease (7). Consequently,\nLeningrad-3 vaccine has not gained much attention outside former\nSoviet Union republics. The Leningrad-3 strain was further attenuated\nin Croatia and was renamed L-Zagreb, which showed equivalent good\nclinical protection (2). Unfortunately, an association with aseptic\nmeningitis has also been a matter of concern for the L-Zagreb strain\nas well as symptomatic transmission of the vaccine virus (4,8,9).\nSeveral other strains have been used for mumps vaccination, but most\nof them on a limited scale. Therefore, little information is\navailable on their safety and effectiveness. Based on the safety and\nefficacy data available for the vaccine strains, it can be concluded\nthat the Jeryl Lynn strain has the most favourable benefit-risk\nprofile.\n\nA mismatch between the genotype of the circulating wild-type mumps\nvirus and the vaccine strain may influence the efficacy of the\nvaccine. At present, the molecular epidemiology of mumps virus is\ncharacterised by the co-existence of 13 different genotypes named A-M\n(10). Those genotypes are defined on the basis of the most variable\npart of the mumps virus genome, that is, the gene encoding the small\nhydrophobic (SH) protein (10).\n\nThe vaccine strains currently available belong to a few different\ngenotypes [Readers should consult Table 1 in the original text to\nview this information. - Mod.CP] Antigenic differences have been\nobserved between different genotypes, which result in incomplete,\ncross-neutralisation (11). The antigenic differences were largest\nbetween genotype A and genotypes B-D and G-I, which correlates well\nwith the relative phylogenetic distance between these genotypes [This\ninformation is presented as a figure in the original text, in the\nform of a phylogenetic tree of published sequences of 53 mumps virus\nstrains, based on the nucleotide sequence of the small hydrophobic\ngene (SH)] (10,11).\n\nAt present, there is no clinical evidence that a genotype mismatch\nleads to vaccine failure or may have epidemiological significance.\nFor example, both the mumps virus in the outbreak in the United\nStates (US) and Canada in 2005-2006 and the virus responsible for the\nmumps outbreak in the United Kingdom in 2004-2005 belonged to\ngenotype G (4,12,13). Nevertheless, the MMR vaccine based on genotype\nA (Jeryl Lynn) appeared to be effective during these outbreaks (12).\nThe mumps strains responsible for the current mumps outbreak in the\nNetherlands and a previous outbreak in an international school in the\nNetherlands in 2004 (14) were both of genotype D, whereas the mumps\nvaccine strain (Jeryl Lynn) belongs to genotype A. Although\ncross-protection after vaccination with genotype A might not be as\neffective after infection with genotype D, no further transmission\ntook place during the outbreak in 2004. This suggests that\nvaccine-induced (herd) immunity was high enough to prevent further\ncirculation of the mumps virus. On the other hand, it is striking\nthat the viruses responsible for reported mumps outbreaks belong to\ngenotypes that are phylogenetically distinct from the vaccine strains\nused in the area of the outbreak [These data are presented as Table 2\nin the original text. - Mod.CP] Therefore, the possibility that the\nmumps virus might evolve under selection pressure from the vaccine\nwarrants surveillance of genotype distribution.\n\nFinally, waning vaccine-induced immunity may contribute to a reduced\neffectiveness of the vaccine. Previously, it was assumed that mumps\nvaccination induces life-long immunity against mumps. However,\nincreasing evidence shows that vaccinated individuals and possibly\nalso naturally infected individuals, become more susceptible with\ntime after the last exposure to the mumps virus (4,12,13). Examples\nare 2 mumps outbreaks that occurred among vaccinated students in an\ninternational school in the Netherlands (14) and on college campuses\nin the US (12). Therefore, stronger precautions should be taken to\navoid an increase in susceptible adolescents and adults that are more\nat risk for mumps-related complications such as orchitis and\nmeningitis. Catch-up immunisations should be considered for\nunvaccinated individuals and susceptible vaccinated people,\nespecially for those living in groups in close contact.\n\nIn response to a mumps outbreak, several countries such as Ireland\nhave decided to move the 2nd MMR vaccination forward to the age of 4\nor 5 years (instead of between 9 and 14 years) to decrease the risk\nof waning immunity between the 2 vaccinations. However, other\noutbreaks show that waning immunity may also occur after the 2nd\nvaccination. Moreover, by decreasing the age of the last MMR\nvaccination, the susceptibility of women for rubella during their\nfertile period may increase, which potentially leads to more cases of\ncongenital rubella syndrome.\n\nConclusion\n----------\nThe 1st priority should be to avoid clustering of unvaccinated people\nby making an effort to convince people to get vaccinated. Although a\nnumber of mumps cases have occurred in vaccinated individuals, no\nother mumps vaccine strain is available at present with equivalent or\nbetter effectiveness and similar safety profile than the currently\nused Jeryl Lynn strain. However, the impact of a genotype mismatch\nbetween the wild-type virus and the vaccine virus on the mumps\nvaccine effectiveness as well as the possibility of waning\nvaccine-induced immunity should be further explored.\n\nAcknowledgments\n---------------\nWe would like to thank Nynke Y Rots, Truus W de Graaf, Andre D\nPlantinga, Renee AJ van Boxtel, Alberdien Haalboom-Clement, and\nMarjolein van Campen-Werkhoven for providing useful suggestions,\nrelevant information, and/or excellent assistance.\n\n[P Kaaijk, BA van der Zeijst, MC Boog, CW Hoitink\nNetherlands Vaccine Institute (NVI), Bilthoven, the Netherlands]\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Karagiannis I, van Lier A, van Binnendijk R, Ruijs H, Fanoy E,\nConyn-Van Spaendonck MA, et al: Mumps in a community with low\nvaccination coverage in the Netherlands. Euro Surveill. 2008; 13(24):\npii=18901. Available from\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=18901>\n2. World Health Organization (WHO). Outbreak news: Mumps virus\nvaccines. Wkly Epidemiol Rec. 2007; 7(82): 51-60. Available from\n<http://www.who.int/wer/2007/wer8207.pdf>\n3 Schlegel M, Osterwalder JJ, Galeazzi RL, Vernazza PL: Comparative\nefficacy of three mumps vaccines during disease outbreak in Eastern\nSwitzerland: cohort study. BMJ. 1999; 319(7206): 352\n4. Peltola H, Kulkarni PS, Kapre SV, Paunio M, Jadhav SS, Dhere RM:\nMumps outbreaks in Canada and the United States: time for new\nthinking on mumps vaccines. Clin Infect Dis. 2007; 45(4): 459-66.\n5. Ong G, Goh KT, Ma S, Chew SK: Comparative efficacy of Rubini,\nJeryl-Lynn and Urabe mumps vaccine in an Asian population. J Infect.\n2005; 51(4): 294-8\n6. J Med Virol.\n2008; 80(2): 323-9\n11. Muhlemann K: The molecular epidemiology of mumps virus. Infect\nGenet Evol. 2004; 4(3): 215-9\n12. Dayan GH, Quinlisk MP, Parker AA, Barskey AE, Harris ML, Schwartz\nJM, et al: Recent resurgence of mumps in the United States. N Engl J\nMed. 2008; 358(15): 1580-9\n13. Atrasheuskaya AV, Kulak MV, Rubin S, Ignatyev GM: Mumps vaccine\nfailure investigation in Novosibirsk, Russia, 2002-2004. Clin\nMicrobiol Infect. 2007; 13(7): 670-6\n16. Atrasheuskaya AV, Blatun EM, Kulak MV, Atrasheuskaya A, Karpov\nIA, Rubin S, et al: Investigation of mumps vaccine failures in Minsk,\nBelarus, 2001-2003. Vaccine. 2007; 25(24): 4651-8.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The recent mumps cases in The Netherlands have been restricted to\ngeographic regions with a high percentage of residents who are\nmembers of a religious community (anthroposophists) that rejects\nvaccination. Two thirds of the mumps patients were not vaccinated,\nhowever some vaccinated individuals in these regions were affected\nalso.\n\nTo what extent this is due to mismatch between the vaccine and the\ngenotype of the virus in circulation remains an open question. The\nmumps component of the MMR triple vaccine is classified as genotype\nA, whereas the virus in the outbreak in the Netherlands was genotype\nD. Although genotype is defined only by the sequence of the SH\nprotein encoding region of the genome, antigenic differences have\nbeen observed between different genotypes which result in incomplete\ncross-neutralisation. These antigenic differences were largest\nbetween genotype A and genotypes B-D and G-I (reference 1), which\ncorrelates well with the relative phylogenetic distance between these\ngenotypes. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "The mumps strains responsible for the current mumps outbreak in the\nNetherlands and a previous outbreak in an international school in the\nNetherlands in 2004 (14) were both of genotype D, whereas the mumps\nvaccine strain (Jeryl Lynn) belongs to genotype A. Although\ncross-protection after vaccination with genotype A might not be as\neffective after infection with genotype D, no further transmission\ntook place during the outbreak in 2004. The antigenic differences were largest\nbetween genotype A and genotypes B-D and G-I, which correlates well\nwith the relative phylogenetic distance between these genotypes [This\ninformation is presented as a figure in the original text, in the\nform of a phylogenetic tree of published sequences of 53 mumps virus\nstrains, based on the nucleotide sequence of the small hydrophobic\ngene (SH)] (10,11). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 26 Jun 2008\n Although a\nnumber of mumps cases have occurred in vaccinated individuals, no\nother mumps vaccine strain is available at present with equivalent or\nbetter effectiveness and similar safety profile than the currently\nused Jeryl Lynn strain. On the other hand, it is striking\nthat the viruses responsible for reported mumps outbreaks belong to\ngenotypes that are phylogenetically distinct from the vaccine strains\nused in the area of the outbreak [These data are presented as Table 2\nin the original text. However, the impact of a genotype mismatch\nbetween the wild-type virus and the vaccine virus on the mumps\nvaccine effectiveness as well as the possibility of waning\nvaccine-induced immunity should be further explored. For example, both the mumps virus in the outbreak in the United\nStates (US) and Canada in 2005-2006 and the virus responsible for the\nmumps outbreak in the United Kingdom in 2004-2005 belonged to\ngenotype G (4,12,13). Since 1987, the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) combination vaccine\nproduced by the Netherlands Vaccine Institute (NVI) is part of the\nDutch national immunisation programme and administered at the ages of\n14 months and 9 years. Several vaccines\nderived from the Urabe AM9 mumps strain were withdrawn from the\nmarket due to an excessive number of cases of vaccine-associated\naseptic meningitis (6). CP]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=18914>\n\n\nIncreased mumps incidence in the Netherlands: review of the possible\nrole of vaccine strain and genotype\n In response to a mumps outbreak, several countries such as Ireland\nhave decided to move the 2nd MMR vaccination forward to the age of 4\nor 5 years (instead of between 9 and 14 years) to decrease the risk\nof waning immunity between the 2 vaccinations. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The recent mumps cases in The Netherlands have been restricted to\ngeographic regions with a high percentage of residents who are\nmembers of a religious community (anthroposophists) that rejects\nvaccination. However,\nincreasing evidence shows that vaccinated individuals and possibly\nalso naturally infected individuals, become more susceptible with\ntime after the last exposure to the mumps virus (4,12,13). Based on the safety and\nefficacy data available for the vaccine strains, it can be concluded\nthat the Jeryl Lynn strain has the most favourable benefit-risk\nprofile. Examples\nare 2 mumps outbreaks that occurred among vaccinated students in an\ninternational school in the Netherlands (14) and on college campuses\nin the US (12). The reported mumps cases are restricted to\ngeographic regions with a high percentage of residents who are\nmembers of a religious community that rejects vaccination.\n Comparative studies of\nthe RIT 4385 and Jeryl Lynn vaccines showed similar seroconversion\nrates, although the geometric mean titre was significantly higher\namong recipients of the Jeryl Lynn vaccine (2). Therefore, stronger precautions should be taken to\navoid an increase in susceptible adolescents and adults that are more\nat risk for mumps-related complications such as orchitis and\nmeningitis. [P Kaaijk, BA van der Zeijst, MC Boog, CW Hoitink\nNetherlands Vaccine Institute (NVI), Bilthoven, the Netherlands]\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. These antigenic differences were largest\nbetween genotype A and genotypes B-D and G-I (reference 1), which\ncorrelates well with the relative phylogenetic distance between these\ngenotypes. Although genotype is defined only by the sequence of the SH\nprotein encoding region of the genome, antigenic differences have\nbeen observed between different genotypes which result in incomplete\ncross-neutralisation. Moreover, by decreasing the age of the last MMR\nvaccination, the susceptibility of women for rubella during their\nfertile period may increase, which potentially leads to more cases of\ncongenital rubella syndrome. Outbreak-based studies have shown an effectiveness of the Jeryl Lynn\nmumps vaccine ranging between 63 percent and 96 percent, depending on\nthe number of vaccinations given (2-4). As reported in a recent issue of Eurosurveillance, a mumps outbreak\nis ongoing in the Netherlands despite high vaccination coverage of\n90-95 percent (1). At present, the molecular epidemiology of mumps virus is\ncharacterised by the co-existence of 13 different genotypes named A-M\n(10). Those genotypes are defined on the basis of the most variable\npart of the mumps virus genome, that is, the gene encoding the small\nhydrophobic (SH) protein (10). MUMPS - NETHERLANDS: INCREASED INCIDENCE\n****************************************\n The Leningrad-3 strain was further attenuated\nin Croatia and was renamed L-Zagreb, which showed equivalent good\nclinical protection (2). Consequently,\nLeningrad-3 vaccine has not gained much attention outside former\nSoviet Union republics.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-02-04 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "1987-03-25 00:00:00", "1106-12-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2054-05-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "1580-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Borges DB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dourado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zagreb", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "eurosurveillance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Neverov AA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belarus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Croatia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sao Paulo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minsk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santos", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leningrad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Novosibirsk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "40442", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (11): (AB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=40442", "date": "2007-12-02 14:00:22", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (11): (AB)\n*************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 1 Dec 2007\nSource: CTV.ca, News team [edited]\n<http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20071129/mumps_071129/20071130?hub=Health>\n\n\nMumps outbreak continues in Alberta\n-----------------------------------------------\nPublic health officials are still trying to contain an outbreak of\nmumps, after almost 100 cases of the virus were confirmed in southern\nAlberta. In the Chinook Health Region, which covers the Lethbridge\narea, most of the 38 confirmed and 21 suspected cases are connected\nto the University of Lethbridge and Lethbridge College.\n\nIn the Calgary area, 57 cases have been reported between January and\nOctober 2007; 43 of those cases were identified in October 2007\nalone. Six of the recent cases were players on the University of\nCalgary's Dino's hockey team. Health officials are now warning all\nhockey players in the city not to share water bottles or mouth guards.\n\nThe province is offering free mumps immunizations in 2 phases: 1st to\npost-secondary students, then to everyone in the high-risk population\nbetween the ages of 17 and 26. People in this age group received only\none dose of the mumps vaccine when they were children, which is now\nthought to have worn off. Those born before 1970 are assumed to have\nbeen exposed to the mumps virus at some point in their life and are\ntherefore immune. Those younger than 17 have been vaccinated twice.\n\nIn an effort to publicize the immunization clinics, the province has\nborrowed some graphic advertisements from Nova Scotia, where more\nthan 700 cases of mumps have been reported since an outbreak began\nlast February [2007]. In one ad, a pair of flaming basketballs are\naccompanied by the headline: 'The swelling's not so bad. It's the\nsevere testicular pain...'' It then reminds viewers that the mumps\ncan lead to sterility, meningitis and deafness. The posters have been\nso popular that many have been stolen in the Chinook region.\n\nMumps is a viral infection of the salivary glands that causes fever,\nheadache and swollen glands around the jaw. In rare cases, it can\nlead to serious complications such as those listed above. The virus\ncan be spread from about 7 days before glands become swollen to 9\ndays after. There is no specific treatment.\n\nMore than 13 500 people have already been vaccinated, and clinics\nwill continue into December 2007 at universities and colleges. A\ngeneral immunization phase is set to start in early December 2007 to\ntarget the 475 000 people who could be at risk. Vanessa Maclean,\nacting medical officer of health for the Chinook Health Region, says\nit could still be a while before there's a slowdown in the number of\ncases, noting that even after immunization, it takes about 12 days\nfor someone to be protected. Dr. Judy MacDonald of the Calgary Health\nRegion says she also expects to see more cases in the short term\nbecause the vaccination campaign is just now in full activation.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[This update records the continued upsurge in cases of mumps\naffecting an age group that was incompletely protected by a single\nvaccine dose in the past. The outbreak is currently restricted mainly\nto university and college students due to their seasonal aggregation\nand housing in close contact. It is estimated that 475 000 people in\nthe general population remain at risk and will be offered a 2nd dose\nof mumps vaccine in due course.\n\nA map of Canada and its constituent provinces can be accessed at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=55.4,-101.9,4>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 1 Dec 2007\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[This update records the continued upsurge in cases of mumps\naffecting an age group that was incompletely protected by a single\nvaccine dose in the past. In an effort to publicize the immunization clinics, the province has\nborrowed some graphic advertisements from Nova Scotia, where more\nthan 700 cases of mumps have been reported since an outbreak began\nlast February [2007]. \nPublic health officials are still trying to contain an outbreak of\nmumps, after almost 100 cases of the virus were confirmed in southern\nAlberta. In the Calgary area, 57 cases have been reported between January and\nOctober 2007; 43 of those cases were identified in October 2007\nalone. The province is offering free mumps immunizations in 2 phases: 1st to\npost-secondary students, then to everyone in the high-risk population\nbetween the ages of 17 and 26. A\ngeneral immunization phase is set to start in early December 2007 to\ntarget the 475 000 people who could be at risk. People in this age group received only\none dose of the mumps vaccine when they were children, which is now\nthought to have worn off.
