Dr. Judy MacDonald of the Calgary Health\nRegion says she also expects to see more cases in the short term\nbecause the vaccination campaign is just now in full activation.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1970-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-12-25 00:00:00", "2007-10-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Calgary", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "42730", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (02): (NV)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=42730", "date": "2007-12-13 21:00:21", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (02): (NEVADA)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 12 Dec 2007\nSource: lasvegasnow.com, News [edited]\n<http://www.lasvegasnow.com/Global/story.asp?S=7481113&nav=menu102>\n\n\nMumps Make Comeback in Southern Nevada\n--------------------------------------\nThere have been 6 cases of mumps reported in Clark County over the\npast several weeks. This is drawing a concern from the Southern\nNevada Health District. The health department says these recent cases\nprove the virus is in circulation locally.\n\nThe health district says in terms of mumps, 6 cases are more than\nthey would want to see in the county. Now the department is asking\npeople to get vaccinated if they haven't yet. And even if you have\nbeen vaccinated, there is still a small chance you might get the virus.\n\n'It's possible any person at any age can come down with mumps even if\nyou have been vaccinated,' said Southern Nevada Health District\nepidemiologist, Brian Labus. It's a virus that can spread fast. Labus\nsays his office has not seen a trend in mumps cases like this in a\nwhile. 'This is out of the ordinary, that's why were interested and\nthat's why we're letting the community know what's going on. This is\nmore than we would expect to see,' said Labus.\n\nThe more visual symptom of the disease are swollen glands near the\nneck. The greatest mumps epidemic was in in 1941, when children were\nmore prone to it. Labus says the 6 people who have come down with the\nmumps vary in age and it is possible for any person at any age to\ncome down with the mumps.\n\n'You really see this disease against all ages. You used to expect to\nsee it as a childhood disease, but it really affects age ranges from\nthe young to the old -- anybody can be at risk for getting the\ndisease,' said Labus.\n\nThe disease is contagious and usually spread by breathing in the\nvirus after an infected person coughs or sneezes near you or by\ncoming in direct contact with the saliva of an infected person.\n\nMumps symptoms:\n-- Fever of 101 F to 104 F.\n-- Headache, earache, sore throat\n-- Pain when swallowing\n-- Tiredness\n-- Muscle and joint aches\n-- Poor appetite and vomiting.\n\nIf you have had mumps in the past, you are pretty much immune from\ngetting it again. Even if you have been vaccinated in the past, there\nis still about a 5 percent chance the vaccine may not work.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The HealthNet interacrive map shows the central location of Nevada; see\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6>.\nClark County is located in the southern tip of the state; see map at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/nevada_map.html>.\nLas Vegas is the principal city.\n\n\nThere has been a massive resurgence of mumps virus infection in\nCanada in recent months, affecting principally young adults who had\nnot been vaccinated or had received only a single dose of mumps\nvaccine as children. The victims were predominantly university and\ncollege students and the outbreak spread across Canada from New\nBrunswick the site of the 1st cases mainly through university\ncampuses. The outbreak is being contained by a comprehensive\nrevaccination campaign.\n\nThe Nevada report contains no information about the ages or\nvaccination status of the 6 cases in Clark county. It would be\ninteresting to know if there is any link with the Canadian outbreak\nthrough the movement of students or young adults. Further information\nwould be appreciated. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 12 Dec 2007\n \n\n\nThere has been a massive resurgence of mumps virus infection in\nCanada in recent months, affecting principally young adults who had\nnot been vaccinated or had received only a single dose of mumps\nvaccine as children. You used to expect to\nsee it as a childhood disease, but it really affects age ranges from\nthe young to the old -- anybody can be at risk for getting the\ndisease,' said Labus. The victims were predominantly university and\ncollege students and the outbreak spread across Canada from New\nBrunswick the site of the 1st cases mainly through university\ncampuses. Labus says the 6 people who have come down with the\nmumps vary in age and it is possible for any person at any age to\ncome down with the mumps. \n\nThe disease is contagious and usually spread by breathing in the\nvirus after an infected person coughs or sneezes near you or by\ncoming in direct contact with the saliva of an infected person. It's possible any person at any age can come down with mumps even if\nyou have been vaccinated,' said Southern Nevada Health District\nepidemiologist, Brian Labus. Labus\nsays his office has not seen a trend in mumps cases like this in a\nwhile. ' Fever of 101 F to 104 F.\n-- Headache, earache, sore throat\n-- Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The HealthNet interacrive map shows the central location of Nevada; see\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6>. Tiredness\n-- Muscle and joint aches\n-- Source: lasvegasnow.com, News [edited]\n<http://www.lasvegasnow.com/Global/story.asp?S=7481113&nav=menu102>\n\n\nMumps Make Comeback in Southern Nevada\n It would be\ninteresting to know if there is any link with the Canadian outbreak\nthrough the movement of students or young adults.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1941-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Clark County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Las Vegas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nevada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "44217", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (02): (ME)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=44217", "date": "2007-12-21 03:00:27", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (02): (MAINE)\n*************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 20 Dec 2007\nSource: The Boston Globe online [edited]\n<http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2007/12/20/\nmumps_outbreak_worries_mass_officials/>\n\nMumps outbreak worries Massachusetts officials\n----------------------------------------------\nMassachusetts health authorities are on high alert for cases of mumps, the\npainful viral illness that has reemerged in Maine and Maritime Canada in\nrecent months, despite decades of vaccinations. Before the outbreak, Maine\nhad not reported a case in at least 20 years. Now mumps has spread across\nthe state, reaching its southernmost county and making nearly 75 children\nand adults sick statewide since September [2007].\nDisease trackers suspect that the Maine outbreak was imported from Canada,\nwhere 1140 people have fallen ill this year [2007], 14 times the average\nfor recent years. Most of the cases have been reported by 3 eastern\nprovinces -- Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island.\nSpecialists in Massachusetts are watching the migration of mumps with\nincreasing concern, knowing that many of the patients in Maine and Canada\nare college students, a group particularly susceptible because they are\nmobile and live in tight quarters, an ideal combination for disease\ntransmission.\n'We are exploring every possible mumps case,' said Dr Alfred DeMaria,\ndirector of communicable disease control for the Department of Public\nHealth in Massachusetts, where only 3 cases have been reported this year.\n'We're going to be especially vigilant after the holidays,' he said,\nbecause Boston students may have contact with students from Maine schools\nduring the break.\nThe resurgence of mumps illustrates the hardiness of a virus, the\nlimitations of a vaccine, and the realities of a world so hooked on air\ntravel that germs can spread from one country to another in a matter of\nhours. Specialists said they believe that is exactly what happened with\nmumps. Like measles, it was a common childhood scourge that appeared headed\nfor extinction in the United States. But in 2005, a strain widely\ncirculating [not terribly common, clinically. - Mod.SH] in the United\nKingdom, where vaccination rates are significantly lower than in North\nAmerica, was imported to a New York state summer camp. Within a year, that\nsame strain was identified as the culprit in a Midwest outbreak. And it is\nbeing blamed for the cases in Canada this year.\n'Mumps is essentially endemic in the rest of the world,' said Dr James\nAlexander, a medical epidemiologist at the US Centers for Disease Control\nand Prevention (CDC). 'Canada and the United States were the 2 countries\nwhere mumps was close to being eliminated.'\nThe virus is transmitted by direct contact with an infected person's\nsaliva, meaning it can travel through a kiss or on utensils, towels, or\ntissues. It causes severe swelling of salivary glands and is heralded by\nfever, headache, body aches, and glandular tenderness where the jaw forms\nan angle. Rarely fatal, it can result in significant complications,\nincluding inflammation of the testes, brain swelling, meningitis, and\nsterility. A vaccine introduced in 1967 led to a steep decline in mumps in\nthe United States, but within 2 decades, the virus had reemerged.\n'Mumps has undoubtedly been with us for millennia, and it's not likely to\ndisappear just because we develop an effective vaccine,' said Dr Kenneth\nMcIntosh, a disease specialist at Children's Hospital Boston. One pivotal\nlesson derived from the return of the mumps in the late 1980s: a single\ndose of vaccine did not provide enough of a shield. It was then that\ndisease specialists began recommending that children receive 2 doses and\nthat schools bar students who were not vaccinated.\nAs Canadian specialists began investigating this year's outbreak, they\nquickly homed in on the vaccination history of patients, unearthing\nimportant clues. Nearly 73 per cent had received only a single dose of\nvaccine, while 19 per cent had no vaccination at all. Those who received at\nleast one dose generally had milder cases. 'I like to compare this disease\nto a heat-seeking missile,' said Jeannette Macey, an epidemiologist with\nthe epidemiologist with the Public Health Agency of Canada. 'If there are\npeople in the population who are not protected, it's going to find them.'\nIn Maine, authorities are collecting comparable data, but they know already\nthat many of the adults who became infected probably only got a single dose\nearlier in life. At the University of Southern Maine, where many of the\nstudents are older, at least 10 people have fallen ill, a spokeswoman said.\nDisease specialists from Maine and the federal CDC are also continuing to\ninvestigate exactly where the virus came from, running sophisticated\ngenetic testing and conducting extensive interviews. 'It's not surprising\nthat Maine would have cases,' said Dr Dora Mills, director of Maine's CDC.\n'New Brunswick is adjacent to Maine, and Nova Scotia might as well be,\nbecause there are several boats that go back and forth every day.'\n[byline: Stephen Smith]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[There has been a considerable increase in the number of mumps cases\nreported in Maine since the initial report on 20 Nov 2007. The case count\nof 7 confirmed and 24 suspected cases of mumps has risen to at least 75\nconfirmed cases. It may be that as time progresses the State of Maine will\nbe required to instigate a comprehensive vaccination campaign to provide\nprotective immunity to those in the population who have previously received\na single vaccinations or none, to contain this outbreak - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Specialists in Massachusetts are watching the migration of mumps with\nincreasing concern, knowing that many of the patients in Maine and Canada\nare college students, a group particularly susceptible because they are\nmobile and live in tight quarters, an ideal combination for disease\ntransmission. [byline: Stephen Smith]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n ----------------------------------------------\nMassachusetts health authorities are on high alert for cases of mumps, the\npainful viral illness that has reemerged in Maine and Maritime Canada in\nrecent months, despite decades of vaccinations. \n'Mumps has undoubtedly been with us for millennia, and it's not likely to\ndisappear just because we develop an effective vaccine,' said Dr Kenneth\nMcIntosh, a disease specialist at Children's Hospital Boston. The resurgence of mumps illustrates the hardiness of a virus, the\nlimitations of a vaccine, and the realities of a world so hooked on air\ntravel that germs can spread from one country to another in a matter of\nhours. It may be that as time progresses the State of Maine will\nbe required to instigate a comprehensive vaccination campaign to provide\nprotective immunity to those in the population who have previously received\na single vaccinations or none, to contain this outbreak - Mod. Source: The Boston Globe online [edited]\n<http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2007/12/20/\nmumps_outbreak_worries_mass_officials/>\n\nMumps outbreak worries Massachusetts officials\n We are exploring every possible mumps case,' said Dr Alfred DeMaria,\ndirector of communicable disease control for the Department of Public\nHealth in Massachusetts, where only 3 cases have been reported this year. The case count\nof 7 confirmed and 24 suspected cases of mumps has risen to at least 75\nconfirmed cases. Disease trackers suspect that the Maine outbreak was imported from Canada,\nwhere 1140 people have fallen ill this year [2007], 14 times the average\nfor recent years. One pivotal\nlesson derived from the return of the mumps in the late 1980s: a single\ndose of vaccine did not provide enough of a shield. Now mumps has spread across\nthe state, reaching its southernmost county and making nearly 75 children\nand adults sick statewide since September [2007]. As Canadian specialists began investigating this year's outbreak, they\nquickly homed in on the vaccination history of patients, unearthing\nimportant clues. We're going to be especially vigilant after the holidays,' he said,\nbecause Boston students may have contact with students from Maine schools\nduring the break. It was then that\ndisease specialists began recommending that children receive 2 doses and\nthat schools bar students who were not vaccinated. I like to compare this disease\nto a heat-seeking missile,' said Jeannette Macey, an epidemiologist with\nthe epidemiologist with the Public Health Agency of Canada. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the State of Maine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maine", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "38573", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA: (ME)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=38573", "date": "2007-11-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA: (MAINE)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 20 Nov 2007\nSource: Bangor Daily News, bangordailynews.com [edited]\n<http://bangornews.com/news/t/news.aspx?articleid=156719&zoneid=500>\n\n\nWith confirmed and suspected cases of mumps on the rise in Maine --\nincluding a suspected case in an employee at Eastern Maine Medical Center\nin Bangor -- and a much more serious outbreak just across the border in\nCanada, Maine's chief public health officer on Monday [19 Nov 2007] issued\nupdated recommendations for vaccination against the potentially serious\nillness. 'Because this outbreak [in Maine] has spread, we are updating\nvaccination recommendations, especially among children, college and\nuniversity students and hospital workers,' said Dr Dora Anne Mills, head of\nthe Maine Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Because of the\nenvironments where they live and work, such individuals are most likely to\ncontract and spread the virus, Mills said.\n\nSince September [2007], 7 cases of mumps have been confirmed in southern\nand central Maine, 4 of them in November 2007 alone. The state is awaiting\nthe results of lab tests on as many as 24 more suspected cases, according\nto the Maine CDC. The age of the sickened individuals ranges from the late\nteens to the late 50s. While the number of cases in Maine may seem\ninsignificant, more than 900 individuals in Nova Scotia and New Brunswick,\nmostly college students, have been sickened with mumps since last winter\n[2006-2007].\n\nOn Monday [19 Nov 2007], a housekeeper at EMMC was given a preliminary\ndiagnosis of mumps pending confirmation by laboratory testing. Donna\nDunton, director of infection control at EMMC, confirmed on Monday evening\nthat the housekeeper has been asked to stay out of work until lab reports\nof her mumps-like symptoms are complete. The employee is not thought to\nhave been in close enough contact with any patients to have spread the\nvirus, Dunton stressed, and routine infection control measures such as hand\nwashing are likely to have minimized the possibility of transmission.\n\nMumps is a viral infection of the salivary glands. Symptoms typically\ninclude fever, headache, muscle ache, and swelling and tenderness of the\nglands at the corner of the jaw. Symptoms may last 7 to 10 days, and\ninfected individuals are contagious for at least 3 days before becoming ill\nand as long as 9 days after symptoms appear. Infection occurs through\ndirect contact with respiratory droplets from the nose or throat, through\nsaliva, coughing, sneezing, sharing drinks, kissing or from contact with\nany surface that has been contaminated with the virus. Rarely, mumps\ninfection can lead to meningitis, inflammation of the testicles or ovaries,\ninflammation of the pancreas, and temporary or permanent hearing loss.\n\n'Although mumps is a virus and is not treatable with antibiotics, the good\nnews is that mumps can be prevented or its impact reduced with vaccine,'\nMills said. The MMR vaccine -- which protects against mumps, measles and\nrubella, or 'German measles' -- is the most common vaccine used to protect\nagainst mumps.\n\nThe Maine CDC's updated guidelines are as follows:\n- For students in kindergarten through 12th grade, all vaccine records\nshould be reviewed and updated. For any students who are not current with\ntheir MMR vaccines, a letter should be given to the parents notifying them\nof the mumps outbreak and informing them that if their child remains\nunimmunized and the infection is detected in their school, their child will\nbe excluded from school for at least 18 days.\n- For college and university students, all vaccine records should be\nreviewed and updated. All students should have documentation of 2 doses of\nMMR rather than the previously required one dose. Most students will have\nhad 2 doses as part of their routine childhood vaccinations, but older\n'nontraditional' students may be lacking the 2nd dose.\n- Hospital health care workers with direct patient contact should have\ntheir vaccine records reviewed and updated.\n\nAdequate mumps vaccination for those born in 1957 or later now consists of\n2 doses of MMR rather than the previously required one dose. Adequate mumps\nvaccination for those born before 1957 now consists of one dose of MMR,\nrather than no doses, as previously required.\n\nBesides the additional vaccinations, the Maine CDC also recommends that\nindividuals who become infected should be isolated for 9 days after the\nonset of illness. Those who are not immunized and who are exposed should be\nisolated for about 18 days after the last known exposure.\n\nMills acknowledged that compliance with these recommendations may be\nfinancially and logistically burdensome for some individuals, institutions\nand families. The average cost of a mumps vaccine is about USD 45, she\nsaid, but the state is trying to secure supplies of lower-cost vaccine. The\nMaine CDC can assist institutions with the process of reviewing records,\nsetting up vaccine clinics and obtaining vaccine supplies, she said.\n\nMills added that the new recommendations are likely to be upgraded to\nrequirements through departmental rule-making in the near future. 'While\nthere is no apparent direct connection between people in Maine with\nconfirmed infection and the current outbreak in Canada, it is not\nsurprising that a border state like Maine would see an outbreak,' Mills said.\n\nA student health official at the University of Maine was unavailable Monday\n[19 Nov 2007] to comment on how the new recommendations might affect the\nOrono campus.\n\nAt EMMC, Dunton said employee charts have been under review for several\nmonths in response to changes in vaccine recommendations from the Maine CDC\nissued earlier this year [2007]. Monday's [19 Nov 2007] announcement, she\nsaid, is likely to 'step up the pace' of that review, and many employees\nare likely to be asked to roll up their sleeves.\n\n[byline: Meg Haskell]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[For further information, visit the state of Maine's website at\n<http://www.mainepublichealth.gov>. The state of Maine's response to the\noccurrence of sporadic cases of mumps is prudent in view of the proximity\nof the state to the Canadian provinces of Nova Scotia and New Brunswick,\nwhich are experiencing substantial outbreaks of mumps infection in young\nadults and older children (see ProMED-mail references below). The words of\nthe director of the Maine CDC are well chosen: 'While there is no apparent\ndirect connection between people in Maine with confirmed infection and the\ncurrent outbreak in Canada, it is not surprising that a border state like\nMaine would see an outbreak.' - Mod.CP]", "summary": "With confirmed and suspected cases of mumps on the rise in Maine --\nincluding a suspected case in an employee at Eastern Maine Medical Center\nin Bangor -- and a much more serious outbreak just across the border in\nCanada, Maine's chief public health officer on Monday [19 Nov 2007] issued\nupdated recommendations for vaccination against the potentially serious\nillness. ' A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 20 Nov 2007\n The state of Maine's response to the\noccurrence of sporadic cases of mumps is prudent in view of the proximity\nof the state to the Canadian provinces of Nova Scotia and New Brunswick,\nwhich are experiencing substantial outbreaks of mumps infection in young\nadults and older children (see ProMED-mail references below). For any students who are not current with\ntheir MMR vaccines, a letter should be given to the parents notifying them\nof the mumps outbreak and informing them that if their child remains\nunimmunized and the infection is detected in their school, their child will\nbe excluded from school for at least 18 days. The words of\nthe director of the Maine CDC are well chosen: 'While there is no apparent\ndirect connection between people in Maine with confirmed infection and the\ncurrent outbreak in Canada, it is not surprising that a border state like\nMaine would see an outbreak.' - Mod. \n\n[byline: Meg Haskell]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[For further information, visit the state of Maine's website at\n<http://www.mainepublichealth.gov>. While\nthere is no apparent direct connection between people in Maine with\nconfirmed infection and the current outbreak in Canada, it is not\nsurprising that a border state like Maine would see an outbreak,' Mills said. Because this outbreak [in Maine] has spread, we are updating\nvaccination recommendations, especially among children, college and\nuniversity students and hospital workers,' said Dr Dora Anne Mills, head of\nthe Maine Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Donna\nDunton, director of infection control at EMMC, confirmed on Monday evening\nthat the housekeeper has been asked to stay out of work until lab reports\nof her mumps-like symptoms are complete. While the number of cases in Maine may seem\ninsignificant, more than 900 individuals in Nova Scotia and New Brunswick,\nmostly college students, have been sickened with mumps since last winter\n The employee is not thought to\nhave been in close enough contact with any patients to have spread the\nvirus, Dunton stressed, and routine infection control measures such as hand\nwashing are likely to have minimized the possibility of transmission. Infection occurs through\ndirect contact with respiratory droplets from the nose or throat, through\nsaliva, coughing, sneezing, sharing drinks, kissing or from contact with\nany surface that has been contaminated with the virus. The MMR vaccine -- which protects against mumps, measles and\nrubella, or 'German measles' -- is the most common vaccine used to protect\nagainst mumps. \n\n'Although mumps is a virus and is not treatable with antibiotics, the good\nnews is that mumps can be prevented or its impact reduced with vaccine,'\n \n\nThe Maine CDC's updated guidelines are as follows:\n- For students in kindergarten through 12th grade, all vaccine records\nshould be reviewed and updated.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2007-11-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maine", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "54261", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=54261", "date": "2008-01-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - MOLDOVA, PRIDNESTROVYE\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] Mumps - Moldova\n[2] Mumps - Pridnestrovye\n\n******\n[1] Mumps - Moldova\nDate: Wed 23 Jan 2008\nSource: Vesti News Agency [in Russian, trans. Corr.ATS, edited]\n\n\nA mumps epidemic rages in Moldova\n---------------------------------\nVasiliy Sokhotskiy, deputy director of the National Centre of Preventive\nMedicine, told journalists today [23 Jan 2008] that the Ministry of Health\nwill order 600 000 doses of mumps vaccine urgently to tackle an epidemic of\nmumps. To control the epidemic health care workers will immunize risk\ngroups who had not been vaccinated previously for various reasons.\n\nMore than 2000 cases have been recorded since the beginning of the year\n[2008] in Kishinev, the Gagauzsky autonomic district, Ungensky, Orgeevsky,\nand other districts of the Republic. The most affected are those in the\n12-19 age group. The reason for this appears to be due to the fact that\nmany children born during the period from 1986 to 1994 immediately after\n'perestroika' did not receive mumps vaccination for various reasons.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Mumps - Pridnestrovye\nDate: Thu 24 Jan 2008\nSource: Noviy Region-2 News Agency [in Russian, trans. Corr.ATS, edited]\n<http://www.nr2.ru/pmr/160539.html>\n\n\nMumps imported to Pridnestrovye from Moldova\n--------------------------------------------\nDuring the past 2 weeks, 16 cases of mumps have been registered in\nPridnestrovye. The deputy director of the Pridnestrovye Centre for Hygiene\nand Epidemiology stated that in 5 cases the infection was among people who\nhad arrived from Moldova recently. He added that colleagues in Moldova sent\na warning at the beginning of December [2007] and measures were taken to\nidentify new cases and set up surveillance.\n\nIn the event of a perceived risk of an epidemic an emergency vaccination\ncampaign will be initiated. The deputy director was confident that all the\nnecessary supplies are available. He reminded journalists that mumps\nvaccine is administered routinely to one year old children and\nrevaccination occurs at age 6-7 years. A mumps outbreak could occur,\nhowever, as a delayed consequence of mass refusal of vaccination in the\n1980s as a result of hostility in the mass media to compulsory mumps [MMR?]\nvaccination.\n\nAccording to the newspaper 'Komsomolskaya Pravda in Moldova' since the\nbeginning of 2008 about 1200 cases mumps have been registered, whereas in\n2006 there were 296 cases, and 1900 in 2007. Most cases were observed in\nKishinev, Orgeev, Ctrasheny, Nisporeny, Yaloveny, Kagul, Komrat, Rezina,\nTeleneshty, Ungeny, Khyncheshty, Novye Aneny, and Floreshty. Fewer mumps\npatients were recorded in the north of Moldova. The Moldovan experts\nconsider that the striking increase of mumps cases is connected with the\noccurrence in the 1990s of problems with vaccines. Kishinev has already\napproached the European Bureau of the World Health Organization (WHO) for\nassistance in control of the mumps epidemic.\n\n[byline: Olga Kuryleva]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This escalating outbreak of mumps appears to be an unintended consequences\nof the breakup of the Soviet Union when a segment of the population did not\nreceive mumps vaccine during the late 1980s and the early 1990s.\n\nAn interactive map of the Republic of Moldova can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=47.2,28.5,5>, and a map of the\nadministrative regions and urban centres of Moldova is available at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moldova#Administrative_divisions>.\n\nAccording to Wikipedia the status of Transnistria is disputed. Although it\nis de jure part of Moldova and is recognized as such by the international\ncommunity, Transnistria is not de facto under the control of the central\ngovernment of Moldova. It is administered by an unrecognized breakaway\nauthority under the name Pridnestrovian Moldovan Republic. - Mod.CP]\n\n.................cp/mj/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] Mumps - Moldova\n cp/mj/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n \nVasiliy Sokhotskiy, deputy director of the National Centre of Preventive\nMedicine, told journalists today [23 Jan 2008] that the Ministry of Health\nwill order 600 000 doses of mumps vaccine urgently to tackle an epidemic of\nmumps. ***********************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\n \n\n[byline: Olga Kuryleva]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nAn interactive map of the Republic of Moldova can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=47.2,28.5,5>, and a map of the\nadministrative regions and urban centres of Moldova is available at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moldova#Administrative_divisions>. Although it\nis de jure part of Moldova and is recognized as such by the international\ncommunity, Transnistria is not de facto under the control of the central\ngovernment of Moldova. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This escalating outbreak of mumps appears to be an unintended consequences\nof the breakup of the Soviet Union when a segment of the population did not\nreceive mumps vaccine during the late 1980s and the early 1990s. A mumps outbreak could occur,\nhowever, as a delayed consequence of mass refusal of vaccination in the\n1980s as a result of hostility in the mass media to compulsory mumps [MMR?] He reminded journalists that mumps\nvaccine is administered routinely to one year old children and\nrevaccination occurs at age 6-7 years. The reason for this appears to be due to the fact that\nmany children born during the period from 1986 to 1994 immediately after\n'perestroika' did not receive mumps vaccination for various reasons. The Moldovan experts\nconsider that the striking increase of mumps cases is connected with the\noccurrence in the 1990s of problems with vaccines. Kishinev has already\napproached the European Bureau of the World Health Organization (WHO) for\nassistance in control of the mumps epidemic. He added that colleagues in Moldova sent\na warning at the beginning of December [2007] and measures were taken to\nidentify new cases and set up surveillance. ATS, edited]\n<http://www.nr2.ru/pmr/160539.html>\n\n\nMumps imported to Pridnestrovye from Moldova\n The deputy director of the Pridnestrovye Centre for Hygiene\nand Epidemiology stated that in 5 cases the infection was among people who\nhad arrived from Moldova recently.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1900-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-01-24 00:00:00", "2008-01-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Khyncheshty", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moldova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Moldova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nisporeny", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rezina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kishinev", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kagul", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orgeev", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ctrasheny", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yaloveny", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Transnistria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ungeny", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "69327", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=69327", "date": "2008-03-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - MOLDOVA, PRIDNESTROVYE (03)\n***************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 27 Mar 2008\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2008 > Volume 13 / Issue 13 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/edition/v13n13/080327_2.asp>\n\n\nMumps outbreak ongoing since October 2007 in the Republic of Moldova\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Republic of Moldova is experiencing a\nnationwide mumps outbreak, with a total of 19 550\nnotified cases as of 23 Mar 2008. The outbreak\nstarted in October 2007, with 105 cases notified\nin that month compared to an average number of 24\ncases per month notified between January and\nSeptember 2007. Between 1 Oct 2007 and 31 Dec 2007, 1 524 cases were notified.\n\nIn the Republic of Moldova, mumps monovalent\nvaccination was introduced in 1983 as a\nsingle-dose schedule targeting children aged\n15-18 months-old. Since 2002, a 2nd dose has been\nadministered to 6- to 7-year-olds (birth cohorts\nfrom 1995 onwards), using a combined vaccine for\nmeasles, mumps, and rubella (MMR). Reported mumps\nvaccination coverage has been high since its\nintroduction, except for a period in the early\n1990s when a vaccine shortage occurred due to\npolitical changes. Successful catch-up campaigns\nsubsequently improved vaccination coverage in\nthose birth cohorts affected by the vaccine\nshortage. According to routine national\nsurveillance data, coverage with one dose of\nmumps vaccine is 94 percent in individuals born\nin 1989-1993. Coverage with 2 doses is 96 percent\nin individuals born in 1995-2000. Coverage in the\n1994 birth cohort is 99 percent and 21 percent\nwith one and 2 doses, respectively. The most\nrecent large mumps outbreak in the Republic of\nMoldova occurred in 1996-1998, with 28 845 cases\nreported, predominantly from birth cohorts 1983-1990 (60 percent).\n\nIn February 2008, the country's Ministry of\nHealth invited an international outbreak\ninvestigation team coordinated by the World\nHealth Organization Regional Office for Europe,\nto identify the extent of the mumps outbreak and\nassess cases and their possible risk factors for\nacquiring mumps, and to provide recommendations for the current outbreak.\n\nThe following is a preliminary description of the\nextent and characteristics of the outbreak until 2 Mar 2008.\n\nMethods\n-------\nIn the Republic of Moldova, mumps cases are\nnotified by family doctors, hospitals and health\ncentres to 44 Regional Centres for Preventive\nMedicine (RCPMs), with date of onset, initial\ndiagnosis, hospitalisation, and vaccination\nhistory where available. The RCPMs aggregate and\ntransmit the data to the National Scientific and\nPractical Centre for Preventive Medicine (NSPCPM)\non a monthly and annual basis. In addition to the\nroutine communicable diseases reporting, a weekly\ntransmission of mumps data to the NSPCPM was\nintroduced on 17 Dec 2007 to monitor the\noutbreak. These reports are based on the\nemergency notifications of suspected cases and\ncontain information on age, vaccination status,\nhospitalisation, and number of cases in\neducational institutions. Here we describe the\ncases reported weekly between 17 Dec 2007 and 2 Mar 2008 (n=13 853).\n\nMumps is notified when suspected on clinical\ngrounds by a physician. For a minority of cases\n(n=388, 3 percent), laboratory testing was\ncarried out. Mumps IgM antibody testing in\npatients' sera (n=367) was performed at the\nNSPCPM using a mumps IgM ELISA kit (Novalisa,\nNovatec Immundiagnostica GmbH, Germany).\nPolymerase chain reaction (PCR) of clinical\nspecimens (n=21) including throat swabs, oral\nfluid, and urine, was performed at the National\nInstitute for Public Health and the Environment\n(RIVM) in the Netherlands, and at the Health\nProtection Agency (HPA), Centre for Infections, in the United Kingdom (UK).\n\nOutbreak description\n--------------------\nBetween 1 Oct 2007 and 2 Mar 2008, a total of 14\n729 mumps cases were notified in the Republic of\nMoldova. Case notifications increased rapidly in\nthe weeks following the holidays around New\nYear's Day. The outbreak is ongoing at the time\nof writing this report, with a peak of 2096 cases\nin week 9 of 2008 (Figure 1). The monthly\nincidence increased from below one case per 100\n000 population in the months preceding the\noutbreak to 25 case per 100 000 in December 2007\nand more than 170 cases per 100 000 in February\n2008 [Illustrated diagrammatically in the original text].\n\nCase description\n----------------\nThe majority of cases (n=11 128; 80 percent) were\n15 to 24 years old (birth cohorts 1983-1992), and\n60 percent (n=8298) were male [illustrated\ndiagrammatically in the original text. By the end\nof February, all regions of the Republic of\nMoldova were affected by the outbreak.\n\nVaccination data were available for 67 percent\n(9223 of 13 853 cases) and 96 percent of them had\nbeen vaccinated. Of these, 96 percent had\nreceived one dose of mumps vaccine and 4 percent had received 2 doses.\n\nIn total, 5649 cases (41 percent) were\nhospitalised for epidemiological (isolation) and\nclinical indications, and where care was not\navailable (e.g., students living in dormitories).\nInformation about complications was not available\nat the national level. No deaths have been reported.\n\nOf 367 serum samples taken from clinical cases\n(one to 28 days after onset of parotid swelling),\n234 (64 percent) were positive for anti-mumps IgM\nat the NSPCPM. 313 of the 367 sera were collected\n8 to 28 days after disease onset, 68 percent of\nwhich were positive. The highest proportion of\npositive results was found in the sera collected\nbetween 11 and 20 days after disease onset (72\npercent). Of 21 case sera tested with PCR at RIVM\n(3 cases) and HPA (18 cases), 20 were positive\nfor mumps virus. The identified genotype G5 has\nrecently been found in several other countries\nincluding Croatia, Denmark, Germany, the UK,\nCanada, and the United States (US) (personal\ncommunication with Dr K. Brown/Dr L. Jin, HPA).\n\nPublic health measures\n----------------------\nFor this outbreak, the NSPCPM recommended\nhospitalisation for epidemiologic indications of\nthose cases for whom isolation was not guaranteed\nat home, particularly for cases living in\ndormitories and boarding schools. Recommended\nisolation was 10 days from onset of parotid swelling.\n\nIn January 2008, the Ministry of Health and the\nNSPCPM initiated the procurement of 600 000 doses\nof MMR vaccine for a Supplemental Immunisation\nActivity (SIA). As of 6 Mar 2008, a total of 42\n500 doses had arrived in the Republic of Moldova\nand were distributed to health facilities. The\nSIA began in week 9 of 2008 targeting individuals\nin all settings born between 1989 and 1994\n(including pupils, students and postgraduate\nstudents in all educational institutions;\nteaching staff born between 1984 and 1988; army,\npolice, and border troops). Information on the\ntotal number of MMR vaccine doses administered to\ndate during the SIA is not available.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe Republic of Moldova is facing a large ongoing\nmumps outbreak in teenagers and young adults, the\nmajority of whom have previously been vaccinated\nwith one dose of monovalent mumps vaccine. Mumps\noutbreaks comparable to this one with respect to\nsize and affected age group have occurred\nrecently in several countries, including the UK,\nthe US, and Canada. In the outbreak in the UK\n[1,2,3], 79 percent of cases in 2004 occurred in\nindividuals born between 1980-1989. Almost 2-3rds\nof the cases were unvaccinated, however, 30\npercent had received a single dose of MMR. In the\noutbreaks in the US and Canada [4], 49 percent of\nthe cases had been vaccinated twice. Mumps\nvaccine failure has often been attributed to\nprimary vaccine failure; i.e., an insufficient\nimmune response after vaccination [5]. More\nrecent studies have suggested that secondary\nvaccine failure, i.e., decreasing antibody titres\nover time (waning immunity), contributes to the\nrecurrence of mumps outbreaks [6,7]. In the\ncurrent outbreak, the high reported vaccine\ncoverage with a single dose of mumps vaccine\namong the cases suggests that 'failure to\nvaccinate' did not play a major role as the cause\nof the outbreak. Primary and secondary vaccine\nfailure [5,8] for one dose of mumps vaccine are\ncurrently being investigated in a further epidemiological study.\n\nA high proportion of cases in this outbreak were\nhospitalised, mainly to ensure isolation but also\nfor clinical and social indications. However, as\nmumps is most infectious from 2 days before to 4\ndays after onset of illness, and inapparent\ninfections can be communicable, hospital\nadmission is not expected to prevent the majority\nof transmission in the population [9].\n\nOutbreak control is ongoing with vaccination of\nhigh risk groups with MMR vaccine, consistent\nwith a recent WHO position paper on mumps [10].\nTo address potential concerns of adverse events\nfollowing immunisation (AEFI), AEFI surveillance\nincluding laboratory investigation of suspected\nmeningitis cases and training of primary health\ncare staff and epidemiologists will accompany this immunisation campaign.\n\n[Byline: H Bernard (<BernardH@rki.de>)*1,2\nNG Schwarz*3,4\nA Melnic5\nV Bucov5\nN Caterinciuc5\nR Pebody4,6\nMN Mulders7\nC Aidyralieva7, S Hahn7,8\n* first authors\n\n1. Rijksinstituut voor Volksgezondheid en Milieu\n(National Institute for Public Health and the\nEnvironment, RIVM)), Bilthoven, the Netherlands]\n\n(Acknowledgments: The authors would like to thank\nthe staff of the RCPMs for providing the data, Dr\nR van Binnendijk (RIVM), Dr K Brown (HPA) and Dr\nL Jin for providing laboratory data, Dr V Bremer\n(ECDC/EPIET) for helpful comments on the\nmanuscript, T Gavrilenco for translating, the\nMinistry of Health of the Republic of Moldova, Dr\nI Bahnarel (NSPCPM), and Dr P Ursu (WHO Country\nOffice, Republic of Moldova) for their support during the mission.)\n\nReferences\n----------\n\n(1) Cohen C, White JM, Savage EJ, Glynn JR, Choi\nY, Andrews N, et al. Available from:\n<http://www.who.int/entity/wer/2007/wer8207.pdf>\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps virus belongs to the genus _Rubulavirus_\nof the family_Paramyxoviridae_. Although there is\nonly one distinct serotype of mumps virus,\nsequence analysis of the variable gene encoding\nthe small hydrophobic protein (the SH gene) has\nshown that a number of distinct genotypes circulate globally.\n\nMumps remains a childhood disease that has been\ndiffficult to contain by vaccination. Although\nnatural infection is believed to provide\nlife-long immunity, the mumps component of the\nMMR triple vaccine is the least effective in\nproviding solid immunity. Insufficient childhood\nvaccination coverage against mumps can result in\nan epidemiological shift of disease incidence to\nolder age groups, potentially leading to higher\nrates of serious disease and complications than\noccurred before large scale immunization was introduced.\n\nThe WHO position paper accessible at\n<http://www.who.int/entity/wer/2007/wer8207.pdf>\nprovides a comprehensive account of the\nproperties and performance of the several\ndifferent vaccines developed to provide immubity to mumps virus infection.\n\nAn interactive map for the Republic of Moldova can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=47.2,28.5,5>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "The\nSIA began in week 9 of 2008 targeting individuals\nin all settings born between 1989 and 1994\n(including pupils, students and postgraduate\nstudents in all educational institutions;\nteaching staff born between 1984 and 1988; army,\npolice, and border troops). In the\ncurrent outbreak, the high reported vaccine\ncoverage with a single dose of mumps vaccine\namong the cases suggests that 'failure to\nvaccinate' did not play a major role as the cause\nof the outbreak. Health invited an international outbreak\ninvestigation team coordinated by the World\nHealth Organization Regional Office for Europe,\nto identify the extent of the mumps outbreak and\nassess cases and their possible risk factors for\nacquiring mumps, and to provide recommendations for the current outbreak. The monthly\nincidence increased from below one case per 100\n000 population in the months preceding the\noutbreak to 25 case per 100 000 in December 2007\nand more than 170 cases per 100 000 in February\n2008 In the Republic of Moldova, mumps cases are\nnotified by family doctors, hospitals and health\ncentres to 44 Regional Centres for Preventive\nMedicine (RCPMs), with date of onset, initial\ndiagnosis, hospitalisation, and vaccination\nhistory where available. Insufficient childhood\nvaccination coverage against mumps can result in\nan epidemiological shift of disease incidence to\nolder age groups, potentially leading to higher\nrates of serious disease and complications than\noccurred before large scale immunization was introduced. However, as\nmumps is most infectious from 2 days before to 4\ndays after onset of illness, and inapparent\ninfections can be communicable, hospital\nadmission is not expected to prevent the majority\nof transmission in the population [9]. (National Institute for Public Health and the\nEnvironment, RIVM)), Bilthoven, the Netherlands]\n\n(Acknowledgments: The authors would like to thank\nthe staff of the RCPMs for providing the data, Dr\nR van Binnendijk (RIVM), Dr K Brown (HPA) and Dr\nL Jin for providing laboratory data, Dr V Bremer\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 27 Mar 2008\n Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) of clinical\nspecimens (n=21) including throat swabs, oral\nfluid, and urine, was performed at the National\nInstitute for Public Health and the Environment\n(RIVM) in the Netherlands, and at the Health\nProtection Agency (HPA), Centre for Infections, in the United Kingdom (UK). The outbreak\nstarted in October 2007, with 105 cases notified\nin that month compared to an average number of 24\ncases per month notified between January and\nSeptember 2007. For this outbreak, the NSPCPM recommended\nhospitalisation for epidemiologic indications of\nthose cases for whom isolation was not guaranteed\nat home, particularly for cases living in\ndormitories and boarding schools. These reports are based on the\nemergency notifications of suspected cases and\ncontain information on age, vaccination status,\nhospitalisation, and number of cases in\neducational institutions. More\nrecent studies have suggested that secondary\nvaccine failure, i.e., decreasing antibody titres\nover time (waning immunity), contributes to the\nrecurrence of mumps outbreaks [6,7]. Reported mumps\nvaccination coverage has been high since its\nintroduction, except for a period in the early\n1990s when a vaccine shortage occurred due to\npolitical changes. In addition to the\nroutine communicable diseases reporting, a weekly\ntransmission of mumps data to the NSPCPM was\nintroduced on 17 Dec 2007 to monitor the\noutbreak. Although\nnatural infection is believed to provide\nlife-long immunity, the mumps component of the\nMMR triple vaccine is the least effective in\nproviding solid immunity. To address potential concerns of adverse events\nfollowing immunisation (AEFI), AEFI surveillance\nincluding laboratory investigation of suspected\nmeningitis cases and training of primary health\ncare staff and epidemiologists will accompany this immunisation campaign. Although there is\nonly one distinct serotype of mumps virus,\nsequence analysis of the variable gene encoding\nthe small hydrophobic protein (the SH gene) has\nshown that a number of distinct genotypes circulate globally. Mumps\noutbreaks comparable to this one with respect to\nsize and affected age group have occurred\nrecently in several countries, including the UK,\nthe US, and Canada. The WHO position paper accessible at\n<http://www.who.int/entity/wer/2007/wer8207.pdf>\nprovides a comprehensive account of the\nproperties and performance of the several\ndifferent vaccines developed to provide immubity to mumps virus infection. Available from:\n<http://www.who.int/entity/wer/2007/wer8207.pdf>\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< The identified genotype G5 has\nrecently been found in several other countries\nincluding Croatia, Denmark, Germany, the UK,\nCanada, and the United States (US) (personal\ncommunication with Dr K. Brown/Dr L. Jin, HPA). \nR Pebody4,6\nMN Mulders7\nC Aidyralieva7, S Hahn7,8\n [abstract available at <http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17498856>]\n\n(7) Vandermeulen C, Roelants M, Vermoere M,\nRoseeuw K, Goubau P, Hoppenbrouwers K. Outbreak\nof mumps in a vaccinated child population: a\nquestion of vaccine failure? \n\nOf 367 serum samples taken from clinical cases\n(one to 28 days after onset of parotid swelling),\n234 (64 percent) were positive for anti-mumps IgM\nat the NSPCPM. The Republic of Moldova is facing a large ongoing\nmumps outbreak in teenagers and young adults, the\nmajority of whom have previously been vaccinated\nwith one dose of monovalent mumps vaccine. Sustained\ntransmission of mumps in a highly vaccinated\npopulation: assessment of primary vaccine failure\nand waning vaccine-induced immunity. Mumps\nvaccine failure has often been attributed to\nprimary vaccine failure; i.e., an insufficient\nimmune response after vaccination [5]. According to routine national\nsurveillance data, coverage with one dose of\nmumps vaccine is 94 percent in individuals born\nin 1989-1993. The majority of cases (n=11 128; 80 percent) were\n15 to 24 years old (birth cohorts 1983-1992), and\n60 percent (n=8298) were male [illustrated\ndiagrammatically in the original text. Mumps outbreak in a highly\nvaccinated school population: assessment of\nsecondary vaccine failure using IgG avidity\nmeasurements. In total, 5649 cases (41 percent) were\nhospitalised for epidemiological (isolation) and\nclinical indications, and where care was not\navailable (e.g., students living in dormitories). Since 2002, a 2nd dose has been\nadministered to 6- to 7-year-olds (birth cohorts\nfrom 1995 onwards), using a combined vaccine for\nmeasles, mumps, and rubella (MMR). Mumps IgM antibody testing in\npatients' sera (n=367) was performed at the\nNSPCPM using a mumps IgM ELISA kit (Novalisa,\nNovatec Immundiagnostica GmbH, Germany). In the Republic of Moldova, mumps monovalent\nvaccination was introduced in 1983 as a\nsingle-dose schedule targeting children aged\n15-18 months-old. The highest proportion of\npositive results was found in the sera collected\nbetween 11 and 20 days after disease onset (72\npercent). Successful catch-up campaigns\nsubsequently improved vaccination coverage in\nthose birth cohorts affected by the vaccine\nshortage. In January 2008, the Ministry of Health and the\nNSPCPM initiated the procurement of 600 000 doses\nof MMR vaccine for a Supplemental Immunisation\nActivity (SIA). The RCPMs aggregate and\ntransmit the data to the National Scientific and\nPractical Centre for Preventive Medicine (NSPCPM)\non a monthly and annual basis. European Training Programme for Intervention\nEpidemiology (EPIET), European Centre for Disease\nPrevention and Control (ECDC), Stockholm, Sweden\n5. (ECDC/EPIET) for helpful comments on the\nmanuscript, T Gavrilenco for translating, the\nMinistry of Health of the Republic of Moldova, Dr\n \n\nOutbreak control is ongoing with vaccination of\nhigh risk groups with MMR vaccine, consistent\nwith a recent WHO position paper on mumps [10]. Between 1 Oct 2007 and 2 Mar 2008, a total of 14\n729 mumps cases were notified in the Republic of\nMoldova. The Republic of Moldova is experiencing a\nnationwide mumps outbreak, with a total of 19 550\nnotified cases as of 23 Mar 2008. \n\nA high proportion of cases in this outbreak were\nhospitalised, mainly to ensure isolation but also\nfor clinical and social indications. Primary and secondary vaccine\nfailure [5,8] for one dose of mumps vaccine are\ncurrently being investigated in a further epidemiological study. The outbreak is ongoing at the time\nof writing this report, with a peak of 2096 cases\nin week 9 of 2008 (Figure 1). (ALBERTA)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2007\nSource: CanWest News Service [edited]\n<http://www.canada.com/saskatoonstarphoenix/news/story.html?id=23860f28-53d0-4feb-a9b7-2d3a9d1ac0f9>\n\n\nMumps is spreading among young adults in Calgary, local health\nofficials confirmed Thursday [15 Nov 2007], as they unveiled a racy\nmarketing campaign aimed at combating the viral disease. Dr. Judy\nMacDonald, deputy medical officer of health for the Calgary Health\nRegion, said 19 cases of the mumps have been identified in\nCalgary-area patients in the past month and a half, bringing the\ntotal number of cases so far this year [2007] to 33. That's a\nsignificant increase over 6 confirmed cases in all of 2006.\n\nThe new Calgary mumps cases come as Lethbridge also battles an\noutbreak of the illness in post-secondary students. At least 27\npeople in the southern Alberta city, most of them at the city's\nuniversity and college, have suspected or confirmed cases of the\nmumps.\n\nIn Calgary, students will be told about upcoming vaccination clinics\nthrough a controversial advertising campaign that was used in Nova\nScotia, where there was a mumps outbreak earlier this year [2007].\nOne of the posters depicts a pair of flaming basketballs, an apparent\nreference to testicular swelling and pain common to the disease.\n\nThe mumps is a virus that causes fever and facial [parotid gland]\nswelling. The disease can lead to inflammation of the testes and, in\nrare cases, infertility and serious brain infections.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The reappearance of mumps in Western Canada (the province of\nAlberta) following its earlier resurgence this year (2007) in Eastern\nCanada (the provinces of Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island) is a\nconsequence of past deficiencies in vaccination coverage and\nefficacy. This has left a small number of young adults of\npost-secondary and college age without adequate protection against\nthis potentially dangerous infection. Vaccination programmes are in\nprogress to address the situation. Fortunately, there have been no\nreports so far of serious disability following recovery from mumps\nvirus infection in these age-groups in the current outbreaks.\n\nA map of Canada and its constituent provinces can be accessed at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=55.4,-101.9,4>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2007\n Dr. Judy\nMacDonald, deputy medical officer of health for the Calgary Health\nRegion, said 19 cases of the mumps have been identified in\nCalgary-area patients in the past month and a half, bringing the\ntotal number of cases so far this year [2007] to 33. Communicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The reappearance of mumps in Western Canada (the province of\nAlberta) following its earlier resurgence this year (2007) in Eastern\n At least 27\npeople in the southern Alberta city, most of them at the city's\nuniversity and college, have suspected or confirmed cases of the\nmumps. The highly infectious disease has been diagnosed in at\nleast 8 students in the past 2 weeks, with more cases likely. All\nlived in the same student accommodation, which houses about 180\npeople. Health authorities have advised the unidentified university\non isolating those affected and have offered mumps vaccine to all\nunvaccinated residents.\nMumps in adults is an uncommon condition which in rare cases can lead\nto meningitis, hearing loss and sterility. Health Department acting\nchief medical officer Professor Paddy Phillips said the disease could\ntake up to 3 weeks to become evident after being exposed. 'I wouldn't\nbe a bit surprised if there were more cases, because it's got such a\nlong incubation period,' he said yesterday [30 Oct 2007]. Most of\nthose affected have been overseas students aged 18 to 24.\nSymptoms include swelling of the sides of the face and jaw line.\nInflammation of the testicles occurs in about 20 per cent of adult\nmale cases and inflammation of the ovaries in 5 per cent of adult\nfemales. Almost 1/3rd of people will have mild or no symptoms but\nwill still be infectious. These apparently well students could be\ninfecting others who will not show signs of the disease for a\nfortnight or more.\nProfessor Phillips said none of the ill students had required\nhospital treatment. 'That's a quite uncommon complication,' he said.\n'Most people have a self-limited, slightly unpleasant illness, no\nresidual effects.' He said many were not fully protected because they\nreceived only one of the required 2 courses of vaccine in childhood.\nAlthough more than 50 doses of vaccine had since been administered to\nstudents, it will take weeks for them to develop immunity. SA has\nrecorded 11 mumps cases this year [2007], compared with 20 for all of\nlast year. Before a vaccine was introduced in the early 1980s, it was\nnormal for most of the population to acquire the virus. Treatment for\nthose affected includes paracetamol for pain and fever and isolation\nuntil 9 days after symptoms disappear.\n[Byline: Jill Pengelly]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n[This outbreak has similarity to an outbreak in Canada earlier in the\nyear, when mumps was disseminated among students across Canada from a\nuniversity in Nova Scotia (see references below). Again in Adelaide\nAustralia, introduction of infection by overseas students has\nrevealed deficiencies in the vaccine status of a considerable number\nof young students. It is to be hoped that the measures taken will be\nsufficient to contain the outbreak to the student population of\nAdelaide. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nInflammation of the testicles occurs in about 20 per cent of adult\nmale cases and inflammation of the ovaries in 5 per cent of adult\nfemales. These apparently well students could be\ninfecting others who will not show signs of the disease for a\nfortnight or more.\n Australia, introduction of infection by overseas students has\nrevealed deficiencies in the vaccine status of a considerable number\nof young students. MUMPS, STUDENTS - AUSTRALIA (ADELAIDE)\n***********************************************\n those affected includes paracetamol for pain and fever and isolation\nuntil 9 days after symptoms disappear.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "11421", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (multi-province) (07)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=11421", "date": "2007-06-02 12:00:01", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (MULTI-PROVINCE) (07)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 1 Jun 2007\nSource: CanadaEast Interactive, Canadian Press report [edited]\n<http://canadaeast.com/ce2/docroot/article.php?articleID=145970>\n\nAnother 2-dozen cases of mumps are being reported in Nova Scotia,\nbringing the total to 326 since the outbreak began in February\n[2007]. Medical officer of health, Dr. Robert Strang, has already\nsaid the peak of the outbreak is over but, as part of the normal\ncycle, more cases can be expected for weeks or months to come. And\nStrang says there's the possibility of an 'upswing' in mumps cases in\nSeptember [2007], when university students return to classes.\nStrang says a vaccination program is being considered for students\nand a meeting has been scheduled for next week with the presidents of\nthe province's universities.\nThe majority of cases have occurred in people between the ages of 20\nand 25. The outbreak in Nova Scotia has also been linked to cases in\nother provinces. In New Brunswick, there have been dozens of cases.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Previously, it was corrected on ProMED-mail that the Canadian mumps\noutbreak originated in the province of New Brunswick (see, 'Mumps -\nCanada (multi-province) (05): corr. 20070529.1720').\nAs of 25 May 2007, the number of confirmed cases were: Nova Scotia\n302 (now 326), New Brunswick 56, Prince Edward Island 2, Ontario 12,\nAlberta 2, Manitoba 2, and British Columbia 2 (see:\n<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/mumps-oreillons/prof_e.html>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: CanadaEast Interactive, Canadian Press report [edited]\n<http://canadaeast.com/ce2/docroot/article.php?articleID=145970>\n\nAnother 2-dozen cases of mumps are being reported in Nova Scotia,\nbringing the total to 326 since the outbreak began in February\n \nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n 302 (now 326), New Brunswick 56, Prince Edward Island 2, Ontario 12,\nAlberta 2, Manitoba 2, and British Columbia 2 (see:\n<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/mumps-oreillons/prof_e.html>. [Previously, it was corrected on ProMED-mail that the Canadian mumps\noutbreak originated in the province of New Brunswick (see, 'Mumps -\nCanada (multi-province) Medical officer of health, Dr. Robert Strang, has already\nsaid the peak of the outbreak is over but, as part of the normal\ncycle, more cases can be expected for weeks or months to come. Strang says a vaccination program is being considered for students\nand a meeting has been scheduled for next week with the presidents of\nthe province's universities. MUMPS - CANADA (MULTI-PROVINCE) (07)\n In New Brunswick, there have been dozens of cases.\n Date: Fri 1 Jun 2007\n **\n \n \n \n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2007-05-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "35401", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (09) (NS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=35401", "date": "2007-11-05 19:00:11", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (09) (NS)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 3 Nov 2007\nSource: Thee Chronicle Herald Nova Scotia [edited]\n<http://thechronicleherald.ca/NovaScotia/976300.html>\n\n\nNova Scotia mumps outbreak hits 715 cases\n-----------------------------------------\nThere are 9 new cases of mumps in Nova Scotia this week, bringing the total\nnumber to 715 since the outbreak began last winter, the Department of\nHealth Promotion and Protection said on Friday [2 Nov 2007]. Dr Shelly\nSarwal, the province's medical officer of health, said last week that\nbetween 10 and 20 new cases have been reported each week since the outbreak\nstarted in February, with a jump since students went back to class.\n\nSince schools reopened in September there have been 129 new cases in the\nprovince. The increase was not unexpected because a second round of\nvaccinations has yet to fully kick in, Dr Sarwal said. In July, the\nprovince announced Nova Scotia's post-secondary and Grade 12 students would\nbe offered a second dose of mumps, measles and rubella vaccine.\n\nThe mumps can be spread through coughing, sneezing and exchanging of saliva\nthrough kissing or sharing drinks. Symptoms include aches, pains, fever and\nloss of appetite. In extreme cases, mumps can lead to meningitis,\ninflammation of the testicles or ovaries, hearing loss and, according to\nthe Canadian Medical Association Journal, reduced male fertility.\n\nDr Sarwal said last week it could be weeks before the mumps outbreak is\nbrought under control. For more information, see:\n<http://www.gov.ns.ca/hpp/mumps/>\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rappoteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Cases of mumps have declined significantly in Canada since the\nintroduction of vaccination programs against the disease in the early\n1970s. This year, a mumps outbreak centred in the Maritime province has\naffected 9 Canadian provinces, and revealed gaps in MMR (mumps, measles and\nrubella) triple vaccine coverage.\n\nIn the early 1950s, an average of 34 000 cases of mumps were reported each\nyear. By the late 1990s, the average number of cases had declined to less\nthan 400 per year. Occurrence of the disease declined further following the\nintroduction in 1996-97 of a second dose of the MMR vaccine for measles\ncontrol. The second dose was introduced for children at either 18 months of\nage or 4-6 years of age, depending on the jurisdiction.\n\nIt is felt that most people over 40 have natural immunity to mumps through\nprevious exposure to the virus. It is possible, however, that individuals\nwho have not received a second dose of the vaccine dose may experience\ndiminishing levels of immunity, and may be susceptible to the virus. In\naddition, some individuals may never have been vaccinated. For this reason,\nindividuals between the ages of 12 or 17 (depending on the jurisdiction)\nand 40 years are considered to be among the most susceptible to mumps\ninfection.\n\nFive mumps outbreaks have been reported in the past decade in Canada.\nOutbreaks of the same strain of mumps virus that is currently occurring in\nCanada have also been reported in the United States and United Kingdom.\n\nAn interactive HealthNet map of Canada can be accessed via <http://\nhealthmap.org/promed?v=55.4,-101.9,4> showing the locations of the\nprovinces. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "For more information, see:\n<http://www.gov.ns.ca/hpp/mumps/>\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rappoteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Cases of mumps have declined significantly in Canada since the\nintroduction of vaccination programs against the disease in the early\n1970s. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 3 Nov 2007\n Dr Shelly\nSarwal, the province's medical officer of health, said last week that\nbetween 10 and 20 new cases have been reported each week since the outbreak\nstarted in February, with a jump since students went back to class. For this reason,\nindividuals between the ages of 12 or 17 (depending on the jurisdiction)\nand 40 years are considered to be among the most susceptible to mumps\ninfection. This year, a mumps outbreak centred in the Maritime province has\naffected 9 Canadian provinces, and revealed gaps in MMR (mumps, measles and\nrubella) triple vaccine coverage. There are 9 new cases of mumps in Nova Scotia this week, bringing the total\nnumber to 715 since the outbreak began last winter, the Department of\nHealth Promotion and Protection said on Friday [2 Nov 2007]. In July, the\nprovince announced Nova Scotia's post-secondary and Grade 12 students would\nbe offered a second dose of mumps, measles and rubella vaccine. Occurrence of the disease declined further following the\nintroduction in 1996-97 of a second dose of the MMR vaccine for measles\ncontrol.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209634", "headline": "PRO/ERR> Mumps - Canada (multi-province) (05): corr.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209634", "date": "2007-05-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (MULTI-PROVINCE) (05): CORRECTION\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 28 May 2007\nFrom: Gaynor Watson-Creed <Gaynor.Watson-Creed@cdha.nshealth.ca>\n\nCorrection re: origin of Canadian mumps outbreak\n------------------------------------------------\nIn a recent ProMED-mail posting (Mumps - Canada (multi-province) (05)\n20070526.1687), Moderator CP commented that the current outbreak of\nmumps started in Nova Scotia.\nIn fact, the outbreak started in New Brunswick, a neighboring\nprovince, with a sick student from there, visiting Nova Scotia while\ninfectious. This is depicted well in the epidemiologic curve on the\nPublic Health Agency of Canada website\n<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/mumps-oreillons/prof_e.html>\nThe commentator correctly pointed out that the outbreak, after\nintensifying in Nova Scotia, has now (predictably) affected other\nprovinces, due to university and college students traveling back to\ntheir hometowns at the end of the school year.\n--\nGaynor Watson-Creed, MSc, MD, CCFP, FRCP(C)\nMedical Officer of Health, District 9 (CDHA)\nNova Scotia Health Promotion and Protection\nc/o Public Health Services, Capital District Health Authority\nUnit 4, 201 Brownlow Ave.\nDartmouth, NS, B3B 1W2\nCanada\n<Gaynor.Watson-Creed@cdha.nshealth.ca>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The commentator correctly pointed out that the outbreak, after\nintensifying in Nova Scotia, has now (predictably) affected other\nprovinces, due to university and college students traveling back to\ntheir hometowns at the end of the school year.
