This is depicted well in the epidemiologic curve on the\nPublic Health Agency of Canada website\n<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/mumps-oreillons/prof_e.html>\nThe commentator correctly pointed out that the outbreak, after\nintensifying in Nova Scotia, has now (predictably) affected other\nprovinces, due to university and college students traveling back to\ntheir hometowns at the end of the school year.\n--\nGaynor Watson-Creed, MSc, MD, CCFP, FRCP(C)\nMedical Officer of Health, District 9 (CDHA)\nNova Scotia Health Promotion and Protection\nc/o Public Health Services, Capital District Health Authority\nUnit 4, 201 Brownlow Ave.\nDartmouth, NS, B3B 1W2\nCanada\n<Gaynor.Watson-Creed@cdha.nshealth.ca>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The commentator correctly pointed out that the outbreak, after\nintensifying in Nova Scotia, has now (predictably) affected other\nprovinces, due to university and college students traveling back to\ntheir hometowns at the end of the school year. This is depicted well in the epidemiologic curve on the\nPublic Health Agency of Canada website\n<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/mumps-oreillons/prof_e.html>\n Nova Scotia Health Promotion and Protection\nc/o Public Health Services, Capital District Health Authority\nUnit 4, 201 Brownlow Ave.\n In fact, the outbreak started in New Brunswick, a neighboring\nprovince, with a sick student from there, visiting Nova Scotia while\ninfectious.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10378", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (multi-province) (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10378", "date": "2007-05-16 23:56:01", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (MULTI-PROVINCE) (04)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 15 May 2007\nSource: CBC radio, Canadian Press report [edited]\n<http://www.cbc.ca/cp/health/070515/x051523A.html>\n\nCanada's ongoing outbreak of mumps has hit the country's biggest\ncity. And Toronto's public health officials expect the current case\ncount of 3 infections to climb before the outbreak subsides. 'I think\nwe may see more cases,' Dr. Barbara Yaffe, Director of communicable\ndisease control for Toronto Public Health, said in an interview\nTuesday 15 May 2007. That's because one of the infected young adults\nspent a number of hours last Thursday night [10 May 2007] at a\ncrowded nightspot in the city's Kensington Market neighbourhood,\nknown as the Supermarket Restaurant and Bar. 'We know it's a very\npopular place. There were probably around 300 people there, so they\nmay have been exposed to mumps,' said Yaffe.\nToronto Public Health called a news conference to [alert] both to\nyoung people who were at the bar and city doctors who may soon be\ndiagnosing a disease many would not have seen in a very long time, if\never. 'So we're saying to those people: If they develop the signs or\nsymptoms, swelling and pain in the salivary glands around the sides\nof their cheeks, fever, headache, muscle pains, aches, fatigue, or\nloss of appetite, they should [consult their doctor],' Yaffe said.\nShe urged people who believe they may have mumps not to go to their\ndoctor without calling first, so that arrangements can be made to\nensure other people aren't exposed to a potential case.\n'We're also telling people in general, and particularly in that age\ngroup -- the university age group -- to try and modify their\nbehaviour; to do less sharing of saliva. You know, don't share\ndrinks. Don't share water bottles. Because that is a great way of\nspreading infections, including mumps.'\nAs of May 11 2007 -- the most recent date for which national numbers\nare available -- the Public Health Agency of Canada was reporting 271\ncases. But those numbers are already out of date. A spokesperson for\nthe Ontario Ministry of Health said on Tuesday [11 May 2007], that\nthe province now has 9 confirmed cases, up from the 8 in the public\nhealth agency's report.\nThere are other discrepancies. British Columbia has stated it had a\ncase, in a student who has recovered and returned to Nova Scotia. But\nthe public health agency doesn't include that case in its tally\nbecause it doesn't meet the national definition. According to the\nagency's criteria, confirmation requires a positive lab test or a\nknown link between the suspected case and someone who tested positive\nfor mumps.\nThe public health agency reports cases in 4 provinces: Nova Scotia,\nNew Brunswick, Prince Edward Island, and Ontario. The vast majority\nof the infections -- 222 as of last Friday [11 May 2007] -- have\noccurred in Nova Scotia, where cases first started cropping up in\nHalifax in mid-to-late February [2007]. The city, which boasts a\nvibrant bar scene ideal for the spread of a disease like mumps, has\nbeen the epicentre of this outbreak.\nYaffe said 2 of the 3 Toronto cases are students who attend\nuniversity in Halifax who came home at the end of the school year.\nThe 3rd was a person exposed to one of the 2 cases.\nUniversity aged young adults make up the majority of the cases. They\nappear to be at greatest risk because they would have only received\none dose of measles, mumps, and vaccine rubella (MMRV) in childhood.\nWhile one dose protected a great number of people, in some people it\nwasn't sufficient to prevent infection; since the mid-1990s, 2 doses\nhave been given. But even 2 doses don't always prevent infection.\nYaffe said one of Toronto's cases had 2 shots of MMR vaccine in childhood.\nSymptoms of mumps include aches, pains, fever, loss of appetite and,\nin about 40 percent of cases, the hugely swollen saliva glands that\ngive mumps its characteristic chipmunk-cheek look. In males past\npuberty the virus can also infect one or both testicles, leading to a\npainful condition known as orchitis. Mumps in both testicles can\nresult in sterility. Other potential, if rare, side effects include\nmeningitis and encephalitis. and women who become infected during the\n1st trimester of pregnancy are at increased risk of miscarrying.\n'It's generally a benign childhood disease -- that's what we think\nof,' said Yaffe. 'But again, with all these benign childhood diseases\nthere is some complication rate.'\n[Byline: Helen Branswell]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph P. Dudley, Ph.D.", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 15 May 2007\n The vast majority\nof the infections -- 222 as of last Friday [11 May 2007] -- have\noccurred in Nova Scotia, where cases first started cropping up in\nHalifax in mid-to-late February [2007]. ' According to the\nagency's criteria, confirmation requires a positive lab test or a\nknown link between the suspected case and someone who tested positive\nfor mumps. Mumps in both testicles can\nresult in sterility.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2007-05-15 00:00:00", "2007-05-11 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10629", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (multi-province)(06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10629", "date": "2007-05-27 19:00:01", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (MULTI-PROVINCE) (06)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 26 May 2007\nSource: CTV.ca, Canadian Press [edited]\n<http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20070526/navy_mumps_070526/20070526?hub=Canada>\n\nAlmost an entire crew of a Halifax-based navy ship has been sent home\nafter one of the vessel's crew members came down with a case of\nmumps. Roughly 50 of HMCS Glace Bay's 60-person crew were sent home\non Thu 24 May 2007 as a precautionary measure, Lt.-Cmdr. Marie-Claude\nGagne said on Sat 26 May 2007.\n'What we've done is we've sent home crew members that have been\nexposed to the sailor in question that hadn't already been immunized\nagainst mumps or that hadn't contracted the disease prior in life,''\nshe said. Gagne said the navy expects the crew will be off for at\nleast a week, when officials will reassess the situation. The ship\nwas not scheduled to participate in any naval operations, so the\ncrew's absence will have little effect.\nA few weeks ago, crew members on another navy ship were sent home\nafter a crew member became ill. The crew member who was sick is now\nback to work. 'Similar precautions were taken with people that were\nin contact with him,'' Gagne said, but she did not know how many\npeople were sent home.\nThe outbreak in Nova Scotia began in February 2007 and has continued\nto grow. On Friday [25 May 2007], provincial health authorities said\n302 people had been infected in the past 3 months, an increase of 30\nover figures released a week earlier.\nSix other provinces have reported cases of mumps, with some of those\nlinked to Nova Scotia's outbreak. The latest provinces to be affected\nby the virus have been British Columbia and Manitoba [The others are:\nNew Brunswick, Prince Edward Island, Ontario and Alberta. - Mod.CP].\nManitoba reported its 1st 2 cases in the ongoing outbreak on Fri 25\nMay 2007, while British Columbia health officials were awaiting test\nresults on 2 more people and observing 2 others. Those 6 cases have\nbeen linked to a sporting event in Winnipeg in early May 2007 that\ndrew participants from around the country, including someone who had\ndeveloped mumps in Nova Scotia. British Columbia had already reported\n3 cases, though the 1st was never tested and, therefore, doesn't meet\nthe national criteria to be counted as a case.\nThe Public Health Agency of Canada, in its most recent update posted\nearlier in the week, listed 45 cases in New Brunswick, 2 in Prince\nEdward Island and one in Alberta. Ontario's Ministry of Health had\nreported 12 confirmed cases as of Friday [25 May 2007], and officials\nthere were still investigating whether the infections were related to\nNova Scotia.\nThe majority of the patients have been young adults between 17 and 24\nyears old, an age group that grew up before children were given 2\nshots of a vaccine against mumps, measles and rubella. The single\ndose they would have received has left many unable to fend off the\nvirus and as a result leaves them more susceptible. Symptoms of mumps\ninclude aches, pains, fever, loss of appetite and swollen salivary\nglands, although there are more serious complications, including deafness.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Information on the vaccination status and the circumstances of the\nexposure of the 2 navy men is required for a proper risk assessment\nof this incident. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 26 May 2007\n Source: CTV.ca, Canadian Press [edited]\n<http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20070526/navy_mumps_070526/20070526?hub=Canada>\n\nAlmost an entire crew of a Halifax-based navy ship has been sent home\nafter one of the vessel's crew members came down with a case of\nmumps. What we've done is we've sent home crew members that have been\nexposed to the sailor in question that hadn't already been immunized\nagainst mumps or that hadn't contracted the disease prior in life,''\n Those 6 cases have\nbeen linked to a sporting event in Winnipeg in early May 2007 that\ndrew participants from around the country, including someone who had\ndeveloped mumps in Nova Scotia. Ontario's Ministry of Health had\nreported 12 confirmed cases as of Friday [25 May 2007], and officials\nthere were still investigating whether the infections were related to\nNova Scotia. Symptoms of mumps\ninclude aches, pains, fever, loss of appetite and swollen salivary\nglands, although there are more serious complications, including deafness.\n \nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n On Friday [25 May 2007], provincial health authorities said\n302 people had been infected in the past 3 months, an increase of 30\nover figures released a week earlier. The majority of the patients have been young adults between 17 and 24\nyears old, an age group that grew up before children were given 2\nshots of a vaccine against mumps, measles and rubella. The Public Health Agency of Canada, in its most recent update posted\nearlier in the week, listed 45 cases in New Brunswick, 2 in Prince\nEdward Island and one in Alberta. British Columbia had already reported\n3 cases, though the 1st was never tested and, therefore, doesn't meet\nthe national criteria to be counted as a case. [Information on the vaccination status and the circumstances of the\nexposure of the 2 navy men is required for a proper risk assessment\nof this incident.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-01-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-05-24 00:00:00", "2007-05-25 00:00:00", "2007-02-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Manitoba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10616", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (multi-province) (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10616", "date": "2007-05-26 19:00:02", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (MULTI-PROVINCE) (05)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 25 May 2007\nSource: CBS News, Canada Manitoba, Fri 25 May 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2007/05/25/mumps-manitoba.html>\n\nMumps arrives in Manitoba\n-------------------------\nAn outbreak of mumps in eastern Canada appears to have spread to\nManitoba. Public health officials have confirmed 2 reported cases of\nmumps in Winnipeg, both in people in their 20s. Neither has been hospitalized.\nOfficials said the 2 were likely exposed to mumps when an infected\nstudent from the east visited the University of Manitoba earlier this\nmonth [May 2007]. There have been more than 300 cases of mumps in\nNova Scotia since the outbreak began there in Feb 20007.\nAlthough there can be rare complications from mumps, most cases are\nmild, with full recovery in a week or 2. Until now, cases in Manitoba\nhave been rare, with either no cases or one case reported a year.\nYoung children are routinely vaccinated for the virus, which causes\nswelling and pain in the salivary glands.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[The mumps epidemic originating in the province of Nova Scotia has\nnot unexpectedly spread eastwards with dispersal of university\nstudents at the end of term to the provinces of New Brunswick, Prince\nEdward Island, Ontario, British Columbia (disputed) and now Manitoba. - Canada (08) (multi-province, PEI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=33707", "date": "2007-10-25 19:00:08", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (08) (MULTI-PROVINCE, PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 24 Oct 2007\nSource: CBC News [edited]\n<http://www.cbc.ca/canada/prince-edward-island/story/2007/10/24/mumps-upei.html>\n\n\nPracticums for student teachers at the University of Prince Edward\nIsland [UPEI] have been postponed after 3 students came down with the\nmumps, CBC News reported Wednesday [24 Oct 2007]. 'Until further\nnotice ... our education students are not in the schools fulfilling\npracticum requirements,' said Tamara Leary, acting director of\nstudent services at UPEI.\n\nLeary said the last case of mumps was diagnosed on 12 Oct 2007. If no\nnew cases are reported, UPEI education students should be back in\nclassrooms to do practical teaching on 19 Nov 2007.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The 2007 Canadian mumps epidemic, originating in the province of New\nBrunswick, spread westwards with dispersal of university students at\nthe end of term from the provinces of New Brunswick and Nova Scotia\nto Ontario, Manitoba and British Columbia. A comprehensive account of\nthe epidemic by the Canadian Public Health Agency, updated to 12 Oct\n2007 and including an epidemiologic curve, is available at\n<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/mumps-oreillons/prof_e.html>.\n\nAs of 12 Oct 2007, 847 confirmed cases of mumps related to the\noutbreak have been reported from 9 out of 13 Canadian provinces and\nterritories (Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Prince Edward Island,\nNewfoundland, Quebec, Ontario, Manitoba, Alberta, and British\nColumbia). The outbreak activity remains centered in Nova Scotia and\nNew Brunswick localities with sporadic exportations to other provinces.\n\nAll cases investigated in the outbreak could be either linked to\ncases in the Maritimes or are close contacts of these cases. To date,\nthere has been no sustained transmission outside of the Maritimes\nrelated to the outbreak, although other imported or sporadic cases of\nmumps may also occur. The viral strain in these outbreaks is\nidentical to the strain (genotype G) detected from the 2005-06 Nova\nScotia outbreaks, the United States' multi-state outbreak in 2006 and\nthe United Kingdom epidemic between 2004 and 2006.\n\nThe case reported above appears to be only the 3rd case to be\nreported in PEI during the course of the outbreak and the 1st since\nMay 2007. Clarification is requested. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 24 Oct 2007\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The 2007 Canadian mumps epidemic, originating in the province of New\nBrunswick, spread westwards with dispersal of university students at\nthe end of term from the provinces of New Brunswick and Nova Scotia\nto Ontario, Manitoba and British Columbia. As of 12 Oct 2007, 847 confirmed cases of mumps related to the\noutbreak have been reported from 9 out of 13 Canadian provinces and\nterritories (Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Prince Edward Island,\n The viral strain in these outbreaks is\nidentical to the strain (genotype G) detected from the 2005-06 Nova\nScotia outbreaks, the United States' multi-state outbreak in 2006 and\nthe United Kingdom epidemic between 2004 and 2006. To date,\nthere has been no sustained transmission outside of the Maritimes\nrelated to the outbreak, although other imported or sporadic cases of\nmumps may also occur. Source: CBC News [edited]\n<http://www.cbc.ca/canada/prince-edward-island/story/2007/10/24/mumps-upei.html>\n\n\nPracticums for student teachers at the University of Prince Edward\nIsland [UPEI] have been postponed after 3 students came down with the\nmumps, CBC News reported Wednesday", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-06-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manitoba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States '", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leary", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Newfoundland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10326", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (multi-province) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10326", "date": "2007-05-14 10:00:02", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (MULTI-PROVINCE) (03)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 11 May 2007\nSource: canada.com, Canadian Press report, Fri 11 May 2007 [edited]\n<http://bodyandhealth.canada.com/channel_health_news_details.asp?news_id=12321&news_channel_id=1020&channel_id=1020>\n\nNova Scotia to begin mumps immunization for health-care workers\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nNova Scotia is starting a mumps immunization program for health-care\nworkers as an outbreak of the virus in the province climbed in the last\nweek [6-12 May 2007] by 19 confirmed cases to 222 on Fri [11 May 2007].\nThe immunization program will begin as early as next week with roughly 40\n000 doses of measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine being made available\nto health-care workers. A week ago [6 May 2007], there were 203 confirmed\ncases of the virus in Nova Scotia.\nDr. Shelly Sarwal, the province's medical officer of health, said the\nvaccination program will help the maintain health services in the\nprovince. 'We feel this is an important public health measure,' Sarwal\nsaid in a news release. 'A vaccination campaign will not stop the\noutbreak, but what it will do is help to manage absenteeism in health-care\nworkers as a result of mumps, and therefore help sustain the health-care\nsystem for Nova Scotians.'\nSince the beginning of the outbreak in February [2007], 222 cases of mumps\nhave been reported across Nova Scotia - and the disease is continuing its\ntrack into other provinces. New Brunswick reported on Friday [11 May 2007]\nthat its case load had jumped to 40, up from 34 a week earlier. Prince\nEdward Island remained unchanged at one confirmed case.\nOntario health officials said there are now 8 confirmed cases in the\nprovince, up from 3 a week ago [6 May 2007]. Of those, 6 are university\nstudents in Nova Scotia who recently returned home to Ontario for the\nsummer. The other 2 cases are adults who had been travelling in the\nAtlantic province.\nWhile the number of new cases in the Halifax region is declining,\nelsewhere across the province cases were up from last week [6-12 May\n2007]. Health officials predicted the decline in the Halifax area as\nuniversity students, where the outbreak is believed to have begun,\nreturned home for the summer. Public health officials said they spoke this\nweek with their counterparts in the United States and the United Kingdom\nabout lessons learned from management of mumps outbreaks in those\ncountries.\nNova Scotia is also looking at an immunization program for the\nuniversity-age population. People are being advised to watch for patients\nwith mumps-like symptoms. These include aches, pains, fever, loss of\nappetite and, in about 40 percent of cases, the hugely swollen saliva\nglands that give mumps its characteristic chipmunk-cheek look.\nThe Nova Scotia outbreak, which began in the 3 week of February [2007], is\nthe province's 3rd in 2 years. It is by far the largest; the earlier\noutbreaks, in 2005, involved 13 and 19 cases respectively. It has been\nfuelled by a pool of susceptible young adults. Sarwal has said authorities\nbelieve many of the province's cases were vaccinated with MMR [measles,\nmumps, rubella] in childhood, but received only one dose. The one-dose\nschedule for the MMR vaccine was adequate to protect many people. If it\nhad not been, this outbreak would be much larger. But it's now known one\ndose doesn't protect everyone and MMR is now given in 2 doses. University\ndormitories and crowded student apartments make for easy spread of the\nvirus among susceptible young adults. When they move home, however, they\nspend more time around adults, most of whom would have had mumps in\nchildhood and would be immune.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 12 May 2007\nSource: globeandmail.com, Canadian Press report, Sat 12 May 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/LAC.20070512.MUMPSCASE12/TPStory/National>\n\nNova Scotian health-care workers to be immunized; 1st case in British\nColumbia\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nWith the number of mumps cases rising in the province, the Nova Scotian\ngovernment announced yesterday it will begin immunizing thousands of\nhealth-care workers against the virus as early as next week [14-19 May\n2007]. As of yesterday [Fri 11 May 2007], 222 confirmed cases had been\nreported in Nova Scotia, up 19 from 203 the previous week. Shelly Sarwal,\nthe province's medical officer of health, said about 40 000 doses of the\nmeasles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine are being made available on a\nvoluntary basis to health-care workers, with the aim of protecting health\nservices in the province. 'Providing this vaccine now to health-care\nworkers isn't going to do much for the current outbreak,' Dr. Sarwal said\nin an interview yesterday. 'It's for preventing future outbreaks similar\nto this and for making sure that our population is properly immunized. The\npurpose of this program is to maintain our health-care system and the\nstaffing within the health-care system,' she said. 'We do have some\nhealth-care workers who have been diagnosed with the mumps who are off of\nwork.'\nAbout 900 of the province's 30 000-plus health providers have been exposed\nto mumps, and currently 130 are off the job, she said. Any worker who has\ncome into contact with an infected person could potentially be off work\nfor 2 weeks or more because the incubation period for the virus is 14 to\n25 days. 'We have to be extra cautious within the health-care system,' Dr.\nSarwal added. 'I can't take the chance of a health-care worker\ntransmitting the infection to a patient.'\nWhile the number of new cases in the Halifax region is declining,\nelsewhere across Nova Scotia cases were up from last week[6-12 May 2007].\nThe Nova Scotia mumps outbreak began in February [2007], likely among\nuniversity-aged students with inadequate immunity to the virus. Cases have\nbegun springing up elsewhere in Canada, as those exposed to the disease\nreturn to their home provinces. The latest province to join the mumps hit\nlist is British Columbia (BC), which has one confirmed case reported, said\nPerry Kendall, BC's medical officer of health.\nAs of yesterday [Fri 11 May 2007], New Brunswick had 40 cases, up from 34\na week earlier. Prince Edward Island remained unchanged at one confirmed\ncase. Manitoba and Saskatchewan report no mumps cases, while Alberta has 3\ncases for the year, but they are among unimmunized, international\ntravellers and unrelated to the Nova Scotia outbreak. In Ontario, health\nofficials said there are now 8 confirmed cases, up from 3 a week ago [6\nMay 2007]. Of those, 6 are students who attend university in Nova Scotia\nand recently returned home to Ontario for the summer. The other 2 cases\nare adults who had been travelling in the Atlantic province.\nSymptoms of mumps include aches, pains, fever, loss of appetite and, in\nabout 40 percent of cases, the hugely swollen saliva glands that give\nmumps patients their characteristic chipmunk-cheek look. Public health\nofficials said they spoke this week with their counterparts in the United\nStates and Britain about lessons they have learned from management of\nmumps outbreaks.\n--\nCommunicated by:\na Canadian correspondent\n[ProMED-mail thanks again our Canadian correspondent for drawing\nattention to these reports. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Shelly Sarwal,\nthe province's medical officer of health, said about 40 000 doses of the\nmeasles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine are being made available on a\nvoluntary basis to health-care workers, with the aim of protecting health\nservices in the province. ' A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 11 May 2007\n Public health officials said they spoke this\nweek with their counterparts in the United States and the United Kingdom\nabout lessons learned from management of mumps outbreaks in those\ncountries.\n Public health\nofficials said they spoke this week with their counterparts in the United\nStates and Britain about lessons they have learned from management of\nmumps outbreaks.\n A vaccination campaign will not stop the\noutbreak, but what it will do is help to manage absenteeism in health-care\nworkers as a result of mumps, and therefore help sustain the health-care\nsystem for Nova Scotians.' While the number of new cases in the Halifax region is declining,\nelsewhere across the province cases were up from last week [6-12 May\n2007]. Symptoms of mumps include aches, pains, fever, loss of appetite and, in\nabout 40 percent of cases, the hugely swollen saliva glands that give\nmumps patients their characteristic chipmunk-cheek look. The latest province to join the mumps hit\nlist is British Columbia (BC), which has one confirmed case reported, said\nPerry Kendall, BC's medical officer of health. ' 'We do have some\nhealth-care workers who have been diagnosed with the mumps who are off of\nwork.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-06-12 00:00:00", "2007-05-11 00:00:00", "2007-05-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Britain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manitoba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10258", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (multi-province) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10258", "date": "2007-05-10 17:00:01", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (MULTI-PROVINCE) (02)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 9 May 2007\nSource: Public Health Agency of Canada [edited]\n<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/mumps-oreillons/prof_e.html#ns>\n\nUpdate on mumps outbreak in the Maritimes: national summary, 4 May 2007\n-----------------------------------------------------------------------\nMumps cases are currently being reported in 4 Canadian provinces (Nova\nScotia, New Brunswick, Prince Edward Island, and Ontario). Mumps is an\nacute viral infection of the salivary glands. Symptoms include fever,\nheadache, muscle ache, and swelling and tenderness of the salivary glands\nat the angle of the jaw (parotid glands). Infection occurs through direct\ncontact with respiratory droplets from the nose or throat, through saliva,\ncoughing, sneezing, sharing drinks, kissing, or from contact with any\nsurface that has been contaminated with the mumps virus. Rarely, mumps\ninfection can lead to meningitis, inflammation of the testicles or ovaries,\ninflammation of the pancreas, and transient or permanent hearing loss.\nAs of 4 May 2007, 241 confirmed cases of mumps had been reported from the 4\naffected provinces.\nTable: Age and sex distribution of confirmed* mumps cases reported in 4\nCanadian provinces, 4 May 2007 (N=241):\nProvince / number / median age / percentage males\nNova Scotia / 203 / 22 / 45\nNew Brunswick / 34 / 21 / 44\nPrince Edward Island / 1 / 18 / 100\nOntario / 3 / 29 / 100\n* Confirmed cases include both laboratory-confirmed and clinical cases\n(latter are epi-linked to laboratory-confirmed cases).\nIn Nova Scotia and New Brunswick, the majority of cases were reported from\nonly one or 2 public health authorities with limited activity seen\nelsewhere in these provinces. About 90 per cent and 25 per cent of the\ncases in Nova Scotia and New Brunswick respectively, are associated with\nuniversity settings. The viral strain in these outbreaks is identical to\nthe strain (genotype G) detected from the 2005-06 Nova Scotia outbreaks,\nthe United States' multistate outbreak in 2006, and the United Kingdom\nepidemic between 2004 and 2006. The Ontario cases are all linked to cases\nin the Maritimes.\nInformation on date of onset is known for 217 of the 241 confirmed mumps\ncases reported, and is displayed as a histogram in the original text. The\nremaining 24 cases are pending or missing dates of onset.\nThe majority of cases are occurring among university-aged individuals. The\nreason for the particular susceptibility among this cohort is\nmultifactorial. The very social and mobile lifestyle of this age group\nappears to be facilitating disease transmission and is posing barriers to\nthe adherence of isolation requests. Communication efforts are increasing\nas the post-secondary academic year [ends] and students disperse.\nAdditional cases in this demographic group and possibly other jurisdictions\nwould not be unexpected. However, during previous outbreaks in Canada, this\nhas not resulted in sustained transmission or large outbreaks.\nIt is assumed that most people over the age of about 40 years have natural\nimmunity to mumps. Most people between the ages of 12 and 17 years\n(depending on the province of residence) have had 2 doses of mumps vaccine\ndue to the introduction of a second dose of measles, mumps and rubella\n(MMR) vaccine for measles control in 1996-97. This has left a susceptible\ncohort of people between the approximate ages of 12 or 17 (depending on the\nprovince or territory) and 40 years who were only eligible for one dose of\nMMR vaccine and who are not assumed to have natural immunity. It is\nimportant to note, that the age at which natural immunity to mumps can be\nassumed is not known with certainty and that some individuals born prior to\n1970 may still be susceptible to mumps.\nThe 2004 national immunization coverage survey (NICS) found that 94 per\ncent of Canadian children had received single dose of the MMR vaccine by\ntheir 2nd birthday. Coverage estimates for the 2nd dose of MMR by 7 years\nof age was 79 per cent. Finally, 93 per cent of Canadians had received one\nor more doses of mumps vaccine by their 17th birthday.\nPublic health actions\n---------------------\n[See Mumps, Canada (multi-province) 20070505.1459]\nDue to a risk of exposure to measles, NACI currently recommends a 2nd dose\nof the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine (MMR) for certain adults born\nafter 1970. This includes students at post secondary institutions and\nhealth care workers.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The information in this report supplements earlier data with a breakdown\nof cases by gender. The original version of this update (available at the\nsource URL above) also contains an epidemic curve, which should be\nconsulted for additional information. ProMED-mail thanks our Canadian\ncorrespondent for drawing attention to this document. - Mod.CP\nThe Canadian Maritimes consists of the 3 provinces of New Brunswick, Nova\nScotia, and Prince Edward Island, which can be located on the map of Canada\nat\n<http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/site/english/maps/reference/national/can_political_e/referencemap_image_view>.\n- CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n New Brunswick / 34 / 21 / 44\nPrince Edward Island / 1 / 18 / 100\nOntario / 3 / 29 / 100\n* Confirmed cases include both laboratory-confirmed and clinical cases\n(latter are epi-linked to laboratory-confirmed cases). \nTable: Age and sex distribution of confirmed* mumps cases reported in 4\nCanadian provinces, 4 May 2007 (N=241):\nProvince / number / median age / percentage males\n Most people between the ages of 12 and 17 years\n(depending on the province of residence) have had 2 doses of mumps vaccine\ndue to the introduction of a second dose of measles, mumps and rubella\n It is\nimportant to note, that the age at which natural immunity to mumps can be\nassumed is not known with certainty and that some individuals born prior to\n1970 may still be susceptible to mumps. This has left a susceptible\ncohort of people between the approximate ages of 12 or 17 (depending on the\nprovince or territory) and 40 years who were only eligible for one dose of\nMMR vaccine and who are not assumed to have natural immunity. Infection occurs through direct\ncontact with respiratory droplets from the nose or throat, through saliva,\ncoughing, sneezing, sharing drinks, kissing, or from contact with any\nsurface that has been contaminated with the mumps virus. The viral strain in these outbreaks is identical to\nthe strain (genotype G) detected from the 2005-06 Nova Scotia outbreaks,\nthe United States' multistate outbreak in 2006, and the United Kingdom\nepidemic between 2004 and 2006. The Canadian Maritimes consists of the 3 provinces of New Brunswick, Nova\nScotia, and Prince Edward Island, which can be located on the map of Canada\nat\n<http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/site/english/maps/reference/national/can_political_e/referencemap_image_view>. \nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org Due to a risk of exposure to measles, NACI currently recommends a 2nd dose\nof the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine (MMR) for certain adults born\nafter 1970. -----------------------------------------------------------------------\nMumps cases are currently being reported in 4 Canadian provinces (Nova\nScotia, New Brunswick, Prince Edward Island, and Ontario). Source: Public Health Agency of Canada [edited]\n<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/mumps-oreillons/prof_e.html#ns>\n\nUpdate on mumps outbreak in the Maritimes: national summary, 4 May 2007\n In Nova Scotia and New Brunswick, the majority of cases were reported from\nonly one or 2 public health authorities with limited activity seen\nelsewhere in these provinces. The 2004 national immunization coverage survey (NICS) found that 94 per\ncent of Canadian children had received single dose of the MMR vaccine by\ntheir 2nd birthday. About 90 per cent and 25 per cent of the\ncases in Nova Scotia and New Brunswick respectively, are associated with\nuniversity settings. Rarely, mumps\ninfection can lead to meningitis, inflammation of the testicles or ovaries,\ninflammation of the pancreas, and transient or permanent hearing loss. The very social and mobile lifestyle of this age group\nappears to be facilitating disease transmission and is posing barriers to\nthe adherence of isolation requests. Symptoms include fever,\nheadache, muscle ache, and swelling and tenderness of the salivary glands\nat the angle of the jaw (parotid glands). This includes students at post secondary institutions and\nhealth care workers.\n The original version of this update (available at the\nsource URL above) also contains an epidemic curve, which should be\nconsulted for additional information. The\nreason for the particular susceptibility among this cohort is\nmultifactorial. \nPublic health actions\n As of 4 May 2007, 241 confirmed cases of mumps had been reported from the 4\naffected provinces. Information on date of onset is known for 217 of the 241 confirmed mumps\ncases reported, and is displayed as a histogram in the original text. It is assumed that most people over the age of about 40 years have natural\nimmunity to mumps. The Ontario cases are all linked to cases\nin the Maritimes.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2005-06-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-05-04 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "1970-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States '", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10058", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (NS) (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10058", "date": "2007-05-01 14:00:01", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (NOVA SCOTIA) (06)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 26 Apr 2007\nSource: Public Health Agency of Canada, National Summary [edited]\n<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/mumps-oreillons/prof_e.html#ns>\n\nIncreased mumps activity is currently being reported in 3 Canadian\nprovinces (Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island).\nMumps is an acute viral infection of the salivary glands. Symptoms\ninclude fever, headache, muscle ache, and swelling and tenderness of\nthe salivary glands at the angle of the jaw (parotid glands).\nInfection occurs through direct contact with respiratory droplets\nfrom the nose or throat, through saliva, coughing, sneezing, sharing\ndrinks, kissing, or from contact with any surface that has been\ncontaminated with the mumps virus. Rarely, mumps infection can lead\nto meningitis, inflammation of the testicles or ovaries, inflammation\nof the pancreas, and transient or permanent hearing loss.\nAs of Thu 26 Apr 2007, 183 confirmed cases of mumps had been reported\nfrom the 3 affected provinces. Confirmed cases include both\nlaboratory-confirmed cases, as well as, clinically confirmed cases\nthat are linked to laboratory-confirmed cases. In Nova Scotia and New\nBrunswick, the majority of cases were reported from only one or 2\npublic health authorities with limited activity seen elsewhere in\nthese provinces. Approximately 90 percent and 25 percent of the cases\nin Nova Scotia and New Brunswick respectively, are associated with\nuniversity settings. The viral strain in these outbreaks is identical\nto the strain (genotype G) detected from the 2005-06 Nova Scotia\noutbreaks, the United States' multi-state outbreak in 2006, and the\nUnited Kingdom epidemic between 2004 and 2006.\n[The data for the 3 provinces (age and sex of confirmed cases now\nslightly out-dated) are tabulated and presented as a histogram in the\noriginal text which should be consulted for precise information]\nConfirmed cases include both laboratory-confirmed and clinical cases\n(latter are epi-linked to laboratory-confirmed cases). Information on\ndate of onset is known for 132 of the 183 confirmed mumps cases\nreported. The remaining 51 cases are pending or missing dates of\nonset. Clinical-confirmed refers to cases that have clinical symptoms\ncharacteristic of mumps PLUS are epidemiologically linked to\nlaboratory-confirmed cases (but have not themselves been laboratory-confirmed\nTable: Age and Sex Distribution of Confirmed Mumps Cases Reported in\n3 Canadian Provinces, 26 Apr 2007 (N=183)\nProvince / Number / Median age / percentage male\nNova Scotia / 154 / 21.5 / 44\nNew Brunswick / 28 / 22 / 57\nPrince Edward Island / 1 / 18 / 100\nThe majority of cases are occurring among university-aged\nindividuals. The reason for the particular susceptibility among this\ncohort is multifactorial. The very social and mobile lifestyle of\nthis age group appears to be facilitating disease transmission and is\nposing barriers to the adherence of isolation requests. Communication\nefforts are increasing as the post-secondary academic year [ends] and\nstudents disperse. Additional cases in this demographic group and\npossibly other jurisdictions would not be unexpected. However, during\nprevious outbreaks in Canada, this has not resulted in sustained\ntransmission or large outbreaks.\nIt is assumed that most people over the age of approximately 40 years\nhave natural immunity to mumps. Most people between the ages of 12\nand 17 years (depending on the province of residence) have had 2\ndoses of mumps vaccine due to the introduction of a second dose of\nmeasles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine for measles control in\n1996-97. This has left a susceptible cohort of people between the\napproximate ages of 12 or 17 (depending on the province or territory)\nand 40 years who were only eligible for one dose of MMR vaccine and\nwho are not assumed to have natural immunity. It is important to\nnote, that the age at which natural immunity to mumps can be assumed\nis not known with certainty.\nThe 2004 national immunization coverage survey (NICS) found that 94\npercent of Canadian children had received single dose of the MMR\nvaccine by their 2nd birthday. Coverage estimates for the second dose\nof MMR by 7 years of age was 79 percent. Finally, 93 percent of\nCanadians had received one or more doses of mumps vaccine by their\n17th birthday.\nPublic Health actions\n---------------------\nCases are asked to self-isolate for a period of 9 days following\nonset of symptoms. The vaccine status of close contacts is assessed\nand updated so that they receive 2 doses of MMR. Guidelines have been\nput in place for health care workers who are cases or who are\ncontacts of mumps cases.\nPublic health and primary care providers are encouraged to refer to\ntheir local or provincial/territorial ministry of health for specific\nrecommendations on action that may be required within that jurisdiction.\nAll provinces and territories, have been informed of the\nepidemiologic situation and the public health management strategies\nin the affected jurisdictions. Based on this, all jurisdictions are\nencouraged to continue monitoring mumps activity within their regions\nand report any changes and/or cases to the Public Health Agency of\nCanada, particularly in provinces and territories not currently\naffected by the on-going outbreak.\nThe Public Health Agency of Canada will continue to provide updates\non the current outbreak of mumps. The Agency is working with the\naffected provinces in monitoring this outbreak, providing technical\nadvice, and assisting with laboratory testing of clinical specimens\nat the National Microbiology Laboratory. The Public Health Agency of\nCanada supports the provincial outbreak response strategies that\ninclude the recommended isolation of cases and targeted immunization\nof contacts. There are on-going discussions regarding an expanded\nimmunization strategy to target the susceptible cohort.\nThe Public Health Agency of Canada encourages parents, guardians, and\nadults to maintain up to date immunizations for themselves and their\nchildren, and encourages susceptible individuals to be immunized in\naccordance with the National Advisory Committee on Immunization\n(NACI) guidelines. All guidelines can be accessed at\n<http://www.naci.gc.ca/>www.naci.gc.ca.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail thanks our Canadian correspondent for drawing attention\nto this document. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Based on this, all jurisdictions are\nencouraged to continue monitoring mumps activity within their regions\nand report any changes and/or cases to the Public Health Agency of\nCanada, particularly in provinces and territories not currently\naffected by the on-going outbreak.\n Clinical-confirmed refers to cases that have clinical symptoms\ncharacteristic of mumps PLUS are epidemiologically linked to\nlaboratory-confirmed cases (but have not themselves been laboratory-confirmed\nTable: Age and Sex Distribution of Confirmed Mumps Cases Reported in\n3 Canadian Provinces, A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Most people between the ages of 12\nand 17 years (depending on the province of residence) have had 2\ndoses of mumps vaccine due to the introduction of a second dose of\nmeasles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine for measles control in\n1996-97. The viral strain in these outbreaks is identical\nto the strain (genotype G) detected from the 2005-06 Nova Scotia\noutbreaks, the United States' multi-state outbreak in 2006, and the\nUnited Kingdom epidemic between 2004 and 2006.\n The Public Health Agency of Canada encourages parents, guardians, and\nadults to maintain up to date immunizations for themselves and their\nchildren, and encourages susceptible individuals to be immunized in\naccordance with the National Advisory Committee on Immunization\n [The data for the 3 provinces (age and sex of confirmed cases now\nslightly out-dated) are tabulated and presented as a histogram in the\noriginal text which should be consulted for precise information]\n In Nova Scotia and New\nBrunswick, the majority of cases were reported from only one or 2\npublic health authorities with limited activity seen elsewhere in\nthese provinces. This has left a susceptible cohort of people between the\napproximate ages of 12 or 17 (depending on the province or territory)\nand 40 years who were only eligible for one dose of MMR vaccine and\nwho are not assumed to have natural immunity. The Agency is working with the\naffected provinces in monitoring this outbreak, providing technical\nadvice, and assisting with laboratory testing of clinical specimens\nat the National Microbiology Laboratory. Confirmed cases include both\nlaboratory-confirmed cases, as well as, clinically confirmed cases\nthat are linked to laboratory-confirmed cases. Infection occurs through direct contact with respiratory droplets\nfrom the nose or throat, through saliva, coughing, sneezing, sharing\ndrinks, kissing, or from contact with any surface that has been\ncontaminated with the mumps virus. \nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org Guidelines have been\nput in place for health care workers who are cases or who are\ncontacts of mumps cases. Dr. Shelly Sarwal, the medical officer of health, says the\noutbreak of the virus continues to center on Halifax, with sporadic\ncases in several other areas. The majority of cases remain in the\n20-25 age group.\nThe Public Health Agency of Canada says in an average year, there are\n30 to 80 cases of the mumps across the entire country. Sarwal says\nthe latest increase was expected as doctors look more closely for\nmumps and people become aware of the symptoms. The most common\nsymptoms include fever, head and muscle aches, and swollen and tender\nglands at the angle of the jaw. Mumps is spread by coughing,\nsneezing, sharing drinks and kissing.\nPublic health officials continue to encourage people to see their\nfamily doctor if they have symptoms.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the last ProMED-mail report on this outbreak (Mumps - Canada (NS)\n(03) 20070409.1189) the case count was 32 confirmed cases. In the\nabove newswire, there is mention of 120 cases under investigation;\neven if 50 percent of those under investigation were ruled out as not\ndue to mumps, this would represent an almost doubling in the number\nof cases in less than 14 days. Obviously, a question is whether there\nis heightened awareness among the community leading to a higher\ncapture rate with more of the cases being reported. In the prior\nposting, there was a discussion on the multifactoral 'vaccine\nfailures' observed -- ranging from failure to get vaccinated (both\n1st and 2nd doses) to failure of the vaccine, either primary or\nsecondary, related to questionable vaccination procedures in vaccine\nadministration and storage -- which pointed out the complex issues\npublic health officials are facing in Nova Scotia (and elsewhere) for\ncontrol of vaccine preventable diseases. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "In the prior\nposting, there was a discussion on the multifactoral 'vaccine\nfailures' observed -- ranging from failure to get vaccinated (both\n1st and 2nd doses) to failure of the vaccine, either primary or\nsecondary, related to questionable vaccination procedures in vaccine\nadministration and storage -- which pointed out the complex issues\npublic health officials are facing in Nova Scotia (and elsewhere) for\ncontrol of vaccine preventable diseases. There have\nbeen 157 laboratory confirmed or clinical cases reported in 7 of 9\nDistrict Health Authorities across the province since the outbreak\nbegan in late Feb 2007. [This represents 37 additional cases since\nthe last update of 20 Apr 2007. - Mod.LM] The majority of cases (88\npercent) have been reported in Capital District Health Authority. The\nage range of cases is 6 to 62 with a median age of 21.5 years.\nFemales represent slightly more than half (56 percent) of all cases.\nPublic health measures continue to include self-isolation of cases\nfor a period of 9 days following onset of symptoms. Close household\nor intimate contacts have been offered MMR based on their vaccination\nhistory. No decision has been made yet on vaccination strategies to\nimprove the herd immunity within this population. Isolation and\nquarantine guidelines have been developed for health care workers who\nare cases or contacts of mumps. Additional information regarding the\noutbreak is now on the Nova Scotia Health Promotion and Protection\nwebsite:\n<http://www.gov.ns.ca/hpp/>\n--\nGaynor Watson-Creed, MSc, MD, CCFP, FRCP(C)\nMedical Officer of Health, District 9 (CDHA)\nNova Scotia Health Promotion and Protection\nc/o Public Health Services, Capital District Health Authority\nUnit 4, 201 Brownlow Ave.\nDartmouth, NS, B3B 1W2\n<Gaynor.Watson-Creed@cdha.nshealth.ca>\n[ProMED appreciates this update of the ongoing outbreak from Dr.\nWatson-Creed. - Mod.LM]", "summary": "Additional information regarding the\noutbreak is now on the Nova Scotia Health Promotion and Protection\nwebsite:\n<http://www.gov.ns.ca/hpp/>\n--\nGaynor Watson-Creed, MSc, MD, CCFP, FRCP(C)\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n There have\nbeen 157 laboratory confirmed or clinical cases reported in 7 of 9\nDistrict Health Authorities across the province since the outbreak\nbegan in late Feb 2007. Women infected with mumps\nwhile pregnant are at a greater risk of miscarriage.\nIn Nova Scotia, children are immunized against mumps, but young\nadults can still get it.\nDr. Gaynor Watson-Creed, a medical officer of health, told CBC News\nWednesday the outbreak started when someone infected with mumps\nvisited the province. She advised anyone with the illness to stay\naway from people for at least 9 days after being diagnosed.\nThis is the 3rd outbreak of mumps to hit Nova Scotia in 2 years.\nThere were 13 reported cases in the spring of 2005 and 19 cases that\nfall, mostly involving university-age adults.\nAll doctors in Nova Scotia are required by law to report cases of mumps.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the 1st posting on this outbreak, Mod.CP put a request for\ninformation on the vaccination status of the cases. The newswire\nabove mentions that this is the 3rd outbreak of mumps in Nova Scotia\nin 2 years, with most of the cases in university-aged adults. The\nobvious question that comes to mind is whether this is a case of\nnon-immunized young adults being exposed to the mumps virus or if\nthis is a case of single dose immunized young adults being exposed to\nthe mumps virus.\nAs reported in a recent Eurosurveillance weekly release report (Vol.\n12, Issue 3 <http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070322.asp#4>),\nBulgaria took a decision to revaccinate the young adult population\nagainst mumps in response to an ongoing mumps epidemic. An analysis\nof the vaccination activities in the country revealed 'Vaccination\nagainst mumps in Bulgaria started in 1972, and a routine mumps\nimmunisation program was launched in 1976. However, different vaccine\nstrains and vaccines have been used, and different immunisation\nstrategies implemented, including a suspension of mumps immunisation\nfor almost 4 years during the period 1982 to 1986....... A risk\nassessment carried out following the outbreak concluded that birth\ncohorts 1982 to 1992 that are at higher risk of mumps infection\nshould be offered supplementary mumps immunisation. As a result, the\nBulgarian Ministry of Health decided to provide supplementary doses\nof MMR vaccine and to conduct immunisation campaigns targeted at\nthese cohorts.' (see ProMED Archive: Mumps - Bulgaria: supplementary\nvaccination 20070322.1007).\nAgain, more information on the epidemiology of the present mumps\noutbreak in Nova Scotia including vaccination histories of the cases\nwould be appreciated. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "The\nobvious question that comes to mind is whether this is a case of\nnon-immunized young adults being exposed to the mumps virus or if\nthis is a case of single dose immunized young adults being exposed to\nthe mumps virus. However, different vaccine\nstrains and vaccines have been used, and different immunisation\nstrategies implemented, including a suspension of mumps immunisation\nfor almost 4 years during the period 1982 to 1986....... As a result, the\nBulgarian Ministry of Health decided to provide supplementary doses\nof MMR vaccine and to conduct immunisation campaigns targeted at\nthese cohorts.' \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n The newswire\nabove mentions that this is the 3rd outbreak of mumps in Nova Scotia\nin 2 years, with most of the cases in university-aged adults. 12, Issue 3 <http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070322.asp#4>),\nBulgaria took a decision to revaccinate the young adult population\nagainst mumps in response to an ongoing mumps epidemic.
