As reported in a recent Eurosurveillance weekly release report (Vol.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-02-25 00:00:00", "1972-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "1976-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "eurosurveillance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10158", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, Canada (multi-province)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10158", "date": "2007-05-05 21:00:01", "main_text": "MUMPS, CANADA (MULTI-PROVINCE)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mailis a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Sat 5 May 2007\nSource: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation News, Fri 4 May 2007 [edited]\n\nMumps in Ontario\n----------------\nThere are now several mumps cases in Ontario. Given that the original\nNova Scotia outbreak was largely focussed on college students, it is\nnot surprising that the disease has spread to other provinces as\nclasses have ended and students are travelling back to their home towns.\nCBS News reported in a Fri 4 May [2007] update that health officials\nare considering a re-vaccination campaign for mumps. The province of\nNova Scotia and the Public Health Agency of Canada are looking at\nre-immunizing people against mumps.\nNova Scotia has experienced 203 cases of mumps since February [2007],\nincluding about 50 new cases that have surfaced since last week\n[23-27 Apr 2007], public health officials said on Fri 4 May 2007. New\nBrunswick and Prince Edward Island have also reported cases, mainly\namong young adults in their 20s. Half a dozen cases of mumps have\nspread as far as Ontario.\nMumps is a highly infectious disease that is spread by coughing,\nsneezing, sharing drinks or kissing. Many of the cases spread through\ndowntown bars in Halifax and on the campus of Dalhousie University,\nhealth officials said.\nSince exams wrapped up about 2 weeks ago [20 Apr 2007], most students\nhave left campus and the disease seems to be receding, said Marla\nCranston, a Dalhousie spokeswoman. The province is talking about a\nnew immunization program for university-aged students and health-care\nworkers, said Dr. Shelly Sarwal, a medical officer of health with the\nNova Scotia health department. 'Right now, we're going to start\ndiscussion with the universities and the district health authorities\nto figure out how to make this happen,' Sarwal said, adding plans\nshould be in place by next week [7-11 May 2007].\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDavid N. Fisman, MD MPH FRCP(C)\nScientist, Child Health Evaluative Sciences\nResearch Institute of the Hospital for Sick Children\nMedical Epidemiologist\nOntario Public Health Laboratories Branch\nRoom 428, 123 Edward Street\nToronto, Ontario, Canada M5G 1E2\n<david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 5 May 2007\nSource: Toronto Star, Sat 5 May 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.thestar.com/article/210743>\n\nMumps outbreak enters Ontario from Maritimes\n--------------------------------------------\nCanada's mumps outbreak has moved out of the Maritimes and into\nOntario, with 3 confirmed and 5 suspected cases, officials confirmed\nyesterday [4 May 2007].\nIn Nova Scotia, the centre of the outbreak, public health officials\nadmitted they are considering a catch-up vaccination campaign for\nuniversity students and health-care workers, several of whom have\nbecome infected while caring for mumps cases. Previously, officials\nin the province had said that any catch-up campaign -- designed to\ngive a 2nd dose of the combined measles, mumps and rubella vaccine to\nyoung adults who only received one in childhood -- would need to be\ndone in conjunction with other provinces and territories.\n'Ideally, we'd have the whole country moving together. And we're\nstill working with the other provinces and with the Public Health\nAgency (of Canada),' said Dr. Shelly Sarwal, a medical officer of\nhealth for the province. 'But, Nova Scotia's going to have to take\nsome steps to protect Nova Scotians.'\nThis week, there was a significant jump in cases in Nova Scotia, to\n203 from 157, with mumps now being reported in all 9 health regions\nin the province. As of yesterday [4 May 2007], New Brunswick reported\n34 cases and Prince Edward Island remains at one confirmed case. For\nthe 1st time the outbreak has moved out of the Maritimes to Central\nCanada, a development public health officials had warned might occur\nas the university year ended and Halifax students dispersed to their\nhomes throughout the Maritimes and beyond.\nDavid Jensen, a spokesperson with Ontario's Ministry of Health and\nLong-term Care, said the province's 3 confirmed cases -- in the\nOttawa, York and Waterloo public health units -- can all be linked to\nthe Nova Scotia outbreak. Test results are still pending on 5\nsuspected cases. Jensen said physicians and public health officials\nin the province should keep mumps in mind if they see patients who\nhave mumps-like symptoms. These include aches, pains, fever, loss of\nappetite and, in about 40 percent of cases, the hugely swollen saliva\nglands that give mumps its characteristic chipmunk-cheek look.\nThe Nova Scotia outbreak, which began in the 3rd week of February\n[2007], is the province's 3rd in 2 years. It is by far the largest;\nthe earlier outbreaks, in 2005, involved 13 and 19 cases\nrespectively. It is fuelled by a pool of susceptible young adults.\nSarwal said authorities believe many of the province's cases were\nvaccinated with MMR [measles, mumps, rubella vaccine] in childhood,\nbut received only one dose. The one-dose schedule for the MMR vaccine\nwas adequate to protect many people. If it had not been, this\noutbreak would be much larger. But it's now known one dose doesn't\nprotect everyone; MMR is now given in two doses. Nova Scotia is\nleaning heavily towards topping up those it considers susceptible to the virus.\n'We are looking more seriously at instituting our vaccination\nprograms. An extra dose of MMR for the at-risk groups, which in this\ncase is 2: university students and health-care workers,' Sarwal said.\nThe vaccination campaign likely can't be mounted quickly enough to\nstamp out this outbreak, but could help prevent additional epidemics, she said.\nThe incubation period for mumps is 12 to 25 days. University\ndormitories and crowded student apartments make for easy spread of\nthe virus among susceptible young adults.\n[Byline: Helen Branswell]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail copy editor Ed Prucha <edprucha@midcoast.com>\n[These reports record a significant increase in number of mumps cases\namong students in the Maritime provinces of Canada; and more\nsignificantly, the geographical spread of the outbreak to Central\nCanada is noted. Catch-up vaccination of students and healthcare\nworkers is fast becoming a priority. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Ontario Public Health Laboratories Branch\nRoom 428, 123 Edward Street\nToronto, Ontario, Canada M5G 1E2\n<david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\n******\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mailis a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Previously, officials\nin the province had said that any catch-up campaign -- designed to\ngive a 2nd dose of the combined measles, mumps and rubella vaccine to\nyoung adults who only received one in childhood -- would need to be\ndone in conjunction with other provinces and territories. For\nthe 1st time the outbreak has moved out of the Maritimes to Central\nCanada, a development public health officials had warned might occur\nas the university year ended and Halifax students dispersed to their\nhomes throughout the Maritimes and beyond. In Nova Scotia, the centre of the outbreak, public health officials\nadmitted they are considering a catch-up vaccination campaign for\nuniversity students and health-care workers, several of whom have\nbecome infected while caring for mumps cases. The province is talking about a\nnew immunization program for university-aged students and health-care\nworkers, said Dr. Shelly Sarwal, a medical officer of health with the\nNova Scotia health department. ' \nCanada's mumps outbreak has moved out of the Maritimes and into\nOntario, with 3 confirmed and 5 suspected cases, officials confirmed\nyesterday [These reports record a significant increase in number of mumps cases\namong students in the Maritime provinces of Canada; and more\nsignificantly, the geographical spread of the outbreak to Central\n And we're\nstill working with the other provinces and with the Public Health\nAgency (of Canada),' said Dr. Shelly Sarwal, a medical officer of\nhealth for the province. ' Right now, we're going to start\ndiscussion with the universities and the district health authorities\nto figure out how to make this happen,' Sarwal said, adding plans\nshould be in place by next week [7-11 May 2007]. These include aches, pains, fever, loss of\nappetite and, in about 40 percent of cases, the hugely swollen saliva\nglands that give mumps its characteristic chipmunk-cheek look.\n University\ndormitories and crowded student apartments make for easy spread of\nthe virus among susceptible young adults.\n Scientist, Child Health Evaluative Sciences\nResearch Institute of the Hospital for Sick Children\nMedical Epidemiologist\n \nCommunicated by:\nDavid N. Fisman, MD MPH FRCP(C)\n Jensen said physicians and public health officials\nin the province should keep mumps in mind if they see patients who\nhave mumps-like symptoms. Nova Scotia has experienced 203 cases of mumps since February [2007],\nincluding about 50 new cases that have surfaced since last week\n Sarwal said authorities believe many of the province's cases were\nvaccinated with MMR [measles, mumps, rubella vaccine] in childhood,\nbut received only one dose. This week, there was a significant jump in cases in Nova Scotia, to\n203 from 157, with mumps now being reported in all 9 health regions\nin the province. David Jensen, a spokesperson with Ontario's Ministry of Health and\nLong-term Care, said the province's 3 confirmed cases -- in the\n Many of the cases spread through\ndowntown bars in Halifax and on the campus of Dalhousie University,\nhealth officials said. Since exams wrapped up about 2 weeks ago [20 Apr 2007], most students\nhave left campus and the disease seems to be receding, said Marla\nCranston, a Dalhousie spokeswoman. Nova Scotia outbreak was largely focussed on college students, it is\nnot surprising that the disease has spread to other provinces as\nclasses have ended and students are travelling back to their home towns. Source: Toronto Star, Sat 5 May 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.thestar.com/article/210743>\n\nMumps outbreak enters Ontario from Maritimes\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-02-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-07-11 00:00:00", "2007-05-04 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "mumps", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9365", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (NS): RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9365", "date": "2007-03-31 17:00:02", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (NOVA SCOTIA): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 31 Mar 2007\nFrom: Brent Barrett <salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\nSource: hfxnews.ca, The Daily News, Halifax, Nova Scotia [edited]\n<http://www.hfxnews.ca/index.cfm?sid=20078&sc=89>\n\nMumps cases [are increasing in number] across the metropolis\n[Halifax, Nova Scotia]. Public Health Services has confirmed 13 more\ncases of this virus infection, bringing the number to 24 so far this\nyear [2007], whereas one or 2 cases per year is normal.\n'We predict that cases will continue to accumulate as some people are\nstill coming into contact with infected cases. At this point our task\nremains finding cases so we can prevent that as much as possible,'\nDr. Gaynor Watson-Creed, chief medical officer for the Capital\nDistrict, said in a news release today [Sat 31 Mar 2007].\n'We remind people that if they have mumps or think they have mumps\nthey should not go to work, or school, or other activities until they\nhave checked with their doctor. We continue to ask cases to\nself-isolate for the 9 days after they become sick to be sure that\nthey do not put others at risk.'\nSymptoms of mumps include fever and swelling of the glands at the\nangle of the jaw [and of the testes. - Mod.JW].\n[Byline: Skana Gee]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Information on the origin of this outbreak and the vaccination\nstatus of the 24 victims would be appreciated. Reliance on\nself-diagnosis and dependence on observation of personal quarantine\nseem hardly adequate responses for containment of a\nvaccine-preventable disease. - Mod.CP\nThe province of Nova Scotia can be located on a map of Canada available at\n<http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/site/english/maps/reference/national/can_political_e/referencemap_image_view>\n. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Reliance on\nself-diagnosis and dependence on observation of personal quarantine\nseem hardly adequate responses for containment of a\nvaccine-preventable disease. - Mod. [Byline: Skana Gee]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Public Health Services has confirmed 13 more\ncases of this virus infection, bringing the number to 24 so far this\nyear [2007], whereas one or 2 cases per year is normal. Source: hfxnews.ca, The Daily News, Halifax, Nova Scotia [edited]\n<http://www.hfxnews.ca/index.cfm?sid=20078&sc=89>\n\nMumps cases [are increasing in number] across the metropolis\n At this point our task\nremains finding cases so we can prevent that as much as possible,'\n The province of Nova Scotia can be located on a map of Canada available at\n<http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/site/english/maps/reference/national/can_political_e/referencemap_image_view>\n. MUMPS - CANADA (NOVA SCOTIA): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************************\n We predict that cases will continue to accumulate as some people are\nstill coming into contact with infected cases.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Halifax", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9569", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (NS) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9569", "date": "2007-04-09 15:00:06", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (NOVA SCOTIA) (03)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 7 Apr 2007\nFrom: Gaynor Watson-Creed <Gaynor.Watson-Creed@cdha.nshealth.ca>\n\n[ProMED-mail would like to apologize for the delay in posting this\nresponse. Multiple computer issues intervened preventing a timely\nreceipt and posting. - Mod.MPP]\n\nMumps Update - Capital District Health Authority, Halifax, Nova Scotia\n-----------------------------------------------\nOverview:\nA total of 32 laboratory confirmed cases of mumps have been reported\nto Public Health Services (PHS) as of [Thu 5 Apr 2007]. Cases have\nbeen confirmed from throat swabs and urine specimens of persons\nmeeting the clinical case definition using RT-PCR [ref 1].\nOutbreak Description:\nThe 1st case was reported to PHS on [25 Feb 2007]. By [28 Feb 2007],\n5 additional cases had been identified. Epidemiologic investigation\nof that initial cluster revealed that the majority of cases (4/6)\noccurred in local university students. These students all attended\nthe same event at a local establishment on [11 Feb 2007], as did a\nknown mumps case from outside of Nova Scotia. This imported case\nappears to have been the source of infection for those 4 students,\nand the index case for the wider outbreak. Subsequent cases have\noccurred mostly in university students. Epidemiologic links to\nconfirmed cases have been evident in nearly all subsequent cases thus far.\nPreliminary analysis of the 25 cases analyzed so far reveals that the\naverage age of the cases is 24.3 years old (mean 20.8; range 6-50).\n64 percent of cases (16/25) have been male. Five cases have had no\nhistory of mumps in childhood or MMR vaccine; 15 cases report having\nhad one MMR, and 2 cases have been confirmed as having had 2 doses of\nMMR vaccine. Vaccine status for the remaining 3 cases is unknown. 20\nof the cases have occurred in university students. No unusual\npresentations of mumps or complications of mumps have occurred in\ncases presenting to this point.\nOutbreak control measures have included:\n- Aggressive contact tracing for each lab-confirmed case, including\nhousehold and intimate contacts as well as casual contacts through\nworkplace, recreational, social, and school settings.\n- Isolation of cases for 9 days post symptom onset (as opposed to the\n5 days used by some authorities)\n- Identification of susceptible contacts via serology; this has\nresulted in 2 non-immune persons quarantined for 25 days to prevent\npossible transmission of disease to high-risk groups.\nVaccine has not been used for outbreak control at this time.\nBackground:\nMeasles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine was introduced in Nova Scotia in\n1975 as a single dose to children 12 to 15 months of age. In 1996 a\n2nd dose was added for children 4 to 6 years of age as part of a\nCanadian strategy against measles. Since this time, fewer than 2\ncases of mumps are reported annually in Nova Scotia, most of which\noccur in un-immunized populations [ref 2].\nHalifax is an international port city and home to 6 post-secondary\ninstitutions. Of the city's 370 000 inhabitants, approximately 50 000\nare believed to fall within the age range affected by the recent\noutbreaks, namely ages 15-25 [ref 3]. Vaccine coverage rates have\nbeen high, with our records showing 94-96 percent of children having\nreceived their 2nd dose of MMR just prior to entering elementary\nschool. However, many current university students were born prior to\n1990, and so there remains a large part of this cohort that has\nreceived only one dose of vaccine.\nThis is the 3rd outbreak in the Halifax area in the past 2 years. The\nHalifax outbreaks have occurred in both a doubly vaccinated cohort of\nadolescents and a singly vaccinated cohort of young adults [ref 4].\nThe nature of these outbreaks raises questions as to the efficacy of\nthe MMR vaccine in each of these cohorts. While the Jeryl-Lynn (JL)\nstrain, used in Canada since 1988, is thought to induce antibodies in\n95 percent of people after one dose, recent studies have estimated\nthe efficacy of a single dose to be less than 70 percent [refs. 5,6].\nPrimary vaccine failure has been suggested as a cause of our\noutbreaks and of the similar outbreak in the US Midwest in 2006 [ref\n7]. However, field studies suggest that reductions in vaccine\nefficacy likely reflect a combination of both primary and secondary\nfailure of the mumps component of the MMR vaccine [ref 6].\nUnfortunately, lot numbers for the administered vaccines have not\nbeen available for review during our outbreaks. Our experience with\nvaccine administration and handling errors in physician offices here\nleads us to believe that these issues may also have led to a degree\nof 'failure' contributing to our outbreaks.\nAn ongoing challenge in this outbreak remains the very social and\nmobile nature of university students. Indeed, preliminary results of\na social network analysis here have supported our hypothesis that\ndisease is being spread as much by the off-campus or 'extra\ncurricular' activities of students as by their on-campus activities.\nThe newspaper reports, including the reports picked up by ProMED,\nhave been part of media strategy designed to alert persons to the\npossibility of mumps in our community and to encourage people to\nrefrain from socializing until they see a physician, as well as to\nrefrain from socializing until they are no longer infectious (e.g.\n'stay home while you are sick'). Resources for communicable disease\ncontrol in this part of Canada are limited by comparison to larger\nprovinces, and so enforcement of isolation and quarantine has proven\ndifficult. Analysis of additional options for outbreak management,\nincluding use of vaccine, is ongoing.\n1. World Health Organization. Recommended Case Definiton for Mumps.\n'Acute onset of unilateral or bilateral tender, self-limited swelling\nof the parotid or other salivary gland, lasting two or more days and\nwithout other apparent cause.' Available at:\n<http://www.who.int/immunization_monitoring/diseases/mumps_surveillance/en/index.html>.\n2. Office of the Chief Medical Officer of Health, Nova Scotia\nDepartment of Health. Notifiable diseases in Nova Scotia:\nsurveillance report 2003-2004. Available at:\n<http://www.gov.ns.ca/health/downloads/CD_Annual_Report_2003-2004.pdf>.\n3. Statistics Canada, 2001. Community Profile, Halifax Regional\nMunicipality. Available at:\n<http://www12.statcan.ca/english/Profil01/CP01/Details/Page.cfm?Lang=E&Geo1=CSD&Code1=1209034&Geo2=PR&Code2=12&Data=Count&SearchText=halifax&SearchType=Begins&SearchPR=01&B1=All&Custom\n=>.\n4. Watson-Creed, G., Saunders, A., et al. Two successive outbreaks of\nmumps in Nova Scotia among vaccinated adolescents and young adults\nCan. Med. Assoc. J., Aug 2006; 175: 483 - 488. Available at:\n<http://www.cmaj.ca/cgi/content/full/175/5/483?maxtoshow=&HITS=10&hits=10&RESULTFORMAT=1&author1=watson-creed&andorexacttitle=and&andorexacttitleabs=and&andorexactfulltext=and&searchid=1&FIRSTINDEX=0&sortspec=relevance&resourcetype=HWCIT,HWELTR>\n5. Vandermeulen C, Roelants M, Vermoere M, Roseeuw K, Goubau P,\nHoppenbrouwers K. Outbreak of mumps in a vaccinated child population:\na question of vaccine failure? Vaccine. 2004; 22:2713-2716.\n6. Harling R, White JM, Ramsay ME, Macsween KF, van der Bosch C. The\neffectiveness of the mumps component of the MMR vaccine: a case\ncontrol study. Vaccine. 2005; 23:4070-4074.\n7. Update: Multistate Outbreak of Mumps --- United States, January\n1--May 2, 2006. MMWR. 2006; Dispatch 55:1-5 [available at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm55d518a1.htm>].\n--\nGaynor Watson-Creed, MSc, MD, CCFP, FRCP(C)\nMedical Officer of Health, District 9 (CDHA)\nNova Scotia Health Promotion and Protection\nc/o Public Health Services, Capital District Health Authority\nUnit 4, 201 Brownlow Ave.\nDartmouth, NS, B3B 1W2\n<Gaynor.Watson-Creed@cdha.nshealth.ca>\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank Dr. Gaynor Watson-Creed for this\nvery complete description of the epidemiology of the outbreak of\nmumps in Nova Scotia. Dr. Watson-Creed has done an excellent job of\npointing out the challenges in mumps control confronting the health\nsector. The discussion on the multifactoral 'vaccine failures'\nobserved, ranging from failure to get vaccinated (both 1st and 2nd\ndoses) to failure of the vaccine either primary or secondary, related\nto questionable vaccination procedures in vaccine administration and\nstorage points out complex issues public health officials are facing\nfor control of vaccine preventible diseases.\nWe would also like to thank Dr. Richard Gould, Richard Gould MD MHSc\nFRCPC, Medical Officer of Health, Western Nova Scotia for responding\nto our request for information as well.", "summary": "The discussion on the multifactoral 'vaccine failures'\nobserved, ranging from failure to get vaccinated (both 1st and 2nd\ndoses) to failure of the vaccine either primary or secondary, related\nto questionable vaccination procedures in vaccine administration and\nstorage points out complex issues public health officials are facing\nfor control of vaccine preventible diseases. \n- Isolation of cases for 9 days post symptom onset (as opposed to the\n5 days used by some authorities)\n- Identification of susceptible contacts via serology; this has\nresulted in 2 non-immune persons quarantined for 25 days to prevent\npossible transmission of disease to high-risk groups. The newspaper reports, including the reports picked up by ProMED,\nhave been part of media strategy designed to alert persons to the\npossibility of mumps in our community and to encourage people to\nrefrain from socializing until they see a physician, as well as to\nrefrain from socializing until they are no longer infectious (e.g.\n'stay home while you are sick'). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Our experience with\nvaccine administration and handling errors in physician offices here\nleads us to believe that these issues may also have led to a degree\nof 'failure' contributing to our outbreaks.\n Five cases have had no\nhistory of mumps in childhood or MMR vaccine; 15 cases report having\nhad one MMR, and 2 cases have been confirmed as having had 2 doses of\nMMR vaccine. \nPrimary vaccine failure has been suggested as a cause of our\noutbreaks and of the similar outbreak in the US Midwest in 2006 [ref\n7]. Vaccine coverage rates have\nbeen high, with our records showing 94-96 percent of children having\nreceived their 2nd dose of MMR just prior to entering elementary\nschool. Outbreak control measures have included:\n- Aggressive contact tracing for each lab-confirmed case, including\nhousehold and intimate contacts as well as casual contacts through\nworkplace, recreational, social, and school settings. [ProMED-mail would like to thank Dr. Gaynor Watson-Creed for this\nvery complete description of the epidemiology of the outbreak of\nmumps in Nova Scotia. Dr. Watson-Creed has done an excellent job of\npointing out the challenges in mumps control confronting the health\nsector. Acute onset of unilateral or bilateral tender, self-limited swelling\nof the parotid or other salivary gland, lasting two or more days and\nwithout other apparent cause.' 2006; Dispatch 55:1-5 [available at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm55d518a1.htm>].\n Available at:\n<http://www.cmaj.ca/cgi/content/full/175/5/483?maxtoshow=&HITS=10&hits=10&RESULTFORMAT=1&author1=watson-creed&andorexacttitle=and&andorexacttitleabs=and&andorexactfulltext=and&searchid=1&FIRSTINDEX=0&sortspec=relevance&resourcetype=HWCIT,HWELTR>\n5.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-05-01 20:06:00", "2007-02-28 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "1975-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9320", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Hungary (Heves) ex Ukraine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9320", "date": "2007-03-29 22:00:01", "main_text": "MUMPS - HUNGARY (HEVES) EX UKRAINE\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 29 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly release [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070329.asp#4>\n\nLocal mumps outbreak in Hungary, 2007\n--------------------------------------------\n9 cases of mumps have been reported recently in a village in Heves\nCounty in northern Hungary. The illnesses occurred between 5 Jan and\n24 Feb 2007 and were epidemiologically related and laboratory-confirmed.\nOutbreak description\n--------------------\nBlood samples taken from 2 patients diagnosed with salivary gland\ninflammation tested positive for mumps-specific IgM at the national\nreference laboratory on 28 Feb 2007. On the following day, an\nepidemiological investigation was carried out in the village the\npatients came from.\nThis established that the 1st case in this outbreak had returned home\non 22 Dec 2006 from the town of Berehove in Ukraine, near the border\nwith Hungary, where he had previously worked for 8 months. He\ndeveloped symptoms on 5 Jan 2007. During January and February 2006,\nmore inhabitants of the village presented with symptoms such as fever\nor elevated temperature and unilateral or bilateral swelling of the\nparotid gland. The patients were aged between 22 and 31 years and\nwere connected with one another through family, friends or work\nrelations. By 15 Mar 2007, 9 mumps cases had been identified\nretrospectively through an epidemiological link and laboratory confirmation.\nAll 9 patients were treated either by a local family doctor or at an\nemergency ward on duty in the nearest town. Two patients were\nreferred further to an infectious diseases specialist. The 1st\nclinical diagnosis in 5 cases was mumps, in 2 cases salivary gland\ninflammation, in one case conjunctivitis and acute pharyngitis, and\nin one case infra-auricular lymphadenitis.\nThe serological analysis performed at the national reference\nlaboratory confirmed all 9 cases to be mumps infection. By the time\nof the epidemiological investigation, however, all patients had\nalready recovered. According to the patient history, none of the\npatients have been previously vaccinated against mumps.\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe above example shows that the mumps virus circulation in a group\nof closely interrelated susceptible individuals can trigger a local\noutbreak. In 2003, comparable outbreaks affecting a similar number of\ncases were reported in close communities of unvaccinated people\n(student houses, schools).\nThe childhood vaccination coverage for mumps in Hungary is high, so\nthe risk of infection is predominantly by virus importation. The\npresent outbreak could have been avoided had the 1st cases been\ncorrectly diagnosed. In Hungary, laboratory testing of all suspected\nmumps cases has been mandatory since September 2006.\nIn the outbreak described here, only the cases with manifest parotid\nswelling have been identified; no wider investigation of other\npossible symptoms and complications has been carried out. In general,\nmumps is a mild and self-limited viral infection; an estimated 1/3rd\nof infections are asymptomatic. However, mumps infection can lead to\nserious complications, such as meningitis, of which a small\npercentage can progress to encephalitis. In addition, mumps causes\nunilateral or bilateral orchitis in approximately 20-30 percent\npost-pubertal males. It is therefore very important to prevent the\nvirus from circulating in groups of young adults.\nBackground information\n----------------------\nThe trivalent measles, mumps and rubella vaccine (MMR) was introduced\nin Hungary in March 1991. As a result, the MMR vaccination coverage\nin children born after 1 Jan 1990 is more than 98 percent. Between\n1993 and 1996, follow-up vaccination campaigns were carried out\ntargeting cohorts born between 1 Jun 1985 and 31 Dec 1989. The\nrevaccination started in 1999 at 11 years, and, therefore, cohorts\nborn after 1 Jun 1987 should have been vaccinated with 2 doses of MMR\nvaccine. The present routine childhood immunization schedule uses the\nMMR vaccine given as a 1st dose at 15 months of age, and as a 2nd\ndose at 11 years of age.\nSince 1973, mumps has been a mandatory notifiable disease in Hungary.\nBetween 1973 and 1990, there were 20 000 to 50 000 mumps cases\nregistered per year. After the introduction of the universal\nvaccination program in 1991, the incidence began to decrease slowly;\n2000 cases were registered in 1994, and 500 cases in 1995. Between\n1996 and 2001, the number of cases reported per year ranged from 180\nto 240, whereas between 2002 and 2005 the number of reported cases\nwas around 100 per year.\nReferences\n----------\nLocal mumps outbreak in Hungary, 2007. Euro Surveill\n2007;12(3):E070329.4. Available from:\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070329.asp#4>.\n[Byline: Zs Molnar <molnarzsu@oek.antsz.hu>1, K Szomor1, G Huszti2, E\nOzsvarne Csepregi2]\n1. Orszagos Epidemiologiai Kozpont (National Centre for\nEpidemiology), Budapest, Hungary 2. Allami Nepegeszsegugyi es\nTisztiorvosi Szolgalat Eszak-magyarorszagi Regionalis Intezete\n(Northern Hungarian Regional Institute of National Public Health and\nMedical Officers' Service), Eger, Hungary.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A map of Hungary showing the county of Heves to the east of Budapest\ncan be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/atlas_east_europe/hungary-map.jpg>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The 1st\nclinical diagnosis in 5 cases was mumps, in 2 cases salivary gland\ninflammation, in one case conjunctivitis and acute pharyngitis, and\nin one case infra-auricular lymphadenitis. Between\n1996 and 2001, the number of cases reported per year ranged from 180\nto 240, whereas between 2002 and 2005 the number of reported cases\nwas around 100 per year. The\nrevaccination started in 1999 at 11 years, and, therefore, cohorts\nborn after 1 Jun 1987 should have been vaccinated with 2 doses of MMR\nvaccine. During January and February 2006,\nmore inhabitants of the village presented with symptoms such as fever\nor elevated temperature and unilateral or bilateral swelling of the\nparotid gland. On the following day, an\nepidemiological investigation was carried out in the village the\npatients came from.\n Blood samples taken from 2 patients diagnosed with salivary gland\ninflammation tested positive for mumps-specific IgM at the national\nreference laboratory on 28 Feb 2007. After the introduction of the universal\nvaccination program in 1991, the incidence began to decrease slowly;\n2000 cases were registered in 1994, and 500 cases in 1995. --------------------------------------------\n9 cases of mumps have been reported recently in a village in Heves\nCounty in northern Hungary. In the outbreak described here, only the cases with manifest parotid\nswelling have been identified; no wider investigation of other\npossible symptoms and complications has been carried out. Source: Eurosurveillance weekly release [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070329.asp#4>\n\nLocal mumps outbreak in Hungary, 2007\n The above example shows that the mumps virus circulation in a group\nof closely interrelated susceptible individuals can trigger a local\noutbreak. In addition, mumps causes\nunilateral or bilateral orchitis in approximately 20-30 percent\npost-pubertal males. The present routine childhood immunization schedule uses the\nMMR vaccine given as a 1st dose at 15 months of age, and as a 2nd\ndose at 11 years of age. In 2003, comparable outbreaks affecting a similar number of\ncases were reported in close communities of unvaccinated people\n(student houses, schools). This established that the 1st case in this outbreak had returned home\non 22 Dec 2006 from the town of Berehove in Ukraine, near the border\nwith Hungary, where he had previously worked for 8 months. The\npresent outbreak could have been avoided had the 1st cases been\ncorrectly diagnosed. In general,\nmumps is a mild and self-limited viral infection; an estimated 1/3rd\nof infections are asymptomatic. However, mumps infection can lead to\nserious complications, such as meningitis, of which a small\npercentage can progress to encephalitis. Between\n1993 and 1996, follow-up vaccination campaigns were carried out\ntargeting cohorts born between 1 Jun 1985 and 31 Dec 1989. The patients were aged between 22 and 31 years and\nwere connected with one another through family, friends or work\nrelations.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1991-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00", "1987-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-12-25 00:00:00", "2007-02-28 00:00:00", "1989-12-31 00:00:00", "2006-09-25 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "1985-03-25 00:00:00", "1973-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-01-05 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-01-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "background", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MUMPS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orszagos Epidemiologiai Kozpont", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hungary", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Budapest", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5609", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Ukraine (Zakarpatye): RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5609", "date": "2006-12-13 00:00:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - UKRAINE (ZAKARPATYE): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 13 Dec 2006\nFrom ProMED-mail Russian Corr.AS <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Newspaper Ukraine [trans. by Mod.NR, edited]\n<http://gpu-ua.info/index.php?&id=142424&lang=ru>\n\nMumps outbreak reported in the Zakarpatye Region of Ukraine\n-----------------------------------------------------------\nAn increased number of cases of epidemic parotitis (mumps) has been\nreported from the Perechinskiy district of the Zakarpatye Region of\nUkraine. Currently, 89 people are under medical care with symptoms of\nparotitis. This information was released on Fri 8 Dec 2006 by the Regional\nOffice of the Ministry of Emergency Situations. The 1st case\nappeared in western Bulgaria. Now there are affected people in the\nlocalities of Varna, Burgas, Sofia, and Plovdiv. Additional vaccines\nwill be [made available] for those who have not been vaccinated.\n[Byline: Petar Peshev]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Outbreaks of mumps still occur sporadically throughout Europe as a\nresult of incomplete vaccine coverage in the past, the inclusion of\nsub-optimal (or no) mump component in triple MMR vaccine, or presence\nof migrant populations.\nPlovdiv is located in south-central Bulgaria. A map of Bulgaria\nshowing the location of Plovdiv and the other cities mentioned can be\naccessed at\n<http://education.yahoo.com/reference/factbook/bu/map.html;_ylt=AtDijegFEGPd.km6_uIUY864ecYF>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Byline: Petar Peshev]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n [Outbreaks of mumps still occur sporadically throughout Europe as a\nresult of incomplete vaccine coverage in the past, the inclusion of\nsub-optimal (or no) mump component in triple MMR vaccine, or presence\nof migrant populations. As quoted by a journalist of the Focus Agency, the national\nconsultant on epidemiology, Mira Kozhuharova, said in the town of\nPlovdiv that as of 2 Mar 2007, 500 people had fallen ill with mumps\nin Bulgaria. A map of Bulgaria\nshowing the location of Plovdiv and the other cities mentioned can be\naccessed at\n<http://education.yahoo.com/reference/factbook/bu/map.html;_ylt=AtDijegFEGPd.km6_uIUY864ecYF>.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burgas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Varna", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sofia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9100", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Bulgaria: supplementary vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9100", "date": "2007-03-22 20:00:02", "main_text": "MUMPS - BULGARIA: SUPPLEMENTARY VACCINATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 22 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly release Vol. 12, Issue 3 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070322.asp#4>\n\nMumps outbreak in Bulgaria, 2007: a preliminary report\n-----------------------------------------------\nThere is an ongoing mumps outbreak in Bulgaria, with a total of 997\ncases notified between 1 Jan and 18 Mar 2007. This number includes\nlaboratory-confirmed and probable epidemiologically-linked clinical\ncases in line with the EU case definition and case classification\nthat have been adopted for mumps surveillance purposes in Bulgaria\nsince 2005 [1].\nFor comparison, only 22 cases were reported in the 1st 11 weeks of\n2005, and 311 cases were registered in the same period in 2006.\nAltogether, 608 cases were notified in 2005, and 919 cases were\nreported during 2006. An increase of the number of reported cases was\nnoted already in 2006, and since the beginning of 2007, the number of\ncases has continued to rise. [The text at this point is supplemented\nby a figure plotting reported mumps cases during weeks 1 to 11 in\n2005 (n=22), 2006 (n=311) and 2007 (n=997)].\nThe present mumps epidemic affects mostly teenagers and young adults.\nMore than 60 percent of the cases reported in 2007 occurred in\npatients aged 15 to 19 years, and about 20 percent in patients aged\n20 to 24 years. To date, 112 out of 997 cases (11.2 percent) have\nbeen laboratory-confirmed.\nConclusion\n----------\nThe outbreak investigation is still ongoing, but preliminary data\nindicate that the predominance of patients in age groups 15-19 and\n20-24 years may be a result of poor immunisation of these birth\ncohorts in general. About 1/3rd of patients aged 15 to 19 years have\nnot been vaccinated at all, whereas more than half have received only\none dose of monovalent mumps vaccine strain Leningrad 3, which has\nbeen shown to have a lower effectiveness [2]. Among the 20- to\n24-year-old patients, over 90 percent have never been immunised against mumps.\nVaccination against mumps in Bulgaria started in 1972, and a routine\nmumps immunisation program was launched in 1976. However, different\nvaccine strains and vaccines have been used, and different\nimmunisation strategies implemented, including a suspension of mumps\nimmunisation for almost 4 years during the period 1982 to 1986.\nDue to the past changes in the immunisation program and occasionally\nincomplete immunisation coverage, the conditions in which outbreaks\ncan occur still exist, despite the current up-to-date mumps\nimmunisation strategy.\nControl measures\n----------------\nA risk assessment carried out following the outbreak concluded that\nbirth cohorts 1982 to 1992 that are at higher risk of mumps infection\nshould be offered supplementary mumps immunisation.\nAs a result, the Bulgarian Ministry of Health decided to provide\nsupplementary doses of MMR vaccine and to conduct immunisation\ncampaigns targeted at these cohorts. In early March 2007, the\nMinistry of Health organized a meeting to inform regional\nepidemiologists about the situation and to discuss with them the need\nfor strengthening disease surveillance and undertaking control\nmeasures to prevent further spread of mumps. Furthermore,\ncommunication aimed at the general public, conveying information\nabout the risks related to mumps infection and the preventive\nmeasures, including immunisation, has been intensified through the\nparticipation of national experts in a series of briefings, TV and\nradio broadcasts.\nA longer article on the epidemiology of mumps in Bulgaria, including\na detailed risk assessment, is planned for publication in the monthly\nrelease of Eurosurveillance.\nReferences\n----------\n(1.) Commission decision of 19 Mar 2002 laying down case definitions\nfor reporting communicable diseases to the Community network under\nDecision No 2119/98/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council\n(2002/253/EC), Official Journal of the European Communities\n03.04.2002. Available from:\n<http://europa.eu.int/eur-lex/pri/en/oj/dat/2002/l_086/l_08620020403en00440062.pdf>.\n(2.) Gatcheva N, Tchakov B, Vladimirova N. Analysis of immunisations\nperformed in 1991. NCIPD Information Journal, 5, 1992; 50-62. (In Bulgarian).\n[Reported by: M Kojouharova <mkojouharova@ncipd.org>, A Kurchatova, L\nMarinova, and T Georgieva; National Center of Infectious and\nParasitic Diseases, Sofia, Bulgaria]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Outbreaks of mumps still occur sporadically throughout Europe as a\nresult of incomplete vaccine coverage in the past, particularly in\ncountries with significant migrant Roma populations that may escape\nroutine immunisation programs. The inclusion of a sub-optimal mump\ncomponent in triple MMR vaccine in the past may be another factor\naffecting the efficacy of vaccination. (E.g. Higher rates of aseptic\nmeningitis have been attributed to the Urabe, Leningrad-Zagreb and\nLeningrad-3 strain vaccines compared with the current Jeryl-Lynn strain vaccine\n<http://www.who.int/vaccine_safety/topics/mumps/statement/en/>.)\nA map of Bulgaria can be viewed at:\n<http://education.yahoo.com/reference/factbook/bu/map.html;_ylt=AtDijegFEGPd.km6_uIUY864ecYF>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "Furthermore,\ncommunication aimed at the general public, conveying information\nabout the risks related to mumps infection and the preventive\nmeasures, including immunisation, has been intensified through the\nparticipation of national experts in a series of briefings, TV and\nradio broadcasts.\n [Reported by: M Kojouharova <mkojouharova@ncipd.org>, A Kurchatova, L\nMarinova, and T Georgieva; National Center of Infectious and\nParasitic Diseases, Sofia, Bulgaria]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n This number includes\nlaboratory-confirmed and probable epidemiologically-linked clinical\ncases in line with the EU case definition and case classification\nthat have been adopted for mumps surveillance purposes in Bulgaria\nsince 2005 In early March 2007, the\nMinistry of Health organized a meeting to inform regional\nepidemiologists about the situation and to discuss with them the need\nfor strengthening disease surveillance and undertaking control\nmeasures to prevent further spread of mumps. Due to the past changes in the immunisation program and occasionally\nincomplete immunisation coverage, the conditions in which outbreaks\ncan occur still exist, despite the current up-to-date mumps\nimmunisation strategy. However, different\nvaccine strains and vaccines have been used, and different\nimmunisation strategies implemented, including a suspension of mumps\nimmunisation for almost 4 years during the period 1982 to 1986. The outbreak investigation is still ongoing, but preliminary data\nindicate that the predominance of patients in age groups 15-19 and\n20-24 years may be a result of poor immunisation of these birth\ncohorts in general. About 1/3rd of patients aged 15 to 19 years have\nnot been vaccinated at all, whereas more than half have received only\none dose of monovalent mumps vaccine strain Leningrad 3, which has\nbeen shown to have a lower effectiveness [2]. [Outbreaks of mumps still occur sporadically throughout Europe as a\nresult of incomplete vaccine coverage in the past, particularly in\ncountries with significant migrant Roma populations that may escape\nroutine immunisation programs. (E.g. Higher rates of aseptic\nmeningitis have been attributed to the Urabe, Leningrad-Zagreb and\nLeningrad-3 strain vaccines compared with the current Jeryl-Lynn strain vaccine\n<http://www.who.int/vaccine_safety/topics/mumps/statement/en/>.) A vaccine advisory committee will gather next\nMonday, and they will propose that young people between 18 and 20\nyears old should be immunized again. According to what the committee\ndecides, immunization may start in 7-8 days in health care facilities.\nMeasles are still prevalent in Navarra, in young people between 18\nand 20 years old, and it is a disease transmitted though particle\ninhalation. The Public Health Institute is studying the current\nsituation in this group, who had the lowest vaccine coverage when\nthey were 15 months old. New vaccine doses will be administered if\npersons had received the triple viral vaccine only once, or if they\nhad never been immunized.\nMumps vaccine used to be administered at 15 months of age, and a\nbooster dose was given at 11 years of age. The currently affected\ngroup was immunized with the Rubini strain, which was proven to be\nless efficacious when administered in the 2nd dose. Those who have\nalready had the disease do not need any additional immunization against mumps.\nThe data indicating there are 3600 vulnerable young people is a 1st\nestimate with respect to those who may possibly receive the vaccine.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n JGM\n<jgonzalezmendoza@gamil.com> edited]\n<http://www.abc.es/20070110/sociedad-sanidad/epidemia-paperas-afecta-personas_200701100255.html>\n\nThe mumps outbreak that started in August 2006 in Navarra affected\nmore than 800 people, and new cases are still being reported, between\n70 and 100 every week. A vaccine advisory committee will gather next\nMonday, and they will propose that young people between 18 and 20\nyears old should be immunized again. New vaccine doses will be administered if\npersons had received the triple viral vaccine only once, or if they\nhad never been immunized. Measles are still prevalent in Navarra, in young people between 18\nand 20 years old, and it is a disease transmitted though particle\ninhalation. The Public Health Institute is studying the current\nsituation in this group, who had the lowest vaccine coverage when\nthey were 15 months old.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-08-25 00:00:00", "2007-01-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MUMPS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Navarra", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8069", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8069", "date": "2007-02-16 09:00:02", "main_text": "MUMPS - SPAIN (NAVARRA) (02): 2006 - 2007\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 15 Feb 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org?\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly releases 2007, Volume 12, Issue 2 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070215.asp#1>\n\nMore than 1300 cases of mumps were reported in\nNavarra, an autonomous community in northeast\nSpain, between August 2006 and January 2007. The\n1st outbreak of 19 cases was reported on 10 Aug\n[2006] in Viana, a village with a population of\n3860 people. The chain of transmission was\nthought to have begun at the summer festival in\nViana, on 22-25 Jul [2006], attended by several\nhundred inhabitants of the neighbouring villages\n[1]. In the following months, cases of mumps\noccurred throughout the entire region of Navarra,\nincluding the capital, Pamplona.\nAn increase of the number of mumps cases has been\nnoted since week 32 [5 - 11 August] of 2006,\nwhich has been linked to a series of outbreaks in\nplaces frequented by young adults [illustrated by\na histogram in the original text]. By the end of\n2006, 908 cases had been reported. In 2007 so\nfar, the incidence has continued to increase,\nwith 489 cases notified up to 2 Feb 2007. The\nhighest incidence was noted in the 2nd week of\n2007 (mid January), with 33 cases per 100 000\ninhabitants.\nThe modal age of patients was 19 years, with 82\npercent of cases occurring in patients aged\nbetween 16 and 30 years and 34 percent between 18\nand 20 years [illustrated by a histogram in the\noriginal text].\nThe following case definition was used in this outbreak:\nClinical case: Disease with sudden onset, uni- or\nbilateral facial swelling, duration of more than\n2 days and limited in time; no other apparent\ncauses.\nConfirmed case: Clinical case with\nlaboratory-confirmed virology (virus detection,\nPCR), serology (IgM positive) or epidemiological\nassociation with other confirmed cases.\nOf all reported cases, 210 (15 percent) fulfilled\nthe criteria for a laboratory-confirmed case\neither by virology or serology (IgM positive).\nThe remaining 85 percent of cases were clinically\ncompatible with mumps, and very likely to be\nconfirmed on the basis of epidemiological\nassociation, given the large scale of the\noutbreak. The epidemiological investigation,\nhowever, is still ongoing.\nCases with mild symptoms were frequent. Often the\nsymptoms lasted fewer than 5 days. Severe\ncomplications arose in 17 patients who presented\nwith orchitis (testicular inflammation) and 3\npatients who developed meningitis.\nLaboratory results\n------------------\nSerology was performed for 708 (51 percent)\ncases. Of these, 26 percent were serologically\npositive for IgM, and 74 percent were positive\nfor IgG and negative for IgM. As we do not have a\nprevious serology study for comparison, this\npattern might be due to prior vaccination failure\nsignified by a decrease of protective antibodies.\nWe considered these as non laboratory-confirmed\ncases, but we included them as part of the\noutbreak, because their clinical symptoms and the\nepidemiological context were compatible with\nmumps.\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine was\nintroduced in the childhood immunisation\nprogramme in Navarra in 1982, with one dose given\nat 15 months of age. Since 1995 a 2nd dose has\nbeen added, initially given at 11 years, and\nsince 1999, at 6 years. Vaccination coverage with\n2 doses has reached more than 90 percent in all\ncohorts born after 1985. The Rubini mumps strain\nwas used in MMR vaccine in Navarra only in the\ncohorts born between 1986 and 1988 in a 2nd dose\ngiven at the age of 11 years. Vaccines produced\nusing the Rubini strain have previously been\nfound to have low efficacy [2,3,4].\nSeroepidemiological surveys show that more than\n90 percent of people born before 1975 have\nantibodies against mumps [5], acquired during a\nclinical or subclinical contact with the virus.\nIt means that most people in these cohorts are\nnaturally immunised.\nIn the recent outbreak, in 143 cases the\nvaccination history was known, 112 patients had\nreceived 2 doses of the vaccine. Almost all (138)\npatients vaccinated with at least one dose were\naged 25 years or less.\nCases in vaccinated patients can be explained\nbecause the efficacy of the MMR vaccine to\nprevent mumps is 75-91 percent [6,7]; and it is\neven lower in patients who received only one dose\nas children [8,9], especially if the mumps\ncomponent included the Rubini strain [2-4, 9,\n10]. However, vaccination with the Rubini strain\ncan explain no more than a small proportion of\ncases, since only patients aged between 18 and 20\nyears (34 percent of all cases) received this\nvaccine in the past.\nIn conclusion, several causes are thought to have\ncontributed to this outbreak. They include the\nincomplete effectiveness of the vaccine against\nmumps, the limited coverage of vaccination in the\n1st years after introduction, the unvaccinated\npopulation that had not been naturally exposed to\ninfection in childhood and the low effectiveness\nof the Rubini strain. This outbreak could also be\npartially explained by the waning immunity in\nolder vaccinated populations, as has been\nsuggested by other authors [11].\nIn order to control this outbreak, the Public\nHealth Institute of Navarra has recommended the\nfollowing measures:\n* The maintenance of high vaccination coverage\nwith 2 doses of the MMR vaccine in the childhood\nimmunisation programme;\n* The vaccination of people born after 1980\nwho have not received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine;\n* A specific vaccination programme for young\nadults who were born in 1986, 1987, and 1988 and\nreceived only one MMR dose with Rubini strain;\n* The home isolation of cases and vaccination\nof all contacts aged 35 or less, who have not\nreceived 2 doses of MMR vaccine and have not\npreviously been infected with mumps.\n[Byline: J Castilla, M Garc\ufffdCenoz, et al]\nReferences:\n1. Gerstel L, Lenglet A, Garc\ufffdCenoz M. Mumps\noutbreak in young adults following a village\nfestival in the Navarra region, Spain, August\n2006. Euro Surveill 2006;11(11):E061109.4.\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/061109.asp#4>\n2. Akehurst C. Resurgence of mumps in Singapore\nassociated with Rubini vaccine. Eurosurveillance\n1999;10 (43) 991021.\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/1999/991021.asp#3>\n3. Goncalves G, de Araujo A , Monteiro Cardoso\nML. Outbreak of mumps associated with poor\nvaccine efficacy - Oporto Portugal 1996. Euro\nSurveill 1998; 3(12): 119-21.\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/em/v03n12/0312-222.asp>\n4. In conclusion, several causes are thought to have\ncontributed to this outbreak.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-02-02 00:00:00", "1982-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-08-25 00:00:00", "1975-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-01-25 00:00:00", "1980-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-02-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-05-11 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "1987-03-25 00:00:00", "1985-03-25 00:00:00", "1986-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-02-04 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MUMPS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pamplona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viana", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2651", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Fiji", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2651", "date": "2006-09-13 00:00:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - FIJI\n***********\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 13 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Fiji Times Online [edited]\n<http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=48194>\n\nHealth ministry warns of mumps outbreak\n-----------------------------------------------\nThere is an outbreak of mumps in the Labasa and Suva areas, says\nHealth Ministry officer Doctor Josaia Samuela.\nHe said there had been an increasing number of mumps cases,\nespecially in the Labasa area, for the past 2 months.\n'This has been evident from the reported number of cases seen at the\nLabasa Hospital for the past 2 months. For the Suva area, there have\nbeen anecdotal reports of increasing number of mump cases occurring\nin various schools in Suva for the past 2 months.\n'Labasa Hospital has [had] an average of 120 cases for the past 12\nmonths. Lautoka Hospital reported about 30 cases in total for the\npast 2 months, and the Suva Private Hospital reported 15 cases last\nmonth [August 2006],' he said.\nHe said the reported mumps cases were based solely on clinical\nsymptoms of the patients since no blood test had been sent to Suva\nfor laboratory confirmation.\nDr. Samuela said mumps was the commonest cause of painful and swollen\nsalivary glands. 'The most prominent symptoms are the presence of\npainful swelling or lumps at the angle of the jaw. These swellings of\nthe salivary glands could be on one or both sides. Associated\nsymptoms include body aches, loss of appetite, generalized weakness,\nheadache and low grade fever,' he said. He said that panadol was a\nsuitable and effective medicine for both fever and pain relief and\nthat soft food should be given to the affected child, as chewing made\nthe pain worse.\nDr. Samuela said the child infected with mumps should be stopped from\ngoing to school until symptoms subside.\nLast week, Fiji College of General Practitioners president Doctor\nWahid Khan said children suffering from mumps should be allowed a lot\nof bed rest and not sent to school. He said that more than 50\npatients had visited his general practice seeking treatment for mumps\nand that proper care should be taken by the parents on the issue.\n'If there are more than one child living in a household whose member\nhas the virus, the sick child's utensils should be kept separately\nfrom the rest of the family, because it is a contagious disease that\ncould be passed easily from one member to another,' he said.\nHe said children suffering from mumps should wear warm clothing and\ndrink a lot of fluids with paracetamol, panadeine and codeine.\n'I have seen some boys who come with mumps and complain of pain in\nthe scrotum, and this was not good, so extra care should be taken at\nall times,' he said.\nHe said those infected with mumps should not be given orange or any\ncitrus drink to take while being infected because it could worsen the pain.\nMeanwhile, Health Ministry chief executive officer Doctor Lepani\nWaqatakirewa said the current outbreak was viral in origin and\nantibiotics such as amoxycillin are for bacterial infections.\nIn a statement reacting to the current outbreak of mumps among\nchildren, Dr. Waqatakirewa said virus and bacteria were different and\ngiving antibiotics for viral infection was a waste of medicine.\nSome parents had shown concern that their children with virus-related\ninfectious were in fact given antibiotics.\n'However, do note that in some children, there could be co-exiting\nbacterial infection in the chest or elsewhere in the body. In such\ncases, antibiotics such as amoxycillin could be prescribed,' he said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is the 1st ProMED report of mumps in Fiji and the 2nd in\nSoutheast Asia. The previous report was of mumps infection associated\nwith use of the Rubini vaccine. - Mod.TY]\n[Mumps is a vaccine preventible disease. In a recent posting on\nmeasles in Fiji, the information on vaccination program activities\nmentioned that measles-rubella vaccine is used for routine\nimmunizations in Fiji. Hence, in the absence of a major vaccination\nprogram, periodic outbreaks of mumps would be expected. - Mod.MPP]\n[see also\nMeasles - Fiji 20060908.2551\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937]\n...................mpp/ty/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "summary": "...................mpp/ty/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n Measles - Fiji 20060908.2551\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937]\n ***********************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\n He said that more than 50\npatients had visited his general practice seeking treatment for mumps\nand that proper care should be taken by the parents on the issue.\n' If there are more than one child living in a household whose member\nhas the virus, the sick child's utensils should be kept separately\nfrom the rest of the family, because it is a contagious disease that\ncould be passed easily from one member to another,' he said. He said that panadol was a\nsuitable and effective medicine for both fever and pain relief and\nthat soft food should be given to the affected child, as chewing made\nthe pain worse. In a recent posting on\nmeasles in Fiji, the information on vaccination program activities\nmentioned that measles-rubella vaccine is used for routine\nimmunizations in Fiji. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n In a statement reacting to the current outbreak of mumps among\nchildren, Dr. Waqatakirewa said virus and bacteria were different and\ngiving antibiotics for viral infection was a waste of medicine. He said the reported mumps cases were based solely on clinical\nsymptoms of the patients since no blood test had been sent to Suva\nfor laboratory confirmation. I have seen some boys who come with mumps and complain of pain in\nthe scrotum, and this was not good, so extra care should be taken at\nall times,' he said. Lautoka Hospital reported about 30 cases in total for the\npast 2 months, and the Suva Private Hospital reported 15 cases last\nmonth \nDr. Samuela said mumps was the commonest cause of painful and swollen\nsalivary glands. ' Associated\nsymptoms include body aches, loss of appetite, generalized weakness,\nheadache and low grade fever,' he said. Source: Fiji Times Online [edited]\n<http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=48194>\n\nHealth ministry warns of mumps outbreak\n MUMPS - FIJI\n***********\n Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: He said there had been an increasing number of mumps cases,\nespecially in the Labasa area, for the past 2 months. He said those infected with mumps should not be given orange or any\ncitrus drink to take while being infected because it could worsen the pain.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-08-25 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Labasa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Suva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4443", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, village festival - Spain (Navarra)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4443", "date": "2006-11-09 00:00:00", "main_text": "MUMPS, VILLAGE FESTIVAL - SPAIN (NAVARRA)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 9 Nov 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly Release, Vol. 11, Issue 11, Thu 9 Nov\n2005 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/061109.asp#4>\n\nSpain: Mumps outbreak in young adults following a village festival in\nthe Navarra region, August 2006\n---------------------------------------------------\nOn 10 Aug 2006, 12 cases of mumps were notified from a village of\naround 3500 inhabitants in Navarra, northern Spain. In 2005, the\nPublic Health Institute of Navarra received only 33 mumps\nnotifications for the whole region of Navarra (population 560 000).\nSince December 2005, mumps outbreaks have been reported from several\nregions of Spain [1] including the neighbouring region of La Rioja.\nAn investigation into the outbreak in Navarra was begun and\ninformation on the patients' vaccination status and possible sources\nof infection was collected in order to recommend measures to prevent\nfurther spread of mumps in the area.\nMumps is a notifiable disease in Spain and vaccination was introduced\nin 1981. A seroprevalence study for measles in Navarra in 1993 showed\nthat more than 95 percent of people between 0-34 years were\nprotected, indicating a high vaccine coverage for measles, mumps and rubella.\nSince 1995, the childhood immunisation programme has included 2 doses\nof trivalent measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine, initially given\nat 15 months and 11 years of age, and since 1999, given at 15 months\nand 6 years of age. Since 1985, the annual incidence of mumps in\nSpain has decreased, although 3 epidemics have occurred, most\nrecently in 2000. Between 1996 and 1998, as in most regions of Spain,\nthe mumps component used in Navarra included the Rubini strain, and\nthis was withdrawn in 1998 because it was found to have reduced\neffectiveness [2,3].\nMethods\n-------\nA probable case was defined as a person from village A who had acute\ninflammation of the parotid glands on or after 1 Jul 2006. A\nconfirmed case was defined as a probable case with mumps IgM or an\nelevated IgG or isolation of mumps virus. The mandatory notifications\nof the region of Navarra was checked for patients fulfilling the case\ndefinition. The general practitioner who worked in the only\nhealthcare centre in village A was asked to report additional cases\nto the regional epidemiology division and to collect samples. Blood\nwas tested for IgM and IgG against mumps virus with ELISA; saliva and\nurine were tested by PCR. A telephone questionnaire was administered\nto all patients, asking them about their vaccination status, symptoms\nand activities since the 15 Jul 2006. Mumps vaccination status was\nverified through regional vaccination records and personal vaccination cards.\nResults\n-------\nA total of 19 cases was identified in village A, 10 (53 percent) of\nwhom were male. Patients' ages ranged between 18 and 37 years.\nSamples from 2 cases were laboratory tested and both were confirmed\nby serology. None of the 18 patients interviewed was admitted to\nhospital. One patient had orchitis. Symptom onset of the 18 patients\ninterviewed was between 3 to 31 August, with a peak on 8 August\n[These data are presented graphically by date of onset in the\noriginal text, which should be consulted for more detailed information].\nSix patients reported that they had never been vaccinated, and a\nfurther 2 patients reported that their vaccination status was\nunknown. Eleven patients reported having been vaccinated twice, and\nthis was verified for 10 cases. Two of these were verified through\npersonal vaccination cards only, and 2 through the regional\nvaccination records only; the remaining 6 were verified by checking\nboth records. Six of the patients who had been vaccinated twice had\nreceived 2nd dose of mumps vaccine between 1996 and 1998, when the\nRubini vaccine was being used (Table). No patients received their 1st\nMMR dose between these dates.\nTable: Vaccination history of cases of mumps during the outbreak in\nVillage A, Navarra, Spain, August 2006 (n=19).\nVaccination history / No. of cases ( percent) / Vaccine status verified\nUnvaccinated / 6 (32 percent) / 2\n1 dose / 0 (0 percent) / 0\n2 doses, date unknown / 1 (5 percent) / 0\n2 doses, 2nd <1996 or >1998 / 4 (21 percent) / 4\n2 doses, 2nd 1996-1998 / 6 (32 percent / 6\nUnknown / 2 (11 percent) / 0\nTotal / 19 (100 percent) / 12\n17 (94 percent) of the 18 patients interviewed about their activities\nsince 15 Jul 2006 reported attending the annual festival held in the\nvillage from 21 to 25 Jul 2006. These traditional festivals (fiestas)\ninclude bullfighting, processions, music, fireworks, and eating and\ndrinking special dishes. They are attended by people who live in the\nvillage and many people from neighbouring villages. Other common\nactivities reported in the interviews included visiting the swimming\npool in the village (9 cases, 50 percent) and bars in the village (10\ncases, 56 percent).\nDiscussion\n----------\nConsidering the mean incubation of 18 days, the outbreak probably\nbegan with transmission at the village festival. As we did not\nconduct an analytical study, it was not possible to identify risk\nfactors or transmission routes. The places where there was a\npossibility of close contact, and where exposure could therefore have\ntaken place, include the swimming pool, bars and the village\ncelebrations. These may well reflect the average summer activities in\nvillages in Spain.\nOur results suggest that this outbreak occurred partly because of the\npresence of susceptible people in cohorts who received a second dose\nof MMR vaccine between 1996 and 1998 with the Rubini strain, even\nthough this group had received a different vaccine strain in the\nfirst MMR dose. As the data for calculating vaccine effectiveness was\nnot collected, the precise role of the Rubini vaccine remains\nunclear. The outbreak follows the known cyclical pattern of mumps,\nand the presence of other susceptible persons (including\nnon-vaccinated people and non-responders') in the population may have\ncontributed to its occurrence.\nRecommendations\n---------------\nCases in neighbouring villages started to appear from 14 August and\nfurther spread of mumps in Navarra seemed likely. We recommended\nenhanced surveillance in schools and universities where there would\nbe people who had received the Rubini strain-containing vaccine at\nthe start of the new academic year in September. Susceptible contacts\nof the cases, including those people who had been vaccinated with the\nRubini strain, were vaccinated soon after the cases were ascertained.\nFollow up\n---------\nDespite these measures, from 1 Sep to 15 Oct 2006, 58 further cases\nof mumps were notified in different places in Navarra. As the current\nmeasures do not seem to have been effective in preventing further\nspread of mumps, further studies in Spain and in other countries that\nused the Rubini strain such as Switzerland, Italy and Portugal\n[2,4,5] are needed to investigate whether large scale vaccination\ncampaigns in people vaccinated with the Rubini strain of the vaccine\nwould be appropriate to prevent further outbreaks within a country.\nThese studies should include an estimation of the costs and side\neffects of revaccination with MMR in young adults and the amount\n(burden) of disease that can be prevented.\n(Acknowledgements: The authors would like to thank J Castilla\nCatalan, M Arriazu Berastegui and A Barricarte Gurrea from the\nEpidemiology Division of the Public Health Institute of Navarra,\nPamplona, Spain for inviting fellows of the Spanish field\nepidemiology programme (PEAC) and for their support during the study\nand the coordinators of the European Programme for Intervention\nEpidemiology Training (EPIET)and PEAC for their supervision and support.)\n(By L Gerstel1,2\n(<lissana@isciii.es>), A Lenglet1,2, M Garcia Cenoz3\n1 Spanish Field Epidemiology Programme (PEAC) and European Programme for\nIntervention Epidemiology Training (EPIET)\n2 National Centre for Epidemiology, Instituto de Salud Carlos III,\nMadrid, Spain\n3 Epidemiology Division, Public Health Institute of Navarra, Pamplona, Spain)\nReferences:\n-----------\n[1] Cardenosa N, Dominguez A, Camps N, Martinez A, Torner N, Navas E\net al. Non-preventable mumps outbreaks in schoolchildren in\nCatalonia. Scand J Infect Dis 2006; 38(8):671-674.\n(<http://taylorandfrancis.metapress.com/openurl.asp?genre=article&id=d\noi:10.1080/00365540600606382>) [abstract]\n[2] Pons C, Pelayo T, Pachon I, Galmes A, Gonzalez L, Sanchez C et\nal. Two outbreaks of mumps in children vaccinated with the Rubini\nstrain in Spain indicate low vaccine efficacy. Euro Surveill 2000;\n5(7):80-84. (<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/em/v05n07/0507-223.asp>)\n[3] Germann D, Strohle A, Eggenberger K, Steiner CA, Matter L. An\noutbreak of mumps in a population partially vaccinated with the\nRubini strain. Scand J Infect Dis 1996; 28(3):235-238.\n[4] Goncalves G, De Araujo A, Monteiro Cardoso ML.
