The Benevento and\nCompobasso Pediatricians Network for the Control of\nVaccine-Preventable Diseases. Vaccine 1998; 16(8):818-822.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The mumps virus component of the MMR triple vaccine has varied.\nSince 1990, 3 strains of mumps virus -- the Urabe, the Rubini and the\nJeryl-Lynn vaccine strains -- have been used in MMR triple vaccines\nat various times. The Urabe strain was withdrawn in 1992 after an\nincreased risk of aseptic meningitis was reported in some countries\nand replaced by the Rubini strain in some triple vaccines between\n1993 and 1995 and in turn by the Jeryl-Lynn strain in most current\ntriple vaccine formulations.\nA map showing the location of the Navarra region in the north of\nSpain can be accessed at\n<http://www.agrobiotecnologia.es/images/01_map_espana.gif> - Mod.JW]", "summary": "\nCatalan, M Arriazu Berastegui and A Barricarte Gurrea from the\nEpidemiology Division of the Public Health Institute of Navarra,\nPamplona, Spain for inviting fellows of the Spanish field\nepidemiology programme (PEAC) and for their support during the study\nand the coordinators of the European Programme for Intervention\nEpidemiology Training (EPIET)and PEAC for their supervision and support.) The Urabe strain was withdrawn in 1992 after an\nincreased risk of aseptic meningitis was reported in some countries\nand replaced by the Rubini strain in some triple vaccines between\n1993 and 1995 and in turn by the Jeryl-Lynn strain in most current\ntriple vaccine formulations.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n (0 percent) / 0\n2 doses, date unknown / 1 (5 percent) / 0\n2 doses, 2nd <1996 or >1998 / 4 (21 percent) / 4\n2 doses, 2nd 1996-1998 / 6 (32 percent / 6\n Our results suggest that this outbreak occurred partly because of the\npresence of susceptible people in cohorts who received a second dose\nof MMR vaccine between 1996 and 1998 with the Rubini strain, even\nthough this group had received a different vaccine strain in the\nfirst MMR dose. Other common\nactivities reported in the interviews included visiting the swimming\npool in the village (9 cases, 50 percent) and bars in the village (10\ncases, 56 percent). 12\n17 (94 percent) of the 18 patients interviewed about their activities\nsince 15 Jul 2006 reported attending the annual festival held in the\nvillage from 21 to 25 Jul 2006. An investigation into the outbreak in Navarra was begun and\ninformation on the patients' vaccination status and possible sources\nof infection was collected in order to recommend measures to prevent\nfurther spread of mumps in the area. Between 1996 and 1998, as in most regions of Spain,\nthe mumps component used in Navarra included the Rubini strain, and\nthis was withdrawn in 1998 because it was found to have reduced\neffectiveness The outbreak follows the known cyclical pattern of mumps,\nand the presence of other susceptible persons (including\nnon-vaccinated people and non-responders') in the population may have\ncontributed to its occurrence. National Centre for Epidemiology, Instituto de Salud Carlos III,\nMadrid, Spain\n3 Epidemiology Division, Public Health Institute of Navarra, Pamplona, Spain)\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Six of the patients who had been vaccinated twice had\nreceived 2nd dose of mumps vaccine between 1996 and 1998, when the\nRubini vaccine was being used (Table). A seroprevalence study for measles in Navarra in 1993 showed\nthat more than 95 percent of people between 0-34 years were\nprotected, indicating a high vaccine coverage for measles, mumps and rubella. Six patients reported that they had never been vaccinated, and a\nfurther 2 patients reported that their vaccination status was\nunknown. Susceptible contacts\nof the cases, including those people who had been vaccinated with the\nRubini strain, were vaccinated soon after the cases were ascertained. A\nconfirmed case was defined as a probable case with mumps IgM or an\nelevated IgG or isolation of mumps virus. Mumps outbreak in young adults following a village festival in\nthe Navarra region, August 2006\n [3] Germann D, Strohle A, Eggenberger K, Steiner CA, Matter L. An\noutbreak of mumps in a population partially vaccinated with the\nRubini strain. A telephone questionnaire was administered\nto all patients, asking them about their vaccination status, symptoms\nand activities since the 15 Jul 2006. In 2005, the\nPublic Health Institute of Navarra received only 33 mumps\nnotifications for the whole region of Navarra (population 560 000). As the data for calculating vaccine effectiveness was\nnot collected, the precise role of the Rubini vaccine remains\nunclear. The general practitioner who worked in the only\nhealthcare centre in village A was asked to report additional cases\nto the regional epidemiology division and to collect samples. MUMPS, VILLAGE FESTIVAL - SPAIN (NAVARRA)\n*****************************************\n Blood\nwas tested for IgM and IgG against mumps virus with ELISA; saliva and\nurine were tested by PCR. Table: Vaccination history of cases of mumps during the outbreak in\nVillage A, Navarra, Spain, August 2006 (n=19).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "measles", "mumps", "pertussis", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1985-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-07-15 00:00:00", "1993-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-12-25 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "1992-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-08-10 00:00:00", "1981-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-08-14 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-08-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-08-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sanchez", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Navarra", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pamplona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1892", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Austria (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1892", "date": "2006-07-06 00:00:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - AUSTRIA (03)\n*******************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 6 Jul 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly releases 2006, Volume 11/Issue 7,\nThu 6 Jul 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/060706.asp#2>\n\nRecently, we reported on a mumps outbreak in Austria (1). By Mon 3\nJul 2006, the outbreak was estimated to include at least 150 cases.\nAs mumps is not a notifiable disease in Austria, data protection\nissues are hindering appropriate investigation. The 3 provinces\naffected by the unusually high number of mumps cases since May 2006\nhave documented a total of 107 serologically confirmed cases,\nincluding 56 cases in Kaernten [Carinthia] (involving 7 health\ndistricts), 22 from Niederoesterreich, 19 from Wien [Vienna], and 10 cases for\nwhich the province of origin is unknown.\nThe 107 serologically confirmed cases include 2 cases of mumps\nmeningitis, 9 cases of orchitis, and 2 cases of pancreatitis. One\ncase involved a pregnant woman. The initial analysis of case data had\nsuggested that attendance at an Easter celebration on 16 Apr 2006\ncould be a common link between the initial cases in Kaernten [see the\nepidemic curve illustrated by a histogram in the original text].\nAnonymised questionnaires have been completed for 46 cases. The\nprimary case among these 46 had symptom onset on 10 Apr 2006,\nand the most recent case had symptom onset on 2 Jul 2006. The\nepidemic curve [not shown here] illustrated a propagated spread.\nAccording to the questionnaires that have so far been completed, men\nwere 1.3 times more often affected than women. Of the 46 cases, 12\n(26 percent) were admitted to hospital. All but one of these 46 cases\nwere in patients aged between 16 and 32 years (median age 23,\ninterquartile range 21-28) and one female patient (the mother of an\ninfected teenager) was 59 years old.\nThe 45 cases aged 16 to 32 years were born into birth-cohorts that\nshould have been vaccinated with at least one dose of mumps vaccine\nin the years from 1974 to 1990. In our initial report, we\nhypothesised that teenagers and young adults born before 1994 had\neither not been vaccinated or had been vaccinated with one dose only.\nOnly 4 of the 46 cases (9 percent) had received 2 vaccine doses.\nFourteen cases (30 percent) received only one dose, and 25 cases (54\npercent) were unvaccinated; in 3 cases, vaccination status was\nunknown. A bivalent mumps-measles (MM) vaccine provided by Merck\nSharp & Dohme was introduced in Austria in 1974, and was replaced in\n1994 by the trivalent mumps, measles and rubella (MMR) vaccine.\nReliable data on vaccination coverage for MMR in Austria are not\navailable. Since 31 May, MMR vaccine has been offered to the\npopulation of Kaernten (population approximately 550 000) by local\nhealth authorities, physicians and hospitals. Approximately 1200\npeople have so far been vaccinated.\nA final analysis of the outbreak will be published soon.\n(From D Schmid1, A-M Pichler1, H Wallenko2, H Holzmann3, T\nPopow-Kraupp3, F Allerberger1 (<franz.allerberger@ages.at>) 1-\nOesterreichische Agentur fuer Gesundheit und Ernaehrungssicherheit,\nVienna, Austria;2 - Landessanitaetsdirektion Kaernten, Klagenfurt,\nAustria; and 3 - Institute of Virology, Medical University of Vienna,\nVienna, Austria\nReference\n---------\n(1) Schmid D, Pichler A-M, Wallenko H, Holzmann H, Allerberger F.\nMumps outbreak affecting adolescents and young adults in Austria,\n2006. Euro Surveillance 2006;11(6):E060615.1. Available from:\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/060615.asp#1>\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The resurgence of mumps in young adults in several parts of the\nworld can be related most often to inadequate vaccination (either a\nhistory of a single dose of vaccine, or a history of no vaccine).\nThe epidemiologic data described above reflect this situation, with\nthe added feature that attendance at an Easter celebration could be a\ncommon link between the initial cases in the outbreak in Kaernten\n(Carinthia).\nA map of the Austrian provinces can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/austria_pol99.jpg> - Mod.CP]\n[Will the index case eventually be identified and found to have come from the\nAmerican outbreak? See ref. below. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "The 3 provinces\naffected by the unusually high number of mumps cases since May 2006\nhave documented a total of 107 serologically confirmed cases,\nincluding 56 cases in Kaernten [Carinthia] (involving 7 health\ndistricts), 22 from Niederoesterreich, 19 from Wien [Vienna], and 10 cases for\nwhich the province of origin is unknown. 1-\nOesterreichische Agentur fuer Gesundheit und Ernaehrungssicherheit,\nVienna, Austria;2 - Landessanitaetsdirektion Kaernten, Klagenfurt,\nAustria; and 3 - Institute of Virology, Medical University of Vienna,\nVienna, Austria\nReference\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The initial analysis of case data had\nsuggested that attendance at an Easter celebration on 16 Apr 2006\ncould be a common link between the initial cases in Kaernten [see the\nepidemic curve illustrated by a histogram in the original text]. All but one of these 46 cases\nwere in patients aged between 16 and 32 years (median age 23,\ninterquartile range 21-28) and one female patient (the mother of an\ninfected teenager) was 59 years old. The epidemiologic data described above reflect this situation, with\nthe added feature that attendance at an Easter celebration could be a\ncommon link between the initial cases in the outbreak in Kaernten\n ---------\n(1) Schmid D, Pichler A-M, Wallenko H, Holzmann H, Allerberger F.\nMumps outbreak affecting adolescents and young adults in Austria,\n2006. In our initial report, we\nhypothesised that teenagers and young adults born before 1994 had\neither not been vaccinated or had been vaccinated with one dose only.\n Fourteen cases (30 percent) received only one dose, and 25 cases (54\npercent) were unvaccinated; in 3 cases, vaccination status was\nunknown. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n The 45 cases aged 16 to 32 years were born into birth-cohorts that\nshould have been vaccinated with at least one dose of mumps vaccine\nin the years from 1974 to 1990. The\nprimary case among these 46 had symptom onset on 10 Apr 2006,\nand the most recent case had symptom onset on 2 Jul 2006. [The resurgence of mumps in young adults in several parts of the\nworld can be related most often to inadequate vaccination (either a\nhistory of a single dose of vaccine, or a history of no vaccine). A bivalent mumps-measles (MM) vaccine provided by Merck\nSharp & Dohme was introduced in Austria in 1974, and was replaced in\n1994 by the trivalent mumps, measles and rubella (MMR) vaccine. Source: Eurosurveillance weekly releases 2006, Volume 11/Issue 7,\nThu 6 Jul 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/060706.asp#2>\n\n The 107 serologically confirmed cases include 2 cases of mumps\nmeningitis, 9 cases of orchitis, and 2 cases of pancreatitis.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-05-31 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "1974-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-05-25 00:00:00", "2006-04-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vienna", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kaernten", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Niederoesterreich", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wien", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Klagenfurt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Schmid D", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1692", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Austria (Carinthia)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1692", "date": "2006-06-08 00:00:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - AUSTRIA (CARINTHIA)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 8 Jun 2006\nFrom: Thomas Roesel <roesel@lycos.com>\nSource: derStandard.at/Panorama, Tue 6 Jun 2006 / Austrian Press\nAgency [trans by submitter; edited]\n<http://derstandard.at/?url=/?id=2469332>\n\nThe lower Drave (Drau, Drava) valley in Carinthia has been stricken\nby a mumps epidemic. Approximately 100 individuals are ill. Two\nyouths have been hospitalized with meningitis. More young men are\nsuffering testicular inflammation, which can lead to sterility. On\nTuesday [6 Jun 2006] vaccinations will begin.\nThe first case was recorded at Easter. The onset of the epidemic was\nat an Easter festival in Feistritz on the Drave according to research\nby physicians. Some students, who became ill in Graz, also took\npart. The incubation time for mumps is as long as 3 weeks. During\nthis time, individuals can be infectious, even when the illness has\nyet to show symptoms.\nMumps is not a harmless disease according to Barbara Eichwalder,\nphysician at the Pedicatrics and Adolescent Medicine Department at\nthe District Hospital of Villach. There can be complications,\nincluding meningitis, and inflammation of the testicles, salivary\nglands, and pancreas. Among those who have been immunized, there are\nvaccine failures in 3-5 percent, which can lead to the risk of\ncontracting mumps despite immunization. For this reason,\npediatricians recommend a 2nd immunization in the 2nd year of life,\nafter a specific interval, to lower the chance of infection.\nDr. Wolfgang Schantl (Socialist Party of Austria), the District\nHealth Administrator, explained to Austrian radio over the weekend\nthat vaccinations for as many people as possible in the affected\nregion will begin on Tue 6 Jun 2006. These will be administered by\nthe public health physicians and ancillary personnel from the Health\nDepartment of Villach.\n--\nThomas Roesel, MD PhD\n<roesel@lycos.com>\n[There has been a resurgence of mumps in young adults in several\nparts of the world in recent months, attributable predominantly to\nsingle immunisations (rather than the optimal 2) or no immunisations\nat all. In some previous reports this was attributed to deficiencies\nin the availability of the mumps component of the triple MMR vaccine.\nSee the ProMED-mail references below.\nThomas Roesel indicates that a map of Austria with an arrow pointing\nto Feistritz on the Drave (Drau) can be found at\n<http://at.postleitzahl.org/k%E4rnten/images/karte_feistritz_an_der_drau.png>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: derStandard.at/Panorama, Tue 6 Jun 2006 / Austrian Press\nAgency [trans by submitter; edited]\n<http://derstandard.at/?url=/?id=2469332>\n\nThe lower Drave (Drau, Drava) valley in Carinthia has been stricken\nby a mumps epidemic. [There has been a resurgence of mumps in young adults in several\nparts of the world in recent months, attributable predominantly to\nsingle immunisations (rather than the optimal 2) or no immunisations\nat all. Dr. Wolfgang Schantl (Socialist Party of Austria), the District\nHealth Administrator, explained to Austrian radio over the weekend\nthat vaccinations for as many people as possible in the affected\nregion will begin on Tue 6 Jun 2006. These will be administered by\nthe public health physicians and ancillary personnel from the Health\nDepartment of Villach.\n --\nThomas Roesel, MD PhD\n<roesel@lycos.com>\n Among those who have been immunized, there are\nvaccine failures in 3-5 percent, which can lead to the risk of\ncontracting mumps despite immunization. For this reason,\npediatricians recommend a 2nd immunization in the 2nd year of life,\nafter a specific interval, to lower the chance of infection. Mumps is not a harmless disease according to Barbara Eichwalder,\nphysician at the Pedicatrics and Adolescent Medicine Department at\nthe District Hospital of Villach.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Carinthia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Graz", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3129", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (IL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3129", "date": "2006-10-03 00:00:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (ILLINOIS)\n*****************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 29 Sep 2006 2006\nFrom: Brent Barrett <salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\nSource: cbs2chicago.com, Fri 29 Sep 2006 [edited]\n<http://cbs2chicago.com/topstories/local_story_272115905.html>\n\nThe total number of confirmed mumps cases at Wheaton College has now\nreached 37, officials there said on Fri 20 Sep 2006.\nThe cases at Wheaton College have all been reported since 7 Sep 2006. Of\nthe 37 students with mumps and 3 additional suspected cases, 23 have\nreturned to class after completing the required 9-day isolation period. A\ncase of mumps was also reported at Benedictine University in Lisle this\nmonth. The DuPage County Health Department said that [prevention measures\nhave been employed] vigilantly at both campuses.\nMumps has been on the decline since a vaccine was developed in the late\n1960's. Federal health experts say that the mumps outbreak that began in\nIowa last December [2005] and spread to other Midwest states is considered\nto be the largest in nearly 20 years.\nIt has not been determined if the DuPage County cases have a connection to\nan outbreak in Iowa. More than 600 cases have been reported in Illinois\nthis year. Prior to 2006, Illinois averaged about10 mumps cases per year.\nDuPage County averages from zero to 3 mumps cases per year over the past 5\nyears.\nIf a person is vaccinated against mumps, his or her risk of getting mumps\nis very low. It is important, however, to be aware of the signs and\nsymptoms of mumps, because a person can still get mumps, regardless of age\nor vaccination status. Symptoms of mumps [virus infection] include swollen\nglands near the jaw, fever, headache or muscle aches.\nAnyone who exhibits any of the symptoms of mumps should contact their\nfamily physician for further evaluation. In Illinois, patients with mumps\nmust be isolated from day care, school, work, and public gatherings until\nat least 9 days after the onset of symptoms. Complications of mumps\ninfection are rare, and can include deafness, meningitis/encephalitis, or\ninflammation of the testicles, ovaries, or breasts. With the exception of\ndeafness, these complications are more common among adults than children.\nSince mumps is primarily spread by direct contact with respiratory\ndroplets, persons may prevent contracting mumps with a few simple actions:\n(1) Children and adults should be up to date with their immunizations.\nPlease discuss your family's vaccination history with your physician.\n(2) Cover your nose and mouth with a tissue when you cough or sneeze, and\nthrow the tissue away after use.\n(3) Wash your hands often with soap and water, especially after you cough\nor sneeze. If water is not near, use an alcohol-based hand cleaner.\n(4) Do not share eating utensils or drinking containers.\n(5) Refrain from close contact with individuals who are sick/experiencing\nsymptoms.\n(6) Avoid touching your eyes, nose or mouth. (Germs are often spread when a\nperson touches something that is contaminated with germs and then touches\nhis or her eyes, nose, or mouth.)\n--\nBrent Barrett\n<salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\n[An outbreak of mumps began in Iowa in December 2005 and involved at least\n10 additional states by May 2006. As a consequence updated recommendations\nof the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) for the Control\nand Elimination of Mumps were published in June 2006 (see: MMWR Weekly\nRelease of 1 Jun 2006/55; 1-2). Sporadic outbreaks have continued up to the\npresent, the Wheaton College outbreak being an example.\nThe first cases in this multistate outbreak were detected on a college\ncampus in eastern Iowa in December 2005; the source of these initial cases\nis unknown. Although the age group most affected (38 per cent of cases) has\nbeen young adults aged 18 to 24 years, many of whom are college students,\nthe outbreak has spread to all age groups.\nDuring the first 4 months of 2006, 11 states reported 2597 cases of mumps.\nEight states (Illinois, Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska, Pennsylvania,\nSouth Dakota, and Wisconsin) reported mumps outbreaks with ongoing local\ntransmission or clusters of cases; 3 states (Colorado, Minnesota, and\nMississippi) reported cases associated with travel from an outbreak state.\nThe majority of mumps cases (1487 [57 per cent]) were reported from Iowa;\nstates with the next highest case totals were Kansas (371), Illinois (224),\nNebraska (201), and Wisconsin (176). Twelve mumps viral isolates from 6\nstates were characterized; all were mumps genotype G. The genotype of the\nmumps virus responsible for the outbreak at Wheaton College has yet to be\nestablished.\nReaders are referred to the account of this multistate outbreak of mumps\npublished in MMWR (reproduced in ProMED-mail as 'Mumps - USA: multistate\n(02) 20060520.1432') for discussion of the factors likely to be responsible\nfor the vulnerability of student populations to mumps virus infection. -\nMod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Readers are referred to the account of this multistate outbreak of mumps\npublished in MMWR (reproduced in ProMED-mail as 'Mumps - USA: multistate\n(02) 20060520.1432') for discussion of the factors likely to be responsible\nfor the vulnerability of student populations to mumps virus infection. Twelve mumps viral isolates from 6\nstates were characterized; all were mumps genotype G. The genotype of the\nmumps virus responsible for the outbreak at Wheaton College has yet to be\nestablished. Eight states (Illinois, Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska, Pennsylvania,\nSouth Dakota, and Wisconsin) reported mumps outbreaks with ongoing local\ntransmission or clusters of cases; 3 states (Colorado, Minnesota, and\nMississippi) reported cases associated with travel from an outbreak state. As a consequence updated recommendations\nof the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) for the Control\nand Elimination of Mumps were published in June 2006 (see: MMWR Weekly\n \nBrent Barrett\n<salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\n Since mumps is primarily spread by direct contact with respiratory\ndroplets, persons may prevent contracting mumps with a few simple actions:\n(1) Children and adults should be up to date with their immunizations. It is important, however, to be aware of the signs and\nsymptoms of mumps, because a person can still get mumps, regardless of age\nor vaccination status. The majority of mumps cases (1487 [57 per cent]) were reported from Iowa;\nstates with the next highest case totals were Kansas (371), Illinois (224),\nNebraska (201), and Wisconsin (176). Of\nthe 37 students with mumps and 3 additional suspected cases, 23 have\nreturned to class after completing the required 9-day isolation period. Federal health experts say that the mumps outbreak that began in\nIowa last December [2005] and spread to other Midwest states is considered\nto be the largest in nearly 20 years. Although the age group most affected (38 per cent of cases) has\nbeen young adults aged 18 to 24 years, many of whom are college students,\nthe outbreak has spread to all age groups. The first cases in this multistate outbreak were detected on a college\ncampus in eastern Iowa in December 2005; the source of these initial cases\nis unknown. In Illinois, patients with mumps\nmust be isolated from day care, school, work, and public gatherings until\nat least 9 days after the onset of symptoms. A\ncase of mumps was also reported at Benedictine University in Lisle this\nmonth. MUMPS - USA (ILLINOIS)\n*****************\n (Germs are often spread when a\nperson touches something that is contaminated with germs and then touches\nhis or her eyes, nose, or mouth.) (2) Cover your nose and mouth with a tissue when you cough or sneeze, and\nthrow the tissue away after use.\n The total number of confirmed mumps cases at Wheaton College has now\nreached 37, officials there said on Fri 20 Sep 2006. [An outbreak of mumps began in Iowa in December 2005 and involved at least\n10 additional states by May 2006.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2006-06-25 00:00:00", "2006-09-07 00:00:00", "2005-12-25 00:00:00", "2006-05-25 00:00:00", "1487-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the DuPage County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois , Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mississippi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DuPage County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1748", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Austria (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1748", "date": "2006-06-16 00:00:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - AUSTRIA (02)\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 15 Jun 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly release, Vol.11 Iss. 6 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/060615.asp#2>\n\nEpidemiology:\nAustria is currently experiencing the longest outbreak of mumps since\nmumps vaccination was first introduced into the national immunisation\nprogramme in 1974. A total of 87 cases have been reported. The main\naffected provinces are Kaernten (known in English as Carinthia,\nlocated in southern Austria), Niederoesterreich and Wien (both in\nnortheast Austria). The age group most affected is people between 18\nand 30 years old.\nThe provincial health authorities in Karnten were informed of an\nincreased number (n=16) of cases of mumps in adolescents and young\nadults aged 16-20 years that occurred in 5 neighbouring health\ndistricts in Kaernten in April and May 2006. On 22 May 2006, the\nAustrian Agency for Health of Food Safety's department for infection\nepidemiology was asked for help to investigate a temporal and\ngeographical cluster of mumps. As mumps is not a notifiable disease\nin Austria, data protection issues have hindered the investigation of\nthis outbreak, and active case finding by personal interviews of the\n87 passively ascertained cases was not possible.\nBy 14 Jun [2006], 47 cases of mumps from 5 neighbouring districts in\nKaernten had been serologically (blood samples) confirmed in the\nnational reference laboratory in Vienna. Data on possible or probable\ncases are not yet available. In 2 further Austrian provinces local\nmedical laboratories have noticed an unusually high number of mumps\ncases since April 2006 (18 cases in Niederoesterreich and 13 cases in Wien).\nBy 14 Jun [2006], there were 2 serologically confirmed cases of mumps\nmeningitis, 5 serologically confirmed cases of orchitis, and one\nserologically confirmed case of pancreatitis, and another case\ninvolved a pregnant woman.\nInvestigation:\nAfter the first alert in Kaernten, mumps information sheets (one type\nfor healthcare providers and another type for the affected\npopulation) were disseminated to local physicians and hospitals in\nthe 5 districts. The local physicians and hospitals were asked to\ncomplete a questionnaire which, despite data protection requirements,\nshould enable a proper case series investigation. Currently,\ndemographic data, clinical onset, case classification (possible,\nprobable or confirmed case), complications (such as meningitis and\norchitis), admission to hospital and history of mumps infection and\nmumps vaccination is being collected. In order to identify sources of\ninfection and people at risk of mumps infection, data are being\ncollected on contact history between 25 and 14 days before clinical\nonset (swelling of one or more salivary glands) and between the 2\ndays before clinical onset and the 9th day after clinical onset\n(period of infectiousness).\nInitial analysis of case data suggested that there could be a link\nbetween the initial cases in Kaernten, namely attendance at an Easter\nfestivity on 16 Apr [2006], which may have been the occasion on which\nthe mumps virus was introduced to a community with a high proportion\nof susceptibles. We hypothesise that adolescents and young adults\nborn before 1994 have either not been vaccinated or have been\nvaccinated with one dose only.\nRoutine vaccination programmes and current responses:\nThe bivalent mumps-measles (MM) vaccine was introduced in Austria in\n1974, and was replaced in 1994 by the trivalent mumps, measles and\nrubella (MMR) vaccine. Reliable data on vaccination coverage for MMR\nin Austria are not available.\nSince 31 May [2006], MMR vaccine has been offered to the population\nof these 5 health districts by local health authorities, physicians\nand hospitals. Between 500 and 600 people have so far been\nvaccinated. The vaccination campaign is being publicised in the media.\nFurther information on the outbreak will be provided when it becomes\navailable..\nAcknowledgements:\nInstitute of Virology, Medical University of Vienna\n[Reported by: D Schmid /1, A-M Pichler /1, H Wallenko /2, H Holzmann\n/3, F Allerberger /1 (<franz.allerberger@ages.at>)\n1/ Oesterreichische Agentur fuer Gesundheit und\nErnaehrungssicherheit, Vienna, Austria\n2/ Landessanitaetsdirektion Kaernten, Klagenfurt, Austria\n3/ Institute of Virology, Medical University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As mentioned by Mod.CP in the earlier posting on this outbreak (see\nbelow), there has been a recent resurgence of mumps in young adults\nin several parts of the world, most often related to inadequate\nvaccination (either a history of a single dose of vaccine, or a\nhistory of no vaccine). The above discussion on the demographics of\nthe outbreak seems to further support this observation. One suspects\nthat once all of the epidemiologic data are in, the findings will be\nconsistent with high attack rates in incompletely or never vaccinated\nindividuals.\nFor a map of Austria with provinces,\nsee <http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/austria_pol99.jpg> - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "Ernaehrungssicherheit, Vienna, Austria\n2/ Landessanitaetsdirektion Kaernten, Klagenfurt, Austria\n3/ Institute of Virology, Medical University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n In order to identify sources of\ninfection and people at risk of mumps infection, data are being\ncollected on contact history between 25 and 14 days before clinical\nonset (swelling of one or more salivary glands) and between the 2\ndays before clinical onset and the 9th day after clinical onset\n(period of infectiousness). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Currently,\ndemographic data, clinical onset, case classification (possible,\nprobable or confirmed case), complications (such as meningitis and\norchitis), admission to hospital and history of mumps infection and\nmumps vaccination is being collected. CP in the earlier posting on this outbreak (see\nbelow), there has been a recent resurgence of mumps in young adults\nin several parts of the world, most often related to inadequate\nvaccination (either a history of a single dose of vaccine, or a\nhistory of no vaccine). One suspects\nthat once all of the epidemiologic data are in, the findings will be\nconsistent with high attack rates in incompletely or never vaccinated\nindividuals.\n By 14 Jun [2006], there were 2 serologically confirmed cases of mumps\nmeningitis, 5 serologically confirmed cases of orchitis, and one\nserologically confirmed case of pancreatitis, and another case\ninvolved a pregnant woman. The provincial health authorities in Karnten were informed of an\nincreased number (n=16) of cases of mumps in adolescents and young\nadults aged 16-20 years that occurred in 5 neighbouring health\ndistricts in Kaernten in April and May 2006. As mumps is not a notifiable disease\nin Austria, data protection issues have hindered the investigation of\nthis outbreak, and active case finding by personal interviews of the\n87 passively ascertained cases was not possible. After the first alert in Kaernten, mumps information sheets (one type\nfor healthcare providers and another type for the affected\npopulation) were disseminated to local physicians and hospitals in\nthe 5 districts. On 22 May 2006, the\nAustrian Agency for Health of Food Safety's department for infection\nepidemiology was asked for help to investigate a temporal and\ngeographical cluster of mumps. The main\naffected provinces are Kaernten (known in English as Carinthia,\nlocated in southern Austria), Niederoesterreich and Wien (both in\nnortheast Austria). In 2 further Austrian provinces local\nmedical laboratories have noticed an unusually high number of mumps\ncases since April 2006 (18 cases in Niederoesterreich and 13 cases in Wien). By 14 Jun [2006], 47 cases of mumps from 5 neighbouring districts in\nKaernten had been serologically (blood samples) confirmed in the\nnational reference laboratory in Vienna. The bivalent mumps-measles (MM) vaccine was introduced in Austria in\n1974, and was replaced in 1994 by the trivalent mumps, measles and\nrubella (MMR) vaccine. Austria is currently experiencing the longest outbreak of mumps since\nmumps vaccination was first introduced into the national immunisation\nprogramme in 1974. Since 31 May [2006], MMR vaccine has been offered to the population\nof these 5 health districts by local health authorities, physicians\nand hospitals. The local physicians and hospitals were asked to\ncomplete a questionnaire which, despite data protection requirements,\nshould enable a proper case series investigation. [2006], which may have been the occasion on which\nthe mumps virus was introduced to a community with a high proportion\nof susceptibles. Initial analysis of case data suggested that there could be a link\nbetween the initial cases in Kaernten, namely attendance at an Easter\nfestivity on 16 Apr We hypothesise that adolescents and young adults\nborn before 1994 have either not been vaccinated or have been\nvaccinated with one dose only.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2006-05-22 00:00:00", "2021-04-25 00:00:00", "2021-06-14 00:00:00", "1974-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-04-25 00:00:00", "2006-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-05-31 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Klagenfurt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kaernten", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Karnten", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wien", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vienna", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Niederoesterreich", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3947", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (multistate) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3947", "date": "2006-10-27 00:00:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (MULTISTATE) (03)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 27 Oct 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promedmail@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR Weekly, Fri 27 Oct 2006, 55, (42) ;1152-1153 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5542a3.htm?s_cid=mm5542a3>\n\nUSA - Mumps Activity Update; 1 Jan to 7 Oct 2006\n------------------------------------------------\nDuring the period 1 Jan to 7 Oct 2006, a total of 45 states\n(Connecticut, Delaware, Maine, Montana, and Vermont did not report\ncases) and the District of Columbia reported 5783 confirmed or\nprobable mumps cases to CDC (data presented as a histogram in the\noriginal article). This includes 2597 cases previously reported by 11\nstates during the period 1 Jan to 29 Apr 2006 (1). This report\nsummarizes the epidemiology of mumps cases in the United States\nduring 2006. With low levels of reported mumps continuing,\nhealth-care workers should remain alert to suspected mumps, conduct\nappropriate laboratory testing, and use every opportunity to ensure\nadequate immunity, particularly among populations at high risk for mumps.\nCases of mumps are reportable through the National Notifiable\nDiseases Surveillance System (NNDSS). Reports are transmitted\nelectronically via NNDSS to CDC each week and include individual case\ninformation such as age, sex, date of symptom onset, vaccination\nstatus, and complications of illness. Mumps cases included in this\nreport are those with onset from 1 Jan to 7 Oct 2006 (week 40).\nThe clinical case definition of mumps is an illness with acute onset\nof unilateral or bilateral tender, self-limited, swelling of the\nparotid or other salivary gland, lasting 2 or more days, and without\nother apparent cause. A confirmed case of mumps is one that is\nlaboratory confirmed or meets the clinical case definition and is\nlinked epidemiologically to a confirmed or probable case. A probable\ncase meets the clinical case definition but is neither laboratory\nconfirmed nor linked to another confirmed or probable mumps case (2).\nOf the 5783 cases, 3113 (54 percent) were confirmed, and 2612 (45\npercent) were probable; for 58 cases (1 percent), classification was\nunknown. Six states reported 84 percent of the cases: Iowa (1968),\nKansas (904), Wisconsin (750), Illinois (591), Nebraska (357), and\nSouth Dakota (288).\nFor 5747 (99 percent) of the 5783 mumps cases with patient age\navailable, the median age was 22 years (range: 1 month to 96 years).\nAmong the 5739 (99 percent) patients for whom sex was known, 3644 (63\npercent) were female. As reported previously (1), the highest\nage-specific rate continues to be among persons aged 18 to 24 years,\nmany of whom were college students.\nData regarding vaccination status are incomplete. In Iowa, one of the\nstates with the most complete data, preliminary vaccination data have\nbeen reported through 20 Sep 2006. Among 1798 patients with completed\nfollow-up reports, 123 (7 percent) were unvaccinated; 245 (14\npercent) had received one dose of measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR)\nvaccine, and 884 (49 percent) had received >2 doses of MMR vaccine.\nThe vaccination status of 546 (30 percent) patients, the majority of\nwhom were adults, was unknown (3).\nAmong the 5783 cases for which weeks of onset are known, cases peaked\nduring the period 16 to 29 Apr 2006, the onset period for 1498 (26\npercent) cases. The number of reported cases decreased during the\nperiod May to September, when most students were not attending\ncollege. However, since students began returning to school in August,\nmumps clusters have been reported from three college or university\ncampuses in Illinois (84 cases), Kansas (22 cases), and Virginia (12\ncases). Most of these cases (96 percent) were reported in persons who\nhad received 2 doses of MMR vaccine. Because 2 doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine are not 100 percent effective, in a setting\nwith high vaccination coverage such as the United States, most mumps\ncases likely will occur in persons who have received the 2 doses.\nMultiple other factors might have contributed to the spread of the\nmumps outbreak (e.g., the close-contact environment of college\ndormitories or varying college admission requirements for MMR vaccination) (1).\nHealth-care providers should continue to remain alert for suspected\nmumps cases, conduct appropriate diagnostic testing, and report these\ncases to local or state health departments. At the initial visit,\nrecommended specimens for laboratory testing include serum to test\nfor mumps immunoglobulin M (IgM) antibodies and a swab from the\nparotid duct or other affected salivary gland ducts for viral\nisolation, reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction testing,\nor both. Parotid duct swab is the preferred viral sample for mumps;\nurine samples are no longer recommended. The first (acute) serum\nspecimen should be collected within 5 days of illness onset. If the\nIgM antibody titer is negative, a 2nd (convalescent) serum specimen\nfor IgM antibodies is recommended 2 to 3 weeks after onset of signs\n(e.g., parotitis) or symptoms; a delayed IgM response has been\nobserved in patients with confirmed cases of mumps, especially in\nvaccinated persons. The paired serum specimens also can be used to\ndetect a significant rise (as defined by the testing kit\ninstructions) in immunoglobulin G (IgG seroconversion) if measured by\nenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay or a fourfold rise in titer if\nmeasured using plaque-reduction neutralization assays or similar\nquantitative assay.\nNegative laboratory tests, especially in vaccinated persons, should\nnot be used to rule out a mumps diagnosis, because these tests are\nnot sensitive enough to detect infection in all persons with clinical\nillness. In the absence of another diagnosis, cases meeting the\nclinical case definition should be reported as mumps cases.\nIn response to this nationwide mumps outbreak, ACIP recommendations\nfor prevention and control of mumps were updated (4). Evidence of\nimmunity through documentation of vaccination is now defined as one\ndose of live mumps vaccine for preschool-aged children and adults not\nat high risk for exposure and infection and 2 doses of live mumps\nvaccine for school-aged children (i.e., grades kindergarten-12) and\nadults at high risk for exposure and infection (i.e., health-care\nworkers, international travelers, and students at post-high-school\neducation institutions). Additional recommendations for outbreak\ncontrol include administering a second dose of MMR for preschool\nchildren and adults not at high risk for exposure and infection if\nthese persons are part of a group that is experiencing an outbreak\n(4). To ensure high levels of immunity, especially among groups at\nhigh risk for exposure and infection, every opportunity should be\nused to provide the 1st or 2nd dose of MMR vaccine to those without\nadequate evidence of immunity (e.g., documentation of vaccination).\nPrivate health-care providers, clinics, health departments,\nhealth-care institutions, schools, universities, and colleges should\nconsider offering MMR vaccine through such settings as routine\npreventive health services and special immunization clinics,\nincluding providing MMR in conjunction with influenza vaccine.\n(Reported by: S Reef, MD, G Dayan, MD, W Bellini, PhD, A Barskey,\nMPH, S Redd, D Bi, MS, P Rota, PhD, J Rota, MPH, Div of Viral\nDiseases, National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases\n(proposed), CDC.)\nReferences\n-----------\n(1) CDC. Update: multistate outbreak of mumps---United States,\nJanuary 1--May 2, 2006. MMWR 2006;55:559--63.\n(2) Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists (CSTE). 1999\nposition statements. Position Statement ID-9. CSTE National Meeting,\nMadison, WI, 1999. Available at <http://www.cste.org/ps/1999/1999-id-09.htm>.\n(3) Iowa Department of Public Health. Mumps information. Mumps\nupdate: 30 Sep 2006. Available at\n<http://www.idph.state.ia.us/adper/mumps.asp>.\n(4) CDC. Updated recommendations of the Advisory Committee on\nImmunization Practices (ACIP) for the control and elimination of\nmumps. MMWR 2006;55:629--30.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This outbreak, which peaked in April/May 2006, has declined to\npre-2006 levels. It has resulted in revision of the US ACIP\nrecommendations for control and elimination of mumps virus infection\nin the USA. These recommendations are relevant to control and\nelimination of mumps elsewhere. This thread is now closed. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Evidence of\nimmunity through documentation of vaccination is now defined as one\ndose of live mumps vaccine for preschool-aged children and adults not\nat high risk for exposure and infection and 2 doses of live mumps\nvaccine for school-aged children (i.e., grades kindergarten-12) and\nadults at high risk for exposure and infection (i.e., health-care\nworkers, international travelers, and students at post-high-school\neducation institutions). \nPrivate health-care providers, clinics, health departments,\nhealth-care institutions, schools, universities, and colleges should\nconsider offering MMR vaccine through such settings as routine\npreventive health services and special immunization clinics,\nincluding providing MMR in conjunction with influenza vaccine.\n At the initial visit,\nrecommended specimens for laboratory testing include serum to test\nfor mumps immunoglobulin M (IgM) antibodies and a swab from the\nparotid duct or other affected salivary gland ducts for viral\nisolation, reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction testing,\nor both. The paired serum specimens also can be used to\ndetect a significant rise (as defined by the testing kit\ninstructions) in immunoglobulin G (IgG seroconversion) if measured by\nenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay or a fourfold rise in titer if\nmeasured using plaque-reduction neutralization assays or similar\nquantitative assay. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Additional recommendations for outbreak\ncontrol include administering a second dose of MMR for preschool\nchildren and adults not at high risk for exposure and infection if\nthese persons are part of a group that is experiencing an outbreak\n(4). Because 2 doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine are not 100 percent effective, in a setting\nwith high vaccination coverage such as the United States, most mumps\ncases likely will occur in persons who have received the 2 doses. With low levels of reported mumps continuing,\nhealth-care workers should remain alert to suspected mumps, conduct\nappropriate laboratory testing, and use every opportunity to ensure\nadequate immunity, particularly among populations at high risk for mumps. Among 1798 patients with completed\nfollow-up reports, 123 (7 percent) were unvaccinated; 245 (14\npercent) had received one dose of measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR)\nvaccine, and 884 (49 percent) had received >2 doses of MMR vaccine. However, since students began returning to school in August,\nmumps clusters have been reported from three college or university\ncampuses in Illinois (84 cases), Kansas (22 cases), and Virginia (12\ncases). \nHealth-care providers should continue to remain alert for suspected\nmumps cases, conduct appropriate diagnostic testing, and report these\ncases to local or state health departments. (Connecticut, Delaware, Maine, Montana, and Vermont did not report\ncases) and the District of Columbia reported 5783 confirmed or\nprobable mumps cases to CDC (data presented as a histogram in the\noriginal article). The clinical case definition of mumps is an illness with acute onset\nof unilateral or bilateral tender, self-limited, swelling of the\nparotid or other salivary gland, lasting 2 or more days, and without\nother apparent cause. To ensure high levels of immunity, especially among groups at\nhigh risk for exposure and infection, every opportunity should be\nused to provide the 1st or 2nd dose of MMR vaccine to those without\nadequate evidence of immunity (e.g., documentation of vaccination). Negative laboratory tests, especially in vaccinated persons, should\nnot be used to rule out a mumps diagnosis, because these tests are\nnot sensitive enough to detect infection in all persons with clinical\nillness. Reports are transmitted\nelectronically via NNDSS to CDC each week and include individual case\ninformation such as age, sex, date of symptom onset, vaccination\nstatus, and complications of illness. If the\nIgM antibody titer is negative, a 2nd (convalescent) serum specimen\nfor IgM antibodies is recommended 2 to 3 weeks after onset of signs\n (Reported by: S Reef, MD, G Dayan, MD, W Bellini, PhD, A Barskey,\nMPH, S Redd, D Bi, MS, P Rota, PhD, J Rota, MPH, Div of Viral\nDiseases, National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases\n(proposed), CDC.) Among the 5783 cases for which weeks of onset are known, cases peaked\nduring the period 16 to 29 Apr 2006, the onset period for 1498 (26\npercent) cases. Of the 5783 cases, 3113 (54 percent) were confirmed, and 2612 (45\npercent) were probable; for 58 cases (1 percent), classification was\nunknown. A probable\ncase meets the clinical case definition but is neither laboratory\nconfirmed nor linked to another confirmed or probable mumps case (2). In the absence of another diagnosis, cases meeting the\nclinical case definition should be reported as mumps cases.\n A confirmed case of mumps is one that is\nlaboratory confirmed or meets the clinical case definition and is\nlinked epidemiologically to a confirmed or probable case. (e.g., parotitis) or symptoms; a delayed IgM response has been\nobserved in patients with confirmed cases of mumps, especially in\nvaccinated persons. Source: MMWR Weekly, Fri 27 Oct 2006, 55, (42) ;1152-1153 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5542a3.htm?s_cid=mm5542a3>\n\nUSA - Mumps Activity Update; 1 Jan to 7 Oct 2006\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-08-25 00:00:00", "2006-09-20 00:00:00", "2612-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2055-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "5747-03-25 00:00:00", "2042-03-25 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-01 00:00:00", "1968-03-25 00:00:00", "5783-03-25 00:00:00", "1498-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vermont", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "W Bellini", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1225", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - China (Nanjing)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1225", "date": "2006-05-15 00:00:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - CHINA (NANJING)\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sun 14 May 2006\nFrom: Dan Silver <dgsilver@yahoo.com>\nSource: Sina.com, 13 May 2006 [translated, edited]\n<http://news.sina.com.cn/c/2006-05-13/03578910912s.shtml>\n\nNanjing quarantines nearly 100 primary schoolchildren with mumps\n-----------------------------------------------------\nSince more than one month ago, more than 700 pupils of Cheng-xi primary\nschool in the Liou-He district of Nanjing have contracted mumps. Nearly 100\npupils who suffered from the disease were forced to stay home. Up to now,\nan average of 10-20 students daily have been affected and ordered not to\nattend class. The Liou-He district health and education authorities are\ninvolved in the investigation.\nAfter 2 pm [on 12 May 2006] afternoon, a reporter visited to Cheng-xi\nprimary school and talked to several pupils. A girl aged 7 or 8 years told\nthe reporter that several children in her class had been absent with mumps:\n'Many people in our class had fallen ill. Once they became ill, their faces\nwere swollen. So they had to stay home.' The reporter [was shown] a copy of\nthe daily tally of mumps-infected students. On 12 May 2006, a total of 27\nstudents in the whole school were found infected with mumps and were forced\nto stay home. One day earlier, on 11 May 2006, there were 11 students in a\nsimilar condition.\nTeacher Wang explained that the mumps first appeared in a student in March\n2006. The school arranged for this student to stay at home. The next day,\nanother student fell ill similarly, and the school made the same\narrangement. 'Between that time and the May 1st Laborer's Day, few students\nwere ill. Shortly after Laborer's Day, the cases mounted considerably.' An\ninsider told the reporter that from March 2006 to now, there were nearly\n100 pupils who suffered from mumps in this school. From grade one to grade\n6, nearly each class had sick students.\nThe school authority admits to having insufficient knowledge of the\noutbreak. The reporter has met the school headmaster, Mr Jin-Fong Ping. Mr\nPing was quoted as saying that as soon as the school found out that there\nwere students who suffered from the mumps, the school ordered the ill\nstudents to stay home and not to come to school. Besides taking the measure\nof home quarantine, the school did not disinfect the classrooms or engage\nin vaccine inoculation of the other students.\nMr Ping said the school had established a mumps prevention and treatment\nmanagement group, which is responsible for vaccine inoculation, medicines\ndelivery, and data collection, etc. 'Up till now, I have not obtained any\nconcrete data yet, because some students went home without suffering from\nthe mumps, but [from] catching a cold, or having a fever etc.'\nAt present, the Disease Prevention and Control Centers (DPCC) as well as\nthe Bureau of Education of Liou-He District have already gone to the school\nto carry out an investigation.\n--\nDan Silver\n<dgsilver@yahoo.com>\n[A map of China with the mumps-affected area, Nanjing, can be accessed at:\n<http://www.lonelyplanet.com/mapshells/north_east_asia/china/china.htm>.\nMumps is a viral infection of the salivary glands that is vaccine\npreventable (90 per cent efficacy). It causes an unpleasant illness\nincluding fever, headache, and swelling of the glands around the jaw. It is\nnearly as infectious as influenza. As of mid-March this year (2006), mumps\nhas been exceptionally prevalent in as many as 9 states of the United\nStates. - Mod.RY]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Mr\nPing was quoted as saying that as soon as the school found out that there\nwere students who suffered from the mumps, the school ordered the ill\nstudents to stay home and not to come to school. At present, the Disease Prevention and Control Centers (DPCC) as well as\nthe Bureau of Education of Liou-He District have already gone to the school\nto carry out an investigation.\n On 12 May 2006, a total of 27\nstudents in the whole school were found infected with mumps and were forced\nto stay home. --\nDan Silver\n<dgsilver@yahoo.com>\n An\ninsider told the reporter that from March 2006 to now, there were nearly\n100 pupils who suffered from mumps in this school. Mr Ping said the school had established a mumps prevention and treatment\nmanagement group, which is responsible for vaccine inoculation, medicines\ndelivery, and data collection, etc. ' Up till now, I have not obtained any\nconcrete data yet, because some students went home without suffering from\nthe mumps, but [from] catching a cold, or having a fever etc.' Besides taking the measure\nof home quarantine, the school did not disinfect the classrooms or engage\nin vaccine inoculation of the other students. A girl aged 7 or 8 years told\nthe reporter that several children in her class had been absent with mumps:\n'Many people in our class had fallen ill. Source: Sina.com, 13 May 2006 [translated, edited]\n<http://news.sina.com.cn/c/2006-05-13/03578910912s.shtml>\n\nNanjing quarantines nearly 100 primary schoolchildren with mumps\n The next day,\nanother student fell ill similarly, and the school made the same\narrangement. ' As of mid-March this year (2006), mumps\nhas been exceptionally prevalent in as many as 9 states of the United\nStates. - Mod.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-05-12 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-05-14 00:00:00", "2006-05-11 00:00:00", "2021-05-01 00:00:00", "2006-05-13 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nanjing", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209497", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (NE, IA)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209497", "date": "2006-04-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (NEBRASKA, IOWA) (02)\n**********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 5 Apr 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Medpage Today online, Tue 4 Apr 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.medpagetoday.com/PublicHealthPolicy/PublicHealth/tb/2987>\n\nIowa: Mumps Outbreak Linked to Primary Vaccine Failure\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe tally of mumps cases has climbed to 300 in an outbreak that started in\nIowa and has spread to all bordering states, with the exception of South\nDakota. Meghan Harris M.P.H., of the Iowa Department of Public Health, said\nthat the latest state affected by mumps is Missouri, which has reported a\nsingle case. The tally, which was released here today [5 Apr 2006], has\nincreased by 55 cases since Fri 31 Mar 2006. Harris said she expects the\nnumbers to be higher when the next scheduled update is issued Thu 6 Apr 2006.\nFollow-up reports have been completed on 154 cases. Of those, 68 percent\noccurred in people who had received the recommended 2 doses of the\nmeasles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine. Iowa, according to Harris, is a state\nwith a high vaccination rate, and she anticipates the majority of mumps\ninfections will occur in people who are considered safe on the basis of\ntheir immunization records. 'But we know the vaccine doesn't work in\neveryone,' she said. Harris said published data suggest that the vaccine\nfailure rate for mumps is about 5 percent. 'So by my estimate, there are\nabout 200 000 people in Iowa who have received the recommended vaccinations\nbut who have no immunity to mumps.' The current recommendation is that a\n1st dose of MMR triple vaccine be administered at age 12-15 months, with a\n2nd dose at 4-6 years. But Blaise Congeni, M.D., director of infectious\ndiseases at the Akron (Ohio) Children's Hospital, said that if the 2nd dose\nis missed, it can also be administered during adolescence.\nThe 300 confirmed, probable, or suspected cases of mumps represent the\nnation's largest mumps outbreak in 17 years. Early on, most of the Iowa\ncases were reported in college-age students. The mean age at onset was 21,\nand almost 45 percent of the cases occurred in 19-year-olds. But Harris\nsaid that no single college or university was implicated in the outbreak.\n'We can assume that this outbreak is associated with some aspects of\ncollege life, such as living in dorms or mixing together at the same\nclubs,' she said. The best explanation, according to Harris, is that\ncollege students 'in general have a higher risk of sharing saliva.' But the\nnewer numbers confirmed that the outbreak is moving beyond the college\ncampuses. 21 percent of cases occurred in students attending college, down\nfrom 23 percent of cases reported by 30 Mar 2006.\nThe public health data include confirmed, suspect and probable cases of\nmumps. Probable cases are those that meet the clinical case definition but\nhave no confirmed serologic or virologic testing. Suspect cases are those\nwith positive IgM serology, and confirmed cases are cases that meet\nclinical definition that are also laboratory-confirmed or epidemiologically\nlinked.\nDr. Congeni speculated that it may be difficult to identify an index case,\nbecause the primary symptom of mumps, parotitis, is often not fully\nevaluated by clinicians. 'If the patient's record indicates that he or she\nhas been received 2 MMR doses, the assumption would be that this is caused\nby another virus,' he said. If the symptoms abate, the episode would be\nlittle more than a notation in a medical record.\nHarris agreed that Dr. Congeni's theory best explains what has happened in\nIowa, especially since the mumps strain is the same one that caused\noutbreaks in England over the past few years. That suggests that mumps\narrived with a recent visitor from Britain, but 'because these symptoms are\noften overlooked -- especially in people who have received the required\nvaccinations -- we doubt we will ever identify the index case,' she said.\nDr. Congeni said, however, that a mumps outbreak does not carry the\npotential for public health disaster that would be associated with a\nmeasles or rubella outbreak. 'There is a small risk that some kids will\ndevelop viral meningitis, and orchitis is a concern, but we know that\norchitis doesn't cause sterility,' Dr. Congeni said. As of today, 5 percent\nof cases included orchitis among symptoms, and there was one case of\nencephalitis being investigated.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Suspect cases are those\nwith positive IgM serology, and confirmed cases are cases that meet\nclinical definition that are also laboratory-confirmed or epidemiologically\nlinked. That suggests that mumps\narrived with a recent visitor from Britain, but 'because these symptoms are\noften overlooked -- especially in people who have received the required\nvaccinations -- we doubt we will ever identify the index case,' she said. \nDr. Congeni said, however, that a mumps outbreak does not carry the\npotential for public health disaster that would be associated with a\nmeasles or rubella outbreak. ' Iowa, according to Harris, is a state\nwith a high vaccination rate, and she anticipates the majority of mumps\ninfections will occur in people who are considered safe on the basis of\ntheir immunization records. ' Of those, 68 percent\noccurred in people who had received the recommended 2 doses of the\nmeasles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine. The tally of mumps cases has climbed to 300 in an outbreak that started in\nIowa and has spread to all bordering states, with the exception of South\nDakota. Meghan Harris M.P.H., of the Iowa Department of Public Health, said\nthat the latest state affected by mumps is Missouri, which has reported a\nsingle case. As of today, 5 percent\nof cases included orchitis among symptoms, and there was one case of\nencephalitis being investigated. We can assume that this outbreak is associated with some aspects of\ncollege life, such as living in dorms or mixing together at the same\nclubs,' she said. The current recommendation is that a\n1st dose of MMR triple vaccine be administered at age 12-15 months, with a\n2nd dose at 4-6 years. Dr. Congeni speculated that it may be difficult to identify an index case,\nbecause the primary symptom of mumps, parotitis, is often not fully\nevaluated by clinicians. ' So by my estimate, there are\nabout 200 000 people in Iowa who have received the recommended vaccinations\nbut who have no immunity to mumps.' Harris agreed that Dr. Congeni's theory best explains what has happened in\nIowa, especially since the mumps strain is the same one that caused\noutbreaks in England over the past few years. There is a small risk that some kids will\ndevelop viral meningitis, and orchitis is a concern, but we know that\norchitis doesn't cause sterility,' Dr. Congeni said. If the patient's record indicates that he or she\nhas been received 2 MMR doses, the assumption would be that this is caused\nby another virus,' he said. But the\nnewer numbers confirmed that the outbreak is moving beyond the college\ncampuses. >\nSource: Medpage Today online, Tue 4 Apr 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.medpagetoday.com/PublicHealthPolicy/PublicHealth/tb/2987>\n\nIowa: \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org> 21 percent of cases occurred in students attending college, down\nfrom 23 percent of cases reported by 30 Mar 2006.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-04-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "M.D.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Britain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1354", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (multistate)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1354", "date": "2006-04-21 00:00:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (MULTISTATE)\n*****************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this posting:\n[1] Multistate\n[2] Nebraska\n[3] Kansas\n[4] Illinois\n[5] Wisconsin\n\n****\n[1] Multistate\nDate: 19 Apr 2006\nFrom: George Robertson <geo456@comcast.net>\nSource: Reuters UK [edited]\n<http://today.reuters.co.uk/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=healthNews&storyID=2006-04-19T215543Z_01_N19230281_RTRIDST_0_HEALTH-MUMPS-DC.XML\n>\n\nThe number of mumps cases has risen to 1100 in 8 Midwestern states\nand prompted the federal government to distribute vaccines from its\nstockpile to stop the outbreak's spread, health officials said on Wednesday.\nThe outbreak is the largest mumps epidemic in the United States in\nmore than 20 years, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention said. Most are in Iowa, where 815 cases have been\nrecorded, the CDC said.\nAn additional 350 mumps cases have been reported in Minnesota,\nKansas, Illinois, Nebraska, Wisconsin, Missouri and Oklahoma,\nofficials said. Investigators are reviewing possible cases in 7 other\nstates that were not named.\nMumps usually is not serious and rarely kills. None of the cases in\nthe recent outbreak have been fatal.\nOnce a common childhood illness, mumps was virtually eradicated with\nwidespread use of the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine. But\nthe vaccine is effective in only about 90 percent of people, which\ncould partly explain the recent outbreak, CDC Director Julie Gerberding said.\n'Although this is a very good vaccine, it's not perfect,' Gerberding\nsaid at a news conference.\nMany college-age students may have received just one of the 2\nrecommended doses when they were young, and therefore may not have\nthe same level of immunity as others, she said.\nFederal officials urged students, people who work in school or\nuniversity settings and health-care workers who did not get both\ndoses to get a 2nd dose.\nThe CDC is sending 25 000 doses of MMR vaccine to Iowa for that\npurpose, Gerberding said. Drug maker Merck & Co. Inc. has donated an\nadditional 25 000 doses for health officials to use as they see fit.\nInvestigators do not yet know how many of the people infected with\nmumps were vaccinated. So far, 'we have absolutely no information to\nsuggest there's a problem with the vaccine,' Gerberding said.\nMumps is a viral infection of the salivary glands. It causes\nunpleasant illness including fever, headache and swelling of the\nglands around the jaw.\nUp to 10 percent of patients may develop encephalitis. Other serious\ncomplications that sometimes occur include meningitis, inflammation\nof the testicles, ovaries or pancreas, or permanent deafness. There\nis no approved treatment.\nThe mumps virus is transmitted by coughing and sneezing. Experts say\nit is about as infectious as influenza. People can transmit mumps to\nothers for 3 days before they have any symptoms.\nIn the United States, an average of 265 mumps cases have been\nreported each year since 2001. Mumps vaccinations started in 1967.\n[Byline: Lisa Richwine]\n--\nGeorge Robertson\n<geo456@comcast.net>\n******\n[2] Nebraska\nDate: 18 Apr 2006\nFrom: Dr. Alfonso J. Rodriguez <ajrm_msds@yahoo.es>\nSource: WRFV [edited]\n<http://wfrv.com/health/health_story_108004733.html>\n\nNebraska, which is part of a 9-state mumps epidemic, is now reporting\n110 cases of the disease in 22 counties, health officials said\nMonday, 32 of which are confirmed.\n'Currently, most of our mumps cases are in southeastern Nebraska,'\nsaid Dr. Anne O'Keefe, epidemiologist for the state Health and Human\nServices System.\nShe said most of the cases are among people ages 10 to 18 and 35 to\n45. 'However, we're seeing cases in children as young as 2 and adults\nup to age 64,' she said.\nThe mumps epidemic is the nation's first in 20 years.\nSome 600 suspected cases have been reported in Iowa, according to the\nnational Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. There are also\ncases reported in Kansas, Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Missouri,\nWisconsin and Minnesota.\nMumps is a viral infection of the salivary glands. Symptoms include\nfever, headache, muscle aches and swelling of the glands close to the\njaw. It can cause serious complications, including meningitis, damage\nto the testicles and deafness. Mumps is spread by coughing and sneezing.\nNo deaths have been reported from the current epidemic.\nA 2-dose mumps vaccine is recommended for all children and is\nconsidered highly -- but not completely -- effective against the illness.\nAccording to HHS, Nebraskans ages 30 to 65 years old are the most at\nrisk to catch the disease because they probably never were vaccinated\nor had the disease.\nNebraska law for years has required 2 doses of the mumps vaccine\nbefore a child can enter school or college. Thus Nebraskans under the\nage of 30 who followed the K-12 and college entry requirements\nprobably have been vaccinated. Nebraskans over the age of 65 are\nlikely to have natural immunity to the virus. Many in this age group\nhad mumps as a child.\nTwo infected airline passengers may have helped spread Iowa's mumps epidemic.\nIowa health officials last week identified 2 people who were\npotentially infectious when they were traveling in late March and\nearly April [2006].\nThe CDC said the present outbreak is the nation's biggest epidemic of\nmumps since 269 cases were reported in Douglas County, Kansas, from\nOctober 1988 to April 1989.\nA mumps vaccine was introduced in 1967.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3] Kansas\nDate: 20 Apr 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: KCTV5 [edited]\n<http://www.kctv5.com/Global/story.asp?S=4797962>\n\nState health officials say Kansas now has 170 confirmed or probable\ncases of mumps in 29 counties.\nLocal health departments are also investigating an additional 23\npatients with potential symptoms of mumps.\nDouglas County remains the epicenter of the outbreak, with 87 cases.\nThe rest are scattered in 28 other counties, with only the southeast\ncorner of the state apparently spared so far.\nTwo counties -- Crawford and Trego -- were dropped from the state's\nlist today after people who had mumps-like symptoms were determined\nnot to have the viral infection.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4] Illinois\nDate: 20 Apr 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Belleville News Democrat [edited]\n<http://www.belleville.com/mld/belleville/news/state/14390279.htm >\n\nThe number of mumps cases both confirmed and suspected in Illinois\nsurged past 100 on Thursday, further dwarfing the infection\noccurrence that averaged just 13 in the state over the previous 5\nyears, Illinois' Department of Public Health said.\nAs of Thursday morning [20 Apr 2005], Illinois' 110 mumps cases were\nevenly split between confirmed cases and possible ones, department\nspokeswoman Melaney Arnold said. That's up from 81 total cases -- 42\nconfirmed, 39 probable -- just a day earlier.\nCarol Finley, the assistant programs chief with the department's\nimmunization unit, said the one-day spike may reflect statistical\ncatch-up in fielding reported cases from local health agencies over a\n3-day holiday weekend last week.\nWhile it appears 'like we got a boatload' of new cases in a short\nspan this week, Finley said, 'we're picking up about 11 cases a day.\nOur numbers are changing daily,' she said.\nAs of Thursday, mumps had been reported in 31 of Illinois' 102\ncounties, as well as the city of Chicago. Finley said at least 6 of\nthe Illinois cases were considered linked to an outbreak in Iowa,\nwhere more than 800 mumps cases had been reported as of Wednesday.\nFederal health officials said this week that the outbreak -- more\nthan 1000 cases -- is the nation's largest in almost 2 decades and is\nexpected to keep growing.\nMumps is a virus spread by coughing and sneezing. The most common\nsymptoms are fever, headache and swollen salivary glands under the\njaw. But it can lead to more severe problems, such as hearing loss,\nmeningitis and fertility-diminishing swollen testicles. Illinois has\nhad a couple of cases involving swollen testicles but apparently no\nother instances of the other complications, Finley said.\nIn recent weeks, health officials throughout Illinois and elsewhere\nhave stressed that the virus should pose no cause for alarm. But they\nsay people should consider precautions, including inoculations\nagainst the virus if they haven't already done so, good hygiene and\navoid contact with people showing symptoms of the illness.\nFinley credited the increased public awareness with encouraging more\npeople to have possible symptoms get checked by a doctor, then\nswiftly isolating themselves until those symptoms pass to avoid\nspreading the virus.\n'Based on help from the media, they're more educated and responsive\nto see what they should do for themselves and other people,' she said.\nAs of Thursday, 20 of Illinois' cases have been reported as of\nThursday in Jo Daviess County, wedged in extreme northwest Illinois\nalong the Iowa and Wisconsin borders, Illinois' health department\nsaid. Another 14 were in far north-central Illinois' Winnebago\nCounty, which hugs the Wisconsin line. Chicago and Rock Island\nCounty, which also neighbors Iowa, each had 9 cases.\nIllinois Department of Public Health:\n<http://www.idph.state.il.us/mumps/index.htm>\n[Byline: Jim Suhr]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n*******\n[5] Wisconsin\nDate: 20 Apr 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Channel 3000 [edited]\n<http://www.channel3000.com/news/8861231/detail.html>\n\nMumps cases are spilling out of Iowa and popping up in several other\nMidwestern states.\nThere are now more than 800 confirmed cases in Iowa and 14 in\nWisconsin, most along the Iowa border.\nRacine and Waukesha counties both have one confirmed case, while\nMilwaukee County reported 2 cases. Grant County has confirmed 8 cases.\nThere are also 2 confirmed cases in Dane County.\nAlthough there are no reported cases among Madison school students or\nstaff, Madison public schools are sending an information letter home\nto parents.\nThe letter answers all the questions parents may be asking, such as\nsusceptibility, symptoms and how to protect your family from the illness.\nSchool health officials say it's a pre-emptive move to try to help\ninform parents of the symptoms.\nMumps is a viral infection that can cause swelling of the salivary\nglands in the neck.
