It spreads through the air by coughing, sneezing\nor simply talking.\nChildren in school nowadays are required to have 2 doses of MMR --\nthe measles mumps rubella vaccine -- and there's no recommendation to\nget another dose if they've already had the required shots.\nHowever, experts say adults born after 1957 who have not had the\nmumps vaccine may want to consider getting one.\nMumps is so rare most people don't even recognize it. The virus\nswells the salivary glands, creating a chipmunk look in the cheek and jaw area.\nMumps is most often relatively mild. Deafness and death, the most\nextreme results, are extremely rare.\nThere are no deaths and few complications being reported from this\nvirus, WISC-TV reported.\nCases have also been reported in Minnesota, Missouri, Kansas,\nNebraska and Illinois.\nWisconsin reported only 5 mumps cases in the state last year.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[From the above newswires it appears as though the mumps outbreak is\ncontinuing to spread, and now involves 9 states in the midwest of the\nUSA (Iowa, Nebraska, Kansas, Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Missouri,\nWisconsin and Minnesota). Given the extension, we have decided to\nchange the thread name to reflect the increase in geographic extent\nof this outbreak. There was a CDC Health Alert Network Advisory\n(HAN) posted on 12 Apr 2006, discussing the identification of the G\ngenotype virus in this outbreak, but mentioning that the source of\nthe outbreak was as yet unknown. (There has been an ongoing outbreak\nof mumps in the UK since 2004 involving more than 70 000 cases to\ndate. See\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/infections/topics_az/mumps/data_quarter.htm>\nfor data as of the end of 2005.) Additional information provided in\nthe HAN advisory was mention that the efficacy of one dose of mumps\nvaccine (in the trivalent measles-mumps-rubella MMR vaccine) is 80\npercent after one dose and approximately 90 percent after 2 doses of\nthe vaccine. (see\n<http://www.phppo.cdc.gov/HAN/ArchiveSys/ViewMsgV.asp?AlertNum=00243 >\nfor more detailed information on the outbreak as of 12 Apr 2006\nalong with more technical information on the disease and control\nstrategies). - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Byline: Lisa Richwine]\n--\nGeorge Robertson\n<geo456@comcast.net>\n******\n Source: Belleville News Democrat [edited]\n<http://www.belleville.com/mld/belleville/news/state/14390279.htm >\n\nThe number of mumps cases both confirmed and suspected in Illinois\nsurged past 100 on Thursday, further dwarfing the infection\noccurrence that averaged just 13 in the state over the previous 5\nyears, Illinois' Department of Public Health said. Additional information provided in\nthe HAN advisory was mention that the efficacy of one dose of mumps\nvaccine (in the trivalent measles-mumps-rubella MMR vaccine) is 80\npercent after one dose and approximately 90 percent after 2 doses of\nthe vaccine. (see\n<http://www.phppo.cdc.gov/HAN/ArchiveSys/ViewMsgV.asp?AlertNum=00243 >\nfor more detailed information on the outbreak as of 12 Apr 2006\nalong with more technical information on the disease and control\nstrategies). Source: WRFV [edited]\n<http://wfrv.com/health/health_story_108004733.html>\n\nNebraska, which is part of a 9-state mumps epidemic, is now reporting\n110 cases of the disease in 22 counties, health officials said\nMonday, 32 of which are confirmed. Carol Finley, the assistant programs chief with the department's\nimmunization unit, said the one-day spike may reflect statistical\ncatch-up in fielding reported cases from local health agencies over a\n3-day holiday weekend last week. Children in school nowadays are required to have 2 doses of MMR --\nthe measles mumps rubella vaccine -- and there's no recommendation to\nget another dose if they've already had the required shots.\n As of Thursday, 20 of Illinois' cases have been reported as of\nThursday in Jo Daviess County, wedged in extreme northwest Illinois\nalong the Iowa and Wisconsin borders, Illinois' health department\nsaid. [From the above newswires it appears as though the mumps outbreak is\ncontinuing to spread, and now involves 9 states in the midwest of the\nUSA (Iowa, Nebraska, Kansas, Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Missouri,\nWisconsin and Minnesota). \nMany college-age students may have received just one of the 2\nrecommended doses when they were young, and therefore may not have\nthe same level of immunity as others, she said. But they\nsay people should consider precautions, including inoculations\nagainst the virus if they haven't already done so, good hygiene and\navoid contact with people showing symptoms of the illness. Finley credited the increased public awareness with encouraging more\npeople to have possible symptoms get checked by a doctor, then\nswiftly isolating themselves until those symptoms pass to avoid\nspreading the virus. There was a CDC Health Alert Network Advisory\n(HAN) posted on 12 Apr 2006, discussing the identification of the G\ngenotype virus in this outbreak, but mentioning that the source of\n It causes\nunpleasant illness including fever, headache and swelling of the\nglands around the jaw.\n According to HHS, Nebraskans ages 30 to 65 years old are the most at\nrisk to catch the disease because they probably never were vaccinated\nor had the disease.\n [Byline: Jim Suhr]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Finley said at least 6 of\nthe Illinois cases were considered linked to an outbreak in Iowa,\nwhere more than 800 mumps cases had been reported as of Wednesday. As of Thursday morning [20 Apr 2005], Illinois' 110 mumps cases were\nevenly split between confirmed cases and possible ones, department\nspokeswoman Melaney Arnold said. Federal health officials said this week that the outbreak -- more\nthan 1000 cases -- is the nation's largest in almost 2 decades and is\nexpected to keep growing. The number of mumps cases has risen to 1100 in 8 Midwestern states\nand prompted the federal government to distribute vaccines from its\nstockpile to stop the outbreak's spread, health officials said on Wednesday. The CDC said the present outbreak is the nation's biggest epidemic of\nmumps since 269 cases were reported in Douglas County, Kansas, from\nOctober 1988 to April 1989. Source: KCTV5 [edited]\n<http://www.kctv5.com/Global/story.asp?S=4797962>\n\nState health officials say Kansas now has 170 confirmed or probable\ncases of mumps in 29 counties. An additional 350 mumps cases have been reported in Minnesota,\nKansas, Illinois, Nebraska, Wisconsin, Missouri and Oklahoma,\nofficials said. Currently, most of our mumps cases are in southeastern Nebraska,'\nsaid Dr. Anne O'Keefe, epidemiologist for the state Health and Human\nServices System. Two counties -- Crawford and Trego -- were dropped from the state's\nlist today after people who had mumps-like symptoms were determined\nnot to have the viral infection. A 2-dose mumps vaccine is recommended for all children and is\nconsidered highly -- but not completely -- effective against the illness.\n The outbreak is the largest mumps epidemic in the United States in\nmore than 20 years, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention said. (There has been an ongoing outbreak\nof mumps in the UK since 2004 involving more than 70 000 cases to\ndate. Source: Channel 3000 [edited]\n<http://www.channel3000.com/news/8861231/detail.html>\n\nMumps cases are spilling out of Iowa and popping up in several other\nMidwestern states. Illinois has\nhad a couple of cases involving swollen testicles but apparently no\nother instances of the other complications, Finley said. Although there are no reported cases among Madison school students or\nstaff, Madison public schools are sending an information letter home\nto parents. But\nthe vaccine is effective in only about 90 percent of people, which\ncould partly explain the recent outbreak, CDC Director Julie Gerberding said. Iowa health officials last week identified 2 people who were\npotentially infectious when they were traveling in late March and\nearly April [2006]. Federal officials urged students, people who work in school or\nuniversity settings and health-care workers who did not get both\ndoses to get a 2nd dose. There are also\ncases reported in Kansas, Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Missouri,\nWisconsin and Minnesota. The most common\nsymptoms are fever, headache and swollen salivary glands under the\njaw. Symptoms include\nfever, headache, muscle aches and swelling of the glands close to the\njaw. In this posting:\n[1] Multistate\n While it appears 'like we got a boatload' of new cases in a short\nspan this week, Finley said, 'we're picking up about 11 cases a day. Once a common childhood illness, mumps was virtually eradicated with\nwidespread use of the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine. In the United States, an average of 265 mumps cases have been\nreported each year since 2001. That's up from 81 total cases -- 42\nconfirmed, 39 probable -- just a day earlier.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "1100-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "1989-04-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dane County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Douglas County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rock Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jo Daviess County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Milwaukee County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chicago", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grant County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209489", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (NE, IA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209489", "date": "2006-04-03 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (NEBRASKA, IOWA)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Thu 30 Mar 2006\nFrom: Joe Davis <LJDavis@mlmh.org>\n\nThis is a preliminary report from Hastings, Nebraska USA.\nInfection control reports 2 hospitalized adult males with mumps orchitis.\nThe local health department reports 14 clinical cases and 2 lab confirmed\ncases. One hospitalized case has reported normal IgM. Two adult males had\nbeen to an Iowa wrestling tournament during the incubation period. One is a\nteacher, the other a physician. Travel by one teenager to Colorado during\nher infectious pre-clinical presentation is reported. It appears most cases\nhave had immunization with mumps-containing vaccines. One case had a\nhistory of natural mumps.\n--\nJoe Davis MD, MPA\nUtilization Review Physician\nMary Lanning Memorial Hospital\nHastings, NE USA\n<LJDavis@mlmh.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 31 Mar 2006\nFrom: Patricia Doyle <dr_p_doyle@hotmail.com>\nSource: Yahoo, 31 Mar 2006 [edited]\n<http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20060331/ap_on_he_me/mumps_outbreak;_ylt=AoTGGdDqcRjX_Qrses1w9cOs0NUE;_ylu=X3oDMTA3czJjNGZoBHNlYwM3NTE->\n\nNumber of Mumps Cases Swells Across Iowa\n-----------------------------------------------\nA mumps epidemic is sweeping across Iowa in the biggest outbreak in the\ncountry, puzzling health officials and worrying parents.\nAs of Thursday [1 Apr 2006], 245 confirmed, probable or suspected cases of\nmumps had been reported to the Iowa Department of Public Health since\nmid-January 2006. The federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\nsaid it is the only major outbreak in the nation.\n'We are calling this an epidemic, not just an outbreak,' said Iowa state\nepidemiologist Dr. Patricia Quinlisk, explaining that mumps has spread to\nmore than a 3rd of the state and does not appear to be confined to certain\nage groups or other sectors of the population. Quinlisk said Iowa has had\nabout 5 cases of mumps a year in recent years, and this is the 1st large\noutbreak in nearly 20 years. 'We're trying to figure out why is it\nhappening, why is it happening in Iowa and why is it happening right now.\nWe don't know,' she said.\nCDC spokeswoman Lola Russell said the federal agency has no answers yet.\nQuinlisk said one theory is that the infection was brought over from\nEngland -- perhaps by a college student -- because the strain seen in Iowa\nhas been identified by the CDC as the same one that has caused tens of\nthousands of cases of the mumps in a major outbreak in Britain over the\npast 2 years. 'It may have been a college student, since we did see the 1st\nactivities on college campuses, but we can't prove that,' Quinlisk said.\nThe Public Health Department said 23 percent of the 245 reported patients\nare in college.\nMumps is a viral infection of the salivary glands. Symptoms include fever,\nheadache, muscle aches and swelling of the glands close to the jaw. It can\ncause serious complications, including meningitis, damage to the testicles\nand deafness.\nA mumps vaccine was introduced in 1967. Iowa law requires schoolchildren to\nbe vaccinated, and the state's last major outbreak was in 1987, when 476\npeople were infected.\nOf the 245 patients this year [2006], at least 66 percent had had the\nrecommended 2-shot vaccination, while 14 percent had received one dose, the\nPublic Health Department said.\n'The vaccine is working,' Quinlisk said. 'The vaccine certainly was made to\ncover this particular strain, because it's a fairly common strain of\nmumps.' Quinlisk said the vaccine overall is considered about 95 percent\neffective.\nQuinlisk said the mumps started in eastern Iowa and is spreading statewide\nand possibly into the neighboring states of Illinois, Minnesota and\nNebraska. Those states may have one or 2 cases of the mumps, she said.\nWhen an [11-year-old boy] of Davenport starting feeling sick in mid-January\n2006, his family thought he had a bad case of the flu. But his face and\nthroat swelled, and his temperature climbed to 103. His parents took him to\nthe doctor, and he was diagnosed to their surprise with full-blown mumps.\nAbout 2 weeks later, his 21-year-old sister came down with the mumps too.\nBoth children had gotten the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine, or MMR. So\nhad their other 13-year-old brother who did not get the mumps.\n'He had all the shots and everything. You don't think you're going to get\nthe mumps after you've been inoculated,' said boy's father.\n[Byline: Melanie S. Welte]\n--\nPatricia A. All regions have reported cases in 2004, and all\nexcept 2 have already had more cases this year than in the whole of 2003. Of\nall cases this year, 78 percent (2886 cases) were reported in young people\naged 15-24.\nImmunisation against mumps was introduced in England and Wales in October\n1988 as a component of the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine and\noffered routinely to all children aged 12 to 15 months. A 2nd dose of MMR\nvaccine at pre-school age was introduced in October 1996. Before the\nintroduction of MMR in 1988, mumps was not notifiable and surveillance was\nbased on laboratory reports. Since 1989, mumps has been notifiable and since\nlate 1994, the facility to test saliva for [mumps] IgM has been available to\nfamily doctors.\nFollowing the introduction of MMR, the incidence of mumps decreased rapidly\nuntil 1997. Since then the number of confirmed cases has increased. In 2003,\nthere was a rise in notifications which has continued throughout 2004, with\nfurther increases in the numbers of confirmed cases (illustrated as a figure\nat URL above). A 2nd figure (also at URL above) shows the number of\nconfirmed mumps cases by year of birth in 2004 compared to previous years.\nThere is a slight shift in incidence in 2004 to the older cohorts.\nThis increase in mumps cases in England and Wales since 1997 was predicted\nby seroprevalence studies in 1993. The results suggested that certain\ncohorts had remained susceptible -- probably due to reduced exposure to\nnatural infection following high uptake of MMR vaccine [1][which would have\nreinforced their vaccine-produced immunity. - Mod.JW]. The cohort identified\nto be at particularly high risk of mumps were those who are too old to have\nreceived 2 doses of MMR in the routine schedule (born before 1992) but young\nenough to have grown up during a period of low incidence, and so have\nescaped mumps infection in childhood. Confirmed mumps cases have been mainly\nin older teenagers and young adults (born between 1982 and 1990), and\noutbreaks have moved from being mainly in secondary schools to universities\nand further education colleges. Many of this group received measles-rubella\n(MR) vaccine in 1994, as at that time there was a shortage of MMR. Some may\nnot recall that the 1994 vaccine campaign was not the MMR vaccine, and so\nthey are not protected against mumps.\nThe Health Protection Agency and the Department of Health recommend that all\nschool-leavers and university entrants who have not received MMR vaccine or\nwho have only received one dose should have the opportunity to get MMR.\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpa/news/articles/press_releases/2004/041102_mumps.htm\n>\nMany universities across England and Wales have experienced outbreaks of\nmumps this year and have organised institution-based vaccination campaigns.\nReference\n---------\nGay N, Miller E, Hesketh L, Morgan-Capner P, Ramsay M, Cohen B, Brown D.\nMumps surveillance in England and Wales supports introduction of two dose\nvaccination schedule. Commun Dis Rep CDR Wkly 1997; 7(2):21-26.\n[Byline: Emma Savage <emma.savage@hpa.org.uk>, Mary Ramsay & Natasha\nCrowcroft. [see all:\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland Mumps, students - UK & Ireland (03) 20041117.3089\nMumps - UK (Scotland) 20040220.0545\n Before the\nintroduction of MMR in 1988, mumps was not notifiable and surveillance was\nbased on laboratory reports. 20041110.3039\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (02) 20041112.3055\n MUMPS, STUDENTS - UK (02)\n*************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1988-10-25 00:00:00", "1989-03-25 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1996-10-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "1993-03-25 00:00:00", "2886-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "1992-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209423", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps virus, genotype G - USA (IA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209423", "date": "2006-03-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS VIRUS, GENOTYPE G - USA (IOWA)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 15 Mar 2006\nFrom: Alfonso Rodriguez <ajrm_msds@yahoo.es>\nSource: ABC News, Wed 15 Mar 2006 [edited]\n<http://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory?id=1725948&CMP=OTC-RSSFeeds0312>\n\nUSA: Iowa Officials Concerned About Mumps Cases\n-----------------------------------------------\nState health officials have stated that they are concerned about a\nrare strain of mumps virus behind an outbreak of 60 mumps cases in\nIowa. Mary Gilchrist, director of the State University's Hygienic\nLaboratory, said the genotype G strain is infrequently seen in the\nUnited States. With the number jumping from 17 cases just 2 weeks\nago, she predicted there could be more outbreaks this spring [2006].\n'If the past predicts the future, it will get worse in April,' she\nsaid.\nSo far, there are 18 cases recorded in Johnson County, 16 in Dubuque,\n5 in Black Hawk County and 4 in Scott County. 2 cases were confirmed\nin Linn County, while other counties have one to 3 cases, according\nto the lab's website.\nThe patients with confirmed cases of mumps range in age from 11 to\n41, but Gilchrist said half have been college students. She said the\nvirus may have come from Europe, but a similar strain has been\ndetected in New Jersey. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention is investigating the source.\nSymptoms of mumps include fever, headache and swollen salivary glands\nat the jaw line, below and in front of the ears. Mumps is generally a\nmild illness for healthy people and is spread through coughing or\nsneezing. It can cause serious complications, including deafness in\nchildren and spontaneous abortion in pregnant women.\nA mumps vaccine was introduced in 1967. People born before 1957 are\nbelieved to have been exposed to mumps during childhood and therefore\nshould be immune, according to the CDC. The last mumps outbreak in\nIowa was in 1987, when 467 cases were recorded. Since then, less than\n60 cases have been reported annually, with only one to 3 cases\nreported in the past 5 years.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Mumps infection occurs worldwide, and humans are the only natural\nhost for the virus. Various vaccine strains have been developed and\nhave been effective in reducing the incidence of mumps worldwide. The\nvirus is essentially monotypic, although there may some mismatch\nbetween individual strains and vaccines. Despite the monotypic nature\nof mumps virus, different genetic lineages of mumps virus exist and\nco-circulate globally. Genotypes A to J have been defined on the\nbasis of the nucleotide sequence of the most variable gene, the SH\ngene. The different lineages are useful properties for tracking the\nspread of mumps virus, but there is no clear association of the\ndifferent lineages with different clinical symptoms. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Despite the monotypic nature\nof mumps virus, different genetic lineages of mumps virus exist and\nco-circulate globally. State health officials have stated that they are concerned about a\nrare strain of mumps virus behind an outbreak of 60 mumps cases in\nIowa. The different lineages are useful properties for tracking the\nspread of mumps virus, but there is no clear association of the\ndifferent lineages with different clinical symptoms. Source: ABC News, Wed 15 Mar 2006 [edited]\n<http://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory?id=1725948&CMP=OTC-RSSFeeds0312>\n\nUSA: Iowa Officials Concerned About Mumps Cases\n----------------------------------------------- Since then, less than\n60 cases have been reported annually, with only one to 3 cases\nreported in the past 5 years. 2 cases were confirmed\nin Linn County, while other counties have one to 3 cases, according\nto the lab's website. People born before 1957 are\nbelieved to have been exposed to mumps during childhood and therefore\nshould be immune, according to the CDC. Mumps is generally a\nmild illness for healthy people and is spread through coughing or\nsneezing. She said the\nvirus may have come from Europe, but a similar strain has been\ndetected in New Jersey. The\nvirus is essentially monotypic, although there may some mismatch\nbetween individual strains and vaccines. Mary Gilchrist, director of the State University's Hygienic\nLaboratory, said the genotype G strain is infrequently seen in the\nUnited States.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-04-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Black Hawk County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scott County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johnson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Linn County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209547", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (NE, IA) (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209547", "date": "2006-04-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (NEBRASKA, IOWA) (05)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 14 Apr 2006\nFrom: George Robertson <GRobertson@neotropix.com>\nSource: washingtonpost.com, Thu 13 Apr 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/04/12/AR2006041201458.html>\n\nHealth officials are battling a mumps epidemic in the Midwest that\nhas infected at least 515 individuals in Iowa, mostly young adults,\nand spread from Iowa to a number of other states. At least 100 cases\nof mumps have also been recorded in nearby Nebraska, Kansas,\nMinnesota, Wisconsin, Indiana, Michigan, Missouri, and Illinois.\nInvestigators are following leads to the United Kingdom, which\nbecause of relatively low vaccine uptake rates due to fears over\nlinks to autism has been battling mumps outbreaks for years; the\nmumps strain seen in Iowa is the same as the one in the United\nKingdom.\nThe number of cases experienced in the epidemic this year, the\nlargest since a 1988 outbreak in Kansas, far outpaces the 200 to 300\ntypically experienced in the United States annually. Health officials\nare responding with vaccine campaigns and investigating the\npossibility that the protection afforded by the vaccine being used\nwanes over time, or is simply not as strong as thought. Nearly 70\npercent of the infected individuals had received the 2 recommended\ndoses of the mumps vaccine as part of routine childhood immunization\nschedules. The vaccine is believed to be 95 percent effective.\n--\nGeorge Robertson\nVice President\nNeotropix\n351 Phoenixville Pike\nMalvern, PA 19355\n<GRobertson@neotropix.com>\n[Mumps infection occurs worldwide, and humans are the only natural\nhost for the virus. The virus is essentially monotypic, although\nthere may some mismatch between individual strains and vaccines.\nDespite the monotypic nature of mumps virus, different genetic\nlineages of mumps virus exist and co-circulate globally. Genotypes A\nto J have been defined on the basis of the nucleotide sequence of the\nmost variable gene, the SH gene. Previously state health officials\nhave stated that they are concerned that a rare genotype of mumps\nvirus may be responsible for this unusually large outbreak of mumps\nin midwestern states. The strain of mumps virus implicated in this\noutbreak is a genotype G strain, a genotype that has been seen\ninfrequently in the United States. It has been suggested that the\nvirus may have been imported from the United Kingdom or Ireland where\nthere have been extensive outbreaks of mumps in recent years.\nHowever, a similar strain has been isolated also in New Jersey,\nand the Centers for Disease Control have yet to make a pronouncement\non the suspected origin of the epidemic strain. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Investigators are following leads to the United Kingdom, which\nbecause of relatively low vaccine uptake rates due to fears over\nlinks to autism has been battling mumps outbreaks for years; the\nmumps strain seen in Iowa is the same as the one in the United\nKingdom. Previously state health officials\nhave stated that they are concerned that a rare genotype of mumps\nvirus may be responsible for this unusually large outbreak of mumps\nin midwestern states. Source: washingtonpost.com, Thu 13 Apr 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/04/12/AR2006041201458.html>\n\nHealth officials are battling a mumps epidemic in the Midwest that\nhas infected at least 515 individuals in Iowa, mostly young adults,\nand spread from Iowa to a number of other states. Nearly 70\npercent of the infected individuals had received the 2 recommended\ndoses of the mumps vaccine as part of routine childhood immunization\nschedules. It has been suggested that the\nvirus may have been imported from the United Kingdom or Ireland where\nthere have been extensive outbreaks of mumps in recent years.\n Health officials\nare responding with vaccine campaigns and investigating the\npossibility that the protection afforded by the vaccine being used\nwanes over time, or is simply not as strong as thought. \nGeorge Robertson\nVice President\n The strain of mumps virus implicated in this\noutbreak is a genotype G strain, a genotype that has been seen\ninfrequently in the United States.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1988-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209506", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (NE, IA) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209506", "date": "2006-04-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (NEBRASKA, IOWA) (03)\n*************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 6 May 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR Weekly, Fri 7 Apr 2006 / 55(13);366-368 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5513a3.htm?s_cid=mm5513a3_e>\n\n[On March 30, this report was posted as an MMWR Dispatch on the MMWR\nwebsite (<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr>).]\nIn the United States, since 2001, an average of 265 mumps cases (range:\n231--293 cases) have been reported each year, and in Iowa, an average of 5\ncases have been reported annually since 1996. However, in 2006, by March\n28, a total of 219 mumps cases had been reported in Iowa (illustrated by a\nfigure in the original text), and an additional 14 persons with clinically\ncompatible symptoms were being investigated in 3 neighboring states (11 in\nIllinois, 2 in Nebraska, and one in Minnesota) in what has become the\nlargest epidemic of mumps in the United States since 1988 (1). This report\nsummarizes and characterizes the ongoing mumps epidemic in Iowa, the public\nhealth response, and recommendations for preventing further transmission.\nMumps is an acute viral infection characterized by fever and nonsuppurative\nswelling of the salivary glands; an estimated 20-30 percent of cases are\nasymptomatic. Complications can include inflammation of the testicles or\novaries, meningitis/encephalitis, spontaneous abortion, and deafness.\nDuring the prevaccine era, nearly everyone in the United States experienced\nmumps, and 90 percent of cases occurred among children aged less than 15\nyears. In 1977, Iowa law mandated one dose of measles, mumps, and rubella\n(MMR) vaccine for entry to public schools; in 1991, the mandate became 2\ndoses. For the 2004-05 school year, 97 percent of children entering school\nin Iowa had received 2 doses of MMR vaccine (2).\nThe first reports to the Iowa Department of Public Health (IDPH) of\nmumps-like illness occurred in December 2005 at a university in eastern\nIowa, where several students with glandular swelling were tested, 2 of whom\ntested positive for mumps-specific IgM antibodies. In mid-January 2006, an\nisolate from an unrelated patient was cultured and identified as mumps\nvirus at the University Hygienic Laboratory (Iowa's state public health\nlaboratory). Viral isolates were sent to CDC, and the mumps strain was\nidentified as genotype G. By mid-February, active surveillance had been\ninitiated in 7 geographic areas, including the campuses of the 3 largest\nuniversities in Iowa.\nOf the 219 cases reported in Iowa, the median patient age was 21 years\n(range: 3-85 years), with 48 percent of patients aged 17-25 years\n(illustrated by a figure in the original report); 30 percent (34 of 114)\nwere known to be college students. Of the 133 patients with investigated\nvaccine history, 87 (65 percent) had documentation of receiving 2 doses, 19\n(14 percent) one dose, and 8 (6 percent) no doses; vaccine status could not\nbe documented in 19 (14 percent) patients. Among the 114 patients for whom\nsymptomatic information was available, the most common symptoms were\nparotitis in 94 (83 percent) patients, submaxillary/sublingual gland\nswelling in 46 (40 percent), fever in 41 (36 percent), and sore throat in\n36 (32 percent); average duration of illness was 5.1 days. Six (5 percent)\npatients reported complications (e.g., orchitis); one suspected case of\nencephalitis is being investigated. As of 28 Mar 2006, investigators had\ndetermined that only 36 (16 percent) of the 219 cases were linked\nepidemiologically (i.e., a source of infection was identified), suggesting\nfrequent unapparent transmission.\nThe source of the Iowa epidemic is unknown; however, the United Kingdom\n(UK) experienced a recent mumps epidemic that peaked during 2005 with\napproximately 56 000 cases and a high attack rate among young adults (3).\nThe mumps strain in the UK epidemic also was identified as genotype G (4),\nand the UK epidemic has been linked to a 2005 mumps outbreak in the United\nStates (5).\nTo educate health-care professionals in Iowa regarding the epidemic and\nmumps, information has been distributed via Iowa's Health Alert Network\n(HAN), in weekly electronic newsletters, and via frequent conference calls.\nThe IDPH website has provided biweekly updates, county case counts, fact\nsheets, and guidance to local health departments and health-care facilities\non case investigations. IDPH recommendations include 1) requesting at least\n5 days of isolation for all patients (quarantine is not being used), 2)\nensuring that students and staff members on all Iowa college campuses have\nhad 2 doses of MMR or are immune from mumps (6), 3) assessing vaccination\nstatus of all health-care professionals in Iowa and offering vaccination\nwhere appropriate (7), and 4) sending all specimens collected from possible\ncases to University Hygienic Laboratory for testing.\nDespite control efforts and a highly vaccinated population, this epidemic\nhas spread across Iowa and potentially to neighboring states. Ongoing\ninvestigations will focus on identifying actual vaccine coverage on college\ncampuses, potential modes of mumps transmission, and the effectiveness of 1\nor 2 doses of MMR.\n(Reported by: Local Iowa public health departments; University Hygienic\nLaboratory, Iowa City; P Quinlisk, MD, M Harris, MPH, T Thornton, Iowa Dept\nof Public Health. L Flamigni, MD, EIS Officer, CDC.)\nReferences\n----\n(1) CDC. Mumps surveillance---United States, 1988--1993. In: Surveillance\nSummaries, August 11, 1995. MMWR 1995;44(No. SS-3).\n(2) Iowa Department of Public Health, Bureau of Disease Prevention and\nImmunization. Immunization audit 2004--2005 school year, K-12 summary\nreport by county. Des Moines, IA: Iowa Department of Public Health.\n(3) CDC. Mumps epidemic---United Kingdom, 2004--2005. MMWR 2006;55:173--5.\n(4) Jin L, Brown DW, Litton PA, White JM. Genetic diversity of mumps virus\nin oral fluid specimens: application to mumps epidemiological study. J\nInfect Dis 2004;189:1001--8.\n(5) CDC. Mumps outbreak at a summer camp---New York, 2005. MMWR 2006;55;175--7.\n(6) CDC. Measles, mumps, and rubella---vaccine use and strategies for\nelimination of measles, rubella, and congenital rubella syndrome and\ncontrol of mumps: recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization\nPractices (ACIP). MMWR 1998;47(No. RR-8).\n(7) CDC. Immunization of health-care workers: recommendations of the\nAdvisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) and the Hospital\nInfection Control Practices Advisory Committee (HICPAC), 1997. MMWR\n1997;46(No. RR-18).\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmai.org>", "summary": "IDPH recommendations include 1) requesting at least\n5 days of isolation for all patients (quarantine is not being used), 2)\nensuring that students and staff members on all Iowa college campuses have\nhad 2 doses of MMR or are immune from mumps (6), 3) assessing vaccination\nstatus of all health-care professionals in Iowa and offering vaccination\nwhere appropriate (7), and 4) sending all specimens collected from possible\ncases to University Hygienic Laboratory for testing. However, in 2006, by March\n28, a total of 219 mumps cases had been reported in Iowa (illustrated by a\nfigure in the original text), and an additional 14 persons with clinically\ncompatible symptoms were being investigated in 3 neighboring states (11 in\nIllinois, 2 in Nebraska, and one in Minnesota) in what has become the\nlargest epidemic of mumps in the United States since 1988 (1). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Among the 114 patients for whom\nsymptomatic information was available, the most common symptoms were\nparotitis in 94 (83 percent) patients, submaxillary/sublingual gland\nswelling in 46 (40 percent), fever in 41 (36 percent), and sore throat in\n36 (32 percent); average duration of illness was 5.1 days. Ongoing\ninvestigations will focus on identifying actual vaccine coverage on college\ncampuses, potential modes of mumps transmission, and the effectiveness of 1\nor 2 doses of MMR.\n Measles, mumps, and rubella---vaccine use and strategies for\nelimination of measles, rubella, and congenital rubella syndrome and\ncontrol of mumps: recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization\nPractices (ACIP). As of 28 Mar 2006, investigators had\ndetermined that only 36 (16 percent) of the 219 cases were linked\nepidemiologically (i.e., a source of infection was identified), suggesting\nfrequent unapparent transmission. Viral isolates were sent to CDC, and the mumps strain was\nidentified as genotype G. By mid-February, active surveillance had been\ninitiated in 7 geographic areas, including the campuses of the 3 largest\nuniversities in Iowa. In mid-January 2006, an\nisolate from an unrelated patient was cultured and identified as mumps\nvirus at the University Hygienic Laboratory (Iowa's state public health\nlaboratory). In the United States, since 2001, an average of 265 mumps cases (range:\n231--293 cases) have been reported each year, and in Iowa, an average of 5\ncases have been reported annually since 1996. The mumps strain in the UK epidemic also was identified as genotype G (4),\nand the UK epidemic has been linked to a 2005 mumps outbreak in the United\nStates (5). The source of the Iowa epidemic is unknown; however, the United Kingdom\n(UK) experienced a recent mumps epidemic that peaked during 2005 with\napproximately 56 000 cases and a high attack rate among young adults (3). Mumps is an acute viral infection characterized by fever and nonsuppurative\nswelling of the salivary glands; an estimated 20-30 percent of cases are\nasymptomatic. During the prevaccine era, nearly everyone in the United States experienced\nmumps, and 90 percent of cases occurred among children aged less than 15\nyears. To educate health-care professionals in Iowa regarding the epidemic and\nmumps, information has been distributed via Iowa's Health Alert Network\n(HAN), in weekly electronic newsletters, and via frequent conference calls. In 1977, Iowa law mandated one dose of measles, mumps, and rubella\n(MMR) vaccine for entry to public schools; in 1991, the mandate became 2\ndoses. This report\nsummarizes and characterizes the ongoing mumps epidemic in Iowa, the public\nhealth response, and recommendations for preventing further transmission. Of the 133 patients with investigated\nvaccine history, 87 (65 percent) had documentation of receiving 2 doses, 19\n The first reports to the Iowa Department of Public Health (IDPH) of\nmumps-like illness occurred in December 2005 at a university in eastern\n The IDPH website has provided biweekly updates, county case counts, fact\nsheets, and guidance to local health departments and health-care facilities\non case investigations. (Reported by: Local Iowa public health departments; University Hygienic\nLaboratory, Iowa City; P Quinlisk, MD, M Harris, MPH, T Thornton, Iowa Dept\nof Public Health. Immunization of health-care workers: recommendations of the\nAdvisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) and the Hospital\nInfection Control Practices Advisory Committee (HICPAC), 1997. \n(2) Iowa Department of Public Health, Bureau of Disease Prevention and\nImmunization.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "1977-03-25 00:00:00", "1991-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2005-12-25 00:00:00", "1987-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "2046-03-25 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-08-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thornton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Des Moines", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206884", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, students - UK & Ireland (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206884", "date": "2004-11-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS, STUDENTS - UK & IRELAND (03)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Tue 16 Nov 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: BBC News, Tue 16 Nov 2004 [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/kent/4016867.stm>\n\nEngland: emergency vaccinations for mumps offered in Kent\n---------------------------------------------------------\nDr Mathi Chandrakumar, director of the Kent Health Protection Unit,\nannounced a mumps vaccination program, after cases rose from 39 last year\n[2003] to 113 so far in 2004. Dr Chandrakumar said the rise was not an\nepidemic, but protection was needed. Health officials are targeting up to\n30 000 at-risk teenagers at 8 tertiary education sites.\nDr Chandrakumar told BBC South East Today: 'We don't need to be worried as\nlong as this campaign is successful, and we can prevent large numbers of\ncases. We know it works, because, when we had an outbreak in the University\nof Kent, we carried out a campaign, and we stopped it in its tracks; we did\nnot have any further cases.' The mumps immunization centers include the\nfollowing: Canterbury College (Canterbury); Christchurch University College\n(Canterbury and Thanet); South Kent College (Ashford); West Kent College\n(Tonbridge); Oakwood Park Centre (Maidstone); and Mid Kent College (City\nWay site).\nDr Chandrakumar said outbreaks were occurring in people too old to have\nbeen offered measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) jabs routinely as children.\nThe MMR program only started in 1988. Dr Chandrakumar said the vaccination\nwas 'perfectly safe' and did not have any serious side effects.\nKent University completed a round of immunizations for new students at the\nstart of term in late October 2004. Other UK universities are also\nlaunching mass MMR vaccinations to stem the mumps threat.\nMumps is a viral infection that is transmitted through airborne droplets\nfrom the coughs and sneezes of infected people. It takes about 16 to 21\ndays between coming into contact with an infected person and the appearance\nof symptoms, such as painful swelling of saliva-making glands found on\neither side of the face. The vast majority of people make an easy recovery\nfrom mumps infection. However, it can rarely cause unpleasant and painful\ncomplications and can be particularly dangerous in young men who may\ndevelop swelling of the testis that can cause infertility.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 16 Nov 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Cambridge News, Tue 16 Nov 2004 [edited]\n<http://w3.cambridge-news.co.uk/news/story.asp?StoryID=64957>\n\nEngland: meningitis warning for Cambridge students\n--------------------------------------------------\nStudents in Cambridge could be at risk from a new outbreak of the\npotentially deadly illness meningitis. This is the warning issued by the\nmedical charity the Meningitis Trust. They say the recent outbreak of mumps\namong university students could lead to an increase in cases of particular\nstrains of viral meningitis, because the viruses that cause both illnesses\nare closely linked. Although the strains of meningitis concerned are very\nrarely lethal, they can lead to severe side effects and after effects such\nas headaches, fever, joint pain and stiffness in the neck, diarrhea,\nvomiting, and aversion to light.\nIn total, 38 students have been struck down with mumps so far this term,\ncompared with a recent average of only one or 2 per academic year.\nUniversity authorities are urging students under 24 years of age to take\nthe triple MMR vaccine, which prevents mumps, measles, and rubella.\nBridie Taylor, community services manager with the Meningitis Trust, said\nthat most of the current generation of students at Cambridge had not\nreceived the triple vaccine, because it was not introduced until the late\n1980s, after their infancy. But some symptoms of mumps are similar to those\nof meningitis, and Miss Taylor said: 'the incubation period for mumps is\nanything up to 3 weeks.'\n'We do not want GPs to be inundated. But, it is an especially nasty kind of\nillness, and we want people to be aware of the risks. If any of these\nsymptoms persist for more than 3 weeks, people should seek medical help.'\n******\n[3]\nDate: Tue 16 Nov 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The National Student, November 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.national-student.co.uk/2004_11/national_news_mumps.htm>\n\nUK: students are being warned of an imminent mumps epidemic\n-----------------------------------------------------------\nUniversities and colleges from the Scottish Highlands to Cornwall are\nreporting massive increases in mumps cases this year [2004]. The problem is\nbeing taken seriously in all areas. The Edinburgh Evening News reports that\n'thousands of students are being offered a vaccine against mumps, after\ncases in the Lothians soared 5-fold in a year.' The number of suspected\ncases in Grampian region alone has risen to 10 times what it was last year\n[2003]. There had been 37 confirmed cases in Grampian region, 53 in Tayside\nand 18 across the Highlands and Islands. In the same period, suspected\ncases in Grampian have risen to 88, compared to just 8 for the whole of\n2003. Almost all of the cases involve adolescents aged 13 to 25, with the\nmajority falling into the 17 to 20 age group.\nDr Arun Mukarjee, an expert in communicable diseases at NHS Grampian, said\nthat the age group accounted for about 50 per cent of the number of\nreported cases this year [2004], and the high incidence of mumps could be\nexplained by the introduction of the MMR vaccine when they were children.\n'The MMR vaccine was introduced in 1988,' he said. 'Initially, we started\nwith one dose, and the uptake was very good. As a result, mumps and measles\nwere almost eradicated in this country. We soon realized that not one but 2\ndoses of MMR were needed to give over 99 per cent protection from mumps,\nso, in 1996, we gave a 2nd dose, but those born between 1984 and 1987\nmissed out.'\nDr Mukarjee said youngsters born between those dates would have received a\n2nd measles and rubella vaccine, introduced in 1996 [this was actually a\none-off campaign late in 1994. See\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/cdr/CDRreview/1994/cdrr1294.pdf> - Mod.SH], but the\njab would not protect them against mumps. 'No one knows why cases are on\nthe increase for this age group this year [2004], as opposed to last year\nor next year,' he added. 'What we do know is that the disease spreads like\nwildfire in areas like universities.' Health authorities have written to GP\npractices around the north and north-east [of Scotland] asking them to\nconduct selective immunization for young people aged 17 to 20.\nIn England, there is a similar picture. The Bath Chronicle reports that\n'thousands of adults are to be offered vaccinations to prevent a mumps\nepidemic in Bath. A program of inoculations is being devised to target 16\nto 25 year olds, after a massive increase in cases of the infection over\nthe past year.' The Express reported that 'an outbreak of mumps has struck\n85 1st year students at one university. Mass vaccination schemes are being\nset up over fears of an epidemic sweeping the country.' Colleagues of\nstudents at Exeter University have been offered vaccinations, and 1000 1st\nyear students have so far been given the MMR jab. Stuart Franklin, a\nspokesman for the university, said that 'it is too early to say we are on\ntop of the situation, but in the last few days the number of cases has\ndropped off.' Oxford, Manchester, Leeds, Kent, Nottingham, and Birmingham\nuniversities have all recently reported outbreaks of mumps. Official\nfigures show a dramatic rise in cases from 180 in 1996 to 3756 so far this\nyear. The number of cases of mumps reported at Lancaster University has\nrisen to 30, as health bosses warn of a national outbreak among students,\nreports the Lancaster Guardian. In Plymouth, extra immunization clinics are\nbeing added at the Bailrigg campus, as the capacity to administer MMR jabs\nhas been totally outstripped by demand, says the Western Morning News. Lynn\nJones, practice director at the Bailrigg Health Centre, said 'we had 500\nimmunization packs ready for students on Tuesday [16 Nov 2004], so we were\ncompletely unprepared when nearly 1000 turned up, and we had to turn the\nrest away.' In recent weeks, Exeter University has had 76 confirmed cases\nof mumps in 3 of its halls of residence on campus, and 300 of its students\nhave already received the MMR vaccine.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Remarkably, the mumps epidemic in young people in the 17 20 year age range\nis now affecting those attending universities and tertiary education\ninstitutions throughout the UK and Ireland. It is believed that the high\nsusceptibility of this age group relates to the fact that these young\npeople have received only a single mumps vaccination, which appears not to\nbe sufficient to confer complete protection. However, it is not clear why\nthe incidence of mumps is higher in 2004 than in immediately preceding\nyears. A warning of increased risk of viral meningitis, as a consequence of\nthe mumps epidemic, has been issued by the Meningitis Trust, although the\nextent of the risk, and the viral pathogen(s) involved, have not been\nspecified. Central Nervous System (CNS) involvement during acute mumps\nvirus infection occurs at such high frequency that it has been considered\nto be a primary manifestation of mumps, rather than a complication. The\nconsequences of CNS infection caused by mumps virus infection extend from\naseptic meningitis (common and mild) to fulminant encephalitis (rare but\nlife threatening). The term mumps meningoencephalitis has been coined to\ncover the range of intermediate manifestations of mumps virus infection of\nthe CNS. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Lynn\nJones, practice director at the Bailrigg Health Centre, said 'we had 500\nimmunization packs ready for students on Tuesday [16 Nov 2004], so we were\ncompletely unprepared when nearly 1000 turned up, and we had to turn the\nrest away.' We soon realized that not one but 2\ndoses of MMR were needed to give over 99 per cent protection from mumps,\nso, in 1996, we gave a 2nd dose, but those born between 1984 and 1987\nmissed out.'\n The mumps immunization centers include the\nfollowing: Canterbury College (Canterbury); Christchurch University College\n(Canterbury and Thanet); South Kent College (Ashford); West Kent College\n(Tonbridge); Oakwood Park Centre (Maidstone); and Mid Kent College (City\nWay site). Dr Arun Mukarjee, an expert in communicable diseases at NHS Grampian, said\nthat the age group accounted for about 50 per cent of the number of\nreported cases this year [2004], and the high incidence of mumps could be\nexplained by the introduction of the MMR vaccine when they were children. They say the recent outbreak of mumps\namong university students could lead to an increase in cases of particular\nstrains of viral meningitis, because the viruses that cause both illnesses\nare closely linked. \nDr Mathi Chandrakumar, director of the Kent Health Protection Unit,\nannounced a mumps vaccination program, after cases rose from 39 last year\n A warning of increased risk of viral meningitis, as a consequence of\nthe mumps epidemic, has been issued by the Meningitis Trust, although the\nextent of the risk, and the viral pathogen(s) involved, have not been\nspecified. It is believed that the high\nsusceptibility of this age group relates to the fact that these young\npeople have received only a single mumps vaccination, which appears not to\nbe sufficient to confer complete protection. The\nconsequences of CNS infection caused by mumps virus infection extend from\naseptic meningitis (common and mild) to fulminant encephalitis (rare but\nlife threatening). Bridie Taylor, community services manager with the Meningitis Trust, said\nthat most of the current generation of students at Cambridge had not\nreceived the triple vaccine, because it was not introduced until the late\n1980s, after their infancy. Stuart Franklin, a\nspokesman for the university, said that 'it is too early to say we are on\ntop of the situation, but in the last few days the number of cases has\ndropped off.' Although the strains of meningitis concerned are very\nrarely lethal, they can lead to severe side effects and after effects such\nas headaches, fever, joint pain and stiffness in the neck, diarrhea,\nvomiting, and aversion to light. It takes about 16 to 21\ndays between coming into contact with an infected person and the appearance\nof symptoms, such as painful swelling of saliva-making glands found on\neither side of the face. However, it can rarely cause unpleasant and painful\ncomplications and can be particularly dangerous in young men who may\ndevelop swelling of the testis that can cause infertility.\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n The Edinburgh Evening News reports that\n'thousands of students are being offered a vaccine against mumps, after\ncases in the Lothians soared 5-fold in a year.' But some symptoms of mumps are similar to those\nof meningitis, and Miss Taylor said: 'the incubation period for mumps is\nanything up to 3 weeks.' In recent weeks, Exeter University has had 76 confirmed cases\nof mumps in 3 of its halls of residence on campus, and 300 of its students\nhave already received the MMR vaccine. No one knows why cases are on\nthe increase for this age group this year [2004], as opposed to last year\nor next year,' he added. ' The number of cases of mumps reported at Lancaster University has\nrisen to 30, as health bosses warn of a national outbreak among students,\nreports the Lancaster Guardian. [Remarkably, the mumps epidemic in young people in the 17 20 year age range\nis now affecting those attending universities and tertiary education\ninstitutions throughout the UK and Ireland. \nUniversities and colleges from the Scottish Highlands to Cornwall are\nreporting massive increases in mumps cases this year [2004]. Central Nervous System (CNS) involvement during acute mumps\nvirus infection occurs at such high frequency that it has been considered\nto be a primary manifestation of mumps, rather than a complication. The term mumps meningoencephalitis has been coined to\ncover the range of intermediate manifestations of mumps virus infection of\nthe CNS. University authorities are urging students under 24 years of age to take\nthe triple MMR vaccine, which prevents mumps, measles, and rubella.\n A program of inoculations is being devised to target 16\nto 25 year olds, after a massive increase in cases of the infection over\nthe past year.' Source: The National Student, November 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.national-student.co.uk/2004_11/national_news_mumps.htm>\n\nUK: students are being warned of an imminent mumps epidemic\n----------------------------------------------------------- Source: BBC News, Tue 16 Nov 2004 [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/kent/4016867.stm>\n\nEngland: emergency vaccinations for mumps offered in Kent\n--------------------------------------------------------- Colleagues of\nstudents at Exeter University have been offered vaccinations, and 1000 1st\nyear students have so far been given the MMR jab. The Bath Chronicle reports that\n'thousands of adults are to be offered vaccinations to prevent a mumps\nepidemic in Bath.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-11-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Manchester", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oxford", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Highlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Birmingham", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Plymouth", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canterbury", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Islands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leeds", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cambridge", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206852", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, students - UK & Ireland", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206852", "date": "2004-11-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS, STUDENTS - UK & IRELAND\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Wed 10 Nov 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Scotsman newspaper, Press Association report, Tue 9 Nov 2004\n[edited]\n<http://news.scotsman.com/latest.cfm?id=3737362>\n\nUK: mumps outbreak hits Cambridge University\n-----------------------------------------------\nStudents at Cambridge are among the latest to be affected by a mumps\nepidemic striking British universities. University officials said today\n[Tue 9 Nov 2004 ] that 38 students had been diagnosed with the disease\nsince the autumn term began. Students under the age of 25 were being\noffered vaccinations, said a spokeswoman. Affected colleges include Jesus,\nEmmanuel, Pembroke, St. Catharine's, Peterhouse, Corpus Christi, Churchill,\nand Trinity Hall.\n'The university published advice in the student handbook. We advised all\nstudents to check if they had been immunized, and if not, to arrange for\nimmunization through their GP,' she said. '1st-year students were offered\nthe opportunity to be vaccinated free of charge through their GP, once they\narrived in the city.'\nUniversities across the UK have been setting up vaccination programs in\nrecent weeks. Experts believe that around 3000 students and young people --\nborn before the infant MMR triple vaccine program began -- could be\ninfected with the virus by the end of the year [2004] if trends continue.\n[Byline: Brian Farmer]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 10 Nov 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News, Tue 9 Nov 2004 [edited]\n<http://212.2.162.45/news/story.asp?j=123501286&p=yz35xy99z&n=123502046>\n\nIreland: mumps outbreak hits 3 colleges\n-------------------------------------------\nThe National Disease Surveillance Centre is investigating an outbreak of\nmumps at 3 colleges in Westmeath, Donegal, and Kildare. Around 75 cases of\nthe viral infection have been reported in Athlone Institute of Technology,\nLetterkenny Institute of Technology, and St. Patrick College in Maynooth.\nThis is more than double the total number of mumps cases reported for this\ntime last year [2003].
