MUMPS, STUDENTS - UK & IRELAND\n Date: Wed 10 Nov 2004\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cambridge", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Westmeath", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Donegal", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205316", "headline": "PRO> Mumps - UK (Scotland) (02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205316", "date": "2004-02-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - UK (SCOTLAND) (02): BACKGROUND\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 21 Feb 2004\nFrom: Dr. S. Berger <mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\nSource: The Gideon Database, Sat 21 Feb 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.GideonOnline.com>\n\nBackground Data on Incidence of Mumps in Scotland\n-------------------------------------------------\n[The following background data on mumps in Scotland has been extracted from\nthe GIDEON database by Dr. Steve Berger.]\nRoutine immunization was introduced in 1968. Routine immunization\n(Measles-Mumps-Rubella triple vaccine) is given at age 12 months, and [a\nbooster at] 3 to 5 years. During 1990 to 2001, infant vaccine coverage ranged\nfrom 85-92 percent.\nYear / Cases\n1989 / 3095\n1990 / 833\n1991 / 723\n1992 / 601\n1993 / 458\n1994 / 546\n1995 / 371\n1996 / 368\n1997 / 282\n1998 / 251\n1999 / 218\n2000 / 196\n2001 / 151\n2002 / 156\n2003 / 86 [January to June]\nNo cases of mumps *meningitis* were reported during 1999 through 2002.\n--\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>", "summary": "Year / Cases\n1989 / 3095\n1990 / 833\n1991 / 723\n1992 / 601\n1993 / 458\n1994 / 546\n1995 / 371\n1996 / 368\n1997 / 282\n1998 / 251\n1999 / 218\n2000 / 196\n2001 / 151\n2002 / 156\n2003 / 86 A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Routine immunization\n(Measles-Mumps-Rubella triple vaccine) is given at age 12 months, and [a\nbooster at] 3 to 5 years. Source: The Gideon Database, Sat 21 Feb 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.GideonOnline.com>\n\nBackground Data on Incidence of Mumps in Scotland\n MUMPS - UK (SCOTLAND) (02): BACKGROUND\n**************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1997-03-25 00:00:00", "1993-03-25 00:00:00", "1989-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-02-25 00:00:00", "1968-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "1992-03-25 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205323", "headline": "PRO> Mumps - UK (Scotland) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205323", "date": "2004-02-23 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - UK (SCOTLAND) (03)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 23 Feb 2004\nFrom: Dr Richard Smithson <rsmithson@whssb.n-i.nhs.uk>\n\n\nMumps Outbreak Not Related to Decline in MMMR Uptake\n---------------------------------------------------\nIn fact this outbreak and similar ones like it elsewhere in the UK are not\na result of recent falls in MMR uptake -- they are affecting the wrong age\ngroup for that -- but are as a result of previous vaccination policy.\n\nThey are occurring in an age group who are too old to have been recommended\n2 doses of MMR -- this was introduced in the UK in 1996. Prior to that in\n1994 there was a school based one-off campaign that offered all children at\nschool aged 5-18 measles and rubella (MR), but mumps was not included (the\ncampaign was run at short notice because of a predicted measles outbreak,\nand it was not possible to obtain the mumps component in the timescale\nrequired) -- there was a very high uptake for this of about 90-95 percent.\n\nThe age group now being affected by the mumps outbreaks would have been\npart of this campaign, and it is interesting to note that whilst this age\ngroup is suffering from mumps outbreaks, they are not being affected by\neither measles or rubella, which were included in the school campaign.\nWhilst I do not know the details of the currently reported Glasgow\noutbreak, analyses of other similar outbreaks have shown most of the\naffected children have received MR and either no dose or only one dose of MMR.\n\nIn contrast, there have been some local measles outbreaks in parts of the\nUK in children under 5 and are the result of the falling MMR uptake.\n\n--\nDr Richard Smithson\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control\nWestern Health and Social Services Board\n15 Gransha Park, Clooney Road\nDerry BT47 6FN\n<rsmithson@whssb.n-i.nhs.uk>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 23 Feb 2004\nFrom: Claire Bramley <Claire.Bramley@scieh.csa.scot.nhs.uk>\n\n\nThank you for your interest in mumps in Scotland. One aspect to clarify,\nthough, is that the recent cases of mumps are almost all in teenagers and\nyoung adults (ages 13-25 years; median/mean 19 years). The currently\nincreased incidence of mumps in Scotland is therefore due to these older\nindividuals not having had the opportunity to receive 2 doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine (i.e. MMR) in the routine schedule, rather than\nthe recent decline in MMR vaccine uptake in young children.\n\nSimilar outbreaks have occurred elsewhere in the UK in the past few years.\nFurther information on the recent mumps cases is available in the latest\nWeekly Report from the Scottish Centre for Infection and Environmental\nHealth (SCIEH).\n<http://www.show.scot.nhs.uk/scieh/PDF/pdf2004/0407.pdf>.\n\n--\nDr J. Claire Bramley\nEpidemiologist (Immunisation)\nScottish Centre for Infection and Environmental Health\nClifton House, Clifton Place\nGlasgow G3 7LN\n<claire.bramley@scieh.csa.scot.nhs.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks both correspondents for their comments, which correct\nan erroneous statement appended to the original report by the moderator.\nTheir help is greatly appreciated in keeping the record straight - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Prior to that in\n1994 there was a school based one-off campaign that offered all children at\nschool aged 5-18 measles and rubella (MR), but mumps was not included (the\ncampaign was run at short notice because of a predicted measles outbreak,\nand it was not possible to obtain the mumps component in the timescale\nrequired) A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n The currently\nincreased incidence of mumps in Scotland is therefore due to these older\nindividuals not having had the opportunity to receive 2 doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine (i.e. MMR) in the routine schedule, rather than\nthe recent decline in MMR vaccine uptake in young children. \n\nThe age group now being affected by the mumps outbreaks would have been\npart of this campaign, and it is interesting to note that whilst this age\ngroup is suffering from mumps outbreaks, they are not being affected by\neither measles or rubella, which were included in the school campaign. Scottish Centre for Infection and Environmental Health\nClifton House, Clifton Place\nGlasgow G3 7LN\n<claire.bramley@scieh.csa.scot.nhs.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks both correspondents for their comments, which correct\nan erroneous statement appended to the original report by the moderator. \n\n--\nDr Richard Smithson\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control\nWestern Health and Social Services Board\n15 In fact this outbreak and similar ones like it elsewhere in the UK are not\na result of recent falls in MMR uptake -- they are affecting the wrong age\ngroup for that -- but are as a result of previous vaccination policy. One aspect to clarify,\nthough, is that the recent cases of mumps are almost all in teenagers and\nyoung adults (ages 13-25 years; median/mean 19 years). Whilst I do not know the details of the currently reported Glasgow\noutbreak, analyses of other similar outbreaks have shown most of the\naffected children have received MR and either no dose or only one dose of MMR. Further information on the recent mumps cases is available in the latest\nWeekly Report from the Scottish Centre for Infection and Environmental\nHealth (SCIEH).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-02-23 00:00:00", "2021-05-18 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gransha Park", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209546", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (NE, IA) (04): air travel exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209546", "date": "2006-04-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (NEBRASKA, IOWA) (04): AIR TRAVEL EXPOSURE\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 11 Apr 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR, 11 Apr 2006 / 55(Dispatch); 1-2 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm55d411a1.htm?s_cid=mm55d411a1_e>\n\nExposure to Mumps During Air Travel - United States, April 2006\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe state of Iowa has been experiencing a large mumps outbreak that\nbegan in December 2005 (1). As of 10 Apr 2006, a total of 515\npossible mumps cases have been reported to the Iowa Department of\nPublic Health (IDPH) during 2006 (2). This outbreak has spread across\nIowa, and mumps activity, possibly linked to the Iowa outbreak, is\nunder investigation in 6 neighboring states, including Illinois (n =\n4), Kansas (n = 33), Minnesota (n = one), Missouri (n = 4), Nebraska\n(n = 43), and Wisconsin (n = 4) (CDC, unpublished data, 10 Apr 2006).\nThe reasons for this outbreak are under investigation.\nMumps is an acute viral infection characterized by a nonspecific\nprodrome, including myalgia, anorexia, malaise, headache, and fever,\nfollowed by acute onset of unilateral or bilateral tender swelling of\nparotid or other salivary glands (2). An estimated 60 percent to 70\npercent of mumps infections produce typical acute parotitis (3).\nApproximately 20 percent of infections are asymptomatic, and nearly\n50 percent are associated with nonspecific or primarily respiratory\nsymptoms. Complications include orchitis, oophoritis, or mastitis\n(inflammation of the testicles, ovaries, or breasts, respectively),\nmeningitis/encephalitis, spontaneous abortion, and deafness.\nTransmission occurs by direct contact with respiratory droplets or\nsaliva. The incubation period is 14-18 days (range: 14-25 days) from\nexposure to onset of symptoms. The infectious period is from 3 days\nbefore symptom onset until 9 days after onset of symptoms.\nIDPH has identified 2 persons who had mumps diagnosed and were\npotentially infectious during travel on 9 different commercial\nflights involving 2 airlines during 26 Mar-2 Apr 2006. The commercial\nairline flights identified with a potentially infectious traveler are\nlisted below by date, carrier, and flight number:\nNorthwest Airline (NWA) flights:\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3025 from Waterloo, Iowa to Minneapolis, Minnesota\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA #760 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Detroit, Michigan\n27 Mar 2006 - NWA #0260 from Detroit, Michigan, to Washington,\nDC--Reagan National\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA #1705 from Washington, DC--Reagan National to\nMinneapolis, Minnesota\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3026 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Waterloo, Iowa\nAmerican Airlines (AA) flights:\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #1216 from Tucson, Arizona, to Dallas, Texas (DFW)\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #3617 from DFW to Lafayette, Arkansas (Northwest\nArkansas Regional [NAR])\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5399 from NAR to St. Louis, Missouri\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5498 from St. Louis, Missouri, to Cedar Rapids, Iowa\nPersons on these flights who have symptoms consistent with mumps\nwithin 21 days of travel should be evaluated for mumps by an\nhealth-care provider. Health-care providers should remain vigilant\nfor mumps among persons with parotitis or other salivary gland\ninflammation. Cases of suspected mumps should be reported immediately\nto public health officials.\nA multistate investigation has been initiated by CDC and the state\nhealth departments in affected states to notify potentially exposed\npassengers (i.e., those seated in close proximity to the index\ncases). This investigation is using a new software application,\neManifest, developed by the CDC Division of Global Migration and\nQuarantine (DGMQ) to securely import, sort, and assign\npassenger-locating information to jurisdictions to facilitate timely\nidentification of exposed persons. These data are securely\ntransmitted to state and territorial health departments via the\nEpidemic Information Exchange (Epi-X) Forum (available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/epix/epix.html>) for notification of\npotentially exposed passengers.\nIncidence of mumps in the United States began to decrease after\nvaccine introduction in 1967 and recommendations for routine\nvaccination of children in 1977. Since the 1990s, a further decrease\nin the reported incidence of mumps has occurred, which is thought to\nbe attributable to the implementation of the 2nd dose of measles,\nmumps, and rubella vaccine (3). The risk for transmission of\nrespiratory infectious diseases during air travel might depend on\nseveral factors, including 1) immunity of passengers; 2)\ninfectiousness of the organism; 3) degree of shedding of the pathogen\nby infected passengers; 4) hygienic practices of infectious\npassengers; 5) proximity of others to infectious passengers; 6)\nhygienic practices of the other passengers/crew; 7) flight duration;\nand 8) cabin environment of the aircraft (4). Transmission of other\nrespiratory pathogens during air travel has been reported (5-9).\nExposure and transmission of mumps during commercial air travel has\nnot been described previously.\n[Reported by: P Quinlisk, MD, Iowa Dept of Public Health. S Redd, G\nDayan, MD, National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases;\nN Gallagher, Geographic Medicine and Health Promotion Br, P Lutz, K\nMarienau, MD, F Averhoff, MD, Quarantine and Border Health Svcs Br,\nDiv of Global Migration and Quarantine, National Center for\nInfectious Diseases, CDC.]\nReferences:\n1. CDC. Mumps epidemic, Iowa, 2006. MMWR 2006;55:366-8.\n2. Iowa Department of Public Health, Center for Acute Disease\nEpidemiology. Iowa mumps update. Des Moines, Iowa: Iowa Department of\nPublic Health; 2006. Available at\n<http://www.idph.state.ia.us/adper/common/pdf/mumps/mumps_update_041106.pdf>.\n3. Plotkin SA, Orenstein WA, eds. Vaccines. 4th ed. Philadelphia, PA:\nWB Saunders; 2003:441-69.\n4. Mangili A, Glendreau M. Transmission of infectious diseases during\ncommercial air travel. Lancet 2005;365:989-96.\n5. World Health Organization. Tuberculosis and air travel: guidelines\nfor prevention and control. 2nd ed. Geneva, Switzerland: World Health\nOrganization; 2006:5-7. Available at:\n<http://www.who.int/docstore/gtb/publications/aircraft/PDF/98_256.pdf>\n6. CDC. Postexposure prophylaxis, isolation, and quarantine to\ncontrol an import-associated measles outbreak - Iowa, 2004. MMWR\n2004; 53:969-71.\n7. Moser MR, Bend TR, Margolis HS, et al. An outbreak of influenza\naboard a commercial airline. Am J Epidemiol 1979;110:1-6.\n8. Klonz KC, Hynes NA, Gunn RA, et al. An outbreak of influenza\nA/Taiwan/1/86 infections at a naval base and its association with\nairplane travel. Am J Epidemiol 1989;129:341-8.\n9. Marsden AG. Influenza outbreak related to air travel. Med J\nAustral 2003;179:172-3.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail has been covering this unusual outbreak due to the size\nof the outbreak, the genotype involved (genotype G, most recently\nassociated with outbreaks in the United Kingdom) and now the\nadditional information that there may be spread to neighboring states\nand the possibility of exposure during airline travel. The mention of\na new software application 'eManifest' is interesting, and one\nwonders whether it shortens the time necessary to identify passengers\nat risk of exposure to diseases while traveling. We look forward to\nhearing more about this tool. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "The risk for transmission of\nrespiratory infectious diseases during air travel might depend on\nseveral factors, including 1) immunity of passengers; 2)\ninfectiousness of the organism; 3) degree of shedding of the pathogen\nby infected passengers; 4) hygienic practices of infectious\npassengers; 5) proximity of others to infectious passengers; 6)\nhygienic practices of the other passengers/crew; 7) flight duration;\nand 8) cabin environment of the aircraft (4). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n This outbreak has spread across\nIowa, and mumps activity, possibly linked to the Iowa outbreak, is\nunder investigation in 6 neighboring states, including Illinois (n =\n4), Kansas (n = 33), Minnesota (n = one), Missouri (n = 4), Nebraska\n(n = 43), and Wisconsin (n = 4) (CDC, unpublished data, 10 Apr 2006). 26 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3025 from Waterloo, Iowa to Minneapolis, Minnesota\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA #760 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Detroit, Michigan\n27 Mar 2006 - NWA #0260 from Detroit, Michigan, to Washington,\nDC--Reagan National\n [ProMED-mail has been covering this unusual outbreak due to the size\nof the outbreak, the genotype involved (genotype G, most recently\nassociated with outbreaks in the United Kingdom) and now the\nadditional information that there may be spread to neighboring states\nand the possibility of exposure during airline travel. 29 Mar 2006 - NWA #1705 from Washington, DC--Reagan National to\nMinneapolis, Minnesota\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3026 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Waterloo, Iowa\nAmerican Airlines (AA) flights:\n The commercial\nairline flights identified with a potentially infectious traveler are\nlisted below by date, carrier, and flight number:\nNorthwest Airline (NWA) flights:\n These data are securely\ntransmitted to state and territorial health departments via the\nEpidemic Information Exchange (Epi-X) Forum (available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/epix/epix.html>) for notification of\npotentially exposed passengers. This investigation is using a new software application,\neManifest, developed by the CDC Division of Global Migration and\nQuarantine (DGMQ) to securely import, sort, and assign\npassenger-locating information to jurisdictions to facilitate timely\nidentification of exposed persons. \nIDPH has identified 2 persons who had mumps diagnosed and were\npotentially infectious during travel on 9 different commercial\nflights involving 2 airlines during 26 Mar-2 Apr 2006. 2 Apr 2006 - AA #5498 from St. Louis, Missouri, to Cedar Rapids, Iowa\nPersons on these flights who have symptoms consistent with mumps\nwithin 21 days of travel should be evaluated for mumps by an\nhealth-care provider. Mumps is an acute viral infection characterized by a nonspecific\nprodrome, including myalgia, anorexia, malaise, headache, and fever,\nfollowed by acute onset of unilateral or bilateral tender swelling of\nparotid or other salivary glands (2). Since the 1990s, a further decrease\nin the reported incidence of mumps has occurred, which is thought to\nbe attributable to the implementation of the 2nd dose of measles,\nmumps, and rubella vaccine (3). A multistate investigation has been initiated by CDC and the state\nhealth departments in affected states to notify potentially exposed\npassengers (i.e., those seated in close proximity to the index\ncases). The mention of\na new software application 'eManifest' is interesting, and one\nwonders whether it shortens the time necessary to identify passengers\nat risk of exposure to diseases while traveling. S Redd, G\nDayan, MD, National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases;\nN Gallagher, Geographic Medicine and Health Promotion Br, P Lutz, K\n Source: MMWR, 11 Apr 2006 / 55(Dispatch); 1-2 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm55d411a1.htm?s_cid=mm55d411a1_e>\n\nExposure to Mumps During Air Travel - United States, April 2006\n As of 10 Apr 2006, a total of 515\npossible mumps cases have been reported to the Iowa Department of\nPublic Health (IDPH) during 2006 (2). Exposure and transmission of mumps during commercial air travel has\nnot been described previously.\n MUMPS - USA (NEBRASKA, IOWA) (04): AIR TRAVEL EXPOSURE\n******************************************************\n Health-care providers should remain vigilant\nfor mumps among persons with parotitis or other salivary gland\ninflammation. Incidence of mumps in the United States began to decrease after\nvaccine introduction in 1967 and recommendations for routine\nvaccination of children in 1977. Approximately 20 percent of infections are asymptomatic, and nearly\n50 percent are associated with nonspecific or primarily respiratory\nsymptoms. An outbreak of influenza\nA/Taiwan/1/86 infections at a naval base and its association with\nairplane travel. Marienau, MD, F Averhoff, MD, Quarantine and Border Health Svcs Br,\nDiv of Global Migration and Quarantine, National Center for\nInfectious Diseases, CDC.] Complications include orchitis, oophoritis, or mastitis\n(inflammation of the testicles, ovaries, or breasts, respectively),\nmeningitis/encephalitis, spontaneous abortion, and deafness. --\nProMED-mail\n< Available at:\n<http://www.who.int/docstore/gtb/publications/aircraft/PDF/98_256.pdf>\n6. \nReferences:\n1.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206807", "date": "2004-11-03 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS, STUDENTS - UK\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 3 Nov 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Medical News Today, Tue 2 Nov 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/medicalnews.php?newsid=15795>\n\nUK-wide outbreak of mumps among students\n-----------------------------------------\nUniversities across the UK are launching a mass MMR vaccination campaign in\na bid to control the latest outbreak of mumps among students. The Health\nProtection Agency (HPA) believes that nearly 3000 students and young people\ncould be infected with mumps by the end of the year [2004] if the current\noutbreak continues.\nOne possible reason for the epidemic could be due to the disease occurring\nin people who were too old to have been offered the MMR vaccines routinely\nas children. 'These youngsters (currently aged between 14 and 22 years,\nborn 1982-1990) would have been offered a single measles vaccine, and most\nwill have had the combined measles and rubella vaccine,' said Dr. Mary\nRamsay from the HPA. 'However, only a few will have received MMR vaccine,\nand hardly any will have received a 2nd dose of MMR, which is important in\nsecuring good levels of protection. We recommend that those in this age\ngroup, for example school leavers and those starting university, who have\nnot received MMR, or had only one dose, should be offered MMR.'\nUniversities in Oxford, Manchester, Leeds, Kent, Nottingham, and Birmingham\nare planning campus vaccination days as well as raising the profile of the\ndisease through student websites and newspapers. (Based on a News release\nfrom NHS Health Development Agency.\n<http://www.hda-online.org.uk >)\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This outbreak is not a direct consequence of the current reduced uptake of\nthe MMR triple vaccine in the UK due to the activities of single-issue\npressure groups, but it does illustrate the need for awareness of potential\ngaps in vaccine coverage in vulnerable groups. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [This outbreak is not a direct consequence of the current reduced uptake of\nthe MMR triple vaccine in the UK due to the activities of single-issue\npressure groups, but it does illustrate the need for awareness of potential\ngaps in vaccine coverage in vulnerable groups. These youngsters (currently aged between 14 and 22 years,\nborn 1982-1990) would have been offered a single measles vaccine, and most\nwill have had the combined measles and rubella vaccine,' said Dr. Mary\nRamsay from the HPA. ' The Health\nProtection Agency (HPA) believes that nearly 3000 students and young people\ncould be infected with mumps by the end of the year [2004] if the current\noutbreak continues. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n However, only a few will have received MMR vaccine,\nand hardly any will have received a 2nd dose of MMR, which is important in\nsecuring good levels of protection.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manchester", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Birmingham", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leeds", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oxford", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205313", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK (Scotland)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205313", "date": "2004-02-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - UK (SCOTLAND)\n*********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 20 Feb 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Evening Times (Glasgow) & Netdoctor online, Fri 20 Feb\n2004) [edited]\n<http://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/hi/news/5023151.html>\n<http://www.netdoctor.co.uk/news/index.asp?y=2004&m=2&d=20&id=108556>\n\nScotland: Alarming Rise in Mumps Among Teenagers in Glasgow\n-----------------------------------------------------------\nThe city of Glasgow is at the centre of an alarming rise in mumps\namong teenagers. Confirmed cases of the disease in Scotland have\nsoared to 49 since 1 Dec 2003 -- almost double the tally of 26 cases\nfor the rest of 2003. And 71 percent of these cases were in Glasgow.\nA report by the Scottish Centre for Infection and Environmental\nHealth (SCIEH) said 35 of the 49 cases were within the Greater\nGlasgow NHS board area, with others in areas adjacent to Greater\nGlasgow. The potentially-fatal disease can cause meningitis,\ninflammation of the brain, and infertility in boys.\nDr Claire Bramley of the SCIEH said: 'Like the rest of the UK, we are\nseeing cases of mumps in older teenagers and young adults [90 percent\nof the cases were in the 16-24 year age group - Mod.CP]. The virus\nhas come into circulation and is infecting those who have not been\nvaccinated. You could describe it as an outbreak -- certainly in\nGlasgow. We encourage as many people as possible to take their\nchildren for vaccination.'\nExperts said there had been outbreaks elsewhere in the UK, and there\nwas no specific reason why it had spread to Scotland. Dr Syed Ahmed,\nconsultant in public health at Greater Glasgow Health Board, said the\nlatest cases were a worrying development. He said: 'This is very much\nhigher than normal, as we usually have only one or 2 confirmed cases\nin a year.'\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This outbreak is a further unfortunate consequence of the decline in\nuptake of the triple measles-mumps-rubella vaccine in the UK provoked\nby fears of [an unproven - Mod.JW] link with autism. In the Greater Glasgow\narea, the uptake of triple vaccine has declined to 85 percent in 2003 from 87\npercent in the previous year. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Evening Times (Glasgow) & Netdoctor online, Fri 20 Feb\n2004) [edited]\n<http://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/hi/news/5023151.html>\n<http://www.netdoctor.co.uk/news/index.asp?y=2004&m=2&d=20&id=108556>\n\nScotland: Alarming Rise in Mumps Among Teenagers in Glasgow\n A report by the Scottish Centre for Infection and Environmental\nHealth (SCIEH) said 35 of the 49 cases were within the Greater\nGlasgow NHS board area, with others in areas adjacent to Greater\nGlasgow. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Dr Claire Bramley of the SCIEH said: 'Like the rest of the UK, we are\nseeing cases of mumps in older teenagers and young adults [90 percent\nof the cases were in the 16-24 year age group - Mod. Confirmed cases of the disease in Scotland have\nsoared to 49 since 1 Dec 2003 -- almost double the tally of 26 cases\nfor the rest of 2003. In the Greater Glasgow\narea, the uptake of triple vaccine has declined to 85 percent in 2003 from 87\npercent in the previous year. Dr Syed Ahmed,\nconsultant in public health at Greater Glasgow Health Board, said the\nlatest cases were a worrying development.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2003-12-01 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Glasgow", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1391", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA: multistate (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1391", "date": "2006-05-20 00:00:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA: MULTISTATE (02)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1] Mumps - Virginia\nDate: Thu 18 May 2006\nFrom: Raymond Weinstein <AlaskaRay@aol.com>\n\nI thought you might be interested to learn that today [Thu 18 May 2006] I\ndiagnosed what I believe is the 1st case of mumps in Virginia associated\nwith the current multistate outbreak. The patient is a 17 year old female\nfrom Manassas with no known recent contact with anyone having mumps and no\nrecent travel or visitors from outside Virginia. She became ill with fever\nand headache about 5 days ago and developed symptoms of bilateral parotitis\nwithin the last 2 days.\nLaboratory confirmation of the diagnosis is pending. What ties this case to\nthe other outbreaks is the fact that this patient is originally from Kansas\nand received her 2 MMR vaccinations there in 1990 and 1994.\nThis occurrence makes me wonder: 1. Since this patient was vaccinated in\nKansas, but no longer lives there, could this be an indication of vaccine\nfailure? 2. Does her development of mumps, with no known contact with the\nillness, in a community with a high vaccination rate and where an outbreak\nis not occurring, indicate that there may be an intermittent subclinical\noccurrence of the illness? I can imagine a scenario where this might occur\nin patients who have partial immunity from previous vaccination and who\nmight shed virus without having any symptoms, or at least symptoms to\nsuggest mumps.\n--\nRaymond Weinstein, MD\nManassas,Virginia\nUSA\n<AlaskaRay@aol.com>\n[Some of Dr Weinstein's observations are dealt with in detail in the\nfollowing MMWR dispatch. - Mod.CP]\n******\n[2] Mumps - multi-state outbreak\nDate: Fri 19 May 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR Dispatch 18 May 2006 / 55(Dispatch);1-5 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm55d518a1.htm?s_cid=mm55d518a1_e>\n\nUpdate: multi-state outbreak of mumps - United States; 1 Jan to 2 May 2006\n-----------------------------------------------------\nCDC and state and local health departments continue to investigate an\noutbreak of mumps that began in Iowa in December 2005 (1) and involved at\nleast 10 additional states as of 2 May 2006. This report summarizes\npreliminary data reported to CDC from these 11 states and provides\nrecommendations to prevent and control mumps during an outbreak.\nCases of mumps are reportable through the National Notifiable Diseases\nSurveillance System (NNDSS) (2). NNDSS reports are transmitted\nelectronically to CDC each week and include information on individual cases\nsuch as age, sex, date of symptom onset, vaccination status, and\ncomplications of illness. Mumps cases included in this report are those\nwith onset from [1 Jan 2006] (MMWR week 1) through [29 Apr 2006] (MMWR week\n17) that were reported to CDC as of [2 May 2006] through NNDSS (or the Iowa\nmumps outbreak-specific reporting system) from Iowa and 10 additional\nstates that reported one or more cases of mumps epidemiologically linked to\nthe multistate outbreak. In addition to cases reported through NNDSS, to\nprovide information rapidly during this outbreak, states have been\nreporting aggregate numbers of mumps cases and mumps-related\nhospitalizations and complications biweekly to CDC. Cases reported in this\nmanner through [2 May 2006], also are included in this report.\nThe clinical case definition of mumps* is an illness with acute onset of\nunilateral or bilateral tender, self-limited swelling of the parotid or\nother salivary gland, lasting 2 or more days, and without other apparent\ncause. A confirmed case of mumps is one that is laboratory confirmed or\nmeets the clinical case definition and is linked epidemiologically to a\nconfirmed or probable case. A case is classified as probable if it meets\nthe clinical case definition but is neither laboratory-confirmed nor linked\nto another confirmed or probable mumps case. In accordance with these\ndefinitions, asymptomatic, laboratory confirmed infections were counted as\nconfirmed cases in all states except Iowa. In Iowa, laboratory-confirmed\ncases that were asymptomatic or had clinical information pending, and cases\nfor which high suspicion for mumps existed but case classification was not\nyet determined were classified as suspect.\nDuring the period 1 Jan to 2 May 2006, 11 states reported 2597 cases of\nmumps. Eight states (Illinois, Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska,\nPennsylvania, South Dakota, and Wisconsin) reported mumps outbreaks with\nongoing local transmission or clusters of cases; 3 states (Colorado,\nMinnesota, and Mississippi) reported cases associated with travel from an\noutbreak state. The majority of mumps cases (1487 [57 per cent]) were\nreported from Iowa; states with the next highest case totals were Kansas\n(371), Illinois (224), Nebraska (201), and Wisconsin (176) (Figure 1 [see\nURL link above]). Of the 2597 cases reported overall, 1275 (49 per cent)\nwere classified as confirmed, 915 (35 per cent) as probable, and 287 (11\nper cent) as suspect; for 120 (5 per cent) cases, classification was\nunknown. Twelve mumps viral isolates from 6 states were characterized; all\nwere mumps genotype G.\nFor 2067 (80 per cent) of the 2597 mumps cases with patient age available,\nthe median age was 21 years (range: less than 1 year to 96 years). In the 8\nstates with outbreaks, the incidence rate was highest among persons aged 18\nto 24 years (17.1 per 100 000 population), followed by persons aged 5 to 17\nyears (5.2) and 25 to 39 years (4.8) (Figure 2 [see URL link above]). Among\nthe 2073 patients for whom sex was known, 1244 (60 per cent) were female.\nAmong the 2073 cases for which week of onset was known, 1426 (69 per cent)\nwere reported in April (Figure 3 in original text). The peak week of onset\nhas been April 2 to 8 (week 14) in Iowa and April 16 to 22 (week 16) in\nother states.\nHowever, additional cases with onset dates in April continue to be\nreported. Parotitis was reported in 870 (66 per cent) of the 1327 patients\nfor whom such data were available. Data regarding mumps complications and\nhospitalizations are incomplete. However, complications have included 27\nreports of orchitis, 11 meningitis, 4 encephalitis, 4 deafness, and one\neach of oophoritis, mastitis, pancreatitis, and unspecified complications.\nA total of 25 hospitalizations were reported, but insufficient data were\nprovided to determine whether mumps caused all the hospitalizations. No\ndeaths have been reported.\nVaccination status of reported mumps patients is being ascertained. In\nIowa, preliminary vaccination data were reported through [3 May 2006].***\nAmong 1192 patients, 69 (6 per cent) were unvaccinated, 141 (12 per cent)\nhad received 1 dose of measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine, and 607\n(51 per cent) had received 2 doses of MMR vaccine; the vaccination status\nof 375 (31 per cent) patients, the majority of whom were adults who did not\nhave vaccination records, was unknown. Preliminary data, as of [10 Apr\n2006], from 2 mumps outbreaks on college campuses in an Iowa county\naffected early in the outbreak, identified attack rates of reported mumps\ncases*** of 2.0 per cent (31 of 1542 students) and 3.8 per cent (44 of 1168\nstudents). Preliminary data from vaccine coverage surveys suggest that the\ncollege with the higher attack rate had a smaller proportion (77 per cent\nversus 97 per cent) of students documented as having received 2 doses of\nMMR vaccine.\nAs of [10 May 2006], a total of 11 persons potentially infected with mumps\nwho traveled by aircraft during [26 Mar-25 Apr 2006] had been identified on\n33 commercial flights operated by 8 different airlines. Notifications had\neither been initiated or completed for persons potentially exposed on all\nidentified flights. As of [12 May 2006], of about 575 persons potentially\nexposed on the flights, 132 had received follow-up greater than 25 days\nafter their potential exposure. Two cases of mumps were identified,\npossibly associated with transmission during air travel. Both cases\noccurred among Iowa residents, one of whom was a traveling companion of a\nperson known to have mumps.\n(Reported by: K Gershman, MD, S Rios, D Woods-Stout, Colorado Dept of\nPublic Health and Environment. M Dworkin, MD, K Hunt, Illinois Dept of\nPublic Health. DC Hunt, MPH, J Hill, MPH, Kansas Dept of Health and\nEnvironment. P Quinlisk, MD, M Harris, MPH, Iowa Dept of Public Health. C\nKenyon, MPH, Minnesota Dept of Health. C Evans, K Mills McNeill, MD, PhD,\nRG Travnicek, MD, Mississippi Dept of Health. B Zhu, MD, E Hedrick, HL Marx\nJr, R Renicker, MSA, Missouri Dept of Health and Senior Svcs. AL O'Keefe,\nMD, T Safranek, MD, Nebraska Health and Human Svcs System. S Slagy, S\nSilvestri, Allegheny County Health Dept; J Sullivan, York City Health Bur;\nJ Mankowski, Erie County Health Dept; R Grill, K Luckenbill, P Lurie, MD, R\nRickert, MPH, H Stafford, Pennsylvania Dept of Health. S Gannon, L\nKightlinger, PhD, South Dakota Dept of Health. J Berg, J Davis, MD, J\nGabor, Wisconsin Dept of Health and Family Svcs. F Averhoff, MD, K\nMarienau, MD, Div of Global Migration and Quarantine; M Bell, MD, E\nBolyard, MPH, C McDonald, MD, A Srinivasan, MD, Div of Healthcare Quality\nPromotion, National Center for Preparedness, Detection, and Control of\nInfectious Diseases (proposed); TA Santibanez, PhD, and J Santoli, MD,\nImmunization Svcs Div, SW Roush, MPH, PU Srivastava, MS, Div of Bacterial\nDiseases, L Anderson, MD, B Bellini, PhD, CB Bridges, MD, G Dayan, MD, ST\nGoldstein, MD, M Marin, MD, U Parashar, MD, S Redd, S Reef, MD, J Rota,\nMPH, PA Rota, PhD, J Seward, MBBS, C Shawney, Div of Viral Diseases,\nNational Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases (proposed); A\nHuang, MD, A Parker, MSN, MPH, T Shimabukuro, MD, EIS officers, CDC.)\nMMWR editorial note\n-------------------\nIn the United States, the reported incidence of mumps declined after\nintroduction of mumps vaccine in 1967 and the recommendation for its\nroutine use in 1977 (3). After expanded recommendations for a 2-dose MMR\nvaccine schedule for measles control in 1989 (3), mumps cases declined\nfurther (Figure 4 [see URL link above]). During the period 2001 to 2003,\nfewer than 300 mumps cases were reported each year, a 99 per cent decline\nfrom the 185 691 cases reported in 1968 (2).\nThe current multistate mumps outbreak, with 2597 cases reported through [2\nMay 2006], is the largest number of mumps cases reported to CDC in a single\nyear since 1991, when 4264 cases were reported (2). The first cases in the\ncurrent outbreak were detected on a college campus in eastern Iowa in\nDecember 2005; the source of these initial cases is unknown (1). Although\nthe age group most affected (38 per cent of cases) has been young adults\naged 18 to 24 years, many of whom are college students, the outbreak has\nspread to all age groups (1). Multiple factors might have contributed to\nthe spread of mumps in this outbreak and on college campuses. First, the\ncollege campus environment (such as living in dormitories with frequent and\nextended close contact with other students) facilitates transmission of\nmumps and other illnesses that are spread through respiratory and oral\nsecretions. Second, only 25 states***** and the District of Columbia report\na college admission requirement of 2 doses of MMR vaccine, including 3 of\nthe 11 states with outbreak-associated cases of mumps; no data on\nimplementation and evaluation of the 2-dose college admission requirement\nare available (CDC, unpublished data, 2006). Thus, 2-dose coverage with\nmumps-containing vaccine among college students likely is lower than the\nmedian 97 per cent (range: 57 per cent --99 per cent) coverage for\nmeasles-containing vaccine (almost exclusively administered as MMR vaccine)\nfor students entering elementary school and the median 98 per cent (range:\n62 per cent -- 99 per cent) coverage for students entering middle school\nreported in 2000 from 38 and 25 states, respectively (4). Third, delayed\nrecognition and diagnosis of mumps cases might have contributed to the\nspread in this outbreak; younger physicians in the United States likely\nhave not seen mumps, and physicians might not consider the diagnosis in\nvaccinated persons. Fourth, 2 doses of MMR vaccine are not 100 per cent\neffective in preventing disease, and accumulation of susceptible persons\nwho were not successfully immunized might be sufficient to sustain\ntransmission in certain settings. In addition, the vaccine might be less\neffective in preventing asymptomatic infection or atypical mumps than in\npreventing parotitis, and persons with asymptomatic infection or mild\ndisease might contribute to transmission. Finally, waning immunity has been\npostulated as a contributing factor in this outbreak. Young adults aged\n18-24 years would most commonly have received their most recent dose of\nmumps-containing vaccine (i.e., MMR vaccine) 6-17 years ago. High\nvaccination coverage with 2 doses of MMR vaccine, especially in school-aged\npopulations in the United States, likely prevented thousands of additional\ncases of mumps in this outbreak. Post-licensure studies conducted in the\nUnited States during the period 1973 to 1989 determined that one dose of\nmumps or MMR vaccine was 75 to 91 per cent effective in preventing mumps\nwith parotitis that lasts greater than 2 days (5). Although fewer data are\navailable on the effectiveness of 2 doses of MMR vaccine against mumps, one\nstudy from the United Kingdom documented vaccine effectiveness of 88 per\ncent with 2 doses (6). In a mumps outbreak in a high school in Kansas,\nstudents vaccinated with 1 dose of MMR vaccine had an attack rate 5 times\nthat of students vaccinated with 2 doses (7). In a mumps outbreak in a\nmiddle school in 1982, before mumps vaccination became widespread, attack\nrates of 25 to 49 per cent occurred among unvaccinated students, depending\non how cases were ascertained (8). During the 1986 to 1990, after\nwidespread implementation of a 1-dose mumps vaccination policy, attack\nrates of 2 to 18 per cent (most greater than 6 per cent) were documented in\nmumps outbreaks among junior high and high school students with vaccination\ncoverage of greater than 95 per cent (7,9). In contrast, preliminary data\nfrom 2 colleges in Iowa during the current outbreak identified attack rates\nof 2.0 per cent and 3.8 per cent, respectively, with the lower attack rate\nin the college with higher 2-dose vaccination coverage.\nTo prevent mumps, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP)\nrecommends a 2-dose MMR vaccination series for all children, with the first\ndose administered at ages 12-15 months and the second dose at ages 4-6\nyears (3). Two doses of MMR vaccine are recommended for school and college\nentry unless the student has other evidence of immunity (3). In a specially\nconvened meeting on [17 May 2006], ACIP redefined evidence of immunity to\nmumps through vaccination as follows: 1 dose of a live mumps virus\nvaccine** for preschool children and adults not at high risk; 2 doses for\nchildren in grades K--12 and adults at high risk (i.e., persons who work in\nhealth-care facilities, international travelers, and students at post-high\nschool educational institutions). Other criteria for evidence of immunity\n(i.e., birth before 1957, documentation of physician-diagnosed mumps, or\nlaboratory evidence of immunity) are unchanged. Furthermore, health-care\nfacilities should consider recommending 1 dose of MMR vaccine to\nunvaccinated health-care workers born before 1957 who do not have other\nevidence of mumps immunity.\nDuring an outbreak and depending on the epidemiology of the outbreak (e.g.,\nthe age groups and/or institutions involved), a 2nd dose of vaccine should\nbe considered for adults and for children aged 1-4 years who have received\n1 dose. The 2nd dose should be administered as early as 28 days after the\nfirst dose, the minimum recommended interval between 2 MMR vaccine doses.\nIn addition, during an outbreak, health-care facilities should strongly\nconsider recommending 2 doses of MMR vaccine to unvaccinated workers born\nbefore 1957 who do not have other evidence of mumps immunity. An MMWR\nNotice to Readers will be published, summarizing these interim\nrecommendations in more detail.\nAdditional means to decrease transmission in outbreak settings include\nexclusion of persons without evidence of immunity to mumps from\ninstitutions such as schools and colleges that are affected by the\noutbreak. Once vaccinated, students and staff can be readmitted to school\nimmediately, even if they have been exposed to a case of mumps. The period\nof exclusion for those who remain unvaccinated is 26 days after the onset\nof parotitis in the last person in the affected institution. Students who\nacquire mumps illness should be excluded from school until 9 days after the\nonset of parotitis. After an exposure to mumps, unvaccinated health-care\nworkers without evidence of immunity should be vaccinated and excluded from\nduty from the 12th day after the first exposure through the 26th day after\nthe last exposure. Health-care workers with mumps illness should be\nexcluded from work until 9 days after the onset of parotitis.\nIn response to the current outbreak, the Iowa Department of Public Health\n(IDPH) issued vaccination recommendations in March targeting college campus\nand health-care worker populations at high risk. On 14 Apr, CDC issued a\nHealth Advisory Notice summarizing vaccine policy recommendations for mumps\nprevention and control. In conjunction with local health departments, IDPH\nlaunched a statewide vaccination campaign during 24-26 Apr, targeting\npersons aged 18-22 years in the 35 Iowa counties with the state's largest\ncolleges and universities. In the second phase of the campaign, conducted\n2-4 May, vaccination was expanded to the remaining 64 counties, targeting\npersons aged 18-25 years. A third phase of the vaccination campaign was\nbegun 10 May and targets persons aged 18-46 years. Vaccination activities\nalso are being conducted or planned in Kansas, South Dakota, and Wisconsin.\nThe data presented in this report are preliminary; the case count is likely\nto change as additional data become available. Certain reported cases might\nnot have been caused by mumps; cases in persons without parotitis might\nhave been masculinized on the basis of serologic tests. Because of the low\nnumber of reported mumps cases during the last decade, laboratorians have\nlimited experience with mumps tests, particularly IgM antibody tests (10).\nSeveral different mumps IgM antibody tests are in use; however, neither the\nsensitivities nor specificities of these tests when used with serum\nspecimens from either unvaccinated or vaccinated persons have been clearly\ndefined. Consequently, interpretation of these antibody test results is\ndifficult, especially in previously vaccinated persons.\nStudies to define the sensitivity and specificity of mumps IgM antibody\ntests and reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) tests\nfor mumps virus RNA are in progress. CDC continues to work with state and\nlocal health departments to conduct mumps surveillance, assist with\nprevention and control activities, and evaluate vaccine effectiveness,\nduration of immunity, and risk factors for mumps illness.\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC. Mumps epidemic -- Iowa, 2006. MMWR 2006; 55: 366-8.\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5513a3.htm>\n2. CDC. Summary of notifiable diseases---United States, 2003. MMWR 2005;\n52(54). <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5254a1.htm>\n3. CDC. Progress toward\nimplementation of a second-dose measles immunization requirement for all\nschoolchildren in the United States. J Infect Dis 2004; 189(Suppl 1): S98-103.\n5. Plotkin SA, Orenstein WA, eds. Vaccines. 4th ed. Philadelphia, PA:\nElsevier; 2003: 441-5.\n6. Harling R, White JM, Ramsay ME, Macsween KF, van den Bosch C. The\neffectiveness of the mumps component of the MMR vaccine: a case control\nstudy. Vaccine 2005; 23: 4070-4.\n7. Hersh BS, Fine PE, Kent WK, et al. Cheek JE, Baron R, Atlas H, Wilson DL, Crider RD. Mumps outbreak in a\nhighly vaccinated school population: evidence for large-scale vaccination\nfailure. Arch Pediatr Adolesc Med 1995; 149: 774-8.\n10. Warrener L, Samuel D. Evaluation of a commercial assay for the\ndetection of mumps specific IgM antibodies in oral fluid and serum\nspecimens. J Clin Virol 2006; 35: 130-4.\nNotes\n-----\n* Available at <http://www.cste.org/ps/1999/1999-id-09.htm>.\n** Combined MMR vaccine generally should be used whenever any of its\ncomponent vaccines are indicated. For children aged 1-12 years, MMRV\nvaccine can be considered if varicella vaccine is indicated.\n*** Available at\n<http://www.idph.state.ia.us/adper/common/pdf/mumps/mumps_update_050406.pdf>.\n**** Defined as isolation of mumps virus from a clinical specimen;\nparotitis or orchitis; or submaxillary or submental swelling.\n***** Arizona, Arkansas, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Georgia, Hawaii,\nIllinois, Indiana, Kansas, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Mississippi, Montana,\nNevada, New York, North Carolina, North Dakota, Oklahoma, Oregon, Rhode\nIsland, Tennessee, Texas, Vermont, and Virginia.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Despite the monotypic nature of mumps virus, different genetic lineages\nexist and co-circulate globally. Genotypes A to J have been defined on the\nbasis of the nucleotide sequence of the most variable gene, the SH gene.\nThe different lineages are useful properties for tracking the spread of\nmumps virus, but there is no clear association of the different lineages\nwith different clinical symptoms. This outbreak appears to be homogeneous\nin that 12 isolates from 6 of the 11 affected states have been\ncharacterised as genotype G viruses. It has been stated previously that G\ngenotype mumps virus has been rarely observed in the United States and most\nrecently has been associated with outbreaks in the United Kingdom. However,\nthe possibility of introduction of the virus and its spread to neighboring\nstates within the United States by exposure during airline travel could not\nbe confirmed conclusively. Only 2 of 575 airline passengers at risk might\npotentially have been exposed to virus. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "F Averhoff, MD, K\nMarienau, MD, Div of Global Migration and Quarantine; M Bell, MD, E\nBolyard, MPH, C McDonald, MD, A Srinivasan, MD, Div of Healthcare Quality\nPromotion, National Center for Preparedness, Detection, and Control of\nInfectious Diseases (proposed); TA Santibanez, PhD, and J Santoli, MD,\nImmunization Svcs Div, SW Roush, MPH, PU Srivastava, MS, Div of Bacterial\nDiseases, L Anderson, MD, B Bellini, PhD, CB Bridges, MD, G Dayan, MD, ST\nGoldstein, MD, M Marin, MD, U Parashar, MD, S Redd, S Reef, MD, J Rota,\nMPH, PA Rota, PhD, J Seward, MBBS, C Shawney, Div of Viral Diseases,\nNational Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases (proposed); Thus, 2-dose coverage with\nmumps-containing vaccine among college students likely is lower than the\nmedian 97 per cent (range: 57 per cent --99 per cent) coverage for\nmeasles-containing vaccine (almost exclusively administered as MMR vaccine)\nfor students entering elementary school and the median 98 per cent (range:\n62 per cent -- 99 per cent) coverage for students entering middle school\nreported in 2000 from 38 and 25 states, respectively (4). Mumps cases included in this report are those\nwith onset from [1 Jan 2006] (MMWR week 1) through [29 Apr 2006] (MMWR week\n17) that were reported to CDC as of [2 May 2006] through NNDSS (or the Iowa\nmumps outbreak-specific reporting system) from Iowa and 10 additional\nstates that reported one or more cases of mumps epidemiologically linked to\nthe multistate outbreak. Among 1192 patients, 69 (6 per cent) were unvaccinated, 141 (12 per cent)\nhad received 1 dose of measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine, and 607\n(51 per cent) had received 2 doses of MMR vaccine; the vaccination status\nof 375 (31 per cent) patients, the majority of whom were adults who did not\nhave vaccination records, was unknown. Preliminary data, as of [10 Apr\n2006], from 2 mumps outbreaks on college campuses in an Iowa county\naffected early in the outbreak, identified attack rates of reported mumps\ncases*** of 2.0 per cent (31 of 1542 students) and 3.8 per cent (44 of 1168\nstudents). During the 1986 to 1990, after\nwidespread implementation of a 1-dose mumps vaccination policy, attack\nrates of 2 to 18 per cent (most greater than 6 per cent) were documented in\nmumps outbreaks among junior high and high school students with vaccination\ncoverage of greater than 95 per cent (7,9). Second, only 25 states***** and the District of Columbia report\na college admission requirement of 2 doses of MMR vaccine, including 3 of\nthe 11 states with outbreak-associated cases of mumps; no data on\nimplementation and evaluation of the 2-dose college admission requirement\nare available (CDC, unpublished data, 2006). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nRaymond Weinstein, MD\nManassas,Virginia\nUSA\n<AlaskaRay@aol.com>\n Eight states (Illinois, Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska,\nPennsylvania, South Dakota, and Wisconsin) reported mumps outbreaks with\nongoing local transmission or clusters of cases; 3 states (Colorado,\nMinnesota, and Mississippi) reported cases associated with travel from an\noutbreak state. Third, delayed\nrecognition and diagnosis of mumps cases might have contributed to the\nspread in this outbreak; younger physicians in the United States likely\nhave not seen mumps, and physicians might not consider the diagnosis in\nvaccinated persons. In contrast, preliminary data\nfrom 2 colleges in Iowa during the current outbreak identified attack rates\nof 2.0 per cent and 3.8 per cent, respectively, with the lower attack rate\nin the college with higher 2-dose vaccination coverage.\n First, the\ncollege campus environment (such as living in dormitories with frequent and\nextended close contact with other students) facilitates transmission of\nmumps and other illnesses that are spread through respiratory and oral\nsecretions. Post-licensure studies conducted in the\nUnited States during the period 1973 to 1989 determined that one dose of\nmumps or MMR vaccine was 75 to 91 per cent effective in preventing mumps\nwith parotitis that lasts greater than 2 days (5). In a mumps outbreak in a\nmiddle school in 1982, before mumps vaccination became widespread, attack\nrates of 25 to 49 per cent occurred among unvaccinated students, depending\non how cases were ascertained (8). In addition to cases reported through NNDSS, to\nprovide information rapidly during this outbreak, states have been\nreporting aggregate numbers of mumps cases and mumps-related\nhospitalizations and complications biweekly to CDC. Although fewer data are\navailable on the effectiveness of 2 doses of MMR vaccine against mumps, one\nstudy from the United Kingdom documented vaccine effectiveness of 88 per\ncent with 2 doses (6). High\nvaccination coverage with 2 doses of MMR vaccine, especially in school-aged\npopulations in the United States, likely prevented thousands of additional\ncases of mumps in this outbreak. Of the 2597 cases reported overall, 1275 (49 per cent)\nwere classified as confirmed, 915 (35 per cent) as probable, and 287 (11\nper cent) as suspect; for 120 (5 per cent) cases, classification was\nunknown. Preliminary data from vaccine coverage surveys suggest that the\ncollege with the higher attack rate had a smaller proportion (77 per cent\nversus 97 per cent) of students documented as having received 2 doses of\nMMR vaccine. CDC continues to work with state and\nlocal health departments to conduct mumps surveillance, assist with\nprevention and control activities, and evaluate vaccine effectiveness,\nduration of immunity, and risk factors for mumps illness. To prevent mumps, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP)\nrecommends a 2-dose MMR vaccination series for all children, with the first\ndose administered at ages 12-15 months and the second dose at ages 4-6\nyears (3). \nCDC and state and local health departments continue to investigate an\noutbreak of mumps that began in Iowa in December 2005 (1) and involved at\nleast 10 additional states as of 2 May 2006. During an outbreak and depending on the epidemiology of the outbreak (e.g.,\nthe age groups and/or institutions involved), a 2nd dose of vaccine should\nbe considered for adults and for children aged 1-4 years who have received\n1 dose. The majority of mumps cases (1487 [57 per cent]) were\nreported from Iowa; states with the next highest case totals were Kansas\n(371), Illinois (224), Nebraska (201), and Wisconsin (176) (Figure 1 [see\nURL link above]). Measles, mumps, and rubella---vaccine use and strategies for\nelimination of measles, rubella, and congenital rubella syndrome and\ncontrol of mumps: recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization\nPractices (ACIP). Furthermore, health-care\nfacilities should consider recommending 1 dose of MMR vaccine to\nunvaccinated health-care workers born before 1957 who do not have other\nevidence of mumps immunity. Although\nthe age group most affected (38 per cent of cases) has been young adults\naged 18 to 24 years, many of whom are college students, the outbreak has\nspread to all age groups (1). In Iowa, laboratory-confirmed\ncases that were asymptomatic or had clinical information pending, and cases\nfor which high suspicion for mumps existed but case classification was not\nyet determined were classified as suspect. In the 8\nstates with outbreaks, the incidence rate was highest among persons aged 18\nto 24 years (17.1 per 100 000 population), followed by persons aged 5 to 17\nyears (5.2) and 25 to 39 years (4.8) (Figure 2 [see URL link above]). Additional means to decrease transmission in outbreak settings include\nexclusion of persons without evidence of immunity to mumps from\ninstitutions such as schools and colleges that are affected by the\noutbreak. The clinical case definition of mumps* is an illness with acute onset of\nunilateral or bilateral tender, self-limited swelling of the parotid or\nother salivary gland, lasting 2 or more days, and without other apparent\ncause. In addition, the vaccine might be less\neffective in preventing asymptomatic infection or atypical mumps than in\npreventing parotitis, and persons with asymptomatic infection or mild\ndisease might contribute to transmission. Does her development of mumps, with no known contact with the\nillness, in a community with a high vaccination rate and where an outbreak\nis not occurring, indicate that there may be an intermittent subclinical\noccurrence of the illness? After an exposure to mumps, unvaccinated health-care\nworkers without evidence of immunity should be vaccinated and excluded from\nduty from the 12th day after the first exposure through the 26th day after\nthe last exposure. The current multistate mumps outbreak, with 2597 cases reported through [2\nMay 2006], is the largest number of mumps cases reported to CDC in a single\nyear since 1991, when 4264 cases were reported (2). Fourth, 2 doses of MMR vaccine are not 100 per cent\neffective in preventing disease, and accumulation of susceptible persons\nwho were not successfully immunized might be sufficient to sustain\ntransmission in certain settings. Several different mumps IgM antibody tests are in use; however, neither the\nsensitivities nor specificities of these tests when used with serum\nspecimens from either unvaccinated or vaccinated persons have been clearly\ndefined. I can imagine a scenario where this might occur\nin patients who have partial immunity from previous vaccination and who\nmight shed virus without having any symptoms, or at least symptoms to\nsuggest mumps. Both cases\noccurred among Iowa residents, one of whom was a traveling companion of a\nperson known to have mumps.\n In conjunction with local health departments, IDPH\nlaunched a statewide vaccination campaign during 24-26 Apr, targeting\npersons aged 18-22 years in the 35 Iowa counties with the state's largest\ncolleges and universities. NNDSS reports are transmitted\nelectronically to CDC each week and include information on individual cases\nsuch as age, sex, date of symptom onset, vaccination status, and\ncomplications of illness. The peak week of onset\nhas been April 2 to 8 (week 14) in Iowa and April 16 to 22 (week 16) in\nother states.\n However,\nthe possibility of introduction of the virus and its spread to neighboring\nstates within the United States by exposure during airline travel could not\nbe confirmed conclusively. Source: MMWR Dispatch 18 May 2006 / 55(Dispatch);1-5 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm55d518a1.htm?s_cid=mm55d518a1_e>\n\nUpdate: multi-state outbreak of mumps - United States; 1 Jan to 2 May 2006\n----------------------------------------------------- In the United States, the reported incidence of mumps declined after\nintroduction of mumps vaccine in 1967 and the recommendation for its\nroutine use in 1977 (3). In addition, during an outbreak, health-care facilities should strongly\nconsider recommending 2 doses of MMR vaccine to unvaccinated workers born\nbefore 1957 who do not have other evidence of mumps immunity. Because of the low\nnumber of reported mumps cases during the last decade, laboratorians have\nlimited experience with mumps tests, particularly IgM antibody tests (10). Young adults aged\n18-24 years would most commonly have received their most recent dose of\nmumps-containing vaccine (i.e., MMR vaccine) 6-17 years ago. After expanded recommendations for a 2-dose MMR\nvaccine schedule for measles control in 1989 (3), mumps cases declined\nfurther (Figure 4 [see URL link above]). Certain reported cases might\nnot have been caused by mumps; cases in persons without parotitis might\nhave been masculinized on the basis of serologic tests. Studies to define the sensitivity and specificity of mumps IgM antibody\ntests and reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) tests\nfor mumps virus RNA are in progress. This report summarizes\npreliminary data reported to CDC from these 11 states and provides\nrecommendations to prevent and control mumps during an outbreak. Twelve mumps viral isolates from 6 states were characterized; all\nwere mumps genotype G.\n As of [10 May 2006], a total of 11 persons potentially infected with mumps\nwho traveled by aircraft during [26 Mar-25 Apr 2006] had been identified on\n33 commercial flights operated by 8 different airlines. From: Raymond Weinstein <AlaskaRay@aol.com>\n\nI thought you might be interested to learn that today [Thu 18 May 2006] I\ndiagnosed what I believe is the 1st case of mumps in Virginia associated\nwith the current multistate outbreak. A confirmed case of mumps is one that is laboratory confirmed or\nmeets the clinical case definition and is linked epidemiologically to a\nconfirmed or probable case. A case is classified as probable if it meets\nthe clinical case definition but is neither laboratory-confirmed nor linked\nto another confirmed or probable mumps case. {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2200519", "headline": "PRO> Mumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2200519", "date": "2001-08-31 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS, CONSEQUENCE OF REDUCED MMRV UPTAKE - UK (02)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2206864", "headline": "PRO> Mumps, students - UK & Ireland (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206864", "date": "2004-11-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS, STUDENTS - UK & IRELAND (02)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 11 Nov 2004\nFrom: Gary Reynolds <Gary.Reynolds@herefordpct.nhs.uk>\n\nA Comment on the History of Mumps Vaccination in the UK\n-------------------------------------------------------\nThe UK item from The Scotsman newspaper, 'Mumps outbreak hits Cambridge\nUniversity' (see: Part [1] of the ProMED-mail post of 10 Nov 2004 entitled\n'Mumps, students - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039') stated that: 'Experts\nbelieve that around 3000 students and young people -- born before the\ninfant MMR triple vaccine program began -- could be infected with the virus\nby the end of the year [2004] if trends continue.' These people being born\nbefore the MMR programme began -- my own 2 eldest children included -- are\nnot the problem. The problem is that this cohort has had on average only a\nsingle dose of mumps immunisation.\nFollowing the start of the single-dose MMR programme (given at age about 13\nmonths) in the UK in 1988, there was also a catchup programme targeted at\nsuccessively older groups of children. By 1993-4 the experience\nof countries that had had a successful MMR programme for longer than the\nUK showed that measles outbreaks were again occurring. This was due to the\nslow accumulation of susceptibles, due in large part to the 5-10 percent of\nimmunoconversion failure rate for the measles component of the MMR.\nIn 1994 the UK added a 2nd dose of MMR to the scheduled pre-school booster\nimmunisations given at age 4, and at the same time carried out a catch-up\n2nd dose programme for all children aged 5 to 15. For logistical reasons,\ninsufficient MMR was obtainable to maintain the primary programme AND\nservice the catch-up, so the 1994 catch-up consisted of a measles-rubella\n(MR) vaccine.\nThe programme was a success. Uptake levels were high (I don't have the\nexact figures), and the UK averted the measles recurrences seen elsewhere.\n(The later MMR-autism bad science and media frenzy is another story.)\nHowever, that 1994 group of 5-to-15 year-olds, having had only one dose of\nmumps vaccine, must include a minority remaining susceptible. As they come\ntogether in tertiary and further education institutions, there is the\nopportunity for susceptibles to cluster and to meet a new virus.\n--\nDr Gary Reynolds\nConsultant in Health Protection\nHereford-Worcester HPU\nPublic Health, Belmont Abbey, Hereford HR2 9RP\n<gary.reynolds@herefordpct.nhs.uk>\n[Dr. Reynolds comments are very much appreciated. As stated above, the\naddition of the second dose of vaccine (MMR) served to capture those\nindividuals who did not seroconvert after receipt of the first dose of\nvaccine.\nClinical vaccine efficacy in the US is estimated to be 95 percent (range 90\n- 97 percent) following a single dose of the vaccine. (from the Mumps\nchapter of the 'Pink' book on vaccine preventible diseases\n<http://www.cdc.gov/nip/publications/pink/mumps.pdf>)\nReaney et. al. (ref. 1) reported on a mumps outbreak in Northern Ireland in\n1999/2000 with 332 confirmed cases of which 184 (55.4 percent) had a\nhistory of one dose of vaccine and 3 (0.9 percent) had a history of 2 doses\nof vaccine. Information on the population at risk was not available to\nattempt to calculate vaccine efficacy during this outbreak.\nPugh et. al. ( ref. 2) reported on a mumps outbreak among school aged\nchildren in Walsall, UK in 2000. In this outbreak, 49 percent of cases\nhad a history of one dose of vaccine and 18.5 percent of cases had a\nhistory of 2 doses of vaccine (overall 68 percent of cases had a history of\nreceiving mumps vaccine). The authors concluded that with the decrease in\nvaccination coverages observed in the UK in recent years (to below 90\npercent), future mumps outbreaks in schools and among older age groups can\nbe predicted since most older children and young adults have received only\none dose of MMR vaccine or no vaccination at all.\nNardone et al (ref. 3) reported the results of a serosurvey for prevalence\nof mumps antibodies in Europe (Denmark, England and wales, France, Germany,\nItaly and The Netherlands) as part of the European Sero-Epidemiology\nnetwork (ESEN). The authors concluded that a build-up of susceptibles in\nolder children and adolescents in England and Wales, France, the former\nWest Germany and Italy indicates the possibility of further mumps outbreaks\nin secondary school environments\nAmela, Pachon, and de Ory (ref. 4) reported on a serologic study done in\nSpain showing a vaccine efficacy of 76.7 percent in children 2-5 years of\nage felt to be associated with use of the Rubini vaccine strain. Lopez\nHernandez et. al. (ref. 5) in an earlier study of mumps vaccine efficacy\nduring an outbreak in Spain, showed a one dose vaccine efficacy of 46\npercent (range 0-84 percent) and a 2 dose efficacy of 87 percent (range 27-99).\nSchlegel et. al. (ref. 6) reported on a study comparing vaccine efficacy\nof 3 different mumps vaccine strains in Switzerland during a mumps outbreak\nwhere they observed a similar attack rate in unvaccinated children (63\npercent) and children vaccinated with the Rubini strain (67 percent) but\nsignificantly lower in those vaccinated with the Jeryl-Lynn (14 percent) or\nthe Urabe strain (8 percent). The comparative vaccine efficacies were minus\n4 percent (range minus 218 to 15 percent) for the Rubini strain, 78\npercent (range 64 to 82 percent) for the Jeryl-Lynn strain, and 87 percent\n(76 to 94 percent).\nIt would be interesting to know if studies on vaccine efficacy have been\nconducted in the UK, and what strains of mumps vaccine virus were used in\nthe cohort currently affected by the ongoing mumps activity in the UK.\nReferences\n1. Reaney EA, Tohani VK, Devine MJ, Smithson RD, Smyth B. Mumps outbreak\namong young people in Northern Ireland. Commun Dis Public Health. 2001\nDec;4(4):311-5.\n2. Pugh RN, Akinosi B, Pooransingh S, Kumar J, Grant S, Livesley E,\nLinnane J,Ramaiah S. An outbreak of mumps in the metropolitan area of\nWalsall, UK. Int J Infect Dis. 2002 Dec;6(4):283-7.\n3. Nardone A, Pebody RG, van den Hof S, Levy-Bruhl D, Plesner AM, Rota MC,\nTischer A, Andrews N, Berbers G, Crovari P, Edmunds WJ, Gabutti G, Saliou\nP, Miller E. Sero-epidemiology of mumps in western Europe. Epidemiol\nInfect. 2003 Aug;131(1):691-701.\n4. Amela C, Pachon I, de Ory F. Evaluation of the measles, mumps and\nrubella immunisation programme in Spain by using a sero-epidemiological\nsurvey. Eur J Epidemiol. 2003;18(1):71-9.\n5. Lopez Hernandez B, Martin Velez RM, Roman Garcia C, Penalver Sanchez I,\nLopez Rosique JA. [An epidemic outbreak of mumps. A study of vaccinal\nefficacy] Aten Primaria. 2000 Feb 28;25(3):148-52.\n6. Schlegel M, Osterwalder JJ, Galeazzi RL, Vernazza PL. Comparative\nefficacy of three mumps vaccines during disease outbreak in Eastern\nSwitzerland: cohort study. BMJ. 1999 Aug 7;319(7206):352.\n<http://bmj.bmjjournals.com/cgi/content/full/319/7206/352>\n- Mod.MPP]", "summary": "6) reported on a study comparing vaccine efficacy\nof 3 different mumps vaccine strains in Switzerland during a mumps outbreak\nwhere they observed a similar attack rate in unvaccinated children (63\npercent) and children vaccinated with the Rubini strain (67 percent) but\nsignificantly lower in those vaccinated with the Jeryl-Lynn (14 percent) or\nthe Urabe strain (8 percent). The UK item from The Scotsman newspaper, 'Mumps outbreak hits Cambridge\nUniversity' (see: Part [1] of the ProMED-mail post of 10 Nov 2004 entitled\n'Mumps, students - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039') stated that: 'Experts\nbelieve that around 3000 students and young people -- born before the\ninfant MMR triple vaccine program began -- could be infected with the virus\nby the end of the year [2004] if trends continue.' The authors concluded that with the decrease in\nvaccination coverages observed in the UK in recent years (to below 90\npercent), future mumps outbreaks in schools and among older age groups can\nbe predicted since most older children and young adults have received only\none dose of MMR vaccine or no vaccination at all.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n In this outbreak, 49 percent of cases\nhad a history of one dose of vaccine and 18.5 percent of cases had a\nhistory of 2 doses of vaccine (overall 68 percent of cases had a history of\nreceiving mumps vaccine). The comparative vaccine efficacies were minus\n4 percent (range minus 218 to 15 percent) for the Rubini strain, 78\npercent (range 64 to 82 percent) for the Jeryl-Lynn strain, and 87 percent\n(76 to 94 percent). (ref. 1) reported on a mumps outbreak in Northern Ireland in\n1999/2000 with 332 confirmed cases of which 184 (55.4 percent) had a\nhistory of one dose of vaccine and 3 (0.9 percent) had a history of 2 doses\nof vaccine. The authors concluded that a build-up of susceptibles in\nolder children and adolescents in England and Wales, France, the former\nWest Germany and Italy indicates the possibility of further mumps outbreaks\nin secondary school environments\n (ref. 5) in an earlier study of mumps vaccine efficacy\nduring an outbreak in Spain, showed a one dose vaccine efficacy of 46\npercent (range 0-84 percent) and a 2 dose efficacy of 87 percent (range 27-99). As stated above, the\naddition of the second dose of vaccine (MMR) served to capture those\nindividuals who did not seroconvert after receipt of the first dose of\nvaccine. For logistical reasons,\ninsufficient MMR was obtainable to maintain the primary programme AND\nservice the catch-up, so the 1994 catch-up consisted of a measles-rubella\n(MR) vaccine. (from the Mumps\nchapter of the 'Pink' book on vaccine preventible diseases\n<http://www.cdc.gov/nip/publications/pink/mumps.pdf>)\n --\nDr Gary Reynolds\nConsultant in Health Protection\n It would be interesting to know if studies on vaccine efficacy have been\nconducted in the UK, and what strains of mumps vaccine virus were used in\nthe cohort currently affected by the ongoing mumps activity in the UK. Following the start of the single-dose MMR programme (given at age about 13\nmonths) in the UK in 1988, there was also a catchup programme targeted at\nsuccessively older groups of children.
