As they come\ntogether in tertiary and further education institutions, there is the\nopportunity for susceptibles to cluster and to meet a new virus. Spain showing a vaccine efficacy of 76.7 percent in children 2-5 years of\nage felt to be associated with use of the Rubini vaccine strain.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1993-04-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Walsall", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pachon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204937", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, increase - UK (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204937", "date": "2003-11-23 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS, INCREASE - UK (02)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sun 23 Nov 2003\nFrom: H.Larry Penning <hlpenning@yahoo.com>\nSource: The Independent online, Home news, Sun 23 Nov 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.independent.co.uk>\n\nUK (England & Wales): Mumps Cases at Highest Level for a Decade\n---------------------------------------------------\nCases of mumps are at the highest levels for almost a decade. So far this\nyear, there have been more than 2000 formal notifications of the disease in\nEngland, at least half of them thought to be positive. In Wales there have\nbeen 323 confirmed cases, compared with just 2 in 1999.\nPublic health doctors have warned that in some areas, one child in 5\nstarting primary school this year was not protected against the disease.\nThe massive rise in mumps cases is a cause of huge concern for health\nofficials, who have seen the take-up of the triple measles, mumps and\nrubella (MMR) vaccination drop alarmingly because of health scares.\nMumps can cause fever, headache and inflammation of the salivary glands,\nand occasionally infection of the membrane covering the brain. The disease\ncan also cause permanent deafness. About one in 5 adolescent or adult males\nwho contracts mumps develops a painful inflammation and swelling of the\ntesticles, which can in a small number of cases result in infertility.\nCentral nervous system complications are not uncommon. Teenagers are the\ngroup most at risk because they may have missed out on the MMR, which was\nintroduced in 1988. Some universities are now offering MMR vaccinations to\nstudents.\nLatest provisional figures show that for the 2nd quarter of this year there\nwere 1439 notifications of mumps in England, the highest number since 1995.\nIn the previous quarter, there were 972 notifications, also the highest\nsince 1995. It is estimated that around half of those notifications are\npositive. 'In the 2nd quarter of this year, there were 1439 notifications\nof mumps, and saliva tests were sent out and returned for 824 of those\ncases, of which 47 percent were positive,' said a spokesman for the Health\nProtection Agency. 'From that, we estimate that the number of positive\ncases overall for that quarter was around 700. It is high and it is the\nhighest for some years.' In Wales, both mumps and measles are on the\nincrease, and doctors are warning of outbreaks of both diseases.\n'The number of mumps cases stands at 323 so far, compared to 2 in 1999,'\nsaid a spokeswoman for the National Public Health Service for Wales. 'We\nare seeing cases of mumps and measles in younger children because of poor\nuptake of the MMR vaccine. 'Our overall uptake is 78 percent, but in some\nareas it is as low as 69 percent. One in 5 children who started school in\nSeptember was not protected against mumps, measles or rubella. We are\nworried and we are warning of the danger of outbreaks. 'We think about 3/4\nof the cases of mumps are teenagers, and the majority of these cases are\npeople who were born before the MMR launch in 1988. They may have had\nrubella and measles vaccine, but that didn't contain mumps. Our advice is\nthat people who are not protected, including teenagers, should have the MMR.'\nThere have been warnings that the fall in the take-up of the MMR, blamed on\ncontroversial and hotly disputed links that have been made between the\nvaccine and autism, will result in more outbreaks of measles and rubella.\nLess attention has been paid to mumps, which is often considered a benign\nillness with low mortality rates. But doctors warn that it should not be\nunderestimated.\n--\nH.Larry Penning\n<hlpenning@yahoo.com>\n[Similar data have been reported by the Information and Statistics Division\nof the National Health Service (NHS) Scotland. Over the past 18 months the\nincidences of suspected (but not necessarily confirmed) mumps rose by 27\npercent, rubella by 22 percent, and measles by 18 percent in children under\n15 (see: <http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/low/uk_news/scotland/3227345.stm>). New\nnotifications of mumps in children under 15 rose from 98 in 2001 to 124 in\n2002, according to the findings, which cover the year 2002 and the first\nhalf-year period of 2003. Notifications of rubella increased from 222 in\n2001 to 270 in 2002. In Scotland take-up rates for the triple measles,\nmumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine are running at their lowest levels for at\nleast 8 years.\nA similar upsurge in mumps cases in Northern Ireland was reported in\nProMED-mail in 2001. The increase in mumps cases is occurring nationwide,\nirrespective of social or local economic factors, and can be related\ndirectly to the decline in acceptance of the MMR triple vaccine by parents.\nSince replacement in September 1992 of the Urabe strain of mumps virus by\nthe Jeryl Lynn strain, the triple MMR vaccine has performed satisfactorily\nwith no serious complications, notwithstanding the subsequent finding that\nthe Jeryl Lynn strain of mumps virus is a mixture of 2 distinct isolates\n(Afzal et al., J Gen Virol 75, 2139, 1994). The resurgence of mumps cases\nand the apparent lack of protection are likely to be related to the decline\nin uptake of the MMR triple vaccine in the UK as a result of adverse\npublicity surrounding the unsubstantiated claim of a link between the\ntriple vaccine and autism. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The resurgence of mumps cases\nand the apparent lack of protection are likely to be related to the decline\nin uptake of the MMR triple vaccine in the UK as a result of adverse\npublicity surrounding the unsubstantiated claim of a link between the\ntriple vaccine and autism. Over the past 18 months the\nincidences of suspected (but not necessarily confirmed) mumps rose by 27\npercent, rubella by 22 percent, and measles by 18 percent in children under\n15 (see: <http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/low/uk_news/scotland/3227345.stm>). In the 2nd quarter of this year, there were 1439 notifications\nof mumps, and saliva tests were sent out and returned for 824 of those\ncases, of which 47 percent were positive,' said a spokesman for the Health\nProtection Agency. ' New\nnotifications of mumps in children under 15 rose from 98 in 2001 to 124 in\n2002, according to the findings, which cover the year 2002 and the first\nhalf-year period of 2003. the Jeryl Lynn strain, the triple MMR vaccine has performed satisfactorily\nwith no serious complications, notwithstanding the subsequent finding that\nthe Jeryl Lynn strain of mumps virus is a mixture of 2 distinct isolates\n The massive rise in mumps cases is a cause of huge concern for health\nofficials, who have seen the take-up of the triple measles, mumps and\nrubella (MMR) vaccination drop alarmingly because of health scares. \nH.Larry Penning\n<hlpenning@yahoo.com>\n The increase in mumps cases is occurring nationwide,\nirrespective of social or local economic factors, and can be related\ndirectly to the decline in acceptance of the MMR triple vaccine by parents. We\nare seeing cases of mumps and measles in younger children because of poor\nuptake of the MMR vaccine. ' In Scotland take-up rates for the triple measles,\nmumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine are running at their lowest levels for at\nleast 8 years. We think about 3/4\nof the cases of mumps are teenagers, and the majority of these cases are\npeople who were born before the MMR launch in 1988. About one in 5 adolescent or adult males\nwho contracts mumps develops a painful inflammation and swelling of the\ntesticles, which can in a small number of cases result in infertility. Source: The Independent online, Home news, Sun 23 Nov 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.independent.co.uk>\n\nUK (England & Wales): Mumps Cases at Highest Level for a Decade\n There have been warnings that the fall in the take-up of the MMR, blamed on\ncontroversial and hotly disputed links that have been made between the\nvaccine and autism, will result in more outbreaks of measles and rubella. So far this\nyear, there have been more than 2000 formal notifications of the disease in\nEngland, at least half of them thought to be positive. MUMPS, INCREASE - UK (02)\n************************\n Teenagers are the\ngroup most at risk because they may have missed out on the MMR, which was\nintroduced in 1988.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "1992-09-25 00:00:00", "1439-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2192269", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (British Columbia) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192269", "date": "1997-11-23 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (BRITISH COLUMBIA) (02)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post", "summary": "MUMPS - CANADA (BRITISH COLUMBIA) (02)\n **\n A ProMED-mail post", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2196799", "headline": "PRO> Mumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2196799", "date": "1999-10-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS & RUBINI VACCINE - SINGAPORE\n**********************************\nA ProMED post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nDate: Fri, 22 Oct 1999\nFrom: Chan Yow Cheong mailto:chanyowcheong@pacific.net.sg\nProMED Regional Moderator for Asia\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly, issue 43, 21 Oct 1999\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/update/>\n\nResurgence of mumps in Singapore associated with Rubini vaccine\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nThe incidence of mumps has increased in Singapore since the measles, mumps,\nand rubella (MMR) vaccine was introduced into the national childhood\nimmunisation programme in 1990, while the incidence of measles and rubella\nhas declined (1). Since 1990 three strains of mumps virus - Urabe,\nJeryl-Lynn, and Rubini - have been used in MMR vaccines. The Urabe strain\nwas withdrawn in 1992 after an increased risk of aseptic meninigitis was\nreported in other countries and the Rubini strain was purchased between\n1993 and 1995. In more recent years the Jeryl-Lynn strain (vaccine efficacy\n75%) has also been used (KT Goh, personal communication). The incidence of\nmumps increased from 674 cases in 1997 to 1183 cases in 1998, 2586 cases\nwere reported in the first seven months of 1999, and it is estimated that\nthe incidence will reach 200 per 100 000 population by the end of 1999.\nForty-four per cent (258) of 592 cases that arose in the last four months\nof 1998 had received MMR vaccine. Of 195 whose mumps vaccine strain was\nknown, 144 (74%) had received the Rubini strain, 42 (22%) the Jeryl-Lynn\nstrain, and nine (5%) the Urabe strain. About 75% of cases had received MMR\nvaccine between one and four years before developing mumps.\nEpidemiological evidence suggested that the Rubini vaccine strain offered\nno protection. One hundred and forty of 1546 children who had been\nvaccinated with the Rubini strain developed mumps - an attack rate of 9%.\nThe short interval between vaccination and illness indicated primary rather\nthan secondary vaccine failure due waning immunity over time.\nSeroepidemiological evidence showed that the prevalence of mumps antibody\nin children aged under 5 years of age was 22% in 1989 before MMR was\nintroduced. It increased to 72% in 1993 after mumps vaccination with the\nUrabe and Jeryl-Lynn strains was introduced, but it fell to 26% in 1998.\nThe Ministry of Health in Singapore deregistered the MMR vaccine containing\nthe Rubini strain in May 1999.\nThe poor protection of the Rubini strain in mumps vaccine has been noted in\nother countries (2-4). In Portugal, Rubini replaced the Urabe strain in MMR\nvaccine in October 1992 and resulted in a large increase in the incidence\nof mumps in children (5). The highest rates of mumps occurred in children\naged 1 to 4 years during a mumps epidemic in 1995/96. By January 1998 all\nPortuguese health centres had begun to use MMR vaccine containing the Jeryl\nLynn strain in place of the Rubini strain (6).\nReferences:\nGoh KT. Resurgence of mumps in Singapore caused by the Rubini mumps virus\nvaccine strain. Lancet 1999; 354: 1355-6. (http://www.thelancet.com/)\nGalazka AM, Robinson SE, Kraigher A. Mumps and mumps vaccine: a global\nreview. Bull World Health Organ 1999; 77: 3-14. (http://www.who.int/bulletin/)\nToscani L, Batou M, Bouvier P, Schlanepfer A. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n The incidence of mumps has increased in Singapore since the measles, mumps,\nand rubella (MMR) vaccine was introduced into the national childhood\nimmunisation programme in 1990, while the incidence of measles and rubella\nhas declined (1). The incidence of\nmumps increased from 674 cases in 1997 to 1183 cases in 1998, 2586 cases\nwere reported in the first seven months of 1999, and it is estimated that\nthe incidence will reach 200 per 100 000 population by the end of 1999. The Urabe strain\nwas withdrawn in 1992 after an increased risk of aseptic meninigitis was\nreported in other countries and the Rubini strain was purchased between\n1993 and 1995. Of 195 whose mumps vaccine strain was\nknown, 144 (74%) had received the Rubini strain, 42 (22%) the Jeryl-Lynn\nstrain, and nine (5%) the Urabe strain. In Portugal, Rubini replaced the Urabe strain in MMR\nvaccine in October 1992 and resulted in a large increase in the incidence\nof mumps in children (5). By January 1998 all\nPortuguese health centres had begun to use MMR vaccine containing the Jeryl\nLynn strain in place of the Rubini strain (6). Source: Eurosurveillance Weekly, issue 43, 21 Oct 1999\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/update/>\n\nResurgence of mumps in Singapore associated with Rubini vaccine\n Seroepidemiological evidence showed that the prevalence of mumps antibody\nin children aged under 5 years of age was 22% in 1989 before MMR was\nintroduced. \nForty-four per cent (258) of 592 cases that arose in the last four months\nof 1998 had received MMR vaccine. MUMPS & RUBINI VACCINE - SINGAPORE\n**********************************\n Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: (Reported by Caroline Akehurst, (cakehurs@phls.nhs.uk), PHLS Communicable\nDisease Surveillance Centre, London, England.)\n A ProMED post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n \nProMED\n Resurgence of mumps in Singapore caused by the Rubini mumps virus\nvaccine strain. The poor protection of the Rubini strain in mumps vaccine has been noted in\nother countries (2-4). The highest rates of mumps occurred in children\naged 1 to 4 years during a mumps epidemic in 1995/96. Galazka AM, Robinson SE, Kraigher A. Mumps and mumps vaccine: a global\nreview. We are investigating the possibility that the current\noutbreak may also be associated with travel abroad. We are particularly\ninterested in hearing about recent or ongoing outbreaks of mumps in Eastern\nEurope, Indian subcontinent, Israel or Belgium and would like to hear about\nmumps activity anywhere, but particularly in the above-mentioned countries.\nAll information gratefully received!\n--\nCorry van den Bosch,\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control\nDirectorate of Public Health\nEast London and City Health Authority\nLondon, UK\ne-mail: corry@elcha.co.uk\n[We regret the delay in posting. From: Van Den Bosch Corry <Corry@elcha.co.uk>\n\nMumps outbreak\n----------------- We are investigating the possibility that the current\noutbreak may also be associated with travel abroad.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-02-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2200369", "headline": "PRO> Mumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2200369", "date": "2001-08-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS, CONSEQUENCE OF REDUCED MMRV UPTAKE - UK\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 6 Aug 2001\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters Health Online, 6 Au 2001 [edited]\n<http://www.reutershealth.com/frame2/eline.html>\n\nUK: Mumps outbreak after parents shun MMR vaccine\n-------------------------------------------------\nLONDON: A mumps outbreak is 'spreading alarmingly' across the UK as parents\nshun the combined measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine (MMRV) for\nchildren, the Independent on Sunday reports. The newspaper said that\naccording to the Public Health Laboratory Service, cases of mumps have\nalmost doubled following a drop of 12% in the number of children being\nimmunized with the MMRV. There is continuing public anxiety that the\ncombined vaccine might trigger autism or bowel disease. It said the\noutbreak was particularly severe in Northern Ireland, where cases of mumps\nhad risen tenfold from 95 cases in 1999 to 1000 last year.\nMeanwhile, the Sunday Telegraph reports that a doctor who has been offering\nsingle vaccines instead of the triple vaccine has been ordered to appear\nbefore the General Medical Council (GMC) disciplinary body and could be\nbarred from medical practice. It said that Peter Mansfield, a former\ngeneral practitioner (GP) who has been seeing up to 70 families [at] a time\nat twice-monthly private clinics in Worcestershire, was told last week that\nthe GMC intends to consider his conduct because 'it may pose an immediate\nrisk to patient safety.' The GMC's intervention follows a complaint by\nWorcester Health Authority alleging that Mansfield has been putting\nchildren 'at risk' because his actions are 'outside normal clinical\npractice' and against Department of Health advice. Mansfield told the\nnewspaper he would vigorously defend his actions. 'The people who have come\nto us have denied their children MMR, in some cases as long as 3 years ago.\nThe single measles vaccine I am prescribing is the best available for\nsomeone who is unwilling to have MMR. The Department of Health's view is a\ndenial of choice.' The report notes that a GMC ruling against Mansfield\nwould make it difficult for any other doctor to continue to offer the 3\nvaccines separately and would have far-reaching implications for the\nfreedom of doctors to prescribe the medicines of their choice.\nThe row over MMR began 3 years ago and continued earlier this year when Dr.\nAndrew Wakefield, a researcher at the Royal Free Hospital in London, said\nhe had seen 170 children with a new syndrome of digestive problems and\nautistic behavior, the 'majority' of whom had fallen ill after the triple\njab. He suggested that the safest option was for children to be given the\nvaccines separately. The Department of Health dismissed the research as\n'bad science' and launched a GBP 3 million [(US $4.25 million)] campaign in\nJanuary to reassure parents. Liam Donaldson, the Chief Medical Officer,\nadvised doctors that children should not be given separate measles, mumps\nand rubella vaccines in place of MMRV because there was a 'clear risk of harm.'\n[Byline: Richard Woodman]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[An increase in measles as a consequence of reduced uptake of MMR vaccine\nhas been forecast, but the increase in incidence of mumps is potentially a\nmore serious development. - Mod.CP]\n....................cp/pg/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The GMC's intervention follows a complaint by\nWorcester Health Authority alleging that Mansfield has been putting\nchildren 'at risk' because his actions are 'outside normal clinical\npractice' and against Department of Health advice. [Byline: Richard Woodman]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< A mumps outbreak is 'spreading alarmingly' across the UK as parents\nshun the combined measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine (MMRV) for\nchildren, the Independent on Sunday reports. It said the\noutbreak was particularly severe in Northern Ireland, where cases of mumps\nhad risen tenfold from 95 cases in 1999 to 1000 last year.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-08-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Worcestershire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MMRV", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Independent", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mansfield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LONDON", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2192254", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (British Columbia)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192254", "date": "1997-11-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Mon, 17 Nov 1997 10:21:31 -0800\nFrom: James Chin, MD, MPH, CDPC-mail and Canada Communicable Disease\nReport:23(22),\nNovember 15, 1997.\n\nMumps, an acute viral disease caused by mumps virus (family\n_Paramyxoviridae_, genus _Rubulavirus_), is defined for surveillance\npurposes as an illness characterized by fever and tender, self-limited\nswelling of the salivary gland(s), lasting about 2 days without other\napparent cause.\nIn January and February 1997, an unexpected number of cases of mumps were\nreported to the Vancouver/Richmond Health Board (V/RHB). An investigation\nwas initiated with the British Columbia Centre for Disease Control (BCCDC).\nBetween 1 January 1997 and 31 March 1997, a total of 83 cases of mumps were\nreported via the BC Communicable Disease Surveillance System.\nA universal combined measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) immunization program\nwas introduced in BC in 1981 for children aged >12 months.\nInitial case follow-ups by the V/RHB suggested that public social events\nwere risk factors for acquiring mumps in the young adult age group. A\ncase-control study was initiated to examine this hypothesis and to further\nexplore the outcomes of mumps illness. Vaccine effectiveness, ascertained\nby self-reported immunization status, was estimated to be 80% (95%\nconfidence interval [CI] = 29% to 96%).\nEighty-eight percent (45/51) of the cases reported being in the Greater\nVancouver area during the exposure period. Among the 47 matched\ncase-control pairs, contact with a person with mumps was significantly\nassociated with illness (odds ratio = 13, 95% CI = 1.95 to 552). Sixteen\nof the 40 cases aged 17 to 40 years, and one of the nine cases aged <17\nyears reported attending a 'rave' party during the exposure period.\n'Raves' are very large gatherings of teenagers and young adults who listen\nand dance to electronic music in warehouse type venues. Of the risk\nfactors examined, exposure to rave parties was the most strongly associated\nwith illness (odds ratio = 17, 95% CI = 2.7 to 710). All 'rave' attendees\nreported sharing drinks and dancing in close proximity to others.\nAttending educational institutions, having contact with >50 persons per day\nat work, being a health-care professional, attending dance clubs, bars, or\nother social events, and playing group sports were not associated with\nillness.\nThe increased incidence rates in this outbreak suggest that the 1957 to\n1980 birth cohorts were most at risk. These incompletely vaccinated birth\ncohorts sustain an adult population susceptible to outbreaks of mumps in\nthe future. This investigation highlights, as previously described, the\nhigh proportion of extra-salivary symptoms of mumps experienced by an adult\npopulation.\nThis is the second communicable disease outbreak reported to be associated\nwith 'rave' parties in Canada, the first being a 1996 meningitis outbreak\nin Quebec. These social events, characterized by close contact and sharing\nof drinks, should be considered as a risk factor for mumps and other\nillnesses transmissible by person-to-person droplet spread.\nIn response to the outbreak and this investigation, the V/RHB released a\npublic notice about 'raves' as a risk factor for acquiring mumps and a\nreminder about MMR vaccinations.\nSource: A Bell, MDCM, MHSc, M Fyfe, MD, MSc, Communicable Disease\nEpidemiology Services, BCCDC, M Bigham, MD, MHSc, P Daly, MD, V/RHB, J\nBuxton, MBBS, MHSc, Community Residency Program, Department of Health Care\nand Epidemiology, UBC, Vancouver, BC; C Craig, DVM, BSc, Field Epidemiology\nTraining Program, LCDC, Ottawa, ON.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n[This report comes long after the epidemic occurrence but serves as a\nreminder that mumps virus has not yet been eradicated and that appropriate\nvaccination levels must be maintained. - Mod.CHC]\n......................................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "summary": "CHC]\n......................................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n Source: A Bell, MDCM, MHSc, M Fyfe, MD, MSc, Communicable Disease\nEpidemiology Services, BCCDC, M Bigham, MD, MHSc, P Daly, MD, V/RHB, J\nBuxton, MBBS, MHSc, Community Residency Program, Department of Health Care\nand Epidemiology, UBC, Vancouver, BC; C Craig, DVM, BSc, Field Epidemiology\nTraining Program, LCDC, Ottawa, ON.\n \n\nMumps, an acute viral disease caused by mumps virus (family\n_Paramyxoviridae_, genus _Rubulavirus_), is defined for surveillance\npurposes as an illness characterized by fever and tender, self-limited\nswelling of the salivary gland(s), lasting about 2 days without other\napparent cause. Attending educational institutions, having contact with >50 persons per day\nat work, being a health-care professional, attending dance clubs, bars, or\nother social events, and playing group sports were not associated with\nillness. \nProMED-mail\ne-mail: <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n Sixteen\nof the 40 cases aged 17 to 40 years, and one of the nine cases aged <17\nyears reported attending a 'rave' party during the exposure period. These social events, characterized by close contact and sharing\nof drinks, should be considered as a risk factor for mumps and other\nillnesses transmissible by person-to-person droplet spread. Among the 47 matched\ncase-control pairs, contact with a person with mumps was significantly\nassociated with illness (odds ratio = 13, 95% CI = 1.95 to 552). Of the risk\nfactors examined, exposure to rave parties was the most strongly associated\nwith illness (odds ratio = 17, 95% CI = 2.7 to 710). In response to the outbreak and this investigation, the V/RHB released a\npublic notice about 'raves' as a risk factor for acquiring mumps and a\nreminder about MMR vaccinations. This is the second communicable disease outbreak reported to be associated\nwith 'rave' parties in Canada, the first being a 1996 meningitis outbreak\nin Quebec. This investigation highlights, as previously described, the\nhigh proportion of extra-salivary symptoms of mumps experienced by an adult\npopulation. A\ncase-control study was initiated to examine this hypothesis and to further\nexplore the outcomes of mumps illness. These incompletely vaccinated birth\ncohorts sustain an adult population susceptible to outbreaks of mumps in\nthe future. [This report comes long after the epidemic occurrence but serves as a\nreminder that mumps virus has not yet been eradicated and that appropriate\nvaccination levels must be maintained.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1981-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "1980-03-25 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-11-15 00:00:00", "1997-11-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}]}]}], "mumps_num_of_articles": "299"}
